headline: Rating the Red Bulls vs. the Houston Dynamo
text: The Red Bulls (3-3-3, 12 points) came into Saturday night’s game after their worst performance of the season, last week’s 5-1 loss to the Chicago Fire. This week, the Red Bulls are in Houston to play the two-time defending Major League Soccer champion Dynamo (3-5-3, 14 points).

headline: Porter: Appropriate Time Is Derby
text: Rick Porter, the owner of Eight Belles, has decided to not pursue a tribute to the filly before the Belmont Stakes, despite initially supporting a petition to do so.

headline: A Tribute to Jim Gray: Sometimes Nice Guys Do Finish First
text: For a half-decade, the San Francisco bureau of The New York Times had a remarkable resource. Just five floors above us were the offices of Microsoft’s Bay Area Research Center and more specifically, Gordon Bell and Jim Gray, two of the world’s legendary computer scientists. I would have coffee with Jim on occasion, and from time to time, we would head down the alleyway to have lunch at Yank Sing, the local dim sum restaurant.

headline: If Presidents Faced Question Time
text: After years of watching President Bush ignore Congress, at best, or disdain it, at worst, there is relief in listening to the British prime minister face questions in Parliament. As seen on C-Span, these events feature literate parries and thrusts, complete sentences, artful arguments, all to a chorus of noisy yeas and brays.

headline: Cluster Bombs, Made in America
text: On Friday, 111 nations, including major NATO allies, adopted a treaty that sets an eight-year deadline to eliminate stockpiles of cluster arms  pernicious weapons that scatter thousands of small bombs across a wide area, where they pose a long-term deadly threat to innocents. The Bush administration not only failed to sign the treaty but vigorously opposed it.

headline: The Lawyers’ Crusade
text: In April, on the highway outside the little Punjabi town of Renala Khurd, Aitzaz Ahsan was waylaid by a crowd of seemingly deranged lawyers. The advocates, who wore black suits, white shirts and black ties, were not actually insane; they just seemed that way because they were so overcome with excitement at greeting the mastermind of Pakistan’s lawyers’ movement, perhaps the most consequential outpouring of liberal, democratic energy in the Islamic world in recent years. The 62-year-old Ahsan was on his way to address the bar association of Okara, 10 miles away, but the lawyers, and the farmers and shopkeepers gathered with them, were not about to let him leave. They boiled around the car, shouting slogans. “Who should our leaders be like?” they cried. “Like Aitzaz!” And, “How many are prepared to die for you?” “Countless! Countless!”

headline: Boekie Woekie
text: Amsterdam is the antithesis of one-stop shopping.

headline: Swallow This
text: From the perspective of an athlete, few things top the virtuous satisfaction that comes from a hard workout. That 10-mile run, that 1,500-meter pool sprint, that hour with the free weights. Makes you feel great, right? You’ll do it again tomorrow, for sure. But then it hits  the aftermath.

headline: Datebook
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A New Web Site for Students Abroad
text: Exchange students and young United States citizens now have a Web site to use as a resource for international travel. Created and maintained by the State Department’s Bureau of Consular Affairs, the site, studentsabroad.state.gov, is part of a larger campaign to promote smart, safe travel by students.

headline: Coffee Mated to Chocolate
text: The Quick Bite article last Sunday, about the Kent Coffee & Chocolate Company in Kent, gave an incorrect phone number for the shop. It is (860) 927-1445.

headline: In a Girlhood Memoir, Not a Happy Camper
text: THE first time Stephanie Klein heard herself called “moose,” it was in a school hallway, chanted by a group of older boys while she stood at her locker. She was 13, and had been visiting a nutritionist since she was 8.

headline: One-Stop Shopping for Tracking Criminals
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Correction: Edging Closer in Cyprus’s Divided Capital
text: A map with an article on May 18 about Nicosia, Cyprus, incorrectly described the Republic of Cyprus, the political division on the southern side of the island. While its residents are primarily ethnically Greek, it is an independent country, not part of Greece. The map has been corrected online.

headline: Downsizing to 5,000 Square Feet
text: GREENWICH

headline: She’s in a Battle to the Very End
text: With no makeup, straggly gray hair framing her face, a shapeless gray cardigan pulled around her shoulders and a stooped gait, Olympia Dukakis looks weak and battered when she comes onstage in “The Milk Train Doesn’t Stop Here Anymore.” Don’t you believe it. Her Flora Goforth is far from done for.

headline: McCain’s McClellan Nightmare
text: THEY thought they were being so slick. When the McCain campaign abruptly moved last Tuesday’s fund-raiser with President Bush from the Phoenix Convention Center to a private home, it was the next best thing to sending the loathed lame duck into the witness protection program. John McCain and Mr. Bush were caught on camera together for a mere 26 seconds, and at 9 p.m. Eastern time, safely after the networks’ evening newscasts. The two men’s furtive encounter on the Phoenix airport tarmac, as captured by a shaky, inaudible long shot on FoxNews.com, could have been culled from a surveillance video.

headline: Talking to Graduates in South Carolina, Bush Calls for Culture of Responsibility
text: GREENVILLE, S.C.  President Bush called Saturday for a new “culture of responsibility,” and he told students they would never find fulfillment in “alcohol, drugs or promiscuity.”

headline: In Love With Fishing at 8, She’s Now a Charter Captain at 22
text: Port Jefferson

headline: ‘Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas!’
text: A case could be made that the best show on Broadway this past season was not on Broadway at all, but in Justice Helen E. Freedman’s courtroom at the State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The show ran for one morning: the day before Thanksgiving, the 11th day of a 19-day strike by the stagehands’ union. The central character was a man named James Sanna, a producer of the perennial Broadway musical “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas! The Musical.” He had cut a side deal with the union, which agreed to stop striking against the St. James Theater, where “Grinch” was playing (the symbolism of the Grinch’s stealing Christmas from Whoville, pounced upon by the news media, was too much even for the powerful union).

headline: Baghdad Jews Have Become a Fearful Few
text: BAGHDAD  “I have no future here to stay.”

headline: Kristen Kennedy, John Koecheler
text: Kristen Patricia Kennedy, a daughter of Roseanne C. Kennedy and Robert E. Kennedy of Vero Beach, Fla., was married there on Saturday to John Edward Koecheler, a son of Maureen D. Koecheler of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Gary E. Koecheler. The Rev. Kevin W. Wildes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Bullfighting Is Dead! Long Live the Bullfight!
text: It was the time of Las Fallas, the annual spring festival in Valencia. Giant papier-mâché cartoon floats of Sinbad and Snow White and troupes of amateur dancers with lacquered hair and sequined outfits jammed the old city squares. Spanish matrons and women in evening dresses joined the teenagers and the men in business suits thronging the plaza de toros. The matador José Tomás had come to fight.

headline: The Burgers Are Back
text: After a fire closed it for winter repairs, the Blazer Pub in Purdys is back in business. Scrubbed and repainted, this casual roadhouse has rarely missed a beat in its 30 years of operation, the last 15 under the O’Leary family. Little has changed over the years, and that’s the way Blazer customers like it.

headline: A Hush-Hush Plan for a Not-So-Secret Garden
text: THE trustees of New York Marble Cemetery, in the East Village, like to think of their half-acre as a secret garden. The cemetery sits within the block bounded by Second Avenue, the Bowery, and Second and Third Streets, and the sole, gated entrance, on Second Avenue, is opened only on the fourth Sunday of every month.

headline: Hall of Famer
text: He wasn’t a sportswriter. No insult implied, but sportswriters tend to fall into two categories: stylists attempting to turn sport into literature in glossy magazines, and reporters serving it up as news in daily papers. By the evidence of the 44 pieces in this occasionally satisfying collection  spanning his career, from 1955 to 2006  David Halberstam was a different animal.

headline: Jamaican Sets World Record in 100 Meters at 9.72
text: The Reebok Grand Prix meet took place at Randalls Island on Saturday night, but it was a home crowd for Jamaica’s newest sprint star at 100 meters, Usain Bolt.

headline: The Backstage Sights, the Locker Room Scents
text: THE behind-the-scenes tour is a staple of the pamphlet-driven tourist routine, promising a glimpse beyond the glitzy sites where shows and sporting events are put on in this city.

headline: ‘Passing Strange’
text: It’s particularly satisfying because it doesn’t happen every night. Sometimes during “Keys,” a climactic number in the first act of “Passing Strange,” Stew (left) thrusts a microphone into the audience so his listeners can sing along. Playing the narrator (he also wrote the book, the lyrics and part of the music), he sings about the sexual and intellectual liberation that the American protagonist, played by Daniel Breaker, has found in Europe. Stew works himself into a gospel-rock lather as he repeats the words “It’s all right,” and when he lies down on the stage, stretching across it so that the front row can shout the chorus with him, he transforms the spectators into full participants. Instead of just observing it, the crowd helps create the moment.

headline: New Hampshire Hoedown
text: Boozing and brawling and country music might not be the first things that come to mind when you think of New Hampshire; presidential primary is more like it. But after reading “Sing Me Back Home,” you’re likely to agree with Dana Jennings, a native of one of the rougher regions of that state, that the feel-bad songs of Hank Williams and George Jones and Loretta Lynn are the soundtrack for the lives we all live.

headline: Correction: Making Sense of Money for Those Who Can’t
text: The introduction to a chart last Sunday showing artists’ proposals for currency that would help the visually impaired differentiate among denominations referred incorrectly to one proposal. Two of the icons that the designer called for punching into each bill represented the founding fathers Hamilton (a pistol for the $10 bill) and Franklin (a kite for the $100 bill). The icons were not all representing former presidents.

headline: Setting Politics Aside to Help Victims of China Earthquake
text: In the three weeks since the earthquake ravaged China’s Sichuan Province, the Chinese-American community that stretches from Chinatown in Lower Manhattan to the large enclaves on the West Coast has contributed millions of dollars to relief efforts, dwarfing past fund-raising campaigns.

headline: Let Them Count the Ways
text: Carl Ballenas

headline: My Dropout Boyfriend Kept Dropping In
text: IN April of my freshman year, my boyfriend, Terry, decided he wanted to be homeless. Among the decisions I expected a college-age boyfriend to make (changing cellphone plans, or maybe going vegan), homelessness was not one of them.

headline: Connie Ng, Paul Hess
text: Dr. Connie May Ng and Dr. Paul Laurence Hess were married on Saturday evening at the Memorial Church of Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Mark D. W. Edington, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: The Texas Carny and His Coney Island Gal
text: THE Tornado roller coaster, precursor and rival to the world-famous Cyclone, stood on the east side of Stillwell Avenue in Coney Island from 1926 until 1977, when it perished in a fire. More recently, that block, between Bowery Street and the Boardwalk, was home to a go-cart track and a cluster of batting cages. Then last spring, in preparation for a planned revitalization that has yet to arrive, the land’s owner, Thor Equities, cleared it of everything but rocks and dirt, and it sat empty, all summer long.

headline: Put a Little Science in Your Life
text: A COUPLE of years ago I received a letter from an American soldier in Iraq. The letter began by saying that, as we’ve all become painfully aware, serving on the front lines is physically exhausting and emotionally debilitating. But the reason for his writing was to tell me that in that hostile and lonely environment, a book I’d written had become a kind of lifeline. As the book is about science  one that traces physicists’ search for nature’s deepest laws  the soldier’s letter might strike you as, well, odd.

headline: Claudia DeSimio and Alexander Gil
text: Claudia Marie DeSimio, a daughter of Sheila E. DeSimio and Christopher J. DeSimio of Cincinnati, was married on Saturday to Alexander Guillermo Gil, the son of Christine E. Argento of Miami and the late Guillermo A. Gil. Lea J. Goldman, who became an associate pastor of Rose Ministries for this event, officiated at the Caneel Bay resort on St. John, Virgin Islands.

headline: Letters: The Hillary Lesson
text: Peggy Orenstein (May 18) is correct: all is not quite well for women today. Clinton’s bid for the presidency has unleashed the dormant monster of sexism that our mothers and grandmothers recognize all too well. Misogyny is alive, and “post-feminism” is my generation’s delusion.

headline: City of Eclectics
text: If the romance of Paris is a cultural commonplace, so too is its reputation for depths that can never be plumbed, a code that cannot be deciphered. “You might know every street in Paris,” observed Henry Miller, one of the city’s best-known expatriates, “and not know Paris.” Cole Porter likewise cautioned that “you may know Paris, but you don’t know Paree.” Yet clichés (if you’ll pardon the cliché) ring true for a reason; accordingly, “Métro Stop Paris: An Underground History of the City of Light” confirms the notion that there is always something more to learn about France’s capital. Written by Gregor Dallas, this “thinker’s guide to Paris” attempts to probe unexplored or underappreciated aspects of the city’s history. To this end, Dallas, whose books include a study of the Loire peasantry and a biography of Georges Clemenceau, offers a dozen vignettes from different historical eras, each tale at least ostensibly associated with a specific Parisian neighborhood.

headline: A Studio, Priced Just Right
text: JEFF SIEBERT grew up in a small farming town near Fresno, Calif., watching movie musicals and yearning for a life in the big city. He got it when he moved to New York 24 years ago, beginning a successful career as a Broadway dancer with parts in “Miss Saigon,” “Cabaret” and “Chitty Chitty Bang Bang,” among others.

headline: Sex and the City (Circa 1840)
text: On April 9, 1842, The Whip, a weekly New York newspaper that pledged to “keep a watchful eye on all brothels and their frail inmates,” carried an article about chambermaids. Chambermaids were women of flesh and blood, according to the article, “with the same instinctive desires as their masters, and much of their time is necessarily passed alone, in remote apartments, which usually contain beds.” Accompanying the article was a drawing: a chambermaid gripped the long wooden handle of a warming pan that projected rudely from between a tailcoated gentleman’s legs.

headline: Two Different Developers Gave Block Its Character
text: Q I live at 632 West End Avenue. Why are there two nearly identical corner buildings flanking a row of nearly identical brownstones? ... George Moran, Manhattan

headline: A Very Dirty Movie
text: Documentarians don’t get much burlier than Chris Bell. The 35-year-old was a competitive powerlifter before geneticshe stands 5-foot-6 on a good dayforced a career change and sent him off to the University of Southern California’s film school. Bell’s two brothers, Mad Dog and Smelly, weren’t so quick to give up their athletic dreams and turned to steroids to further their pursuits of glory. Bell’s debut film, “Bigger Stronger Faster,” uses his family as a starting point to probe the sport’s world obsession with sports-enhancing drugs. It had its premiere at Sundance in January and went into limited release in New York and Los Angeles on May 30. Wider release will follow. He spoke to Play about juicing, family style

headline: Think the Economy Is Bad? Wait Till the States Cut Back
text: Struggling as we are with the housing bust, the credit crunch, shrinking consumption, rising unemployment and faltering business investment, we can be forgiven for thinking that all the big shoes have dropped. There is another one up there, however, and it is about to come down.

headline: When Thumbs Up Is No Comfort
text: OVER the Memorial Day weekend, the actor Patrick Swayze, who is being treated for pancreatic cancer, made a pointedly public appearance at a Los Angeles Lakers game, looking strong-jawed and bright-eyed. He released a statement about his lively schedule and good response to therapy. Meanwhile, Senator Ted Kennedy, who had recently left Massachusetts General Hospital with a diagnosis of brain cancer, flashing crowds a thumbs up, competed in a sailing race. International headlines cheered, “Fight, Ted, Fight!”

headline: Pulling No Punches, Brawler Wins His Prime-Time Debut
text: NEWARK  At 9 p.m. on a wet Saturday, mixed martial arts opened its case to join the mainstream. The CBS announcer Gus Johnson looked into the camera and proclaimed the evening  the sport’s live debut on network television  “the dawn of an era in American sports.”

headline: High-End Hotels Are Still Opening in Beijing
text: The hotel boom in Beijing continues as the Summer Olympics draw near. The stylish Hotel G Beijing will open this month in the Chaoyang District, where bars and restaurants like the Green T. House abound. The design of the 110-room hotel (www.avantgardehotels.com) seems to be inspired by the retro-chic sensibility of the Austin Powers movie series, and guests have a choice of three restaurants: 25 Degrees (upscale burgers and cocktails), Gilt (Mediterranean cuisine) and Morio (Japanese fine dining). There is also a spa. Nightly rates start at about 2,010 yuan, or $289 at 7 yuan to the dollar, through the end of the month, after which the rates will increase to about 2,369 yuan, or $334 at the same exchange rate. For those who prefer a corporate ambience  and to stay high above the city  there is the Park Hyatt Beijing (www.beijing.park.hyatt.com), scheduled to open next month in the business district. There will be 237 rooms on floors 37 to 49 in the Park Tower (part of the Beijing Yintai Center). Rates are expected to start at 3,500 yuan.

headline: Lindsey Dickinson, Ernest Baynard IV
text: Lindsey Putnam Dickinson and Ernest Cornish Baynard IV were married on Saturday in Ludlow, Vt. The Rev. Michael E. Augustinowitz officiated at Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Al Green: Neo-Soul’s Not Over
text: To the Editor:

headline: Humanitarian Vanities
text: Ours is an age in which the responsibility for protecting people when their physical survival is at stake has become an increasingly accepted principle in international relations. It is even enshrined in a United Nations-approved covenant as the “responsibility to protect”  the idea being that a state that engages in criminal behavior toward its own people has forfeited not just its moral but also its legal right to sovereignty.

headline: Relief Helicopter Crashes in China
text: SHANGHAI  A Chinese military helicopter involved in relief operations crashed in heavy fog near the town of Yingxiu on Saturday with 14 people on board, according to China’s official news agency, Xinhua, which provided no details about casualties.

headline: Roberta Finke, Alan Franklin
text: Roberta Sue Finke and Alan Marc Franklin were married Thursday evening at Cipriani 23rd Street in New York. Rabbi Marcelo R. Bronstein officiated.

headline: Darcy Bentley, Daniel Frisch
text: Darcy Virginia Bentley and Daniel Frisch were married on Friday evening in Manhattan. Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the New Leaf Café in Fort Tryon Park.

headline: Triway to Hell
text: Because a triathlon requires a swim, a bike ride and a run, a staple of most training schedules is the dreaded “brick” workout: two or more disciplines back to back. The theory is that the brick familiarizes you with the feeling of running on legs whose freshness has long since expired. For most people, a brick is a run immediately following a ride, but really, what’s the difference? Work is work is work.

headline: They’re Grants to Some, Pork Barrel to Others
text: WITH $9.8 million in taxpayer money to spend at their discretion, Nassau County’s 19 legislators are in an enviable position as they look to do good and win friends.

headline: Technology Stocks Are the Week’s Stars
text: The overall stock market managed a small gain for the week, and technology stocks propelled the Nasdaq composite index to a hefty advance.

headline: Connecticut Lobstermen Hope for a Reprieve
text: HARTFORD

headline: It’s All About Leverage
text: Barack Obama is getting painfully close to tying himself in knots with all his explanations of the conditions under which he would unconditionally talk with America’s foes, like Iran. His latest clarification was that there is a difference between “preparations” and “preconditions” for negotiations with bad guys. Such hair-splitting word games do not inspire confidence, and they play right into the arms of his critics. The last place he wants to look uncertain is on national security.

headline: Officials Look at Equipment, Not Crane’s Operators
text: This article was reported by Charles V. Bagli, Ken Belson and William Neuman, and written by Mr. Neuman.

headline: It’s Good to Be Immortal
text: 1. “HE HAD SHARPIE ALL OVER HIM.”

headline: Working the Reunion
text: You always knew when, at the end of the spring semester, reunion week approached. They would drape a three-story-tall blue banner over Commons; emblazoned on it were gigantic white letters: YALE. When I was in school there, I always worked reunions. You could score about two thousand bucks in a few weeks doing custodial work, waiting on tables, making up rooms and “Y”-ing the beds. To “Y” a bed, you’d make it up with a Yale blue blanket, then arrange three white towels on top into a Y, for Yale. Actually, everything had to be in a Y  the soaps, the extra blankets, any spare change left on the dresser.

headline: ’60s Legacy, Personal Histories
text: LESLIE HEWITT was not yet a glimmer in her parents’ eye when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech at the March on Washington. Still, whenever Ms. Hewitt, a 30-year-old artist, sees images of the crowds at this 1963 event, she searches the more than 200,000 faces for her mother.

headline: When a Landlord Won’t Return a Security Deposit
text: Q I moved into an apartment on a one-year lease. Thirty days before the end of my lease, I gave notice to vacate and requested, in writing, the return of my security deposit and interest.

headline: A Union President Presses for Growth Amid a New Round of Criticisms
text: As 2,000 convention delegates gather in Puerto Rico, the Service Employees International Union is about to jettison a time-honored union tradition  having members go to their union representatives with their questions and grievances.

headline: Large Fire Strikes Universal Studio Lot
text: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  A massive fire erupted early Sunday at NBC Universal’s studio lot here, destroying a vault full of video and television images and parts of a popular studio tour, including the studio’s King Kong attraction.

headline: Marriage Partners
text: The recent California Supreme Court decision granting gays the right to marry creates a novel predicament. In November, California voters will quite likely have to decide whether to take marriage away from gay couples rather than whether to grant it to them. If Golden State voters decide to preserve that right, the freedom to marry will no longer be the product of “activist judges” but will acquire a democratic imprimatur. This high-stakes vote squarely poses the question of whether and how gays can get the support of straights on this issue.

headline: Shuttle Discovery Heads Toward the Space Station
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Discovery blasted its way into orbit on Saturday through wispy clouds against blue skies on its way to deliver a bus-size laboratory to the International Space Station.

headline: What to Watch
text: Consider the following definition: “I know what madness is. It’s not knowing how another man feels.” And this corollary: “A madman’s never been in another man’s shoes.”

headline: ‘Come Back, Little Sheba’
text: It’s the morning after in the life of Lola Delaney. The last time she saw her husband, he called her a fat slut and a whoremonger, screamed that she had ruined his life, and as a coup de grâce, lunged at her with a butcher knife.

headline: Road Maps to Automotive Adventures
text: SPRING and summer have traditionally been the time for piling into the car and heading out for an adventure, whether in the next county or on the next continent. Some recent books document just such “drives on the wild side.” Other current titles take the reader on a different sort of ride: an armchair tour of dream garages or a journey down the long and winding road traversed by Henry Ford’s Model T. Here are some road maps for whatever trip you choose.

headline: Emily Ryan Lerner, Evan Kindley
text: Emily Ryan Lerner, the daughter of Margaret R. Ryan and Steven P. Lerner of Manhattan, was married last Monday to Evan Sinnard Kindley, a son of Louise S. Kindley and Jeffrey B. Kindley, also of Manhattan. Magistrate Judge Ronald L. Ellis, of Federal District Court in Manhattan, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: From Clay to Bronze to the Hall
text: TRYON, N.C.  The door to the sculptor’s studio in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains swung open, and there stood Buck O’Neil, the Negro leagues legend, in red clay, 6 feet tall, nearly ready to be bronzed.

headline: Jennifer Baker, Samuel Taylor
text: Jennifer Marie Baker was married on Saturday to Dr. Samuel Arthur Taylor in Cleveland. The Rev. John L. Viall, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. John Cantius Church, with the Rev. Donald H. Dunson, also a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: The Supper Club
text: When I think of home, I think of the index-card reminder that arrives in the mailbox each month with the words “FIRST WEDNESDAY” scribbled in Magic Marker. If we lived in a small town in Iowa, or in Pennsylvania Dutch country, the freewheeling potluck dinner that has been held on our block on the first Wednesday of every month for the past 18 years might not seem like such big a deal. But this is Oakland, Calif.

headline: High Pants Forever
text: Why did the nerd button the top button of his shirt? That’s not the setup to a riddle. It’s one of the mysteries solved in “American Nerd: The Story of My People,” by Benjamin Nugent.

headline: Who Has the Horse Tranquilizers?
text: The Olympics in Beijing are nearly upon us, and if the previous Summer Gamesnot to mention the events of the intervening four yearsare any indication, drug scandals will be part of the festivities. In March, 11 of 14 weight lifters on the Greek Olympic team tested positive for steroid use, and the Greek coach, in turn, blamed a Chinese manufacturer for providing them with tainted supplements. And so it begins. “There will always be someone who tests positive at the Olympics,” says Gary Wadler, a New York University medical professor and the chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency’s Prohibited List and Methods Committee. “Somebody will do a dumb thing, thinking they can get away with it.” To some athletes, apparently, doping remains an unofficial Olympic sport. Time for a tutorial on the drugs of summer.

headline: City to Explore a Way to Add Organ Donors
text: New York City is pioneering a potential solution to a supply-and-demand problem that has long vexed doctors the world over: how to meet a desperate need for donated organs without trampling on sensitivity surrounding the sanctity of death.

headline: Personalize This
text: By VIRGINIA HEFFERNAN

headline: Hannah Means, Russell Shannon
text: Hannah Elizabeth Means and Russell Andrew Shannon were married on Saturday in Lahaska, Pa. The Rev. William Peterson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Anna Stancioff, Frederick Bierman
text: Anna Marion Stancioff and Frederick Carrington Bierman were married on Saturday evening at Woodend Sanctuary in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Beth Humphrey, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Meeting Set to Discuss Future of Maple Bats
text: Representatives from the commissioner’s office, the players union and major league teams will meet June 24 in New York to discuss the future of maple bats.

headline: Swing Science: The Fine Points
text: THE MOST DIFFICULT FEAT IN SPORTS, DEMYSTIFIED. HALL OF FAMER AND THREE-TIME BATTING CHAMPION GEORGE BRETT DISCUSSES THE CRAFT OF HITTING: HOW TO IDENTIFY A PITCH THAT IS TRAVELING AT MORE THAN 90 MILES AN HOUR AND THEN MAKE CONTACT WITH ITALL IN LESS THAN A SECOND.

headline: Again, for the First Time
text: WHEN your high school English teachers talked about the rewards of revisiting the classics, they probably didn’t mean musicals. Most likely they were referring to fat, dense novels (“Middlemarch,” “Anna Karenina”) and long, lofty plays (“Hamlet,” “Long Day’s Journey Into Night”): works of weight, they liked to tell us, dragging out a favorite dog-eared phrase, with “universal human truth.”

headline: Prison Puppies
text: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y.

headline: History, Revised
text: To the Editor:

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Film

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BLACK FLIES, by Shannon Burke. (Soft Skull, paper, $14.95.) A rookie paramedic in New York City is overwhelmed by the horrors of his job in this arresting, confrontational novel, informed by Burke’s five years of experience on city ambulances.

headline: With Few Policy Differences, Little to Argue in Senate Race
text: TRENTON

headline: Sacrificing Space for Scenery
text: “IT’S a view with an apartment,” said Mark Del Vecchio of his home on the 42nd floor of a beige brick behemoth near Lincoln Center.

headline: Beyond Harry & David
text: The coconut is technically a fruit, and every now and then it grows a pearl. The pearl-bearing coconut is one of some 30 surprising fruits that caused me to pencil an exclamation mark in the margins of “The Fruit Hunters: A Story of Nature, Adventure, Commerce and Obsession.” Though I did not rank them, I would place the coconut more or less equidistant between the orange that tastes like chicken noodle soup and the exploding variety of pomegranate (“grenade means pomegranate in French”), but some distance below the miracle fruit, which makes everything eaten afterward taste sweet, including “boyfriends.” Adam Leith Gollner possesses a talent as rare and exotic as a coconut pearl. I opened this book, Gollner’s first, expecting the standard nutmeat of competent nonfiction and found instead something lustrous and exhilarating. Gollner’s is not the sort of talent one can develop. It is genetic, physical  an exquisite sensitivity of tongue, nose and eye. He describes one variety of the stinking durian fruit as tasting like “undercooked peanut butter-mint omelets in body-odor sauce”; langsats are “tangy-sweet detonations of citric perfection”; biting into a monkey tamarind is “like eating cloud.” Here is the Kuching market in Borneo, through the prism of Gollner’s gifts: “Balmy effluvia rising off the sidewalk clamp down on your sinus cavity. ... Writhing, roiling masses of fat sago worms are sold out of tree trunks. Men shout death threats at one another over corridors littered with squid tentacles.”

headline: Surf and Turf

headline: Letter: Ireland and Progress
text: To the Editor: Regarding Dan Barry’s search for the “real” Ireland in his article, “Does the ‘Real’ Ireland Still Exist?” (May 18): The issue lies in what he is searching for. If you believe the real Ireland to be the one portrayed in “The Quiet Man” or more recently in “Far and Away,” you are searching for something that exists primarily in the minds of movie producers or those nostalgic for a past no longer widely seen.

headline: French Toast
text: Many culturally hungry Americans dream about moving to France. “We’ve Always Had Paris ... and Provence” is the story of two who did so and have lived happily ever after. Patricia Wells, known best for her seminal “Food Lover’s Guide to Paris,” and Walter Wells, a high-ranking editor of The International Herald Tribune from 1980 to 2005, have written a he-said, she-said memoir, volleying back and forth to tell how a girl from Wisconsin and a boy from South Carolina met while working at The New York Times and went to France in 1980 on what they assumed would be temporary journalistic assignments. They found their lives’ calling as expatriates, transcending prejudice to be accepted and even revered by the foreign culture they embraced. Walter was awarded the French Legion of Honor. Patricia recounts with no small measure of self-amazement the time she showed the Frenchman Joël Robuchon, “the greatest chef in the world,” how to make her special bouillabaisse.

headline: Patrolling the Streets, and Dissing the Rivals
text: IN mid-April, a young black man in Crown Heights was struck with a baton and sprayed with Mace by two white men, according to the police, and ever since, tensions have run high in the Brooklyn neighborhood. Jews and blacks who live there eye one another warily, and police patrols and surveillance have intensified.

headline: Hope You Like Jamming Too

We’re a country.” So a Jamaica Tourist Board ad campaign stated in the 1970s, as tourism became the bread and butter of the Caribbean and Bob Marley secured international fame. To cite the current Jamaica Tourist Board motto, which has “cult” written all over it, “Once you go, you know.”

headline: It’s Where You Live That Matters
text: Q. I have lived in my rent-stabilized two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan for more than 12 years. Recently, title to my mother's condominium in New Jersey was transferred to my name for estate planning purposes. She resides there and pays me a nominal rent. My apartment in New York is my legal mailing address and is where I actually live. Have I put myself in a situation whereby my landlord could challenge my right to continue to live in my apartment?

headline: And Now, the Biggest Entertainer in Entertainment
text: Floyd Mayweather Jr., the welterweight widely regarded as pound for pound the best boxer in the world, is about as rich and famous as a 147-pound fighter can get these days. People who don’t know anything about boxing beyond Mike Tyson and Muhammad Ali recognize him on the street (Who’s that little guy with all the bodyguards?), although sometimes it takes an extra second or two. (It’s that boxer who was on “Dancing with the Stars.”) Mayweather, who used to be known as “Pretty Boy” and now answers to “Money,” is famous, but he’s not famous famous. He won’t settle for that. He wants to be bigger than boxing today can make him.

headline: Triple Play
text: The sun is shining, the school year is winding down and librarians everywhere are promoting summer reading. Promoting? Cheerleading, browbeating and nagging is more like it. Every public library children’s room is gearing up. Reading records? Check. Book lists? Check. Giveaway prizes, stickers, bookmarks? Check, check, check.

headline: In the Pacific, a New Kind of Monument Is Proposed

headline: Bro Knows Football
text: Only one sports fan has managed to go the entirety of the N.B.A. playoffs while ignoring Charles Barkley’s television commercials. His name is Charles Barkley. It is not that Sir Charles is embarrassed by his commercial work, past and present: the famous “I Am Not a Role Model” ad for Nike; his battle against Godzilla; the opera buffa “Barkley of Seville”; and, most recently, the series of T-Mobile ads co-starring Dwyane Wade that seem to appear at least 90 times during any N.B.A. telecast. No, it’s that for Barkley, there is something unnerving about being confronted with his commercial self. “I try to always look away or something like that,” Barkley told me recently. “I don’t want anyone to think I’m an egomaniac.”

headline: ‘August: Osage County’ and ‘Macbeth’
text: It’s a tough call this season about what constituted the worse invitation: dinner at the Westons’ or at the Macbeths’. One’s immediate response is: “The Macbeths’ of course. The head of the household’s a murderer, after all.” But while the onstage supper table in “August: Osage County” (left), Tracy Letts’s three-act drama of mounting family turmoil, is not haunted by any bloodied ghosts, there are plenty of place settings for skeletons of the closet variety. And though Violet Weston (Deanna Dunagan), the soul-flaying matriarch of the play’s Oklahoma clan, doesn’t actually kill anybody during the searing dinner scene, she has assassin’s skills to match anything the Thane of Cawdor can muster. Venom tongued and gimlet eyed, she seasons her brood’s repast with cutting remarks, knocking off relations like so many targets in a sideshow shooting gallery.

headline: Taking Their Faith, but Not Their Politics, to the People

headline: Going Nowhere
text: “Dear American Airlines,” Jonathan Miles’s fine first novel, takes the form of a letter to the titular air carrier, which has stranded Benjamin R. Ford, the book’s middle-aged protagonist, in O’Hare Airport on the way to his estranged daughter’s wedding. One doesn’t take this premise literally, of course. As Bennie waits to be put on another flight, he has a lot of time on his hands, enough to miss first the rehearsal dinner and then the “wedding” itself (quotation marks courtesy of Benjamin, who’s just found out that his daughter is marrying a woman), but not enough to write a novel. The premise works though, because, as anyone who’s ever been stalled in an airport knows, time crawls. It feels like eternity,

headline: Four's a Charm
text: WHAT do you wear to your own relaunching? That was the question on Ashanti’s mind on a recent Thursday evening as she prepped and primped in a suite at the Four Seasons.

headline: 36 Hours in Lima, Peru
text: LIMA has long been a cosmopolitan city hesitant to embrace its diversity. A capital founded by Spanish conquistadors that subsequently exploded with influxes from Asia and then from Peru’s own Andean highlands, it has remained a city of fairly segregated neighborhoods. But led by Lima’s cuisine  which is rapidly gaining worldwide renown for its freshness and creativity  that is changing. Sushi and ceviche chefs are learning from one another. The most popular street food is “five flavors” a rice and pasta dish with Italian, Chinese, Andean, Japanese and African influences. Restaurants that once hid their existence from all but the “in the know” are now advertising their presence with Web sites and  gasp  signs out front. For the tourist, it means days of exploring neighborhoods and attractions with distinct cultures and histories, interspersed with the spicy, sweet, and subtle gastronomic experience of how it all comes together.

headline: Imported Plays? Small World
text: IN the last year I have seen shows in Off Broadway theaters from, among other places, Argentina, Canada, England, Ireland, Israel, Korea, Poland, Russia and Scotland. New York is as much a global theater capital as ever, so why doesn’t it always seem that way?

headline: Chile and Peru Vie in Spat Over Spud

headline: Swiss to Decide on Secret Votes by Public on Citizenship Candidates

headline: Correction: She Just Might Be President Someday
text: An article on May 18 exploring the question of who might be the first female president of the United States referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for candidates. In a brief reference to Maria Shriver, the article noted that her husband (Arnold Schwarzenegger) “can’t run because he was not born in this country.” The Constitution says only that the president must be “a natural-born citizen,” not that the president must have been born in the United States.

headline: What You Need to Know to Get a Mortgage

headline: Sticking to What It Knows: Chinese

It was one of the first things I had planted in the garden; when I found it at the nursery, I was transported back to an island off the Georgia coast where it climbed high into the trees, perfuming the air and showering me with golden petals. That was eight years ago, and it had never bloomed.

headline: Good Housing News, and From a Banker
text: Under Ed Clark, its chief executive, the Toronto-Dominion Bank has emerged largely unscathed by the current subprime credit trouble. That, in turn, has left Mr. Clark with some very valuable stock options, which he must exercise soon.

headline: Safe at Home
text: As a junior in high school in 1984 I studied Russell Baker’s Pulitzer Prize-winning 1982 memoir, “Growing Up,” in which he recounted his childhood after his father died when Baker was 5. He grew up in rural, Depression-era Virginia, without plumbing or electricity, and later in Baltimore. Baker demonstrated that ordinary tales told plainly could rise to the level of art, and the book stuck with me over the years, through the rise of the memoir industry, as a premier example of writing about boyhood.

headline: Finding Hope for ’08 Holidays, on the Web

headline: Kicked Out of the Play Group
text: My daughter’s play group consists of children ranging in age from infancy to 4 years old. One mother revealed that she does not vaccinate her son. Did the group behave ethically? J.G., PASADENA

headline: With Tony Peña
text: The Kansas City Royals travel to Yankee Stadium on Friday, a complicated proposition for the Yankees’ first-base coach, Tony Peña. His son, Tony Peña Jr., is the Royals’ shortstop. He has a way to go to match his father for longevity: Tony Sr., who turns 51 on Wednesday, caught 1,950 games from 1980 to 1997. Athletic talent runs in the family. Tony Sr.’s mother, Rosalia, is a former softball player. TYLER KEPNER

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Metro

headline: Paperback Row
text: LEGACY OF ASHES: The History of the CIA, by Tim Weiner. (Anchor, $16.95.) This National Book Award-winning history of the Central Intelligence Agency’s first 60 years “describes how the most powerful country in the history of Western civilization has failed to create a first-rate spy service,” Weiner, a reporter for The Times, writes. Using tens of thousands of declassified documents and on-the-record recollections of former officials, Weiner presents the agency’s ineptitude with embarrassing detail (when the Berlin Wall fell, the leader of the Soviet division had to rely on CNN for his information). Scheming or feckless directors and misguided orders from presidents explain some of the problems, Weiner says, and he warns that “this nation may not long endure as a great power unless it finds the eyes to see things as they are in the world.”

headline: ‘South Pacific’
text: The defining moment of Lincoln Center Theater’s lavishly praised revival of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s South Pacific” arguably comes before the show has actually begun, when not a single actor is onstage. This nonprofit theater has made much of its decision to employ a full complement of orchestra musicians at a time when pits are being pared down to the core. And Lincoln Center makes it clear at each performance in the most dramatic way possible. At the beginning of the overture, just as the violins introduce the lushly melodic lines of “Bali Ha’i,” the stage floor above the musicians’ heads begins to recede, drawing back to reveal every one of the pit’s 30 members.

headline: The Livin’ Is . . .
text: I’m standing on a Maui beach, surfboard under my arm, lip split and bleeding from a wipeout. I’m trying not to smile, because it opens the cut even more, but I can’t help myself. I’ve just learned how to turn on a wave.

headline: Calls for Daly to Reform Don’t Come From Within
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  Amid the soft sands and mild island breezes of Hawaii, some hard career decisions occurred to Pat Perez at the start of the 2008 season. He would hire a trainer to continue the workouts he had begun in the off-season. He would cut out beer during tournament weeks. The practice tee, a place he visited with the same enthusiasm he might have for the proctologist’s office, would become a regular haunt.

headline: Mindy Sprung, Evan Fox
text: Mindy Pamela Sprung, a daughter of Susan Sprung and Dr. Craig Sprung of Wayside, N.J., was married on Monday to Evan David Fox, the son of Dinah Fox and Dr. Bruce Fox of Randolph, N.J. Rabbi Joel E. Soffin officiated at the Wilshire Grand Hotel in West Orange, N.J.

headline: Making Noise Behind the Scenes
text: BACK in 1961 who would have guessed that “Show Girl” was making history? Yet by listing Jack Mann in its program, that lightweight musical revue became the first Broadway show to acknowledge a sound designer. It took a few decades, but now the Tony Awards are following suit.

headline: Coldplay Tries a Few New Things
text: WITH its frescoed walls and waiters in white jackets, the Café Carlyle is like a Hollywood version of old-school New York sophistication.

headline: Albert Brooks Gives Himself the Business
text: ALBERT BROOKS, who turns 61 in July, hasn’t had a recurring part on a television series since 1970, when he played a guy named Rudy in two episodes of “The Odd Couple.” He mostly made movies after that: his own movies, written and directed by Albert Brooks and starring Albert Brooks as a less aware, less competent, more easily flustered versions of Albert Brooks. “The Woody Allen of the West Coast,” a critic once called him.

headline: Social Lions
Above the City, Juggling Patience, Precision and Danger
text: They sit in cubicles in the sky, at the controls inside an operator’s cab 20 or 30 stories above the streets of New York City. They spend their days hooking and hoisting  even when off-duty, since a number of them unwind by going fishing. They have withstood sudden wind gusts, irate contractors and even lightning strikes, all in a day’s work, for a maximum salary of about $60 an hour.

headline: Jordan Wright, 50, Political Archivist, Dies
text: Jordan M. Wright, who at 10 was thrilled to learn that politicians hand out self-promotional baubles, then collected more than a million bumper stickers and other campaign artifacts  from the time of George Washington to that of George W. Bush  died on May 11 at his home in Atlantic Beach, N.Y. He was 50.

headline: County Presses Proposal for Bike Trail
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Northern Composure
text: According to Harry Boyd, one of the main characters in Elizabeth Hay’s new novel, radio is like poetry, and television is like a blockbuster novel. A radio program, Harry continues, is “about one person learning something interesting and telling it to somebody else.” In “Late Nights on Air,” which was awarded Canada’s Giller Prize in 2007, many people tell other people many things  and many of them are very interesting.

headline: Letter: Toronto Bargains
text: To the Editor: Matt Gross’s recent visit to Toronto as the Frugal Traveler would have benefited from more research and/or a longer stay. His article “O Canada, Where Have Your Bargains Gone?” (May 18) paints a rather shallow and limited picture of the many modestly priced attractions in this cosmopolitan, accessible, largely peaceful city, whose metropolitan population is more than 2.7 million, and which harbors communities drawn from nearly every other country.

headline: New Tastes of Bohemia
text: “Rent,” which was originally scheduled to close this weekend after 12 years on Broadway, has extended its lease through Sept. 7. And there lies a poignant irony: The musical’s struggling artists surely could no longer afford even one more day in Alphabet City. But these restaurants seem poised for long runs there.

headline: Tatis Plays the Star in Another Comeback
text: Any elation the Mets derived from learning that Chad Billingsley, the Dodgers’ right-hander, would be leaving after throwing seven shutout innings Saturday vanished as soon as Jonathan Broxton, the hulking set-up man, loped in from the bullpen. Due up first for the Mets in the eighth, David Wright. After him, Carlos Beltrán. Their career success against Broxton: no hits in eight at-bats with six strikeouts.

headline: A Player Destined for the Majors Chose First to Play for Himself
text: NASHVILLE  A high school senior named Pedro Alvarez went to bat during a major league draft showcase at Yankee Stadium three springs ago.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 38 of the Magazine today about the talk-show host Tyra Banks misspells, in one reference, the middle name of the president of Telepictures Productions, which produces Banks’s show. She is Hilary Estey McLoughlin, not Estes.

headline: Cult of Deception
text: WASHINGTON

headline: From a Leisurely Trot to a Showdown at Belmont
text: Each morning, Casino Drive is saddled up and ridden along the backside of Belmont Park. For an hour, he darts between barns, sends puffs of dirt in the air as he clip-clops down shady paths and garners admiring stares from the most hard-bitten of horsemen. When Casino Drive, a chestnut colt, finally hits the racetrack for a gallop, he swallows the ground with his giant strides.

headline: A Novel’s Twists Immerse a Writer in the World of Addiction
text: Falls Village

headline: 10 Years Later, Carrie Coordinated
text: TEN years of watching “Sex and the City,” including the sanitized reruns on TBS, has trained a generation of label- and love-addled romantics not to raise an eyebrow, presuming Botox hasn’t yet made that impossible, when Carrie Bradshaw dons a black Burberry coat and a trilby to go shopping, film noir style, at Duane Reade. Or when Carrie wears a four-figure Nina Ricci sweater trimmed with hundreds of feathers while typing on a laptop in the privacy of her own home. Or when Carrie crawls into Big’s big bed, wearing makeup and a single strand of pearls.

headline: Letters: General Vang Pao’s Last War
text: As a professor of Hmong/Southeast history, in particular the Vietnam War era, I am troubled by the continued portrayal of Hmong people as an “ancient tribe” who were diehard American allies (Tim Weiner, May 11). There were Hmong fighting on both sides, supported by both East and West. Many were neutral, struggling just to stay alive in the most bombed region in world history to date. Hmong expatriates’ relationships with Laos are widely varied, and thousands return from abroad annually to visit relatives, establish businesses or even to set up residence. Actual Hmong returns to Laos are neither unrealistic nor simply a military fantasy, but part and parcel of globalization.

headline: On the Trail of a Sustainable Feast in Sonoma
text: THE psychedelic, hand-painted, Mushroom Man pickup truck parked at the New Carpati Farm in Sonoma County, Calif., just outside the town of Sebastopol, was the first sign that this vacation was going to be a little out of the ordinary.

headline: Using It Before Losing It
text: Secession movements are an American instinct, and Andrew D. Blechman sees one afoot in the migration of young, well-off retirees to the land of golf and sunshine. “I could feel it,” he writes, watching his sprightly New England neighbors pack up for Florida. “I suspected that the Andersons were in the vanguard of a significant cultural shift.”

headline: Blythe Pittman and Aris Winger
text: Blythe Harriet Pittman and Aris Benjamin Winger are to be married on Sunday on the grounds of Tobias Smyth Cabin at Emory & Henry College in Emory, Va. The Rev. Timothy Kobler, a United Methodist minister, is to officiate.

headline: Rachael Degenshein, Alen Lapidis
text: Rachael Lynn Degenshein, a daughter of Jane R. Degenshein and Larry C. Degenshein of West Orange, N.J., is to marry Alen Lapidis, the son of Mila Lapidis and Felix Lapidis of Costa Mesa, Calif., on Sunday. Rabbi Steven Kushner is to officiate at the Manor, an event space in West Orange.

headline: A Co-op Superintendent Casts a Lot of Votes
text: Q The superintendent in our co-op also owns shares and occupies the unit related to those shares.

headline: Correction: Now He’s Only Hunted by Cameras
text: An article last Sunday about Salman Rushdie misstated the way in which he learned of the end of his marriage with Padma Lakshmi. She discussed the matter in person; she did not tell him via e-mail.

headline: Smoke Clears, Dust Does Not in Beijing
text: THESE pre-Olympic mornings, when the air is thick with the scent of jasmine and roses, I gaze out the window of my high-rise apartment in northwest Beijing and see  alas, not much. That’s because the air is also thick with oxides of many colors and complex carbon chains yet unclassified.

headline: Mozart’s Rivals: A Neglected Contemporary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Grace Lockhart, Marko Djuranovic
text: Grace Strahan Lockhart, the daughter of Carolyn S. Lockhart and James B. Lockhart III of Greenwich, Conn., was married on Saturday evening to Marko Djuranovic, the son of Gordana and Mirko Djuranovic of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Greenwich. The couple met at Duke, from which they graduated.

headline: Democrats See Cuba Travel Limits as a Campaign Issue in Florida
text: MIAMI  Baltasar Martin Garrote desperately wants to see his mother turn 86 in August at her home in Cuba. But an American law will not let him.

headline: Correction: Resistance Is Futile
text: A caption with an article last Sunday about the Nintendo video-game designer Shigeru Miyamoto misidentified the character from the Zelda series shown. It is Link, not Zelda.

headline: Where Nerds Rule the Night
text: PINWORMS. Flatworms. Roundworms. Fish tapeworms tens of meters long, inside someone’s intestine. Worm cysts in the brain. Gross-out pictures of worm extractions.

headline: Jennifer Brosnahan, Kevin McIntyre
text: Jennifer Ru-chiao Brosnahan and Kevin Joseph McIntyre were married on Saturday at St. Joseph’s on Capitol Hill, a Roman Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Peter J. Vaghi performed the ceremony.

headline: Da Vinci, Retrofitted for the Modern Age
text: WHEN Thomas Alva Edison was starting in business, his first patent was for an automated vote-tallying machine to let legislators know instantly which measures had passed and which had been voted down. He sold not a one. It seems that legislators, accustomed to schmoozing and politicking right through a vote’s tally, didn’t want to speed the process.

headline: The Trouble in Housing Trickles Up
text: Greensboro, N.C.

headline: Laura Wareham, Mark Tortorella
text: Laura Stewart Wareham, a daughter of C. Lee Wareham and Raymond N. Wareham of New York, was married on Saturday evening to Mark Philip Tortorella, a son of Deborah J. Tortorella and Philip J. Tortorella Jr. of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall officiated at Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, where he is pastor.

headline: Banksable
text: Tyra Banks has 275 smiles. Like a star athlete who has perfected a jump shot or a curveball, Banks has studied, honed and mastered the smile. In her arsenal are the “surprise smile,” the “angry but still smiling” smile, the “flirting with boyfriend” smile and the “commercial” smile, which, like the rest of Tyra’s smiles, was designed and perfected when Banks, who is now 34, began modeling at 15. From the start of her career, when she was virtually plucked from an all-girl Catholic high school in Los Angeles and whisked off to Paris, to her days as a mass-market first-name-only supermodel strutting the catwalk in her underwear for Victoria’s Secret, Banks always treated modeling as a kind of beautiful science. Then, and now, the smiles were her secret weapons: they could compel, manipulate, seduce. Banks did not become a model to be a muse to designers or because she loved fashion. Modeling  and smiling  was a skill that could, if engineered and managed carefully, change the course of your life.

headline: A Nod to the Insiders
text: As John McCain was purging Washington lobbyists from his campaign last month, Barack Obama fired up a withering put-down.

headline: Shovelware
text: Naming-day in our electronic Eden.

headline: Beauty and the Beasts
text: Insofar as the Gilded Age model Evelyn Nesbit  arguably the most famous face of the early 20th century  is remembered today, it’s as a tease and a gold digger. She has long been held vicariously responsible for the 1906 murder of the architect Stanford White, who was shot by Nesbit’s jealous husband during a performance at what was then Madison Square Garden.

headline: Royal Care for Some of India’s Patients, Neglect for Others
text: BANGALORE, India — “To get the best care,” Robin Steeles said gamely, “you gotta pay for it.”

headline: For People With Down Syndrome, Longer Life Has Complications
text: His Superman T-shirt was bold and bright, but his face was creased with confusion. Gerry Thomas was stumped by a question most men can answer in an instant.

headline: Beauty, Brutality and Three Tough Mothers
text: FOR nearly 40 years Dario Argento, the so-called Italian Hitchcock, has had blood on his hands: deliberately, unashamedly, darn near literally. When a deranged killer stabs, slashes, throttles, garrotes or otherwise violates the corporal integrity of a screaming victim in one of Mr. Argento’s films  this happens with some frequency  the hands inside the black gloves have traditionally been those of the director himself. (It’s his version of the Hitchcock cameo.)

headline: Sugar High
text: The Australian artist Timothy Horn has a fondness for taking historical objects out of context and altering their scale and materials. He made a Chippendale-inspired sconce in rubber, and has enlarged 18th-century jewelry in scale to create large wall pieces. But he has outdone himself with “Timothy Horn: Bitter Suite,” an exhibition that opens June 14 at the de Young Museum in San Francisco. The three large-scale works that make up the show were inspired by objects in the decorative-arts collections of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco (which include the de Young and the California Palace of the Legion of Honor), and by the rags-to-riches story of Alma Spreckels, the colorful collector whose sugar fortune was used to found the Legion of Honor museum, which opened in 1924.

headline: A Drug Is Credited With Slight Gains for Patients Who Have Lung Cancer
text: CHICAGO  The drug Erbitux lengthened the survival of patients with advanced lung cancer by about five weeks, researchers are reporting here this weekend.

headline: More School Districts Look to Hire Teachers of Chinese
text: MOUNT VERNON

headline: Iraqi Military Extends Control in Northern City
text: MOSUL, Iraq — The recent successes in quieting violence in Basra and Sadr City appear to be stretching to the long-rebellious Sunni Arab district here in Mosul, raising hopes that the Iraqi Army may soon have tenuous control over all three of Iraq’s major cities.

headline: Contributor Biography: Gary Leib
text: Gary Leib is an animator and cartoonist.

headline: Never Satisfied, American Vaulter Edges Upward
text: Sixteen years ago, when track and field authorities concluded that women could pole-vault without breaking their necks, Jenn Stuczynski was a 10-year-old in Fredonia, N.Y., participating in softball, volleyball, basketball and golf.

headline: Lone Star Superstar
text: It was 1975, and Willie Nelson was about to begin a national tour of hockey arenas and other massive concrete venues. Country music had seldom been heard in spaces of that scale. His first album for Columbia Records, “Red Headed Stranger,” was about to be released, and its sound was so spare and stark that the label’s president introduced it to his executives by saying, “It’s probably not commercial and might not be made for country radio.”

headline: It’s Back: The Minimum Stay
text: AFTER eight years, the airlines’ Saturday-night-stay rule has risen zombielike from the grave, and Peter Greenberg, for one, wants to rally a mob with torches.

headline: Travel
text: Travel is often a means of escape, and this year’s travel books offer plenty of it. Failed relationships, dead-end jobs and other disappointments infest the current crop like bedbugs in a youth hostel, driving their authors around the globe in search of transformation. The seekers range from bored young drifters to anxiety-stricken middle-agers, motivated by the quixotic hope that cutting loose will stimulate the mind and heal the soul.

headline: Actress Stone and Dior Differ Over Apology
text: THERE is no denying that the high-heeled foot in Sharon Stone’s mouth at the Cannes Film Festival belongs to the actress herself. She admitted that her comments suggesting that karmic retribution may have caused the devastating earthquakes in China were blithering.

headline: ‘Black Watch’
text: It’s unlike any red carpet, as are the fashion statements. Unfurled the length of a battlefield  and three centuries  across the concrete floor of St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, where moments before the contemporary warfare of the play “Black Watch” had raged, it lets an actor (Paul Rattray, above) and a lightning series of costume changes tell the 300-year history of the Royal Highland Regiment through all of its wars. The most recent is in Iraq, the setting for much of this National Theater of Scotland production, which returns to St. Ann’s in the fall.

headline: Big-Top Gala Will Mark Gunn Library’s Centennial
text: Washington

headline: Try the Appetizers, Along With Thai Beer
text: WITH its muted color scheme, delicate tile flooring and dark wood wainscoting, Fairfield’s King and I is as elegant as it welcoming. The accommodating service at this small Thai restaurant on the Post Road (sister restaurant to one of the same name in Bridgeport) is diner-friendly, as are the prices. And some of the food is more than satisfactory, especially the appetizers, although there is a lack of consistency in quality and preparation.

headline: A Timely Way to Go Back in Time
text: AS temperatures, gas prices, carbon-emission anxieties and airfares continue their stealthy creep, one cannot help but gripe anew at the measly network of passenger trains in the United States.

headline: Look Who’s Tough on Iran Now
text: In the annals of role reversal, the switch by the United Nations’ atomic sleuths in Vienna and the American intelligence community has been striking. Having long taken a back seat to the Bush administration in publicly challenging Iran’s nuclear program, the global inspectors last week moved into the driver’s seat, demanding that Tehran come clean on any progress it has made toward building a bomb.

headline: ‘Young Frankenstein’
text: Tragedy next season, comedy tonight.

headline: Continuing to Heal After Returning to Work
text: Q. You are on medical leave after learning that you have cancer, and you plan to return to work after your treatment. Should you return full time or part time?

headline: Clinton’s Next Campaign
text: RACISM. Sexism. Say what you will about the Democratic primaries, they have at the very least provoked a national dialogue about those two shameful scourges of American society. Just as the furor over the Rev. Jeremiah Wright drove Senator Barack Obama to make a widely admired speech on race, the growing outrage on the part of her supporters offers an opportunity for Senator Hillary Clinton to speak out on sexism in American life.

headline: The Watch List
text: José Contreras walked eight batters in six starts in May, or one more than he did in his first two starts of the year. That accuracy has helped him win his last three decisions and lower his earned run average to 2.89. In his last three starts, he has struck out 19 and walked 3.

headline: A Baton for the Youth of the Americas
text: AS a child in Mexico City, Alondra de la Parra felt mixed emotions when she attended symphonic concerts with her parents, both ardent music lovers. “It was frustrating to be sitting in the audience,” she said recently in New York, where she lives now. “I wanted to be onstage, with the sound.”

headline: Entitled to Their Opinions, Yes. But Their Facts?
text: ON May 12, The Times published an Op-Ed article by Edward N. Luttwak, a military historian, who argued that any hopes that a President Barack Obama might improve relations with the Muslim world were unrealistic because Muslims would be “horrified” once they learned that Obama had abandoned the Islam of his father and embraced Christianity as a young adult.

headline: I’m Forever Drinking Bubbles
text: THE current housing variety aside, Americans love bubbles.

headline: Entrepreneur’s Act of Faith Bred on the Gridiron
text: Newark

headline: Taming the Falls
text: The scenic attributes of Niagara Falls are well known, but if the pilot points them out to you in a plane at 30,000 feet, the falls can look more problematic than sublime, as if there’s a leak in the Great Lakes  it makes you want to call someone. On the ground, there’s a long list of things the falls have made people want to do, including but not limited to the following: kill people to own the falls for navigational purposes; cross the falls on a tightrope while making an omelet; pay people off to own the falls for power-production purposes; pay people off to own them for scenic-enrichment purposes, covertly affiliated with the power purposes; inflict electrical consumption on a nation that first thought electricity was deadly but then, when it saw all the gadgets that could be bought, said, Electrify me!; use the falls to make chemicals to help make said gadgets, dumping the leftovers all over the place, especially in the infamous Love Canal; make more chemicals in the name of war  arsenic trichloride, for instance, which makes a gas called lewisite, now on terrorism watch lists; stay overnight in a hotel adjacent to the falls to inaugurate a long marriage (“Every American bride is taken there,” Oscar Wilde said, in the days before Niagara rhymed with Viagra); bury nuclear waste in and around workers’ neighborhoods and not mention it; depopulate the city named after Niagara Falls by building a highway through it; attempt to repopulate the city by building a big mall (the Rainbow Center); attempt again with a casino; and, most recently, write a book that is wild and sometimes thrilling, as far as local history goes  like a ride over the falls in a barrel that turns out O.K., from which you emerge with a new view of Niagara as well as what we call nature.

headline: Do You Love the Job, or Just the Paycheck?
text: AFTER 12 years climbing the corporate ladder to the upper reaches of middle management, I found myself facing a surprising career conundrum: My big paycheck was making me miserable. In short, I hated my job, but I was afraid to give up my hard-earned six-figure salary for what I really wanted: a career as an entrepreneur.

headline: Starwood Starts a Chain for the Electronic Era
text: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is scheduled to start a new chain next month with a high-design/low-cost concept called Aloft. Starwood hopes to have as many as 500 Aloft hotels worldwide by 2012.

headline: The Artist in Search of a Patron
text: THE only bright spot on the Bowery at Great Jones Street that rainy evening was a halogen-lit storefront packed floor to ceiling with ink studies of jazz musicians, dancers and slinky nudes.

headline: Big Brown, Big Hype, Big Payday, Bad Drama
text: Not everybody in thoroughbred racing is giddy over the prospect of a Big Brown Triple Crown.

headline: ‘The House on Fortune Street’
text: The letter came, deceptively, in the kind of envelope a businesslike friend, or his supervisor, might use. It was typed on rather heavy white paper and signed with the pleasing name of Beth Giardini. Sean read the brief paragraphs twice, admiring the mixture of courtesy and menace. Perhaps it had escaped his notice that he was overdrawn by one hundred and twenty-eight pounds? As he doubtless recalled, the bank had waived the penalty last time; this time, regretfully, they must impose their normal fee. Would he kindly telephone to discuss the matter at his earliest convenience?

headline: A Bit of Unpleasantness Won’t Deter Hamptonites
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Modern Kitchens, Set to a Broadway Beat
text: YES, GE Appliances sells most of its $7 billion a year in refrigerators, dishwashers and other home products around the world through retail chains. But recently, the business, the major appliance division of General Electric, decided to market its GE Monogram line for kitchens directly to design professionals as well as to consumers, something it had never really done before.

headline: Inside the List
text: FREY’S RETURN: James Frey’s “Bright Shiny Morning” isn’t his first work of fiction, but it’s his first book to be billed as such, and it crashes into the fiction list at No. 9.

headline: Truth to Power
text: The Book Review asked a handful of writers to recommend books for the presidential candidates. Their suggestions are below.

headline: Dangerous Catch
text: If you are one of the millions of Americans who have been seduced by “Deadliest Catch,” the Discovery Channel’s testosterone-fueled show about king crab fishermen in the Bering Sea, then you know that commercial fishing is dangerous work  and irresistible to watch. Every year, boats sink, fishermen drown and captains clash with the elements, all of which result in huge ratings. In Bill Carter’s “Red Summer,” his account of four summers working as a set-net fisherman in a rough town in southwestern Alaska, the fishing and the weather are less extreme, but the danger level is tantalizingly high. Death, we are reminded, is always one mistake away  a shoelace caught in a net, a skiff overloaded with salmon. Fall into the 42-degree water and you’ll be dead in minutes. But if you live in a town as tough as Egegik, it’s the lifestyle that’s going to kill you, not the fishing.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Properly Soused
text: There has never been a more charming, erudite, eager, generous and devoted lover of drink  to judge by his writing  than Kingsley Amis, who was also, by his own admission, “frighteningly authoritative.” But too much of a good thing generally leaves one cranky, and reading straight through “Everyday Drinking: The Distilled Kingsley Amis” classifies as a binge. The book is actually a compilation of three books, written first as columns between 1971 and 1984 by the author of “Lucky Jim.” Under no circumstance should it be read in one go. Not even with a pitcher of dry martinis at hand. You’ll do Amis’s work proper justice, as even he suggests, by reading it at the rate of, say, one chapter a night. You may even try reading it out loud at bedtime. Or not.

headline: On Venice’s Grand Canal in a Kayak
text: THEY helped fleeing Romans evade Attila the Hun and held a glittering city aloft for more than 1,500 years. But the wooden pilings rising out of the Grand Canal in Venice are so decayed that as we clung to them one afternoon it wasn’t at all clear whether they would be sturdy enough to prevent us from capsizing into its murky waters.

headline: A Party to Forget
text: A Party to Forget

headline: Roads to Recognition That Were Really Short
text: BROADWAY debuts ain’t what they used to be. Oh, they’re nice and all, but consider this: On each of the four shows nominated for a Tony Award for best musical, at least one major creative player is doing this whole professional theater thing for the first time. Not just Broadway debuts; theater debuts. We’re talking people who have no experience in their field, no years on the regional circuit, no résumé of Off Broadway shows, no Playbill credits that cause an expectant theatergoer to point and whisper: “Ech. I saw that. I can only assume he’s improved.” Like, none (O.K., with a little fudging in places).

headline: Feta Accompli
text: Six kinds of feta cheese are on display in the refrigerator at New Bakaliko, a Greek market in Hicksville, where choosing one is a part of the fun. “Everybody gets a taste so they can decide,” said Chrystalla Miglis.

headline: Venture Capital, Before High Tech
text: THE United States military  credited with spawning the Internet  also helped in the genesis of venture capital. So reveals Spencer E. Ante in “Creative Capital” (Harvard Business School Press, $35), a sometimes slow but ultimately satisfying biography of Georges F. Doriot, the transplanted Frenchman who is often called the father of V.C.

headline: Correction: A Fiery Theology Under Fire
text: An article on May 4 about black liberation theology and the debate surrounding the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr, Senator Barack Obama’s former minister, erroneously confirmed a statement by Mr. Wright that the United States has used biological weapons against other countries. There is no evidence that the United States ever did so.

headline: Comics
text: In 1970, Superman went down a rabbit hole: a secret tunnel on the outskirts of Metropolis leading to a bizarre underground world inhabited by hippies, drop-outs and mutant creatures.

headline: Libertarians Dream of Being the Tie-Breaker
text: So maybe it isn’t very “live and let live” for libertarians to assemble en masse in the hopes of exerting power. But some libertarians, feeling a little heady after their party’s national convention last weekend, are making a bold claim: this is the year their voting bloc will hold some serious sway in American politics.

headline: Letter: Energy Solutions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Big Sur, Calif.: Post Ranch Inn
text: THE BASICS

text: Sarah Megan Thomas, a daughter of Regina O’Brien Thomas and Frank M. Thomas Jr. of Haverford, Pa., was married on Saturday to Jason Steven Donehue, the son of Mary J. Donehue and Alan M. headline: When I Paint My Masterpiece
text: These days the word “artist” is pretty tired. It’s one-size-fits-all like no other word in the English language, maybe apart from “god” and pronouns. It describes Isadora Duncan, Spike Lee, Picasso and Q-Tip, all in a day’s work. And just when it thinks it can take a breather, it has to account for that kid living on the Bowery praying his orgy Polaroids make it into the Whitney and that writer in Starbucks taking trippy liberties with linear structure in a screenplay called “Mama.” Even the man on 42nd Street who believes the world could always use a few more faces of Leonardo DiCaprio in “Titanic” spray-painted onto felt, even he has a claim on the word.

headline: Broadway, Before It Was Their Job

headline: Every Thursday Night, Liberal Politics and Pints

Across the yard, Rachel Maddow, a host on Air America Radio, poured glasses of beer for a table of friends and debated Senator John McCain’s war record.

headline: Cooking
text: It is an immutable truth of the food world, right up there with watched pots never boiling: most cookbooks are failures. You can cook with joy and distraction or follow the instructions to the letter, like a terrified parent responding to a detailed kidnapper’s note. Too often the result is mediocrity, food that just sits there on the plate, undercooked, overcooked, not rich enough, broken or, worse, boring.

headline: Quickly Drawing Attention

headline: At a Soggy Memorial, a New Face in the Lead
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  Mathew Goggin of Tasmania, seeking his first PGA Tour victory, clung tenaciously to the lead after the third round of the Memorial on Saturday. Patiently waiting out a two-and-a-half-hour rain delay and holding off a horde of challengers with a one-under-par 71, Goggin took a three-stroke lead over Kenny Perry, Mike Weir, Justin Rose, Matt Kuchar and Jerry Kelly.

headline: Today’s Landscapes, Tomorrow’s Dystopia
text: There are a lot of ways to depict the landscape. You can faithfully reproduce what you see; you can improvise, painting in an impromptu manner without prior preparation or thought; or you can imagine a fictional space. All of these options are sampled in “Future Tense: Reshaping the Landscape,” the Neuberger Museum of Art’s behemoth of a summer painting show.

headline: Can Anything Replace My Old Reliable Friend?
text: IF you reach me on my cellphone when I’m home, I always ask, “Can I call you back on my landline?” Then we enjoy a crystal-clear connection, and I say to myself, “Nothing matches POTS,” or Plain Old Telephone Service.

headline: Consumers Lean on Rebate Checks for Bills and Gas
text: MIAMI  The federal government is showering households with tax rebates to spur spending and invigorate a troubled economy. But many Americans are so consumed with debt and the soaring price of gasoline that they are opting to save the money or use it to pay bills, according to surveys, sales data and interviews with people from Florida to California.

headline: Mrs. Corbett’s Request
text: The girlfriend of the late Roger Corbett, Eliska Sedlacek, finally phoned me at my office the next morning. But I was on a call. It was yet another case of a desperate middle-aged man. Why is America so full of them? The claimant owned a large boatyard and marina in Pensacola, Fla. This location, it may be remembered, was flattened in 2005 by Hurricane Dennis. In this case the insured, a man named Otto Planck, had filed a complete-loss claim for his $2.238-million, 85-foot sailboat, the Becky’s Best Boy, which, he said, he desperately tried to tow out of harm’s way and failed, resulting in his rescue in a life raft by the Coast Guard and utter destruction of the boat, which he claimed he saw sink with his two own salt-stung eyes. Our local insurance investigator was disturbed by the condition of a piece of the teak hull of the Becky’s Best Boy that was found washed up on a local beach. The piece had been broken outward, against the curvature of the hull, seemingly from a great force, and the investigator also noted that Otto Planck had training as a Navy Seal years earlier. He knew how to blow things up, and he also knew how to survive in extreme conditions. The boat, built in 1923 for a minor British industrialist (and no doubt christened with a more stately name), was valuable but would have been tough to resell, given the extensive restoration it needed.
