text: If Penguins defenseman Brooks Orpik’s third-period body-crunching shift defined Game 3, Red Wings center Henrik Zetterberg’s play during the Pens’ 1 minute 26 second five-on-three man-advantage defined Game 4 — and perhaps this Stanley Cup final.

headline: When a Landlord Won’t Return a Security Deposit
text: I moved into an apartment on a one-year lease. Thirty days before the end of my lease, I gave notice to vacate and requested, in writing, the return of my security deposit and interest.

headline: It’s Where You Live That Matters
text: I have lived in my rent-stabilized two-bedroom apartment in Manhattan for more than 12 years. Recently, title to my mother’s condominium in New Jersey was transferred to my name for estate planning purposes. She resides there and pays me a nominal rent. My apartment in New York is my legal mailing address and is where I actually live. Have I put myself in a situation whereby my landlord could challenge my right to continue to live in my apartment?

headline: A Co-op Superintendent Casts a Lot of Votes
text: The superintendent in our co-op also owns shares and occupies the unit related to those shares.

headline: Secret Vote Totals in a Co-op Election
text: Our co-op recently held a board election. The seven incumbent members were re-elected and two individuals running to become board members were not elected.

headline: Maintenance Fees: How a Co-op Sets Them
text: In our co-op, the tax deductions we get are set on a per-share basis, but the maintenance allocation is not being assessed on a per-share basis. The board is unable to explain this discrepancy. We would like to know if the Internal Revenue Code provides that maintenance for a co-op housing corporation must be based on the share allocation.

headline: Hogwash. Hogwash! HOGWASH!
text: The team at McClatchy, understandably miffed at the hoocoodaonode responses of their colleagues at other news orgs to Scott McClellan’s book, point out that people coodanode — after all, they did:

headline: The Primary in Puerto Rico
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Puerto Rico primary on Sunday, another victory for her over Senator Barack Obama in the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: From Sport of Kings to Sport of Dreamers
text: It was spot-on TV commentator Randy Moss, on ESPN’s Preakness Stakes “Round Table” telecast, who laid open the nasty reality that the tendencies of the modern day thoroughbred owner aren’t as pure as those of yesteryear’s.

headline: Water Polo: Signs of Life From the U.S. Men
text: While the USA Women’s Water Polo team is considered the favorite for gold in Beijing, the men’s team is considered a long shot. But the Americans showed on Saturday with an upset of Croatia, the No. 1-ranked team in the world, that they may be more dangerous than perceived.

headline: Getting the Quote
text: As Twins reliever Juan Rincon headed into pitch the 11th inning Saturday night, the Daily News beat writer Mark Feinsand turned to me in the Metrodome press box and said: “Juan Rincon. The greatest quote of all time.”To those of us who covered Game 4 of the division series in Minneapolis in 2004, this required no explanation.That’s the game where Rincon, then a dominant Twins setup reliever, blew a 5-1 lead in the eighth for Johan Santana.It was 5-2 when Rincon hung a slider that Ruben Sierra sent clattering into the retractable seats above the baggie in right-center for the game-tying three-run homer. The Yankees went on to win, 6-5, and clinch the series, and afterward Rincon, a Venezuelan whose English wasn’t the greatest, said, “Nobody wants to be in my pants right now.”This morning’s news: With the bullpen overworked the last few days, the Yankees summoned Scott Patterson from Scranton/Wilkes-Barre and designated Morgan Ensberg for assignment. Ensberg got the news shortly after he arrived at the Metrodome this morning, and was back out the door within minutes. Patterson is the 28-year-old career minor leaguer who had a surprisingly good spring (0.00 ERA in seven and two-thirds innings over eight appearances) and hung around until the final cuts.

headline: Belmont News: Sunday
text: Tomcito and Spark Candle are no longer being considered for the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Living in Yorkville
text: On the Upper East side of Manhattan, Yorkville's skyline is growing taller, but still beckons newcomers with affordable rents and a vibrant street life.

headline: The Iraq Challenge
text: It turns out that Iraq is not the pivotal campaign issue that it seemed to be less than a year ago. Indeed, the war is no longer the top concern among voters.

headline: Red Wings, Penguins Fly in Under the Radar
text: DETROIT — The Stanley Cup final returned here with — literally — a roar on Sunday. The Red Bull Air Race had taken over downtown Detroit, filling the streets with people and the air with thundering planes.

headline: Filly Third in French Derby
text: Natagora missed making history by a length and a half at Chantilly on Sunday, finishing third in the French Derby behind the undefeated Vision d’Etat and Famous Name. Instead of becoming the first filly to win the Derby in 100 years, she had to settle for being the first to be placed in 50 years. She was the first to even try since 1994.

headline: The Red Wings’ Gift to Hockey
text: We said it here back in December, and even though they still haven’t won the Stanley Cup yet against a Penguins team with enormous potential, we’ll say it again anyway: the Detroit Red Wings are the gold standard for all of hockey.

headline: Classics on the Pier
text: A look at the work of the Chicago Shakespeare Theater.

headline: Norms and Deviations: Who’s to Say?
text: A letter published in the May 26 issue of Time magazine protests the inclusion, in Time’s list of the world’s 100 most influential people, of two researchers allied with the organization Cure Autism Now (a name that speaks for itself). The letter writer declares himself to be “outraged” because, in his view, “Autistic spectrum disorders are not diseases, but rather markers of ‘genetic difference’ in the same vein as skin color [and] gender.” He equates the search for a cure with genocide — it’s “part of a campaign to wipe out ASDs” [autism spectrum disorder] — and he wants the world to know that those to whom the cure would be offered neither need it nor desire it: “I speak for many when I say we are happy the way we are.”A genetic difference is often adaptive and can be regarded as an advance in the evolutionary process; it is well-known that autism sometimes brings with it remarkable powers in the areas of music, art and mathematics. In the 2006 movie “X-Men: The Last Stand,” the augmented powers of those known as “mutants” are even more remarkable and include the ability to walk through walls, to move metal objects as large as California’s Golden Gate Bridge, to auto-generate fire or ice, to be in seven places at the same time, to read minds, to assume any identity, to kill with a touch, to fly like Icarus, to change the weather. These abilities are seen by many “normal” human beings, and a few mutants, as disabilities, as an indication that the person who possesses one of them is a freak.

headline: Clinton’s Balancing Act
text: Once again, we have the incongruous spectacle of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton winning big in a contest while the nomination slips further and further from her reach.

headline: Bolt Commands Attention
text: Usain Bolt of Jamaica set a world record for 100 meters late Saturday, running 9.72 and defeating the reigning world champion in the event, Tyson Gay of the United States, in what was billed as a preview of the Olympic final. About 6,500 fans watched the Reebok Grand Prix at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island. The meet was televised live on ESPN2 and highlights were shown the next afternoon on CBS.

headline: Democratic Primary Fight Is Like No Other, Ever
text: The 2008 Democratic primary battle between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, which concludes Tuesday with contests in Montana and South Dakota, has developed such a reliable story line that pundits can recite it in their sleep.

headline: Do Your Colleagues Really Know You?
text: I spent a lot of time over the past few weeks talking with people about the subject of authenticity at work, first for my print column about Stewart Friedman’s leadership philosophy and then in conversations for my Web column about Lisa Sherman’s experiences in coming out as a lesbian executive.

headline: Welcome to the neighborhood, Brad and Angelina
text: The news wires are buzzing with reports that the media monster known as Brangelina is settling into the south of France. Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie and their rapidly expanding brood have apparently signed a 3-year lease on the 35-bedroom, 880-acre estate known as Chateau Miraval.

headline: Intel’s Chief on Strategy, Globalization and the Price of Oil
text: In a wide-ranging conversation with New York Times editors and reporters Wednesday, Intel’s chief executive, Paul Otellini, explained the grand plan behind the chip maker’s new Atom microprocessor, took a gentlemanly swipe at Apple’s iPhone and called on the next president to commit $25 billion to alternative fuel programs to liberate the economy from imported oil and “reinvigorate math and science” education in America.

headline: Big Brown Doesn’t Need Patch Until Race
text: The hoof specialist Ian McKinlay says that Big Brown, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness champ, does not need a patch on the quarter crack on his left front hoof until the morning of the Belmont Stakes. So the trainer Rick Dutrow will give Big Brown his final hard workout Tuesday without it and gallop him into the race confident the colt’s tender hoof is healed.

headline: Fire Destroys Buildings at NBC Universal Studio Lot
text: A large fire erupted early Sunday at NBC Universal’s studio lot in Universal City, California, “destroying a video vault full of movie and television images and parts of a popular studio tour,” Michael Cieply reports.

headline: The Democrats in Puerto Rico and South Dakota
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won by a wide margin in Puerto Rico, but Senator Barack Obama was already looking toward the general election.

headline: The Movie Awards Must Go On
text: MTV went ahead with the 17th annual “MTV Movie Awards” at the Universal Studios lot on Sunday, “hours after a spectacular blaze destroyed chunks of Hollywood history nearby,” Reuters reports.

headline: NBC Leads Bidding For Weather Channel
text: The New York Times reports: “An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel, as final offers were due Friday night, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: For Annie’s Composer
text: Charles Strouse, the award-winning composer of “Annie,” “Applause” among a dozen other Broadway shows, will turn 80 on Saturday, but the party will last more than one day. Tonight at 6 p.m., the Paley Center for Media (formerly the Museum of Television and Radio) will present “Applause, Applause: A Salute to Charles Strouse,” which will include rarely seen television footage, a piano performance by Mr. Strouse, a panel discussion and a live performance by Lauren Bacall, who starred in the original Broadway production of “Applause.” Tuesday, the new double CD set, “Annie: The 30th Anniversary Cast Recording,” will go on sale, and on Wednesday Mr. Strouse will sign copies at the Virgin Megastore in Times Square starting at 4 p.m. Former cast members featured on the newly recorded disc  including Kathie Lee Gifford, Shelly Burch and Andrea McArdle   will join him and other “Annie” creators. Details of these and other events, including the release of Mr. Strouse’s memoir, “Put On a Happy Face,” are at charlesstrouse.com. ... Original cast recordings for “In the Heights” (Ghostlight) and “Adding Machine” (PS Classics), will also be on sale starting Tuesday.

headline: Repairing New York’s Justice System
text: New York’s justice system has fallen into crisis. Yet Albany is not dealing with three big problems dragging the system down  missing judicial pay raises, glaring deficiencies in indigent defense services and the swelling workload overwhelming Family Court.

headline: Student Loans Start to Bypass 2-Year Colleges
text: Some of the nation’s biggest banks have closed their doors to students at community colleges, for-profit universities and other less competitive institutions, even as they continue to extend federally backed loans to students at the nation’s top universities.

headline: U.S. Deaths in Iraq Fell Sharply in May
text: BAGHDAD  American deaths in the Iraq war dropped to 19 in May, their lowest monthly level since the invasion in 2003, the United States military said Sunday, though officials said they were reluctant to highlight the number as a milestone.

headline: The Humans Behind the Google Money Machine
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  If Google were the United States government, the data that streams onto Nicholas Fox’s laptop every day would be classified as top secret.

headline: With Europeans Dominant, the French Is Open in Name Only
text: PARIS  The French Open has turned, very nearly, into the European Open.

headline: Free for the Summer
text: The official beginning of summer is still a few weeks away, but it really starts on Tuesday at the Hudson River Park as the first event of the summer-long “Take Me to the River” festival begins with a 6:45 p.m. jazz concert on Pier 45 at Christopher Street. The ongoing Tuesday night “Stars of Tomorrow” concert series will kick off with a performance by the Stu Bidwell Duo, from the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music. The festival will also offer movies on Wednesday nights at Pier 54 (at West 14 Street) beginning July 9 with “La Bamba”; movies for children on Friday nights at Pier 46 (at Charles Street) beginning July 11 with “The Wizard of Oz”; as well as other concerts, dances and a blues festival. The schedule is available at hudsonriverpark.org, and the best news is that all events are free. ... The free outdoor Central Park SummerStage series begins its season of concerts, films and other events on June 13. Details are at SummerStage.org.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of one-year and four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: From a Master of Weather, 4 Waterfalls for New York
text: On an unusually cold and rainy spring afternoon, Olafur Eliasson was huddled under a large umbrella in Lower Manhattan gazing down the East River toward Governors Island.

headline: Red Wings’ Success Rooted in Players’ Sense of Family
text: DETROIT  To get to their locker room at Joe Louis Arena, the Red Wings walk through hallways that are painted with the names of players from Detroit’s Stanley Cup-winning teams. In red block letters, the names serve as daily reminders of the franchise’s success.

headline: Some Construction Is Halted After Fatal Crane Collapse
text: The construction of several large buildings in Manhattan is likely to be delayed for days, if not weeks, as city officials determine the safety of the tower cranes being used at those sites, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Sunday.

headline: At a Global Media Company, a Fresh but Less Sexy Approach
text: BERLIN  When Hartmut Ostrowski was an up-and-comer in Bertelsmann’s printing and services division in the 1990s, his bosses were discouraged from speaking at meetings of the top executives.

headline: Financier in Hollywood Strikes Deal in D.W.I.
text: MALIBU, Calif.  It wasn’t exactly “A Perfect Getaway,” as in the title of a coming film backed by the Hollywood financier Ryan Kavanaugh. But last month Mr. Kavanaugh struck a deal under which a judge dismissed two out of three charges stemming from his 2006 arrest for allegedly sideswiping a Los Angeles Police Department cruiser while under the influence of alcohol.

headline: College Alumni Magazines Struggle to Compete With Facebook
text: Most people read their college alumni magazines for the class notes, immediately flipping to the back to see who was married, had a baby or was promoted to an envy-inducing job. The columns tend to be meatiest at this time of year  class reunion season.

headline: What Do You Call a Terror(Jihad)ist?
text: IMAGINE if Franklin D. Roosevelt had taken to calling Adolf Hitler the “leader of the National Socialist Aryan patriots” or dubbed Japanese soldiers fighting in World War II as the “defenders of Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere.”

headline: Fire Destroys Parts of a Popular Movie Lot in California
text: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  A large fire erupted early Sunday at NBC Universal’s studio lot here, destroying a video vault full of movie and television images and parts of a popular studio tour.

headline: U.S. Remakes Jails in Iraq, but Gains Are at Risk
text: BAGHDAD  Once a byword for torture and disgrace, the American-run detention system in Iraq has improved, even its critics say, as the military has incorporated it into a larger counterinsurgency strategy that seeks to avoid mistreatment that could create new enemies.

headline: Industries Allied to Cap Carbon Differ on the Details
text: Some of the most powerful corporate leaders in America have been meeting regularly with leading environmental groups in a conference room in downtown Washington for over two years to work on proposals for a national policy to limit carbon emissions.

headline: Australia Defeats Iraq
text: Harry Kewell scored for Australia to secure a 1-0 win against visiting Iraq and extend the Socceroos’ lead in Asian qualifying for the 2010 World Cup. Iraq was able to play after FIFA, the world governing body, three days ago “temporarily and conditionally” lifted a one-year ban against the country.

headline: What Obama Left Out
text: Commencement speeches are hard.

headline: A Primary Calendar Democrats Will Never Forget
text: WASHINGTON  Howard Dean convened the meeting of his party’s Rules and Bylaws Committee on Saturday with words of congratulation for a measure that will almost certainly be forever identified with his tenure as the chairman of the Democratic National Committee: the calendar of primaries and caucuses.

headline: A Divertimento and a Serenade, Played as in Mozart’s Day
text: It is a testament to the power of live music that even with the amazing sophistication of sound systems and recordings, hosts at weddings and garden parties often still prefer a live ensemble serenading their guests, just as in Mozart’s day.

headline: In Horse Racing, Test of Beefed-Up Champions
text: Regulators and racing authorities are making headway in their efforts to curb the sport’s seemingly insatiable appetite for drugs, but when Big Brown and his rivals compete in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, horse racing will still be in the midst of its steroid era.

headline: Shyamalan’s Hollywood Horror Story, With Twist
text: M. Night Shyamalan says he knows exactly when his relationship with Hollywood started to sour.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 1, 2008

headline: Underdog Taps YouTube to Make Election Close
text: Was Steve Novick the first major YouTube political candidate? O.K., he didn’t quite win the Democratic Senate nomination in Oregon, and there was more to his unusual campaign than YouTube  in fact, most things about it were unusual, starting with the candidate.

headline: Winning Again, Clinton Ponders Continuing Fight
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won another overwhelming victory over Senator Barack Obama on Sunday  this time in Puerto Rico  even as many Democrats, including some of her supporters, suggested it would be best if she dropped her threat to battle on past the end of the primary voting on Tuesday.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager's Death Does Not Halt Suit Against N.F.L. and Players Union
text: ATLANTA  When Kirk Wright was found dead last weekend, suspended from a rope improvised from bedsheets in his jail cell, the book seemed all but complete on a tale of greed and betrayal.

headline: Wine Auction in Hong Kong
text: A wine auction in Hong Kong, run by the American auction house Acker Merrall & Condit, raised more than 64 million Hong Kong dollars (about $8 million) on Saturday, breaking an Asian record for wine auctions and beating a presale estimate of 50 million Hong Kong dollars, Agence France-Presse reported. The hot lot of the day, a case of 1990 Domaine de la Romanée-Conti, went for 1.89 million Hong Kong dollars (about $242,000). The auction was the second major sale in Hong Kong since February, when the government removed duties on imported wines.

headline: Senate Bid Falls Victim to Bruno-Paterson Truce
text: ALBANY  Tim Green is pulling the plug on his plans to run for State Senate.

headline: Deck of Cards Holds Multiple Meanings
text: Basic Assembly’s “Game On” is proof that a dance can be born in the unlikeliest of places, even in a Slovakian hotel courtyard during a card game. The production, seen on Friday at the Chocolate Factory, also takes inspiration from “Open Score,” a 1966 performance piece by Robert Rauschenberg that began with a tennis match.

headline: ‘Sex and the City’ Leads Weekend Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES  “Sex and the City” and its legion of female fans over the weekend gave Hollywood exactly what it needs to survive an uncertain summer movie season: an unconventional hit.

headline: Festival’s 21st Birthday Celebration Blurs Boundaries, Dusk Till Dawn
text: Musical calendar watchers love the seeming portent of anniversaries that end in a zero or a five. But in America, turning 21 is meaningful, too. It’s an age that comes with a certain implied license to go a bit crazy, to take risks, maybe even to lose control for a while. Perhaps that explains what was by all accounts a first for the Bang on a Can Marathon, which began in the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center on Saturday night: a mosh pit.

headline: Twins Lose Their Starter but Still Beat Yanks
text: MINNEAPOLIS  What was the most disconcerting part of Minnesota Twins pitcher Nick Blackburn’s taking a Bobby Abreu line drive to the face Sunday? As Blackburn headed to the clubhouse, pressing a white towel over his bloody mouth and chin, his teammates Justin Morneau and Mike Redmond walked around near the mound looking for teeth.

headline: A Return of That ’70s Show?
text: Which decade is it, anyway?

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about film and theater events in Bryant Park this summer misstated the day of the week for the Broadway in Bryant Park lunchtime concerts. The concerts, from July 10 through Aug. 14, are on Thursdays, not Mondays.

headline: Far From Her Party’s Bitter Feuding, a Breezy Island Weekend for Clinton
text: SAN JUAN, P.R.  While the Democratic Party was flirting with civil war, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spent her weekend in the relative fun and frolic of the Caribbean.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Saturday about attorneys general from 10 states asking the California Supreme Court to stay its decision legalizing same-sex marriages misstated the given name of the governor of New York, who last week ordered state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. He is David A. Paterson, not James.

headline: It’s Time for the U.S. to Ban the Cluster Bombs
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Comforts of Home
text: The Mets’ 6-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium on Sunday night elevated several home-team participants on various levels and, in particular, the man at the top, although he did not care to discuss it much.

headline: In New Sale, Starrett City Would Stay Affordable
text: The owners of Starrett City, a 34-year-old housing complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, have reached an agreement with federal, state and city officials on the sale of the 140-acre enclave under guidelines that would ensure that it remains a haven of housing affordable to working and middle-class families.

headline: Fast Food’s Portion of Parents’ Dollars
text: The average mother of a child under 15 spends more on fast food every year than on books, music, movies and video games combined, according to a report by the NPD Group, a market research firm. NPD surveyed 1,437 mothers through an online panel, asking them about discretionary spending for the youngest child, as well as spending on apparel and footwear.

headline: In Louisiana, Inklings of a New (True) Champion of the Right
text: BATON ROUGE, La.  Religion and fiscal stringency have a friendly home at the state Capitol here, with a conservative, Bobby Jindal, in the governor’s office, a host of straight-arrow novice legislators eager to please him and an honored spot for the Louisiana Family Forum in the old marble halls.

headline: For Riders and Mounts, Rough Going in Prospect Park
text: A mustang named Benny suffered a stone bruise. Dave, a Peruvian Paso, slipped and gouged his ankle. A thoroughbred named Sham, a former show horse, now needs regular hock injections for his stiffening joints.

headline: New Jersey Rivals Wage Bitter Battle Over Age
text: TRENTON  One came of age in the hardscrabble city of Paterson, a self-made millionaire businessman who entered politics late in life. The other grew up in a small working-class town in South Jersey and entered Congress at 32, when he was soon pegged as a future governor or even president.

headline: Democratic Primary Fight Is Like No Other, Ever
text: The 2008 Democratic primary battle between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, which concludes Tuesday with contests in Montana and South Dakota, has developed such a reliable story line that pundits can recite it in their sleep.

headline: Taliban Leader Flaunts Power Inside Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  With great fanfare, the Pakistani Army flew journalists to a rugged corner of the nation’s lawless tribal areas in May to show how decisively it had destroyed the lairs of the Taliban, including a school for suicide bombers, in fighting early this year.

headline: Yves Saint Laurent, Giant of Couture, Dies at 71
text: Yves Saint Laurent, who exploded on the fashion scene in 1958 as the boy-wonder successor to Christian Dior and endured as one of the best-known and most influential couturiers of the second half of the 20th century, died on Sunday at his apartment in Paris. He was 71.

headline: Doubts Rise as 100-Meter Record Falls
text: When Usain Bolt of Jamaica set a world record of 9.72 seconds at 100 meters Saturday night, two questions became urgent:

headline: Violence Erupts in Macedonian Election
text: PARIS  Macedonia’s aspirations to join the European Union and NATO suffered a heavy blow on Sunday when violence and allegations of fraud marred parliamentary elections.

headline: Church Back in Lineup With a Smile
text: At first, Ryan Church played coy. Would he be back in the Mets’ lineup against the Dodgers on Sunday night after not starting since May 20 because of a concussion?

headline: 3 Czech Friends, Cast as Heroes and as Murderers
text: PRAGUE  To some Czechs, it was the greatest escape of the cold war.

headline: In Harlem, the Governor’s Support of Same-Sex Marriage Gets a Mixed Reaction
text: The news not only caught Edwin Perez off guard, it turned his stomach.

headline: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Conduct Indefinable: Beethoven Here, Laura Nyro There
text: New York is awash in freelance orchestras. But as young players pour out of conservatories, new ensembles continue to crop up, and the savviest of them have grasped the need to cultivate a distinctive image. The Knights, a young, energetic chamber orchestra formed by the cellist and conductor Eric Jacobsen and his brother, the violinist Colin Jacobsen, has been turning up with increasing frequency since 2006, as both a standard repertory ensemble and a new-music band.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Jacob Robbins, 85, Thyroid Researcher, Is Dead
text: Dr. Jacob Robbins, whose studies of the thyroid gland at the National Institutes of Health helped explain how it helps govern metabolism and how thyroid cancers caused by radiation may be treated or possibly prevented, died on May 12 in Bethesda, Md. He was 85.

headline: The World Is Upside Down
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Parents of Quake Victims Protest at Ruined Schools
text: BEIJING  It is meant to be a celebration of childhood, but in Sichuan Province on Sunday, Children’s Day turned into a day of mourning, and a provocation to parents whose children were crushed to death by falling school buildings during the powerful earthquake three weeks ago.

headline: Increased Flow of Council Grants to Private Groups Leads to a Backlog
text: An Orthodox Jewish school in Queens was to get $500,000 for a swimming pool. A social service agency in Queens plagued by financial mismanagement was set to receive $100,000 for a shelter and a van.

headline: Getting Emotional Over Luxury Beds
text: A company that has long sold its pricey wares on the basis of functional features is changing course in a new image-oriented campaign that celebrates the products as fashionable luxury goods.

headline: Relax, That Shot Is Easy
text: Don’t you hate the feeling of gloom when you face a finesse shot? Most golfers know this pressure situation  and the dismal thoughts that go with it. Butch Harmon, a teacher of many of the world’s top golfers and regular players, too, said the typical golfer faced with hitting a short, lobbed shot over a bunker should be thinking about how easy it is.

headline: Transracial Adoptions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Program Averages 4.3 Million Viewers
text: CBS’s broadcast of the Elite XC mixed martial arts program Saturday night  the first on a broadcast network in prime time  generated a preliminary national rating of a 2.7, or an average of 4.3 million viewers. The viewership fell from the 5.9 million CBS generated this season for the crime series that usually run Saturday nights on the network. But the national rating covered the 9 to 11 p.m. Eastern time period and did not include the main event, won by Kimbo Slice over James Thompson. In Nielsen Media’s 54 metered markets, the rating peaked at a 4.7 from 11:30 to 11:45, when Slice fought.

headline: It’s Raining Rupiah
text: Tung Desem Waringin, an Indonesian author and motivational speaker, took an unusual approach to publicize his new book on Sunday, above, when he threw money from a plane as he circled repeatedly over a soccer field in Serang, 45 miles west of the Indonesian capital, Jakarta. On the ground, hundreds of people scrambled excitedly for the 100 million rupiah (about $10,700) that showered down, Reuters reported. His initial hope had been to fly over Jakarta, but police denied permission amid concerns that large crowds would gather and chaos might ensue in a country where millions live on the equivalent of less than $2 a day. This was not the first time that this author, 42, has pulled an odd publicity stunt: he pushed his first book, “Financial Revolution,” by riding through Jakarta on a white horse. The book became a best seller in 2005. His new book is, appropriately, titled “Marketing Revolution.”

headline: Grooming Tomorrow’s Orchestras and Stars
text: One promising sign for the future of classical music is the number of children still willing to dedicate hours after school and on weekends to practice and rehearsals, thereby providing ample talent for the nation’s conservatories.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture caption on Friday with an art review of exhibitions of sculpture by Anish Kapoor at a museum in Boston and at two galleries in Manhattan misstated the name of the museum. As the review noted, it is the Institute of Contemporary Art, not the Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Philadelphia Theater Company has announced a one-week extension of “The Happiness Lecture,” created and performed by the Tony Award-winning actor and clown Bill Irwin (“Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf”), along with an ensemble of eight actors and dancers. Tickets and information about the show, which will close after the Sunday matinee on June 22, are available at philadelphiatheatrecompany.org. ... The New York City Gay Men’s Chorus (nycgmc.com) will perform twice this week, Wednesday and Thursday at 8 p.m. at the Haft Auditorium at the Fashion Institute of Technology, where it will present “Vibrate,” an evening of contemporary song. ... The original cast and director of the LAByrinth Theater Company’s 2000 production of “Jesus Hopped the A Train,” by Stephen Adly Guirgis, will be reunited for a benefit reading of the play at Town Hall (123 West 43rd Street) on June 22 at 7 p.m. Philip Seymour Hoffman will direct. ... A lineup of a dozen artists whose combined sales top 80 million records are appearing together as “The Ultimate Doo-Wop Show,” and will perform Saturday night at the Beacon Theater (beacontheatrenyc.com). Among the featured groups are Johnny Maestro & the Brooklyn Bridge (“Sixteen Candles”), the Drifters featuring Charlie Thomas (“This Magic Moment”) and Jay Siegel & the Tokens (“The Lion Sleeps Tonight”). ... The Tony Award-winning musical “Avenue Q” will play performance No. 2,000 at the Golden Theater Tuesday night. It opened there on July 31, 2003.

headline: Electronic Device Stirs Unease at Book Fair
text: LOS ANGELES  Is the electronic book approaching the tipping point?

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A dance review on Thursday about “The ’80s and ’90s on Screen,” part of the Somewhere Out There spring festival presented by Movement Research, using information in the program, misstated the title of a 1984 solo by Ishmael Houston-Jones that was shown. It is “f/i/s/s/i/o/n/i/n/g” not “f/i/s/s/i/o/n/i/n/8.”

headline: Walter H. Diamond, Expert on Taxation, Is Dead at 95
text: Walter H. Diamond, an expert on international taxation, trade and economics who advised world leaders and wrote more than 80 books, died on May 23 in White Plains. He was 95 and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

headline: Clinton Wins Puerto Rico, but Her Fate Is Still Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Puerto Rico primary by a huge margin on Sunday, another victory for her over Senator Barack Obama in the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination. Still, after an explosive weekend in Democratic presidential politics, the big drama now facing the party remains how, when  and even if  she departs from the race.

headline: Survivors of the Pacific War
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Latecomer to the Bidding Finds Success, With Help
text: The trial to pick the United States open team for the first World Mind Sports Games in Beijing in October is taking place in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Monday will see the completion of the 120-board quarterfinals, which began on Sunday.

headline: A Battered Feeling at Obama’s Former Church
text: CHICAGO  For weeks, the members of Trinity United Church of Christ on the South Side of the city felt battered by the national spotlight that had accompanied the growing fame of their longtime member, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: The Week’s Major Economic Reports
text: BY THE NUMBERS The main economic news of the week will be the unemployment report on Friday, which is expected to show that May was the nation’s fifth consecutive month of job losses. Other reports include the I.S.M. manufacturing index for May, due out Monday morning, and factory orders for April on Tuesday.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Anne Adriance joined Guideposts magazine, part of Guideposts, Carmel, N.Y., as vice president for consumer marketing, a new post. She had most recently been a senior executive and principal at the BurnsGroup, New York.

headline: Is the Main Character Missing? Maybe Not.
text: When Dan Walsh, a 33-year-old technology manager in Dublin, started posting doctored versions of the comic strip “Garfield” on his blog in February, he thought he might amuse a few friends.

headline: Mr. Rove Talks, but Doesn’t Answer
text: In a recent appearance on “This Week With George Stephanopoulos,” Karl Rove was asked if he had a role in the Justice Department’s decision to prosecute Don Siegelman. The former Democratic governor of Alabama was convicted and sentenced to more than seven years, quite possibly for political reasons, and there is evidence that Mr. Rove may have been pulling the strings.

headline: When Intolerance Becomes Intolerable
text: Correction Appended

headline: Shooting for Ryder Cup, Perry Charges to Victory at Memorial
text: DUBLIN, Ohio  With a shifting wind gusting, with the big, loud galleries shouting at him between the walks from tees to greens at Muirfield Village Golf Club  “Go Big Blue!” “Ryder Cup!” “Go Kenny!”  Kenny Perry put on the blinders and ran the race.

headline: 2 Opposition Leaders Arrested in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  In the latest move against the Zimbabwean opposition in advance of runoff elections on June 27, the police arrested two prominent politicians on Sunday in their homes, opposition officials said.

headline: It Might Be, It Could Be, It Is ... Only June
text: In the short space of six years, three absolutely wonderful things have happened in baseball: the Angels, the Red Sox and the White Sox have all outlasted decades of gloom and futility to win the World Series.

headline: Corrections
text: National

headline: Life in the Boroughs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oprah Is Everywhere
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study Groups: Eat Your Veggies!
text: To the Editor:

headline: A $10 Mosquito Net Is Making Charity Cool
text: Donating $10 to buy a mosquito net to save an African child from malaria has become a hip way to show you care, especially for teenagers. The movement is like a modern version of the March of Dimes, created in 1938 to defeat polio, or like collecting pennies for Unicef on Halloween.

headline: Shuttle Discovery Docks at Space Station
text: The crews of the shuttle Discovery and the International Space Station got together while orbiting over the South Pacific on Monday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about the growth of women’s wrestling at small, private institutions referred imprecisely to the location of Menlo College, which has had a team since 2001. It is in Atherton, Calif., in the San Francisco Bay Area  not in San Francisco.

headline: Lead Singer Back in the Fold, Not Back From the Edge
text: HOLMDEL, N.J.  Scott Weiland, the lead singer of Stone Temple Pilots, had just a few words for the crowd at the PNC Bank Arts Center on Saturday night, and that was probably a good thing. Two weeks into this post-grunge band’s reunion tour, he seemed bedraggled and bushed, like a scarecrow. His first comments were barely coherent, and what came next was dispiriting. “Sometimes you make crazy choices,” he said, in a distinctly undefiant tone.

headline: A Little Something for Dad’s Bookshelf
text: Father’s Day is less than two weeks away, and a golf book is a popular gift, especially if you know a father who loves the game or wishes he could play more (it’s sometimes easier to find time to read). There is never a shortage in this category, but I have been happy to review some that were entertaining or informative, if not both:

headline: Hezbollah Hands Over Purported Israeli Remains
text: JERUSALEM  Hezbollah handed over to Israel on Sunday what it said were the remains of Israeli soldiers killed in the 2006 war in Lebanon. The move was seen in Israel as a gesture of good will and a possible prelude to a prisoner swap involving two Israeli soldiers whose capture by Hezbollah set off the monthlong war.

headline: They Walk the Line (Between Formalism and Anarchy)
text: In the White Stripes, Jack White plays truant officer and truant, setting up mock aesthetic rules about rock purity like a formalist, then subverting them with spastic energy. In the Raconteurs, he works in a double singer-songwriter front line with an actual rock formalist, Brendan Benson. In the more Benson-like of the Raconteurs’ songs, studied homages to 1970s album-oriented rock, Mr. White can use the context to be as truant as he wants, setting himself loose in places where in the White Stripes he would rein himself in.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions last Monday about the consecration of the first major Hindu temple on Staten Island misidentified the geographical region that is the home of Rajiv S. Gowda, a City Council candidate from Staten Island who called the temple “a true blessing for our community.” Mr. Gowda’s home country, India, is in South Asia  not Southeast Asia.

headline: ImClone Says Its Cancer Drug Works as Initial Treatment
text: CHICAGO  Two biotechnology giants did battle here at the nation’s largest cancer conference over the weekend. And both remained standing.

headline: Clothing Designers Honor ... Bloomberg?
text: Several times a year, a king-size Chevrolet Suburban stops on Madison Avenue at 45th Street, depositing Michael R. Bloomberg for 30 minutes of power shopping.

headline: Still Holding on to the Feeling: Journey in 2008
text: JOURNEY “Revelation” (Nomota)

headline: Gates Accuses Myanmar of ‘Criminal Neglect’
text: BANGKOK  In the strongest remarks yet by a high-ranking American official, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Sunday that Myanmar was guilty of “criminal neglect” for blocking large-scale international aid to cyclone victims, and that more Burmese civilians would perish unless the military regime reversed its policy.

headline: A Bear Stearns Refugee Gets a New Start at Merrill
text: As a vice chairman and longtime stockholder of Bear Stearns, Fares D. Noujaim suffered an emotional and financial blow when the investment bank imploded.

headline: Favorite Does Not Need Patch Until Race
text: The hoof specialist Ian McKinlay says that Big Brown, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness champ, does not need a patch on the quarter crack on his left front hoof until the morning of the Belmont Stakes. So the trainer Rick Dutrow will give Big Brown his final hard workout Tuesday without it and gallop him into the race confident the tender hoof is healed.

headline: Tough Guy at the Border of Hope and Despair
text: Leaves turn. Snow falls. Robins tweet. And a new Jack Reacher novel arrives as the year’s first red-hot beach book. Truly, this is how some of us keep track of the seasons.

headline: Oliver Has His Nancy
text: After 12 weeks of competition, the future London production of “Oliver!” has found its Nancy. Jodie Prenger, 28, won Britain’s “I’d Do Anything” television talent contest on Saturday night, beating first the runner up, Jessie Buckley, 18, in a decision determined by public call-in voting, the BBC and The Daily Mail reported. For Ms. Prenger, right, of Blackpool, this is the second television competition victory in two years: she also won the British version of “The Biggest Loser” in 2006. “Oliver!,” to be produced by Cameron Mackintosh, also found its title character  or rather characters  on “I’d Do Anything.” Three young actors, Harry Stott, 12, and Gwion Jones and Laurence Jeffcoate, both 11, will rotate in the title role. Rowan Atkinson will star as Fagin. The show will be directed by Rupert Goold, currently represented on Broadway by “Macbeth,” with Matthew Bourne (“Mary Poppins”) as co-director and choreographer. Previews begin on Dec. 12 for a Jan. 14 opening.

headline: In at the Birth of Death
text: From the human perspective, the universe is not a very sudden place. What is going on in the heavens has been going on for a good long time. The sudden events  like the death of a star in an explosion called a supernova  are usually detected well after they begin, and, of course, millions of years after they actually occurred, given the great distances their light has to travel.

headline: At His Door, Officer Kills Armed Man
text: An off-duty police officer fatally shot a man who pulled a gun on the officer’s wife and 3-year-old daughter outside the door of their Bronx apartment, the police said on Sunday.

headline: Dances With Song, Woodwind and Water
text: The last place you might expect to see a new ballet is at La MaMa, a theater that is virtually a synonym for all things avant-garde. Of course, there is no rule that a new ballet can’t be avant-garde; it just almost never is. And sadly, it wasn’t on Thursday night, when Christopher Caines presented “Exquisite Hour” as part of “An Evening of Dance Works,” the final program, in the Annex, of the “La MaMa Moves!” dance festival.

headline: Indian Media Giant Buys Virgin Radio From Scottish Firm
text: NEW DELHI  An Indian media conglomerate that owns The Times of India, the world’s largest-circulation English newspaper, has agreed to buy Virgin Radio Holdings for £53.2 million ($105 million) in its first foreign acquisition.

headline: The Childhood Obesity Numbers
text: It is a sad commentary on the health of American youngsters that we are cheering a leveling off of childhood obesity rates. Far too many children and teenagers are still overweight.

headline: Gauging Fallout From Rules Committee’s Decisions
text: There’s some follow-up news to the Democratic Party’s rules committee’s decisions over the weekend.

headline: An Open Seat in California? That’s Just the Start
text: AUBURN, Calif.  While most Congressional races are known for incumbency comfort, a nasty battle over the seat held since 1993 by John T. Doolittle  a Republican who decided not to seek re-election after coming under fire over his ties to a convicted lobbyist  has shaken up this reliably conservative spot on the California map.

headline: Swiss Voters Reject Secret Ballots on Citizenship
text: ZURICH  Swiss voters on Sunday defeated a measure that would have legitimized the practice of allowing secret votes by townspeople on granting citizenship to foreigners in their communities.

headline: Hollywood Helps Out
text: The seventh annual Butterfly Ball in Los Angeles on Saturday night brought together celebrities including Demi Moore, Ashton Kutcher, cast members from “Grey’s Anatomy” and others for a fund-raising evening to support Chrysalis, a Los Angeles-based nonprofit organization, The Associated Press reported. The charity, which helps the homeless and others find work, reportedly raised over $1 million at the event. Also appearing on the red carpet (though they did not stay for the ball) were the “Two and a Half Men” star Charlie Sheen and his new wife, Brooke Mueller, a real estate developer. The couple met at the Butterfly Ball in 2006 and were married on Friday night.

headline: Our Crowded Planet
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Network to Make an Environmental Point
text: CAN the environment make for entertaining TV? Discovery Communications is about to find out.

headline: State Dept. Reinstates Gaza Fulbright Grants
text: JERUSALEM  The American State Department has reinstated seven Fulbright grants offered to Palestinians in Gaza for advanced study in the United States, reversing a decision to withdraw the scholarships because of Israel’s ban on Palestinians’ leaving Gaza for study abroad.

headline: A Drier, Greener Footprint
text: To the Editor:

headline: In the Middle of Nowhere, a Nation’s Center
text: BUTTE COUNTY, S.D.

headline: Slumber Parties Go Digital
text: In the gender wars, men generally win the race to the bottom. This past week though, women were the ones who seemed completely preoccupied by the reproductive act: a cultish cable series that gave birth to a movie.

headline: Louise Firouz, Horse Breeder, Dies at 74
text: Louise Firouz, an American-born horse breeder who while roaming a mountain range in Iran in 1965 discovered a pony-size Caspian horse, from a breed that had long been thought extinct, died on May 25. Caspian horses were found to be a precursor of modern racehorses.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article last Monday about the problems of Argentina’s first elected female president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, in her first five months in office misidentified a political job once held by Alfonso Prat-Gay, a former central bank chief who criticized her tax increases on agricultural products. He was the economic adviser to Elisa Carrió, the opposition candidate defeated by Mrs. Kirchner in last year’s election; he was not Mrs. Carrió’s running mate. (Her running mate was Rubén Giustiniani, a senator.)

headline: Just Do It All
text: When I was a kid, I had a neighborhood friend, Benny, who played a lot of golf. He attended golf clinics, and his parents wanted him to become the next Jack Nicklaus.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 88 Buffalo
text: Location: Amherst, N.Y.

headline: Test of Beefed-Up Champions
text: Regulators and racing authorities are making headway in their efforts to curb the sport’s seemingly insatiable appetite for drugs, Bill Finley writes in Monday’s Times, but when Big Brown and his rivals compete in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, horse racing will still be in the midst of its steroid era.

headline: Talk to the Newsroom: News Editor Paul Winfield
text: Paul Winfield, news editor of The New York Times, answered questions June 2-6, 2008.

headline: No Slave to Fashion
text: It is safe to say that when the Council of Fashion Designers of America gives Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg its annual award, it will not be for his groundbreaking clothing selections.

headline: Wages and inflation
text: The story in today’s column about the United Mine Workers comes from an old paper by John Taylor, Union wage settlements during a disinflation. What I really like about that paper is the concreteness: economists often talk about how expectations of inflation get embedded in price- and wage-setting, but don’t offer direct evidence that this is happening. Taylor, however, had the goods: you can actually see the wage settlements, and you can even see the difference between settlements with and without escalator clauses.

headline: Europe, off the rails
text: Yesterday I took the high-speed train from Barcelona to Madrid (yeth, I’m now in Cathtile). It was terrific, and fed my usual American train envy.

headline: The Lobbying War Over Carbon Controls
text: The U.S. Senate is debating the sort of system to put in place to curb carbon dioxide emissions from leading industries — and the lobbying war is ferocious.

headline: ‘Faithful ‘Til the End’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Weegee Found
text: A trunk bought by two Indiana women contained 210 vintage prints by the photographer.
From The Onion:

headline: India’s Sterlite Buys Bankrupt Miner Asarco
text: India’s Sterlite Industries on Saturday agreed to buy the operating assets of bankrupt copper miner Asarco for $2.6 billion, the latest in the series of overseas acquisitions by Indian firms.

headline: Venture Capital, Before High Tech
text: The United States military – credited with spawning the Internet – also helped in the genesis of venture capital.

headline: Silverjet Ceases Operations as Funding Falls Through
text: Silverjet on Friday became the third business-class-only airline in just six months to cease operations, unable to cope with rising fuel costs or attract new financing.

headline: China Telecom Buys Wireless Network for $14 Billion
text: China Telecom and its state parent will pay more than $14 billion to buy a wireless network owned by the China Unicom group, entering a lucrative mobile arena in the first deal reached under Beijing’s sweeping overhaul of the world’s largest telecommunications industry, according to a report.

headline: Indian Media Giant Buys Virgin Radio From Scottish Firm
text: An Indian media conglomerate that owns The Times of India, the world’s largest-circulation English newspaper, has agreed to buy Virgin Radio Holdings for 53.2 million pounds ($105 million) in its first foreign acquisition.

headline: KSL Partners Said to Be Among Esporta Bidders
text: KSL Capital Partners, a U.S. buyout firm that counts golf-course operator Clubcorp among its investments, is one of half a dozen suitors to have submitted initial offers for British fitness club chain Esporta last week, The Times of London reported.

headline: Nymex Delays Meeting Over CME Bid
text: The New York Mercantile Exchange has pushed back a meeting with members unhappy over the terms of a $9 billion merger with the CME Group.

headline: Australia’s Centro Wins Reprieve on $2.6 Billion of Loans
text: Centro Properties Group, one of Australia’s biggest casualties of the global credit crunch, won more time to repay about 2.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.67 billion) in debt, sparking a rally in its shares on Monday.

headline: Stores of Bankrupt Sharper Image to Be Liquidated
text: All remaining stores of bankrupt gadget retailer Sharper Image will be closed and liquidated, its new owners said on Sunday.

headline: The Stalking of Sourcefire
text: Sourcefire, a network security company, has had a rough go of it on the Nasdaq since going public in March. Now, private-equity-backed Barracuda wants to end its run.

headline: Rodney Harrison on David Tyree’s Supernatural
text: Can we call it nostalgia if it’s only four months old?

headline: Origin Says It Will Still Talk With Spurned BG
text: Origin Energy, Australia’s biggest producer of gas from coal seams, said Sunday that it remained open to further talks with BG Group after rejecting its sweetened 13.6 billion Australian dollar ($13 billion) takeover offer last week.

headline: Goldman Said to Name Co-Heads of Asia Investment Banking Group
text: Goldman Sachs on Monday announced two new co-heads to its investment banking group for Asia excluding Japan, highlighting a shifting of talent by Western banks to Asia.

headline: After Financier’s Death, Suit Against Union Lives On
text: When Kirk Wright was found dead last weekend, suspended from a rope improvised from bedsheets in his jail cell, the book seemed all but complete on a tale of greed and betrayal.

headline: Banking Group Won’t Overhaul Way Libor Is Set
text: The group that oversees the London interbank offered rate will implement no changes in the way it is set, confounding critics who said the rate, known as Libor, had become unreliable as a gauge of the cost of borrowing.

headline: 10 Years for Ex-Banker Convicted of Insider Trading
text: A former Credit Suisse investment banker convicted of insider trading was sentenced to 10 years in prison by a judge who said Wall Street professionals were failing to understand that it was a serious crime to cheat in the markets.

headline: NBC Leads $3.5 Billion Bid for Weather Channel
text: An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel, as final offers were due Friday night, The New York Times reported.

headline: Hunting Safaricom’s I.P.O.
text: On June 9, shares in Kenyan mobile service provider Safaricom will begin trading on the Nairobi Stock Exchange, in the biggest initial public offering ever in sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: Germany to Sell Deutsche Bahn Stake
text: Ending years of wrangling, the German Parliament on Friday voted to sell a stake in Deutsche Bahn, the former state railroad monopoly that is now a logistics company.

headline: Société Générale Replaces Investment Banking Chief
text: Société Générale announced Friday that it would replace its head of investment banking, Jean-Pierre Mustier, in the latest effort to restore a reputation badly bruised by a massive trading scandal.

headline: With Shell Deal, Arrow Shelves I.P.O. Plans
text: Arrow Energy said it no longer needs to spin off its overseas coal seam gas operations now that it has reached a deal for an investment from Royal Dutch Shell.

headline: Disney and Pixar: The Power of the Prenup
text: When the Walt Disney Company bought its rival, Pixar, in 2006 for $7.4 billion, many people assumed the deal would play out like most big media takeovers: abysmally.

headline: First Comes the Swap. Then It’s the Knives.
text: Investors don’t often get a peek inside the vast, opaque and unregulated world of credit default swaps, those privately traded insurance contracts that essentially allow participants to bet on or against a debt issuer’s financial condition. (Remember, these are the same instruments that played such a pivotal role in the collapse of Bear Stearns.)

headline: Alstom Denies Report of Talks With Rolls-Royce
text: French engineering group Alstom on Monday denied a newspaper report it was mulling a tie-up with British aero engine and turbines group Rolls-Royce.

headline: Former Yahoo Chief Said to Eye Forstmann’s IMG
text: Former Yahoo and Warner Bros. Entertainment chief, Terry Semel, plans to make a run at acquiring private-equity investor Teddy Forstmann’s IMG marketing and talent agency, The New York Post reported.

headline: Cuomo to Argue for Charges in Grasso Suit
text: New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo will get his last chance Tuesday to have four key charges reinstated to the blockbuster lawsuit against former New York Stock Exchange chieftain Richard Grasso.

headline: Investors Sue Hedge Fund Over Redemptions
text: Angry investors in an embattled $650 million Greenwich, Conn. hedge fund sued last week to take control of the fund from Philip and Alan Milton, the brother investment team that had steered the fund through many years of fat returns before it hit trouble in 2007.

headline: Delphi Creditors Team Up Against Appaloosa
text: Appaloosa Management is getting hit from multiple angles in its attempt to walk away from the deal they struck with auto parts maker Delphi. Appaloosa, a hedge-fund firm, is not only being sued by Delphi, but now creditors of Delphi are seeking to intervene on the case, HedgeCo.Net reports.

headline: A Bear Stearns Refugee Gets a New Start at Merrill
text: As a vice chairman and longtime stockholder of Bear Stearns, Fares D. Noujaim suffered an emotional and financial blow when the investment bank imploded.

headline: Thompson Is Ousted as Wachovia Chief Executive
text: G. Kennedy Thompson, the head of Wachovia, on Monday became the latest banking executive to be shown the door during the credit squeeze, as Wachovia‘s board requested that he step down amid a stock slide and a series of losses.

headline: Congress Returns to Face Climate Bill
text: Congress is coming back in session and is worried about the climate – and for once it isn’t strictly the political kind that has captured the attention of lawmakers.

headline: Cerberus Sold Big GMAC and Chrysler Stakes, Report Says
text: Cerberus Capital Management is hardly the only one feeling the pain from the troubles at Chrysler and GMAC. According to a report in The Financial Times, the buyout firm sold “significantly” more than half its equity in those two businesses shortly after winning control of them.

headline: TPG Invests in Troubled British Lender
text: TPG has agreed to take a 23 percent stake in Bradford & Bingley, the troubled British mortgage lender, for 179 million pounds ($353 million). Bradford & Bingley also said Monday that it slashed the price of a proposed rights offerings; its stock plunged as much as 32 percent.

headline: Answers From Iraqi Women
text: Video

headline: A Familiar End to Prior’s Season
text: Another year, another season-ending injury for Mark Prior.

headline: The Early Word: A Week To Remember
text: The first week of June 2008 may be one for the history books, either because it could be when Senator Barack Obama all but wraps up the Democratic presidential nomination after Tuesday’s primaries in Montana and South Dakota, or, when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton decides to make a game-changing decision — to continue fighting for a while longer.

headline: Spanish market dips; U.K. continues to slide; More gloomy news from global markets
text: Headlines from the international property business:

headline: Deal Reached to Keep Starrett City Affordable
text: Federal, state and city officials have reached an agreement with the owners of Starrett City, a 34-year-old housing complex on Jamaica Bay in Brooklyn, that would allow the sale of the 140-acre, 5,881-unit enclave under guidelines while ensuring that it remains a haven of housing affordable to working-class and middle-class families, Charles V. Bagli reports.

headline: Fashion’s Yves
text: The morning news shows carried Saint Laurent’s death—last night in his Left Bank apartment around 11:10—and I was surprised to hear a news reader say he was the last of a generation of couturiers that included Coco Chanel and Christian Dior. Chanel was born in 1883, Dior in 1905. At his death, Saint Laurent was 71: do the math.

headline: The Lure of Content
text: Content, still king: “People are just beginning to realize that Google has redefined the media business by adding an entirely new format – software,” writes Fred Vogelstein, a contributing editor at Wired, on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. He adds:

headline: Promoting Planet Green
text: Can the environment make for entertaining TV? Discovery Communications is about to find out.

headline: And Down the Stretch, It’s Red Smith!
text: We at The Rail could not have planned it any better — six days to the 140th running of the Belmont Stakes and Big Brown, an undefeated colt, is running with a chance to become only the 12th Triple Crown champion.

headline: In AIPAC Speech, McCain Hits Obama on Iran, Iraq
text: WASHINGTON – Senator John McCain of Arizona used a speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the pro-Israel lobby, to lambaste Senator Barack Obama on two fronts: he charged that Mr. Obama’s calls for diplomacy with Iran were misguided and insufficient, and that his proposal to begin withdrawing United States troops from Iraq would lead to chaos in the region and endanger Israel.

headline: As Local as it Gets
text: Everybody, it seems, wants to eat local food these days. They may want better tasting produce or they may want to cut their carbon footprint down to the size of a starry-nosed mole’s, but one way or another they’re trying to cut down on the distance food travels from farm to mouth.

headline: This Land: Where the Grass Meets the Sky
text: In 1959, when the center of the nation was declared to be in Butte County, S.D., local officials envisioned a tourist haven. But plans have since dried up.

headline: WaMu Separates Chairman, Chief Executive Titles
text: Washington Mutual said on Monday that it would strip its chief executive, Kerry E. Killinger, of his chairman title as part of a shakeup at the nation’s largest savings and loan as it struggles to overcome steep mortgage-related losses.

headline: Another CEO Gone
text: Give Wachovia’s board credit for honesty. The board fired Ken Thompson, who had been chief executive since 2001, and did not mince words in explaining why he was leaving.

headline: Prince’s Late Night at Book Expo
text: The editors with the bleariest eyes on Saturday morning at Book Expo America, the annual publishing confab in Los Angeles, were probably employees of Simon & Schuster. Its Atria Books division, which is publishing “21 Nights,” a multi-media volume documenting the musician Prince’s three-week concert series at London’s O2 arena in 2007, publicized the upcoming title by sponsoring a late-night soiree at Prince’s estate high in the Hollywood hills.

headline: The End of the Embargo?
text: When a book — even one that is expected to be a best-seller, like Scott McClellan’s poison-pen account of his years in the White House press office — becomes an unexpected, early hit, it can throw a publisher’s marketing and distribution plans into disarray, something that is both a blessing and a curse for the publisher.

headline: Tourmalet, The Unavoidable
text: 34 Days to L’Étape. Today is a day off after two long, hilly rides north of the city on Saturday (60 miles) and Sunday (70 miles). Rode alone on Saturday, across the George Washington Bridge and up, in pouring rain, what local cyclists call River Road, which includes a 1.5 mile climb up a 7% grade hill near Alpine, N.J. Rode with a former local racer on Sunday, along a variation of the popular GWB to Nyack route, but with added climbs, including one known as “the wall,” which is a third of a mile up a 12.1% hill.

headline: Rethinking the Paperback Timeline
text: With the publishing industry’s annual convention, Book Expo America, taking place within sight of the Hollywood sign, it is a natural question to wonder how the distribution practices of the two media universes differ.

headline: CBS, CNET and the Perils of Mergers
text: Is CBS Chief Executive Leslie Moonves making a big mistake?

headline: Just Browsing | Y.S.L., R.I.P.
text: Saint Laurent in 1985 (AP).

headline: Does M&A Pay?
text: James Surowiecki doesn’t seem to like mergers and acquisitions. In his latest column for The New Yorker, he asserts: “In fact, corporate marriages only rarely end in bliss-many studies have found that most mergers and acquisitions do little for the acquiring company’s bottom line.”

headline: Loeb Wins Fifth, Takes Over WRC Lead
text: The weekend’s results in racing and more…

headline: Cancer Emotions: Upbeat, Stoic or Just Scared?
text: Years ago, a friend and co-worker of mine with ovarian cancer lost all of her blonde hair during treatment. She donned a red wig and declared, “I’m going to do cancer as a redhead!”

headline: Can We Build a Better Crane?
text: The construction crane has seen many incarnations over the 2,500 years that men have employed the machines. Beasts of burden are no longer needed to power them. Winches and pulley systems became ever more elaborate. Steel replaced wood at the onset of the industrial revolution, allowing for ever greater loads to be lifted.

headline: When Money Falls From the Sky
text: Stories about money falling from the sky usually feature lame clip-art or reassurances that “all you need is a dollar and a dream.” From time to time, however, it happens for real, as was the case in Serang, Indonesia, over the weekend.

headline: London Guzzles Before Alcohol Measures
text: BRIEFS As promised, London instituted a ban on drinking in the subway on Sunday, but not before one last booze on the Tube, as one British paper put it. As photographs of guzzling young men and women surfaced, so did news stories of a new government push to curb underage binge drinking.

headline: The Least Surprising News in Soccer
text: Before we get completely wrapped up in Euro 2008, which begins Saturday when co-host Switzerland faces the Czech Republic in Basel, and Concacaf World Cup qualifying (U.S.A. vs. Barbados in L.A. on June 15), let’s round up the big managerial moves European clubs have made in recent weeks.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Scrambled Eggs With Shrimp
text: It’s amazing how good this dish is, how simple it is, how easy and fast it is. It’s also amazing how puzzled you must be hearing me say these things about scrambled eggs with shrimp. Have faith.

headline: Planet Green’s Premiere Schedule
text: When the Discovery Home Channel becomes Planet Green Wednesday at 6 p.m., the new channel will offer a broad sample of its environmentally-themed schedule. Here is the premiere night programming, according to Discovery:

headline: Sundance To Show ‘On the Road’
text: The producers of “On the Road in America,” described by Jacques Steinberg last year as a “caravan of young, good-looking Arabs crisscrossing America on a mission to educate themselves and the people they encounter along the way,” has found an American distributor.

headline: NBA Playoff Ratings ‘On A Roll’
text: MediaWeek: “The NBA Playoff ratings on ESPN, TNT and ABC are on a roll, with ESPN household ratings up 35 percent through 19 telecasts, TNT up 16 percent through 40 telecasts, and ABC up 28 percent through 10 telecasts, according to Nielsen Media Research.”

headline: Future Cities — and Festivals?
text: Wait ’til next year?

headline: Thoughts on ‘South Pacific’
text: In Frank Rich’s eloquent Memorial Weekend column, he wrote about the relevance of the current hit revival of the 1949 “South Pacific” to today. His admiration for the show was not tinged with nostalgia, he explained, because he was too young to have seen the original production.

headline: Will Steve Jobs Set Me Free?
text: Enough about my iPhone; let’s talk about Me.

headline: A Primary Calendar Democrats Will Never Forget
text: Never before have so many states played host to so many meaningful Democratic primaries or caucuses. In places like Indiana, Puerto Rico and Montana, local Democratic leaders and newspaper editorials reveled in the presidential attention and at unexpectedly being players in an electoral process that they had for years observed only from a distance.

headline: A Banking Career Built on Deals
text: Until its Golden West Financial acquisition proved a millstone around Wachovia‘s neck, G. Kennedy Thompson made a name for himself as a master of the deal — and more specifically, about making mergers work.

headline: Positively Prospect Park

headline: A Voice From Japan
text: Yumiko Osawa is a horsewoman based at Nakamaya Racecourse in Funabashi, Japan.

headline: For Wachovia Chief, a Less-Golden Parachute
text: So how much will G. Kennedy Thompson take with him now that Wachovia has shown him the door? Not nearly as much as some of his peers.

headline: ‘In Plain Sight’ Begins Cable’s Summer Season
text: Now it is cable’s turn.

headline: Australia Looks Back on Iraq War
text: Following through on a campaign promise, Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia is withdrawing all his country’s combat troops from Iraq. At a low-key ceremony on Sunday, troops lowered an Australian flag at Camp Terendak, an American-run base in the southern part of the country, to symbolize the departure of 550 Australian troops. The country still has 1,000 soldiers deployed in Afghanistan.

headline: Uma Thurman’s Stalker Is Given Probation
text: A state judge sentenced Jack Jordan, the man convicted of stalking the actress Uma Thurman, to three years probation on Monday, ordering Mr. Jordan to receive psychiatric treatment but declining a request by prosecutors to jail Mr. Jordan for up to a year, the maximum penalty. [See update.]

headline: Finding Simplicity Through Reduction
text: I took some time yesterday to read “The Laws of Simplicity,” by John Maeda, an MIT technologist (his word, not mine) who can actually write. The book is about a hundred pages long, and while I don’t recommend you rush out and buy it (it’s all on the Web site), and besides it’s extremely simple stuff — as it should be), there was one section that really struck me as being relevant to cooking, at least the style of cooking in which I’m interested.

headline: Required Viewing | ‘Cassandra’s Dream’ and ‘Match Point’
text: (Everett Collection)

headline: The Morning Skate: Wings Are Fam-i-ly and What Would Gary Roberts Do?
text: Game 5 of the Stanley Cup final goes tonight with Detroit having a chance to win their 11th championship. Their 10 ranks third in the NHL behind the Canadiens (24, including one prior to the formation of the NHL) and the Leafs (who last won the Cup when Canada had a prime minister who was born in the 19th century).

headline: Tavern on the Green Pays $2.2 Million to Settle Bias Claim
text: Tavern on the Green, the restaurant on the western edge of Central Park, has agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle a racial discrimination lawsuit filed last fall by the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. In a news release announcing the settlement, the commission said on Monday that Tavern on the Green had “engaged in severe and pervasive sexual, racial and national origin harassment of female, black and Hispanic employees.”

headline: Say It in Broken Chinglish
text: Olympics organizers have announced they will revise the English-language manual for volunteers after it drew criticism for portraying disabled athletes and visitors as “introverted,” “unsocial,” “stubborn,” and “controlling.” The guide, distributed to 100,000 volunteers for the Games, drew strong criticism last week for its advice on how to assist the disabled, whom it called “defensive” and with “a strong sense of inferiority,” but organizers have since expressed their “deepest apologies.”

headline: A ‘Race’ to Save Ancient Sea Turtle Species
text: [UPDATE, 4/15: The turtles are off and running swimming again.]

headline: Now Screening | YSL on YouTube
text: While Yves Saint Laurent pre-dates the “Project Runway” generation’s love affair with fashion TV, there’s still plenty of YouTube treasures that capture his immense creativity and Gallic wit. First up, a vintage clip from a mysterious French documentary on the designer. Beside the candy-colored knits, the best part of the snippet is Saint Laurent’s own musings, a translation of which appears below.

headline: Looking for Wachovia’s Next Chief Executive
text: Another day, another banking defenestration. This time, it was G. Kennedy Thompson of Wachovia who was shown the door. His exit from the Charlotte banking giant inevitably raises one question: Who will take his place?

headline: Answers About Fighting Poverty in New York, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of answers from David R. Jones, the president of the Community Service Society of New York. He has been answering questions about how New York City and its residents can fight poverty, and how to help low-wage, working Americans who are increasingly marginalized by the global economy. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

headline: Gauging Fallout From Rules Committee’s Decisions
text: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes that it remains uncertain whether Florida and Michigan delegates will get a full vote, and whether the Clinton campaign will challenge the decision. Go to column

headline: Ex-Dow Executives Admit to Unauthorized Buyout Talks
text: After loudly protesting their dismissal from Dow Chemical a year ago, a former executive and a former director of the chemical giant have admitted that they took part in unauthorized talks about a potential sale of the company while the leveraged buyout boom was still in full swing.

headline: Making The Most of Discovery’s ‘Beachfront Real Estate’
text: With Planet Green about to debut, which channel will Discovery Communications set its sights on next?

headline: Assembly Primary to Match Friends Turned Rivals
text: For years, Adriano Espaillat and Miguel Martinez were a highly visible political team in Washington Heights. In fact, theirs was a big brother and little brother relationship — or at the very least political mentor and mentee. They were part of the same political club and campaigned for each other in their races for office.

headline: Mr. Bill as Priceless Pitchman
text: Mr. Bill, an icon of Saturday Night Live, gets tapped for MasterCard's "Priceless" campaign.

headline: The Patch Debate
text: ELMONT, N.Y. — There’s little debate within the Big Brown camp about the colt’s quarter crack in his left front hoof: It’s healing close to perfect. But there’s some question when exactly Big Brown will be fitted with an acrylic and fiberglass patch.

headline: Hard Times for the G.O.P.: New York City Edition
text: Until his recent travails, Vito Fossella was mostly known during his 10 years in Congress as the only Republican in New York City’s delegation.

headline: Getting Rich — If Your Successor Does Well
text: Wachovia has filed an 8-k with the S.E.C. giving details on what Ken Thompson gets as he leaves. (See prior post here.)

headline: One Long, Failed Bromance
text: Does anyone understand why “What Happened,” Scott McClellan’s Book of Non-Revelation, has caused such a ruckus? Pro-war Republicans get to yelp about his disloyalty (as Gail Collins pointed out, it’s not as if they could argue with his thesis), while antiwar Democrats get to say, not for the last time, “We told you so.”

headline: The Cat Isn’t Where It’s At
text: Today’s Times reports on “Garfield Minus Garfield,” which strips away everybody in the “Garfield” comic strip except for Jon Arbuckle, the main human. Without the cutesy thought-bubbles of his lasagna-loving cat, Jon’s observations seem to teeter between existential crisis and deep despair. (Originally in the first strip below, for example, Garfield kept Jon company in all three panels. In the middle one, Garfield thinks, “Oh sure,” and then in the third: “There’s the one about the 12-foot chocolate éclair …”) Jim Davis, “Garfield’s” creator, says he’s flattered rather than peeved by the imitation. Read more …

headline: The Night Before the Day Before Art Basel 39
text: Partial view, Barnett Newman/Alberto Giacometti installation in the Beyeler Foundation Picasso Room.

headline: Philbin’s ‘Password’ Wins Sunday Night
text: Regis Philbin made a promising return to prime-time television on Sunday as the host of a new game show, “Million Dollar Password.” The series, an updated version of the classic game show in which contestants team up with celebrity guests to win a million dollars, attracted the night’s largest audience, 10.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. (Watch the show here.)

headline: Felder Shakes Up State Senate Race
text: With one swoop, City Councilman Simcha Felder changed the dynamics of two contests that are shaping up to be among the most competitive in next year’s elections: races for New York City comptroller and Brooklyn’s 21st State Senate District seat.Viewed for many months as an all-but-declared candidate for the comptroller’s position, Mr. Felder announced this morning that he will seek the Democratic nomination for the State Senate, taking on a three-time incumbent, and a fellow council member who is also vying for the post.

text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Weiss Gets 30 Months in Prison
text: Melvyn I. Weiss, the prominent class-action lawyer, was sentenced on Monday to 30 months in prison by a federal district judge in Los Angeles for his role in concealing illegal kickbacks to plaintiffs.

headline: Chocolate, ‘Part of a Balanced Diet’?
text: In a British newspaper today, a 37-year-old man claimed to have settled into an extraordinary lust for Mars chocolate bars. A 12-bar-a-day habit, which began 17 years ago, is fortified with orange juice and vitamins, Keith Sorrell claimed.

headline: Female Jihadists
text: Terror | Female jihadists want equal rights to become suicide bombers and terrorists. On extremist web sites, they object to online advice from Ayman al-Zawahiri, Osama bin Laden’s No. 2, that they should stick to being housewives. “How many times have I wished I were a man,” says one. — The Scotsman
