headline: As Gas Prices Rise, Scooters Grow in Popularity
text: Bicyclists in New York are known to possess an evangelical fervor. (What other mode of transportation has its own self-declared celebratory month? Imagine “city bus month.”) Now another fervor-driven environmentally friendly transportation group is growing up behind them: the scooter obsessives.

headline: From Horses to Horsepower
text: A century ago the word horseless had many of the same overtones wireless does today: it seemed high tech and futuristic. And at the end of the 19th century, the idea that personal locomotives powered by new types of motors might replace the horse seemed improbable.

headline: Even for McCain Crowd, Clinton’s Worth a Mention
text: NASHVILLE – Senator John McCain spent so much of his appearance here at the Ryman Auditorium – one of the ancestral homes of the Grand Ole Opry – hammering Senator Barack Obama that an audience member rose during the question-and-answer session to note that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was still in the race.

headline: Queens Voters to Choose Gallagher’s Successor
text: Tuesday is the special election in Queens for the City Council seat vacated by Dennis P. Gallagher, and there are four candidates on the ballot.

text: In a bid to counter Google, Facebook is going open-source.

headline: Investigators: NASA Officials ‘Mischaracterized’ and Limited Flow of Findings on Climate
text: Two years after James E. Hansen, the leading climate scientist at NASA, and other agency employees described a pattern of distortion and suppression of climate science by political appointees, the agency’s inspector general has concluded that such activities occurred and were “inconsistent” with the law that established the space program 50 years ago.

text: Mark Bittman makes an American classic, hash, from leftovers.

headline: The E-mail-Free Presidency
text: Wondering why President Bush decided to quit a favorite pastime — e-mail — when he came to Washington in 2000 (see last month’s Lede post)? Jaime Sneider, a former deputy associate director of the White House Communications Office, has an explanation this week in The Weekly Standard.

headline: Jury Acquits Man in Gym Assault Case
text: Christopher Carter, a stockbroker who was charged with assault after confronting a noisy gym customer during a spinning class in an Upper East Side fitness club last summer, was found not guilty of assault in Manhattan Criminal Court on Monday afternoon.

text: Tonight, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is playing host to a party at Gracie Mansion to kick off New York City Internet Week — “a weeklong festival of events saluting New York’s thriving Internet industry and the many talented companies, organizations and innovators creating the future of online media!”

headline: Water Polo Diary: Getting Ready for the Super Final
text: Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. women’s water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. She’ll be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog in the buildup to the Olympics.

headline: Leafs to Hire Ron Wilson?
text: TSN is reporting that former San Jose Sharks coach Ron Wilson is about to be offered the job of Toronto Maple Leafs coach.

headline: Return of ‘The Mole’

headline: Superdelegate Swirl
text: Updated The superdelegate shuffle seems to be in full swing today, with senators meeting on Capitol Hill and several leaders in the states coming out for Senator Barack Obama, along with two for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: It’s All in Place for the Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO — My flight arrived here too late Sunday night to catch any of the Mets’ 6-1 win against the Dodgers, but from what I’ve read and seen, the details can be distilled into this: The Mets looked like a formidable team again, which is what happens when their best players — Johan Santana, Jose Reyes, David Wright, Carlos Beltran — all take leading roles.

headline: Cleaner Classrooms Mean Fewer Sick Kids
text: Regular wiping of student desks and use of hand sanitizers during the school day can significantly reduce student illness and absenteeism, a new study shows.

headline: Rowing for Gold
text: The Chinese are recruiting foreign help with the aim of increasing their medal count this summer.

headline: The 2008 Democratic Race
text: John Harwood of The Times and CNBC counts the ways in which the 2008 Democratic primary fight stands alone in American history.

headline: We Will See an Octopus. Will We See the Stanley Cup?
text: The Red Wings are hoping to turn tonight’s Game 5 at Joe Louis Arena into their coronation with the hoisting of their fourth Cup in 11 years. The Penguins are trying to mess up that plan, but as this series goes along, they are looking more and more like the Edmonton Oilers of 1983. That is the young, ridiculously talented team that, before they could dominate the rest of the ’80s, took a drubbing in the Cup final from a proud, aging Islanders dynasty.

headline: Core Competency Mothers
text: According to a series of blog posts on The Huffington Post by Laura Vanderkam, a new type of outsourcing is sweeping dual-income households around the country, and it has a lot to do with sweeping (or not sweeping) the floors. The first post describes what Ms. Vanderkam refers to as the core competency mom, who manages to both have a job and a career by focusing her limited time at home on tasks that give her the most time with her children. As she puts it, “Going on a hike with your teenage children on a Saturday is a better way to show you care than washing their jeans.” As for the floor sweeping — that falls into the category of stuff that is either outsourced or ignored by the core competency mother.

headline: McCain and Obama’s Excellent Adventure
text: Dan Schnur was the national communications director for John McCain’s presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)

headline: Belmont News: Monday
text: Icabad Crane breezed a half mile in 48.6 this morning at Fair Hill Training Center. The work pleased his connections, and he is scheduled to ship to New York tomorrow.

headline: A Study in Spacs
text: The Heckmann Corporation, a special purpose acquisition company, has announced an agreement to acquire China Water and Drinks for approximately $625.0 million. According to Euromonitor International, China Water is the fifth-largest bottled water supplier in China, based on 2007 estimated revenue figures.

headline: Trading Places: Mother-Daughter Clinton Routine
text: YANKTON, S.D. — As Hillary Clinton closed out the penultimate day of the primary season here today, the press corps traveling with her was taking great pains to notice every possible sign or omen that her campaign was on its last legs.

headline: Readers Respond to China’s Pollution
text: In a recent column, Nick describes the links between China’s brutal environmental tolls and its economic boom. While the government is working to curb pollution, dirty air and tainted water persist. Readers responded by sharing stories about brown air, smog clouds and bronchial issues, as well as suggesting that the situation calls for international cooperation. In the Chinese media, environmental news of the moment includes the ban (“限塑令”) prohibiting shops from giving out free plastic shopping bags that went into effect on June 1. Reactions have been warm, with one report from Xinhua news agency finding that most people are feeling confident about environmental protection (“大部分市民表现出的态度让人对 ‘环保’ 充满信心”).

headline: Bloggers’ Delight: A Smorgasbord of Embeddable Clips
text: By the fall, virtually every TV episode broadcast by the big four networks will be available for embedding in blogs, personal profiles and other Web pages.

headline: Bloggingheads: Are Blogs Bad for Us?
text:
Legal scholars Cass Sunstein, left, of the University of Chicago and Eugene Volokh of UCLA debate the relative merits of blogs and newspapers.

headline: Holdout Superdelegates
text: Robert Rankin, an uncommitted superdelegate from California, arrived home on Monday afternoon to find a last-minute telephone message from a surrogate for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, presumably to ask — again — for his support.

headline: McCain a One-Term President?
text: NASHVILLE – Some of Senator John McCain’s advisers suggested last year that he take the unusual but dramatic step of pledging to serve only one term as president if elected, but he decided it would be a mistake to do so, campaign aides said Monday.

headline: Brain Surgeons and Cellphones
text: Last week, I spent several hours on my cellphone doing interviews. That’s not unusual, except this week, the subject of my Well column is whether regular cellphone use is risky to the brain.

text: If you watched the post position draws for the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, you may be expecting to turn on ESPN2 at 5 p.m. on Wednesday and find the Belmont draw.

headline: Euro 2008: Swiss at Home in Group A
text: Since the introduction in 1980 of the group stage of the European Championship, only one host nation — Belgium (a co-host with the Netherlands) in 2000 — has failed to advance to the knockout round. This year, Switzerland (No. 48 in the latest FIFA rankings) and Austria (No. 101) are co-hosts, and there is a better than even chance they will both be on the sideline by June 19.

text: One of the most influential couturiers of the second half of the 20th century died on June 1 in Paris.

headline: If You Have Diarrhea or Vomiting Symptoms, How Do You Lodge a Complaint?
text: That important question is among 57 laid out for foreign visitors by the Beijing Olympic organizing committee in advance of the Games this August. Many of the questions published in Chinese on the organizing committee’s web site take the form of warnings and prohibitions, as Keith Bradsher reports: Do not bring any printed materials critical of China. Do not plan on holding any rallies or demonstrations in China. Do not think that you are guaranteed an entry visa because you hold tickets to an Olympic event. And do not even think about smuggling opium into China.

headline: A Conversation With Dr. James Hansen
text: Dr. James Hansen, NASA's top climate scientist, speaks about global warming. Producer: Erik Olsen.

headline: Kelsey Grammer Has ‘Mild’ Heart Attack
text: Associated Press: A spokesman for Kelsey Grammer says the ”Frasier” star is recovering in a Hawaii hospital after a mild heart attack this weekend. Mr. Grammer most recently starred in the Fox sitcom “Back to You.”

headline: Kamsky-Topalov Match Is on in Ukraine
text: After several blown deadlines for settling the time, location and prize fund for a match between Gata Kamsky of the United States and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, the World Chess Federation announced yesterday that the match will take place in Lvov, Ukraine, from Nov. 26 to Dec. 14. The prize fund will be $750,000.

headline: Bo Diddley, Who Gave Rock His Beat, Dies at 79
text: Bo Diddley, a singer and guitarist who invented his own name, his own guitars, his own beat and, with a handful of other musical pioneers, rock ’n’ roll itself, died Monday at his home in Archer, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Repairing the Damage, Before Roe
text: With the Supreme Court becoming more conservative, many people who support women’s right to choose an abortion fear that Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that gave them that right, is in danger of being swept aside.

headline: Mtv Movies: Real Awards, Fake Dope
text: Seth Rogen and James Franco play stoners in the coming film “Pineapple Express,” and they reprised their roles at the MTV Movie Awards on Sunday night: they pulled out a bag of fake marijuana onstage, then Mr. Rogen lighted a fake joint and Mr. Franco puffed on it. “Kids don’t really smoke fake weed like this,” Mr. Rogen, above with glasses, told the crowd at the Gibson Amphitheater in Los Angeles, where they were presenting the award for the best summer movie so far. Before television viewers could get a closer look at what was real and what was not, the camera moved to a wide angle and stayed that way until Mr. Rogen and Mr. Franco, above in white T-shirt, left the stage, The Associated Press reported. It was an awkward moment that made some in the audience laugh. Backstage, Mr. Franco told The Associated Press that MTV had put them up to the joke  supplying the script as well as the fake pot and joint  and then had a last-second change of heart.

headline: Building Washer Falls 4 Stories to His Death in Brooklyn; Officials Cite Safety Omissions
text: A worker who was power-washing the upper facade of an apartment building in Brooklyn without wearing a safety harness died on Monday after he fell four stories to the ground, officials said.

headline: Secret Life of a Deal

headline: Listen, You Brat, to Plain Truths About the Beauty Myth

headline: Wedding Crashers Flew In, and the Lawn Wore White
text: I love strange weather. My bookshelf holds such must-haves as “Tornadoes, Dark Days, Anomalous Precipitation, and Related Weather Phenomena,” which chronicles things like giant snowflakes and clouds that hiss like snakes. Not to mention big hail, a personal favorite.

headline: Two Months Later, Martínez Comes Back

headline: Godard Cancels Visit to Film Festival in Israel
text: The French filmmaker Jean-Luc Godard has dropped plans to attend a film festival in Tel Aviv after a Palestinian group urged him to boycott Israel, Reuters reported. Mr. Godard, one of the founders of the French New Wave of the 1960s, canceled the trip to the Tel Aviv International Student Film Festival, citing “circumstances beyond his control,” festival organizers said Monday. The Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel urged Mr. Godard in an open letter last week to “take a courageous stand and cancel your trip to Israel.” The letter asked: “Did you ever go to an Afrikaner film festival in apartheid South Africa? Why Israel, then?” Reuters said a source in Mr. Godard’s office declined to comment but said he had canceled his visit for political reasons. Festival organizers said they were disappointed but respected Mr. Godard’s decision. Pro-Palestinian groups frequently call on prominent cultural and academic figures to boycott Israel because of its occupation of the West Bank and its blockade of the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip.

headline: Starrett City Residents Breathe Easier With the Announcement of Sale Terms
text: With grocery bags in his hands, Jose Figueroa stood on a hill above the politicians as they announced an agreement on Monday that would keep his rent at the sprawling Starrett City residential complex in Brooklyn affordable for years to come.

headline: Creating a Don Quixote of the Cheap Motel Circuit
text: Lee Child is 6 foot 5, the same height as Jack Reacher, the sexy, drifter hero of his best-selling thriller series, but he’s about 75 pounds lighter. He hardly looks like a condom crammed with walnuts, as a female friend of Reacher’s once described him, and he doesn’t appear to be the sort of person who would be much use in a bar fight. You can’t picture him head-butting, or breaking someone’s nose with his elbow. Reacher does both in “Nothing to Lose,” the 12th and latest installment in the series, while taking on six assailants at once. He also breaks a guy’s ribs with a chair leg and crushes the larynx of another.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the World Science Festival in New York misstated the relationship between the festival’s founders, Brian Greene and Tracy Day, in some copies. They are married, not simply companions. (The error also appeared in The Arts on April 3 in an article about the festival.)

headline: Documents Said to Be Seized From Crane Owner’s Offices
text: Prosecutors investigating a fatal crane collapse on East 91st Street have taken away boxes of documents and computers from the offices of the crane’s owner, New York Crane and Equipment, two people involved in the inquiry said on Monday.

headline: A Mercy Killer, Dying a Little Death
text: Waiting for Liza Lentini’s play “The Euthanasist” to begin at Performance Space 122, the people around me were cheerfully expecting to be moved and forced to confront demons. “I hear we’re going to be angry when we leave,” a man behind me said, and his friend replied that it would probably be a tear-jerker.

headline: Experts Revive Debate Over Cellphones and Cancer
text: What do brain surgeons know about cellphone safety that the rest of us don’t?

headline: Bloomberg Claims Victory as Georgia Gun Dealer Withdraws From Trial
text: Saying he could not afford what he feared would be an unfair trial, a Georgia gun dealer accused by New York City of illegally selling handguns that made their way to New York backed out of his federal trial on Monday, the day it was set to begin.

headline: Banks and Student Loans
text: Despite the credit crunch, there is little danger that students who need federally backed college loans will not be able to get them. That’s partly because of a law signed last month  the Ensuring Continued Access to Student Loans Act  that will help lenders raise money to make new loans. It is also because the federal government offers loans both privately, through lenders that earn subsidies to participate in the program, and publicly, through its direct-lending program.

headline: Survey of Medical Schools Is Critical of Perks
text: Most medical schools in the United States fail to police adequately the money, gifts and free drug samples that pharmaceutical companies routinely shower on doctors and trainees, according to a ranking by the American Medical Student Association.

headline: When Guys and Grunts Get Tangly
text: You see, there were these two New York guys acting like, well, New York guys. In some circles, they’re called alpha males. Sometimes, alpha males come hard-wired with omega emotional quotients.

headline: Uma Thurman’s Stalker Sentenced to 3 Years’ Probation and Treatment
text: Jack Jordan, once a promising youth who became a drifter and has been diagnosed with mental illnesses, was sentenced on Monday to three years’ probation for stalking the actress Uma Thurman. He was ordered to undergo psychiatric treatment.

headline: Progress Has Been Made in Fight Against AIDS, but Not Enough, U.N. Report Says
text: JOHANNESBURG  The good news on AIDS: Nearly a million people began life-prolonging drug treatment in developing countries last year. The bad news: 2.5 million people were newly infected with H.I.V.

headline: ‘Sisters’ Colleges See a Bounty in the Middle East
text: Women’s colleges are a dwindling breed in the United States.

headline: Parents Receive Medal of Honor for Soldier Killed in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush awarded the military’s highest honor to a 19-year-old soldier who was killed in Iraq after falling on a grenade to save his fellow soldiers.

headline: Myanmar Rulers Still Impeding Access
text: BANGKOK  One month after a powerful cyclone struck Myanmar and 10 days after the ruling junta’s leader promised full access to the hardest-hit areas, relief agencies said on Monday that they were still having difficulty reaching hundreds of thousands of survivors in urgent need of assistance.

headline: DNA on Parade
text: Q. Can you see DNA under a microscope?

headline: NASA Office Is Criticized on Climate Reports
text: Two years after James E. Hansen, the leading climate scientist at NASA, and other agency employees described a pattern of distortion and suppression of climate science by political appointees, the agency’s inspector general has concluded that such activities occurred and were “inconsistent” with the law that established the space program 50 years ago.

headline: Despite Fire, Universal Studios Is Open
text: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  Ron Meyer, president of Universal Studios, was not kidding when he said it would be “business as usual” here Monday, despite a weekend fire that consumed two square blocks and many structures on the studio lot.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Tuesday about the success of the Marines in a recent operation against the Taliban in southern Afghanistan misidentified the Marine unit commanded by officers who were investigated, but not charged, after a convoy killed 19 unarmed civilians and wounded 50 on March 4, 2007. It is F Company, Second Marine Special Operations Battalion, not the 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit.

headline: China Lists Dos and Don’ts for Olympics-Bound Foreigners
text: HONG KONG  Do not bring any printed materials critical of China. Do not plan on holding any rallies or demonstrations in China. Do not think that you are guaranteed an entry visa because you hold tickets to an Olympic event. And do not even think about smuggling opium into China.

headline: China: Bank Makes Hong Kong Acquisition
text: The China Merchants Bank Company agreed to pay 19.3 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.5 billion) for control of the Wing Lung Bank of Hong Kong. Merchants Bank will buy 123.3 billion shares, a 53.1 percent stake, at 156.5 Hong Kong dollars each, from Wing Lung’s chairman, Michael Wu, and his family, the two companies said. China Merchants Bank, based in Shenzhen, will also make a general offer for the rest of Wing Lung’s shares at the same price, valuing the bank at $4.66 billion.

headline: On Rounds, Observing the Suits, Not Saints
text: What a miserable place the modern hospital is. Even those of us who work in one and have become inured to the general ambience are constantly startled by new instances of cruelty, idiocy, disorder and profit taking where, in theory, only selfless lovingkindness should dwell.

headline: Giants Sign Veteran Defensive End
text: The Giants signed defensive end Renaldo Wynn, an 11-year veteran who played for New Orleans last season. He was a first-round draft choice, 21st over all, out of Notre Dame in 1997 by Jacksonville, when Tom Coughlin was the coach of the Jaguars. He has 25 sacks in 164 career games.

headline: Chamberlain Moves From Late Relief to Early Arrival
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Shortly after 3 p.m. Monday, Joba Chamberlain assumed the unaccustomed role of the next day’s starting pitcher. Dressed in a black T-shirt and jeans and pulling a small suitcase, Chamberlain shook hands with Robinson Canó and other teammates as he headed for the clubhouse door at the Metrodome, set to fly home ahead of the team. Canó, of course, could not let Chamberlain depart without a sarcastic remark.

headline: Sharapova Roars, but She Is Silenced by Safina Once Again
text: PARIS  Shrieking and swearing like a street fighter, Maria Sharapova was in no mood to accept that she was about to blow another lead in the fourth round of the French Open against Dinara Safina.

headline: Lawsuit Criticizes Yahoo Retention Plan
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo’s chief executive, Jerry Yang, pushed for an expensive plan to retain employees in the event of an acquisition by Microsoft despite reservations of some Yahoo executives and of a consulting firm that Yahoo hired to help devise the plan, according to a shareholder lawsuit.

headline: Grasso’s Grit May Win After All
text: Call it the curse of Dick Grasso.

headline: Following the Money Behind Big Brown
text: James Tagliaferri is bullish on horse racing, a sport that he is still learning, but also one that has already rewarded his St. Thomas Island-based asset-management company handsomely. His company, TAG Virgin Islands, is the real money behind Big Brown and his owner, International Equine Acquisitions Holdings. And Tagliaferri is also the real brains behind a proposed $100 million equine fund that he contends will revolutionize the horse racing business.

headline: Horse Racing and Steroids
text: When you watch Big Brown at the Belmont Stakes, you will be watching a horse that is running on steroids. There is no denying the natural athleticism of Big Brown, who stands an excellent chance of becoming the first Triple Crown winner in 30 years. There is also no denying that it would be all the more impressive if it were not drug-enhanced.

headline: Senate Opens Debate on Politically Risky Bill Addressing Global Warming
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Monday opened a raucous debate over climate change legislation even though it will put supporters of the bill, including all three presidential candidates, on the spot  essentially forcing them to come out in favor of high energy costs at a time when American consumers are paying record fuel prices.

headline: Forest Disappearing in Papua New Guinea
text: A new satellite analysis of logging in Papua New Guinea shows that the country has been losing about 1,400 square miles of rain forest, or about 1.4 percent of its total forest cover, each year.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about billboards equipped with cameras that gather details about passers-by reversed the identifications, in some editions, for two men shown looking at a billboard. Rick Rivera is at the left; Nathan Lichon is at the right. The article also misstated the name of an industry association that is devising standards to measure the impact of advertising methods like digital billboards and signs. It is the Out-of-Home Video Advertising Bureau, not the Out-of-Home Video Advertising Association.

headline: Same-Sex Parents in Albatross Colony
text: Cooperative breeding, in which an animal assists in caring for offspring that are not its own, is often found in nature. But researchers in Hawaii have uncovered a case that is not so common, involving long-term pairs of unrelated birds of the same sex.

headline: Britain: Dry Subways’ Rough Departure
text: London’s new policy of banning alcohol on the subways got off to a poor start when a party called to mark the last night of legal drinking descended into a chaotic free-for-all, with revelers vomiting, urinating, climbing onto train roofs and assaulting and pouring beer on one another, subway workers and police officers. Seventeen people were arrested, six stations were closed and several trains were so badly damaged that they had to be removed from service. The party on the Circle Line on Saturday night was advertised on the Internet. Bob Crow, general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union, said that at least 12 union members had been attacked at one station alone.

headline: North Korea Didn’t Dupe U.N. Office, Report Says
text: UNITED NATIONS  American allegations that North Korea duped the United Nations Development Program by diverting aid money for its own needs are not supported by any evidence, according to a lengthy external review released Monday.

headline: Lyrics and Lyricists, and a Curator
text: The 92nd Street Y has announced its 2009 lineup for Lyrics & Lyricists, its popular series devoted to the American songbook. This is the first season run by Deborah Grace Winer, the series’s new artistic director, who has created three shows for Lyrics & Lyricists over the last five years. Ms. Winer’s inaugural lineup of guest artistic directors includes Martin Charnin, David Zippel, Robert Kimball, Rex Reed and Billy Stritch. The series will showcase, among others, Mr. Zippel, Richard Rodgers, Mel Tormé and Ira Gershwin’s collaborations with artists like Jerome Kern, Harold Arlen and Kurt Weill. Subscriptions for the season go on sale June 15. Ticket information: (212) 415-5500.

headline: Kennedy on His Feet After Surgery
text: One day after undergoing surgery for a malignant brain tumor, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is up and walking the hallways of his hospital while spending time with his family, his aides said in a statement.

headline: In 3rd Overtime, Penguins Stay Alive
text: DETROIT  By the time the Penguins pulled their final magic act of Game 5 with Petr Sykora’s season-saving goal in the third overtime for a stunning 4-3 victory, they had withstood nearly everything the Red Wings could throw at them in trying to end the Stanley Cup finals Monday night.

headline: 8 Are Killed in Bombing in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful car bomb exploded outside the Danish Embassy in an upscale area of the Pakistani capital on Monday, killing eight people, the police said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about Pittsburgh’s 3-2 victory against Detroit in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals reversed the order of the game’s final two goals. Adam Hall had the Penguins’ third goal before  not after  Mikael Samuelsson scored for the Red Wings.

headline: Corrections
text: Metro

headline: Dance in Review
text: CATCH 30

headline: Tavern on the Green to Pay $2.2 Million to Settle Harassment Claim
text: Tavern on the Green, the landmark restaurant in Central Park, agreed on Monday to pay $2.2 million to settle a lawsuit in which the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission had accused it of severe sexual and racial discrimination.

headline: Security Breach at Military Hospital
text: Sensitive information on about 1,000 patients at Walter Reed Army Medical Center and other military hospitals was exposed in a security breach. Hospital officials said the information included names, social security numbers and birth dates but not medical records. Walter Reed officials declined to explain exactly how the information was compromised, pending an investigation.

headline: Corrections
text: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about the Triple Crown rivalry of Affirmed and Alydar in 1978, misidentified the individual for whom Alydar was named. He was a friend of the horse’s owners named Aly Khan, not “the Aga Khan.” (As the column noted, the colt’s name came from “Aly darling,” which is how the owners addressed their friend.)

headline: Obama, Awaiting a New Title, Carefully Hones His Partisan Image
text: SIOUX FALLS, S.D.  In his telling, his opponent is wrong on the Iraq war and wrong on the ailing economy, a would-be George W. Bush running for what amounts to a third term.

headline: Elite XC Was Brutal. So Was the Hyperbole.
text: The production team behind CBS’s broadcast of the EliteXC circus Saturday night must have believed that high-voltage hyperbole was the route to success for the first live network prime-time showing of a mixed martial arts show.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 2, 2008

headline: The Future Is Now? Pretty Soon, at Least
text: Before we get to Ray Kurzweil’s plan for upgrading the “suboptimal software” in your brain, let me pass on some of the cheery news he brought to the World Science Festival last week in New York.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,079 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the American-run detention system in Iraq misstated the location of One World Research, a human rights organization whose executive director, John Sifton, criticized what he called the American military’s overly broad interpretation of a United Nations resolution in order to detain suspects. It is based in New York, not Los Angeles.

headline: British Bank Gets Private Equity Lifeline
text: LONDON  A leading British mortgage lender was forced Monday to seek emergency help from investors and cut the price of a planned share sale as more borrowers defaulted on mortgages, sowing fears that the global credit crisis was weighing heavily on the broad economy.

headline: Panel Urges 4% Tax Cap on Property in New York
text: ALBANY  A state commission urged the governor on Monday to cap local property tax increases at 4 percent a year as part of a preliminary proposal aimed at reducing New York’s local tax burden, among the highest in the nation.

headline: Storytelling and Deception in a Magic Kingdom
text: Salman Rushdie’s new novel, “The Enchantress of Florence,” reads less like a novel by the author of such magical works as “Midnight’s Children” and “The Moor’s Last Sigh” than a weary, predictable parody of something by John Barth.

headline: The Claim: Drinking Flat Soda Can Ease an Upset Stomach
text: THE FACTS

headline: Plans for a Park in Queens
text: To the Editor:

headline: Downgrade of 3 Banks Revives Credit Fears
text: Stocks markets dropped on Monday after three of Wall Street’s biggest banks were hit with a harsh ratings downgrade, sending the Dow Jones industrials down 134 points and leaving some investors worried about additional losses.

headline: Mr. Bill Returns (in One Piece) to Pitch a Debit Card
text: MasterCard executives have found a new poster boy for the angst-ridden economy: Mr. Bill.

headline: 3 Years Later, Knees Made for Dancing
text: The question most often asked by longtime readers and acquaintances I haven’t seen for a while is, “How are your knees?”

headline: Bo Diddley: The Beat That Will Go On
text: Bo Diddley, who died on Monday, understood the power of suggesting the past and the future at the same time, combining country wisdom and space-age innovation on the same record.

headline: Japan: Nissan Leads Decline in Auto Sales
text: Nissan led a decline in domestic auto sales in May, as higher taxes and fuel costs cut demand. Sales of cars, trucks and buses fell 6.1 percent from a year earlier to 221,377, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said. The total excludes minicars. Sales at Nissan dropped 11.4 percent to 33,681 vehicles. Toyota’s sales fell 2.8 percent to 105,519 vehicles. Honda sold 26,900 vehicles, a 5.1 percent increase, helped by its revamped Fit compact.

headline: Airlines Face ‘Desperate’ Situation, Official Says
text: ISTANBUL  Citing high oil prices and the slowing economy, the International Air Transport Association on Monday sharply lowered its industry forecast for 2008, saying it now expected a collective loss of at least $2.3 billion.

headline: Trade Center to Get Tenant From China
text: A Chinese real estate company has signed a nonbinding deal to lease space in the Freedom Tower, making it the first private company to agree to occupy the 102-story skyscraper now under construction at the former World Trade Center site.

headline: Anne d’Harnoncourt, Who Led Philadelphia Museum, Dies at 64
text: Anne d’Harnoncourt, who revivified the Philadelphia Museum of Art and maintained the intellectual standards of its program of exhibitions, died on Sunday night at her home in Philadelphia. She was 64.

headline: Tatum O’Neal Faces Drug Charge
text: Tatum O’Neal was arrested and released after being accused of buying crack cocaine near her home in Manhattan, The Associated Press reported Monday. Police officers said Ms. O’Neal, 44, was seen making the purchase at about 7:30 p.m. on Sunday on the Lower East Side. She was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance. Ms. O’Neal, right, who wrote about her problems with addiction in her memoir “A Paper Life,” appears regularly on “Rescue Me,” the FX television series about New York City firefighters. Ms. O’Neal, the daughter of the actor Ryan O’Neal, became the youngest person to win an Oscar in 1974 when, at age 10, she received the best supporting actress award for her role in “Paper Moon.”

headline: Pieces That Give Musical Chairs a New Meaning
text: Leon Botstein closed the American Symphony Orchestra’s season on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall with a selection of works about space: that is, about the way distances and the placement of instruments affect the sound of a work and also, at least glancingly, about the cosmos.

headline: Alumni Group Tries to Elicit Social Action From Harvard
text: For three years, a handful of Harvard University alumni have waged a quiet effort to persuade the university to expand its mission far beyond its Cambridge campus, the students it educates there and the multitude of research labs, libraries and other facilities available to them.

headline: A Win for Password
text: Regis Philbin made a promising return to prime-time television on Sunday as the host of “Million Dollar Password” on CBS. The new series, an updated version of the classic game show, attracted the night’s largest audience, 10.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. It followed “60 Minutes” at 7 p.m. (10 million); together, the two shows made CBS the night’s most-watched network, despite more modest ratings later with repeats of “Cold Case” (7.8 million) and “The Unit” (5 million) opposite NBC’s “Dateline” from 9 to 11 (8.1 million). NBC finished second in total viewers but first among adults 18 to 49. An encore of NBC’s special “100 Most Outrageous Moments of All Time” averaged 5.4 million viewers from 7 to 9 p.m. Fox and ABC finished in a tie for third place. Both networks broadcast lineups of all reruns.

headline: Cheney Discloses His Lighter Side
text: WASHINGTON  Signs that Vice President Dick Cheney is contemplating life after the White House: He hinted he might write a book; floated the possibility of a family reunion with his distant cousin, Senator Barack Obama; and made a wisecrack about a battleground state  all in a single talk Monday at the National Press Club here.

headline: Politics Invades Celebration in Trinidad
text: In the often politicized world of soccer, England’s recent four-day visit to Trinidad and Tobago to celebrate that country’s soccer centenary was, well, political.

headline: Chavez Decree Tightens Hold on Intelligence
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez has used his decree powers to carry out a major overhaul of this country’s intelligence agencies, provoking a fierce backlash here from human rights groups and legal scholars who say the measures will force citizens to inform on one another to avoid prison terms.

headline: Mars Lander Is Poised to Begin Digging for Ice
text: After a couple of days of playing in the dirt, the Phoenix Mars lander is to begin its scientific work in earnest on Tuesday or Wednesday, looking for ice and hints of past liquid water in the planet’s far north.

headline: Converging Cultures (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Peace Fills a Vacuum
text: IN the last few weeks, three long-frozen conflicts in the Middle East have displayed early signs of thawing. Israel and Hamas may be inching toward a cease-fire that would end attacks by both sides and, perhaps, loosen the siege imposed on the impoverished Gaza Strip. The factions in Lebanon, after a long period of institutional paralysis and a near civil war, have reached a tentative political agreement. And eight years after their last negotiations, Israel and Syria have announced the resumption of indirect peace talks.

headline: Protests Shake a Divided Thailand
text: BANGKOK  Only five months after national elections ended military rule here, a week of street protests has weakened the coalition government and highlighted the country’s failure to move beyond the stalemate that has frozen politics here for more than two years.

headline: Obama Pushes Effort to Claim Victory Tonight
text: This article was reported by Adam Nagourney, Carl Hulse and Jeff Zeleny and written by Mr. Nagourney.

headline: Shuttle Docks With Space Station
text: The crews of the Space Shuttle Discovery and the International Space Station got together while orbiting over the South Pacific. The hatch between the two spacecraft opened shortly after 3:30 p.m. Eastern time, followed by embraces and backslapping. The docking began nine days of operations that will include installing the main component of a Japanese-made science module and repairing the station’s sole toilet, which has been malfunctioning. Earlier, as the Discovery made its approach, Cmdr. Mark E. Kelly put it through a back flip that allowed members of the station crew to take photographs of the underbelly of the shuttle.

headline: Kentucky Yard Sale Yields a Trove of Weegee Images
text: As letters go, they aren’t exactly the stuff of literature. One from 1959 asks that the recipient phone Con Edison and complain about an unusually high electric bill ($54.92). Another requests a shipment of beloved New York cigars because of apparent dissatisfaction with the options available in Europe. At least one, written from the Regina-Palast Hotel in Munich, Room 551, starts to provide a hint of the sender.

headline: A Wet Western Spring
text: Take it as a rule of Wyoming life: a wet rancher is a happy rancher. And right now, many of the ranchers in the state are sopping and grinning.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on May 25, about alumni donating to Harvard, misstated a requirement for spending by non-university charitable foundations. Federal law requires them to disburse 5 percent of their endowment a year, not their income.

headline: New DVDs: An Antiwar Farce and a Vintage Paramount Collection
text: ‘WHAT DID YOU DO

headline: Gym Grunter Not Assaulted by Silencer, a Jury Rules
text: They are among the irritants who are an unfortunate part of the New York experience: the loud cellphone talker in the elevator, the picture-happy tourist blocking a crowded sidewalk, the testosterone-laced grunter who practically coughs up a parakeet with each biceps curl.

headline: Baseball Follows Selig’s Lead on Cancer
text: Bud Selig was halfway out the door, eager to be done with his annual checkup. All the tests said he was healthy, so he was ready to get back to work. But then his doctor called him back from the threshold and took a closer look at a splotch near Selig’s right temple. And suggested a trip to the dermatologist. Right away.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Monday about the reaction in Harlem to Gov. David A. Paterson’s move to order New York State agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere referred incorrectly in some copies to his support for gay rights. He has expressed his support in public before; his directive was not the first indication of such support.

headline: A Gift to the G.O.P.
text: Talk about self-inflicted wounds.

headline: Calling Dr. Doom
text: It took Christopher Columbus about 70 days to get to the New World  a bit less than half as long as it took us to get through the 2008 primary calendar. But by Tuesday night, we’ll have reached our destination, and people in the Obama and McCain camps are feeling good about themselves.

headline: Judge Orders Sect Children’s Release
text: A judge in Texas ordered more than 460 children seized in April from a polygamist sect to be released from state custody on Monday, while imposing conditions on their families that would allow officials to monitor the children’s welfare.

headline: No Ruling Means No Change for Fantasy Baseball Leagues
text: WASHINGTON  Major League Baseball’s effort to maintain exclusive control of its players’ statistics failed Monday, when the Supreme Court turned down its appeal of a ruling that gave fantasy baseball leagues the right to use the data without purchasing a license.

headline: Class-Action Lawyer Gets 30 Months in Prison
text: Melvyn I. Weiss, the prominent class-action lawyer, was sentenced on Monday to 30 months in prison by a Federal District Court judge in Los Angeles for his role in concealing illegal kickbacks to plaintiffs.

headline: The Science of Sarcasm (Not That You Care)
text: There was nothing very interesting in Katherine P. Rankin’s study of sarcasm  at least, nothing worth your important time. All she did was use an M.R.I. to find the place in the brain where the ability to detect sarcasm resides. But then, you probably already knew it was in the right parahippocampal gyrus.

headline: Late for Work: Amy Winehouse
text: She’s back. Amy Winehouse, in her first concert since leaving rehab, showed up almost an hour late with a bandage on her hand to an outdoor music festival in Lisbon. “I’m sorry I’m late,” Ms. Winehouse, above, told the crowd, according to The Associated Press, which said that she appeared distracted, that she had cuts on her left arm, and that her right arm was bandaged. She also apologized for having a sore throat, and her voice cracked during the set. Some in the crowd of 90,000 booed when Ms. Winehouse failed to appear on time, although she is known for missed concerts and odd behavior. Ms. Winehouse walked offstage in Lisbon without playing an encore, after singing hits like “Rehab” as well as soul classics and reggae songs. She is scheduled to appear at a series of music festivals in Europe this summer.

headline: Wachovia Forces Out Its Chief
text: G. Kennedy Thompson spent 32 years building the Wachovia Corporation into one of the nation’s biggest banks. But late last Thursday, as problems at Wachovia continued to worsen, the company’s chairman gave Mr. Thompson the bad news: his career at the bank was over.

headline: More Give Than Take for Pettitte and Yankees
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Andy Pettitte stood on the mound at the Metrodome, hands on his hips, as the crowd of 20,168 roared around him. For the third time, Pettitte had given back a lead the Yankees had provided him, this time in spectacular fashion  on Joe Mauer’s first home run of the season, a long, loud drive that slammed into the facing of the upper deck in right.

headline: Pension Costs Off by $500 Million, City Finds
text: ALBANY  An actuary paid by public employee unions and yet relied upon by the State Legislature to determine the cost of proposals affecting New York City’s pension system underestimated their ultimate cost by at least $500 million, city documents and other records show.

headline: Dark, Perhaps Forever
text: BALTIMORE  Mario Livio tossed his car keys in the air.

headline: Doctor Says Kennedy’s Brain Surgery Is Successful
text: Senator Edward M. Kennedy successfully underwent surgery at Duke University Medical Center on Monday for a malignant brain tumor, the doctor who performed the procedure said.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture caption on Monday with the Critics’ Choice column about new CDs, including “Revelation” by Journey, referred incorrectly to Steve Perry, a former singer for Journey to whom its new singer, Arnel Pineda, was compared. Mr. Perry joined the band after it was formed; thus he was not Journey’s first singer. Gregg Rolie (also the keyboardist) was.

headline: Memo Pad
text: DELTA INTERNATIONAL Delta Air Lines, which has said that more than 40 percent of its flying will be in international traffic by this summer, will start nine new international routes through June 12, including nonstop service between Salt Lake City and Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris in a partnership with Air France. Delta said it has added more international capacity than any major domestic airline in the last two years.

headline: Human Rights Advocate Is Freed
text: A prominent Uzbek human rights advocate was freed on Monday after more than two years in captivity, a release that coincided with a visit by an American official.

headline: Iraq Opened Door to Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sect’s Children Returned to Parents, but Inquiry Continues
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  More than 460 children seized by state authorities in April in an investigation of possible sexual abuse at an isolated West Texas polygamist community began going home on Monday.

headline: In Spain, Water Is a New Battleground
text: FORTUNA, Spain  Lush fields of lettuce and hothouses of tomatoes line the roads. Verdant new developments of plush pastel vacation homes beckon buyers from Britain and Germany. Golf courses  dozens of them, all recently built  give way to the beach. At last, this hardscrabble corner of southeast Spain is thriving.

headline: Nostrums: After Taser Jolt, a Regular Heartbeat Again
text: The Taser is known mainly as the shock-giving device that helps police officers incapacitate suspects and, thanks to YouTube, made “Don’t Tase me, bro” a national catchphrase. But could there be a medical application in its future?

headline: An Impossible Dream, the Euro Finds Its Way
text: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, still marvels at the feat.

headline: Footnotes
text: Brian Stokes Mitchell, the Tony-winning singer and actor, is joining the Boston Pops at Radio City Music Hall on Aug. 21, Playbill reported. ... Yoko Ono has lost her legal battle to keep John Lennon’s song “Imagine” out of a film that challenges the theory of evolution, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Ono had sued the makers of “Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed,” accusing them of using the song without her permission. A federal judge decided Monday that the filmmakers are protected under the “fair use” doctrine, which permits use of small parts of a copyrighted work. The film opened in this country in April and is scheduled to be released in Canada on Friday. ... “Gone With the Wind,” the British musical that was pummeled by the critics, will close June 14 after 79 performances, Variety reported. ... Shakespeare’s Globe Theater in London will present a special performance of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at midnight during the summer solstice on June 21. Breakfast will be available after the show in the theater bar and brasserie.

headline: Embassy Attack in Pakistan Kills at Least 6
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A car bomb exploded outside the Danish Embassy in an upscale area of the Pakistani capital Monday, killing at least six people, according to reports from hospitals.

headline: With a Tiny Bit of Cancer, Debate on How to Proceed
text: In a cancer patient, lymph nodes are the closest thing to a crystal ball. Gaze into them after removing a tumor. The presence of malignant cells may be a sign that the cancer will recur, leading to more tests and intensive treatment.

headline: Noninfectious Illnesses Are Expected to Become Top Killers
text: As the world’s population ages, gets richer, smokes more, eats more and drives more, noncommunicable diseases will become bigger killers than infectious ones over the next 20 years, the World Health Organization is reporting.

headline: Placebo for Warts (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a plan by Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, to create a charity that would use religion as a force for economic development and conflict resolution described the religion of one of his predecessors, Benjamin Disraeli, incorrectly. Although Mr. Disraeli was of Italian-Jewish descent, he was baptized and practiced in the Church of England; he was not an exception to the tradition of prime ministers belonging to that church.

headline: Study Finds State Gains in Insurance
text: Massachusetts reduced its proportion of uninsured adults by nearly half in the first year of mandatory health coverage and made gains in the share of people receiving routine preventive care, according to the first major study of the 2006 law.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture with an article in some editions on Sunday about a course in Midtown Manhattan for aspiring sommeliers carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The Times photographer who took the picture of students at the Sommelier Society of America is Earl Wilson, not James Estrin.

headline: Despite Land for the Taking, No Cry of Northward Ho
text: SHIBETSU, Japan  “If you build a home and move here, the land is yours free,” read a billboard on the side of a quiet two-lane highway that disappeared straight into the horizon here, under northern Japan’s big sky.

headline: William P. Ford, 72, Rights Advocate, Dies
text: William P. Ford, a former Wall Street lawyer who spent more than two decades seeking to bring high-ranking military officials to justice after his sister and three other American churchwomen were murdered in El Salvador’s civil war in the 1980s, died on Sunday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 72.

headline: Series Taps Rich Vein of N.B.A. History
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Luke Walton and his three brothers might have grown up in San Diego, but when it came to basketball, their father ensured they were raised under the church of shamrock. They were to supplicate before the vision of Larry Bird, they believed in the gospel of Johnny Most, and when they heard the word parquet, they did not think it was butter, but the Boston Garden floor.

headline: William E. Odom, Former Director of N.S.A., Dies at 75
text: WASHINGTON  William E. Odom, a director of the National Security Agency in the Reagan administration who became an early and outspoken opponent of the Iraq war, died Friday at his vacation home in Lincoln, Vt.. He was 75.

headline: The Michigan-Florida Compromise
text: To the Editor:

headline: Court Rules on Money-Laundering
text: WASHINGTON  Humberto Fidel Regalado Cuellar may have been up to no good when he was pulled over in South Texas for driving erratically on July 14, 2004, but he was not guilty of “money-laundering,” the Supreme Court said on Monday in a ruling that could hamper federal prosecutors in illicit-money cases.

headline: This Time, Rumors of Demise May Be True
text: HARTFORD  It was here in the third-floor billiard room where America’s greatest humorist used to hole up when the bustle of his house, and the nursery one flight below, became too great, leaving strict orders not to be disturbed.

headline: Pérez Sleeps Well, but Doesn’t Pitch Well
text: SAN FRANCISCO  After their game Sunday night in New York, the bleary-eyed Mets arrived here at 4:30 a.m. Monday. They pulled into their hotel about an hour later, just as the sun was rising, with Oliver Pérez already ensconced in his bed, enjoying a peaceful night’s sleep.

headline: In a Reverse Rollout, an Indie Film Has Its Premiere in Austin
text: LOS ANGELES  On June 13, Sony Pictures Classics, one of New York’s wilier distributors of independent films, plans to open its little comic thriller “Baghead” with a splash.

headline: Mercantile Library Moves, and Gets a Nudge Into the 21st Century
text: Above an ornate iron staircase, marble busts of past presidents and members watch over the reading room of the Mercantile Library, with its molded fireplace and grand piano. It is an elegant space befitting one of the three private libraries remaining in New York City.

headline: U.S. Reports Gains Against Taliban Fighters
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban forces in southern Afghanistan are fleeing to the Pakistani border after being routed in recent operations by the United States Marines, the American commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan said on Monday.

headline: Corrections
text: A brief article in the Vital Signs column on May 20 about new findings suggesting that aspirin may help lower blood pressure in some patients if taken at night misstated a current treatment guideline for people with hypertension, or high blood pressure. Aspirin is not in fact prescribed to lower blood pressure in people with full-blown hypertension.

headline: The Brain: Caller May Be Out of Sight, but in Mind
text: A study may shed light on why talking on a cellphone appears to make drivers prone to accidents.

headline: 2nd Plea Near in Prostitution Tied to Spitzer
text: A graduate of an elite New Jersey prep school is expected to plead guilty on Tuesday to charges related to running the day-to-day operations of a prostitution ring that authorities say was patronized by, among others, Eliot Spitzer, a person briefed on the case said on Monday.

headline: Pentagon Accounting
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York in Newport
text: “Man on Wire” will kick off the 11th annual Newport International Film Festival when it opens Tuesday in Newport, R.I. The film, directed by James Marsh, explores Philippe Petit’s high-wire routine between the twin towers of the World Trade Center on Aug. 7, 1974. It picked up a prize for best documentary at the Sundance Film Festival this year. Mr. Petit, who will be on hand for the screening, walked between the buildings eight times in 45 minutes. This year’s films, more than 100 in all, are almost evenly divided between feature-length documentaries and narrative films, with four programs of shorts. They include a celebration of the life of the Italian actress Anna Magnani  who would have turned 100 this year  with a screening of “The Rose Tattoo,” for which she won an Oscar in 1956. The festival runs through Sunday. More information can be found at newportfilmfestival.com.

headline: In 3rd Overtime, Penguins Stay Alive
text: DETROIT  With the Stanley Cup only 34.3 seconds from being presented to the Detroit Red Wings, the Penguins staved off elimination with a stunning goal by forward Maxime Talbot and won the game, 4-3, in triple overtime on a goal by Petr Sykora at 12:47 Tuesday morning at Joe Louis Arena.

headline: Officials Criticize Mugabe’s Presence at a U.N. Conference in Rome
text: ROME  Skirting some restrictions on his international travel, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe arrived in Rome over the weekend to attend a United Nations food conference, and raised protests on Monday from some European and other officials.

headline: At Small Tracks, High Fuel Prices Put Racers in a Pinch
text: NEW EGYPT, N.J.  The cost of high-octane fuel for the racecars is up to $8.25 a gallon. And that is not the worst of it.

headline: As Clinton Campaign Winds Down, a Spouse Remains Wound Up
text: MILBANK, S.D.  Former President Bill Clinton took the microphone here on Monday and began with a lament that it might be his last day as a campaigner.

headline: 60-Year-Old Bias in Data on Sea Temperatures
text: Every scientist knows about measurement bias, the systematic errors that can creep into data. A simplistic example would be a metal ruler that gives inaccurate readings when it expands in warmer temperatures.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with a front-page article about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s victory in Puerto Rico’s primary on Sunday misidentified the location of the Corn Palace, where Barack Obama campaigned the same day. It is in Mitchell, S.D., not Sioux City. (There is a North Sioux City and a Sioux Falls in South Dakota.)

headline: Iran: Court Sentences 3 to Death
text: Iran’s judiciary has sentenced to death a Kurdish teacher, Farzad Kamangar, and two other people on charges of being members of the Kurdish Workers’ Party, an armed opposition group that has led an insurgency against Turkey. Mr. Kamangar and those sentenced with him have appealed the verdict. According to Iran’s penal code, armed opposition against the government is punishable by death.

headline: The Dress Is in Chicago, but Lou Lou’s With Me
text: THOUGH I’m a fashion designer, I never stuff my luggage with too many items. But like many people, I like to travel with a companion. In my case, it’s my 6-year-old Maltese, Lou Lou. She is a great traveler and loves exploring hotels in Paris and other exotic locales.

headline: McCain Attacks Obama as Too Easy on Iran
text: WASHINGTON  As the bitter Democratic nomination battle continued to be bogged down in rancorous maneuverings to the very end, Senator John McCain honed his national security message before Jewish-American leaders, charging on Monday that Senator Barack Obama’s policies toward Iraq and Iran would create chaos and endanger the United States and Israel.

headline: Ending in Main Event Raises Fans’ Suspicions
text: More than 8,000 fans headed to Prudential Center in Newark on Saturday to witness a milestone for mixed martial arts: a series of fights shown on live network television in prime time.

headline: City’s Leading Choice to Run Downtown Heliport Puts a Former City Official in Charge
text: The company that New York City chose to operate a heliport near Wall Street revealed on Monday that it would place a former city official in charge of the facility, despite criticism that it was getting the contract through political connections.

headline: Canada: Supreme Court to Hear Bell Case
text: The Supreme Court of Canada said it would hear an appeal from Bell Canada that will very likely determine the fate of a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company. Last month the Court of Appeal of Quebec blocked the buyout, ruling that Bell’s directors had not adequately considered the interests of current bondholders when they agreed to sell the company to a group led by the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan. Since the takeover agreement expires at the end of this month, the court set June 17 as a hearing date.

headline: It Isn’t Magic: Putin Opponents Vanish From TV
text: MOSCOW  On a talk show last fall, a prominent political analyst named Mikhail G. Delyagin had some tart words about Vladimir V. Putin. When the program was later televised, Mr. Delyagin was not.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors to Visit Syria
text: Syria will let nuclear inspectors visit the site of a suspected reactor that Israeli warplanes bombed last September, the International Atomic Energy Agency said Monday. The visit, to a desolate spot on the Euphrates River some 90 miles north of the Iraqi border, is to take place June 22 to 24.

headline: Justices Narrow Money-Laundering Law
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court narrowed the application of the federal money-laundering statute on Monday, ruling for criminal defendants in two cases in which prosecutors had employed broad definitions of two of the law’s major provisions.

headline: Value of Meditation (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Commodity Regulators Vow Stricter Oversight
text: Regulators of the nation’s commodity markets will demand more information about investors to determine whether they are evading market limits on speculation and artificially driving up world food prices.

headline: Where Illegal Guns Can Do No More Harm
text: In New York City, where taking illegal handguns off the streets is high on the mayor’s agenda, thousands of firearms make it into the hands of law enforcement officers each year.

headline: Iraqi Premier May Discuss Allegations in Iran Visit
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, has scheduled a visit to Iran later this week and is expected to broach a subject high on the agenda of American commanders here: the allegation that Iran is supporting the insurgency in Iraq with men and weapons.

headline: Czech Republic: Airport Operator for Sale
text: The Czech government agreed to sell Letiste Praha, operator of the Prague airport, to raise at least 100 billion koruna ($6.2 billion) for the state budget. The government ordered the Finance Ministry to call a tender for an adviser, Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek said.

headline: Perils of Gene Testing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kurt Cobain’s Ashes Were Stolen, Courtney Love Says
text: The ashes of Kurt Cobain were stolen from the Hollywood home of his widow, Courtney Love, The Guardian of London reported. Ms. Love, left, told authorities that the ashes had recently been stolen from a heart-shaped handbag in a secret hiding place in a wardrobe. She said that she was suicidal as a result of the theft, The Guardian reported, and that the ashes had been taken by an acquaintance. “I can’t believe anyone would take Kurt’s ashes from me,” she said. “If I don’t get them back I don’t know what I will do.” Most of the ashes of Cobain, the lead singer and songwriter for Nirvana, were scattered at a New York Buddhist temple and in the Wishkah River near Aberdeen, Wash., where he lived as a boy. He committed suicide in 1994.

headline: The Great Immigration Panic
text: Someday, the country will recognize the true cost of its war on illegal immigration. We don’t mean dollars, though those are being squandered by the billions. The true cost is to the national identity: the sense of who we are and what we value. It will hit us once the enforcement fever breaks, when we look at what has been done and no longer recognize the country that did it.

headline: Real MTV Film Awards, but Fake Dope
text: Seth Rogen and James Franco play stoners in the coming film “Pineapple Express,” and they reprised their roles at the MTV Movie Awards on Sunday night: they pulled out a bag of fake marijuana onstage, then Mr. Rogen lighted a fake joint and Mr. Franco puffed on it. “Kids don’t really smoke fake weed like this,” Mr. Rogen, above with glasses, told the crowd at the Gibson Amphitheater in Los Angeles, where they were presenting the award for the best summer movie so far. Before television viewers could get a closer look at what was real and what was not, the camera moved to a wide angle and stayed that way until Mr. Rogen and Mr. Franco left the stage, The Associated Press reported. It was an awkward moment that made some in the audience laugh. Backstage, Mr. Franco told The Associated Press that MTV had put them up to the joke  supplying the script as well as the fake pot and joint  and then had a last-second change of heart.

headline: An Overflowing Five-Day Banquet of Science and Its Meanings
text: It was on Friday evening, about 7 o’clock, that I began to wonder whether I would wind up hating Brian Greene and Tracy Day.

headline: The Extremist’s Paradox
text: To the Editor:

headline: McCain Sharpens His Foreign Policy Attacks on Obama
text: NASHVILLE  As the bitter Democratic presidential nomination battle was consumed by rancorous maneuverings, Senator John McCain honed his national security message before Jewish leaders on Monday, saying Senator Barack Obama’s policies toward Iraq and Iran would create chaos in the Middle East and endanger the United States and Israel.

headline: Kennedy’s Surgery for Tumor Called Success
text: Senator Edward M. Kennedy successfully underwent surgery on Monday in Durham, N.C., for a malignant brain tumor, his surgeon said.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 87 Louisiana-Monroe
text: Location: Monroe, La.

headline: Behind the Money Behind Big Brown
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Joe Drape introduces James Tagliaferri, the little-known owner of the asset-management company TAG Virgin Islands, which supplied the real money behind Big Brown and International Equine Acquisitions Holdings.

headline: It’s Been a Long Time Running
text: Just as the seasons came and went so did the primaries, and with them, one by one, the candidates. Except three.

headline: Salad Olivier
text: My mother has always removed her shoes under the table, placed her feet on top of them, and entertained herself by curling and uncurling her toes. Aunt Masha liked to scratch her ankles with her stiletto heels. Uncle Boris stomped his right foot when he argued. "I insist!" he would say, and his hard leather heel went boom! against the linoleum floor. My father's feet weren't particularly funny, except when he wore mismatched socks, as he often did.

headline: The CFDA Awards
text: Photos from the annual CFDA awards held at the New York Public Library.

headline: Does Evolution Go Fast-Forward?
text: Does this graph help explain why you could soon live forever? That’s one theory, but let’s start out with a simpler question to debate: Is it evidence that life and technology evolve at a predictable pace – faster and faster?

headline: Bill Clinton’s Campaign Gone By
text: As the primary season draws to a close, an inveterate campaigner's days on the trail could be coming to an end as well.

headline: I’M NOT YELLING — I JUST TYPE THIS WAY
text: From a mock missive (found here):

headline: The Grand Tour: Paris
To the Swift: Red Smith on Alydar
text: The following column, “He Was Named for Aly, Darling,” by Red Smith, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist, appeared in The New York Times on March 24, 1978, and is from “To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory” (St. Martin’s Press), edited by Joe Drape.

headline: Alimna Jumps 80 Percent in First Day of Trading
text: Alinma Bank, which in April raised $2.8 billion in Saudi Arabia’s biggest initial share sale for five years, jumped as much as 80 percent as it began trading in Riyadh Tuesday.

headline: Arnault Ready to Set Sail With Princess Yachts
text: French billionaire Bernard Arnault is poised to buy Princess Yachts for an estimated 200 million pounds ($393.6 million).

headline: Ford Completes Jaguar, Rover Sale
text: Ford Motor officially completed the sale of its Jaguar and Land Rover businesses Monday.

headline: Survey Says Venture Capitalists Increasingly Looking Abroad
text: Europe and Asia are quietly gaining in clean tech and software venture capital according to a survey released Tuesday by Deloitte and the National Venture Capital Association. Further, nearly three out of every five of U.S. venture capitalists, or 57 percent, are now investing outside the country, compared with 46 percent last year, the survey found.

headline: ‘The Bride’s Dress Was Beautiful’
text: More of your “late night” standup (send via the comment link below):

headline: CBOE Settlement Clears Path to Go Public
text: One billion dollars later, the question of who owns the Chicago Board Options Exchange has been resolved.

headline: U.S. Bancorp Closes Deal for Mellon Unit
text: U.S. Bank National Association, the lead bank of U.S. Bancorp., on Monday completed its acquisition of Mellon 1st Business Bank in California, previously announced in March. According to the deal U.S. Bank acquired $2.9 billion in assets, $1.1 billion in loans, and $2.7 billion in deposits. The companies did not disclose details of the cash deal, The Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal reported.

headline: Vodafone Looking for Bigger Stake in South Africa’s Vodacom
text: Vodafone has offered to buy an additional 12.5 percent stake in the South African mobile phone operator Vodacom, which it jointly owns with Telkom.

headline: Tesco to Buy Back RBS Stake in Joint Venure
text: Tesco is close to announcing a 1 billion pound ($1.97 billion) deal to buy out Royal Bank of Scotland‘s share of its Tesco Personal Finance joint venture.

headline: Mayor Unveils New York City Venture Fund
text: New York City Mayor Michael P. Bloomberg announced the debut of NYC Seed, a venture firm for early-stage technology companies in the city, CNET News.com reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Fret Ahead of Swap Ruling
text: Activist investors may be on the brink of losing a tool that aids in their battles with corporate management — and the hedge fund industry is worried, MarketWatch reported.

headline: Spain’s Banco Bilbao to Double Stake in Citic Group
text: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria will double its stakes in units of China’s state-owned Citic Group for $1.24 billion to increase revenue from the fastest-growing major economy, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Potential Air Canada Sale Could Add to Cerberus Woes
text: With problems at Chrysler and GMAC making headlines in recent months, another Cerberus Capital Management investment is also at an awkward pass.

headline: $500,000 Homes
text: Properties on the market in Connecticut, Iowa and California.

headline: China Merchants Bank Wins Auction for Wing Lung
text: China Merchants Bank, coming from behind in a three-month auction, has agreed to buy 53 percent of Wing Lung Bank, a family-controlled lender in Hong Kong. It will also offer to buy the rest of Wing Lung’s shares at the same price, valuing the bank at $4.66 billion.

headline: Semel’s IMG Plans: Wishful Thinking?
text: Reports surfaced Monday that Terry Semel, the former Yahoo C.E.O. has been eyeing Ted Forstmann’s talent and marketing agency IMG.

headline: Say What?
text: Eighth-grader Sameer Mishra of West Lafayette, Ind., seems poised for Internet stardom — not for winning the 2008 Scripps National Spelling Bee, but for being asked to spell the word “numnah,” and mis-hearing the word (as many people did during the national broadcast):

headline: Cerberus Denies Sales of GMAC, Chrysler Stakes
text: Cerberus Capital Management has denied selling any of its stake in Chrysler or GMAC, a spokesman said on Monday.

headline: Russia-Bank of New York Mellon Suit Brings Out Legal Aces
text: Later this month, the Bank of New York Mellon will battle it out with the Russian Federation over a $22.5 billion money laundering case.

headline: TPG Bets on Another Ailing Lender
text: TPG may hope to profit from consolidation in the banking sector with its recent investment in Bradford & Bingley, a troubled British mortgage lender, some analysts said.

headline: Staples Raises Corporate Express Bid to $2.6 Billion
text: Staples has raised its offer for Corporate Express to 1.67 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after the Dutch company rejected two takeover attempts and agreed to buy a French rival.

headline: Problems Likely to Worsen at Wachovia
text: The ouster of G. Kennedy Thompson as chief executive of Wachovia, announced Monday morning, leaves the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank confronting an uncertain future. Some see Mr. Thompson’s hasty exit as a sign that the troubles at Wachovia – and indeed at many banks – will continue to deepen as credit problems spread.

headline: Bankers Take Refuge Down Under
text: Australia has become a refuge for a new endangered species: the high-flying banker. With layoffs rampant throughout Europe and the U.S., bankers are increasingly looking down under for shelter, according to a report by Reuters.

headline: Lawsuit Criticizes Yahoo Retention Plan
text: Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, pushed for an expensive plan to retain employees in the event of an acquisition by Microsoftdespite reservations of some Yahoo executives and of a consulting firm that Yahoo hired to help devise the plan, according to a shareholder lawsuit.

headline: Grasso’s Grit May Win After All
text: Call it the curse of Dick Grasso.

headline: Cheeky One, That
text: A posting about an unhappy customer at an electronics store in Middlesbrough, England, found on notalwaysright.com (as in, “The customer is not always right”) — a place for service personnel to vent:

headline: Facing Loss, Lehman May Seek Fresh Capital
text: Lehman Brothers may raise billions of dollars of fresh capital, suggesting the investment bank will post its first quarterly loss since going public, The Wall Street Journal said on Tuesday, citing sources familiar with the matter.

headline: John McCain’s Remarks in Louisiana
text: The following is the prepared text of Senator John McCain’s speech to supporters in Kenner, La., after the last day of voting of the 2008 primary season.
