headline: Barack Obama’s Remarks in St. Paul
text: The following a transcript of Senator Barack Obama’s speech to supporters on the last night of voting in the primary campaign, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

headline: Inside Dow’s Rogue Buyout Talks
text: Dow Chemical may have settled a legal dispute over last year’s firing of two former executives, but the legal filings have revealed some juicy details about the unauthorized buyout talks that were at the heart of the controversy.

headline: The Early Word: One Last Tuesday
text: The primary season, which began on the snowy roads of Iowa and New Hampshire six months ago, ends today on the plains of South Dakota and Montana. As voters in both states cast their ballots, The Times’s Adam Nagourney reports that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is preparing to deliver what aides described as a “farewell speech” in New York, clearing the way for Barack Obama to claim the mantle of presumptive Democratic nominee.

headline: ResCap to Sell Assets to GMAC to Stay Afloat
text: Residential Capital said its parent company, GMAC, and GMAC lead investor Cerberus Capital Management agreed to inject $1.43 billion in cash to help keep the distressed mortgage-finance company afloat, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: New Portals Exploring How We Survive Ourselves
text: Here’s a quick roundup of some new and emerging experiments aimed at charting how humanity might head toward a stable, prospering population without too much wreckage along the way.Yale Environment 360, also called e360, is a new online magazine on the environment. It is the brainchild of Gus Speth, the dean of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies and author of a string of books on balancing human advancement and the planet’s limits. Don’t expect a genteel, Ivy League approach. The editor is Roger Cohn, formerly editor in chief of Mother Jones.

headline: G.M. Chief Discusses Plant Closings
text: CNBC coverage of speech by Rick Wagoner, chief executive of G.M., as he discusses company's shift in focus from pickup trucks to cars.

headline: The Highest-Paid Voices on TV?
text: According to The Hollywood Reporter:

headline: 11 Pension Bills, and a $500 Million Tab
text: An actuary paid by public employee unions and yet relied upon by the State Legislature to determine the cost of proposals affecting New York City’s pension system underestimated their ultimate cost by at least $500 million, Danny Hakim reports.

headline: Famous for 40 Years
text: File under “But Mrs. Lincoln, how was the play?” Valerie Solanas, the subject of the 1996 movie “I Shot Andy Warhol,” is remembered these days mostly for, well, shooting Andy Warhol exactly 40 years ago today. But on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times, A.S. Hamrah suggests that Solanas should be remembered as something of a prophet, not just a “failed assassin and crackpot writer.”

headline: Would Newfangled Airport Security Work in New York?
text: When it comes to air travel, are you a green circle, a blue square or a black diamond?

headline: Can Water Shortages in Europe Be Curbed?
text: Water shortages are striking mainland Europe and in particular the Spanish province of Murcia, where prosperity is on the rise but where farmers are fighting with developers over water rights.

headline: Cheney Apologizes to West Virginia
text: As it turns out, even the lighter side of Dick Cheney can prompt major disapproval. As Sheryl Stolberg reported this morning, the vice president elicited a wave of laughter from the National Press Club on Monday by cracking a joke about his extended family, which includes a tie to Senator Barack Obama:

headline: Fashion Designers Honor Their Own
text: WHILE smoking a cigarette outside the New York Public Library on Monday night, at the end of a press line where a modest number of celebrities and large contingent of the American fashion industry were dutifully talking about dresses, Fran Lebowitz, the satirist, was asked what she was wearing.

headline: Another M.V.P. in Philly?
text: Chase Utely seems to be accomplishing everything of late.

headline: Another Voice From Japan
text: Naohiro Goda is a horse racing journalist based in Tokyo with a regular television show on NHK Network, Green Channel and J-Sports. He writes for several publications, including Sports Nippon, netkeiba.com, and Monthly Thoroughbred.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Remarks in New York City
text: The following is a transcript of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s speech to supporters after the last day of voting in the primary season, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

headline: Yahoo’s Tin Parachutes
text: On Thursday, Chancellor William B. Chandler III in the Delaware Court of Chancery unsealed the amended complaint in the Delaware shareholder class action lawsuit filed against Yahoo‘s board. The complaint alleges that Yahoo’s board breached its fiduciary duties by acting to obstruct Microsoft‘s offer to acquire Yahoo.

headline: A 1,900-Foot Concrete Canvas
text: No one will ever mistake Jersey barriers for works of art, but a fledgling effort is under way to make them a bit more aesthetically palatable.

headline: Poetry: Read It When You’re Drunk
text: Books of quotations about writing and writers are things I usually flee from — the sanctimony level grows toxic almost immediately.

headline: Bears Latch Onto Lehman
text: The Lehman Brothers galleon hasn’t run aground, but it looks like it has entered some shallow waters. At least, that is the feeling coming from Wall Street analysts, who in recent weeks have grown much more pessimistic about the securities firm, which now has the dubious distinction of being the smallest of the major Wall Street investment banks, following the demise of Bear Stearns.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Bitter Greens With Sour-Cream Dressing
text: This incredibly rich dairy-based dressing, found throughout Eastern Europe, is a mix of yolks from hard-cooked eggs, sour cream and lemon — a combination so full-bodied that it makes traditional Caesar dressing look thin.

headline: Ex-N.B.A. Player Urges Athletes in Beijing to Speak Out
text: John Amaechi, the out gay former N.B.A. player and Amnesty International’s first sports ambassador to the Olympic Games, spoke out strongly last weekend in support of the idea that athletes at the Beijing Olympics should not be prevented from expressing their opinions on human rights issues.

headline: To the Batcave, Old Chum, for Some Viral Marketing
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Bernanke Signals Halt to Rate Cuts
text: CNBC coverage of speech by Ben S. Bernanke to an international monetary conference in which he signals renewed inflation concerns.

headline: Belmont News: Tuesday
text: As anticipated Big Brown worked Tuesday morning at Belmont Park. He went five-eighths in one minute. This was his only work between the Preakness and the Belmont.

headline: The High Low | American Eagle Sunglasses, $19.50
text: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant affordable gets. In this column, T’s fashion team rummage for the cheap and the chic.

headline: His Tux? Conventional. Her Gown? Stunning!
text: “My skinny jeans are at the cleaners and my gladiator sandals are being resoled,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg explained, apologetically, on Monday night, when he showed up at a fashion award ceremony wearing what he called “a conventional tuxedo.”

headline: Clyburn Endorses Obama
text: Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina became the first senior member of the House leadership today to formally endorse Senator Barack Obama for president, predicting a flow of superdelegates throughout the day that would put the Illinois senator over the threshold for the nomination as early as tonight.

headline: Ron Kuby To Join Air America Radio
text: Ron Kuby, the liberal-leaning, sometime television analyst who lost his job as co-host of a talk show on WABC radio in New York City at least partly to make room for Don Imus, will return to radio on Monday, on the Air America network.

headline: A New Life in Oak
text: A look at a barn in Bunwell, England, that has been completely renovated into a 1,300-square-foot home.

headline: ‘A Lack of Inquisitiveness’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: In his new book, President Bush’s former press secretary said that Bush has a lack of inquisitiveness. Yeah. When he heard this, Bush said, “I don’t know what he’s saying, and I don’t care.”

headline: ‘Get Ready’
text: Aired Monday night on CBS: Let’s talk about the presidential Democratic primary. Over the weekend, I guess you know this, Hillary Clinton won the Puerto Rican primary, so she is now president of Puerto Rico.

headline: Mine Owner’s Collapse Theory Ruled Out
text: As some reports tell it today, Robert E. Murray merely suggested in August that an earthquake caused the collapse of the coal mine he co-owns at Crandall Canyon, Utah. But his point of view was more like downright insistence that scientists were wrong to say the opposite — that the mine collapse caused the seismological readings.

headline: ‘Looking for a New Church’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Over the weekend, a man named Usain Bolt of Jamaica set a new world record in the 100 meter dash — 9.72 seconds. That broke the old world record of 9.73 seconds set by superdelegates running away from Hillary Clinton.

headline: For the Moment | Peep Show
A Few Less Minutes With Andy Rooney
text: Cue the whiny voice: “Ever wonder whether Andy Rooney would be better if there were less of him?” Well, wonder no more: Joe Mande, a comic, claims on his blog to have invented the “Andy Rooney Game”: simply edit out everything but the first and last sentence of each Rooney “60 Minutes” commentary, then post the result on YouTube. There. That better?

headline: A Bronx ‘Local’ Who Lives in New Rochelle
text: Citizen of the City. The phrase echoes Citizen of the World, which is more or less what it means when the city in question is New York. It is also how the chief marketing officer at NYC & Company, Jane Reiss, described the celebrities in its “Just Ask the Locals” campaign. She described them as “really committed to the city and want to donate their time to the city — they’re passionate about the city.”

headline: Dick Cheney Takes a Shot at West Virginia
text: Vice President Dick Cheney, who is hardly known for his lighthearted banter, showed his humorous side on Monday in a talk at the National Press Club in Washington — at the expense of the people of West Virginia.

headline: D’oh! Homer and Marge Break a Record
text: At the end of next season, “The Simpsons” will be the longest-running series in the history of prime time television.

headline: In Focus | Paolo Roversi
text: (Paolo Roversi)

headline: Answers From Iraqi Women, Part II
text: Video

headline: Governor Embraces Property Tax Cap
text: Gov. David A. Paterson said on Tuesday that he would propose a ceiling on increases to local property taxes, embracing the recommendation of a commission led by the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, that studied the issue. Rising property taxes have been a major complaint of homeowners in the suburbs, upstate and on Long Island.“The property tax cap is a blunt instrument, but it will force us to make hard choices,” the governor said at a news conference. “It will force us to save our state from the peril that looms in our future if we don’t act.”

headline: Chief Executives: The Good and Bad
text: CNBC interviews Joe Nocera, a columnist for The Times, about the wide range of quality that exists among modern chief executives.

headline: Smells of Gaza
text: Nicki Bennett, an aid worker with Oxfam, reports from Gaza, where the dumping of sewage into coastal waters has created a deeply worrying situation — both in terms of pollution and from a humanitarian perspective.

headline: Jane Brody’s New Knees
text: If you’re thinking about knee replacement, don’t miss my colleague Jane Brody’s update on her artificial knees, three years after surgery.

headline: Talking to the Author of ‘Stuffed and Starved’
text: In looking at food, nutrition, and the perverse phenomenon of overnutrition, many of us have had occasion to notice and cite the fact that worldwide, roughly the same number of people are starving as are overweight.

headline: And the Winners Are …
Are Endurance Sports Good For You?
text: 33 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: climbing repeats. Given the constraints of a weekday schedule, this interval training will have to take place on a shorter, less steep slope than those available to New York-area riders on weekends, so I’ll be riding up Harlem Hill in Central Park again and again and again, to work on the muscles needed for going up much more serious climbs in the near future.

headline: Goodwill Hurting: The Coming Write-Downs
text: Chief executives rarely come right out and admit that they massively overpaid in a merger deal. But the accountants have to be a bit more forthcoming.

headline: One Less Olympic Hazard to Worry About: Plastic Bags
text: However much Americans may talk about the air pollution in Beijing as the Olympics draw near, one thing they can’t say is that China lags behind the United States when it comes to the plague of plastic bags that litter the landscape. In fact, on Sunday China surged ahead of the U.S. by instituting a nationwide ban on the production and distribution of ultra-thin plastic bags in an effort to address its growing environmental problem.

headline: ExxonMobil Resumes Its PBS Sponsorship
text: After a four year absence, ExxonMobil will resume sponsorships of PBS programs this month, the public broadcaster announced Tuesday.

headline: In India, Cremations During Protests
text: Almost two weeks of violent protests in the Indian state of Rajasthan showed no sign of stopping today. But the protesting Gujjars, a group of traditionally nomadic shepherds, stopped to cremate at least four of their dead, according to Reuters. More than 40 people have died, many from gunfire from police trying to beat back the demonstrations aimed at getting more government benefits. For more on their struggle, check out Somini Sengupta’s article from last year, “Indian Officials to Rule How ‘Backward’ Group Is.”

headline: Clinton Campaign Confronts A.P. Report
text: In another sign of just how bedeviled the Clinton campaign continues to be, it spent this morning frantically trying to keep news organizations from following an Associated Press report that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will concede tonight that Barack Obama has enough delegates to claim the nomination.

headline: The Morning Skate: Reality Bites the Red Wings
text: It could have been something out of a middling hockey movie, maybe Youngblood or even one of those Mighty Ducks films. But at some point, fiction becomes unnecessary, because nothing a novelist or scriptwriter conjures up can be richer than reality for its uncertainty, drama and heroics.

headline: The Science of Sarcasm
text: Two versions of the same scene used in a scientific study of sarcasm. (Courtesy of Pearson Assessment)

headline: Airport Cat Roundups Resume, as Do Protests
text: After a hiatus of several months, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has started to round up feral cats at Kennedy International Airport again, drawing protests from animal advocacy groups.

headline: Trolling for Trouble in the Red Light District
text: One dark and freakishly stormy night several years ago in San Diego, my car stalled at a flooded intersection. As I pushed the car out of the intersection, lightning was going off all around like flash bulbs. I felt lucky to be able to restart the engine and drive safely home.

headline: Will She or Won’t She?
text: Is it over? The Atlantic’s Marc Ambinder says yes, “the Democratic primary campaign is over.” He expects Hillary Clinton to “acknowledge reality” and “publicly acknowledge that Obama has crossed the threshold” of 2,118 delegates, the number required to secure the nomination.

headline: Recchia Won’t Run for Fossella’s Seat
text: City Councilman Domenic M. Recchia Jr. made official today what many have long suspected. He withdrew from the race for the Congressional seat now held by Vito J. Fossella and endorsed a fellow Democratic councilman, Michael E. McMahon, for the seat.

headline: Turnout Strong in South Dakota and Montana
text: So, we’re about to proceed to report on turnout in South Dakota and Montana, the last primary states. But first, can we just pause for a moment of reflection here? We’re reporting on turnout in the last two primary states, South Dakota and Montana.

headline: Even With Repeats, Fox Leads the Pack
text: Repeats on Fox lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings on Monday, as “House” at 9 p.m. attracted the night’s largest audience, 9.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. While Fox’s “Bones” was the most watched show during the 8 p.m. hour with 6.7 million viewers, it trailed in its time slot among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, June 3:

headline: What in God’s Name is That? Part 4: Hong Kong Sweets
text: When I was a kid growing up in the U.S., my mother, a Hong Konger, bought those plastic molds used for making popsicles. American neighbors taught her to pour in anything sweet, like orange juice or fruit punch, and then putting them in the freezer for a healthy, homemade dessert.

headline: In City’s Rating Game, Your Postcard May Be in the Mail
text: Dear New Yorker: If a postcard from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum lands in your mailbox within the next few weeks, don’t toss it in the recycling bin. Stop and read it. The city really does want to hear you out.Starting next week, the mayor and public advocate will send postcards to 100,000 homes that have been randomly selected to participate in a survey about the quality of city services. The survey will come in the mail in the weeks that follow, in English or in one of three other languages — Russian, Chinese or Spanish — of the recipient’s choice.

headline: The Insider | Ohne Titel
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Alexa Adams and Flora Gill, the designers behind the women’s wear label Ohne Titel, share a few of their stylish essentials. After working for Karl Lagerfeld (Adams also worked for the real Helmut Lang), the two founded Ohne Titel in 2006 and quickly became known for their abstract approach to tailored pantsuits and print dresses. They chose their equally conceptual moniker as an homage, in part, to the artist Anselm Kiefer, who titled many of his paintings “ohne titel” (German for “untitled.”) The East Village-based designers are currently hard at work on their spring collection, which will take place during New York fashion week in September.

headline: Colon Cancer in Family Predicts Better Survival
text: People with a family history of colon cancer carry the emotional burden of knowing they have twice the risk of developing the disease themselves. But now, a new study may ease some of their anxiety. Patients with a family history of colon cancer are also more likely to survive the disease.

headline: An Open-Source Internet Week Brings Open Gripes
text: At Gracie Mansion on Monday night, a bunch of New York’s Internet executives gathered to hear Mayor Michael Bloomberg proclaim the beginning of Internet Week.

headline: Few Things More Frustrating
text: I’ve said many times, too many times, that I like videos of demos and how-tos. But I haven’t been completely honest. While I like these videos in principle, I have never used a single one myself. I didn’t use one to learn how to tie a symmetrical bow, or to make gingerbread, or to rig up a cheap laptop-cooling system. It kept not occurring to me.

headline: At U.N. Food Summit, Let Them Eat Meatballs
text: At international conferences, some of the most important behind-the-scenes maneuvers take place in the kitchen. And the delicate dance is particularly sensitive at this week’s United Nations food summit in Rome, which takes place as the global food crisis continues.

headline: The Democratic Primary: The End Game
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC discusses the beginning of the end of the Democratic race for the presidential nomination.

headline: Lightning Fire Tortorella
text: The Tampa Bay Lightning announced Tuesday John Tortorella will not return next season as the team’s head coach. They have scheduled a news conference for 5 PM today.

headline: The Superdelegate Tally
text: Updated | 10:20 p.m. Five minutes after the polls closed in Montana, the Obama campaign released what might be called a little insurance: a list of 28 superdelegates pledging their support.

headline: 50 Million Visitors a Year Are Expected by 2012
text: Two years ago, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg set the goal of attracting 50 million visitors a year to the city by 2015, it seemed like one of those audacious goals that were all the rage in corporate boardrooms in the 1990s.

headline: My Queen Bee, for Better or Worse
text: In my last entry, you may recall I used smoke in biblical proportions to try to force the queen bee of one of my two hives into the lower, or brood, chambers. That’s where I wanted her to lay her eggs, saving the upper boxes, or supers, for honey collection.

headline: Señor Eriksson, Bienvenido a Concacaf
text: Less than a week after his agent called the rumor “hot air,” and days after being dismissed from Manchester City, Sven Goran Eriksson has a new job. The Swede, and former England manager, will take over as coach of Mexico, according to the Associated Press, after a vote Tuesday by the owners of Mexico’s 18 first-division clubs.

headline: Two Organizations Worth Supporting
text: Coming off exit 26B of the Cross Island Parkway onto Hempstead Turnpike, the looming magnitude of Belmont Park is unavoidable; it’s there in front of you, and then to your left, as you head toward the main gate. It seems to go on forever.

headline: Roman Holiday
text: While the publishing world headed west to L.A. for B.E.A. last week, I headed east — to Italy, for a long-scheduled vacation. While in Rome, where I lived in the late 90s, I did a book-related guest post for Eternallycool.net, the blog about Rome run by my friends Laura Flusche and Susan Sanders, high-end tour guides, teachers and experts in all things Roman, from what’s up with the Palatine excavations to where to find funky sandals.

headline: Pettigrew Agrees to Return His 2000 Gold Medal
text: The American sprinter Antonio Pettigrew has agreed to return the gold medal he won as part of the U.S. 4×400-meter relay team at the 2000 Sydney Olympics after admitting last month that he took EPO and human growth hormone, the Associated Press is reporting.

headline: Hillary’s Last Hope
text: The superhero-delegates:

headline: Lower East Side Art Show Has Pizazz, and Pride
text: The gymnasium at 200 Madison Street, inside the Rutgers Houses Community Center on the Lower East Side, hardly look like a repository of great art. The low-slung, brick-fronted building, part of a public housing complex built in the 1960s, could hardly look more different than the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with its Beaux Arts facade, wide steps and imposing columns.

headline: A Turning Point in Chamberlain’s Career
text: Joba Chamberlain’s long-awaited and much-debated debut as a starting pitcher at the major league level will take place tonight against the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Favorite Reads of ’08 (so Far)
text: A running tally of non-New York Times articles (not a ranking):

headline: Eight Large Eggs, in a Hue of Blue
text: You may say the modern renaissance of New York City is complete: We will be celebrating the beauty of our own sludge tonight when the eight great digester “eggs” of the Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Brooklyn are illuminated with what the designer Hervé Descottes of L’Observatoire International calls a “diaphanous layer of blue light.”

headline: Will Amazon Lose Sales Because It Collects New York Taxes?
text: The comments to our posts about a rule that forced Amazon.com and some other large online stores to collect sales tax on shipments to New York State residents reflect the interest Internet shoppers have in tax policies. Many agreed with a respondent named Michael who said, “And just like that, I stop using Amazon. Pity.”

headline: Cheap Thrills in Beijing: Try Riding a Taxi
text: In Beijing, nothing is as certain as death and taxis. The city is home to 66,000 licensed cabs, five times more than New York City, and you can barely raise your arm without a liveried chariot halting at your feet.

headline: Clinton Open to V.P. Slot, Lawmakers Say
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has told supporters that she would agree to be Senator Barack Obama’s running mate if he offered her the vice presidential spot.

headline: A Fine Whine?  A Fair One?
text: I was out of town for stretches of May, and so I’m still catching up on some of what happened in the world in general, the restaurant world in particular and most especially the world of griping about restaurants.

headline: Hummer to Get Heave Ho?
text: “You know you’ve come full circle when you have Hummer involved in a press conference about energy independence and the environment. The world truly is changing. But here it is: The Hummer HX concept, powered by the extremely capable Flex Fuel V-6 powertrain.”— Mark LaNeve, vice president of sales and marketing for General Motors, at the Detroit auto show.

headline: Getting to Know … Terry Finley
text: Terry Finley is the founder and president of West Point Thoroughbreds, which will run the second-place Preakness finisher Macho Again in the Belmont Stakes. A graduate of West Point, Finley is a former Army Captain and Airborne Ranger. He lives in Mount Laurel, N.J., with his wife, Debbie, the operations manager for the company, and his daughter, Erin, and son, Ryan.

headline: A Toast to Burgundy
text: I’m writing from my hotel room in Paris. My windows are open to the fresh air, and I can hear kids playing basketball and rugby in the schoolyard – I’m surprised each time I visit to see how big rugby is in France: allez les bleus! But the clouds are out and soon it will rain. How do I know this? I arrived in France on May 23 and it has rained every single day since, including the five days I spent in Burgundy.

headline: UrbanEye: Dance Theater Workshop
text: Melena Ryzik reports from the gala benefit for the Dance Theater Workshop.

headline: With Chamberlain, Yankees Heed Cautionary Tale of Mark Prior
text: It’s funny how baseball works sometimes. The Yankees are going to extraordinary lengths to protect the golden arm of Joba Chamberlain, who turns 23 in September. Baseball history is littered with pitchers who threw too many innings too soon in their careers, none more prominent than Mark Prior.

headline: Why Cable Execs Love Warm Weather
text: Cable’s summer season is off to a high-rated start.

headline: UrbanEye: Dance Theater Workshop
text: Melena Ryzik reports from the gala benefit for the Dance Theater Workshop.

headline: The Summer of Our Discontent?
text: One of my favorite things about going to baseball games when I was younger was filling out the All-Star ballots. I would find something sharp, usually my dad’s car key, and punch out those little holes beside players I loved watching. Maybe that’s why Wes Chamberlain got all those votes.

headline: Marcum Has Been There
text: The Blue Jays pitcher Shaun Marcum could identify with Joba Chamberlain.

headline: The Penguins’ Unlikely Hero
text: PITTSBURGH — There were so many fabulous story lines lingering from the Penguins’ amazing Game 5 victory over Detroit to keep the Stanley Cup final alive — I tried to get to most of them in tomorrow’s Times story — but perhaps the most entertaining was forward Maxime Talbot’s role as savior.

headline: Big Brown's Run for the Triple Crown
text: Sports reporter Joe Drape looks ahead to the Belmont Stakes race that could clinch the Triple Crown for Big Brown.

headline: Babcock Expresses His Displeasure
text: PITTSBURGH — Detroit was saying all the right things the day after losing their epic Game 5 after being 34.3 seconds from hoisting the Stanley Cup. They were disappointed but they will bounce back. They have been through this before. They remain confident.

headline: Controversial Priest Ordered to Take a Leave
text: CHICAGO — The priest whose mocking of Hillary Rodham Clinton stirred racially tinged turmoil in the presidential campaign within the last month was asked Tuesday to take a leave from his pastoral work at the parish he has led since 1983.

headline: The Weird Sisters
text: They just keep getting weirder. The "they" I'm referring to are the bdelloid rotifers — small transparent animals that live in damp places such as puddles, or patches of moss. Among evolutionists, these animals have something of a cult following, because they have a lifestyle that is not supposed to exist. As far as anyone can tell, the bdelloid rotifers are ancient asexuals: they appear to have been living entirely without sex for more than 85 million years. And each time we learn more details of their lifestyle, the wackier it becomes.  Evolving to live without sex is easy; all sorts of organisms do it the whole time. For example: aphids, weevils, snails, water fleas, nematode worms, scorpions, even the occasional lizard, have all been known to evolve asexuality. Instead of reproducing via eggs and sperm, asexuals can reproduce in any number of ways. For instance, some bud off a piece of themselves; the piece grows into a whole new animal. The bdelloids, like many other asexuals, reproduce by means of eggs that don't need to be fertilized.   No, evolving asexuality isn't the hard part. The hard part is making an evolutionary success of it.   In the short-term, asexuals seem to have an advantage: they don't have to waste time finding and seducing mates, but can just get on with reproducing. Not having to find a mate makes it easy for asexuals to live in transient habitats, such as puddles, for it doesn't matter if they never encounter anyone else. Moreover, because asexuals only have daughters, their populations can grow rapidly. In a sexual population such as humans, females must have, on average, two children for the population to remain the same size. In an asexual population, females only need to have one. If each female has two, the population grows. Sex, in other words, is expensive.   Yet if you look at the great tree of life, asexual groups tend to be out on the twigs: there are no great branches of the tree that contain only asexuals. In other words, no one can point to a big group, such as birds or fish, or even snails, and say, "That's a group composed only of asexuals." What this means is that asexuality evolves often, but rarely persists for long: asexuals typically go extinct soon after they appear.   The swift extinction of asexuals, and the absence of big asexual groups, suggests that sex is essential for long-term evolutionary success: giving up sex is a Bad Idea, a kind of evolutionary suicide.   Exactly why this is so remains unclear. But it's thought to have something to do with the fact that sex generates new gene combinations. Whereas a sexual creature like you or me inherits a unique mix of genes from our parents, asexuals are lumbered with the same set of genes their mother had. For an asexual, then, the only source of genetic novelty is mutation. (Mutations and sex are both sources of genetic variation, but they work differently. Mutations — accidental changes to DNA — are the ultimate source of genetic novelty. However, mutations tend to be harmful more often than they are helpful: they tend to disrupt genes that are already working. Sex, in contrast, takes pre-existing genetic variation and shuffles it, generating new gene combinations.)   Which brings me to the bdelloids. These animals are the great exception: a group of more than 450 species from which sex is entirely absent. How are they managing to flourish despite this epic period of abstinence? For they do flourish: bdelloids are everywhere. Go outside, collect some damp moss, and stick it under the microscope, and the odds are you'll find some. You can even find them in Antarctica.   One possibility is that they are having sex after all, just very secretly. Certainly, other supposed ancient asexuals turned out to be having sex on the sly. For instance one group of aphids that were thought to be ancient asexuals turned out to be producing males. And genetic evidence has revealed sex in several groups, such as the Placazoa (small animals that live in the sea), that have never actually been seen doing it.  But genetic evidence suggests that the bdelloids are not having conventional sex: their genomes show no sign of it. Instead, they seem to be getting up to something else entirely.   It now looks as though the bdelloids do acquire new genes from time to time — that mutation isn't their only source of genetic novelty. Yet their means of getting new genes is unlike anything previously known for an animal. Namely: they seem to pick up genes from the environment, and add them into their genomes.   The latest analysis of bdelloid genomes shows that the animals don't just have rotifer genes. They also have dozens of genes from bacteria, fungi, and plants. For instance, the genome of the bdelloid rotifer Adineta vaga contains genes that bacteria use for making components of their cell walls. (What the rotifer is using them for is unclear.) Some of the other genes the animal has acquired are known only from a few groups of bacteria and fungi.  Which is seriously weird. Horizontal gene transfer — the technical term for when genes move sideways between distantly-related species — is common among bacteria, but extremely rare in animals. The likely reason for the difference is that bacteria have only one cell, and their genes are not sequestered in a cell nucleus, so adding a new piece of DNA here or there is easy. Animals, in contrast, not only keep their genes away from the rest of the cell, in a cell nucleus. They also have specialized sex cells — eggs and sperm. In order for a gene from a fungus to be permanently added to, say, the human genome, it must somehow get into the sex cells.   No one knows how the bdelloids pick up these genes. One idea is that it may be due to another oddity of their lifestyle: their ability to dry up and blow away. When the piece of moss they are living in dries up, these animals often dry up, too. It's a state of suspended animation — add water and, all being well, they come back to life as frisky, or even friskier, than before. (This isn't unique to bdelloids — some other small animals have evolved to endure desiccation. But most of these others can only do it at particular stages of their lives. The bdelloids can do it at any time. They can also — probably as a consequence of their desiccation abilities — survive high levels of radiation. Much higher than other animals can.) During the drying and rehydration, cell membranes may become disrupted, and their DNA fragmented. Perhaps all this makes it easier for stray bits of foreign DNA to get into the cells that will become eggs.   Some of the bacterial genes were clearly acquired a long time ago. We know this because they have evolved features that bacterial genes lack. Which suggests that getting new genes this way may be rather rare — the sort of thing that happens maybe once every five hundred thousand years or so. All the same, the occasional acquisition of foreign genes may have helped the bdelloids to their profoundly unorthodox success.   But personally, I'm glad that making a go of chastity is so difficult. For the real lesson from these weird sisters is that, for most of us, it's far better to have sex.  **********  NOTES:  The ease of evolving asexuality, and the possible advantages of sex, have been much discussed; see, for example, Bell, G. 1982. "The Masterpiece of Nature: The Evolution and Genetics of Sexuality." University of California Press. For a non-technical account, see chapter 13 of my book, "Dr. Tatiana's Sex Advice to All Creation." Metropolitan Books.  For the number of bdelloid species, see Segers, H. 2007. "Annotated checklist of the rotifers (Phylum Rotifera), with notes on nomenclature, taxonomy, and distribution." Zootaxa 1564: 1-104. For bdelloids in Antarctica, see Izaguirre, I., Allende, L. and Marinone, M. C. 2003. "Comparative study of the planktonic communities of three lakes of contrasting trophic status at Hope Bay (Antarctic Peninsula)." Journal of Plankton Research 25: 1079-1097.  For how genetics gives clues to sexual or asexual lifestyles, and for examples of "asexuals" engaging in sex on the sly, see Normark, B. B., Judson, O. P. and Moran, N. A. 2003. "Genomic signatures of ancient asexual lineages." Biological Journal of the Linnean Society 79: 69-84. For the detection of sex in Placozoa, see Signorovitch, A. Y., Dellaporta, S. L. and Buss, L. W. 2005. "Molecular signatures for sex in the Placozoa." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 102: 15518-15522.  For genetic evidence of the asexuality of bdelloids, see Mark Welch D. and Meselson M. 2000. "Evidence for the evolution of bdelloid rotifers without sexual reproduction or genetic exchange." Science 288:1211-1215; Arkhipova, I. and Meselson, M. 2000. "Transposable elements in sexual and ancient asexual taxa." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 97: 14473-14477; and Barraclough, T. G., Fontaneto, D., Ricci, C. and Herniou, E. A. 2007. "Evidence for inefficient selection against deleterious mutations in cytochrome oxidase I of asexual bdelloid rotifers." Molecular Biology and Evolution 24: 1952-1962.   For horizontal gene transfer in bdelloids (including the hypothesis that their lifestyle somehow facilitates it), see Gladyshev, E. A., Meselson, M. and Arkhipova, I. R. 2008. "Massive horizontal gene transfer in bdelloid rotifers." Science 320: 1210-1213. For their ability to dry up and blow away, see Ricci, C. N. 1987. "Ecology of bdelloids: how to be successful." Hydrobiologia 147:117-127. For their resistance to radiation, see Gladyshev, E. and Meselson, M. 2008. "Extreme resistance of bdelloid rotifers to ionizing radiation." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 105: 5139-5144.  Many thanks to Dan Haydon and Jonathan Swire for insights, comments and suggestions.

headline: The Weird Sisters
text: They just keep getting weirder. The “they” I’m referring to are the bdelloid rotifers — small transparent animals that live in damp places such as puddles, or patches of moss. Among evolutionists, these animals have something of a cult following, because they have a lifestyle that is not supposed to exist. As far as anyone can tell, the bdelloid rotifers are ancient asexuals: they appear to have been living entirely without sex for more than 85 million years. And each time we learn more details of their lifestyle, the wackier it becomes.

headline: Season Finale: TV Networks Note History
text: Chris Matthews and Keith Olbermann on MSNBC.

headline: Season Finale: The Long-Awaited Primary Projection
text: As the Barack Obama campaign rolled out superdelegates one by one on Tuesday, manufacturing momentum for the candidate’s speech, the television networks that help dictate the political mood of the country watched anxiously and at times impatiently. They were waiting until prime time to do what The Associated Press did hours earlier: Call Barack Obama the presumptive Democratic nominee.

headline: Opening Act
text: Wait a minute, John McCain is running for president? Before South Dakota was called for Hillary Clinton and before Montana and the Democratic presidential nomination was called for Barack Obama, John McCain took to the airwaves to remind American voters of his existence. The instant reviews among his supporters at The Corner, the staff blog of National Review, were not good.

headline: Clinton: No Decision

text: Amsterdam-based developer La Perla International Living is opening offices in Toronto and Florida, hoping to generate more activity out of North America for its worldwide projects.

text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks to supporters after the final primaries of the season.

headline: Season Finale: Watched Around The World
text: In the words of the MSNBC anchor Chris Matthews, “in Europe, in Africa, in Cape Town, in Nairobi, everywhere, in Bangladesh, in Asia — this is a huge story.”

headline: Tracing the Arc of Beethoven’s Career in One Night
text: When the school year ends, Mannes College the New School for Music goes into summertime overdrive, offering a back-to-back series of specialized institutes with master classes, lecture demonstrations, seminars and public performances by both faculty members and students. The first is the Mannes Beethoven Institute, now in its eighth year, and in the opening faculty recital on Monday evening the cellist Colin Carr and the pianist Thomas Sauer, who directs the institute, played all five of Beethoven’s cello sonatas.

headline: Sex, Cinema, Marriage and Other Dangerous Activities
text: Sergio Castellitto, the star of “The Wedding Director,” is not what you would call a comedian. His glowering ferocity is currently on display in “The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian,” in which he plays the principal villain with Shakespearean relish. Over the last decade his anxious, melancholy countenance  the difference between mild concern and existential agony can be measured in the angle of his frown  has lent intelligence and gravity to films directed by Jacques Rivette, Marco Bellocchio and Mr. Castellitto himself.

headline: Corrections
text: Obituaries

headline: Property Taxes ’08
text: New York’s homeowners can’t be blamed for wanting relief from today’s heart-stopping property-tax bills. But a new call to cap property taxes for schools is an election-year gimmick that will do far more damage than good. Gov. David Paterson, who endorsed the idea on Tuesday, should take a deep breath and then call for a broader look at ways to make taxes fairer and the state’s contributions to schools more equitable.

headline: Creating a Melody From Fear of Failure
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  At its premiere in 1913, Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring,” an explosive and sometimes violent interpretation of a pagan ritual sacrifice, provoked brawls between its defenders and critics. So it was perhaps appropriate that the question of whether to perform the work became a contentious one for the national youth symphony in this Central Asian country.

headline: In a Crackdown, Zimbabwe Curbs Aid Groups
text: JOHANNESBURG  Hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of Zimbabweans  orphans and old people, the sick and the down and out  have lost access to food and other basic humanitarian assistance as their government has clamped down on international aid groups it says are backing the political opposition, relief agencies say.

headline: As Costs Keep Rising, Restaurateurs Find Creative Ways to Cope
text: At Maple Garden, a Shanghai-style restaurant in Flushing, Queens, rice is no longer served automatically with every meal.

headline: Homemade Sodas Dressed for a Night Out
text: Restaurants are not only making their own bottled water and seltzer, a number of them are also concocting soft drinks with in-house carbonation systems.

headline: On Long Island, a Push to Nurture Biotech Work
text: As dozens of states and municipalities across the country pass initiatives to develop office space for biotechnology businesses, Long Island has, in fits and starts, been working to attract start-up life sciences companies.

headline: Pride of Youngstown: A ‘Ghost’ Who Didn’t Vanish
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  Called the Ghost early in his career for his ability to make opponents swing and miss, Kelly Pavlik, this city’s favorite son, has developed into a relentless power puncher with an iron chin. But still, he cannot shake the nickname, which now applies more to his complexion than to the straight-ahead, proficient fighter he has become.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Monday about a project by the artist Olafur Eliasson to create four waterfalls in New York City misstated his age. He is 41, not 47.

headline: Another Conviction for Brigitte Bardot
text: A Paris court on Tuesday found Brigitte Bardot, right, guilty of provoking discrimination and racial hatred for writing that Muslims are destroying France, The Associated Press reported. It was her fifth conviction for inciting racial hatred. Ms. Bardot, the film star turned animal rights campaigner, was also fined $23,325 and ordered to pay $1,555 to the French group Movement Against Racism and for Friendship of People. The group filed a lawsuit last year over a letter Ms. Bardot sent in December 2006 to Nicolas Sarkozy, then the interior minister and now the president of France. In that letter, published in her animal rights foundation’s journal, Ms. Bardot said that France was “tired of being led by the nose by this population that is destroying us, destroying our country by imposing its acts.” She was referring to the Muslim feast of Aid el-Kebir, which is celebrated by slaughtering sheep.

headline: New Restaurants for Families and Burger Lovers
text: NEW PLACES

headline: China Moves Quickly in Drug Mystery
text: HONG KONG  The deaths of six hospital patients who received a blood-based drug at a hospital in the south-central Chinese province of Jiangxi have prompted an unusually swift and vigorous response from Chinese regulators, the first sign that the government may be following through on promises of tighter scrutiny of the pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Paul Sills, a Guru of Improv Theater, Dies at 80
text: Paul Sills, a founder of the Second City theater company and the godfather of modern improvisational sketch comedy, died on Monday in Sturgeon Bay, Wis. He was 80.

headline: Ambac Writes Little New Business
text: The Ambac Financial Group, the bond insurer, is writing minimal new business as it seeks to restore market confidence and stabilize its credit rating, its chief executive, Michael A. Callen, said.

headline: Improved Accessibility for Spy Museum
text: The Justice Department and the International Spy Museum have reached a settlement to bring the museum into compliance with the Americans With Disabilities Act, making its exhibitions and public programs more accessible to people with impaired hearing and vision, the department said on Tuesday. The museum will begin offering tactile maps and floor plans, as well as tours with a docent to talk about the visual presentations and exhibits. Since opening in 2002, the private International Spy Museum has been a popular attraction in Washington.

headline: Gates Approves of 3-Year Tours for U.S. Troops in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Tuesday that he supported extending the tours of thousands of troops stationed here to three years and allowing their spouses and children to live with them during their assignments.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,080 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Bloomberg Is Said to Explore a Third Mayoral Term or a Bid for Governor
text: As the end of his term nears, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his senior advisers have been exploring strategies that would allow him to remain in political life, including undertaking a campaign to overturn the city’s term limits law or making a bid for governor, according to two people who have been briefed on the deliberations.

headline: Claiming Lack of Evidence, Astor’s Son Seeks Dismissal of Fraud Case
text: Brooke Astor was generous with her only son, Anthony D. Marshall, but prosecutors mistook her motherly largess for a scheme by him and one of Mrs. Astor’s lawyers to swindle her, defense lawyers for the two men said on Tuesday as they asked a judge to throw out the criminal case.

headline: Revived Penguins Smile Through the Pain
text: PITTSBURGH  When the Penguins arrived at Mellon Arena for a meeting Tuesday morning, their incredulous smiles had not faded in the hours since their season-saving victory over the Detroit Red Wings in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals. Neither had their bruises.

headline: Briton Admits to Plot to Set Off Explosives at Heathrow Airport
text: LONDON  A British man accused of leading a plot to blow up as many as seven trans-Atlantic airliners on a single day in 2006 said in a London court on Tuesday that he had planned to set off one or two explosive devices at Heathrow Airport, but that he had never intended to place them on aircraft.

headline: Recipe Deal Breakers: When Step 2 Is ‘Corral Pig’
text: I WAS reading a recipe for apple strudel when I came to a sentence that stopped me cold: “If you don’t have a helper,” it began.

headline: Cardinal Tells Priest Who Mocked Clinton to Take a Leave and ‘Reflect’
text: CHICAGO  The priest whose mocking of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton stirred more racially tinged controversy in the presidential campaign was effectively placed on leave from his pastoral work Tuesday at the Roman Catholic parish he has led since 1983.

headline: Next on Agenda Is Clinton’s Role
text: Senator Barack Obama heads into the general election with obvious advantages: He is a Democratic candidate running in a sour atmosphere for Republicans, in a contest where voters are hungry for change and coming out of a campaign in which he filled arena after arena with supporters.

headline: Parody and Innuendo Are Out, Artistry Is in for a Music Channel
text: WHEN it comes to music-oriented television networks, MTV and VH1 are the mainstream Hertz-and-Avis, Coke-and-Pepsi pairing that comes to mind.

text: Can two of Hollywood’s most innovative executives help MSN become a player in advertiser-supported entertainment on the Web? MSN, the Microsoft portal, is betting millions of dollars that the answer is yes.

headline: Mexican Olive Oil: Ensenada to Fairway
text: This extra virgin olive oil, Fairway’s house brand Mexican Mission, made entirely from Mission olives on a small estate near Ensenada in Baja California, is about as subtle as a mariachi band. It is sunny, fairly viscous and green, with substantial olive and sage flavors.

text: HONG KONG  The powerful earthquake that devastated southwestern China three weeks ago seems to have had only a limited effect on China’s overall economy.

text: IF a hope chest bloomed into a restaurant, Elettaria might be the outcome.

headline: Vote Lets Grand Prix Boss Keep Job, Despite Scandal

headline: Toasting the Joys of Imbibing Properly
text: Got a hangover? Search Google, and you’ll find a thousand home remedies, from mild palliatives (buttermilk, honey, bananas) to shock therapy (pickle juice, kudzu extract, raw cabbage). If you can drag yourself into Walgreens or Rite Aid, there’s usually a potion or two that promises relief.

headline: CORRECTIONS

headline: Thousands Arrested in Bangladesh Anti-Crime Sweep
text: NEW DELHI  The army-backed caretaker government in Bangladesh that has netted hundreds of politicians and business people in a year-long anti-corruption drive has now rounded up nearly 12,000 people in what it calls a crusade against crime.

headline: Mexico at the Brink
text: The War on Drugs may be fading from memory north of the Rio Grande, but south of the river, bloody battles are threatening to overwhelm Mexico’s democratically elected government. The timid assistance package proposed by the Bush administration and pared down by Congress suggests that Washington doesn’t grasp either the scale of the danger or its own responsibilities.

headline: French Rotisserie Joins the Midtown Takeout Rotation
text: Midtown options for lunch and takeout just improved with the opening of a rotisserie and boulangerie on one side of the new Brasserie Cognac de Monsieur Ballon, 1740 Broadway (55th Street). Organic chicken stuffed with herbs and lemon, $13.95 whole or $7.95 half, was satisfying, well flavored and moist. It comes with a little green salad. The shop’s other items, all made in-house, include breads and croissants, $1.95 to $9; sandwiches, $5.95 to $6.95; a proper salade niçoise, $6.99; and pastries like fruit and lemon meringue tartlets, $4.95. The store opens at 7:30 a.m. Monday through Friday and 8 a.m. Saturday and Sunday, and closes at 10 every night; (212) 757-3600.

headline: New Life, New Name and a New Chef for Montrachet
text: IT hasn’t been the best kept secret, but it has kept the New York restaurant world wondering for two years: What is Drew Nieporent going to do with to Montrachet, the restaurant that helped recast dining in the city?

headline: Prado Gets to Play the Spoiler Once Again
text: Edgar Prado is pretty good at preventing history from being made. Twice he has been the winning rider aboard horses that thwarted Triple Crown bids; first when Sarava beat War Emblem in 2002, and two years later when Birdstone defeated Smarty Jones. He will try to do the same Saturday, and this time he will have some extra motivation.

headline: Alton Kelley, 67, Artist of the 1960s Rock Counterculture, Dies

text: Text messages are zipping this way and that, suffusing the suburban airwaves with digital indignation.

headline: Senator Warns of a ‘Crisis’ in Pentagon Cost Overruns
text: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday declared that cost overruns for Defense Department weapons had “reached crisis proportions,” after government auditors reported that the projected final cost of the Pentagon’s major programs had ballooned $295 billion over initial budget estimates.

text: Five days after “Entertainment Tonight” reported that Angelina Jolie had given birth to twins, it is starting to look more and more as if the syndicated show  which is on every weeknight, primarily on CBS affiliates  made a serious mistake.

headline: G.M. Shifts Focus to Small Cars in Sign of Sport Utility Demise
text: DETROIT  Even General Motors, the steadfast champion of big sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, is thinking small now.

headline: Former Referee Cooperated, Prosecutors Say in Letter
text: Federal prosecutors tacitly vouched for the credibility and candor of Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, in a letter filed in federal court last month. The government also stated explicitly, for the first time, that Donaghy did not intentionally make calls to affect the outcome of games.

headline: Museums Set Stricter Guidelines for Acquiring Antiquities
text: After a year and half of deliberations, the directors of the country’s largest art museums will announce new guidelines on Wednesday for how their institutions should collect antiquities, a volatile issue that has led in recent years to international cultural skirmishes and several highly publicized art restitution cases.

headline: Maryland: Threats on Immigrant Group
text: A well-known immigrant advocacy organization based in Silver Spring said it had received a string of anonymous telephone messages threatening violence. The Rev. Simón Bautista, vice president of the board of the group, CASA de Maryland, said a message was left Sunday, May 18, on an office phone warning that he could have a “bullet in the back” of his brain, while a bomb threat was left the same day on the cellphone of Mario Quiroz, the group’s spokesman. The group, which runs several centers for immigrant day laborers in Maryland, frequently receives hostile calls and e-mail, Mr. Quiroz said, but threats of violence are unusual. Maryland police and the F.B.I. said they were investigating the calls.

headline: Celebrated Rivalry Has Its Roots in ’62 Finals
text: Before the confetti fell at Staples Center last Thursday, a chant swept through the arena: “We want Boston!” One night later, 2,986 miles to the east, the response came booming back: “Beat L.A.!”

headline: Fledgling Dancers, Already Fluent in Two Languages: Balanchine and Robbins
text: In 1941, just seven years after he helped found the School of American Ballet with Lincoln Kirstein, George Balanchine choreographed a work whose opening position and opening step seem to delineate specifically American qualities of ballet schooling. When the school danced this classic over the weekend, it was performed with a freshness that made it look as if nobody had ever danced it before.

headline: Defense to Have a Turn in R. Kelly Trial
text: The defense begins presenting its case on Wednesday in the R. Kelly child pornography trial in Chicago, after testimony by a woman who said she had had several three-way sexual encounters with Mr. Kelly and an allegedly under-age victim. The prosecution witness, Lisa Van Allen, 27, told jurors on Monday that Mr. Kelly, the R&B star, offered her $250,000 last year to recover a tape of one of the trysts, The Associated Press reported. She denied a defense lawyer’s accusation that she was trying to extort money, but admitted stealing his $20,000 diamond-studded watch. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to charges of videotaping himself having sex with a girl who prosecutors say was as young as 13. On Tuesday, the judge, Vincent Gaughan, issued a new order for a Chicago Sun-Times reporter to appear in court. The reporter, Jim DeRogatis, who was sent the tape in question, has argued that his actions are protected under the First Amendment.

headline: Sampling Imported Fare (and a Bit of Badminton)
text: When Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was founded in 2003, the company, financed by the Wal-Mart heiress Nancy Laurie, was a punch line: Which troupe has all the money and no artistic reason for being?

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An obituary on Saturday about the film and television composer Alexander Courage, who wrote the “Star Trek” theme, misidentified the studios that produced two of the movies for which he orchestrated and arranged music. “Guys and Dolls” was a Samuel Goldwyn production distributed by MGM; it was not an MGM production. “Funny Face” was made by Paramount, not MGM.

headline: No Films Appear Permanently Lost in Fire at Universal Lot
text: LOS ANGELES  The flames at Universal Studios last weekend may disrupt viewing plans for some film buffs in the coming weeks, though no movies appear to have been lost forever, studio executives said in response to queries on Wednesday.

headline: Protests Strain Thai Coalition and Put Focus on Deadlock
text: BANGKOK  Only five months after national elections ended military rule here, a week of street protests has weakened the coalition government and highlighted Thailand’s failure to move beyond the stalemate that has frozen politics for more than two years.

headline: Opponents of Evolution Adopting a New Strategy
text: DALLAS  Opponents of teaching evolution, in a natural selection of sorts, have gradually shed those strategies that have not survived the courts. Over the last decade, creationism has given rise to “creation science,” which became “intelligent design,” which in 2005 was banned from the public school curriculum in Pennsylvania by a federal judge.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about plans by the Alliance Defense Fund, a conservative Christian group, to sue Gov. David A. Paterson to block his directive to New York State agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere used an erroneous title for James C. Dobson, one of the founders of the group. Dr. Dobson holds a doctorate in child development but is not an ordained minister, and so he is not “the Rev.” James Dobson.

headline: Emotion-Tinged Testimony Against Union Officials
text: The tears flowing from Sean J. Richard’s eyes in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday seemed hardly indicative of the man he once was.

headline: Spice-Roasted Cornish Hens With Spring Garlic Jus
text: Adapted from Fabienne Escoffier, Ma Cuisine, Beaune, France

headline: DNA Test Offers Inmate a Chance at Freedom After 16 ½ Years
text: Ten feet away, Everton Wagstaffe stopped. He was on his way to a meeting, but first, everything in his possession would be searched. This is life behind bars on Monday morning at the Greene Correctional Center in Coxsackie, N.Y. He handed a mesh sack of papers to a correction officer, then waited without a blink of impatience.

headline: Surviving Colon Cancer Is Tied to Family History of It
text: People with a family history of colon cancer carry the emotional burden of knowing they have twice the risk of developing the disease themselves. But a new study may ease some of their anxiety. Patients with a family history of colon cancer, the researchers found, are also more likely to survive it.

headline: Big Vehicles Stagger Under the Weight of $4 Gas
text: A fully loaded Ford F-250 pickup truck is a whole lot of vehicle. It can tow a horse trailer with multiple horses. It comes with a DVD-based navigation system for the driver as well as a DVD player for passengers who are sitting in the extended cab.

headline: Obama Looks to Recruit Clinton’s Top Fund-Raisers
text: As Senator Barack Obama edges closer to the Democratic presidential nomination, his campaign is gearing up to recruit many of Senator Hillary Clinton’s top fund-raisers, a move that could provide him with a huge infusion of cash if he wins the party’s nod and the two camps can get past the rancor of the primary season.

headline: Union Takes Anti-Buyout Campaign Worldwide
text: It started with faux billionaires in the Hamptons and a fat-cat tycoon (or at least an actor wearing a cat mask) in Washington. Now, a union-led campaign against wealthy private equity firms is going global.

headline: Cigarette Tax Arrives Amid Grumbling and Vows
text: Fear of a dreaded disease has been part of the bargain for years. Shame came slower, as smokers were cast from offices, restaurants and even bars. Now, in New York City, there is yet another scary side effect to smoking: empty pockets.

headline: Nadal Gets a Cakewalk on His 22nd Birthday
text: PARIS  With the matches turning into mismatches on a clammy, dreary day at the French Open, the consolation was the future.

headline: Long Island Publisher Buys the Riverdale Press
text: The Riverdale Press, the small Bronx weekly with an outsize reputation for serious journalism, was sold on Tuesday to a Long Island publisher after 58 years as the personal project of two generations of one family.

headline: Contractors Consider Ways to Make Cranes Safer
text: In the wake of last week’s deadly crane collapse, some of the city’s largest general contractors are considering whether to hire their own third-party inspectors to ensure the safety of the tower cranes used at their construction sites.

headline: Nuclear Cleanup Could Derail an Experimental Cancer Treatment, Study Says
text: WASHINGTON  A cleanup of nuclear waste from the cold war era threatens to eliminate the supply of an obscure isotope that shows great promise in cancer treatments, according to a report by the Energy Department’s inspector general.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about William P. Ford, who spent decades pursuing justice after his sister and three other American churchwomen were murdered in El Salvador, misidentified the religious order of one of the slain women, Dorothy Kazel. She was an Ursuline sister, not a Maryknoll sister.

headline: A Reality Competition Shows a Few Wrinkles
text: “She’s Got the Look” demonstrates a lack of progress on two fronts: feminism and, more crucial to the show’s future, development of the reality-competition format.

headline: In Charting Its Future, City Opera Chooses an Adventurous Path
text: The most vibrant performing arts institutions strive to find a balance between hewing to a historic mission and branching into new territory. If done right, which usually means gradually, adventurous initiatives and dynamic change can be not just artistically enriching but smart business as well.

headline: A.M.D. Set to Introduce a New Chip for Laptops
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Eager to declare its troubles behind it, the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices is ready for a new turf war with its rival, Intel.

text: June 3, 2008
