headline: Museum Acquires Modernist House
text: The nonprofit MAK Center for Art and Architecture in Los Angeles has acquired R. M. Schindler’s renowned Modernist Fitzpatrick-Leland House, shown above when it was built in 1936, perched on a cliff near the intersection of Laurel Canyon Boulevard and Mulholland Drive, the center said. The three-level L-shaped house, with its interlocking volumes, was a gift from Russ Leland, who bought it in 1990 and spent years restoring it to its original design. The MAK Center said the house would be used for its new Urban Future Initiative program, which grants two-month residencies to researchers from around the world exploring urban issues like sustainability, immigration and social justice.

headline: Chief Cleric Says Iran Doesn’t Seek Nuclear Arms
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s supreme religious leader vowed Tuesday that his country would pursue a peaceful atomic energy program and had no interest in nuclear weapons, calling them expensive and useless.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An obituary on Monday about the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent misspelled the name of a company that at one point owned his haute couture house, the House of Saint Laurent. It is Squibb-Beechnut, not Squibb-Beach Nut.

headline: Mourners Gather to Honor a Crane Operator’s Life, Full but All Too Brief
text: The embraces thumped and cracked with slaps on the back instead of words, and then it was time.

headline: Her Killer Meatballs Are the Stuff of Fiction
text: CANNED peas and boiled bologna, Lara Vapnyar says, is a dish she has missed since arriving in Brooklyn from Moscow in 1994. “We also ate a lot of black caviar,” she said last week. “But I don’t feel nostalgic for that.”

headline: Sexual Assault of Soldiers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rice Calls Dialogue With Iran Pointless
text: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice escalated the Bush administration’s anti-Iran rhetoric on Tuesday, accusing its government of pursuing nuclear weapons and calling any dialogue with its leaders pointless until they suspend the country’s enrichment of uranium.

headline: Myanmar: Navy Aid Ships to Leave
text: The Pentagon’s Pacific Command announced that Navy ships off the coast of Myanmar ready to offer assistance for cyclone victims would leave Thursday because the ruling junta had not approved. “Over the past three weeks we have made at least 15 attempts to convince the Burmese government to allow our ships, helicopters and landing craft to provide additional disaster relief for the people of Burma, but they have refused us each and every time,” said Adm. Timothy J. Keating, commander of American forces in the Pacific. The four-ship Essex group can produce fresh water from seawater, has medical facilities on board and landing craft and helicopters that can ferry personnel and supplies to remote locations. Admiral Keating said the ships and marines on board could still offer assistance “should the Burmese rulers have a change of heart.”

headline: Beijing Suspends Licenses of 2 Lawyers Who Offered to Defend Tibetans in Court
text: BEIJING  Two prominent human rights lawyers have lost their licenses after volunteering to defend Tibetans charged in the violent anti-China protests that erupted in March. The decision comes as Chinese authorities are tightening scrutiny over dissidents in advance of the Olympics in August.

headline: Bo Diddley’s Legacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Science of Denial
text: The Bush administration has worked overtime to manipulate or conceal scientific evidence  and muzzled at least one prominent scientist  to justify its failure to address climate change.

headline: Newest Yankee Just Tries to Blend In
text: Dan Giese had never been to Yankee Stadium before Tuesday, when he showed up five and a half hours before game time. Giese wanted to see the sights, and he noticed a group taking a tour of the ballpark. He tagged along a few feet behind, careful not to step out of line.

headline: Rating Firms Seem Near Legal Deal on Reforms
text: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general to reform some of their core business practices, according to people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Clinton Donor Base Is Obama’s Next Prize
text: As Senator Barack Obama claims the Democratic presidential nomination, his campaign is gearing up to recruit many of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s top fund-raisers, a move that could provide him with a huge infusion of cash if the two camps can get past the rancor of the primary season.

headline: New Job at Met Opera
text: Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Opera’s general manager, has added a member to his brain trust. Lesley Koenig will become assistant manager for production starting Aug. 1. She will oversee all resident designers and directors, who handle revivals, and coordinate the activities of the creative types who make new productions. Ms. Koenig spent the 1980s and most of the 1990s at the Met, mainly working on the directing staff. She was the rare resident director to create a new production, a 1996 “Così Fan Tutte.” Her job is new. Joe Clark, the technical director, had encompassed much of the work, but he is retiring at the end of the summer. His replacement, John Sellars, will take on purely technical duties. “It’s sort of like separating church and state,” Mr. Gelb said. For the last six years Ms. Koenig was general manager of the San Francisco Ballet.

headline: Courting Donors, Finding Freedom
text: BADEN-BADEN, Germany  A decade ago, during a speech in Vienna, the mild-mannered director of a German art museum lit into the Guggenheim for carpetbagging, siphoning money from European companies like Deutsche Bank. The audience ritually nodded.

headline: Woman Admits Role in Ring Tied to Spitzer
text: A 23-year-old New Jersey woman pleaded guilty on Tuesday to running the daily operations of a high-priced escort service linked to Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Russia: President Fires Top General
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev dismissed the military’s top general, Yuri N. Baluyevsky, amid reports of conflict between military leaders and the civilian defense minister over spending and administrative priorities and replaced him with Gen. Nikolai Makarov, above. General Makarov was most recently the military’s armaments chief and, earlier, commander of forces in Siberia. General Baluyevsky had been the military’s chief of general staff since 2004 and a strong critic of the United States, particularly of American plans to build a missile defense system in Eastern Europe. He will now be deputy director of the Russian Security Council.

headline: Anne d’Harnoncourt: Discerning Enthusiasm for Art
text: By any measure, Anne d’Harnoncourt’s tenure as director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, cut short by her sudden death on Sunday at 64, was distinguished. It shone forth in major acquisitions, successful fund drives, vast gallery renovations, a marvelous rehang of the collection and, above all, her refusal to let the museum become a three-ring circus.

headline: 'House' Leads the Night
text: Repeats on Fox lifted that network to No. 1 in the ratings on Monday, as “House” at 9 p.m. attracted the night’s largest audience, 9.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. While Fox’s “Bones” was the most-watched show during the 8 p.m. hour, with 6.7 million viewers, it trailed in its time slot among adults 18 to 49. Fox ranked third for the night in that demographic, just behind CBS and NBC, which tied for first. CBS earned second place in total viewers thanks to solid ratings for repeats of its comedy lineup followed by a rerun of “CSI: Miami” at 10 (8.8 million). Meanwhile, NBC’s live coverage of Game 5 of the N.H.L. Stanley Cup finals averaged about 6 million viewers, on a par with ABC’s schedule for the night. ABC broadcast a two-hour edition of “The Bachelorette” (6.5 million), followed by the season premiere of “The Mole” at 10 (4.7 million). ABC finished fourth over all among the 18-to-49 set.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Benefit, With Wine

headline: Pennsylvania: Gun Ordinances Voided
text: A judge ruled that the City of Philadelphia could not enforce new ordinances that would ban assault weapons and limit handgun purchases to one per person per month. The judge, Jane Cutler Greenspan of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas, ruled in favor of the National Rifle Association, which argued that only the legislature had the right to make gun laws. But Judge Greenspan denied on procedural grounds the association’s request to overturn three other gun ordinances. One would allow guns to be removed from people who were declared to be a risk to themselves or others, and another would do the same for those under a protection-from-abuse order. The third would require the reporting of lost or stolen guns.

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: Groton, Conn.

headline: Final Workout for Big Brown as Trainer’s Chatter Gallops On
text: Rick Dutrow talks trash. He cannot help it. He believes Big Brown, the colt he trains, will be the next Triple Crown champion. Dutrow may not have the lyricism of the trainer Buddy Delp, who referred to Spectacular Bid as the “greatest horse to ever look through a bridle,” but he speaks with great conviction.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Sunday about Big Brown’s place in history as a contender for the Triple Crown misstated the year in which a past winner, Seattle Slew, was named the horse of the year. It was 1977, not 1978.

headline: A Court for Veterans
text: There is a small bright spot on the normally bleak terrain for military veterans who return home and fall into addiction, mental illness and crime. Buffalo has established a specialized court to give veterans and their family members, mainly those accused of nonviolent crimes, a chance to avoid jail and rebuild their lives.

headline: Palmer’s Legend, Good and Bad, Lives On
text: Far Hills, N.J.

headline: Massachusetts: Kennedy Is Recuperating
text: One day after undergoing surgery on a malignant brain tumor in North Carolina, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts was walking around and recuperating well, according to a statement from his office. Mr. Kennedy, 76, had the surgery Monday at Duke University Medical Center. The statement said he was experiencing no complications and was walking the hallways and spending time with family. Mr. Kennedy is expected to return to his home in Hyannis, Mass., in about a week.

headline: Barack Obama: Calm in the Swirl of History
text: He gives the appearance of a strikingly laid-back victor, this presumptive Democratic presidential nominee.

headline: Obama Claims Nomination; First Black Candidate to Lead a Major Party Ticket
text: Senator Barack Obama claimed the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday night, prevailing through an epic battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters from every corner of America to demand change in Washington.

headline: Chamberlain Hits Pitch Count, Not Plate
text: It felt like a graduation ceremony on Tuesday night in the Bronx, with everyone applauding a student who stays on stage for an instant. Joba Chamberlain reached another level in his baseball education, and the fans stood and cheered for him before the first of his precious few innings.

headline: An English Barn With American Flourishes
text: BUNWELL, Norfolk

headline: Yankees Find Effective if Not Electrifying Arm
text: Joba Chamberlain is a rookie celebrity, cheered in Yankee Stadium even before he made his first major league start Tuesday night, and again when he left the game before sundown in Toronto’s 9-3 victory.

headline: Buildup Lasts Longer Than the Start
text: One day we will look back at Joba Chamberlain’s first Yankee start Tuesday and ask ourselves, “How did this turn into the biggest thing since Hideki Irabu’s debut?”

headline: Expertise Called Crucial to China Deals
text: Expertise can be more important than cash when it comes to winning investments in China, managers of four of the world’s biggest buyout firms said on Tuesday.

headline: Education Stories, Inspiring or Otherwise
text: In the season of sheepskin and mortarboard, report card and honor roll, I have reached my own commencement. After four years, this is my last education column, as I move on to other journalistic endeavors.

headline: Steel Price Is Latest Setback for European Pipeline
text: BERLIN  Nabucco, the European Union’s natural gas pipeline project, intended to reduce the bloc’s dependence on Russian natural gas, has been dealt another setback  and this one could hit European consumers in the wallet.

headline: Once a Pride of the Yankees, Irabu Slipped Out of Sight
text: LOS ANGELES  As Joba Chamberlain stepped into the maelstrom Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium, there was one person who could probably relate to making his first major league start in such extraordinary circumstances. That would be Hideki Irabu, who with a Steinbrenner as a benefactor and with the city’s full attention, turned a midweek, midseason game into a late October night.

headline: What’s the Peppery Note in Those Shirazes?
text: HOW far wrong can you go with mashed potatoes? I had no idea until last month, when I tasted the worst of my life in a new Midtown restaurant whose French pedigree had led me to expect some of the best. They were smooth and buttery, but the flavor was strangely harsh, with a chemical aftertaste. “Like Band-Aids,” my companion said.

headline: Good Deed, Unscripted Consequences
text: Sometimes, if you’re a documentary filmmaker, you can search years looking for the right subject. At other times the subject will walk right up to your camera, which is pretty much what happened with “Operation Filmmaker,” an absorbing story about the best intentions gone terribly and comically awry.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on May 24 about France’s obsession with the life of President Nicolas Sarkozy misspelled the surname of the editor in chief of Le Canard Enchaîné, a weekly newspaper, who said the obsession had turned negative “like a bad love affair.” He is Eric Emptaz, not Empatz.

headline: The Primary Season’s Final Debate
text: Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton spoke past their cheering, chanting supporters and directly to each other on Tuesday in what was one of the most intimate, tense moments of the campaign, like parents arguing in French at the dinner table so the children won’t get upset.

headline: Last Season’s Success Hard to Duplicate for Mets’ Pérez
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Oliver Pérez and John Maine began this season as interchangeable parts in the Mets’ rotation. Each won 15 games last year while posting comparable earned run averages, and the Mets hoped  check that, expected  that they would join the ranks of the National League’s elite.

headline: Would Stonehenge Be Built Today?
text: At least part of the mystery of Stonehenge may have now been solved: It was from the beginning a monument to the dead.

headline: She’s Still Here!
text: He thought a little thing like winning would stop her?

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A music review on Saturday about Jeff Harnar, at the Metropolitan Room, referred incorrectly to a song he performed, “At Long Last Love,” in his tribute to Cole Porter. It is from the 1938 musical “You Never Know.” It is not a “1938 movie song.”

headline: St. Vincent’s Says It Will Close if It Can’t Build Tower
text: St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan will have to shut its doors if it cannot build a medical tower in Greenwich Village, representatives of the hospital said Tuesday at a hearing of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

headline: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.

headline: Obama Clinches Nomination; First Black Candidate to Lead a Major Party Ticket
text: Senator Barack Obama claimed the Democratic presidential nomination on Tuesday evening, prevailing through an epic battle with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in a primary campaign that inspired millions of voters from every corner of America to demand change in Washington.

headline: Garlicky Spinach Salad With Pine Nuts and Raisins
text: Time: 20 minutes

headline: Clinton Discusses What She Wants, but Not What She Will Do
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took the stage before supporters Tuesday night and finally asked the question that so many people had been posing: “What does Hillary want?”

headline: Clinic Treats Mental Illness by Enlisting the Family
text: It was hard to tell just who was the patient, as the Cunanan siblings  Jennifer, Adrian and Anthony  sat in a row on three chairs in a sparsely decorated therapist’s office at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

headline: In South Florida, Eviction Spares Few
text: MIAMI  In a decade handling evictions for the Miami-Dade County Police Department, Albert Fernandez has run across a middle-class father bankrupted by his daughter’s cancer treatment; an old woman scammed by a gambling husband; and countless families perpetually on the edge of poverty.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Friday about a report released by the Bush administration describing the effects of climate change on the United States described the time frame for the last such assessment incorrectly. The report undertaken in the Clinton administration was published in 2000, during the last year of the Clinton presidency, not in “the early days of the Bush presidency.”

headline: In Hiring, Europeans Go Global
text: PARIS  When José Luis Duran came from Spain in 1994 to work at Carrefour, the big French retailer, he spoke no French. “It was total immersion from the first day,” he said. “It was shocking, but you learn fast.”

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An obituary headline on Tuesday about Anne d’Harnoncourt, the director and chief executive of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, attributed an erroneous distinction to her. She succeeded Jean Sutherland Boggs as director; she was not the first woman to lead a major museum.

headline: McCain Distances Himself From Bush and Jabs Obama
text: KENNER, La.  Senator John McCain marked the unofficial beginning of the general election with a speech here Tuesday in which he sought to distance himself from President Bush and to argue that he has stronger credentials as an independent agent of change than his all-but-certain Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: New Hints Seen That Red Wine May Slow Aging
text: Red wine may be much more potent than was thought in extending human lifespan, researchers say in a new report that is likely to give impetus to the rapidly growing search for longevity drugs.

headline: Bargain Seeking
text: FEW Burgundies are cheap, but good values nonetheless abound.

headline: A Sidekick No More, Ashanti Tries Some New Poses for the Spotlight
text: Ashanti has never needed to be great, and so she never has been. Or is it that Ashanti has never been thought to be great, so no one has ever asked much of her?

headline: Asparagus With Chardonnay Sabayon
text: Adapted from Fabienne Escoffier, Ma Cuisine, Beaune, France

headline: Lehman Battles an Insurgent Investor
text: David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble  and he is not being quiet about it.

headline: Martínez Gives Mets Lift, and Some Life
text: SAN FRANCISCO  After throwing his 57th pitch of the game Tuesday, Pedro Martínez did not grab his leg or buckle over in pain. No flashbulbs went off and no balloons were set free to commemorate the occasion, but already Martínez had done better, pitched longer, than in his first  and last  start of the season, on April 1 in Miami, when he felt a pop in his left hamstring.

headline: ‘Inside the Nfl’ Lands on Showtime
text: “Inside the NFL,” which HBO Sports canceled in February after a 31-year run, was picked up by Showtime. It will be produced by CBS Sports, a corporate sister of Showtime, and NFL Films, and be shown Wednesday nights. HBO dropped the program, saying that it had lost its uniqueness amid the proliferation of N.F.L.-oriented studio programs on television.

headline: In a First, Asian Autos Outsold Detroit’s in May
text: The three Detroit automakers were outsold for the first time ever by their Asian rivals in May, and a sedan was the top-selling vehicle in the United States for the first time in 16 years.

headline: Former Prosecutor Leading in Council Race in Queens
text: Anthony Como, a former Queens prosecutor and longtime aide to State Senator Serphin R. Maltese, was leading a special election Tuesday night for a City Council seat in Queens that was vacated by Dennis P. Gallagher, a Queens Republican.

headline: Revealing the Wonder in the Why
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Pizza’s Secret? Whole-Wheat Crust
text: It may dismay the Neapolitan pizza police, but whole-wheat pizza is showing up more often. Last week the Papa John’s chain introduced pizzas with whole-wheat crusts and five grams of fiber per slice, $11.99 for a large plain pizza. Toppings like pesto and peppers are good with the tender, earthy crust.

headline: Suit Seeks to Block State Policy on Same-Sex Unions
text: ALBANY  Five state lawmakers, backed by a conservative Christian policy group, sued Gov. David A. Paterson on Tuesday, seeking to block the governor’s order directing state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed outside New York. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in the Bronx, came as the Senate Republican conference all but ruled out taking any action to try to challenge the governor.

headline: U.N. Says Food Plan Could Cost $30 Billion a Year
text: ROME  Faced with an immediate hunger crisis and the need to double food production in the next 30 years, world leaders meeting Tuesday to discuss soaring food prices were mostly in agreement on how the problem could be resolved. The questions were how to get there and who was going to pay for it.

headline: Stalled Sale Seeks Power From Wind
text: ALBANY  One of the world’s largest energy companies proposed on Tuesday to build hundreds of wind turbines in New York, significantly raising the stakes in a nine-month battle with state regulators over its intended purchase of a power company.

headline: Prado Has Chance to Beat the Horse He Never Rode
text: Edgar Prado is pretty good at preventing history from being made. Twice, he has been the winning rider aboard horses that thwarted Triple Crown bids; first when Sarava beat War Emblem in 2002, and two years later when Birdstone defeated Smarty Jones. He will try to do the same Saturday, and this time he will have some extra motivation.

headline: ‘Everyday Drinking’
text: Anthropologists assure us that wherever we find man he speaks. Chimpanzee-lovers notwithstanding, no animal other than man is capable of laughter. And, although some undiscovered tribe in the Brazilian jungle might conceivably prove an exception tomorrow, every present-day society uses alcohol, as have the majority of those of the past. I am not denying that we share other important pleasures with the brute creation, merely stating the basic fact that conversation, hilarity and drink are connected in a profoundly human, peculiarly intimate way.

headline: Daughter of Sect Leader Gets Additional Protection
text: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  A 16-year-old girl who, her lawyers said, was sexually abused in a West Texas polygamist group led by her father, Warren S. Jeffs, was given added legal protections on Tuesday by a district court judge who barred any contact between her and Mr. Jeffs.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Regulators Move to Tighten Oversight of Commodities
text: Regulators of the nation’s commodity markets on Tuesday announced steps to demand more information about investors to determine whether they are evading market limits on speculation and artificially driving up world food prices.

headline: Chinese Stifle Grieving Parents’ Protest of Shoddy School Construction
text: DUJIANGYAN, China  Police officers here on Tuesday surrounded more than 100 parents protesting shoddy school construction and mourning the deaths of thousands of children during the recent earthquake.

headline: Tori Amos Drops Her Label
text: The singer-songwriter Tori Amos has left Epic Records after six years to become independent and urged her fellow artists to “stop being dependent, dependent on any system that has become undependable,” Reuters reported. In a statement on her Web site (toriamos.com), Ms. Amos, 44, said she looked forward to crossing into the new uncharted music frontier. She released three albums on Epic, most recently “American Doll Posse” in 2007, which hit No. 5 on the Billboard 500. Before that she was with Atlantic from 1992 to 2001, when she, along with Rod Stewart, Poe, Collective Soul and other artists, left that label.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a contentious race for a House seat in Northern California misstated the number of terms served by the incumbent, John T. Doolittle, who is stepping down. He is serving his 9th term, not his 10th.

headline: Same-Sex Marriages Performed in Greece
text: ATHENS  Defying governmental wrath, the mayor of a remote Greek island performed the country’s first same-sex marriages on Tuesday, wedding two men and two women.

headline: Pakistan Calls Embassy Blast Suicide Attack
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The car-bomb attack on the Danish Embassy that killed eight people appears to have been carried out by a suicide bomber, Pakistani investigators and diplomats at Western embassies in Islamabad said Tuesday.

headline: Correction
text: Bob Herbert’s column on Saturday misspelled the surname of a Philadelphia woman whose son died in the Iraq war. She is Celeste Zappala, not Zappa.

headline: Toll Brothers Reports a Loss, but Not as Deep as Expected
text: Toll Brothers, the builder of luxury homes, reported a second-quarter loss on Tuesday, still hurt by plunging home prices and a weakened economy. But the results were better than expected, and the company’s shares were up more than 4 percent in midday trading.

headline: Awaiting Spring’s Exotic Greens With an Old Family Friend
text: IN the days before spicy mizuna mix, delicate mâche, and resplendent heads of purple radicchio were available at every corner greengrocer, spinach was about as exotic as salad greens got  at least in my childhood Brooklyn kitchen.

headline: Sun, Sherry, Castanets: Musical Postcards From Spain
text: The French composer Paul Dukas accused the Spanish composer and virtuoso pianist Isaac Albéniz of handling his colors as lavishly as his money. Albéniz indeed illustrates the scorching colors of Andalucia with Technicolor brilliance in “Iberia,” described by Messiaen as “the masterpiece of Spanish music.”

headline: Impish Writer on the Edge of Tomorrow
text: In “Dreams With Sharp Teeth,” the writer Harlan Ellison is variously described by friends and colleagues as “a hurricane,” “performance art,” “an alternately impish and furious 11-year-old boy,” “a cranky old Jew” and, most memorably by his buddy Robin Williams, as “a skin graft on a leper.”

headline: A New Emerald Is Fashioned for Boston’s Necklace
text: BOSTON  On the long-neglected site of a state mental hospital that closed more than two decades ago, a mixed-income community is under construction.

headline: Lautenberg Easily Wins Spirited Primary Race, Despite a Tepid Turnout
text: TRENTON  In a barbed contest that focused as much on his age as on his accomplishments, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg easily swatted away a challenge from Representative Robert E. Andrews in the Democratic primary on Tuesday and will seek his fifth term in the Senate in November.

headline: Global Trade Negotiations Are Dealt Another Setback
text: BRUSSELS  Global trade talks have stumbled again after a frustrated mediator suspended negotiations over industrial goods, complaining that it was “pointless to continue” because diplomats were refusing to negotiate.

headline: The Healing Power of Classical Music
text: From the classical music world come two stories of coping. The Philharmonie, home of the Berlin Philharmonic, reopened for concerts and tours on Monday, less than two weeks after a fire, and the Philadelphia Orchestra turned its Beijing concert into a benefit for rebuilding after the earthquake that devastated parts of Sichuan Province, China, last month. The German Symphony Orchestra was the first to perform in the Philharmonie’s main concert hall after a May 20 fire forced rescue crews to tear down a quarter of the roof, The Associated Press reported. The Berlin Philharmonic is scheduled to return Thursday to perform works by Shostakovich and Ravel. Meanwhile on Tuesday, the Philadelphia Orchestra’s concert, with the pianist Lang Lang and the conductor Christoph Eschenbach, was to be recorded and broadcast by CCTV, China’s largest television network, and fed to Phoenix TV in Hong Kong for broadcast, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. Negotiations are under way with PBS for an American broadcast, according to the report. The proceeds will help rebuild the Sichuan school system. The orchestra, which is near the end of a three-week tour of Asia, is waiving its broadcast fee and will make a donation to the China Youth Development Foundation. The broadcasts will solicit individual donations.

headline: Start-Up Releases Smaller Version of Flip Camcorder
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In the last year, Pure Digital, a small San Francisco start-up, has shown the world’s consumer electronics companies how to build a camcorder that regular people actually use.

headline: Suit Opposes Elk Feeding in Wyoming
text: Environmentalists filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in an effort to stop a federal wildlife refuge in Wyoming from continuing its longtime practice of feeding wild elk. They say such feeding could lead to or worsen an outbreak of chronic wasting disease in the large wildlife populations around Yellowstone National Park.

headline: The Long Goodbye
text: Maybe it was her night after all: Hillary Clinton decided not to withdraw from the presidential campaign tonight, and the liberals in blogville are not happy about it, to put it mildly. Matthew Yglesias of The Atlantic begins his blog post on Clinton’s speech by writing, “I probably shouldn’t write any more about this woman and her staff. Suffice it to say that I’ve found her behavior over the past couple of months to be utterly unconscionable and this speech is no different.” He continues, ” I think if I were to try to express how I really feel about the people who’ve been enabling her behavior, I’d say something deeply unwise. Suffice it to say, that for quite a while now all of John McCain’s most effective allies have been on Hillary Clinton’s payroll.”

headline: It’s a Process, and a Painful One for the Yankees
text: My friend Tim was visiting from Washington, D.C., on Tuesday. He said he got off the train and it seemed as if the city had exploded with all things Joba. And it was true – everywhere, it seemed, people were buzzing about the first start for Joba Chamberlain.

headline: McCain Marks General Election
text: Senator John McCain speaks to supporters after the final primaries of the season. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: In Harlem, ‘It’s a Wonderful Day’
text: Lester Cousey, 74, a retired postal supervisor, gazed up at a television inside Amy Ruth’s, a soul food restaurant on 116th Street in Harlem, as Senator Barack Obama stepped on stage Tuesday night to deliver a speech declaring himself the Democratic Party’s presidential nominee, defeating Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York. “I’m mind-boggled; I really never thought that I would live to see a black candidate,” Mr. Cousey said. “Knowing this country, it’s rather difficult for a black man to attain the level he’s gotten to so far; it was indeed surprising.”Read More at The Caucus …

headline: Art Basel
text: Images from the art fair in Switzerland.

headline: Obama Claims Nomination
text: Senator Barack Obama speaks to supporters after the final primaries of the season. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 86 Iowa State
text: Location: Ames, Iowa

headline: How Different Groups Voted in the 2008 Democratic Presidential Primaries
text: Looking back at where Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton found their greatest support in the nominating contests.

headline: How Different Groups Voted in the 2008 Democratic Presidential Primaries
Remembering Alton Kelley
text: Alton Kelley, whose psychedelic concert posters for artists like the Grateful Dead and Jimi Hendrix helped define the visual style of the 1960s counterculture, has died.

headline: Art from Cars?! The Vauxhall Art Car Boot Sale
text: >The Lady Greys

headline: The Pride of Youngstown
text: The boxer Kelly Pavlik has quietly and suddenly amassed two of the four middleweight belts.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Muret, France
text: The Frugal Traveler works for his keep on a farm in southwestern France.

headline: Frugal Traveler: The Grand Tour
text: The Frugal Traveler works for his keep on a farm in southwestern France.

headline: ‘That Makes Big Brown Like Roger Clemens’
text: More of your “late night” standup (send via the comment link below):

headline: Union’s Buyout Protests Go Global
text: It started with faux billionaires in the Hamptons and a fat-cat tycoon (or at least an actor wearing a cat mask) in Washington. Now, a union-led campaign against wealthy private equity firms is going global.

headline: First Day Success for Indian Companies May Signal Revived Investor Interest
text: Anu’s Laboratories and Gokul Refoils & Solvent gained on their first day of trading in Mumbai, following the slowest month for initial share sales in two years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: BSNL Considers I.P.O.
text: Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited  is considering offering shares to government employees along with a considerable reservation for BSNL staff. Should the proposal go through, it would be the first such I.P.O., RTT News reported.

headline: Kirin, Warrnambool Try to Gulp Down Dairy Farmers
text: Kirin Holdings and Warrnambool Cheese & Butter Factory will partner to bid for Dairy Farmers, the Australian producer of Bornhoffen yogurt and the Coon and Cracker Barrel cheeses, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Sinosteel Lifts Midwest Stake
text: Sinosteel has lifted its stake in Midwest to 28.4 percent from just under 20 percent in its tussle for control of the miner with Australian bidder Murchison Metals.

headline: Novartis Nabs Protez for $400 Million
text: Novartis has bought U.S.-based Protez Pharmaceuticals in a deal worth up to $400 million, Reuters reported. The deal would give Novartis rights to an antibiotic which could be used to fight superbugs such as MRSA, the Swiss drugmaker said.

headline: Exchange Pays $625 Million For Creditex
text: Securities exchange IntercontinentalExchange has entered into an agreement to buy credit processor Creditex Group in a cash and stock deal valued at $625 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: China Telecom in Talks to Sell Stake to Strategic Investor
text: China Telecom said it is in talks to sell a stake to a strategic investor to help it expand after acquiring mobile-phone assets, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Carlyle Closes $3.4 Billion European Property Fund
text: The Carlyle Group has announced the closing of its third European property fund at 2.2 billion euros ($3.4 billion), far above its initial fundraising target of 1.5 billion euros, and an indication of the continued strength of European demand, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Shareholders Advised to Back Restoration Buyout
text: Restoration Hardware said earlier this week that two proxy advisories had recommended shareholders vote in favor of a proposed buyout by a Catterton Partners-led group valued at $4.50 per share.

headline: Veoh Raises An Extra $30 Million
text: Online video site Veoh has received a further $30 million in financing from such new backers as Intel and Adobe Systems.

headline: Texas Oil Companies Consolidate
text: Smith International has agreed to acquire W-H Energy Services for $3.2 billion, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Third Suit Filed Against San Jose Investor
text: The third time may not be the charm for San Jose investor William “Boots” Del Biaggio III. A new lawsuit accuses Mr. Del Biaggio of scamming Modern Bank of New York out of a $10 million loan so he could buy an interest in the Nashville Predators hockey team.

headline: Polygon Investment Chief Is Gone
text: Polygon Investment Partners‘ chief investment officer, Alexander Jackson, is the latest casualty of the ongoing credit cruch.

headline: Bidding War Continues for Herald Resources
text: In what is quickly turning into a heated bidding war, a consortium of Antam and Shenzhen Zhongjin have offered up to A$524 million ($500 million) for Australian mineral exploration and development company Herald Resources, trumping an earlier offer made by Bumi Resources.

headline: Stalled Sale Seeks Power From Wind
text: Iberdrola, one of the world’s largest energy companies, proposed on Tuesday to build hundreds of wind turbines in New York. The move significantly raises the stakes in its nine-month battle with state regulators over its intended purchase of Energy East, a power company.

headline: Rally Software Raises Nearly $17 Million
text: Rally Software Development, based in Boulder, Colo., was expected to announce that it raised $16.85 million in venture funding in a Series C round led by Mohr Davidow Ventures.

headline: European Banks May Need Additional Capital to Stem Losses
text: BNP Paribas and European rivals including Societe Generale and Barclays may need to raise additional capital as their finances weaken, Bloomberg reported citing statements made by a Fitch Ratings executive.

headline: Smucker Shines to Folgers’ Crystals
text: J.M. Smucker Company said Wednesday it would buy the Folgers coffee business from Procter & Gamble in a stock deal it valued at about $3.3 billion, including the assumption of about $350 million of Folgers debt.

headline: Lehman Battles an Insurgent Investor
text: David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble – and he is not being quiet about it.

headline: TPG to Continue Stake Building in Banks
text: Texas Pacific Group plans to use its investment in Bradford & Bingley as a springboard for stake-building in other banks. The Telegraph reported that such a move could trigger a wave of private equity investments in Britain’s distressed financial services sector.

headline: Senate Panel to Examine Underwriting Practices
text: The Senate Banking Committee is planning to hold a hearing next Tuesday to examine underwriting practices at some of the top investment banks, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.

headline: This Red’s for You
text: New research hints red wine may slow aging, but you’d have to drink like four glasses a day, at least. Four glasses? Maybe it’s time to start marketing wine like beer:

headline: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
text: The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.

headline: Rating Firms Seem Near Legal Deal on Reforms
text: Under fire for the high ratings they awarded to subprime mortgage securities, three large credit rating firms are close to announcing a broad deal with the New York attorney general to reform some of their core business practices, The New York Times reported citing people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Willer
text: (Bill Batten)

headline: Reliance Said to Consider Buyout Partners in MTN Bid
text: Anil Ambani, the billionaire Indian industrialist, is considering linking up with private equity groups on his bid to gain a powerful foothold in South African mobile operator MTN, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources close to the matter.

headline: Should Google Buy Salesforce.com?
text: If Google is serious about selling business applications, it may need to make a major acquisition to catalyze that effort. Two analysts at The 451 Group present their point of view on why Salesforce.com would be one of the better targets — though an expensive one.

headline: The Early Word: Obama’s Record-Breaking Journey
text: What we know after Tuesday’s final primary contests is that Senator Barack Obama has clinched the Democratic nomination, becoming the first black candidate to lead a major political party into the general election. Under a history-making banner headline, The Times’s Jeff Zeleny writes that Mr. Obama’s showing in the South Dakota and Montana primaries as well as a “last-minute rush of Democratic superdelegates” allowed him to claim victory over his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton:

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Dana Jennings
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: To the Swift: Red Smith on Affirmed
text: The following column, “Man Here Loves His Horse,” by Red Smith, the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist, appeared in The New York Times on June 10, 1978, and is from “To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory” (St. Martin’s Press), edited by Joe Drape.

headline: Bloomberg Might Try to Stay in Public Life
text: As the end of his term nears, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his senior advisers have been exploring strategies that would allow him to remain in political life, including the undertaking a campaign to overturn the city’s term limits law or making a bid for governor, Raymond Hernandez reports.

headline: Canceled By HBO, ‘Inside the NFL’ Lands On Showtime
text: “Inside the NFL,” which HBO Sports canceled in February after a 31-year run, was picked up by Showtime, Richard Sandomir reports.

headline: Art Basel Unlimited | The All-Day Schmooze
text: On the schmooze: Swiss collector Maja Hoffmann, artist Ugo Rondinone, film producer Stanley Buchthal, collector Peter Soros, collector Randy Slifka, artist Doug Aitken (on Slifka’s shoulder), New Museum curator Masimilliano Gioni and Gagosian Gallery’s Beijing director Nick Simunovic.

headline: CBS And Yahoo In Web Video Sharing Deal
text: Reuters reports: “CBS Corp. said on Wednesday it reached a deal to allow its Web videos to be carried by Yahoo Inc., part of a broader plan by the media company to add new outlets for its television shows.”

headline: ‘Entertainment Tonight’ Sticking With Report on Angelina Jolie’s Twins
text: Five days after “Entertainment Tonight” reported that Angelina Jolie had given birth to twins, it is starting to look more and more as if the syndicated show — which is on every weeknight, primarily on CBS affiliates — made a serious mistake.

headline: Geometries | Water Tunnel No. 3
text: At the junction of three sections of Water Tunnel No. 3 under construction beneath Manhattan — at this point, 580 feet beneath Manhattan. This section of the tunnel is 10 feet in diameter. The project, to bring more drinking water to New York City, was authorized in 1954 and started in 1970; several stages remain to be built.

headline: How will the campaign be covered?
text: The Democratic nomination fight has been hog heaven for the celebrity-journalism style of campaign reporting: with two candidates not too different on the issues (despite the health care divide), plus a special dispensation (under the Clinton rules) to invent scandals when needed, it was all personalities — make that all personas, because the way politicians are portrayed generally has little or nothing to do with what they’re really like — all the way.

headline: Will eBay Go Shopping?
text: Who knows whether or not Microsoft and Yahoo will ever merge. In the meantime, investment bankers might consider cruising eBay for their next assignment. The online auction site has money in the bank, a unit it may want to sell and a track record of growing through acquisitions.

headline: Honda’s Live TV Commercial
text: Last week, 19 skydivers successfully jumped out of an airplane in the skies above Madrid to spell the word “Honda” live on British television.

headline: Yahoo’s Potential Scheduling Conflict
text: On Tuesday Yahoo finally set an Aug. 1 date for its annual shareholder meeting. Why they picked this date over any other in this time period, including the July 3 one originally scheduled, I have no idea.

headline: Lost Brother Is Found at a Dominoes Game
text: It had been almost 30 years since Ana Mojica last saw her half brother, Ruben ,on Fordham Road. In the intervening decades, she moved to Reading, Pa., started a family and eventually her own housecleaning business. Comfortable and far away from the Bronx, she still prayed to find her brother.

headline: How Much Nature Is Enough?
text: I asked and answered a provocative, and rhetorical, question the other day, and it engendered some strong responses. Here’s what I wrote about a marine denizen that is among the world’s largest, and most venerable, reptiles: “Does the world need leatherback turtles? Most likely not.”

headline: Will There Be a Roar, or Silence?
text: The oldest of the baby boom generation were infants when Assault won the Triple Crown in 1946, and toddlers when Citation swept the series in 1948. They were adults scarred by the war in Vietnam and aghast at Watergate by the time Secretariat became the first in a quarter century to win the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes in 1973, and enamored of Big Red’s charisma, many had embraced the sport by the time Seattle Slew and Affirmed earned racing immortality during the 1970s.

headline: India Plans a ‘New Colossus’ of Its Own
text: When a proposal emerged to build an immense statue on an island off the coast of one of India’s largest cities, there was no point in denying a nod to New York: “It is true that the Statue of Liberty was perhaps an inspiration a little bit,” one official told Reuters.

headline: Hit Science Show Renewed for 2009
text: I asked Monday if there should be another science festival in New York next year. I now have the answer from the organizers of the first World Science Festival: The show must go on!

headline: ‘We Have a Democratic Nominee’
text: Aired Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: It looks like we have a Democratic nominee for president, Barack Obama. And now, Hillary Clinton is indicating privately to friends, who then blab it to the cable news channels, that she would be open to the vice presidency. That would mean the chain of command would be Hillary as vice president, Obama as president, and then Oprah on top of them.

headline: The Starting Line: The Tiananmen Square Protests, 19 Years Later
text: Today is the 19th anniversary of the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square pro-democracy protests. In an op-ed piece in today’s Washington Post, Wang Dan, a student organizer who was sent to prison for his role in the 1989 pro-democracy protests at Tiananmen Square, calls for the Chinese government to declare an “Olympic amnesty” for what he says are the thousands of Chinese who are “serving long prison terms for activities that are normal political engagement in most of the world” and “to allow those of us who are in exile to at last return home.”

headline: ‘Hillary May Be Dropping Out’
text: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Our Vice President, our old friend Dick Cheney, apologized for a joke he made about West Virginia. Nothing yet on the Iraqi war.

headline: ‘Assassination’ Artist Is Questioned and Released
text: Updated, 3:30 p.m. | This morning, a Boston-born performance artist, Yazmany Arboleda, tried to set up a provocative art exhibition in a vacant storefront on West 40th Street in Midtown Manhattan with the title, “The Assassination of Hillary Clinton/The Assassination of Barack Obama,” in neatly stenciled letters on the plate glass windows at street level.By 9:30 a.m., New York City police detectives and Secret Service agents had shut down the exhibition, and building workers had quickly covered over the inflammatory title with large sheets of brown paper and blue masking tape. The gallery is across the street from the southern entrance to The New York Times building.

headline: Bruce Wasserstein on Oil, Lehman and His Own Pay
text: “The smart money is buying land in Kazakhstan.”

headline: ‘Bill Clinton May Have Had an Affair’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The Associated Press reported today that Barack Obama has won enough delegates to clinch the Democratic presidential nomination. As a result, Hillary Clinton will concede sometime in the next 30 years.

headline: Miles: Give the Kids a Shot at the Big Time
text: The requisite chants of “Come on Inger-land!” which usually course through a game at Wembley are only echoes a week after the Euro 2008 exiles defeated a stale United States men’s national team 2-0.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Crispy Baby Artichokes, Capers and Spaghetti
text: Today’s Minimalist column could be my last story and post about artichokes this year; then again maybe not. Meanwhile, David Latt, frequent Bitten contributor (and host of www.menwholiketocook.com), has filed an artichoke piece of his own –MB

text: The field for the 140th Belmont Stakes grew by one Wednesday, when Guadalcanal, who is owned and trained by Fred Seitz, was entered in the race.

headline: ‘Looking for Donors’
text: Aired Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: John McCain is campaigning, out traveling around the country, looking for donors, mostly organ donors.

headline: On Your Mark
text: The workers behind the horses' starting gate at Belmont Park talk about the importance of their jobs. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: A New Face for Fuse
text: Fuse, a lesser known version of MTV and VH1, has endured a revolving door of top executives and rebranding campaigns over the past five years, Claire Atkinson reports.

headline: Mind the Bagpiper
text: Meet Paul Rutgersen, a bagpiper who practices by the West Side Highway. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: Max attack – and what comes next?
text: I was on the airplane flying over from Paris to Canada when the news of Max Mosley’s victory in the FIA vote broke. Formula One-related FIA pronouncements are a moving target, and I was never sure whether the results would be announced on Tuesday or on Wednesday. In any case, for months – or was it only weeks? – I had been saying to anyone who asked my opinion, that the vote was foregone conclusion, Max would win. So what did I care? Best get on with business and wait for the real stories to break, those of the vote’s aftermath.

headline: Please Do Not Sit on the Steps
text: A longtime haven for tired visitors, the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are temporarily off limits. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: ‘Bill Clinton Is Starting To Lose It’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The good news — the whole voting process ended tonight. The bad news — the 2012 Democratic primary starts on Thursday.

headline: Another Cycling Blogger Doubles Down
text: 32 Days to L’Étape. Training: a one-hour session of interval training in a class led by my coach, with the bike on an indoor trainer hooked up to a machine that allowed me to gauge the power in watts of every pedal stroke.

text: BATON ROUGE, La. – Senator John McCain issued an invitation to Senator Barack Obama Wednesday to join him in 10 joint town-hall-style meetings in which the likely Republican and Democratic nominees could discuss the issues this summer.

headline: For Hindus, New Temples Are a Sign of Having Arrived
text: Staten Island may well be known for many things. But for all the borough’s offerings — Vito J. Fossella‘s Congressional seat among them — it does not generally conjure up images of a thriving Indian-American community.

text: Kronvall’s Greatest Hits, Volume 1.

headline: Socializing Appears to Delay Memory Problems
text: An active social life appears to delay memory loss as we age, a new study shows.

headline: Tending the Farm Stand in Southern France
text: French people never smile—except, of course, when they do. A hunchbacked old woman, with Nixonian jowls and a face riven by time, might be shuffling through a Saturday-morning marketplace, and you’d think she’d never seen a happy day in her long life. Then, suddenly, her eyes sparkle, her eyebrows arch and a smile stretches from gold-encrusted earlobe to earlobe. She is, for a moment, a ray of sunshine.

headline: Auctioning Paris mini-bars and memories
text: Royal Monceau

headline: Chicago Becomes 2016 Finalist as Dispute Flares Between I.O.C. and ‘Immoral’ U.S.O.C.
text: The International Olympic Committee has announced that Chicago is among four cities selected as finalists to play host to the 2016 Summer Games, along with Madrid, Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo.

headline: Obama Reaches Out to Pro-Israel Group
text: Updated|1:40 p.m. Introduced as the nominee of the Democratic Party, Senator Barack Obama drew several standing ovations from a vastly Jewish crowd at the American Israel Public Affairs Committee’s annual policy conference in Washington on Wednesday, talking tough on the Iranian threat to Israel while also promising that he would lead in pursuing a peace settlement in Israel.

headline: Making Seasoned Salts
text: While I realize that there are different types of salt, it kills me that people now think it’s a subject about which we all have to become conversant. (“I made this amazing dish with Hawaiian pink salt,” someone said the me the other day, as if the salt were the main ingredient.)

headline: Owings Not Alone as a Hitter
text: Earlier this season Micah Owings, the Arizona Diamondbacks starting pitcher, was getting a lot of attention for his prowess as a hitter, and rightfully so as he was hitting well above .300 and even hit a pinch-hit homer at one point. But it is possible all of that attention stirred up some competitive fire in one of the game’s other good hitting pitchers, because recently no one has been hotter than Carlos Zambrano, the Cubs starter.

headline: How Does Altidore Look in Amarillo?
text: Rumors have swirled around America’s most promising young striker, Jozy Altidore, for months. The Red Bulls strike acknowledged the chatter himself in his May 6 entry on this blog. But today, rumors (more in Marca today) become firm, reported news as a club official told The New York Times on Wednesday that Villareal, in Spain, has agreed in principle with Major League Soccer, to acquire the U.S. forward.

headline: Susan Decker on Yahoo Discussions
text: CNBC interviews Susan Decker, president of Yahoo, about whether the company is still in talks with Microsoft.

headline: Like Politics, All Weather Is Local
text: NBC Universal is believed to be leading the bidding for The Weather Channel, the 26-year-old cable channel that delivers weather forecasts around the clock and turns into must-see TV during snowstorms, hurricanes and floods.

headline: Sports and Sexual Segregation
text: “We should not sort athletes by what sex they are, but rather by their skill,” Eileen McDonagh and Laura Pappano write in “Playing with the Boys: Why Separate Is Not Equal in Sports.” At first glance, this book might seem one more example of gender equality gone wild, like coed bathrooms or pornography for women. Mixed-sex football? But give the authors a chance to make their argument and they begin to play with your head. Their book isn’t well-written, and it’s no fun to read, but start thinking about the issues they raise and you may never stop.

headline: Madrid and Beyond With a Teenage Grandson
text: I am taking my 13-year old grandson to Spain for one week in July with a first stop in Madrid. I am looking for a 4-star hotel centrally located and ideas what to do and where to go in this one week (besides spending one day in Toledo).

text: In Slate, Meghan O’Rourke pens (pixels?) an obituary for Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign. “Her problem wasn’t that she was a feminist,” she writes. “Her problem was that she wasn’t feminist enough.”

headline: The Great Days Are Now
text: These are the delicious days, the days of debate and doubt as we wait for the Belmont Stakes, the toughest race to win in the United States and the last leg of the Triple Crown. There is no better time to be a horse racing fan.

headline: Comcast Tests a New Bandwidth Throttle
text: UPDATE | 6/5 7:40 PM: Comcast objected to the first version of this post, which referred to its method for identifying heavy users as a blacklist. After several conversations, including a call with Mitch Bowling, Comcast’s senior vice president and general manger of its Internet service, I’ve rewritten the headline and a bit of the explanation about how the system being tested works.

headline: For Clinton’s Women Fans, Mourning and Anger

headline: Truck Explosion in Baghdad
text: A truck carrying explosives blew up in a Shiite neighborhood of the Iraqi capital, killing at least 18 people in the most lethal such incident in Baghdad in months.

headline: Verizon in Talks to Buy Alltel
text: Updated: Verizon Communications is in talks to buy Alltel for about $27 billion including the assumption of debt, creating the nation’s largest cellphone service company, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: This Chinese Deliveryman Works at Google
text: The new film “Take Out,” about a Chinese deliveryman struggling to pay off his debt, is not a documentary. Really. Even though its gritty style makes it look like one.

headline: Google Plans Major Expansion in Its Backyard
text: With about 8,000 workers at its Mountain View, Calif., headquarters, Google is already the largest employer in its hometown. And while Google is now growing even faster overseas, it has plans to turn the Googleplex into a mega-Gooplex.

headline: Icahn Rattles Yahoo’s Cage (Again)
text: Carl C. Icahn sharpened his attack on Yahoo with a public letter to the company’s board that says “the only way to salvage Yahoo is to merge with Microsoft.”

headline: 2008 J.D. Power Rankings Released
text: These are the rankings by nameplate for the 2008 Initial Quality Study by J.D. Power & Associates. Numbers in the fourth column indicate the number of problems per 100 vehicles that were reported by owners in the survey. Numbers in the second column show the change in ranking, if any, from last year.

headline: An American S.U.V. in Paris
text: PARIS — The tan Chevrolet Tahoe — something that would never warrant a second glance in the U.S. — parked around the corner from my apartment here in Paris looked like the proverbial bull in a china shop. It towered over the tiny French hatchbacks beside it, and took up more parking acreage than a handful of Smart cars. A sticker on the rear window read “American Car City” and included a phone number. I was on my cell phone and dialing in less time than it takes to say “nine dollars a gallon.”

headline: See Something, Say Something?
text: BRIEFS Like the fine citizens of New York, police officers across the country are urged to say something if they see something. Unfortunately, they “fail to notify federal authorities about encounters with possible terrorism suspects up to 10 times a day, a senior FBI official said.” [USA Today]

headline: BB sticks to his guns
text: Ben Bernanke’s aggressive response to the financial crisis may have saved the world from a very severe credit crunch. But where the “committee to save the world” was lionized for its response to a much less serious crisis, Bernanke is getting a lot of grief from critics who think he’s been too soft on inflation — and want him to reverse course.

headline: Murder, She Wrote?
text: As a clearinghouse for police auctions, the Web site PropertyRoom.com usually offers your typical recovered swag: laptops, jewelry, leather jackets of uncertain origin. But every now and then you can find books there, too, and when they’re presented as a complete lot they can reveal delicious insight into the previous owner. Currently on auction (until 8 tonight, so hurry!):

headline: Drugs and Racehorses
text: Phenylbutazone seemed a miracle drug when the stuff began entering the bloodstreams of racehorses in the 1960s. I was collecting the post-race urine that concentrated the metabolites of that drug during the ’60s, and as a teenager I became acutely aware of drugs and racehorses.

headline: Without ‘Idol,” Fox Loses a Tuesday to CBS
text: CBS’s line-up of mostly repeats edged past Fox for the most viewers on Tuesday, even as Fox easily led the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox broadcast the top two shows in that demographic, “The Moment of Truth” at 8 p.m. and “Hell’s Kitchen” at 9 p.m., which also delivered the night’s single largest audience, 9.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Ken Griffey, Jr: Idling at 599
text: Four and a half hours before the Reds were scheduled to play the Phillies, there were four men on the field at Philadelphia’s Citizens Bank Park on Wednesday: three groundskeepers and Ken Griffey, Jr. All four were working.

headline: ‘The Wire,’ ‘Mad Men’ Top Critics’ Picks
text: Zap2It: “The closing chapters of ‘The Wire’ and the stylish first season of ‘Mad Men’ lead the nominees for the 2008 Television Critics Association Awards. Each show earned four nominations, the most of any program, and both are up for the top honor of program of the year.”

headline: Teams Preparing for a More Visible Draft
text: Traditionally, the baseball draft has not been as celebrated or hyped as it is in the other major sports. But this year’s player lottery seems to be getting extra attention.

headline: Season Finale: CNN’s Ratings During Obama Speech Are a Milestone
text: It is extremely rare for a cable news channel to draw higher ratings than the broadcast networks, but CNN apparently managed to pull it off on Tuesday night, when its telecast of Barack Obama’s victory speech attracted 4.73 million viewers, according to Nielsen Media Research.

Bloomberg announced on Wednesday afternoon what he called a sweeping package of legislation to improve safety for workers and residents at big construction sites. The legislation would:

headline: Euro 2008: The Group of Death
text: Every soccer tournament has one, and this is it … the 2008 European Championship Group C, the Group of Death. The players, coaches and fans from Italy, France, the Netherlands and Romania have got to be wondering what they have done to deserve this.

headline: Slovenia Accident Could Show Limits to ‘Nuclear Renaissance’
text: Just as atomic power was regaining ground as a source of electricity because of near-zero emissions of greenhouse gases, there was a reminder from Slovenia on Wednesday of how easily aspirations for a “nuclear renaissance” could be obliterated.

headline: Are Blood Pressure Drugs Safe for Seniors?
text: Everyone knows that we face a “silver tsunami” of senior citizens as baby boomers age and as researchers find new ways to turn back the diseases that once limited lifespan. Yet large-scale clinical trials often exclude the elderly, or include too few to draw statistically valid guidance for clinical practice. The effects of high blood pressure treatment in older folks have remained a particularly vexing gap in our knowledge, particularly because this condition becomes more prevalent as we age.

headline: Rezko Convicted in Corruption Trial

headline: Answers About Development on the Hudson
