headline: Chicago 2016: Sure Thing, Say Oddsmakers; Long Shot, Says I.O.C. Report
text: If the oddsmakers of the world are to be believed, the Olympic flame will be rising above Chicago for the Summer Games in 2016. Even before the announcment Wednesday of the four finalists, Chicago was the favorite, and oddsmakers currently rate it at 4-5 — meaning it has a bit better than 50/50 chance of winning the Games. Rio de Janeiro is the 2-1 second choice, while Madrid and Tokyo are the outsiders for now, at odds ranging from 7-1 to 12-1, depending on the bookmaker.

headline: Electoral Enchantment
text: SANTA FE, N.M. -- He is bamboo-thin, relies on a pair of walking sticks to help him up a canyon trail, and has lost most of his vision. But at age 88, Stewart Udall, patriarch of the first family of the American West, politics division, has seen enough history to recognize a Big Moment when it's staring back at him.   "I think we're moving into a new era," he said. "There's something very pleasing and hopeful going on, a resurgence after a long drought of positive conservation sentiment."  (Photo: Stewart Udall at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. (Credit: AP Photo/Jeff Geissler)) He was talking about love of land and passion for place, and how it can crystallize in a political shift once every generation or so. For Udall, one of only two surviving members of President John F. Kennedy's original cabinet, that time first came with the 1960 election.  Doors opened. Fresh ideas were aired. And from Udall's long tenure as secretary of the interior for both Kennedy and President Lyndon Johnson came a legacy of public land protection responsible in large part for so many wilderness areas just outside Western cities.   Now, the son also rises. And so does the nephew.   Udall's next-door neighbor in the 400-year-old city of Santa Fe, his son Tom, a Democratic congressman, has a huge lead in the polling on who will become New Mexico's next United States senator, in the seat being vacated by the Republican Pete Domenici. Udall's nephew Mark, a Democratic congressman from Colorado, is a slight favorite in the open senate race in that state, for the seat opened by the retirement of Republican Wayne Allard.   Two new Democratic senators — first cousins from a family that dates to early Mormon settlers in the Southwest — does not an earthquake make. But New Mexico also has three open Congressional seats, and the presidential campaigns will spend a lot of time here in the Land of Enchantment as well.  If the West does prove to be the gateway to the presidency this year — with at least three purple states in play — the campaigns could do no better than to look at polyglot New Mexico.   Urban and wild define the New West — fast-growing cities nestled in Wallace Stegner's "geography of hope." The art, the history and the food of New Mexico have been commoditized, for obvious reasons. But many of its special places are intact, and owned by every American because of the Wilderness Act, which dates to the fertile years of Stewart Udall's reign as the emperor of the outdoors.  Mark Udall has climbed every one of Colorado's 54 peaks over 14,000 feet (and has come within 3,000 feet of the summit of Everest). Tom Udall is the driving force behind legislation that saved the spectacular Valle Vidal in northern New Mexico from the predations of Dick Cheney and his allies.   Not so long ago, when Western Democrats wanted to caucus, "it was sometimes my cousin Tom and I having a beer," Mark Udall told Outside Magazine. Now Democrats are poised to own the West, or so goes the heady talk here at 7,000 feet.   Mountain Democrats found their way in part by rejecting the excesses of coastal Democrats, and by looking at what worked for their elders, like Stewart Udall and his brother, the late Morris Udall. The Udall name is written deep into the salmon-colored canyons and mesas of the Southwest, as prominent as a petroglyph. The family traces its lineage to John D. Lee, who was shot by a firing squad as a scapegoat for the slaughter of 120 settlers by a Mormon militia in 1857.   The leaders of the Mountain Meadows massacre were never held to account. Instead, John Lee, who was treated like a son by the Mormon patriarch Brigham Young, was offered up to the government for his role in the execution-style killings of men, women and children.   "I have been sacrificed in a cowardly, dastardly manner," said Lee, just before the blindfold was slipped over his eyes. His last words were: "Center my heart, boys. Don't mangle the body."  From Lee, who married 11 women, came the Udall dynasty, which also includes the current Republican senator from Oregon, Gordon Smith, a distant cousin of Tom and Mark.   "I don't like the term dynasty," said Stew Udall in our interview. "We're Westerners and small-town people."   The bolo-tied elder in the adobe house is modest about his influence. "The Bush Administration has all by itself created a backlash," he said. "They've been anti-science, and anti-environment." That backlash, plus a longing for a clean break with the energy policies of the past, are what make him think Democrats can ride an ascendancy of ideas into office in the fall.  Republican opponents of the Udall cousins, by contrast, show how that party has faltered. The nominee in Colorado, Rep. Bob Schaffer, has been trying to explain a junket to the Mariana Islands partly arranged by the firm of the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff. Pictures show him parasailing while supposedly investigating labor practices. In New Mexico, Republicans just chose as their senate candidate Rep. Steve Pearce, whose hard-right rigidity is a poor fit for this year and this state.   Stewart Udall was a child in the still-frontier West of the 1920s; he struggled through the Great Depression, and fought the Nazis in World War II. Reflecting on his long life recently, he wrote a message to his grandchildren.  "The lifetime crusade of your days must be to develop a new energy ethic to sustain life on earth," he wrote. "Cherish sunsets, wild creatures and wild places. Have a love affair with the wonder and beauty of the earth."  His intention was to give the kids something to outlive him. He didn't need to worry. The legacy is already there, in the land and the love affair that brought him to it.

headline: Electoral Enchantment
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — He is bamboo-thin, relies on a pair of walking sticks to help him up a canyon trail, and has lost most of his vision. But at age 88, Stewart Udall, patriarch of the first family of the American West, politics division, has seen enough history to recognize a Big Moment when it’s staring back at him.

headline: No Kidding
text: Moody’s said today that it might reduce the AAA ratings of MBIA and Ambac. The stocks of the insurance companies fell, so I guess somebody thinks this is important news.

headline: Clinton to Suspend Campaign, Endorse Obama
text: Updated | 10 p.m. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will endorse Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, bringing a close to her campaign for the White House, aides said. Her decision came after Democrats urged her Wednesday to leave the race and allow the party to coalesce around Mr. Obama. (Full article by Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny here.)

headline: Abusive E-mail May Contain More Than Insults
text: I constantly get e-mail messages with subject lines like “Can’t wait to see you again,” “I miss you,” “About last night” and so on. Unfortunately, they’re not from anyone who actually knows me. (Rats.)

headline: Evercore to Hire Bear Stearns’s Restructuring Head
text: Evercore Partners has hired Daniel A. Celentano, the former head of Bear Stearns‘s restructuring practice, who will join the boutique investment bank’s own restructuring team.

headline: Michelle Obama To Be A Guest Host On ‘The View’
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Yahoo’s Chairman Fires Back at Icahn
text: In a tit-for-tat common in election campaigns, Yahoo’s chairman, Roy Bostock, lashed out against Carl C. Icahn late Wednesday, refuting the accusations made by the billionaire investor earlier in the day.

headline: Griffey: No 600 Tonight
text: Ken Griffey, Jr. pinch-hit for the Reds on Wednesday night and he walked, so he remained at 599 career homers. Griffey has not started the first three games of this series because of what the Reds are calling general soreness.

headline: ‘The Interfamily Squabble Is Done’
text: Senator Barack Obama attended back-to-back fund-raisers Wednesday night in Manhattan – raising more than $2.5 million for the party – as a burst of new contributors turned out one day after he won enough delegates to claim the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Name to Remember in the Yankees’ Farm System: Alfredo Aceves
text: You never know what you’ll find in the Mexican League. At the start of this season, our old friend Colter Bean was pitching there. At the end of last season, a right-hander named Alfredo Aceves was finishing his sixth season in the league.

headline: Training the Mind for Resiliency
text: Karen Salmansohn has written 29 books and, in the process, created her own mini genre that she calls “self-help for people who wouldn’t be caught dead reading self-help.” The ingredients for a Salmansohn book include bold graphics, advice distilled to digestible nuggets and lots of humor. The levity does not preclude her from tackling weighty subjects, and her latest, “The Bounceback Book,” looks at the psychology behind resiliency and offers 75 tips on how to bounce back after both minor setbacks or major trauma. The tips are brief and punchy (“Walk yourself out of a bad mood,” “If you ask depressing questions, you will 100 percent get depressing answers.” “Change your body. Change your mind.”) and the text that follows offers scientific backing or quotes from the likes of Aristotle, Deepak Chopra or Martin Seligman, a leader in the field of positive psychology.

headline: What Winstrol?
text: In Thursday’s Times, Joe Drape writes that Rick Dutrow said if Big Brown wins the Triple Crown, it will be without his monthly shot of Winstrol.

headline: A Look Back at ‘Hillary 2008’
text: In June 2008 — at the end of one of the most astonishing primary campaigns in history — The New York Times looked back at what went wrong for Hillary Clinton’s run.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S.A. vs. Spain
text: The United States men’s national team turned in a much better performance Wednesday against a superior opponent than it did in London last week against an England team who was a class below Spain. But the result was the same: another loss for the Americans in Europe.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: A Town-Hall Summer
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, June 5 column.

headline: Q&A With Ivan Gazidis About the Jozy Altidore Transfer
text: Ivan Gazidis, the deputy commissioner of Major League Soccer, discussed on Wednesday the pending transfer of Red Bulls striker Jozy Altidore to Villarreal of Spain’s La Liga.

headline: In London, world’s most expensive city, $1.5 million doesn’t go far
text: What does $1.5 million (about €974,000) buy in the world’s most expensive markets? Not much, it turns out.

headline: MSNBC’s New Morning Face
text: “When MSNBC awarded Don Imus’s old morning-show slot to Joe Scarborough last summer, it did so with little enthusiasm and few expectations,” Jacques Steinberg writes.

headline: The Police Will Play the Garden for Public Television
text: In early April the business manager for the rock band the Police shot off an e-mail message to William F. Baker, the president emeritus of the New York public television stations WNET and WLIW, with an offer: the band wanted to add one last show in New York City to what it billed as its last tour, and it would do it as a fund-raiser for public television.

headline: Investment Places F.C.C. Aide Amid Fraud Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  For the last three years, Daniel Gonzalez has been the loyal lieutenant and gatekeeper to Kevin J. Martin, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. He has kept the agency humming, the paper flowing and the staff vacancies filled as Mr. Martin’s chief of staff.

headline: William Odom, 75, National Security Director, Dies
text: WASHINGTON  William E. Odom, a director of the National Security Agency in the Reagan administration who became an early and outspoken opponent of the Iraq war, died last Friday at his vacation home in Lincoln, Vt. He was 75.

headline: Leaders Speak of Their Own Issues at a Conference Addressing Food Shortages
text: ROME  It was supposed to be an emergency conference on food shortages, climate change and energy. At the opening ceremony, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, noted that there were nearly one billion people short of food, and he called upon countries gathered here to act with “a sense of purpose and mission.”

headline: F.D.A. Reviews Arthritis Drugs for Links to Cancer
text: The Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday that it was investigating whether four drugs used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and other immune system diseases might increase the risk of cancer in children.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: Track Down Your Car, With Help From an Electronic Sidekick
text: In plenty of cinematic thrillers there is a scene where the villain attaches a tiny bug to the hero’s car and tracks it through the city.

headline: Two Straight Belmont Winners and Possibly Three
text: Casino Drive is listed at short odds for Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, but a victory by him would nonetheless represent one of the biggest winning long shots in horse racing history. The Japanese-based Casino Drive, who is 7-2 in the morning line, will be attempting to become the third straight Belmont winner out of the dam Better Than Honour, a proposition that is, depending on how you crunch the numbers, as high as 43 trillion to 1.

headline: Woodchuck au Vin
text: The gardener who created this dish notes that the herbs and vegetables in this recipe are available fresh from the garden because they have not been eaten by the dish’s main ingredient.

headline: Hells Kitchen Is Hot
text: CBS’s lineup of mostly repeats edged past Fox for the most viewers on Tuesday, even as Fox easily led the night among adults 18 to 49. Fox broadcast the top two shows in that demographic, “The Moment of Truth” at 8 p.m. and “Hell’s Kitchen” at 9 p.m., with “Hell’s Kitchen” also delivering the night’s largest audience, 9.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Leading the night for CBS was a rerun of “NCIS” (9.1 million), which easily outdrew Fox’s “Moment of Truth” (6.7 million) in total viewers during the 8 p.m. time slot. At 9, CBS’s “48 Hours Mystery” garnered 8 million viewers, while CBS’s repeat of “Without a Trace” won the 10 p.m. hour (7.6 million) ahead of reruns of ABC’s “Boston Legal” (3.9 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (5.9 million). NBC finished third for the night, followed by ABC.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Reign of Terror
text: In his cynical and bloody bid to hang on to power, Zimbabwe’s president, Robert Mugabe, has bet on the indifference of his neighbors and the rest of the world. So far, shamefully, he has been right.

headline: Boris Shakhlin, 76, Is Dead; Won 13 Olympic Medals in Gymnastics
text: Boris Shakhlin, the brilliant Soviet gymnast of the 1950s and ’60s who won six individual Olympic gold medals, a record for men’s gymnastics, died last Friday in Kiev, Ukraine. He was 76.

headline: Reporter Wont Testify in R. Kelly Trial
text: A writer for The Chicago Sun-Times refused to answer questions on Wednesday at R. Kelly’s child pornography trial, The Associated Press reported. In his refusal, the writer, Jim DeRogatis, cited an Illinois law that governs reporters’ rights, as well as the First and Fifth Amendments to the Constitution. Mr. DeRogatis read a statement more than a dozen times in response to questions, including whether he had once made a copy of a sex tape that is at the center of the trial. Defense lawyers have said that copying the tape  which is said to show Mr. Kelly having sex with a minor  would have been a crime. Mr. Kelly has said that he was not the man in the tape. After Mr. DeRogatis’s 10 minutes on the stand, Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court said reporters’ privileges did not apply. But the judge ruled that Mr. De Rogatis did not have to testify, citing his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.

headline: Red Cross in New Dispute Over Disaster Relief Funds
text: The American Red Cross has again found itself at the center of a dispute over its fund-raising, this time in the backyard of a major Congressional critic, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa.

headline: Cell Services Keep It Easy, and Free
text: You hear it all the time: “These cellphones are too complicated, by cracky! I don’t want to play music or surf the Internet. I just want to make phone calls!”

headline: Lights, Camera, Tax Credit: Massachusetts Lures Filmmakers With Generous Rebate
text: Angela Peri was shepherding the more than 200 extras she had sent to the set of a new movie, “Paul Blart: Mall Cop,” being filmed in an upscale mall near Boston. So Ms. Peri, who runs a small casting agency, Boston Casting, hardly had a moment to talk about the impact of the new tax credits going to filmmakers in Massachusetts.

headline: Latino Immigrants Hit by Jobs Shortage
text: Latino immigrants were especially hard hit over the last year by the slump in the construction industry, reaching 7.5 percent unemployment in the first three months of 2008, according to a report released Wednesday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

headline: Court Won’t Delay Same-Sex Marriages
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The California Supreme Court on Wednesday refused to stay its landmark decision allowing same-sex marriage, clearing the way for gay weddings to begin statewide later this month.

headline: Immigration Perspectives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Waiting for Triple Crown: What’s the Rush?
text: How many times can one person commit? My horse was Charismatic. I actually drove down to the airport with a photographer buddy of mine in 1999 to see Charismatic get off the transport from Louisville.

headline: Senate Panel Accuses Bush of Iraq Exaggerations
text: WASHINGTON  A long-delayed Senate report endorsed by Democrats and some Republicans has concluded that President Bush and his aides built the public case for war against Iraq by exaggerating available intelligence and by ignoring disagreements among spy agencies about Iraq’s weapons programs and Saddam Hussein’s links to Al Qaeda.

headline: Is Art Furniture Growing Up?
text: LONDON

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press game report on Wednesday in some editions of the baseball roundup misstated the score of Philadelphia’s victory against Cincinnati. It was 3-2, not 6-3.

headline: It’s Over. Now It Begins.
text: The Democratic Party has chosen Barack Obama, and that left Hillary Rodham Clinton with a choice.

headline: Mets and Reyes Changing Attitudes and Getting Results
text: SAN FRANCISCO  No words were exchanged, no eye contact made when the José Reyes Home Run Celebratory Tour reached John Maine. He just tapped Maine on the shoulder, and off he went. Maine appreciated the gesture, which, in the wake of the Mets’ 5-3 victory against the San Francisco Giants on Wednesday afternoon, carried more than a trace of symbolism.

headline: The Touch of a Ten-Spot
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shopping for Old Furniture With Michele Spadaro
text: MICHELE SPADARO once made a sofa from garbage, not because she was enamored of refuse, but because as a set designer on a small budget, she needed one for a play. She had to buy only tubing for the frame; the foam, fabric and plywood were all found on the street.

headline: Thomas A. Johnson, Pioneering Black Journalist, Dies at 79
text: Thomas A. Johnson, the first black reporter at Newsday and later, at The New York Times, one of the first black journalists to work as a foreign correspondent for a major daily newspaper, died on Monday in Queens. He was 79.

headline: $50 Million More to Physics Institute
text: The ubiquitous Blackberry has been good for Canadian physics. Mike Lazaridis, founder and co-chairman of the Blackberry’s maker, Research in Motion, announced Wednesday night that he was donating an additional $50 million to the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in Waterloo, Ontario. Mr. Lazaridis attended college in Waterloo before dropping out in 1984 to start RIM. In 2000 he founded the physics institute, which has done pioneering work in quantum information and quantum gravity. His new gift brings his total contributions to $150 million.

headline: Tip of the Week: Let Your iPhone Do the Walking
text: Got an iPhone and need to quickly find pizza, coffee, cash or Thai food nearby? Tap the Maps icon on the Home screen, then tap the small locator button in the bottom left corner to pinpoint your position. Tap the Search button and type in a keyword like “ATM” or “Thai” in the box at the top of the screen with the onscreen keyboard. Tap the keyboard’s blue Search button to see all the banks and restaurants near you pop up as red pins on the map.

headline: Wal-Mart’s Detractors Come In From the Cold
text: Over the last several months, a confidential report has circulated within the headquarters of Wal-Mart Stores, proposing sweeping changes to its employee health care plans.

headline: A Boom in Brooklyn
text: To the Editor:

headline: Food Is Gold, So Billions Invested in Farming
text: Huge investment funds have already poured hundreds of billions of dollars into booming financial markets for commodities like wheat, corn and soybeans.

headline: Opposition to Menthol Cigarettes Grows
text: Seven former federal health secretaries joined on Wednesday to protest menthol’s special treatment in a tobacco bill pending in Congress.

headline: Awaiting Clinton’s Return to Home on Old House Lane
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

headline: Bearing Witness to the Fallen and the Grieving
text: “The scenes in this book are true,” Jim Sheeler writes of “Final Salute,” his book about fallen military personnel. “I witnessed most of them firsthand, and have the tear-smeared notebook to prove it.” Nobody who reads Mr. Sheeler’s account of just how the families of the dead are notified, the lost loved ones enshrined and their memories preserved and honored will have any question about where those tears came from.

headline: A One-Day, Two-Way Sale
text: Modernica, a store that sells reproductions of midcentury modern furniture and lighting, will hold a one-day warehouse sale on Saturday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Biscuit Company Lofts at 1820 Industrial Street in downtown Los Angeles. The company also will have an online sale of 10 pieces from 6 a.m. to midnight. They include a Case Study daybed ($1,116.50), a Noguchi coffee table ($486.50), a Noguchi dining table ($556.50) and a fiberglass rocker ($262.50). Information: (323) 933-0383 or modernica.net.

headline: Tomato Catch-Up
text: GROWING great tomatoes is like having a baby. You either start your own from seed, or adopt little ones through an organization you have seriously investigated.

headline: U.S. Not Seeking Permanent Iraq Bases, Ambassador Says
text: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Iraq on Thursday dismissed any suggestion that the Bush administration is maneuvering to set up permanent military bases in Iraq.

headline: Guards Charged in Smuggling
text: SAN DIEGO  Two men working as security guards for a company under contract to the Border Patrol were arraigned Wednesday in federal court here on charges that they had agreed to accept a bribe to smuggle two illegal immigrants into Los Angeles instead of returning them to Mexico.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the home of J. Morgan Puett, a fashion designer and artist, described her affiliation with the School of the Art Institute of Chicago incorrectly. She is an instructor there, not an adjunct professor.

headline: Borrowing a Cup of Sugar (and Maybe a Spouse)
text: Each generation looks back at its parents’ youth with pity and envy: people were so naïve back then, and life was so easy.

headline: 9/11 Suspects Arraigned at Guantánamo Hearing
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba  Five detainees who the government says were high-level coordinators of the Sept. 11 terror attacks were arraigned in a military courtroom here on Thursday morning.

headline: Explosions and Shootings Disrupt Relative Calm in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Insurgents preparing to attack an American military base in Baghdad accidentally killed themselves and more than a dozen civilians on Wednesday when their rocket-loaded truck exploded in a residential area.

headline: The Revolutionary
text: FASHION, they say, is ephemeral. But in the case of Yves Saint Laurent, that adage holds little weight. During much of his 45-year career, Saint Laurent, who died in Paris on Sunday at the age of 71, held the style world in his thrall, wielding an influence that dominated the runways and exerts a fascination to this day.

headline: Penalties Sought From Utilities Over Untrimmed Trees
text: WASHINGTON  Almost five years after overgrown trees helped set off a blackout that left 50 million people in the dark, a reliability enforcement group announced on Wednesday that it had lowered the boom on two electric utilities that were still not trimming their trees properly, and demanded $225,000 in civil penalties from them.

headline: Shifting Ground on Recovery
text: How'd we get from icing and Advil to drinking chocolate milk for muscle recovery? Gretchen Reynolds, who wrote about recovery from workouts in the latest issue of PLAY, says that until recently, no one actually tested the conventional strategies. Rather, many athletes just trusted the advice passed down by a friend or relative. But now, she says, we have some solid evidence, in the form of legitimate medical studies, about what works and doesn't work. If you want to see real benefits, studies show, you'll need the right mix of proteins and carbohydrates to replenish stressed muscles, and the sooner they're taken after a workout, the better. That's where the chocolate milk comes in (and the multitude of protein drinks now available).

headline: Footnotes
text: The revival of “A Chorus Line,” playing at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway, will close on Aug. 17. The critically praised production opened in October 2006 and will have played 18 previews and 759 regular performances when it closes. It recouped its $8 million investment in less than five months. ... Sharon Stone is not welcome at the Shanghai International Film Festival, as the backlash in China against her continued on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Stone stirred outrage in China after suggesting that the recent earthquake had been the result of bad karma. Meanwhile, the Black Eyed Peas helped raise nearly $870,000 for victims of the earthquake at a private charity concert in Shanghai, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Van Morrison and Patti Smith will be among the 30 acts at this year’s four-day Stockholm Jazz Festival, which is to start on July 16, organizers said.

headline: Inquiry Opens Into Northern Rock Bailout
text: BRUSSELS  Northern Rock may be getting government aid for longer than necessary, according to an official European Commission document that suggests that the nationalization of the troubled British lender faces tough scrutiny from regulators.

headline: Research Finds Wide Disparities in Health Care by Race and Region
text: Race and place of residence can have a staggering impact on the course and quality of the medical treatment a patient receives, according to new research showing that blacks with diabetes or vascular disease are nearly five times more likely than whites to have a leg amputated and that women in Mississippi are far less likely to have mammograms than those in Maine.

headline: Still Swinging, Still Hungry, Keely Smith Keeps the Passion
text: “I’d kill right now for a meatball sandwich,” Keely Smith declared from the stage of Birdland on Tuesday evening. Ms. Smith, who has recently acquired the nickname Queen of Swing, has expressed the same craving for meatballs on New York nightclub stages before. Performing clearly stimulates her appetites.

headline: Klaus Perls, Art Dealer Who Gave Picassos to the Met, Dies at 96
text: Klaus G. Perls, who sold art for more than 60 years at the Perls Galleries and donated an important collection of African royal art from Benin and modern works by Picasso and Modigliani valued at more than $60 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Monday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 96 and lived in Armonk, N.Y.

headline: A Pageant of Early Aileys on a Journey to Posterity
text: New York audiences are so used to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s annual winter appearances at City Center that the idea of finding the company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in June is positively disconcerting. But it was resident at the Brooklyn Academy from 1969 to 1971, and the fit seems natural  or so thought the Joyce Theater directors who are presenting the Ailey company’s short run this week.

headline: The Joy of Insects
text: WHEN summer comes, and flowers and windows open, insects follow. They in turn are often followed, swiftly, by a fly swatter. But if you can’t beat them, why not let them join the party? This season, jewelry designers, perhaps recalling the imaginative little girl whose surreal interactions with insects brought a dreamy beauty to “Pan’s Labyrinth,” have shone a spotlight on the Insecta class, finding glamour and chic in all manner of creepy-crawlies.

headline: Mortgage Fraud Is Found During Fire Investigation
text: An investigation into a rash of arsons two years ago in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, helped prosecutors uncover a different crime in the neighborhood: mortgage fraud.

headline: Real Thought for Food for Long Workouts
text: DR. MARK TARNOPOLSKY, a muscle physiology researcher at McMaster University in Canada and a physician, knows all about the exhortations by supplement makers and many nutritionists on what to eat and when to eat it for optimal performance.

headline: At Harvard, They Hail a Fed Chief
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Ben S. Bernanke spoke about the economic pressures created by high oil prices and inflation at his alma mater on Wednesday.

headline: A City Where Hospitals Are as Ill as the Patients
text: LOS ANGELES  The patients line up at 6:30 a.m. outside the tidy clinic. Two hours later, when it opens, they will sit and wait some more.

headline: Like the Water, Grand Plans Buoy Spirits at a Vacation Spot From a Bygone Era
text: SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y.  The Vanderbilts and the Macys were regulars. Oscar Wilde held readings of his latest works here. Ulysses S. Grant and Theodore Roosevelt came for brief respites.

headline: Spanish Soccer Team Strikes Deal for Altidore
text: The Spanish club Villarreal reached an agreement in principle with Major League Soccer and the Red Bulls to sign Jozy Altidore, an 18-year-old striker, a team official said on Wednesday. Ivan Gazidis, the league’s deputy commissioner, confirmed the agreement.

headline: Ochoa Stars on Screen as Well as Green, in Documentary Charting Her Rapid Rise
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  Documentary filmmakers often spend years tailing their subjects, trying to capture the money shot. Lorena Ochoa of Mexico made it easy for the two men who followed her around with a handheld camera for 11 months. What they caught on film was a great comet: Ochoa supplanting Annika Sorenstam as the world No. 1 and winning her first major, on the hallowed grounds of St. Andrews.

headline: Correction: Critical Shopper - Catherine Malandrino
text: The Critical Shopper column last Thursday, about the Catherine Malandrino boutique at 652 Hudson Street, misstated the location of Vento, a nearby restaurant. It is across Hudson Street from the store, on the next block north; it is not next door.

headline: Getty Adds to Antiquities With Third-Century Work
text: LOS ANGELES  The J. Paul Getty Museum announced Wednesday that it had acquired a third-century Roman marble sarcophagus that includes a detailed relief carving of a Dionysiac vintage festival. It is the museum’s second antiquities purchase since it adopted a new, stricter policy on buying ancient objects in 2006.

headline: Producing Substitute Natural Gas From Coal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Less-Is-More Notebook Makes Its Bid for a Little Space on the Desktop
text: The laptop’s assault on the desktop PC continues. Asus has announced it is repacking its ultra-light, ultra-cheap notebook PC, the Eee, into a slim box for the office.

headline: O.E.C.D. Cuts Its Growth Forecast
text: PARIS  Growth among the leading industrialized countries will slip this year and next, with activity flat in the United States, but a serious recession or inflation spiral should be avoided, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Wednesday.

headline: Clinton Ready to End Bid and Endorse Obama
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will endorse Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, bringing a close to her 17-month campaign for the White House, aides said. Her decision came after Democrats urged her Wednesday to leave the race and allow the party to coalesce around Mr. Obama.

headline: Film Spotlights City Life Often Overlooked
text: The directors of “Take Out,” a feature film about a Chinese deliveryman who must pay off his debt to immigrant-smugglers, do not claim that their movie is based on a true story. But it has more than a passing resemblance to a documentary, so much so that after a screening, one of the audience members asked where the man was now, and whether he was doing all right.

headline: Malaysia and India Increase Price of Subsidized Fuel
text: India and Malaysia risked the wrath of voters by raising the price of subsidized fuel, measures that could further weaken the governments of both countries, already made fragile by recent electoral setbacks.

headline: A Household’s Wounds Are Raw, but No One Is Willing to Ease the Tensions
text: The beseeching smile flickers and then widens. The eyes crinkle nervously, glinting with hope. The voice is a soothing, silky purr. Joyce, the unofficial family negotiator played by JoBeth Williams in “Body Awareness,” always seems to be apologizing for something or somebody.

headline: Horror Show’s Life Lessons ...Er, Maybe Death Lessons
text: You know things are not going to work out well for a petty criminal when, stranded in a fortlike compound occupied by three young women who look like American Girl versions of 19th-century psychiatric nurses and talk like the weird sisters in “Macbeth,” he innocently inquires about Internet access. “You don’t even have any dial-up, or anything?” the crook (Jesse Plemons) asks. “Are you Amish?”

headline: Secret Service Detains Artist Over ‘Assassination’ Exhibit
text: New York City police detectives and Secret Service agents briefly detained and questioned an artist on Wednesday morning as he installed an exhibition with the title, “The Assassination of Hillary Clinton/The Assassination of Barack Obama.”

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A Man in the News article on Wednesday about Senator Barack Obama misstated the name of a club in Chicago where he played basketball on Tuesday. It is the East Bank Club, not the Back Bay Club.

headline: A Town-Hall Summer
text: John McCain wants to recreate the old Mickey Rooney-Judy Garland movies about a couple of kids putting on a show in the barn. Him and Barack, barnstorming around the country. They could fly together on the same plane!

headline: A Way to Solve Crosswords Without Pencil (or Eraser)
text: When should Grandma get a Nintendo DS? When it lets her work an endless supply of crossword puzzles, that’s when.

headline: Many Blacks Find Joy in Unexpected Breakthrough
text: Kwabena Sam-Brew, a 38-year-old immigrant from Ghana, doubted that Nana, his 5-year-old American-born daughter, would remember the rally that effectively crowned Senator Barack Obama as the Democratic nominee Tuesday night.

headline: Venezuela: Killing of Executive Might Have Been a Mistake
text: The police in Caracas said that the killing of a newspaper executive on Monday might have been a case of mistaken identity. Pierre Fould Gerges, 48, the vice president of Reporte de la Economía, a business newspaper, was killed by a gunman on a motorcycle who followed him after he left the newspaper’s headquarters in a car that belonged to his brother, Tanous Gerges, the newspaper’s president.

headline: Monsanto Seeks Big Increase in Crop Yields
text: Monsanto, the leader in agricultural biotechnology, pledged Wednesday to develop seeds that would double the yields of corn, soybeans and cotton by 2030 and would require 30 percent less water, land and energy to grow.

headline: Ex-Obama Fund-Raiser Is Convicted of Fraud
text: CHICAGO  Antoin Rezko, a once-powerful fund-raiser who helped propel the career of Senator Barack Obama, was found guilty on Wednesday by a federal jury of 16 counts, including fraud, money laundering and bribery in an influence-peddling scheme that touched the highest levels of the administration of Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois.

headline: Two Sides of the Cape
text: "Why can't The New York Times write about the SAVAGERY and BRUTALITY" of bullfighting, ended one letter from a reader in Chicago. It was a sentiment echoed by a New Jersey reader who wrote, "This kind of gory spectacle deserves to die. To glorify it is disgusting."

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about efforts by some Harvard alumni to persuade the university to use its wealth in new ways, like supporting colleges in Africa, misstated the graduation year of Tamara Rogers, an alumna who is vice president for university development. It was 1974, not 1981.

headline: Smucker to Pay $3 Billion for Folgers Coffee
text: The J. M. Smucker Company, the maker of jams and jellies, announced Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the Folgers coffee business from Procter & Gamble for $2.95 billion in stock.

headline: U.S. Pushes to Rely More on Remotely Piloted Craft
text: WASHINGTON  Early last year, the Air Force was able to keep no more than 11 of the remotely piloted, armed Predator surveillance aircraft flying over Iraq and Afghanistan at any one time.

headline: A Historic Night, an American Dream
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bryant Park Braces for a Tidal Wave of Traffic
text: Bryant Park in Midtown may soon confront a fate that only Yogi Berra could have described: It will be so crowded, nobody will go there anymore.

headline: Governor Declares Drought in California
text: LOS ANGELES  Its reservoir levels receding and its grounds parched, California has fallen officially into drought, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Wednesday, warning that the state might be forced to ration water to cities and regions if conservation efforts did not improve.

headline: France: Paintings Retrieved
text: Four paintings stolen from an art museum in Nice in August were recovered undamaged in a car in Marseille. The paintings  Claude Monet’s “Cliffs Near Dieppe,” Alfred Sisley’s “Lane of Poplars at Moret-sur-Loing,” above, and Jan Brueghel the Elder’s “Allegory of Water” and “Allegory of Earth”  were taken from the Museum of Fine Arts on Aug. 5 by masked gunmen who held visitors and staff members hostage. The police said they had arrested more than 10 people in connection with the theft.

headline: Hollywood’s Snakes and Assassins Squeeze Into a Video Game Console
text: With the release of the action adventure game Lego Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures, Harrison Ford has become the first actor to be turned into a Lego video game character twice. That may not be the first thing he lists on his résumé, but it’s got to rank above starring in “Six Days, Seven Nights.”

headline: TV Host Is in His Prime With a Morning Audience
text: When MSNBC awarded Don Imus’s old morning-show slot to Joe Scarborough last summer, it did so with little enthusiasm and few expectations. Mr. Scarborough, a former Republican congressman from Florida, had never quite seemed comfortable on his prime-time show, “Scarborough Country,” nor did he seem to mesh ideologically with this cable news channel’s more liberal-leaning stars, Keith Olbermann and Chris Matthews.

headline: Afghan Borders Concern NATO Force Leader
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the new commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan expressed fresh concern over rising activity by militants in Pakistan’s tribal areas, two powerful suicide bombs killed two people and wounded several others near the Pakistani border on Wednesday.

headline: Big Brown Free of Steroids, Trainer Says
text: Big Brown will begin the Belmont Stakes from the No. 1 post position. The big bay colt is a prohibitive 2-5 favorite to win the 140th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday and become only the 12th Triple Crown champion in history. Big Brown will also attempt to remain undefeated and gain immortality without his monthly steroid injection.

headline: Bro Knows You
text: “The power of the sports commercial is that it conveys the illusion of intimacy with an athlete,” Bryan Curtis writes in the June issue of PLAY. “It was from a commercial that we learned that Michael Jordan was jolly; that LeBron James could inhabit multiple characters with the aplomb of Alec Guinness in ‘Kind Hearts and Coronets’ (or at least Eddie Murphy in ‘The Nutty Professor’); that Peyton Manning was a hipster ironist. In the span of a 30-second ad, the gulf between athlete and fan seems to close, at least a bit. Against all evidence to the contrary, Charles and Michael and Peyton and LeBron begin to feel like our old pals.

headline: Detroit Automakers Compete for a Vanishing Truck Market
text: DETROIT  Ford Motor and Chrysler expected to find themselves in a hard-fought showdown when they rolled out bigger, brasher pickup trucks this fall, hoping to enlarge their shares of a segment that has brought them huge profits.

headline: An Award for Floral Arrangement
text: IN a spring season of graphic wallpaper patterns and hothouse floral prints, those of the Belgian designer Dries Van Noten stand out as particularly vivid. A single dress was made up of irises, roses and tulips in such a way as to suggest that its wearer was the fashion opposite of a shrinking violet.

headline: Spanish Club to Pay Record Sum for an M.L.S. Star, Altidore
text: The Spanish club Villarreal reached an agreement in principle with Major League Soccer and the New York Red Bulls to sign Jozy Altidore, an 18-year-old striker, a team official said on Wednesday and Ivan Gazidis, the league’s deputy commissioner, confirmed.

headline: Poppies and Dill
text: Q. Are plume poppies really invasive? And are they really poppies?

headline: Injury Throws a Snag into Home Run Derby Plans
text: David Ortiz’s wrist injury is forcing Major League Baseball to look at alternatives to him trying to hit a home run to a specific area of Yankee Stadium designated by a fan at the Home Run Derby on the night before the All-Star Game.

headline: In Rare Study, Cubans Put Money Worries First
text: MEXICO CITY  A rare study conducted surreptitiously in Cuba found that more than half of those interviewed considered their economic woes to be their chief concern while less than 10 percent listed lack of political freedom as the main problem facing the country.

headline: Clinton to End Bid and Endorse Obama
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will endorse Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, bringing a close to her 17-month campaign for the White House, aides said. Her decision came after Democrats urged her on Wednesday to leave the race and allow the party to coalesce around Mr. Obama.

headline: Verizon in Talks to Buy Alltel
text: Verizon Communications is near a deal to buy Alltel for about $27 billion, including the assumption of debt. Vodafone, Verizon’s partner in its wireless business, confirmed the talks in a short statement Thursday, which said Verizon Wireless was in “advanced discussions regarding the potential acquisition of Alltel.”

headline: From $15 Per Diem in Albany to N.B.A. Riches
text: Coach Phil Jackson once had to complain that his road per diem wasn’t enough for a decent meal. He once had to lobby for a raise to $30,000 after winning his first championship on the bench.

headline: Manager of Rogue Trader Calls Himself Unqualified
text: PARIS  The former boss of Jérôme Kerviel, the trader whose hidden bets cost Société Générale nearly 5 billion euros or $7.2 billion, suggested Wednesday that the bank should not have put him in that supervisory job because he was not qualified.

headline: Two Early Trump Tricks Prove to Be One Too Many
text: At the trial in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., to select the United States open team for the next world championship in Beijing in October, the two-day, 120-board final starts on Thursday.

headline: Salad Days for the Internet
text: THE other afternoon, my husband and I were drinking beer on the front porch and already feeling a little dirty about what we planned to do later  grill a big fat steak brushed with butter. Then a terrible thing happened.

headline: Palestinian Leader Urges Talks With Hamas
text: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, called unexpectedly late Wednesday for a resumption of dialogue with the Islamic militant group Hamas, a move that could herald a breakdown of his peace talks with Israel.

headline: Standing Up for Sales
text: Usher, below, has made the second-biggest splash of the year on the Billboard chart. His new album, “Here I Stand” (LaFace/Zomba), sold 433,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan; so far only Mariah Carey has had a bigger entrance, with “E=MC2” (Island) moving 463,000 in April. In an otherwise slow week, Usher’s album sold more than the rest of the Top 10 put together. The soundtrack to “Sex and the City” (New Line) bowed at No. 2 with 66,000. Last week’s top seller, the self-titled record on Universal Republic by 3 Doors Down, dropped to No. 3 with 63,000, and Bun B’s “II Trill” (Rap-A-Lot/Asylum) fell two spots to No. 4, with 40,000. Leona Lewis, a 23-year-old British singer who has been a steady presence in the Top 10 for two months, moved up one to No. 5, with 39,000 sales of “Spirit” (Syco/J). Down the chart, Al Green scored the highest opening-week chart position of his career: his acclaimed new album, “Lay It Down” (Blue Note), moved 34,000 copes to reach No. 9.

headline: Ikea’s Brooklyn Beachhead
text: Soon, New York City residents in need of a new sofa or Swedish meatballs won’t have to visit Long Island or New Jersey to get an Ikea fix. Ikea Brooklyn is to open June 18 at 1 Beard Street on the Erie Basin in Red Hook. Although the new location will sell the same products as the 34 other Ikea stores in the United States, it will have a cafeteria with views of the Statue of Liberty and the Manhattan skyline, and a 6 ½-acre waterfront esplanade that will be open to the public.

headline: Iran: Bahai Arrests Confirmed
text: A government spokesman confirmed that a group of Bahai religious leaders had been arrested, but said that the charges against them related to security and not religion. The spokesman, Gholam Hossein Elham, said the group had “acted against the country’s interests” and had links with Israelis, according to the state-run news agency, IRNA.

headline: Philadelphia Will Try to Reduce Foreclosures
text: PHILADELPHIA  Philadelphia announced a program on Wednesday to reduce the number of people who are forced from their homes because they cannot afford the payments on an adjustable-rate subprime mortgage.

headline: With Opponent in Place, McCain Adapts Strategy
text: BATON ROUGE, La.  Now that there is a presumptive Democratic nominee, the presumptive Republican nominee, Senator John McCain, began to show some inklings on Wednesday of what his complicated general election strategy might look like.

headline: Paramount Vantage Takes a Trim
text: The division of Paramount Pictures that helped produce the Oscar-winning films “No Country for Old Men” and “There Will Be Blood” has been cut back, The Hollywood Reporter said. The two-year-old Paramount Vantage will continue as a production label under its president, Nick Meyer, but its marketing, distribution and physical production departments will be taken over by Paramount Pictures. Three senior positions are being cut, the report said, including that of Vantage’s executive vice president, Rob Schulze. Paramount Vantage became partners with Miramax on both “No Country for Old Men” and “There Will Be Blood.” Other notable films it has released include “Into the Wild” and “An Inconvenient Truth.”

headline: More Space for TiVo
text: My TiVo recorder is constantly running out of space. Can I get a bigger hard drive for it?

headline: Nearly 12,000 Are Arrested in Bangladesh
text: NEW DELHI  The army-backed caretaker government in Bangladesh that has netted hundreds of politicians and businesspeople in a yearlong anticorruption drive has now rounded up nearly 12,000 people in what it calls a crusade against crime.

headline: Zapping Teenage Torment
text: ADOLESCENCE is an awkward time to grow a mustache. Especially if you’re a girl.

headline: Employee Stock Plans
text: To the Editor

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Big City column in some editions on May 19, about a reunion of 14 women who were in the same sixth-grade class at Public School 87 on the Upper West Side in 1956, referred incompletely to the occupation of the reunion organizer, Jessica Weber. In addition to her work as a graphic designer, she owns her own graphic design company.

headline: More Talking Than Listening in the Senate Debate About Climate Change
text: WASHINGTON  About a day into the debate over legislation to combat global warming but before Republicans brought the discourse to a stop on Wednesday by insisting that the clerk read every word of the 492-page bill, Senator James M. Inhofe decided to get a few things off his chest.

headline: Player Caught in a Web Not of His Spinning
text: Few opponents have been able to slow Bol Kong on the basketball court.

headline: Man Falls to Death Fleeing Drug Raid in the Bronx
text: A man fleeing a drug raid in a Bronx apartment on Wednesday afternoon fell three stories to his death, while two women making the same escape attempt survived and were hospitalized, the authorities said.

headline: Senate Approves Framework for Spending in Coming Year
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday gave final approval to a $3 trillion budget blueprint that calls for more spending than President Bush requested for education, highway construction and other domestic programs.

headline: Surf Channels, or the Web, With a Remote
text: ESPN the Ultimate Remote, a bright-red home theater remote control from tvCompass, is the first in what one can only hope will be a long line of TV-channel-branded electronics.

headline: Slate’s Editor Will Head a New Unit at the Washington Post Co.
text: The editor of Slate will oversee a new unit of the Washington Post Company and look to broaden the pioneering Internet magazine’s portfolio.

headline: Slashed Woman’s Ex-Boyfriend Is Held on Harassment Charges
text: A former boyfriend of a woman slashed in the face by two attackers in a condominium lobby in Chinatown last week has been arrested in New Jersey on charges that he had previously harassed her, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Big City column in some editions on May 5, about Nancy Weiser, a lifestyle coach who teaches Westchester County mothers how to simplify their lives and eat more healthful food, overstated her academic work at Teachers College at Columbia University. She has a certificate in health counseling from a continuing education program formerly offered in conjunction with Teachers College; she does not have a degree from the college.

headline: More Cuts as United Grounds Its Low-Cost Carrier
text: The closet with the Kate Spade flight attendant uniforms just got some company: teddy bears.

headline: Step Right Up: A Playful, Complex Whirl, According to Tharp
text: While I was watching Tuesday night’s world premiere of “Rabbit and Rogue,” Twyla Tharp’s new work for American Ballet Theater, I was unaware of any particular audience excitement. Almost the reverse: though the dancers performed some spectacular feats, seldom could you hear any of the responsive noises usually elicited by the company’s virtuoso stunts. An ovation, however, ensued. And you could tell by what some in the audience were saying on the way out  wonderful, exciting, surprising, beautiful  that many people sincerely admired it.

headline: Foreclosure Possible for Ed McMahon
text: Ed McMahon, below, Johnny Carson’s former sidekick on “The Tonight Show” and the former host of “Star Search,” is said to face foreclosure on his multimillion-dollar Beverly Hills house, above, because he is $644,000 behind in payments. The Associated Press reported that Mr. McMahon had fallen behind in payments on $4.8 million in mortgage loans. A unit of the Countrywide Financial Corporation filed a default notice on Feb. 28 with the Los Angeles County Recorder’s Office, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Beyond his decades of work with Carson, Mr. McMahon, 85, has also been a spokesman for the American Family Publishers’ sweepstakes. But Howard Bragman, his spokesman, said Mr. McMahon had not been able to work as a spokesman for various products since he broke his neck 18 months ago. He added that Mr. McMahon had been in “very fruitful discussions” with the lender to resolve the situation. It is unclear whether Mr. McMahon and his wife, Pamela, will remain in the six-bedroom, five-bathroom house, in a hilltop gated community overlooking Mulholland Drive. It is listed for sale at $6.25 million and has been on the market for two years, said a real estate agent, Alex Davis.

headline: Sharks Strike Panic Along Mexico’s Pacific Coast
text: IXTAPA, Mexico  “Tiburón!” a little boy cried out, jumping up and down in the sand with his finger outstretched toward the ocean. Everyone around followed the youngster’s panicky gaze out past the waves and into the Pacific, where they spotted not a shark’s fin but a buoy.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,081 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: Zimbabwean Opposition Leaders Held by Police
text: JOHANNESBURG  Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader who placed first in Zimbabwe’s March elections and now faces a runoff with President Robert Mugabe, was detained by the police for nine hours on Wednesday and charged with drawing a big crowd, his party said. He was released late in the evening.

headline: Charles Moskos, Policy Adviser, Dies at 74
text: Charles Moskos, a sociologist who regularly advised policy makers, senators and generals on military matters, including coming up with the armed services’ “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gay personnel, died on May 31 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 74.

headline: Martínez Feels Fine but Keeps Outlook Day to Day
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The morning after making his first major league start in two months, Pedro Martínez said he did not feel sore. Not yet, at least. After finishing a hearty breakfast and autographing a box of baseballs, he turned to his personal trainer, Chris Correnti, who nodded back. Workout time.

headline: 3rd Minnesota Bridge Is Closed as Special Inspections Continue
text: ST. PAUL  State officials have closed a bridge over the Mississippi River after finding problems similar to those suspected of contributing to the fatal collapse of the Interstate 35W bridge in downtown Minneapolis last Aug. 1.

headline: Vigil for Tiananmen Dead Draws Fewer in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG  A somewhat smaller crowd than in previous years turned out here on Wednesday evening for the annual candlelight vigil commemorating the 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square, the participation depressed by a growing reluctance among many Hong Kong residents to confront Beijing officials on human rights issues.

headline: Old Music Online
text: Lynyrd Skynyrd, Bob Marley and Jimi Hendrix are among the performers whose vintage concerts will become part of the nearly 500 recordings available for download purchase at Wolfgang’s Vault, the music and memorabilia site (wolfgangsvault.com). The additions came through a deal between Universal Music Group and the founder of Wolfgang’s Vault, Bill Sagan, Reuters reported. Of the 1,434 concerts on the site, 488 can be downloaded now, Mr. Sagan told Billboard.com, adding that “some very major artists will be downloading within the next 30 to 60 days.”

headline: Taking ‘No’ for an Answer
text: Boston

headline: Revived Paper Mill Brings a Town Back With It
text: NEWTON FALLS, N.Y.  Eight years ago, a paper mill closed in this remote corner of the western Adirondacks, taking with it more than 100 jobs. Most of the 75 houses in this speck of a hamlet a two-hour drive from Canada soon fell into disrepair, their frames thrashed by weather and hardship.

headline: Moving Beyond the Kitchen
text: New Paltz, N.Y.

headline: Refinishing Floors With Less Mess
text: REFINISHING a hardwood floor is dirty and disruptive work. Dust-removal systems can reduce the mess, but the job will still take days and require moving furniture, corralling the cat and enduring the fumes.

headline: To Adopt, Please Press Hold
text: JOHN AND JULIE CASSERLY, both lawyers in St. Paul, have been waiting 11 months to complete the adoption of a Guatemalan girl whom they have named Ruby Rosario. But they say they are afraid to check e-mail messages or answer the phone. It’s always some update from their adoption agency regarding the latest suspension of the process or some other bad news.

headline: Carefully Planned Jazz, Fit for a ’50s Soundtrack
text: The bassist Ben Wolfe has some very tight ideas about composition, an interest in combining a small jazz band with strings and an admiration for jazz of the late 1950s. Where that leads him, inevitably, is to music that sounds as if it’s made for a film: noirs, thrillers, movies shot at night with rain-slicked streets reflecting the lights, that kind of thing.

headline: Proposals Would Curtail Power of Pakistan Leader
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In its first substantial move since taking power, the main political party in Pakistan has proposed sweeping constitutional changes intended to limit the authority of President Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Obama Offers Assurances at Pro-Israel Meeting
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama, in his first day as the Democrats’ presumptive presidential nominee, plunged into the thicket of Middle East politics on Wednesday with comments on the status of Jerusalem and deterrence of Iran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: Indonesia Cracks Down on Extremists
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Hundreds of police officers swept through a Jakarta neighborhood Wednesday morning, arresting about 60 members of a hard-line Islamic group blamed for a violent attack last Sunday at an interfaith rally in the capital.

headline: The Delta in Our Home
text: Baltimore

headline: Touring Wonderland With Guides Who Sing
text: Peter Westergaard had five operas under his belt when he began work on “Alice in Wonderland,” a straightforward if mildly quirky setting of the Lewis Carroll fantasy. Two years ago the Center for Contemporary Opera, which often presents workshop productions, staged the first half of the work, and on Tuesday evening the center and Princeton University’s music department, where Mr. Westergaard is a professor emeritus, presented the complete opera at Symphony Space.

headline: Yahoo Tries to Move Past Takeover Status
text: YAHOO has been very much in the headlines these days, much to its chagrin. But on Wednesday the company set out to make news of its own, describing a menu of deals in the online advertising realm.

headline: Thunder, Rain and Crickets as a Prelude to Ravel’s Swirl
text: Pascal Rioult is presenting works choreographed to Bach and Ravel for his company’s current Skirball Center stint, which began Tuesday. This is not to his advantage. He is a creator of decorative modern dances that do not gain in strength when set to “The Art of Fugue” or “Bolero.”

headline: Obscure Labels of a Boldface Kind
text: I RECOMMEND visiting the new hipster high-end clothing store Aloha Rag as soon as possible, because it’s in the dead center of a freshly gentrified neighborhood that is about to become the city’s next overhyped fashion and night life destination.

headline: PBS Gains Sponsors
text: After a four-year absence,ExxonMobil will resume sponsorships of PBS programs this month, PBS announced. ExxonMobil will partly underwrite the news program “Nightly Business Report” and the science program “Nova” through the end of 2008. The company had sponsored “Masterpiece Theater” and other PBS programs for three decades but decided to withdraw its support in 2004. The new sponsorship fills a significant gap for “Nightly Business Report,” a half-hour daily broadcast. One of the show’s two sponsors, A. G. Edwards, ended its support in January, citing budget restraints. The other sponsor, Franklin Templeton, renewed its deal in January. The program still has room for two more sponsors. “Nova” is also underwritten by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and David H. Koch, an owner of Koch Industries. That program is seeking another sponsor as well.

headline: Experts Warned of Quake Risk in China
text: SHANGHAI  Chinese scientists say that even before a final accounting can be made in last month’s earthquake in Sichuan Province, one thing is painfully evident: The huge death toll stems partly from a failure to heed clear warnings of a devastating earthquake in the area.

headline: 42 Statues of Liberty Will Start All-Star Hype
text: When 42 eight-and-a-half-foot replicas of the Statue of Liberty crop up across the city in the coming weeks, it will mark the beginning of Major League Baseball’s campaign to generate hype for the 79th All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium on July 15.

headline: The Jews of Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with a film review of the documentary “Operation Filmmaker,” using information provided by Icarus Films, which released the movie, misidentified the man on the left who worked on the film. He is Kouross Esmaeli  not David Schisgall, a producer.

headline: United Chief’s Message to Employees
text: Following is the text of a telephone message that Glenn F. Tilton, the chief executive of UAL, gave to employees of United Airlines on Wednesday morning. United chief operating officer, John Tague, also participated.

headline: Scoop It Up or Pay: On Patrol With Enforcers of the Dog Law
text: It was just after dawn when Theo Otibu began prowling Ditmas Park in Brooklyn in his unmarked Sanitation Department car. He scanned the sidewalk for an elusive prey, one known only by the droppings of its best friend: the dog owner who does not scoop.

headline: Posada Is Back and Ready to Get Behind the Plate
text: Jorge Posada returned to the Yankees’ roster Wednesday, with his sore right shoulder feeling better, and said he expected to start at catcher Thursday afternoon in the finale of a three-game series against the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: Smaller Than a Laptop, but Bigger Than a Phone
text: LUGGING around a big-screen MacBook Pro or other large laptop to the local Starbucks may give you a great visual experience on the road, but at close to seven pounds, it could also give you a bad back.

headline: Former Nicaraguan Official Wins U.N. Assembly Presidency
text: UNITED NATIONS  The Rev. Miguel d’Escoto Brockmann, an outspoken leftist critic of the United States and a former foreign minister in Nicaragua’s Sandinista government, was elected president of the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

headline: China: Japanese Ship to Visit
text: The first Japanese vessel to visit China since the Communist takeover in 1949 will call at an unidentified port this month, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. The Takanami, a guided missile destroyer, will make the visit under an agreement reached during the recent trip to Japan by President Hu Jintao of China.

headline: Groups Seeking Reforms Assail Paterson
text: ALBANY  The government reform groups were already angry enough with Gov. David A. Paterson. At a news conference on Wednesday, they accused him of abandoning the reform platform on which he had campaigned alongside Eliot Spitzer, in 2006.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 4, 2008

headline: Monkeys and Humans, and Their Brains
text: To the Editor:

headline: President of Union Wins Fight Over Power
text: Andy Stern, the president of the Service Employees International Union, went into its convention under heavy fire from one of its largest locals, but he emerged stronger  overwhelmingly re-elected for another four years and with his power consolidated.

headline: Penguins Raise Scare, but Red Wings Raise Cup
text: PITTSBURGH  The Penguins’ last-gasp shot skidded along the goal line, carrying their Stanley Cup fate in the final seconds of Game 6. The puck finally wobbled past the net as the clock ticked to zero.

headline: Space Station Toilet Is Working Again
text: The troublesome toilet aboard the International Space Station appears to be working again, thanks to a replacement pump taken to the station by the shuttle Discovery.

headline: Foreign Reaction to Obama’s Claim Is Favorable
text: LONDON  Across the globe, pundits and politicians of all stripes competed for hyperbole on Wednesday to applaud Senator Barack Obama’s claim of victory in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, almost as if he had already been elected to the White House.

headline: Marine Is Acquitted in Iraq Killings
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  A Marine intelligence officer has been acquitted of charges that he tried to help cover up the killings of 24 Iraqi men, women and children.

headline: Energy Lessons
text: Perhaps there’s something to treadmill wisdom. We’re all so narrow-band these days, using the vast resources of broadband to direct ourselves into a chosen news and ideological tunnel. Polarized pluralism defines us.

headline: Euro Opener to Be Shown in Central Park
text: Saturday in the park will offer New Yorkers a new experience  the opportunity to see the opening game of the 2008 European Championship on a big screen at the Central Park Bandshell, between 66th and 72nd Streets. ESPN is sponsoring the public viewing, which it said it believed would be the first time a soccer game has been shown outdoors in New York.

headline: A Public Job Still Appeals to Bloomberg
text: As his political team considers strategies that would allow him to remain in public life, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged with rare candor on Wednesday that he was unsure about what to do next, and whether it would be as satisfying as being mayor.

headline: At Art Basel, Old Names and Few Showstoppers
text: BASEL, Switzerland  Twenty-four hours before Art Basel’s invitation-only opening on Tuesday, scores of the art elite gathered, sheeplike, on a wooden ramp at a related event in a cavernous installation space. Word had spread that there was something exciting to see: a dusty old train car whose windows flashed black-and-white images of troubled moments from China’s past.

headline: Cellphone Tracking Study Shows We’re Creatures of Habit
text: News flash: we’re boring.

headline: Mussina Puts Yanks Back on Winning Track
text: At the age of 39, after 18 seasons in the major leagues, the Yankees’ Mike Mussina has nine victories in 2008, tied for the most in the American League. The latest was his best of the season, a 5-1 win against the Toronto Blue Jays that raised his record to 9-4.

headline: India and Malaysia Risk Voters’ Wrath by Raising Fuel Prices
text: BANGKOK  With no end in sight to high world oil prices, India and Malaysia on Wednesday became the latest Asian countries to risk the wrath of voters by raising the price of subsidized fuel, a highly unpopular measure that could further weaken the governments of both countries made fragile by recent electoral setbacks.

headline: Peter Rabbit Must Die
text: THE homeowner, a city-boy artist and illustrator who had moved to rural Pennsylvania, never wanted to kill the woodchucks. Sure, they were ruining the garden and digging up the foundations of outbuildings, but it was a moral issue: the artist, who is still so uncomfortable about what transpired  and so concerned about how his New York clients would feel about it that he is not willing to be identified  did not want to take a life.

headline: Lessons of the Magnolia Tree
text: MY father sat upstairs in his study, working in the one room of our sprawling house that we children could not storm into unless it was a matter of utmost urgency. I now know that the big brown desk was where he wrote his books and often drafted important speeches or new legislation. On the day etched in my memory, all I knew was that I needed his immediate attention.

headline: In N.B.A. Finals, Defenses Hone a Battle Cry: Help!
text: BOSTON  On the eve of his N.B.A. finals debut, the long and lanky Lamar Odom considered the task of guarding the longer and lankier Kevin Garnett and arrived at a simple conclusion.

headline: Remembering Our Father
text: Forty years ago, as he was celebrating his victory in California’s Democratic presidential primary, Senator Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated. To mark the occasion, Op-Ed editors invited his children to share their memories of him.

headline: Sneaking Into History
text: It was spring 1968. I was a teenager and had just gotten my driver’s license when I decided to take my parents’ Chevy Impala from Paramount, the suburb where we lived, into downtown Los Angeles. I had heard that Robert F. Kennedy would be giving a speech on Olvera Street, near Union Station, and I wanted to shake his hand.

headline: Safina Turns the Tables Again to Reach Semifinals
text: PARIS  A sign of impending doom to most tennis players who confront it, match point has been a guarantee of nothing but sunshine ahead for Dinara Safina at this rainy French Open.

headline: Surrounded by Water, and Sights to Shoot
text: Camera makers have found they need to differentiate their new products by appealing to niche markets. Pentax is taking its compact Optio W60, an update of its waterproof cameras, even deeper underwater to find customers.

headline: Rejoicing in Kenya at U.S. Triumph of a Sort of Native Son
text: NAIROBI, Kenya The banner headline across The Kenya Times on Wednesday seemed to say it all, “Obama makes history, beats odds.”

headline: Best Ever? Cast Your Vote
text: On Sunday PLAY presented readers an online video debate over whether Tiger Woods was the greatest athletic performer of all time. Readers were allowed to cast their own vote and share their opinion, and the result was a mixture of outrage, rumination, praise and detailed analysis. As of mid-day Thursday, almost 4,700 readers had cast votes, with 72 percent saying Woods is not the best ever, and 28 percent saying he is. More than 500 people posted comments, ranging from "He has good aim, does that make him an athlete?" to "without Tiger, Obama would not be possible."

headline: Chicago Stays in Running After Early Vote to Decide Host of 2016 Olympics
text: Chicago joined three cities Wednesday in moving a step closer to becoming the host of the 2016 Olympics, setting up a final, fierce race to see which one will hold those Summer Games.

headline: Chateau: The Condensed Version
text: While James Westwater, an artist, and his partner, Naomi Sachs, were renovating an old gymnasium in Beacon, N.Y., into a home in 2005, they lived in a 120-square-foot shed for six months with three dogs and a king-size bed  “and it was great,” Mr. Westwater said. It was in this small space that he conceived the idea for his Plywood Chateaux. “It occurred to me that people could live in much smaller houses. All you need is a 4-foot cube, and it’s a room within a room, a mini-retreat within a house.” To decorate his 4-by-4-foot boxes, he lined the walls with adhesive-backed vinyl printed with photos of French chateaux, and covered the floors with flokati wool rugs. Mr. Westwater’s two Plywood Chateaux prototypes ($12,000 each) will be shown Saturday to July 7, along with 10 of his paintings, at Van Brunt Gallery, 460 Main Street, Beacon, N.Y. (845) 838-2995.

headline: Take Me Out© to the Ballgame®
text: Imagine having to swipe your credit card to debate whether Justin Verlander or Rich Harden has the better fastball? Or flip cards with a pal on the sidewalk? Or endure another of Grandpa’s stories about the glory days of the Brooklyn Dodgers?

headline: India Mahdavi Introduces Furniture to the United States
text: India Mahdavi , an Iranian-born, Parisian designer and architect, recently introduced her line of furniture to the United States. The 18-piece collection of tables, chairs, stools, desks and lighting, is a sculptural mix of lacquer, wood and ceramics. Some of it was used to furnish her projects, like the new Coburg Bar and Hélène Darroze restaurant at the Connaught hotel in London.

headline: Because It’s a Jungle Under There
text: The CableBox is large enough 16 inches long, 6 1/4 inches wide and 5 ½ inches tall  to conceal most surge protectors, with enough room left over for the tangle of wires surrounding them. Made of fire-retardant plastic, it has openings at either end so cords can run in and out, above, and generously sized rubber feet to keep it from sliding across the floor. Dominic Symons, the designer, describes it as “the absolute simplest way” of organizing cables. “Basically, you can take the mess under your desk,” he said, “fit it in the box without even unplugging any of the cables, and put the lid on it.” Available later this month for about $30. Information: bluelounge.com.

headline: High Fidelity On the Go
text: Q. I don’t like the sound quality of MP3 files used by portable music players. Is there a way to play CD-quality music on one of these things?

headline: City Unveils Plan to Improve Safety at Construction Sites
text: Plagued by a rash of fatal construction accidents and widespread concern about public safety, the Bloomberg administration and the City Council unveiled a 13-point legislative package on Wednesday to broaden oversight of building sites, increase fines for violations and register all key contractors.

headline: HarperCollins Chief Executive Resigns
text: Jane Friedman, the president and chief executive of HarperCollins Publishers Worldwide, is stepping down from her post, becoming the second high-profile publishing executive to leave the top slot in the last month.

headline: For Clinton, a Key Group Didn’t Hold
text: This article was reported by Julie Bosman, Larry Rohter and Katharine Q. Seelye and was written by Ms. Seelye.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 85 Louisiana Tech
text: Location: Ruston, La.

headline: Statistical Leaders for the Stanley Cup Final
text: Detroit defeated Pittsburgh, 4 games to 2

headline: Red Wings’ Lidstrom Skates Into History
text: It was no secret that the Red Wings leaned on their unflappable captain, defenseman Nicklas Lidstrom, in bouncing back from crushing defeats in these playoffs. After taking big leads on Nashville (two games to none) and Dallas (3-0), the Wings kept making things interesting. They had to put away the Stars in a huge Game 6 in Dallas. On Wednesday, they had to face a rejuvenated Penguins team that stole Game 5 from the Wings in their building when they were seconds from hoisting the Cup.

headline: Health Care Struggles in South L.A.
text: Ten months after Martin Luther King Jr.-Harbor Hospital closed, local clinics strain from the weight of long lines of patients who are in need of affordable, quality care.

headline: Canada: Union Protests G.M. Plant Closing
text: A blockade forced General Motors of Canada to close its head office in Oshawa, Ontario. The Canadian Auto Workers union has charged that a decision by the automaker to close a truck plant in Oshawa violates a labor agreement reached last month. Under the contract's terms, the union contends that G.M. is obliged to find another product to replace the pickup trucks now assembled in the factory, which employees about 2,600 unionized workers. The province of Ontario has also said that G.M. may have to repay hundreds of millions of dollars in incentives it received because of the plant closing. About 100 people blocked roads leading to the head office and demanded a meeting with the company. G.M. has agreed to meet with the union in Detroit on Friday. The union has not indicated when it will lift the blockade.

headline: Getting to Know … Edgar Prado
text: Edgar Prado will ride perhaps Big Brown’s toughest foe, Casino Drive, in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday. And he is not intimidated. After all, he has been nicknamed “the Triple Crown killer,” stopping attempts by War Emblem in 2002 with the 70-1 shot Sarava and Smarty Jones in 2004 with the 36-1 shot Birdstone. Asked if Casino Drive, at 7-2, can win, he said simply, “I hope so.” Here we see another side of the Hall of Famer.

headline: California: Conservative Wins Primary
text: Republicans chose State Senator Tom McClintock, a conservative, in a heated primary race for the Fourth Congressional District seat. By 54 percent to 39 percent, Mr. McClintock, 51, defeated Doug Ose, 52, a former congressman who is considered a moderate. Mr. McClintock will face Charlie Brown, a Democrat, in November. The seat, in northeastern California, is being vacated by Representative John T. Doolittle, a nine-term Republican, after an F.B.I. investigation tied him to the corrupt lobbyist Jack Abramoff, accusations Mr. Doolittle denies.

headline: Space Station’s Toilet Repair Is Success
text: The troublesome toilet aboard the International Space Station appears to be working again, thanks to a replacement pump delivered by the shuttle Discovery. The single toilet on the station has separate systems for solid and liquid waste. The solid-waste system was operating properly, but the liquid system began malfunctioning more than a week before the shuttle's arrival on Monday. Oleg Kononenko, the cosmonaut who did the repair work, replaced a balky pump for the urine collection system with one delivered by the shuttle.

text: Since Jimmy Carter was in the White House when a horse last won the Kentucky Derby, Preakness Stakes and Belmont Stakes, it is no surprise much is made of the difficulty of winning a Triple Crown.
