headline: Euro 2008: Group D, Spain’s Time to Shine
text: Four years ago, Greece shocked Europe, and probably itself, by winning the European Championship in Portugal. It may not have been pretty, but in soccer it is often only about getting the proverbial result. And that is exactly what Greece did … three straight 1-0 wins to claim the title against the hosts in the final in Lisbon. But can anyone remember a champion returning to defend its title being so disrespected and dismissed?

headline: Big Brown Vs. Curlin for $5 Million?
text: Suffolk Downs in East Boston will offer a $5 million purse for this year’s Massachusetts Handicap if Big Brown sweeps the Triple Crown and both he and the 2007 Breeders’ Cup Classic winner Curlin remain unbeaten in 2008 and agree to face each other.

headline: Say It Ain’t So Dept.: ‘Hockey Night in Canada’ to Drop Theme Song?
text: The Canadian Press is reporting that CBC’s “Hockey Night in Canada” may discontinue the signature theme music it has used since 1968. The license agreement for the tune, written by Dolores Claman, expired last night when this year’s Stanley Cup final ended.

headline: So Far, So Good, for Upfront Ad Sales
text: So far the broadcast networks aren’t talking on the record, but media reports suggest some good news for the 2008-09 upfront season of advertising sales.

headline: Obama and Clinton Meet in Washington
text: Updated, 3:20 a.m. | Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton held a private meeting tonight in Washington, a session initiated by Mrs. Clinton after a daylong series of talks between their aides.

headline: Q & A: Joe Drape From Belmont Park
text: The Rail invited readers Thursday to submit questions for Joe Drape, The Times’s Eclipse Award-winning horse racing writer.

headline: Framing a Century
text: In its show of master photographers, the Metropolitan Museum presents the history of a medium as well as history itself. Roberta Smith reviews.

headline: Player Ratings: Red Bulls vs. Chivas USA
text: The Red Bulls (4-3-3, 15 points) started the season losing only one of their first seven games, and they allowed just six goals over that period. Heading into the match Thursday night against visiting Chivas USA (4-5-2, 14 points), the Red Bulls had lost two straight games, allowing six goals in the process. Chivas was trying to extend its unbeaten streak to four games, but failed. Red Bulls won 1-0.

headline: As Usual, Elbow Issue Doesn’t Scare Yankees on Draft Day
text: It was no surprise Thursday that with the 44th overall pick in the draft (their second selection, as compensation for the loss of Luis Vizcaino as a free agent) the Yankees took a pitcher who had an elbow injury this season – the Stanford lefty Jeremy Bleich. The Yankees have been undeterred in taking such risks, selecting Mark Melancon, Alan Horne and Andrew Brackman in recent years despite elbow issues with all three.

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: The Aftermath and the Afterglow
text: It’s all over — a tremendous Stanley Cup final is in the books. Well, not quite, not until the HNIB bloggers have had their say. First, our independent blogger for the proud finalists from Pittsburgh.

headline: A 4-Foot-9 Gymnast Takes a Big Step Toward Beijing
text: BOSTON – Dressed in a tangerine-colored leotard with the initials “SJ” in rhinestones on her right shoulder, the tiny Shawn Johnson sparkled Thursday in more ways than one at the U.S. gymnastics nationals.

headline: Guns in National Parks
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Explosion of Sales of 20th-Century Design
text: There may well be too much 20th-century design for sale in New York next week for the market to absorb.

headline: 16 Monks Arrested in Tibet Bombings
text: HONG KONG  The police in Tibet have arrested 16 Buddhist monks and accused them of involvement in three bombings, a police spokesman in northeastern Tibet said Thursday.

headline: Dance Draws a Crowd
text: Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” earned Wednesday night’s highest ratings, as an average of 9.3 million viewers tuned in to the show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox led the night over all, but CBS ranked a close second with repeats of “Criminal Minds” at 9 (8.2 million) and “CSI: NY” at 10 (9.2 million). CBS’s prime-time edition of “The Price is Right” attracted 7 million viewers at 8 p.m. But in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, CBS tied for third with ABC, which was the least-watched of the four major networks, with repeats of "Wife Swap" at 8 (5.1 million), "Supernanny" at 9 (6 million) and "Men in Trees" at 10 (5.2 million). NBC earned the night’s second-highest ratings in the 18-to-49 set with a live broadcast of Game 6, the conclusion of this year’s National Hockey League championship, attracting approximately 7 million total viewers.

headline: Oscar Ratnoff, 91, Expert on Blood Clots, Is Dead
text: Dr. Oscar D. Ratnoff, whose insightful research into how the blood coagulates helped reveal the “waterfall” biochemical response involved in the body’s reaction to wounds and trauma, died on May 20 in Cleveland. He was 91.

headline: Wealthy Americans Under Scrutiny in UBS Case
text: One afternoon in April, six dozen wealthy Americans were entertained at a luncheon party in Midtown Manhattan, along with a special guest from Paris: Henri Loyrette, the director of the Louvre.

headline: Timilick Tahoe and North Shore at Lake Marion
text: Timilick Tahoe

headline: Justice Dept. Investigating Deportation to Syria
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department’s ethics office is reviewing a decision in 2002 by department officials to send a Canadian citizen to Syria, where he was tortured, American officials said Thursday.

headline: ‘The Uncertain Art’
text: There is wisdom in the acceptance of uncertainty. Well used, it can make a philosopher of an ordinary man. To the intuitive mind of the twenty-two-year-old John Keats, that precious insight appeared in a flash of understanding one day in 1817, while he was deep in conversation on a long walk with two friends: “[S]everal things dove-tailed in my mind, and at once it struck me what quality went to form a man of achievement,” he later wrote in a letter to his brothers. “I mean negative capability, that is, when a man is capable of being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts.” To become comfortable with uncertainty is one of the primary goals in the training of a physician.

headline: Tough Workouts Are Now as Rare as the Crown Itself
text: Secretariat, Seattle Slew and Affirmed were as fit as a horse could be when they pulled into the Belmont Stakes and captured their Triple Crown championships. Each sported a series of workouts that rarely, if ever, are seen these days, when top horses do not race very much or stick around very long.

headline: After a Stunning Collapse, Gustafson Stumbles Yet Again
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  Bulle Rock golf course was a soaked green sponge. It had been doused a day earlier with more than an inch of rain in less than two hours. On Thursday, the sun broke through the low ceiling of pewter clouds, and the previous afternoon’s freakish storm, which resulted in tornado watches and power outages, receded into the distance.

headline: Festival Highlights
text: The Vision Festival presents a rich bounty of music, rewarding the intrepidness and patience of its audiences. Here are some especially promising sets scheduled for this year’s edition, at the Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street, at Rivington Street, Lower East Side; (212) 696-6681, visionfestival.org. Tickets are $35 per night, $30 in advance, $20 for students; brownpapertickets.com/event/30125.

headline: One Bus, Many Plot Twists
text: A love quadrangle, a soup-slurping subplot and concern about global warming are the incongruous ingredients of “Polar Bears.” The fourth Naked Brothers movie, which will be shown on Nickelodeon Friday night, is clumsy but criticproof.

headline: UBS Plans to Close Its Municipal Bond Business
text: UBS said Thursday it would close its municipal bond business after failing to find a buyer for what was the third-largest underwriter of American state and local government debt last year.

headline: A Tall Order
text: “Take Out” tracks, with nimble attention and fine curiosity, a day in the life of an illegal Chinese immigrant as he darts around Upper Manhattan on a cheap bicycle laden with MSG-soaked delicacies. There’s a lot at stake on this particular day, which begins as Ming Ding (Charles Jang) is rudely awakened by a pair of thuggish debt collectors demanding a full $800 payment by night’s end.

headline: 2 Men Scale New York Times Building Hours Apart
text: Two men, one a practiced French stuntman known for climbing tall buildings, the other a New Yorker who said he wanted to raise awareness of the dangers of malaria, scaled the 52-story New York Times Building in Times Square on Thursday just hours apart. Each was arrested when he stepped safely onto the roof.

headline: Seafaring Puppets Rock on a Trip to Party Island
text: Pay no attention to this review, because nothing in it will adequately convey the demented brilliance of “Jollyship the Whiz-Bang,” a puppet show within a rock show (or perhaps it’s the other way around) now occupying Ars Nova.

headline: Germany: A Newspaper Provokes
text: A leftist German newspaper provoked outrage and condemnation for printing what many readers called a racial slur about Senator Barack Obama. The newspaper, Die Tageszeitung, printed a front-page article about Mr. Obama’s becoming the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee and used a photograph of the White House and the headline “Uncle Barack’s Cabin,” in German, a reference to the antislavery novel “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” by Harriet Beecher Stowe, which contains negative racial stereotypes. Editors at the newspaper said the headline was satirical and intended to provoke a discussion of race and politics, according to the online version of the leading German magazine Spiegel. The paper is known for standing up for foreigners, but also for crossing the line with articles critics say are in bad taste.

headline: New York’s Big Backyard
text: GOING to our local playground in Brooklyn can be painful. When friends are there, it’s great. But it’s hard to make small talk with people I barely know about high-tech strollers, whose kid is taking French lessons (mine are not), the pros and cons of gifted-and-talented programs  the usual nightmare urban-mommy conversation.

headline: Forge a Unity of Purpose, Then Conquer the World
text: “Mongol”  or, as I prefer to think of it, “Genghis Khan: The Early Years”  is a big, ponderous epic, its beautifully composed landscape shots punctuated by thundering hooves and bloody, slow-motion battle sequences.

headline: He Set Tongues Wagging With His Music and Muses
text: Speculation was rife during and after Vivaldi’s life about possible improprieties committed with the girls he taught at the Ospedale Della Pietà, an orphanage in Venice. Several young women were certainly his muses, although scholars continue to debate the precise nature of the inspiration they provided. At Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening the Little Orchestra Society, conducted by Dino Anagnost, offered insights on the matter in a lively program called “The Two Annas: Vivaldi’s Muses.”

headline: 2 Leaders Ousted From Air Force in Atomic Errors
text: WASHINGTON  The Air Force’s senior civilian official and its highest-ranking general were ousted by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday after an inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons and components found systemic problems in the Air Force.

headline: Trails of the South
text: THOUSANDS of hikers invade the Appalachian Mountains south of the Mason-Dixon line when the weather turns warm, eager to buck the daily grind  not to mention the heat and haze  by tackling trails that cross rivers, pass refreshing waterfalls and often lead to breathtaking vistas shrouded in mist. These escapes are cool, literally.

headline: About 1 in 11 Mortgageholders Face Loan Problems
text: About 1 in 11 American mortgages were past due or in foreclosure at the end of March, according to a report released on Thursday, a figure that is rising fast as home prices fall and the job market weakens.

headline: Giambi’s Home Run Is a Pain Reliever
text: After Jason Giambi’s titanic home run landed in the third deck to give the Yankees a 9-8 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Thursday afternoon at Yankee Stadium, he hopped, skipped and jumped around the bases, ignoring the pain in his sore left foot that had kept him out of the starting lineup for two games.

headline: A Media History Site
text: The Museum of the Moving Image has started a new Web site devoted to the history of film, television and digital media, Rochelle Slovin, the museum’s director, said. The site, movingimagesource.us, will feature articles by scholars, critics and authors, a calendar highlighting major gallery festivals, exhibitions and retrospectives around the world, and a guide to research resources online.

headline: Bush Overstated Iraq Evidence, Senators Report
text: WASHINGTON  A long-delayed Senate committee report endorsed by Democrats and some Republicans concluded that President Bush and his aides built the public case for war against Iraq by exaggerating available intelligence and by ignoring disagreements among spy agencies about Iraq’s weapons programs and Saddam Hussein’s links to Al Qaeda.

headline: 50 Years of NASA’s Home Movies
text: ABOUT midway through “When We Left Earth,” a sweeping new video history of the American space program, the former NASA flight director Eugene F. Kranz looks into the camera with an intensity that is almost frightening.

headline: Blanket Coverage of Big Brown’s Bid
text: If you watch the 1978 Belmont Stakes (go to YouTube), you’ll see what CBS Sports lacked: cameras in the starting gate and in a blimp, cameras isolated on several horses, close-ups of the field or running graphics to show what places the horses were in.

headline: Trail of Bad Loans Leads to the Couple Next Door
text: This is a tale of sex, lies and foreclosures.

headline: France Salutes the Ultimate Couturier
text: PARIS  Two shopgirls in their uniform red jackets and black blouses stared down from the windows above the Elena Miro shop on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honoré on Thursday, as the fashion world gathered below to mourn Yves Saint Laurent.

headline: For Jazz’s Avant-Garde, an Annual Gathering and a Little Competition
text: During his youth, the New Orleans tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan worked with some of the brightest lights of soul and R&B, like Ray Charles, Aretha Franklin and Stevie Wonder. And that’s just for starters. “You name the genre, I’ve done it,” Mr. Jordan, 73, said this week from Baton Rouge, La., his temporary home since shortly after Hurricane Katrina hit in 2005. “But when I was playing in all those other genres, I wasn’t satisfied with what I was doing. I always was one of them who would search, and keep searching.”

headline: $21.5 Million Is a Record for McCain
text: Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign raised at least $21.5 million in May  its best fund-raising month yet  in a sign that its effort to draw donations in tandem with the Republican National Committee is yielding dividends.

headline: Israel to Loosen Limits on Gaza Scholars
text: TEL AVIV  Senior Israeli officials said Thursday that they would no longer stop all Palestinians who had foreign study grants from leaving Gaza and would look favorably upon their applications for exit permits. The move departs from the near total Israeli ban on movement out of Gaza, the Hamas-controlled coastal strip, since late 2007.

headline: Year Later, Another Jets Player Is Unhappy
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Tight end Chris Baker ripped Jets management Thursday, bringing an air of familiarity to the first minicamp practice.

headline: Two Fed Bank Presidents Warn About Lending to Securities Firms
text: Two Federal Reserve Bank presidents warned in separate speeches on Thursday that the central bank’s decision in March to lend to securities firms might sow the seeds of further financial crises.

headline: 2 Central Banks in Europe Keep Rates Unchanged
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank, alarmed by soaring prices for food and fuel, warned unexpectedly Thursday that it might raise interest rates next month to counter an inflationary spiral.

headline: Big Airlines in a Rush to Go Small
text: In the three decades since deregulation, the nation’s major airlines have operated with a simple strategy that bigger was better, and that the way to win the industry dogfight was to fly more planes on more routes to attract the most passengers.

headline: Qaeda Group Says It Bombed Embassy
text: FRANKFURT  A Qaeda operative based in Afghanistan claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing outside the Danish Embassy in Islamabad, according to a posting on jihadist Web sites, saying the attack was in revenge for the publication of cartoons caricaturing the Prophet Muhammad in Danish newspapers.

headline: Mukasey Declines to Create a U.S. Task Force to Investigate Mortgage Fraud
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey rejected on Thursday the idea of creating a national task force to combat the country’s mortgage fraud crisis, calling the problem a localized one akin to “white-collar street crimes.”

headline: Helping Young Golfers Shoot for the Stars
text: Brian Carty would like to be Tiger Woods when he grows up. Better, actually, if that is humanly possible.

headline: Steroid Dealer Who Cooperated With N.F.L. Is Found Dead
text: A convicted steroid dealer who provided documentary evidence and testimony to N.F.L. officials last month that tied several players to the use of performance-enhancing drugs was found shot to death Thursday morning at his home in Plano, Tex., the police said.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on May 24 about a production of the opera “Amistad” at Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., misstated the name of the company that first presented the work 11 years ago. It is Lyric Opera of Chicago, not Chicago Lyric Opera.

headline: Aristocracy of Talent for an Egalitarian Art
text: From the daguerreotype to the cellphone snapshot, the history of photography has unfolded as a series of miracles, each of which has profoundly altered our understanding of the time-space continuum. As the innovations become familiar, the photographs become miracles in another way, as connections to a past we’ve never seen.

headline: From TV to M.L.S., One Mexican Teen’s Soccer Dream
text: CARSON, Calif.  To describe how Jorge Flores ended up here  an unknown teenager traveling to South America and Europe to play for his country after emerging quite literally from a cast of thousands to win a tryout with Chivas USA  a word is worth a thousand pictures.

headline: No Steroids for Horses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Banker to Lead State Agency for Economic Development
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson named a prominent banking executive, Robert G. Wilmers, on Thursday as chairman of the state’s economic development agency.

headline: Israeli Man and Gaza Child Die in Strikes
text: TEL AVIV  Mortar shells fired from Gaza killed a 52-year-old Israeli worker on Thursday, and two hours later, an Israeli missile aimed at the source apparently killed a 4-year-old girl playing in her yard.

headline: Mergers Accelerate as Telecoms Seek Growth
text: BERLIN  A multibillion-dollar telecommunications merger was announced Thursday, reflecting a trend for mobile phone operators to consolidate in their own crowded backyards while they scout for growth in emerging economies.

headline: A Gym Designed to Cater to Christians
text: CLERMONT, Fla.  Jason Russell, a fitness buff, had long found it difficult to combine his Christian faith with his job as a gym manager, which required him to be around women in spandex and men concerned only with how macho they are.

headline: Theater Listings
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Ousted Executive Provides a Feminine Face to the McCain Campaign
text: WASHINGTON  Three years ago, Carleton S. Fiorina was the celebrity C.E.O. who was spectacularly fired by the Hewlett-Packard board. She produced a best-selling memoir, “Tough Choices,” but for the most part spent the years after her ouster in relative self-imposed exile from public life.

headline: Vijay Tendulkar, Indian Theater Innovator, Dies at 80
text: Vijay Dhondopat Tendulkar, one of the most important and influential Indian playwrights of the last six decades and the writer for some critically acclaimed Hindi films, died on May 19 in Pune, India. He was 80.

headline: BP Says It Is Committed to Russian Venture
text: MOSCOW  The chief executive of BP, Tony Hayward, said Thursday that the company was committed to staying in Russia, even as its joint venture, TNK-BP, came under fresh pressure from the authorities investigating accusations of tax evasion.

headline: 2 Top Leaders of Air Force Pushed Out After Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  The Air Force’s senior civilian official and its highest-ranking general were ousted by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday following an official inquiry into the mishandling of nuclear weapons and components, an episode that Mr. Gates called an indication of systemic problems in the Air Force.

headline: Fuzzy Outsider, Kicking His Way Toward His Dream
text: At once fuzzy-wuzzy and industrial strength, the tacky-sounding “Kung Fu Panda” is high concept with a heart. Even better, this animated feature from DreamWorks is so consistently diverting and visually arresting that it succeeds in transcending its storybook clichés. The tale has the consistency of baby pablum  it’s nutritious and easy on the gums  but there’s enough beauty and pictorial wit here from opening to end credits, enough feeling for the art and for the freedom of animation, that you may not care.

headline: The Art of Growing Up
text: In January 1841, Abraham Lincoln seems to have at least vaguely thought of suicide. His friend Joshua Speed found him one day thrashing about in his room. “Lincoln went Crazy,” Speed wrote. “I had to remove razors from his room  take away all Knives and other such dangerous things  it was terrible.”

headline: Myanmar Detains Activist Comedian
text: YANGON, Myanmar  A popular comedian here who had been carrying out a private campaign to help the victims of last month’s cyclone has been detained by the police, his friends said Thursday.

headline: Rivers’s Sleight of Hand: Making Three Stars Think as One
text: BOSTON  Doc Rivers has a trophy that bears Red Auerbach’s likeness and the words “Coach of the Year”  an award that has nothing to do with Rivers’s success with the Celtics, but perhaps foreshadowed it.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: As a Father Nears Death, a Son Grows No Closer
text: A gentle tale gently told, “When Did You Last See Your Father?” is grown-up, civilized fare. If that sounds like a compliment, it is, even though the whole thing might have been improved with a bit of messiness, a little vulgarity to leaven its tastefulness and tact. This isn’t a groundbreaking work; just a smartly played story, enlivened by drama and spiked with passion, the very thing that thinking audiences pine for, especially during the summer spectacle season when theaters are clogged with sticky kids’ stuff and television reruns.

headline: Wonder Tour, Yes; Yes Tour, No
text: Stevie Wonder, below, is set to perform a series of concerts in Europe for the first time in a decade, BBC News reported. Mr. Wonder will begin his tour in Britain on Sept. 8 in Birmingham, followed by dates in Manchester and at London’s 02 arena. He is to perform in seven other countries, ending with a concert in Paris on Sept. 28. Tickets for the concert will go on sale on June 13. ... The classic progressive-rock band Yes canceled its 40th anniversary tour after its singer, Jon Anderson, suffered a severe asthma attack, The Associated Press reported. The band was to start a 26-city summer tour in Quebec on July 12.

headline: Vote by Numbers
text: IT appears that Hillary Clinton is going to suspend her presidential campaign this weekend, at the urging of Democratic Party leaders and superdelegates. Before that happens, Mrs. Clinton and the superdelegates might want to know this: if the general election were held today, Barack Obama would lose to John McCain, while Mr. McCain would lose to Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Security Council Members Push to Condemn Sudan
text: UNITED NATIONS  The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court presented a grim portrait of conditions in the Darfur region of Sudan to the Security Council on Thursday, as a majority of Council members pushed for what would be the first statement in three years condemning the Sudanese government.

headline: For Young Penguins, Loss Hurts, but There’s Hope
text: PITTSBURGH  When Sidney Crosby’s first shot at a Stanley Cup championship fell short by the smallest of margins Wednesday night, he looked every bit like a 20-year-old who had just had his dream snatched away. He sat at his locker in full uniform, his eyes red, his voice wavering. Finally, he got up and walked away, passing his hero and landlord  the Penguins’ owner, Mario Lemieux  and headed down a hallway without a word.

headline: Portraits of Divas
text: Francesco Clemente’s exhibition of eight portraits called “The Sopranos” opened at Gallery Met at Lincoln Center on Thursday. Created in collaboration with the Metropolitan Opera, the exhibition features portraits of eight divas who are to figure prominently in the Met’s 2008-9 season. The oil-on-linen portraits, on display until Sept. 26, depict in their coming roles Diana Damrau, Natalie Dessay, Renée Fleming, Angela Gheorghiu, Susan Graham, Karita Mattila, Anna Netrebko and Deborah Voigt, above as the title character of “La Gioconda.” Mr. Clemente began his association with the Met earlier this year when he created the front-of-house banner for the Philip Glass opera “Satyagraha,” in April.

headline: A Live Promotion, at 14,000 Feet
text: “THIS is live, at 14,000 feet, over Spain,” a man shouted over the roar of the wind as he and a group of fellow skydivers plunged toward the earth near Madrid.

headline: You Mean Outerbridge Isn’t Far Away?
text: The Robert F. Kennedy Bridge needs no explanation, but people honored by some other local bridges might need introductions:

headline: Rooms With a Viewfinder
text: WHEN Catherine Chalmers was preparing to film her video “Safari,” which documents the journey of a cockroach through a mini-tropical landscape, she turned to animal breeders to buy her exotic cast of creatures, which included a poison dart frog and a pygmy chameleon. Even the cockroach came from a lab. But there was something missing, she felt  she wanted more bright color.

headline: Mahler’s Haunting Ruminations at the Abyss
text: Many Mahler devotees demand the ultimate in intensity and transcendence from performances of that composer’s symphonies. Lorin Maazel would not be the conductor of choice for those who feel this way. Mr. Maazel conducts Mahler with cool expressivity, exacting execution and musical integrity, a refreshing break from Mahler performances that strive to express the inexpressible.

headline: To Save a Life: Mosquito Nets, and More
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art in Review
text: JESS

headline: Leaders of 4 ‘F’ Schools Are Now Up for Bonuses
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released stark new report cards last fall, grading all schools on a scale of A through F, the Acorn High School for Social Justice, in Brooklyn, was branded with an F. Later on, its principal, Joseph Parker, resigned under pressure.

headline: Europe Warns Germany About Shielding VW
text: BRUSSELS  The European Commission threatened on Thursday to take Germany to court for failing to revoke a law shielding Volkswagen from a hostile takeover in the latest round in a furious legal battle over the future ownership of the car giant.

headline: Watch Out, He’s Packing a Blow-Dryer
text: Let me be blunt: “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan” is the finest post-Zionist action-hairdressing sex comedy I have ever seen. That it is the only one I have ever seen  and why is that? what cultural deficiency or ideological conspiracy has prevented this genre from flourishing?  does not much detract from my judgment.

headline: Clinton May Come Home to Find a Little Fence-Mending Is Needed
text: Do not get Antoine Njeim or Jaye Griffith started about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: More People Undergoing Colonoscopy in New York
text: The number of New York City residents 50 and older who have undergone a colonoscopy has risen by about 50 percent in five years, city officials announced on Thursday.

headline: Giving Voice to Poetry in a Concert of Choral Works
text: In its heyday the American Composers Alliance fostered several important institutions, most notably CRI (Composers Recordings Inc.), a label that specialized in new American music, and the American Composers Orchestra. But that was midway through the last century. These days the alliance works mostly behind the scenes, publishing, archiving and advocating for American music. In a way it has been hobbled by its success: American music just isn’t as hard to sell now as it was in 1937, when Aaron Copland helped found the organization. Some of it is downright popular.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Clinton Says Running Mate Choice Is Obama’s
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday disavowed a campaign by some of her supporters to press Senator Barack Obama into selecting her as the Democratic party’s vice presidential candidate. Mrs. Clinton said the supporters were acting on their own, and that the choice of a running mate was “Senator Obama’s, and his alone.”

headline: How About Slaughterhouse Tour Before Supper, Food Lover?
text: For New Yorkers, Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the bucolic counterpart to Washington Square Park’s Blue Hill restaurant, is a locavore’s idyll. About 30 miles from the city, the restaurant, on the grounds of the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture near Tarrytown, is set among green pastures dotted with the chickens, turkeys and pigs that will eventually show up on the menu for both Blue Hill restaurants.

headline: Former Chief of Broadcom Is Indicted
text: Henry T. Nicholas III, the flamboyant co-founder and former chief executive of the chip maker Broadcom, was indicted Thursday in California on fraud, conspiracy and drug charges, including allegations that he spiked the drinks of other executives with ecstasy.

headline: Jets’ Elam Perseveres With Faith in the Face of Tragedy
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Abram Elam leaned forward, covered his face with his hands and clenched his body to stop the shaking. He wiped the tears running down both cheeks with tissues. Through the silence came the occasional muffled sob.

headline: Scratching and Clawing Their Way to the Middle
text: “The Promotion” tells you everything you might want to know but were too uninterested to ask about working as an assistant manager in a supermarket. As this sweet, ineffectual comedy follows two sad sacks competing for the job of manager at a new branch of a Chicago grocery chain, it pointedly avoids the raucous bad-boy clowning of the typical Everyguy farce. Think of it as a polite, tightly muzzled “Clerks.”

headline: Soft Shoe With Stamina and a Smile for the Ladies
text: They were there  fewer than in recent years because his television talk show was canceled  but the ladies with their digital cameras still turned out on Wednesday evening for Tony Danza’s new act, “I Could Have Danced All Night,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. As cameras flashed, the trim, grinning 57-year-old star with short salt-and-pepper hair struck poses and radiated cocky charm.

headline: Germany Abuzz at Racy Novel of Sex and Hygiene
text: TEGERNHEIM, Germany  Not many literary readings are restricted to an over-18 audience. Fewer still take place under circus tents. Yet nothing could be more appropriate for the scandalous German best-seller “Wetlands,” by a television personality and author, Charlotte Roche.

headline: Big Brown vs. Curlin? A Track May Offer $5 Million
text: If Big Brown wins the Triple Crown and he and the 2007 Breeders’ Cup Classic winner, Curlin, remain unbeaten in 2008, Suffolk Downs in East Boston will offer a $5 million purse for them to face each other in this year’s Massachusetts Handicap.

headline: Stravinsky on His Mind; Barbra Streisand and the Sex Pistols, Too
text: What is it about choreographers and Stravinsky? Like moths to a flame they keep coming, along with the inevitable immolations.

headline: Continental Cuts Jobs and Grounds Jets
text: Continental Airlines said Thursday that it would cut 3,000 jobs and retire 67 Boeing aircraft, becoming the latest airline to announce capacity reductions in the face of high prices for jet fuel.

headline: Corrections
text: Front Page

headline: Verizon Agrees to Buy Alltel for $28.1 Billion
text: Verizon Communications agreed on Thursday to buy Alltel for about $28.1 billion, including the assumption of debt, creating the nation’s largest cellular telephone provider.

headline: In Upper Manhattan, Cheers for the No. 2 Pick
text: Pedro Alvarez sat on the couch between his parents in their cramped Upper Manhattan apartment Thursday afternoon. Twenty-eight people had packed themselves into the sweltering living room to watch Major League Baseball’s amateur draft. With the television volume turned all the way up, no one paid any attention when Alvarez answered his cellphone.

headline: A Sect’s Families Reunite, and Start to Come Home
text: ELDORADO, Tex.  The cows still get milked each day by machine here at the Yearning for Zion ranch, although the raw-milk cheese is stacking up uneaten. The onions in the garden are as big as grapefruits, ready for harvest, with few people to pick them.

headline: No Bed of Roses for a Sudden First Lady
text: ASKED to identify which items in the generic East Side office designated for the spouse of the governor of New York actually radiate her personal decorative karma, Michelle Paige Paterson, 47, takes a cursory assessment. She then shrugs her slim shoulders in a silent yet succinct expression of negativity.

headline: The Clues and Conspiracies of an Assassination
text: Heads talk and reason walks in the documentary “RFK Must Die: The Assassination of Bobby Kennedy,” a conspiracy-addled trudge through the Ambassador Hotel’s most fateful event.

headline: The Truth About the War
text: It took just a few months after the United States’ invasion of Iraq for the world to find out that Saddam Hussein had long abandoned his nuclear, biological and chemical weapons programs. He was not training terrorists or colluding with Al Qaeda. The only real threat he posed was to his own countrymen.

headline: Fresh Produce for Ratatouille, Please, but No Attitude
text: The rolling countryside of Provence may be a dream vacation spot, but it is the last place in the world that Antoine (Nicolas Cazalé), the sullen 30-year-old protagonist of “The Grocer’s Son,” would like to be. In this French variation of the fable of the prodigal son, Antoine reluctantly returns to his rural hometown after 10 years in the big city when his father (Daniel Duval) has a heart attack.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about free cellphone information services, gave an incorrect phone number for the reQall service, which allows users to dictate reminders to themselves. It is 888-9REQALL.

headline: Zagat Family Says Company Is No Longer for Sale
text: Zagat Survey, publisher of the popular user-generated reviews of restaurants, hotels and other leisure businesses, has ended its effort to sell itself, the company said Thursday.

headline: With Yelp, Ivanovic Is in French Final
text: PARIS  As the service breaks and momentum shifts piled up late in the third set Thursday, it was exceedingly difficult to know which Serbian tennis player was going to end up No. 1 on the day and No. 1 in the world.

headline: Fierce Swing, Deep Grooves and Even a Little Singing
text: Growing up in a jazz family in New Orleans, the trumpeter Nicholas Payton absorbed a host of lessons about melody, rhythm and the implicit arrangement between an artist and his audience. And over the last decade or so he has weighed those lessons against the modernist imperative of open-ended abstraction. Now, in his mid-30s, Mr. Payton still seems to be seeking an arable middle ground, the zone where post-bop evasiveness mingles with soulful reassurance.

headline: Tranghese, Commissioner of Big East, to Step Down in 2009
text: Mike Tranghese, the commissioner of the Big East, who has been with the league from its inception through its revival, announced Thursday that he would step down in June 2009.

headline: Lessons of the Road, With Phone
text: The long and winding road traveled by Mercer White (Lou Taylor Pucci), the ingenuous 19-year-old protagonist of Martin Hynes’s wispy but appealing film “The Go-Getter,” leads from Eugene, Ore., to Reno, Nev.; Mojave, Calif.; Los Angeles; Ensenada, Mexico; and back, with many stops along the way. Mercer’s vehicle is a well-traveled Volvo station wagon he impulsively steals at a car wash and drives off into the unknown.

headline: It’s So Much Nicer on K Street
text: The more the presidential candidates promise to rein in the rich Washington culture of influence-peddling, the more voters need a reality check.

headline: Norway: A Crime-Fighting Duo
text: The Norwegian Supreme Court ruled that assaulting a police dog was equivalent to assaulting an officer. The suspect in an attempted burglary last year in the city of Bergen is accused of hitting and kicking Vera, a Belgian Shepherd police dog, after she chased him down, will now face a charge of assaulting a civil servant. Two lower courts had dismissed the assault charge, which carries a maximum penalty of three years in prison, but a panel of Supreme Court judges ruled that a police officer and dog are to be treated as a single unit.

headline: What’s Really in the Well?
text: YOU’VE found the perfect summer cottage in the country. You can bicycle into town. There are a couple of good restaurants. The shops are cute, and your friends are eager to visit. The house passed the usual presale inspection, the closing was a snap, and now you’re moving in and reaching for the kitchen tap to get a glass of water.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Remembering Too Well Back When Rock Mattered
text: Picture Michael Douglas in the film “Wonder Boys,” unkempt and used up, though once brilliant and vital. Then imagine (or remember) Goldie Hawn 40 years ago, in her young and kooky mode, possibly kooky to the point of danger.

headline: The Views Are the Selling Point
text: PEOPLE “from away” have been summering in north coastal Maine for generations. And in parts of Hancock County, there is ample evidence of the grandeur and wealth that characterized many of earliest summer populations. But a large part of Hancock County and bordering Washington County remains affordable.

headline: China Reports Declines in 3 Major Pollutants, Reversing Trend
text: HONG KONG  After rising steeply for many years, emissions of three important pollutants began to decline last year, China’s Ministry of Environmental Protection announced Thursday as part of an annual report.

headline: Germany: Russian President Visits
text: On his first official visit to Germany, President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia cited the same issues for which his predecessor, Vladimir V. Putin, had repeatedly taken Europe and the United States to task. “I won’t hide the fact that we are concerned by the tendency toward a narrowing of our mutual understanding within Euro-Atlantic politics,” Mr. Medvedev said after meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel. Addressing a German-Russian economic forum, he reiterated his criticism of NATO’s plan to offer eventual membership to Ukraine and Georgia.

headline: A Son’s Initiation in the Fraternity of the Lawn
text: THE 6.5-horsepower lawn mower roared to life on the first pull, just as I knew it would. I was late opening up my Charlestown, R.I., beach house after the winter, and the grass  crab grass, weeds and dandelions actually  was out of control. Out of habit, I thought to thank my dad for his help, forgetting for a moment that he was gone. The first summer after I bought the cottage, I’d begged the misnamed Toro GTS (Guaranteed to Start) engine to turn over before phoning the expert.

headline: A Gulf Retreat for the Upscale but Unfussy
text: WHEN Mike Ford was in college, he became acquainted with the Florida Panhandle’s coast on spring-break jaunts that lured him to its developed, party-hearty beach towns like Panama City and Fort Walton Beach. So when his future wife introduced him to the small and far-removed Grayton Beach, a low-key spit of sand that offers nothing but houses and beach, where she had spent summers all her life, he didn’t quite know what to make of it.

headline: Obama Moves to Next Phase as Clinton Douses Talk of Ticket
text: BRISTOL, Va.  Senator Barack Obama moved forcefully into the general election on Thursday, placing his stamp on the Democratic Party apparatus and holding a private nighttime meeting with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in an effort to unify Democrats.

headline: Turkey’s High Court Overturns Headscarf Rule
text: ISTANBUL  Turkey’s highest court dealt a stinging slap to the governing party of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Thursday, ruling that a legal change allowing women attending universities to wear head scarves was unconstitutional.

headline: Bits, Bands and Books
text: Do you remember what it was like back in the old days when we had a New Economy? In the 1990s, jobs were abundant, oil was cheap and information technology was about to change everything.

headline: The Mets Choose Power With Top 2 Draft Picks
text: SAN DIEGO  The upper levels of the Mets’ farm system, depleted by their trade for Johan Santana and recent free-agent signings that forfeited draft picks, received a major boost during Thursday’s amateur draft when they used their two first-round picks on power-hitting college infielders.

headline: Combating Illegal Guns
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s campaign against illegal guns won a notable victory this week when a Georgia gun dealer decided to default rather than go to trial in a civil lawsuit that accused him of illegally selling handguns that were later used to commit crimes in New York.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: U.S. Not Seeking Permanent Iraq Bases, Ambassador Says
text: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Iraq dismissed any suggestion on Thursday that the Bush administration was maneuvering to set up permanent military bases in Iraq.

headline: Retailers Post Surprising Sales
text: Retailers’ fears that their customers would keep their pocketbooks shut proved to be unfounded last month.

headline: Bosses May Have Hastened Chief’s Departure at HarperCollins
text: One day after Jane Friedman, the charismatic chief executive of HarperCollins Publishers Worldwide, stunned colleagues and the publishing industry with her abrupt exit, it appeared that she had been nudged out from the top spot at the News Corporation books unit that she had ruled for more than a decade.

headline: Arraigned, 9/11 Defendants Talk of Martyrdom
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba  When at last he got the chance to speak, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed planner of the Sept. 11 attacks, on Thursday called President Bush a crusader and ridiculed the trial system here as an inquisition.

headline: Ellsworth Kelly, Basking in Basel
text: BASEL, Switzerland  Unlike most dealers at the Art Basel fair, who are showing a smorgasbord of the artists they represent, the New York dealer Matthew Marks has mounted an exhibition honoring one artist, Ellsworth Kelly, who turned 85 last month.

headline: Museums and Antiquities
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pierce’s Return Fuels Celtics and a Rivalry
text: BOSTON  A brilliant rivalry was renewed Thursday night, with all the attendant tension, drama, ill will and ear-splitting volume.

headline: Zimbabwe Tells All Aid Groups to Halt Efforts
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s government has ordered all humanitarian aid groups to suspend their operations in the deeply impoverished nation, a prohibition that relief agencies estimate will deprive two million people of food aid and other basic assistance.

headline: Sales Double for Game Maker
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A bid by Electronic Arts to take over Take-Two Interactive is facing mounting challenges, including possible concerns of federal antitrust regulators and strong game sales that have raised Take-Two shares above the asking price.

headline: After 84 Years, WNYC Cuts a Cord With the City as It Moves
text: He’ll miss his view, Brian Lehrer said, and who can blame him? From his 24th-floor office in the Municipal Building, where he has presided for nearly two decades over a talk show on radio station WNYC, he looks north and west across a cityscape that never fails to make the heart skip a beat.

headline: Matthew J. Bruccoli, 76, Scholar, Dies; Academia’s Fitzgerald Record Keeper
text: Matthew J. Bruccoli, whose biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald and outpouring of scholarly essays and critical editions made him the dean of Fitzgerald studies in the United States, died at his home in Columbia, S.C., on Wednesday. He was 76.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 5, 2008

headline: Resurrecting an Artist’s Greatest Creation: Herself
text: Louise Nevelson hasn’t let death go to her head. As reincarnated with disarming casualness and unimpeachable conviction by Mercedes Ruehl in “Edward Albee’s Occupant,” this imposingly flamboyant, Russian-born New York sculptor returns to the land of the living without a wisp of the oracular mysticism you might expect from someone who has spent two decades on the Other Side.

headline: In Juneau, Firm Resistance to a Road Out of Isolation
text: JUNEAU, Alaska  The proposed 51-mile Juneau Access Road would provide something this remote capital city has never had: an overland route to the rest of North America. No longer would people have to take a ferry or a flight.

headline: British Writer Wins Fiction Prize
text: The Orange Broadband Prize for Fiction has been awarded to the British author Rose Tremain for her 10th novel, “The Road Home.” The prize, awarded annually for the best novel written by a woman in English and published in Britain in the previous year, was presented at a ceremony Wednesday night in London. Ms. Tremain, who writes novels, short stories and screenplays, received £30,000, or nearly $59,000, for the novel, which tells the story of Lev, a shy Eastern European widower who comes to Britain in search of work and experiences the dissonance of the immigrant diaspora. Recent Orange Prize winners include Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie for “Half of a Yellow Sun” in 2007 and Zadie Smith for “On Beauty” in 2006.

headline: Surge in Shipping Benefits a Tiny Exchange
text: LONDON  The prices of wheat, soybeans and iron ore have surged in the last two years, but that is nothing next to the surging cost of shipping goods like these.

headline: The Ailey Company Exults in the Sheer Thrill of Putting on a Show
text: Watching the second program of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s weeklong run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music amplified just how good these dancers are at the theatrical presentation of their material.

headline: A Doctor Finds Miracles in Medicine
text: The celebrated writer-physician Sherwin B. Nuland  a clinical professor of surgery at Yale, the author of nine previous books, the winner of the National Book Award  is a believer in miracles. Not the parting-of-the-Red-Sea kind of miracles that suspend physical laws, but phenomena and events that can’t be explained by current scientific knowledge, and perhaps never will be.

headline: Another Can’t-Miss Prospect May Help Yankees Bullpen
text: NORWICH, Conn. — The ballpark here sits at the end of a winding industrial road, surrounded by trees, with no sense of place. It rained all day Wednesday, and most of the 1,353 paying fans stayed home. Kids were disappointed if they left with only one foul ball.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Dickens Desk and Chair Sold
text: The mahogany desk and walnut chair, left, at which Charles Dickens wrote a number of his novels and short stories, including “Great Expectations,” was sold on Wednesday for £433,250, about $848,000, at an auction at Christie’s in London. The desk and chair were recent gifts to Great Ormond Street Children’s Hospital from Jeanne-Marie Dickens (the widow of the writer’s great-great grandson Christopher) and were sold to raise money for the hospital. Charles Dickens was a close friend of the hospital’s founder and spoke at its first fund-raising dinner, in 1858. The buyer was a private Irish collector.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on May 26 about police corruption and Mexico’s war on drugs misidentified the academic affiliation of Bruce Bagley, a professor of international studies who is an expert on Latin American narcotics trafficking. He teaches at the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla.  not Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.

headline: U.N. Food Meeting Ends With a Call for ‘Urgent’ Action
text: ROME  A three-day United Nations conference on spiraling food costs concluded late on Thursday with the delegates calling on countries and financial institutions to provide more food for the world’s poor and increase agriculture production to ensure adequate supplies in the future.

headline: Parents Find Frustration With Process at Schools
text: Kate Yourke does not have the heart to tell her daughter Coral she was rejected from the prekindergarten program at Public School 132 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where her sister goes, even though siblings were supposed to get priority.

headline: Doubts About ‘Clean Coal’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: South Carolina to Offer Cross on Car Plates
text: South Carolina drivers will be the first in the nation to be offered license plates that carry the phrase “I Believe” and a Christian cross over a stained-glass window under a law that took effect on Thursday.

headline: When Sons Die, Hard-Hat Pride Becomes Grief
text: They worked hard for decades, scaling miles of scaffolding or sitting long hours behind the levers of a high crane. It was hard and dangerous work, but when their sons were old enough to follow in their footsteps, the fathers watched with pride. When the fathers retired, the sons were their link to the job, their dinner conversations threaded with stories of projects in the works and newer, bigger machines.

headline: Songs of Africa
text: You don’t have to be a fan of African tunes to appreciate “On the Rumba River,” Jacques Sarasin’s heartfelt ode to Congolese music and its resilient practitioners.

headline: British Judge Sets Hearing on Evidence for Detainee
text: LONDON  A British judge has ordered a hearing into whether the British government must turn over evidence bearing on accusations by a prisoner at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, that he was tortured during interrogation in Morocco.

headline: Adviser Says McCain Backs Bush Wiretaps
text: WASHINGTON  A top adviser to Senator John McCain says Mr. McCain believes that President Bush’s program of wiretapping without warrants was lawful, a position that appears to bring him into closer alignment with the sweeping theories of executive authority pushed by the Bush administration legal team.

headline: Prosecutor Details Rape That Lasted 19 Hours
text: The time crept by so slowly and painfully that the 23-year-old Columbia University journalism student had decided it was time to end her life.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,083 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: $42 Billion French Bid for TeliaSonera
text: BERLIN  France Telecom on Thursday offered $42 billion in cash and stock for TeliaSonera, the Swedish-Finnish phone company with holdings across the former Soviet Union, in the latest bid by a European operator to enter faster-growing emerging markets.

headline: Bush in the Background
text: WASHINGTON  Scenes from the quiet life of George W. Bush, master of ceremonies and president of the United States:

headline: Los Angeles Sues Time Warner Cable
text: In the two years since becoming the major cable provider in the Los Angeles area, Time Warner Cable has drawn sometimes colorful criticism from its subscribers.

headline: Footnotes
text: The actor Kelsey Grammer is resting comfortably at his home in Hawaii, four days after being hospitalized because of a mild heart attack, The Associated Press reported. A publicist for Mr. Grammer, who starred in “Cheers” and “Frasier,” said that he sent thanks to those who called and wrote expressing concern. ... Ozzy Osbourne has won libel damages from the Daily Star, the British newspaper, over allegations that he suffered a health scare which jeopardized this year’s Brit Awards, according to reports from BBC News and The Associated Press. Mr. Osborne, 59, the rock singer and former frontman for Black Sabbath, has indicated that he would donate the damages, the amount of which was undisclosed, to the colon cancer charity set up by his wife, Sharon Osbourne.

headline: Yanks’ First Draft Pick Is a Pitcher
text: The struggles of the Yankees’ young pitching prospects this season have been well documented. Ian Kennedy and Phil Hughes have yet live up to their potential, and Joba Chamberlain’s conversion to the rotation is a work in progress. Only Darrell Rasner has provided any consistency this year.

headline: Cool, Hot and Finnish, With a Dose of Mythic Imagination
text: Its title notwithstanding, nothing in “Arctic Hysteria: New Art From Finland” betrays pathological overexcitement. On the surface, at least, all the works in this 16-artist show at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center are coolly controlled. Nevertheless, something hot runs through them: urgent emotions and irrational fantasies. Whether or not this cool-hot dichotomy reflects a split between the flinty and the mystical in the Finnish sensibility, it makes for a transporting show. The most striking instances of emotional tension are in film and video works. Veli Grano’s 35-minute film “Meet You in Finland Angel” is a gorgeous, heartbreaking documentary portrait of a Finnish couple who believe that their unborn child was taken by aliens to live on a planet in the Sirius star system.

headline: ‘Gossip Girl’ Author Aims Older
text: Hyperion said it would publish the first adult novels by Cecily von Ziegesar, the author of the best-selling “Gossip Girl” series of books for young adults. The first of the two books, “Cum Laude,” due out in 2009, tells the story of a group of characters who meet freshman year at a small college in Maine. “Gossip Girl,” a television adaptation of the series, is a popular program on the CW network that tells stories about wealthy young New Yorkers.

headline: Greece on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shawn Johnson Leads in Women’s Gymnastics Nationals
text: BOSTON  Dressed in a tangerine-colored leotard with the initials “SJ” in rhinestones on her right shoulder, Shawn Johnson sparkled Thursday in more ways than one at the United States gymnastics nationals.

headline: Tribune Co. Plans Sharp Cutbacks at Papers
text: Tribune Company newspapers like The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune will quickly cut costs  by printing fewer papers and employing fewer journalists  top company executives said on Thursday.

headline: After the Long Primary Campaign
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a dispute over Red Cross fund-raising for victims of a tornado in Iowa in May misidentified, in some editions, the party of Senator Charles E. Grassley, who has criticized the group’s efforts. He is a Republican, not a Democrat.

headline: A Night for Robbins to Give Chopin a Twirl or Three
text: Jerome Robbins would remain one of the most diverse, successful and appealing choreographers of all time if he had never set anything to the music of Chopin. Yet to imagine ballet without Robbins’s Chopin works is to imagine a painful diminution. Though the current Robbins retrospective from New York City Ballet has been successfully under way for over a month, its “Definitive Chopin” program, which opened on Wednesday night at the State Theater, brings us closer to the choreographer’s heart than any other evening this season.

headline: Supernatural Stew, Served With Camp
text: “The Mother of Tears” is silly, awkward, vulgar, outlandish, hysterical, inventive, revolting, flamboyant, titillating, ridiculous, mischievous, uproarious, cheap, priceless, tasteless and sublime. And that’s before the evil monkeys and sniggering Japanese harpies start running amok. By the time it gets to the diabolical subterranean soft-core orgies, this lunatic B-movie extravaganza has long since defied description and dazzled every irreverent, gore-hungry synapse in the brain.

headline: Highly Rated Auto Plants Set to Close
text: DETROIT  Some of the most productive automobile factories, as rated by an influential study released Thursday, are closing down or losing large numbers of jobs in the motor industry’s upheaval.

headline: R.F.K. Bridge May Meet Fate of Ave. of the Americas
text: What’s in a name, anyway? Would that which we call the Triborough Bridge by any other name  oh, let’s skip the Shakespeare and get to the point. Would anybody call the Triborough anything but the Triborough?

headline: In Utah, Rafting Through Prehistory
text: SOUTHEASTERN Utah, with its crimson canyons and flat-as-a-dinner-plate desert, would seem to be an improbable place to find wild water. But there, one morning early this spring, the San Juan River, as wide as a football field and as fast as a galloping horse, surged amid the dusty buttes of Bluff, Utah.

headline: Pelfrey Is Solid, but Mets Still Lose
text: SAN DIEGO  This was a pivotal moment, a pivotal moment in the game, in Mike Pelfrey’s development, and the Mets’ pitching coach, Rick Peterson, sensed it. He ran out to check on his struggling pitcher, putting his hands on Pelfrey’s shoulders. Staring back, Pelfrey nodded every few seconds like a dutiful son, as if to say, ‘It’s cool. I got it covered.”

headline: Steroids Dealer and Girlfriend Found Dead at Home
text: A convicted steroids dealer who provided documentary evidence and testimony to N.F.L. officials last month that tied several players to the use of performance-enhancing drugs was found dead on Thursday morning at his home in Plano, Texas, the police said.

headline: Analysts see new international interest in Phuket, Thailand
text: Two new studies show a dramatic increase in international buying activity in Phuket, Thailand’s popular tourist destination.

headline: Giambi Homer Lifts Yankees
text: The Yankees made mistakes along the way, but finally put a spectacular end to the Blue Jays after almost four hours.

headline: Friday’s Links: Come On, Let’s Talk About Persuasion
text: In the past week, I stumbled on two articles about the art of persuasion, and suddenly I’m persuaded that beefing up our ability to persuade people is crucial to succeeding in today’s team-oriented, less hierarchical work environments.

headline: Journey to Belmont Not Just for Horses
text: Julie Stewart is the National Airspace Program Manager for the United States Forest Service.

text: A look at the new Contemporary Jewish Museum building in San Francisco.

text: by Alex Hawgood

‘The Man Who Invented the Pringles Can’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Barack Obama clinched the Democratic presidential nomination this week and it’s been reported that Hillary Clinton is going to concede on Saturday. That’s Saturday, Dec. 15, 2017.

headline: Thoroughbreds and the Law
text: Kerry O’Neill is a rising third-year law student at the University of Kentucky College of Law in Lexington. An avid horsewoman and a student of horse racing history, Kerry says she is quite possibly the worst handicapper you will ever meet.

headline: Showdown at Pigeon Pool
text: At the top of the Times most e-mailed list is an article about otherwise tenderhearted gardeners who finally go Rambo and kill the pesky critters plaguing them (“Peter Rabbit Must Die”). Brings to mind this more humane approach to pests — a motion-activated sprinkler that thwarts pigeons from pooping in the pool:

headline: Deutsche, Merrill to Underwrite Indiabulls I.P.O.
text: Indiabulls Real Estate has said that Deutsche Bank and Merrill Lynch will underwrite the intial public offering of its Singapore-based investment trust.

headline: RockPort Raises $450 Million Fund
text: RockPort Capital Partners has closed its third venture capital fund, pulling in commitments of more than $450 million. The funds will be used to focus on clean-technology investments.

headline: BHP Asks Australian Regulator for Rio Tinto Approval
text: Pursuing its $167 billion takeover of Rio Tinto Group, BHP Billiton has made a submission to the Australian competition regulator seeking approval for the hostile bid, Bloomberg reported.

headline: F.C.C. to Soon Decide Sirius-XM Merger’s Fate
text: The long wait for an answer on the proposed Sirius Satellite Radio–XM Satellite Radio merger may soon be in the offing.

headline: Deutsche Bahn Plans Global Push
text: Deutsche Bahn will use funds from the proposed initial public offering of its DB Mobility Logistics unit to expand globally, German newspaper Boersen-Zeitung reported, citing an interview with Deutsche Bahn’s chief executive, Hartmut Mehdorn.

headline: Answers From Iraqi Women, Part V
text: Video

headline: Macquarie Raises $1.15 Billion in Bond Sale
text: Macquarie Group has raised $1.15 billion in a sale of asset-backed bonds and could use some of the proceeds as collateral to borrow $709 million from the European Central Bank.

headline: G.E. Hires Advisers for Sale of Wizard Unit
text: General Electric has hired Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase to advise on the sale of its Wizard mortgage unit in Australia, Bloomberg News reported citing people with knowledge of the decision.

headline: Regulator Welcomes Hedge Funds to Taiwan
text: Lee Shyan-Yuan, a commissioner at Taiwan’s Financial Supervisory Commission is actively courting hedge funds to invest in the country and raise money from investors in that market.

headline: Tom Tom Completes Tele Atlas Takeover
text: After nearly a year of fighting to acquire Tele Atlas, TomTom completed its $4.3 billion takeover bid on Thursday, the company said.

headline: Asian Hedge Fund Chief Sees Consolidation Ahead
text: The chief executive of Value Partners Group, Asia’s second-largest hedge fund manager by assets, told Bloomberg News that lackluster returns in the industry may lead smaller firms to be acquired by their bigger rivals.

headline: S.E.C. Sides With Hedge Fund in Legal Dispute
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission sided with activist hedge fund The Children’s Investment Fund on Thursday in a legal dispute over when investors should disclose stakes in companies, MarketWatch reported.

headline: UBS Plans to Close Its Municipal Bond Business
text: UBS said Thursday it would close its municipal bond business after failing to find a buyer for what was the third-largest underwriter of American state and local government debt last year.

headline: Expert Advice From Jonathan Vaughters
text: 30 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: practice spinning up hills while pedaling at high cadences.

headline: PrivateBancorp Begins Public Offering
text: PrivateBancorp has commenced a public offering of 3.7 million newly issued shares of common stock.

headline: Fed Approves Countrywide Deal
text: The Federal Reserve has approved Bank of America‘s purchase of distressed mortgage lender Countrywide Financial.

headline: A.I.G. Falls Under S.E.C. Scrutiny
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether American International Group overstated the value of contracts linked to subprime mortgages, The Wall Street Journal said Friday, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Anheuser Investors Say They Like $65-a-Share Offer
text: A bid by Belgium’s InBev for Anheuser-Busch at $65 a share would be reasonable, and a takeover would boost the Budweiser beer maker’s sluggish growth, Anheuser shareholders told Reuters.

headline: Mergers Accelerate as Telecoms Seek Growth
text: A multibillion-dollar telecommunications merger was announced Thursday, reflecting a trend for mobile phone operators to consolidate in their own crowded backyards while they scout for growth in emerging economies.

headline: ‘High Overhead’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Edison, Make Way for the L.E.D.’s
text: If you’re looking for the latest advancements in incandescent light bulb technology, one place you don’t want to go is to a lighting trade show. I learned that in about five minutes last week, while touring the aisles of Lightfair, the lighting industry’s big convention, held this year in Las Vegas.

headline: Private Equity and Banks: A Good Match?
text: TPG has recently invested in troubled lenders such as Washington Mutual and Bradford & Bingley, which has The Telegraph wondering: Are private equity firms making a contrarian bet on the financial services sector, or just desperate for a place to put their investors’ cash?

headline: Two Fed Bank Presidents Warn About Lending to Securities Firms
text: Two Federal Reserve Bank presidents warned in separate speeches on Thursday that the central bank’s decision in March to lend to securities firms might sow the seeds of further financial crises.

headline: Tribune Plans Sharp Cutbacks at Papers
text: Tribune Company newspapers like The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune will quickly cut costs – by printing fewer papers and employing fewer journalists – top company executives said on Thursday.

headline: Don’t Rain on My Parade
text: Hey! Let’s all go to the parade!

headline: Abu Dhabi Fund Still Sees U.S. as ‘Attractive’
text: Executives from the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the Mideast sovereign wealth fund that invested $7.5 billion in Citigroup last year, talked to BusinessWeek about the fund’s strategy and investment outlook.

headline: Will Lehman Announce Earnings Early?
text: Lehman Brothers may release its second-quarter earnings a week earlier than expected and could also use that opportunity to unveil a plan to raise capital, The New York Post reported. A separate report by Bloomberg said that the bank could raise as much as $5 billion by next week, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Information wants to be free — so how can I make a living?
text: The most fun I ever had writing an article was back in 1996, when I was asked to contribute to a centenary issue of the NYT magazine. Authors were told to write as if looking back from 2096. Hardly anyone was willing to do that — the other authors were, apparently, afraid to seem undignified. But I did — and the article looks pretty good today, if I say so myself.

headline: Drug, Backdating Charges for Ex-Broadcom Chief
text: Henry T. Nicholas III, the flamboyant co-founder and former chief executive of the chip maker Broadcom, was indicted Thursday in California on fraud, conspiracy and drug charges, including allegations that he spiked the drinks of other executives with ecstasy.

headline: BP Says It Is Committed to Russian Venture
text: The chief executive of BP, Tony Hayward, said Thursday that the company was committed to staying in Russia, even as its joint venture, TNK-BP, came under fresh pressure from the authorities investigating accusations of tax evasion.

headline: National City Said to Face S.E.C. Scrutiny
text: National City, the large Midwestern bank that sold a stake to an investor group earlier this year, has entered into a memorandum of understanding with federal regulators, effectively putting the bank on probation, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

headline: Expense-Account Science
text: Scientists are at last beginning to fathom the mystery of the business lunch. They find that your chances of getting someone else to accept an unfair deal depends on the other person’s level of serotonin, a neurotransmitter created in the body by an amino acid obtained through eating.

headline: Backdating and Drug Charges for Broadcom Ex-Chief
text: What appeared to be yet another investigation into options backdating has taken a truly bizarre twist — one that features allegations of secret drug warehouses, drinks spiked with ecstasy and a pot-smoke-filled private plane.

headline: Cloudy, Chance of Granite
School Admissions Changes Frustrate Parents
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has streamlined and centralized the dizzying array of admission procedures for the city’s prekindergartens and middle schools in order to equalize the process. But the dizzying array of changes, intended to treat families fairly, have frustrated many of them instead.

text: A couple of things that inspired me to create a salmon burger. I knew it would taste good, which is reason enough. And then there’s the fact that when it’s in season — like now — wild salmon is not all that expensive, and it’s superb stuff.

headline: Hansen on Next Climate Steps: Charge Polluters; Pay People
text: [UPDATED 6/9, 11:30 p.m.: John Tierney, hardly a Jim Hansen cheerleader, has strongly endorsed “tax and dividend.” UPDATED 12:10 p.m. with slide show.] Even as Senate Republicans blocked Democrats’ attempt to move forward with global warming legislation today, other approaches to federal climate action have already begun to percolate.  James E. Hansen, the NASA climate expert who has long been a bellwether for global warming campaigners, has strongly endorsed one of the less-popular options — a variant on the “cap and dividend” system for cutting greenhouse-gas emissions. (This is very different from the “cap and trade” mechanism in the blocked Lieberman-Warner-Boxer bill, which would invest revenue in a host of ways, with little money returning directly to taxpayers.)

headline: An Interactive Map of Stories From New Yorkers

The scheduling strategy begins on the first day of September, leading up to the introductions of the network’s two new fall shows, “Fringe” and “Do Not Disturb,” on Sept. 9 and 10 respectively.

headline: Chronic Youth
text: Face it: if you’re over 16, you’re too old to be reading Tiger Beat and BOP. But for those who feel forever young, there’s Electric Youth!, a new “magateen” from Luis Venegas, a former art director and the creator of Fanzine 137. Borrowing its name from Debbie Gibson’s chart-topping album (and fragrance) from 1989, the Madrid-based teen ’zine has become a cult read for the fashion set and anyone interested in the city’s burgeoning youth culture scene (bushy guybrows and all).

headline: The Starting Line: Gymnastics the Way It Used to Be
text: A small woman holds the lead at the U.S. gymnastics championships, as Juliet Macur reports from Boston, which for casual followers of the sport seems true to form — aren’t all top female gymnasts small? Those who follow women’s gymnastics more closely understand that there is a wider range of body types among elite performers, but still, you have to be getting up there in years to remember a time when female Olympians were generally bigger than the athletes who started to dominate the discipline in the 1970s.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Rank and File
text: Blessed are the list makers, with their sharp pencils, their certainties, their mix of words and numbers. Walt Whitman made lists. Nabokov made lists. Last year, while declaring in Time magazine that “literary lists are basically an obscenity,” Tom Wolfe admitted to having made many in his life, and then introduced a new one, ranking the best novels in the world.

headline: Red Sox Slap Fight
text: From the first day of spring training until the final out of the season, baseball players spend at least seven months together. They eat together, play together, travel together and critique each other. Players are around each other more than most families. And not every family holds hands all the time.

headline: In the Red Wings, a Lesson for the Rangers
text: Watching the Red Wings drive through the playoffs drove home a point for me. They are the perfect example of a franchise that is built on a philosophy. They decided years ago how they want to play and hired people skilled at finding players who fit an archetype. They are dedicated to being a puck possession team, one that plays a solid and cohesive brand of defense and for the most part ignores the hue and cry for thuggery.

headline: Raise a Glass to the Ex-Bar Owner’s Memory
text: GARRISON, N.Y. — Life’s not always fair, and every story doesn’t have the right ending. Four months after saying goodbye to the rickety refuge on the Hudson that he helped to define, they’ll say goodbye to John Guinan today and Saturday, and in the process say goodbye to a bit of the river’s soul as well. From 1959 to the beginning of this year, Guinan’s — between the Garrison railroad station and the east bank of the Hudson — was a combination deli, general store and pub with a tiny barroom with green walls and an alarmingly sloping floor that had Irish Music Nights the first Thursday after each full moon. Run first by his father, Jim, it evolved over time into one of those rare places that transcends its own myth — a time capsule, a home away from home, a place to hide out, and in the richest way a community.

headline: Icahn vs. Yahoo: The Latest Exchange

Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, said Friday that Yahoo should offer to sell itself to Microsoft for approximately $49.5 billion, about $2 billion more than Microsoft offered last month, after getting rid of an employee severance plan which he described as a costly “poison pill.”

headline: How Much Does It Cost to Go Green? The Answer is $45 trillion
text: The International Energy Agency today put a figure on the amount it will cost to go green, and it’s a lot: $45 trillion. Even when you spread that amount over the next 42 years, it’s still more than $1 trillion annually, or more than the GDP of many industrialized nations.

headline: Number One Rays: Where Are They Now?
text: The Rays’ long run of having high draft picks may have come to an end with their selection of shortstop Tim Beckham in Thursday’s draft. After years of losing, the Rays are now a force in the American League, currently in second place in the A.L. East. Some of their first-round picks in recent years have contributed to their new found success, but not all of them have panned out.

headline: Man Accused in Columbia Rape Case Stays in Cell
text: An ex-convict who is on trial for the brutal rape and torture of a Columbia University student did not show up in court today. The presiding judge in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Justice Carol Berkman, announced in court that the Correction Department had told her that he had refused to leave his cell.Last week, the defendant, Robert A. Williams, 31, also refused to appear for other hearings related to the case. At that time, Justice Berkman had made it clear that she would proceed without him even if he did not appear in court.

headline: This Ferry Terminal Will Come to You
text: Now ready to depart for the World Financial Center at Battery Park City: the whole ferry terminal — with six slips, two passenger service kiosks and a half-acre waiting room under hillocks of translucent fabric canopy, wrapped in a glass windscreen.On Saturday, the Port Authority plans to tow a new floating ferry terminal to its permanent berth at the foot of Vesey Street in Battery Park City. The journey is expected to last two hours from the 39th Street pier in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where the $50 million terminal has been under construction for a year and a half.

headline: Massa teaches marshals three-point turn
text: The most entertaining moment in today’s practice sessions was when Felipe Massa 15 minutes before the end of the second session became involved in teaching the track marshals how to drive his Ferrari. In case you missed the show, Massa had to pull out of the session with a likely engine problem and park at the edge of the track. The car was parked in such a way that the yellow flags came out. It was soon clear that the car was in a slightly dangerous position, so a group of marshals gathered round to pull the car through an opening in the guardrails to make sure it was on the other side of barrier and out of the way of the other drivers.

headline:
Eat (A Little), Drink (A Lot)
And Be . . . Immortal?
text: Here’s what I love about science: it tells us, on the one hand, that if we live by a severely calorie-restricted diet, eating less in a day than many of us eat in the first 15 minutes at the dinner table, we may extend our lives by a few years, thus enabling a continuation of this self-torture. Oh joy!

headline: Bank Analysts Get Middling Grades
text: Equity analysts just can’t catch a break these days – especially those covering the financial sector. headline: Playing Chess With RZA
text: RZA, one of the founders of the Wu-Tang Clan, the rap super group, is a huge chess fan, and a pretty good player. On Monday, in conjunction with Chesspark, he launched a Web site called Wuchess.com, where fans of the group (and even those who are not) can play chess and socialize online. The site also has news and information about Wu-Tang and its members. RZA has said the site may have monthly tournaments with the winner playing a game against him online. In an interview in his Manhattan hotel room last month, RZA played a blitz game against the chess columnist for The Times. Readers who want to see what happened can replay the game by clicking on the board below.

headline: We need a new business cycle vocabulary
text: Today’s employment report wasn’t as bad as the markets seem to have thought: the big jump in the unemployment rate was due to a jump in labor force participation — maybe by teens looking for gas money? — rather than a large drop in employment. The economy still seems to be in a sort of slow-mo slump: employment gradually falling, labor markets gradually worsening, GDP positive but barely.

headline: Ratings: Swingtown’s Come-Hither Look
