The provocative new series set in the 1970s has drawn scrutiny for its relatively explicit depictions of sex and drugs. Among adults 18 to 49, it was far from the night’s highest rated show, but “Swingtown” did improve on CBS’s performance in that demographic earlier in the night.

headline: Climber Tells of Test Run at Times Building

He said he climbed several feet and discovered that scaling the whole building would not be hard. (The company said Friday it was undertaking new security measures.)

headline: Disunity at Clinton-Obama Unity Event

It featured elected officials — many of them Clinton enthusiasts, donning Obama stickers.

Several high-profile supporters of Mrs. Clinton were on hand, along with hundreds of younger staff members clad in flip-flops and spring attire.

headline: Financials Hit New Low
text: Financial stocks bounced off their lows in March, after the Fed bailed out the creditors of Bear Stearns. That was taken as a sign that the Fed would prevent disaster.

headline: What Makes a Good Trainer?
text: I saw my first Belmont in 1986. It was run over a sloppy track on which Danzig Connection became the trainer Woody Stephens’s fifth consecutive Belmont Stakes winner. I knew it was a big deal for a trainer to win a Triple Crown race even once, but I was new to the sport, and even when the crowds began chanting “Wood-y! Wood-y!” I didn’t fully appreciate how extraordinary this record was.

headline: Albino Killings in Tanzania
text: At least 19 albinos, including several young children, have been killed in Tanzania in the past year.

headline: Albino Killings in Tanzania
text: At least 19 albinos, including several young children, have been killed in Tanzania in the past year.

headline: The Warner Music Ends at Last.FM
text: Let’s just say, God help you, that some mix of spring fever and midlife crisis made you decide that you simply could not make it through your afternoon without listening to Led Zeppelin’s “Stairway to Heaven.” So you click over to Last.FM, because, as an attentive Bits reader, you remember that site, now owned by CBS, is offering to let you listen to any track you want anytime you want to.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the aftermath of another construction crane accident, the doors closing on a historic library, increased fines for not picking up after your dog, and two climbers who scaled the New York Times building.

headline: Steroid-Free Breeders’ Cup
text: The 25th running of the Breeders’ Cup World Championships in October at Santa Anita Park will be contested without steroids for the first time and the only race day medication that will be allowed will be the anti-bleeder medication Lasix.

headline: Art Basel Parties
text: After-parties may be the coveted tickets during New York Fashion Week or the Oscars in Los Angeles, but in the art game, it is all about the pre-party.

headline: Randi and Loren
text: Randi Kirtman's first date with Loren Forrest Jr. was at the same Upper West Side cafe where, two years later, he proposed.

headline: Randi and Loren
text: Randi Kirtman's first date with Loren Forrest Jr. was at the same Upper West Side cafe where, two years later, he proposed.

headline: The Big Drop
text: Bill Pennington learns how to hit the green from 80 feet above.

headline: Giambi’s no Gibson, but He Had Fun
text: It was high drama at Yankee Stadium on Thursday when a hobbling Jason Giambi smashed his pinch-hit, game-ending home run. But Giambi did not want to oversell the moment. He was in the stands at Dodger Stadium for Game 1 of the 1988 World Series, when a hobbling Kirk Gibson did the same thing, and this was a far cry from that.

headline: Casual Conquest: England’s Big Brown?
text: With all the coverage of Big Brown and his attempt at the Triple Crown, it is easy to overlook the running of the Epsom Derby on Saturday in England. While our Belmont Stakes is obviously going to be the more fancied event for American punters, the 17 colts lining up at Epsom will be something to watch.

headline: The Next Big East Commissioner?
text: One of the reasons why Mike Tranghese announced that he would be retiring as the Big East’s commissioner more than a year in advance was to give the league’s presidents ample time to search for his successor.

headline: Bloggingheads: Terror on Trial
text:
Dahlia Lithwick of Slate and Benjamin Wittes of the Brookings Institution discuss whether the justice system can impartially prosecute terrorists.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: On the Verge of 100 Caps, Donovan Nears 100 Percent
text: If U.S. soccer fans were disappointed that Landon Donovan missed two international friendlies against England and Spain, imagine how Donovan felt.

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: What We Learned This Season
text: Well, after all that, what did we learn? Our HNIB crew of independent bloggers was asked this very question, but it turns out some of them are already on holiday (we’ll get their answers when they come back). Fortunately, though, most are still around, and these are their replies, arranged ingeniously by team nickname in alphabetical order.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: What Hillary Won
text: I get asked all the time whether I think Hillary lost because sexism is worse than racism in this country. The answer is no. She lost because Obama ran a smarter, better organized campaign. But if Barack had failed in his attempt to make history by becoming the first African-American presidential nominee, you can bet we’d have treated his defeat with the dignity it deserved.

headline: Wild Night in the Minors for the Yanks
text: It was a rough game at Yankee Stadium on Friday night. The Yankees got eight strong innings from Darrell Rasner but lost to Kyle Davies, 2-1. At least, for Johnny Damon’s sake, his 14-game hitting streak is over and he finally has an excuse to shave that hideous mustache.

headline: Police Say Steroids Dealer Shot Himself
text: PLANO, Tex.  A preliminary examination by the Dallas County Medical Examiner’s Office found that David Jacobs, a convicted steroids dealer who had linked several N.F.L. players to the use of performance-enhancing drugs, committed suicide, according to the police.

headline: Ending Her Bid, Clinton Backs Obama
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton formally threw her support behind Senator Barack Obama on Saturday, clearing the way for Mr. Obama to head into the general election with a plan to challenge Senator John McCain in typically Republican states.

headline: Full of Laughs, Ochoa Makes Serious Charge Into Lead
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  Morgan Pressel sidled up to Lorena Ochoa on the last green Friday and said something that made them both smile. Pressel, Ochoa and the third member of their group, Karrie Webb, had spent four hours putting on a clinic at Bulle Rock Golf Course, competing to see who could produce the better approach shot or purer putt during the second round of the L.P.G.A. Championship.

headline: After Playing Dirty, a Laundry List of Suspensions
text: BOSTON  There was a new traveling act in the Fenway Park circus Friday night. The Seattle Mariners and their clubhouse antics rolled into town still fresh from their manager’s expletive-laden tirade to reporters Wednesday and an accountability meeting with their general manager Thursday to explain why they have the worst record in baseball.

headline: Taking Steps to Feel Your Best
text: Dr. William Sandborn, a professor of gastroenterology at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., says people with ulcerative colitis “should have high expectations that they should be in remission and feel well.”

headline: Patrick Swayze’s New TV Series Will Proceed Despite His Cancer
text: Patrick Swayze, who only a few months ago was found to have a life-threatening case of pancreatic cancer, has recovered enough that his planned drama series for the A&E network will go into production this summer, with him in the starring role.

headline: California: A New Hearing in V.A. Case
text: A federal judge presiding over a lawsuit alleging mistreatment of veterans has ordered a hearing regarding new evidence in the case. The judge, Samuel Conti of Federal District Court in San Francisco, ordered the hearing, scheduled for Tuesday, after the emergence of an internal e-mail message that appears to urge Veterans Affairs clinicians to avoid making a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder to save money. The message was written by a V.A. psychologist in Texas, but it did not surface until after the trial concluded in April, prompting the plaintiffs to request that the case be reopened. “It’s part of a systemic pattern where there’s a divergence between the pristine world of the V.A.’s central office and what goes on around the country,” said Gordon Erspamer, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. On Wednesday, a lawyer with the Justice Department wrote to Judge Conti contending that the e-mail message in question did not represent V.A.-wide practice or policy. Also on Wednesday, Norma Perez, the psychologist who wrote the message, told members of Congress that it was poorly worded and was meant only to suggest diagnostic options for doctors. The lawsuit was filed last year by veterans’ groups.

headline: Smiles All Around at Wal-Mart’s Annual Meeting
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  The dark days are over at Wal-Mart, or at least that was the message at the retailer’s relentlessly upbeat shareholder meeting here Friday.

headline: Audit Faults an Education Nonprofit
text: A federal audit of Teach for America, a nonprofit that recruits college graduates to teach in low-income schools, has found that the organization did not properly account for $775,000 in government money it says it spent for summer training sessions and related purposes.

headline: Microsoft Is Closing a Classified Ad Site
text: Microsoft is closing Windows Live Expo, the classified advertising Web site that was initially seen as a potential competitor to Craigslist, the San Francisco-based online classified service. The service, started in February 2006, will close on July 31, a post on the site said Friday. Live Expo was one of a series of services Microsoft started to beef up its online presence.

headline: Mexico, an Oil Producer, Hasn’t Benefited From Soaring Prices
text: MEXICO CITY  Mexico is the world’s sixth-largest oil producer, and the steady climb in the price of oil has reached record highs. The soaring prices should have generated $3 billion above budget estimates for the state oil monopoly, Pemex. But now the government says that windfall just is not there.

headline: Unemployment Rate Hits 5.5% as 49,000 Jobs Lost
text: The unemployment rate surged to 5.5 percent in May from 5 percent, the largest monthly spike in more than two decades, as the economy shed 49,000 jobs for a fifth month of decline, the Labor Department reported on Friday.

headline: Big Brown’s Path Could Be Missing a Rival
text: Early Friday morning the Big Brown camp learned that Casino Drive, its main rival, had developed a foot problem and may miss the 140th running of the Belmont Stakes. Shortly after 1 p.m., the hoof specialist Ian McKinlay emerged from Barn 2 here at this grand old racetrack on Long Island and announced that Big Brown’s left front hoof was healed and patched and ready for an assault on history.

headline: Cleveland Orchestra Extends Music Director’s Contract
text: At major American symphony orchestras just now, as in American politics, the watchword is change. A number of music directorships recently turned over, with others to follow. And several of the new appointments have signaled changes of direction, most notably at the New York Philharmonic and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, where youthful hirings hark back to the orchestras’ earlier days.

headline: Georgia Is Warned by Russia Against Plans to Join NATO
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia warned the Georgian president, Mikheil Saakashvili, on Friday that Georgia’s joining NATO would deepen the conflict between the former Soviet states.

headline: Schedule Revives Memories of Coach’s Emotional Journey
text: The last time Mike Candrea went to Stevens Point, Wis., his wife died.

headline: Retrieving Older Friends and Hearing Them Out
text: New-music groups almost always include a premiere or two on their programs, but reviving works that have been set aside is important too. For the closing program of its 37th season, on Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the Da Capo Chamber Players resisted the lure of the new and revisited seven substantial works by five composers.

headline: Job Losses and Oil Surge Spread Economic Gloom
text: The unemployment rate surged to 5.5 percent in May from 5 percent  the sharpest monthly spike in 22 years  as the economy lost 49,000 jobs, registering a fifth consecutive month of decline, the Labor Department reported Friday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with a cover article about more sophisticated testing of lymph nodes for cancer described incorrectly the lymph node tissue that was shown. The tissue appeared to be free of cancer tumors; there were not “many cancer cells” present.

headline: Home Run Derby Swaps Ortiz for 2 to Be Named
text: David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox was supposed to try to mimic Babe Ruth during a Call Your Shot promotion in next month’s All-Star Game festivities at Yankee Stadium. After the Yankees protested and Ortiz was injured, officials decided to have two players replace him.

headline: CBS Swings on Thursday
text: The debut of the CBS drama “Swingtown” attracted moderate interest on Thursday, delivering an audience of 8.6 million viewers at 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series, set among suburban libertines in the 1970s, has drawn scrutiny for its depictions of sex and drug use. Among adults 18 to 49, it was far from the night’s highest-rated show, but “Swingtown” did improve on CBS’s performance in that demographic earlier in the night. In the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, the network broadcast two repeats of “CSI,” which, despite low ratings among the 18-to-49 set, fared well in total viewers, with 8.2 million and 9.4 million respectively. CBS ranked third for the night over all, just behind Fox and its two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” from 8 to 10 (9.1 million). ABC led over all with live coverage of the first game of the N.B.A. finals, which averaged approximately 10 million viewers from 9 to 11.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on May 22 about reactions among blind people to a ruling that the government discriminates against them by making paper money all the same size and texture included an erroneous statistic from an advocacy organization. According to Lighthouse International, 16.5 million Americans  many of whom could be affected by the ruling  report that they have vision impairment even when wearing glasses or contacts. That number does not, however, include the legally blind population, which the American Foundation for the Blind puts at 1.3 million.

headline: What to Ask About Ulcerative Colitis
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening, and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

headline: Labeling the Terrorists
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Gift of Prose to Soothe the Traveler
text: “Poetry makes nothing happen,” W. H. Auden wrote in his elegy to William Butler Yeats.

headline: Clinton Bloc Becomes the Prize for Election Day
text: Now that a would-be first female president is ending her quest for the White House, the race is more about women than ever before.

headline: Savor the Moment
text: Friday was the 40th anniversary of the death of Robert F. Kennedy. Had he lived, he would be 82 now.

headline: Talk of War and Family Highlights McCain’s Kickoff Commercial
text: This is a television advertisement for the campaign of Senator John McCain, and it is the start of Mr. McCain’s first major advertising push of the general election. It was released Friday morning on the Internet.

headline: Big Oil Is Owed Some Love
text: WHO says everyone loves a winner? Big diversified oil companies are reporting enormous profits but they are receiving what seems to be a record amount of grief.

headline: Keep It Short, Make It Instant
text: SOME of us find those bouncing or flashing icons on computer screen to be disruptive and distracting. But apparently, many workers believe instant messaging causes less interruption than other forms of communication like phone calls, e-mail and talking face to face.

headline: Dream Round of Golf Becomes a Humbling Test
text: SAN DIEGO  The question was simple enough. Could a 10-handicap golfer shoot less than 100 on a golf course set up for a United States Open, under Open conditions with U.S.G.A. officials, NBC television cameras and a live gallery in tow?

headline: Drama Aside, Celtics Expect Pierce to Play
text: BOSTON  Thirteen hours after he etched himself into N.B.A. finals history, Paul Pierce limped back into TD Banknorth Garden, looking and sounding a bit closer to mortal. His right knee was swollen and painful, and his outlook for Game 2 was unclear.

headline: Feud Is Rekindled Between Organizer of Tour de France and World Cycling Body
text: The International Cycling Union is warning riders that they will face sanctions if they enter the Tour de France next month.

headline: Top City Crane Inspector Accused of Taking Bribes
text: The city’s chief crane inspector was arrested on Friday and charged with taking bribes to allow cranes to pass inspection, the authorities said. He was also accused of taking money from a crane company that sought to ensure that its employees would pass the required licensing exam.

headline: Justices List Their Assets; Wide Range of Wealth
text: WASHINGTON  Justice Clarence Thomas earned $500,000 in book advances in 2007, one of three Supreme Court justices to receive book-related income last year, according to financial disclosures released Friday.

headline: Holdouts Test Aid’s Limitations as FEMA Shuts a Trailer Park
text: BAKER, La.  Theresa August spent the official closing day of the Renaissance Village trailer park singing, muttering to herself and dancing on a picnic table. Finally, wearing an infant’s flowered onesie on her head like a kerchief, she began to pack up.

headline: Casino Buyout Is Extended
text: Penn National Gaming has extended the deadline for the completion of its $6.1 billion sale to Fortress Investment Group and Centerbridge Partners to Oct. 13.

headline: Taming the Inflammation of Ulcerative Colitis
text: Dr. Stephen Hanauer is professor of medicine and clinical pharmacology and chief of gastroenterology, hepatology and nutrition at the University of Chicago Medical Center. He is chairman of the International Organization for Inflammatory Bowel Disease, a group of clinical researchers who gather annually to review emerging concepts and publish innovative research on inflammatory bowel disease from an international viewpoint.

headline: A.I.G. Says It Is Subject of Inquiries
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department are investigating the American International Group, examining how the company valued certain complex derivative transactions, A.I.G. confirmed on Friday.

headline: In Three No-Trump, Inching Toward Beijing
text: The final of the trial to pick the United States open team for the first World Mind Sports Games in Beijing next October was scheduled to conclude Friday evening in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The 120-board match was between the top-seeded team of Aubrey Strul, Michael Becker, David Berkowitz, Larry Cohen, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby and the second seeds: Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Chris Compton, Bob Hamman, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell.

headline: Celtics Redux: Grit Over Glamour
text: Boston

headline: Serving Time, but Lacking Remorse
text: Some guys just don’t know when to shut up. William S. Lerach is one of those guys.

headline: Times Imposes Security Measures After Climbers’ Stunts
text: Executives of The New York Times Company undertook security studies in planning its new headquarters after 9/11, focusing on terrorist threats but apparently never considering that the building  sheathed in rows of horizontal ceramic bars  could become an urban ladder for climbers, as it did twice on Thursday.

headline: Married, Not So Happily, to the Army
text: For years, Lifetime has been regarded as “television for women.” But if you are familiar with the movies for which the channel serves as fear-mongering auteur  “A Lover’s Revenge,” “A Face to Die For,” “A Face to Kill For,” “A Killer Upstairs,” “A Vow to Kill,” “A Killing Spring”  then you know that Lifetime is not television for every woman, and certainly it is television for no man.

headline: Rivalry Isn’t a Big Draw
text: The ballyhooed renewal of the Lakers-Celtics rivalry in the N.B.A. finals did not generate spectacular viewership for Game 1 Thursday night compared with the Lakers’ last appearance in the finals four years ago. Los Angeles is the nation’s No. 2 market. ABC could boast that it defeated its prime-time competition and won in all the key demographics. And while the 13.4 million viewers watching Game 1 represented a 45 percent increase over the 9.2 million who saw the Spurs-Cavaliers opener last year, the game drew 13 percent fewer viewers than Game 1 of the 2004 Lakers-Pistons finals.

headline: Pakistan Police Say They Foiled Attack
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Four days after a car bomb attack on the Danish Embassy in Islamabad killed eight people, the Pakistani authorities said Friday that they had foiled a new onslaught when police officers intercepted three vehicles laden with explosives and arrested three potential suicide bombers.

headline: The False Trail That Led to War
text: To the Editor:

headline: University Head Resigns After Degree Dispute
text: Bogged down for more than five months by a controversy surrounding a master’s degree improperly awarded to the governor’s daughter, the president of West Virginia University announced Friday that he would step down in September.

headline: Obama’s Comments on Israel Stir Criticism in U.S.
text: The morning after claiming the Democratic nomination, Senator Barack Obama spoke to skeptical members of a pro-Israel lobby and made a pledge that some of them found pleasantly surprising: “Jerusalem will remain the capital of Israel, and it must remain undivided.”

headline: Rains Add to Flood Threat in Quake Area
text: ANCHANG, China  They gathered by the hundreds on the riverbank here to face the latest insult delivered to them by nature.

headline: Mother in Virginia Loses Bid to Void Same-Sex Ruling in Vermont on Child Custody
text: Virginia must honor a child custody order from a Vermont court issued after the breakup of a same-sex civil union there, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled on Friday.

headline: Selected Studies: Ulcerative Colitis
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Tight Rein on Blood Sugar Has No Heart Benefits
text: Two large studies involving more than 21,000 people found that people with Type 2 diabetes had no reduction in their risk of heart attacks and strokes and no reduction in their death rate if they rigorously controlled their blood sugar levels.

headline: Sven Davidson, 79, Hall of Famer in Tennis, Dies
text: Sven Davidson, the first Swede to win a Grand Slam tennis championship, a leading international player of the 1950s and a member of the International Tennis Hall of Fame, died May 28 in Arcadia, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Postage Paid: $2.2 Million
text: A rare strip of three Brazilian postage stamps from 1843 has been sold for $2,185,000 at an auction to an anonymous telephone bidder. The strip, known to philatelists as the Pack Strip after one of its early owners, is considered one of the top rarities in stamp collecting. The auction took place on Thursday during a two-day sale of Latin American stamps at a gallery in New York, which brought in a total of more than $7.5 million, including commission.

headline: Workers on Hunger Strike Say They Were Misled on Visas
text: WASHINGTON  About a dozen metalworkers from India staged the fourth week of a hunger strike here this week, camped under a shade tree on Embassy Row.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 6, 2008

headline: Oil Prices Take a Nerve-Rattling Jump Past $138
text: The rise in oil prices turned into a stampede on Friday with futures jumping a staggering $11 a barrel to set a record above $138 a barrel. The unprecedented surge came as the dollar fell sharply against the euro and a senior Israeli politician once again raised the possibility of an attack against Iran.

headline: For Movement Research, a Time to Cast a Wide Net Over Disciplines and Countries
text: It’s that time of year when Europe is flooded with festivals that dwell on more than new choreography and try, through theoretical discussion, to relate dance to larger issues about the body and the art form’s place in the world. The spring festival of Movement Research is a scrappier version of that model; organized by artists, it gives those in the New York dance world a chance to stop complaining about the lack of discourse and do something about it.

headline: Where Hollywood’s Stars Are Interred, but Live Forever on Screen
text: LOS ANGELES  A few hundred people poured through the gates of Hollywood Forever Cemetery last Saturday, carrying picnics, blankets and folding chairs. They moved along a path toward the sound of a Jimi Hendrix song coming from the foot of a high marble mausoleum.

headline: Remembering a Master Drummer as Bandleader
text: When Max Roach died last August at 83, he was remembered for a number of things: his stature as a patriarch of bebop; his role in quickening the pulse of jazz drumming; his intelligent ambitions as a conceptualist and composer; his commitment to social justice and equality. What was sometimes buried in the mix was Mr. Roach’s track record as a bandleader, which began in earnest in the 1950s.

headline: Pelfrey Throws More Pitches, Learning More
text: SAN DIEGO  Manager Willie Randolph had about 97 reasons he could have pulled Mike Pelfrey after five innings in the Mets’ 2-1 loss to the San Diego Padres on Thursday night, reasons he could have brought in the already warmed-up Claudio Vargas to pitch the sixth. But, Randolph said, “You learn a lot from going out there and grinding it out and going through some ups and downs and adversity.”

headline: Moving Money, Not Telegrams, Across Borders
text: MENTION the name Western Union and most people probably think of one thing: telegrams. But the company sent its last dispatch in 2006.

headline: While Rasner Goes Deep, Yankees Don’t
text: The Yankees have gotten the fewest innings from their starting pitchers in the American League. It has placed a burden on their bullpen and eventually could threaten the team’s streak of 13 consecutive playoff appearances.

headline: Zimbabwe Blocks Opposition’s Rallies and Again Detains Its Leader
text: JOHANNESBURG  With only three weeks to go before Zimbabwe’s presidential runoff, the police briefly detained the opposition’s standard-bearer, Morgan Tsvangirai, on Friday for the second time this week and directed his party to cancel political rallies, effectively preventing him from addressing voters.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Metro

headline: Belmont Is Goal for Ailing Casino Drive
text: Casino Drive, considered the main threat to Big Brown’s Triple Crown bid, has sustained an injury to his left hind foot, but a spokesman for the owner Hidetoshi Yamamoto said late Friday afternoon that the colt was expected to start in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Mistakes Mar Close Game as Mets Slip Back to .500
text: SAN DIEGO  Baseball purists would have delighted in the first five innings of the Mets’ game Friday night, which featured a total of five hits and zero runs, the product of an entrancing pitchers’ duel between Johan Santana and the Padres’ Randy Wolf. They might have walked out of Petco Park altogether after watching the sixth, which included Santana’s failure to field a bunt and put one down, and a Padre’s being hit by a batted ball for the second consecutive night.

headline: Putting Talent First, Yanks Will Deal With Boras Later
text: For much of baseball, an important factor in the draft is a player’s willingness to sign. Of course, the Yankees do not operate like most of their peers, generally ignoring the bonus recommendations of the commissioner’s office.

headline: Virgin America Protests Rivals’ Bid to Protect Slots
text: Virgin America opposes an effort by six rivals to protect takeoff and landing slots they may not use in New York, Chicago and Washington this winter because of high fuel costs. The request by AMR’s American Airlines, UAL’s United Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines, the US Airways Group and AirTran Holdings is “anticonsumer,” Virgin America’s lawyer told regulators in Washington. Under federal law, carriers must use slots at restricted airports or risk giving them up to rivals. The six want to waive the requirement so they can trim flights without later losing the access.

headline: Raising the Bar at the Pentagon
text: It’s not often in American politics or government that officials are held accountable these days, so Defense Secretary Robert Gates’s decision to fire the top two Air Force leaders on Thursday was as surprising as it was commendable.

headline: Tournament Opens With No Shortage of Favorites
text: The 13th European soccer championship begins Saturday and will last 23 days, with games in Austria and Switzerland. The quadrennial 16-team tournament, played in even-number years between World Cups, has emerged as one of the most popular sporting events among TV viewers around the world.

headline: Afghan Tribal Leader Killed
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  A powerful tribal leader was gunned down outside his home in the southern city of Kandahar by suspected Taliban Friday morning, Afghan officials said. Muhammad Akbar Khakrezwal, a former commander and supporter of the government, was shot by two men on a motorbike, a preferred tactic by Taliban gunmen. He died before he reached the hospital.

headline: Hollywood Is Burning
text: Los Angeles

headline: The Cons of Creationism
text: When it comes to science, creationists tend to struggle with reality. They believe, after all, that evolution by means of natural selection is false and that Earth is only a few thousand years old. They also believe that students who are taught a creationist view of biology  or who are taught to disregard the Darwinist view  are not being disadvantaged.

headline: Candidates Forgo Soft Money, but Conventions Rake It In
text: One of Senator Barack Obama’s first acts after claiming the Democratic nomination was declaring he would not take special-interest money for his presidential bid, even going so far as to bar lobbyists from donating to the Democratic National Committee.

headline: Fingers Pointed as Climate Bill Dies for the Year
text: WASHINGTON  Before the anticlimactic demise on Friday of legislation to combat global warming, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, called climate change “the most important issue facing the world today.” Senator George Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, a critic of the bill, nonetheless called it “the most significant piece of legislation to ever come out of the Environment and Public Works Committee.”

headline: Myanmar Junta Begins Evicting Cyclone Victims From Shelters
text: LABUTTA, Myanmar  Within a week of the storm that flooded the delta here last month with waves as high as 20 feet, the monasteries in this village were swarming with 14,000 people who had lost their families, homes and livelihoods.

headline: Nadal Rolls On to French Open Final and Federer
text: PARIS  The manner and methods were certainly different as Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer secured their latest rendezvous in the French Open final.

headline: After Verbal Fire, Senate Effectively Kills Climate Change Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Before the anticlimactic demise on Friday of legislation to combat global warming, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, called climate change “the most important issue facing the world today.” Senator George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio, a critic of the bill, nonetheless called it “the most significant piece of legislation to ever come out of the Environment and Public Works Committee.”

headline: Panel Upholds Sprinter’s Suspension
text: The sprinter Justin Gatlin’s appeal of his four-year drug suspension was rejected by the Court of Arbitration for Sport on Friday, ensuring that he will not be able to defend his Olympic gold medal in the 100 meters at the Beijing Games this summer.

headline: A U.S. Olympic Marathoner and Her Coach
text: Four years ago, Blake Russell’s stunning tumble from first place to fourth at the Olympic women’s marathon trials provoked whispers of pity from the running community and tears from Russell and her coach, Bob Sevene.

headline: Rape Victim Recounts 19 Hours of Terror
text: She entered the courtroom on Friday afternoon wearing a tan dress, red flats and thick-framed glasses. She was petite  about five feet tall and weighing 130 pounds  with brown hair hanging halfway down her neck.

headline: Two Teenagers and Their Murderous Spree, Evoked in Gesture and Movement
text: The brutal murders committed in Nebraska in 1958 by the 19-year old Charles Starkweather and his 14-year-old girlfriend, Caril Ann Fugate, have inspired a number of books, songs and films, including “Badlands” and “Natural Born Killers.” Now there is a dance-theater piece, too: Brendan McCall’s “Stark Weather,” which opened Thursday night at Danspace Project.

headline: Fall Wave in Brooklyn
text: The 26th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will open on Sept. 30 with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, as part of a season packed with dance, the academy announced. The troupe, above in rehearsal with Mr. Jones, will perform the New York premiere of “A Quarreling Pair,” based on a puppet play by Jane Bowles. Other dance presentations include La La La Human Steps, from Montreal; the French nouveau cirque group Compagnie 111; and return engagements from two Brooklyn Academy regulars, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and Pina Bausch. The Vesturport Theater of Iceland will offer a new production of Georg Büchner’s “Woyzeck” with music by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis, and Ivo van Hove brings his Toneelgroep Amsterdam for a stage adaptation of John Cassavetes’s 1977 film “Opening Night.” Music bookings include “Red Hot + Rio 2,” a two-night Brazilian concert with Bebel Gilberto, José González, Céu and others; the avant-garde string quartet Ethel; “Arjuna’s Dilemma,” a chamber opera based on the Bhagavad-Gita by the New York composer Douglas J. Cuomo; and a multimedia interpretation of Emily Dickinson’s poems by the Bang on a Can composer Michael Gordon, with the Ridge Theater and the filmmaker Bill Morrison. Information and tickets: (718) 636-4100, bam.org.

headline: Virgin Wears a Mustache (It’s Spring)
text: The Scottish choreographer Michael Clark continued his “Stravinsky Project” odyssey on Thursday evening at the Rose Theater with productions of “Le Sacre du Printemps” and “Les Noces,” both American premieres.

headline: Conditions on U.S. Aid in Drug Fight Anger Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Few slights irk Mexican politicians so much as when Washington treats Mexico like a backward country in need of outside guidance, and that anger raged full throttle this week as top Mexican officials threatened to walk away from a major United States aid package to help defeat drug traffickers.

headline: Where Housing Prices Go, Views of the President Follow
text: HOME prices in the United States are plunging, and the president’s economic policies are unpopular.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the Inside Art column on Friday about art in the piazza outside the Art Basel fair in Switzerland referred incorrectly to an artist who has a work on view there. The artist, Roxy Paine, is a man.

headline: Martial Art of Chess, Promoted by a Rapper
text: The rapper RZA, a founder of the Wu-Tang Clan, sat in a suite on the 48th floor of the Mandarin Oriental hotel overlooking Central Park, staring at a chess game through a pair of sunglasses. His hand was frozen a few inches above the board as he looked for a strategy to thwart his opponent.

headline: Billboards and Privacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Problem With Being Preordained
text: It seemed that the gods were finally smiling on the Chicago Cubs. After coming from Florida with a 3-games-to-2 lead in the best-of-seven National League Championship Series, the odds were in our favor. Not only were we returning home to play the final two games of the series in front of the Wrigley Field faithful, but we had our two top guns pitching for us. Mark Prior and Kerry Wood had been dominant for the last three months of the season, and they were primed for these two final tests. More importantly, all we needed to do was win one of these games to propel us into the World Series.

headline: Life at the Starting Gate at Belmont Park
text: Belmont Park will be packed on Saturday as Big Brown, who has won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, tries to win the Belmont Stakes to become the first Triple Crown winner in 30 years. Thousands of spectators will try to get as close as they can to the finish line. But what happens at the beginning of the race might be just as important, and that is where the workers at the starting gate come into play.

headline: Roadside Oddities
text: “EVER since Model T’s first roamed the earth, attention-grabbing roadside curiosities  giant concrete dinosaurs, house-size artichokes and the like  have been luring drivers off the asphalt to enrich community coffers,” Mike Stevens notes in Endless Vacation.

headline: In Turnabout, Antitrust Unit Looks at Intel
text: WASHINGTON  A global legal battle between the two largest makers of computer processors took an abrupt turn this week when the Federal Trade Commission opened a formal antitrust investigation of the Intel Corporation.

headline: Two Rivals Sneak Away to Meet, and the Hunt Is On

headline: One Less Obstacle in Big Brown’s Path
text: When the 140th edition of Belmont Stakes is run Saturday afternoon, the favorite Big Brown will have one less obstacle between him and the Triple Crown. His main rival, Casino Drive, was scratched Saturday morning because of a stone bruise to his left hind hoof.

headline: California Teachers Challenge Proposed Cuts
text: LOS ANGELES  Tens of thousands of teachers formed picket lines outside nearly 900 schools here Friday morning to protest cuts to education financing proposed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger to help close California’s projected $17 billion budget gap.

headline: The People Who Aspire to Great Heights, Literally, Hand Over Hand
text: The urge to climb came early to Timmy O’Neill, when there was nothing around him but concrete and steel. To the teenage Timmy, during a visit to New York from Philadelphia, the cables on the Brooklyn Bridge were as alluring as any playground jungle gym, but his short vertical clamber ended the same way some of his climbs do today: with a visit from the police.

headline: In Shift for Japan, Salarymen Blow the Whistle
text: TOKYO  A car company that hid dangerous flaws to avoid embarrassing recalls. A meat processor that sold ground pig hearts as beef. A fancy restaurant chain that served customers leftover sashimi from other diners.

headline: What Hillary Won
text: As the sun was sinking on Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign, the nation’s wounded feminists were burning up the Internet.

headline: Bonds’s Trial Set to Start in March
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Barry Bonds’s trial is scheduled to begin March 2 now that he has pleaded not guilty to 14 charges of making false statements under oath about whether he used performance-enhancing drugs and to one charge of obstruction of justice.

headline: What Paintings?
text: Vladimir Voronin, the president of Moldova, made a wonderful announcement on Friday, saying that two paintings stolen from the State Hermitage Museum in Russia had been found in Moldova and would soon be returned, The Associated Press reported. There’s just one problem: He did not say what the works were, and the Hermitage’s press office said it had no idea what paintings he was talking about. In Russia for talks with President Dmitri A. Medvedev, Mr. Voronin said the paintings had been recovered three days earlier after a long police investigation. The Interior Ministry of Moldova said that the investigation was under way and that details would not be revealed until Tuesday, but the Russian news service Itar-Tass, citing an unidentified law enforcement source in Moldova, said the paintings were believed to be by the 19th-century landscape artist Vasily Polenov and the Soviet-era social realist Boris Ioganson. The Hermitage, in St. Petersburg, said in July 2006 that 221 items had been stolen, but did not report any missing paintings.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com

headline: The Wrong Models for Fighting Climate Change

headline: Europe Fears a Post-Bush Unilateralism, This Time on Trade
text: The Democrats’ vocal hostility to trade is starting to scare many of America’s best friends. As Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton have bashed China and a variety of free trade agreements, allies who have been yearning for an end to President Bush’s in-your-face unilateralism are worried that a Democratic president may be just as undiplomatic, and unreasonable, when it comes to economic protectionism.

headline: Surgery for Ulcerative Colitis Is a Difficult Choice
text: When, or whether, to have surgery may be the most difficult decision facing a patient with ulcerative colitis.

headline: Chinese Buddhist Treasures, Written in Stone
text: The script is familiar but irresistible. A cache of art is stored, unexamined, in the bowels of an esteemed institution. Scholars become intrigued. Cataloging begins. The quality is unexpectedly high, and soon an exhibition materializes, accompanied by a catalog that illuminates the tale of neglect, renewed interest and diligent scholarship as well as the splendors of the art.

headline: Olmert Warns of a Major Military Thrust in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, warned on Friday that Israel could soon opt for a major military operation in Gaza to try to stop rocket and mortar fire from that area, which has killed three Israelis in recent weeks.

headline: He Still Loves New Orleans, and Now He’s Mad
text: NEW ORLEANS  Mac Rebennack, the 67-year-old New Orleans pianist, guitarist and songwriter better known as Dr. John, carries the city’s lore in his fingers, his scratchy voice and his memory. He has lived in New York City and on Long Island since the 1980s, but when he revisits his birthplace it’s as if he never left. New Orleans culture, he said in his ever-surprising vocabulary, has “wacknosity”  things only New Orleanians do.

headline: Tax Laws Popularize the Small Foundation
text: When John Lane III assumed the investment responsibilities for the Edward H. Lane Foundation in 2004, he took on a lot of headaches.

headline: S.E.C. Closes Inquiry of Overstock.com
text: Overstock.com, the online seller of excess inventory, said the Securities and Exchange Commission did not plan to file a complaint after completing an investigation of the company and its officers. Overstock disclosed the inquiry in 2006, saying the S.E.C. was examining its accounting policies and its complaint against research company Gradient Analytics. Patrick Byrne, Overstock’s chief executive, has accused hedge funds, analysts and financial journalists of spreading negative information about his company so that short-sellers can profit from a drop in its stock. The S.E.C. ended a related inquiry of Gradient last year and also declined to take action.

headline: Mayweather Retires
text: There will, it seems, be no rematch for Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya. Mayweather retired Friday, saying in a statement that “these past few years have been extremely difficult for me to find the desire and joy to continue in the sport.” Mayweather (39-0), the W.B.C. welterweight champion, said he had talked about retiring over the last two years, but subsequently rekindled his passion to compete. Now, “after many sleepless nights and intense soul-searching, I realized I could no longer base my decision on anything but my own personal happiness, which I no longer could find.”

headline: An Artist Brings Religion Into His Work, in Big, Bold Style
text: Archie Rand is standing in a Brooklyn warehouse and surveying “The 613,” a vast artwork it has taken him five years to complete.

headline: T-Mobile Sues Starbucks Over Hot Spots
text: T-Mobile USA sued Starbucks, saying the coffee chain breached a contract by allowing AT&T to supply in-store customers with free wireless Internet access using T-Mobile’s lines and equipment. T-Mobile, which said it agreed to provide Wi-Fi service at Starbucks in 2002, accused the largest American coffee chain of secretly developing a plan to let AT&T provide free Internet service at more than 7,000 Starbucks stores in the United States. T-Mobile said it is bearing the cost and burden of the free Wi-Fi service offer because it provided equipment and technology at thousands of Starbucks stores. Valerie O’Neil, a spokeswoman for Starbucks, did not return a voice-mail message left at her office seeking comment.

headline: Gas by the Liter
text: To the Editor:

headline: Harriet Johnson, 50, Activist for Disabled, Is Dead
text: Harriet McBryde Johnson, a feisty champion of the rights of the disabled who came to prominence after she challenged a Princeton professor’s contention that severely disabled newborns could ethically be euthanized, died on Wednesday at her home in Charleston, S.C. She was 50.

headline: Film Notes
text: Adam Sandler’s production company, Happy Madison, is branching into thrillers with a new division called Scary Madison, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The division’s first picture is “Shortcut,” about two brothers who find a neglected  and presumably frightening  route in their town. Not counting Happy Madison’s latest movie, “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan,” which stars Mr. Sandler and opened on Friday, the company has produced 18 films that have grossed more than $1.1 billion in ticket sales, according to Baseline, an entertainment database. ... Columbia Pictures and CBS Films will make a new version of “My Fair Lady,” the classic Lerner and Loewe musical, the companies announced on Friday. It will be produced by Duncan Kenworthy (“Four Weddings and a Funeral”) and Cameron Mackintosh (“Cats,” “Les Misérables”), who said in a statement that they would use the songs from the original Broadway show and shoot part of the film on location in London. Variety reported that the studios were in discussions with Keira Knightley to play Eliza Doolittle, but a Columbia spokesman declined to comment on casting.

headline: Undefeated, Mayweather Retires From Boxing
text: There will, it seems, be no rematch for Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Oscar De La Hoya. Mayweather retired on Friday, saying in a statement, “These past few years have been extremely difficult for me to find the desire and joy to continue in the sport.”

headline: The Card-Carrying Starbucks Fan
text: IN 1981, when American Airlines was struggling to differentiate itself in a newly deregulated industry, it invented the frequent flier mile. Ten years later, American Express responded to its own competitive crisis by introducing what we now know as Membership Rewards.

headline: Modern Pieces, Classically Performed
text: Few pianists approach Philip Glass’s music with the level of devotion and insight that Bruce Brubaker brings to it, precisely the reason he gets so much expressivity out of it. On Wednesday night at the Stone, a small experimental-music space on the Lower East Side, Mr. Brubaker performed two of Mr. Glass’s major piano works as well as compositions by William Duckworth and Alvin Curran.

headline: Photographer Cleared in Australia
text: The Australian police have dropped their investigation into the work of Bill Henson, whose photographs of naked children caused controversy after the authorities shut down an exhibition in Sydney last month, Bloomberg News reported. The New South Wales state police said in a statement on Friday that “there is no reasonable prospect for a successful conviction.” Mr. Henson’s images captured headlines after officers shut down the exhibition, saying they had received complaints. Australia’s prime minister, Kevin Rudd, called the photos “absolutely revolting,” while more than 40 prominent people in the arts, including the actress Cate Blanchett, signed an open letter in support of Mr. Henson. The artist said in a statement that it had been “profoundly humbling to witness the depth of support” for his work in the last few weeks. “It is reassuring to see existing laws, having been rigorously tested, still provide a framework in which debate and expression of ideas can occur,” he added.

headline: Hamilton Home Heads to a Greener Address
text: No matter that Alexander Hamilton’s country home, the Grange, is 206 years old. Until now, it had been in a perfectly contemporary Manhattan real estate bind: not enough space.

headline: International Agency Urges the Start of an ‘Energy Revolution’
text: BRUSSELS  The International Energy Agency, a group that advises industrialized countries, said Friday in a report that investments of at least $45 trillion might be needed over the next half-century to prevent energy shortages and greenhouse gas emissions from slowing economic growth.

headline: Footnotes
text: Miriam Makeba, below, has canceled two American concerts this month because of a fall she sustained last week. The dates included the Detroit Festival of the Arts on Sunday and Celebrate Brooklyn on June 14. Ms. Makeba will be replaced at the Brooklyn show by Sibongile Khumalo, another South African singer. ... Playwrights Horizons has announced two new plays for its 2008-9 season. “The Savannah Disputation” by Evan Smith, to be directed by Walter Bobbie (“Chicago”), will feature Dana Ivey; and “Inked Baby” by Christina Anderson is a world premiere for the play and an Off Broadway debut for the writer. The theater company also announced that Michael Mayer (“Spring Awakening”) will direct the previously announced Theresa Rebeck satire “Our House”; Maura Tierney (“ER”) will star in Nicky Silver’s play “Three Changes”; and Jonathan Groff will join “Prayer for My Enemy.”

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on May 25, about alumni donating to Harvard, misstated a requirement for spending by foundations, and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated which entities are covered by the requirement. Federal law requires private foundations to disburse 5 percent of their endowment a year, not 5 percent of their income. The requirement does not apply to “charitable foundations.”

headline: Wholesale Inventories Grew Faster in April Than Forecasters Expected

headline: Vacations Are Good for You, Medically Speaking

headline: How Not to Bet Belmont (or Any Race in New York)
text: Saturday will undoubtedly be the biggest betting day of the year in New York racing. With a Triple Crown on the line, attendance will likely exceed 100,000, and total betting handle for the day on the Belmont card should top $100 million, with at least 10 percent of that bet right at the racetrack. Those are totals not seen since the last time the Belmont Stakes had a potential Triple Crown winner — Smarty Jones, who lost to the longshot Birdstone in 2004.

headline: It’s Hot Out Here for a Horse
text: Horses don’t like heat. They evolved in cool, even sub-arctic climates and are generally poorly-suited to deal with hot, humid weather. Heat makes horses sweat. Horses dissipate 75 percent of excess heat by sweating. The remainder of the heat is blown off by respiration. High humidity reduces the horse’s ability to dissipate heat by sweating, making it more difficult to keep the body temperature normal.

headline: Next Steps on Climate and Energy
text: When lawmakers get into partisan tangles over legislation and a bill dies a slow procedural death, as happened with a climate bill in the Senate this week, the result is ugly and incremental, and doesn’t compete well with news of spiking oil prices. That makes for shrinking space in the very finite (and ever more finite) confines of a newspaper.

headline: My Family and Other Animals
text: It looks as if every horse in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday is a descendant of Native Dancer. The “Gray Ghost of Sagamore,” who won every race he ever ran in except the 1953 Kentucky Derby — a race he lost by a narrowing head — was bred and owned by my father, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt Jr. If it proves to be true, this will be the first time that any thoroughbred has had his bloodline in every horse that ran in every race of the Triple Crown series. Only the Godolphin Arabian, Darly Arabian and Byerley Turk, the foundation sires of the breed, are said to have done the same.

headline: When Everyone Wants to Be Your Friend
text: A few months ago, I blogged about my mixed feelings toward Facebook, LinkedIn and the like. I get about 15 invitations a day, from people I don’t know, asking to be friends. It’s flattering, of course, but there’s an etiquette problem: Do I accept them all, just to be friendly — but thereby defeat the purpose of building a true social network? Or do I reject or ignore them, hurting their feelings and making me seem like an ingrate?

headline: Big Brown Falters in Bid for Crown
text: Live from Belmont Park, welcome to our coverage of the 140th running of the Belmont Stakes. We couldn’t have planned it any better. There’s a Triple Crown on the line, and it’s become a very real possibility that by the time we close down this post tonight the decades-long drought will be over. As always, send us your comments. Ask us some questions. We are thrilled to be here with you.

headline: Playing the Odds
text: State lotteries, it’s sometimes said, are a tax on people who don’t understand mathematics. But there is no cause for anyone to feel smug. The brain, no matter how well schooled, is just plain bad at dealing with randomness and probability. Confronted with situations that require an intuitive grasp of the odds, even the best mathematicians and scientists can find themselves floundering.

headline: Yes, Dear. Tonight Again.
text: LET’S say you and your spouse haven’t had sex in so long that you can’t remember the last time you did. Not the day. Not the month. Maybe not even the season. Would you look for gratification elsewhere? Would you file for divorce? Or would you turn to your mate and say, “Honey, you know, I’ve been thinking. Why don’t we do it for the next 365 days in a row?”

headline: Catherine Herrick, Robert Levy

headline: Corrections: For the Record

headline: Ouch! ABC Buys the Buzz and Then Is Stung

headline: Rank and File
text: Blessed are the list makers, with their sharp pencils, their certainties, their mix of words and numbers. Walt Whitman made lists. Nabokov made lists. Last year, while declaring in Time magazine that “literary lists are basically an obscenity,” Lev Grossman admitted to having made many in his life, and then introduced a new one, ranking the best novels in the world.

headline: A World of Marvels
text: From the very beginning of his new novel, “The Enchantress of Florence,” Salman Rushdie plunges us into a world of marvels: “In the day’s last light the glowing lake below the palace-city looked like a sea of molten gold. ... Perhaps (the traveler surmised) the fountain of eternal youth lay within the city walls  perhaps even the legendary doorway to Paradise on Earth was somewhere close at hand? But then the sun fell below the horizon, the gold sank beneath the water’s surface, and was lost. Mermaids and serpents would guard it until the return of daylight.” And sure enough, that’s where he began to lose me. I’m probably not Rushdie’s target audience: in literature, at least, I find the marvelous tedious, and the tedious  as rendered by a Beckett or a Raymond Carver or even a Kafka  marvelous. But if I can upset myself over the plight of a traveling salesman who wakes up one morning as a bug, why did this ingenious and ambitious novel  no less than a defense of the human imagination  leave me unmoved?

headline: At Pocono, It’s Life in the Smooth Lane
text: LONG POND, Pa.  Joseph Mattioli, the 83-year-old dentist who is widely known as Doc, went for a slow stroll last August around Pocono Raceway, the two-and-a-half-mile track he built nearly four decades ago.

headline: Variety by the Water
text: Bay Ridge, tucked away on the Narrows in the shadows of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, may not be the easiest Brooklyn neighborhood to reach, and as a result many New Yorkers are unaware of its vibrancy. But Bay Ridge boasts an ever-evolving population that includes nearly every ethnic group. These restaurants, which range from veritable institutions to one newcomer, reflect that diversity.

Chevalier and Dr. James L. Chevalier of Central Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Gorman, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont.

headline: Police Sergeants to Carry Stun Guns
text: The New York Police Department has issued new instructions regarding the use of Taser stun guns, telling sergeants on patrol to carry them in holsters on their gun belts, Paul J. Browne, the department’s chief spokesman, said on Saturday.

headline: Summer’s Best Deals Are Close to Home
text: LAST summer, Lisa Clark, a management consultant from Los Angeles, spent about three weeks in Europe, touring Scotland by car, spending a weekend in Paris and biking in Tuscany. Though it wasn’t cheap (France and Italy cost roughly $4,300 alone) Ms. Clark made it work by using frequent flier miles to get there and by buying packaged tours to keep her expenses contained.

headline: Irregular Warfare
text: Beyond the Unconventional.

headline: Death in Wyoming
text: If one compares a book to a house, the primary difference between the novelist and the nonfiction author is that novelists can build the most glorious mansion with nothing but their minds. With apologies to writers like Tom Clancy and Tom Wolfe, who actively research their books, a novel, for the most part, is just a dream on the page. The nonfiction author, however, must build his house by tramping into the woods of society day after day, rooting through the underbrush for just the right wood; then he must fell the trees, haul them back to his site and assemble his dwelling log by log, nail by nail, all the while keeping in mind that if one plank is out of place, someone will howl.

headline: Asian Fusion, Japanese Emphasis
text: EVEN among new Japanese restaurants, Asian fusion has become the latest fad. The most recent example is Matsuri on the Post Road in Darien, which subtitles itself “Japanese cuisine and sushi bar.”

headline: Jim McKay, Pioneer Sports Broadcaster, Dies at 86
text: Jim McKay, the genial ABC Sports broadcaster whose calm voice and trustworthy demeanor were synonymous with the network’s Olympic broadcasts and the celebrated sports anthology series “Wide World of Sports,” died Saturday at his country estate in Monkton, Md. He was 86.

headline: Afghan Heroin Suspect Was U.S. Asset, He Says
text: In August 2004, in a hotel room overlooking the Persian Gulf, an Afghan mujahedeen commander met with two Americans to talk about the Taliban, the heroin trade and the possibility of helping the United States by revealing what he knew about the complex political situation back home.

headline: Found Gems From a Pianist Gone Too Soon
text: IN August 1953 the astonishing young American pianist William Kapell traveled to Australia for an extended tour. Over 14 weeks he played 37 concerts, both solo recitals and concertos. On his return trip to New York, where his wife of five years and their young son and daughter were awaiting him, the DC-6 Kapell was flying in clipped a forested mountain 35 miles south of San Francisco, plunged into a ridge and fell apart in flames. All 19 people aboard died. Kapell was 31.

headline: Jennifer McCarthy, Charles Doyle
text: Jennifer Perry McCarthy and Charles Robert Doyle were married on Saturday by James Pringle, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, at the Harbor View Hotel in Edgartown, Mass.

headline: The Drench Connection
text: My husband’s mother and stepfather live in Hawaii, and while this arrangement is the envy of many of our friends who dream of tropical vacations, it is, in my opinion, an inconvenient one. When they visit, we seem to fall into rituals, keeping to certain haunts, as if to suggest that not much time has passed since we saw them last. One such place was a Greek restaurant in the West Village that served revani, an ambrosial dessert traditional to Macedonia, Greece’s largest region. The moment my in-laws would bite into this tender semolina cake, the stress of their long flight east would fall away, and calm would settle over the table. When the restaurant sadly closed, I decided to try to recreate it for them at home.

headline: Sarah Gregg, William Orum
text: Sarah Tasha Gregg, a daughter of Senator and Mrs. Judd Alan Gregg of Rye Beach, N.H., was married on Saturday to William Bernard Orum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey John Orum of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Peter A. Lane, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew’s-by-the-Sea in Rye Beach.

headline: Dim Sum Amid Las Vegas’s Casinos
text: MENTION Sin City’s Chinatown to most Americans, and the reply is invariably, “Las Vegas has a Chinatown?”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in some copies last Sunday with an article about the last days of the Democratic presidential race referred incorrectly to demonstrators, using information from Getty Images, who waited outside a meeting of the Democratic Party’s rules committee while the panel debated whether to seat the Michigan and Florida delegations. Some of the protesters shown were part of an organization, Florida Demands Representation; they were not all expressly supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Colonial Williamsburg Offers Summer Package
text: For families who would like to explore the 18th-century history of the United States while on vacation  and not go broke in the process  there is the Summer Saver package at the official Colonial Williamsburg hotel, the Woodlands Hotel and Suites (www.colonialwilliamsburg.com). For families of four (two adults and two children under 18) who stay through Aug. 28, the package costs $600 (plus tax) and includes four nights of accommodations with daily breakfast; unlimited access to the historic area, including all exhibit sites; a new street theater production, “Revolutionary City,” above; and indoor museums like the DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Museum and the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Museum. Participants will also receive free parking, a 50 percent discount on Colonial Evening Program tickets and a $200 resort credit, which can be applied toward meals in 10 restaurants or taverns, golf at the Golden Horseshoe Golf Club or services at the spa. Participants must check in on Sunday or Monday. The number for reservations is (800) 447-8679. The package is based on availability.

headline: Cycling Along at the Conventions
text: Politicos concerned about carbon emissions will have the opportunity to make a statement  and get some exercise  during the Democratic and Republican conventions held in Denver this August and in Minneapolis-St. Paul this September. Freewheelin, a bike-sharing program based in Louisville with about 2,500 registered users, recently started an initiative to provide about 1,000 bicycles for free use at both conventions. The brainchild of Humana, a health benefits company, and Bikes Belong, a cycling advocacy organization, Freewheelin is currently in discussions to expand the program to other cities, and plans to leave behind about 70 bicycles in both Denver and Minneapolis-St. Paul for public use after the conventions.

headline: What Went Wrong | Stuck to Iraq
text: Had Hillary Clinton’s vote to authorize the use of force in Iraq proved uncontroversial, or had she provided a compelling explanation for it, she might now be the Democratic nominee. Instead, she was saddled with a vote mistakenly remembered as an eager embrace of war.

headline: Olympic Hopeful Is Facing Some Tough Choices
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  At last year’s world championships in Australia, nobody was faster than Ben Wildman-Tobriner, who won the 50-meter freestyle. So why is it that he spends his days at the pool feeling as if he is not moving at all?

headline: Book Review: ‘Bush’s Law,’ by Eric Lichtblau
text: Get it out of your head that “Bush’s Law” is another high-minded, high-umbrage, A.C.L.U.-channeled eulogy to the United States Constitution, which died on the table at the hands of Bush administration surgeons. No, it’s Stephen King country, a collection of horror stories every bit as mouth-drying and finger-curling as Kathy Bates’s taking the lumber to James Caan in “Misery.”

headline: Bank of America Is Firm on Countrywide Buyout
text: IN the six months since Bank of America announced its plans to take over Countrywide Financial, many investors have doubted that the $4 billion deal for the hobbled mortgage lender would get done. Bank of America has been strangely silent about its plans for merging the two operations, with the exception of a cryptic regulatory filing last month warning that investors should not count on it assuming all of Countrywide’s debt.

headline: A Not Very Private Feud Over Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON — A bitter personal struggle between two powerful figures in the world of terrorism has broken out, forcing their followers to choose sides. This battle is not being fought in the rugged no man’s land on the Pakistan-Afghan border. It is a contest reverberating inside the Beltway between two of America’s leading theorists on terrorism and how to fight it, two men who hold opposing views on the very nature of the threat.

headline: A Love That Dare Not Compute Its Name
text: THE Sci Fi Channel’s “Battlestar Galactica” is a fantasy about a race of hokily spiritual robots in search of their destiny and the harassed humans who are trying to escape them. Torture, religious extremism, the precariousness of democracy in times of terror: the echoes of political conundrums are hard to miss in this show.

text: Deena Kastor is usually not a good loser. She is graceful, to be sure, but the desire to win sometimes seems to consume her.

text: The scorching heat at Belmont Park on Saturday took its toll on everyone  the jockeys, the horses, the fans, and perhaps more than anyone else, the people waiting in line for the restrooms.

headline: Pay It Back if You Didn’t Earn It
text: READY for some good news from your humble research assistant? During this proxy season, almost 300 companies adopted provisions allowing them to recover executive pay that they find to have been based on incorrect financial statements. Four years ago, such clawback policies were found at only 14 companies.

headline: What Went Wrong | Forced to Be a Pol
text: It is hard to be first. Hillary Clinton, the first viable female candidate for president, had to determine whether to run a traditional campaign that addressed the perceived challenges facing women (a strategy that worked in her successful Senate campaigns), or an alternative one that would have flaunted her gender. Mrs. Clinton took the safe course.

headline: Drawing a Map for the Later Years
text: LAURA MORGAN’S father, in his final years, had lost much of his short-term memory to Alzheimer’s disease. But Ms. Morgan was moved by what remained. On one visit, he didn’t seem to know her until she spoke her name: Then, “he put his arms together like he was holding a baby,” she recalls.

headline: From Provinces of Italy, Classics Get Their Due
text: CASA BRUSCO is a find. This classy new Eastchester restaurant provides warm service and accomplished Italian food, from antipasto to dessert.

headline: Survivors in China Sift Rubble for the Past
text: YINGXIU, China  There are no more rescues. The survivors say miracles are just that: only miracles.

headline: Long May They Wave? No Way, Says Park Avenue

headline: The Life of Rumpole’s Creator
text: Sir John Mortimer, 85 this year, once worried that he was merely “repeating” the life of his father, Clifford, the blind divorce lawyer he (and Laurence Olivier) made famous in “Voyage Round My Father.” The younger Mortimer might still have his eyesight, but he had, after all, followed the elder into the law, and lived out most of his life in Turville Heath Cottage, the Thames Valley house Clifford had built in 1932.

headline: Clinton Ends Campaign With Clear Call to Elect Obama
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton brought her campaign for the White House to an end on Saturday with a rousing farewell to thousands of supporters here and an emotional and unequivocal call for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama, the man who defeated her for the Democratic nomination.

headline: As Skiers Depart Aspen, Chowhounds Take Their Place
text: EACH spring, Aspen’s ski bunnies and powder hounds disappear with the melting snowpack, and the Colorado resort town transforms itself from a winter sports paradise into a thriving cultural destination, with a packed calendar of music, dance and food festivals. Headlining the so-called summer off-season is the 26th annual Aspen Food & Wine Classic (June 13 to 15), a gathering of hundreds of local and international chefs that has solidified Aspen’s reputation as the culinary capital of the Rocky Mountains.
