text: An article on Thursday about a Food and Drug Administration review of a possible link between arthritis drugs and cancer misstated the name of the company that sells the drug Cimzia. It is UCB, not UBC.

headline: Orange County Museum on the Move
text: The Orange County Museum of Art has announced that its new building, planned for the Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif., will be designed by the Pritzker Prize-winning architect Thom Mayne and his Los Angeles firm, Morphosis. “We will start this project with questions,” Mr. Mayne said in a statement about the project, which will be his first art museum. “In the 21st century how can an art museum invigorate and maintain significance within the local and global context?” Morphosis will work with the museum, now in Newport Beach, over the next six months to develop a design and a budget for the building, which will occupy a newly acquired piece of land at the Segerstrom Center, currently home to the Renée and Henry Segerstrom Concert Hall and South Coast Repertory Theater. The museum expects to break ground by 2013 and open the new museum by 2016.

headline: A Mission to Make Suburbs, Well, More Like the City
text: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y.  The “Downtown” that Petula Clark evoked in her 1964 pop song of that name (where “you can forget all your troubles, forget all your cares”) never made much sense to anyone who worked or lived in an actual downtown. It was a song for people who did not.

headline: Old Partisan Gulf Is Back, Broad and Looming Large
text: Strange as it sounds, the first five months of the 2008 campaign lacked the most powerful force in contemporary politics: partisanship fueled by ideology.

headline: New York Justice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Student Loans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mud to Throw? Here’s Our New Chief
text: “If you could change the way wireless companies did things, what would you do?” asked the new chief executive of Sprint Nextel, Dan Hesse, in a commercial this spring.

headline: Museum’s Vision: West Coast Paradise
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When deciphered, the jagged lights on the sloping lobby wall of the new Contemporary Jewish Museum that opened here on Sunday form four Hebrew letters that spell out pardes. That word has the same Persian root as the English word paradise. It alludes to a park, a garden, an orchard, and thus invokes the pastoral promise of Eden as well.

headline: Antiterrorism Money
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: L.P.G.A. Rookie Makes Her First Victory a Major
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  The day started with the golf world wondering if Lorena Ochoa could win her third consecutive major. By dusk on Sunday, the L.P.G.A. Championship belonged to someone who was playing in her third major.

headline: Money Talks at Russian Forum as Business Leaders See Past Hurdles to Investing
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The lineup told it all about Russia’s importance today. There, on one stage, sat the leaders of BP, Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron, Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips, Total, Schlumberger and Dow Chemical, as well as the chairman of the Russian energy giant Gazprom and the president of the Russian oil company Lukoil.

headline: Mechanical Dreams Come True
text: The American composer George Antheil, the Bad Boy of Music, as he titled his 1945 autobiography, is best known for a jackhammer of a piece he wrote in Paris in his mid-20s, “Ballet Mécanique.” It was originally conceived as a 25-minute score to accompany a Dadaist silent film by Fernand Léger and Dudley Murphy. The music was supposed to be performed by 16 synchronized player pianos, but Antheil could never figure out how to get the pianos to play in sync. A concert version for a roster of percussion instruments including an airplane propeller was introduced in Paris in 1926.

headline: Chávez Urges Colombian Rebels to End Their Struggle
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela called on Sunday for Colombia’s largest guerrilla group to end its four-decade struggle to overthrow Colombia’s government, a surprising policy shift just months after he called for the rebels to be recognized as a legitimate insurgent force.

headline: Uncertainty as Tribune Prepares to Retrench
text: Is Sam Zell right about the newspaper business?

headline: Ex-N.B.A. Star Adds Glitz to Sacramento’s Mayoral Race
text: SACRAMENTO  Overshadowed by state politics and a high-profile governor, Sacramento cannot seem to shake its reputation as a cow town, despite being the capital of California.

headline: Lost Letter Raises Questions About Mbeki’s Role in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  The curious case of the mysterious letter from Zimbabwe’s opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, to South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, got a new chapter this weekend that raised yet more questions about Mr. Mbeki’s credibility as the regional mediator in Zimbabwe’s increasingly tumultuous political crisis.

headline: The Good American and Monsieur Obama
text: PARIS

headline: Nadal’s Rout Makes Mockery of a Rivalry
text: PARIS  So what was Roger Federer to do with the elusive French Open trophy once again in sight and Rafael Nadal looming larger than ever across the net?

headline: Airbrushed by the Kremlin, Again
text: Years ago, Soviet news agencies grew to be experts in removing unwanted comrades from official photographs. People disappeared in the developing rooms just as they disappeared in real life, and early group photos with Stalin often contracted into a picture of the Soviet dictator standing alone. That grim history makes what’s happening today on Russia’s national television networks all the more chilling.

headline: Corrections
text: The TV Sports column on Tuesday, about the first live network prime-time broadcast of a mixed martial arts show, misstated the number of known deaths in the sport’s history. It is two, not zero. (One of them occurred in an unsanctioned bout.)

headline: Two Romeos Romance the World to an Adrenalized Reggaetón Beat
text: Reggaetón, the Puerto Rican rhythm-and-rhyme style that spread from regional to international audiences as the 21st century began, has been stalled in the United States by a language barrier. Hip-hop and R&B had their flirtation with it around 2005. But in other Spanish-speaking territories, reggaetón has entrenched itself so strongly that the Puerto Rican duo Wisin & Yandel sold out Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

headline: Former Justice Promotes Web-Based Civics Lessons
text: Sandra Day O’Connor, the former Supreme Court justice, began her remarks at the Games for Change conference in New York by saying aloud what the few hundred people in the audience were already thinking.

headline: Campaign Adds to Complicated Clinton Legacy
text: WASHINGTON  Bill and Hillary Clinton have stirred virulent passions in their nearly two decades in the national spotlight. They have been known as many things, good and bad  brilliant policy analysts, manipulators of facts and friends, tireless campaigners, skillful political tacticians, monumentally self-absorbed baby boomers. But most of all they were known as winners.

headline: Kudos for Zito, and Questions About Big Brown
text: In Barn 12 on Sunday morning, Nick Zito accepted congratulations for spoiling yet another Triple Crown bid. Just as he did in 2004, Zito stopped the coronation of a Triple Crown champion. Four years ago, he did it with the 36-1 shot Birdstone against Smarty Jones. This time, it was a 38-1 long shot named Da’ Tara beating Big Brown.

headline: Testimony on Steroids in Baseball Is Questioned
text: When baseball and union officials appeared before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on March 17, 2005, they presented figures that showed that baseball’s two-year-old testing program had substantially reduced the number of positive tests for performance-enhancing drugs. According to the figures, the number of players who had failed drug tests in 2004 had dropped to about a dozen from about 100 in 2003.

headline: In a Dispute, Teenager Is Fatally Shot in Upper Manhattan
text: A teenager who was walking to a party with friends in Upper Manhattan was shot and killed late Saturday night after a dispute with another group, the police and the victim’s half-brother said.

headline: A Future for Writers in an Age of E-Books?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dizzying Combinations Mix It Up at Durham Festival
text: What is the American Dance Festival?

headline: Giants’ Strahan Ends 15-Year Career
text: Michael Strahan, the longtime leader of the Giants defense and widely recognized for his gap-toothed smile, is retiring from the N.F.L., leaving his lone Super Bowl victory as the final game of a 15-year career.

headline: A Whiff of Naples Arrives in Hamburg
text: HAMBURG, Germany  Naples’ garbage  the plastic Ferrarelle water bottles, the soggy copies of Internazionale magazine, the decomposing kitchen compost  has ended up here, waiting to be dumped into an incinerator on the outskirts of this tidy German city.

headline: The Week’s Major Economic Reports
text: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY Economic news will be led by the Federal Reserve’s beige book report (Wednesday) and the Consumer Price Index for May (Friday). Together they will provide a measure of economic growth versus inflation.

headline: U.S. Is Kept on Move by Argentina, but Earns a Tie in a Tuneup
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Argentine fans began accompanying every one of their team’s passes with a cry of “Ole!” they might have been breaking one of soccer’s conventions. Those kinds of taunts are usually reserved for the closing minutes of a game and here they were goading the home crowd in the 12th minute.

headline: From a Whistle-Blower to a Target
text: On May 14, 2001, Joseph A. Ripp, the newly appointed chief financial officer of America Online, faxed a letter to the Las Vegas offices of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen with disturbing news: it appeared that an AOL business partner, and Arthur Andersen client, had forged a signature on a contract and booked several million dollars of sham revenue.

headline: The Seductive Charms of Term Limits
text: An article in The Times the other day about Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s political ambitions reminded us of how little we like term limits.

headline: Laura Bush Visits Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Laura Bush flew by helicopter deep into central Afghanistan on Sunday on a one-day visit to highlight the United States’ continued commitment to the country and to President Hamid Karzai, ahead of an international donors conference this week in Paris.

headline: Visions for Coney Island Differ: Breathtaking Rides, or Shopping?
text: Friday was a perfect beach day, warm and sunny but not as hot as the weekend to come, so proximity to water still felt like a luxury or a lark, not a health imperative. Maybe because it was a weekday, the stands and rides at Coney Island were mostly empty, but some of the barkers did not let that lull them into a torpor.

headline: Dr. Randolph Chase Jr., 79, Disease Expert, Dies
text: Dr. Randolph M. Chase Jr., one of the first tenured black members of the New York University medical school faculty and an infectious disease expert whose research shed light on organ transplant rejections, died on May 16 in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline: Safe Havens for the Elderly
text: To the Editor:

headline: States Take New Tack on Illegal Immigration
text: MILTON, Fla.  Three months after the local police inspected more than a dozen businesses searching for illegal immigrants using stolen Social Security numbers, this community in the Florida Panhandle has become more law-abiding, emptier and whiter.

headline: Earthquake Kills 2 in Southern Greece
text: ATHENS  An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 6.5 rattled southern Greece on Sunday, killing two people, injuring dozens more and damaging scores of homes, officials said.

headline: ‘Brokeback,’ the Opera
text: The New York City Opera announced on Sunday that it had commissioned the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Charles Wuorinen to create an opera based on the 1997 short story “Brokeback Mountain,” by Annie Proulx, that was the source of the Academy award-winning film of 2005, directed by Ang Lee and starring Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal. The opera is scheduled for a premiere in 2013. City Opera has commissioned Mr. Wuorinen once before, for “Haroun and the Sea of Stories,” which opened in 2004 and was based on the novel by Salman Rushdie.

headline: McCain and Obama Decline Invitation to New York Forum
text: WASHINGTON  The presidential campaigns of Senators Barack Obama and John McCain on Sunday rejected an invitation for a town-hall-style meeting in Manhattan that had been proposed by ABC News and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, and auctions of four-week bills Tuesday and 10-year notes Thursday.

headline: Marijuana Hotbed Retreats on Medicinal Use
text: UKIAH, Calif.  There is probably no marijuana-friendlier place in the country than here in Mendocino County, where plants can grow more than 15 feet high, medical marijuana clubs adopt stretches of highway, and the sticky, sweet aroma of cannabis fills this city’s streets during the autumn harvest.

headline: A Back-and-Forth Battle for a Trip to a Beijing Competition
text: The United States Open Team for the first World Mind Sports Games, being held in Beijing in October, will be Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Chris Compton, Bob Hamman, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell.

headline: More Channels Are Coming. Will Anyone Be Watching?
text: When broadcast television stations first transmitted their signals digitally at the end of the 1990s, consumers received a benefit besides clearer pictures: a multitude of new channels made possible by digital compression technology.

headline: Rural U.S. Takes Worst Hit as Gas Tops $4 Average
text: TCHULA, Miss.  Gasoline prices reached a national average of $4 a gallon for the first time over the weekend, adding more strain to motorists across the country.

headline: Sardines With Your Bagel?
text: Montreal

headline: Annie Get Your Blue Jeans (and Reverse Expectations)
text: Are dances on tiny stages set to music from big Broadway musicals a new subgenre? On Friday night David Parker and the Bang Group’s “ShowDown,” to Irving Berlin’s songs from “Annie Get Your Gun,” began a two-night engagement at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater. That’s the same spot that Doug Elkins’s “Fräulein Maria,” to a score from “The Sound of Music,” had its premiere in 2006 and a rapturously received repeat run just six months ago.

headline: Man Kills 7 on Tokyo Street in Rampage
text: TOKYO  A 25-year-old man who told the police he was tired of life went on a killing rampage in a popular shopping street in central Tokyo on Sunday, plowing his truck into a crowd of pedestrians before stabbing passers-by with a survival knife. Seven people died and 11 were injured.

headline: After Lead Almost Evaporates, Celtics Solidify Hold on Series
text: BOSTON  Paul Pierce did not need a dramatic exit, entrance, wheelchair or miracle cure Sunday night to give his fans another thrill. All he needed was two free throws  the cushion the Boston Celtics required when a rout turned into a nail-biter at TD Banknorth Garden.

headline: A Night Out That Became a Night In. In the Bar.
text: The singer R. Kelly wrote a popular R & B opera about being trapped in a closet. Nicholas White became a minor celebrity after security cameras caught him stuck in a Manhattan elevator for 41 hours. Add to these annals of urban misfortune the tale of Kyle Hausmann, a mild-mannered paralegal who recently found himself locked in a Brooklyn bar.

headline: Wearing CNN’s Quirkiest Headlines
text: As if it’s not hard enough to summarize a story in six or seven words, CNN.com has a new test for editors: is the headline witty enough to be worn on a T-shirt?

headline: Corrections
text: Business Day

headline: Comptroller Criticizes Homeless Program
text: Five years after the Bloomberg administration pledged to change the practice, the city continues to hire providers of temporary housing for homeless families without contracts, the comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said on Sunday.

headline: Stepping (Carefully) in a Champion’s Footsteps
text: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md.  Annika Sorenstam calmly prepared to hit her first tee shot at the L.P.G.A. Championship. She didn’t appear nervous, although I was terrified. I had to sneeze and was standing six feet away.

headline: Stern Ponders Moving  Start Times Earlier
text: BOSTON  Parents of young N.B.A. fans, take heart: the league may reconsider the late tip-off times that push the end of finals games to midnight.

headline: Iraqi Premier Tells Iran Not to Fear U.S. Presence
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, sought to soothe Iranian opposition to a long-term American military presence in Iraq by offering assurances in Tehran on Sunday that American bases would not be used to attack Iran.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about Thomas A. Johnson, a pioneering black journalist, misstated his association with Black Enterprise magazine. He was a member of its founding board of advisers, not a founder of the magazine. The obituary also referred incorrectly in some copies to the racial unrest in the Watts section of Los Angeles that Mr. Johnson covered for The New York Times in March 1966. Those events were a resurgence of violence seven months after the main Watts riots; they were not the riots themselves.

headline: In Student Steps and Leaps, a Survey of National Styles
text: WASHINGTON  This week Washington will be the nation’s ballet capital, as the Kennedy Center hosts nine different companies in its Ballet Across America season. And over the weekend it was an international ballet capital when the Kennedy Center presented four of the world’s leading ballet schools, each dancing one item of its national choreography, on one program repeated three times.

headline: A Pain No One Can Bear to Live With
text: CRANDON, Wis.

headline: A Campaign We Can Believe In?
text: Hillary Clinton’s concession speech Saturday was the story of the weekend. But the dueling speeches by John McCain and Barack Obama on Tuesday night, after the last primaries, are what voters  and campaign operatives  should be revisiting.

headline: A Shift in Real Estate Books
text: When Ralph Roberts, a Detroit real estate broker, learned last week that Ed McMahon was facing foreclosure on his home in Beverly Hills, he called one of the star’s representatives to volunteer his help.

headline: Chamberlain a Little Better, but Highlights Come Later
text: When Joba Chamberlain spotted Yankees Manager Joe Girardi ascending the dugout stairs, Chamberlain retreated to the back of the mound. After unleashing 78 pitches, Chamberlain knew what was coming. So did virtually everyone else at Yankee Stadium. Chamberlain’s day was over  over early and over by design again.

headline: Greased Lightning
text: South Burlington, Vt.

headline: Dino Risi, Italian Filmmaker, Dies at 91
text: Dino Risi, an Italian filmmaker whose searing satires about the newfound prosperity of his countrymen during the Italian “economic miracle” of the 1950s and ’60s helped establish a new style that became internationally known as commedia all’italiana, died on Saturday at his home in Rome. He was 91.

headline: Golden Age for TV? Yes, on Cable
text: Maybe it’s because I’m from Minneapolis, but I’ve always had a soft spot for the Saturday nights on CBS that I spent with Mary Tyler Moore during her show’s heyday in the ’70s. Sure, Saturday night on the Tiffany network also had “All in the Family,” “M*A*S*H” and “The Bob Newhart Show,” but who else could take a nothing day, a Saturday for instance, and suddenly make it all seem worthwhile?

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on May 14 about Shmuel Katz, a close adviser to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel who later opposed Begin’s peace efforts, misstated the year that Begin and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt met at Camp David. It was in September 1978, not 1979. The obituary also misidentified the location for the signing in 1979 of a treaty that returned Sinai to Egypt and called for Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza. It was was signed at the White House, not at Camp David.

headline: 20 Dead as Heavy Fighting Unsettles Somalia’s Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  More than 20 people were killed and 80 wounded Sunday in especially heavy fighting in Mogadishu, Somalia’s war-ravaged capital, where government troops face a deepening insurgency.

headline: McCain Extends His Outreach, but Evangelicals Are Still Wary
text: Lori Viars, an evangelical activist in Warren County, Ohio, essentially put her life on hold in the fall of 2004 to run a phone bank for President Bush. Her efforts helped the president’s ambitious push to turn out evangelicals and win that critical swing state in a close election.

headline: Inside Gate, India’s Good Life; Outside, the Servants’ Slums
text: GURGAON, India  When the scorch of summer hit this north Indian boomtown, and the municipal water supply worked only a few hours each day, inside a high-rise tower called Hamilton Court, Jaya Chand could turn on her kitchen tap around the clock, and water would gush out.

headline: Beat Lives On at a Memorial for Bo Diddley
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  In one of his best-known songs from the 1950s, Bo Diddley proclaimed “I’m a Man.” At his funeral and a celebration that followed, he was also lionized as a musical legend.

headline: They’ll Shake His Hand, but They Aren’t Passing His Bills
text: ALBANY  Why isn’t the Legislature passing Gov. David A. Paterson’s bills?

headline: G.O.P. Candidate for Congress Faces Challenge From His Son
text: Competition and rivalry are common in politics, just as they are within families. But it is highly uncommon for a family rivalry to boil over into politics, and that is just what has occurred in the race for the Congressional seat that is being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Advanced Micro Devices’ new chip for notebook computers described the production schedule for the chip incorrectly. A.M.D. plans to ship the chip by mid-2008, its previously stated target date; the introduction will not be “several months later than expected.”

headline: 50s ‘Celebrities’ Show Off 2008 Laminate Flooring
text: Editors’ Note: As Stuart Elliott is traveling, Jane L. Levere is writing the Campaign Spotlight feature today. The Q & A and Webdenda will return with Stuart next Monday.

headline: British Insurer to Acquire Hilb Rogal for $2.1 Billion
text: The Willis Group, a British insurance brokerage firm, announced that it will acquire Hilb Rogal & Hobbs for about $2.1 billion, in a merger aimed at bolstering its presence in the United States.

headline: Here They Run Again: Term Limits Don’t Seem to Faze Council Members
text: For New Yorkers who voted to impose term limits on the City Council, the promise was to sweep clean a moldering institution and fill it with “citizen legislators” who would bring energy and fresh ideas from the private sector, where they would return after their eight-year allotments.

headline: In the Hands of a Pro, the Moves Meet the Grooves
text: “It’s been about four years since we last met,” Usher said on Friday night, addressing a sold-out audience as a single acquaintance. “I wanted it to be here at the Apollo.”

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 81 Washington State
text: Location: Pullman, Wash.

headline: The Marijuana State
text: Twelve years after California voters legalized medical marijuana, it is being exploited as a cash crop and for recreational use. (June 9, 2008)

headline: Talk to the Newsroom: The Use of Anonymous Sources
text: The New York Times's public editor, Clark Hoyt, commissioned a study by students at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism about the use of anonymous sources in The Times and reported on the results in his column Sunday. Bill Keller, the executive editor of The Times, issued a memo to the newsroom last week in which he discussed the Columbia study and reminded the staff about the key points in The Times's policy regarding anonymous sources. Jill Abramson, the managing editor, answered questions about The Times's policy and practices regarding anonymous sources.

headline: Two Indias, Side by Side
text: Gated communities, pressed up against the slums that serve them, have underscored more than ever the stark gulf between those worlds.

headline: Obama Delivers Speech on Economy
text: The following is the text of Barack Obama's speech in Raleigh, N.C., as prepared for delivery and provided by his campaign.

headline: Old Partisan Gulf Is Back, Broad and Looming Large
text: Strange as it sounds, the first five months of the 2008 campaign lacked the most powerful force in contemporary politics: partisanship fueled by ideology.

headline: Different Visions for Coney Island
text: As the history of Coney Island proves, entertainment tastes change.

headline: This Land: The House
text: The house in Crandon, Wis., where 18-year-old Jordanne Murray and five of her friends were shot and killed last October is scheduled for demolition.

headline: California’s Battle Over Marijuana
text: Some residents of California are wondering if the state’s embrace of marijuana for medicinal purposes has gone too far.

text: To the Staff:

text: If he were Emeril, he’d kick-drum it up a notch. But this is not Emeril:

headline: Taib Bank to Expand Turkish Investment Banking Services
text: The Turkish unit of Bahrain’s Taib Bank has acquired corporate finance advisors PDF Kurumsal Finansman Danismanlik Hizmetleri AS of Istanbul. Taib Bank is controlled by Dubai’s ruling sheikh, Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum.

headline: Iliad Chatting Up Telecom Italia’s Alice
text: Iliad, the parent of French internet service provider Free, on Monday confirmed it is in exclusive talks to buy Telecom Italia‘s Alice France ISP unit. The discussions are based on an enterprise value for Alice France of up to $1.25 billion, Iliad said.

headline: Former Morgan Executives Launch Japan Fund in New York
text: Hedge fund manager Shaka Capital Management has launched the Shaka Japan fund in New York with an estimated capacity of $1 billion, Asian Investor reported.

headline: PVR Pictures Rolls with $28 Million
text: PVR Pictures, the movie-making arm of India’s second-largest theater chain, has raised $28 million from two venture capital funds, Variety reported.

headline: I.P.O. Planned for Magapolitan
text: Indonesia property company PT Megapolitan Developments has said it will launch an initial public offering this year to sell 30 percent of its shares worth about $44 million.

headline: Lotte Takes Cosmo Stake
text: The Lotte Group has agreed to buy more than 50 percent of Cosmo Investment Management, South Korea’s largest investment consulting firm, from Japan’s Sparx Group.

headline: Indonesia’s Adaro Has Biggest I.P.O. Since 1995
text: In Indonesia’s biggest initial share sale in over a decade, PT Adaro Energy has raised 12.25 trillion rupiah ($1.32 billion) to help fund acquisitions and pay debt.

headline: EDF Could Complete BE Takeover Within Weeks
text: Electricite de France could complete a 10 billion pound ($19.8 billion) takeover of British Energy within the next few weeks, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Deutsche Post Said to Be Close to Selling Postbank
text: Deutsche Post is preparing to begin an auction for Postbank, its internal banking operation, within days, The Financial Times reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: ‘Thought They’d Be Flying to Paris’
text: More of your standup humor (send via the comment link below):

headline: K.K.R. to Acquire Singapore’s Unisteel
text: Unisteel, a Singapore disc drive component maker, said on Saturday that it has agreed to be bought by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for S$575 million ($422 million).

headline: The Kids’ Table
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Bidders Said to Line Up for BankThai Stake
text: HSBC, Standard Chartered and CIMB Group are among potential bidders for a 42 percent stake in unprofitable BankThai, which is partially owned by TPG, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Britain’s Informa Tables Bid for United Business Media
text: Informa, the publisher of the Lloyd’s List maritime newspaper, said it is in “preliminary discussions” with United Business Media about a possible all-share merger worth about 3 billion pounds ($5.9 billion).

headline: Calpers Prepping Clean Tech Investment?
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, or Calpers, is expected to invest up to $640 million in Khosla Ventures, PE Hub reported.

headline: Swiss-Run Firm Bids for Troubled Silverjet
text: A Swiss investment company said on Sunday it had made an offer to buy and relaunch Britain’s business class-only airline Silverjet which collapsed last month.

headline: Barclays Said to Look for Cash Infusion
text: Executives at Barclays are in advanced talks with overseas government-backed funds to secure a capital injection of more than 3 billion pounds ($5.9 billion), The Sunday Telegraph reported.

headline: R.B.S. Issues $23.5 Billion in Shares
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday that 95.1 per cent of shareholders had subscribed to its record $23.5 billion rights issue – a level seen by many analysts as in line with their expectations.

headline: Lehman Expects $2.8 Billion Quarterly Loss
text: Lehman Brothers said Monday that it expects to report a $2.8 billion loss for its second quarter, its first ever as a public company, confirming investors’ skepticism that it has continued to suffer from the turbulent markets.

headline: When Googling a Person (or Yourself) Isn’t Enough
text: We’ve all heard the warnings about how difficult it is to erase our electronic tracks. A new Web site, Pipl.com, can give you a vivid sense — in just a few seconds — of what people would find about you if they searched a little deeper than Google allows.

headline: Insurance Brokers in $2.1 Billion Merger
text: The Willis Group, a British insurance brokerage firm, announced that it will acquire Hilb Rogal & Hobbs for about $2.1 billion, in a merger aimed at bolstering its presence in the United States.

headline: Ex-AOL Executive Goes From Whistle-Blower to Target
text: On May 14, 2001, Joseph A. Ripp, the newly appointed chief financial officer of America Online, faxed a letter to the Las Vegas offices of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen with disturbing news: it appeared that an AOL business partner, and Arthur Andersen client, had forged a signature on a contract and booked several million dollars of sham revenue.

headline: Freescale to Announce Spinoff of Unit
text: Freescale Semiconductor, the chip manufacturer taken private in 2006, is expected to announce Monday that it will join with several venture capital firms to spin off a unit that focuses on a newer kind of computer memory.

headline: Unemployment, Gas Prices on Congress’s Minds
text: WASHINGTON – Those rising unemployment numbers may be bad news for the economy but could be good news for Americans whose jobless benefits are running out.

headline: Cuban Wants to Play Ball with Cubs
text: Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, told a Chicago radio show on Friday that it is his “job” to convince people he is the best choice to own the Chicago Cubs baseball franchise, which the Tribune Company has put up for sale.

headline: Pier One Offers to Buy Cost Plus
text: Pier One Imports, the home-furnishings chain, said Monday it offered to buy Cost Plus in a stock swap valued at about $88 million.

headline: Today’s Health Tip
text: Health-conscious potheads who smoke 350 joints a week might want to think about cutting back, according to government research reported by Reuters:

headline: Honeywell to Sell Unit for $1.05 Billion
text: Honeywell International said it would sell a unit that distributes aerospace fasteners and hardware to B/E Aerospace for $1.05 billion, at least $800 million of which would be in cash and the rest in B/E stock. The business, called Consumable Solutions, generated revenues of $524 million last year, Honeywell said in a press release.

headline: A Bitter Good-Bye Prompts a Lawyer’s Suit
text: From Jonathan D. Glater, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Another Top Banker Leaves Bear Stearns
text: The defections following JPMorgan Chase‘s acquisition of Bear Stearns continue.

headline: Geithner’s Plan to Save the Financial System
text: Timothy F. Geithner has lived through the rockiest moments of the credit squeeze that have battered the global financial system, leading to the collapse of Bear Stearns. Now he has some ideas to help prevent a future crisis.

headline: Term Limits Law Hasn’t Had Intended Effect
text: For New Yorkers who voted to impose term limits on the City Council, the promise was to sweep clean a moldering institution. But as the first class of council members elected under the term limits law in 2001 prepares to leave office next year, the very opposite is becoming reality: With lawmakers seeking new elective offices and career politicians looking to join, or rejoin, the body, the Council may well become a political revolving door.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Hedge Fund Wager
text: Warren Buffett, a longtime critic of the fees charged by some money managers, has put his own cash on the line — or, at least, a small chunk of it — in an attempt to prove his point.

headline: The Early Word: Duel Over the Economy
text: With his long-time primary challenger, Hillary Rodham Clinton, no longer at his heels, Barack Obama steps into his role as the presumptive Democratic nominee today with a speech that lays out his plan “to provide opportunity to working families who are struggling and restore fairness and balance to our economy,” according to his campaign.

headline: A New Climate Deal?
text: The global-warming bill died in the Senate last week, and the margin of the vote suggests that it won’t be easy to pass a similar bill next year even if the Democrats do well this fall. But maybe a better deal — and a better policy — will emerge from this failure.

headline: Not Ready for Prime Time
text: The McCain and Obama campaigns have promised to hold a series of town hall-style meetings, but according to CNN they “quickly rejected an offer by New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and ABC News to hold the first such get-together as a 90-minute, prime time broadcast on ABC. But the Obama and McCain camps said the idea of one network putting on the event is a non-starter … McCain spokesman Tucker Bounds said, ‘Both campaigns agree the town hall meetings will be open to press but not sponsored or moderated by the press.’ ”

headline: Eight Questions for Steve Jobs
text: Steve Jobs will ascend the stage at Apple’s Worldwide Developers Conference at 10 a.m. Pacific time this morning. The rumor mill isn’t adding much to what we’ve already heard about the iPhone except that there are some Do-Not-Open-Until-Monday boxes being sent to Apple stores.

headline: Some Trees Grow in London. A New Celebration at Kew
text: At a time when we are being urged to nurture trees to save our planet, the Royal Botanic Gardens in Kew has opened A Year of the Tree Festival. And what a feast it can put on: 14,000 trees within its 300 acres of gardens.

headline: The Cost of Lehman’s Loss
text: Shares in Lehman Brothers plummeted more than 10 percent in early-morning trading Monday, after pre-announcing a $2.8 billion loss for its second quarter and disclosing that it will seek $6 billion in additional capital.

headline:
Monday Morning

text: With the winners of the James Beard Awards last night, as with the nominees, New York seemed to do better than any other city, and that’s as it should be: the depth of our bench here, to borrow a sports term, puts us head and shoulders above any other American city in the arena of restaurants.

headline: Jones and Berkman Flirting With History
text: Many have tried, few have come close, but nobody has done it since 1941. The Braves’ Chipper Jones is the latest slugger to flirt with a .400 batting average.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Chicken With Sorrel
text: Raw sorrel, which is in season locally now, is so sour that it can be used only as an accent. Cooked, however, its strength is nearly perfect, mild enough that it is traditionally teamed with fish. But with chicken, it becomes the dominant flavor.

headline: Easy oil arithmetic
text: If I’ve got it right, America consumes, directly and indirectly, just about 1000 gallons of oil products per capita each year — that’s 1000 gallons for every man, woman, and child. The price of crude is up 60-something dollars over the past year, or about $1.50 per gallon.

headline: Police Need More Weapons Training, Study Says
text: Updated, 12:01 p.m. | Police recruits as well as veterans require more dynamic and frequent firearms training, according to a study of the New York Police Department’s shooting habits released on Monday. The study [pdf], by the Rand Corporation, was commissioned in January 2007, about seven weeks after an unarmed Queens man, Sean Bell, died in a hail of 50 police bullets. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said at the time that questions about the department’s effectiveness and training required an independent look at its tactics.

headline: The General Election Begins

headline: How Much Nature Is Enough? Leatherbacks Linger; Caribbean Monk Seal Gone

headline: In France, a Sturdier Horse Is Born
text: Debate about the soundness of racehorses might be hotter now than ever before, but the hand-wringing over the fragility of the thoroughbred has been around just about as long as the breed itself. Around the 1900s, French breeders started to out-cross thoroughbreds with sturdier stock to build a better steeplechaser. By the end of the century, these cross-breds were routinely beating thoroughbreds over the big fences at Auteuil, and a new breed was born: the AQPS, or “autre que pur sang” — “other than thoroughbred.”

headline: A Common Symptom of Heat Illness: Denial
text: Years ago as a high school student, I attended a summer running camp in Pennsylvania. During a routine six-mile run, I stumbled, and a coach stopped me and asked me if I was okay. “I’m fine,” I assured him, and kept running.

headline: ‘I Miss the Earth So Much’

headline: The Press’s Mistakes…
text: I’m just back from ten days’ vacation, mostly spent pounding away on the book that my wife and I are working on about women in the developing world. So I didn’t weigh in on the dispute about Scott McLellan’s new book and whether the press rolled over in the run-up to the Iraq War. Katie Couric notably sided with the critics, saying it was “one of the most embarrassing chapters in American journalism.”

headline: When Horses Posed a Public Health Hazard
text: Think the amount of dog waste on city streets is getting out of control? Certainly, the State Legislature does, passing a new “pooper scooper” law that will more than double the maximum fine, to $250 from $100, for failing to pick up after your dog.

headline: David Einhorn Rolls the Dice
text: The most loathed person at the craps table is the one who plays the “don’t come” and “don’t pass” bets. These bets carry slightly better odds than others, but playing this wager means that you are betting against the table and hoping the other players crap out. No one likes the person who makes money only if you lose — and then goes and roots for it.

headline: Einhorn on Lehman's Loss
text: CNBC's Squawk Box talked with David Einhorn about Lehman Brothers' expected loss, as the hedge funder claimed some vindication.

headline: The Starting Line: How New Swimsuits Break Records and Boost Stocks
text: Forgive the pun, but Japanese swim fans have to be buoyed by Kosuke Kitajima’s world-record performance on Sunday. Kitajima, who already has two Olympic gold medals on his mantelpiece, finished the 200-meter breaststroke in 2 minutes 7.51 seconds at the Japan Open in Tokyo yesterday, breaking the previous record by a full second.

headline: Lehman Makes Its Case to the Street
text: David Einhorn has been telling the world what’s wrong with Lehman Brothers of late. Monday morning, Erin Callan, the firm’s chief financial officer and front-line defender of its honor, made her case about what’s right.

headline: At Least We Can Protect you from Flooding in Mumbai
text: The United States government did not receive glowing reviews about its preparations for Hurricane Katrina. And so, in what would appear to be the ultimate overcompensation, it is now issuing warnings for when faraway Mumbai will flood.

headline: So Far, So Tired
text: 27 Days to L’Étape.Today’s training: A day off after two long, hilly rides north of the city on Saturday (75 miles) and Sunday (52 miles). Rode early Saturday morning with a small group of experienced riders, roughly along this route, getting a lot of invaluable advice and a chance to practice some basic bike skills, like riding in a paceline. Best tip: while riding up the 7.1% gradient of Alpine Hill in New Jersey, a 47-year-old photographer, who once rode professionally in France, told me as we discussed how long this section of the road was (a mile or a mile and a half, depending on where you start), that once you pass 40, it’s best to describe the distances you ride in kilometers and your weight in kilos.

headline: When an Amendment Takes Effect
text: We are owners in a condominium in New York State where proposed amendments to the bylaws have been passed by the requisite two-thirds vote. Are these bylaws now valid, or do the changes need to be registered with a New York State agency?

headline: The Right to Read the Board’s Minutes
text: Historically, our co-op has let tenants read monthly minutes of the board of directors’ meetings in the office. We were encouraged to come to those meetings, but when anything important was being discussed, the directors held private meetings and turned off the tape.

headline: Why the Boring iPhone Software Stuff Matters

headline: A Simple Parisian Meal
text: I had the good luck to be in Paris last week, but for the most part the work I was doing did not involve restaurants. The last couple of times I’ve been there, I found few restaurants to recommend for people who, like me, would prefer not to spend $200 a person. So I was especially happy this time to have a kitchen.

headline: Do We Need to Give Airlines a Break From Carbon Rules?
text: The European Union plans to impose its carbon regulations on most commercial flights in and out of any European airport starting early in the next decade. Most airlines dislike the idea intensely, and say Europe should wait for the rest of the world to adopt similar systems to prevent unfair competition between airlines flying internationally.

text: Connecticut Gov. M. Jodi Rell cited her concern for business recently when she vetoed a bill that would have raised the state’s minimum wage from $7.65 an hour to $8 next January and $8.25 in 2010.

headline: Without a Grain of Salt
text: Water | As more of the world faces water shortages, seawater’s looking mighty tempting nowadays. But experts aren’t crazy like sailors of yore mad from thirst. They’re overcoming drawbacks of cost, energy use and waste. A recently built plant in Perth, Australia, uses power from a nearby wind farm. — Economist.

headline: Coffee Pollutant No. 1: Cream
text: Cream, along with sugar, is one of the most basic condiments in the coffee universe. And by cream, I mean milk and all its variants: half-and-half, whole, skim, nonfat, soy, rice.

headline: Fountainhead of Wikipedia
text: Internet | So it turns out Ayn Rand is the den mother of Wikipedia. A spirited debate over her objectivist philosophy led to the friendship between Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger, Wikipedia’s founders. Sure, the online encyclopedia jibes with Rand’s view that decentralized markets work best. But what of her belief that truth exists independently of the opinions of people? — Economist.

headline: City’s Genital Herpes Rate Is Above National Average
text: More than one-fourth of adult New Yorkers — 26 percent, compared to the national average of 19 percent — are infected with herpes simplex virus 2, the virus that causes genital herpes, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced on Monday. Officials said they were concerned about the prevalence of the condition because it facilitates the spread of H.I.V. and can also be transmitted to newborns, though such cases are rare.

headline: Race-Horse Hedge Funds Begin to Gallop
text: Big Brown may have failed to complete his Triple Crown sweep on Saturday — indeed, he came in dead last. But hasn’t slowed down what appears to be a burgeoning new sector: the race-horse hedge funds.

For weeks, they have worried how they would explain that only two male triathletes qualified for Beijing, instead of the long-presumed three, and why one of those sitting home is Matt Reed, the man who won the United States trials.

The new model has built-in G.P.S., a normal headphone jack instead of a custom one, and slightly better battery life. And, of course, double the Internet speed (because of the “3G” antenna).

headline: AT&T Targets Business Customers With iPhone
text: To hear AT&T executives tell it, the company expects the iPhone to strike at the heart of the BlackBerry, taking aim at business customers who have been devoted fans of the so-called “CrackBerry” for years.

headline: AT&T: New Low Price Will Move iPhones to Mass Market
text: AT&T restructured its deal with Apple, said Ralph de la Vega, the chief executive of AT&T Mobility, in order to overcome resistance from mass consumers to the high $399 price of the iPhone. Now, instead of paying Apple a portion of their monthly fees, carriers like AT&T will make a large payment to Apple every time an iPhone is sold and attached to their network.

headline: Big Brown Back at the Big A

Those who’ve either left or retired are Kevin White (gone from South Bend to Duke), Mike Tranghese (retiring June 2009) and today Tom Hansen (retiring July 2009).
