headline: Nutrition: Mediterranean Diet May Cut Diabetes Risk
text: Sticking to the Mediterranean diet  rich in olive oil, grains, fruits, nuts, vegetables and fish, and low in meats and dairy  may lower the risk for diabetes.

headline: Mets’ Record Is ‘Not Acceptable’ to Minaya or Randolph
text: GREENWICH, Conn.  Omar Minaya, the general manager of the Mets, described his underachieving team in an exasperating way. He called it a .500 club, meaning the Mets win as many games as they lose. Actually, at 30-32, the Mets are not even a .500 team.

headline: Getting to Spend a Year as a Shadow to a Star
text: When her agent called to ask where to forward a package that he had received for her from Rolex, the Canadian mezzo-soprano Susan Platts assumed it was a mistake. “I didn’t order a watch,” she said she told him.

headline: Physicists in Congress Calculate Their Influence
text: WASHINGTON  According to the Congressional Research Service, there are only about 30 scientists among the 535 senators and representatives in the 110th Congress, and that is counting the psychologist, the psychiatrist, a dozen other M.D.’s, three nurses, an engineer, two veterinarians, a pharmacist and an optometrist.

headline: New DVDs: Deneuve and Loren Still Haunt the Screen
text: These days, all it takes to be labeled a diva is to release a couple of pop albums in a row and exhibit some bad behavior in public. But at least two extraordinary examples of the genuine article continue to walk the earth: Sophia Loren, 73, and Catherine Deneuve, 64. This week Lionsgate Entertainment honors these two near-mythological figures of the European cinema with boxed sets of seldom-seen films.

headline: Justices to See Philip Morris Case a Third Time
text: WASHINGTON  A staring contest between the United States Supreme Court and the Supreme Court of Oregon over a $79.5 million punitive damage award to a smoker’s widow has entered its fifth year, and so far neither side has blinked.

headline: Fewer Planes, but Not Fewer Delays
text: WASHINGTON  With airlines grounding planes because of fuel costs, there will be fewer planes in the sky. Logic suggests passengers could hope for fewer delays.

headline: Plea No. 3 Due in Call-Girl Case Tied to Spitzer
text: A 62-year-old former tax specialist who is accused of starting a prostitution ring to pay his late wife’s medical bills and ended up unwittingly ensnaring former Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to plead guilty this week to money laundering and prostitution charges, his lawyer said yesterday.

headline: Kennedy Is Released From Hospital
text: One week after undergoing surgery to remove a malignant brain tumor, Senator Edward M. Kennedy was quietly released from a North Carolina hospital on Monday and was returning to his home in Hyannis Port, his aides said.

headline: Bush Talks Up Dollar as He Heads to Europe
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush, departing Monday for a weeklong trip to Europe, promised to stress “our nation’s commitment to a strong dollar”  a signal that, amid soaring oil prices and worrisome inflation, the White House is joining with the Federal Reserve in calling for an end to the dollar’s slump.

headline: Applying Iraq’s Lessons in an Afghan Village
text: HAZARJOFT, Afghanistan  United States marines pushed the Taliban out of this village and the surrounding district in southern Helmand Province so quickly in recent weeks that they called the operation a “catastrophic success.”

headline: King Coal Country Debates a Sacrilege, Gas Heat
text: POTTSVILLE, Pa.  Over the last 150 years, Schuylkill County has been famous for a rare hard coal called anthracite that fed the explosive growth of the East Coast during the Industrial Revolution, fostered the rise of the United Mine Workers union and powered many of the factories that supplied troops through both world wars.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Schedule information on Monday with a music review of a concert at the 3LD Art & Technology Center that featured “Ballet Mécanique,” by George Antheil, and that was presented in conjunction with “Frequency Hopping,” a play about Antheil and Hedy Lamarr, misstated the center’s address. It is 80 Greenwich Street in Lower Manhattan (at Rector Street), not 80 Rector Street.

headline: Following as Plots Thicken and Thicken
text: The beautiful crazy lady is the best part of Daniel Roberts’s “Monsterface.” Melanie (Sarah Grace Wilson), a New York actress, is young, delicate and prone to taking her clothes off in front of guests. She talks to an invisible turtle named Seymour. And the more bizarre her comments, the more she smiles like a perky cheerleader who has just been named homecoming queen.

headline: Direct Advice Has Direct Effects on Improving Neonatal Survival
text: Four million babies a year die in their first month of life. Very few die in hospital incubators; most were born in huts to mothers helped only by relatives or a village midwife.

headline: A Lighthearted Tale of Sex for Money
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: France: Chirac Creates Foundation
text: Jacques Chirac, the former president of France, announced the creation of a nonprofit organization, the Chirac Foundation, to promote sustainable development and dialogue among cultures. The foundation will work to improve water supplies and provide better access to health care in poor countries, fight against deforestation and desertification, and save threatened languages and cultures.

headline: East Coast Heat Wave Bakes Wide Area
text: The East Coast continued to bake on Tuesday with temperatures in the upper 90s for the fourth straight day, but weather forecasters say relief is on the way.

headline: Outcomes: Tooth Loss Tied to Pregnancy
text: A new study suggests that the more babies a woman has, the more likely she is to lose teeth.

headline: Bush, in German Visit, Will Discuss Iran With Merkel
text: BERLIN  When Chancellor Angela Merkel plays host to President Bush on Tuesday and Wednesday, it will be well away from the bright lights of this capital.

headline: U.S. Troops Causing Instability, Iran’s Religious Leader Tells Iraqi Premier
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s supreme leader told Iraq’s prime minister on Monday that the American forces in Iraq were the biggest obstacle to Iraqi stability.

headline: With Fall Vote in View, Obama Assails McCain on Economy
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  Senator Barack Obama, with the Democratic stage to himself for the first time, began a two-week assault on Senator John McCain’s economic policies in a series of battleground states on Monday, moving to focus on the ailing economy as the central theme of the general election campaign.

headline: Plan to Cut Back Public Defenders Stirs Worry in Georgia
text: ATLANTA  The chief judge of the Fulton County Superior Court on Monday sharply criticized a state plan to lay off a large group of public defenders, saying it could cause a legal crisis.

headline: Among Scientific Treasures, a Gem
text: One thing you can say about the copy of Nicolaus Copernicus’s book “De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium” (“On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres”), on sale next week at Christie’s auction house, is that it looks and feels old.

headline: The Great Seduction
text: The people who created this country built a moral structure around money. The Puritan legacy inhibited luxury and self-indulgence. Benjamin Franklin spread a practical gospel that emphasized hard work, temperance and frugality. Millions of parents, preachers, newspaper editors and teachers expounded the message. The result was quite remarkable.

headline: Japanese Architect to Make American Debut
text: The University of California, Berkeley, Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive have unveiled the conceptual design for the first American project by the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. He has designed a three-story curvilinear arts complex, above, for the joint institution, in Berkeley, with a fluid steel interior and towering windows. Inside will be a grid of interlocking spaces with curved walls for exhibition galleries as well as two theaters, a cafe, a screening room, a library and a study center. The final design is expected to be ready by the end of 2009, and the museum hopes construction will be completed by 2013. Mr. Ito is known for dynamic experimental spaces in urban settings like the Sendai Mediathèque in Sendai, Japan, and Tod’s Omotesando, a boutique and offices for a luxury footwear maker in Tokyo.

headline: The Laws of the Universe (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where the Growth of Lush Fairways Has No Bounds
text: SEOUL, South Korea  As dusk fell, a restaurant-lined lane in Seoul’s Mapo district filled with customers. While many loosened their ties and bought a round, at Kwon Sung-woon’s place men took off their ties and prepared to play a round  of golf.

headline: Pierce’s Road From Inglewood Could Hit Its Summit Nearby
text: INGLEWOOD, Calif.  At 5:30 in the morning, Paul Pierce would peel himself out of bed, rub the sleep from his eyes, and hop in his beat-up, brown, two-door Datsun 210 hatchback. He would head over to Inglewood High, often stopping to pick up a couple of friends  one of whom would be unlucky enough to have to crouch down in the hatch. When they arrived at school, they were met by Scott Collins, a policeman and assistant basketball coach at the school.

headline: Broadway Vets
text: Next season has already been shaping up with starry projects on Broadway: Katie Holmes and Daniel Radcliffe are already on their way. But how about some real veteran wattage? Jeremy Irons, left, last seen on Broadway in “The Real Thing,” which opened in 1984, and Joan Allen (“The Heidi Chronicles,” which opened in 1989) are planning to return in “Impressionism,” a new play by Michael Jacobs about the relationship between a photojournalist and a New York gallery owner. Mr. Jacobs had a play on Broadway in 1978, “Cheaters,“ but has since written primarily for television. Jack O’Brien is scheduled to direct the play, which is to open in spring 2009.

headline: Super Bowl Ring in Hand, Strahan Says He’s Retiring
text: Michael Strahan, the longtime leader of the Giants’ defense, is retiring from the N.F.L., leaving his lone Super Bowl victory as the final game of a 15-year career.

headline: New Storms Cause Flooding in Three States
text: CHICAGO  A stalled storm system poured heavy rain on parts of the Midwest on Monday, setting off severe flooding in Indiana, Iowa and Wisconsin, where already swollen rivers and lakes overflowed their banks, broke through dams and created havoc for thousands of residents.

headline: In a Bronx Funeral Parlor, a Veteran’s War Memorial
text: The old marine was back on duty Thursday, standing guard over a military shrine in the Morris Park section of the Bronx.

headline: Spanish Truckers Block Border
text: MADRID  Spanish truck drivers began a blockade of their country’s border with France on Monday, lining up their rigs and slowing them to a crawl to protest the cost of diesel fuel.

headline: Another Scandalous Video, Another Apology
text: Amy Winehouse apologized on Monday for yet another offensive appearance in yet another videotape that surfaced over the weekend on the Web site for yet another British tabloid. In the video, posted on the News of the World site (notw.co.uk), Ms. Winehouse, above, is seen in a squalid room littered with drug paraphernalia and, at one point, singing a racist chant with a friend. In the brief chant, set to the tune of a children’s rhyme, Ms. Winehouse makes slurs about blacks and Asians, while her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, promises repeatedly that he is not filming the episode. Another video surfaced in January showing Ms. Winehouse, 24, apparently smoking crack. ... Mr. Fielder-Civil, 26, has pleaded guilty to assaulting a pub proprietor two years ago and then conspiring with the man to withdraw as a witness at the trial, Reuters reported. Mr. Fielder-Civil and three-co-defendants pleaded guilty last week; a court order that barred reporting the pleas was lifted Monday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Monday about a temporary agreement by Hamburg, Germany, to incinerate the trash of Naples, Italy, referred incorrectly to Hamburg’s political leadership. It is a coalition of the conservative Christian Democratic Union and the environmentally conscious German Green Party; it is not governed solely by the Green Party. (The Greens do control Hamburg’s environmental waste policy.)

headline: Gay Unions Shed Light on Gender in Marriage
text: For insights into healthy marriages, social scientists are looking in an unexpected place.

headline: Showing the Patient the Door, Permanently
text: It wasn’t the boy I had a problem with. It was his mother.

headline: Promised Brooklyn Community Center May Not Open
text: In 2000, the New York City Housing Authority decided to tear down the playground at the Marcus Garvey housing project in East New York, Brooklyn. It was not very big or all that attractive. But it was a refuge where children played on two sets of jungle gyms, slides and a water sprinkler, next to a small grassy field.

headline: Yahoo Shareholders Seek Repeal of Severance Plan
text: SAN FRANCISCO  An employee severance plan put in place by Yahoo to protect workers after a merger with Microsoft should be rescinded immediately, according to a brief filed by plaintiffs in a shareholder lawsuit against Yahoo and its directors.

headline: Menthol Cigarettes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disorder Magnifies Blood Clot Risk
text: When David Bloom, 39, went to Iraq in 2003 to cover the war for NBC News, his wife, Melanie, naturally feared for his safety. Would a bullet or a bomb claim him? A land mine? An ambush?

headline: Will Peace Take Flight?
text: LATE last month, Israel announced that it had named the hoopoe as its national bird. The long-billed hoopoe, which has a punky orange crest tipped black, is barely mentioned in the Bible (as an unclean animal that may not be eaten) but it plays a role in rabbinic literature and in Islamic lore as well. It is celebrated, among other things, as the messenger that shuttles between King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba. It is in other words well suited to the symbolic burden the country has placed on it.

headline: Survey of Israelis’ Attitudes Toward Politics Finds Disgust and a Growing Apathy
text: JERUSALEM  A third of Israelis expressed feelings of nausea, revulsion, depression or despair when asked what they felt or thought about the word “politics,” according to a new survey. Another third said they instinctively associated politics with corruption, betrayal or deceit.

headline: How to Cope With Hard Times
text: For small businesses that are trying to ride out an uncertain economy, all solid suggestions about cutting costs, reducing the amount of time it takes to collect a receivable, or finding forgotten tax breaks are much needed.

headline: Doctors Say Hospital Is Falling Victim to Its Own Real Estate Value
text: Doctors at a community hospital in Brooklyn that is part of a large system of hospitals say they are being squeezed out so the system can sell off property in popular neighborhoods.

headline: More Money for Food Safety Is Sought
text: WASHINGTON  Two days after announcing a large-scale recall of raw tomatoes, the Bush administration asked Congress on Monday to give the Food and Drug Administration an additional $275 million in next year’s budget to help improve the safety of the nation’s food supply.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An art review on Friday about “Framing a Century: Master Photographers, 1840-1940,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the surname of the curator who organized the exhibition. He is Malcolm Daniel, not Daniels.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Faulty Scaffold Repair Preceded 47-Floor Fall, Investigator Says
text: A device that holds a cable in place for a scaffold was installed improperly last year, three weeks before the scaffolding gave way and sent two window washers plunging 47 floors on the Upper East Side, a federal investigator said on Monday. One of the two men was killed in the fall.

headline: Adding to a U.S. Legacy Defined by One Pass
text: The place of Eddie Lewis in the history of United States soccer is secure, frozen in a flash of his polished left foot. Lewis delivered a perfect cross to Landon Donovan’s forehead in a second-round game of the 2002 World Cup, and Donovan nodded the ball into Mexico’s net for an insurance goal as the Americans advanced to the quarterfinals.

headline: Times Vice President Is Appointed
text: The New York Times announced the appointment of Michael Valentine on Monday as vice president for human resources.

headline: Film Notes
text: Brian De Palma will direct “The Boston Stranglers,” based on the book by Susan Kelly about the series of murders of young Boston women in the early 1960s and the man who confessed to the killings but later recanted, announced Gale Anne Hurd, the producer. Albert DeSalvo claimed in 1965 to have committed the Strangler killings but later said he was only seeking notoriety, and investigators have long doubted that Mr. DeSalvo committed the crimes. He was never charged for them and was killed in prison while serving a sentence for an unrelated rape conviction. ... Leonardo DiCaprio, above, will produce and star in “Atari,” about Nolan Bushnell, one of the two men who founded the Atari video game company in 1972, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Doctors Miss Cultural Needs, Study Says
text: As researchers ponder growing evidence that blacks have worse outcomes than whites in the treatment of chronic disease, they often theorize that members of minorities suffer disproportionately from poor access to quality care. Now a new study of diabetes patients has found stark racial disparities even among patients treated by the same doctors.

headline: $4.5 Million Water Bill for a New York Agency
text: One of the biggest water bill deadbeats in New York City is the Economic Development Corporation, according to an audit released by the city comptroller’s office on Monday.

headline: Virginia: Death Sentence Commuted
text: The life of a man who killed three people in November 1996 was spared by Gov. Tim Kaine, a day before the scheduled execution, on grounds that the inmate was mentally incompetent to understand his situation. In commuting the death sentence of Percy L. Walton, Governor Kaine said a new sentence of life in prison without the possibility of parole “is now the only constitutionally appropriate court of action” in view of Mr. Walton’s continuing mental defectiveness. The defendant had just turned 18 when he shot three of his neighbors to death in Danville.

headline: After 100 Years, Tribe’s Ancestors Head Home
text: A hushed group of people, nearly four dozen strong, slipped into the American Museum of Natural History early Monday, ahead of the crowds. Their cheeks were smeared with rust-colored dye, red and white woven bands encircled their heads, the men wore ceremonial vests and the women were wrapped in shawls, fringed with red.

headline: Bryant in Need of Celtic-Like Embrace
text: BOSTON

headline: Worries Mount as Farmers Push for Big Harvest
text: GRIFFIN, Ind.  In a year when global harvests need to be excellent to ease the threat of pervasive food shortages, evidence is mounting that they will be average at best. Some farmers are starting to fear disaster.

headline: Obama, Adopting Economic Theme, Criticizes McCain
text: RALEIGH, N.C.  With the Democratic stage to himself for the first time, Senator Barack Obama opened a two-week tour of battleground states on Monday, attacking Senator John McCain’s economic policies and moving to focus on the ailing economy as the central theme of the general election campaign.

headline: New Type of Paper Won’t Let You Just Rip It Apart
text: This newspaper is printed on paper made from cellulose fibers obtained from wood pulp. The fibers are fairly large, on the order of tens of micrometers wide, and the resulting paper is fairly weak  pull on it and it tears easily.

headline: Ranks of Underinsured Are Rising, Study Finds
text: The number of people in this country who have health insurance but not the ability to afford adequate medical care continues to climb.

headline: McCain and Obama Trade Charges on Economy
text: With grim financial reports dominating the news, the presidential candidates are trading charges over economic policy in recent appearances and are offering sharply contrasting remedies for the country’s ailing economy.

headline: Sunday TV: N.B.A. and the Rest
text: ABC easily dominated Sunday night’s ratings with live coverage of the N.B.A. finals, and CBS was the second-most-watched network, leading early in the night with “60 Minutes” and “Million Dollar Password.” According to Nielsen’s overnight estimates, those two CBS shows delivered 9.6 million viewers each at 7 and 8 p.m. No other program on Sunday had a larger audience except for ABC’s basketball broadcast, which attracted well over 10 million viewers. Meanwhile, from 9 to 11 p.m., repeats of CBS’s “Cold Case” (8.1 million) and “The Unit” (4.2 million) trailed just behind NBC’s two-hour edition of “Dateline” (7.9 million). NBC finished third over all with four reruns of “Most Outrageous Moments” from 7 to 9, drawing an average of 5 million viewers. Fox was fourth with repeats of its animated comedy line-up. Among adults 18 to 49, Fox, NBC and CBS finished in a virtual three-way tie for second place behind ABC.

headline: Return to Form Puts Wie Back in Open Field
text: ROCKVILLE, Md.  On the tee box of a par-3 near the end of a marathon day, Michelle Wie consulted with her caddie, Kenny Harms. She had 168 yards to the pin and a 7-iron in her hands.

headline: Memo Pad
text: FARE INCREASE ROLLBACK Four major airlines all retreated on Monday from an across-the-board fare increase that United Airlines initiated over the weekend. Continental Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Airlines and United rescinded the increases, typically $20 on most round-trip tickets, which would have been the 17th fare increase this year. Neither Northwest Airlines nor US Airways had rescinded their increase on Monday, but they were expected to do so by Tuesday. The old-line carriers’ inability to make the latest fare increases stick “could be the first sign that demand is softening,” said Graeme Wallace, of the airfare tracker FareCompare.com

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,087 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: Scorching Heat Blankets East Coast
text: Scorching heat and stifling humidity gripped much of the East Coast on Monday, with the National Weather Service issuing heat advisories as temperatures approached 100 degrees in many areas.

headline: Chávez Goes Over the Line, and Realizes It
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela started this month as the most prominent political supporter of Colombia’s largest rebel group and a fierce defender of his own overhaul of his nation’s intelligence services. But in the space of a few hours over the weekend, he confounded his critics by switching course on both contentious policies.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An obituary on Thursday about William E. Odom, a director of the National Security Agency in the Reagan administration, misstated his position under President Jimmy Carter. He worked for the National Security Council, not the National Security Agency.

headline: A Picture of a Family’s Tragicomic Tree
text: Every family has its oddball or two, and many can even lay claim to a bona fide black sheep. But none of the in-laws who turn up in “The Framer,” a new play by Edward Allan Baker, would be at home in the smiling happy-family photographs the picture framer of the title works on.

headline: CSX Grasping at Straws to End Battle
text: Lou Dobbs, wearing an American flag pin in his left lapel, introduced a segment on his CNN program last week with his trademark outrage. “Tonight, there is a new threat to national sovereignty and security: A foreign hedge fund trying to take control of CSX.”

headline: Gadfly, Contending Price Fixing, Sues OPEC
text: MIAMI  With Democrats in Congress demanding a get-tough-or-else approach to the oil industry, Larry Klayman decided he’d had enough. It was time to call gasoline prices what he thinks they are  economic terrorism.

headline: Judge Tells Ohio to Change Executions
text: Ohio must stop using a common combination of three chemicals to execute condemned inmates because they may produce excruciating pain, a state court judge there ruled Tuesday.

headline: Share Sale by British Bank Draws 95% of Shareholders
text: LONDON  Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday that 95.1 percent of shareholders had subscribed to its record $23.5 billion rights issue  a level many analysts saw as in line with their expectations.

headline: In Air Force Changes, Signs of an Overhaul
text: LANGLEY AIR FORCE BASE, Va.  Earlier this year, the Air Force unveiled an advertising campaign that sought to distinguish the service as being “Above All”  exceptional in its training, technology and war-fighting skills.

headline: Playing a Leading Role in the Ruins of a Tornado
text: On May 23 the people of Greensburg, Kan., found themselves back where they’d been when life as they knew it ended: burrowed underground, wind and hail composing a raucous symphony above, a tornado headed their way.

headline: Bush Orders Contractors to Vet Status of Workers
text: President Bush has ordered federal contractors to participate in the Department of Homeland Security’s electronic system for verifying the immigration status of their workers, greatly expanding the reach of the administration’s crackdown on employers who hire illegal immigrants.

headline: China: Beijing Bans Fireworks
text: The Beijing city government has banned fireworks for three months around the time of the Summer Olympics for safety reasons, according to a post on a government Web site. From July 1 until Oct. 8, fireworks dealers will have to suspend sales and lock existing stocks in special warehouses. The ban is among a host of restrictions that the Chinese government has imposed for the Olympics, which begin on Aug. 8.

headline: Guilty Plea in Slaying of Officer
text: A retired city police officer pleaded guilty on Monday to fatally shooting a retired Port Authority officer in 2006, as part of a plea agreement that will send him to prison for 21 years, according to Staten Island prosecutors.

headline: Lehman Posts Loss and Plans to Raise Capital
text: Richard S. Fuld tried for months to persuade Wall Street that Lehman Brothers, the investment bank he runs, could weather the storm in the financial markets. But by last Wednesday his time had run out: Confidence in Lehman seemed to be slipping away.

headline: Woman a Homicide Victim, the Police Say
text: A preliminary examination by the Dallas County Medical Examiner’s Office has determined that the woman found dead last week with David Jacobs, a convicted steroids dealer who tied several N.F.L. players to performance-enhancing drugs, was a homicide victim, the police said. The woman, Amanda Jo Earhart-Savell, and Jacobs were found dead on Thursday at Jacobs’s home in Plano, Tex. Last week, a preliminary examination by the medical examiner’s office found that Jacobs had shot himself. The police have said that the deaths are consistent with a murder-suicide.

headline: At Airports, Lines Made for Speed
text: The Transportation Security Administration is trying to speed up airport screening by asking passengers to choose a line based on their familiarity with checkpoint procedures. But human nature being what it is, this approach may hit its own snags: people typically opt for the shortest line, and all think they are experts.

headline: Israeli Soldier, Held for 2 Years, Writes to Family
text: JERUSALEM  The family of Gilad Shalit, the Israeli corporal who was seized by Palestinian militants and taken to Gaza in June 2006, received a rare letter from him on Monday, apparently proving that he is still alive.

headline: S. Korean Cabinet Offers to Quit After Beef Protests
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea’s entire cabinet offered to resign on Tuesday as President Lee Myung-bak struggled to find a breakthrough in the biggest political crisis to face his young government, one set off by fears that an agreement to reopen markets to American beef could expose the public to mad cow disease.

headline: Report on City Police Shootings Urges More Use of Tasers Before Guns
text: Police recruits and veteran officers could benefit from more frequent firearms training and a wider use of Taser stun guns, according to a study of the New York Police Department’s shooting habits released on Monday.

headline: In a Sweltering City, Any Sliver of Shade Will Do
text: For working stiffs, the fun in the sun ended on Monday. After two days of toying with the stifling weather in shorts and T-shirts, they found the most mundane chores a challenge during record-high temperatures in the New York region.

headline: Help the Parks
text: It is only June, but given a summer recess and the fall’s campaigning, the rest of the legislative year could well be wasted, and some good bills left to die, unless Congress starts working harder now.

headline: A Balanchine Prodigal Who Inhabits the Journey
text: On Sunday afternoon, many in the New York City Ballet audience leapt to their feet to applaud Damian Woetzel’s performance of the title role in Balanchine’s ballet “The Prodigal Son.” Quite right, too. Mr. Woetzel is due to retire from dancing next week, and it seems that each performance he gives is greeted by a heightened intensity in the auditorium.

headline: Return to Old Spy Rules Is Seen as Deadline Nears
text: WASHINGTON  With Congress at an impasse over the government’s spy powers, Congressional and intelligence officials are bracing for the possibility that the government might have to revert to the old rules of terrorist surveillance, a situation that some officials predict could leave worrisome gaps in intelligence.

headline: Net Providers to Block Sites With Child Sex
text: ALBANY  Verizon, Sprint and Time Warner Cable have agreed to purge their servers of Internet bulletin boards and Web sites nationwide that disseminate child pornography.

headline: Broken Finger Won’t Keep Scott Out
text: SAN DIEGO  Adam Scott, the No. 3 player in the world, who is grouped with No. 1 Tiger Woods and No. 2 Phil Mickelson in the first and second rounds of the United States Open, told U.S.G.A. officials he would be ready to go Thursday despite a broken pinkie.

headline: Field Trips to Dark Reaches of the Soul
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The Pink Pony is a strip club here, across the street from the Banned Bookstore, the House of Leather and the Fantasy Shoppe. On the evening before 9/11 the club was visited by three men who may have been part of the terrorist plot. They stayed for hours, dropping several hundred dollars on drinks and lap dances and left behind a Koran.

headline: British Bank Issues $23.5 Billion in Shares
text: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland said Monday that 95.1 per cent of shareholders had subscribed to its record $23.5 billion rights issue  a level seen by many analysts as in line with their expectations.

headline: Man Who Killed 7 in Tokyo Left Online Warnings
text: TOKYO  The final, chilling posting read, “It’s time.”

headline: The Claim: Ice Is Good for a Skin Burn
text: THE FACTS

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: International

headline: Sabbatini Says He's Not Afraid to Face the Best
text: SAN DIEGO  The last time the high-octane talent that is Rory Sabbatini popped up on the radar screen this season was here at Torrey Pines Golf Course, where he finished third in the Buick Invitational, 10 strokes behind the winner, Tiger Woods.

headline: Spread of Tuberculosis Seen Slowing Progress on AIDS
text: Inadequate attention to the spread of tuberculosis is undermining recent gains made against the virus that causes AIDS, United Nations officials said Monday.

headline: Regimens: Wine May Help Keep Liver Healthy
text: Recent reports suggest that red wine is a potent force in increasing lifespan, and a new study offers still more good news for wine drinkers. A glass a day, whether white or red, may reduce the risk of developing the nation’s most common liver disorder, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

headline: Smartphones Now Ringing for Women
text: If recent history is any guide, roughly a third of the people snapping up Apple’s new iPhone are likely to tote it in a purse.

headline: Pacific-10 Commissioner to Announce His Retirement
text: Pacific-10 Commissioner Tom Hansen announced Monday that he would retire in July 2009, the second major change in college athletics leadership in less than a week.

headline: Nickel and Diming, but Still Traveling
text: SUCCESSIVE fare increases, a sharp reduction in flights and seats, crammed planes, chronic delays and missed connections  all of these would seem to argue that business travel is falling.

headline: Tallying the Toll on an Elder of the Sea
text: MILFORD, Conn.  Horseshoe crabs may look ancient and alien and battery-operated, they may look like Wilma Flintstone’s idea of a Roomba vacuum cleaner, yet to the sixth-grade students from Columbus School in nearby Bridgeport, the most outrageous thing about the bronze-helmeted creatures crawling clumsily along the beach was not their appearance but their size  or rather sizes.

headline: Change of Control at the Los Angeles Times Magazine
text: The Los Angeles Times has made plans to transfer control of its monthly magazine from its newsroom to its business operations and to replace the magazine’s entire editorial staff, according to two executives at the newspaper.

headline: Anticipating the Future to ‘See’ the Present
text: Staring at a pattern meant to evoke an optical illusion is usually an act of idle curiosity, akin to palm reading or astrology. The dot disappears, or it doesn’t. The silhouette of the dancer spins clockwise or counterclockwise. The three-dimensional face materializes or not, and the explanation always seems to have something to do with the eye or creativity or even personality.

headline: For Clinton, Millions in Debt and Few Options
text: With her campaign now officially suspended, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is confronting still another challenge: whittling down what is believed to be the largest presidential campaign debt in history.

headline: President of Indonesia Restricts Muslim Sect
text: MANIS LOR, Indonesia  President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono signed a decree on Monday ordering members of a minority Muslim sect to stop practicing their form of Islam or face arrest.

headline: Midwest Braces for More Flooding
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Sodden communities in the upper Midwest braced for more flooding on Wednesday as rising rivers threatened to overcome levees protecting many downtown areas.

headline: Kaiser Backs Microsoft Patient-Data Plan
text: Kaiser Permanente, the nation’s largest nonprofit health maintenance organization, is endorsing the drive toward consumer-controlled personal health records in a partnership with Microsoft.

headline: Threatening Iran
text: Israeli leaders spent last week talking tough about Iran and threatening possible military action. The United States and the other major powers need to address Tehran’s nuclear ambitions, but with more assertive diplomacy  including greater financial pressures  not more threats or war planning.

headline: Gates Selects New Air Force Leaders
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced his new Air Force leadership team on Monday, tapping Michael B. Donley, a Pentagon administrator, to be the service’s next secretary and Gen. Norton A. Schwartz, who has been in charge of transportation for the Pentagon, to be chief of staff.

headline: A Fierce Predator Makes a Home in the Suburbs
text: WEST GREENWICH, R.I.  Last summer, Kerry Beaudry heard yelping from her German shepherd, Holly, and went outside to investigate. What she found still gives her chills. A small, mangy creature was on top of Holly, digging its claws into the scruff of her neck and gnawing at her face.

headline: The Summer Wind
text: Q. This came up when someone tried to talk me out of even looking at an apartment with a terrace in a high-rise building: Does it get windier the higher up you go? Or does it depend on the wind conditions in general and the arrangement of surrounding buildings?

headline: Victim Testifies About Small Talk With Rapist and How She Escaped
text: As a man raped her, threw boiling water and bleach in her face and tossed her around like a rag doll, a woman testified on Monday, there were many moments when all she could do was scream or beg for mercy.

headline: Spain, Like U.S., Grapples With Immigration
text: MADRID  With the United States riven by calls to legalize millions of illegal immigrants, Americans might consider the possible effects by looking at southern Europe, where illegal immigration has abounded and so have forgiveness plans.

headline: More Girls, Little Ones, Try to Take Back the Multiplex
text: LOS ANGELES  “Kit Kittredge: An American Girl” has no sex and not much of a city.

headline: The Unexamined Life? He Never Heard of It
text: “It sometimes helps to remind myself that not everyone is like me,” David Sedaris writes in his spotty new collection, “When You Are Engulfed in Flames.” “Not everyone writes things down in a notebook and then transcribes them into a diary. Fewer still will take that diary, clean it up a bit, and read it in front of an audience.”

headline: Japan: Rampage Plans Online
text: In the hours before a 25-year-old man went on a rampage in central Tokyo on Sunday that left seven people dead, he posted a series of messages on an online bulletin board from his cellphone, the authorities said on Monday. The attacker, Tomohiro Kato, above, described his intention of using a vehicle and knife to kill people in the district of Akihabara. The first message to the thread was titled “I will kill people in Akihabara.” In later posts, Mr. Kato described leaving his home just west of Tokyo and worrying that rain might hamper his plans. The final post was at 12:10 p.m., and 20 minutes later he plowed a rental truck into a crowd of pedestrians before stabbing passers-by.

headline: Activity in Saturn Ring May Provide Clues to Birth of Solar System
text: Among the rings of Saturn, the ones designated A, B, C, D, E and G are the good children, neat and tidy with nary an ice or dust particle out of place. F, on the other hand, the narrowest ring at less than 100 miles wide, is the family freak. It appears to have a core of material that is surrounded by spiraling braided streams.

headline: Libertarians Choose Candidate for Fossella Seat
text: The Libertarian Party selected Susan Overeem on Monday night as the nominee for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island. She had nearly three times as many votes as the other Libertarian candidate, Francis M. Powers, the son of the Republican Party candidate, Francis H. Powers.

headline: Saudi Arabia Calls for Summit on Energy Costs
text: Saudi Arabia, the world’s biggest oil exporter, said on Monday that it wanted to convene an energy summit of producers and consumers to focus on “how to objectively deal” with high prices.

headline: Two Opinions of Desormeaux’s Ride of Big Brown
text: After spending the past three weeks at Belmont Park, Big Brown returned Monday to the Aqueduct barn of his trainer, Rick Dutrow, according to Michael Iavarone, co-president of International Equine Acquisitions Holdings, which is part owner of the colt.

headline: Link Between Signaling and Physiology in Birds May Be Two-Way Street
text: Sexual signaling in animals is generally considered a one-way street. That is, a physical characteristic that conveys information about an animal’s desirability takes a physiological toll, and thus keeps things “honest”  if the animal isn’t up to it physiologically, it can’t produce the signal.

headline: Two Actors’ Unions Fight as One Tries for a Deal
text: LOS ANGELES  Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild publicly declared war on a fellow actors’ union at a Monday rally here, increasing the likelihood of new labor strife in an entertainment industry still recovering from a writers’ strike that ended just four months ago.

headline: Owens Will Be Tested for Drugs More Often
text: Dallas Cowboys wide receiver Terrell Owens and the Cowboys’ owner, Jerry Jones, issued statements Monday after ESPN reported that Owens was placed in the N.F.L.’s “reasonable cause” testing program for performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: The Family That Drinks Together Bickers Together
text: “The Cocktail Hour,” A. R. Gurney’s mild examination of an overprivileged family that fights domestic battles while downing drinks, must have seemed fairly thin when it had its premiere in 1988. Now, with so many real-life families struggling to fill the gas tank and pay the grocery bill, Mr. Gurney’s story of a self-absorbed clan whose biggest problem is whether the maid can cook a roast is in danger of registering as just plain annoying.

headline: At the Intersection of Styles, Taking Some Songs for a Ride
text: In a video clip available on YouTube, a young woman named Briana Cartwright appears on the stage of “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” dressed as the host. Ms. DeGeneres had recently been in a car accident and could not perform her signature dance, so she asked her employees to come out and entertain her viewers. For a minute and a half Ms. Cartwright, who was a producer on the show at the time, did just that, all liquid shoulders, slinky hips and high-fives to audience members, then merrily skipped off.

headline: McCain and Wiretaps: The View From the A.C.L.U.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Soda and Stomachaches (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Loyal to Its Roots
text: From its diminutive lavender flowers to its straggly windblown stalks, there is nothing about the beach weed known as the Great Lakes sea rocket to suggest that it might be any sort of a botanical wonder.

headline: Justices Reject ‘Class of One’ Argument
text: WASHINGTON  Government employees who are singled out for arbitrary, irrational or even vindictive treatment by their supervisors will find no relief in the Constitution’s guarantee of equal protection, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday, unless the mistreatment is due to discrimination on the basis of race, sex or another protected category.

headline: Derivatives Trading Is Scrutinized
text: The Federal Reserve moved Monday to overhaul the financial apparatus behind derivatives trading, a regulatory step intended to assure that the failure of a major bank or investment firm would not create the systemic threat seen in March after the collapse of Bear Stearns.

headline: France: News Anchor Off the Air
text: France’s best-known newscaster, whose name became a brand, is being pushed out after decades on the air because of declining ratings, the French news media reported. The newsman, Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, 60, known as PPDA, has been the anchor of the main news program at 8 p.m. on TF1, the country’s largest private broadcaster, since 1987, after years of similar work on the public broadcast station France 2. He will be replaced by Laurence Ferrari, 41, who is both glamorous and popular.

headline: F.H.A. Faces $4.6 Billion in Losses
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Housing Administration expects to lose $4.6 billion because of unexpectedly high default rates on home loans, officials said Monday.

headline: Mets’ Debt Comes Due in 100 Games
text: SAN DIEGO  One of Willie Randolph’s preferred phrases is “serious payback.” He has used the term a lot over the past year as the Mets have encountered increasing adversity and Randolph, perhaps wishfully, has promised that his team will get revenge.

headline: A Writer Decides to Leave His Legacy and Enjoy It Too
text: The three funniest words in “Three on a Couch” are JetBlue and Paula Abdul. And they are punch lines to two of the play’s rare straightforward pieces of humor.

headline: Open Search Urged for U.N. Rights Job
text: UNITED NATIONS  The online advertisement that appeared Monday on The Economist magazine’s Web site seemed straightforward enough, seeking candidates for the position of United Nations high commissioner for human rights.

headline: Out of Sight
text: When the dismal unemployment numbers were released on Friday (at the same time that oil prices were surging to record highs), I thought about the young people at the bottom of the employment ladder.

headline: Stolen Artifacts Returned to Iraq
text: A cache of ancient artifacts stolen from the National Museum of Iraq during the American-led invasion in 2003 were returned to Iraq’s Antiquities Ministry on Monday in a ceremony in Baghdad, Reuters reported. The items, 11 cylinder seals made from agate and alabaster between 3,000 and 2,000 B.C., were found in Philadelphia last month by American customs officials and turned over to the Iraqi embassy in Washington, a spokesman for the ministry said. Thousands of pieces were looted after the 2003 invasion, and Iraqi officials have blamed the pilfering on smugglers and occupying troops. The National Museum said that 15,000 items were stolen and that up to 6,000 have been returned. In April, Syria returned more than 700 stolen artifacts seized by its customs officers. “This is only the start,” Hoshyar Zebari, Iraq’s foreign minister, said of the cylinders’ return. “We hope to return more of these pieces in the near future.” The National Museum remains closed to the public because of its poor condition and a lack of security.

headline: Report Takes Aim at ‘Model Minority’ Stereotype of Asian-American Students
text: The image of Asian-Americans as a homogeneous group of high achievers taking over the campuses of the nation’s most selective colleges came under assault in a report issued Monday.

headline: Apple Aims for the Masses With a Cheaper iPhone
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple, introduced a new cheaper iPhone model on Monday that navigates the Internet more quickly, expanded its distribution overseas and displayed a range of new applications and services in order to establish Apple as a major player in the cellphone industry.

headline: Brainpower May Lie in Complexity of Synapses
text: Evolution’s recipe for making a brain more complex has long seemed simple enough. Just increase the number of nerve cells, or neurons, and the interconnections between them. A human brain, for instance, is three times the volume of a chimpanzee’s.

headline: Illinois: Yippie Leader Faces Charges
text: Dana Beal, a longtime Yippie leader, is facing money laundering charges and is being held in the Coles County Jail on bail of $250,000, a sheriff’s department spokeswoman said. Further information about the charges was not yet public. Mr. Beal became a member of the Youth International Party, known as the Yippies, shortly after the group was founded in the 1960’s by Abbie Hoffman and others. Since 1973 Mr. Beal and other Yippies have lived in a building on Bleecker Street in New York City that the group used as a headquarters.

headline: Footnotes
text: Kanye West’s elaborate “Glow in the Dark” tour, which follows the story of Mr. West as an outer-space explorer whose ship crashes on an unknown planet, is returning to Madison Square Garden on Aug. 5. Lupe Fiasco and N.E.R.D. will open the show, and tickets go on sale through livenation.com on Friday at 10 a.m. ... The Sphinx Organization, a nonprofit group that works to increase minority participation in classical music, has commissioned a piece from the Puerto Rican-born composer Roberto Sierra. Sphinx says works by black and Latino composers account for less than one percent of music played by American orchestras.

headline: The U.N. in Congo
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Thursday about the election of the Rev. Miguel d’Escoto Brockmann of Nicaragua as president of the United Nations General Assembly misstated the year he was appointed Nicaragua’s foreign minister under the Sandinista government. It was 1979, not 1989.

headline: A Venerable Sports Paper Plays Catch-Up
text: WHEN Sporting News first hit the presses in 1886, there was no World Series, no National Football League, and no Cracker Jack, much less the Internet, mobile score updates or jeering sports bloggers. In its heyday  the 1950s and ’60s  it was the authoritative paper for serious sports fans, publishing comprehensive box scores and earning the nickname the bible of baseball.

headline: Facing Life Without Children When It Isn’t by Choice
text: When Pamela Mahoney and Alex Tsigdinos were married, they never thought they would have trouble having a baby. But after 11 years and many fertility treatments, they are still only a family of two.

headline: ‘August’ Cast Changes; ‘November’ to Close
text: As “August: Osage County” barrels onto the Tony Awards, its producers have been announcing a series of coming cast replacements. Deanne Dunagan and Rondi Reed are both up for Tonys, but win or lose, you won’t be able to see them in “August” after the awards. Estelle Parsons will be stepping into the role currently being performed by Ms. Dunagan, and Molly Regan (“The Crucible” on Broadway) will be replacing Ms. Reed. Recently Jim True-Frost (“The Wire”), Robert Foxworth (recently on Broadway in “Twelve Angry Men”) and Frank Wood (“Side Man”) were announced as replacements for three of the male roles. All the replacements will begin on June 17. ... “November,” David Mamet’s satire of Oval Office machinations, with Nathan Lane, above, playing the president, will close July 13. It will have played 33 previews and 205 regular performances.

headline: Suicide Rate High in Violent Death Data
text: More than half of all violent deaths are suicides, a quarter are homicides and the typical victim is an African-American man in his 20s.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A “Notes” entry in some editions on Monday with an article about the scoreless soccer draw between the United States and Argentina referred incorrectly to an accomplishment by Landon Donovan, who played in his 100th international match. He became the 11th American man to reach that milestone, not the 11th American. (The feat has also been accomplished by 19 American women, according to U.S. Soccer.)

headline: Travelers, Yes. Skateboards, No.
text: I’M obsessive about frequent-flier status. During the summer, I travel extensively for our Boom Boom HuckJam Tour and that helps me rack up some miles. I like the shorter lines and priority seating that 1K frequent-flier status offers. Yes, I am one of those who gets to board the plane by walking on the pretentious red carpet.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 9, 2008

headline: Stocks Are Steadier, but Analysts Are Cautious
text: The Dow Jones industrial average on Monday recovered from some of Friday’s big losses after oil prices retreated, but the broader stock market remained mixed as financial stocks continued to tumble.

headline: Warren A. Croll Jr., Trainer, Is Dead at 88
text: Warren A. Croll Jr., a Hall of Fame trainer who won the 1987 Belmont Stakes with Bet Twice and trained four thoroughbred champions, died Friday in Long Branch, N.J. He was 88.

headline: Mr. Lesniak Changes His Mind
text: Raymond Lesniak tells anyone who asks that he made a big mistake. The admission would not be noteworthy except that Mr. Lesniak is a state senator in New Jersey, and it is unusual for an elected official not only to admit an error but to convert it into something positive.

headline: In Iowa, Saving Tradition Amid the Debris
text: PARKERSBURG, Iowa  Ed Thomas stood in the ruins of Room 214 at the high school, where the clock face on the wall was stuck in time: 4:56.

headline: Hidden Drug Payments at Harvard
text: Three prominent psychiatrists at the Harvard Medical School and its affiliated Massachusetts General Hospital have been caught vastly underreporting their income from drug companies whose fortunes could be affected by their studies and their promotional efforts on behalf of aggressive drug treatments. Their failure to divulge their conflicts is striking proof that today’s requirements for reporting payments from industry  essentially an honor system in which researchers are supposed to reveal their outside income to their institutions  needs to be strengthened.

headline: Hair Analysis Deflates Napoleon Poisoning Theories
text: Was Napoleon poisoned?

headline: Rapper’s Road to Pop
text: “Mr. Carter,” a song on Lil Wayne’s long-awaited album “Tha Carter III” (Cash Money/Universal), brings together Lil Wayne, born Dwayne Michael Carter Jr., and Jay-Z, born Shawn Carter. Since they share a last name  and no rapper would let the sonic coincidence go unexploited  some kind of identity-defining encounter was probably inevitable.

headline: The End of the Clinton Campaign
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A museum review on Monday about the new Contemporary Jewish Museum in San Francisco referred imprecisely to the landmark power plant on the site that was incorporated into the museum’s design. While the plant was indeed first built there in the 19th century, the landmark status derives from a rebuilding of it in the early 20th century, not the 19th.

headline: Royals Cool Off Rivera at End of a Scorching Day
text: The temperature was 94 degrees and rising at game time. Soon, the heat was on everyone’s mind and its effects were on most people’s shirts.

headline: A Spot for Kennedy Remains a Question Mark
text: Nearly two weeks after Ian Kennedy was put on the disabled list, the Yankees’ rotation may no longer have a spot for him. Darrell Rasner has been the team’s most consistent young pitcher, and Joba Chamberlain, while far from stellar in his tentative first steps as a starter, has not pitched badly.

headline: Hit and Run Kills Girl, 6, in Bronx
text: A 6-year-old girl was killed after she was struck by a hit-and-run driver and possibly by a second vehicle on Monday evening in the Bronx, the police said.

headline: The Departed
text: How much nature is enough? We may be finding out, species by species, as we whittle away in that slow-drip style. This is just a quick note of farewell to the Caribbean monk seal, not seen since 1952 and given its formal designation as extinct by federal fisheries officials last Friday.

headline: Study finds 204 towers under development in Panama City
McCain at the National Small Business Summit
text: Following are the remarks by John McCain at the National Small Business Summit in Washington, as prepared for delivery and provided by his campaign.

headline: Martha Plimpton
text: The actress, who is nominated for a Tony Award for her performance in “Top Girls,” answered readers’ questions in an e-mail.

headline: Washed Away in the Midwest
text: Thousands of residents evacuated in Wisconsin, some rivers were exceeding records in Iowa and military crews joined sandbagging operations to hold back Indiana streams.

text: Additional photos from the Tory Burch store in SoHo.

text: A look at an American family’s historic “black and white” house in Singapore.

text: Properties on the market in North Carolina, Louisiana and Oregon.

text: The actor, who is nominated for a Tony Award for his performance in “Mauritius,” answered readers’ questions in an email.

headline: RockYou Posts $35 Million from V.C.’s
text: RockYou, the social-media application powerhouse behind SuperWall, Vampires and Likeness, announced Monday that it has raised $35 million in Series C venture capital.

headline: Sun’s Gage to Join Gore at Kleiner Perkins
text: After annexing Al Gore, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, one of Silicon Valley’s largest and most prominent venture capital firms, has scored another high-profile hire, announcing Monday that it has made former Sun Microsystems executive John Gage a partner

headline: NYSE Euronext to Announce Tech Partnership, Report Says
text: NYSE Euronext, the transatlantic exchange group, will on Tuesday step up its efforts to become a one-stop shop for U.S. equity trading in the face of mounting competition by announcing a partnership with Progress Software, a company specializing in advanced trading technology, The Financial Times reported.

headline: London Is King of Financial Centers, According to Survey
text: London is the most influential financial center in the world for the second year running, according to MasterCard’s second annual survey.

headline: CIT Scores Debt Financing from Goldman
text: The CIT Group, a commercial finance company struggling to secure financing for billions of dollars of debt maturing this year, said on Monday that it had secured $3 billion of financing from Goldman Sachs.

headline: TSX Picks American as New Chief
text: Canada’s dominant market operator, TSX Group, has picked an American as its new chief executive, announcing on Monday that former Fimat USA executive Thomas Kloet will start running the company on July 14.

headline: Colorado Baggage and Gart Capital Pick Up Bag’n Baggage
text: Bag’n Baggage, a Dallas-based luggage retailer operating in bankruptcy, has been acquired for $10.5 million by a Denver-based competitor, Colorado Baggage Company, and private equity firm Gart Capital Partners.

headline: Citigroup to Issue $940 Million in Samurai Bonds, Report Says
text: Citigroup will reportedly issue as much as 100 billion yen ($940.6 million) in samurai bonds on July 1, its first such offering aimed at Japanese retail investors since 2000.

headline: WiMax Backers Seek to Encourage Use by Pooling Patents
text: Cisco Systems, Intel and four other backers of the wireless Internet standard WiMax said they want to help spread use of the technology by limiting possible patent royalties.

headline: Lawyer for Former Merrill Executive Seeks Inquiry into Enron Trial
text: A lawyer for one of three former Merrill Lynch executives convicted of participating with Enron in a sham barge sale has asked for congressional, Justice Department and bar association investigations into alleged prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: Fed to Scrutinize Derivatives Trading
text: The Federal Reserve moved Monday to overhaul the financial apparatus behind derivatives trading, a regulatory step intended to assure that the failure of a major bank or investment firm would not create the systemic threat seen in March after the collapse of Bear Stearns.

headline: China’s $31.1 Billion Spending Spree
text: China Inc. is on a shopping spree, BusinessWeek reported.

headline: Discover Is Seeking $6 Billion From Rivals
text: Discover Financial Services wants roughly $6 billion in damages from its larger rivals Visa and MasterCard in a long-running antitrust lawsuit, court documents made public on Monday show.

headline: Safaricom Pops 60% in Debut
text: The biggest initial public offering in East Africa took place on Monday with shares in Kenya’s Safaricom surging as much as 60 percent to value the mobile phone company at more than $4.5 billion.

headline: Britain’s F.S.A. Said to Pressure Banks to Support Lender’s Rights Issue
text: Britain’s Financial Services Authority last week took the unprecedented step of pressuring the country’s five biggest banks into supporting the rescue capital-raising at Bradford & Bingley, the troubled British lender, according to The Times of London.

headline: 2 Bear Bankers to Hang Their Own Shingle
text: Two top Bear Stearns investment bankers are opening an advisory boutique and plan to split with JPMorgan Chase the fee they expect to earn on a $5.2 billion buyout deal, according to TheStreet.com.

headline: Yahoo Shareholders Seek Repeal of Severance Plan
text: An employee severance plan put in place by Yahoo to protect workers after a merger with Microsoft should be rescinded immediately, according to a brief filed by plaintiffs in a shareholder lawsuit against Yahoo and its directors.

headline: A Boom for Those Looking to Sow Seeds in Hedge Funds?
text: A mini-boom is under way in the business of providing hedge funds with seed capital as investors become less willing to put money into start-ups without a track record or expensive risk control systems, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Roy Lichtenstein at Gagosian
text: “Roy Lichtenstein: Girls,” at the Gagosian Gallery reveals the artist honing his indelible yet impersonal style. Roberta Smith reviews.

headline: Blackstone Taps Merrill’s Tosi as C.F.O.
text: The Blackstone Group has hired Merrill Lynch‘s former chief operating officer to be its chief financial officer. After 14 years with the buyout shop, Michael Puglisi will step down to make way for Laurence Tosi, who spent nine years at Merrill.

headline: Very | Amy Winehouse
text: (Bauer-Griffin)

headline: CSX Grasps at Straws to Fight a Fund
text: CSX has scored a coup in its efforts to win a proxy fight against a pair of hedge funds, one of which is British: It has cast the battle as a matter of national security.

headline: Private Equity Investors Fear ‘Strategy Drift’
text: Three-quarters of the institutional investors surveyed by Coller Capital said they were concerned about “strategy drift,” in which a private equity fund strays from its area of expertise because of a dearth of big buyout opportunities.

headline: JetBlue Flies Off With Verizon Unit
text: JetBlue Airways, the U.S. discount carrier, agreed to buy Verizon Communications‘s Airfone business to offer e-mail and messaging services aboard planes.

headline: Pier One Investors Jump Ship After Deal Announcement
text: Investors in Pier One Imports apparently weren’t too keen on the home-furnishings chain’s announcement Monday that it was seeking to buy Cost Plus in a stock swap valued at about $88 million.

headline: Soaring Steel
text: A soaring steel house rests gently on the California landscape.

headline: Leaving Baghdad: The View From Syria
text: Ahmad Fadam was a member of the Iraqi staff in the newsroom of The New York Times in Baghdad. He left Baghdad in May to take up a visiting fellowship at the University of North Carolina. He will continue to contribute to the Baghdad Bureau blog from there.

headline: Peacock and GMT Score Bigpoint for $110 Million
text: The boom in online gaming was underlined on Monday with the 70 million euro ($110 million) acquisition of Bigpoint, a German-based computer games website, by NBC Universal‘s Peacock Equity Fund and GMT Communications Partners, the British private equity group.

headline: SABMiller Swallows Russia’s Vladpivo
text: SABMiller announced the acquisition of the Russian brewer Vladpivo. SABMiller did not disclose the cost of the transaction, but said Tuesday that the gross assets of the Russian company are valued at $69 million.

headline: Go for the Burn (Make That Lightly Toasted)
text: After a “gym rage” incident in Manhattan ended in acquittal, fitness club managers dish to Newsweek.com about their members’ most obnoxious habits. Here’s one:

headline: Haier Said to Move Forward With G.E. Appliances Interest
text: China’s Qingdao Haier is advancing its interest in General Electric‘s appliance business and has begun to approach investment banks for the advisory assignment, The Financial Times reported citing an unnamed source.

headline: Experience, in Its Most Extreme Forms
text: A selection of artist Marlene Dumas’s body of work.

headline: Candover and Cinven Said to Consider Informa Bid
text: British private equity firms Cinven and Candover are actively considering tabling a bid for business publishing group Informa, which is in talks with United Business Media for a 3 billion pound ($5.9 billion) merger, according to The Telegraph.

headline: For Lehman’s Fuld, A Reversal of Fortune
text: Richard S. Fuld tried for months to persuade Wall Street that Lehman Brothers, the investment bank he runs, could weather the storm in the financial markets. But by last Wednesday his time had run out: Confidence in Lehman seemed to be slipping away.

headline: While You Were Out
UBS Faces More Trouble With Mortgage Securities
text: Lehman Brothers may have drawn the lion’s share of concern on Monday, but UBS remains a big worry for financial investors as well, The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday.

headline: Hopeful Signs in Buyout Debt Market
text: Is it time to go shopping for some cheap debt?

headline: Group to Add More Banks to Help Set Libor
text: The British Bankers’ Association, yielding to pressure from investors and regulators, will increase the number of banks that set the London interbank offered rate in the biggest change to Libor in 10 years, Bloomberg News reported

headline: Credit Suisse Puts a New Spin on Spin-Offs
text: Big companies spin off units all the time. But Credit Suisse is trying something different: It is cleaving off virtualization technology developed in-house into a new company, DynamicOps, to be backed by its own venture fund, Next II.

headline: About Those Steroids and Big Brown
text: Lack of steroids did not appear to be the reason Big Brown tanked the Belmont. I went over the reasons I thought were significant in my last article. Big Brown is a stallion. Horses are seasonal breeders. Anabolic steroids are naturally occurring. As days lengthen the endogenous anabolic steroids, those produced internally by intact male horses, are increasingly secreted into their bloodstream.

headline: The Early Word: McCain’s Turn on the Economy
text: If the bickering between Barack Obama and John McCain on Monday is any indication, both campaigns regard their differences over fiscal issues as one of the most important markers of contrast to voters as the general election fight gets under way.

headline: Paris Summer Festival: Escape to Books, not the Beach
text: By Tara Mulholland and Isobel O. Scott

headline: Sudan’s First Lady
text: The wife of Sudan’s brutal president, Omar al-Bashir, is visiting New York City with a retinue of about eight aides and security guards. Nominally they’re here for a U.N. session on AIDS, but that seems odd because Mrs. Bashir has never evinced interest in the subject before. Some U.N. hands think this is just a big shopping trip, perhaps timed partly out of concern that sanctions on her family will tighten in the coming months. The International Criminal Court is also expected to hand down new indictments for the genocide in Darfur, and these may even include President Bashir himself.

headline: Utley by Any Other Name…
text: Now batting for the Philadelphia Phillies, second baseman, “Carter Utley.”

headline: Lazard to Hire Ex-Belgian Prime Minister’s Chief of Staff
text: Lazard said Tuesday that it has hired the former chief of staff to Belgian prime minister Guy Verhofstadt as a managing director for its European investment banking team, in what is the firm’s second major political hiring over the past year.

headline: XTO to Buy Hunt Petroleum for $4.2 Billion
text: XTO Energy, an oil and natural gas producer, said Tuesday that it will acquire Hunt Petroleum, a company owned by descendants of oil tycoon H.L. Hunt, for about $4.2 billion in cash and stock, in what is the latest in a string of rapid-fire deals this year.

headline: Developing a Generation of Eco-Engineers
text: “We’re not expecting some technological epiphany,” Bob Kruse of General Motors told me flatly outside Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

headline: Internet Providers Agree to Block Child Pornography
text: Verizon, Sprint and Time Warner Cable have agreed to block access to Internet bulletin boards and Web sites nationwide that disseminate child pornography, Danny Hakim reports in a front-page article. The move is part of a groundbreaking agreement with the New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, that will be formally announced today as a significant step by leading companies to curtail access to child pornography. Many in the industry have previously resisted similar efforts, saying they could not be responsible for content online, given the decentralized and largely unmonitored nature of the Internet.

headline: Rumors to Rest
text: Good advice from the enemy? Jim Geraghty of National Review’s Campaign Spot blog thinks Barack Obama would be wise to release his birth certificate, thus quelling “unlikely” rumors circulating on the right side of the Web.

headline: Gender Roles, Marriage and Anger
text: My Well column this week focuses on the study of same-sex relationships, and what everyone can learn from them.

headline: Commerce Founder Gets Back Into Banking
text: He may have been forced out of his last company, Commerce Bancorp, amid a cloud of controversy. But it appears that Vernon W. Hill II can’t stay away from banks.

text: “Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild publicly declared war on a fellow actors’ union at a Monday rally here, increasing the likelihood of new labor strife in an entertainment industry still recovering from a writers’ strike that ended just four months ago,” Michael Cieply reports.

text: It seems that Guy Hands, the billionaire financier who leads the British buyout firm Terra Firma Capital Partners, isn’t the only one worried about mission creep in the private equity industry.

headline: Taser Suffers a Rare Loss in Court
text: Despite a steady stream of negative news coverage, Taser International’s business has sailed above it all, rolling with the punches before coming out on top of a growing industry.

headline: Are Doctors Screwing Up Public Health?
text: Health work in poor countries looks easy — vaccinate the kids, treat malaria, prevent mother-to-child transmission of AIDS — and yet in fact it’s extraordinarily difficult and has often failed. Because of AIDS, life expectancy has fallen. A quarter more women die in childbirth now in Africa than in 1990. As for malaria, we don’t even have a good sense of the scale of the challenge. We roll out multi-billion dollar anti-retroviral programs for AIDS, but we don’t even deworm kids or iodize salt — two simple interventions that would raise school attendance, reduce malnutrition and anemia, and prevent cognitive impairment and even cretinism.

Just to be sure it’s credible, I checked out the Kaiser Family Foundation’s data, which bear indirectly on the issue; KFF’s data show declining overall rates of coverage, and at least a suggestion that very large deductibles are becoming much more common.

These weren’t soccer fans mind you, but still: as big of a surprise as it was when Coach Otto Rehhagel’s stingy and determined boys defeated the hosts, it was as easy to forget. headline: Recipe of the Day: Strawberry Fool
text: It’s fun to reintroduce — and try to improve upon — a classic, once commonplace dish that has all but vanished from the repertory of most home cooks. The dish is the fool, a sublimely easy fruit dessert that is little more than fruit and stiffly whipped cream, sweetened with sugar. The fool can be made with almost any fruit but is best with berries, especially strawberries.

headline: Meet the Intraterrestrials
text: Some weeks ago, I wrote about microbes in the air and their possible role in helping clouds form, in causing rain and in altering the chemistry of the high atmosphere. This week, I want to go in the opposite direction and plunge down into the earth. For many bacteria live deep in the oceans and deep in the earth, far from light, far from what we normally think of as good, comfortable places to live.

headline: Meet the Intraterrestrials
text: Some weeks ago, I wrote about microbes in the air and their possible role in helping clouds form, in causing rain and in altering the chemistry of the high atmosphere. This week, I want to go in the opposite direction and plunge down into the earth. For many bacteria live deep in the oceans and deep in the earth, far from light, far from what we normally think of as good, comfortable places to live.   For example: the bottom of the Mariana Trench. This is a seam on the sea floor in the northwestern Pacific, not far from the island of Guam; it's where the Pacific plate is sliding under the Philippine plate. The ocean is deeper here than anywhere else in the world: the seabed is 11 kilometers (almost 7 miles) below the surface of the sea. Yet even here, where the pressure of the water would crush you or me, there are bacteria. Some of them won't grow at all unless the atmospheric pressure is at least 50 megapascals (around 7,000 pounds per square inch), and they grow better if the pressure is greater — 70 megapascals (more than 10,000 pounds per square inch). For comparison, the pressure at sea level — the pressure we have evolved to bear — is 700 times less.   Then there are the "intraterrestrials" — the organisms that live in rocks deep in the earth, the creatures of the "deep subsurface biosphere." Bacteria have been found in rock samples taken several hundred meters below the sea floor, even when the sea floor itself is 4 kilometers (2.5 miles) below sea level.   We don't know how many organisms are living in this (to us) alien environment. But based on what's been found in rock samples so far, the numbers are likely to be gigantic. One recent study found between 1 million and 1 billion bacteria per gram of rock (a gram is 1/28 of an ounce). It may be that a large proportion — perhaps as many as a third — of all bacteria on Earth live in rocks below the floor of the sea. That would be a lot of bacteria.  Until recently, it was assumed that the chemical alteration and decomposition of rocks in the ocean crust was due purely to elemental forces — the circulation of seawater, the grinding of rocks against one another. But increasingly, intraterrestrial bacteria are suspected of making a contribution, too. Shards of volcanic glass from basaltic rocks hundreds of meters beneath the seabed show grooves and etchings that appear to have been made by bacteria.   Volcanic glass? When molten basaltic rock wells up from deep in the earth and meets cold water at the bottom of the ocean, the heat is quenched and the rock hardens. As it does so, it forms a characteristic shape known as a pillow basalt — for it looks as though someone has stacked up a pile of rocky pillows. (Every year, around 20 cubic kilometers -- around 5 cubic miles — of new basalt forms at the mid-ocean ridges — the places where the sea floor is spreading apart as tectonic plates move away from each other.) Glass forms when the rock cools so fast that crystals don't have time to take shape. Thus the edges and rims of pillow basalts are often highly glassy; indeed basaltic glass is an important component of the top layers of the oceanic crust.   Bacteria of the deep biosphere can't get energy directly from sunlight, but they can get energy from a surprising array of other sources, including iron, manganese, sulfur or nitrogen compounds, methane and hydrogen. Indeed, bacteria collected from the deep biosphere show an enormous diversity of metabolic activities. And in chiseling away at rocks, in leaching out minerals to consume, and by excreting waste products, they alter the chemical composition of rocks — and also the composition of the seawater that circulates through the pores and fractures in them. Perhaps — though no one yet knows for sure — they do so on a grand scale, contributing substantially to the composition of rocks and oceans. Experiments suggest that deep biosphere bacteria may accelerate the weathering of basalt rocks by a factor of six compared to physical or chemical forces, especially at the low temperatures that prevail in much of the seabed.  And here's something nifty. By altering the chemical composition of rocks, the bacteria may alter the magnetic properties of rocks as well.  Basaltic rocks newly arrived at the sea floor give off a strong magnetic signal. This is due to titanomagnetites — iron oxides that contain some titanium — that are present in the rocks. As a result, the mid-ocean ridges often feature a zone of high magnetization known as the central anomaly magnetization high. The strength of the magnetic signal fades as you move away from the newest rocks — as you move from the mid-ocean ridges towards the coasts. (The new rocks are gradually pulled away from the ridge by the spreading apart of the ocean plates; a rock's distance from the ridge is thus a reflection of its age.) Soon after basalts arrive at the sea floor, then, they lose some of their magnetism. Why?  A recent series of experiments that looked at the loss of magnetism of young basaltic rocks shows that bacteria may greatly accelerate the loss. Rock slices were kept for 355 days in vials of seawater with or without bacteria. The bacteria in question were strains of Desulfovibrio — bacteria that give off hydrogen sulfide much as we give off carbon dioxide. Hydrogen sulfide interacts with the iron in the rocks to form iron sulfide; in doing so, it destroys the magnetic signal. And after 355 days, the rocks kept with bacteria gave off a lower signal than the rocks kept in seawater alone. Bacteria, it seems, can efficiently reduce the magnetic signal of young rocks.  No one knows, yet, how significant such effects are. Moreover, we're only beginning to make an inventory of who's down there — the identity of most intraterrestrials remains mysterious. But given their vast numbers, and the range of their activities, these small organisms from the weird world of the rocks below the sea will probably turn out to have a big-time influence on the composition of the oceans and the rocks of the seabed.   **********  NOTES:  For bacteria of the Mariana Trench, see Kato, C., Li, L, Nogi, Y., Nakamura, Y., Tamaoka, J. and Horikoshi, K. 1998. "Extremely barophilic bacteria isolated from the Mariana Trench, Challenger Deep, at a depth of 11,000 meters." Applied and Environmental Microbiology 64: 1510-1513. For the term intraterrestrials, see Pedersen, K. 2000. "Exploration of deep intraterrestrial microbial life: current perspectives." FEMS Microbiology Letters 185: 9-16.   For bacteria in rock samples from deep below the seafloor, see D'Hondt, S. et al 2004. "Distributions of microbial activities in deep subseafloor sediments." Science 306: 2216-2221. For 1 million-1 billion bacteria per gram of rock, see Santelli, C. M. et al 2008. "Abundance and diversity of microbial life in ocean crust." Nature 453: 653-657. Estimates of the number of intraterrestrials varies; but all the evidence suggests that the numbers are likely to be enormous. See, for example, Schippers, A. et al 2005. "Prokaryotic cells of the deep sub-seafloor biosphere identified as living bacteria." Nature 433: 861-864.  For microbes and the weathering of volcanic glass, see Thorseth, I. H., Torsvik, T., Furnes, H. and Muehlenbachs, K. 1995. "Microbes play an important role in the alteration of oceanic crust." Chemical Geology 126: 137-146, and Fisk, M. R., Giovannoni, S.
