J. and Thorseth, I. H. 1998. "Alteration of oceanic volcanic glass: textural evidence of microbial activity." Science 281: 978-980.  For a selection of bacterial metabolic activities in the seabed, see table 1 of Edwards, K. J., Bach, W. and McCollom, T. M. 2005. "Geomicrobiology in oceanography: microbe-mineral interactions at and below the seafloor." Trends in Microbiology 13: 449-456. For bacteria increasing the rate of weathering, see Edwards, K. J., Bach, W., McCollom, T. M. and Rogers, D. R. 2004. "Neutrophilic iron-oxidizing bacteria in the ocean: their habitats, diversity, and roles in mineral deposition, rock alteration, and biomass production in the deep-sea." Geomicrobiology Journal 21: 393-404.   For bacteria reducing the magnetic signal of young basalts, see Carlut, J., Horen, H. and Janots, D. 2007. "Impact of micro-organisms activity on the natural remanent magnetization of the young oceanic crust." Earth and Planetary Science Letters 253: 497-506.   Many thanks to Julie Carlut, Katrina Edwards, Dan Haydon and Stephen Porder for insights, comments and suggestions.    ************  Editors' note: In an earlier version of this essay, "iron sulfide" was in one instance mistakenly referred to as "iron sulfur." It has been corrected.

headline: Frugal Traveler: The Grand Tour
text: The Frugal Traveler makes a stop in Monaco, then heads to the beach town of Menton, France.

headline: Frugal Traveler: The Grand Tour
text: The Frugal Traveler makes a stop in Monaco, then heads to the beach town of Menton, France.

headline: Top architects explore connection between design and… jelly?
text: Foster + Partners, Will Alsop and Rogers Stirk Harbour + Partners are among the big name U.K. architects turning their talents to jelly. Specifically, they are participating in the Architectural Jelly Design Competition, which seeks to “raise awareness of the relationship between food and architecture,” as part of the London Festival of Architecture 2008, June 20 to July 20.

headline: Wang and Rivera Right Themselves in Oakland
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  As his latest setup man tried to navigate the eighth inning Tuesday, Mariano Rivera rose from the bench in the right field bullpen. Rivera stood near the foul line with his warm-up jacket on, jangling his arms to get loose.

headline: Chefs Find Winner’s Circle Familiar Turf
text: A SENSE of déjà vu has often surrounded the James Beard Foundation’s annual culinary awards, which took place Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall. This year was no different.

headline: Grilled or Broiled Kebabs
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: France: Industrial Production Rises
text: French industrial production rebounded in April from a decline in the previous month, led by output of cars, electrical equipment and chemicals. Production at factories and utilities, which accounts for 15 percent of the economy, gained 1.4 percent from March, when it fell 1 percent, said the national statistics bureau, Insee.

headline: 6 to Get Presidential Medal of Freedom
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. Peter Pace, who was denied a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff a year ago because of the war in Iraq, will receive a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian award, the White House announced today.

headline: Lakers Allow Themselves to Smile After Climbing Back in the  Series
text: LOS ANGELES  Kobe Bryant regained his balance Tuesday night and with it, a self-deprecating sense of humor. It was a lot easier to joke about all that had gone wrong after the Los Angeles Lakers finally put their stamp on the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Winners’ List Shows the Reach of Golf
text: SAN DIEGO  There was a time when the United States Open could not have seemed more aptly named, when the winners of the tournament were rarely non-American.

headline: Overhaul Is Set for N.Y. Governor’s Police Unit
text: The state police unit that protects and travels with the governor will be overhauled in an effort to ensure that governors do not exert improper influence over the troopers or compromise their security decisions, one of several officials briefed on the changes said on Tuesday.

headline: With One Eye on Gasoline and the Economy, Congress Keeps the Other on November
text: WASHINGTON  Congress is shifting quickly to a general election footing, with lawmakers of both parties intensifying efforts to exploit public alarm about gasoline prices and the economy as a way of making the political case for themselves and their respective White House contenders.

headline: Philippine Television Crew Believed to Be Kidnapped
text: MANILA  A television news team from the Philippines’ largest network, including one of the country’s best-known journalists, was believed to have been abducted by members of the militant group Abu Sayyaf, officials said Tuesday.

headline: The Explanation: Climb Here to Combat Malaria
text: During his psychiatric examination at Bellevue last week, Renaldo Clarke was asked a series of routine questions  routine, that is, if you’ve just scampered up the side of a building 746 feet tall.

headline: A Missing Staple Puts Many a Maine Chowder Recipe in Jeopardy
text: CHEBEAGUE ISLAND, Me.  Few pantry items can inflame an entire island, let alone a region. But not many snack foods have a history and following like that of the Crown Pilot cracker.

headline: Putting Meat Back in Its Place
text: LET’S suppose you’ve decided to eat less meat, or are considering it. And let’s ignore your reasons for doing so. They may be economic, ethical, altruistic, nutritional or even irrational. The arguments for eating less meat are myriad and well-publicized, but at the moment they’re irrelevant, because what I want to address here is (almost) purely pragmatic: How do you do it?

headline: A Violinist With Stories to Share (and Sing)
text: One evening last month, the violinist Jenny Scheinman settled in for her customary early set at Barbès, the cozy Park Slope bar that has long been her second home. Though she has been heralded over the last five years as a venturesome improviser, her first number was a vocal feature, “I Was Young When I Left Home,” one of many traditional songs associated with the young Bob Dylan. Ms. Scheinman, cradling her violin in the crook of an elbow, sang in a clear, agreeable tone, with a hint of nasal twang.

headline: To Save Fuel, Airlines Find No Speck Too Small
text: The nation’s airlines are scrutinizing every step of their operations, from the tarmac to the sky, and from the nose to the tail of their planes, searching for new ways to cut their soaring fuel bills.

headline: Questions on U.S. Beef Remain
text: About 50 countries, including Korea, Taiwan and Japan the last of which accounted for 36 percent of American beef exports closed their doors to American beef after the first confirmed case of mad cow disease was found in Moses Lake, Wash., in December 2003.

headline: Bank of America Sells Its Equity Brokerage
text: Bank of America is selling its prime brokerage operation to BNP Paribas for around $300 million after a six-month bidding process, according to people briefed on the deal.

headline: In a New World, Less Can Mean More
text: CHEAPNESS has many manifestations. A perfect example is the 1950s monster movie cheapness that Frank Zappa once sang about, with creatures that looked like giant poodles and “visible nylon strings attached to the jaw of a giant spider.” I love that sort of “cheepnis,” as Zappa put it. Who doesn’t? The schlock and the camp were appealing precisely because they were an affront to pomposity and pretension.

headline: Austria: Ex-Captive No Longer in Coma
text: A 19-year-old Austrian woman, whose illness helped expose the secret of a 73-year-old man accused of locking several family members in a cellar for up to 24 years, has been revived from a medically induced coma, according to hospital officials. The woman, Kerstin Fritzl, is the eldest daughter of Elisabeth Fritzl, who the authorities say was imprisoned and raped by the man, Josef Fritzl, her father, bearing seven children. Mr. Fritzl freed his captives after taking Kerstin to the hospital.

headline: Ban All Nuclear Weapons
text: To the Editor:

headline: Records Tumble and Sweaty New Yorkers Grumble as Heat Persists
text: New York is famous for its superlatives. On Tuesday, the city did not disappoint.

headline: First the Announcement, Then the Understanding
text: “Anyone and Everyone,” which looks at how various couples took the news that their child is gay, ultimately decides to be an advocacy film rather than a documentary. But before it does, it tells some truly moving stories of the power of parental love.

headline: O.K., Dad, Just This Once You Can Play With Your Food
text: Though they may seem a bit  shall we say it?  corny, these corn holders in the shape of golf balls by Charcoal Companion are actually a practical gift for a golf-loving dad. They are easy to grip, and a set of eight is $9.99 from mortongolfsales.com.

headline: Immelman Isn’t Banking on Winning Grand Slam
text: SAN DIEGO  As the winner of the Masters, Trevor Immelman is the only golfer eligible to win the 2008 Grand Slam, which would mean winning the United States Open, British Open and the P.G.A. Championship. Asked Tuesday if he had considered that possibility, Immelman quickly answered: “No.”

headline: Despite Dutrow’s Criticism, Big Brown’s Jockey Will Stay
text: Already planning ahead for Big Brown’s next race, members of his team said Tuesday that they planned to stick with their regular rider, Kent Desormeaux, and resume the colt’s monthly treatments of Winstrol.

headline: Mincing Up Michelle
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Crackdown on Violators of Fire Code
text: More than 100 people have been arrested in New York City this month as part of a continuing effort to crack down on buildings with outstanding fire code violations  everything from a Costco in Brooklyn to a Merrill Lynch in Manhattan to small auto repair shops in Queens and the Bronx.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Saturday about an increase in security measures at the New York Times Building after two men scaled the exterior misstated the share of the 52-story building owned by Forest City Ratner, the real estate company that was The Times’s development partner. It is 42 percent, not 48.

headline: Study Shows Colorado Has Largest Rise in Child Poverty
text: DENVER  Colorado experienced the nation’s largest rate of growth in impoverished children from 2000 to 2006, according to a study released Tuesday.

headline: Chinese Stocks Plunge 8.1 Percent
text: HONG KONG  Chinese stocks plummeted 8.1 percent on Tuesday, their biggest single-day drop in nearly 16 months, leading a broad downturn in Asian stock markets.

headline: Strong Action Urged to Curb Warming
text: The scientific academies of 13 countries on Tuesday urged the world to act more forcefully to limit the threat posed by human-driven global warming.

headline: Lamb ‘Falafel’ With Lemony Tahini Sauce
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Mets Seek Bright Spots Amid a Gloomy Defeat
text: On a long, rain-delayed evening at Shea Stadium, the Mets lost their fifth consecutive game, a dreary 9-5 decision to the Arizona Diamondbacks. They squandered a four-run lead and allowed four home runs.

headline: Google Co-Founder Books a Space Flight
text: Space tourists are getting their own ride. Space Adventures, a Virginia company that arranges passage for wealthy explorers to ride on Russian Soyuz rockets to the International Space Station, plans to buy a Soyuz flight all its own in 2011, with the option of buying more.

headline: Vetting a Vetter: Obama’s Pick Fuels G.O.P. Criticism
text: In choosing James A. Johnson for his vice-presidential selection committee, Senator Barack Obama tapped the ultimate Washington insider: a nationally recognized business executive who also helped Walter F. Mondale and John Kerry pick their Democratic running mates.

headline: Inspiration Can Come in a Can
text: IT all started with the super-size bag of dried organic chickpeas my husband, Daniel, brought home last December.

headline: Scottish Play Gets Polish Makeover
text: “Three. Two. One. Fire!” With a satisfying boom, flames exploded into the air on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. Standing a few feet away, Grzegorz Jarzyna, a Polish theater director sporting a slick leather jacket and a soul patch, looked on approvingly.

headline: Standing Up for Workers’ Rights in Japan
text: TOKYO  Japan’s salarymen, famous for their work ethic and their corporate loyalty, fueled this nation’s industrial rise. But more recently, they have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime.

headline: Going Out on Top, on Time
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Flank Steak With Zucchini
text: Time: 40 minutes plus 3 to 5 hours’ marinating

headline: Korean Leader Considers Ways to Rework Government
text: SEOUL — President Lee Myung-bak pledged a "new beginning" on Wednesday as he contemplated reorganizing his unpopular government which has been shaken by the biggest anti-government demonstrations in two decades.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: International

headline: Landowner Who Balked Gives In to Columbia
text: A business owner who had pledged not to sell her property to make way for Columbia University’s expansion has reached a deal with the university, Columbia officials said on Tuesday.

headline: In Singapore, a House Steeped in Tradition
text: SINGAPORE

headline: Banking on Gardening
text: CASSANDRA FEELEY prefers organic ingredients, especially for her baby, but she finds it hard to manage on her husband’s salary as an Army sergeant. So this year she did something she has wanted to do for a long time: she planted vegetables in her yard to save money.

headline: Kenya: Plane Crash Kills 2 Officials
text: A Kenyan cabinet minister and an assistant minister were killed when their small plane crashed near the Masai Mara game reserve. Kipkalya Kones, the roads minister, and Lorna Laboso, assistant minister for home affairs, both in the leading opposition party, were flying to a town west of Nairobi to oversee a local election.

headline: The Food Festival Booker, Catering to Star Chefs
text: ON a morning early this spring, Lee Brian Schrager phoned Kimberly Yorio, a publicist who works with chefs. Ms. Yorio had been trying to figure out how to promote a client’s book, and she used the occasion of the call to ask about the New York City Wine & Food Festival that Mr. Schrager was planning for October.

headline: Judge Orders Ohio to Alter Its Method of Execution
text: Ohio must stop using a common combination of three chemicals to execute condemned inmates because they may produce excruciating pain, a state court judge there ruled Tuesday.

headline: A Big Sound From a Voice for Wide-Open Spaces
text: Many performers can recall that inspirational flashpoint when the future revealed itself and they beheld what they wanted to be. The Broadway belter Martin Vidnovic chose as his role model the now half-forgotten Italian tenor Sergio Franchi, whom he discovered while in high school in Virginia in the early 1960s.

headline: In Oakland, Giambi Talks of Unmet Goals in New York
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  There has been much fascination lately about Jason Giambi’s good-luck gold thong, which hung brazenly in his locker for years. Now it is out of view, leaving his wooden hat-stretcher as the everyday reminder of his younger days in Oakland.

headline: ‘A Commander in Chief Moment’ on Iraq?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Russia: Nickel Producer’s Profit Falls
text: OAO Norilsk Nickel, the world’s biggest producer of nickel and palladium, reported an unexpected decline in profit for 2007 after cutting almost $2 billion off the value of mining and power companies it bought last year. Net income fell 11 percent, to $5.32 billion, or $29.20 a share, from $5.97 billion, or $31.70 a share, a year earlier, said the company, which is based in Moscow.

headline: A Big New York City Movie Studio Is Getting Bigger
text: Kaufman Astoria Studios, one of New York City’s three largest movie studios, is moving ahead with a major expansion plan, nine years after it was announced.

headline: Letters: On Second Thought
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Many Goodly Creatures Are There on Mr. Herzog’s Planet
text: Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does, or as inexorable. In his documentary “Encounters at the End of the World,” this professional madman and restlessly curious filmmaker travels to the blinding white of the Antarctic, where he meets melancholic scientists, brooding journeymen and various poets of the soul who, ensconced in the American headquarters, McMurdo Station, have traveled so far beyond the familiar coordinates  so far beyond traditional cities, suburbs and banal existence  that they might as well be on another planet.

headline: Scorpions for Breakfast and Snails for Dinner
text: IN Beijing, where my family lives, I once returned home from a restaurant with a doggy bag full of deep-fried scorpions. The next morning, I poured them instead of imported raisin bran into my 11-year-old son’s cereal bowl. I wanted to freak him out. The scorpions were black and an inch long, with dagger tails.

headline: Mexico: Antidrug Aid’s Strings Intact
text: A plan to help Mexico fight drug trafficking emerged from a House-Senate conference in Washington with controversial human rights conditions intact, although softened in response to objections from Mexican officials and the White House, officials said. The initiative will send $400 million to Mexico. Fifteen percent of the money will be conditioned on governments’ holding their security forces more accountable for abuses.

headline: Fuel Protest Begins to Pinch in Spain
text: MADRID  The customer ordered a tortilla  a traditional Spanish potato omelet  but Graciela Gómez Torea, owner of the San Telmo cafeteria in Madrid, sadly shook her head.

headline: Gates Offers Assurances on Support for Air Force
text: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill.  A senior sergeant complained that the attention to the ground wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had left the Air Force short of personnel.

headline: New Effort to Monitor Benchmark Loan Rate
text: LONDON  Recognizing that the turmoil in the credit market is not yet over, British banking officials on Tuesday revealed how they plan to restore confidence in the lending market and ensure financial stability.

headline: Lobbying Investigation Prompts Raid of Albany Firm
text: ALBANY  Federal law enforcement agents have raided the offices of an influential lobbying firm in Albany as part of the latest investigation connected to the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal in Washington.

headline: Can Rice Lead to Gold? Marathon Will Offer Test
text: Olympic marathon runners are no less obsessed about shoes than the gal pals in “Sex and the City.”

headline: Another Failure on Climate Change
text: The most obvious lesson to be learned from the Senate’s failure to mount any sort of grown-up debate on climate change last week is that the country needs a new occupant in the White House.

headline: Roast Turkey With a Salsa Beat
text: HAVING been scrupulous in observing my government’s ban on travel to Cuba, I don’t know what the country’s restaurants look like. So why did Sophie’s Cuban Cuisine, a takeout or sit-down lunch place that opened on 40th Street earlier this year, strike me as inauthentic?

headline: Elusive Starting Point on Harsh Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON  In a flurry of oversight that some critics say comes years too late, Congress is pressing Bush administration officials on a still-unanswered question: How did the United States come to embrace harsh interrogation methods it had always shunned?

headline: What You Get for ... $300,000
text: Banner Elk, N.C.

headline: Paulson Will Again Press China to Make Changes
text: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, the Treasury secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. left Goldman Sachs and joined the Bush administration hoping to use his expertise and contacts to ease economic tensions with China. His other goal was to stop Congress from passing legislation that might make tensions worse.

headline: Those Loyal to the Clintons Take Note of Who Was Not
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was gracious in her full-throated endorsement of Senator Barack Obama. But that does not mean all is forgiven by others in the Clinton universe.

headline: Ripples in the Vice-Presidential Pool
text: It’s so early in the vice presidential search process that aides to Senator Barack Obama will not even speak of a “list” of names they are working on. But the universe of potential candidates shrank by one name and grew by another on Tuesday.

headline: Safety Board Determines Pilot Fatigue Caused Skid
text: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday identified sleepy pilots as a reason that a regional jet slid off a snowy runway in Traverse City, Mich., in April 2007, and the agency again called on the Federal Aviation Administration to take steps to manage fatigue.

headline: Paulson’s Path to China: Progress, but Miles to Go
text: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. left Goldman Sachs and joined the Bush administration, hoping to use his expertise and contacts to ease economic tensions with China. His other goal was to stop Congress from passing legislation that might make tensions worse.

headline: F.D.A. Reports Progress in Tracing Salmonella
text: WASHINGTON  Federal health officials said Tuesday that they hoped to announce soon the source of a salmonella outbreak associated with raw tomatoes that has sickened at least 167 people in 17 states and led restaurants and grocery stores to remove some types of raw tomatoes from their menus and shelves.

headline: Amid Boom, a Battle Over Buildings Chief’s Qualifications
text: As the city struggles to keep pace with a building boom, enforce safety laws and curb fatal construction accidents, architects and engineers are fighting Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s effort to downgrade the qualification requirements for the city’s buildings commissioner.

headline: Don’t Leave Home Without a Cultural Compass
text: CAIRO  Emad Refaat strode out of his workshop with purpose, his grease-covered hands pointing down the road even before he could see the road. “Come here,” he said, his voice strong with reassurance. “Go to the light, make the first right. That’s Salah el-Din Street.”

headline: Fund Figure Disappears on Date Set for Prison
text: A little more than an hour before a former hedge fund manager was to report to federal prison on Monday, his sport utility vehicle was found abandoned on a bridge over the Hudson River with the phrase “Suicide Is Painless” written in dust on its hood.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Way It Was

headline: Water District in Southern California Issues an Alert on Use
text: LOS ANGELES  The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California issued a water alert on Tuesday, asking communities to modernize and toughen their water conservation rules.

headline: Austen’s Inspiration
text: A portrait of the man believed to have inspired the character of Mr. Darcy in Jane Austen’s “Pride and Prejudice” is going on sale for £50,000 (about $98,000) at an antiques fair in London, the BBC reported. Thomas Lefroy, right, born in Ireland, met Austen in 1796, when both were in their early 20s. They had a flirtation, but Lefroy, whose family was poor, married an heiress. The watercolor portrait, 3 inches by 1 1/4 inches, was painted in 1798 by George Engleheart, and will be on sale at the Grosvenor House Art & Antiques Fair, which runs Thursday to next Wednesday. ... Christie’s in New York will put hundreds of James Brown items up for auction on July 17, Reuters reported. The 320 lots in “The James Brown Collection” include a rhinestone “Sex Machine” belt buckle, handwritten lyrics, instruments and grooming items, and are estimated to take in about $1 million.

headline: Spain Arrests 8 It Says Aided a Qaeda-Linked Cell
text: PARIS  The Spanish police on Tuesday arrested eight men suspected of giving financial and logistical support to a terrorist group in Algeria linked to Al Qaeda, Spain’s Interior Ministry said.

headline: Fresh From the Fire, Dressed-Up Ciabattas
text: Jonathan and Nina White, who own Bobolink Dairy in Vernon, N.J., also bake breads in a wood-fired oven. Among them is a ciabatta that’s about 20 inches long and paved with the dairy’s own Cheddar cheese, $5. Portions of it, warmed, make a sumptuous breakfast. With ham or bacon on top you have lunch. And thin toasted slices can be passed on a board with cocktails. Another option is the Whites’ duck fat and garlic ciabatta, also $5, to accompany soup or salad or to eat with cured meats.

headline: When Golf’s Past, Present and Future Met in Denver
text: It was a multigeneration conflict impossible to imagine in another sport: at the 1960 United States Open golf championship, three men who defined their eras in their sport battled one another nearly to the end of 72 holes on a course in Denver. Ben Hogan was 47, a savvy shotmaker ending his career; Arnold Palmer was 30 and about to be golf’s populist king; and Jack Nicklaus was 20, a powerful amateur still at Ohio State.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A news analysis article on Tuesday about policy reversals by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela mistranslated part of a nickname that critics use to describe his proposed intelligence agency reform, which they say will force people to spy on each other. As the article noted, the nickname, “the Getsapo Law,” is a play on the words Gestapo and sapo, which as slang means snitch. But sapo literally translates as toad  not frog.

headline: Strahan Flashes a Smile as a Giant for the Last Time
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After a year of seriously contemplating retirement, the most difficult part for Michael Strahan came at the end.

headline: A Yippie Veteran Is in Jail Far From the East Village
text: It has been more than 40 years since Dana Beal came to prominence as a theoretician for the Youth International Party, known as the Yippies, and embarked on a long career in the world of countercultural politics.

headline: Obama on the Nile
text: Cairo

headline: Donaghy Cites Broad Misconduct in N.B.A.
text: LOS ANGELES  N.B.A. executives and referees are accused of broad misconduct and outright manipulation of game results  including a highly disputed 2002 playoff series  in the latest court filing by the lawyer for the former referee Tim Donaghy.

headline: China’s List of Olympic Don’ts
text: Now that the shock of the earthquake (which they could not control) in Sichuan Province has dissipated somewhat, China’s leaders are focusing again on something that they think they can control: people. Sports fans attending the 2008 Olympics in Beijing will have a long list of rules to carry in their pockets along with their tickets.

headline: Alou Is Back, Church Is on the D.L. and the Mets Stagger On
text: In the cool air of the Mets’ clubhouse late Tuesday afternoon at Shea Stadium, the televisions showed highlights from the 2000 season, the last year in which the team played in the World Series.

headline: Zimbabwe: Challenger Denies Deal
text: The opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai, left, dismissed speculation that he was negotiating with President Robert Mugabe to form a unity government and cancel the presidential runoff on June 27. The state-owned newspaper, The Herald, said the government would give amnesty to prisoners to open space in the jails for those convicted of political violence. The opposition, whose members are being jailed in large numbers, interpreted the plan as a signal for an intensified crackdown.

headline: Technology and Food Yield Choice at Charity
text: With its airy dining room, round tables and sleek wood chairs that look like something from a SoHo showroom, the new St. John’s Bread and Life center in Bedford-Stuyvesant bears very little resemblance to the traditional soup kitchen.

headline: Squeezing Big-Box Retailing Into Small City Spaces
text: When David Blumenfeld, a developer in Syosset, N.Y., bought a long-dormant wire factory in the East Harlem section of Manhattan in 1994 with the intention of turning it into a vertical shopping center for big-box stores, the notion that quintessentially suburban retailers could adjust to an urban setting had yet to be fully tested.

headline: McKay Remembered as a Storyteller
text: BALTIMORE  Jim McKay was at heart a storyteller, a television adventurer who traveled millions of miles for ABC Sports to describe the feats of figure skaters, Olympians, auto racers, golfers and cliff divers.

headline: In Europe, Debate Over Islam and Virginity
text: PARIS  The operation in the private clinic off the Champs-Élysées involved one semicircular cut, 10 dissolving stitches and a discounted fee of $2,900.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Wednesday about deal-breaking instructions in recipes misspelled the given name of the cookbook author whose recipe for a Mexican sausage calls for two quarts of pig’s blood. She is Diana Kennedy, not Diane.

headline: From the Vault, a Complex Ostrich and Sculptural Movement
text: DURHAM, N.C.  The American Dance Festival’s 75th-anniversary celebration has historical implications worth addressing. It tells us that before Balanchine started work on American soil in 1934, there was already enough American dance to make much of.

headline: John S. Zinsser Jr., 84, Book Popularizer, Is Dead
text: John S. Zinsser Jr., who as editor of Reader’s Digest Condensed Books in the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s made nearly 800 carefully crunched versions of popular books available to millions of readers, died on May 27 at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 84.

headline: Thai Beef Salad
text: Time: 25 minutes

headline: European Leaders Back Bush on Iran
text: KRANJ, Slovenia  Opening a farewell tour of Europe, President Bush won European support on Tuesday to consider additional punitive sanctions against Iran, including restrictions on its banks, if Iran rejects a package of incentives to suspend its uranium enrichment program.

headline: Eliot Asinof, ‘Eight Men Out’ Author, Is Dead at 88
text: Eliot Asinof, whose journalistic re-creation of the 1919 Black Sox scandal, “Eight Men Out,” became a classic of both baseball literature and narrative nonfiction, died Tuesday in Hudson, N.Y. He was 88 and lived in Ancramdale, N.Y.

headline: Super Bowl-Winning Giants Get Canyon of Heroes Honor
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the defensive end Justin Tuck of the New York Giants in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday morning to unveil a sidewalk plaque commemorating the Giants’ historic win over the heavily favored New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Beloved Characters as Reimagined for the 21st Century
text: LOS ANGELES  Strawberry Shortcake was having an identity crisis. The “it” doll and cartoon star of the 1980s was just not connecting with modern girls. Too candy-obsessed. Too ditzy. Too fond of wearing bloomers.

headline: Concerns on Economy Are Shifting to Inflation
text: In the past 48 hours, Wall Street has issued a sobering message: The days of easy money from the Federal Reserve are nearly over.

headline: Pumpkin Seeds Step in as Pesto
text: The pesto lineup  basil, mint, cilantro, tomato  works overtime in summer, being slathered on chicken or fish for the grill, dolloped into cold soup or served as a dip or hors d’oeuvre spread. New to the American market are pumpkin seed pestos from Austria, the country that has already given us pumpkin seed oil for flavorful drizzling.

headline: 2 Energy Bills, Including Windfall Tax, Stall in Senate
text: WASHINGTON  A Democratic proposal to impose heavier taxes on big oil companies stalled in the Senate on Tuesday as Republicans and Democrats offered different ideas on how to deal with soaring energy costs.

headline: Bomb on Car Kills Leader of Hussein’s Tribe
text: BAGHDAD  The leader of Saddam Hussein’s tribe was killed by a bomb on Tuesday, after he had spoken publicly in favor of reconciling with the government in Baghdad.

headline: Second Date With a Little Black Dress
text: Deborah Voigt is finally putting on that little black dress.

headline: A Stuntman Dies Making Woo Film
text: A 23-year-old stuntman died and six others were injured in a fire in Beijing while shooting a historical epic by the director John Woo, The Associated Press reported. The film’s crew and Chinese news media reported on Tuesday that the accident occurred on Monday morning while filming an action sequence for “Red Cliff.” A small boat was set ablaze and collided with a larger boat as the filmmakers had intended, but the fire quickly raged out of control and engulfed both craft. Mr. Woo, told of the news while promoting his film in Hong Kong, rushed back to Beijing, the crew said. “Red Cliff,” about a well-known battle in feudal China, has suffered casting changes and set problems since it started filming.

headline: A Name Change in Philadelphia
text: Last year Live Nation, the giant concert promoter, renamed a handful of clubs and small theaters around the country to give them a unified brand: Fillmore, after Bill Graham’s famous clubs in San Francisco and New York. In Philadelphia the Theater of the Living Arts became the Fillmore at the TLA, and in New York, Irving Plaza became the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza. The Philadelphia club has now reverted to its old name, but Live Nation said it had no plans to change the name of the New York club. “Although Fillmore is a valuable and powerful brand, which we remain committed to,” the company said in a statement, “the fans in Philadelphia made it known to us that the Theater of the Living Arts was a more relevant name in their local community.”

headline: Dying in Detention
text: The government has a duty to provide decent, effective, timely medical care to people in its custody. That should be beyond debate, but not when the government in question is the Bush administration and the people in custody are illegal immigrants.

headline: Even the Most Romantic of Poets Can Sometimes Be Awfully Hard of Heart
text: “Once the world was whole, in Antiquity and the Middle Ages,” Heinrich Heine wrote. “There was still a unity in the world and there were complete poets. We rightfully honor these poets and take pleasure in their poetry; but any aping of their wholeness is a lie.”

headline: A Decision That May Benefit Both Parent and Spinoff
text: The heirs of Laurence Tisch, who died in 2003, and his brother, Preston Robert Tisch, who died in 2005, controlled an estimated 23 percent of Loews stock before the spinoff of its Lorillard tobacco company on Tuesday.

headline: The End of Intervention
text: Washington

headline: The Painter Who Adored Women
text: “Roy Lichtenstein: Girls,” at the Gagosian Gallery, presents 12 of Lichtenstein’s early paintings of the female creatures otherwise known as women. Based on cartoons and mostly blond, they are anonymous, beautiful and often unhappily bothered, usually by men. Or, if you like, by boys.

headline: Pakistani Lawyers Demand Reinstatement of Judges
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Hundreds of Pakistani lawyers began a two-day march from the southern city of Karachi to Islamabad, the capital, on Tuesday to demand the reinstatement of 60 judges removed by President Pervez Musharraf.

headline: Student Loans, for Adults
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Memories of Florent
text: To the Editor:

headline: Flashing Capes and Other Spanish Flourishes
text: To put it politely, “Don Quixote” might not be the most artistically profound ballet ever staged. What remains of the original choreography, from different 19th-century versions, is debatable; its music, by Ludwig Minkus, is not much more than nicely dancey; its relationship to the Cervantes novel minimal; its Spanishness a matter of flourishing fans and wearing capes.

headline: Fans, Not Umpires, at Heart of Griffey Home Run Dispute
text: Although Major League Baseball remains undecided about using instant replay for home runs, that did not stop the police from watching video to determine who caught the 600th home run hit by Ken Griffey Jr. on Monday night in Miami.

headline: For Hot Days, a Cool Spot on the Sidewalk
text: When Marisa Ferrarin and Frank Locker took over the Duane Park Cafe, they found a closet near the front window. With downtown real estate running at a gazillion dollars a foot, they turned it into a profit center: an ice cream counter open to the street.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Friday about the Discovery Channel documentary "When We Left Earth," a history of the American space program, misstated the surname of a former astronaut who appears in the film. She is Kathryn Sullivan, not Harrison.

headline: Broadcasters Fare Surprisingly Well in Ad Sales
text: THE biggest broadcast television networks are concluding surprisingly good advance advertising sales for the 2008-9 season.

headline: Channeling Noir, Dickens-Style
text: Last year “Tree of Smoke,” a sweeping novel by Denis Johnson, below, about the Vietnam War, won the National Book Award for fiction, and this year it was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize. But Mr. Johnson is not resting easy. Beginning with its July issue, which arrives at newsstands on Friday, Playboy will publish his next novel, “Nobody Move,” in four monthly installments of 10,000 words each, to be written on deadline each month through the October issue. The magazine described “Nobody Move” as a hard-boiled noir in the style of Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett, but Mr. Johnson said he was also inspired by an earlier writer. “I’ve always admired Charles Dickens, who wrote big, involved novels in monthly installments,” he said in a statement, “and I wanted to find out what it was like. It’s a little nerve-racking.”

headline: A Soulful Sojourn Backtracks to Voltage
text: On his last two albums, the recent “Jim” and “Multiply” in 2005, the British musician Jamie Lidell all but foreswore the cold, jagged electronic music with which he first made his name in favor of straightforward, classic soul. With his sheepish and gawky persona, Mr. Lidell seemed an unlikely candidate for such a switch, but thanks to his tender voice and taut, faithful arrangements, the results were astonishingly sincere and often great.

headline: Indonesian Village Struggles With Ban on Muslim Sect
text: MANIS LOR, Indonesia  A large sign spans the road just outside the main mosque in this quiet, well-kept village in West Java here reading, in big red letters, “Banned.” Residents pass beneath the sign every day on their way to the market, work or school.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A brief report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about observations of Saturn’s F ring misidentified the journal in which the study appeared. It was in Nature, not Science.

headline: U.S. News Plans to Publish Biweekly and Expand Consumer Focus
text: Critics have carped for some time that U.S. News & World Report had stopped being a newsweekly  that both “news” and “weekly” were questionable descriptions.

headline: Brazil: Economic Growth Slows
text: Brazil’s economy grew 5.8 percent in the first quarter, powered by higher consumer spending that is stoking inflation and forcing the central bank to raise interest rates. The growth rate slowed from 6.2 percent in the last three months of 2007. Brazil’s statistics agency also reported that exports had fallen 2.14 percent from a year ago, their first quarterly decline since June 2006.

headline: China Lets Town’s Ruins Wash Away, in Effort to Avert Disaster Downriver
text: BEIJING  Low-lying areas in one of the towns most devastated by the May 12 earthquake were flooded Tuesday as a torrent of water was released from a dangerous lake formed by landslides, dislodging wrecked homes, cars and corpses.

headline: Reality’s Low Numbers
text: Reality television proved lackluster in the ratings on Monday as ABC and NBC struggled opposite mostly repeat fare on CBS and Fox. According to Nielsen’s estimates, Episode 2 of “The Mole” had the weakest ratings, drawing 4 million viewers for ABC at 10 p.m., following “The Bachelorette” from 8 to 10 (6.4 million). ABC finished fourth for the night, just behind NBC, which garnered similarly low ratings for “American Gladiators” at 8 (5.6 million) and the debut of the singing competition “Nashville Star” from 9 to 11 (6.6 million). CBS was the night’s highest rated network with a lineup of mostly comedy repeats followed by a rerun of “CSI: Miami” (8.6 million), the 10 p.m. time-slot leader. Fox was in second place with repeats of “Bones” at 8 (7.3 million) and “House” at 9 (8 million). ... On Sunday two popular cable series made strong second-season premieres. At 9 p.m. the History Channel’s “Ice Road Truckers” garnered 3.9 million viewers, the highest rating ever for a premiere on that channel, and at 10 p.m. Lifetime’s “Army Wives” delivered 4.5 million viewers, that channel’s largest audience in its 24-year history.

headline: Energy Agency Reduces Forecast for Oil Demand
text: Global oil demand is expected to grow at a slower pace than previously expected this year as a result of record prices and shrinking subsidies in some emerging countries, a leading energy forecaster said on Tuesday.

headline: Campaigns Collide Over McCain Remark
text: WASHINGTON  The war over the war exploded anew here on Wednesday. Advocates and spinmasters for both presumptive presidential nominees jumped into all-out battle after Senator John McCain, when asked whether he now had a better idea when American troops could return home from Iraq, replied, “No, but that’s not too important.”

headline: 2 New-Style Candidates Hit Old Notes on Economy
text: For all the efforts of Senators John McCain and Barack Obama to portray themselves as willing to break with party orthodoxy to get things done, the economic debate that opened their general election campaign this week previews a classic clash. It is a battle between Republican supply-side economics and a Democratic tradition that uses government levers to try to reduce inequality and spur the economy.

headline: India’s Fiscal Gains Offset by Rising Prices
text: NEW DELHI  Since a low-key economic liberalizer named Manmohan Singh became prime minister four years ago, India’s economy has soared by nearly 9 percent a year on average and per capita income is nearly double that of a decade ago.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Apple’s new iPhone models misidentified the location of the headquarters of Gartner, a market research firm. It is based in Stamford, Conn., not San Jose, Calif. (Mike McGuire, a Gartner vice president who commented on Apple’s strategy, is based in San Jose.)

headline: Hope and Doubt Greet Peace Deal in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Peace is no small feat in Somalia, and if the reaction to the accord struck on Monday night is any gauge, peace may still be a long way off.

headline: Access to Primary Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jabbing Begins as Woods Steps Back in the Ring
text: SAN DIEGO  The atmosphere changed at Torrey Pines on Tuesday. With Tiger Woods pronouncing himself “good to go,” but not fully recovered, the pressure and the volume and the hype were ratcheted up, and the event that begins on Thursday took on a feel that was a little more heavyweight championship fight than United States Open championship.

headline: Edamame With Pork, Tomatoes and Parsley
text: Time: 25 minutes

headline: Vegetables and Chicken
text: Time: 30 minutes

headline: Agency Slightly Trims Oil Use Forecast
text: PARIS  Global demand for oil is likely to be slightly lower than previously estimated as the effect of shrinking government subsidies for fuel in Asia softens demand, the International Energy Agency forecast Tuesday.

headline: E.U. Snubs Microsoft on Office Systems
text: BRUSSELS  Competition Commissioner Neelie Kroes of the European Union delivered an unusually blunt snub to Microsoft on Tuesday by recommending that businesses and governments use software based on open standards.

headline: Kerkorian Plans to Increase Stake in Ford
text: DETROIT The financier Kirk Kerkorian said Tuesday that he would increase his stake in Ford Motor Company to 5.5 percent after stockholders offered to sell him nearly half of the automaker’s outstanding shares.

headline: Pairings: A Soy Marinade for Steaks
text: Argentina suggests red meat on the grill. But in many of the malbecs we tasted I found hints of soy sauce, intriguing vegetal flavors and touches of spice. Then why not just add a splash of soy sauce to a green chimichurri?

headline: A Far-Too-Dangerous Business
text: Something is very wrong with how buildings are going up in New York City. After 15 deaths of construction workers and bystanders this year, the city is just beginning to get serious about making construction safety a priority. It must do more to fix not just questionable equipment, but a broken system.

headline: Vatican City: Focus on Islam Criticized
text: A senior Vatican official said that the West had become “obsessed by Islam,” to the detriment of other religions involved in interfaith dialogue. The Roman Catholic Church “has to have regard for all religions,” said the official, Cardinal Jean-Louis Tauran, the president of the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue, in an interview posted on a Web site of The Holy Land Review, which is published by an American church organization.

headline: Guilty Plea Given in Iraq Contract Fraud
text: WASHINGTON  A retired Army colonel who has been a focus of a wide-ranging criminal inquiry into contracting fraud in Iraq pleaded guilty on Tuesday to steering a military contract for warehouses in Iraq to a contractor for $4,000 and a vacation to Thailand.

headline: Mets’ Bullpen to the Rescue in Delay
text: The Mets had an entertaining rain delay Tuesday night at Shea Stadium after the sixth inning of their game against the Diamondbacks. As Pedro Feliciano took the mound as the new relief pitcher for the Mets in the top of the seventh, the grounds crew was on the infield to smooth the dirt of the base paths with brooms.

headline: New Faces on Fox News
text: Still seeking a new format for the 5 p.m. hour, the Fox News Channel will use a rotating series of people in that time slot, beginning next week with the conservative radio host Laura Ingraham, left, the channel announced on Tuesday. Fox appears to be grooming Ms. Ingraham, who often fills in for Bill O’Reilly, as a new host. According to the blog the Radio Equalizer, Ms. Ingraham took a sudden leave of absence from her nationally syndicated radio show last week, apparently because of a contract dispute. Other hosts will have trial runs after her in the weekday slot. Fox’s schedule has been remarkably stable in recent years, helping it maintain consistently high ratings, but it has made several tweaks over the past year. In February it replaced John Gibson, the longtime host at 5 p.m., with an election-oriented show. In another change “The Live Desk With Martha MacCallum” at 1 p.m. will be expanded to two hours and add a co-host, Trace Gallagher. Fox has not determined the new role for E. D. Hill, the current 2 p.m. host.

headline: Favorites Portugal and Czech Republic Look to Move On
text: The two heavyweights in Group A of the European Championship, the Czech Republic and Portugal, both looked good, rather than great, as they won their opening games.

headline: Harsh Words for Microsoft Technology
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union’s competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, delivered an unusually blunt rebuke to Microsoft on Tuesday by recommending that businesses and governments use software based on open standards.

headline: In Germany, Bush Protests Lose Appeal
text: BERLIN  The young anarchists, middle-aged peace activists and established left-wing politicians here have at least one thing in common: none bothered to keep a six-year tradition alive by organizing a protest against President Bush’s arrival here Tuesday.

headline: Evolution and Creationism in Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kelly Declines to Testify
text: R. Kelly told the judge in his child-pornography trial on Tuesday that he did not plan to testify in his own defense, The Associated Press reported. After Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court in Chicago told Mr. Kelly he had a right to decline to testify, he leaned forward at the defense table with his hands folded and  speaking for the first time at the trial  responded, “I decided not to testify.” The defense rested its case on Monday, and the jury was not present to hear Mr. Kelly’s statement. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to charges that he videotaped himself having sex with an underage girl. Mr. Kelly and the woman, said to be the victim, who is now 23, have denied being on the tape. The judge said that closing arguments would probably begin on Thursday.

headline: Bellevue Is Allowed to Medicate Suspect
text: A lawyer for a schizophrenic man accused of killing an Upper East Side psychotherapist tried three times on Tuesday morning to persuade his client to leave his holding cell for a hearing. Each time, the lawyer, Ben Bernstein, got little response from his client, David Tarloff.

headline: 50 Cent Can't Sell Long Island Home
text: A judge has told 50 Cent, left, that he may not dispose of the Long Island property where a $2.4 million house, above, was destroyed by fire two weeks ago, The Associated Press reported. Justice Carol R. Edmead of State Supreme Court in Manhattan also ordered him to put insurance proceeds in a trust account pending the outcome of his dispute with his ex-girlfriend, Shaniqua Tompkins. Ms. Tompkins says 50 Cent, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, promised her a house a decade ago, but recently wanted to evict her and their 10-year-old son, Marquise, from the house in Dix Hills, on Long Island. A fire destroyed the house on May 30. Ms. Tompkins, Marquise and four others were treated for smoke inhalation.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Open Now

headline: Electric Fire Closes One Set of PATH Tracks Through the Evening Rush
text: A fire on the PATH train tracks near the Ninth Street station in Greenwich Village knocked out service between West 33rd Street in Manhattan and New Jersey on Tuesday, snarling the way home for tens of thousands of commuters on a hot and steamy day.

headline: Profits in Hand, Wealthy Family Cuts Tobacco Tie
text: Forty years ago, the New York business magnates Laurence A. Tisch and Preston Robert Tisch capitalized on growing public health concerns over smoking by buying a cigarette company at a bargain price.

headline: XTO Agrees to Buy Hunt Petroleum for $4.2 Billion
text: HOUSTON  XTO Energy agreed on Tuesday to buy the Hunt Petroleum Corporation for nearly $4.2 billion in cash and stock, adding some profitable oil and gas wells to its portfolio. But the deal is also adding fuel to the fire of a family feud embroiling the Texas dynasty founded by the legendary oilman H. L. Hunt.

headline: Union Officials Cleared in Bribery Case
text: A jury on Tuesday acquitted two carpentry union officials of charges that they had taken a bribe.

headline: Lottery Numbers
No Trouble Drawing a Crowd
text: BECAUSE our 8:30 p.m. table at Ago wasn’t ready by 8:51, we were still at the bar when the great wave of white wine crashed over it.

headline: Most Experts Foresee a Repeat, at Least, of 2007 Arctic Ice Loss
text: Fourteen research teams studying the impacts of warming on the Arctic Ocean have issued independent projections of how the sea ice will behave this summer, and 11 of them foresee an ice retreat at least as extraordinary as last year’s or even more dramatic. The other three groups that issued a numerical estimate see the ice extent heading back toward, but not equaling, the average minimum for summers since satellites began tracking the comings and goings of Arctic sea ice in 1979. Five other groups chose not to issue a numerical estimate.

headline: Arsenio Signs With MyNetworkTV
text: Arsenio Hall, best known for his eponymous 1990s late-night talk show, “has been named host of MyNetworkTV’s new comedic clip show, ‘Funniest Moments,'” according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: A Strong ‘Upfront,’ But With Caveats
text: Stuart Elliott’s verdict on the upfront market of TV advertising sales: “It appears, from discussions with network executives and industry analysts, that the broadcasters may have matched the $9.1 billion to $9.2 billion they took in last spring before the start of the 2007-8 season.”

headline: Kent D. Is Still Waiting
text: Kent Desormeaux initially thought he was off the hook this time.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 79 Central Florida
text: Location: Orlando, Fla.

headline: Three Legs, a Big Heart, and a Lot of Fans
text: Molly, a three-legged Shetland pony, survived Hurricane Katrina and a pit bull attack. Now, she’s helping human amputees cope and is advancing the cause of equine medicine.

headline: Madrona Raises $250 Million Fund
text: Madrona Venture Group has raised a $250 million venture fund, the largest in the 13-year history of the Seattle venture capital firm.

headline: Japan’s Daiichi Coughs Up $4.6 Billion for Ranbaxy
text: Japanese drug maker Daiichi Sankyo moved to take majority control of India’s biggest drug maker Ranbaxy Laboratories in a friendly deal worth up to $4.6 billion.

headline: Constellation Uncorks $209 Million Deal With Ascentia
text: Constellation Brands‘ Columbia Winery has been sold along with sister winery Covey Run as part of an eight-winery, $209 million deal with Ascentia Wine Estates, a newly formed private company based in California.

headline: Peloton Founder Said to Prepare New Fund
text: A founder of Peloton Partners, the Britain-based hedge fund group that folded earlier this year, is marketing a new fund to investors, The Financial Times reported, calling it “the latest example of how quickly investors can forgive managers of failed funds.”

headline: PBS Coal Said to Mull $294 Million I.P.O. on Toronto Exchange
text: Soaring commodity prices have triggered an avalanche of coal miners looking to go public in Canada, including a Pennsylvania producer considering a listing that could value the company at about 1 billion Canadian dollars ($981 million), according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: Cracking the Code
text: Clues in the Fifth Avenue apartment of the Klinsky-Sherry family embedded by their architectural designer led them on a scavenger hunt through their home.

headline: Canada’s Precision Drilling Hunts Grey Wolf
text: Precision Drilling Trust, Canada’s largest oil services company, is launching a hostile $1.6 billion bid for U.S. driller Grey Wolf Inc. as it joins the move to tap the booming – and more stable – American energy market.

headline: Vale Plans to Raise $15 Billion in Share Sale, Amid Deal Chatter
text: Brazilian mining giant Vale said Tuesday it was preparing a share offering worth up to $15 billion to help finance organic growth and potential acquisitions, but denied it was in talks on an acquisition.

headline: Perimeter to Acquire Edgeos
text: Perimeter eSecurity, a provider of network security services, said on Tuesday it has acquired security vendor Edgeos for an undisclosed amount to boost the capabilities in its products.

headline: Deconstructing the Bump
text: The affectionate fist bump between Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, before his victory speech last week in St. Paul became an instant source of fascination among commentators in the news media, who for days have tried to decipher the meaning behind this supposedly odd gesture.

headline: UnitedHealth Chief May Have Stronger Ties to Backdating, Report Says
text: Lawyers in a class action suit against UnitedHealth Group say freshly unsealed documents show that the company’s current chief executive, Stephen Hemsley, was more involved in granting backdated options than previously thought, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Peplin Cancels Offering
text: Peplin, a development-stage pharmaceutical company, has canceled its proposed U.S. initial public offering, citing “unfavorable market conditions,” according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

headline: CCS Medical Holdings Pulls I.P.O.
text: Medical supply management company CCS Medical Holdings has canceled its proposed initial public offering of 10 million shares because difficult market conditions, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Monday.

headline: Islamic Buyout Fund Banks $500 Million in New Capital
text: The Middle East is getting another home-grown private equity fund, as the new $500 million Islamic Buyout Fund has received commitments from Global Investment House and Dubai Islamic Bank, according to The Deal.com.

headline: C.F.T.C. to Launch Task Force to Probe Energy Speculation
text: The Commodities Futures Trading Commission said Tuesday that it is establishing a task force to study the role of speculators and index traders in commodities that will include representatives of the Federal Reserve, the Securities Exchange Commission and other agencies.

headline: HSBC Says It May Pull Plug on Korean Bank Deal
text: HSBC said on Wednesday it might consider pulling out of a $6.3 billion deal to buy Korea Exchange Bank , a move analysts say would heap more pressure on South Korean regulators.

headline: Fund Challenges Syms on Real Estate Disclosure
text: An activist investor is accusing Syms Corporation, an off-price clothing retailer whose motto is “an educated consumer is our best customer,” of not being too forthright about its real estate assets.

headline: Investors Rush to Sell Ford Shares to Kerkorian
text: Kirk Kerkorian wasn’t at loss for options Tuesday, as Ford Motor investors rushed to tender their shares after the financier offered to buy 20 million shares of the automaker for $8.50 a piece.

headline: Merrill Trader Said to Jump to Citadel
text: A director in single stocks equity derivatives trading at Merrill Lynch in London has quit and is thought to be joining a hedge fund, amid a trend in which investment bank staff are leaving to join alternative investors or brokers in the hope of greater rewards.

headline: Loews Cuts Lorillard Loose
text: The heirs of Laurence Tisch, who died in 2003, and his brother, Preston Robert Tisch, who died in 2005, controlled an estimated 23 percent of Loews stock before the spinoff of its Lorillard tobacco company on Tuesday.

headline: United Rentals Goes Where Cerberus Wouldn’t
text: Seven months after the $6.6 billion leveraged buyout of United Rentals by Cerberus Capital Management was scuttled, the tool rental company is planning what amounts to its own leveraged buyout.

headline: Abu Dhabi Said to Be in Deal Talks for Stake in Chrysler Building
text: The latest Big Apple trophy being coveted by oil-rich sovereign wealth funds is the landmark Chrysler Building, according to The New York Post.

headline: Investors Bailed From Hedge Funds in April
text: Investors withdrew a net amount of nearly $6 billion from hedge funds in April, according to a report from TrimTabs Investment Research and BarclayHedge. It was the first time in more than two years that outflows outpaced inflows, according to Financial News; Reuters said it was the largest outflow in six and a half years. Either way, it suggested investors were not happy with the returns they were seeing.

headline: ‘Having an Affair With Bill’
text: More of your standup comedy (send via the comment link below):

headline: Maybe the Devil Does Wear Prada …
text: … or else someone can’t spell:

headline: Merrill Chief Campaigns for Reserve Window
text: Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, John Thain, on Tuesday said he would like to see broker-dealer access to the Federal Reserve discount window continue longer term, though any increase of regulation in exchange must be appropriate for securities firms.

headline: Is There a Deal in Lehman’s Future?
text: With its latest $6 billion capital-raising plan, Lehman Brothers seemed to have staved off a panic along the lines of the one that forced Bear Stearns into an emergency sale.

headline: Cerberus Not Second-Guessing Chrysler Deal
text: The chief executive of Chrysler, Robert Nardelli, said on Tuesday that the private equity buyers of auto maker Chrysler weren’t second guessing their decision to buy Chrysler, and that the business was ahead of target.

headline: Sarcasm Is Really Helpful
text: Last week the Times alerted you to the science of sarcasm. Now we find this insightful Wikipedia entry called “Sarcasm is really helpful”:

headline: Staples Wins Corporate Express for $2.65 Billion
text: Staples, the office goods supplier, won approval from Corporate Express on Wednesday to take over the Dutch firm with a sweetened 1.7 billion euro ($2.65 billion) bid.

headline: E.U. to Investigate Italian Aid to Alitalia
text: European Union regulators said Wednesday that they would investigate whether Italy’s rescue loan to ailing national airline Alitalia is illegal, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Pandit Calls for Debate on Financial Regulations
text: Citigroup‘s chief executive, Vikram Pandit, on Tuesday called for a “vigorous” debate on regulatory oversight as the crisis in the financial services industry continues, Dow Jones Newswires reported.

headline: The (Don’t Call Her That) Lady Is About To Sing
text: Big news from the opera world: The soprano Deborah Voigt’s returning to the London production she was fired from in 2004 because the director considered her too heavy to wear a sleek black cocktail dress. The ensuing uproar is now famous, and revenge is sweet, as she pokes fun in this video:

headline: Yahoo and Icahn Spar Over Severance Plan
text: Yahoo‘s war of words with Carl Icahn keeps heating up.

headline: Iraq Closeup: Looking Back at Three Iraqi Victories
text: A closer look at our coverage on Iraq.

headline: Job creation?
text: Dean Baker is upset at a news report suggesting that John McCain — unlike Barack Obama! — is concerned with job creation.

headline: Going Hyper Over Gas Mileage
text: With average gasoline prices hitting a record $4 a gallon, drivers are increasingly looking for ways to cut fuel costs.

headline: Post Post post post post
text: Pointless post: this story made me think of the example Stephen Pinker gives of a grammatical but incomprehensible sentence:

headline: The Early Word: Of Veeps and Vetters
text: The speculation over who the two presumptive nominees will tap as their running mate is heating up as the media and the opposing campaign place more scrutiny, not only on the field of potential vice presidential contenders, but also on the campaign operatives who are combing through their resumes.

headline: Webby Winners
text: The Webby Awards were handed out last night in downtown Manhattan. Some of the comedy winners have been featured here before, like these two (others can’t be featured here, ever). First, The Onion reporting on just what paranoid schizophrenics need — help from the government …

headline: New iPhone Pricing Model Is a Step Backward for Consumers
text: Of all the research reports written about the debut of Apple’s new $199 iPhone this week, one written by Craig Moffett of Sanford C. Bernstein was particularly notable: He warned that the cheaper iPhone is really a step back, not a step forward, for open networks.

headline: PBS Goes Commercial on Hulu
text: In the world of broadcasting, PBS shuns commercials. On the Internet, things are different.

headline: The Heat Abates, but Just a Bit
text: It’s hot! (We tell you, as if you haven’t noticed yourself.) But a small measure of relief may be in sight.

headline: Obama’s Long Short List, Part II
text: Perhaps none of the folks being considered for the Democrats’ No. 2 slot is as intriguing as Jim Webb, the former Reagan Navy secretary turned Virginia senator. Now a few in the blogosphere are trying to derail that train before it leaves the station. David Mark of the Politico feels Webb has a problematic sense of nostalgia:

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by William Gibson
text: William Gibson’s most recent novel is “Spook Country.”

headline: Geometries | Loew’s Jersey Theater
text: The Loew’s Jersey Theater in Jersey City was once threatened with demolition but has been brought back to life through renovation.

headline: Neither Fish Nor Fowl
text: The private equity implosion has cast dubious light on the optionality inherent in private equity agreements. Many commentators, including myself, thought that the repeated invocation of these provisions by private equity firms last fall and in the new year would lead targets to demand firmer, less optional agreements from their private equity acquirers.

headline: Poll Shows Obama Leading McCain in New York
text: Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, has pulled even among white voters in New York State with Senator John McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, and now has a commanding overall lead over Mr. McCain, 50 percent to 36 percent, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released on Wednesday. The survey suggests that New York remains a securely blue state, notwithstanding disappointment over the defeat of its home state senator, Hillary Rodham Clinton, by Mr. Obama in the Democratic nominating contests.

headline: Circling Back: dell’Anima
text: Over the last few months several people whose opinions I respect have told me about positive experiences at dell’Anima, an Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village that hadn’t impressed me so much right after it opened late last year. In a prior blog post I described a meal I had there in its early days.

headline: Common Sleep Problem Linked With Memory Loss
text: The part of the brain that stores memory appears to shrink in people with sleep apnea, adding further evidence that the sleep and breathing disorder is a serious health threat.

headline: Our Weekend Plans, Laid Out 150 Years Ago
text: “It is the most important work of American art of the 19th century,” Sara Cedar Miller said.

headline: Silverjet Agrees to Sell Itself to Swiss-Owned Firm
text: The collapsed business class airline Silverjet plans to be back in the skies within weeks after its administrators accepted a buyout offer from a Swiss investment firm.

headline: In Europe, Bush Repeats a Regret on Iraq: His Tone
text: Although critics like to portray President Bush as unyielding, his steadfast opposition to the view held by many Americans that the Iraq war a mistake is not without caveats. There were mistakes made — or at least one that he acknowledged during his last swing through Europe as president.

headline: Horse Wear
text: I promised one of our most loyal readers and posters, Dan from South Baltimore, that I’d give a shout out to his new T-shirt and hat business. It’s good stuff for horse enthusiasts. Check it out.

headline: Medical Marijuana Links
text: We’ve been discussing the presidential candidates’ positions on medical marijuana. Here are a couple of other interesting reports on the subject:

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Talavera
text: Aurora Lopez Mejia’s Amulet ring and her 18k gold Eternity handcuffs (Shuli Hallak).

headline: Rhetoric: From Zimbabwe to Myanmar
text: BRIEFS As his struggle against President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe continues, Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader, has begun to embrace a old term most often associated of late with Myanmar’s reclusive government: “This country is effectively now run by a military junta,” he said. Whether this rhetorical shift helps matters on the ground remains to be seen, though South Africa’s leader, a key player in the region, voiced “serious concern” on the violent situation there hours later.

headline: Less Sex and Candy
text: BRIEFS From this morning’s USA Today, two items that demonstrate the impressive willpower of today’s young people. One survey found that virginity pledges are working for some teenagers, and another declared that cookies and candy were losing out to fruit as the most popular treats for children under 6.

headline: A Sideshow, Predictable and Silly
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Some Still Don’t Have Power After Storm
text: Updated, 5:10 p.m. | The heat wave may have ended, but utilities around the region were still grappling with power failures on Wednesday, thanks to the thunderstorm that blew through the region on Tuesday night. Con Edison had more than 500 power failures, while P.S.E.&G. in New Jersey was struggling get power to tens of thousands of residents. By 2 p.m., P.S.E.&G. had restored power to 120,000 of its customers and was working to repair service to another 87,000 customers in Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Passaic Counties.

headline: The Battle for CSX
text: CNBC's David Faber takes a look at the proxy battle at CSX, the railroad operator, as it fights off a challenge from a hedge fund.

headline: The Insider | Patrick Li
text: Patrick Li is our tastemaker of the week. (Sophia Kokosalaki)

headline: Welcome to the Cult
text: 25 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: an indoor interval class at Cadence Cycling in Manhattan, with the bike on a CompuTrainer, allowing me to work with an awareness of the power output of every pedal stroke.

headline: ‘Infinitesimal’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC:  Barack Obama said his differences with Hillary Clinton are “infinitesimal, tiny, minute, trivial and inconsequential.” When he heard this, President Bush said, “That guy knows way too many words to be president.”

headline: Answers About Mass Transit, Part 2
text: This is the second set of answers from Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign. This week he answered selected City Room readers’ questions about improving New York City’s public transportation, where the city stands on congestion pricing and concerns about the subways and buses. We are sorry; we are no longer taking questions for this feature.

headline: ‘Hillary May Secretly Be Glad’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: You know, I’ll tell you, things are not good. The price of oil doubled in less than a year. Home foreclosures are at a record high. Unemployment is surging. But yesterday, we saw a ray of hope. President Bush left the country. So maybe things will get better.

headline: Beauty Call | Crashing Banana Republic’s Fragrance Luncheon
text: Goodie bags for all at the Banana Republic luncheon. (Patrick McMullan)

headline: Where Are All Those Priuses?
text: As longtime Pogue’s Posts readers know, I’m a huge Toyota Prius nut. We bought ours in 2004, and have derived ridiculous amounts of pleasure from its 45 m.p.g. average, its high-tech smarts (keep the key in your pocket—it unlocks for you automatically!), its incredible reliability (No. 1 in its category in Consumer Reports) and its roominess for our family of five.

headline: Rebuilding ‘Greensburg’
text: On May 4, 2007, an F5 tornado devastated the town of Greensburg, Kansas. Ninety-five percent of the town was wiped off the map and eleven people were killed.

headline: Julie Andrews’s Bliss
text: “Home,” the well-received new memoir by Julie Andrews, pulls back the curtains on her early years, before Hollywood and her megamusicals. It’s an honest book, but it’s no sloppy tell-all. The famously composed Ms. Andrews serves up her revelations with discretion, and even the ruder bits seldom stray far beyond the safe territory of the talk-show couch.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Radish Salad
text: Radish salad is something you see in various places around the world, but only rarely in the States. Once radishes are salted they can be dressed with a traditional vinaigrette — or the more tropical (and oil-less) version here.

headline: The Charitable Side of Hedge Funds
text: Hedge fund managers are better known for making money — scads of it — than for giving it away.

headline: Who Is a Public Intellectual?
text: Daniel W. Drezner, a political economist at Tufts University and a veteran blogger, has posted a provocative essay about public intellectuals on his site. He argues that contrary to what has become the conventional wisdom, there has not been a decline in the quality of American intellectual life from the postwar glory days of Lionel Trilling, Edmund Wilson, Mary McCarthy and others who constituted the circle now known as the New York Intellectuals. Drezner goes on to list a battalion of contemporary public intellectuals to prove his point, everyone from Barbara Ehrenreich to Tom Wolfe to Samuel Huntington.

headline: For Networks, Is Content Replacing Creativity?
text: In the broadcast television business, “level” is the new “up,” writes Frazier Moore of the Associated Press. Noting that NBC has said “the audience is returning to the familiar right now,” he wonders whether the industry has been zapped of its creativity:

headline: The Energy Bug
text: Energy | Craig Venter, the scientist who decoded the human genome faster and more cheaply than a well-funded government team, has a new ambition: an “energy bug—a bacterium that will ingest CO2, sunlight and water, and spew out liquid fuel.” “I envision maybe a million micro-refineries,” he says. — Newsweek

headline: Winning Back Women
text: A new daily tracking poll by Gallup shows that Senator Barack Obama has pulled ahead of Senator John McCain in the last week, thanks largely to women who have turned to Mr. Obama since Senator Hillary Clinton ended her campaign last week.

headline: Cutting Down on Meat
text: When I was in Paris last week I made the trip to Brussels to meet an anti-meat activist from the Netherlands, Niko Koffeman, and his wife, Antoinette Hertsenberg. Mr. Koffeman is a senator in the Dutch parliament, representing the Party for the Animals (humans count, by the way). Ms. Hertsenberg’s popularity as a television personality in the Netherlands is akin to that of Oprah here. (About a third of the Dutch people watching television during her Monday night time slot are tuned to her program.)

headline: The Webbys in Five Words: Cynical, Campy, Goofy, Hot, Long
text: Imagine someone created an award ceremony for every possible use of paper, with awards for the best supermarket tabloid, the most disingenuous autobiography by a former government official, the most comprehensive bibliography and the best folding for a paper airplane.

headline: Prices Are 100 Years Old. The Sturgeon Is Fresh.
text: Barney Greengrass, the sturgeon institution whose customers over the last century have included Franklin D. Roosevelt and Jerry Seinfeld, is celebrating by bringing back 1908 prices just for today for eat-in customers.

headline: The Starting Line: Her Kingdom for a Horse
text: Bad news for Royals fans: Queen Elizabeth’s granddaughter, Zara Phillips, is out of the Olympics. Phillips was on the British equestrian team and headed to Beijing, but today it was announced that her horse, Toytown, is injured and will not be able to compete. That means another horse-and-rider combination will take their place.

headline: Campaign Conversations: Barack Obama
text: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC interviews Senator Barack Obama about gas prices, taxes, housing and other economic issues.

headline: Golf Cart Injuries Are on the Rise
text: Golf carts are moving off the golf course, and the result appears to be a surge in injuries, a new report shows.

headline: Rwanda as an Example of the Dangers of Climate Change
text: Global warming could have a devastating effect on parts of the world with especially large, impoverished populations to feed. In Africa, global warming is expected to bring more desertification and reductions in available arable land. In India and China, the effects are expected to be severe water shortages and reduced capacity for irrigation. Rising sea levels could inundate many coastal towns and cities and provoke mass migrations.

headline: Desormeaux Speaks With Stewards
text: Big Brown’s jockey Kent Desormeaux met with racing stewards at Belmont Park on Wednesday to talk about his controversial ride, and eventual surrender in the 140th running of the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Nervous Democrats? Dean Is ‘Delighted’
text: If Democrats are a little worried about their general election prospects against a seasoned candidate like Senator John McCain, it’s just fine with Howard Dean.

headline: Off the Hot Seat: What Now? That’s Cool!
text: So it’s not exactly cool out there — 81 degrees in Central Park at 11 a.m., 80 at La Guardia Airport and indisputably hot compared with the 48-degree reading in Anchorage at the same time. But it is cooler than it was in New York on Monday or Tuesday, and it feels — although not quite like Alaska — less like a giant steam bath.

headline: Brookings on the Marshall Plan
text: While President Bush is in Europe marking the 60th anniversary of the postwar Marshall Plan, the Brookings Institution takes a bow as its intellectual author. — Brookings Institution

headline: C.D.C.’s Most Dangerous Outdoor Sports
text: On Tuesday, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a study of serious injuries — those that require a trip to the emergency room — stemming from outdoor sports and recreational pursuits. Included in the study was a list of the sports that account for the most injuries seen in 2004 and 2005 at the 63 hospitals across the country whose statistics were included in the study.

headline: Adventures in Equal Parenting
text: Marc and Amy Vachon have built their lives around a philosophy of splitting everything down the middle.

headline: The Morning Skate: Trevor Linden’s Legacy, and the Coaching Carousel Spins
text: Lidstrom, Osgood and the trophy purchased by Frederick Arthur Stanley, on Leno.

headline: U.S.A. Basketball: No Need for Tryouts?
text: Officials with USA Basketball have announced that there will be no tryouts for the 12-man Olympic roster, as originally planned. Instead, the roster will be announced during the NBA final, in advance of its training camp later this month in Las Vegas.

headline: BlackRock on the Markets' Health
text: BlackRock's chief executive, Larry Fink, talks with CNBC's Maria Bartiromo about Lehman Brothers and what investors should consider.

headline: Governor Cuomo? Mayor Cuomo?
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo is riding fairly high in Democratic circles these days, coasting in his current job and a frequent topic of speculation in the 2010 governor’s race and in an article on Wednesday in The New York Sun about the mayor’s race.

headline: Quote Unquote | Office Space
text: — Pamela Constable in the June 11 Washington Post on what it’s like to be a lawyer in Pakistan (when not on the front lines of protest, that is). Your cubicle’s starting to look pretty good now, isn’t it?

headline: Emptied Mediterranean – Sharks Nearly Gone
text: Several ecologically-important shark populations in the Mediterranean Sea have completely collapsed, according to a new study, with numbers of five species now more than 96 percent below what existed two centuries ago.
