headline: You Built an Electric Car … Out of a DeLorean?
text: The DeLorean Car Show this weekend in Gettysburg, Pa., will probably bring out many different examples of the much beloved stainless steel car, from pristine restorations to the requisite B.T.T.F. (that’s “Back to the Future”) time machine conversions. But the most interesting car at the biannual event could be an electric DeLorean, built by Dave Delman out of his garage in Jericho, N.Y.

headline: Late Delivery of the 2 World Trade Center Site
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday that it is running more than a month behind schedule in delivering the site of Tower 2 at the new World Trade Center to the developer, Silverstein Properties. The authority will pay Silverstein a $300,000 daily penalty, beginning July 1, until the site can be turned over fully excavated, some time in August.

headline: The Webb Formula
text: Politics | Are the Scots-Irish the key to the White House? That’s the sort of thinking behind the buzz for Senator Jim Webb of Virginia as Obama’s running mate. Webb’s Appalachian roots “lie in exactly the area in which Obama has shown his greatest weakness so far.” — New York Review of Books

headline: What Did Ken Lewis Say Last Night?
text: Meredith Whitney, the outspoken banking analyst from Oppenheimer & Company, shared a meal Tuesday night with Bank of America boss Kenneth D. Lewis, along with a few buy-side clients. Among the topics on the table at the dinner, held at an upscale restaurant in New York’s Upper East Side, were the bank’s acquisition of Countrywide Financial, future mergers and the fate of the bank’s dividend.

headline: Jason and the Obamanauts
text: OK, this furor over Jason Furman’s appointment is silly, on two levels.

headline: Milestones: Who’s Next to 600, 500 and 300?
text: For all the talk of asterisks and illegitimate statistics over the last decade, baseball is still very much a game of numbers. And with Ken Griffey Jr.’s recent entrance into the 600-homer club (an event not without its own wierd dispute), we offer a look at some of the other candidates to join baseball’s still-exclusive fraternities.

headline: Obama Dials Back the Pace of Events
text: CHICAGO – Continuing his leisurely pace of campaigning since he nailed down the Democratic presidential nomination last week, Senator Barack Obama held an hour-long discussion with three Chicagoans about their problems with credit card debt and surprised a girls’ school eighth-grade graduation ceremony with an unplanned appearance that brought shrieks of joy.

headline: Obama’s Top Vetter Resigns
text: James A. Johnson, a leading member of the vice-presidential search team for Senator Barack Obama, quit his post with the campaign today after he and the campaign came under sustained Republican fire in the last several days for several favorable loans he had received.

headline: Princely Monaco, on a Pauper’s Budget
text: Monaco, the richest 0.76 square miles on the Mediterranean, is not exactly the Frugal Traveler’s kingdom. This independent principality is synonymous with money — big, untaxed money — and ways of spending it: fast cars, luxury goods, gourmet meals and high-stakes gambling. That was apparent even on the five-hour train ride from Montpellier (41.60 euros, or about $67 at $1.61 to the euro; www.voyages-sncf.com) along thegorgeous French Riviera. Instead of backpacks and sandals, my well-tanned fellow passengers were armed with Louis Vuitton handbags and Gucci sunglasses.

text: Mike Wallace, the veteran correspondent for “60 Minutes,” has appeared on the show sporadically since he retired two years ago. But health problems have gotten in the way, and he probably will not be returning to the air anytime soon, according to U.S. News and World Report.

headline: Young and Good
text: So there’s this player for Portugal. He’s going to be a good one. You heard it here first. His name is Cristiano Ronaldo, or something. He has a few strengths like running fast, dribbling, passing and scoring that, down the road, will enable him to perform well on a soccer field. A hint of this was on display today in Portugal’s victory over the Czech Republic in the European championships.

headline: How College Entrance Exams Shortened the Olympic Torch Relay
text: China’s annual college entrance exam, known as the gaokao (高考), took place this past weekend, affecting millions of Chinese students as well as the Olympic torch relay. According to Xinhua news agency, both the route and the timetable of the torch relay were adjusted on Sunday in order to minimize disturbance on the examinees in Baise, a city in southwestern China’s Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region.

headline: Buildings Commissioner, Ousted but Lauded
text: Patricia J. Lancaster, the former Department of Buildings commissioner, got the kind of warm sendoff on Monday that was missing last month when she was unceremoniously forced out of her job by City Hall.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Confirms $46.4 Billion InBev Offer
text: Anheuser-Busch confirmed on Wednesday that it has received a $46.4 billion takeover offer from Belgium’s InBev, in what would be a union of two of the largest beer brewers in the world. (Read InBev’s letter to Anheuser-Busch here.)

headline: Benign Neglect
text: Context isn’t everything in politics, but it’s an awful lot. President George W. Bush has been credited with creating an environment so inhospitable to fellow Republicans that Barack Obama is now the front-runner in the race for the White House. But the president has had a hand in creating another context favorable to Mr. Obama — one that has lent Mr. Obama’s claim to racial transcendence a more generous hearing than many expected it would receive. This one has been a long time coming.

headline: Weather for Hoses, Not Hosiery
text: This past week I had plenty of moments where I reveled in the ability to work from home, mostly because it allowed me to save time worrying about what to wear during New York’s unexpected heat wave. The basic problem is that anything that made sense for being outside or underground in the subway would not be warm enough once I reached an air-conditioned destination. I probably could have written three blog posts in the time it took me to figure out what to wear to the few meetings I had outside my home office.

headline: Iraq Closeup: Who Decides When U.S. Troops Leave?
text: The question of when to end the American military presence in Iraq is, of course, a central issue in the presidential campaign and is assumed to be the No. 1 foreign policy issue awaiting either Barack Obama or John McCain when one or the other moves into the Oval Office next year.

The topic of her “Notebook” segment is the coverage of Senator Hillary Clinton’s candidacy but listeners may wonder if it might also be about coverage of the first solo female anchor of an evening news broadcast.

text: As Michael Cieply wrote in the paper earlier this week, “Films With Limited Release Find a Home on the Web.” Cieply’s excellent story is about Reframe, a platform for films with limited circulation.

headline: Horsemanship and Horse Racing
text: I have to be careful writing about jockeys and riding as I still do veterinary regulatory racetrack work from time to time representing the horses and jockeys safety and welfare on race day. I try to stay out of debates involving riding strategy, so as not to have jockeys lose confidence in me should I happen to perform regulatory work at their track in the future. In order to effectively carry out regulatory duties, veterinarians have to maintain trusting working relationships with the jockeys. On the other hand, proper horsemanship is essential for horse racing safety, and regulatory veterinarians are certainly responsible for that.

headline: Rodney King to Appear On VH1’s ‘Celebrity Rehab’
text: Associated Press: “Rodney King will appear in the next installment of VH1’s ‘Celebrity Rehab With Dr. Drew.’ The show features famous people dealing with drug and alcohol problems aided by celebrity addiction specialist Dr. Drew Pinsky.”

headline: Jeff Francoeur: The Brave Who Loves the Packers

text: One of the biggest nonstories of this season has been the reception for Andy Pettitte in visiting ballparks after a winter of dealing with his place in the Roger Clemens steroids saga. In two words: nobody cares.

headline: Sharks Hire Todd McLellan as Coach
text: The San Jose Sharks hired Detroit Red Wings assistant coach Todd McLellan to be their head coach today, bringing in a leader with Stanley Cup-winning credentials to replace the fired Ron Wilson, who yesterday took the Toronto Maple Leafs job.

headline: Your Suggestions for Obama’s Speech on Gender
text: My Thursday column is about the speech that Barack Obama should give about women in leadership. I offer him a few helpful talking points — please offer yours below, or just warn him off mine….

headline: Psychic kids
text: So, you get through grad school. You do research that gets lot of citations. You get tenure. You branch out into policy work, and into writing for a broader audience. You try to play a role in the important economic debates. And finally, you really hit the big time — you’re debating the economy on Larry King, with who knows how many people watching.

headline: Godless
text: This Father's Day, one of most popular pastors in America will open his megachurch to homosexual dads, an event that would usually signal an extreme weather alert from old guard Republican evangelical leaders.  (Photo: Rick Warren. (Credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images for Meet the Press)) But by welcoming gay fathers into his Southern California flock, Rick Warren, author of the "The Purpose Driven Life," is not just living up to the highest standards of Christian fellowship, he's turning the page on a particularly embarrassing part of our politics.   Just to refresh: it was televangelist Pat Robertson who predicted "earthquakes, tornadoes and possibly even a meteor" would hit Orlando for inviting gays to Disney World, and Rev. John Hagee who blamed Hurricane Katrina on a vengeful God angered over a gay pride parade in New Orleans. And they did this even without Doppler radar.   The fact that these people were taken seriously about anything other than, say, what color socks to wear on bingo night, tells us something about how far we've strayed rom the pulpit into the town square.   Over the last 30 years, church and state have become far more entangled than any of our fair-minded founders and their better successors -- including some chiseled on Mount Rushmore -- envisioned.   The good tidings from Warren's Saddleback Church come at a time when Barack Obama has ditched his incendiary ex-preacher, and John McCain has separated himself from the apocalyptical Hagee.   It's a start, but how about a clean break? Let's go Godless for the rest of the campaign.  I know, it's not going to happen, with Obama courting evangelicals this week and McCain trying to figure what makes Catholics in the Rust Belt tick.   But for a moment, imagine no religion, as John Lennon sang.   Forty-eight years ago an Irish Catholic presidential candidate said this about a bedrock principle of his:  "I believe in an America where the separation of church and state is absolute."  And, "I believe in a president whose views on religion are his own private affair."  That was John F. Kennedy, of course, sounding light years removed from Mitt Romney, who declared this year that "freedom requires religion," and Mike Huckabee, who called himself a "Christian leader" and advocated amending the Constitution to follow Biblical principles. Both men are being touted as running mates for McCain.  "Where we are today is almost the antithesis of Kennedy's time," said David Domke, a professor of communications at the University of Washington and co-author, with Kevin Coe, of "The God Strategy: How Religion Became a Political Weapon in America."   Not so long ago, politicians could talk about national defense or currency fluctuations without having to mention Him. But since 1980, the total number of references to God in major presidential speeches has jumped 120 percent over the preceding half-century, Domke and Coe found.   "It's the verbal equivalent of an American flag lapel pin: few notice if you do it, but many notice if you don't," Domke and Coe wrote in a recent essay in Time. Domke, by the way, is no tweedy secularist; his wife is a Presbyterian minister.   Obama has been the more overtly God-centric candidate in this campaign, perhaps because of the whispers that falsely paint him as a Muslim, or interchangeable blondes on Fox News who interpret playful hand gestures with his spouse as "a terrorist fist jab," as E.D. Hill said on air.  At a meeting with prominent Christian leaders on Tuesday, Obama discussed his "personal journey of faith," as one participant recounted. That, alone, goes against Kennedy's dictum of keeping it private.   Teddy Roosevelt, a McCain hero, was prescient on this point as well. He argued against putting, "In God We Trust," on the currency in 1907, saying it cheapens the divine. "It not only does no good," he wrote, "but it does positive harm."  (Photo: Ted Haggard. (Credit: AP Photo/Erik Stenbakken, New Life Church)) To their credit, some ministers have learned from their fallen fellows of the cloth. Four years ago, Ted Haggard's phone number was on speed dial at the White House, and he regularly boasted of his political clout as head of the 30-million-member National Association of Evangelicals.   Then came his admission of patronizing a gay prostitute and buying crystal methamphetamine, a two-fer in the hypocrisy sweepstakes. It also made for one the strangest images on television -- a smiling Haggard in his S.U.V., with wife and kids, talking about meth and massages from a buff male escort.   On the plus side, Pastor Ted is now welcome at Rick Warren's church on Sunday.  Joel Osteen, the feel-good Texas optimist who is perhaps the nation's most popular minister, and Warren have both disavowed politics this year. They will not endorse a candidate, allow politics in the service, or issue thinly disguised election "guidelines," hint, hint.   Bless 'em.   Now let the politicians pick up the cue, following advice of one of Teddy Roosevelt's Rushmore face mates.  "Say nothing of my religion," said Thomas Jefferson. "It's known to my God and myself alone."  **********  POSTSCRIPT: Following news of the plan by gay fathers to attend Saddleback Church this coming Sunday, the church's pastor, Rev. Rick Warren, has issued a statement clarifying the church's role. "We did not invite this group, and I will not be meeting with them," he said, adding that he had a previous commitment and would not be in church on Sunday.

headline: On TV, The Housing Market Is Still Booming
text: Amid a collapsing housing market, television shows that were hallmarks of the bubble — like “Flip That House” (on TLC) and “Flip This House” (on A&E) — are still attracting viewers. But the “shelter shows” popularized by TLC and HGTV are less about real estate as a speculative sport now, and more about the emotions of the home-buying experience.

headline: Random Thoughts on the Oakland A’s
text: With the Yankees trailing, 6-1, early on Wednesday, there’s a lot of time to look around this ballpark and blog about the Philadelphia-Kansas City-Oakland Athletics.

headline: Sunny Soriano Will Miss Six Weeks
text: About 75 minutes before the Cubs and Braves played at Wrigley Field on Wednesday night, I saw Alfonso Soriano in the Chicago clubhouse. Soriano was sitting by himself at a long table, eating yogurt.

headline: BP Says Talks With Venture Investors Continue
text: LONDON  The dispute between the oil giant BP and its partners in the Russian joint venture TNK-BP escalated on Wednesday when the two parties could not even agree to be on talking terms with each other and one threatened legal action.

headline: Mystery on Fifth Avenue
text: THINGS are not as they seem in the 14th-floor apartment on upper Fifth Avenue. At first blush the family that occupies it looks to be very much of a type. The father, Steven B. Klinsky, 52, runs a private equity company; the mother, Maureen Sherry, 44, left her job as a managing director for Bear Stearns to raise their four young children (two boys and two girls); and the dog, LuLu, is a soulful Lab mix rescued from a pound in Louisiana.

headline: Harry Potter Prequel Goes for $61 a Word
text: An 800-word handwritten prequel to the “Harry Potter” series by J. K. Rowling was sold for nearly $49,000, or just over $61 a word, on Tuesday at an auction for charity in a London bookstore, The Associated Press reported. The story, on both sides of a sheet of A5 paper (about 5 7/8 by 8 1/4 inches), was auctioned at the flagship store of the Waterstone’s chain to benefit a dyslexia charity and the English branch of PEN, the writers’ association. In addition to Ms. Rowling, right, 12 writers and illustrators contributed short stories on cards, including the novelists Doris Lessing, Nick Hornby and Margaret Atwood and the playwright Tom Stoppard, whose mystery story sold for more than $7,000. Copies of the cards are on display in Waterstone’s stores and online at Waterstones.com, and will be collected into a book available in August.

headline: Green Jackets, Not Gold Medals
text: The image of Tiger Woods standing on a podium with an Olympic gold medal around his neck probably inspires heavy breathing among golf officials and some Olympic executives, but the bet here is that we'll never see it , nor should we. The start of the United States Open today at Torrey Pines, with all the anticipation about Woods's return from knee surgery and his pairing with Phil Mickelson, is a perfect reminder that major championships provide the most valid and respected measuring sticks in golf, and that the renewed effort to make it an Olympic sport is a fool's errand.

headline: Court Rejects Decisions of Immigration Board
text: In a scathing opinion, a federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday that immigration judges and the appellate system established as a check on their decisions committed “obvious errors” by denying asylum to three Guinean women who claimed that they were victims of genital cutting back in Africa.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Wednesday about the violinist Jenny Scheinman erroneously included a Web site for online purchases of her new album, “Crossing the Field,” which is due out in the fall. While the album can be downloaded now from Internet digital retailers, and is on the Koch label, it cannot be bought at kochentertainment.com.

headline: Pirates Terrorize Nigeria’s Fishing Fleet
text: LAGOS, Nigeria  Early this year, the crew members of the Mareena 1 fishing trawler had just finished hauling in their catch 15 miles off the coast and were settling into their bunks for a few hours of sleep when they were awakened by machine-gun fire.

headline: Officials Broaden Focus of Inquiry Into Corruption in Crane Inspections
text: The authorities have widened their criminal investigation of potential corruption inside the Department of Buildings’ crane inspection operations to focus on several current and former agency employees who had responsibilities in that area, a law enforcement official involved in the inquiry said on Wednesday.

headline: Up Next, a Show From Our Sponsor
text: DECADES after advertisers produced TV series like “Schlitz Playhouse of Stars” and viewers watched Barbara Walters and Ed McMahon deliver Alpo commercials on “Today” and “The Tonight Show,” marketers of beer and pet food are developing programs that are centered on their products.

headline: Evolution and the Facts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oceangoing Anglers May Have to Register
text: WASHINGTON  The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is proposing a rule that would require recreational anglers and spearfishers who fish in federal ocean waters to join a national registry.

headline: Union Critical of Obama’s Top Economics Aide
text: Acting quickly after securing his party’s presidential nomination, Barack Obama picked a well-known representative of Bill Clinton’s economic policies as his economic policy director and signaled this week that the major players from the Clinton economics team were now in his camp  starting with Robert E. Rubin.

headline: The Day New York Found That Its Fever Had Broken
text: It was not exactly cold out on Wednesday  84 degrees in Central Park at 6 p.m., 85 at La Guardia Airport. But New York was cooler than it was on Monday or Tuesday, and it felt less like a giant, hair-frizzing, shirt-ruining steam bath, the kind of thing Ethel Merman or Marilyn Monroe sang about  take your pick  “We’re having a heat wave, a tropical heat wave.”

headline: Lieberman Seeks Limits to Reduce Speculation
text: A prominent Washington lawmaker said Wednesday that he would propose next week to ban large institutional investors, including index funds, from the nation’s booming commodity markets.

headline: A Justice Orders a Pay Raise for New York’s Judges
text: Weighing in on a longstanding tug of war between New York’s jurists and lawmakers, a State Supreme Court justice ordered the Legislature on Wednesday to give the state’s 1,250 judges their first pay raise in 10 years.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Saturday, about Big Brown, incorrectly described the disciplinary record of his trainer, Rick Dutrow. An Association of Racing Commissioners International report lists 72 rulings involving more than 50 offenses by Dutrow, not 72 offenses.

headline: Terror Bill Passes Narrowly in Britain
text: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown faced down a revolt within his governing Labor Party on Wednesday, winning a precariously narrow victory in the House of Commons for a measure that among other things would allow the authorities to hold terrorism suspects for up to 42 days without charges.

headline: Interrogation for Profit
text: Congress is finally moving to ban one of the Bush administration’s most blatant evasions of accountability in Iraq  the outsourcing of war detainees’ interrogation to mercenary private contractors.

headline: An Imitator That Rivals the iPhone
text: The story so far: Apple introduced the iPhone a year ago, and has sold six million of them. Then on Monday, Apple unveiled an improved model that brings faster Internet, G.P.S. and a much lower price to an already well-designed device.

headline: What Women Want (Maybe)
text: LADIES! Behold the splendor of the nude male form: sleek and powerful, a miracle of sculpted sinew, striding confidently across the sand or stretching out before you in ever-uncoiling glory.

headline: Corrections
text: Sports

headline: Nepal: Deposed King Leaves Palace
text: The world’s last Hindu king, Gyanendra of Nepal, turned in his scepter and bird-of-paradise plumed crown, and he announced that he would live as a commoner, accepting the will of the country’s new Maoist-led government. Nepal became a republic last month and Gyanendra, now known as Gyanendra Shah, had been given about two weeks to vacate the Narayanhiti Palace in Katmandu, the capital. He left for a smaller summer palace outside the capital. The palace is to be turned into a museum.

headline: Credibility Gap?
text: The charges by a former N.B.A. referee that the league used its referees to manipulate the outcomes of games has rocked the sport and put the league on the defensive. Do you believe the charges, and if so, how serious a blow is it to the league's credibility. If you don't believe them, why not?

headline: Bill to Extend Jobless Benefits Stalls in House
text: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday narrowly defeated a plan to provide added unemployment aid for Americans whose benefits are running out after Republicans, bolstered by a White House veto threat, opposed the measure.

headline: Building a Better Ankle
text: Bionic ankles dominated the chatter coming from the latest annual meeting of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, especially a study that followed more than 5,000 ankle-surgery patients in California over the course of 10 years, including those who have had complete ankle-joint replacement.

headline: Video Draws Attention to Growing Violence Against Minorities in Russia
text: MOSCOW  Shamil U. Odamanov used to call his parents almost daily from Moscow, where he worked as a laborer after moving from his village in Russia’s North Caucasus region in search of a better job. Then, just over a year ago, the phone calls stopped.

headline: Footnote
text: Alan Gilbert, who will take over as the music director of the New York Philharmonic in the 2009-10 season, has been named conductor laureate of the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic. He is the third person to hold the title in the 106-year history of the orchestra.

headline: Unlike Others, U.S. Defends Freedom to Offend in Speech
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A couple of years ago, a Canadian magazine published an article arguing that the rise of Islam threatened Western values. The article’s tone was mocking and biting, but it said nothing that conservative magazines and blogs in the United States do not say every day without fear of legal reprisal.

headline: No Beating Basketball
text: With Tuesday night’s television ratings again dominated by ABC’s live coverage of the N.B.A. finals, Fox and CBS shared runner-up status: CBS was second in total viewers, Fox second among adults 18 to 49. Fox got a lift in that demographic from the night’s highest-rated nonsports program, “Hell’s Kitchen,” at 9 p.m., which drew a solid if less impressive audience of 8.8 million total viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox’s “Moment of Truth” at 8 p.m. attracted 6 million. CBS, despite finishing virtually even with NBC for third place in the 18-to-49 set, fared consistently well in total viewers with reruns of “NCIS” at 8 (10 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 (8.3 million), as well as “48 Hours Mystery” at 9 (9.1 million). ABC’s audience for the third game in the Los Angeles Lakers-Boston Celtics series appeared to exceed Sunday’s Game 2 ratings, which averaged 13.5 million viewers when Nielsen’s final ratings were released.

headline: Harmonious Tension and Dueling Flaxen Locks
text: On “Raising Sand” (Rounder), the spooky, beautiful album they released last year, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss tilt toward each other from starkly different vantage points: heat-blistered arena rock (his) and coolly plaintive bluegrass (hers). Their material, scouted out by the producer T Bone Burnett, mines a deep, dark region of Americana somewhat familiar to them both. But their chemistry springs partly from contrast; even the most harmonious moments convey a subtle, fruitful tension.

headline: Hedge Funds Can Vote at CSX Meeting
text: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at the CSX Corporation had violated securities laws by not disclosing their positions and intentions many months before they did.

headline: At Practice, 2 Giants Are Conspicuous in Absence
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants took the field for the first time in the post-Michael Strahan era, it was the absence of two other stars that threatened the team’s harmony and quickly dimmed its championship glow.

headline: Four Years On, Clinging to Lower Status
text: Kathy Griffin returns for a fourth season of “Kathy Griffin: My Life on the D-List,” bearing an Emmy Award. Literally: she carries her 2007 trophy for outstanding reality program around her living room, musing, “Winning the Emmy was great, but, hey, the statue doesn’t pay the bills around here, honey.”

headline: Some Shark Populations Collapsing
text: Some shark populations in the Mediterranean Sea have completely collapsed, according to a new study, with numbers of five species declining by more than 96 percent over the past two centuries.

headline: Until Sudden Death, an Immigrant Worker Toiled Six Days a Week
text: The routine never changed. Six days a week, Lauro Ortega shuttled from pit to pit, taking another construction job. At the end of each week, he sent more than half of his weekly salary of about $700 to his wife and two children in Ecuador. On Sunday, he went to church and prayed.

headline: Tornado Kills 4 in Iowa Boy Scout Camp
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Four teenagers were killed and 48 people were injured when a tornado tore through a Boy Scout camp in western Iowa on Wednesday night, according to a spokeswoman for the Iowa Homeland Security Division and news agency and local newspaper reports.

headline: White House Names 6 for Medal of Freedom
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. Peter Pace, who was denied a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff a year ago because of the war in Iraq, will receive a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian award, the White House announced on Wednesday.

headline: East Meets West, and Elegantly Sits Down
text: The name of Doshi Levien’s new sofa, My Beautiful Backside, might not sound as if it has genteel origins, but inspiration for it “came from a painting we have in our studio that illustrates a maharani, or a princess” sitting on the floor with a multitude of cushions, said Jonathan Levien. Mr. Levien, a designer based in London who created the piece with Nipa Doshi, his Indian-born partner, explained that it “fuses an Indian way of sitting with the European typology of a sofa.” Because the backrest is made up of cushions of varying sizes printed with metal foil patterns on the back, it is suited for placement in the middle of the floor, rather than against a wall. A prototype, on view at the Moroso showroom in SoHo, is $18,500. Production pieces, available late this fall, will start at $14,300. Moroso, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 334-7222 or www.morosousa.com.

headline: Mets’ Alou Is Left Discouraged After Hurting His Calf Again
text: Moises Alou is injured yet again, and he is not sure how seriously. But Alou described himself as frustrated, disappointed and embarrassed by his frequent absences from the Mets’ lineup. “I’m not out yet,” he said Wednesday, “but I’m pretty down.”

headline: Norway: New Rights Granted to Gays
text: The Parliament granted gay and lesbian couples the right to marry and to adopt children on an equal basis with heterosexual couples. The country’s new universal marriage act, which also allows lesbians to be artificially inseminated in Norwegian medical facilities, supersedes a domestic partnership policy. “No longer will there be different classes of love,” Erling Lae, the chief commissioner of Oslo, told an online newspaper minutes after the Parliament’s 84-41 vote, adding that he now plans to marry his male companion of 26 years.

headline: One Evening, Five Works for Final Leg of the Spring
text: Saving the worst for last, Series C of “Marathon 2008,” the final, frustrating collection of short plays produced by the Ensemble Studio Theater this spring, features a few good ideas, the occasional lovely phrase but not one completely satisfying work.

headline: A Gardener’s Purple Prose
text: There are many familiar pleasures in “The Unlikely Lavender Queen: A Memoir of Unexpected Blossoming” (Broadway Books, $23.95), which chronicles Jeannie Ralston’s transformation from a proto-Carrie Bradshaw type into a lavender farmer in Texas. Ms. Ralston is a true New Yorker, the sort of changeling born elsewhere (in her case, Tennessee) who feels at home for the first time in Manhattan. But she falls in love with a handsome Texan who plucks her from her life as a freelance writer and parks her on 200 acres in Blanco, Tex., leaving her largely alone to build their dream house, as his work as a photographer requires months-long absences. She also raises two sons, and then fields of lavender, turning tiny Blanco into the state’s “lavender capital.” What’s unfamiliar is the resolution: After 10 years of finding her way in a foreign land, when her peripatetic husband wants to sell their home because land values have risen so much, she acquiesces. “I realized I wanted a happy home,” she writes, “versus this particular home.” Now they live in Mexico. Last week she admitted: “I’m not quite over the house, but I am over the lavender.” Nonetheless, she’ll be reading this weekend in Blanco, at the Lavender Festival she started.

headline: Lawmakers Seek to Close Foreign Lobbyist Loopholes
text: Loopholes that lobbyists for foreign clients sometimes use to keep their activities under wraps would be closed under legislation that two Democratic senators are expected to offer on Thursday.

headline: The National Challenge: Finding Offense
text: While our friends across the pond battle it out in the European Championship, the U.S. team faces its own high-stakes international competition this Sunday, playing Barbados in the national team's first qualification match for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. And though we can (and often do) talk until we're blue in the face about soccer's growth in America, one fact remains: The U.S. attack needs a serious upgrade.

headline: A Couple Grapple for Love, and Love of Achievement
text: LAS VEGAS  Friends say Patricia Miranda and Levi Weikel-Magden argue like an old married couple, but really, they argue more like what they are  married wrestlers with law degrees.

headline: Safety Starts at the Top
text: Brookline, Mass.

headline: Canada Offers an Apology for Native Students’ Abuse
text: OTTAWA  The government of Canada formally apologized on Wednesday to Native Canadians for forcing about 150,000 native children into government-financed residential schools where many suffered physical and sexual abuse.

headline: Sprucing Up the Start Menu
text: Q. I have so many programs on my PC that it takes me forever to find them in the Windows XP All Programs menu. Is there a way to customize the order they appear?

headline: On a Highway, Looking for the Exit to Fame
text: It takes more than a video camera and a good idea to make convincing reality television. That is abundantly clear in the first episode of “The Road Hammers,” an eight-part series that was broadcast in Canada last year and will be shown on the Great American Country channel beginning Thursday night. “Hammers” follows the members of the country band by the same name as they try to translate Canadian success  they are award winners and veterans of an earlier reality series there  into fame and fortune in Nashville.

headline: Putting ‘You Look Tired’ to Rest
text: IRY CHANG is sick of people telling her she looks exhausted. She gets enough sleep, but the dark circles under her eyes still elicit stares and make her look much older than her 25 years.

headline: Popular García Just Can’t Seem to Win the Big Ones
text: SAN DIEGO  Sergio García’s winning smile was once the spark for a series of whimsical television beer commercials. A would-be king, García is still popular with golf galleries, and with his bright wardrobe he is easy to find on fairways and greens. A title contender in every tournament he enters, he remains ranked among the world’s golf elite.

headline: The Plight of the Underinsured
text: It is well known, by now, that almost 50 million Americans lacked health insurance for all or part of last year. What is less well known is that 25 million Americans who did have health insurance often found it pitifully inadequate when a medical crisis hit. They were only marginally better off than those who had no coverage at all.

headline: To Light Up New York, We’d Have to Run Hard!
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shopping High-End Resale
text: MICHAEL’S 1041 Madison Avenue, New York; michaelsconsignment.com.

headline: Neil MacNeil, Among First of TV Reporters on Congress, Dies at 85
text: Neil MacNeil, who covered Congress for Time magazine through seven presidential administrations and was among television’s first Congressional correspondents, died Saturday in Bethesda, Md., where he made his home. He was 85.

headline: Events
text: Music

headline: Japan’s Upper House Censures Prime Minister
text: TOKYO  The opposition-controlled upper house of Parliament passed a nonbinding censure motion against Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda on Wednesday, the first against a prime minister in postwar Japan.

headline: A Winning Formula Is Written for the Mets
text: More than a six-run homer, more than a couple of perfect games back to back, what the Mets need now is leadership, sweet leadership.

headline: Iowa Flooding Prompts Evacuations
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  The supply of water in Cedar Rapids was dwindling and electricity was scarce and likely to be spotty for days after parts of the city were submerged by flooding from the Cedar River. A local hospital rushed to evacuate 176 patients.

headline: Fish Got to Swim, Birds Got to Fly, Genres Got to Meld
text: Carnegie Hall is justly renowned for its splendid acoustics. Yet because the sound of Isaac Stern Auditorium, the hall’s principal performance space, is so warm, rich and present, using amplification there has typically been a challenge. Like a prickly diva, Ms. Carnegie recoils when microphones and speakers are set up on her stage.

headline: No Time Off for Olbermann
text: Keith Olbermann, below, the host of “Countdown” on MSNBC, canceled his time off this week when it appeared likely that he would score a ratings victory over his competition at the Fox News Channel once last week’s numbers were tallied. Sure enough, with an average of 477,000 viewers in the 25-to-54 demographic, he beat Fox’s “O’Reilly Factor” by 5,000, according to Nielsen  a first in the five-year history of “Countdown.” (As usual, however, Bill O’Reilly had about twice as many total viewers, and on the three days the two hosts went head to head the Fox host won among the demographic.) Hoping to win a second week, Mr. Olbermann, who has engaged in increasingly bitter mudslinging with Mr. O’Reilly, has delayed his vacation indefinitely. But on Monday Mr. O’Reilly was back on top, attracting 60,000 more 25-to-54 viewers than Mr. Olbermann. Mr. O’Reilly doesn’t appear worried. He took a vacation day on Friday.

headline: A 21st-Century Profile: Art for Art’s Sake, and for the U.S. Economy, Too
text: If all the professional dancers in the United States stood shoulder to shoulder to form a single chorus line, it would stretch from 42nd Street for nearly the entire length of Manhattan. If every artist in America’s work force banded together, their ranks would be double the size of the United States Army. More Americans identify their primary occupation as artist than as lawyer, doctor, police officer or farm worker.

headline: Second Thoughts on Pulling the Guard From the Border
text: NOGALES, Ariz.  Swooping low over the Mexican border in her Blackhawk helicopter, Chief Warrant Officer Christina Engh-Schappert of the Virginia National Guard spots ... nothing. No sign of the migrants who would congregate in the washes for the mad dash to the United States. No clusters of people hiding in the bushes. Nobody in the throes of dehydration and heat exhaustion.

headline: American Aid Is Seized in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwean authorities confiscated a truck loaded with 20 tons of American food aid for poor schoolchildren and ordered that the wheat and pinto beans aboard be handed out to supporters of President Robert Mugabe at a political rally instead, the American ambassador said Wednesday.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Wednesday about airlines’ efforts to save fuel misidentified the employer of the airline workers shown checking dirt cleaned from a jet’s engine. They work for Southwest Airlines, not Northwest Airlines.

headline: Times Hires New Chief of the About Group
text: The New York Times Company announced on Wednesday the appointment of Cella M. Irvine as chief executive of the About Group, which includes About.com, the information and advice Web site.

headline: India: Larger Bid for Esmark
text: Essar Steel Holdings, an Indian steel maker, plans to raise its bid for Esmark, a steel maker in West Virginia, by 12 percent to about $750 million to thwart a bid by Severstal of Russia. Essar intends to raise the bid to $19 a share, from $17 once the two companies sign a merger agreement, the company said. Essar also said it would negotiate a collective labor agreement with the United Steelworkers union.

headline: Manslaughter Charge in Trench Collapse
text: The owner of a Brooklyn construction site where a day laborer died in March when earth and debris collapsed on him was charged with manslaughter on Wednesday. In announcing the indictment, at a time in which construction-related deaths in New York are running far ahead of last year’s pace, the authorities said that more construction-related prosecutions may be ahead.

headline: Rough Events at Mexican Rodeos in U.S. Criticized
text: TURLOCK, Calif.  It always begins at noon in a dusty arena, with brisk salutes on the brims of glittering sombreros and mustachioed horsemen in three-piece suits.

headline: Commodity Prices Show No Letup
text: CHICAGO  Commodity prices went wild on Wednesday, with the price of corn shooting through the $7 barrier for the first time, soybeans and wheat moving up sharply and oil jumping more than $5 a barrel.

headline: Shaken Korean Leader Promises New Beginning
text: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak pledged a "new beginning" on Wednesday as he contemplated reorganizing his unpopular government, which has been shaken by the biggest anti-government demonstrations in two decades.

headline: So Young, and So Gadgeted
text: EVERYONE knows that babies crawl before they walk, and that tricycles come before two-wheelers. But at what age should children get their first cellphone, laptop or virtual persona?

headline: Chief Executive Resigns at Martha Stewart Living
text: The woman who kept Martha Stewart’s company going while the homemaking doyenne served prison time stepped down on Wednesday, raising fresh questions about whether the company can find its way in a tough economy.

headline: Petty Enterprises Sells Stake to an Equity Firm
text: CONCORD, N.C.  Outside investors have poured into Nascar in recent years, buying stakes in race teams eager for an influx of money as the cost of competition rises.

headline: Obama Camp Courts Clinton Fund-Raisers
text: With Senator Barack Obama’s campaign manager scheduled to meet Thursday with top fund-raisers for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in New York, there is resistance from at least some in her once-vaunted network to supporting Mr. Obama.

headline: Lithuania Approves Guggenheim Project
text: The government of Lithuania approved construction of a new museum in Vilnius, its capital, on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported. A joint project between Lithuania, the Guggenheim and the State Hermitage Museum in Russia, the museum will be designed by Zaha Hadid and is to open in 2013. “This is an important project, in a move to attract tourists to Lithuania,” Gediminas Kirkilas, the country’s prime minister, told reporters. “It is also important to Lithuania’s image.” The estimated value of the project, shown above in a rendering, is $117 million, with the Lithuanian government to pay 10 to 15 percent of the total. The museum will build its own collection and display art from the Hermitage and the Guggenheim. Arturas Zuokas, a former mayor of Vilnius who is an organizer of the project, said the museum could draw 400,000 visitors a year, half of them from outside Lithuania.

headline: Chief Judge Contributed to Racy Web Site
text: The chief judge of the federal appeals court in California, Alex Kozinski, has contributed to a Web site that featured sexually explicit materials, The Los Angeles Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Yankees’ Veras Making the Most of His Chance
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  José Veras visited Alcatraz on Wednesday, taking a morning boat ride to the island with Mariano Rivera and Edwar Ramírez, his teammates in the Yankees’ bullpen. They heard tales of Al Capone and Machine Gun Kelly and marveled at the hopelessness.

headline: In Kentucky, Reinterpreting English Gardening for a Bluegrass Climate
text: ONCE a house is built and its interior decorated, it is pretty much finished unless the owner feels the need to add something new. A garden is different. Plants change, maturing into large and vibrant shapes or dying back. They cannot be ignored.

headline: Robbins the Contrarian Will Now Bow, Thanks
text: You think you know me? No, you don’t. The need to resist categorization goes deep in many of the greatest performing artists, and in many of the greatest creative artists too. Part of the fascination of the current Jerome Robbins Celebration from New York City Ballet is to see how hard he worked throughout his career to escape pigeonholing. I could do without the title of its latest program, “Generation Next,” but I’m grateful for how well it demonstrates his resistance.

headline: At Minicamp, 2 Giants Are Conspicuous by Their Absence
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants took the field for the first time in the post-Michael Strahan era, it was the absence of two other stars that threatened the team’s harmony and quickly dimmed its championship glow.

headline: Ultrathin Laptop Starts Up Quickly and Comes With a Brand Name That Gamers Love
text: The Voodoo PC brand, favored by gamers, and the brothers behind it, Rahul and Ravi Sood, did not disappear when it became part of Hewlett-Packard. The latest Voodoo is the ultrathin Envy 133, which will be in stores and on Hewlett-Packard’s Web site this month.

headline: Putting the Riviera in the Rental
text: FOR many people, moving into a summer rental means throwing a sheet over the lumpy sofa or rushing out to the hardware store and stocking up on plastic tumblers and paper plates.

headline: Charges in Death at Construction Site
text: Correction appended.

headline: Honey, Can You Answer That? The Clock Radio Is Ringing
text: The iHome clock radio for the Apple iPhone has not changed radically from versions of the iHome for the iPod. They allowed you to insert the iPod into a dock built into the top of the clock radio for recharging and — here is the cool part — play the contents of the iPod through the clock radio’s speakers. Thanks to a set of adapters that comes with the new $150 iP99 model of the iHome, the iPhone as well as various versions of the iPod can be docked.

headline: Big Brown’s Trainer Ready to Testify
text: Big Brown’s trainer, Rick Dutrow, said Wednesday that he intended to be prepared next week when he appears at a Congressional hearing examining safety issues in thoroughbred racing.

headline: Modern Samples, Marked Down
text: Property, a SoHo store that sells modern furniture, will hold a floor sample sale from June 23 to 29. The prices of all pieces in the showroom will be reduced 20 to 60 percent, and orders for new furniture placed during the sale will be discounted 20 percent. Floor sample merchandise on sale includes a 94-inch-long 60’s Cabinet in light-blue matte lacquer, similar to the one shown here ($4,780); the Urban sofa, upholstered in brown fabric ($5,765); the Eureka hanging chair, made of bamboo with a black seat cushion ($2,316); and the Trach chair, covered in gray and brown fabric ($2,190). Property, 14 Wooster Street (Canal Street), (917) 237-0123 or propertyfurniture.com.

headline: Networks Firm Up Convention Lineups
text: Those political aficionados wondering whether Senator Barack Obama looks better from the right or left, take note: in August visitors to the official Web site of the Democratic National Convention will be able to choose from a menu of camera angles as they tune in live, high-definition video streamed from the party gathering in Denver.

headline: With the Stroke of a Pen, a Popular Educational Toy That Helps Children Learn to Read Is Simplified
text: What if you could take the popular LeapPad educational toy and shrink it down into a pen? That pretty much sums up the Tag Reading System, available now for $50 from LeapFrog.

headline: Bronx Produce Co-op Says Market May Leave the City
text: For 41 years a raucous, muscular ballet of men and trucks, shipping pallets and sweat has unfolded before dawn most days at the Hunts Point produce market in the South Bronx.

headline: Irish to Vote on Complex European Union Treaty
text: DUBLIN  The final straw, said Dermot Gilmartin, was seeing an official struggle on television to answer questions about the topic of the hour: the European Union’s Lisbon Treaty, which is being put to a referendum here on Thursday. Challenged on a technical point, the official sputtered, began frantically rifling through his papers and fell silent.

headline: Claims May Be Bogus, but the Perception Is Real
text: Los Angeles

headline: Bush Loyalist Fights Foes of ‘No Child’ Law
text: NEWPORT, Ky.  Margaret Spellings is not running for office  at least, not yet. But in the waning days of the Bush presidency, she is running one last campaign.

headline: Rebuilding New Orleans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sentences in Goya Theft
text: Two men who stole a valuable Goya painting are going to federal prison, The Associated Press reported. The men, Steven Lee Olson and Roman Szurko, stole “Children With a Cart,” above, from a transport truck in November 2006 as its drivers spent the night at a motel in Bartonsville, Pa. The work was on its way to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York from the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio. The painting, from 1778, was insured for $1 million. It was eventually returned undamaged to the Toledo museum. In United States District Court in Newark on Wednesday, Mr. Olson was sentenced to the maximum five-year term; the judge said he had led the theft and had an extensive criminal record. Mr. Szurko received a year and a day. Lawyers for the men have said they did not realize the painting was famous when they took it.

headline: Grass, Simplified: Hire Someone
text: WARMER weather and longer days mean more time to spend out in the yard. But how do you want to spend that time: relaxing in a lawn chair, or walking behind a lawn mower?

headline: A Recycled Pavilion, to Shelter Furniture, Friends or Ferraris
text: On Saturday, the gabled pavilion designed by the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban for Artek, a Finnish furniture manufacturer, will be auctioned at Sotheby’s for an estimated $800,000 to $1.2 million. The 120-foot-long portable pavilion is open at both ends and has walls, trusses and a roof made of recycled plastic and paper.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An obituary on Tuesday about the horse trainer Warren A. Croll Jr. erroneously included a race among notable victories by his horse Holy Bull. The horse did not compete in the Jockey Club Gold Cup as a 3-year-old.

headline: Texas Leader Vows to Rebuild Governor’s Mansion After Fire
text: HOUSTON  Gov. Rick Perry pledged Wednesday to rebuild the Governor’s Mansion, which was damaged by fire on Sunday, and expressed outrage that someone would set fire to such an important symbol of state history.

headline: The Netherlands: Staples Sets Deal
text: Staples agreed to buy Corporate Express for 1.68 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after raising its offer three times, becoming the world’s largest direct distributor of office supplies to companies. Staples, which has more than 2,000 stores, will get operations that ship office supplies to companies in Europe, the United States and Canada and add markets in Australia and New Zealand. Staples said it would pay 9.25 euros a share for Corporate Express. The bid was 28 percent more than Staples’s original offer made in February. The agreement scuttles a deal Corporate Express struck to acquire a French rival, Lyreco, last month.

headline: David Mitton, a Creator of ‘Thomas’ for TV, Dies at 69
text: David Mitton, a creator of the gentle children’s television series “Thomas the Tank Engine and Friends,” which evolved into an international hit and a merchandising juggernaut, died on May 16 in London. He was 69.

headline: Tornado Hits Scout Scout Camp in Iowa, Killing 4
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  At least four people were killed and about 40 injured when a tornado tore through a Boy Scout camp in western Iowa on Wednesday night, a spokeswoman for the Iowa Homeland Security Division said.

headline: Top Secret Files Left on British Train
text: LONDON  The police opened an investigation on Wednesday after secret intelligence assessments of Al Qaeda and Iraq’s security forces were left on a commuter train.

headline: Police Review Lab Work After Suicide of Scientist
text: New York State Police officials are notifying district attorneys across the state that evidence in criminal cases may have been compromised by a forensic scientist who committed suicide last month after auditors discovered that he had not followed proper procedures in some cases, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Now It’s Tomatoes
text: Last week, federal officials started alerting consumers to avoid certain raw tomatoes  red plums, red Romas and round reds  that may have infected scores of people with a rare type of salmonella. Many grocers and restaurants rushed to remove all tomatoes from their stock  an over-reaction, but an understandable one.

headline: Reflecting, in a Place of Racial Tolerance, the Long Road Traveled, and to Come
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J.

headline: Palestinian Students
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fed Says Economy Was Weak in April and May
text: The economy sputtered along in May and the last weeks of April, as Americans spent less and overall growth stayed soft, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

headline: Democrats Criticize McCain on Strategy in Iraq
text: PHILADELPHIA  The presidential campaigns clashed Wednesday over strategy in Iraq as advisers to Senator Barack Obama seized on remarks by Senator John McCain to accuse him of being insensitive to the sacrifices being made by American soldiers.

headline: In Postwar Britain, the Grim Face of Victory
text: The historian David Kynaston’s “Austerity Britain: 1945-1951” seems less a book than a scroll. You don’t feel that you’re turning pages so much as unrolling a single piece of parchment, with facts, figures and, most of all, people moving by in grand procession. There go Churchill, Keynes and other leading politicians and policymakers, also Kingsley Amis, Graham Greene, Isaiah Berlin, J. R. R. Tolkien, a dashing Dirk Bogarde, a young Bill Wyman, as well as dozens of unknowns who happened to keep a diary or utter an especially piquant remark.

headline: Not a Planet, but a Plutoid
text: Pluto is still not a planet, but now it is a plutoid. Two years ago, the International Astronomical Union decreed that Pluto was no longer a planet, but a member of a new category known as dwarf planets, bodies that were large enough to be round, but which did not gravitationally dominate their orbital neighborhoods. On Wednesday, the union announced the creation of the term “plutoid” for a dwarf planet beyond the orbit of Neptune. There is only one plutoid other than Pluto: Eris, the sphere of rock and ice formerly nicknamed Xena that is slightly larger than Pluto.

headline: Never Mind Third Hand High; Count the Clubs
text: There were several interesting deals during the open trial to pick the United States team for the World Mind Sports Games in Beijing. In the diagramed deal at the trial, which finished last Friday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., Michael Becker made a great defensive play that would have been missed by many.

headline: Can Credit-Card Interest Be Deducted for a Home?
text: Q. If I take out a cash advance on a credit card to use toward a down payment on a home, is the interest I pay on the credit card deductible on my federal income tax return?

headline: 6 Deaths in Brooklyn and Queens Are Attributed to Heat
text: Six people in New York City died because of exposure to the heat on Tuesday, the medical examiner’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: The Gravity of Donaghy’s Accusations Is Unclear
text: LOS ANGELES  Troubling new allegations of referee misconduct have dampened the celebratory mood here at the N.B.A. finals, although the line between temporary crisis and long-term scandal is not clear.

headline: Adding Movies to PowerPoint
text: Q. I want to insert a video clip that I took with my digital camera into a PowerPoint file. The movie is in the QuickTime format, which doesn’t work with my version of PowerPoint for Windows. Is there a way to make this work?

headline: A Life of Quality
text: In “Parting the Waters,” his history of the early civil-rights movement, Taylor Branch recounts how a teacher of Gandhian resistance, James Lawson, would tell his students not to curl passively into fetal balls when segregationists came to beat them up. It only made them more brutal.

headline: After Moving Past .500, the Yanks Tumble Back
text: The .500 mark is like a vicious undertow for the Yankees. Over and over, they struggle their way to the shore, seemingly ready to make a run. Yet over and over, they are pulled back, treading water again.

headline: Barack’s Bad Day
text: Everybody knows that the very first rule in picking a vice president is to do no harm. Really, you can choose anybody. How dumb would you feel if it turned into an embarrassment?  This is why the careful, modern candidate sets up a screening system.

headline: Pakistan Angry as Strike by U.S. Kills 11 Soldiers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American air and artillery strikes killed 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers during a clash with insurgents on the Afghan border on Tuesday night, a development that raised concerns about the already strained American relationship with Pakistan.

headline: Work at Ground Zero Site Is Behind Schedule
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday that it was running more than a month behind schedule in delivering the site of Tower 2 at the new World Trade Center to the developer, Silverstein Properties. The authority will pay Silverstein a $300,000 daily penalty, beginning July 1, until the site can be turned over fully excavated in August.

headline: Report Faults F.D.A. Action for Safe Food
text: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration has failed to carry out much of its own plan to protect the nation’s food supply, Congressional investigators say in a report that is to be released on Thursday.

headline: European Airlines Reap Benefits of Oil Hedging
text: PARIS  As United States airlines reel from soaring oil prices and a sinking domestic economy, most of their European rivals appear better placed to ride out the storm.

headline: Beltrán Saves the Mets, as Wagner Fails Again
text: In the normal course of events, a 13-inning victory that ends a five-game losing streak would be a cause for celebration. That was the result for the Mets on Wednesday night at Shea Stadium when they beat Arizona, 5-3.

headline: Be Old Money or Just Look Like It
text: AN arresting image in fashion, these last few weeks, was the wives from the Yearning for Zion polygamist ranch. It is a muscular look primed for cultural combat: identically starched high-collared, pastel box-pleat dresses with huge princess sleeves; shellacked, high, French-braided hair; and Oakley wraparound mercenary sunglasses. You could imagine them stalking out of the courthouse in a horizontal row, slow motion à la “Reservoir Dogs,” their brown oxfords hitting the ground to the drumbeat of “In-a-Gadda-Da-Vida.”

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Wednesday about deaths in immigration detention misidentified the ranking Republican member of the House subcommittee on immigration. He is Steve King of Iowa, not Peter King of New York.

headline: Britain: Better Late Than Never
text: Prince Charles paid off a 17th-century royal debt of about $900, but he steered clear of paying interest of more than $90,000. On a tour of Worcester, the heir to the throne made the payment of 453 pounds and three shillings, about $900 at present exchange rates, to settle a bill run up by King Charles II in preparation for what turned out to be a losing battle between his forces and Oliver Cromwell’s. The bill, owed to the Clothiers Company of Worcester for uniforms worn by the royalists in the battle, was left unpaid when Charles fled the country, and it remained unsettled after he returned to claim the throne in 1660. The prince said he was happy to pay the debt, but not the interest. “I wasn’t born yesterday,” he said.

headline: ‘No Wave: Post-Punk’
text: Foreword

headline: Obama Aide Quits Under Fire for His Business Ties
text: CHICAGO  James A. Johnson, the consummate Washington insider whom Senator Barack Obama tapped to head his vice-presidential search effort, resigned abruptly on Wednesday to try to silence a growing furor over his business activities.

headline: Art? Design? You Make the Call
text: The new Avant Gallery in Miami Beach, Fla., is a “fused concept store,” according to Dmitry Prut, the owner, who said he makes no distinction between art and design.

headline: Housing Slump Helps the Draw of Fixer-Upper TV
text: The housing market is collapsing, but television shows about housing are booming.

headline: For Those Who Think Outside of the Box, Speakers in the Round
text: Most speakers are built into large square boxes. This poses a problem for home theater buffs without much space to spare. JBL’s Control Now speakers are quarter-round, which means that four of them can fit together to make one round speaker.

headline: When Conscience and Closet Collide
text: REVIEWING her wardrobe earlier this season, Elizabeth Marvin had a moment of reckoning. “How did this closet become so massively overstuffed?” she mused, disconcerted by the sight of so many Marni jackets, Chloé bags and Jimmy Choo shoes jostling for space on the racks. “From my green perspective, part of me feels guilty about being such a major consumer.”

headline: HBO Mines the Web
text: Coming soon to HBO: programming from the creators of the comedy Web site Funny or Die (funnyordie.com), founded last year by the actor Will Ferrell, the writer and director Adam McKay and the writer Chris Henchy. HBO, under pressure to develop a new stable of hit shows, said on Wednesday that it was investing in the site, which is best known for “The Landlord,” a short video featuring an angry baby. This is HBO’s first partnership with an Internet video site, and the investment is for somewhat less than $10 million, according to executives involved with the deal. Funny or Die will produce 10 half-hour shows for HBO. “The Internet comedy we do is short-form. HBO gives us a longer-form opportunity,” said Dick Glover, the chief executive of Funny or Die. Some of the shows may be episodic, others stand-alone, and the partnership may expand to include a live comedy tour.

headline: Brewer Bids $46 Billion for Anheuser-Busch
text: One of the nation’s most prominent family-run companies, Anheuser-Busch, formally became the target of a $46.4 billion unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium on Wednesday.

headline: NASA Launches an Orbiting Mystery-Solver
text: A new space telescope designed to keep vigil on the most violent and energetic objects in the universe took wing Wednesday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,088 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

headline: Small-Business Agency’s Problems Linger as Leader Moves on to HUD
text: WASHINGTON  Steven C. Preston’s signature accomplishment as head of the Small Business Administration was overhauling the agency’s disaster loan assistance program, a program that was foundering under the crush of Hurricane Katrina claims when he took over nearly two years ago.

headline: Fusing Movement to Melody
text: Non-French speakers seemed to be at a distinct disadvantage during the opening performance of the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance on Tuesday night. Or so it seemed at first, when confronted with “Récitations” by the Greek composer Georges Aperghis, a set of 14 vivid short pieces for unaccompanied vocalist.

headline: Afghanistan’s Progress: The View From Kabul
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Dad’s Résumé Lists ‘Car Pool’
text: THE résumé gap isn’t just for mothers anymore.

headline: Hong Kong: Market Poultry to Be Killed
text: The authorities said that all poultry in Hong Kong’s markets would be killed after signs of avian flu were found among chickens in four markets. No bird-flu deaths or illnesses among people have been reported here.

headline: Giving a Modern African Twist to Those Rites of Spring
text: Throughout June the Joyce Theater is unveiling its French Collection, a festival of three groups, starting with Compagnie Heddy Maalem in yet another version of “Le Sacre du Printemps.” A French-Algerian choreographer, Mr. Maalem was inspired by time spent in Lagos, Nigeria, for this work featuring 14 performers from Mali, Benin, Nigeria, Senegal, Togo and Mozambique. In his rendition of “Sacre” performed on Tuesday night the story of a pagan spring ritual is transported to modern Africa.

headline: Tip of the Week: Thinking Green When You Print
text: Hate those printed Word documents that have a few lines spilling over onto the last page? You can save paper by going to Word’s Print Preview in the File menu and clicking the “Shrink to Fit” or “Shrink One Page” button, which has an icon showing multiple pages transforming onto one page. Word will automatically fiddle with the document’s text size and spacing to get it all on a single page. But if the shrinkage messes up your formatting or looks too cramped, undo it by pressing Control-Z (Command-Z on a Mac), which reverses the process.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Six Months Later, Start-Ups Find Their Goals Are Elusive
text: IT has not been an easy six months.

headline: Iran Dismisses Talk of Sanctions
text: TEHRAN  As President Bush pressed European leaders to adopt a tougher posture toward Iran, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad Wednesday brushed aside pressure to curb Tehran’s nuclear ambitions, saying the West “cannot do anything” and “all their plans have failed.”

headline: Bush Does Europe Incognito
text: PARIS

headline: Illinois: Museum in Protected Park
text: The Chicago City Council approved a plan to let the Chicago Children’s Museum build a new home in Grant Park, a downtown park that is protected from development. Much of the museum would be underground. With a 33-to-16 vote, aldermen supported Mayor Richard M. Daley, an ardent promoter of the plan, bucking the opposition of the local alderman, Brendan Reilly, and the tradition of giving aldermen power over decisions in their own wards. “They understood that the issue was bigger than any one ward,” Mr. Daley said. “It was about doing the right thing on behalf of all Chicago, especially the children.” Mr. Reilly accused the Daley administration of securing the vote through “arm-twisting and deal making.”

headline: A Brief, Noisy Moment That Still Reverberates
text: Of all the strange and short-lived periods in the history of experimental music in New York, no wave is perhaps the strangest and shortest-lived.

headline: The Fourth Leg of the Triathlon: Bike Transport
text: THESE days, triathlons take place all over the country, and getting your bicycle to them can be an endurance event in itself.

headline: Immigration Raid in Arizona Could Test New State Law
text: MESA, Ariz.  A raid on two busy water parks and the arrest of nine workers suspected of being illegal immigrants might become the first case to test Arizona’s new employer sanctions law.

headline: Discovery Heads Back to Earth
text: The space shuttle Discovery pulled away from the International Space Station early Wednesday as the 123rd mission of the shuttle fleet headed toward a close.

headline: Bangladesh: Party Leader Released
text: The army-backed Bangladeshi government released Sheik Hasina Wazed, the leader of a major political party who had been imprisoned on corruption charges, so she could get medical treatment in the United States. Later that evening, she met with senior government officials about whether and how her party, the Awami League, would participate in elections, scheduled for December. The party had refused talks with the government until her release.

headline: When a Tree Falls on a Neighbor’s House
text: Q. If a tree on my property falls on a neighbor's house during a storm and damages it, whose insurance covers the damage?

headline: An Anger in Korea Over More Than Beef
text: SEOUL, South Korea  When tens of thousands of South Koreans spilled into central Seoul on Tuesday in the country’s largest antigovernment protest in 20 years, the police built a barricade with shipping containers. They coated them with oil and filled them with sandbags so protesters could not climb or topple them to march on President Lee Myung-bak’s office a couple of blocks away.

headline: Iran Unmoved by Threats on Its Atomic Program
text: MESEBERG, Germany  Increasingly tough warnings from President Bush and his European allies have done nothing to temper Iran’s stance on its nuclear program, worsening the confrontation over what American officials and others suspect is a covert Iranian plan to build an atomic bomb.

headline: A Big Birthday in the realm of the 'Sturgeon King'
text: Ivan Steinberg suspiciously studied the gleaming, succulent sturgeon on his plate, prodded one of the three thin slices with his fork as if it were a splayed frog in biology class, then took the plunge. He nibbled. He smiled.

headline: Mississippi: Workers End Hunger Strike
text: About two dozen guest workers from India who said they were victims of human trafficking at an oil rig construction company in Mississippi ended a hunger strike in Washington. The workers said the protest was to pressure the Justice Department to allow them to remain legally in the United States while their case is under investigation. They were brought to this country in 2006 and 2007 under temporary visas to work at Signal International, based in Pascagoula. Twenty workers fasted for varying periods over 29 days; five were hospitalized, said Stephen Boykewich of the New Orleans Workers’ Center for Racial Justice, which organized the protest. After a rally outside the department on Monday, justice officials agreed to meet with workers’ representatives.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline in some editions on Tuesday about a successful effort by Company C of the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit to pacify a Taliban-infested area of southern Afghanistan misidentified the foreign forces that failed to achieve the same result in that area earlier. They were soldiers from NATO and the United States Army  not the Marines.

headline: Invasives and Dame’s Rocket
text: Invasives and Dame’s Rocket

headline: Americans Living in a Material World
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rondo’s Injury Adds Uncertainty to Celtics’ Backcourt
text: LOS ANGELES  When Boston Celtics point guard Rajon Rondo wrenched his left ankle early in the third quarter of Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals, it was possible he may have turned something else  the series.

headline: Democrats Offer Plans to Revamp Schools Law
text: Democrats are dividing into camps as they debate a new course for education policy after President Bush leaves office.

headline: Desormeaux Meets With Racing Stewards
text: Big Brown’s jockey Kent Desormeaux met with racing stewards Wednesday to discuss his controversial ride, and eventual surrender, in the 140th Belmont Stakes.

headline: The Open Course Is at Its Best
text: SAN DIEGO  Right in the middle of June, a cold sense of dread used to descend on the afternoon before the opening day at the United States Open. All out of preparation time and looking down the narrow fairways of another penal golf course layout, many of the 156 golfers were beaten right then, the day before they showed up on the tee looking as if they were in line for the root canal chair.

headline: Counting Steps, Not Votes, on Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A True Ensemble Performer
text: HOW does one say good luck to a Broadway dancer who is designing a cast mate’s dress for the Tony Awards on Sunday?

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about a program run by Rolex that pairs developing artists with master mentors reversed the identities of the women shown. Julie Taymor was on the left, and Selina Cartmell was on the right.

headline: As Revenue Falls, M.T.A. May Raise Fares Again in ’09
text: A worsening financial picture could force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to raise subway, bus and commuter rail fares again next year, the authority’s executive director said on Wednesday.

headline: Dan Jenkins: Dead Solid Fun
text: In "The Franchise Babe" (Doubleday, $24.95), our narrator, the sportswriter Jack Brannon, spots a woman on a golf course. She is "MVP toned and shaped...first-team upstairs in a form-fitting, sleeveless, scoop-neck white top" and a "jacked-up mini." Sports fans will recognize this greens report as the work of Dan Jenkins, who since his seminal golf novel, "Dead Solid Perfect" (1974), has explored the relationship between the gentleman's game, and, well, the gentleman's game. Brannon makes his approach and unfurls his best pick-up line: "Golf is my life -- how about you?"

headline: The Sex Speech
text: One of the missed opportunities of the primary season was that Hillary Clinton never gave a speech about gender comparable to Barack Obama’s speech about race.

headline: Smooth Translations
text: THE tribal trend, seen on spring runways awash with ikat, batik and African wax prints, is hot this summer. For accessories, the look is sweltering.

headline: A 150-Year-Old Map of Central Park Still Comes in Handy Today
text: “It is the most important work of American art of the 19th century,” Sara Cedar Miller said.

headline:
Woods
Stays
Off Course
Again
text: Tiger Woods did not practice on the golf course Wednesday, preferring to chip and putt for an hour in the morning before leaving for the day. There has been much speculation about whether Woods is fit enough to compete, playing in his first tournament since having surgery on his left knee April 15.

headline: Summer Hits
text: Disturbed, a hard-rock band from Chicago, this week scored its third No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with sales of 252,000 copies of “Indestructible” (Warner Brothers), below, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week busy with new releases, Volume 28 of the pop compilation “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” with songs by Leona Lewis, Lil Wayne, Jordin Sparks, John Mayer and others, opened at No. 2 with reported sales of 185,000. Weezer’s self-titled album on Geffen bowed at No. 4 with 126,000; Journey’s “Revelation” (Nomota), sold only at Wal-Mart, moved 105,000 to reach No. 5 in its first week. Ashanti’s new album, “The Declaration” (Universal Motown), is No. 6 with 86,000, and Jewel’s country album “Perfectly Clear” (Valory) is No. 8 with 48,000. Usher’s “Here I Stand” (LaFace/Zomba), last week’s No. 1, fell two spots to No. 3 with 145,000, a 67 percent decrease.

headline: 5 Killed by Bomb on Baghdad Bus
text: BAGHDAD  Five people were killed on Wednesday when a bomb exploded on a bus in Kadhimiya, a Shiite neighborhood that has been largely controlled by the Mahdi Army, which is loyal to the rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr.

headline: Tiny, Inviting and Ready for a Party
text: ON a recent Saturday afternoon, in the span of half an hour, more than 20 people craned their necks as they walked by a carriage house on 19th Street between Irving Place and Third Avenue, or stopped and stared, or pulled out cameras. A tourist couple from Minneapolis, Mark and Jackie Addink, studied the house for half a minute, until Ms. Addink admiringly pronounced it “so unique.”

headline: Israeli Cabinet Votes to Seek Truce in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli security cabinet voted on Wednesday to pursue an Egyptian-brokered cease-fire with Palestinian militant groups in Gaza, but it left open the possibility of a military offensive should the truce talks fail.

headline: Photographs From ‘No Wave: Post Punk’
text: Photographs by Julia Gorton of the downtown art rock scene from 1976 to 1980.

headline: Leatherback Turtle in Texas – First Since 1930s
text: UPDATED, 8:00 a.m.: For the first time since the 1930’s, federal biologists confirmed that a leatherback sea turtle has nested on a Texas beach, at the Padre Island National Seashore near Corpus Christi.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 78 Mississippi
text: Location: Oxford, Miss.

headline: Nascar Says Litigant Did Not Complain
text: Brian France, the Nascar chairman, said Wednesday that a former race official who filed a sexual and racial discrimination suit never complained about treatment from co-workers and supervisors before she was dismissed. Mauricia Grant, 32, who is black, filed suit Tuesday in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York claiming 23 incidents of sexual harassment and 34 incidents of racial and gender discrimination. She is seeking $225 million in damages.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Barack’s Bad Day
text: Barack Obama is having the first post-primary crisis, a moment in which the only conceivable response is what was he thinking? Talk about unnecessary disasters. It’s like having your career ruined because you invited the wrong person to host a party in honor of your nephew’s godparents.

headline: Stuck at .500 Again, the Yankees Take Solace in the Schedule
text: The schedule is the great equalizer for a baseball team. If the Yankees are home a lot one month, chances are they’ll be gone a lot the next month. Everything evens out.

headline: Shot by Shot, Portugal Wears Down Czechs
text: GENEVA — Cristiano Ronaldo and Petr Cech last met in the Champions League final in Moscow on May 21.

headline: Compliance Week Magazine Is Sold
text: Haymarket Media has agreed to buy Compliance Week magazine from Financial Media Holdings Group for an undisclosed price. Haymarket’s parent company, a privately held group based in the United Kingdom, owns about 100 magazines, including PR Week and Management Today.

headline: ‘Trump’s Island’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: A.I.G. Shareholders Call for Management Change, Report Says
text: Shareholders of American International Group are reportedly demanding changes to the management and board of the world’s largest insurer, which has been struggling with the fallout of the subprime mortgage mess.

headline: Boston Ventures Gets Into NASCAR
text: Outside investors have poured into Nascar in recent years, buying stakes in race teams eager for an influx of money as the cost of competition rises.

headline: Despite Deal Chatter, Alcoa Shares Fall Sharply on Downgrade
text: Alcoa stock fell nearly 8 percent Wednesday after a brokerage firm cut its investment rating and profit estimate, expressing doubts that Wall Street would like the new chief executive’s strategy for the aluminum company.

headline: Bankrupt Airline Sues FedEx
