text: ATA Airlines is suing the FedEx Corporation over its decision to drop the airline from its military charter team, a move ATA says forced it into bankruptcy protection and left it financially destroyed.

headline: Lieberman Seeks Limits to Reduce Commodities Speculation
text: A prominent Washington lawmaker said Wednesday that he would propose next week to ban large institutional investors, including index funds, from the nation’s booming commodity markets.

headline: BP Says Talks With Venture Investors Continue
text: The dispute between the oil giant BP and its partners in the Russian joint venture TNK-BP escalated on Wednesday when the two parties could not even agree to be on talking terms with each other and one threatened legal action.

headline: Brazil’s OGX Raises $3.58 Billion in I.P.O.
text: OGX Petroleo e Gas, the Brazilian oil company controlled by billionaire Eike Batista, raised 5.87 billion reais ($3.58 billion) in what could be the country’s biggest initial public offering.

headline: Mistras Group Files for I.P.O.
text: Mistras Group, a provider of technology-enabled testing software, on Tuesday filed for an initial pubic offering worth up to $172.5 million.

headline: Threat Seen to Deutsche Bahn Offering
text: Deutsche Bahn‘s initial public offering may be threatened by possible violations of European Union law, The Financial Times Deutschland reported, citing Juergen Basedow, head of the Bonn-based Monopolies Commission.

headline: Limerick Said to Reap $15.2 Million from V.C.s
text: Limerick BioPharma, a life sciences start-up in stealth mode, has raised $11 million in venture funding and $4.2 million in debt, according to VentureWire.

headline: BofA Chief Says He’s Committed to Coutrywide Deal
text: The chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Wednesday he remains committed to buying Countrywide Financial, the giant money-losing mortgage lender.

headline: My Haunted House
text: Anwar J. Ali is an Iraqi employee for The New York Times.

headline: The Writers’ M.V.P. vs. the Players’ M.V.P.
text: Fans sometimes forget that at each year’s NHL awards show, two MVP awards are given out: the Hart Memorial Trophy, voted on by the Professional Hockey Writers Association, and the Lester B. Pearson Award, voted on by the N.H.L. Players Association — the players themselves.

headline: BHP Chief Makes His Case for Rio Deal
text: BHP Billiton on Thursday took its case for a takeover of rival Rio Tinto to well-heeled investors on Thursday, saying a marriage could better capture markets in fast-industrializing Asian economies.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Tighter Credit-Rating Rules
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed new rules on Wednesday intended to stem conflicts of interest, expand disclosure for Wall Street’s credit rating industry and flag the ratings of more complex securities.

headline: Citigroup to Shut Down Pandit’s Old Lane
text: In a press release early Thursday, Citigroup said it would “restructure” Old Lane, buying the assets of its multi-strategy hedge fund at fair value and integrating some of its other strategies — convertible equities, credit fixed income and structured credits — elsewhere at the bank.

headline: Merrimack Pharmaceuticals Swallows $60 Million
text: Merrimack Pharmaceuticals, which focuses on drug discovery and development of treatments for cancer and autoimmune disease, announced Wednesday that it has raised $60 million in a Series F round of financing.

headline: Bullhorn Bulks Up With $26 Million
text: Bullhorn, a Boston-based maker of software that helps companies with staffing and recruiting, said Wednesday that it received $26 million in financing from a consortium led by area venture capital firms Highland Capital Partners  and General Catalyst Partners.

headline: Essar Sweetens Bid in Battle for Esmark
text: Essar Steel Holdings, an Indian steel maker, plans to raise its bid for U.S. rival Esmark by 12 percent to about $750 million to thwart a bid by Severstal of Russia.

headline: Goldman Executive Moves to Buyout Arm
text: Tom Connolly, head of Goldman Sachs‘s U.S. leveraged-finance business, is leaving his post to join the firm’s private-equity arm, where he will likely run a new fund investing in debt, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Commerzbank and Dresdner Mulling Merger, Report Says
text: Commerzbank and Allianz‘s Dresdner Bank are checking each others books in preparation for possible merger talks, Handelsblatt reported.

headline: Take-Two in Tussle With F.T.C. Over Electronic Arts Bid
text: Take-Two Interactive Software is not only fighting a hostile bid from Electronic Arts, but it is also fending off an antitrust investigation from the Federal Trade Commission that was launched as a result of the prospective takeover.

headline: Dating Network Zoosk Raises $4.1 Million
text: Zoosk, an online social dating network, said Thursday it raised $4.1 million from a group led by Canaan Partners, its second round of venture funding since it was founded last year. In a press release, Zoosk said it would use the money to build its subscriber base and add new features to its network.

headline: Bertelsmann May Cash Out of Sony Venture, Report Says
text: Bertelsmann, the German media group, is seeking $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion for its half share in Sony BMG after opening talks that could result in Sony gaining full control of the world’s second-largest music company within weeks, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Merrill Said to Raise $6 Billion Buyout Fund
text: Merrill Lynch is raising a $6 billion private equity fund, according TheStreet.com, which cited a pitch to an investor earlier this year.

headline: Merrill May Consider Selling Stakes in Bloomberg and BlackRock
text: The chief executive of Merrill Lynch, John Thain, said that the bank would consider selling its stakes in BlackRock and Bloomberg if it needed more capital.

headline: A Third Proxy Firm Criticizes Icahn’s Biogen Slate
text: Another major shareholder advisory firm recommended stockholders reject billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn’s slate of nominees to Biogen Idec‘s board, reducing his odds of success.

headline: Lehman Stock Keeps Falling
text: Wednesday proved to be another grim day for Lehman Brothers as the investment bank’s shares continued their plummet downward.

headline: Hedge Funds Can Vote at CSX Meeting
text: The fight between the CSX Corporation and two hedge funds seeking to win a proxy fight at one of the largest railroad companies in the nation, it seems, may not be over, despite a ruling Wednesday by a federal judge that the two activist funds ad violated securities laws by not disclosing their positions and intentions many months before they did.

headline: The Digital Ramble | The Natural Look
text: The Digital Ramble explores aesthetic topics through materials found online.

headline: How Equal Is My Marriage?
text: “And what about you and your husband?”

headline: Keeping Up Court Appearances
text: He laughs at the TV so hard he falls off the sofa. A neighbor downstairs thinks he’s collapsed and calls the police. The police pepper spray him. Life imitates “Benny Hill.” From the Daily Mail of London:

headline: Defining the Spirit of 13(d)
text: In the end the CSX decision was not a surprise. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of the Federal District Court in Manhattan had signaled on Monday that he would side with the railroad operator when he held a hearing on possible remedies. (Read his ruling as a PDF here.)

headline: We Did Not Win One
text: The Webby Awards, which honor just about everything on the Internet, try to move things along by requiring that acceptance speeches consist of exactly five words (see above headline). Here are a few five-worders from the ceremony in New York Tuesday night (from the Bits technology blog):

headline: Swing ‘Em Home
text: President Bush may have sworn off golf during wartime, but these patriots didn’t. From the humor site 23/6:

headline: International buyers fueling sales in Chicago residential towers
text: >The Chicago Spire

headline: Biotech Firms in $6.7 Billion Merger
text: Invitrogen, which makes chemical kits used to analyze and clone genes, said it agreed to combine with Applied Biosystems Group, a unit of Applera, in a cash and stock deal it valued at $6.7 billion. The deal price of $38 per share is 17 percent above Applied Biosystems’ closing stock price on Wednesday.

headline: Bid May Spark Battle Royale for Anheuser-Busch
text: A bitter battle for control of Anheuser-Busch appears to be looming after the brewer, one of the nation’s most prominent family-run companies, formally became the target of a $46.4 billion unsolicited takeover offer from InBev of Belgium on Wednesday.

headline: The Early Word: A Setback for Obama
text: The resignation of Senator Barack Obama’s top vice presidential vetter, James A. Johnson, whose businesses dealings had been called into question by the media and the opposing campaign, poses two sticky problems for the presumptive Democratic nominee.

headline: Lehman Shakes Up Top Management
text: Lehman Brothers, suffering from a steep stock decline and its first quarterly loss as a public company, said Thursday that it replaced its chief financial officer and chief operating officer, effective immediately.

headline: More Construction Prosecutions May Be on Way
text: The owner of a Brooklyn construction site where a day laborer died in March when earth and debris collapsed on him was charged with manslaughter. In announcing the indictment, at a time in which construction-related deaths in New York are running far ahead of last year’s pace, the authorities said that more construction-related prosecutions may be ahead, Michael Wilson reports.

headline: Authorities Retrieve Car From Hudson River
text: Updated, 4 p.m. | The Police Department said that divers searching the Hudson River on Thursday morning for a car that had become submerged in the water did not, in fact, find a body, contradicting an earlier account from a Fire Department spokesman.

headline: Neck and Neck Until the End, Turkey Dispatches Switzerland
text: One minute remained in the tumultuous, rain-soaked encounter between Switzerland and Turkey in Basel on Wednesday night when, with great optimism and good fortune, a young Turk named Arda Turan won a thrilling game, 2-1. The rain gods frowned on the Swiss and smiled, ultimately, on the Turks, who came from a goal down to win.

headline: Polly Want a Conversation?
text: Video

headline: Was It a Slur?
text: Salon’s Alex Koppelman, tipped off by a reader, reports that on Fox News yesterday, “during a segment discussing conservative attacks against Michelle Obama, the wife of presumptive Democratic nominee Barack Obama, the network described the former as ‘Obama’s baby mama.’ ” (Koppelman has the video clip of the controversial chyron on his blog.)

headline: ‘Top Chef’ Finale Cooks Up A First For Bravo
text: “It took four seasons, but a woman finally took the top spot on Bravo’s ‘Top Chef,'” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Democrats Rally Around McMahon in S.I. Race
text: Democratic elected officials are clearly trying to make sure that City Councilman Michael E. McMahon has the upper hand in his campaign for the party’s nomination for the Congressional seat now held by Vito J. Fossella, a Republican who represents Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn.

headline: News Networks Firm Up Convention Plans
text: In the days since Barack Obama solidified his standing as the presumptive Democratic nominee, “television news executives have begun to set their plans for covering the four-day Democratic convention, which begins on Aug. 25, and its Republican counterpart, which opens in St. Paul on Sept. 1, Labor Day,” Jacques Steinberg reports.

headline: U.S. Releases Video of Pakistan Airstrike
text: The United States military today confronted the sharpest criticism of an airstrike that left 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers dead on Tuesday night by releasing what it says is a video of the incident. (For background, see this article by Carlotta Gall and Eric Schmitt).

headline: Rule 1: Don’t Discuss Politics
text: Who says there are no literary feuds these days?

headline: The Hazard of Being Near the Top
text: You’re one of the top-ranked executives at a big-name Wall Street firm. You’re in good with the boss (or so you think). And then it happens — someone else gets your job.

headline: Indiana Jones and the Fake Crystal Skull
text: Now that we’ve seen one Hollywood version of pre-Columbian crystal skulls, could there be another crystal-skull movie with some real archeology in it — and a very devious French forger? I’m not sure what the box-office potential is, but if any reader can come up with the outline of a clever plot, I’ll award a prize: your choice of an Indiana Jones DVD or a one-year subscription to the magazine Archaeology.

headline: Lehman Shares Climb Back to Neutral
text: It may be difficult to tell from this stock chart, but Lehman Brothers‘ stock has actually improved from earlier this morning.

headline: Has Pelfrey Figured It Out?
text: Pop Quiz: Which pitcher would you rather have?

headline: Paging Dr. Melfi
text: STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL

headline: Obama Campaign Builds Rumor Debunking Site
text: With rumors and innuendo flying around the Internet with greater ease — and nastiness — then ever before, the Obama campaign has decided to use the same medium to take on the purveyors of what the campaign is calling “dishonest smears.”

headline: CNN And The Weather Channel: Complementary Channels?
text: Casual cable viewers could occasionally be forgiven for confusing CNN with The Weather Channel.

headline: Finding Fun in Salmonella
text: BRIEFS What to do with all the tomatoes banned from shelves these days? Today’s edition of the Newseum’s excellent feature on the nation’s front pages offered an idea: “You say ‘to-may-to’ and I say ‘to-mah-to.’ But however we say it, it’s front-page news. Since mid-April, salmonella-tainted tomatoes have sickened more than 150 people in 17 states, putting restaurants and consumers on alert. Today newspapers across the country highlighted the story as health officials, searching for the outbreak’s source, struggled to ketchup.

headline: Poll: Support for Gay Rights, and Bloomberg for Governor
text: New York State voters support, by a margin of 53 percent to 40 percent, Gov. David A. Paterson’s order to state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed outside the state, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released today. But the poll found that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg got the most votes when respondents were asked about the race for governor in 2010.

headline: Keep Your Jell-O Shot Away From My MacBook
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: How to Block Cellphone Spam
text: If I told you that today's e-column would change your life, would you mind that it's sort of short?

headline: Recipe of the Day: Spaghetti With Zucchini and Mint
text: Spaghetti carbonara — spaghetti tossed with egg, crisp bacon or pancetta and loads of Parmesan — has become something of a symbol for over-the-top pasta. Made with zucchini, though, the dish becomes a little less fat-laden. And because the backbone of the sauce remains eggs and Parmesan, it is still rich — and quite delicious.

headline: YouTube for PictureBooks?
text: Lookybook is a new site where you can browse children’s picture books by flipping through every page. There’s a bit of a half-baked social-networking angle to it — users can comment on books and build bookshelves of favorites. But mostly it’s a try-before-you-buy tool. And maybe the coolest thing (for bloggers) is that you can embed any book on your own site as easily as a YouTube video.

headline: Satellites and Human Rights
text: It’s pretty clear that technology can potentially smooth the path toward 9 billion people (more or less) seeking a decent life. The most familiar applications are in realms like energy (cheaper solar cells), transportation (Masdar’s smart people movers) and health (water filters or quick tuberculosis tests). But there is growing evidence that another field, human rights, can be aided by gadgets — in this case eyes in the sky.

headline: ‘Don’t Worry, America Is Safe’
text: Aired Wednesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: President Bush is in Europe right now, on a tour of Germany, Italy, France, England, and several other countries that hate him.

headline: When a Tree Falls on a Neighbor’s House
text: If a tree on my property falls on a neighbor’s house during a storm and damages it, whose insurance covers the damage?

headline: ‘E-Mail Buddies’
text: Aired Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Apparently Barack Obama is e-mail buddies with Scarlett Johansson. This is making me question Barack Obama’s judgment, though. If he has Scarlett Johansson’s e-mail address, why is he wasting time running for president?

headline: Can Credit-Card Interest Be Deducted for a Home?
text: If I take out a cash advance on a credit card to use toward a down payment on a home, is the interest I pay on the credit card deductible on my federal income tax return?

headline: France in racing focus
text: Just a moment to reflect on the coming week and a half: France is the place to be this time. First, this weekend there is the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Yesterday the first qualifying session gave us all what we expected – or not quite. The top six cars were the Audis and the Peugeots and the seventh car was a Pescarolo. Wait, sorry, that order is not quite right, and that’s what’s interesting: The Peugeots took the top three spots, followed by the Audis and then the Pescarolo.

headline: ‘A Pay Cut To Work From Home’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC:  Well, John McCain just announced he wants to do a series of town hall meetings where he’ll meet with the public. That’s a good idea, yeah. It’s all part of McCain’s “Speak Up, I Can’t Hear You” tour.

headline: Answers About Mass Transit, Part 3
text: This is the third set of answers to selected reader questions from Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, which advocates for public transit improvements.

headline: Bear Bankers Land at Barclays
text: Barclays said it picked up several former Bear Stearns bankers, as the British bank continues to bulk up its presence in the United States.

headline: Greece: Ransom Deadline Announced
text: The kidnappers of a prominent businessman have demanded a $46.5 million ransom and have given his family a week to obtain the money and arrange for his release, the Greek media said. Police officials did not confirm the ransom request, but the state-run NET television network said that an anonymous caller had contacted the family of George Mylonas. Mr. Mylonas, chairman of an aluminum conglomerate with operations in Europe, Africa and the Middle East, was ambushed by three hooded men while driving to his home in Thessaloniki late on Monday.

headline: Just Asking | When Cindy Met Oscar
text: Cindy McCain, who recently spurned Oscar de la Renta, sporting what appears to be a Chanel watch (AP).

headline: Serbia: War Crimes Fugitive Arrested
text: The Serbian police arrested one of the four remaining war crimes fugitives wanted by the United Nations tribunal in The Hague. The suspect, Stojan Zupljanin, was arrested outside Belgrade, said Bruno Vekaric, spokesman for Serbia's war crimes prosecution office. Mr. Zupljanin was a Bosnian Serb police commander during the civil war in the 1990s. The tribunal wants him on charges of crimes against humanity for overseeing Serbian-run prison camps.

headline: ‘Trip to the Sun’
text: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: NASA has announced a plan to take a trip to the sun. So, apparently, the search for bin Laden continues.

headline: ‘Flirty E-Mails’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: For the first time ever, gas across the entire country averaging $4 a gallon. Or as we call that in Los Angeles, the good old days.

headline: How to Block Cellphone Spam
text: If I told you that today’s e-column would change your life, would you mind that it’s sort of short?

headline: What Does the Future Hold?
text: As the fog of the Triple Crown hangover begins to clear, everyone connected to American horse racing, from fans (those that are left) to hot-walkers, will be wondering what the future holds. Will the legacy of Big Brown and Eight Belles be change for the sport?

headline: Iraq Briefing
text: A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog’s Google Reader Shared Items.

headline: Two Kinds of Numb
text: 24 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: an hour and half “endurance” ride, which for me means a ride to the park after work, two quick laps of the 6.1 mile circuit, and a ride home.

headline: Lost Power? Con Ed Tool May Help (if Your Battery Is Charged)
text: When lights and air-conditioners went out in Yorkville and Bensonhurst during this week’s heat wave and thunderstorms, Consolidated Edison customers were able to track the utility’s efforts to restore power in real time online. That is, if they still had power (or a battery-powered laptop or other device).In any case, those who could sign on found a nifty map that Con Edison started on May 30 to show which neighborhoods and how many customers lost power, the cause of the power failure and the estimated time until power would be restored.

headline: Woman Power on ‘Top Chef’
text: Hillary didn’t make it, but Stephanie did.

headline: $1.1 Billion in Claims Paid by M.T.A., Report Finds
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has paid out more than $1.1 billion in claims for personal injury and property damage over the last 12 years, according to a new report [pdf] by State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli.The claims include $285,046 paid by the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad to riders who ripped their pants or other items of clothing on the armrests in the M7 train cars. The armrests are notorious among riders on the two railroads because their design makes them uniquely suited to snag on clothing, especially pants pockets. The two railroads received a total of more than 1,400 claims for torn clothing last year, significantly more than the two previous years, when about 800 claims were filed annually.

headline: The Morning Skate: N.H.L. Awards, Ron Wilson’s Day 1 and Bogey
text: Maybe we missed something, but it seems there’s no mention in any of the area papers this morning that either Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist or Devils goalie Martin Brodeur might win the Vezina Trophy as the NHL’s top netminder tonight.

headline: Another Night, Another Fox/CBS Ratings Slugfest
text: A two-hour edition of “So You Think You Can Dance” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, with 8.8 million viewers tuning in from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: A Trip to Morocco
text: Six of us are interested in traveling to Morocco. What are the best ways to travel among the cities, and are there tour companies that deal with small groups?

headline: Credibility Gap?
text: The charges by a former N.B.A. referee that the league used its referees to manipulate the outcomes of games has rocked the sport and put the league on the defensive. Do you believe the charges, and if so, how serious a blow is it to the league’s credibility. If you don’t believe them, why not?

headline: An English Approach to Peas
text: From Ed, a regular Bitten contributor. –MBAs of the first weekend in June there were still no real peas in the farmers’ market. By “real” peas, I mean the roundish ones you take out of the pods while listening to music and looking forward to dinner. As opposed to snap peas and snow peas, where you eat the whole thing, pod and all, which I view as the most sinful sort of laziness. Next thing you know, they’ll develop a peanut with an edible shell.

headline: Bonnaroo: A Wildly Diverse Lineup
text: Another June, another Bonnaroo festival, and I’m headed back to that big rolling hay pasture in Manchester, Tenn. with its natural amphitheaters, tent stages and tie-dyed diehards. Bonnaroo still has its original core of jam bands and rootsy Americana–it ends on Sunday with a Widespread Panic marathon, and the Dead’s Phil Lesh and Friends are booked for the wee hours of Saturday night/Sunday morning.

headline: Habeas Gitmo
text: “Foreign terrorism suspects held at the Guantánamo Bay naval base in Cuba have constitutional rights to challenge their detention there in United States courts, the Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, on Thursday in a historic decision on the balance between personal liberties and national security,” reports The Times’s David Stout, and again the court finds itself playing politics.

headline: Join the Blog Revolution
text: First, thanks to the people at The Rail, especially Melissa, who had the foresight to add actual bloggers, found me and Alan Mann (Left at the Gate), and put up with me. Not every blog is a “blog,” but The Rail was one for sure.

headline: Barron’s Fund-Raising Lags, but Not His Confidence
text: It was more than a year ago when City Councilman Charles Barron announced that he would run for Brooklyn borough president in 2009 and that he was abandoning his plans to challenge Representative Edolphus Towns this year for his Congressional seat.

headline: Nevada’s Texter-in-Chief
text: While Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada most certainly had textual relations with that woman, none of the 867 mobile text messages between them over six weeks were “love notes,” the governor told reporters on Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Assemblywoman Is Sentenced to 2 to 6 Years
text: Diane M. Gordon, the former state assemblywoman from Brooklyn who was convicted of helping a developer acquire city-owned land in exchange for building her a house in a gated community in Queens, was sentenced on Thursday to from two to six years in prison.

headline: One Firm, Two Weeks, Three Ratings
text: In these volatile times for Wall Street, it’s hard for an analyst to know whether to rate a banking stock a buy, neutral or underperform. Guy Moszkowski of Merrill Lynch seems especially torn — this month alone, he has given all three ratings to Lehman Brothers.

headline: Fed's Plosser Warns on Inflation
text: CNBC interviews Charles Plosser, president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank about his hawkish position on inflation.

headline: City Takes Action Against Brooklyn Architect
text: Updated, 4:01 p.m. | Administrative charges have been filed against Robert M. Scarano Jr., an architect who built his career during Brooklyn’s construction boom, saying that he made false or misleading statements on applications submitted to the Department of Buildings in connection with two projects in Greenpoint, the authorities announced on Thursday.

headline: Willis’s Decline Wasn’t Surprising
text: Things have not turned out as planned in Detroit, where the Tigers, buoyed by a major trade in the off-season that landed them the prized young stars Miguel Cabrera and Dontrelle Willis, have scuffled along to a 28-37 record good for second-to-last in the American League Central.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, June 12:

headline: Dark Humor
text: Qassem H.J. is a newspaper cartoonist working in Iraq. He abbreviates his name to protect his identity.

headline: Look Who’s Walking
text: Judging from Sean John’s fall lookbook, black is the new black.Ensuring that there is adequate racial representation in fashion, an industry that tends to favor whitewashed ideals of beauty, is a hot-button topic. So it was a welcome surprise to see that Sean John’s new fall/winter lookbook features exclusively black models. But then you start to wonder, where are all the Asians? And who’s thinking about the poor freckly redheads? What do you think — is Diddy going in the right direction, or is it all about promoting a good mix?

headline: Update on J.B. Cox
text: When the Yankees placed reliever J.B. Cox on the disabled list Wednesday without specifying a reason, it did not seem to be a good sign. But in talking just now to Mark Newman, the team’s senior vice president for baseball operations, it seems to be just a minor problem.

headline: Foreshadowings: A Judge’s Leanings
text: BRIEFS Previewing a major pornography case over the weekend, The Los Angeles Times noted that Judge Alex Kozinski’s “involvement in the case may be a stroke of luck” for the defendant, Ira Isaacs. The paper cited some pornography-friendly rulings, though it didn’t mention that he contributed to a Web site that featured sexually explicit materials. Now that the revelation has halted the trial, however, Mr. Isaacs’s luck seems to have run out.

headline: It’s Over: What Now?
text: The Triple Crown is over. We came very close to seeing a horse sweep the series. Big Brown was much the best in the Derby and the Preakness. The same horse did not show up for the Belmont for whatever reasons.

headline: When Chiefs Follow Lieutenants Out the Door
text: Perhaps the ultimate test of a top Wall Street executive is simple: Stay in the game. Of course, one needs to make money, and preferably lots of it, but especially when times grow tough, the hardest task is simply to hold onto one’s seat.

headline: More Top Yahoos Heading for the Exits
text: A pair of senior Yahoo executives is leaving the beleaguered Internet company, continuing a steady exodus of executives that began more than two years ago.

headline: Cuban Breaks World Record in Hurdles
text: There’s a new world record holder in the 110-meter hurdles: Dayron Robles of Cuba. Running at a meet in the Czech Republic today, Robles broke the world record set in 2006 by China’s Liu Xiang by 1 one-hundredth of a second.

headline: Going Down to Central Park
text: City Room opened the mail recently and discovered three sweatbands — a headband and two wristbands — promoting BeFitNYC, a new Parks Department initiative for recreational sports and physical exercise. Normally, we pay little attention to publicity-seeking giveaways. But it’s a little unusual for the city to venture into the world of athletic wear (O.K., they did do bike helmets).

headline: An Antimodernist in Paris
text: Architecture |“Paris is miraculous in no small measure because modern architects have not been able to get their hands on it.” An essay about Léon Krier, architect-philosopher who believes that architectural modernism is not just ugly but also mistaken about people. — City Journal

headline: Yahoo Picks Google Deal Over Microsoft
text: The talks are dead. Really, this time they are dead.

headline: Screen Writers
text: I finally watched “Starting Out in the Evening” the other night, prompted by one rave review after the next, and I came away with a little shrug — entertained but not dazzled, and a bit mystified as to all the huzzah. Mostly I think that’s because Lauren Ambrose’s character was so despicable from the outset, so nakedly manipulative and self-serving, that I didn’t believe a man as cautious and guarded as Frank Langella’s character would ever be taken in by her. (Or maybe my expectations were too high. I had the same reaction to the overhyped “Sideways,” after all, which I found merely likable enough.)

headline: Yahoo Decides Not to Split Its Ad Baby in Two
text: Microsoft and Yahoo have broken up again — and this time, they say the relationship is over. In a news release Thursday afternoon, Yahoo said it had “concluded” discussions about a “potential transaction” with Microsoft for a full or partial acquisition.

headline: Misdemeanor Charges Dismissed Against Times Building Climber
text: A grand jury has dismissed all criminal charges against Alain Robert, the first of two men to scale the New York Times building last week, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney’s office said on Thursday.

headline: Berlusconi Likes McCain — (It’s an Age Thing)
text: ROME – International diplomacy obliges leaders not to comment on the political affairs of other countries.

headline: N.R.C.C. Lost $725,000 to Former Treasurer, Audit Finds
text: A scheme by a former treasurer resulted in a loss of about $725,000 to the House Republicans’ campaign arm, according to an audit released today.

headline: Coldplay Lyrics Take a Swipe at Bill O’Reilly
text: Coldplay’s new album comes out today, and one of the songs on it was inspired by an unusual source: Bill O’Reilly, the Fox News Channel host. Not surprisingly — given the source — the tune isn’t exactly an endorsement of the conservative commentator.

headline: A Budweiser Independence Plan
text: Quite a European party. That was my biggest impression listening to InBev‘s conference call Thursday morning. As everyone knows by now, InBev has made a proposal to acquire Anheuser-Busch at $65 a share.

headline: From Failed to Just Fragile?
text: Iraq has transitioned from a “failed state” to a “fragile state,” in the felicitous phrase of Vali Nasr, a senior fellow for Middle Eastern affairs at the Council on Foreign Relations, who with a colleague, Stephen Biddle, recently returned from a two-week tour of Iraq. The job before the American military is now changing from counter-insurgency to peacekeeping, they say, which sounds very promising.

headline: Citigroup’s $800 Million Misstep
text: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Reaching the Finish Line
text: I think I’m in denial. I can’t stop looking at the site, moderating comments, hoping for one more post to arrive to extend the life of The Rail. It’s like a drug, and I’m severely addicted. A month and a half ago I couldn’t have imagined this.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'The Incredible Hulk'
text: A.O. Scott reviews "The Incredible Hulk," based on the Marvel comic about a scientist who has a monstrous transformation.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'The Incredible Hulk'
text: A.O. Scott reviews "The Incredible Hulk," based on the Marvel comic about a scientist who has a monstrous transformation.

headline: Feeling For … Desert Boots in Summer
text: Bruce Pask, T Magazine’s men’s fashion director, writes on style every two weeks.

headline: From Amazon to Zadie
text: After more than a decade, Robert McCrum has left his post as literary editor of The London Observer to become associate editor. He reflects on the major developments of his tenure, from Amazon to Zadie Smith, here. McCrum also stirred up some debate with a recent post about whether blogs have been good for books. It’s an interesting question…

headline: For the Moment | Viktor & Rolf
text: Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

headline: No Recession?

headline: Report Says One-Third of City Has Trouble Affording Food
text: About 3.1 million New Yorkers — more than a third of the city’s population — had problems affording food at some point last year — a figure that is slightly up from last year, but 55 percent more than 2003, the first year the annual survey was conducted by the Food Bank for New York City in conjunction with the Marist Institute.The report, the “NYC Hunger Experience 2008,” [pdf] was released on Wednesday at a news conference with City Council members.

headline: Getaway Day
text: Thank you. Posters. Readers. Our contributors — a committed and star-studded bunch that worked for free over the past seven weeks. Thanks to the bloggers of the Thoroughbred Alliance and beyond. I appreciate you letting us poach your work, and I am grateful for your passion and expertise and how it enriched the content and experience of The Rail.

text: Ground-breakings are a dime a dozen in Washington, D.C., where cranes and high-rises glut the skyline. But the spade of dirt turned last week near the National Mall for the new headquarters of the United States Institute of Peace was a real milestone.

headline: The World’s First Olympian-Paralympian
text: The South African swimmer Natalie du Toit, who had already qualified for the Beijing Olympics, is poised to make history after being named to her country’s Paralympic team on Thursday. If she competes in both sets of Games this August and September, she will become the first athlete to accomplish the feat.

headline: Summer Music in the Homes of the Tsars
text: Summer is the time to enjoy the musical bounty of Moscow’s tsarist palaces. Although Petersburg is legendary for palaces such as the Catherine Palace at Tsarskoye Selo, Moscow also has its fair share of pre-revolutionary estates. These form the backdrop for concerts of jazz, symphonies, and chamber music throughout the Russian capital’s precious warm weather months, which, for the most part have been unseasonably cool so far. But, well, that’s another story. Now on to the music.

headline: And the Award for Best Deal-Maker Goes to …
text: Forget about Microsoft being a “disciplined” investor. Or Yahoo successfully defending itself. The best deal maker in the Microsoft-Yahoo saga is clearly Google.

headline: Grand Theft Auto IV Didn’t Bolster Console Sales
text: Makers of video game consoles had hoped that the wild success of Grand Theft Auto IV, which hit stores in late April, would inspire consumers to buy hardware on which to play the game.

headline: PC Sales Projections Are Better Than Expected
text: Two data research firms, Gartner and IDC, have just come out with new forecasts for PC shipments, and they’re not what they expected.

headline: ‘The Jacobsons’
text: “The Jacobsons” is a sort of modern silent film, inspired by early silent films. It is a story told purely in pictures. It is about a contest between a father and son with a vaudevillian flavor; perfect for Father’s Day.

headline: M. Night Shyamalan’s New Villain
text: What does this week’s Science Times section have in common with “The Happening,” the new thriller from M. Night Shyamalan? The common element is the ability of non-human nature to unnerve us when it acts out of character. I explored this notion for a half hour on the phone with the writer/director a few days ago, talking about science, nature, scary movies, the Gaia hypothesis, bee die-offs and more. Then I had an advance look at the film, which opens this weekend.

headline: The Scout in the Back of the Press Box
text: The scout in the back of the press box is 83 years old, with a World Series ring on both hands and a folded-up piece of paper that celebrates his claim to fame. The piece of paper is 19 years old, and the words “pine polisher” are underlined in blue pen — pine polisher being a synonym for bench warmer.

headline: N.H.L. 2007-08 All-Star Teams, All-Rookie Team Announced
text: The 2007-08 first and second NHL All-Star teams and the NHL All-Rookie team were announced Thursday.

headline: Bonnaroo: Tie-dye, Hacky Sack, Bikinis
text: Arriving back at the Bonnaroo site gives me what I can’t resist calling deja ‘Roo. It’s one of those Tennessee days when the sun beats down and the sweat just starts to roll down my face two steps out of an air conditioned car. Teen-agers in tie-dye, check. Someone’s got a T-shirt that reads, “The Hippies Were Right.” There are the guys playing hacky sack, glancing at the girls walking by in bikinis. Someone on the little Solar Stage is proudly explaining that it’s entirely powered by solar cells recharging batteries.

headline: Pure Tyranny
text: Righteous indignation is so easy, so pleasant, when you can sit back and fling it overseas.  I had that edifying experience on the D.C. Metro Wednesday morning, reading in the Times about the Muslim women in France who are going to cosmetic surgeons for hymen replacement surgery so that they can bleed as seeming virgins on their wedding nights.   It's a practice that has, apparently, become relatively common in the immigrant communities of Europe. But, of course, it seems like hair-raising news in a country like ours, where a young woman's right to do with her body as she sees fit has, for decades, been enshrined as perhaps the most essential part of her God-given human dignity.  As my 11-year-old says, Yeah, right.   Right after I finished reading the Times piece, I called the French Embassy to find out under what conditions French social security would pay for the hymen-restoration procedure. (It's "mostly done in private clinics and in most cases not covered by tax-financed insurance plans," said the Times article; "Oh la la!" said the receptionist to whom I relayed my query.)  I then started rifling through my desk. And there, beneath a report showing paid family leave to be on the decline, beneath a Newsweek article on a new children's book, "My Beautiful Mommy," that tells the story of a mom who becomes even prettier after a nose job and a tummy tuck, I found the story that the hymen news had immediately brought to mind.  It was also from The Times, from May 19, and featured 70-odd girls, of "early grade school to college" age, with their fathers, stepfathers and fathers-in-law-to-be, at the ninth annual, largely evangelical "Father-Daughter Purity Ball."   "The evening, which alternated between homemade Christian rituals and giddy dancing" – and which culminated, for at least one father and his daughters, with a dreamy walk in the night around a lake, "was a joyous public affirmation of the girls' sexual abstinence until they wed," said the Times article.   "From this, it's only a matter of degree to the man in Austria," I'd scribbled across the first page.  The "man in Austria," of course, was 73-year-old Josef Fritzl, who was around that time also making headlines after it was discovered that he had kept his daughter, Elisabeth, 42, locked up in a cellar for 24 years, during which time he'd raped her regularly, and had her bear him seven children.   ("It was a lovely idea for me, to have a proper family … down in the cellar, with a good wife and a couple of children," he said in his confession.)  Fritzl, a self-described "man of decency and good values," had imprisoned his daughter after she began staying out all night and drinking. "I had to create a place where I could keep Elisabeth by force if necessary, away from the outside world," he confessed.   "Fathers, our daughters are waiting for us," Randy Wilson, one of the ball's organizers, said at the Colorado Springs "Purity" event. "They are desperately waiting for us in a culture that lures them into the murky waters of exploitation. They need to be rescued by you, their dad."  I don't want to take this analogy too far. I don't mean to imply that there's any equivalency between Josef Fritzl's acts and the Purity Ball. Fritzl's actions were uniquely horrific, and I am not accusing the men who danced in Colorado Springs of any crimes. But there is nonetheless a kind of horror to their obsession with their daughters' sexuality. There is a dangerous boundary violation contained in their vow "before God to cover my daughter as her authority and protection in the area of purity." And there is even greater danger to the fact that this particular aspect of the nationwide "abstinence movement" has not been broadly denounced as the form of emotional violence against girls that it indisputably is.  Judith Lewis Herman, a clinical professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, whose work with and writings on incest victims in the 1980s revolutionized the understanding of the crime and its perpetrators, believes that incest, like rape generally, has to be viewed within a wider context of power relations. Incest, she says, is "an abuse of patriarchal power," a criminal perversion of fatherly control and influence. It is perpetrated, in many cases, by men who present themselves as the guardians of the moral order. And it isn't always physical; in her 1981 book (with Lisa Hirschman), "Father-Daughter Incest," she writes that the violation can be emotional, too, as when a "seductive father" oversteps his boundaries and goes places he never should in his daughter's head.   "Something I need from dad is affirmation, being told I'm beautiful," said 19-year-old Jordyn Wilson at the ball. "If we don't get it from home, we will go out to the culture and get it."  Sexual abuse – judging by statistics mostly based upon reports of incest – has greatly decreased in our country in recent years. From 1992 to 2003, substantiated cases went down 40 percent, according to the Crimes Against Children Research Center at the University of New Hampshire. Lisa Jones, a research professor at the center, says she thinks the impressive decrease isn't just due to changed reporting patterns or data collection methods. "We feel like it's very suggestive of a likelihood that there's a real decline," she said.  There are many possible reasons for this improvement. But one, I think, that has to be considered is that girls' and women's status has risen. Acceptance of sexual assault and insult has declined. In a world where girls and women are stronger, "abuses of patriarchal power" are less tolerable, acceptable, and possible.  Or should be.  In highly secular France, the reaction to the drama over young women's virginity playing out in Muslim communities has been public and profound. Justice Minister Rachida Dati recently had to fight off calls for her resignation after she upheld a ruling by a regional court that had annulled the marriage of two French Muslims because the bride turned out not to be a virgin.   Our condemnation of cultural practices and beliefs in our own country that violate girls' and young women's dignity and most intimate personal boundaries should be no less total. For, when it comes to female chastity, much of what passes for "protection" is nothing less than sick.

headline: Screen Actors Guild Says Contract Talks May Extend Into July
text: Associated Press: “The Screen Actors Guild said Thursday that talks with Hollywood studios could extend past the end of the current contract on June 30, but was willing to keep actors working without a deal.”

headline: Mud and Muck in Minnesota's Everglades of the North
text: IT was a Sunday morning at Bemidji Regional Airport in northern Minnesota, and our plane had just left the ground. The wings shuddered as we buzzed above a highway and banked right, climbing in the four-seat Cessna toward clouds and a view so flat the land looked concave.

headline: Mixed Feelings as Change Overtakes 125th St.
text: It isn’t news that just two or three years ago, Harlem had a paucity of bank branches, grocery stores and other basic amenities, or that now that more affluent people have started to move there, upscale shops and restaurants have followed.

headline: In Eastern Iowa, the City That ‘Would Never Flood’ Goes 12 Feet Under
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  They said this city would never flood. They talked about 1993, and 1966 and 1851, years when the Cedar River swelled and hissed but mostly stayed within its banks. They thought they were safe. They were wrong.

headline: Rangers, and Some Drama, Are Headed to Shea
text: Only one of two teams yet to play the Mets at Shea Stadium, the Texas Rangers arrive on Friday with three intriguing story lines.

headline: Footnotes
text: Pete Seeger, below, has been added to the lineup of “Roots of American Music,” the two-day series that closes the free Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. He will appear at 11 a.m. on Aug. 24, the second day of “Roots,” with his grandson Tao Rodriguez-Seeger and the blues singer Guy Davis, on a bill that also includes Patti Smith, Charlie Haden, the Knitters and the Music Makers Blues Revue. ... Martin I. Kagan has been named executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Foundation. Mr. Kagan, 61, who has been the executive director of Opera America, managing director of the John Anson Ford Amphitheater in Los Angeles and general manager of Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., succeeds Wallace Chappell, who held the job for four years. ... The Lebanese-born author Rawi Hage has won the 100,000-euro ($154,240) International Impac Dublin Literary Award, billed as the world’s richest prize for a single work of fiction. He won for his debut novel, “De Niro’s Game,” about growing up in war-torn Beirut.

headline: Like American, More Airlines Add Fees for Checking Luggage
text: For weeks, American Airlines stood alone in facing the ire of passengers over its decision to begin charging $15 to check the first bag. But it now has some company.

headline: For China’s Top Star, Record Is Lost and Challenge Grows
text: Dayron Robles of Cuba set a world record of 12.87 seconds in the 110-meter hurdles Thursday, eclipsing the mark previously held by China’s most celebrated Olympic star and setting the stage for a potential upset in the country’s most eagerly awaited event at the Summer Games in Beijing.

headline: 3rd Guilty Plea in Prostitution Ring
text: A 62-year-old former tax specialist who ran the high-priced online escort service that was patronized by Eliot Spitzer pleaded guilty on Thursday to federal prostitution and money laundering charges.

headline: Obama’s Campaign Opens a New Web Site to Strike Back at ‘Dishonest Smears’
text: KAUKAUNA, Wis.  Confronted with one of the trickiest problems in politics  when to ignore rumors and misrepresentations and when to risk giving them greater visibility by rebutting them  Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign began to push back aggressively on Thursday against what it said were unfounded and potentially damaging reports.

headline: This Land Is Her Land (and Her Artwork, Too)
text: To judge from the museum calendars of the last few seasons, the ’70s were segregated by gender: large surveys of Robert Smithson and Gordon Matta-Clark at the Whitney and Richard Serra at the Museum of Modern Art; equally hefty exhibitions of feminist art across the river at P.S. 1 and the Brooklyn Museum. What’s missing is a sense of the decade as radical for male and female sculptors alike.

headline: ‘I Do’? Oh, No. Not Here You Don’t.
text: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Thousands of gay and lesbian couples across California are expected to marry next week, when a State Supreme Court decision granting that right becomes official.

headline: McCain and Obama Split on Justices’ Guantánamo Ruling
text: BOSTON  The presidential candidates took differing positions Thursday on the Supreme Court decision granting foreign terrorism suspects at Guantánamo Bay a right to challenge their detention in civilian courts. Senator John McCain expressed concern about the ruling, while Senator Barack Obama lauded it.

headline: Deafening Howl, Then Deadly Chaos for Scouts
text: BLENCOE, Iowa  Just before the tornado hit, the Boy Scouts were gathering on the porch of a shelter, playing cards and waiting out what many of them thought was just a pelting rain. In a matter of moments, a scout leader, hearing a faint tornado siren, hurried them inside, and then, as he stared out the open door and saw the twister in the distance, ordered them to dive under tables, survivors said.

headline: Art in Review
text: TOM SACHS

headline: Unemployment Aid Extension Easily Passes House
text: WASHINGTON  The House took another step on Thursday in a running political fight over unemployment insurance by ignoring a veto threat from President Bush and easily approving an extension of benefits for idle workers whose aid is running out.

headline: Something Lethal Lurks in the Rustling Trees
text: The knives had been out and sharpened long before M. Night Shyamalan’s latest movie, “The Happening,” opened on Friday. A fine craftsman with aspirations to the canon, this would-be auteur has, in the last few years, experienced a sensational fall from critical and commercial grace, partly through his own doing  by making bad movies and then, even after those movies failed, by continuing to feed his ego publicly  and partly through the entertainment media that, once they smell weakness, will always bite the hand they once slathered in drool.

headline: Obama, Liberalism and the Challenge of Reform
text: Is Barack Obama really a force for change, or is he just a traditional Democrat with a patina of postpartisan rhetoric?

headline: Music Writer Resigns
text: A music writer and columnist for The San Antonio Express-News resigned on Tuesday after the paper accused him of hiring a ghost writer to produce more than 100 articles since 2001, the paper reported. Ramiro Burr, 52, who had been writing for the paper for 15 years, stepped down as an ethics investigation was coming to a close. “Ramiro caused The Express-News to unknowingly publish work under his name that was not, in fact, his own work,” said Robert Rivard, the editor. Mr. Burr, whose writing was also syndicated in other newspapers, had contested the allegations but, calling it a “difficult situation,” told the paper in a statement, “I may have been a little overzealous, or overreached in trying to be the best reporter/syndicated columnist I could be.” He added, “I sincerely apologize for breaking any rules.”

headline: How to Curb Big Builders’ Big Appetites
text: PRISCILLA ALMODOVAR, a tiny presence with a towering agenda, is describing the reception she received from some of New York City’s most aggressive  as in profit-conscious  real estate developers after she assumed control of the hitherto myopic New York State Housing Finance Agency during the reform groundswell that characterized the salad days of the Spitzer administration. Before that administration wilted.

headline: A Bull Market Sees the Worst in Speculators
text: In Washington, financial speculators have fat targets on their backs.

headline: Will the Real Tax-and-Spender Please ’Fess Up?
text: With the general election in full gear, Senator John McCain has stepped up efforts to paint his rival, Senator Barack Obama, as what he calls a traditional Democratic tax-and-spend liberal. On Tuesday, for instance, Mr. McCain, addressing a business gathering, accused Mr. Obama of wanting to enact “the largest single tax increase since World War II.”

headline: Disputed Blast in Gaza Kills 5
text: JERUSALEM  A large explosion destroyed a residential building in the northern Gaza town of Beit Lahiya on Thursday, killing at least five Palestinians, among them several Hamas militants and a baby girl.

headline: What to Ask About Schizophrenia
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening, and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

headline: Politics and Race: History Lessons
text: To the Editor:

headline: Retail Sales Rise Above Forecasts
text: Retail sales picked up last month as Americans received more than $50 billion in stimulus checks. Investors took the report as an encouraging sign for the resilience of the economy, even as some analysts wondered how long the uptick would last.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about severe weather in Iowa referred incorrectly to the president of the chamber of commerce of Cedar Rapids, who released a statement about bridge closings. The official, Lee R. Clancey, is a woman.

headline: Moving, Roof, Walls and All
text: ROUGHLY 10,000 private homes are moved in the United States annually, according to the International Association of Structural Movers, the trade association for those who haul everything from houses to lighthouses. Now that doesn’t mean that 10,000 people pack up their things and members of the movers’ group help them carry the boxes (though that would be nice). It means that the entire house is put on a truck or barge, then hauled to another site.

headline: Another Great Start, Another Bad Finish
text: The Mets’ recent losses have come in a sickening loop, one in which the outcome is sensed before the rest of the grisly plot unfolds. One loss is barely distinguishable from the next because only the details  how many runners were left on base, which reliever failed  change from game to game.

headline: Invitrogen to Buy Applied Biosystems for $6.7 Billion
text: Invitrogen, an acquisitive provider of cells, probes and chemicals used in life sciences research, has made its biggest purchase yet. It will pay $6.7 billion in cash and stock to buy Applied Biosystems, the company that provided most of the equipment used in the Human Genome Project but that has struggled to adjust since that project ended early in this decade.

headline: Pentagon Shows Video of Strikes Tied to Deaths of 11 Pakistani Soldiers
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon on Thursday sought to justify airstrikes that killed 11 Pakistani soldiers by releasing what it said was a videotape of part of the episode.

headline: Banyan Tree Mayakoba and Magnolia Private Residence Club
text: Banyan Tree Mayakoba

headline: 6 More States Report Illnesses From Tomatoes
text: WASHINGTON  The tainted-tomato outbreak has spread to six more states, federal health officials said on Thursday, even as they acknowledged to lawmakers that they had yet to nail down major aspects of a food-safety plan released seven months ago.

headline: Courage to Bear Witness to Man’s Infinite Cruelties
text: “A Promise to the Dead: The Exile Journey of Ariel Dorfman,” the opening-night selection of this year’s Human Rights Watch International Film Festival, may not be the strongest of the program’s 19 feature-length films, but its rambling portrait of Mr. Dorfman, the Chilean playwright (“Death and the Maiden”), novelist and essayist, is a profile in courage colored with the anxiety of a human rights activist faced with painful moral choices.

headline: Mighty Climbers
text: United by blood, rope and a serious adrenaline addiction, Thomas and Alexander Huber run up rocks the way some of us run up credit cards  rapidly, fearlessly and with little regard for consequences.

headline: Japan, Seeking Trim Waists, Measures Millions
text: AMAGASAKI, Japan  Japan, a country not known for its overweight people, has undertaken one of the most ambitious campaigns ever by a nation to slim down its citizenry.

headline: Group Says Satellite Images Prove Rights Abuses in Ethiopia
text: Human rights advocates on Thursday said that Ethiopia has been committing “crimes against humanity,” including the torture, murder, rape, and forced eviction of civilians, in its crackdown on insurgents in the country’s isolated eastern Ogaden desert region.

headline: Harlan Cleveland, Diplomat and Scholar, Dies at 90
text: Harlan Cleveland, a former president of the University of Hawaii and an American ambassador to NATO who pressed for nuclear arms control and strengthening of the United Nations, died May 30 near his home in Sterling, Va. He was 90.

headline: With the Perfect Script, the Plot Thickens for the N.B.A.
text: Long before the buzzer sounded on the corrupt officiating career of Tim Donaghy, extraordinary notions of result-rigging occasionally took root in the minds of chagrined fans, in the stomachs of coaches dying a thousand playoff deaths and especially in the simple everyday language in and of the game.

headline: Dance Competition Tops Ratings Contest
text: A two-hour episode of “So You Think You Can Dance” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, as 8.8 million viewers tuned in to watch the dancers compete from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Fox led over all, CBS finished close behind, drawing the night’s largest audience with a rerun of “CSI: NY” during the 10 p.m. hour (9.2 million). CBS earned lower ratings earlier in the night with “The Price is Right” at 8 (6.1 million) followed by a repeat of “Criminal Minds” at 9 (8.2 million). Despite trailing just behind CBS in total viewers, NBC won a solid second-place finish among adults 18 to 49 thanks to the strength in that demographic of “Deal or No Deal” from 8 to 9:30 (8.5 million) and the premiere of “Celebrity Circus,” which attracted just 6.5 million total viewers from 9:30 to 11. With mostly repeats, ABC finished a distant fourth.

headline: Chinese Parents Call Off Quake Memorial After Official Warning
text: BEIJING  Parents who lost children in a particularly horrific school collapse during the May 12 earthquake in Sichuan Province scrapped their plan for a one-month mourning ceremony on Thursday after local officials warned them not to go through with it, two of the parents said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on May 4 about the Japanese baseball legend Sadaharu Oh misidentified the first Japanese native to go to the major leagues in the United States from the Pacific League in Japan. It was Masanori Murakami, in 1964  not Hideo Nomo, in 1995. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Thursday.
