text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: One Thing We Can Predict: A Poll Is Not an Election
text: To the Editor:

headline: Good Times Left Lehman Unprepared for the Bad
text: Sometimes, when you really mess up, it is good to admit you erred.

headline: A Femme Fatale Who Finds Mystery and Eroticism in a Wheelchair
text: “Quid Pro Quo” hovers in a noir-shaded twilight zone where repressed memories, dreams, desire and guilt merge in an obsession with physical and emotional paralysis. The first feature written and directed by Carlos Brooks, this small, intensely acted film is a psychological detective story that suggests a boutique version of David Cronenberg’s “Crash” or David Fincher’s “Fight Club,” but it eventually runs out of courage.

headline: V.A. Ban on Voter Drives Is Criticized
text: Voting rights groups are criticizing the Department of Veterans Affairs for its decision to ban registration drives among the veterans living at federally run nursing homes, shelters for the homeless and rehabilitation centers across the country.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: NATIONAL

headline: A Familiar Refrain for Struggling Stricker
text: SAN DIEGO  Adam Scott gave a few more details about his right hand injury after Thursday’s first round of the United States Open.

headline: A Sax Man of Distinction and That Vision Thing
text: To the extent that the tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan is known in the general jazz world, he’s known as a New Orleans patriarch and educator. Dig deeper and you might also hear about his long, eclectic career as a sideman and his role in inspiring the formation of both the Dirty Dozen Brass Band and the World Saxophone Quartet. But Mr. Jordan, 73, has never made much of a dent as a solo artist, and he still doesn’t have an entry in “The Biographical Encyclopedia of Jazz” (Oxford).

headline: Lottery Numbers
Britain: Wife of Failed Bomber Is Sentenced to 15 Years
text: A London judge sentenced the wife of one of four men convicted in an abortive plot to bomb London subway trains to 15 years in prison for failing to inform the police of her husband’s plans. Yeshi Girma, 32, is the wife of Hussain Osman, who was sentenced to life imprisonment last year for his plan to set off a bomb in West London in July 2005. The failed attack came two weeks after attacks on London’s transit system killed 56 people, including the four bombers.

headline: Phase 2 for Ron Paul
text: Representative Ron Paul announced on Thursday that he was legally suspending his Web-driven campaign for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Gates Presses NATO on Missile Defense
text: BRUSSELS  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates joined NATO defense ministers here Thursday in an effort to push forward a design for missile defenses that will protect all alliance nations from a potential Iranian ballistic missile attack.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Maple Man Has Ideas to Solve Baseball’s Bat Problem
text: More than 100,000 pieces of wood hang on a Wall of Shame in the Original Maple Bat Corporation’s factory in Quebec. Sam Holman, the company’s founder and the father of maple bats, said the remnants were put there because they were rejected for making bats.

headline: The MetroCard Is the Medium, With No Particular Message
text: Andy Padre, a 40-year-old artist, once went through 35,000 staples in one week, creating massive lilies out of foam and wire that would hang, suspended, over a table at a wedding at the Waldorf-Astoria. While he was working a day job at Microsoft, he once spent several hours every day for a week neatly wrapping every object in his supervisor’s office in green tissue paper to surprise her upon her return from vacation.

headline: Blast in Falluja Damages Sunni Party’s Main Office
text: BAGHDAD  A leading Sunni political party’s headquarters in western Iraq was blown up early Thursday morning, while in southern Iraq, where Shiite factions have been fighting one another, a powerful bomb was discovered on the road to an important Shiite shrine.

headline: The Ghost of Jack Abramoff
text: Jack Abramoff must have been one heck of a lobbyist. He has not set foot on Capitol Hill in years yet is still a major player in everyday Congressional life.

headline: A Charter Deal for Taiwan and China
text: BEIJING  Representatives of China and Taiwan agreed Friday to start weekend charter flights next month between the two sides, taking the first step toward establishing regular transportation links that could ease relations.

headline: In California, a House Divided Stands Strong
text: LOS ANGELES  It is one thing to disagree about politics with your spouse at a backyard barbecue. It is quite another to do it in front of the 38 million people of California, with apparent and abundant passion.

headline: Trevor Wilkinson, 85, a Maker of Sports Cars, Is Dead
text: Trevor Wilkinson, the founder of TVR, the small British carmaker known for nimble little sports cars that early owners often assembled from a kit, died on June 6 in Minorca, Spain. He was 85.

headline: Detention Camp Remains, but Not Its Rationale
text: The Guantánamo Bay detention center will not close today or any day soon.

headline: What’s in a Name? For This Justin Hicks, a Place on the Leader Board
text: SAN DIEGO  There have been no-names near the top of the United States Open leader board after the first round before. This year, there is a “No, not him” in that position.

headline: Still No Plan to Rescue the City’s OTB Parlors
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson and the State Legislature did not reach an agreement on Thursday on a plan that would rescue New York City’s Off-Track Betting Corporation before Sunday, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is scheduled to shut down the city’s 60 betting branches.

headline: Commodity Prices Climb Again
text: CHICAGO  Commodity prices continued to rise on Thursday, with the price of corn remaining above $7 a bushel. Soybeans also moved higher.

headline: The Test of Pi
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bond Star Is Injured
text: Daniel Craig, below, who plays James Bond, was sent to the hospital after suffering a minor hand injury while filming “Quantum of Solace,” the latest Bond movie, near London, The Associated Press reported. “There was a minor incident on set,” a spokesman for Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group said on Wednesday. “He was back on the set within a matter of hours, and production went on.” It was not the first accident that’s occurred during the filming; stuntmen were injured in April while filming an action sequence in northern Italy. In other Bond-related news, Sean Connery will offer the first public glimpse of his memoir, “Being a Scot,” at the Edinburgh Book Festival on Aug. 25, his 78th birthday, The Associated Press reported. The book contains Mr. Connery’s views on “many aspects of Scottish culture and life, including sport, architecture and, of course, the Gothic tendency in Scots literature,” said Catherine Lockerbie, the festival’s director.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a new product introduction by Apple Inc. misidentified the location of a market research firm that commented on the company’s strategy, and a correction in this space on Wednesday misidentified the product being introduced. The company, Gartner, is based in Stamford, Conn., not San Jose, Calif., and Apple introduced its new iPhone models, not iPods.

headline: The Cycle of Seasons Illuminated
text: I take no pleasure in dumping on a 25-year-old pseudo-experimental nature documentary, but neither did I find much to like in “Blue Planet.” Granted, there are dozens of lovely images to behold in this lush 35-millimeter tone (deaf) poem by the filmmaker Franco Piavoli: the fat fall of plump raindrops; a meadow sculptured by wind; workmen silhouetted at dusk; a scrawl of hieroglyphic sunlight along the surface of a pond, as if Mother Nature were setting out to one-up the painter Cy Twombly.

headline: Hirst: A Throwaway
text: Chris Evans, a BBC pop D.J., accidentally discarded a signed Damien Hirst print while packing to move to a new home, the BBC reported. Mr. Evans, 42, told his listeners on Wednesday that the print, one of Mr. Hirst’s early “dot pictures,” had ended up in a charity shop in a small town in Surrey, England, after some boxes were mixed up by his mover. The picture is worth thousands of pounds, Mr. Evans said. ... U2 is selling a painting by Jean-Michel Basquiat that has hung in its studio in Dublin since 1989, the BBC reported. The painting, “Untitled (Pecho/Oreja),” was made in 1983 and bought at a New York gallery in 1989 by the band’s bassist, Adam Clayton. It will go up for auction at Sotheby’s in London on July 1 as part of a sale of contemporary art. Basquiat died in 1988.

headline: Foster Children Bring Joy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stuck in His Team’s Undertow, Santana Sees Another Win Slip Away
text: Johan Santana and Dan Haren opposed each other Thursday for the second time in nearly six weeks. The first time, in Phoenix, Haren was sharper, but the Mets won. In the rematch, Santana dominated, but the Diamondbacks won, 5-4, in 10 innings.

headline: Celtics’ Rally Puts Title Within Reach
text: LOS ANGELES  It took the Boston Celtics 21 years to get back to the N.B.A. finals. On Thursday night, they waited 44 minutes just to take a lead. Once they got it, they refused to let go, and now they stand one victory away from claiming the 17th championship in franchise history.

headline: Stern Unconcerned About F.B.I. Inquiries of Bavetta
text: LOS ANGELES  Commissioner David Stern restated his unwavering support for his referees on Thursday and said he was not concerned that at least one referee, Dick Bavetta, had been the subject of inquiries by federal agents.

headline: Moody’s May Align Municipal Debt Ratings With Corporate
text: Criticized by states and cities for how it rates their bonds, Moody’s Investors Service said on Thursday that it was considering rating municipal debt on the same scale it uses for corporate debt.

headline: Shift in Family Management at a New York Developer
text: Less than three weeks after Macklowe Properties was forced to sell its trophy General Motors Building and three other Midtown Manhattan office towers to pay off its creditors, William S. Macklowe has replaced his father, Harry, as chairman and chief executive of the vastly diminished real estate portfolio, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: Pakistan Angry as Strike by U.S. Kills 11 Soldiers
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  American air and artillery strikes killed 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers during a clash with insurgents on the Afghan border on Tuesday night, a development that raised concerns about the already strained American relationship with Pakistan.

headline: A May-December Love for All Seasons
text: The three-and-a-half-decade relationship of the British writer Christopher Isherwood and the American portrait artist Don Bachardy is one of the ultimate true stories of a proto-gay-marriage succeeding in a forbidding climate.

headline: From the Elusiveness of Schizophrenia, New Clues to Treatment
text: The people who suffer from schizophrenia are hardly the only ones confounded by its symptoms. Scientists are baffled, too, and despite years of study they’ve had little success in explaining how the disorder develops, in whom, and why.

headline: Homeless but Hopeful
text: So earnest it hurts, “Kicking It” follows a half-dozen homeless men from around the globe as they ready for the fourth annual Homeless World Cup in Cape Town. Introduced and narrated by the actor Colin Farrell, who sports a thick brogue and thicker eyebrows and intones the thickest of schmaltz (“from war-torn Afghanistan to the slums of Africa to the streets and fields of Dublin where even as a child I spent many o’ me years kickin’ a football around ...”), the movie has its heart in the right place, if not its mind or muscles.

headline: A Venerable Jazz Festival Seems Ready to Evolve
text: The summer jazz festival season is upon us, and as usual, the JVC Jazz Festival New York will be the most visible. Under new management this year, the festival will feature concerts in new theaters and clubs and some curious and challenging double bills, like the pairing of Cecil Taylor and George Cables, pianists representing very different parts of the jazz spectrum. These are potentially exciting developments for a festival that has seemed stolid at times.

headline: Making Wood Furniture, Early American Style
text: MAKING WOOD FURNITURE,

headline: WNYC Star Power Helps Make a Sale
text: They may be calm and gentle, and perhaps a bit droll.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: G.O.P. Says Ex-Treasurer Stole Funds
text: An internal investigation by the National Republican Congressional Committee has determined that $725,000 is missing from its fund-raising accounts, money that the group says was stolen as part of a six-year scheme carried out by its former treasurer.

headline: Vets Are Going Public
text: The Public Theater’s 2008-9 season will include new works by playwright royalty, some big-name directors and a couple of visits from Public leaders past, the theater announced on Thursday. Starting things off is the long-anticipated New York production of Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman’s musical “Bounce,” directed by John Doyle, followed by the latest from the monologist Mike Daisey, “If You See Something Say Something”; Danny Hoch, a hip-hop playwright, will perform a solo show, “Taking Over”; and George C. Wolfe, a former artistic director of the Public, will direct “A Free Man of Color,” John Guare’s epic about the Louisiana Purchase. Next comes another Public veteran, Tracey Scott Wilson, with “The Good Negro,” presented earlier as part of the Public Lab series. Then Christopher Durang returns to the Public with a new play, “Why Torture Is Wrong, and the People Who Love Them.” The downtown season concludes with Craig Lucas’s “Singing Forest,” directed by Bartlett Sher. The Public also announced that “The Bacchae,” with music by Philip Glass and directed by another former Public artistic director, JoAnne Akalaitis, will be a part of the 2009 Shakespeare in the Park season.

headline: Zoning Rules Are Flouted by Architect, City Says
text: New York City announced fresh administrative charges on Thursday against a Brooklyn architect whose name has become identified both with the building boom that has transformed large swaths of the borough and with its many excesses.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Bad Cow Disease
text: “Mary had a little lamb / And when she saw it sicken / She shipped it off to Packingtown / And now it’s labeled chicken.”

headline: Zimbabwe Detains Opposition Leaders
text: JOHANNESBURG  The standard-bearer for Zimbabwe’s opposition was twice detained by the police on Thursday, and one of his most important deputies was arrested to face treason charges. The events underscored the daunting obstacles to campaigning against President Robert Mugabe in the two weeks before a presidential runoff.

headline: Web Tool to Track Con Ed Power Failures
text: When lights and air-conditioners went out in Yorkville and Bensonhurst during this week’s heat wave and thunderstorms, Consolidated Edison customers were able to track the utility’s efforts to restore power in real time online. That is, if they still had power (or a battery-powered laptop or other device).

headline: Microsoft Said to End Talks With Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Talks between Yahoo and Microsoft have ended with the two companies unable to reach a deal, Yahoo said in a news release on Thursday.

headline: Deadlock on Appeals Court Judges Ends
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee split largely along party lines as it voted 10 to 8 in favor of two nominees from Michigan to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati. The nominees, Helene N. White, a liberal Democratic candidate originally put forward by President Bill Clinton, and Raymond M. Kethledge, a conservative Republican chosen by the Bush White House, were part of a compromise effort to break a years-long deadlock involving candidates from Michigan for the federal appeals bench. But many committee Republicans said the White House should have sought agreement from Democrats for the confirmation of additional Republican candidates. All but one of the Republicans, Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, voted against Ms. White’s nomination, the key to the deal. The full Senate may take up the nomination before the July 4 recess.

headline: Are Washington Insiders Necessary?
text: Both presidential candidates have now been bruised by talking the talk of reform while walking the walk of old Washington habits.

headline: The Health of Hospitals in California, and in Brooklyn
text: To the Editor:

headline: Absence Could Prove Costly for Giants’ Burress
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants can fine receiver Plaxico Burress for refusing to take the field during minicamp, and at least one teammate is frustrated by his decision to negotiate a bigger contract by watching from the sideline.

headline: U.S. Marshals Continue Search for Missing Trader
text: A manhunt continued on Thursday for a hedge fund manager who disappeared Monday hours before he was to have reported to prison to serve a 20-year federal sentence for conspiracy and fraud in a scheme to cheat investors out of $450 million.

headline: The Cross-Country Currents in American Ballet
text: WASHINGTON  On paper the Ballet Across America season unfolding this week at the Kennedy Center is exciting, and it causes excitement in the theater too. On three triple-bill programs nine American companies are dancing one work apiece.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Bloomberg to Give Out $60 Million
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is funneling another enormous set of ostensibly anonymous grants to hundreds of arts and social services groups through the Carnegie Corporation, spreading them over the next two years as he begins establishing his own philanthropic foundation.

headline: Justices Rule Terror Suspects Can Appeal in Civilian Courts
text: WASHINGTON  Foreign terrorism suspects held at the Guantánamo Bay naval base in Cuba have constitutional rights to challenge their detention there in United States courts, the Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, on Thursday in a historic decision on the balance between personal liberties and national security.

headline: Seeking Free Home, Ex-Legislator Will Get a Prison Cell Instead
text: Calling her actions “an outrageous breach of trust,” a judge sentenced Diane M. Gordon, a former state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, to two to six years in prison on Thursday for offering to help a developer acquire city land if he would build her a house free.

headline: Airline Economies: A Few Modest Proposals
text: Readers of nytimes.com were invited to suggest ways that airlines and passengers could deal with rising fuel prices. Here are some ideas from readers who identified themselves.

headline: Vermont to Offer Fuel and Food Assistance
text: Vermont is creating a task force to help residents combat the high prices of gasoline, home heating oil and food, Gov. Jim Douglas announced on Thursday.

headline: Mayo Looks to the Future as His Past Is Questioned
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  O. J. Mayo wore a sleeveless Knicks T-shirt soaked in sweat, and blue Knicks shorts and black N.B.A. socks into the media room at the team facility.

headline: Bright Waters and an Old-Time Catskills Feel
text: WILD turkeys coursing through the backyard and coyotes howling at the full moon might be among the reasons to buy a second home in Livingston Manor, N.Y. But many weekenders are drawn to the town, which sits at the western edge of the Catskills, by its low-key, artistic temper.

headline: Belgium: Gates Pushes NATO Missile Defense System
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates joined NATO defense ministers in an effort to push forward a design for missile defenses that would protect all alliance nations from a potential Iranian ballistic missile attack. A senior Defense Department official traveling with Mr. Gates said the United States would press alliance members to agree on options for a defensive system against short- and medium-range ballistic missiles. That future NATO missile defense system would cover territory across the southeastern rim of the alliance: Bulgaria, Greece, Romania and Turkey. Parts of those nations  including almost all of Turkey  would not be covered by a longer-range system that the United States hopes to install in Poland and the Czech Republic.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Schizophrenia
text: Dr. Jeffrey Lieberman is the chairman of the psychiatry department at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and director of the college’s Lieber Center for Schizophrenia Research. He was also a principal investigator in a federal study that compared the effectiveness of an older schizophrenia drug with newer, more expensive drugs. The large, multisite study found that the older drug was generally as effective as the newer ones.

headline: Officials Find Expired Items at Drugstores in New York
text: Caveat emptor: When you go into a drugstore in New York City, it’s best to check the expiration date of common over-the-counter medications, which can be expired even at large national chains, a survey by the state attorney general’s office has found.

headline: Federal Agency Grounds Light Jet Used as Air Taxi
text: WASHINGTON  A week after both engines on a small jet became stuck at full power as the pilots were trying to land, the Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order Thursday grounding the planes of that model until the throttle controls can be inspected.

headline: Cultivating Leisure
text: WHO Regina Regner, 64, a retired registered nurse, and her husband, David, 63, a pharmacist, from Sylvan Lake, Mich. WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Suttons Bay, Mich.

headline: Caution: Contents Turn Angry When Shaken
text: Five years ago there was a movie about Dr. Bruce Banner, a scientist who, when agitated, turns large and green. It was called “Hulk” and it didn’t do very well, either with critics or with the legions of comic-book fans expected to sacrifice a portion of their pocket money every summer to keep the movie studios afloat. Now Universal and Marvel, every bit as indomitable as their rampaging asparagus-colored intellectual property, have given the franchise another try.

headline: Texas: Rare Beach Nesting for Turtle
text: For the first time since the 1930s, federal biologists confirmed that a leatherback sea turtle has nested on a Texas beach, at the Padre Island National Seashore near Corpus Christi. Last Friday, staff members conducting a beach patrol found turtle tracks and a few exposed eggs. They were thought at first to be those of a green turtle. But the eggs and the width of the tracks, more than six feet across, were later determined to be from a leatherback. The giant turtles, endangered around the world, have until now only been known to nest in three spots in the United States  with about three dozen females a year laying eggs on beaches along the east coast of Florida and slightly larger nesting populations in Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands.

headline: National Red Cross Campaign Begins as a Logo on a Stock Car
text: IN a perfect world, donating blood would be purely an altruistic pursuit. In the real world, however, the American Red Cross is finding that a little corporate sponsorship  plus a few freebies  helps to coax people to roll up their sleeves.

headline: In Rio Slum, Armed Militia Replaces Drug Gang’s Criminality With Its Own
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  When several Brazilian journalists decided to go undercover here in May to report on life in one of the hundreds of slums that have sprouted up around Rio, they thought they had chosen carefully.

headline: Correction: Rooms With a Viewfinder
text: The Away column last Friday, about the home of two photographers in Rensselaerville, N.Y., misspelled the surname of the chief curator of the International Center of Photography in Manhattan. He is Brian Wallis, not Wallace.

headline: Britain: Lawmaker Quits Over Detention Bill
text: The Conservative Party’s leading spokesman on security issues, David Davis, announced that he was quitting the House of Commons to protest “the insidious, surreptitious and relentless erosion of fundamental British freedoms” under the Labor government. Mr. Davis said he would run for the seat again and use the campaign to debate the government’s plan to extend to 42 days the maximum period for which terrorist suspects can be detained before being charged. The measure was approved by the Commons on Wednesday.

headline: Donors Press Karzai on Corruption
text: PARIS  The United States, Europe and more than 60 other countries and international institutions offered about $20 billion in aid for Afghanistan as part of a big donors conference here Thursday.

headline: The Mingling of Dreams and Life
text: Max Kohn (Otto Tausig), the aging Lothario of “Love Comes Lately,” is very much like the movie itself: doddering and milquetoasty, but ultimately disarming. Blending three short stories by the Nobel laureate Isaac Bashevis Singer, the filmmaker Jan Schütte may well have made a minor classic for the retired-Jews-of-Miami set. In this admirably grown-up tale, with its keen sympathy for autumnal sentiments, he has, at the least, offered mellow counterprogramming to frivolous summer fare.

headline: Iraq Seeks Shield Against Claims by Hussein Victims
text: UNITED NATIONS  The Iraqi foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, said he would ask the United Nations Security Council on Friday to start exploring ways to protect his government from an avalanche of financial claims from people harmed by Saddam Hussein’s government.

headline: Over a River and Into the Woodlands at the Delaware Water Gap
text: ON weekends all through summer, tens of thousands of motorists will find themselves slowing down as they cruise into the S-curves of Interstate 80 at the Delaware Water Gap. Hurrying west to the Poconos, east to the Jersey Shore or far afield to all the other familiar vacationlands, many may glance up, where the speed limit decreases from 65 miles per hour to 50, at the crazily piled rock of one of the Northeast’s most interesting geological formations. But most will be only dimly aware that they are skirting one of the most used (though least heralded) sites of the National Park Service.

headline: Aid Team Head Says Team Will Have Full Access in Myanmar
text: SINGAPORE, June 12, 2008 (AFP) — A team of aid experts from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the UN will have full access to parts of cyclone-devastated Myanmar, ASEAN's secretary general said Thursday.

headline: Orchestral Performance of One ‘Ring’ to Shrink Them All
text: “The ‘Ring’ Without Words” has been one of Lorin Maazel’s showpieces since 1987, when he assembled this orchestral overview of Wagner’s four “Ring” operas for a recording project with the Berlin Philharmonic on Telarc Records. He has performed it in New York with the Pittsburgh Symphony (in 1990) and the New York Philharmonic (in 2000), and when the Philharmonic paid a rare visit to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, he offered it again as the sole work on the program.

headline: On Further Review, That Game Was Badly Officiated
text: I watched Game 6 of the 2002 N.B.A. Western Conference finals Thursday in the hope of spotting any signals, winks, nods, smiles or arched eyebrows among the referees that would buttress the accusation by their felonious ex-colleague, Tim Donaghy, that two of them rigged their calls to help the Lakers beat the Kings and advance to a seventh game.

headline: On His Birthday, Matsui Gives Yankees Reason to Party
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  When Hideki Matsui arrived at the Coliseum on Thursday, about 30 Japanese reporters greeted him in the parking lot with a strawberry shortcake for his 34th birthday. A few hours later, Matsui returned the favor with a perfect story line.

headline: What Do the Simple Folk Do? They Toil and Sing
text: You can almost smell the heather in “The Hired Man,” a chamber musical at the 59E59 Theaters that’s part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. Set in the rolling hills of Cumbria, this intimate show from the 1980s is a far cry from the bigger, better-known, Broadway-devouring British musicals of that era. No whirling turntable piled with flag-waving French students. No masked man scurrying around the smoky bowels of the Paris Opera, fiddling with the light fixtures. Just the small victories and bitter losses of simple folk set against the pleasures and pastimes of the country.

headline: Depending on the Kindness of Strangers
text: Set between the devastation of a flood and the safety of a private swimming pool, “Beauty in Trouble” uses the changing moods of water as both metaphor and frame for the infinite adaptability of human emotions.

headline: Staking Claim to a City, With Camera in Hand
text: The title “Eminent Domain: Contemporary Photography and the City” suggests a history of contested municipal development projects like the Atlantic and Hudson Yards. Instead, this show at the New York Public Library is about the photographer’s proprietary claim to the urban landscape. That claim was briefly threatened last year by a Bloomberg administration proposal that would have required a permit to film and take pictures in public places.

headline: World-Weary Fantasy
text: “You’re stifled by rather precarious aesthetics,” one character says to another in Pere Portabella’s “Warsaw Bridge,” a film from 1990 that begins a weeklong run at the Museum of Modern Art on Friday. Aren’t we all? For his part Mr. Portabella seems pretty comfortable with his aesthetic of narrative enigma, elegant camerawork and attractive people who speak in literary and intellectual riddles.

headline: On Martha’s Vineyard on a Budget. Seriously.
text: MARTHA’S VINEYARD, the 100-square-mile triangle of an island off the coast of Cape Cod, has been a summer retreat for New England Brahmins since the 1800s, and has never shed its pricey and exclusive reputation.

headline: Two Charged in Getting Drugs for Winehouse
text: The police in London have charged a man and a woman there with supplying drugs to the singer Amy Winehouse, The Associated Press reported. The charges stem from a video that appeared to show Ms. Winehouse smoking crack cocaine. John Blagrove and Cara Burton have been charged with conspiracy to supply cocaine and MDMA, also known as Ecstasy. They were released on bail Thursday and are due back in court on July 1. The police began investigating after pictures from the video were published in The Sun newspaper in January. Detectives say that Ms. Winehouse will not be charged in the case.

headline: John Rauch, 80, Coach of Raiders and the Bills, Dies
text: John Rauch, who coached the Oakland Raiders in the second Super Bowl and was later O. J. Simpson’s first coach in professional football, with the Buffalo Bills, died Tuesday at his home in Oldsmar, Fla., near Tampa. He was 80.

headline: A Question Mark Looms Over 3 Expensive Projects
text: More than two years ago, the Bloomberg administration came up with an aggressively creative way to use tax-exempt bonds to finance two of the most expensive stadiums in the world, one for the Yankees in the Bronx and another for the Mets in Queens.

headline: Justice 5, Brutality 4
text: For years, with the help of compliant Republicans and frightened Democrats in Congress, President Bush has denied the protections of justice, democracy and plain human decency to the hundreds of men that he decided to label “unlawful enemy combatants” and throw into never-ending detention.

headline: Trading Pickles for Art Galleries
text: The warning from the National Trust for Historic Preservation that the Lower East Side is one of the 11 most endangered places in America seems fast food for thought. Hasn’t that been the case ever since this sliver of Manhattan was laid bare more than a century ago as the crammed tenement haven for immigrants?

headline: Europe to Investigate U.S. Exports of Biodiesel Fuel
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union on Thursday accused United States producers of biodiesel fuel of benefiting from subsidies that threaten to put European producers out of business.

headline: Classroom Door Gives Immigrants an Entry to Society
text: FRANKFURT  The first four years after Sara Tahir moved to Germany, she barely left her home because she could not speak the language. “I didn’t want to take a single step without my husband, even to the gynecologist. He had to go with me and translate,” she said, turning red with shame just at the memory.

headline: A Dangerous Place
text: There is enormous confusion about what happened Tuesday night on Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan. Pakistani officials say that American air and artillery strikes killed 11 of their paramilitary troops, and some are angrily demanding an end to all military cooperation. The Bush administration says that American forces were firing in self-defense  against Taliban fighters crossing into Afghanistan  and made conflicting statements about whether any Pakistani troops had died.

headline: Police: Robbers Used Craigslist
text: Trying to exploit the popularity of iPhones, four men used Craigslist to lure would-be buyers to Brooklyn and then robbed them at gunpoint, the police said on Thursday.

headline: Global Image of U.S. Improves Slightly
text: PARIS  There is good news and bad news for President Bush as he pursues his valedictory tour of Europe this week, according to a new worldwide study by the Pew Global Attitudes Project. The image of the United States has improved slightly in many countries over the past year, the poll results show. But the new optimism appears to be driven largely by the fact that Mr. Bush will soon be leaving office.

headline: M.L.B. Questioned Over 2004 Steroid Testing
text: A Congressional oversight committee Thursday submitted questions to Major League Baseball and its players union asking whether steroid testing was suspended during the 2004 season and, if so, why they did not tell Congress about it during a 2005 public hearing.

headline: Darkness Was Muse for a Master of Light
text: “The Starry Night,” van Gogh’s hypnotic canvas from 1889, is one of the Museum of Modern Art’s most popular paintings, attracting thousands of visitors every year since it entered the collection in 1941.

headline: In Lehman Fallout, Two Stars Are Given Lesser Roles
text: After 10 nightmarish days inside the headquarters of Lehman Brothers, nerves on the 31st floor continued to fray. By Wednesday evening, the president and chief financial officer were out  a dramatic attempt by Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehman’s pugnacious chief executive, to restore confidence in his beleaguered bank and safeguard his own job.

headline: A Packed Gallery, but No Masterpieces on First Day of Open
text: SAN DIEGO  Kevin Streelman, who made his first surprise visit to the top of the leader board at Torrey Pines Golf Course five months ago during the Buick Invitational, made his second appearance there on Thursday. Despite a bogey at his final hole, Streelman shot a three-under-par 68 to join Justin Hicks as the co-leader at the 108th United States Open.

headline: Regrets Only
text: ELLEN ARCHER loves her weekend home in Sharon, Conn., savoring every moment spent within its 150-year-old walls. The house, a colonial-style from the mid-19th century, has three bedrooms and a screened-in porch and is on a road that time seems magnanimously to have forgotten.

headline: Yanks Would Have Interest in Sabathia
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  A painful swing by the Cleveland Indians’ Víctor Martínez on Wednesday could have significant ramifications for the Yankees. An elbow injury to Martínez all but ended the Indians’ flickering playoff hopes, and will probably lead to a trade of the ace left-hander C. C. Sabathia.

headline: Red Cross Reaches Out to Nascar
text: IN a perfect world, donating blood would be purely an altruistic pursuit. In the real world, however, the American Red Cross is finding that a little corporate sponsorship  plus a few freebies  helps to coax people to roll up their sleeves.

headline: Talking to Dogs, Without a Word
text: “This will be his earliest memory,” “The Story of Edgar Sawtelle” says about its title character. “Red light, morning light. High ceiling canted overhead. Lazy click of toenails on wood. Between the honey-colored slats of the crib a whiskery muzzle slides forward until its cheeks pull back and a row of dainty front teeth bare themselves in a ridiculous grin.”

headline: Ad Accord for Yahoo and Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft’s four-month-long courtship of Yahoo has finally thrown Yahoo into the arms of their biggest common rival, Google.

headline: Most Charges Dropped in Building Climb
text: A grand jury has decided to dismiss criminal charges against Alain Robert, one of two men who climbed The New York Times Building last week, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney’s office said Thursday.

headline: Closing Arguments in Kelly Trial
text: In closing arguments at R. Kelly’s child pornography trial in Chicago, prosecutors replayed the sex tape at the center of the case for jurors, telling them that the man in the video is Mr. Kelly, right, an R&B star, and that he controlled the encounter with the girl, who was as young as 13, The Associated Press reported. “We’re going to see his direction,” Shauna Boliker, an assistant state’s attorney, told the jury. He is “directing her to dance, where to stand, when to stop urinating,” she said. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of child pornography. His lawyers have argued that the man in the video is not him and that the reported victim, now 23, has also denied that she is in the video. The prosecution has called 22 witnesses in the monthlong trial, including several relatives of the woman they identified as the girl in the video. The defense attorney, Sam Adam Jr., told jurors that charges against Mr. Kelly came about because people were trying to extort money from him. “That’s what this is about,” he said, “money, money, money.”

headline: Media Charged With Sexism in Clinton Coverage
text: Angered by what they consider sexist news coverage of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, many women and erstwhile Clinton supporters are proposing boycotts of the cable networks, putting up videos on a “Media Hall of Shame,” starting a national conversation about sexism and pushing Mrs. Clinton’s rival, Senator Barack Obama, to address the matter.

headline: Sunday in the Dark With Tony?
text: Really, we never learn. After a primary season that proved scientific polling has the precision of a coin toss, after years of losing 10 bucks in the office Oscar pool (darn you, documentary short subject), after Big Brown did whatever he did last week at the Belmont Stakes, you would think we would have come to our senses.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a Planet Green television series on the rebuilding of Greensburg, Kan., after a tornado destroyed most of it in May 2007 misstated the tornado’s speed. While its winds were estimated at 205 miles per hour, the tornado itself was estimated to have moved through the town at about 20 m.p.h., not 200 m.p.h.

headline: Visualizing Schizophrenia
text: Paul Thompson is professor of neurology at the University of California, Los Angeles, and leads the research group at the school’s Laboratory of Neuro Imaging. He uses imaging technology to map disease processes involving the human brain, carried out in collaboration with the National Institutes of Health and more than 40 laboratories around the world. A goal is to create disease-specific atlases of the brain that can aid in the diagnosis, treatment and possible prevention of illnesses like schizophrenia.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about a genetic abnormality that raises the risk of blood clots, referred incorrectly to federal legislation that protects against genetic discrimination. The law offers protection in employment and health insurance, but not life insurance. (Go to Article)

headline: An Avant-Gardist’s Sparse Stories, in Film and Fragments
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Chantal Akerman is a hero of the avant-garde cinema. Her most famous film, “Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai de Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles” (1975), devotes more than three hours to observing a woman’s domestic routines before climaxing in, as accounts regularly put it, “an act of shocking violence.”

headline: Japanese Culture, in Vivid Color
text: It was probably too much to expect the International Center of Photography to have two excellent group shows of contemporary art in a row. Not many New York museums, especially small ones, manage that regularly. Thus “Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video From Japan,” coming after the dense, thought-provoking “From the Archive,” is just average, or a little less, by the center’s own standards.

headline: Brown Faces New Protests Over Terror Bill
text: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown faced down a revolt within his governing Labor Party on Wednesday, winning a precariously narrow victory in the House of Commons for a measure that among other things would allow the authorities to hold terrorism suspects for up to 42 days without charges.

headline: Bonnaroo: No Need to Work This Crowd
text: Impassive hipster audiences can warp a band. Vampire Weekend’s guitarist and singer, Ezra Koenig, had to rethink his patter in the face of a Bonnaroo audience. He introduced “A-Punk” as a song good for dancing, and explained dancing: “It’s a form of exercise and it’s great.” But Vampire Weekend’s upbeat pop songs, with their underpinnings of African triplets, had the crowd dancing from their first song. Later, he called for a singalong on “One (Blake’s Got a New Face),” describing the process as if it were unfamiliar. He sang the line and the roar of the audience response nearly knocked the band over. He didn’t ask for a louder one. But the band’s drummer, Chris Tomson, was wearing a Phish T-shirt, and had attended the first Bonnaroo, Mr. Koenig said to a wave of applause. He also jokingly described Vampire Weekend as “a jam band but with shorter songs” — which paid off for the crowd, since to play a full-length set the band had to add some new ones.

headline: Croatia Triumphs Over Complacent Germany
text: KLAGENFURT, Austria — Germany, the favorite in many experts' minds to win Euro 2008, is rocking. Croatia thought it could cause an upset here Thursday, and then proved it by winning on merit, 2-1. The reality was that Croatia had the better skills, with and without the ball, and ultimately the better match temperament.

headline: Friday’s Links: Why Lawyers Leave
text: Lots of people ask me why I left the law and I usually give them a few reasons, including the following: I went to law school mostly to please my parents; the idealism I’d felt as a law student waned when I saw how challenging it was to craft meaningful legal work that paid a living wage; I fell into a specialty that didn’t sustain my interest and found it easier to reinvent myself in a new career than within my existing one.

headline: The Computer Age and Its Carbon Footprint
text: There is a sleek quality to so much modern technology, and that may make it hard to imagine its polluting potential. But think about it: Many of us in the developed world plug and unplug our cellphones, music players, printers and laptops from wall sockets several times a day. It turns out that these goods are responsible for a significant amount of the electricity that we use in homes and offices.

headline: Sexism? Who, us?
text: The 2008 campaign has been a very disillusioning experience for a lot of people. You can make a very good case that Barack Obama was the right person for the Democrats to nominate, and Hillary Clinton the wrong choice. But the way we got there was terrible. The raw sexism, in all too many cases coming from alleged progressives — see above — was part of it. So, too, was the inability of many alleged progressives to see that the news media created the narrative of Hillary Clinton as race-baiter in much the same way that, 8 years ago, they created the narrative of Al Gore as congenital liar — by assembling a montage of quotes taken out of context and willfully misinterpreted.

headline: What’s Behind the Lehman Bounce?
text: For five consecutive days, shares of Lehman Brothers have plodded lower. Which is hardly surprising, given the firm’s announcement Monday that it would report the first quarterly loss in its history as a public company, and the rampant speculation that it was vulnerable to a crisis in confidence similar to the one that felled Bear Stearns. On Thursday, as Lehman replaced its chief financial officer and chief operating officer, the firm’s chief executive, Richard Fuld Jr., told employees in a memo that “our credibility has eroded.”

headline: Bonnaroo: Jimi Hendrix’s $15,500 Wah-Wah

headline: One Last Dinner Out in Paris
text: I try never to visit Paris without at least attempting to intersect with my bi-continental friend Dorie Greenspan, the food writer, whom I see in New York with some frequency. She spends enough time in Paris to really know what’s going on (check out her site: www.doriegreenspan.com), she knows how to eat, and her French is 10 times better than mine. So when she’s there, and I’m there, it’s a no-brainer. Fortunately, on this trip she was, and on the second-to-last night I was in town she took me to the much-heralded Les Papilles. (It’s right around the corner from the Luxembourg Gardens at 30 rue Gay-Lussac; 011 33 1 43 25 20 79.)

headline: How Long Is a Coney Island Minute?
text: Part innocent exuberance, part shameless self-promotion, part carnival sideshow and unmistakably all-American (right down to its former six-time Japanese champion), the Nathan’s Famous Fourth of July International Hot Dog Eating Contest has been a cherished tradition at Coney Island since the last innocent days before World War I, annually answering the question so many New Yorkers ask themselves as summer rolls around: Just how many hot dogs can someone eat in 12 minutes?

headline: The Morning Skate: OV Stars at N.H.L Awards, But Where’s Ozzie?
text: U.S. viewers watching the TV Awards on the inept Versus network were denied the chance to see Stompin’ Tom Connors perform The Hockey Song. Here’s a version with vintage video.

headline: What’s in a Name? In China, It Could Be ‘Olympic Games’
text: One fun way to track the growing popularity of the Beijing Games: follow the number of Chinese children named after either the Games or their official mascots. The Associated Press brought attention to this phenomenon last fall, saying most of the 3,491 children registered under the name Aoyun (奥运), which is short for Olympic Games, were born around the year 2000.

headline: Hagee Clarifies Holocaust Comments
text: Last month he expressed regret for offending Roman Catholics. Now the Rev. John Hagee is extending his regret to Jews.

headline: McCain, Obama Debate Debate Deals
text: After a week of proposals and counter-proposals concerning how many times Barack Obama and John McCain will meet for face-to-face debates between now and Election Day, both campaigns appear to be feeling a little rejected.

headline: Big Names, Little Interest
text: The resignation this week of senior Obama advisor Jim Johnson, who had received sweetheart loans from the troubled lender Countrywide Financial, was apparently just the beginning of the story. Portfolio’s Daniel Golden has the scoop:

headline: The Conversation: Living Off the Handle
text:  Previous Conversation: Following the Rules (May 29) Previous Conversation: Primary Days of Yore (June 5)

headline: Bid for Weather Channel Now Rests With NBC
text: A group led by NBC Universal now appears likely to acquire The Weather Channel, after Time Warner Inc. withdrew its bid for the channel on Friday.

headline: A Path to Fowl-Free Foie Gras?
text: Chicago’s two-year try at a ban on serving force-fattened duck liver, otherwise known as foie gras, has ended. (Click here see a remarkable video moment showing how it ended, and revealing a lot about Chicago politics.)

headline: First Class Graduates From Cristo Rey High
text: Four years ago, Maria del Carmen Sanchez marched into St. Cecilia’s Church in East Harlem as a girl with big hoop earrings and even bigger dreams. She was among the inaugural class at Cristo Rey New York High School, an alternative Roman Catholic college preparatory school, which provides a free education for talented but poor students.

headline: Advertisers Give Thumbs-Down to Google-Yahoo Deal
text: Eric E. Schmidt, Google’s chief executive, said Thursday that his company’s search deal with Yahoo was a win-win-win: a win for the companies, a win for the publishers and a win for advertisers.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, June 13:

headline: Response: Diversity and Equality
text: A question raised well and often in the responses to this article is one of diversity. As a reader named Shak writes: “There’s a glaring omission in this article, specifically in regards to economic status, education and race.” Or, as Lee writes: “One thing that strikes and saddens me is that the discussion so noticeably focuses on a mostly white, college-educated and white collar segment of the population. Perhaps the argument can be made that you’ve got to start somewhere, but I’m hard-pressed to see how shared care translates to those who are lower income, less educated and working jobs where there’s no possibility to flex a schedule.”

headline: McCain: Guantánamo Decision One of Worst Ever
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona, the presumed Republican nominee, came out swinging today against the Supreme Court’s decision granting suspected terrorists the right to challenge their detention in federal courts.

headline: The Ghost of Jack Abramoff
text: “Jack Abramoff must have been one heck of a lobbyist,” Carl Hulse writes in his column today. “He has not set foot on Capitol Hill in years yet is still a major player in everyday Congressional life.”

headline: The Newest Twist in ConnectU v. Facebook
text: Earlier this year, Facebook reached a settlement in its long-simmering, often embarrassing lawsuit with ConnectU, a Harvard dating site whose founders assert that their one-time employee, a then-college sophomore, Mark Zuckerberg, stole their idea.

headline: Proxy Advisory Support Helps Countrywide, a Little
text: Countrywide Financial hasn’t had much good news in months, and this week was mostly no exception. (For starters, a connection to Countrywide founder Angelo R. Mozilo helped lead to the ouster of James A. Johnson from Barack Obama’s campaign.) And its stock has fallen more than 7.5 percent this week.

headline: High Water and the American Character
text: “Come hell or high water.” “God willing, and the river don’t rise.” As record-topping rains and raging rivers inundate wide swathes of the midwest, The Lede has gotten to thinking today about colloquial expressions like those, and how they are clues to a home truth — that floods are, in some sense, the quintessential American disaster.

headline: Yahoo + Google – Microsoft: The Morning After
text: Some morning-after thoughts on the Yahoo-Google advertising deal:

headline: Q&A: Iraqi Teenagers
text: BAGHDAD — One day is left for submitting questions to our video Q&A with Iraqi teenagers. Together with Ali Hameed, an Iraqi employee in our newsroom, I spent two hours today interviewing more than a dozen teenage boys in eastern Baghdad. Many of the youngsters we approached did not wish to appear on video, but others crowded around us mugged for the camera. One teenager was playing the music of 50 Cent on his MP3 player. He said he enjoyed working out to hip hop.

headline: City Wants Higher Fines for ‘Blocking the Box’
text: Blocking the box could get more expensive for New York City drivers.

headline: Big Names, Big Moves?
text: As Tyler Kepner reported in today’s Times, the Cleveland Indians are leaning towards dealing their ace C.C. Sabathia, with the Yankees, Red Sox, and Cubs as possible suitors. There are a couple other big-name players who may have new homes by the time the trading deadline passes.

text: From our colleagues at Bits:

headline: How Does Your Waist Measure Up?
text: Imagine if your employer started measuring your waist as a measure of your health.

headline: Obama on Social Security Changes
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio – Halfway through a two-week economic tour, Senator Barack Obama turned the topic to Social Security on Friday, sharply criticizing Senator John McCain for his stance and suggesting that Mr. McCain is a flip-flopper.

text: Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

text: Stewart R. Mott, philanthropist and heir to the General Motors fortune, dedicated his life and money to liberal politics and progressive causes.

text: Stewart R. Mott, philanthropist and heir to the General Motors fortune, dedicated his life and money to liberal politics and progressive causes.

headline: NBC’s Tim Russert Dies
text: 8:30 p.m. | A Giant With a Small-Town Quality:  The wrap for now comes from Ben Bradlee, former editor of the Washington Post, who provided a spontaneous eulogy by phone to Andrea Mitchell in classic Bradlee fashion.

headline: At Least It’s Getting Airplay
text: NBC News tells us that John McCain’s use of the 1970s hit song “Still the One” at a New Hampshire event yesterday offended more than simply good taste:

headline: NBC Nears a Deal for Weather Channel
text: A group of investors led by NBC Universal and the Blackstone Group is near a deal to buy The Weather Channel for more than $3 billion, people briefed on the negotiations said.

headline: NBC’s Tim Russert Dies
text: Tim Russert, the host of “Meet the Press,” and NBC’s Washington bureau chief, has died, Katharine Q. Seeyle reports.

headline: Tim Russert and New York Politics
text: Tim Russert, the Washington bureau chief of NBC News, died at age 58 today; The Times’s Caucus blog has a complete report. Years before he entered the world of political journalism, in the mid-1980s, he was intimately involved in the New York political world. From 1977 to 1982, he was the first chief of staff to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat elected in 1976. He was instrumental in Mario M. Cuomo’s election as governor of New York, in 1982, and was counselor to the governor in 1983 and 1984.

headline: Bonnaroo: Getting Interactive
text: For this weekend, Bonnaroo may be the best-connected pasture anywhere. Verizon BlackBerry service only covers about half the field (bah humbug), but my little wi-fi computer is picking up networks everywhere: from individual stages, an overarching Bonnaroo signal, from tech-company booths and perhaps from more cosmic sources. The only obstacle is finding a flat surface–and missing more music while I blog.

headline: The Well Podcast: Answers to Your Cellphone Questions
text: How do cellphones work? At what point do they emit the most energy? What do we know about Bluetooth and other headsets?

headline: Who Is Killing the Writers of South Dakota?
text: Having declared the death of reading, the folks at the National Endowment of the Arts are now proclaiming the health of the arts economy.

headline: Panthers Hire Peter DeBoer as Coach
text: The Florida Panthers filled their coaching vacancy today by tapping highly successful junior coach Peter DeBoer to be the 10th coach in club history. He will be introduced at a press conference on Monday.

headline: Taking the L Out of LBOs
text: CNBC talks with Robert Profusek of Jones Day and James Woolery of Cravath Swaine & Moore about the changes in private equity deal-making.

headline: Bonnaroo: Southern Stories from Drive-by Truckers
text: Things went right on schedule for the Drive-By Truckers set at Bonnaroo. At 12:30 pm, Patterson Hood, lead storyteller of a band that’s lived a few, stepped up to the mike and told the fans, many of whom had just crawled out of their tents, that this was their “wake-up call.” The band kicked hard into “Gangsterbilly” and then quickly wheeled through “Ghost to Most” and “Marry Me.”

headline: Tim Russert’s Turnaround of ‘Meet the Press’
text: For more than 16 years, Tim Russert served as the moderator of “Meet the Press,” the award-winning Sunday public affairs program on NBC.

headline: When the ‘L’ Is Removed from ‘LBOs’
text: It’s no secret that many private equity firms have found the last 11 months to be a challenge. The lifeblood of their deal-making activity, cheap debt, has all but disappeared, as lenders have become much more hesitant to offer up their balance sheets. That in turn has dramatically undercut mergers and acquisitions activity.

headline: Answers About Mass Transit, Part 4
text: This is the fourth and final set of answers to selected reader questions from Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, which advocates for public transit improvements. We are no longer taking questions. Thanks to everyone who participated.

headline: Macy’s Founder May Be Honored (for One Month)
text: The man who founded Macy’s could finally have a street in Manhattan named after him –­ but only for a month. On Thursday night, Community Board 5 unanimously approved the temporary installation of a street sign dubbing the block of 34th Street occupied by the Macy’s flagship store “R. H. Macy Way.” The resolution, which now goes to the City Council for a final decision, calls for the sign to remain up only from Oct. 15 through Nov. 15. (Most honorary street renamings, like Jerry Orbach Way, have been permanent.)

text: What a picture.
