text: Drive-By TruckersJosé GonzálezThe Fiery FurnacesUmphrey’s McGeeMinus the Bear

headline: Portrait of Ability
text: Zoraida Morrison lost her sight at 26, but her other four senses work overtime.

headline: Microsoft’s Internal Letter about Yahoogle
text: In the wake of Yahoo‘s decision to embrace a Google partnership in its ad search business, many have wondered what Microsoft will do next.

headline: Iowa Flooding Disrupts Triathlon Qualifying
text: Severe flooding in Iowa has left organizers of the Hy-Vee Triathlon, the last leg of the Olympic qualifying process, scrambling to find a new location for the June 22 race. They believe they have found one, seven miles west of the original site in Des Moines.

headline: The Shelf Life of the Roasted Bean
text: Ninth Street Espresso sells Stumptown coffee beans shipped in from the roaster in Portland, Ore., three times per week. Most small batch roasters believe in the mantra that fresher is better, and coffee is at its best when made from beans roasted no more than two weeks ago.

headline: First Thoughts on Russert
text: The death of Tim Russert at age 58 is garnering the sorts of blog attention usually reserved for presidents and popes. Here’s a quick roundup:

headline: A Lawyer With Two Clients at Large
text: Robert G. Morvillo, one of the go-to members of the criminal bar, had some explaining to do this week when two of his law firm’s high-profile clients appeared to be flouting the criminal justice system.

headline: Albany and Mayor at Odds Over Future of Off-Track Betting
text: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson and the leaders of the Legislature announced on Friday a deal under which New York State would take over the financially unprofitable Off-Track Betting operation from New York City, the biggest change in the governance of the state-regulated gambling entity since its creation of 1970. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg — who had moved to shut down the operation, saying that it was not profitable and that it was not in the city’s interests to continue running it — said the deal was unfair to the city and immediately vowed to move forward with a plan to close all 71 O.T.B. outposts this weekend. The political dispute meant that the agency’s future remained uncertain.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 13
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Events include the Puerto Rican Day parade, scorching temperatures, a new home for the Grange and more.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Swapland
text: The reason bartering can work in villages — including, during various periods, Greenwich Village, the Haight-Ashbury and Burning Man — is that village neighbors make and need comparable products. Some corn, some carpentry, an embroidered pillowcase, firewood, horseshoes, quilts. Marijuana. A bottle of water.

headline: Brokaw To Host Sunday’s ‘Meet the Press’
text: One of the most pressing concerns for NBC News has swiftly been addressed: Tom Brokaw will anchor the Father’s Day edition of “Meet the Press” on Sunday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Fallen Sports Idols
text: Bryan Curtis, left, of Play Magazine and sportswriter Robert Lipsyte explore how the sports media covers the personal lives of athletes.

headline: Iowa Flooding Hits Shawn Johnson’s Gym
text: Shawn Johnson, the world champion in the women’s gymnastics all-around, had to pack up her things and flee her gym this week because of heavy flooding in Iowa.

headline: Signs of Peace in Burundi
text: Burundians hope that recent developments may lead to peace in their country for the first time in 15 years.

headline: Signs of Peace in Burundi
text: Burundians hope that recent developments may lead to peace in their country for the first time in 15 years.

headline: Club vs. Country, Cavs-Style: LeBron Wins, Lithuanian Loses
text: More evidence that American clubs just don’t get the whole playing-for-your-country thing: the Cleveland Cavaliers of the NBA announced today that they will not allow center Zydrunas Ilgauskas to play for the Lithuanian Olympic team at the Beijing Games this summer. The reason? He’s had injuries to his foot and lower back, and his contract is not fully insured.

headline: American Album
text: Two preachers hope to save at least some of the souls who pass the strip of all-night waffle houses and gas stations in Breezewood, Pa.

headline: Good to See You. Is It You?
text: Regarding full disclosure, dear reader, I feel I know you well enough by now to confide that, yes, it was at Yale that I myself learned what it means to be gay.

headline: At the End of the Earth
text: One of the most forlorn countries in the world is Central African Republic, CAR. It is landlocked, desperately poor, and has always had awful leadership — and now it is destabilized by Darfur and by its own civil war. The world pretty much looks the other way: The World Bank has a huge office in China, which couldn’t grow by less than 10 percent annually if it tried to, and has no office at all in CAR.

headline: Yanks Play in Houston, Defying George Costanza
text: If you love baseball and Seinfeld, an Astros-Yankees matchup brings to mind a classic episode from 1995, when George Costanza parties with some bawdy Houston executives as they plan an interleague series.

headline: Bonnaroo: An Extended Bass Solo
text: With a head on a swivel, we stepped out into the great heaving mass of possibilities at Bonnaroo. Here is what we, not the royal we, but me and my new 80,000 friends found.

headline: Bonnaroo: M.I.A’s Last Gig Ever?
text: “This is my last show,” the rapper M.I.A. announced from the stage of That Tent, “and I’m glad I’m spending it with all my hippies.” If, as she announced at least three times, it was M.I.A.’s last gig ever, she went out with a boom. The seismic riffs of her songs, which sound like they’re made on the world’s cheapest equipment, puffed bass notes at everyone’s chest, and M.I.A. was all of her interlocking selves: fighter, lover, immigrant, instigator, party girl.

headline: Beijing Nightclubs
text: Images that capture the city and its nocturnal celebrators.

headline: Bonnaroo: Respite in the New Orleans Tent
text: We were told not to miss Henry Butler, he of the psychotic, off-the-hook right hand. He was playing in the New Orleans tent, which was dark, dust-free and nearly people-free, which provided a respite to what was going on just outside. Mr. Butler is one of the most celebrated pianists in a town – New Orleans — that has its share. He can do anything and often does, opening with a riff on Debussy or at least what sounded like one, and then vamping his way into “Let It Roll.” His hands did very different things and then came together and did precisely the same thing, with sparks nearly coming out when his paws collided. I watched a kid next to me spaz out during one of his more remarkable riffs, clicked my tongue in judgment and then found myself doing something similar five minutes later. The guy can go.

headline: Slimming Japan
text: Japan has undertaken one of the most ambitious campaigns ever by a nation to slim down its citizenry.

headline: Women’s Wrestling: Miranda Fails to Qualify for Beijing
text: LAS VEGAS — After Patricia Miranda lost Friday, after her wrestling career possibly ended along with her 2008 Olympic bid, she walked past a crowd of reporters toward a concrete wall deep in the Thomas & Mack Center. She knelt down, hands on knees, and leaned forward until her head rested on the concrete. A friend stood sentry, blocking Miranda from the outside world.

headline: Bonnaroo: Exclamation Point Rock
text: Few bands are more precious than !!! (think chk, chk, chk by way of pronouncers.) The dance punk ensemble – three exclamation points and at least eight musicians, push the jungle sound through a psychedelic prism that, well, really had the kids freaking out – and yeah, a creaky old rocker who stopped by too. The deeper one went into the thicket of fans, the darker and more intense it got, until up by the stage a full-on rave seemed to be underway. These guys got it all: chops, mood and a frontman, Nic Offer, who actually looked pretty fine in a pair of Spandex-like shorts.

headline: Judo: Getting to Beijing Is Easier Than Getting to Arena
text: LAS VEGAS – The United States’ best chance at an Olympic medal in judo clinched a spot in the Games without breaking a sweat Friday.

headline: Bonnaroo: “I Just Wanted to Know Where North Was”
text: The number one most asked question today?

headline: ‘American Idol’ Producers Sued
text: The musicians union filed a federal lawsuit against the producers of “American Idol” on Thursday, claiming that its members had been underpaid because the show’s live music was rerecorded for reruns, The Associated Press reported. The suit by the American Federation of Musicians contends that American Idol Productions and its subsidiary violated a collective bargaining agreement. According to court papers, the producers used different musicians to record new music for the season highlights show in 2007 and did not inform the union. The damages sought were unspecified.

headline: China: More Antiterrorism Drills
text: The Chinese government began a final round of antiterrorism drills at various Olympic sites this week. The exercises include simulations of a chemical attack and of hijacking of athletes’ buses, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. At the beach volleyball ground in Chaoyang Park, firemen, police officers and other security workers evacuated 400 spectators in a simulated blast. The Olympics begin Aug. 8.

headline: Iowa’s Disasters
text: The heaviest rains in Iowa this past week fell in the northern part of the state  a torrential downpour in many cases, following the third-wettest May on the books. That water has been draining out of fields  washing away soil and crops as it goes  and into the rivers, which in the eastern half of the state flow predominantly to the southeast. Des Moines, Iowa City and Cedar Rapids have all watched as floods have approached, but it has been impossible to turn them away. Cedar Rapids and Iowa City have been engulfed. Fifty-five of Iowa’s 99 counties have been declared a disaster.

headline: A Primer for Young People Starting Their First Job
text: To the hundreds of thousands of young people who have landed entry-level jobs that come with health insurance and a retirement plan, I offer my congratulations. Things are tough out there right now, so you must be doing something right.

headline: How to Get It Done
text: “A BRILLIANT strategy, blockbuster product or breakthrough technology can put you on the competitive map, but only solid execution can keep you there,” the lead article in the Harvard Business Review begins. “You have to deliver on your intent. Unfortunately, the majority of companies aren’t very good at it, by their own admission.”

headline: Britain Strengthens Rules on Disclosure of Short Sales
text: LONDON  The British financial regulator introduced rules on Friday covering the disclosure of certain types of share bets  short-selling  that are aimed at protecting the integrity of the country’s financial market.

headline: Northern Japan Quake Kills 2 and Injures Dozens
text: TOKYO  A powerful earthquake with a magnitude of 7.0 shook northern Japan on Saturday morning, killing two people and injuring dozens, the Japanese government said.

headline: China Increases Lead as Biggest Carbon Dioxide Emitter
text: China has clearly overtaken the United States as the world’s leading emitter of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas produced by human activity, a new study has found, its emissions increasing 8 percent in 2007. The Chinese increase accounted for two-thirds of the growth in the year’s global greenhouse gas emissions, the study found.

headline: Campaigns Unable to Agree on Series of Meetings
text: In almost every campaign appearance this week, Senator John McCain has been leaning on Senator Barack Obama to accept his offer to engage in a series of 10 one-on-one town-hall-style meetings, a format that worked well for Mr. McCain in the primaries.

headline: Papa Was a Rolling Stone, and a Famous Disc Jockey
text: Anger, bitterness and ceaseless yearning course through the quest narrated and enacted by W. Allen Taylor in his one-man show at the Abrons Arts Center of the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side.

headline: Star Shuns Emmys, Angering Producers
text: LOS ANGELES  Writers and producers for the ABC hit “Grey’s Anatomy” are fuming after one of the show’s stars, Katherine Heigl, said this week that she had opted out of the Emmy race this year because she was not given good enough material to work with last season.

headline: Courting Conflict
text: Judges must be impartial  in both appearance and reality  so federal law sensibly requires that they disqualify themselves from cases if they own stock in a company that is a party in the matter. It would be best if all judges ordered their investments to avoid conflicts. But the issue is most acute for Supreme Court justices, who cannot be replaced by another jurist. When Supreme Court justices recuse themselves, they risk altering important decisions and blocking the court from doing its job.

headline: Afghanistan: More Aid Is Promised
text: At a two-day session of NATO defense ministers in Brussels, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pleaded with allies to fulfill pledges for troops, and they promised modest additions. The alliance has almost 53,000 troops in Afghanistan, but commanders want three more battalions and more trainers for Afghan forces. Mr. Gates said he told his counterparts that in May, for the first time, more coalition troops were killed in a month’s fighting in Afghanistan than in Iraq.

headline: Legal Drugs Kill Far More Than Illegal, Florida Says
text: MIAMI  From “Scarface” to “Miami Vice,” Florida’s drug problem has been portrayed as the story of a single narcotic: cocaine. But for Floridians, prescription drugs are increasingly a far more lethal habit.

headline: An Iowa Town’s Landmark, Leveled by Explosion, Is Rebuilt by Friendships
text: BALLTOWN, Iowa  The morning before Christmas 2007, an explosion rocked this village of 70 people on a bluff overlooking the Mississippi River, just north of Dubuque. Within minutes, Breitbach’s Country Dining had burned to the ground.

headline: Tim Russert, ‘Meet the Press’ Host, Is Dead at 58
text: Tim Russert, a fixture in American homes on Sunday mornings and election nights since becoming moderator of “Meet the Press” nearly 17 years ago, died Friday after collapsing at the Washington bureau of NBC News. He was 58 and lived in Northwest Washington.

headline: Rowing Is Invigorating (but Do Stay in the Boat)
text: I CROUCHED in the cockpit of a recreational scull, pulling on a pair of oars and going nowhere. It was an unseasonably warm Saturday morning on Sag Harbor Cove at the far eastern end of Long Island. The sky was blue, the waves were flat and my knees were bent as I tried to execute a rowing stroke with my back toward the bow.

headline: For 3 Celtics, Parade Route Wouldn’t Be Strange Path
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce and Ray Allen had just become teammates last summer when they were ushered onto one of Boston’s famous duck boats and taken on a tour by Celtics Coach Doc Rivers.

headline: California Braces for ‘New Summer of Love’
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The groom was shopping for the perfect diamond for his betrothed  the other groom. As Rey Almeida, a 47-year-old elementary school principal, perused the Equality Forever rings (a same-sex wedding special at 40 percent off if purchased from June 16 to June 26), he couldn’t help reflecting on the symbolism.

headline: N. Korea Yields Slightly on Abductions
text: TOKYO  North Korea said Friday that it would reopen an investigation into abductions of Japanese citizens, reversing its longstanding position that the issue had been settled.

headline: Corrections
text: A Spare Times listing on Friday about the 32nd American Crafts Festival misstated the location and this weekend’s dates. It is in Damrosch Park today, noon to 9 p.m., and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. It will also be held there next Saturday and Sunday. It is not at the Lincoln Center plazas on Sunday (nor was it held there on Friday).

headline: A Ruling on the Rights of the Detained
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lost in E-Mail, Tech Firms Face Self-Made Beast
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The onslaught of cellphone calls and e-mail and instant messages is fracturing attention spans and hurting productivity. It is a common complaint. But now the very companies that helped create the flood are trying to mop it up.

headline: Making City Buses Run Cleaner Yields a Big Bonus: Fewer Trips to the Gas Pump
text: When you buy 55 million gallons of diesel fuel a year to power some 5,000 buses, even small improvements in fuel efficiency can make a big difference.

headline: A World of Competitions and Desires With No Exit
text: “Blind Spot” is something of a misnomer for the 2003 dance by Pavel Zustiak that opened at Performance Space 122 on Wednesday. What he offers is far more encompassing.

headline: An Author Underwrites a Successful Track Program
text: NEW BERN, N.C.  At the convergence of the Trent and Neuse Rivers in the wetlands of eastern North Carolina sits this town of 29,000 people. It has been around for nearly 300 years, but has never had a reputation as a breeding ground for professional athletes. One of its proudest athletic achievements came last year, when the New Bern Bears defeated Charlotte Independence for the Class 4A high school state football championship, after which the town threw a parade.

headline: U.S. Gets Modest NATO Accessions on Afghanistan
text: BRUSSELS  A two-day session of NATO defense ministers ended Friday after following a now-familiar script in the debate over Afghanistan: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates made a heartfelt plea for allies to fulfill pledges for troops. Allies promised modest additions.

headline: Gas Prices and the Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Winehouse in Moscow
text: The troubled British singer Amy Winehouse performed for the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich and his girlfriend, the model Daria Zhukova, at the opening of an art gallery in Moscow on Thursday, the BBC reported. For the hourlong performance, which was watched by 300 people at the gallery, the Garage, Ms. Winehouse was paid a reported £1 million, about $1,950,000.

headline: Corrections
text: Front Page

headline: High End or Low, Ballparks Break Bank
text: An interesting problem is what to do with the words and numbers “$2 billion.” Hardly anyone really knows what they mean. One example, worth repeating, is that the difference between a million and a billion seconds is the difference between 11 days and 33 years. A thousand seconds is 16 minutes.

headline: Woods Charges at U.S. Open, but He Has Company
text: SAN DIEGO — The misty fog that creeps ashore in the afternoons in coastal California occurs when cool ocean temperatures mix with heat on the land. So it was no surprise when the intense heat coming from the shots being hit and the putts being made at Torrey Pines Golf Course on Friday produced a brand of United States Open marine layer like none seen before.

headline: Talks With U.S. on Security Pact Are at an Impasse, the Iraqi Prime Minister Says
text: BAGHDAD  Negotiations on a long-term security agreement with the United States are at a stalemate because of American demands that compromise Iraq’s sovereignty, the Iraqi prime minister said Friday.

headline: Disclosures Give Look at Candidates’ Personal Finances
text: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama released their Senate financial disclosure statements on Friday, revealing that Mr. McCain and his wife had at least $225,000 in credit card debt and that Mr. Obama and his wife had put more than $200,000 into college funds for their daughters.

headline: Two Swiss Banks Agree to Settlement in Parmalat Case
text: UBS and the Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland’s two largest banks, agreed to pay almost 357 million euros ($548 million) to settle all legal claims related to their role in financing Parmalat, the dairy company that collapsed five years ago in Italy’s biggest bankruptcy. UBS will pay more than 184 million euros and Credit Suisse will pay 172.5 million euros, Parmalat said in separate statements on Friday. Parmalat’s chief executive, Enrico Bondi, filed lawsuits against dozens of Parmalat’s banks, contending they helped hide the true state of the company’s finances from investors. The banks did not acknowledge any wrongdoing.

headline: The Recession in the Rearview Mirror
text: HOPES that the United States could avoid a recession were renewed this week by evidence that the government’s rebate checks were stimulating spending, at least for now. But two recession indicators based on employment statistics offer evidence that a recession may have begun months ago.

headline: Writers for a Fox Cartoon Walk Out
text: The writing staff of “Sit Down, Shut Up,” a Fox animated series about a high school scheduled to begin next spring, walked off the job on Wednesday. The writers, who had been working without a contract for weeks, expected to receive the benefits recently negotiated by the Writers Guild of America, but the studio producing the series, Sony Pictures Television, said that another union, the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, would have jurisdiction over the show instead. It was one of the first confrontations between writers and a studio since the crippling three-month writers’ strike was settled in February. “We thought there would be no more shenanigans like this,” said John Aboud, a writer for the series. He noted that the writers union contract had covered every Fox animated series since 1998. Sony said the production of its animated shows has been covered by agreements with the theatrical stage employees union for at least 10 years. The conflict has arisen because this is the first animated series Sony has produced for Fox.

headline: Justices Come Under Election-Year Spotlight
text: WASHINGTON  Thanks in no small part to Justice Antonin Scalia’s dire warning that granting Guantánamo detainees access to habeas corpus “will almost certainly cause more Americans to be killed,” the Supreme Court finds itself on the verge of becoming something that it has not been for many election cycles  a campaign issue.

headline: Question of Bush’s Legacy Lingers Over His Farewell Visits to European Capitals
text: PARIS  The final days of George Bush’s presidency have never seemed more imminent as during his tour of Europe’s capitals, a farewell visit in which reminiscence, valediction and even eulogies have trailed him.

headline: In France, Plans to Make a Bit More of the Bubbly
text: MAGNEUX, France  Jean-Michel Petit, a third-generation beet farmer in this village, yearns to trade his earthy roots for the sparkle of Champagne.

headline: Green Thievery in the South Bronx
text: Many promises were made two years ago when the New York Yankees grabbed prime parkland in the South Bronx to build a new stadium. One of them, made by the city, was that residents would have better parks, soccer fields, tracks and ball courts to replace what was taken away. That has not yet happened  and it must.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about retail sales in May misstated the year-over-year sales trend. Sales were 2.5 percent higher than in May 2007  not lower. (The figures did extend a six-month downward trend in year-over-year sales growth when adjusted for inflation.)

headline: A Father’s Tribute to Three Dead Daughters Is Restored
text: There were once  but far too briefly  three sisters from Jamaica, Queens.

headline: No Problems Seen for Shuttle Landing
text: There was a flurry of activity on Friday morning aboard the space shuttle Discovery after astronauts noticed an object floating away from the orbiter and saw what appeared to be a small protrusion sticking out of its rudder.

headline: The Search for a Missing Trader Goes Global
text: Is Samuel Israel III dead or alive?

headline: Bending Gender Every Which Way
text: It’s a mystery why sometimes a few people moving on a stage in apparently random patterns can look so right. In the first 10 seconds  maybe 5  of Dance by Neil Greenberg’s “Quartet With Three Gay Men,” the oddly graceful, undulating movements of the four dancers, the jangly sounds of Zeena Parkins’s score, and Michael Stiller’s clear, bright light have the immediate effect of a poem. Meaning is compressed and harbored, to be released in thrilling fragments, inconclusive and richly layered.

headline: Social Bees Fluttering to Bach’s Sonatas
text: The Czech choreographer Dusan Tynek is a bit of an anomaly nowadays: he makes dances, formal ones, set to Baroque music that burst with leaps, turns and lifts. A former competitive ballroom dancer, Mr. Tynek ended up at Bard College, where he studied with Aileen Passloff, and later went on to dance with the Merce Cunningham Repertory Understudy Group and Lucinda Childs. He has, in dance terms, been around the block.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sexism in Clinton Coverage? Issue Hits a Nerve
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taliban Free 1,200 Inmates in Attack on Afghan Prison
text: In a brazen attack, Taliban fighters assaulted the main prison in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar on Friday night, blowing up the mud walls, killing 15 guards and freeing around 1,200 inmates. Among the escapees were about 350 Taliban members, including commanders, would-be suicide bombers and assassins, said Ahmed Wali Karzai, the head of Kandahar’s provincial council and a brother of President Hamid Karzai.

headline: What Is Life Without a Tram? Residents Are Getting a Taste
text: They waited at the island’s single subway stop as jam-packed cars  two, three, four of them  clacked by without a seat to spare. Then the grumbling began. “The tram is always on time,” said Sally Jenkyn Jones as she forced herself aboard an already brimming F train. “This is always too packed.”

headline: Bloomberg Says Tax Rate on Property May Go Up
text: With the economy in the doldrums, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that the city might scrap a popular tax cut for homeowners in 2009  a step he previously said he would try to avoid.

headline: Newspaper Advertising Takes Big Fall
text: Print advertising sales by American newspapers fell the most on record in the first quarter, tumbling 14 percent as the real estate and job markets shrank and business was lost to the Internet.

headline: Candidates, Fly Away Home
text: The lifespan of a ladybug is four to six weeks.

headline: Mets Add Trot Nixon in a Trade With Arizona
text: In what General Manager Omar Minaya described as a trade that improves the team and the clubhouse, the Mets acquired outfielder Trot Nixon from the Arizona Diamondbacks on Friday for cash or a player to be determined.

headline: Tim Russert, 58, NBC’s Face of Politics, Dies
text: Tim Russert, a fixture in American homes on Sunday mornings and election nights since becoming moderator of “Meet the Press” nearly 17 years ago, died Friday after collapsing at the Washington bureau of NBC News. He was 58 and lived in Northwest Washington.

headline: R. Kelly Is Acquitted in Child Pornography Case
text: CHICAGO  It took more than six years for prosecutors to get the R&B star R. Kelly into court on charges of child pornography. It only took a few hours for a jury to declare him not guilty on all 14 counts.

headline: Playground Rules: A Game N.B.A. Players Grasp
text: Los Angeles

headline: Jeter’s Homer in Eighth Lifts Yankees
text: HOUSTON  For anybody who doubted the wisdom of making Joba Chamberlain a starter, the Yankees can point to Friday’s game as the reason they did it.

headline: Footnotes
text: Mary Higgins Clark is to receive the First Lady of Mystery Award at the International Mystery Writers’ Festival in Owensboro, Ky., on June 22. ... Warren Beatty received a lifetime achievement award from the American Film Institute at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles on Thursday.

headline: The Greeting Card Business Adapts to Change
text: FATHER’S DAY is Sunday, and many greeting cards that will be given out are likely to have been made by the American Greetings Corporation. Zev Weiss, the company’s chief executive, says the holidays and annual events this time of year are important generators of revenue for the company, regardless of whether someone is looking for a card made of paper or a digital one to send by e-mail.

headline: Pettitte Still Admired by Houston Fans
text: HOUSTON  When Andy Pettitte tried to park his car at Minute Maid Park on Friday, the attendant directed him to a different lot than the one he used when he played for the Astros from 2004 through 2006.

headline: Ford Executives and Kerkorian Expected to Talk Next Week
text: DETROIT  The investor Kirk Kerkorian will meet with top executives at Ford next week as a way to show his support for management and its turnaround strategy, people with knowledge of the plans said Friday.

headline: Winter Worries Come Early
text: IT may seem crazy to fret about winter, with summer’s official start just days away. Yet the rising price of winter is on my mind, as it is for many of us who heat our homes  most unfortunately  with oil.

headline: Giuliani Plans to Aid Hopefuls, for His Share
text: WASHINGTON  With the Republican Party in need of money for the November elections, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered to appear at fund-raisers around the country for G.O.P. candidates. But there is a catch: He wants some cash out of the deal.

headline: Greenspan Sees Light at the End of the Credit Tunnel
text: American financial markets, roiled by the collapse of the subprime-mortgage market, have shown a “pronounced turnaround” since March, Alan Greenspan, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Friday. The worst is over for the credit crisis, or will be soon, and there is now a “reduced possibility” of a deep recession, Mr. Greenspan said in remarks via satellite to a conference in Mexico City. His remarks echo the assessment of the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, who said this week that danger of a “substantial downturn” in the economy had receded.  Still, the persistent slump in the housing market is putting ”major downward pressure” on the economy, said Greenspan, who served as Fed chairman from August 1987 to January 2006.

headline: Flood Puts Triathlon Qualifier in Doubt
text: Even the selection of the United States Olympic team is being affected by the severe flooding in Iowa. Next weekend’s Hy-Vee Triathlon, the third and final qualification race to determine who goes to Beijing, has been washed out of its home at Gray’s Lake Park near downtown Des Moines and moved seven miles west.

headline: National Politicians Sought Out the Crucial ‘Russert Test’
text: Through Republican revolution and Republican collapse, the rise and fall of the Houses Clinton and Bush, one war in Afghanistan and two in Iraq, Tim Russert remained a center of gravity in the national discourse every Sunday on “Meet the Press.”

headline: Taking Out the Trash
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a decision overturning rulings that denied asylum to three Guinean women who said they were victims of genital cutting misidentified the judge who wrote the opinion for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. It was Judge Chester J. Straub  not Judge Rosemary S. Pooler  who wrote that the court was “deeply disturbed” that the women’s cases “did not receive the type of careful analysis they were due,” and who quoted from a State Department report that said women in Guinea often endured domestic violence and rape. And it was Judge Straub who used a political analogy to dismiss the argument that genital cutting was a “one-time act” of persecution. (Judge Straub also submitted his own concurring opinion.)

headline: His Status Uncertain, Randolph Relaxes
text: The question was asked with a laugh, and Willie Randolph responded in kind.

headline: Canada Orders the Recall of Some Rail Car Wheels
text: OTTAWA  For safety reasons, the Canadian government ordered the removal on Friday of about 10,000 wheels used on railroad freight cars operating throughout North America.

headline: Access to Health Records
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Oxford Appointment for Kevin Spacey
text: The actor Kevin Spacey, below, has been named Cameron Mackintosh visiting professor of contemporary theater at Oxford’s St. Catherine’s College, The Associated Press reported on Friday. Mr. Spacey, who also serves as the artistic director of the Old Vic in London and has won two Academy Awards, succeeds Patrick Stewart. Stephen Sondheim, Alan Ayckbourn and Diana Rigg have also held the post. During his yearlong term Mr. Spacey will offer workshops, lectures and seminars.

headline: A Buildings Commissioner’s Qualifications
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Men Shift From Friendly to Qualifier
text: CARSON, Calif.  In the past two and a half weeks, the United States men’s soccer team has struggled against England, endured against Spain and battled against Argentina, the top team in the FIFA world rankings. But when World Cup qualifying opens Sunday, the United States’ opponent will be decidedly less glamorous.

headline: Corrections
text: An article and headlines on Tuesday about an agreement by three Internet providers and the office of the New York attorney general under which the three companies will curb access to child pornography overstated the extent of one aspect of the agreement. The providers  Verizon, Sprint and Time Warner Cable  have agreed to purge Web sites that display child pornography and are hosted on the three companies’ servers. The agreement does not, however, prevent customers from accessing such sites on other servers not controlled by those companies.

headline: City and Labor Leaders Reach Deal on Plan to Develop Willets Point
text: The Bloomberg administration has forged an unusual pact with labor leaders, promising that in exchange for their support of the city’s ambitious plan to transform Willets Point, a 62-acre enclave of auto repair shops and cinder block sheds near Shea Stadium, the project will provide union jobs and good wages.

headline: Metallica Says It’s Sorry
text: In its latest cybercontroversy, the heavy-metal band Metallica apologized for asking several bloggers to remove their online reviews of its untitled coming record, The Guardian of London reported. The band upset fans by suing the file-sharing service Napster in 2000 and by removing its music from iTunes in 2003  a decision that was reversed in 2006  but says the removal of the reviews was orchestrated by its management company, Q Prime, without the band’s permission. In a statement on Metallica.com, its Web site, the band described its own reaction to the move. “Our response was ‘WHY?!!!,’ ” the statement said. “Why take down mostly positive reviews of the new material and prevent people from getting psyched about the next record ... that makes no sense to us!” Links to the reviews are now available on the site.

headline: Euro 2008, and the Joys of Being Stateside
text: Every four years, for three short and delightful weeks, I rediscover the pure joy of being a sports fan. I am nowhere near the Euro 2008 soccer tournament being played in Austria and Switzerland, and maybe that’s why I’m having such a wonderful time.

headline: Senators Caught in Mortgage Fallout
text: When Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota wanted a mortgage for his beach house, he turned to a Washington insider, James A. Johnson, former head of Fannie Mae, the government mortgage giant, who then put the senator in touch with Angelo Mozilo, chief executive of the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial.

headline: Stewart R. Mott, Longtime Patron of Liberal and Offbeat Causes, Dies at 70
text: Stewart R. Mott, a philanthropist whose gifts to progressive and sometimes offbeat causes were often upstaged by his eccentricities, like cultivating a large garden atop his Manhattan penthouse, complete with 460 plant species (including 17 types of radishes) and a chicken coop, died on Thursday night. He was 70 and had homes in North Salem, N.Y., and Bermuda.

headline: Lost Baroque Work Is a Spectacle Again
text: ROME  Every afternoon at 5:30 sharp, the “ta-da” moment arrives at the Chiesa del Gesù, the mother church of the Jesuit order.

headline: Another Art Theft in São Paulo
text: Two Picasso prints were stolen by three armed robbers from a museum in São Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. Along with the Picasso prints, “Minotaur, Drinker and Women” from 1933 and “The Painter and the Model” from 1963, the thieves took paintings by two Brazilian artists  “Couple” by Lasar Segall and “Women in the Window,” above, by Emiliano Di Cavalcanti  from the Pinacoteca do Estado museum. The works were estimated to be worth a combined $612,000. The robbers paid the museum’s entrance fee of $2.45 and then overpowered guards to take the framed works. In December another Picasso, “Portrait of Suzanne Boch,” and a painting by the Brazilian artist Candido Portinari were stolen from the São Paulo Museum of Art after men used a crowbar and car jack to force open the museum’s doors. The paintings from that robbery were later found leaning against a house on the outskirts of the city.

headline: Oh Jerry, It’s No Longer Your Baby
text: To: Jerry Yang

headline: Some Cling to Hope for a Deal After Microsoft Discloses Details
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A day after Yahoo said it had ended talks with Microsoft and signed an advertising deal with Google, some of its shareholders were still holding on to hopes that some kind of marriage between Yahoo and Microsoft could be consummated.

headline: Saatchi Taps Young Artists
text: The art collector Charles Saatchi was in a generous mood on Wednesday when he bought almost all the works by three young students from their final graduation exhibit at the Royal Academy Schools in London, The Times of London reported. The student artists are Carla Busuttil, 26; Angus Sanders-Dunnachie, 28; and Jill Mason, 33. Mr. Saatchi’s early purchases helped begin the careers of now-famous artists including Damien Hirst, Tracy Emin, Natasha Kissell and Jake and Dinos Chapman.

headline: Wood Reinvents Himself as the Cubs’ Closer
text: CHICAGO  Kerry Wood was not asked to choose a song for his entrance into games as the closer for the Chicago Cubs. The Cubs play “Welcome to the Jungle” by Guns N’ Roses, but they selected it. Wood cited an antiquated sound system  “we’ve got a couple of indoor-outdoor speakers,” he said  while playfully saying there was no need to have a personally picked tune.

headline: Ireland Derails a Bid to Recast Europe’s Rules
text: Europe was thrown into political turmoil on Friday by Ireland’s rejection of the Lisbon Treaty, a painstakingly negotiated blueprint for consolidating the European Union’s power and streamlining its increasingly unwieldy bureaucracy.

headline: A Tosca Who Comes Out to Meet the Audience
text: The stage at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, when Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic gave a concert performance of Puccini’s “Tosca,” looked as though it had been set up for a rock concert. Loudspeakers were everywhere.

headline: Surprise in Wrestling
text: Patricia Miranda, a bronze medalist in 2004 in Athens and the first woman to win an Olympic wrestling medal, failed to qualify for the United States Olympic team, losing to Clarissa Chun at the wrestling trials in Las Vegas.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some copies on Friday about the Celtics’ victory against the Lakers in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals referred incorrectly to Ray Allen’s performance for Boston. As the article noted, he had 19 points and 9 rebounds  not a “double-double.”

headline: After Silly Mistakes, Singh Just Makes Cut
text: SAN DIEGO  Only at the United States Open could a top professional golfer make this statement just after shooting a seven-over-par 78: “I still played really well.”

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from June 6 through June 13:

headline: Stewart R. Mott, 70, Offbeat Philanthropist, Dies
text: Stewart R. Mott, a philanthropist whose gifts to progressive and sometimes offbeat causes were often upstaged by his eccentricities, like cultivating a farm with 460 plant species (including 17 types of radishes), a chicken coop and a compost pile, atop his Manhattan penthouse, died Thursday night. He was 70 and had homes in North Salem, N.Y. and Bermuda.

headline: At Even Par, Four Veterans Are Down but Not Out
text: SAN DIEGO  It is a foursome that has combined to win 4 major championships, 26 PGA Tour events and 32 European Tour tournaments. Geoff Ogilvy, Ernie Els, Luke Donald and Robert Allenby are tied at even par after two rounds of the 108th United States Open, and while each golfer feels as if the Torrey Pines Golf Course has beat him up for two days, each also feels quietly thankful.

headline: George E. Moore, 88, Cancer Researcher, Is Dead
text: Dr. George E. Moore, a versatile cancer researcher who found an early association between chewing tobacco and mouth cancer while directing the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, a state-financed research center in Buffalo, died on May 19 in Evergreen, Colo. He was 88 and lived in Conifer, Colo.

headline: Progress in Salmonella Investigation
text: Nine of the 228 people who have gotten sick from salmonella-tainted tomatoes ate at two restaurants in the same chain, a federal food official said. The official, David Acheson, the associate commissioner for foods at the Food and Drug Administration, did not name the chain or disclose the location of the restaurants. In a conference call with reporters, he said the agency was keeping the information confidential because the investigation was continuing. A spokeswoman for the Illinois Department of Public Health said the agency was looking at a cluster of cases in the Chicago area. The tainted raw tomatoes, which have sickened people in 23 states, most likely came from Mexico or central or southern Florida, Dr. Acheson said.

headline: A Moment of Clarity in Baghdad
text: The disconnect between Washington’s stay-the-course Republicans  President Bush and Senator John McCain, in particular  and the Iraqi government has grown too wide to ignore. As the administration pushes for a legal agreement to extend the American military presence in Iraq, the Iraqis are pushing back. That is a positive sign.

headline: South Korean Truckers Strike to Protest Rising Fuel Costs
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Thousands of South Korean truck drivers went on strike on Friday to protest rising fuel prices, threatening to paralyze the country’s ports and challenging the already unpopular government of President Lee Myung-bak.

headline: Letters From Vermont
text: Despite the focus on the housing crisis, gasoline prices and the economy in general, the press has not done a good job capturing the intense economic anxiety  and even dread, in some cases  that has gripped tens of millions of working Americans, including many who consider themselves solidly middle class.

headline: The Latest Candidates for an Image Makeover
text: They don’t grow on you.

headline: No Problems Seen for Shuttle Landing
text: Astronauts aboard the shuttle Discovery prepared for a Saturday landing as their 14-day mission to the International Space Station neared an end.

headline: Top Opposition Official Still Missing in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  A high court judge in Zimbabwe on Friday ordered the police to produce Tendai Biti, the opposition party’s secretary general and chief strategist, who was arrested Thursday the moment he re-entered the country and whose whereabouts has since remained a mystery.

headline: Password Helps CBS
text: A special Thursday edition of “Million Dollar Password” gave CBS a ratings lift as 9.4 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen. That tally made it one of the night’s most-watched programs, even with CBS’s repeat of “CSI” at 9 (9.4 million) and ahead of the network’s “Swingtown” at 10 (7 million). CBS earned a second-place finish for the night, trailing only ABC and its live broadcast of Game Four of the N.B.A championship series between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers. On par with earlier games in the series, Thursday’s broadcast averaged 13.8 million viewers. Fox, in third place, edged past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49, thanks to “So You Think You Can Dance” at 9 (8 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, broadcasting a repeat of “My Name Is Earl” at 8 (3.3 million) followed by “Last Comic Standing” from 8:30 to 10 (4.1 million).

headline: Tiny Town, Quaint House, Big Voices
text: CENTRAL CITY, Colo.  The city is not so central anymore, though it played host to a Republican convention of some sort in 1871 and was visited by President Ulysses S. Grant two years later. Nor is it very citylike by 21st-century standards, with its population of 515 or so nestled 8,500 feet high in the Rockies, a spectacular hour’s drive west of Denver.

headline: In Midwest, Rising Waters and Fears of Worse
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  All around the Midwest, the water just kept rising.

headline: The People You Meet in a Ladies’ Bathroom
text: Thank you, Lily Tomlin, Whoopi Goldberg, Tracey Ullman and Anna Deavere Smith. You showed us how satisfying a one-woman show presenting multiple characters of varying ages, ethnicities, accents, social strata, hopes and dreams can be. But because of you, we’re not so bowled over by that sort of thing anymore.

headline: A Major Arms Dealer in Shackles, Delivered to New York
text: Manhattan on a Friday afternoon: downtown along the East River, where the sun was flashing brightly and a lazy weekend called. Women strolled through the South Street Seaport in their summer dresses; tourists went on round-the-island helicopter tours. It was close enough to Wall Street to almost feel the brokers getting ready to head off to their houses by the sea.

headline: Building Permit Revoked at Site of Crane Collapse
text: The city revoked the construction permit on Friday for the high-rise building on East 51st Street where a tower crane toppled and killed seven people in March.

headline: Filling Up for a Bit Less
text: LIFEHACKER this week offered a set of “tips, tricks and hacks” for saving money on gasoline (lifehacker.com). These included the usual advice: do not speed, slow down before applying the brakes, use cruise control.

headline: Europe Worries About a 1970s-Style Oil Shock
text: FRANKFURT  In Europe, where the tight credit market has caused less havoc than in the United States, fears are focusing on another economic bogeyman: a 1970s-style oil shock.

headline: Why Is Mom in Rehab?
text: The actress Tatum O’Neal was arrested recently on charges of buying crack cocaine from a man on the street near her New York City home. She is a 44-year-old mother of three. She has spent years in and out of drug abuse treatment (which she chronicled in her 2004 memoir), and according to her publicist she will continue to “attend meetings” for drug and alcohol abuse.

headline: Wilpons Need to Give Randolph an Answer, Any Answer
text: Jeff Wilpon needs to come out of the shadow now, step up to the plate. He needs to stop whispering to his favorite news media people, hiding behind his general manager and hanging his manager out to dry.

headline: Express Scripts to Buy Smaller Drug Benefit Manager
text: Express Scripts, the prescription manager, will pay $248 million to the private equity firm Monitor Clipper Partners for Medical Services’ division that provides drug benefits for people injured on the job. The division serves more than 500,000 people through workers’ compensation. Express, based in St. Louis, said the deal would not add to earnings until 2009, and then only “slightly.” Express and companies like it operate drug plans for employers, unions and governments.

headline: A Daughter of France’s ‘Lost Territories’ Fights for Them
text: CHANTELOUP-LES-VIGNES, France

headline: Resolution in OTB Dispute Fades Away
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson announced a last-minute deal on Friday in which the state would take over New York City’s Off-Track Betting parlors, averting a planned shutdown. But the plan appeared to fall apart almost immediately over disagreements with the Bloomberg administration over gambling revenue.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture with the Metropolitan Diary on May 12 showing the reflection of a couple strolling by a puddle was published in mirror image. The couple should have been walking toward the right.

headline: Mexico: Cuban Detainees Missing
text: Thirty-three Cubans who fled Cuba this month in motorboats were still missing the day after a Mexican government bus transporting them was stopped by armed men Thursday night. A half-dozen armed men in ski masks hijacked the bus, which also carried four Central Americans, and forced officials away at gunpoint in Chiapas. The Cubans had been detained in motorboats near Cancún on June 5. Immigration officials were transporting them to a detention center in Tapachula, on Mexico’s southern border.

headline: Thousands Fill Streets for Protest in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In the darkness of night, thousands of protesters, many of them lawyers, converged on the main boulevard of Islamabad on Friday, chanting and calling for the dismissal of President Pervez Musharraf and the restoration of the senior judges he dismissed.

headline: Needing Two Tricks, Weighing the Options
text: The final of the trial in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., to select the United States open team for the World Mind Sports Games in Beijing in October had seen more than its share of interesting deals by the time it ended June 6. The one in the diagram was Board 24.

headline: Neighborhood Without a Swimming Pool Gets an Alternative to the Bronx River
text: There is not a single public pool in all of Community District 2 in the Bronx.

headline: NBC Trying to Close Deal for Weather Channel
text: A group led by NBC Universal is in exclusive negotiations to buy the Weather Channel, NBC confirmed on Friday, hours after Time Warner withdrew its bid. The acquisition may be completed in a matter of days.

headline: Shadowy World of Spies, Created in a Secluded Studio
text: SAG HARBOR, N.Y.  Like its predecessors, Alan Furst’s new novel, “The Spies of Warsaw”  the 10th in his highly acclaimed series of historical spy novels set during the advent of World War II, when Nazi power was on the rise in Europe  reads like the kind of book that might have been written in a Paris cafe where men with pencil-thin mustaches while away rainy winter afternoons, smoking Balkan Sobranie cigarettes and talking about the old days.

headline: Plan Would Lift Saudi Oil Output
text: Saudi Arabia, the world’s biggest oil exporter, is planning to increase its output next month by about a half-million barrels a day, according to analysts and oil traders who have been briefed by Saudi officials.

headline: Oil and Food Prices Add to Inflation Pressures
text: Inflation hit harder in May as prices for a wide swath of consumer goods rose at their fastest pace in six months, underscoring warnings from central bankers and adding to a growing consensus that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates by the end of the year.

headline: Lawyer-Turned-Nun Rises to Israel’s Defense
text: Sister Ruth Lautt works from a single room on the 19th floor of the God Box. Such is the nickname for the Interchurch Center, the office building on Riverside Drive in Manhattan that is the closest thing to a Vatican for America’s mainline Protestant denominations. Indeed, Sister Ruth’s fellow tenants include agencies of the United Methodist Church, the United Church of Christ and the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.).

headline: Day of Celebration: From Russia With Love and a Few Other Things
text: It looked promising: “Stars of the Kirov Celebrate Russia Day” brought together a handful of Russian singers, a chorus, a pianist and a cellist to commemorate the Russian Federation’s national day on Thursday at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Detainee Lawyers to Use Ruling for New Attacks
text: A day after the Supreme Court’s ruling granting detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the right to challenge their detention in federal court, military defense lawyers said they planned to use the decision to mount new attacks on the government’s war crimes prosecutions that could stall or stop trials.

headline: Reality Sets In as the Giants Leave Camp
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants arrived at minicamp on Wednesday feeling like Super Bowl champions, and they left on Friday feeling like just another contender.

headline: Yahoo Stock Outpaces the S.&P. 500

headline: Bonnaroo: With Metallica, a Hippie Fest Goes Metal
text: Soon after Metallica started its Friday night headlining set, its guitarist and lead singer, James Hetfield, asked the arm-pumping throng at the What stage a question he often asks along Metallica’s perpetual tour: How many people were seeing Metallica for the first time? Maybe he was surprised that a huge majority of hands went up — or maybe not, since Bonnaroo is the life-affirming hippie festival, and Metallica songs just about always revolve around death: via electrocution (“Ride the Lightning”), addiction (“Master of Puppets”) or war (“No Remorse”). The singalongs were there but less vociferous at Bonnaroo than at a typical Metallica show. And it wasn’t a mosh pit crowd.

Now we’re down to a couple of reformers who don’t like each other. It feels as if we’re embarking on a very long cruise with two neighbors in the last throes of a troubled marriage.

headline: Bonnaroo: No More Films for Glen Hansard from “Once”
text: Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova dueted in the film “Once” and now front a touring band called the Swell Season that includes musicians from the Frames, Mr. Hansard’s longtime band. Sitting in the artist tent after a 90-minute set that landed nicely, he said it’s been a heady couple of weeks. When the band was in Louisville, word came that it was invited to hear Barack Obama speak. “It was amazing, just like everything else that has been happening for us,” he said. Mr. Hansard is contemplating a move to New York from Dublin. “I don’t really live anywhere right now, but Dublin is where I keep my stuff,” he said. The band sold out Radio City Music Hall last month, and Mr. Hansard is continually amazed that people find his and Ms. Irglova’s turn in “Once” riveting enough to stop them everywhere they go. Perhaps a bit more film work then? “No, I’m going to leave that alone,” he said. “I got lucky with the one I already did.”

headline: On Saturday, Houston Is the City of Brotherly Love
text: Some years ago, my two brothers and I all played in the same Connie Mack League baseball game. It was sort of a farce, actually; our team was short a few players, and the coach called my youngest brother, Dave, out of the stands, draped a baggy jersey over him and stuck him in right field. He was 11, I was 17, and our other brother, Tim, was 14.

headline: The Early Word: McCain Cancels Fund-Raiser

The McCain campaign has canceled a fund-raiser at the home of an 86-year-old Texas oilman, Clayton Williams, after ABC News and The Washington Post questioned the campaign about comments Mr. Williams made in a 1990 Texas gubernatorial election.

headline: Bonnaroo: Jack White, Guitar Hero
text: Back before the video game, a guitar hero was a musician who stepped forward out of the band and wrung every iota of drama out of a song: streaking up to a precipitous high note, getting that note to bend and moan and wail, diving down for another, pushing the next phrase even further. Oh, and making dramatically contorted faces to match.

headline: Your Comments on the Mass Rape Column
text: My Sunday column is about the Security Council next week taking up an issue that has never received the attention it deserves: sexual violence in conflicts. It’s partly because of the indelicacy of the issue that victims don’t talk about it and diplomats don’t want to address it either. And that’s what makes it such an effective way to terrorize people and depopulate an area.

headline: The Hardest Words
text: Hillary Clinton campaigned for 16 months and all she gets is this Jpeg. While some might agree that this luminous blue banner on Barack Obama’s Web site thanking her for a gracious concession is the appropriate conciliatory gesture to a formidable opponent, graphic designers see multiple layers of meaning in the design decision, from the selection of the photo to the overall composition.

headline: Where Have You Gone, Willie Davenport?
text: If there is one event in track and field that the United States has dominated in the Olympics, it is the men’s 110-meter high hurdles. In the 14 Summer Games the U.S. has competed in since the end of World War II, American hurdlers have won 10 gold medals in the event, swept it four times and won two of the three medals eight times. For more than 40 years the highs were synonymous with American hurdlers — Willie Davenport, Lee Calhoun, Skeets Nehemiah, Greg Foster, Roger Kingdom and Allen Johnson.

headline: Bonnaroo: Swapping Spit
text: Near the back entrance to Bonnaroo, a woman was talking to her boyfriend and then turned her head quick and spit. Right on a guy who was walking in. “Dude, I am sooooo, soooo sorry,” she said. “No worries,” he said, not breaking stride. No worries. The only real rule at Bonnaroo.

headline: New Americans in Previous Olympics
text: An article in the Sunday Times looks at the increasing number of elite athletes from other countries who move to the United States for one reason or another, gain citizenship and then join the U.S. Olympic team.

headline: Blogtalk: Tim Russert Remembered
text: In many ways, the best political bloggers were just imitating Tim Russert. Digging up past comments and votes and actions, holding up statements side-by-side and decrying inconsistency, Mr. Russert became a force in Washington. Yet one of the consistent themes we see in tributes is that while he was a pit-bull in the studio, he was a teddy bear the rest of the time.

headline: Bonnaroo: Dancing While Standing Still
text: Late afternoon at Bonnaroo will be a little thin, but right now there is much to stare at, including a lovely, moody set by Iron and Wine, the 8-piece ensemble from North Carolina led by Sam Beam. The band opened with “Boy with a Coin” from “The Shepherd’s Dog,” which was followed by “Sodom, South Georgia,” from an album titled “Our Endless Numbered Days,” that had a lot of heads slowly turning.

headline: Winning in Spain, and Enjoying the Culture
text: Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. women’s water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. She’ll be writing occasional posts for the Rings blog in the buildup to the Olympics.

headline: BMX: A New Day
text: The BMX racer Mike Day qualified for the Olympics today. He won the first two races of the first BMX Olympic Trials, held in Chula Vista, Calif., and placed second in another.

headline: Bad free trade arguments
text: Supporters of free trade do not help their case when they accuse those who worry about trade impacts of forgetting about the good stuff, like exports and lower import prices. All they do is show that they don’t understand textbook international economics — the very textbook economics on which the standard case for free trade is based.

headline: Player Ratings: Red Bulls vs. D.C. United
text: The Red Bulls (4-4-3, 15 points) were at a soggy Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington Saturday night to play D.C. United (5-7-1, 16 points) after an eight-day break since their last game. Claudio Reyna and Juan Pablo Ángel, the team’s two designated players, both missed the game because of injuries. (They are also expected to miss the midweek game against New England.) Jozy Altidore will soon wear the yellow uniform of Villarreal of Spain, which left Coach Juan Carlos Osorio with few options other than John Wolyniec up front in a 4-5-1 formation. Seven mostly young Americans were in the Red Bulls’ uninspired and rudderless starting lineup.

headline: Bonnaroo: Warmed Up for Pearl Jam
text: Jack Johnson is no slouch, having moved about 15 million copies of his various albums, but he had to notice that the space in front of him at the What Stage for his 7:30 pm set was filling up with a few more people than he might have expected. The rest of the Bonnaroo stages had closed down and there seemed to be massive anticipation for the Pearl Jam show tonight. It was if someone had lifted up one corner of the site and all the bodies slowly rolled down toward the What Stage. The reflexively mellow crowd seemed a bit amped, anxious to get a cherished spot, or at least a defendable space, for Pearl Jam’s set.

headline: Bonnaroo: Ring of Fire
text: Late Saturday afternoon and gigantic black smoke rings more than 50 feet wide were floating over the Bonnaroo site, as if Godzilla was working a stogie just over the hill. As it turns out, Ken Smith of Muscle Shoals, Ala., had set up a liquid-fueled flame projector, a contraption that shoots a giant fireball into the air, which then leaves a legacy in the form of a smoke ring.

headline: The Weapon of Rape
text: World leaders fight terrorism all the time, with summit meetings and sound bites and security initiatives. But they have studiously ignored one of the most common and brutal varieties of terrorism in the world today.

headline: Up Front
text: Vanessa Grigoriadis has written many memorable articles (she won a National Magazine Award in 2007 for a profile of Karl Lagerfeld that appeared in New York magazine), but the one that may have been the most fun to work on was a Britney Spears cover story for Rolling Stone this year.

headline: In Harmony With His Daughter, in Song and in the Dugout
text: THE day I auditioned for the New York City Gay Men’s Chorus, I thought it would be fun for any number of reasons. Chief among them: I’m a gay rights activist who loves to sing. But over the past three years, during which I have been the group’s only female singing member, one reason more than any other has given it a special meaning. Surrounded by 249 talented men, I find myself remembering my favorite Irish tenor. My dad.

headline: On Bench, Canó Gets a Chance to Watch
text: HOUSTON  When the Yankees first used Robinson Canó as a pinch-hitter this season, on April 14, he sat on the bench, studied other left-handed hitters, and smacked a go-ahead home run at Tampa Bay. That was in Canó’s mind on Saturday, when he watched the first seven innings of an 8-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

headline: As a Father, I Was Hardly a Perfect Fit
text: DURING our weekly telephone call, my 10-year-old son told me he wanted a Yankees cap. Not just any Yankees cap; it had to be a fitted cap. “Fitted caps don’t have the little plastic adjuster on the back,” he told me. “All the pro players wear them.”

headline: Summer in the Caribbean
text: HOUSTON in summer can be a miserable place.

headline: A Mixed Bag, With Inflation a Top Worry
text: It was a mixed week for the stock market, which was constrained by unfavorable economic reports but nonetheless had some pockets of strength.

headline: Storms Cause Power Failures and Close Roads and Subways
text: Heavy storms disrupted subway service, flooded highways and caused power failures throughout the region on Saturday evening.

headline: With the Passage of Years, a Coming Together
text: IT took dementia to finally bring me and my 86-year-old father together. A few months ago, I rather brazenly suggested that he and Marilyn, his partner of the last 20 years, separate to their respective families for the holidays. At his age, I thought, it might be one of the last times he could see many of his grandchildren together in one place. To my surprise, Marilyn agreed, and the following week he was dropped off with his small valise, for four days.

headline: Correction: Fashion Designers Honor Their Own
text: An entry in the Evening Hours column last Sunday, about the New York City Outward Bound benefit on June 3, omitted the name of an honoree. Besides Louis V. Gerstner Jr., Tim Armstrong, second from right in the last picture, was also honored. The column also misidentified the educational affiliation for the Outward Bound graduates shown with Quemel Arroyo. They attend Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning School, not the Bronx Expeditionary Learning High School.

headline: Oyster Bay Ordered to Permit Mall’s Construction
text: IN what could be a decisive moment in a seven-year legal battle over plans to build a luxury mall in Syosset, a Suffolk County judge has ordered the Town of Oyster Bay to immediately issue a permit that would allow construction to begin on a 39-acre former industrial site next to the Long Island Expressway.

headline: 36 Hours in Vienna
text: THERE is new energy in Vienna’s imposing gorgeous streets. Where museum-worthy beauty may once have felt untouchable, there is a palpable sense of a city loosening up. It’s alive in the reinvention of the gasthäuser — the Austrian greasy spoons that haunt every corner — now taken over by young chefs’ reinvigorating menus. It’s in the night life, which ranges from gritty to über-designed lounges. It’s in festivals like ImpulsTanz (www.impulstanz.com), the modern dance extravaganza that charms the city each summer, and will do so again this year from July 10 to Aug. 10.

headline: On Cozy Streets, a Great Divide
text: FOR the first hour or so, the gathering of the Manhattan Beach Neighborhood Association on June 3 resembled any other such meeting. About 70 residents fidgeted and murmured in the auditorium of Public School 195, while a procession of local officials trooped up to the stage.

headline: Two Styles of Dysfunctional Family. Which One Reassures?
text: From "August: Osage County," by Tracy Letts

headline: The Gambler
text: “There are only two kinds of gamblers: the lucky and the broke,” says the compulsive wagerer at the center of Preston L. Allen’s casino noir “All or Nothing.” Known simply as P (protagonist? Preston?), he’s been one or the other his entire adult life. A Miami school bus driver with a large family and an even larger jones, he squanders his paychecks and scrounges loose change from school bus seats, then loses it all at South Florida Indian casinos, mostly to slot machines, the crack cocaine of gambling. P is not above wishing for his young son’s life-threatening allergic reactions, believing the child utters winning numbers while slipping toward a coma. He plays, he loses and, with the Sisyphean regularity of the certifiably insane, he returns to play again. Above all, he lies  to his wife, his bosses, his children, himself.

headline: On a Park’s Border, Fears of Long Shadows
text: SINCE its completion more than 30 years ago, Mount Sinai Medical Center’s Annenberg Building, at 99th Street off Fifth Avenue, has been regarded by some people as the sore thumb of East Harlem, a 31-story black monolith that intrudes on the mostly pristine skyline on the northeast border of Central Park. But if a plan put forth by the medical center gains city approval, the Annenberg may be relieved of its pariah status, surpassed in height and maybe local resentment by a condo tower.
