headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the Rail roundup in some editions last Sunday about the search for answers after Big Brown’s failure at the Belmont Stakes misidentified a medical procedure that the horse’s handlers said they would have done to check for a breathing obstruction or internal bleeding. It was an endoscopic exam, not arthroscopic surgery.

headline: Welcome to the Dollhouse
text: About a decade ago, when Dutch fashion was still something of an oxymoron, Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren could fit their dreams of becoming world famous designers into a shoe box.

headline: Letters: The Lawyer’s Crusade (Continued)
text: I read with interest James Traub’s article on the Pakistani lawyers’ movement (June 1). As a humble participant in the movement, I took exception to the comparison of our leader and guide Aitzaz Ahsan with Jawaharlal Nehru. While Nehru was called to the bar he did not make a living as a lawyer, partially because he didn’t need to and partially because he was no good. Aitzaz on the other hand is nothing if not a great lawyer. If there is a silver-tongued barrister he reminds us of, it is Muhammad Ali Jinnah, held by many to be the greatest lawyer in the British Empire. Like Jinnah, Aitzaz is at the top of the legal game and a politician who uses mainly constitutional means to advance his cause. What is more, Aitzaz consciously emulates Jinnah in his measured, logical exposition of facts.

headline: A Long Road to the Right Fit
text: PROFESSIONALLY, Carlos Vargas trains financial executives on managing mergers and developing investment strategies. Having such expertise didn’t hurt when it came time for his own recent entrepreneurial move: the sale of his West Village co-op apartment.

headline: Love at First Touch
text: The real hero of Katie Hafner’s book “A Romance on Three Legs” is not, as the subtitle suggests, the pianist Glenn Gould, or even the piano he was obsessed with, but a nearly blind man named Verne Edquist, who confirms that behind every great pianist is a great tuner.

headline: Almighty Dollar
text: Now the child of scorn.

headline: Angry Clinton Women ♥ McCain?
text: TEN years ago John McCain had to apologize for regaling a Republican audience with a crude sexual joke about Hillary and Chelsea Clinton and Janet Reno. Last year he had to explain why he didn’t so much as flinch when a supporter asked him on camera, “How do we beat the bitch?” But these days Mr. McCain just loves the women.

headline: LieDate.Com
text: A few months ago, I met my boyfriend on JDate, a dating site for Jewish singles. He assumed I was Jewish, and I didn’t correct him when I had the chance. Now I’m afraid that if I tell him, he’s going to dump me. What do I do? I really like this guy, but it’s getting weird. C.T., Brooklyn

headline: A 3-Wheel Dream That Died at Takeoff
text: BUCKMINSTER FULLER’s 1933 Dymaxion, a streamlined pod on three wheels, is one of the lovable oddballs in automotive history. Three were built, fawned over by the media and by celebrities, but the car pretty much disappeared after one crashed, killing the driver.

headline: Lily Stockman, Peter Brooks
text: Isabel Robinson Stockman, a daughter of Lisa Russell Stockman and Robert Bernard Stockman of Princeton, N.J., was married at her family’s farm there on Saturday afternoon to Lt. Peter Harrington Brooks, a son of Virginia Woodworth Brooks and Stephen Harrington Brooks of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Valerie Webster, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Think First, Bail Out Later
text: Boston

headline: That Bag Is Suddenly $15 Heavier
text: ONCE upon a time, the music associated with air travel was the soaring theme from “Rhapsody in Blue,” which United Airlines licensed as its signature song in 1976.

headline: A World of Curiosity
text: I WAS born in Boston and lived there for all of three weeks, until I was old enough to travel. My father had lined up a job in California with a military contractor. He was originally from Thailand and had come to the United States to go to graduate school. He arrived with a suitcase of pots and pans.

headline: Where the Wild Things Came From
text: When my second-grade teacher was growing up during the Great Depression, she discovered what would become her favorite book at the Cleveland Heights Public Library. Unfortunately, by the time she’d finished reading “The Hobbit” and persuaded her parents to buy her a copy, they couldn’t find it in the bookstore. Undeterred, she checked out the library’s copy over and over again, determined to make one of her own by pecking out the entire text with two fingers on the family’s manual typewriter. How many authors who write for adults can boast of having a reader so utterly devoted to their work?

headline: The Power of the Powerless
text: There are not many countries whose stories are so intensely bound to the character of a single person, much less a person with no tangible power, not even the power to leave her house or receive a visitor or make a telephone call. Yet for nearly two decades, events in Myanmar (formerly Burma) have revolved around the condition, the policies and most of all the victimization of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, now 62, who has been held under house arrest for 12 of the past 18 years. Hers is a symbiotic power, as Justin Wintle describes it in his aptly titled “Perfect Hostage,” bestowed by the almost cartoonish thugs who have made her “an outstanding example of the power of the powerless,” in the words of the former Czech president Vaclav Havel.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An obituary last Sunday about the ABC Sports broadcaster Jim McKay misidentified the birthplace of David Berger, a weight lifter who was one of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team killed by terrorists in 1972 in Munich, an episode Mr. McKay covered. Mr. Berger was born in Shaker Heights, Ohio; he was not “Israeli-born.”

headline: Two Twosomes, Not a Script in Sight
text: THE improv duo of T J Jagodowski and David Pasquesi, better known as TJ and Dave, do not speak to each other on the day before a show. They think any sort of contact detracts from the spontaneity of the performance. Murray Nossel and Paul Browde, the two men in “Two Men Talking,” meanwhile, won’t shut up. Before facing the audience, they confide intensely with each other for up to two hours (longer than the actual show), pouring out the thoughts and events of the day.

headline: Report of Horse Deaths Creates More Questions
text: Over the past five years, 3,035 thoroughbreds, standardbreds and quarter horses have died at racing facilities, but not all of them on the racetrack or in racing-related accidents, according to statistics provided to a Congressional subcommittee by the Association of Racing Commissioners International.

headline: Correction: The Wiki-Way to the Nomination
text: An article last Sunday about the importance of the Internet to Barack Obama’s presidential campaign misstated a Web address for the campaign. It is my.barackobama.com.

headline: Very Colorful Cynicism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: A listing of renovation tips with an article last Sunday about brokers who advise owners to keep resale in mind when renovating their apartments referred incompletely to the life span of prefinished floors. While laminated prefinished floors may indeed need to be replaced after being refinished only once or twice, a solid hardwood prefinished floor can stand up to just as many sandings as any other solid wood floor.

headline: It’s Zaragoza’s Turn to Make a Splash
text: UP to now, one could be forgiven for knowing next to nothing about the ancient Spanish city of Zaragoza, capital of Aragon and the country’s fifth largest metropolis. For some reason, it’s never had the same mystique as, say, Granada, Salamanca or Toledo. But that seems likely to change very soon.

headline: Nixon Joins the Mets, Rejoining the Majors
text: Trot Nixon has spent the past three months with players who know nothing of winning a World Series, of playing in a rabid baseball town like Boston or of even playing in the major leagues.

headline: Imprinted With Surrealism’s Influence
text: Not only did Adolph Gottlieb make oil paintings that burn with calligraphic intensity, he was also good at printmaking. Fourteen of the Abstract Expressionist’s linocuts, lithographs and etchings can be seen in “Adolph Gottlieb: Early Prints,” a national touring exhibition at the Pollock-Krasner House in Springs.

headline: Staying in the Apartment for an Extra Month
text: Q I live in a rent-regulated apartment in Brooklyn, which I rent on a yearly basis. I plan to vacate my apartment one month past the expiration of the lease because I am moving out of state. My landlord tells me to sign a lease for a whole year and to sign a letter saying I am responsible for rent if he is unable to replace me with another tenant. What should I do?

headline: An Olympics to Make and a Promise to Keep
text: LAS VEGAS  After winning a Greco-Roman wrestling world title in 2002, Dremiel Byers celebrated like a man possessed.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Sports

headline: Guiding Hands Help Immigrant Artists Connect
text: Something about the man in the banana costume appealed to Ricardo Miranda Zúñiga. Maybe it was the sign he wore that read, “A banana from my country can travel easier than me.” Maybe it was the fruit-wearer’s free-spiritedness as he paraded in his peel through public places. Or maybe it was the Latino roots they shared.

headline: Letters | The Great Unknown
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Bid for .400 Comes Out of Nowhere
text: CHICAGO  Chipper Jones is chasing the magically elusive .400 batting average, but he paused to remind everyone where the chase started. Not while Jones was in spring training with the Atlanta Braves and not during a secret batting practice, but way back. Years back, back home.

headline: Finding He’s at Home in His Second Skin
text: DAD was always the silent type. Slipping home quietly after work every evening, he would let my sister and me take turns pulling the knot out of his tie. Then he tended to his menagerie, which consisted of either dogs, birds, chinchillas, iguanas or all of the above at any given time. Later, he’d sip Bustelo espresso and watch old westerns. Ask him about those cinematic classics and he can still recite a few lines of dialogue with his Spanish drawl.

headline: Literary Lion
text: Q: At the age of 82, you will be publishing your new collection of essays this week, which seems likely to confirm your reputation as one of America’s last public intellectuals. Why do you think that critics have traditionally praised your essays more than your fiction, which includes “Burr,”   “Myra Breckinridge” and 20 other novels? That’s because they don’t know how to read. I can’t name three first-rate literary critics in the   United States . I’m told there are a few hidden away at universities, but they don’t print them in The   New York Times .

headline: The Late Dictator
text: Assassination has long been an appealing subject for male novelists. Geoffrey Household’s “Rogue Male” (1939), Richard Condon’s “Manchurian Candidate” (1959), Frederick Forsyth’s “Day of the Jackal” (1971), Don DeLillo’s “Libra” (1988) and James Ellroy’s “American Tabloid” (1995): all are fictions plotted by men about men plotting to murder other men.

headline: Swapland
text: The reason bartering can work in villages  including, during various periods, Greenwich Village, the Haight-Ashbury and Burning Man  is that village neighbors make and need comparable products. Some corn, some carpentry, an embroidered pillowcase, firewood, horseshoes, quilts. Marijuana. A bottle of water.

headline: Letter From Cairo
text: Cairo

headline: Letter: How to Pick Asparagus
text: To the Editor: In the explorer column, “On the Trail of a Sustainable Feast” (June 1), the author states that Ana Stayton reached “under a blueberry bush to yank a stray asparagus stem out of the ground for us to taste.”

headline: Bearing Bad News
text: In Steven Spielberg’s “Saving Private Ryan,” soon after the re-creation of D-Day, attention turns stateside to a middle-aged woman washing dishes as a car approaches her home. The vehicle comes to a stop, and the woman  knowing what awaits  steps outside and onto her porch before falling to the ground, almost as if she were a soldier wounded in battle. Spielberg chooses to place the camera behind his actress and at somewhat of a distance; we do not see her face when she hears the news that three of her sons have been killed in combat. There is no audible dialogue, either. The power of the scene lies in its universality: a parent collapsing from an emotional anguish projected over a barren landscape.

headline: ‘The Other’
text: No Escape from the Unhappiness Machine

headline: In a Year Off the Beaten Path, a New Direction for Life
text: AT the end of my junior year in high school in Maryland, I realized I wasn’t ready to apply to college or take the SAT. I wanted to postpone the whole application process and focus on my studies during senior year. A friend suggested a gap year  a year to pursue other interests  after high school.

headline: Still the King, but Money Rules
text: The last few yards of stock-car racing’s Tobacco Road heritage were finally paved over last Wednesday when Petty Enterprises, a team dating from the start of Nascar in 1949, announced the sale of a majority interest to a private equity firm, Boston Ventures. Pressed for money and without a victory since 1999, Petty Enterprises needed capital to compete with the better-financed teams that now dominate.

headline: Restrictions Reduce Horseshoe Crab Fishing
text: WESTHAMPTON DUNES

headline: His Dad, the World’s Darling
text: MY father was a saint. Everyone said so. His family. My mother’s family. His business partners. His employees. Even his competitors.

headline: ‘A Case of Exploding Mangoes’
text: There is something about these bloody squadron leaders that makes them think that if they lock you up in a cell, put their stinking mouth to your ear, and shout something about your mother, they can find all the answers. They are generally a sad lot, these leaders without any squadrons to lead. It's their own lack of leadership qualities that stops them mid-career, nowhere for them to go except from one training institute to another, permanent seconds in command to one commander or the other. You can tell them from their belts, loose and low, straining under the weight of their paunches. Or from their berets, so carefully positioned to hide that shiny bald patch. Schemes for part-time M.B.A.'s and a new life are trying hard to keep pace with missed promotions and pension plans.

headline: Scraping the Sky, and Then Some
text: THE world’s population is expected to climb to nine billion by the middle of the century, from six and a half billion today, according to the United Nations, and a staggering number of those people are likely to be living in big cities.

headline: DeMille’s Close-Up
text: Simon Louvish’s elegantly exhaustive study of Cecil Blount DeMille (1881-1959) carries the respectful if not necessarily reverent title “Cecil B. DeMille: A Life in Art.” It examines that life largely though not entirely through his 70 movies, completed during a 42-year career, from “The Squaw Man” in 1914 to “The Ten Commandments” in 1956, itself a remake of his own 1923 “Ten Commandments.” “The Squaw Man” was also remade as an early talkie in 1931, during a period in which all of Hollywood, and DeMille especially, was struggling, often pathetically and disastrously, to make sense and cinema out of the newfangled dimension of talk.

headline: For 3 Days, 2 Jazz Festivals Will Go Head-to-Head
text: FOR 14 years, the jazz acts at the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah have been presented on two consecutive Saturdays at the end of July and the beginning of August. This year, they will be presented on three straight days, Aug. 1 to 3.

headline: They Love (the New) Brooklyn
text: WHILE condominium developers across the country are trying to unload thousands of apartments that they can’t sell, some builders in Brooklyn have found the real estate equivalent of a golden parachute. Having turned their new units into high-priced rentals, they have found a surprising number of eager takers.

headline: Iowa River Falls, but Misery Isn’t Over
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  As the waters of the Cedar River started to slowly recede in this city overnight, officials in other cities in Iowa were fighting untamed rivers.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in some copies of the baseball roundup in some editions last Sunday about the Giants’ 6-0 victory against the Nationals on June 7 misstated the number of runs Washington scored in losing six of seven games. It was 13  not 3, which was the total number of runs in the six losses.

headline: A Graduate of Sha Na Na, Now a Linguistics Professor
text: Hempstead

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about the final efforts to prepare Big Brown for the Belmont Stakes referred incorrectly to his name. His only official name has been Big Brown; he was not named Boundary at birth. (Boundary is his sire.)

headline: Up in Smoke
text: Even if you disregard the van Gogh cover sketch of a skeleton smoking a cigarette, it’s difficult to miss that “When You Are Engulfed in Flames” is a book about David Sedaris’s midlife crisis. He was in his 30s when he was discovered by Ira Glass of NPR, and ever since he has presented himself as a childish genius perpetually late to the literary scene and forever mini-crisis prone. Even as he was transformed into publishing’s Dave Matthews  with four best sellers, endless paid lecture opportunities and 30-city tours  it’s taken his 50th birthday to alert Peter Pan to the onset of maturity. “I’ve been around for nearly half a century,” he moans, later adding, “In another 25 years I’ll be doddering, and 25 years after that I’ll be one of the figures haunting my Paris bedroom.” He tallies up the last 25 years, the prime of his life, and isn’t impressed by the sum: “How had 9,125 relatively uneventful days passed so quickly,” he writes, “and how can I keep it from happening again?”

headline: Tiny Town: Washington After a Fall
text: Washington — “Did you hear about Tim Russert?”

headline: Into the Woods
text: In college, I had a friend named Kurt. A lot of people know someone like Kurt in college  brilliant, obsessive and kind of scary. He stayed up 72 hours reading Goethe. He filled a 50-page notebook with tiny scrawled notes about Henry James. (These weren’t class assignments.) He loved absolute principles and what he called “the timeless.” He railed against hypocrisy. He liked to stand outside fraternities and shout lines from Byron. When a poem offended him, he ate it  crumple, chew, swallow  and ended up with an intestinal blockage. My friends and I loved Kurt, and we worried about him.

headline: A Year Reshapes Hamas and Gaza
text: GAZA  Cursing God in public here  a fairly common event in this benighted and besieged strip of Palestinian land  can now lead to prison. So can kissing in public. A judge ruled last week that a bank could not collect its contracted interest on a 10-year-old loan because Islam forbids charging interest.

headline: Museum Repasts, From Snacks to Tea
text: THE majestic Charles II style manor house at Old Westbury Gardens, built from 1904 to 1906 for John S. and Margarita Grace Phipps and their four children, has been preserved as the family left it in 1958 after more than 50 years in residence. The ballroom has polished teak parquet floors and French doors opening onto a terrace with a sweeping view of the south lawn. A tea table in the chandeliered drawing room is set with the family’s silver.

headline: Two Bubbles, Two Paths
text: LATELY more and more people have been questioning the received wisdom about what a central bank should do when confronted by an asset price bubble. That piece of wisdom, shared by Alan Greenspan and Ben S. Bernanke, the former and present Federal Reserve chairmen, holds that deliberate bubble-bursting is something between impossible and dangerous  and thus best avoided. Instead, according to this view, the Fed should let bubbles burst of their own accord, and then be prepared to mop up after.

headline: Tapped Out
text: To paraphrase an old axiom: You don’t buy water, you only rent it. So why did Americans spend nearly $11 billion on bottled water in 2006, when we could have guzzled tap water at up to about one ten-thousandth the cost? The facile answer is marketing, marketing and more marketing, but Elizabeth Royte goes much deeper into the drink in “Bottlemania: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It,” streaming trends cultural, economic, political and hydrological into an engaging investigation of an unexpectedly murky substance. Partway through her undoctrinaire book, Royte, a lifelong fan of tap water, refills her old plastic water bottle, reflecting that “what once seemed so simple and natural, a drink of water, is neither. All my preconceptions about this most basic of beverages have been queered.” And by the end of the book she will have discarded the old plastic bottle too, but not the tap.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: Elnaz Menhaji, David Klotz
text: Elnaz Menhaji, a daughter of Badrolsadat Menhaji and Mohsen Menhaji of Greenvale, N.Y., was married on Friday to David Matthew Klotz, a son of Nancy H. Klotz and Lt. Gen. Frank G. Klotz of Bolling Air Force Base in Washington. Leslie Gross, the town clerk of North Hempstead, N.Y., officiated in her office there. On Sunday evening, Ahmad Pakzad is to lead a traditional Persian ceremony at the Westbury Manor, a caterer in Westbury, N.Y.

headline: On the Big Stage, No Urge to Disturb
text: The word is that Broadway got hip this year.

headline: To Curb Traffic on the Internet, Access Providers Consider Charging by the Gigabyte
text: Some people use the Internet simply to check e-mail and look up phone numbers. Others are online all day, downloading big video and music files.

headline: Most Formidable Major Frustrates Golf's Greatest
text: For Tiger Woods, the United States Open has been the most difficult of the four major championships to win. If he were to stack his 13 majors as if they were poker chips, he has four Masters, three British Opens and four P.G.A. Championships, but only two Opens.

headline: A Venerable Firm, at Least in Name
text: Thornberg & Forester may sound like a stodgy, corporate Wall Street firm that’s been around for 100 years. In fact, it’s the concocted name of a year-old Manhattan design and communications group.

headline: Senator Says Loan Favoritism Is Possible
text: Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, said Saturday that he would donate $10,500 to charity and refinance a property loan after suggestions that he and other prominent Washington figures received preferential treatment from Countrywide Financial Corporation.

headline: Billionaires Go Shopping
text: THE moment of truth has arrived for 15 Central Park West, the limestone-clad retreat for the rich and very rich.

headline: Thanks, Weird Al, You Model American
text: CAIRO — My son Nikolas will be 10 years old in August. He knows all about Ramadan and can walk into any mosque and tell the mihrab from the minbar. He is absolutely color blind to people and culture. He’s a child of the world, a kid who has spent eight years of his young life living first in Russia and then in Egypt.

headline: Starting to Think Outside the Jar
text: WHEN it comes to innovations in everyday essentials, the glass is either half-empty or half-full.

headline: Stephanie Denton, Zeno Baucus
text: Stephanie Maria Denton, the daughter of Linda L. Denton and Dr. Stephen L. Denton, both of Athens, Tenn., was married on Saturday evening in Big Sky, Mont., to Zeno Benjamin Baucus, the son of Ann Geracimos of Washington and Senator Max Baucus of Helena, Mont., and Washington. The Rev. Dave McConnell, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Big Sky Resort.

headline: Croutons From My Father
text: Los Angeles

headline: Dannielle Tegeder, Pablo Helguera
text: Dannielle Tegeder and Pablo Helguera are to be married on Sunday evening. The Rev. Mark W. Hummell, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate in Brooklyn.

headline: Jennifer Baur, David Rooney
text: Jennifer Marie Baur, the daughter of Carolyn B. Baur and Michael P. Baur of Eatonton, Ga., was married on Friday evening to David Patrick Rooney, the son of Mary Ann and William F. Rooney of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Michael A. Carrano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine Church in Spring Lake.

headline: The Conservator
text: When William F. Buckley Jr. died a few months ago, George F. Will, who dedicates “One Man’s America” to him, became, perhaps, the right’s most enduring elder statesman. It’s a distinction he’s worked assiduously to earn. Over the past three and a half decades, Will has been conservative in everything but his output, which includes several columns a week and regular appearances on Sunday television, along with a steady stream of books on subjects ranging from baseball to politics. But Will isn’t noteworthy simply for his industry. As this droll and discerning examination of America reminds us, he’s also been, and remains, the conscience of conservatism.

headline: The Actor With Stardom in His Eyes
text: JAPAN’S most distinguished living actor, Tatsuya Nakadai, has made well over 100 movies, and he’s still probably best known to American audiences for a role in which he is nearly unrecognizable. As Hidetora, the 80-something feudal patriarch of the Ichimonji clan in Akira Kurosawa’s “Ran” (1985), Mr. Nakadai  then in his early 50s  wore heavy makeup intended not only to age him but also to resemble a Noh mask. In an interview conducted three years ago for the Criterion DVD release of the film he said, “They had to draw in every single wrinkle; the only parts of that face that were actually mine were the eyes.”

headline: When Young Was Old
text: Age can seem more a state of mind than a biological condition, particularly when it comes to presidents, who are often frozen in the images formed by history and legend. It is strange to think that Abraham Lincoln (52) and Franklin D. Roosevelt (51), who sagaciously guided the nation through times of unparalleled crisis, were both younger when they assumed office than George W. Bush (54) was when he did. Strange, too, that Andrew Jackson, the swashbuckling Hero of New Orleans and the embodiment of a new spirit of backwoods populism, began his first term at age 61, making him one of our older presidents, and positively ancient in his own day, when life expectancy for white males was below 40.

headline: Examining Obama’s Call for Scrutiny of Trade Deals
text: As he campaigns against what he describes as unfair foreign trade deals, Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic nominee, often singles out Japan and especially South Korea for criticism. Both countries, he complains, have erected “all kinds of restrictions and barriers” to shut out American products, including beef and automobiles.

headline: Rival Turns Up the Heat on Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The pressure on President Pervez Musharraf to resign escalated Saturday after a senior leader in the civilian government suggested to a large outdoor rally here that Mr. Musharraf should be hanged.

headline: ‘When You Are Engulfed in Flames’
text: It's Catching

headline: After a Final Bow, Continuing a Legacy of Change
text: WHEN Damian Woetzel takes his final bow on Wednesday as a principal dancer for New York City Ballet, balletomanes everywhere will grieve. But as so often of late, City Ballet’s loss is the field’s gain.

headline: Adding Hamlet to Characters Within
text: MICHAEL STUHLBARG spoke so softly at times in this interview that the recording of it had to be played back at maximum volume, and even then some words registered barely above a whisper. The conversational voice of the man is in stark contrast to the speech of the actor.

headline: Letters | Campaign Literature
text: To the Editor:

headline: Inside the List
text: THE BOND ERA: Ian Fleming’s James Bond novels weren’t immediately popular with American readers. The first Bond title, “Casino Royale,” appeared here in 1954, early in Eisenhower’s presidency, and didn’t make much of a dent. “Casino Royale” took a beating in the Book Review. Our critic, Anthony Boucher, liked the novel’s opening baccarat scene but not much else. He complained that Fleming “leads the weary reader through a set of tough clichés to an ending which surprises no one save Operative 007.”

headline: Accessorize Like an Ascetic
text: Your luggage or your wallet.

headline: The Man for a New Sudan
text: When Roger Winter’s single-engine Cessna Caravan touched down near the Sudanese town of Abyei on Easter morning, a crowd of desperate men swamped the plane. Some came running over the rough red airstrip. Others crammed into a microbus that barreled toward the 65-year-old Winter as he climbed down the plane’s silver ladder. Some Sudanese call Winter “uncle”; others call him “commander.” On this day, angry and anxious, the people of Abyei wanted Winter’s help in averting a return to civil war between the predominantly Arab north and the black south  a decades-long conflict, claiming more than two million dead, that Winter helped to end with his work on the Comprehensive Peace Agreement of 2005.

headline: Agee Unfettered
text: On May 16, 1955, James Agee, 45, died of a heart attack in a New York City taxicab while on the way to his doctor’s office. Elegized by the critic Dwight Macdonald as a literary James Dean, he left behind an idiosyncratic nonfiction classic called “Let Us Now Praise Famous Men” along with one of those myths for hard-living and intemperate genius that are far more alluring to young writers than the idea that they are going to spend their working lives alone in a room, hoping that something interesting will happen on the blank screen in front of them. (There are days when more interesting things happen on a widget assembly line.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio referred incorrectly to a military officer portrayed in “Valkyrie,” a planned film from United Artists (of which MGM is part-owner) about a plot against Hitler during World War II. While that officer, Col. Claus Graf Schenk von Stauffenberg, was in the German Army, he was not a member of the Nazi party.

headline: Sarah Lucas and Jonathon Kass
text: WHAT works professionally can sometimes wreak havoc on one’s personal life. As a policy analyst and legislative aide to a city councilman in Washington, Jonathon Kass habitually studies issues from all angles.

headline: Correction: Running in Circles Over Carbon
text: A picture last Sunday with an article about cutting carbon dioxide emissions at coal-fired electric plants may have left an incorrect impression that a white plume shown rising from a cooling tower at one such plant was an example of greenhouse gases being discharged. The plume consisted of water vapor. (Carbon dioxide, which would be emitted from the plant’s smokestack shown at right, is colorless.)

headline: Chasing the Golden Dream
text: An article last Sunday about Debbie Capozzi of Bayport, who will compete in sailing in the Olympics this summer, misidentified the location of Old Dominion University, where she was on the sailing team. It is Norfolk, Va., not Richmond.

headline: Correction: Surf’s Up, Channel Surfers
text: Two television listings last Sunday in the special Emmys section gave outdated broadcast dates. After the section went to press, Fox announced that “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” would begin Sept. 8, not Aug. 11, and “Fringe” would begin Sept. 9, not Aug. 26.

headline: New Laws Try to Keep Swimmers Safe
text: WHEN the Township of West Caldwell, N.J., took on a major renovation at its Westville Avenue community pool five years ago, one news article was fresh in officials’ minds.

headline: School Buys 42 Pianos, Steinways, That Is
text: IN its bid to become an all-Steinway school, the Conservatory of Music at Purchase College has bought a staggering number of grand pianos made by the esteemed 155-year-old manufacturer. The purchase of 42 pianos  20 of them seven-foot-long Model B grand pianos  was “one of the largest acquisitions of Model Bs in Steinway’s history for student practice rooms,” said Sally Coveleskie, national director of institutional sales for Steinway & Sons.

headline: Letters | Double Your Pleasure
text: To the Editor:

headline: Good (for) Shabbat
text: The old ads for Levy’s rye bread (“You don’t have to be Jewish to love Levy’s”) apply to the traditional Friday night dinner as well: You don’t have to be Jewish to love a good Shabbat special. Observant Jews start their day of rest the evening before, and a typical takeout chicken meal has evolved to meet their needs. But others are likely to appreciate these Shabbat specials as a great way to end a hectic week (and a solid value too).

headline: Events on Long Island
text: COMEDY

headline: After 10 Years, Tract Wins Protective Status
text: THE decade-long efforts of a homeowners’ group, town officials in Cortlandt and a developer have finally resulted in the preservation of one of the last large unprotected tracts of open space in the county.

headline: Person-to-Person Loans
text: HOMEOWNERS who are having trouble borrowing against their house are starting to look to an interesting new source for cash: strangers.

headline: Glass Ceiling, Meet Sisterhood
text: THE women are gathered for a celebratory dinner. The wine flows freely, as does the talk. Of the fickleness of men, the pleasures of sex, the price of achievement. Fashion is touched upon briefly  one woman boasts dreamily of a particularly extravagant gown made of eight layers of silk  but, oddly enough, the subject of shoes never once arises.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions last Sunday about the United States gymnastics championships misstated the age, in some copies, of a top competitor, Nastia Liukin. She is 18, not 19.

headline: Homeowners Fight Back as Market Cools Off
text: JOSEPH ELLIOTT has been the tax assessor for Ocean City since 2003. In his five-year tenure, he has already overseen the reassessments of all 18,934 properties in this shore community  twice. And going a third round in the not too distant future is a distinct possibility.

headline: Cheryl Liebman, Keith Guliner
text: Cheryl Jan Liebman and Keith Adam Guliner were married Saturday evening at the summer home of the bride’s parents in East Hampton, N.Y. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated.

headline: Angela Campbell, Ethan Powell
text: Angela Brucia Campbell, the daughter of Margaret A. Brucia and James E. Campbell Jr. of Huntington, N.Y., was married on Saturday afternoon to Ethan Andrew Powell, the son of Andrea M. Powell and Wayne M. Powell of Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. David Robb performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Universalist Church in New York, where he is an assistant minister.

headline: In the E-Mail Relay, Not Every Handoff Is Smooth
text: FOR centuries, letter writers have wondered whether their missives safely reach the hands of their intended recipients. “I know not whether this will ever come to your hands or miscarry,” opened a typical one in 1625, from Roger White in the Netherlands, who was writing to friends at Plymouth colony.

headline: An Eccentric but Loving Man Had a Side No One Knew
text: PEOPLE often referred to my father as “a character.” For one thing, he had two first names. When my parents went to court to shorten our last name from Glovinski to Glovin, he told the judge, “I’d like to also change my first name from Max to Fred.”

headline: When Gas Prices Lead to Roads Less Traveled
text: What price would gasoline have to reach before it caused you to make a big change? Some people have already crossed that barrier. According to a survey by the NPD Group, a research firm, rising fuel prices have caused a small percentage of drivers to buy a more efficient vehicle or to move closer to their work.

headline: Teenage Agenda
text: The mind of a teenage boy is not an easy place to inhabit. Philip Roth examined the exhausting mental  not to mention physical  work of existing in a perpetual state of heat; J. D. Salinger described the panicked resistance to entering the adult world of “phonies; and, more recently, J. K. Rowling explored the frightening black magic of a changing body. The latest bulletin arrives from a 25-year-old Welsh writer, Joe Dunthorne, whose precocious talents and cheerful fondness for the teenage male are showcased in “Submarine,” his first novel.

headline: Randolph Remains Seemingly Unfazed by Talk of Firing
text: Willie Randolph hardly knew him when he added Jerry Manuel to his coaching staff in 2004, before his first season as manager. If Randolph were to be fired, though, Manuel would be asked to take over. Manuel would love to manage in the major leagues again, but this is not how he wants to get that chance.

headline: Bush Shows Optimism on Iraq Deal
text: PARIS  President Bush expressed confidence on Saturday that the United States and Iraq would agree on a new security arrangement this year, even though his strongest ally in Iraq, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, declared the negotiations at an impasse the previous day.

headline: Think the Gender War Is Over? Think Again

headline: Turbans Make Targets, Some Sikhs Find

headline: Free and Flush, Russians Eager to Roam Abroad
text: ANTALYA, Turkey  Yelena Kasyanova booked her trip at a local travel agency in about as much time it takes to drop by the market for a few groceries. She was soon lounging here by the Mediterranean, a working-class anybody from an anyplace deep in Russia, a child of the Soviet era who still remembers the humiliating strictures that once made it difficult to obtain a passport, let alone a plane ticket.

headline: Maligned Buses, Beloved Trees, Perilous Crossings

headline: Elizabeth Willett, Lee Falls

Jackson Willett III of Ruxton, Md., was married in Baltimore on Saturday evening to Henry Lee Falls III, the son of Betty C. Falls and Mr. Falls Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Sandra L. Lawrence, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer, where she is associate rector.

headline: Welcoming a Car You Can Park on a Dime
text: NESTLED between an enormous Mitsubishi and a sprawling Jeep Liberty, the tiny red Smart car sits like a nub of jam between two slabs of cake. A stump of an automobile, a squat, friendly two-seater less than nine feet long, it fits, fuel-efficiently, in the half-spaces outside its owners’ apartment building on West 81st Street near Columbus Avenue.

headline: Tokyo: Kanehara
text: It takes no effort to find good food in Tokyo. From the corner noodle shop and the humble 7-Eleven to deluxe sushi counters and Michelin-starred bistros, Japan’s capital offers great cuisine.

headline: Musician, Sim. Albums, Não.
text: A NUMBER of notable concerts of Brazilian music around the world this year, including one by João Gilberto next Sunday at Carnegie Hall as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, are being advertised with the line “50 Years of Bossa Nova.” Mr. Gilberto is considered by many to have defined the musical form, which was embraced internationally and has never really gone away in Brazil. Yet Mr. Gilberto’s first three albums, some of the best music of the 20th century, have largely been unavailable.

headline: Approve This Deal, or Else
text: BOWING to shareholder pressure, directors at Washington Mutual, the nation’s largest savings and loan, stripped Kerry K. Killinger, chairman and chief executive of the company, of his chairmanship on June 2. The board said it would appoint an independent chairman by July 1, and it instituted a majority voting standard for future director elections.

headline: Willis’s Decline: Was It Foreseeable?
text: Things have not turned out as planned in Detroit. In a major off-season trade, the Tigers landed the prized young stars Miguel Cabrera and Dontrelle Willis.

headline: Georgia Close, Benjamin Spencer
text: Dr. Georgia Molly Close, a daughter of Leslie Rose Close and the artist Chuck Close of Bridgehampton, N.Y., was married there on Saturday evening to Dr. Benjamin Alan Spencer, a son of Susan K. Spencer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Anthony R. Spencer of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa S. Greene, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Tradition, and a Number of Twists
text: SOMETIMES we diners are so busy searching for the next new thing that we forget why we like some of the old, taking for granted their familiar, comfy-slippers appeal.

headline: Falcon Cam
text: TELEVISION monitors rarely make New Yorkers pause, but in the marbled lobby of 55 Water Street, an insurance company worker named Katherine Stronk was transfixed recently by the image on the screen of four peregrine falcons in their nest on the building’s 14th floor.

headline: By Caring for Animals, Foundation Helps Their Human Owners

headline: Darwinists for Jesus
text: In 1981, Michael Dowd would have counted himself among the millions of conservative Christians who blame Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution and the idea of a godless, purposeless universe for the moral decline of society. That year, as a freshman at Evangel University in Springfield, Mo., Dowd felt a rush of indignant anger in biology class when the professor held up a textbook that taught evolution. As he stormed out of the classroom, Dowd could not have imagined that he would come to view evolution as a spiritually inspiring idea that religion must embrace.

headline: Brew Tour, From Kettle to Keg
text: “People want things fresh and local,” Joe Mendyka said, citing farmers markets and the Slow Food movement as examples, while pouring a short glass of pale ale for one of two visitors to the Thomas Hooker brewery’s Saturday afternoon tour. Thomas Hooker, a resurrection of the Trout Brook brand, moved to Bloomfield in 2007.

headline: The Love Song of R. Buckminster Fuller
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: Sloe Gin Is Back, but Hold the Fizz
text: IT hasn’t been easy, in America, to love sloe gin. Once a barman’s delicacy, both here and abroad, the gin-based liqueur  which takes its name and bittersweet flavor from the infusion of sloe berries, the purplish fruit of a wild shrub native to England  suffered a long, painful decline in the United States, when the import market dried up. American distillers filled the gap with mass-produced imitations that, according to the author and bartender Toby Cecchini, evoke grenadine spiked with grain alcohol.

headline: Kathy Griffin Just Can’t Shut Up
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Field of Facial Hair Helps a Place in Baseball History
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.  Have you heard the one about Albert Einstein, Charles Bronson and John Holmes walking into a bar? It sounds like the beginning of a bad joke, but not to some of the workers at the Elysian Cafe on Washington Street. On Tuesday, the cafe will conduct a charity mustache competition with categories like scholarly (Einstein), vigilante (Bronson) and adult film star (Holmes).

headline: Lakers’ Struggles in the Finals Put the Focus on Bryant’s Leadership
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  The Los Angeles Lakers may be down to their final game, and so naturally the conversation has swerved back to where it began, to Kobe Bryant.

headline: Alexandra Melby, Andrew Farnum
text: Alexandra Tripp Melby and Andrew Lawrence Farnum were married in Washington on Saturday. The Rev. Scott A. Benhase performed the ceremony at St. Alban’s Episcopal Church, where he is the rector.

headline: That Pesky Plant Returns in a Vibrant ‘Little Shop’
text: Audrey doesn’t want much from life. Poor, dear, blond, bosomy Audrey, with her nasal New York accent and her perpetual black eye courtesy of her sadistic boyfriend, just wants a little tract house like everybody else’s in an ordinary development.

headline: Living Reminders of Africa’s Colonial Past in Namibia
text: IT was getting toward evening in Swakopmund, on the desert coast of Namibia, and at Kiki’s Pub just off Kaiser-Wilhelm-Strasse, the Pilsener was starting to flow. Swiveling on a stool with a stein of Hansa Draft in his fist, a stout fellow in safari shorts and with gray mutton-chop whiskers was chatting emphatically in German with the young bartender. Waitresses bearing the day’s catch moved through the room, its walls decorated with colonial-era German maps of Africa and sepia-tinted photos of Schutztruppe (German protection force) soldiers riding camels through the bush.

headline: 2008 Tony Award Winners
text: A complete list of winners of 2008 Tony Awards (denoted with a *), with links to the original New York Times reviews. The list will be updated during the evening as the awards are announced.

headline: Major Barbara
text: In 1980, Barbara Walters was about to report that Ronald Reagan had selected George H. W. Bush as his running mate when another reporter at another network beat her to it. Walters says she “nearly went crazy” after losing “the scoop of the whole convention.” Her colleague George Will simply looked at her “with disdain” and declared, “It’s only television, Barbara.”

headline: The C.I.A. and Contractors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Silence Is Golden. Or Not.
text: I am a physician. A 30-year-old woman, a student at a local school, came for an initial visit. Her condition was unremarkable. A few weeks later the administrator of her school, a longstanding patient, mentioned how impressive it is that this woman continues to study despite having terminal cancer. The school even held a fund-raiser to help with her medical bills. I said nothing, but must I let the school know that she does not have cancer? May I confront her about this?  NAME WITHHELD

headline: Fast Finish and Controversy at Women’s Championship
text: The manner in which the United States women’s champion was crowned last month raises questions about the process.

headline: Want to See All of France? Rail Europe’s New Pass Helps
text: Paris not enough for you? Want to eat strudel in Strasbourg, sip wine in Bordeaux or sunbathe on the Riviera, but you’re feeling hemmed in by a tight budget? Now there’s a way to visit all of France without breaking the bank. Anywhere Anytime France, Rail Europe’s first prepaid electronic ticketing system, is for Francophiles on a budget who would like to visit more than two French cities by train. After an initial purchase of $199, travelers can buy an unlimited number of $50 train tickets. All accommodations are in first class. To sign up, visit raileurope.com to set up an account and purchase tickets, which can be printed out later at ticket offices or self-service kiosks in French train stations. There are a few caveats: to get the $50 rate, travelers must purchase all their trips at the same time (subsequent trips will cost $70), and all travel must be completed within 30 days.

headline: House Won’t Sell? Turn It Into a B&B
text: Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: When Old Money Marries New Media
text: MELISSA C. MORRIS was weighing her words carefully. The society wife, whose two-and-half-year-old blog about her rarefied life has garnered a devoted and growing readership, wanted to be sure nothing she said could be taken the wrong way. Over espresso at a restaurant near her Manhattan apartment, she said that, on the Internet and in life, “I focus on the positive. I like to keep things lighthearted.”

headline: Malthus Redux: Is Doomsday Upon Us, Again?
text: During the last American food-and-gas-price crisis, in the 1970s, one of my colleagues on the Berkeley student newspaper told me that he and his semi-communal housemates had taken a vote. They’d calculated they could afford meat or coffee. They chose coffee.

text: It certainly took its time. But the Federal Trade Commission’s decision to open a formal antitrust investigation of Intel is very welcome.

headline: A Sportscaster Revealed a Dictator’s Human Side

headline: Old Farming Habits Leave Uzbekistan a Legacy of Salt
text: KHUJAYLI, Uzbekistan  Salt crunches underfoot like frosty soil on this bare stretch of land in western Uzbekistan.

headline: Correction: Public Theater’s Dreamer in Chief
text: An article last Sunday about Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, misstated the position that his colleague Mara Manus held while at the Ford Foundation. She was a program officer for economic development, not a fund-raiser.

headline: They’re Drawn Back, Once Again, by Stickball
text: Yiggy showed up early, carrying the mop and broom handles he keeps in his closet back home. Barry Heyman, 63, arrived soon afterward, bearing a large black and white photograph of the eighth-grade class of 1958. David Sternthal, 63, the blurry one in the photo because he jerked when the boy next to him pinched him in the behind, brought his video camera.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: WHILE THEY SLEPT: An Inquiry Into the Murder of a Family, by Kathryn Harrison. (Random House, $25.) Harrison’s account brings moral clarity to the dark fate of the family of Jody Gilley, who was 16 when she survived a rampage by her brother in 1984.

headline: Mugabe Vows to Go to War Before Ceding Post
text: JOHANNESBURG  The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, sounding ever more pugnacious, said Saturday that he was prepared to go to war if he lost a runoff election to the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai on June 27.

headline: Shuttle Returns Safely After a 14-Day Mission
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Discovery rolled to a stop here on Saturday morning, bringing a 14-day mission to the International Space Station to a close.

headline: A Father to One Thousand Hits
text: I had made the drive so many times that I wasn’t even conscious of it anymore. Philadelphia to Teaneck, N.J., became a “Star Trek” teleporter from Center City to 619 Cadmus Court. All I knew was I ended up home.

headline: The Taste of Flowers
text: MY favorite French bakery, Madeleine Patisserie, is a quiet oasis on West 23rd Street near Seventh Avenue. Stopping in for Earl Grey tea with soy milk and the best raspberry Parisian macaroons in or out of Paris, I sit by the window, and watch the comings and goings on the street.

headline: Air India Has a Sale, Weather Permitting
text: In this age of ever-rising airfares, here’s a last-minute deal that stands out (even if it does mean dodging monsoons): Air India’s One Price India sale. The sale, which ends Friday, is offering round-trip tickets from Kennedy or Newark airports in the New York area to Chhatrapati Shivaji Airport in Mumbai, and to over 40 other destinations in India served by the carrier, set at $549 (for departures Aug. 19 to Sept. 18); $599 (for departures Aug. 1 to 18 and Sept. 19 to Oct. 31); and $704 (for departures July 14 to 31). To get this rate, travelers must leave New York from Sunday through Thursday and return Monday through Friday (weekend departures are available for an additional $50). Taxes and fees are not included. Passengers must also travel during monsoon season (roughly June through September), unless they are flying in October (www.airindia.com).

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Rutgers Helps Revive Ramapo (the Tomato, That Is)

headline: Jennifer Caruso, Oscar Suarez

Suarez of Haverhill, Mass. The Rev. Herbert T. Nichols performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary, Our Lady of the Isle, on the Massachusetts island of Nantucket.

headline: Chaser of Beer, Rock or Bebop With Your Bach?
text: YOU might not expect to find a polished young ensemble like the Parker String Quartet playing music by Beethoven, Bartok and Ligeti  or collaborating with ensembles like Las Rubias del Norte, which specializes in Latin American folk music  in the no-frills back room of a Brooklyn bar. But the group spent this season as the resident quartet at Barbès, a Park Slope bar that regularly presents classical performers in a schedule otherwise devoted to jazz, pop and world music.

headline: Paperback Row
text: DIVISADERO, by Michael Ondaatje. (Vintage International, $13.95.) This novel by the author of “The English Patient” braids together three stories full of parallels and resonances. On a Northern California farm, two girls grow up with their father and an adopted farmhand whose love for one of the sisters leads to an act of violence with lasting consequences. She becomes a literary historian obsessed by a French poet who vanished mysteriously. And she moves to the French countryside, where she falls in love with a guitar-playing Gypsy who turns out to be the poet’s more-or-less adopted son. Our reviewer, Erica Wagner, found the book initially hard to follow, but concluded, “Give in to Ondaatje and his language will seduce you.”

headline: Fuel Thoughts
text: Between Lowell and Lawrence, Mass., last Tuesday mid-afternoon, the temperature reached 102 degrees. By the time I got to Boothbay Harbor, Me., the thermometer had dropped 40 degrees. To my surprise, the price of fuel had dropped too. In my experience, gas is always more expensive where you’re going than where you’re coming from, unless you’re going to Indiana. At stations along the secondary roads in New York State, diesel fuel, which is what my pickup takes, was over $5 a gallon. In Boothbay Harbor, it was $4.79, and the lobster rolls were cheaper too.

headline: Lorrie Marlow and Robert Hooks
text: Lorrie Gay Marlow and Robert Hooks are to be married on Sunday. Charles James, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at Benvenuto Caterestaurant in Boynton Beach, Fla.

headline: 419 Acres, 2 Plans, 1 Irate Builder
text: AFTER having their hopes for a flashy entertainment complex dashed last year, residents of the rural town of Preston have since been pondering various alternatives for the sprawling grounds of the abandoned Norwich State Hospital.

headline: The Man Who Wasn’t There
text: THIS time in June every year I have only to walk by a drugstore display window filled with Father’s Day cards or to open the newspaper where every advertisement seems to feature a necktie or a power tool that is “Perfect for Dad!” and my youth sweeps over me. Even though I’m halfway through life, a little part of me still dreads Father’s Day  the holiday when, it seemed back then, everyone was celebrating exactly what I didn’t have.

headline: McCain Cuts Fund-Raiser
text: Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign canceled a fund-raiser at the home of an 86-year-old oilman, Clayton Williams, after the campaign faced questions about comments Mr. Williams made in the 1990 race for Texas governor.

headline: Good Fences Make Happy Neighbors
text: FOR at least four years, Barbara Grebin and fellow residents of Bay Ridge Towers, a pair of 30-story co-op buildings at the northern tip of that Brooklyn neighborhood, have been fighting to seal off access to the train tracks that run under the complex’s parking deck and alongside its foundations.

text: OSAKA, Japan  The global economy faces a one-two punch from slowing growth and soaring fuel and food prices, finance ministers from the world’s richest nations warned Saturday, though they stopped short of offering concrete solutions.

headline: An Attention-Getter, Like That or Not
text: BEING skeptical of fame achieved through text messaging, I’d happily throttle those downy warblers on “American Idol." Likewise, I can’t see why anyone would want a shot with MTV’s Tila Tequila, let alone a shot at her love.

headline: Why This Court Keeps Rebuking This President
text: “The most important thing we do is not doing,” Justice Louis D. Brandeis once said of the Supreme Court’s abiding humility, its overwhelming preference to allow the people, through their elected representatives, to govern themselves.

headline: Bush Says Iran Spurns New Offer on Uranium

headline: Letters: The Ethicist
text: On the issue of play groups and vaccines, I respectfully disagree with the conclusions of Mr. Cohen (June 1). As the mother of an immunized child who contracted whooping cough from an unimmunized playmate, I can vouch for the devastating and long-lasting effects of these scourge diseases. My sturdy 7-year-old’s horrifying case was considered “mild,” but if an infant or young toddler caught such a disease from an older child in the play group, the results could be tragic.

headline: Rising Out of the Rust
text: NOT so long ago, the Spichern Höfe, on the gritty edge of Cologne’s Belgian Quarter, consisted of several worn-down apartment houses, an appliance warehouse and an abandoned metal depot. One of the apartments had small trees growing in the hallway.

headline: Nuclear Ring Reportedly Had Advanced Design
text: WASHINGTON  American and international investigators say that they have found the electronic blueprints for an advanced nuclear weapon on computers that belonged to the nuclear smuggling network run by Abdul Qadeer Khan, the rogue Pakistani nuclear scientist, but that they have not been able to determine whether they were sold to Iran or the smuggling ring’s other customers.

headline: Iraqi Troops Mass for Assault in South

headline: Principal Is Suspended Over False Statements
text: A PARENT’S decision to take birthday treats to his daughter’s classroom earlier last month led to the suspension of a Greenwich principal who, officials said, misled administrators about the school’s written policy on classroom celebrations.

headline: Minor Mischief
text: In my childhood, around 1960, we boys loved to whisper stories about all the gory ride disasters taking place at the local amusement park that were being kept out of the papers. “They’re being hushed up,” we told each other confidently.

headline: Chingiz Aitmatov, Who Wrote of Life in U.S.S.R., Is Dead at 79
text: Chingiz Aitmatov, a Communist writer whose novels and plays before the collapse of the Soviet Union gave a voice to the people of the remote Soviet republic of Kyrgyz, and who later became a diplomat and a friend and adviser to the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, died on Tuesday in Nuremberg, Germany. He was 79 and lived in Bishkek, the capital of what is now Kyrgyzstan.

headline: For the Homebound Elderly, Fewer Knocks on the Door
text: SIX days a week, Rafael Cordero, an employee of two senior citizen centers in Washington Heights, delivers hot meals to elderly people who lack the strength, stamina or, for one reason or another, ability to leave their homes.

headline: Mussina Puts Himself on Top Again
text: HOUSTON  The box of Rawlings baseballs was wrapped like a present in a department store, with thick bands of white tape forming a cross on the top and the bottom. It was marked with the score of the game that had just taken place  Yankees 8, Astros 4  with Mike Mussina’s pitching line and this special notation: #260.

headline: Sydney Rose, Brett Cicchillo

headline: The Beauty Hunters
text: YOU occasionally spot one of them on the street: the long, lanky limbs, the sky-high cheekbones and a drift of ethereal hair. Almost everyone else seems to be watching her, too, admiring her towering frame, her stilettos and her incandescent skin. She is that strange, magnificent creature, the model.

headline: 1935: Ramos Gin Fizz
text: Nowadays, when a politician wants to make a point to the “folks,” he goes to the diner to meet and greet and empathize while scarfing a grilled cheese. For all of its hokeyness, it’s a safe strategy because, according to health experts, fried foods are what most Americans subsist on, and for some irrational reason, people trust a politician who appears to eat the same foods they do.

headline: With Gasoline Prices Up, Drivers Push Closer to the End of the Tank

headline: When the Walls Came Tumbling Down
text: A YEAR before his death, my dad was forced to come out to me. I thought he was in Paris for a vacation. Instead, he was there for treatment with AZT, which in 1986 was experimental and not yet approved in the United States for people infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Hobbled Woods Has a Spring in His Step
text: SAN DIEGO  It was the third round of the United States Open, and Tiger Woods was five strokes behind with six holes to play. Turns out he had them right where he wanted them. The fog was gone from Torrey Pines Golf Course, the sun was sinking in the West, and it was prime time in the East  just the time for Woods to embark on one of his most astonishing runs to the finish line.

headline: Hope Garner, Daniel Stephens

headline: The Other Hot Spot
text: Venture a dozen blocks southeast of the meatpacking district, which has been hyped as the hot dining scene for several years, and you’ll come to a refreshing stretch of restaurants along Macdougal Street, which runs north from Avenue of the Americas in SoHo to West Eighth Street in Greenwich Village.

Warren and Dr. Roger N. Warren of Upper Saddle River, N.J. Rabbi David J. Gelfand officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers, an event space in New York.

headline: ‘One Man’s America’
text: Among the shortcomings of the current administration of the universe is the fact that Alistair Cooke is gone. The British-born journalist, who died in 2004 at age ninety-five, was one of the scarce bits of evidence that there really is an Intelligent Designer of the universe. Cooke lived in this country for sixty-seven years, producing a body of work of unrivaled perceptiveness, affectionateness, and elegance. One of his books, published in 1952, was titled One Man's America. The title of the book you are holding is one man's homage to Cooke.

headline: A Slow Market Can Have Its Perks
text: A SLOW real estate market on the East End has increased the supply of vacation rentals, as more sellers take their homes off the market and offer them for rent instead.

headline: Beijing: Ritz-Carlton Beijing
text: THE BASICS

headline: A Block’s Beautification, Lost to More Makeovers
text: THE architect Frederick Sterner’s first “block beautiful,” created in 1910 on 19th Street from Irving Place to Third Avenue, became famous because of how he reclaimed an old row of dingy brownstones: using tinted stucco, tile roofs and iron balconies.

headline: East Village Protesters Denounce All Things Gentrified. It’s a Tradition.
text: Among the seasonal developments that signal the approach of summer in New York City are the ascent of lifeguards into wooden chairs on Rockaway Beach, the appearance of seersucker suits in Madison Avenue store windows and the formation of long waiting lines for tickets to Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Father Knows Pets
text: When my kids started clamoring for a pet, I was strategically indifferent. I grew up in Miami, in a house with more pets than kids, and while I believed that there was an emotional benefit to the dogs, the cats, the birds, the fish and the mice, I wasn’t going to admit it, because then I’d have to think through the practicalities: health, space, food, waste. My wife, who also grew up in Miami, also with pets, readily admitted the benefits and started thinking through the practicalities. She concluded that a cat was problematic. She told the kids. They cried. They promised that they’d do all the cat-related jobs. “Enough,” I said. They fell silent, which meant only that I heard the noise of the clock ticking. The countdown to cat had begun.

headline: As Mickelson’s Ball Kept Slipping, So Did His Chances
text: SAN DIEGO  With the 108th United States Open here in his hometown, Phil Mickelson was a tournament favorite and unofficial host. And although he had played inconsistently during the first two rounds, he was not out of contention.

headline: Market Slumps, but Not Tax Bills
text: TWO years into a rocky real estate market with falling prices, the subprime crisis and a surge in foreclosures, many Long Island homeowners are looking for consolation. They expect a drop in the assessed values of their homes, resulting in smaller property tax bills.

headline: A Once-Successful Show Goes Looking for Its Spark
text: Notice the scales on the dragons that frame the set at the Bay Street Theater. They’re really overlapping CDs that glitter in the lights. They’re also fitting emblems for the world of artifice and illusion that Charles Busch has concocted in “Shanghai Moon,” a comedy about hidden pasts, suppressed emotions and concealed ethnic identities.

headline: Foreclosures and the Election
text: There is much still uncertain about the future course of the home mortgage debacle, but one thing is now clear: Congress and President Bush have done so little for so long that they will never manage an effective response. Like so many other problems, the foreclosure crisis will be dumped on the next president and the next Congress.

headline: Atlantic City Oddity: A Hotel, but No Casino
text: The Water Club, a Signature Hotel by Borgata, which is opening this month in Atlantic City, deserves its name. The club, a 43-story hotel, has five pools (three indoor, two outdoor) and ocean or bay views from all 800 rooms, each with big glass-enclosed showers with waterfall showerheads. The Water Club, the first luxury hotel in Atlantic City that doesn’t have a casino, also features a two-story, 36,000-square-foot spa called Immersion (get it?) and a lobby where water flows across a curved wall, along with a reflecting pool. For those who do not want to swim or soak, they can shop (the Shoppes at the Water Club include La Perla, which sells lingerie, and Hearts on Fire, which sells diamonds), or attend meetings (there is 18,000 square feet of meeting space). Nightly rates start at $299 (www.thewaterclubatborgata.com).

headline: From the Farm | How to Skip Supermarkets
text: With summer approaching in earnest, farmers’ markets have been starting up for the season in towns throughout the state — a boon for shoppers stocking up on locally produced fruits and vegetables, cheeses and even surprises like seafood from the Jersey Shore.

text: WASHINGTON — This year’s campaign for president has provided an extended test of attitudes toward race and gender, two powerful and volatile forces in politics. Now a third is about to join that list: age.

headline: Angle of Repose
text: Seen in profile, perched on a hillside overlooking the ocean in Southern California, this house looks almost birdlike, with outstretched wings and a long tail. The wings turn out to be the upswept roof of the main living areas, and the tail is the roof of a long passage that leads from the front door. Though the roof lines are entirely functional, for the house’s architect, Tom Kundig, the avian analogy is an apt one. Kundig, a partner in the Seattle firm Olson Sundberg Kundig Allen, says that he wanted the house to be “a small building that landed lightly on the landscape,” much like the raptors he had seen hovering over the hills.

headline: A League of Their Own
text: No more tragic or romantic institution emerged from the Jim Crow era of American life than the Negro League. African-Americans were banished from the majors in 1884, and a few seasons later from the minors as well, under a “gentleman’s agreement” between white owners and players. None would return until Jackie Robinson signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers some 60 years later.

headline: Letters: Marriage Partners
text: I agree with Kenji Yoshino’s view (June 1) that proponents of same-sex marriage in California will need to convince straights that they will suffer losses personally in order to get them to vote against the state’s anti-same-sex marriage initiative come November.

headline: Paying Fees and Charges in Addition to Rent
text: Q A friend of mine is subletting a co-op apartment. Besides paying her monthly rent, she is responsible for the sublet fee and the maintenance charge. Is this really her responsibility or the owner’s?

headline: That Buzz in Your Ear May Be Green Noise
text: DESPITE the expense and the occasional back strain, Mary Burnham, a public relations consultant in San Francisco, felt good about the decision she made a few years ago to buy milk  organic, of course  only in heavy, reusable glass bottles. For the sake of the environment, she dutifully lugged them back and forth from the grocery store every week. Cutting out disposable paper cartons, she reasoned, meant saving trees and reducing waste.

headline: As Talks Stall to Save the OTB, Horseplayers Worry About Getting Shut Out
text: There were the usual utterances of triumph and defeat, elation and heartbreak, and there was also this: worry. With time slipping away before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s threatened closing of the city’s Off-Track Betting Corporation, and no agreement between the city and state in sight, the thrill of uncertainty that usually accompanies horse wagering was buffeted by the sobering question of whether Sunday will be the last day of simulcast racing at the parlors.

headline: When Mom and Dad Share It All
text: On her first day back to work after a four-month maternity leave, Amy Vachon woke at dawn to nurse her daughter, Maia. Then she fixed herself a healthful breakfast, pumped a bottle of breast milk for the baby to drink later in the day, kissed the little girl goodbye and headed for the door.

headline: Swapping Passports in Pursuit of Olympic Medals
text: Marching into Beijing Stadium under the American flag this August will be a kayaker from Poland, table tennis players from China, a triathlete from New Zealand, a world-champion distance runner from Kenya and a gold-medal-winning equestrian from Australia.

headline: In ’74 Thesis, the Seeds of McCain’s War Views
text: About a year after his release from a North Vietnamese prison camp, Cmdr. John S. McCain III sat down to address one of the most vexing questions confronting his fellow prisoners: Why did some choose to collaborate with the North Vietnamese?

headline: A Town Right Out of Central Casting
text: MADISON, N.J., is so quaint and charming that people often say the downtown could pass for a movie set  which probably explains why it has done duty as a setting in films like “The World According to Garp” and “The Family Stone,” and in episodes of “The Sopranos.”

headline: An Entertainer Enjoys the Show as Woods Passes Him
text: SAN DIEGO  Playing one group behind Tiger Woods, Rocco Mediate had a front seat for the theater that was Woods’s charge during Saturday’s third round of the United States Open. Mediate, who at one juncture led the Open by several strokes, was slumping Saturday as Woods was surging, but he still marveled at the spectacle of Woods’s back-nine 33, which included two improbable eagles.

headline: Tuscan Ambience, Near the Shore
text: EVEN before you arrive at the new high-end Italian restaurant called Undici, you may feel a twinge of envy for the 7,200 residents of its hometown. As dusk falls on a warm evening, Rumson is bliss: a borough of broad lawns, shade-tree canopies, gabled mansions, graceful parks and gentle slopes that look down to the town’s two rivers, the Navesink and the Shrewsbury. A few minutes’ drive away are the beaches of Sea Bright and Sandy Hook.

headline: Bistro Joins Restaurant Family
text: WITH the arrival of warmer weather, Washington Street between River and North Main in South Norwalk is lively with restaurant traffic. Several places have tables on the sidewalk, and doors are open onto the street. Even on the Thursday evening when I visited, the area had something of the feel of a vacation destination.

headline: Hugo Chávez, New and Improved
text: It turns out that Hugo Chávez is an adaptable man. The Venezuelan president, who has championed  and almost certainly helped arm  Colombia’s FARC rebels, called last week for the rebels to lay down their weapons and unconditionally surrender their hostages.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Red Summer’
text: A review on June 1 about “Red Summer: The Danger, Madness, and Exaltation of Salmon Fishing in a Remote Alaskan Village,” by Bill Carter, misstated the location of Egegik, the village of the title. It is in southwestern Alaska, not southeastern.

headline: Checking Baggage? Not at These Prices
text: FIRST came the liquids and gels crackdown, sending road warriors to their corner drugstores in search of that ever-elusive three-ounce bottle of contact-lens solution. Then came tighter weight restrictions for checked baggage, causing logjams at airport check-in desks as vacationers promptly unzipped their suitcases, transferring shoes and other heavy items into carry-ons in an effort to lighten their checked luggage.

headline: Gay Couples Find Marriage Is a Mixed Bag
text: BOSTON  Four years after Massachusetts became the first state to allow gay couples to marry, there have been blissful unions, painful divorces and everything in between.

headline: Letters: Banksable
text: While not always a fan of Ms. Banks, I have a newfound respect for her business acumen after reading Lynn Hirschberg’s profile of her (June 1). She has created a Tyra Market that is both profitable and marketable.

headline: Messages of Exhortation, Counsel and Congratulation
text: President Bush, addressing students at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., last month, said a bit wistfully that it would be the last commencement address of his presidency. Mr. Bush has seemed to enjoy the campus speeches each spring, often bantering with cadets at military academies. But he has also used them to speak patriotically about his goals in Iraq.

headline: When Dads Were Models for All of Us
text: Long ago, I grew up with three dads: my own and two neighbors who had enough left over after dealing with their own kids to feel like dads to us as well. They lived in split-level houses next to one another that they bought around 1953 for about $30,000 at 39, 35 and 31 Tanners Road in Great Neck. Back then, they were too busy with the grand and quotidian duties of fatherhood to meditate too much about it. So, on Father’s Day 2008, a respectful salute to fatherhood before play dates, before anything 24/7, or 2.0.

headline: Upon This Rock, a Church of Cracks
text: THE hole in the back of St. Brigid’s Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, big enough to walk through, is nailed over with blue plywood now. The tall arched window frames along the side, where construction workers smashed the old painted-glass windows on a day almost two years ago when it seemed the whole building would be razed, are covered in plexiglass.

headline: Satisfying a Suburban Mind-Set
text: SEVEN years ago, Casey J. Pedrick arrived in New York to join her future husband, Steven Jackson. At that point, permanently relocating to the city was not an option. “I am a suburban girl,” she declared.

headline: The Watch List
text: On Saturday night, Braves fans had their first look at the team’s top pitching prospect, Charlie Morton, below, who was called up to fill in for the injured starter Tom Glavine. The 24-year-old Morton struggled earlier in his minor league career, but he improved at the end of last season and continued his solid play in the Arizona Fall League, going 4-1 with a 2.57 earned run average. This season, he has done better, going 4-2 with a 2.05 E.R.A. for Class AAA Richmond. He earned the win in his debut, a 9-4 victory against the Angels. He allowed three runs in six innings, striking out four.

headline: Out of This World, Catchy or Good for Driving
text: After a decade-long hiatus, Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth has gotten back together with two of her Free Kitten band mates, Julie Cafritz and Yoshimi P-We. The product of their reunion is “Inherit” (Ecstatic Peace), a blurry, rowdy guitar fest that Ms. Gordon says was influenced by the freak folk movement in western Massachusetts. “We made this album because we were bored,” she said, “and also because Julie has two kids and needed to get out of the house.” “Inherit” was released last month, and though the band’s in no rush to go on a formal tour, Ms. Gordon did allude to “secret shows.” In addition to recording, Ms. Gordon, 55, has been collaborating on “Sensational Fix,” a traveling exhibition of works by visual artists, filmmakers and others who have worked with Sonic Youth that opens on Tuesday in St. Nazaire, in western France. While in New York City this spring to attend an exhibition at KS Art organized by Thurston Moore, her husband and Sonic Youth band mate, Ms. Gordon spoke by phone with Winter Miller about what she’s listening to now.

text: Montclair

headline: Figuring Marlene Dumas
text: MARLENE DUMAS’S STUDIO occupies an underheated, underfurnished ground-floor apartment on the southern side of Amsterdam. As she sat at her worktable one evening in late March, emptying a bottle of white wine and picking at a plate of almond pastries, she offered an image of contented Bohemianism. Beside her, a red vase held a bouquet of dead white tulips, and beyond an unusually tall window, dusk was gathering in a garden densely overgrown with weeds.

headline: Correction: Childhood Is the Mother of the Play
text: An article on May 25 about “Body Awareness” by Annie Baker overstated the connection between the central character of the play, Frank Bonitatibus, and the photographer Frank Cordelle. The character Frank Bonitatibus is a creation of Ms. Baker; he is not based on Mr. Cordelle’s life and career. (A cast member did consult Mr. Cordelle’s book “Bodies and Souls: The Century Project” for insight during rehearsal, and Ms. Baker mentioned him in an interview.)
