headline: Democrats’ Vote Drive in Louisiana Stirs Concern
text: A Democratic voter registration drive in largely black neighborhoods of Louisiana has swamped the state’s voter registrar offices, forcing them to hire new staff members and work 12-hour days to process thousands of applications.

headline: Anne C. Martindell, Late Bloomer, Lawmaker and Diplomat, Is Dead at 93
text: Anne C. Martindell, who entered politics in her 50s, found true love as ambassador to New Zealand in her 60s, earned a college degree in her 80s and published a memoir titled “Never Too Late” in her 90s, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J. She was 93.

headline: A Fruit Shake, Then Shaking to the Beat of Cumbia
text: IF you always put pineapple on your hamburgers, can identify lulo juice by color, consider vinegar to be a vital ingredient in salsa and can distinguish cumbia music from vallenato, you’re excused from a Colombian weekend in New York.

headline: Landlord’s Dream Confronts Rent-Stabilized Lives
text: When George Boyd arrived the other day at the East Village apartment building where he has lived since 1978, he found his neighbor Alistair Economakis, who at 37 is half his age, politely holding the door open. Mr. Boyd, a retired telephone worker, nodded and walked through, but there was no exchange of pleasantries, no neighborly chitchat.

headline: Working Toward College, a True Juggling Act
text: KEY WEST, Fla.  Some teenagers flip burgers as a summer job. Others mow lawns. Reid Fierheller-Conklin juggles fire by the water at sunset, competing for crowds with a tightrope-walking dog, a sword-swallower, acrobats and Catman (don’t ask).

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 75 Kentucky
text: Location: Lexington, Ky.

headline: If Ted Lyons Is in the Hall of Fame, What Does That Mean for Mike Mussina?
text: Mike Mussina now has 260 career victories. He has 148 losses. Consider that he tied Ted Lyons in victories on Saturday night, and Lyons is in the Hall of Fame. Lyons’s record is 260-230. So Mussina could lose his next 81 starts and still have a better record than Sunday Teddy.

headline: Judo: A Close Call in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS –- Even in this surreal city, with head-shaking scenes on virtually every corner, it’s hard to match the atmosphere at the wrestling and judo Olympic trials.

headline: The Week Ahead: June 15-21
text: Theater

headline: Bonnaroo: A Word About Access
text: People refer to Bonnaroo as a small town and, like every village, it has its hierarchy, in this case, one defined by wrist bands and badges. We do, in fact, need your stinkin’ badges. To have access at Bonnaroo means not having to endure the brutal bathroom lines, enjoying hospitality while others plop in dust, and in general, to want for not much. The press credentials I had helped me get up close at many stages, including right up on top of the My Morning Jacket show. But last night, the Pearl Jam stage locked up early and I was banished to a far hill, where Eddie Vedder,was a dot on the stage and a broadcast presence on the big video screens.

headline: Bonnaroo: Eddie Vedder Sings with Jack Johnson
text: Eddie Vedder knows a Jack Johnson song: “Constellations,” a romantic ballad about lying down under the stars. He came out to sing it with Mr. Johnson, who was playing the big What stage before Pearl Jam’s set there tonight. Mr. Johnson is ubiquitous at festivals this summer, and it’s easy to see why. His songs are catchy, relaxed and full of kindly sentiments. They vamp along like jam-band tunes, but also have pop choruses. Mr. Johnson has an amiable, Everyman voice — like a latter-day Steve Miller — that puts his tunes within just about anybody’s singalong capability. In addition, his entire touring operation seeks to make a minimal environmental impact.

headline: Bonnaroo: Calling for Change
text: If there are any Republicans performing at Bonnaroo, they’re keeping quiet about it. In the meantime, performers that sing about politics, like Pearl Jam and the multicultural Los Angeles groove band Ozomatli, are putting out election-year messages, and bands that generally don’t are subtly or unsubtly stumping for Barack Obama. During Pearl Jam’s exhilarating set, Eddie Vedder, Pearl Jam’s leader, did not mention Mr. Obama’s name, but made heartfelt speeches calling for change, and for an encore he sang “No More,” with the chorus “no more war.”

headline: Another Last-Minute Victory, as Spain Beats Sweden
text: In a tournament where last-minute goals are becoming the norm, Spain went to the limit to defeat Sweden, 2-1, in Innsbruck on Saturday. Why wait to the last gasp to win a game?

headline: Navigating Detroit
text: Barack Obama’s bid for the White House has stirred up excitement in Detroit, where residents have waited for the chance to elect a black president. Yet Detroiters also have been waiting nearly a year to see Mr. Obama, who has not appeared in the city since last July, when he received thunderous applause during an N.A.A.C.P. candidate forum despite being considered a long shot to become the Democratic nominee. He did not campaign in the state before the primary and his name did not even appear on Michigan’s ballot, after party leaders moved up the date in violation of Democratic National Committee rules.

headline: Red Carpet at the Tony Awards
text: Celebrities gathered outside Radio City Music Hall before the 2008 Tony Awards.

headline: The Early Word: Obama on Fatherhood
text: “An experiment with waffles or pancakes,” and then, “a lot of cleanup afterwards” — just another Father’s Day at the Obama home.

headline: Obama’s Father’s Day Remarks
text: Following are the Senator Barack Obama's remarks at the Apostolic Church of God in Chicago as provided by his campaign.

headline: Obama’s Down-Ballot Effect
text: With all the talk and worry about the potential “Obama effect” on races down the ticket, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee believes it has identified a very positive one – Senator Barack Obama runs strongly with independent voters.

headline: Paying Fees and Charges in Addition to Rent
text: A friend of mine is subletting a co-op apartment. Besides paying her monthly rent, she is responsible for the sublet fee and the maintenance charge. Is this really her responsibility or the owner’s?

headline: Staying in the Apartment for an Extra Month
text: I live in a rent-regulated apartment in Brooklyn, which I rent on a yearly basis. I plan to vacate my apartment one month past the expiration of the lease because I am moving out of state. My landlord tells me to sign a lease for a whole year and to sign a letter saying I am responsible for rent if he is unable to replace me with another tenant. What should I do?

headline: ‘I Don’t Think President Bush Really Studies Up’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Things couldn’t get any worse for the Lakers, huh? Did you see that game last night? The Lakers choked so badly, but it’s good news for Hillary Clinton. She will no longer be known as having the biggest collapse of the year.

headline: Erin & Will
text: Will Strouse fell in love with Erin Murtaugh the first moment he saw her.

headline: Bob Dylan in London: The Paintings
text: You always knew he could sing and write lyrics that are poetry. But (as Dylan buffs no doubt already know) Dylan is also an accomplished artist.

headline: Recalling Russert as Political Operative in New York
text: In his column, Adam Nagourney writes about the period in the early 1980s when Tim Russert worked as a counselor to newly elected Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, of New York.

headline: The Willie Chronicles, Part XVI
text: Willie Randolph wheeled his suitcase through the Mets’ clubhouse at 10:20 a.m., said, “Wake up, Johnny,” to a sleepy-looking John Maine lounging on a couch and proceeded to his office. It is still his office, by the way, with it looking more and more likely that Randolph will accompany the team on their flight Sunday night to California. Barring a complete and total disaster during Sunday’s doubleheader, of course, because in the Mets’ bizarre game-by-game, minute-by-minute world, their plans can change with little notice.

headline: Le Mans, les mains and Fernando speaks at Technocenter
text: I can sigh relief today. The lede of one of my stories about Le Mans came true: The top three finishers at Le Mans were Audis and Peugeots. Furthermore, my decision to go not to Le Mans but to the celebration of the 10th anniversary of the Renault Technocenter paid off. I didn’t have to write the story about Jacques Villeneuve winning the Triple Crown – as he finished only second in Le Mans – and I did manage to speak to Fernando Alonso. I have put up a recording of that interview, and I was particularly interested in what he said about why he attacked so hard – and blew it – at the Canadian Grand Prix. I liked that response – it reminded me of the kind of thing you might have heard from…Gilles Villeneuve. But you’ll have to listen to the end of my Alonso interview to hear it.

headline: For the Moment | Sneak Preview from Viktor & Rolf
text: Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren.

text: Why do people miss so many 3-foot putts and what can be done about it?

text: I just can’t help myself. I fully intended to let the “politics and the classroom” thing rest for a while, but in the course of reading the responses to my response to the responses to the first Colorado chair-on-conservative-thought column, I found myself, well, responding.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Barbados
text: Now it’s for real.

headline: The Souljah Legacy
text: This post has been updated.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Warriors Stick Around
text: The Friday and Saturday overload is over. Sunday is for what Aimee Mann just called the “Bonnaroo warriors,” in it to the end. Death Cab for Cutie and the Robert Plant-Alison Krauss collaboration are worth sticking around for, and so was Orchestra Baobab, a Senegalese band in love with Afro-Caribbean music Baobab formed in 1970, before Senegalese rock found a more nationalistic style with mbalax, Baobab’s rhythms have a Caribbean lilt–Cuban and Jamaican–while its vocals are African and its guitarist, Barthelemy Attisso, is quietly startling. His leads have some blues, some jazz, some surf-guitar reverb and tremolo and a supple touch that’s unmistakably African. No wonder group’s audience, which would barely have filled a club as the band started, multiplied across the field before the end of the set.

headline: Bonnaroo: Kanye Goes On Late. Really Late.
text: Somebody’s got beef. Waiting until 4:30 a.m. to start his set, originally scheduled for 2:45, did not endear Kanye West to his audience or to fellow musicians. Robert Randolph, the gospel slide guitarist, came dangerously close to cussing as he complained about Mr. West, and since he was in the middle of a fierce, bluesy, one-chord raveup, with T-Bone Burnett playing blues licks like snakebites, his putdown arrived with extra force. After his set, the crowd chanted “Kanye sucks!”

headline: Russert Warmly Remembered on ‘Meet the Press’
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Memorials Planned For Tim Russert
text: Over the weekend, NBC was preparing for funeral services and memorials to memorialize Tim Russert.

headline: The Empty Chair on ‘Meet the Press’
text: “The sudden death of Tim Russert has left the management of NBC News, for the moment at least, at a loss to contemplate how to replace him,” Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg report.

headline: CBS Considered Olbermann For ‘Evening News’ Job
text: CBS considered Keith Olbermann, the opinionated host of “Countdown” on MSNBC, as a potential replacement for Dan Rather on the “CBS Evening News” before selecting Katie Couric, according to an article in the next issue of The New Yorker magazine.

headline: Bonnaroo: Same Set, Different Sound
text: I had seen Robert Plant and Alison Krauss performing their duets with T-Bone Burnett leading their Raising Sand Revue band in New York, at WaMu Theater, the night before I left for Bonnaroo. It was a memorable concert: hazy with smoke and reverb, full of mystery and melancholy. And I was curious to see how such eerie, pristine music would survive daylight, a standing audience and the bleary day-four Bonnaroo crowd. It did, by turning everything inside out. The set list was virtually the same, the effect entirely different. The “Raising Sand” album was conceived and partly recorded in nearby Nashville, representing Mr. Plant’s discovery of, as he bluntly put it, America’s white songwriters. And behind the grief and solitude in many of the songs, it turned out, was a core of tenacity.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, June 15:

headline: Five Words to Communicate Brand
text: The Webby Awards, honoring excellence on the Internet, were announced last week. And after I recovered from not being nominated, I spent some time browsing the list of acceptance speeches, which adhered to an interesting format. The winners had to accept their awards using no more than five words. The most successful of these speeches are terrific examples of branding. For example, Stephen Colbert, the winner of the Webby person of the year award, simply accepted with “Me. Me. Me. Me. Me.”

headline: Day Three at the United States Open
text: Playing the final six holes in four under par — with two eagles, an accidental chip-in birdie and a bogey — Tiger Woods snatched the lead away from Lee Westwood.

headline: Wrestling: A Dream Fulfilled for Byers
text: LAS VEGAS — As Dremiel Byers walked through the tunnel here at theThomas & Mack Center for the final match that would decide his Olympicfate, one thought kept running through his head.

headline: Still Unable to Play, Church Visits the Mets
text: For four days Ryan Church had been asking the Mets if he could stop by the clubhouse, and for four days they had told him no. But on Sunday, with Church scheduled to begin exercising again the next day, they granted his request.

headline: Museum’s T. Rex Roars Back in New Stance
text: PITTSBURGH  Looking at the 40-foot-long Tyrannosaurus rex in its renovated exhibition space, Matthew C. Lamanna, an assistant curator, said: “It’s the superstar. There are other carnivorous dinosaurs even bigger, but this one had the best publicity agents.”

headline: Fiscal Poison Pill
text: A poison pill, in corporate jargon, is a financial arrangement designed to protect current management by crippling the company if someone else takes over.

headline: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Old Love, New Love, Ev’ry Love but True Love
text: Prostitutes make their money by stoking male desire and delusion, so it makes sense that a series titled “Secret Diary of a Call Girl” would don stilettos and a red corset and purr, “Yes, oh yes,” while surreptitiously glancing at the clock.

headline: Golf Can Extend Your Life, Study Says
text: Golf is good for your health and can extend your life by five years, according to a recently released Swedish medical study. And better golfers seem to live the longest. Data collected from 300,000 Swedish golfers showed that the death rate in golfers was significantly lower than it was for the rest of the population. The lowest death rates were reported among those with the lowest golf handicap. Researchers reasoned that because the game is good for you, playing it more often (typical behavior for better golfers) yields even more benefit.

headline: Purchase of Theme Song, a Staple of Canadian Culture, Upsets Hockey Fans
text: OTTAWA  Imagine if Fox bought up all the rights to “Take Me Out to the Ballgame” and decreed it would be heard only on its own broadcasts. Then you might get some sense of how Canadians feel after the beloved theme song for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation’s “Hockey Night in Canada” was purchased last week by the rival private broadcaster CTV.

text: To the Editor:

text: An obituary on Wednesday about John S. Zinsser Jr., a longtime editor of Reader’s Digest Condensed Books, misidentified the occupation of his son Stephen Zinsser. He is a theater and opera director, not a theater and opera stage manager.

headline: A Big Step Toward Beijing, Courtesy of a Well-Timed Pass
text: The diagramed deal was Board 8 from the final of the open trial in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., to pick the United States team for the first World Mind Sports Games in Beijing in October. The event ended June 6.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some editions on Thursday with coverage of the European Championship soccer tournament described the action incorrectly. Although Arda Turan of Turkey was shown heading the ball, that was not the play in which he scored the winning goal against Switzerland on Wednesday. As the article noted, he scored with a right-footed shot.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Friday about increasing hostility toward commodity speculators misspelled the surname of a managing director of Barclays Capital in London, who suggested that some of the enmity stems from a misunderstanding of investment strategies. He is Paul Horsnell, not Hornsell.

headline: Karzai Threatens to Send Soldiers Into Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan threatened on Sunday to send soldiers into Pakistan to fight militant groups operating in the border areas to attack Afghanistan. His comments, made at a news conference in Kabul, Afghanistan, are likely to worsen tensions between the countries, just days after American forces in Afghanistan killed 11 Pakistani soldiers on the border while pursuing militants.

headline: Gay Marriages Begin in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With a series of simple “I dos,” gay and lesbian couples across California inaugurated the state’s court-sanctioned and potentially short-lived experiment with same-sex marriage on Monday, the first of what are expected to be a crush of such unions in coming weeks.

headline: A Young Man From Omaha, Who May Perfectly Represent Brooklyn
text: Moments before Yosef Abrahamson, 16, accepted an award for the essay he’d written in a competition sponsored by the Police Athletic League, an officer approached him to complain about his fedora. The hat, an essential wardrobe item for Hasidic men, was gaudy, the policeman told him, and what’s with all these kids today and their nose rings and their attitudes. A second police officer, overhearing the conversation, came over to steer away the first one, who reappeared a few minutes later to apologize. He’d never seen a Hasidic Jew, he told Yosef.

headline: Plan Seeks More Access for Disabled
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is about to propose far-reaching new rules that would give people with disabilities greater access to tens of thousands of courtrooms, swimming pools, golf courses, stadiums, theaters, hotels and retail stores.

headline: At the Box Office, Hulk’s More Incredible
text: “The Incredible Hulk,” above, an attempt by Marvel Entertainment Inc. and Universal Pictures to give fans of the Hulk comic books and television series a better movie than the disappointing 2003 Ang Lee film “Hulk,” shows early signs of faring better. The newest version, starring Edward Norton as Bruce Banner, a scientist who turns into a giant green beast when his blood pressure soars, was the top box-office draw over the weekend, making $54.5 million in its first week in theaters. It was a tight race for the No. 2 spot this weekend, between the new M. Night Shyamalan thriller “The Happening” (Fox), starring Mark Wahlberg, and last week’s No. 1 movie, “Kung Fu Panda,” featuring the voice of Jack Black. This animated comedy from DreamWorks Animation and Paramount took in $34.3 million over the weekend for a cumulative gross of $118 million in two weeks out, according to Media by Numbers, a box-office tracking firm. “The Happening” made $30.5 million in its first weekend. In fourth place was “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan” (Sony) starring Adam Sandler, which made $16.4 million for the weekend and $68.8 million to date, and following in fifth place was Paramount’s “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” which took in $13.5 million, for a total of $275.3 million in box office since it opened on May 23.

headline: Five Welcome Comments
text: 1. After your first tee shot: “You been working out?”

headline: Can We Talk? Lively Musical Conversations, With a Contemporary Slant
text: Typically the gifted young musicians of the name-challenged Ensemble ACJW are guided to repertory by their teachers and mentors in the Academy, a select training program run by Carnegie Hall, the Juilliard School and the Weill Music Institute (hence the elusive ACJW). But for their final concert of the season at Zankel Hall on Friday night, the musicians chose the pieces and, always a delicate matter, decided who should play what part in each work. Every piece chosen explored the concept of concertato, the musical equivalent of a conversation in a lively, eclectic social setting: a boisterous pub, perhaps, as the program note suggested.

headline: A Book Club Courts Liberals
text: The progressive movement has prided itself on its ability to get its messages out by harnessing the Internet, through organizations like MoveOn.org and blogs like Daily Kos or The Huffington Post.

headline: As Candidates Emerge for Fossella’s Seat, Contested Primaries Appear Inevitable
text: Nearly a month after Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island said that he would not seek re-election for his Congressional seat in November, the political combat lines are finally being drawn. And it appears that competition for the seat will be fierce.

headline: A Case of Politics
text: Don Siegelman, the former Alabama governor, is asking a federal appeals court to throw out his conviction on dubious corruption charges. His appeal has some surprising backers: a bipartisan group of 54 former state attorneys general has submitted a brief on his behalf. Congress is also investigating charges that Mr. Siegelman was politically targeted.

headline: Nearly Half of Wall St. Bank Profits Are Gone
text: Only a year ago, Wall Street reveled in an era of superlatives: record deals, record profit, record pay. But a mere 12 months later, nearly half of the profits that major banks reaped during that age of riches have vanished.

headline: Big Tim
text: Before he was a journalist, Tim Russert, who died suddenly Friday, was a pol. In both incarnations, he was a pro’s pro. Throughout, he was an awfully good guy.

headline: Small Publishers Feel Power of Amazon’s ‘Buy’ Button
text: PARIS  Amazon, the online retailing giant with a fast-rising share of the consumer book market, has adopted the literary equivalent of a nuclear option for rebellious publishers who balk at its demands.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A news analysis article on Thursday about the connection between anti-government protests in South Korea and its April decision to lift a five-year-old ban on American beef, which many South Koreans fear may be contaminated, misstated the month in 2007 when the World Organization for Animal Health ruled that the beef was fit for consumption. It was May, not September.

headline: Mediate, Golf’s Everyman, Greets Major Chance With a Chuckle
text: SAN DIEGO  The United States Open playoff between Rocco Mediate and Tiger Woods on Monday will not be match play, but as an 18-hole, head-to-head contest, there is still room for gamesmanship.

headline: Truffle Hound and Trusty Snoop Unearth Grim Secrets
text: Ruth Rendell published “From Doon With Death,” the first of her Chief Inspector Wexford novels, in 1964. So it is not surprising that the old boy finds himself in codgerly company these days. Ms. Rendell has ghoulish fun with the assorted elderly, eccentric characters who bedevil him in “Not in the Flesh,” which is only the third of her Wexford books to appear in this present century.

headline: Woods Forces a Playoff With a Dramatic Birdie on 18
text: SAN DIEGO  Tiger Woods, facing defeat in the 108th United States Open, summoned one more dramatic shot Sunday  a birdie putt from 15 feet to tie Rocco Mediate at one-under-par 283 and send the Open into a playoff Monday for the first time since 2001 at Southern Hills.

headline: In Iraq’s South, a Mission Has Dual Aims
text: BAGHDAD  In an operation with military and political objectives, the Iraqi Army continued to assemble troops in and around the southern city of Amara on Sunday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The DealBook column on Tuesday, about efforts by the railroad company CSX to keep a British private equity fund from winning control of some of its board seats, misstated the relationship of Representative Corrine Brown, a Florida Democrat who has spoken out on CSX’s behalf, to Edward Waters College in Jacksonville, Fla. Ms. Brown received an honorary degree from and has close ties to the college, which received $25,000 from CSX and $1 million from its chief executive, but it is not her alma mater.

headline: After a Feud and 2 Deaths, Soldiers’ Families Torn
text: Capt. Phillip Esposito and Staff Sgt. Alberto Martinez went to war together, two very different soldiers from the same New York National Guard unit. After five months in Iraq, a bombing sent both men back home, one in a coffin, the other in handcuffs, a suspect in his murder.

headline: Yanks Lose Their Ace and Eye Another
text: HOUSTON  The Yankees’ season changed irreversibly on Sunday. Chien-Ming Wang’s season is in jeopardy with a serious injury to his right foot, and C. C. Sabathia instantly became a very important name in the Yankees’ universe.

headline: NBC Universal Brings Oxygen Into the Fold
text: NBC Universal spent almost a billion dollars buying the Oxygen cable channel last year. Now it’s busy making it a member of the family.

headline: United States Wins by Record Margin in Cup Qualifier
text: CARSON, Calif.  Freddy Adu was asked after practice last week if he could pick out Barbados, the United States’ first opponent in qualifying for the 2010 World Cup, on an atlas.

headline: Footnotes
text: Primary Stages has announced the cast of “Buffalo Gal,” the new comedy by A. R. Gurney that will be the first production in the company’s 2008-9 season. The six-member cast will include Susan Sullivan, known mostly for her television appearances on “Falcon Crest,” “Dharma & Greg” and other shows; Mark Blum (“Twelve Angry Men”) and Carmen M. Herlihy (“The Piano Teacher”). Performances start July 22 for a limited run through August 30 at 59E59 Theaters. ... One World Symphony (oneworldsymphony.org) will present semistaged performances of Richard Strauss’s “Ariadne Auf Naxos,” on June 27 at St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn Heights and again on June 29 at the Ansche Chesed Synagogue, 251 West 100th Street, Manhattan. Both performances will start at 8 p.m. Tickets are $30 to $40.

headline: MySpace Might Have Friends, but It Wants Ad Money
text: When the News Corporation added MySpace to its portfolio nearly three years ago, it expected that if its base of 16 million users kept growing  and each user kept adding friends, sharing photos and swapping flirty messages  the advertising dollars would roll in.

headline: Separate Bloomsdays for Theater and Radio
text: For nearly three decades theatergoers, literature lovers and admirers of Irish culture have traveled to Symphony Space or tuned in to WBAI on June 16 in order to watch or listen to actors honor the life of James Joyce and interpret his novel “Ulysses,” one of the most celebrated and recondite books of the 20th century.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on the Square Feet pages on June 4 about a mixed-income residential development planned on the site of a former state mental hospital in southwestern Boston referred imprecisely to the organization that runs a nearby nature preserve. Although the area is indeed overseen by “the Audubon Society,” it is the Massachusetts Audubon Society, not the National Audubon Society. (The two groups are not affiliated.)

headline: Officials Fear Bomb Design Went to Others
text: WASHINGTON  Four years after Abdul Qadeer Khan, the leader of the world’s largest black market in nuclear technology, was put under house arrest and his operation declared shattered, international inspectors and Western officials are confronting a new mystery, this time over who may have received blueprints for a sophisticated and compact nuclear weapon found on his network’s computers.

headline: The Forest Premeditated: Illusions of Wildness in a Botanical Garden
text: Before Sunday it was possible to enter the conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden, look out a window resembling the one Charles Darwin once gazed from at Down House in Kent, England, and see a lush overgrowth of petals and leaves, exuberant in its variety and density. Now that view is gone (unless, presumably, you travel to Kent). The Botanical Garden has dispersed the plantings, along with the stagecraft of labels and frames, and replaced David Kohn’s smartly mounted exhibition, “Darwin’s Garden,” with another temporary horticultural display.

headline: The Massachusetts Model
text: Massachusetts’s pioneering plan to provide universal health coverage is off to a good start and is heartening evidence that national health care reform may be possible if sufficient skill and determination are applied to forge a political consensus.

headline: Valentine Vester, Jerusalem Hotelier, Is Dead at 96
text: PARIS  Valentine Vester, a Yorkshire homemaker who went to Jordanian Jerusalem in 1963 to take over a little hotel, the American Colony, and turned it into one of the city’s finest, died on Sunday morning at her home in the hotel. She was 96.

headline: Pot Dealers Washed Up in an Unchic Beach Town
text: For a long time it has been hard to know what “Weeds,” the Showtime series starring Mary Louise Parker as a widowed suburban drug dealer, actually stands for but too easy to see what it is against.

headline: Lack of Care in Detention
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paris Opera to Host New York City Ballet
text: New York City Ballet will become the first non-French dance company to perform at the Opera Bastille in September, when the Paris Opera presents the ballet company in the French capital for the first time since 1965. The engagement marks the first time that Peter Martins, City Ballet’s ballet master in chief, and Gerard Mortier, director of the Paris National Opera and the soon-to-be general manager and artistic director of New York City Opera, will work together. City Ballet will perform Sept. 9 through 21 at the Bastille, the modern opera house that opened in 1989. Highlights will include a joint performance by the Paris Opera Ballet and City Ballet at the Palais Garnier on Sept. 18 and will feature two Gallic hallmarks of City Ballet history  “Apollo,” which Balanchine choreographed and gave its first performance in Paris in 1928, and “Symphony in C,” which was originally titled “Le Palais de Cristal” and was created at the Palais Garnier in 1947. Mr. Martins said his company will present 18 ballets that will pay tribute to Balanchine and Jerome Robbins’s long associations with Paris, as well as ballets by Mr. Martins and Christopher Wheeldon. “We have a whole different repertoire and a whole different take on dance,” Mr. Martins said. The season is made possible through joint financing by Paris National Opera, City Ballet, and the American Friends of the Paris Opera and Ballet.

headline: In a Changing World of News, an Elegy for Copy Editors
text: I went to the Newseum, a shiny new building in Washington that news companies and foundations have erected as a shrine to their industry. Since it’s my industry, too, I thought a museum, where sacred relics and texts have been placed safely in the equivalent of a big glass jar, might make me hopeful about the future.

headline: No Rushing Talks on Pact With U.S., Iraqis Say
text: BAGHDAD  Discussions among Iraqi politicians on the country’s long-term security agreement with the United States were under way over the weekend, but it will take many weeks and more likely months before the agreement is completed, people close to the negotiations said.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted June 6 to 11 with 1,062 adults throughout the state. Of those, 931 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

headline: Gunther Stent, an Early Researcher in Molecular Biology, Is Dead at 84
text: Gunther Stent, one of the original thinkers in the field of molecular biology, whose research wrestled with and validated the breakthrough discovery of the structure of DNA, died Thursday near his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 84.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on May 29 about a decline in liquefied natural gas imports misstated the name of the energy consulting firm that employs Nikos Tsafos, an analyst who commented on shrinking supplies. It is PFC Energy, not PCF Energy.

headline: Recalling Russert as Political Operative in New York
text: WASHINGTON  For most of Washington, Tim Russert was known as the successful moderator of “Meet the Press” on NBC and a premier chronicler of the presidential campaign. His accomplishments and status could be measured in the flood of tributes that poured in from his colleagues, competitors and the people he covered.

headline: Offer Says, ‘This Bud’s for InBev’
text: InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, started to build an argument Sunday for its $65-a-share offer to acquire Anheuser-Busch, saying it was based on the Budweiser maker’s current assets and business.

headline: As Open Goes Public, Many Players Do, Too
text: It is midafternoon on a Friday, and the fairways and greens of the Blue Hill Golf Course 30 miles north of New York City are alive with golfers. In their faces, you see excitement, even glee. It is an 80-degree June day, and cars are streaming up the driveway to Blue Hill’s century-old stone clubhouse.

headline: The Rays Are Putting Their Dismal Past in the Past
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Rays have been surprisingly successful this season, feisty upstarts who have provided a series of eye-popping highlights. One dynamic moment came Friday night, when Cliff Floyd stole second base in an interleague game against the Florida Marlins.

headline: 3 Dead and 5 Hurt in Queens Blaze That Forces Victims to Jump
text: Three people died and five others were injured, two critically, when a fire ripped through a three-story brick building in Queens on Sunday morning and forced people to jump from their windows, police and fire officials said.

text: DEAR DIARY:

text: Accounts

headline: The Tonys Spread the Glory Around
text: Reflecting an eclectic Broadway season, the 62nd Annual Tony Awards crowned a salsa-flavored musical written by a theater novice, a nostalgic glamorous revival, a sweeping melodrama from a writer making his Broadway debut, and the revival of a ’60s sex farce.

headline: The Secret to Success in Publishing: Bash Bush, With Nods to a Classic
text: The manuscript  unsolicited and addressed simply to “Editor in Chief, Little, Brown”  arrived at its destination in a clear envelope, “which was very clever,” said Geoff Shandler, the Little, Brown editor in chief who received the package. “Without opening it, I could see some of the cover image they had designed.”

headline: The Jerome Robbins Touch: Playful as a Somersault or Ethereal as Glass
text: As part of its ongoing Jerome Robbins Celebration, New York City Ballet unveiled another homage to the choreographer in “Bach to Glass: A Musical Odyssey II.” (Between the Bach and the Glass comes Alban Berg.) As theme programs go, it’s a good one, even if the second half, at least on Saturday afternoon, doesn’t have a chance of competing with the first.

headline: The Value of Hedge Funds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rogue Computers Used in Ad Fraud
text: The bane of online advertisers is click fraud, in which people or computers click on ads solely to generate a payment.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Carnival Cruise Lines, Miami, named two agencies owned by Havas to handle its account, with spending estimated at $70 million to $80 million. Arnold Worldwide, Boston, will handle the creative duties as well as direct marketing, design and digital assignments. The Boston office of MPG will handle the media planning and buying duties. Cooper DDB, Coral Gables, Fla., part of the DDB Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, had handled the bulk of the account.

headline: In Poll, Taxes and the Economy Are New Yorkers’ Top Worries
text: Gov. David A. Paterson, elevated unexpectedly to the job three months ago, has won the support of nearly half of New Yorkers, according to a New York Times poll. But many of those surveyed are increasingly worried about the economy and taxes and uncertain about the governor’s ability to address those problems.

headline: Rice Says Houses Hurt Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Sunday that thousands of housing units that Israel is building on captured land were harming peace talks with the Palestinians. She also said she could not understand why Israel was still blocking three Fulbright grantees from leaving Gaza.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Front Page

headline: After Checkpoints, Gratitude and Deep Skepticism
text: WASHINGTON  By Friday evening, the checkpoints were gone from the Trinidad neighborhood, leaving residents to ponder the city’s actions after nearly a week of intense police attention.

headline: How Angel of Sichuan Saved School in Quake
text: SANGZAO, China  The students lined up row by row on the outdoor basketball courts of Sangzao Middle School in the minutes after the earthquake. When the head count was complete, their fate was clear: all 2,323 were alive.

headline: Remote Clicks That Do More Than Just Change Channels
text: AN ambitious effort to take interactive television into American homes is expanding after a test of the system began at a single station last month.

headline: No Ordinary Candidates, No Typical Campaign
text: “Let the conversation begin” is how Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the 2008 presidential campaign. As that conversation now continues without her, it plainly will be different from what American voters have grown accustomed to.

headline: Officiating Crew Is a Focus After Assignment of Bavetta
text: LOS ANGELES  The N.B.A.’s officiating controversy crept back into the finals on Sunday, before the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Lakers ever took the court. Dick Bavetta, who was a subject of inquiries by federal agents last summer, was the lead referee for Game 5 at Staples Center.

headline: After 15 Years, Hints of Peace in Burundi
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi  The hills around town do not ring with gunfire anymore. Terrified civilians have stopped trudging down muddy paths seeking shelter. Areas that had been cut off for years because of fighting are finally opening up. And a cautious optimism seems to be spreading across the land.

headline: Queens Man Is Found Shot to Death in His Car
text: A Queens man was found shot in the head in the front seat of his car early Sunday morning in Jamaica by a woman who said she had been passed out in the back seat, the police said.

headline: A Delegator, Obama Picks When to Take Reins
text: WASHINGTON  In the months leading up to Senator Barack Obama’s big loss in the Pennsylvania primary, he was a detached manager: around, but not meddling. Rarely on early-morning conference calls with his senior advisers, he delegated most decisions to others and did not immerse himself in all of the nuts and bolts of running for president.

headline: In Praise of Being Cut Off
text: About a quarter-century ago, I was in West Beirut at the Commodore Hotel, once described as a functioning telex machine surrounded by 500 broken toilets. You lined up to use the telex. There was a war on in a divided city. There was also plenty of Black Label.

headline: Lakers Say It Isn’t Over; Last Word to Be in Boston
text: LOS ANGELES  Nine bright gold banners are stretched in three neat rows high above the south end of Staples Center, a reminder of past glory and present goals. On Sunday night, that loose quilt of championship dreams looked like one big security blanket to the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: Obama Calls for More Responsibility From Black Fathers
text: CHICAGO  Addressing a packed congregation at one of the city’s largest black churches, Senator Barack Obama on Sunday invoked his own absent father to deliver a sharp message to black men, saying “we need fathers to recognize that responsibility doesn’t just end at conception.”

headline: Kosovo’s New Constitution Takes Effect
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo  This former Serbian province’s new Constitution came into force on Sunday, an important milestone on its path toward full-fledged statehood. But a dispute over who has authority threatens to destabilize the newborn country and to plunge the Balkans into crisis.

headline: New CDs
text: THE HOLD STEADY

headline: Awaiting a Big Blue Box and an Altered World
text: When she moved to her apartment five years ago, Perian Carson’s small corner of Red Hook in Brooklyn looked much different. An abandoned Civil War-era warehouse sat a few blocks away on Van Brunt Street. Nearby, along the cobblestones on Beard Street, she could see the remnants of the old Todd Shipyards, where ships were repaired in a massive graving dock.

headline: Slocum Hits His Shots for a Final-Round 65
text: Heath Slocum shot a six-under-par 65 on Sunday at Torrey Pines Golf Course, the best round in a United States Open since Vijay Singh shot 63 in the second round in 2003. Slocum, 34, who had never made an Open cut before, called it one of the best rounds he had ever played.

headline: JPMorgan’s Stately Old Logo Returns for Institutional Business
text: On the first weekend in June, JPMorgan Chase began phasing out the Bear Stearns name  beginning with the Midtown Manhattan headquarters of the firm it acquired May 31.

headline: A Theater Moves, Again
text: The site of a new home planned for the Theater for a New Audience in the BAM Cultural District in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has shifted yet again, officials involved in the project said over the weekend. In 2004 the city announced that the theater, an itinerant Off Broadway institution known for innovative productions of Shakespearean and classical drama, would get a permanent home opposite the Brooklyn Academy of Music at the intersection of Flatbush and Lafayette Avenues. Then in 2006 the city relocated the theater across the street, to the corner of Ashland Place and Lafayette Avenue, as the site was reconceived as a kind of public gateway to the cultural district. Now the city has moved the theater to the north to make way for a private developer’s tower that will be largely residential. While the theater will remain on the same lot between Lafayette Avenue and Fulton Street, it will face Ashland, not the corner. Jeffrey Horowitz, the theater’s founder, said that he was not deflated. “You have to swing with the punches,” he said. “It’s not as wonderful as being on the corner, but it’s great to have your theater and be in a cultural district, and we’re going to make it work.” Three years ago the city unveiled a design for a glass and stainless steel building designed by Hugh Hardy and Frank Gehry to house the theater. Mr. Horowitz said that $44 million of the theater’s $48.5 million cost had been raised, and that the essential elements of the design had not changed. The building will have a 299-seat theater, a rehearsal room and a studio that will seat 50.

headline: EMI’s New Boss Sees Cracks in Music World
text: One evening last autumn a group of about 10 artist managers, including representatives for the pop stars Kylie Minogue and Robbie Williams as well as an executive who oversees the Beatles catalog, clustered around a table in an executive dining room at the London headquarters of EMI. The purpose was to size up the new boss, Guy Hands, and discuss the future of the record business.

headline: A Treasure Travels, Inconspicuously
text: They didn’t exactly hire two guys with a truck to secretly move one of the world’s largest and most valuable coin collections over the weekend in Manhattan. But they did use five standard-issue moving vans.

headline: With Shares Battered, A.I.G. Ousts Leader
text: For the second time in three years, the board at American International Group, the giant insurance company, replaced its chief executive Sunday in the wake of its falling stock price and regulatory concerns about its accounting.

headline: With Tim Russert’s Death, NBC News Must Replace a Man of Many Roles
text: The sudden death of Tim Russert has left the management of NBC News, for the moment at least, at a loss to contemplate how to replace him.

headline: Jackson May Head to Las Vegas Strip
text: Michael Jackson, below, may be next to follow the well-worn trail of pop star footsteps that leads to the Las Vegas strip, where Celine Dion, Elton John and others have taken up residence at various times. Mr. Jackson, who has had a seemingly endless series of financial troubles over the past few years, including a recent threat of foreclosure at his Neverland Ranch in California, is considering a long term Las Vegas engagement as part of a plan to repay a $23 million debt to Colony Capital, the private equity group that recently bought the loan on Neverland, Reuters reported. Colony owns the Las Vegas Hilton, and is a major shareholder in the Station Casinos chain. There is no deal yet and the possible Las Vegas engagement is one of several repayment options Mr. Jackson and Colony are considering. Mr. Jackson, who was acquitted of child molestation charges in 2005, has been reclusive ever since (O.K., before too), living in Ireland, Dubai and Bahrain at various times. He is now reportedly living in Pahrump, Nev., about 60 miles from Las Vegas.

headline: An Emotional Urge to Get Up and ‘Gro’
text: An energetic new campaign that urges consumers to go outdoors and get their hands dirty looks and sounds as if it could be promoting brands like Gore-Tex, Jeep, North Face, Range Rover or Patagonia.

headline: Stance on Same-Sex Marriage Brings Surprises for Paterson
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson’s decision to direct state agencies to recognize marriages of same-sex couples elevated his status in the eyes of many gays and lesbians to something of a celebrity.

headline: The Associated Press to Set Guidelines for Using Its Articles in Blogs
text: The Associated Press, one of the nation’s largest news organizations, said that it will, for the first time, attempt to define clear standards as to how much of its articles and broadcasts bloggers and Web sites can excerpt without infringing on The A.P.’s copyright.

headline: Star-Laden Celtics Respond to the Zen of Doc
text: Los Angeles

headline: A Split and Mixed Feelings for the Mets
text: A paltry crowd attended the second game of the Mets’ doubleheader against Texas on Sunday at Shea Stadium, but two people who were in their seats were Fred Wilpon, the team’s principal owner, and Omar Minaya, the general manager. From their suites, they watched as their $138 million investment had another bullpen implosion, started a stirring-if-unsuccessful comeback and, eventually, split a doubleheader.

headline: State Seeks Way to Save Benefits for Workers
text: State officials say they may have to create a $200 million emergency fund to finance workers’ compensation benefits for thousands of injured New Yorkers because 12 trusts that provided insurance to their employers have failed financially.

headline: From Would-Be Reformer, to Former Mason, to Plaintiff
text: WELLSBURG, W.Va.

headline: Doctors, Research and Drug Payments
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Trevor Wilkinson, the founder of the sports car maker TVR, misstated the date of his death. It was June 6  not June 11, this past Wednesday.

headline: Jampacked Bonnaroo, Beyond Jams
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  At around 3 a.m. Sunday at the 2008 Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, Phil Lesh and Friends were harmonizing on “Sugaree,” a song by Mr. Lesh’s band mate in the Grateful Dead, Jerry Garcia. The Icelandic art-rock band Sigur Ros had just finished a set that deployed a horn section, a tootling pennywhistle, a group of female drummers singing la-la’s and a confetti drop along with its usual elegiac anthems.

headline: A Tip That Involves Choking? One Pro Swears by It
text: The teaching pro Del Snyder, who has been helping golfers play better since the 1950s, has an easy cure for short-game woes. It’s not what club you hit, but where you grip that club.

headline: Physicians’ Group Furious at Cigars in ‘Hulk’ Movie
text: The American Medical Association is hulking mad at Marvel Studios.

headline: India’s Growing Gap Between Rich and Poor
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,091 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Pop Veterans Still Pumping Anti-Charisma
text: Donald Fagen and Walter Becker seem like the kind of late-1960s hypercerebral born-cynical East Coast hipsters who are often found valorizing authenticity in aesthetic expression. You know: collectors of pre-war blues 78s, memorizers of outdated jazz argot.

headline: Late Deal Pulls OTB From Brink of Shutdown
text: Confusion and discord gave way to handshakes on Sunday as Gov. David A. Paterson and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg agreed on a deal authorizing the state to take over the city’s Off-Track Betting Corporation while still granting the city a share of gambling revenues.

headline: Dianne Bullis Snyder: A Wife, a Mother, a Doer
text: Nothing was handed to Dianne Bullis Snyder; she made things happen. She worked her way through college, waiting on tables, planning on a career teaching disabled children. When she ran out of money a few credits short of a degree, she became a flight attendant instead. She was raising her children, Leland and Blakeslee, while flying coast to coast two weeks a month  and while her husband, John Snyder, worked a job that rarely brought him home for dinner. Leaving for a trip, she would post life lessons on her children’s doors. “Don’t wait for tragedy, say it today,” one of them read. “I love you and I’m glad you’re alive.” She made quilts, taught herself French, timed the cookies to come out of the oven as the children arrived home from school. She was the glue in a network of 50 first cousins. In 1999, to reduce John’s commute, the family moved to Westport, Mass., from Connecticut. Dianne began flying out of Boston and thinking about finally getting her degree and teaching. She died on American Airlines Flight 11 on Sept. 11, 2001, at age 42. “Things were settling out,” John Snyder said. “It just seemed like we were turning that corner. She would have gone back to school.”

headline: The Heir Up There
text: THE appointment of Gen. Norton A. Schwartz as the chief of staff of the Air Force last week is a historic first, one that could serve as inspiration for people who share his underprivileged background. General Schwartz is, you see, a cargo pilot.

headline: Correction
text: A June 7 Editorial Observer about European concerns over rising protectionism in the United States misidentified the European Union’s trade commissioner. He is Peter Mandelson, not Mandelstam.

headline: Another Chance for the Senate
text: Given a chance to do something important about global warming, the Senate fell flat on its face earlier this month when it could not even produce enough votes to have a good debate. It can begin to redeem itself, by approving a bill to extend vital tax credits for renewable fuel sources like wind and solar power.

headline: In Midwest Floods, a Broad Threat to Crops
text: NEWHALL, Iowa  Here, in some of the best soil in the world, the stunted stalks of Dave Timmerman’s newly planted corn are wilting in what sometimes look more like rice paddies than the plains, the sunshine glinting off of pools of collected water. Although time is running out, he has yet to plant all of his soybean crop because the waterlogged soil cannot support his footsteps, much less heavy machinery.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A music review on Friday about the tenor saxophonist Kidd Jordan, who performed in the Vision Festival at the Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center on the Lower East Side, misstated his age. He is 73, not 78.

headline: En Route to Scotland
text: New York theatergoers have become rather used to hits from the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe coming to New York. “Black Watch,” which will return to St. Ann’s Warehouse for a second run in October, is a noteworthy recent example. But 59E59 Theaters annually offers a chance to look at some shows heading in the other direction. The lineup for this year’s “East to Edinburgh” festival, running July 8 to 27, will include the erotic dance-theater piece “The Judgment of Paris,” choreographed and directed by Austin McCormick, which was staged in Brooklyn last month. “Judgment,” presented by Company XIV, was inspired by the Greek myth of what was probably the first ever beauty contest. (The aftermath was not pretty. It led to the Trojan War.) Also on the schedule is “Queen of Wyoming,” a play with music written and performed by the singer-songwriter Maggie Simpson and based on her experience as a fourth-generation member of a political family in Wyoming. Details will be available later this week at easttoedinburgh.com.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY Economic reports will include the Producer Price Index for May, housing starts for May, the current account deficit for the first quarter and industrial production and capacity utilization for May (Tuesday); and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for June and the Conference Board’s leading economic indicators for May (Thursday).

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, the Books of The Times review on Thursday, about “Austerity Britain: 1945-1951,” by David Kynaston, misstated the year of the Labor Party’s second post-World War II electoral victory. It was 1950, not 1951.

headline: In Mourning for a Man, and His Era
text: Sunday was Father’s Day, but when I called my father to wish him a happy one, he was bereft. He had just finished watching the special edition of “Meet the Press” that was broadcast to honor its host, Tim Russert, who died Friday.

headline: Obama Sharply Assails Absent Black Fathers
text: CHICAGO  Addressing a packed congregation at one of the city’s largest black churches, Senator Barack Obama on Sunday invoked his own absent father to deliver a sharp message to African-American men, saying, “We need fathers to realize that responsibility does not end at conception.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Tiger Woods
text: An interview with Tiger Woods, whose birdie on the 18th hole tied Rocco Mediate, courtesy of insidetheropes.com.

headline: Rocco Mediate
text: An interview with Rocco Mediate, who finished tied with Tiger Woods after the final round of the U.S. Open, courtesy of insidetheropes.com.

headline: 2008 Tony Awards
text: “In the Heights” and “South Pacific” won several awards.

headline: ‘Green Noise’ and ‘Destructive Interference’
text: Alex Williams had an interesting story in the Styles section over the weekend examining whether the cacophony of messaging from environmental groups and leaders in recent years has resulted in meaningful change or amounts more to a sonic barrage that dulls as much as it inspires — what some call “green noise.”

headline: Cautious Optimism in Burundi
text: After 15 years of civil war and more than 200,000 deaths, the last of Burundi’s rebel groups has finally come to the negotiating table.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Jane Bornemeier, Editor of New York Times Radio
text: Jane Bornemeier, the editor of New York Times Radio, answered questions June 16-20, 2008.

headline: Rare Coins, Rare Move
text: The American Numismatic Society discreetly moved one of the world’s largest and most valuable coin collections 22 blocks.

headline: Sabathia Is a Tempting Choice to Replace Wang
text: Chien-Ming Wang felt a pop in the top of his right foot when he rounded third base on Sunday in Houson. It was a sobering indication that Wang may have damaged a ligament, and the Yankees will know more on Monday.

headline: No Ordinary Candidates, No Typical Campaign
text: “Let the conversation begin” is how Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the 2008 presidential campaign. As that conversation now continues without her, it plainly will be different from what American voters have grown accustomed to.

headline: A Boost for Hydrogen From Honda
text: Honda is making headlines as the first automaker to begin commercial production of a hydrogen fuel cell car, the FCX Clarity. The car emits only water vapor and none of the gases linked to global warming.

headline: Switzerland Defeats Portugal and Retains Some Pride
text: BASEL, Switzerland: Behind the smiling faces, the punctual trains and the helpful police, the Swiss have spent the last two weeks engaged in a bitter competition with their neighbor and partner Austria. They have been trying to avoid becoming the worst European championship host ever.

headline: Turkey Advances With a Stunning Late Rally
text: In one of the most astonishing turnarounds we will see at this level of tournament play, Turkey played a brutal first half, went down to two goals by the Czech Republic, and in the last 15 minutes scored three times to win not only the match, but qualification for the second round.

headline: Cellphones Can’t Really Pop Popcorn
text: The video shows a group of friends aiming four cellphones at unpopped kernels of popcorn. After they dial the phones simultaneously, the kernels suddenly start popping.

headline: ‘FEMA Is on the Job’
text: More of your “late night” standup (send via the comment link below):

headline: Nothing’s Final
text: From “Pretty Good Jokes” on the Prairie Home Companion site:

headline: Online Ad Start-Up Raises $10.7 Million
text: Jivox, which provides an online video advertising platform for businesses, said it closed a $10.7 million financing round led by venture capital firm Opus Capital. Helion Venture Partners, a new investor, also took part in the round, Jivox said.

headline: U.K. Investors Said to Eye Placing in Housing Companies
text: A group of Britain’s biggest institutional investors are working on plans drawn up by bankers at UBS to provide direct funding to shore up the housebuilding sector, the Sunday Telegraph reported.

headline: Wachovia Shares Fall to Lowest Level Since 1992
text: Wachovia shares on Friday fell as much as 10.2 percent to their lowest level since 1992 on concern the fourth-largest U.S. bank might cut its dividend a second time, and after another mortgage lender with heavy exposure to California reported a jump in nonperforming assets.

headline: R.B.S. Investors Said to Approach Sainsbury Chairman
text: Institutional investors in the Royal Bank of Scotland have approached Philip Hampton, chairman of supermarket group J. Sainsbury, about becoming chairman of the bank, The Telegraph reported.

headline: France’s EDF May Raise Its Bid for British Energy, Report Says
text: Electricite de France could raise its bid for British Energy above 700 pence ($13.74) a share in exchange for the nuclear power company’s support for a deal, Reuters reported, citing a source close to the matter.

headline: PSS Systems Snags $18 Million
text: PSS Systems, which dubs itself as “the standard for legal hold and management software”, has closed a fourth round of funding.

headline: Canada’s Rock Well Said to Plan $2 Billion London I.P.O.
text: Canadian oil company Rock Well Petroleum is planning to float on the London Stock Exchange in a deal that is expected to value the company at 1 billion pounds ($2 billion), The Telegraph reported.

headline: Alliance Settles Class-Action Claims Over Buyout
text: Alliance Data Systems, the credit card processor, said Friday it agreed to settle class-action claims filed against the company and its directors regarding its failed buyout by the Blackstone Group.

headline: Brazil’s OGX Pops in Debut
text: Brazil’s OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes, the oil company controlled by billionaire Eike Batista, surged on its first day or trading on speculation the start-up will match Petroleo Brasileiro‘s success in finding oil.

headline: Austin Ventures Leads Bid for Entrepreneur, Report Says
text: Entrepreneur Media, the Irvine, Calif.-based media company which focuses on small-business owners, is being bought in a deal led by Austin Ventures, paidContent.org reported.

headline: Iron Mountain to Raise $300 Million in Debt
text: Iron Mountain on Monday announced a $300 million debt offering to repay existing debt and for possible use on acquisitions.

headline: Fund Managers Gather for Monaco Confab
text: Top hedge fund bosses are expected to debate whether an upturn in distressed investing or profitable macro strategies offer this year’s blockbuster trade, just as shorting subprime did in 2007, when they meet in Monaco this week.

headline: EADS Hit By Shareholder Suits, Report Says
text: Two U.S. law firms filed lawsuits in U.S. federal court alleging insider trading in shares of EADS and said that managers and shareholders misled investors, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Silverjet Buyout Falls Through
text: It appears to be curtains for Silverjet, after the proposed buyout of collapsed business-class airline fell apart Friday and its 420 employees were laid off.

headline: Technorati Said to Raise $7.5 Million
text: Technorati, a San Francisco-based search engine for the blogosphere, has raised $7.5 million of a $10 million Series D round, peHUB reported, citing a regulatory filing.

headline: NBC Universal Brings Oxygen Into the Fold
text: NBC Universal spent almost a billion dollars buying the Oxygen cable channel last year. Now, The New York Times says, it’s busy making it a member of the family.

headline: Tesla Signs Deal With Daimler
text: Tesla Motors, a maker of electric sports car that has won admirers among the celebrity set, has signed a “small” deal to work with Germany’s Daimler, Tesla Chairman Elon Musk said in a Fox Business News interview last week.

headline: Lloyds TSB Said to Consider Bid for Deutsche Postbank
text: Lloyds TSB, the British bank, is in the early stages of considering a takeover bid for German lender Deutsche Postbank, The Telegraph reported, citing undisclosed sources. The potential offer underscores Lloyds’ “relative immunity to the write-downs that have scarred the balance sheets of its international rivals” and would be a shift from its focus on the domestic market, The Telegraph wrote.

headline: Four Short Thumbs Up
text: There are six-word memoirs, five-word acceptance speeches (Webby Awards), and — not to be outdone — film reviews in four words or fewer. Here are some:

headline: Murdoch’s German Ambitions
text: The last time the News Corporation left the German media market in 2002, the exit was costly. The media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch had been a shareholder in the media group controlled by the Munich entrepreneur Leo Kirch and had to take a $1.93 billion write-off when two Kirch companies filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Some WaMu Shareholders Are Hopping Mad Over TPG Deal
text: Bowing to shareholder pressure, directors at Washington Mutual, the nation’s largest savings and loan, stripped Kerry K. Killinger, chairman and chief executive of the company, of his chairmanship on June 2. The board said it would appoint an independent chairman by July 1, and it instituted a majority voting standard for future director elections.

headline: State of Heads
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Republic Services in Talks to Take Out Allied Waste
text: Trash company Republic Services is in talks to buy competitor Allied Waste Industries in an all-stock deal worth about $6.77 billion, the companies said on Friday.

headline: Lehman Letter Sparks More Outrage
text: There has been much hue and cry over Lehman Brothers‘ overly-confident stance on the state of its finances prior to dropping a bomb on the market last week in announcing that it will report a $2.8 billion loss for its second quarter, the first quarterly loss in its history as a public company.

headline: NBC Trying to Close Deal for Weather Channel
text: A group led by NBC Universal is in exclusive negotiations to buy the Weather Channel, NBC confirmed on Friday, hours after Time Warner withdrew its bid. The acquisition may be completed in a matter of days.

headline: EMI’s Boss Sees Cracks in Music World
text: It has been almost 10 months since Guy Hands, the private equity financier who had made a fortune sprucing up pubs in England and gas stations on the German autobahn through his firm Terra Firma, bought EMI for about $6.4 billion, and by several accounts, including Mr. Hands’s own, it has been a chaotic time.

headline: Search for Missing Fund Manager Goes Global
text: Authorities in the United States on Friday were trying to determine whether Samuel Israel III, a former hedge fund manager who failed to report to prison and is suspected of faking his suicide, will have enough money to sustain life on the run, Reuters reported. The New York Times looked at the many contradictions in the life of Mr. Israel, who managed the now-defunct  Bayou Group hedge fund.

headline: Offer Says, ‘This Bud’s for InBev’
text: InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, started to build an argument Sunday for its $65-a-share offer to acquire Anheuser-Busch, saying it was based on the Budweiser maker’s current assets and business.

headline: Former Bear Fund Managers May Be Indicted, Report Says
text: The managers of two Bear Stearns hedge funds whose collapse last summer signaled the start the of the credit crisis could get slapped with criminal charges this week, according to a published media report.

headline: With Shares Battered, A.I.G. Ousts Leader
text: For the second time in three years, the board at American International Group, the giant insurance company, replaced its chief executive Sunday in the wake of its falling stock price and regulatory concerns about its accounting.

headline: Icahn Sees ‘Some Merit’ in Yahoo-Google Deal
text: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier who launched a proxy battle in May to replace the board of Yahoo in the wake of its failed deal to be acquired by Microsoft, said on Sunday the subsequent deal Yahoo forged with Google “might have some merit.”

headline: Bonnaroo: Didn’t Stop ‘Til We Got Enough
text: There was a sage or a joker working the soundboard of the Other Tent on Sunday afternoon. The tent somehow got behind on Bonnaroo’s usually efficient schedule, which meant that people arriving on time for Aimee Mann or Broken Social Scene ended up hearing recorded music and microphone checks. And what was playing between sets? A hit from 1979: “Don’t Stop ‘Til You Get Enough.” Had Michael Jackson somehow envisioned Bonnaroo?

headline: Barclays Considers Stock Offering
text: Shares of Barclays, the British bank, soared 11 percent Monday after the lender said it was considering a plan to sell new shares.

headline: SPI Said to Explore Sale of Stolichnaya
text: SPI Group, the beverage conglomerate, has hired Lehman Brothers to explore a sale of its Stolichnaya vodka unit in what would be the latest sale of a famous beverage brand, according to press reports.

headline: J. P. Morgan’s Stately Old Logo Returns
Nearly Half of Wall St. Bank Profits Are Gone
text: Only a year ago, Wall Street reveled in an era of superlatives: record deals, record profit, record pay. But a mere 12 months later, nearly half of the profits that major banks reaped during that age of riches have vanished.

headline: Taking Yang to Task
text: In an open letter to Jerry Yang published Saturday, The New York Times’ Joe Nocera lacerates the Yahoo chief to task for his muddled handling of Microsoft’s bid to buy the search giant, as well as his decision to throw his company into Google’s arms.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Backs XM-Sirius Deal
text: XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Satellite Radio moved closer to making their proposed $5 billion merger a reality, following reports that the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission would recommend approving the controversial hook-up.

headline: The Early Word: Economics, Round II
text: At the beginning of the second full week of the general election contest, Senator Obama delivers a message about competitiveness in Flint, Mich., a city known for economic hardship. Later he’ll hold a rally in Detroit.

headline: Congress Nears Deal on Surveillance Bill
text: Lawmakers are hoping for a breakthrough this week on changes to national security legislation that has divided Congress for months: the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.

headline: Lehman Reports $2.8 Billion Loss
text: Lehman Brothers on Monday reported a $2.8 billion loss for its fiscal second quarter, confirming last week’s dismal earnings update. Richard Fuld Jr., the chief executive of the embattled Wall Street firm, said in a statement that Lehman has “begun to take the necessary steps to restore the credibility of our great franchise and ensure that this quarter’s unacceptable performance is not repeated.”

headline: Malthus vs. the Singularity

As he notes, the current forecasts of energy and food disasters sound just like the ones made during the 1970s. Similar apocalyptic forecasts were made in the 1940s (in books like “Our Plundered Planet”) and in other eras by prophets following in Malthus’ tradition.

headline: When a Soldier Attacks a Comrade
text: Fragging. The term sounds like some medieval form of punishment, but actually is quite modern. A fragging is an attack on one soldier by another, most commonly an enlisted man turning on his commanding officer. The weapon most frequently used in such attacks has been a fragmentation grenade, hence the term.

headline: Buildings Department Warns of High Winds

The department directed builders, contractors and property owners to secure their construction sites and buildings, and said it would perform “random spot-check inspections” of construction sites around the city.

headline: An Ordinary Evening in New Haven
text: The New Haven Review, a fledging literary journal, has a new issue out. Each Monday the journal publishes a new book review on its Web site — but there’s a catch. “The reviews are of unfairly neglected books,” said the writer Mark Oppenheimer, who founded the journal. “If The Times or the New York Review or The New Republic reviewed it, we won’t. We’re looking for great books nobody has heard of.” (Today, the review singles out an unfairly neglected writer, Lee Sandlin.)

headline: The A.P., Hot News and Hotheaded Blogs

When I finally reached Jim Kennedy, an Associated Press vice president, he told me that the news agency now feels its demand was heavy-handed and was rethinking its policies. I wrote about this in Monday’s Times.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Shellfish in Packages

It’s based on the classic method of cooking en papillote — in packages — but with aluminum foil, instead of parchment paper, the packages can be placed directly on the grill. And with Asian seasonings, they become slightly exotic and really delicious.

headline: Equal Parenting: Divide and Conquer
text: So much of the conversation here the past few days has been about couples who divide household chores. It brings to mind a memory about how things probably shouldn't work.  When my firstborn was an infant and I was in the middle of a sleep-deprived, hormone-fueled meltdown, my husband, Bruce, made some comment, probably benign, about how having a baby means having no time for yourself. I took this as a declaration of war. I stormed off to make a very detailed chart of how much time each of us spent with our son, as well as how much time we each spent working, doing family-related errands and being alone. Then I flung the chart at him. It actually made me feel a little better, but it didn't measurably fix anything.    The power of lists depends on how you use them. And the discomfort so many of us feel about the approach of many couples in this article, I think, is a fear of my first kind of list. The kind that is built on resentment and that creates obligation.  "They divide a the laundry into, 'You have to do the colored, and I have to do the white'?" Nicholas Bakalar wrote on this blog.   "These are two grown-ups talking? Sounds like a pair of 8-year-olds arguing over whose turn it is to walk the dog."  And a reader named Dee echoed that sentiment, writing, "Keeping score is a relationship killer, especially if you are in it for the long run."  But what I realized during the months I spent with these couples is that they didn't use their lists (mental or physical) this way. Instead of creating bickering, their lists ended it. They decided what stuff went in whose basket of responsibility, and they trusted their partners to do what was in his or her bucket. They also learned to keep their mouths shut if something wasn't done exactly "my way." Then they forgot about it. It was taken care of. They had a lot of conversation upfront, yes, but they eliminated even more conversation down the road.  And to those posters who asked, "Well, what if someone has a bad day or is sick or just plain tired?" Common sense says you pick up the slack for your partner, no? Again, I don't live this life, I am just reporting on it, but these were not militant households here. Yes, they adapt to circumstance.  This isn't for everyone. I'd feel ridiculous dividing laundry into darks and whites. But it seems to work for Marc and Amy, which means that in their house it's a good idea. And that's the entire point here. Not that everyone keep charts or lists or does things the way any one of these couples do. But rather that we should all take some more time to think about how the division of labor evolved in our own relationship and decide in a focused and deliberate way whether or it exists because it make sense for us, or because it just kind of worked out that way. To each his own. But make sure you know what your own really is.

headline: Three Feet High and Rising

headline: Q & A: How the Airlift Changed Our Lives
text: In June 1948, after the Soviet Union blockaded allied deliveries of supplies to the Western sectors of Berlin, the United States and its allies launched what became known as the Berlin Airlift, using transport planes to drop food and supplies to Berliners. The airlift became a turning point in the cold war, when the West pushed back against the Soviet Union’s quest for dominance in central Europe. Here is an interview on that historic crisis with Andrei Cherny, the editor of Democracy, a journal, and the author of “The Candy Bombers: The Untold Story of the Berlin Airlift and America’s Finest Hour” (2008). Mr. Cherny was a policy adviser and speechwriter in the Clinton White House.
