headline: Bill Promotes Universal College Loans
text: Responding to reports that some lenders have stopped offering federal loans at community and other colleges, two Democratic senators introduced legislation Tuesday to prohibit lenders from picking and choosing among institutions.

headline: A Disabled Swimmer’s Dream, a Mother’s Fight
text: SAN DIEGO  As Kendall Bailey swims, his praying-mantis limbs flapping him forward, something about the water disguises his many maladies: cerebral palsy, mental retardation, autism and more. Only in a swimming pool do they dissolve and allow his troubled body and mind to be all but normal. He is happy, safe and possibly the fastest disabled breaststroker in the world.

headline: Veterans and Newcomers in Elliott Carter’s Labyrinth
text: The annual Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance at Mannes College the New School for Music split its focus this year between Georges Aperghis and Elliott Carter, with a handful more composers thrown in for perspective. The Monday-evening installment  for which the festival moved to the Frederick Lowe Theater at New York University  was an all-Carter program performed by Speculum Musicae.

headline: With a Modest Decline in Profit, Goldman Sachs Outshines Rivals Again
text: Over the past year, one investment bank after another has let down Wall Street.

headline: Congressional Committee Will Not Pursue Videotape Scandal, Specter Says
text: Senator Arlen Specter said he would not pursue Congressional hearings on the New England Patriots’ videotape scandal.

headline: Some Choice Words Honor George Carlin
text: George Carlin, below, the veteran comic whose history in Washington includes the Supreme Court’s consideration of his “Filthy Words” routine, will be the 11th person inducted into the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts’ pantheon of humor. The center announced on Tuesday that Mr. Carlin would receive this year’s Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, an award whose previous winners include Richard Pryor, Whoopi Goldberg, Lily Tomlin and Steve Martin. Mr. Carlin has recorded 18 albums of stand-up comedy and received four Grammy Awards. The award will be presented at the center on Nov. 10. Mr. Carlin thanked the prize’s namesake and instructed Mr. Twain to “have your people call my people.”

headline: Wyeth Shares Rise on Promising Study of Alzheimer’s Drug
text: The drug maker Wyeth said on Tuesday that a potential product for treating Alzheimer’s showed promise in an intermediate clinical study.

headline: Every Woman Has the Right to Survive Pregnancy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Iraq: Still Inscrutable
text: When I was in Cairo last week, Osama Ghazali Harb, an Egyptian political analyst, told me about a speech that he had recently given at the main Coptic Cathedral there. It was a discussion about the state of Arab politics. After he had finished, he said, an Iraqi man who had come with some Egyptian friends, got up to ask a question and along the way made the following statement: There are “only two democracies” in the Middle East today: “Iraq and Israel.” The audience booed.

headline: Brown Says Europe Will Tighten Iran Sanctions
text: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced Monday that Britain and the European Union would freeze the overseas assets of Iran’s largest commercial bank, joining the United States in intensifying financial pressure against Iran over its refusal to address international concern over its nuclear activities.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Saturday about the author Nicholas Sparks’s support of a scholastic track program in New Bern, N.C., where he lives, misstated the name of the California town where he ran track in high school. It is Fair Oaks, not Long Oaks.

headline: Museum Campaigns for Shoeless Joe Jackson
text: GREENVILLE, S.C.  Shoeless Joe Jackson died 57 years ago in the tiny, red-brick house on the edge of this city that he shared with his wife, Kate. It was in the 950-square-foot home that he endured the final 10 years of his life and the last of three decades banished from baseball for his role in fixing the 1919 World Series

headline: Judge Sharply Dismisses Former Gossip Writer’s Suit
text: A judge dismissed on Tuesday a suit by a former New York Post gossip writer who accused Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bill Clinton, The Daily News and others of conspiring to ruin his reputation.

headline: Israel Agrees to Truce with Hamas on Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — The prime minister and defense minister of Israel have agreed to an Egyptian-brokered cease-fire with Hamas for the Gaza area starting Thursday, Israel Radio reported on Wednesday morning.

headline: Ford Says Kerkorian’s Investment Is a Sign of Confidence
text: DETROIT  After waging bitter battles with management at Chrysler and General Motors, the financier Kirk Kerkorian is off to a more peaceful start as a major shareholder in the Ford Motor Company.

headline: Pentagon to Consult Academics on Security
text: Eager to embrace eggheads and ideas, the Pentagon has started an ambitious and unusual program to recruit social scientists and direct the nation’s brainpower to combating security threats like the Chinese military, Iraq, terrorism and religious fundamentalism.

headline: At Bar Q, a Chef’s Playroom That Is Full of Surprises
text: A RESTAURANT critic’s most practiced companions know that the questions to be asked in advance of a meal go beyond the address, the hour and the (fake) reservation name.

headline: For SNY, It’s All Randolph From Dawn to Dusk
text: Willie Randolph’s firing was a major story for SportsNet New York.

headline: Producer Prices Rose 1.4% in May
text: Businesses struggled with higher production costs last month, primarily as a result of record-high oil prices, meaning Americans might face more expensive items on store shelves soon.

headline: Chinese Quake Toll, 69,172, Is Just a Guess
text: SHANGHAI  For weeks after the devastating earthquake that struck Sichuan Province last month, the public grew accustomed to a grim daily ritual as the Chinese government provided precise daily updates on the rising numbers of dead and missing.

headline: What You Get for ... $850,000
text: Ogunquit, Me.

headline: MBIA Debt Is Setting Up a Quandary
text: The risks associated with the vast, unregulated market for credit default swaps played a crucial role in the bailout of Bear Stearns. Now these financial instruments are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.

headline: In Park Slope, Vegan and Organic
text: Paul Zumoff, a real estate broker, decided that Park Slope, Brooklyn, needed more organic and vegan prepared food. So, with his parents, Mark and Jeanne Zumoff, who used to be food distributors, he has opened Organic Heights, 460 Bergen Street (Fifth Avenue).

headline: New Look Planned for Pier at South Street Seaport
text: Conceding the failure of the South Street Seaport pier as a “festival marketplace” — these days, it is not much more than a waterfront mall — its owners plan to replace it with a mixed-use project including a 42-story, 495-foot apartment and hotel tower, wrapped in a terra-cotta exoskeleton and rising from new pilings in the East River.

headline: A Swiss Orchestra Rebounds From Loss
text: After losing support from the Swiss bank UBS last fall, the UBS Verbier Festival Orchestra has raised about $1.4 million to continue its operations. Half the money came from public funds and the rest from foundations and private individuals, the festival’s founder and director, Martin Engstrom, said on Tuesday. UBS, which had invested nearly $10 million a year in the orchestra, has transferred its support to a rival Swiss festival in Lucerne. The orchestra still needs to raise about $720,000 to support its orchestra and chamber music activities, Mr. Engstrom said. The Verbier orchestra, a training ensemble based at the Verbier Festival in Switzerland, was founded by the bank and the festival in 2000. After this summer it will stop using UBS in its name. It consists of musicians under 30 who are coached by principal players from the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

headline: Pettitte Passes Guidry With Vintage Performance
text: The last time Andy Pettitte had faced the San Diego Padres for the Yankees, he won the clinching game of the 1998 World Series. It was the second of four titles for the Yankees of that era, when every night, it seemed, another ace took the mound.

headline: Towns on Mississippi Shore Up Levees
text: Residents and emergency workers in dozens of towns threatened with flooding in three states along the Mississippi River were working furiously on Tuesday to shore up nearly 30 levees, federal officials said.

headline: Jobs for Teenagers, and a Job for the Government
text: To the Editor:

headline: Scrutinizing a Red, Grape by Grape
text: FOR almost three months, the tragicomic opera that is the brunello di Montalcino scandal has dragged on. Each apparent step forward turns out to be no more than the dance that comes of shooting oneself in the foot.

headline: A Mature Kind of Salsa, More Tender Than Tough
text: If Victor Manuelle wanted to get half the crowd at Central Park SummerStage whooping on Sunday afternoon, he need only have performed the tiniest of gyrations with his hips. If he wanted both halves to make a ruckus, he need only have waved a Puerto Rican flag.

headline: Floodwaters Flow On, Swelling the Mississippi
text: CLARKSVILLE, Mo.  Already, the new riverfront park was out of sight, under water. Disappearing slowly was the antique mall, the bank, the church, the American Legion hall, the oldest house in town. And the Mississippi River was only getting started.

headline: Executive Questioned in Insider Trading Case at EADS
text: The French authorities have detained another executive in connection with an insider trading investigation at European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent of the plane maker Airbus.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A series of pictures on Tuesday that highlighted five great shots by Tiger Woods at the United States Open misidentified, in some editions, the player leading the tournament when Woods made a 66-foot eagle putt on No. 13 in the third round. It was Rocco Mediate, not Lee Westwood.

headline: Making Disparate Pieces Fit Together
text: New York is a city of endless juxtapositions. In its streets, buildings, parks and rivers, in its neighborhoods, boroughs and blocks, the city conducts an unflagging symphony of collisions. Cultures, religions and ideas cross paths, live side by side, and bounce off each other like the molecules that fill our bodies.

headline: Knocking on Wood, Girardi Aims to Keep Yanks Healthy
text: Among the people who have contacted Chien-Ming Wang since he injured his foot Sunday are two former Yankees coaches, Larry Bowa and Ron Guidry. Bowa showed mercy in a text message, but Guidry was playfully teasing.

headline: Chai-Spiced Chicken Wings With Green Garlic Aioli
text: Time: 30 minutes, plus 6 hours’ marinating

headline: British Inflation Hits a 10-Year High
text: LONDON  Inflation in Britain reached the highest level in more than 10 years in May, fanning fears that the country is moving closer to a recession, and forcing the central bank chief to write a letter of explanation to the government.

headline: McCain Showcases His Environmental Side
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona began running this commercial on Tuesday on cable news and in closely contested states like Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania, where his advertisements have been running for the past couple of weeks.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture caption on Friday with an article about an Internal Revenue Service proposal that would make the construction of three expensive sports arenas in New York even more costly referred incompletely to the site of the planned Barclays Center arena, the centerpiece of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn. The arena site is in the upper left quadrant of the photograph; it does not extend to the area in the center of the frame.

headline: Vietnam, Iraq and John McCain
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fact Mirrors Fiction in African Coup Trial
text: DAKAR, Senegal  The plot to overthrow the government of Equatorial Guinea in 2004 was so improbable that it sounded like something out of a tale from the tropics, too outlandish even for Graham Greene.

headline: An Easier Way to Scrape the Mixer Bowl
text: This efficient and sturdy plastic paddle beater by New Metro Design can be used with most KitchenAid, Cuisinart, Viking and DeLonghi standing mixers. Its outside edge is flexible plastic, like a windshield wiper blade, so it can neatly swipe the inside of the bowl as you mix, eliminating the need to stop the beating and scrape.

headline: Hundreds of Same-Sex Couples Wed in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With a quiet pride and a sense of history, hundreds of gay and lesbian couples across California wed on Tuesday, giving a human face to a landmark court decision and a powerful opening salvo in what is expected to be a bruising fall campaign here over the issue of same-sex marriage.

headline: Yes, We Will Have No Bananas
text: Los Angeles

headline: For Midsummer, a Sparkling Treat
text: “Midsummer” often refers to the solstice, which this year happens on Friday. In England, “midsummer night” is celebrated on June 24, the birthday of St. John the Baptist. Whatever date you prefer, when dusk finally falls, it might be a fine moment to celebrate the season by opening a bottle of suitably named Nocturne, a nonvintage sec Champagne made by Taittinger. It is rounded and mellow, with soft carbonation and aromas of ripe peaches.

headline: A Little Black Dress and the Ear of the Beholder
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Real Schedule for Ground Zero
text: When former Gov. George Pataki was under intense criticism for slow progress at ground zero, he created an aggressive schedule for rebuilding the World Trade Center area. Now, when it appears that not all of those deadlines can be met, New York’s newest governor, David Paterson, is setting the stage for adopting a less rigorous timetable.

headline: Bush Will Seek to End Offshore Oil Drilling Ban
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush, reversing a longstanding position, will call on Congress on Wednesday to end a federal ban on offshore oil drilling, according to White House officials who say Mr. Bush now wants to work with states to determine where drilling should occur.

headline: Obama and Clinton Seek to Unite Donors in Joint Appearance
text: WASHINGTON  Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are set to appear together here next week at a fund-raiser, their first side-by-side appearance since the long Democratic primary battle ended.

headline: A Bumper Film Crop on Cape Cod
text: The cranberry harvest is a few months off, so for now it is film festival season on Cape Cod. The Provincetown International Film Festival opens on Wednesday night with the first American screening of Madonna’s directorial debut, “Filth and Wisdom.” The film, about three young people sharing a house in London, received mixed reviews after its premiere at the Berlin Film Festival in February. At the other end of the Massachusetts cape, the Nantucket Film Festival begins on Thursday and features “Elegy,” an adaptation of the Philip Roth story “The Dying Animal” directed by Isabel Coixet.

headline: Mr. Bush v. the Bill of Rights
text: In the waning months of his tenure, President Bush and his allies are once again trying to scare Congress into expanding the president’s powers to spy on Americans without a court order.

headline: Biscuit Bakers’ Treasured Mill Moves North
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.

headline: U.S. Will Lag in Tech Growth, Study Says
text: Watching television, gaining access to the Internet and listening to music on mobile phones will be a viable business in the next few years, says a study by a consulting arm of PricewaterhouseCoopers. But while marketers and advertisers have much to cheer in the coming digital revolution, the fastest growth will be in emerging markets, with the United States lagging behind.

headline: Sweet Rewards for Apricot Explorers
text: Waterford, Calif.

headline: De Niro Asks Landmark Board to Spare His Hotel’s Penthouse
text: Robert De Niro asked the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday to approve a penthouse atop his new Greenwich Hotel in TriBeCa that is bigger and bulkier than the design the commission approved in 2004.

headline: McCain Urges Building 45 New Nuclear Plants
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mo.  Senator John McCain said Wednesday that he wanted 45 new nuclear reactors to be built in the United States by 2030, a goal that he called “as difficult as it is necessary.”

headline: Japan and China Near Agreement on Offshore Gas Fields
text: TOKYO  Japan’s prime minister said Tuesday that his country and China were close to resolving a dispute over offshore natural gas fields that had become a symbol of rising rivalries between Asia’s two richest nations.

headline: A Slimmed-Down Diva Keeps Her Vocal Heft
text: LONDON  The drama following the 2004 dismissal of the soprano Deborah Voigt from a production of Strauss’s “Ariadne auf Naxos” at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden here had many elements of the work itself: an opera within an opera that blends comic and tragic aspects and caricatures the lofty ideals of high art. Ms. Voigt’s dismissal, because she was too large to wear the cocktail dress stipulated by the director or adhere to his staging concepts, prompted an avalanche of international interest that ranged from buffa laughs about fat ladies singing to ponderous editorials about the meaning of “sacred art” versus Hollywood ideals of beauty.

headline: The Manager Changes, but the Mets’ Results Do Not
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  As either a sign of solidarity for the new manager Jerry Manuel or of the eagerness to move out from under the dark cloud that had hung over Willie Randolph, everyone in the Mets dugout ascended to the top step for the first pitch Tuesday night.

headline: In Life, as in Baseball, Getting Fired Is an Opening for a Comeback
text: Kerry Leishman’s boss did not bother to say, “You’re fired,” face to face. He sent her the news in a text message.

headline: Some Insider Jokes From a Magician and His Troupe
text: DURHAM, N.C.  “Pure” seems like a perfect title for a work by John Jasperse, whose choreography tends to attract adjectives like austere, cerebral or stark. But the piece, commissioned by the American Dance Festival and performed for the first time Monday at the Reynolds Industries Theater at Duke University here, brought other words to mind.

headline: Argentine President Seeks to Quell Criticism
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, sought on Tuesday to cool mounting criticism over her economic policies, saying she would ask the Argentine Congress to legitimize the export taxes that have prompted three months of revolt by farmers.

headline: A Broadway Debut for Neil LaBute
text: Neil LaBute, who has a long Off Broadway history, makes his uptown debut next season. His critically praised “Reasons to Be Pretty,” an MCC Theater production currently at the Lucille Lortel Theater, will begin previews on Feb. 13 at a Broadway theater to be named. The entire cast  including Piper Perabo, Alison Pill, Thomas Sadoski and Pablo Schreiber  will stay for the transfer. Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Steve Traxler, who brought “August: Osage County” to Broadway after it received glowing reviews in Chicago, are behind the move.

headline: Paulson Sees Progress in U.S.-China Ties
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  The United States opened two days of intense economic talks with China on Tuesday with the Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., declaring that despite recent tensions over trade, investment and food and product safety, ties between the two countries were “growing in a positive direction.”

text: Adapted from “CookWise” by Shirley O. Corriher (Morrow)

text: Open Now

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Sunday about the way that foreign athletes switch citizenship and compete for the United States in the Olympics referred incorrectly to the immigration process, gave an outdated title for an expert and misstated the years in which a top distance runner won medals.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with coverage of the United States Open victory by Tiger Woods misspelled, in some editions, the given name of his mother, who was shown celebrating with the family. It is Kultida, not Kutilda.

headline: Mexican Summer on a Stick
text: YOU can freeze fruit juice and call it sorbet. You can add a bit of milk or cream to make it richer and smoother, and call it sherbet.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about the coaching matchup in the N.B.A. finals, misstated the age of Coach Phil Jackson of the Los Angeles Lakers. He is 62, not 63.

headline: U.S. Tells China Subprime Woes Are No Reason to Keep Markets Closed
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Bush administration economic officials, frustrated over the pace of change in China, warned Chinese leaders Tuesday not to let American regulatory failures in the subprime mortgage crisis become an excuse for not deregulating Chinese markets and opening them to foreign investment.

text: Front Page

headline: Stadium Deal Veteran Tapped to Develop Same Site
text: The Related Companies announced on Tuesday that it was hiring Jay Cross, one of the men most closely associated with the ill-fated proposal to build a West Side stadium for the Jets, to run its Hudson Yards development on the same site.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Tuesday about new space suits for American astronauts misspelled the surname of a NASA official. He is Doug Cooke, not Cook.

headline: In London, a Mid-Century Renovation

headline: Sense of Calm as Gay Couples Wed in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With a sense of history and a looming battle at the ballot box, hundreds of gay and lesbian couples in California wed on Tuesday, a steady and decidedly confident celebration that was a marked departure from the mad rush here four years ago.

headline: Panel Pushes Spitzer Aides to Make Deal
text: ALBANY  A state ethics panel is seeking to settle cases against top aides to former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a year after their alleged involvement in an effort to gather the travel records of Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader.

headline: At Least 51 Are Killed in Blast at Baghdad Market
text: This article was reported by Richard A. Oppel Jr., Mudhafer al-Husaini and Ali Hameed, and written by Mr. Oppel.

headline: Conviction in Lobbying Case Overturned
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned the conviction of a former Bush administration official caught up in a lobbying scandal, finding that part of the prosecution’s case was faulty and that the trial judge was wrong to exclude expert testimony for the defense.

headline: Correction
text: A recipe last week with an article about using less meat was mislabeled. The dish was edamame with pork, tomatoes and parsley  not edamame with pork, tomatoes and cilantro.

headline: Budget Hotels for the Garment District
text: The garment district is taking in lodgers. A handful of developers is transforming an erstwhile manufacturing area into a magnet for budget-minded travelers.

headline: Antiwar Activist Returns to Court for Iraq Spy Case
text: She rolled her eyes. She stuck her tongue out at the prosecutor. It was decidedly not the usual courtroom demeanor. Then again, it was not the usual federal case.

headline: Saying ‘I Do,’ Making History, Planning a Party
text: HAILE HAYDEN didn’t grow up eating bland chicken breasts and steamed vegetables, so she certainly wasn’t going to feed them to the 120 people coming to her wedding in July.

headline: A Portrait of the Critic as a Delirious Young Man
text: As James Joyce’s H. C. Earwicker  whose dream sets off the associations, disassociations and language acrobatics of “Finnegans Wake”  stands to fiction, Adam Thirlwell stands to literary criticism.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Doctors and Minorities: 3 Perspectives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Footnote
text: The second Make Music New York festival, the local counterpart of the worldwide Fête de la Musique, will present more than 800 free outdoor concerts on Saturday. Highlights include a classical, opera and jazz block party on 64th Street near Lincoln Center; a punk concert on Governors Island; and “The Music Man,” by the Village Light Opera Group in TriBeCa. A full schedule is at timeoutnewyork.com/makemusic. ... A ribbon-cutting was scheduled for Tuesday night by the Arts Horizons LeRoy Neiman Art Center, a community arts education center scheduled to open in Harlem next month at Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 148th Street, according to The Associated Press. Mr. Neiman, known for his colorful portraits of celebrities, donated $1 million to create the center.

text: Time: 15 minutes

Highlights include a classical, opera and jazz block party on 64th Street near Lincoln Center; a punk concert on Governors Island; and “The Music Man,” by the Village Light Opera Group in TriBeCa. A full schedule is at timeoutnewyork.com/makemusic. ... A ribbon-cutting was scheduled for Tuesday night by the Arts Horizons LeRoy Neiman Art Center, a community arts education center scheduled to open in Harlem next month at Frederick Douglass Boulevard and 148th Street, according to The Associated Press. Mr. Neiman, known for his colorful portraits of celebrities, donated $1 million to create the center.

headline: Reading Into the Future
text: My family has an unhealthy love of books. They attach themselves to us like pets, and our apartment has so many volumes that I worry about the entire eccentric library crashing suddenly through the floor and resettling itself on the neighbor downstairs. So, an electronic book makes sense. One small thing that contains a bookcase full of stories and recipes and solutions for world peace would seem to offer a very advanced solution to our family’s housekeeping problem.

headline: Offer to Drop Charges in Sean Bell Protests
text: The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, announced on Tuesday that his office was prepared to drop all charges against 28 people arrested on May 7 in connection with protests against the acquittals of the officers charged in the shooting death of Sean Bell.

headline: Boston Cheers as Celtics Rout Lakers
text: BOSTON – The sights, smells and happy chaos were familiar, as if borrowed from another era and another arena: Stale cigar smoke filled the air. Champagne soaked the locker-room carpets. Green and white confetti was everywhere.

headline: Esbjorn Svensson, Leader of E.S.T. Jazz Trio, Dies at 44
text: Esbjorn Svensson, a Swedish pianist and leader of the jazz trio E.S.T., one of Europe’s most popular ensembles, which was to appear in New York this Saturday as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, died last Saturday in Stockholm. He was 44.

headline: Three Questions for McCain
text: A week before Pennsylvania’s Democratic primary  in April, back when Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama were still the big story  John McCain traveled to Pittsburgh to remind everyone how different his economic agenda would be from theirs.

headline: A Two-Man, One-Woman Crime Wave
text: The three characters in “Safe,” a play by Ron Fitzgerald about lowlife burglars, don’t have much they can teach us. That’s the problem with the underbelly: Let the characters you find there sound too smart or talk too poetically and they’re not believable. And Mr. Fitzgerald makes his job doubly difficult with the format he chooses. The tale is told as a montage of monologues, with the characters rarely interacting.

headline: Ex-Officer Acquitted in Death of Immigrant in Westchester
text: A former Mount Kisco police officer was acquitted of all charges on Tuesday in the death of an illegal immigrant from Guatemala, ending a case that roiled the Westchester County suburbs a year ago.

headline: Study Finds Little Benefit in New SAT
text: The revamped SAT, expanded three years ago to include a writing test, predicts college success no better than the old test, and not quite as well as a student’s high school grades, according to studies released Tuesday by the College Board, which owns the test.

headline: Celtics Show That Bryant Is No Jordan
text: Boston

headline: Dominance Struggles That Don’t Include Men
text: “Four Women and a Waitress,” a lopsided program of two one-acts  Edward Allan Baker’s blue-collar drama “Rosemary With Ginger” and August Strindberg’s psychological sketch “The Stronger”  starts with a fizzle and ends with a bang.

headline: Campaigns in a Skirmish Over Terrorism and Law
text: A sharp debate over terrorism, security and the rule of law broke out on Tuesday as the campaigns of Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama exchanged pointed salvos over who could best keep the nation safe.

headline: Investors Seek Asian Options to Costly China
text: HANOI  Canon is no longer building or expanding factories in China, but the company is doubling its work force at a printer factory outside Hanoi to 8,000.

headline: American President Pleads Guilty to Hopeless Idealism
text: LONDON

headline: Mississippi Washes Over Illinois Levees
text: CANTON, Mo.  The Mississippi River washed over two levees in western Illinois early Wednesday, forcing people out of their homes, destroying countless acres of crops, and bringing the number of levees that have given way to the river this week to nearly 20.

headline: Ballet Theater’s Revised ‘Beauty’ Spotlights a Very Busy Prince
text: Of the 19th-century classics that dominate today’s ballet repertory, “The Sleeping Beauty” is the most multilayered, the most abundant in telling detail, the most blessed with a score of miraculous eloquence. Which is why it’s the hardest to bring off in the theater. No production has ever been flawless (starting with the 1890 original, which made all sorts of nips and tucks and at least one reordering of the score).

headline: New Mets Manager Mixes Intellect With Fire
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Standing a few feet from his soon-to-be office at Shea Stadium, Jerry Manuel was talking excitedly Saturday evening about a package he received in the mail. A copy of “One Man’s America: The Pleasures and Provocations of Our Singular Nation,” the latest book by the columnist and author George F. Will, had just arrived, and Manuel was eager to start reading.

headline: A Garlic Festival Without a Single Clove
text: “I’D rather have an ounce of garlic than a pound of truffles,” my father often said, setting the tone for garlic worship in our family.

headline: More Medical Tests for Amy Winehouse
text: On the celebrity blotter: The British singer Amy Winehouse remained in a London hospital on Tuesday after collapsing at her North London home on Monday, the Associated Press reported. A spokesman for Ms. Winehouse said that initial tests were inconclusive and more would be performed. ... An unidentified photographer who pressed charges against Britney Spears for running over his foot was found to be at fault himself and prosecutors will not pursue the case, according to The Associated Press. Joseph D. Shidler, a Los Angeles County deputy district attorney, wrote on Friday that based on police records and videotape of the incident last year, the “only way the victim’s foot could have been where the video indicates it to be was by the victim placing it in that location.”

headline: At Social Site, Only the Businesslike Need Apply
text: SAN FRANCISCO  For a Web site, it could hardly look less exciting. Its pages are heavy with text, much of it a flat blue, and there are few photos and absolutely no videos.

headline: Central Park Loses Dozens of Its Trees in Big Storm
text: It would be a sad census in any case, but the tally of trees lost in Central Park to high winds during the storm on June 10 comes with particular ill grace in the middle of the Million Trees NYC campaign.

headline: Burmese Endure in Spite of Junta, Aid Workers Say
text: YANGON, Myanmar  More than six weeks have passed since Cyclone Nargis swept through the Irrawaddy Delta in southern Myanmar, leaving a trail of flattened villages and broken lives and arousing international sympathy that turned to anguish as the military government obstructed foreign aid.

headline: More Illegal Crossings Are Criminal Cases, Group Says
text: Criminal prosecutions of immigrants by federal authorities surged to a record high in March, as immigration cases accounted for the majority  57 percent  of all new federal criminal cases brought nationwide that month, according to a report published Tuesday by a nonpartisan research group.

headline: Flooding in Southern China Claims Scores of Victims
text: SHANGHAI  Torrential rains that have caused some of the worst flooding in 50 years and killed scores of people continued to batter a huge swath of southern China on Tuesday near one of the biggest manufacturing zones in the country.

headline: Dennis Weatherstone, Banking Sage, Dies at 77
text: Dennis Weatherstone, who helped usher in a new era of banking during the early 1990s as chairman and chief executive at J. P. Morgan, died Friday near his home in Darien, Conn. He was 77.

headline: Taliban Fighters Infiltrate Area Near Southern Afghan City
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Afghan families continued to flee the Argandab District in southern Afghanistan on Tuesday as Taliban fighters and NATO and Afghan forces prepared to battle over the strategic region.

headline: Pakistan and Terrorism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Northwest Plans More Fleet Cutbacks
text: Northwest Airlines said Tuesday that it planned to eliminate more planes from its fleet, including Boeing, Airbus and McDonnell Douglas jets, by the end of December, its second cut in capacity this year.

headline: New Jersey’s Office Developers See a Few Bright Spots
text: Last month, a developer began resurrecting the “skeleton of Parsippany”  a steel frame for an office building that was started in the late 1980s but never finished after a recession hit. And some real estate professionals instantly perceived this as a possible harbinger of resurgence for the office market in New Jersey.

headline: Energy Costs Help Push Inflation Higher in Britain
text: LONDON  Inflation in Britain accelerated to the highest level in more than 10 years in May, further tying the hands of policy makers grappling with a slowing economy.

headline: New Florida Rules Return More Than 115,000 Ex-Offenders to Voting Rolls
text: MIAMI  Gov. Charlie Crist announced on Tuesday that 115,232 Florida felons had regained their voting rights since new rules took effect last April, but 80 percent of the state’s disenfranchised ex-offenders remain off the rolls.

headline: Bronze Eagles Owe Survival to Drug Dealer
text: When the price of scrap metal rises, the parks and cemeteries of the world are mined by thieves. Statues are decapitated and delimbed, hacksawed into pieces that can be carried off and sold for their weight, not their grace. One age’s bronzed glories have often become the phone wires or car bushings of the next.

headline: Blessings and Anguish for Pastors in California
text: Some clergy members in California spent Tuesday officiating at same-sex weddings made legal by a State Supreme Court ruling that took effect on Monday night. Others spent the day speaking out against same-sex marriage.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Saturday about efforts to cut down on information overload in the workplace, using data from the research firm Basex, gave an incorrect estimate in some editions for the annual cost of unnecessary interruptions at work. It is $650 billion  not million.

headline: Big Banks Sued Over Sewer Bonds
text: A man in Jefferson County, Ala., has sued JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Keegan and 10 other banks, advisers and insurers, claiming their work on county bond transactions saddled residents with soaring sewer bills.

headline: British Free a Cleric Linked to bin Laden and Wanted in Jordan
text: A London-based Muslim cleric who was known as Osama bin Laden’s spiritual leader in Europe was released under severe restrictions on Tuesday, after a court decision that blocked his deportation to Jordan.

headline: Chimp’s Sex Calls May Reflect Calculation
text: Intricate as the mating dance may be among people, for other primates like chimpanzees and baboons it is even more complicated. This is evident from the work of researchers who report that the distinctive calls made by female chimpanzees during sex are part of a sophisticated social calculation.

headline: Workshop on Preparing for Calamities Focuses on the Flu
text: Be afraid, be very afraid. There is no telling what the next disaster will be. Another terrorist attack? A steam pipe explosion like the one that shut down several blocks of Lexington Avenue a year ago? Or perhaps a pandemic flu that would cripple New York City’s economy by making people afraid to go to work or ride on subways and buses?

headline: After Attacks, Michelle Obama Looks for a New Introduction
text: Michelle Obama’s eyes flicker tentatively even as she offers a trained smile. As her campaign plane arcs over the Flathead Range in Montana, she is asked to consider her complicated public image.

headline: Mets End the Suspense for Randolph
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  It started out as a great story, the quintessential New York story, in fact. Back in 2004, Willie Randolph, the African-American manager from Brooklyn, teamed up with Omar Minaya, the Hispanic general manager from Queens, and together they vowed to bring a World Series championship to the team each rooted for as a child.

headline: Pakistani Fury Over Airstrikes Imperils Training
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military is so angry over the American airstrikes here last week that it is threatening to postpone or cancel an American program to train a paramilitary force in counterinsurgency for combating Islamist militants, two Pakistani government officials said.

headline: Crude? So What? These Characters Still Find Work in Ads
text: THE characters on the Fox television series “Family Guy” make tasteless jokes about sex, AIDS, religion and bodily functions, purposely offending just about every group of people you could name.

headline: Workers of an Extreme World, One Beyond Classes
text: Right away there are gripes to be had with “Black Gold,” a new reality series about oil-rig workers in West Texas that arrives at a moment when their employers are enriching themselves at the spigot of the boom. The show, starting Wednesday on TruTV, refrains from mining the dramatic potential of bad weather, a neglect that would hardly bear remarking if “Black Gold” did not come from the workshop of Thom Beers, the genre-defining producer and creator of severity-virility-unendurable-hardship-wearing-six-parkas-and-still-layering-extreme-sleet TV.

headline: Notes Show Confusion on Interrogation Methods
text: WASHINGTON  When military officers at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, struggled in the fall of 2002 to find ways to get terrorism suspects to talk, they turned to the one agency that had spent several months experimenting with the limits of physical and psychological pressure: the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Minnesota Woos Coen Brothers Film
text: New Yorkers may be blasé or hostile when it comes to film crews in their streets, but other places are willing to pay for the privilege. When Ethan and Joel Coen, coming off their best-picture Oscar for “No Country for Old Men,” were deciding between locations in Wisconsin and Minnesota for their next film, “A Serious Man,” Minnesota lawmakers came up with $500,000 to induce them to shoot in Minneapolis and St. Paul, The Associated Press reported. The Coen brothers  Ethan, above left, and Joel, right  are Minnesota natives.

headline: Drivers Turning to Lower-Grade Gas
text: ARLINGTON, Va.  As the price of fuel continues to climb, more drivers are trying to save 20 or so cents a gallon by using regular or midgrade gasoline, even when their owner’s manuals recommend premium.

headline: Shadows Grow Across One of Africa’s Bright Lights
text: DAKAR, Senegal  From the air, this sprawling city looks like a metropolis on the move, a buzzing quadrilateral jutting into the Atlantic. Cars speed along a supple, newly reconstructed four-lane highway that hugs the rugged coastline. Cranes dot the seaside, building luxury hotels and conference centers, as investors from Dubai revamp the city’s port, hoping to transform it into a high-tech regional hub.

headline: In Hard Times, the Truck Stop Offers a Place to Pray
text: BREEZEWOOD, Pa.  More than six million souls pass through this quarter-mile strip of all-night waffle houses and gas stations each year. The Rev. Shannon Rust hopes to save at least a few of them.

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Conviction of a Former Official Linked to Abramoff
text: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Tuesday overturned the conviction of a former Bush administration official caught up in a lobbying scandal, finding that part of the prosecution’s case was faulty and that the trial judge was wrong to exclude expert testimony for the defense.

headline: Canadian Court Hears Appeal of BCE Buyout
text: The Supreme Court of Canada reserved judgment on the Bell Canada leveraged buyout case after hearing about three hours of arguments on Tuesday.

headline: Report Sees Cost in Some Academic Gains
text: A new study argues that the nation’s focus on helping students who are furthest behind may have produced a Robin Hood effect, yielding steady academic gains for low-achieving students in recent years at the expense of top students.

headline: Cablevision Buys Sundance
text: The future of the Sundance Channel is being defined this week after Cablevision closed a deal to acquire it. Rainbow Media Holdings, a subsidiary of Cablevision, said on Tuesday that it had completed the acquisition of Sundance from NBC Universal, CBS and Robert Redford for $496 million. On Wednesday, Rainbow executives are scheduled to meet Sundance employees in New York. Rainbow officials plan to announce a new structure for the channel that is meant to unify it with Rainbow’s other cable entities, including IFC, according to two people involved in the negotiations who spoke on condition of anonymity because the announcements had not been made. Sundance and IFC both showcase independent films, and some analysts have speculated that Cablevision may try to merge the two channels, although this week’s announcement is expected to keep the brands separate.

headline: Cyd Charisse, 86, Silken Dancer of Movies, Dies
text: Cyd Charisse, the leggy beauty whose balletic grace made her a memorable partner for Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly in classic MGM musicals like “Singin’ in the Rain,” “The Band Wagon” and “Brigadoon,” died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was believed to be 86.

headline: Black Humor, Pageantry and Absurdity for Lunch
text: In the pressurized, volatile world of Wall Street, that finicky beast hope might die and be reborn untold times in a single trading session. It’s the ideal setting, in other words, in which to hold a funeral for optimism, and on Monday the Doorknob Company obliged, during a brief lunchtime performance in Bowling Green Park. No word yet on whether it subsequently held a resurrection ceremony.

headline: Randolph Says He Is ‘Stunned’ by Mets Firing
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Willie Randolph, fired as manager of the Mets in the early hours of the morning Tuesday, said he was “stunned” by the decision to let him go nearly three months into another disappointing season.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the efforts of opponents of abortion to petition for grand jury investigations of abortion providers misstated, in some editions, the surname of an opponent of pornography who used a similar tactic. He is Phillip Cosby, not Crosby.

headline: Despite Leaks Online and File Sharing, Lil Wayne’s New CD Is a Hit
text: In a year when album sales have fallen by another 11 percent after years of declines, the ailing record labels received good news Wednesday: “Tha Carter III” (Cash Money/Universal Mo- town), the new album by the rapper Lil Wayne, looks to be a rare blockbuster hit.

headline: Senator Viewed Mortgage Treatment as a ‘Courtesy’
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut said Tuesday that he was aware that Countrywide Financial Corporation had assigned him to a V.I.P. program in 2003 when he refinanced mortgages on his homes in Connecticut and Washington but that he and his wife “assumed” that “it was more of a courtesy thing.”

headline: World’s Refugee Count in 2007 Exceeded 11 Million, U.N. Says
text: GENEVA  The number of refugees crossing borders to escape conflict and persecution increased last year, and threatens to continue to grow because of factors like climate change and scarce resources, the United Nations refugee agency warned Tuesday.

headline: Austria: $21.5 Million Awarded in Fire
text: The Austrian authorities have awarded $21.5 million to the families of people caught in a deadly fire in November 2000 at the Kaprun ski resort. A cable car transporting skiers to the Kitzsteinhorn glacier caught fire in a tunnel, leading to the deaths of 155 people, among them Austrians, Germans, Japanese and Americans. Only 12 people survived. Relatives of victims will share the money, Austria’s compensation commission said.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Wine and Tapas

headline: Reruns Fuel TV Ratings
text: Reruns ruled the ratings once again on Monday, as Fox and CBS finished first and second for the night over all. According to Nielsen’s estimates, repeats of CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” and Fox’s “House” led the night, with the half-hour CBS sitcom drawing 8.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. and the Fox medical drama averaging 8.6 million viewers over the 9 p.m. hour. Fox edged past CBS for first place by winning the 8 p.m. time slot with a rerun of “Bones” (7 million). CBS led the 10 p.m. hour with a repeat of “CSI: Miami” (8 million). ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for third place over all. ABC earned decent ratings for “The Bachelorette” at 9 (6.9 million), but trailed with a “Bachelorette” special at 8 (5.9 million) and especially with “The Mole” at 10 (3.9 million). NBC broadcast “American Gladiators” at 8 (5.1 million), followed by “Nashville Star” from 9 to 10:30 (6.1 million), with a short edition of “Dateline” afterward (4.7 million).

headline: Sudan: Darfur Groups Urge U.N. Action
text: Representatives of about 15 groups focused on the crisis in Darfur met with the United Nations Security Council, urging it to add muscle to its many statements condemning Sudan. Mia Farrow, the public face of the group Dream for Darfur, said after the meeting that Sudan, backed by China, had blocked the deployment of enough peacekeeping troops by insisting that they all come from African nations.

headline: Horsemen Make Move to Stay Ahead of Congress
text: The Thoroughbred Safety Committee recommended Tuesday that steroids and toe grabs be banned and that new rules be implemented on the use of whips.

headline: Mourning After Queens Fire, and Searching for Cause in Makeup Artist’s Death
text: All day on Tuesday, the phones were ringing in Orlando Tobón’s office in Jackson Heights, Queens. The callers were actors and others in the movie industry saddened to hear of the death of Flor Marina Sandoval, a makeup artist killed on Sunday when a suspicious fire engulfed her home.

headline: Detroit’s Shrinking Sales Take a Toll on Dealerships
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  In the glory days of Detroit carmakers in the 1960s, Leonard J. Immke Jr. used to sell 200 new Buicks a month from his vast downtown showroom here filled with gleaming Electras, Rivieras and Skylarks.

headline: Whips and Scorns of Time, Stinging All They Touch
text: There is one breathtakingly poignant moment in the flat-footed “Hamlet” that opened Tuesday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. It’s the sad spectacle of seeing a human mind genuinely o’erthrown, of someone losing his hold on reality so completely that you gasp in pity and terror and think, “That could be me someday.”

headline: Traditional Media Not Dead Yet for Marketing, Study Says
text: A study to be released on Wednesday finds that advertisements appearing in traditional media like television are still “much more likely” to have made a positive impression with consumers than ads running in digital media.

headline: Oil + Climate + Politics = ?
text: [UPDATED, 6/18, 8 a.m.] For the first year of this long presidential race, there was little focus on energy, climate and the environment, presumably because polls and focus groups showed scant public concern about these issues. The last few weeks, and today in particular, have shown the power of high oil and gasoline prices to get politicians’ attention.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Rome
text: The Frugal Traveler crashes at a convent and takes a high-speed tour of the city by moped.

headline: Frugal Traveler: The Grand Tour
text: The Frugal Traveler crashes at a convent and takes a high-speed tour of the city by moped.

headline: Microsoft Buys TV Ad Technology Company
text: In the latest in a string of acquisitions aimed at expanding its digital advertising services, Microsoft said that it was buying Navic Networks, a maker of television advertising technology.

headline: The Celtics’ Path to a Championship
text: The Boston Celtics beat the Los Angeles Lakers in the 2008 N.B.A. Finals.

headline: Mrs. Obama’s Journey
text: Rather than pulling Michelle Obama behind a curtain, her husband’s campaign is pushing her farther out on stage.

headline: ‘The Delighted States’
text: Chapter 1

headline: The Face of Ordinary Things
text: Images found here.

headline: Redpoint Invests in Answers.com
text: Venture capital firms typically don’t take stakes in public companies.

headline: EU Gives Staples Thumbs Up for Corporate Express Deal
text: Office goods supplier Staples has won approval from the European Commission for its 1.7 billion euro ($2.64 billion) takeover bid for Dutch peer Corporate Express.

headline: In Latest Istallment, RHI Entertainment Prices Below Range
text: RHI Entertainment, a producer of TV miniseries, priced its initial public stock offering late Tuesday at $14 a share, below the $16-to-$18 range the company had hoped to get.

headline: Navios Maritime Seeks $220 Million in Spac I.P.O.
text: Navios Maritime Acquisition, a special purpose acquisition company seeking investments in transportation and logistics industries, on Tuesday filed with regulators to raise up to $220 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

headline: Kuwaiti Bank to Raise $500 Million for New Fund
text: Global Investment House, the Kuwaiti investment bank, on Tuesday announced plans to raise $500 million in an initial public offering for a new private equity fund that will invest in financial services companies across the Middle East and North Africa.

headline: Former Milberg Partner Sues One-Time Colleagues
text: A former partner at law firm Milberg Weiss, now known as Milberg, sued three of his former colleagues on Tuesday, claiming that their actions in a massive kickback scheme caused him serious professional and financial harm.

headline: Platinum Equity Unloads PNA for About $300 Million
text: Platinum Equity has agreed to sell metal processor PNA Group Holding to larger rival Reliance Steel & Aluminum for more than $300 million.

headline: Citigroup Offers Early Retirement for Those in Japanese Unit
text: Citigroup has offered early retirement to the 1,350 employees of its Japanese consumer finance unit, as the subprime-hit U.S. bank retreats from consumer lending in the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Ex-Citi Executive Said to Be Raising Cleantech Fund
text: Todd S. Thomson, the former head of Citigroup’s wealth management unit, is raising a targeted $3 billion for a new cleantech-focused private equity fund, according to VentureBeat, which cited a “tipster”.

headline: IControl Said to Tap Growthink to Help With $15 Million Round
text: iControl Systems has hired the Growthink investment bank to help it raise $15 million in a first round of venture capital, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Executive Questioned in EADS Insider Trading Case
text: The French authorities have detained another executive in connection with an insider trading investigation at European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the parent of the plane maker Airbus.

headline: Rebuffing Cadence Bid, Mentor Cites Antitrust Concerns
text: Mentor Graphics, chip design software maker, on Tuesday rejected a $1.6 billion unsolicited takeover bid from rival Cadence Design Systems, citing antitrust concerns and a price it said is too low.

headline: GSO and Monarch Said to Raise Funds for Distressed Investing
text: GSO Capital Partners, the hedge fund bought by the Blackstone Group earlier this year, and Monarch Alternative Capital are raising money to invest in distressed companies in anticipation that more borrowers will default as the U.S. economy weakens, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: EA Again Extends Offer, Take-Two Again Rebuffs
text: Take-Two Interactive Software has once again turned down an acquisition offer from Electronic Arts.

headline: Microsoft Picks Up Ad Tech Firm
text: Microsoft said on Wednesday it had purchased privately held digital television advertising technology company Navic Networks. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Sanofi Tables $2.57 Billion Counter-Bid for Zentiva
text: French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis plans to make a 40.04 billion Czech crown ($2.57 billion) offer for Czech drugmaker Zentiva, trumping a bid from financial group PPF.

headline: JPMorgan’s Top Film Banker to Cede Post, Report Says
text: JPMorgan Chase veteran David Shaheen has been appointed to succeed film-finance icon John Miller as head of the blue-chip firm’s entertainment banking group, with Mr. Miller to segue into a consulting role in 2009, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Activist Investor Raises Stake in UBS
text: Activist investor Olivant has raised its stake in Swiss bank UBS to 2.5 percent and said on Wednesday it had fully supported the recent rights issue.

headline: Once Again, Goldman Puts Rivals to Shame
text: Over the past year, one investment bank after another has let down Wall Street.

headline: MBIA Debt Is Setting Up a Quandary
text: The risks associated with the vast, unregulated market for credit default swaps played a crucial role in the bailout of Bear Stearns. Now these financial instruments are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.

headline: Big Banks Sued Over Sewer Bonds
text: A man in Jefferson County, Ala., has sued JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Keegan and 10 other banks, advisers and insurers, claiming their work on county bond transactions saddled residents with soaring sewer bills.

headline: Ford Says Kerkorian’s Investment Is a Sign of Confidence
text: After waging bitter battles with management at Chrysler and General Motors, the financier Kirk Kerkorian is off to a more peaceful start as a major shareholder in the Ford Motor Company.

headline: Some Support Remains for Icahn’s Yahoo Slate
text: Yahoo investors are showing more interest in an alternate board slate proposed by billionaire Carl C. Icahn that was first formed to deliver the company to Microsoft in a now-defunct buyout.

headline: Baghdad Bureau Q&A
text: Iraqi teenagers answer questions from readers.

headline: LinkedIn’s New $1 Billion Price Tag
text: For a Web site, it could hardly look less exciting. Its pages are heavy with text, much of it a flat blue, and there are few photos and absolutely no videos.

headline: ‘He’d Replace the White House Bowling Alley’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Barack Obama’s staff and John McCain’s staff are busy negotiating when the Presidential debates will take place. Obama wants them to be in September – and McCain wants them to be after his nap — but before “Wheel of Fortune.”

headline: Dennis Weatherstone, Former J.P. Morgan Chief, Dies
text: Dennis Weatherstone, who helped usher in a new era of banking during the early 1990s as chairman and chief executive at J.P. Morgan, died Friday near his home in Darien, Conn. He was 77.

headline: InBev Chief Says Anheuser-Busch Bid Is Its Best Offer
text: The head of Belgian brewer InBev, on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to promote his company’s takeover of Anheuser-Busch to skeptical lawmakers, told reporters the $65 per share offer is the highest it would bid.

headline: What Exactly Is a ‘Permanent Base’?
text: In the debate over the future American military role in Iraq, the Bush administration has held firm on one point in particular: there will be no permanent American bases in Iraq. Just last week, Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker denied a report in The Independent of London to the effect that the United States was building 50 “permanent” bases.

headline: Fifth Third to Cut Dividend and Raise Capital
text: Fifth Third Bancorp, a Cincinnati-based bank, said Wednesday it would cut its dividend by more than half and raise about $2 billion by selling convertible preferred stock and certain “noncore businesses.” It said it is taking the steps “to strengthen its capital position in light of continued deterioration in credit trends.”

headline: DreamWorks Said to Seek Deal for Independence
text: Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks SKG film studio may soon get a lift from Bollywood.

headline: ‘High Noon on the Streets of Carmel’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Morgan Stanley’s 2nd-Quarter Profit Falls 57%
text: Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that it earned $1.02 billion for its second quarter, as the firm saw declines in its core trading and investment banking operations.

headline: Commence To Laugh
text: Was your graduation ceremony boring? Try Harvard’s in 2000:

headline: The Early Word: Talking National Security
text: After a day when the McCain and Obama campaigns exchanged sharp barbs over the issues of terrorism, war and United States policy governing detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Senator Barack Obama plans to spend part of Wednesday discussing national security with a working group of former senior government officials.

headline: The Decline and Fall of the South Street Seaport
text: Conceding the failure of the South Street Seaport pier as a “festival marketplace” — these days, it is not much more than a waterfront mall — its owners plan to replace it with a mixed-use project including a 42-story, 495-foot apartment and hotel tower, wrapped in a terra-cotta exoskeleton and rising from new pilings in the East River, David W. Dunlap of The Times reports.The seaport plan speaks to the undiminished allure of riverfront sites and of developers’ faith that megaprojects can inject new life into, and create profit out of, areas where other visions have failed.

headline: Baselines, shmaselines
text: Wise words from the Tax Policy Center:

headline: Neighbors | Dominoes
text: In a new Lens series, the photographer Damon Winter of The Times uses double exposures to capture the endless juxtapositions in New York City. Read about how he creates these photographs.

headline: Quote Unquote | It’s a Gas
text: –Jim Ryan, the head of BMW’s hydrogen program, recalling the words of the actress Laura Dern upon test driving the automaker’s still-unreleased Hydrogen 7 series. Published in Dawn C. Chmielewski and Ken Bensinger’s story in the June 15 Los Angeles Times. When it comes to marketing the latest energy-inefficient alternative fuel du jour, all roads lead to Hollywood.

headline: ‘Weeds’ Season Debut Sets Showtime Ratings Record
text: The Hollywood Reporter: The Showtime comedy “Weeds” averaged 1.3 million total viewers for its fourth season premiere on Monday, “becoming the network’s most-watched telecast on record.” And the new series “Secret Diary of a Call Girl,” which led out of “Weeds” on Monday night, averaged 949,000 viewers.

headline: The Case for a Viacom Buyout, Again
text: A lot has changed since the summer of 2006, when leveraged buyouts were booming and most people had never heard of subprime mortgages. But at least one thing remains the same: Richard Greenfield, the outspoken stock analyst from Pali Research, still thinks Viacom would be better off as a private company.

headline: Microsoft’s Entrance Into The Targeted TV Advertising Arena
text: “Microsoft Corporation said Wednesday that it had acquired Navic Networks, which specializes in emerging forms of television advertising technology,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Wild Pitch
text: One of the more unlikely characters in the run-up to the Iraq war was “Curveball,” the Iraqi exile who fed the German intelligence agency, the BND, a healthy diet of unfounded information on Saddam Hussein’s weapons programs. Now John Goetz and Bob Drogin of The Los Angeles Times have done a little catching up with Curveball:

headline: Watching Michelle Obama on ‘The View’
text: Michelle Obama, third from left, on the set of “The View,” on Wednesday. From left are, Whoopi Goldberg, Joy Behar, Mrs. Obama, Sherri Shepard, Elisabeth Hasselbeck and Barbara Walters. (Photo: Steve Fenn/ABC)

headline: How Fast Is Too Fast?
text: On Sunday the Twins were trailing the Brewers by 3-2 with Brendan Harris leading off the eighth inning. After falling behind 0-2, Harris asked home plate umpire Brian Runge for time and seemed to think that he got it as he casually began to stride into the batter’s box and slowly began to set his feet. Runge, however, had not given him time and Milwaukee reliever Guillermo Mota threw a quick breaking ball for strike three before Harris knew what happened.

headline: Money for Needy Goes to Wealthy Schools, Report Says
text: Updated, 9 p.m. | Even as students, parents and teachers continue to protest school budget cuts, there is another debate brewing — just what makes a high-need school? The Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy group that successfully battled a 13-year lawsuit for billions of dollars more for New York City schools, released a report on Tuesday evening detailing how the city is spending roughly $230 million in new education money from the state.

headline: The Amazing Marcus Thames
text: The Tigers’ Marcus Thames has hit some impressive home runs in his career. As a Yankee, in his first major league at-bat in the summer of 2002, he drilled one off of Randy Johnson. And now he’s making memories for Detroit.

headline: Top-Paid Fund Manager Sees More Pain Ahead
text: If the recent wave of Wall Street write-downs has got you down, here’s a depressing thought: Imagine doing it all again. And then again.

headline: A New General in Oprah’s Army
text: Five months after Oprah Winfrey and Discovery Communications announced that they were planning a new cable channel, they have named the first executive for the joint venture.

headline: No sex please, we’re bananas
text: Good piece by Dan Koeppel. I highly recommend his book.

headline: On Travel Cases and Cycling Films
text: 18 Days to L’Étape. On the training schedule: The first of two travel days, after missing my workout last night due to a crush of work that had to get done before I leave the home office for training camp.

headline: 6 New Tainted Tomato Cases in City
text: Six new cases of an unusual form of salmonella linked to eating raw tomatoes have been confirmed in New York City, in addition to a previously known case, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said on Wednesday. In addition, Suffolk County announced that a 26-year-old West Babylon man also contracted the strain of salmonella from eating tomatoes at New York City on May 27.

headline: Living With Music: A Playlist by Luc Sante
text: Luc Sante’s most recent book is “Kill All Your Darlings,” a collection of essays.

headline: What’s Next for Take-Two
text: Call it the beginning of the endgame.

headline: ‘Al Gore. Think About It.’
text: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Al Gore has endorsed Barack Obama for president. Medical experts say this is great because it gives the Obama campaign a much needed shot of boredom.

headline: F.D.A. Takes Aim at Herbal Cancer ‘Cures’
text: With ingredients like bloodroot, shark cartilage and Cat’s Claw and assertions like “causes cancer cells to commit suicide,” it’s no wonder the Food and Drug Administration is taking notice.

headline: A Day of Weddings in California
text: The scene at West Hollywood Park, on the first day that all 58 counties in California began issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

headline: Severe Flooding in the Midwest
‘Carnivals Are Closing Down’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Gay marriage now legal here in California. In fact, you hear who got married today in San Francisco? Rice and Roni. Yeah, finally got married.

headline: On Past a Petaflop
text: Almost two decades ago, Kendall Square Research, an ill-fated Massachusetts start-up company, hinted at the future by making the microprocessors for its KSR-1 massively parallel supercomputer on the same chip-making factory production line that made the processor chip that powered the Sharp Wizard, one of the first P.D.A.’s.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Yucatán Fish With Crisp Garlic
text: I was served this dish at a restaurant in a fishing village in Mexico called Telchac Puerto, where the road ends at a lighthouse, a pier and the Gulf of Mexico. There were good ceviches, and corny, handmade tortillas. Then there was this: fish cooked in what seemed to be a quart of lime juice, with chilies, tomatoes and cilantro, all garnished with toasted garlic.

headline: Yankees Scream for Ice Cream
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Answer This
text: A couple of weeks ago, I reviewed free cellphone information services like ChaCha. ChaCha lets you speak a question — and then, a minute later, the answer arrives on your cellphone as a text message, having been researched by a human operator.

headline: What’s Behind the Stupid Face Spam Scourge?
text: What a stupid face you have.

headline: The Biggest (Water) Pump Wins
text: Economy | T. Boone Pickens thinks the era of fossil fuels is over. He’s into water now, so much so that the oilman and corporate raider is being called the John D. Rockefeller of H2O. He owns more water than anyone else in the country and is looking to control even more. — Business Week

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 72 Indiana
text: Location: Bloomington, Ind.

headline: New Housing Woes for Ex-Citi Chief
text: Charles O. Prince III just can’t seem to escape the real-estate slowdown. The former chief executive of Citigroup, ousted last year amid the troubles emanating from the bursting of the mortgage bubble, is now finding it hard to flush out a buyer for his own home, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: The Allure of the Savory Popsicle
text: One line that was (rightly) edited out of this week’s Minimalist column was this: “You could probably mix chicken stock and soy sauce, freeze it on a stick, and get a pretty interesting popsicle out of it.” That was tongue-in-cheek, but only half so; the point is that savory popsicles can be quite refreshing, and one based on tamarind with very little or no sugar is quite popular in Mexico. I’m wondering what experiences the Bitten community has had with odd-flavored frozen ices, whether on a stick or not.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Tauk
text: Tauk boutique in Montauk, N.Y. (Kathleen Doran)

headline: To Condi
text: Israeli TV announcers have coined the American Secretary of State’s nickname as a verb — “to Condi” — meaning to go endlessly around in circles, accomplishing nothing. She’s made 22 largely futile trips to Israel during the Bush Administration’s eight years. — Time’s Middle East blog.

headline: The Wider Wake of Tree Damage
text: By writing in detail on Tuesday about the tree loss in Central Park from last week’s storm, City Room did not mean to imply that the serious wind damage was in any way limited to that great expanse at the heart of Manhattan. (In fact, I watched a tree out of my own living-room window on West 62nd Street nearly blown over by a punishing and prolonged gust.)

headline: Help Desk | A Wallpaper Update
text: Wallpapers from left, Rentogen in Fire by Wook Kim, Paradise by designyourwall.com

headline: Wandering Beyond Classic Rome
text: The evening began like any other in Piazza San Lorenzo in Lucina, an elongated trapezoid of cobblestones in the center of Rome. Nannies and their charges lounged under the 12th-century portico of the piazza’s namesake church. An elegant man in a crisp shirt steered his bicycle in lazy figure eights. Well-appointed women emerged from Louis Vuitton and Bottega Veneta to clack their high heels over to the three outdoor bars at the wide end of the piazza.

headline: As Japan Ages …
text: BRIEFS A perhaps inevitable headline from a full-fledged aged society: “Japan’s Booming Sex Niche: Elder Porn.” [Time Magazine]

headline: LinkedIn Joins Billion Dollar Club
text: CNBC interviews Dan Nye, LinkedIn's chief exective, on getting a fresh round of venture capital.

headline: Bush on Offshore Oil Drilling
text: CNBC coverage of a speech by President Bush in which he called on Congress to lift the ban on offshore oil drilling.

headline: Standards Issues
text: My week of blog-based exploration of this subject ends today. It has been a fascinating ride. Thanks to all who have taken time to read and comment and argue.

headline: Don’t worry, be happy?
text: Via Tyler Cowen, I learn that there’s a paper, regressions and all, evaluating how happy economists look. Yes, I’m in there — and I cry foul.

headline: Mother’s Diet May Affect Daughter’s Puberty
text: What you eat during pregnancy and nursing may affect the age at which your daughter starts puberty, suggests a new animal study.

headline: Restaurant Workers Await Wage Settlement
text: Waiters and other workers at Shelly’s Prime Steak, Cafe Fiorello, the Redeye Grill and other Manhattan restaurants have accused ownership, the Fireman Hospitality Group, of wage violations, and are hoping that a federal judge will approve a $3.9 million settlement on Wednesday. Two lawsuits against the Fireman Group assert that it systematically ignored federal and state wage and hour laws by often erasing hours that employees worked, not paying minimum wage, giving managers part of the tip pool and docking employees’ paychecks when their customers walked out without paying.

headline: Seaport Plan Faces a Major Roadblock
text: A significant figure in the review and approval process facing the proposal to redevelop Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport, Councilman Alan J. Gerson, said Wednesday morning that the plan is “certainly not going to pass in its present form.”“I’m not a soothsayer,” he added, “but I’m confident in that.”

headline: Before and After: Bank Robbers
text: BRIEFS An elegy of sorts for a crime that is experiencing a restoration in terms of quantity if not quality. These days, “the desperate, the dumb, and more often than not, the drug-addicted” are behind most bank robberies, not celebrity-criminals like Bonnie and Clyde, Mental Floss argues on its excellent blog. The post cites several examples of underwhelming felons of late, but they really need not look further than less-than-glamorous duo Thomas and Rose Marie Uva. The young married couple showed little fear in sticking up New York Mafiosi in the 1990’s, but they also showed little savvy as well. Before they were found dead, they earned a nickname on the streets: Bonnie and Clyde. [Mental Floss]

headline: Debate Over Auctioning of Airport Landing Slots
text: The Bush administration’s decision to impose caps on flights at the three major airports in the New York area, and its plans to auction landing slots at the three airports in a first-of-its-kind experiment to handle congestion, are the subject of intense debate at a House subcommittee hearing in Washington.Senator Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat who has been a persistent critic of the Department of Transportation and the Federal Aviation Administration, excoriated both agencies on Wednesday morning, saying the Bush administration had resorted to “ideological, market-based theory,” while doing little to fill vacancies among air-traffic controllers.

headline: Jay Adelson Diggs the A.P.
text: UPDATE | 4:42 PM Jay Adelson has posted a comment with some further thoughts here.

headline: Oil Crunch Trumping Climate Concerns?
text: In 2006, I interviewed dozens of experts on energy, climate, and the economy for a story in our ongoing Energy Challenge series, and more than a few warned then that, in the world of politics and policy, the need to deal with a growing global oil crunch could well trump the need to curb greenhouse gases and limit long-term climate risks.

headline: MBIA: The Debate Rages On
text: There’s been plenty of heated talk lately about MBIA, the big bond insurer that has fallen on hard times. Much of the discussion is about whether or not the company has enough capital to cover its future losses.

text: From The Oil Drum.

text: Ed, a Bitten contributor, on a nice way to serve white asparagus. –MB

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Scary Trading Surprises
text: Morgan Stanley‘s second-quarter earnings managed to beat Wall Street estimates by a couple of cents per share — but investors weren’t very happy Wednesday. The broker-dealer’s stock was down as much as 4 percent in the afternoon, although the loss later narrowed to about 1 percent.

headline: Offshore Drilling vs. Global Warming
text: Are environmentalists doing themselves — or the environment — any favor by denying states the right to decide whether there should be oil drilling off their shores?

headline: ABC Extends Jimmy Kimmel’s Contract
text: The late-night host Jimmy Kimmel will remain at ABC through at least 2010. The network confirmed Wednesday that it had extended his contract by one year. The extension was first reported by DailyVariety.

headline: America May Have Talent, But ABC’s Got Basketball
text: The two-hour debut of “America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC in the ratings on Tuesday as 12.8 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. to watch the show’s third season get under way, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Missouri Senator Urges Rejection of InBev Offer
text: Anheuser-Busch seems to be brewing up strong resistance to a potential takeover by a foreign suitor.

headline: Will The Times Survive Rupert Murdoch?
text: There’s been so much written about the crisis in the newspaper industry that it’s hard to imagine why anyone would want to read yet another article on it. But Mark Bowden’s “Mr. Murdoch Goes to War,” in the July/August issue of The Atlantic, has a couple of things in its favor: it’s deeper than most takes on the subject — more analysis, less whine — and it provides a layered portrait of Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Licence to Drill

headline: A Skyscraper Scaler Strikes Again
text: FRANKFURT — Lest the office workers at The New York Times Building think their recent encounter with the French stunt climber Alain Robert was something special, he’s already made his next conquest: Dresdner Bank’s 32-story tower in Frankfurt, which he scaled on Wednesday evening.

headline: Louisiana: Closing an Abusive “Center for Youth”
text: Conditions in American prisons are grim, and the inmates are rarely given the help they need to turn their lives around on release. In the correctional world, juvenile facilities are often among the bleakest facilities. And among juvenile facilities, Louisiana’s Jetson Center for Youth stands out for its awfulness.

headline: Obama Camp Apologizes to Muslim Women
text: Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign has apologized for keeping Muslim women wearing headscarves out of a key shot at his Detroit event.

headline: They’ll Have It No Way
text: In a publicity stunt in Britain, Burger King’s going for the Guinness record for world’s most expensive burger. So for 95 pounds (roughly $186) you get flame-grilled wagyu beef topped with white truffles in an Iranian saffron and truffle bun. But some say it won’t make their value menu:

headline: Palestinians Scrutinizing Palestinians
text: Israelis sometimes complain, with some justification, of a double standard: When Israeli troops beat up Arabs, then the world cries foul, but when Arab troops kill Arabs, almost no one notices.

headline: Insights on Reinventing Retirement
text: A new survey conducted by Civic Ventures and the MetLife Foundation shows that the idea of reinventing retirement is not just something that people talk about, but is something they are already doing.

headline: Saluting Some Military Heroes
text: One of the most shameful episodes of the post 9/11 era has been the way the U.S. Government — particularly the Pentagon under Don Rumsfeld — oversaw the torture and abuse of supposed terror suspects, even though there often was little or no serious evidence against them. We’ll remember Guantanamo the way we remember the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.

headline: Should Undercover Patients Check Up on Doctors?
text: The nation’s leading doctor group has temporarily shelved a plan to allow so-called “secret shoppers” to monitor patient care in hospital waiting rooms and doctors’ offices.

headline: Protectionism or Fairness?
text: The Government Accountability Office is out with a statement that backs Boeing in its bitter protests over the award of an Air Force tanker contract to Airbus, its European rival, which paired with Northrop Grumman to submit a bid.

headline: Ex-Hostage on Algerian Terror Group
text: Released hostage recounts kidnapping by the GSPC.

headline: From Beer to Ethanol to Your Car
text: Last week, Leslie Wayne reported on our sister blog, The Caucus, reported that all official vehicles at the Democratic National Convention in Denver in August will be fueled by ethanol derived from beer, of all things.

headline: Nascar’s Latest Detour on the Road to Diversity
text: Auto racing’s search for fresh talent has expanded in recent years to include women and minorities, as a sport long dominated by white men — at least in the United States — looks to broaden its demographic appeal.
