headline: Mama Said There’ll Be Days Like This
text: The Shirelles’ song was playing while I was standing in line to buy lunch yesterday at the little sandwich shop across from the hotel where the Mets are staying in California. You may imagine, it was an apt soundtrack for the day.

headline: Gunman Captured After Fleeing Into School
text: Updated, 6:14 p.m. | An armed robbery suspect running from police officers in Brooklyn on Wednesday afternoon touched off a tense few moments when he fled into an elementary school shortly before dismissal time, the authorities said. Officials evacuated some of the students and staff of the school after the 32-year-old gunman, who was not immediately identified by name, sought cover inside Public School 108, the Sal Abbracciamento Landmark School, at 200 Linwood Street, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Today': Summer Soups

headline: Willets Point Company Agrees to Sell Its Land
text: Updated, 6:12 p.m. | An auto salvage company in the Willets Point enclave near Shea Stadium has agreed to sell its property to the city, breaking ranks with other large business owners in the neighborhood that have been fighting plans to raze most of the buildings and replace them with $3 billion worth of development.

headline: Obama Convenes National Security Team
text: At the first meeting of his national security working group, Barack Obama once again sought to link John McCain’s approach to foreign policy to what he called “the failed policies of the Bush administration.”

text: Decades of declining market share have left the Detroit automakers with too many stores and too few customers to keep all of them open.

text: In today’s Dining section Mark Bittman tells you how easy it is to make your own paletas, Mexican popsicles. My suggestion for enjoying them takes more effort.

headline: The Other Shoe Drops in Canada
text: BRIEFS Guess what’s been turning up in a “place where you would [not] expect to find a bunch of severed feet“? In today’s update, a fifth foot was found on the shore of islands to the south of Vancouver, Canada. By definition, the odd number left something missing in this grisly and mysterious trend. And sure enough, a sixth foot was found by the end of the day.

headline: Beautiful Is Beautiful
text: For the July issue of Italian Vogue, Steven Meisel, one of the most influential photographers in fashion, has photographed only black models.

headline: Mixed Blessing
text: Far from the storied hollows of Appalachia, and well before the Rev. Jeremiah Wright lit up the cable news channels or the “elitist” label was fixed to Barack Obama’s lapel right where his flag pin ought to have been, a group of older white voters drew a firm line on his candidacy. On Feb. 5, Mr. Obama prevailed by just 10,000 votes in Missouri, a general election swing state. His victory margin was cramped by the fact that he lost white voters over age 60 by nearly 40 percentage points, 67 percent to 28 percent. And it had nothing to do with bowling.

headline: Pessimism In the Executive Suite
text: Chief Financial Officers are no longer quite so sure the economy will get worse. But they are a long way from optimistic.

headline: Hexion Sues Huntsman to End Merger
text: Hexion Specialty Chemicals and its owner, the buyout firm Apollo Management, sued the Huntsman Corporation on Wednesday to end their $10.6 billion merger, dragging yet another deal into a court battle.

headline: Image Control
text: “Two Muslim women at Barack Obama’s rally in Detroit on Monday were barred from sitting behind the podium by campaign volunteers seeking to prevent the women’s head scarves from appearing in photographs or on television with the candidate,” reports Ben Smith of the Politico. “The campaign has apologized to the women, both Obama supporters who said they felt betrayed by their treatment at the rally.”

headline: The Danes, Kings of Coffee
text: Tomorrow is the start of the World Barista Championship, five days of caffeinated competition in Copenhagen, Denmark.

headline: Taser Limits Urged for Canadian Police
text: A little more than a week after Tasers suffered a rare loss in a California court and then a strong endorsement in New York city, a government watchdog urged an overhaul to the weapon’s use among The Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

text:
Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Brink Lindsey of the Cato Institute look at the parallels between the Iraq and Vietnam wars.

headline: Answers About City Room, Part 2
text: This week, Sewell Chan, bureau chief of City Room, is answering selected questions from readers about the blog, which began publication a year ago this week. Mr. Chan joined The Times in 2004 and previously covered transportation and City Hall for the Metro staff. Readers were invited to ask about any topic that City Room has covered — or ought to cover — as well as the blog’s practices, philosophy, design and policies. We are no longer taking questions for this feature.

headline: At Home Abroad: Argentina
text: An American discovers Buenos Aires after much turmoil, including her own.

headline: Hitting From Both Sides of the Wicket
text: Cricket’s history dates back to the 16th century, but it was not until last Sunday that the sport had its first switch hitter. In a one day victory over New Zealand, Kevin Pietersen of England hit from both the left and right sides of the wicket. One of the charms of looking at cricket from this side of the Atlantic is the confusing nomenclature of the game and they don’t let us down this time, referring to switch hitting as a “reverse slog-sweep”.

headline: Leave the Wives Alone, Candidates Say
text: Even the Christian Broadcasting Network can’t escape the back-and-forth of the presidential campaign.

headline: Beauty and Soul
text: As some of you may have heard through the grape vine, the July issue of Italian Vogue will have only black models, and all the features are related to black women in the arts and entertainment. Considering the displays of tokenism on the runways last season—Jourdan Dunn at Prada, and in only one look—an entire issue devoted to black models could be seen as making hay of a controversy. I’ll let you be the judge. The issue will be on newsstands in Europe next Thursday, and after in the States. Steven Meisel did the fashion pictures, about 100 in all, and I think they are some of the best he’s done. They are crazily, softly beautiful, plainly the work of someone who knows women and fashion, has looked at both a long time, and when I spoke to Meisel the other day—for a piece in the Times tomorrow—I admitted I didn’t recognize Tyra Banks in one of the portraits. She’s wearing a soft head wrap, and her head is tilted back.

headline: Your Comments on my Gaza Column
text: My Thursday column is about the siege of Gaza, which I argue was both wrong and counter-productive. Before you hit the comment button, however, I have one plea.

headline: Surviving the Hits
text: A couple of weekends ago I began what I call my “bread-and-butter” touring season. I had two shows, one in Long Island and one in Saratoga, N.Y. I had a raging head cold, but made it through and came home to check on a few days worth of e-mails.

text: Explosives stowed in a minibus obliterated part of a bustling marketplace and set ablaze a crowded apartment building.

text: Two teams — the Red Bulls (4-4-4, 16 points) and the Eastern Conference-leading New England Revolution (8-3-3, 27) — heading in opposite directions were on the (plastic) field at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass., in another midweek game in Major League Soccer. They ended the match — a 1-1 draw — in virtually the same place they started.

headline: Thorns and Flowers
text: Q. We want a rose hedge to screen the road that goes by our Hudson Valley weekend home. Can you suggest something hardy, deerproof and low maintenance? Ever-blooming would be nice too.

text: JERUSALEM  Israel offered on Wednesday to start direct peace talks with Lebanon, saying all issues would be negotiable, including a tiny, disputed piece of Israeli-held land on the countries’ border.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on June 6 about federal inquiries into accounts held by Americans in the Swiss bank UBS and other foreign banks that maintain a high level of secrecy referred incorrectly to a tax form required of American clients of such banks. While the client must fill out a W-9 tax form, it is submitted to the bank, not to the Internal Revenue Service, and it discloses name, address and taxpayer identification number, not securities and assets held abroad.

headline: The Country Dream
text: COPAKE FALLS, N.Y.

headline: Randolph Implies Minaya Misled Him About Status
text: The five-hour trip to New York from Los Angeles provides ample time for introspection. Especially if you are Willie Randolph, now the former Mets manager.

headline: Effigies and Aliens Cavort in a Cross-Dressing Wonderland
text: Eat your heart out, Madonna. The chanteuses who play Madison Square Garden and football stadiums have never experienced the imaginative heights of spectacle with which Basil Twist surrounds Joey Arias in “Arias With a Twist,” which opened Wednesday night at the newly renovated Here Arts Center.

headline: Network Storage Comes Home, Not Without Some Difficulty
text: EXTERNAL hard drives, made for people with vast music, photo and video collections, come with instructions even a novice could love: plug the drive into a computer and away you go. Consumers and small businesses bought more than 40 million storage devices connected by U.S.B. or FireWire, some at prices as low as $200 for a terabyte of storage.

headline: Another American Team Receives a Title Sponsor
text: The sport of cycling, left for dead by some sponsors, fans and news media organizations because of doping scandals, received a breath of life Wednesday when Garmin announced it would be the title sponsor of Team Slipstream-Chipotle, one of two American-based teams competing in next month’s Tour de France.

headline: After a Little Boy’s Death, Grief and Regret at Missed Clues
text: Kyle Smith’s deflated body lay in a small white coffin piled with stuffed animals, a bruise still visible on his right cheek. All evening, scores of teary friends and relatives consoled his ashen father, a doorman in Manhattan’s financial district, and his sobbing mother, a newly married restaurant manager now living in South Carolina.

headline: E.U. Passes Tough Migrant Measure
text: STRASBOURG, France  European Union lawmakers voted Wednesday to allow undocumented migrants to be held in detention centers for up to 18 months and banned from European Union territory for five years.

headline: Many Guns Go Missing From Shops, Study Says
text: WASHINGTON  More than 30,000 firearms are unaccounted for in gun dealers’ inventories nationwide, according to a new study by a gun control group.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Tuesday about the Tony Awards misspelled the given name of a writer quoted by Mark Rylance, who won the Tony for best actor in a play (“Boeing-Boeing”), in his acceptance speech. He is Louis Jenkins, not Lewis.

headline: Time Runs Out for Execution in Texas
text: HOUSTON — A day of desperate filings climaxed at midnight on Wednesday when prison officials ran out of time to carry out the execution of a Texas death row inmate who had lost his last-minute bids for a stay.

headline: Broader Role for Federal Reserve Sought
text: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., asked policy makers in a speech on Thursday to move swiftly to give greater tools and authority to the Federal Reserve to handle financial crises.

headline: Cyd Charisse
text: There is an extraordinary joy in watching Cyd Charisse dancing with her lingerie  perhaps her finest partner  in “Silk Stockings.” You remember the story. Ninotchka, a stern Soviet commissar played by Charisse, comes to Paris to retrieve three wayward Soviet emissaries and is wooed by an American, played by Fred Astaire, and the city itself. “Silk Stockings” was released in July 1957, which makes it post-McCarthy but pre-Sputnik. As an expression of personal détente, it is hard to beat Charisse’s erotic, fluttering pas de deux with the Parisian undergarments she has hidden around her hotel room. It is an ode to shame and the setting aside of shame.

headline: Will $4 Gasoline Trump a 27-Year-Old Ban?
text: WASHINGTON  One was an oilman from Texas, the other a high-paid energy executive. Despite that, or perhaps because of it, for seven years George W. Bush and Dick Cheney have been unable to persuade Congress and the public that domestic oil drilling is an answer to America’s energy needs.

headline: Driving Less, Americans Finally React to Sting of Gas Prices, a Study Says
text: HOUSTON  As the price of gasoline quadrupled over the last decade, American drivers seemed to defy the laws of economics by pumping more into their vehicles year after year.

headline: Audit Says Tanker Deal Is Flawed
text: In a stunning turnabout for the Boeing Company, government auditors on Wednesday upheld the company’s appeal of the Air Force’s decision to award a $35 billion contract to build midair refueling tankers to a partnership of Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus.

headline: Mr. Smith Goes to War With KBR
text: In the annals of Iraq war profiteering, put Charles Smith down as one of the casualties. headline: Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Who Helped Sotheby’s Out of Morass, Dies at 67

Take your pants off.”

headline: What to Ask About Foot and Ankle Pain

Anderson, chief of foot and ankle surgery at Carolinas Medical Center in Charlotte, N.C., and president-elect of the American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society, suggests you might ask your doctor, along with notes on why they are important.

text: The political action committees of the liberal political group MoveOn and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees together paid more than $500,000 to run this advertisement this week in Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, and on CNN and MSNBC.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on June 7 about Senator Barack Obama’s stance on an undivided Jerusalem misstated his position. He said in an interview on CNN that a return to separate Israeli- and Arab-controlled sectors, the situation prevailing before 1967, would be “very difficult to execute.” He did not say that about maintaining an undivided Jerusalem.

text: Q. I need to make a quick Web site  is there any downside to using one of the free site-creation services instead of finding a Web host and getting someone to design the pages?

headline: Woods to Have Knee Surgery, Ending His Season
text: A 2008 golf season that many believed would be Tiger Woods’s best has instead become his briefest. Two days after his epic victory in the 108th United States Open, Woods announced that he would have surgery to repair damage to the anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee and would miss the rest of the season.

headline: Russert’s Son Sounds a Theme of Unity at Funeral
text: WASHINGTON  In death, Tim Russert did on Wednesday what no living journalist has accomplished this campaign season: he got Barack Obama and John McCain to sit together and talk, quietly.

headline: Idea of Offshore Drilling Seems to Be Spreading
