headline: Fallout From Bad Loans Rocks Regional Banks
text: In Ohio, the Panic of 1907 drove the Fifth National Bank into the arms of the Third National Bank, creating the singularly named Fifth Third Bank of Cincinnati.

headline: Britain: Chief Out at Woolworths
text: Woolworths Group, the British retailer, said its chief executive, Trevor Bish-Jones, would leave after six years in the position. The timing of the departure was the board’s decision, the chairman, Richard North, said during a conference call. Woolworths also reported a decline in sales and announced the sale of four stores for £25.5 million ($49.8 million). Sales have fallen for four consecutive years at Woolworths stores open at least 12 months. Mr. Bish-Jones, left, will stay in his post for three months while a successor is sought, Woolworths said.

headline: Her Feminine Mystique
text: Because the archetypal women in Daphne Guinness’s short film, “The Phenomenology of Body,” revolve on turntables, it is somehow easier to think of her as a D.J. than as a director. Because the chic images she assembled appear in some sense random, it seems appropriate to think of her as more a sampler than any kind of auteur. And because the story depicting women through the ages is, as its creator points out, not exactly linear and only accidentally feminist, it is easy to see in it hints of autobiography, the personal history of a slightly anachronistic sort of being, less actor than spectator, a woman upon whom the events of life impress themselves.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A Calendar listing on Wednesday about a tasting of spirits, many of them organic, at Counter, 105 First Avenue (Sixth Street), misstated its date. The tasting will be on Saturday, not Friday, from noon to 4 p.m.

headline: Taiwan’s Leader Outlines His Policy Toward China
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan  President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan called on Wednesday for a rapid expansion of economic relations between Taiwan and mainland China over the next year or two that would go far beyond the weekend charter flights and increased tourism announced last Friday.

headline: When the American Dream Gets Lost in a Giant Storm
text: Lois Weaver is a playful pixie of performance art. When, at the start of “Miss America,” she approaches the front of the audience from the back row, clambering over people and snapping pictures of them, she conveys a delightful sense of mischief. Offering mild recriminations (“You never told me that you don’t really love anyone,” “You never told me that you romanticize poverty”), she is a Park Avenue Kaye Ballard in a tiara, bob wig, black dress and a matronly knee-length coat. Onstage she joins Peggy Shaw  a frequent partner of Ms. Weaver’s since 1981 in the Split Britches troupe  who suggests a Bill Irwin clown in her jaunty loose-fitting suit with pants too short.

headline: Morgan Stanley Reports 58% Decrease in Profit
text: The investment bank Morgan Stanley, with its core securities trading business continuing to reel from the tight credit market, reported a 58 percent decrease in net profit on Wednesday.

headline: Art Pranksters Punished
text: The cost of superimposing a nuclear mushroom cloud on a television weather report in the Czech Republic: 50,000 koruna, or about $3,210. That was the fine meted out on Wednesday to each of three artists who hacked into a broadcast of Czech Television’s CT2 channel for 39 seconds last June, Agence France-Presse reported. Seven members of the Ztohoven art collective were acquitted of charges of scaremongering in March, a decision that prosecutors have appealed. The artists have said they were trying to draw attention to the network’s failure to carry out its public broadcasting mission.

headline: The Catch Phrase Is ‘à La Carte’ as Airlines Push Additional Fees
text: Airlines are adding fees and surcharges on top of rising fares. They would like travelers to embrace them as “à la carte pricing.”

headline: Russia in Quarterfinals
text: Russia defeated Sweden, 2-0, on Wednesday in Innsbruck, Austria, to secure the final spot in the quarterfinals of the European Championship.

headline: On a June Day in Philadelphia, a Bit of October Was in the Air
text: Philadelphia

headline: Obama’s Campaign Tightens Control of Image and Access
text: At a rally for Senator Barack Obama in Detroit on Monday, two Muslim women said they were prohibited from sitting behind the candidate because they were wearing head scarves and campaign volunteers did not want them to appear with him in news photographs or live television coverage.

headline: Con Ed Urged to Improve Its Response to Gas Leaks
text: State investigators looking into a fatal gas explosion in November in Queens suggested on Wednesday ways that Consolidated Edison and the New York City Fire Department can better coordinate their response to gas leaks.

headline: Standards of Free Speech, in the U.S. and Abroad
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Ankle: The Last Frontier in Replaceable Body Parts
text: Dr. John G. Kennedy, assistant professor of orthopedic surgery at Weill Medical College of Cornell University, is clinical director of the running clinic in the gait laboratory at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York. He is a specialist in sports medicine of the lower limb.

headline: Similar End, but Different Reaction From Bryant
text: BOSTON  Kobe Bryant’s 12-month journey began with anger and frustration and ended with anger and frustration, although he seemed to enjoy the ride well enough.

headline: U.S. Blames Shiite Leader for Deadly Baghdad Blast
text: BAGHDAD  The American military on Wednesday blamed a Shiite militia leader for detonating a car bomb that killed 63 people in a Shiite district a day earlier, saying he had intended to set off sectarian violence against Sunnis returning to the area as security improved.

headline: Tons of PCBs May Come Calling at a Down-at-the-Heels Texas City
text: PORT ARTHUR, Tex.  This downtrodden chemical town on the Gulf of Mexico has no shortage of nicknames: Cancer Alley, the Armpit of Texas, Ring of Fire.

headline: Realizing a Dream Deferred
text: SOME architects  seething with frustration as the spires they once imagined springing from their pencils vanish in the daily grind of the pencil sharpener  wait their whole lives to work on one dream project.

headline: Abu Sayyaf Releases News Crew in Philippines
text: MANILA  Abu Sayyaf militants have released members of a news team they abducted in the southern Philippines last week, among them one of the country’s best-known television journalists, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Dearth of Ships Delays Drilling of Offshore Oil
text: As President Bush calls for repealing a ban on drilling off most of the coast of the United States, a shortage of ships used for deep-water offshore drilling promises to impede any rapid turnaround in oil exploration and supply.

headline: High-Profile Lineup for Atlantic Theater
text: The Atlantic Theater Company has announced its 2008-9 season, and look who’s back: John Gallagher Jr., Martin McDonagh and Ethan Coen. Mr. Gallagher (who won a Tony for featured actor in “Spring Awakening,” which moved uptown from the Atlantic) will be starring in Beau Willimon’s new play, “Farragut North,” which had been rumored to be associated with Second Stage and then Broadway, as well as with Mike Nichols and Jake Gyllenhaal. It is scheduled to open under Doug Hughes’s direction in October. Along with the Druid Theater in Galway, Ireland, the Atlantic will produce a revival of Mr. McDonagh’s play “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” first seen in New York at the Public Theater in 1998. Garry Hynes, who directed Mr. McDonagh’s “Beauty Queen of Leenane” in 1998 at the Atlantic (and later on Broadway, where it won a Tony), will be directing this revival. Finally, Mr. Coen, whose “Almost an Evening” opened at the theater in January, is back with a new work, “Offices,” which will be directed by the Atlantic’s artistic director, Neil Pepe. At the Atlantic’s Stage 2 theater, David Pittu, who was nominated for acting Tonys the last two years, will perform his own work, “What’s That Smell: The Music of Jacob Sterling.”

headline: Selected Studies: Foot and Ankle Pain
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Shorn Under a Good Sign
text: IF you pay attention as you rush through the streets, you will find constant inspiration in the hilariously ambitious, unintentionally poetic signage on the awnings and doors of small, scrappy businesses. Many of our city’s best signs come from nail or beauty salons. Diva Nails, Salon Mingle, Skillz, Confetti of Nail. Chinatown, near the Manhattan Bridge, has one of my favorites: Amy Artistic Hair, written in dingy pink. Simple, sweet, weird. I love it.

headline: U.S. and China Agree to Ease Foreign Investment
text: WASHINGTON  China and the United States, concluding two days of high-level economic talks, announced Wednesday that they would step up their cooperation on energy and the environment and also try to negotiate a new treaty to ban discriminatory practices that block foreign investments in both countries.

headline: Shopping for Dishware With Sarah Cihat
text: WHEN she’s not busy at her kiln, Sarah Cihat, a ceramist based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, can often be found in thrift stores, scavenging for piles of plates. Ms. Cihat is the designer of Rehabilitated Dishware  old ceramic dishes given new life with fresh patterns and glazing  as well as her own line of porcelain bowls, cups and vases made from scratch.

headline: Testing and Learning
text: To get the well-educated, highly skilled workers that the country needs, states must strengthen public school curriculums, especially in math and science. States also need to adopt high-quality tests that show how students are performing from year to year.

headline: Lifted by Win, Mets Hope Rut Leaves With Manager
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – Less than 48 hours after their manager had left town, the Mets packed their belongings late Wednesday night hoping they had also left behind something else: the aimless, indifferent baseball team they'd been the first 2½ months of the season.

headline: Center of the Universe (in the Auction World)
text: New York was the center of the Copernican universe on Tuesday when a first edition of his “De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium” (“On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres”) sold at auction to a commercial buyer in Britain for more than $2.2 million, nearly double Christie’s high estimate of $1.2 million. The 1543 edition, in which Copernicus put forth his theory that the Earth rotates around the Sun, was among 300 books from the collection of Richard Green, a retired physician and amateur astronomer, which fetched just more than $11 million, a Christie’s spokeswoman said. An 1878 directory for the world’s first commercial telephone system, published in New Haven, sold for $170,500 to a private buyer in the United States.

headline: Crisis and Renewal
text: Buenos Aires

headline: NATO and Afghan Troops Clash With Taliban
text: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan  Using helicopter gunships, NATO and Afghan forces battled Taliban insurgents on Wednesday in this strategic district just a few miles north of the city of Kandahar.

headline: For Your Distorted Pleasure
text: THE affair was bizarre, even by the often loopy standards of a fashion show: art world notables sauntering down a makeshift runway wearing bulbous protuberances and looking like nothing so much as strolling egg cartons with most of their produce intact.

headline: Michelle Obama Shows Her Warmer Side on ‘The View’
text: First, she had to unclench her fist.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture credit on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about a subtle image makeover for Michelle Obama misspelled part of the name of the agency that provided the photograph. The picture of Mrs. Obama at the University of Chicago Medical Center was from Heidi Zeiger Photography, not Zeigler.

headline: Judge Gives a Victory to Tree Sitters in Berkeley Oaks
text: BERKELEY, Calif.  A group of protesters who have occupied a stand of coastal oaks at the University of California, Berkeley, for 19 months claimed victory on Wednesday when a Superior Court judge ruled that a university project on the site must be temporarily delayed to address lingering concerns about the project.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about President Bush’s weeklong visit to Europe misstated the response to the foreign policy issues on his agenda. While there had been some expectation of disagreements, administration officials said they did indeed make progress in several areas; it was not a visit that “featured confrontations over a variety of issues.”

headline: Can’t Place the Phone Number? Perhaps the Face Rings a Bell
text: G.E. is taking caller ID to a new level with a home phone that shows you not only who is calling, but also what the person looks like.

headline: Three Lives Inspire the Portrayal of a Complex Artist
text: “This was the first place I came,” Mercedes Ruehl says, looking around the small white pentagonal chapel that Louise Nevelson designed for St. Peter’s Church in Midtown Manhattan. She is describing how she prepared to portray Nevelson onstage in “Edward Albee’s Occupant.”

headline: Comfortable Seating From Japanese Forests
text: Piave, a surprisingly comfortable chair manufactured by a Japanese company called Hida Sangyo, was created by Enzo Mari, an Italian designer. Part of a line of knotty-looking wood pieces, it is made from sugi, or Cryptomeria japonica, an elegant cedarlike evergreen. (One landscape designer, Tanya Kelley of Newport, R.I., described the trees as “the Chanel of evergreens: they’re terribly chic.”) Sugi was planted en masse in Japan after World War II, and now the forests need thinning; Hida has built an eco-friendly business on making sweetly simple furniture from the stuff. Because the wood is soft like pine, it is compressed until sturdy and dense, then molded into gently rounded forms that hold the human shape in a salubrious manner. Piave is $870, and made to order through Ameico.com.

headline: The Latest Contender in the Lightweight Category
text: The MSI U100 Wind is the latest ultra-light laptop made for office work, Web browsing and portability. The Wind, not to be confused with another light, atmospherically themed laptop, from Apple, stands for Wi-Fi Network Device. It is 10 inches long and about an inch thick.

headline: At 91, He Isn’t Ready for the Last Dance Just Yet
text: GARRISON, N.Y.

headline: Hearst Chief Executive Resigns Over Policy Differences With Family Trust
text: The Hearst Corporation announced on Wednesday the unexpected resignation of its president and chief executive, Victor F. Ganzi, citing unspecified “irreconcilable policy differences” with the Hearst family trust that owns the company.

headline: Lil Wayne’s New CD Breaks One Million in Sales
text: As expected, Lil Wayne easily topped the Billboard album chart this week, selling just over one million copies of his new CD, “Tha Carter III” (Cash Money/Universal), according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the first time an album sold more than a million copies in one week since 50 Cent’s “Massacre” three years ago. (Kanye West came close: His “Graduation” moved 957,000 in its first week last September.) “Definition of Real” (Slip-N-Slide), the new album by the Florida rapper Plies, had a respectable debut, reaching No. 2 with 215,000 in sales. Three more albums opened further down the Top 10: N.E.R.D.’s “Seeing Sounds” (Star Trak/Interscope) was No. 7 with 80,000 in sales; Alanis Morissette’s “Flavours of Entanglement” (Warner Brothers) was No. 8 with 70,000; and My Morning Jacket moved 49,000 copies of “Evil Urges” (ATO) to reach No. 9. Last week’s best seller, Disturbed’s “Indestructible” (Reprise), dropped to No. 4 with 102,000.

headline: In Massachusetts, Diamonds for Once Outscore No-Trump
text: The trial to select the United States senior team for the first World Mind Sports Games in Beijing in October started on Monday and will end Thursday, in Sturbridge, Mass.

headline: Illness Will Keep Dutrow From Attending Hearing
text: WASHINGTON  Rick Dutrow, Big Brown’s trainer and the man who put the use of steroids in horse racing front and center with his colt’s bid for a Triple Crown, is ill and will not testify as expected Thursday before a Congressional subcommittee examining drug use and fatalities in the sport.

headline: Israel Open to Deal With Lebanon on Land
text: JERUSALEM  Israel offered on Wednesday to start direct peace talks with Lebanon, saying all issues would be negotiable, including a tiny piece of Israeli-held land on the countries’ border that Israel has long argued does not belong to Lebanon but that the Lebanese say is theirs.

headline: Think of It as Adding an Extra Room Onto Your TiVo
text: One of the problems with digital video recorders like TiVo is that they eventually run out of room to record. And if you change out the internal hard drive to upgrade, you lose your library of programming.

headline: Chemical Maker Files Suit to Block Its $10.6 Billion Merger
text: Hexion Specialty Chemicals, a chemical maker owned by the buyout firm Apollo Management, sued the Huntsman Corporation on Wednesday to end their $10.6 billion merger, dragging one of the few remaining giant deals of last year into court.

headline: Tales of Summer Heat Along With Thoughts of Cooler Times
text: Cole Porter’s “Too Darn Hot” opposite Billy Barnes’s barroom torch song, “Something Cool”: Sheera Ben-David, a theatrically savvy performer with a strong, steady voice, places these standards side by side in her seasonal cabaret show, “Come Summer,” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

headline: Getting Hooked on Human Power
text: As the cost of gas sinks fishing plans for some power-boaters, paddlers reap the benefits -- they get more fishing hot spots unreachable by motorboat and foot. And don’t think the good news extends just to canoers. Kayak fishing  during which one casts, reels and chills from the sea-level cockpit  is on the rise. Joe Cambria, the editor of Kayak Fisherman magazine, says that 1 of every 10 kayaks bought in 1998 was used for fishing; today, half of all purchased kayaks see some angling action. "Kayaks allow you to get to spots you can’t reach by boat or even by foot, and it’s like fishing from a lounge chair," says Cambria. Compared to canoes, kayaks are faster, lighter and less prone to wind effects, and Cambria says that many new kayak designs add stability, reducing the chances of tipping. (Unless you catch the really big one.)

headline: Testing Linux With a Live CD
text: Q. I am interested in putting Linux on an old computer, but not sure whether it is easy enough to use yet. I have heard you can test it without installing it. How?

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Tuesday about a museum in Belgium devoted to the Mundaneum, an early concept of a worldwide information and communication network, misstated the year the Nazis marched on Belgium. It was 1940, not 1939.

headline: An Ordinary-Looking Bunch, Reflecting the Random Activities of Others
text: Periodically one of the nine dancers in Maguy Marin’s “Umwelt” steps from the forest of standing mirrors assembled onstage to peer at the audience. The lights grow bright overhead (though the numbingly loud score doesn’t let up) so that these confrontations seem somehow out of time, like those moments when you remember something important: a lost lover, the immutability of death, yourself.

headline: Grocery Shopping Made Easy
text: On “The Jetsons,” when George got hungry, he just pushed a couple of buttons on the Food-a-Rac-a-Cycle on the kitchen counter. In seconds, a freshly synthesized meal appeared on a plate, prepared to his exact specifications.

headline: Think of Your Poor Feet
text: The average person walks the equivalent of three times around the Earth in a lifetime. That is enormous wear and tear on the 26 bones, 33 joints and more than 100 tendons, ligaments and muscles that make up the foot.

headline: Recalling the ’80s? Try Selective Memory
text: THE signs of gentrification in the East Village are unmistakable: luxury co-ops, chic bistros, even a branch of Chase Manhattan where the Second Avenue Deli once stood. But one stretch of bohemia has yet to fall to luxury’s wrecking ball  namely, St. Marks Place, presided over since 1975 by its patron-saint store, Trash & Vaudeville.

headline: Most Doctors Aren’t Using Electronic Health Records
text: A government-sponsored survey of the use of computerized patient records by doctors points to two seemingly contradictory conclusions, and a health care system at odds with itself.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the acquittal of a former Mount Kisco, N.Y., police officer in the death of an illegal immigrant misidentified the municipality that is six miles from Bedford, N.Y., where the immigrant, Rene Javier Perez, was found dying by the side of a road. It is Mount Kisco, not Mount Vernon.

headline: Strengthening Extremists
text: GAZA

headline: An Unlikely Antagonist in the Detainees’ Corner
text: When he speaks publicly, Lt. Cmdr. William C. Kuebler, a military lawyer for a Guantánamo detainee, is careful to say his remarks do not reflect the views of the Pentagon.

headline: Paper Mill Playhouse Is Bought by Town
text: The township of Millburn, N.J., has agreed to buy the land and buildings of the Paper Mill Playhouse for $9 million and rent them to the theater, which is recovering from a near-fatal financial crisis. The Millburn Township Committee voted unanimously on Tuesday to approve the purchase, which will help the theater pay off a $3.5 million bank loan it took out last year; close this year’s deficit; provide working capital; and beef up a newly created endowment. The theater’s debt should be cleared by the end of July, said Mark W. Jones, executive director of the Paper Mill. The theater will hold a 75-year lease, with the rent for the first two years set at $1, then growing until it eventually equals 1 percent of the theater’s annual operating income. (Its current budget is $18.6 million.) In the 11th year of the lease, the theater has an option to buy back the land. As landlord, the township has no say over management of the theater, only the use of the property, Mr. Jones said.

headline: F.D.A. Says Source of Tainted Tomatoes May Stay a Mystery
text: The Food and Drug Administration may never be able to pinpoint the origin of salmonella-tainted tomatoes that have sickened hundreds of people, an agency official said Wednesday.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A brief report in the Vital Signs column on Tuesday about the body types of people imprisoned for violent crime referred incompletely to the academic affiliation for one researcher. While Jeffery T. Walker is indeed with the University of Arkansas, he is at the campus in Little Rock, not the flagship campus in Fayetteville.

headline: India: Military Evacuates Flood Victims
text: The Indian Army and Air Force were called in to evacuate people threatened by floodwaters after days of monsoon rains in the eastern and northeastern parts of the country. More than 300,000 people have lost their homes, according to a Reuters report from Bhubaneswar, the capital of Orissa State, which is among the hardest hit. Reuters said the stranded residents were scattered among relief camps and improvised shelters. Electricity was cut off in parts of the affected area, and some roads and rail lines were flooded.

headline: South African Leader Visits Mugabe Amid Election Turmoil
text: JOHANNESBURG  With Zimbabwe’s runoff election only nine days away, President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, the region’s most powerful nation, met on Wednesday with Zimbabwe’s strongman, President Robert Mugabe, as a rising chorus of voices warned that a fair vote could be impossible.

headline: Back a Bill, Then Throw It Under a Bus? It Happens
text: ALBANY  Once again, Michael R. Bloomberg, the mayor of New York City, has been frustrated by the mysterious ways of the capital.

headline: Why the Squint Is Endangered
text: WHEN Wimbledon begins later this month, chances are that the majority of competitors won’t be wearing sunglasses. After all, London summers are often soggy. But what about at the United States Open, or the Australian Open, where the sun shines in full force? Even there, the pros will be squinting. It’s recreational players who appear to be starting a trend.

headline: The Big Pander to Big Oil
text: It was almost inevitable that a combination of $4-a-gallon gas, public anxiety and politicians eager to win votes or repair legacies would produce political pandering on an epic scale. So it has, the latest instance being President Bush’s decision to ask Congress to end the federal ban on offshore oil and gas drilling along much of America’s continental shelf.

headline: Talent Draws a Crowd
text: “America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC on Tuesday, as 12.8 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. for that talent show’s third-season premiere, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show drew 13 million for its 2007 premiere, but faced new competition this time. The final game of the National Basketball Association’s championship series led the night’s ratings with estimates indicating that it earned an audience somewhere between Game 4 on Thursday (13.8 million) and Game 5 on Sunday (17.4 million). At 9 p.m. Fox’s “Hell’s Kitchen” drew a modest 8.2 million total viewers, but was runner-up to basketball for the night’s highest ratings among adults 18 to 49. For the night, Fox tied NBC for second place in that demographic. CBS finished fourth over all with a three-hour special, “AFI’s 10 Top 10” (5.5 million).

headline: Abu Sayyaf Militants Free Kidnapped News Crew in Philippines
text: MANILA  Abu Sayyaf militants have released members of a news team they abducted last week in the southern Philippines, among them one of the country’s best-known television journalists, officials said Wednesday.

headline: China Cracks Down on Drug Companies
text: BEIJING  Chinese officials said Wednesday that licenses had been revoked for three drugmakers, including one that sent human growth hormone to the United States, and that they had punished 125 other companies, mostly pharmacies, for making, selling or distributing performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Bernazard Finds Himself in Middle of Mets’ Turmoil
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The Mets had just started taking batting practice Wednesday evening, and Tony Bernazard, the team’s vice president for development, was standing about 20 feet behind the cage. Alfredo Griffin, the Los Angeles Angels’ first-base coach and Bernazard’s teammate on the 1987 Oakland Athletics, ran over and pumped his hand. Off to the side, Carlos Beltrán, limbering up, offered a smile and slapped Bernazard on the shoulder.

headline: One-Stop Redecorating, From Design to Finishing Touch
text: On Saturday, Ethan Allen, the famously American furniture maker and retailer (think of brown bedroom sets), is opening a 30,000-square-foot store next to Bloomingdale’s on Third Avenue. The furniture is not all brown, or especially American in its styling  at least, not the way you’d imagine. Nor is the space just a store: like the company’s flagship in Danbury, Conn., and, indeed, its 289 other locations around the country, the new Ethan Allen Design Center here aims to be one-stop shopping for anyone looking to redecorate a space.

headline: Some Farmers Devastated by Flooding; Others Brace for What Might Come
text: CANTON, Mo.  Looking out from the highest hill in this town, it suddenly seemed that there were two rivers: the Mississippi, of course, and now a new river, a nameless renegade that had appeared out of nowhere on Wednesday when the Mississippi’s waters broke over a levee near the tiny hamlet of Meyer, Ill., and surged over tens of thousands of acres of farm fields.

headline: Out of a Pocket, a Video Camera Filled With Tricks in High Definition
text: Sanyo’s Xacti HD1000 was one of the first compact cameras to shoot high-definition video. The latest in the line, the HD1010, includes a slow-motion mode and a slick face-tracking feature.

headline: After Being Displaced by Flooding, Top U.S. Gymnast Springs Back for Trials
text: PHILADELPHIA  When the floodwaters rose in Iowa last week and the bloated Raccoon River filled Chow’s Gymnastics and Dance Institute with water that was knee deep, Shawn Johnson suddenly was a gymnast with no gym.

headline: Anxiety Grows in West Over Firefighting Efforts
text: SAN DIEGO  As fire season arrives in the West, there are growing doubts about the region’s ability to attack the kind of sweeping blazes that devastated parts of California last year.

headline: Pedaling Smarter, Not Harder
text: "Most cyclists think that you have to train on hills to be competitive in road races, which typically feature multiple vertiginous, lung-busting climbs. Not Christian Vande Velde, who's expected to be selected next month for the United States road racing team for the Summer Olympics in Beijing," Gretchen Reynolds writes in The Times today. Vande Velde and his coaches have developed innovative training techniques, nutritional plans and strategies, and they share with readers a few clues for riding faster, longer and smarter.

headline: Russia: Four Charged in Killing of Journalist
text: Prosecutors in Moscow formally charged four men in the killing of Anna Politkovskaya, the crusading opposition journalist who was gunned down in 2006, but the person suspected of shooting her remains at large. Three of the men were accused of involvement in the killing while the fourth, a former officer of the F.S.B., a successor to the K.G.B., was charged with abuse of office related to the inquiry, officials said. The authorities last month formally charged the suspected gunman, Rustam Makhmudov, a 34-year-old Chechen, and are searching for him. In August 2007, 10 people were arrested in the case, but some have been released.

headline: New Challenges for European Union’s Next Presidency After the Defeat in Ireland
text: PARIS  The European Union, it seems, just will not take no for an answer.

headline: As Poles Balk, U.S. Eyes Lithuania as Site for Missile Shield
text: BERLIN  Poland is balking at further negotiations with the United States over plans to deploy an antiballistic missile shield, prompting Washington to seek out Lithuania, formerly part of the Soviet Union, as a possible alternative location, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Judge Approves Deal to Settle Suit Over Wage Violations
text: A federal judge on Wednesday provisionally approved the first part of proposed settlements totaling $3.9 million in two closely watched wage-violation lawsuits brought against one of Manhattan’s leading restaurant owners.

headline: Former Company Town Faces Uncertain Future
text: BONNER, Mont.  For the past century, residents here have known two constants. They worked at the local lumber mill, where a seemingly endless supply of timber from the mountains kept saws whirring. And they played at the Milltown Reservoir, fishing and swimming behind a dam that was built at the confluence of the Clark Fork and Blackfoot Rivers to supply electricity to the mill.

headline: DreamWorks Founders Seek a Chance to Move On
text: LOS ANGELES  Steven Spielberg and other top executives at DreamWorks SKG may get a boost from an ambitious Bollywood player, but their planned alliance could be less grandiose than dreams past.

headline: Hymns and Blues in the Name of Family
text: One of the revelations of “A Tribute to Alice Coltrane,” the JVC Jazz Festival concert on Tuesday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, was a short film clip of Ms. Coltrane playing piano in Paris in 1959. She was smiling, running through fast bebop with the drummer Kenny Clarke and the saxophonist Lucky Thompson, and skating through the chord changes.

headline: Unsettling Ideas on Furniture Design
text: “Multiplicity: The Art of the Furniture Prototype,” which opened this week at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y., showcases works culled from an international competition of artists, furniture makers, architects and industrial designers. The show, co-sponsored by the Furniture Society, includes stools made of foam, a lounge that resembles desert dunes and a chair, left, that appears to have been made with green xylophone mallets, aptly named Suspended Chaos. It would have been hard to tell it was a chair without the catalog, so a reporter called the designer, Chris Holden, to see what had provoked him to create such an uncomfortable-looking piece.

headline:
Court Offers Homeowners
Help Avoiding Foreclosure
text: Homeowners in New York who face foreclosures would be offered help by the courts to save their homes or at least make the overall process easier under a new program announced on Wednesday by the state’s chief judge.

headline: All Bad Things Must Come to an End
text: In Ken Burns's documentary about baseball, broadcaster Bob Costas says, "So many things in our country have changed drastically, as they must, over the years and over the decades, and although baseball has changed, its essence remains the same. It's one of the enduring institutions in our country, and I think we take some comfort in that." All due respect to Bob, but the only thing that hasn't changed about baseball over the last 50 years is the wistful musings of baby boomers.

headline: Spielberg Said to Be Seeking Deal
text: NEW DELHI  Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks SKG film studio may soon get a lift from Bollywood.

headline: Spielberg Said to Be in Talks With Reliance
text: NEW DELHI  Steven Spielberg and other top executives at DreamWorks SKG may get a lift from a Bollywood player with ambitious dreams of its own.

headline: Lights, Camera, Inaction
text: THE other day, my daughters brought out some old photos that made them feel so nostalgic they wanted to move on to the harder stuff: videos.

headline: South Street Seaport Building Plan Faces Council Roadblock
text: A significant figure in the review and approval process facing the proposal to redevelop Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport, Councilman Alan J. Gerson, said on Wednesday that the plan was “certainly not going to pass in its present form.”

headline: The Guardian of Gramercy Park
text: Arlene Harrison calls herself the mayor of Gramercy Park, and she does not just mean that she knows almost everybody who walks through the lush, private two-acre expanse in the East 20s enough to say hello. Ms. Harrison’s influence over that particular piece of prime Manhattan green space and its neighbors  some 900 units in 39 buildings border the park  is felt in the “Keep off the grass” signs and the holly bushes she had installed recently “to block out the streets and the sidewalk.”

headline: Rasner Comes Through, Showing Ponson How It’s Done
text: A few hours after the Yankees signed the free-agent pitcher Sidney Ponson, another fill-in starter walked to the mound at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Corrections
text: National

headline: Argentina: Embattled President Addresses Supporters
text: Argentina’s embattled president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, addressed thousands of supporters at a rally in Buenos Aires, two days after her economic policies prompted nationwide protests. Despite concerns that the rally would heighten tensions, the event was peaceful. The president, who has been struggling to quell a revolt by farmers over higher export taxes she imposed in March, did not expand on a plan announced Tuesday to let Congress debate the tax increases. But she defended her move to raise taxes and redistribute wealth to the poor, and called on farmers to end their strikes. “I did not take this decision to hurt anybody,” she said. “This was not against anybody, but it was so that all Argentines could live better.”

headline: The Small Business Administration’s Comeback
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sustaining a Rally in Women’s Tennis
text: FOR years, women’s tennis has had more recognizable  and more marketable  star players than the men’s game, like Serena Williams, Venus Williams and Maria Sharapova.

headline: Paul Pierce’s Crafty Ground Game
text: The collective memories that make up Paul Pierce's Beantown apotheosis are now well documented: The wheelchair exit and the jubilant return. The velcro defense on Kobe Bryant. The dumping of red Gatorade on his bewildered coach. But I choose to recall another moment, when Pierce dunked the ball in Game 5 and the slo-mo replays showed the flab on his arms and shoulder undulating like bread pudding.

headline: Gather Round the Table and Bring Your Electronic Devices
text: The Sun Table, a teak and stainless steel outdoor table, has solar-powered electrical outlets for devices like laptops, telephones, radios and lights. After sitting in the sunlight for four hours, the solar cells in the tabletop are fully charged; they can then generate power for four hours, or an evening’s worth of work or cocktails. At 31 by 54 inches, and 18 inches high, the table is big enough for a small crowd and is water resistant, so it can be left out in the rain. Available from Sudia Design Labs, for about $2,000; information: (206) 666-5869 or suntable.net.

headline: A Like-New Look for an Aging Deck
text: ONE of the most popular gathering places around the house when summer arrives is not inside the home itself but outside, on the deck or terrace.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sea Levels Rose Faster Than Estimated
text: The oceans have been growing warmer and sea levels have been rising at a faster rate than previously estimated, researchers reported. A review of millions of measurements over the past four decades revealed a subtle error, they said; after correcting it, they found that sea levels rose two inches from 1961 to 2003  about 50 percent greater than previous estimates. Experts familiar with the work said the finding, published in the journal Nature, added credence to computer simulations predicting centuries of rising seas from human-caused global warming.

headline: Gifted Programs in the City Are Less Diverse
text: When New York City set a uniform threshold for admission to public school gifted programs last fall, it was a crucial step in a prolonged effort to equalize access to programs that critics complained were dominated by white middle-class children whose parents knew how to navigate the system.

headline: Fleeing Gunman Is Captured in Brooklyn Grade School
text: A robbery suspect being chased by the police burst into a Brooklyn elementary school with a loaded handgun on Wednesday afternoon, prompting students to be evacuated or locked in classrooms with their teachers as officers swarmed the building, the authorities said.

headline: How Big Is ‘Tiger Effect’? Networks Will Soon Learn
text: Network executives and sponsors were not visibly panicking Wednesday that Tiger Woods would be gone from golf for the rest of the year as he recovered from reconstructive knee surgery. But their disappointment was palpable.

headline: One-Man Flamenco, Without Instruments
text: Even before he stepped onstage Tuesday night, everything was working in Israel Galván’s favor. A breeze cast a quiet spell over the crowd gathered outdoors at the Hispanic Society of America on Audubon Terrace in Upper Manhattan. And as soon as Mr. Galván appeared on the unadorned black stage, he fit right in. As a flamenco dancer, he is full of purity, almost shockingly so.

headline: A Facade Like No Other: Once Temporary, Now a Fixture Worth Restoring
text: For more than 30 years the architect Steven Holl has explored an approach to design in which walls, floors and ceilings function as permeable membranes. One of the best illustrations of that concept, which he calls porosity, is his 1993 facade for the Storefront for Art and Architecture, a nonprofit gallery on Kenmare Street in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Sue OPEC
text: THE president of the United States has the power to attack, and perhaps destroy, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, the illegal cartel that has driven the price of oil over $130 per barrel. This can be accomplished without invasion or bombing. No special legislation is needed. The president need simply allow the states to seek relief in the Supreme Court under our antitrust laws.

headline: You Can Chitchat or Watch Some TV
text: Cool-looking phones are a dime a dozen these days. But what about a phone that can stream live television, complete with a TiVo-esque program guide?

headline: The Muck of the Irish
text: ISTANBUL

headline: Conspicuous by Their Presence
text: RACIAL prejudice in the fashion industry has long persisted because of tokenism and lookism. “We already have our black girl,” says a designer to a fashion-show casting agent, declining to see others. Or: “She doesn’t have the right look.” Laziness, paranoia and pedantry may also have something to do with the failure to hire black models for shows and magazine features in any meaningful number, but, hey, that’s just a guess.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article in some editions on Tuesday about a New York State administrative judge’s recommendation that state regulators block a Spanish energy conglomerate’s bid to buy Energy East, which owns two New York utilities, referred incorrectly to power monopoly regulations in New York. A Public Service Commission policy discourages any one company from simultaneously owning generation, transmission and distribution facilities, but there is no state law preventing such an arrangement.

headline: Subway Service Increase to Be Less Than Hoped
text: A burgeoning financial crisis will prevent the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from delivering on most of a series of promised service expansions  but a more modest set of changes aimed at easing subway crowding is still in the works, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Detlef Gromoll, Known for Math ‘Soul’ Idea, Dies at 70
text: Detlef Gromoll, a mathematician who helped lay the foundations for studying the abstract distortions of shapes in three or more dimensions, died on May 31 in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 70.

headline: Out of Opera’s Cradle, Hunky Broadway Babies
text: Opera buffs who admire the American baritone Nathan Gunn should perhaps be concerned about his recent forays into musical theater. After stealing the show as Lancelot in the New York Philharmonic’s presentation of Lerner and Loewe’s “Camelot” in May, he scored another triumph as Gaylord Ravenal in the concert adaptation of “Show Boat,” the landmark Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein II musical, at Carnegie Hall on June 10.

headline: Dr. A-List Can See You Now
text: ATTENTION, plastic surgery shoppers: Dr. Anthony C. Griffin of Beverly Hills has an opening on his schedule.

headline: Tip of the Week: Comparing Gas Prices on the Road
text: GasBuddy.com has been a handy site for finding the cheapest gasoline prices, but more than likely you’ll need the information while on the road, not at your desk. It has instructions for getting current prices with its mobile Web site (GasBuddyToGo.com) or by text message at www.gasbuddy.com/GB_Mobile_Instructions.aspx.

headline: Bach and Jazz Variations, Slightly Abbreviated
text: Le Poisson Rouge, a new club on the site of the old Village Gate on Bleecker Street, opened on Sunday and is devoting much of this month to the JVC Jazz Festival. But its owners are young classical musicians, and they are pointedly including classical music in the club’s programming. They are also intent on projecting a more casual image of the music and its performers, and have engaged Ronen Givony to assemble their classical offerings in the style of his innovative Wordless Music series, which presents joint bills of experimental pop and classical players.

headline: McCain Sets Goal of 45 New Nuclear Reactors by 2030
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mo.  Senator John McCain said Wednesday that he wanted 45 new nuclear reactors built in the United States by 2030, a course he called “as difficult as it is necessary.”

headline: Move to Restrict Free Travel Passes Creates Rare Controversy for M.T.A. Board
text: A revolt over free travel appeared to be brewing Wednesday on the normally docile board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as several board members said they opposed a move backed by their own chairman to restrict their use of free E-ZPass tags and transit and commuter rail passes.

headline: A Costly Victory
text: Is Tiger Woods's U.S. Open victory worth the price he's paying for playing the tournament with a bad left leg?

headline: Newly Released
text: The dysfunctional family (a phrase presumably unknown to Tolstoy) is at the heart of this month’s group of new books. Drug addicts, murderers, child abusers  take your pick. Joyce Carol Oates wades into this territory with her take on the JonBenet Ramsey killing. To round out the list, there’s a Hollywood tale of love and death and an Italian serial killer.

headline: In Egypt at Crossroads, a Faustian Arrangement
text: The Nobel Prize-winning author Naguib Mahfouz, who died in 2006, was Egypt’s Balzac. In his 33 novels, including his masterpiece, “The Cairo Trilogy”; his 16 short story collections; 30 screenplays; and several plays he invented a vast human comedy populated by the inhabitants of Cairo’s sprawling metropolis whose lives embodied the history of his country: wily shopkeepers and heartless bureaucrats, wheedling beggars, voluptuous women, whores and holy men, desperate parents and starving students.

headline: Release of Generic Lipitor Is Delayed
text: For people with high cholesterol, the wait for a cheaper version of Lipitor just got longer. Pfizer announced an agreement Wednesday to head off generic competition for its flagship drug until November 2011  up to 20 months later than many analysts had been expecting.

headline: 2 School Entrepreneurs Lead the Way on Change
text: As the founder of Teach for America, a nonprofit program that recruits elite college graduates to teach in low-income schools, Wendy Kopp has presided over many triumphs, and the group’s annual dinner last month was another. It raised $5.5 million in one night and brought so many corporate executives to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York that stretch limousines jammed Park Avenue for blocks.

headline: Navigating the New World of Cellphones, as the Options Pile Up
text: It’s your cellphone. You should be able to do what you want with it.

headline: Improve the View Inside a Window
text: Metropolitan Window Fashions has discounts up to $100 a window on custom shades, blinds, drapes or curtains that replace old window treatments. Discounts are by width: for each foot up to 10 feet, prices are reduced $10 (a five-foot-wide window, for example, receives a $50 discount). The store will measure, make recommendations, remove old treatments and install new ones. The Hunter Douglas Duette Honeycomb Shade, above, one of the coverings available, starts at $143 (undiscounted) for a 24-by-36-inch panel. Through July 31 at Metropolitan Window Fashions in New York and New Jersey; (212) 501-8282 or (908) 755-4700.

headline: Cubs’ Cachet and Rays’ Success Draw Fans to Tampa
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  After the Chicago Cubs arrived at Tropicana Field on Tuesday for their first visit, relief pitcher Carlos Mármol found a big, empty reclining chair in the visitors’ clubhouse. So he sat down, leaned back  and tipped over.

headline: Tempting Fate With Every Step
text: Each foot has 26 bones (19 of them are in the toes), 33 joints and more than 100 ligaments, helping the feet to bend, twist and flex as we walk, run and jump. With every step, a force two to three times the body’s weight comes down on the foot; that force is easily tripled when running or jumping. Here are five things that Dr. Brian G. Donley, director of the Foot and Ankle Center at the Cleveland Clinic, believes everyone with foot pain should know.

headline: Democrats Vow to Block Airport-Slot Sale
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats said on Wednesday that congestion at New York-area airports was a result of Republican mismanagement and that the Bush administration’s plans to auction scarce landing slots at Kennedy and Newark Airports would be a blow to the public and the airlines. They promised to block the plan.

headline: Sylph or Siren, the Legs Have It
text: Some stars shine, others flicker, lingering in your consciousness and dreams in flashes, favorite scenes and frozen moments. Cyd Charisse, the long-legged beauty who in the 1950s gave Fred Astaire some midcareer oomph and Gene Kelly his match in pure animal vitality, wasn’t a Hollywood immortal. She never transcended the movies in which she appeared  her breakout musical, “Singin’ in the Rain,” could certainly have been produced without her. But it surely would not have been as magnificent without the erotic jolt she gives Kelly.

headline: Fate Finds Rivers but Eludes Randolph
text: Boston

headline: Bush Calls for End to Ban on Offshore Oil Drilling
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush urged Congress on Wednesday to end a federal ban on offshore oil drilling and open a portion of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil exploration, asserting that those steps and others would lower gasoline prices and “strengthen our national security.”

headline: An Olympic Cyclist’s Levelheaded Advice
text: MOST cyclists think that you have to train on hills to be competitive in road races, which typically feature multiple vertiginous, lung-busting climbs. Not Christian Vande Velde, who’s expected to be selected next month for the United States road racing team for the Summer Olympics in Beijing. “I’m proof that you don’t have to ride hills to do well on hills,” he said recently.

headline: Deals With Iraq Are Set to Bring Oil Giants Back
text: BAGHDAD  Four Western oil companies are in the final stages of negotiations this month on contracts that will return them to Iraq, 36 years after losing their oil concession to nationalization as Saddam Hussein rose to power.

headline: China and Japan in Deal Over Contested Gas Fields
text: TOKYO  China and Japan agreed on Wednesday to end a long-running dispute over control of offshore natural gas fields, moving to defuse an issue that had become a symbol of growing frictions between the estranged Asian powers.

headline: Hirst’s Golden Calf Is Pricey Per Pound
text: Damien Hirst’s latest creation  a bull submerged in formaldehyde, with a head crowned by a solid-gold disc, and hooves and horns cast in 18-karat gold  is expected to fetch $16 million to $24 million when it is sold at a Sotheby’s auction in London on Sept. 15. “The Golden Calf,” above, with the artist, will be part of a two-day auction of works made by Mr. Hirst in the last two years, Sotheby’s announced on Thursday. In addition to the bull, the auctions on Sept. 15 and 16 will include some of his new paintings, drawings and sculptures. This is the second time Sotheby’s has held an all-Hirst auction. In 2004 it sold the contents of the Pharmacy, his defunct Notting Hill restaurant, which included Hirst-designed ashtrays and bar stools, as well as his paintings, for $20 million. Last summer Mr. Hirst’s human skull cast in platinum and covered with 8,601 diamonds was said to have been sold to an investment group for $100 million.

headline: Footnotes
text: After being shut out at the Tony Awards and struggling at the box office for several months, “Cry-Baby,” the new musical based on the John Waters movie, will close after Sunday’s performance. The show, at the Marquis Theater on Broadway, will have played 45 previews and 68 performances. ... ABC confirmed on Wednesday that it had extended the contract of the late-night host Jimmy Kimmel, above, by one year, keeping him at the network through at least 2010, Daily Variety reported.

headline: Big News! Press Agent Gets Name in Lights
text: The Manhattan Theater Club has announced a new name for its Biltmore Theater. And who will receive that honor, one now shared on Broadway by a select group of people? Maybe a writer, a critic, an actor, a cartoonist? Perhaps an airline or a large multinational bank?

headline: House Leaders Agree on War Funding
text: WASHINGTON  House leaders struck a bipartisan deal on Wednesday night on a major spending measure that would provide money for the war in Iraq through the end of the Bush administration, establish a significant new education benefit for veterans, and meet Democratic demands for added unemployment benefits.

headline: Remembering Tim Russert: The Memorial Service
text: Jacques Steinberg reports from the memorial service for Tim Russert in Washington, D.C.: “Those who spoke at the afternoon service — including Mario M. Cuomo, the former governor of New York who once employed Mr. Russert as his counselor, and the historian Doris Kearns Goodwin — labored at times to tell stories that they and others had not shared previously in the endless loop of cable coverage that followed Mr. Russert’s death at 58.”

headline: The Siege of Gaza
text: Nicholas D. Kristof spoke with residents of Gaza City about the impact that the siege has had on their lives.

headline: The e-Book Test: Do Electronic Versions Deter Piracy?
text: Well! My goodness!

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Bad day in the Rose Garden
text: There President Bush was in the Rose Garden on Wednesday, unveiling his plan for reducing the price of oil. A little greyer but strangely unchanged.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 71 Troy
text: Location: Troy, Ala.

headline: McCain and Bush to Survey Iowa Flooding, Separately
text: Updated | 8:40 a.m. CHICAGO — The debate about whether Senator John McCain is “McBush’’ continues, but on Thursday one thing will be clear: The presumptive Republican nominee and President Bush will be in Iowa touring areas hard hit by floods.

headline: Gymnastics Champion Will Miss at Least First Day of U.S. Trials
text: [UPDATED, 2:45 p.m.]

headline: Williams to Replace Russert on Sunday
text: NBC News executives, still reeling from the sudden death of Tim Russert on Friday, have yet to begin to grapple with the long-term question of who might replace him in his most visible role, as moderator of "Meet the Press." But they have decided that Brian Williams, anchor of "NBC Nightly News," will take Mr. Russert's place this Sunday, according to Allison Gollust, an NBC News spokeswoman. Mr. Williams recently returned from Afghanistan and is being replaced on "Nightly News" for the remainder of the week by Ann Curry. Last Sunday, two days after Mr. Russert's death, a special edition of "Meet the Press" was led by Tom Brokaw. Mr. Williams's guests will be Senators Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Joseph Biden of Delaware, who were to have been Mr. Russert's guests last Sunday.

headline: Spanish developers blaming environmentalists for market woes
text: Property developers in Spain threatening to sue Greenpeace may think they’re making a bold statement about environmentalists, but they’re really saying far more about the state of the Spanish property market.

headline: Bush, McCain, Obama and Offshore Oil Drilling
text: There was big news today in the United States on energy and the environment, where President George W. Bush called on Congress to end a 27-year ban on drilling for oil and gas off America’s coastline. Bush also called for oil to be pumped from an Alaska wildlife refuge and to step up extraction from oil shale.

headline: U.K. estate agent rep says gloomy reports “don’t stack up”
text: National Association of Estate Agents chief executive Peter Bolton King stands ready to counter the “doom and gloom” and “scaremongering” in the U.K. housing market. He scoffs at recent reports that dozens of estate agents a week are closing their doors.

headline: Bar Bans
text: From a post at Holy Taco titled “14 Songs You Should Never Play in a Bar”:

headline: Blue Cross Buys Medecision for $120 Million
text: The parent of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois said it will buy for more than $120 million a maker of software designed to help health insurance companies better manage diseases of plans’ subscribers.

headline: Bentley Forges Ahead With Cpex Spin-Off
text: Bentley Pharmaceuticals is moving forward with plans to spin off its drug delivery division as a publicly traded entity under the name Cpex Pharmaceuticals, ahead of its own $360 million merger with Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.

headline: Western Canandian Coal Receives Takeover Proposals
text: Western Canadian Coal said it has received “a number” of proposals to buy all or part of the company, news that sent its once-suffering stock to a record high despite a deepening loss in 2007.

headline: Energy Recovery Details I.P.O. Plans
text: Energy Recovery, which develops devices used to make water desalination more efficient, disclosed the terms of its planned $56.7 million initial public offering.

headline: Cooking.com Gobbles $13 Million Served by V.C.s
text: Cooking.com, the food-focused marketplace, has raised $13 million in a second round led by Azure Capital Partners, which includes venture debt from Orix Venture Finance.

headline: Mochi Media Swallows $10 Million
text: Mochi Media, a company that helps developers monetize their Flash games, has closed a $10 million Series B funding round.

headline: PMI Unloads FGIC Portfolio
text: PMI Group announced late Tuesday that it agreed to transfer its entire FGIC reinsurance portfolio to Assured Guaranty Re. The move reflects PMI’s plans to shore up its own capital and refocus on its core mortgage insurance business.

headline: HBOS Warns of $2 Billion Write-Down
text: British bank HBOS said on Thursday it was trading in line with its expectations, but warned of a 1 billion pound ($2 billion) write-down in the first half of its financial year and a bigger fall in British house prices.

headline: Thomson Reuters Said to Team With S&P for Hedge Fund Research
text: A half-dozen members of the Thomson Reuters  research department are moving to Standard & Poor’s to form a new department to produce market research for hedge funds and other Wall Street players, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The Digital Ramble | Machinery Nostalgia
text: The Digital Ramble explores aesthetic topics through materials found online.

headline: Goldman Executive to Become Harvard V.P.
text: The global head of Goldman Sachs‘ investment management arm has taken a senior role at Harvard University during a period of frequent staff changes in the investment bank’s asset management business.

headline: S.E.C. Subpoenas Thornburg, Whose Survival Is In Doubt
text: Thornburg Mortgage, the jumbo mortgage lender that lost $3.31 billion in the first quarter, said on Wednesday it has received subpoenas from U.S. securities regulators and its survival remains in doubt.

headline: Flickr Founders Join Yahoo Exodus
text: Flickr founders Caterina Fake and Stewart Butterfield have joined an exodus of senior Yahoo managers, the company confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Hearst Chief Resigns Unexpectedly
text: The Hearst Corporation announced on Wednesday the unexpected resignation of its president and chief executive, Victor F. Ganzi, citing unspecified “irreconcilable policy differences” with the Hearst family trust that owns the company.

headline: Providence Said to Bid for British Business Publisher
text: Providence Equity Partners reportedly emerged Wednesday night as a surprise bidder for Informa as the Lloyds List publisher’s merger talks with United Business Media collapsed.

headline: Proxy Firm Backs Hedge Funds As CSX Awaits Appeal Review
text: The management of CSX was dealt a blow on Wednesday as a leading proxy advice firm recommended that shareholders vote for most of a dissident slate being proposed by two activist hedge funds battling with management for control of the railway operator’s board.

headline: Ambac Asks Fitch to Remove Ratings
text: Ambac Financial, the big bond insurer struggling with the effects of the mortgage debacle, said Wednesday that it has asked Fitch Ratings to withdraw its ratings “effective immediately.”

headline: Trouble in Financials Drags Down Shares
text: Wall Street sank Wednesday for the second consecutive day in part on renewed concerns about the financial sector.

headline: Huawei Invites P.E. Firms to Bid for $4 Billion Unit, Report Says
text: Huawei Technologies, China’s biggest phone-network equipment maker, is considering selling a majority stake of a handset unit that may be worth at least $4 billion, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Investment Banks Need More Supervision, F.D.I.C. Head Says
text: Any troubled U.S. investment bank headed toward bankruptcy should be subject to supervisory intervention just like commercial banks, the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said on Wednesday.

headline: Yang Goes to Capitol Hill to Talk Up Google Deal
text: Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, made the rounds on Capital Hill on Wednesday, in an effort to dispel antitrust concerns surrounding its search advertising deal with Google.

headline: DreamWorks and Viacom: Breaking Up May Be Hard to Do
text: While Steven Spielberg and other top executives at DreamWorks may finally break free with a little help from an ambitious Bollywood player, their planned alliance could be less grandiose than dreams past, The New York Times noted.

headline: Should Cerberus Partner Up on Chrysler?
text: Does Cerberus Capital Management need to seek a partner in order to salvage its $7.4 billion bet on Chrysler?

headline: What to do with aggressive beggars and hawkers?
text: I was always considered a softie because of my American / Canadian upbringing. No street-smart Hong Kong kid would worry about bringing leftovers to poor people or dropping coins into a beggar’s cup.

headline: Lehman Sells Assets to Ex-Trader’s New Fund
text: Lehman Brothers invested in a new hedge fund run by its former trader, Rick Rieder, and sold it about $5 billion of assets, Bloomberg News reported. It said the move positioned Lehman “to profit from the stakes while shrinking its own balance sheet.”

headline: Anheuser-Busch to Meet Over Inbev Bid, Report Says
text: Anheuser-Busch‘s board of directors plans to meet face-to-face this week for the first time since rival brewer InBev formally made its $46 billion bid to acquire the company, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Chatter Flies on Possible Lehman Deal
text: The question Wednesday seemed to be: Is it deal or no deal for Lehman Brothers?

headline: Toxic Town
text: The E.P.A may let a French-owned company import toxins from Mexico to Texas for incineration, but not if the town has its way.

headline: Broader Role Sought for Federal Reserve
text: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., in a speech to be delivered to a professional group on Thursday, will ask policy makers to move swiftly to give greater tools and authority to the Federal Reserve to handle financial crises.

headline: Mystery Anagram in the Sky
text: You may be able to get the scoop on the discovery of a planet near another star if you can unscramble this anagram:

headline: Icahn Blog to Go Live (Finally)
text: The New York Post can finally drop its Carl C. Icahn blog-watch timer. The long-delayed Icahn Report blog is going live on Thursday, the financier and corporate agitator said on Wednesday.

headline: Loan Fallout Rocks Regional Banks
text: In Ohio, the Panic of 1907 drove the Fifth National Bank into the arms of the Third National Bank, creating the singularly named Fifth Third Bank of Cincinnati.

headline: ’15 Lobster Tails in His Pants’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Kerkorian Picks Up More of Ford
text: He may be in the red with his Ford Motor investment, but Kirk Kerkorian is still buying.

headline: Here’s the Drill
text: Yesterday the Opinionator had trouble finding supporters of offshore drilling, today the Corner’s Larry Kudlow ups the ante.

headline: Former Bear Stearns Fund Managers Are Arrested
text: Two former managers of hedge funds at Bear Stearns were arrested this morning at their homes and were expected to appear in court later in the day to be indicted on charges related to the funds’ collapse, according to reports.

headline: The Early Word: Obama Opts Out of Public Financing
text: Updated In a video message sent to supporters this morning Senator Barack Obama said his campaign had made the decision not to participate in public financing during the general election. It marks the first time since 1976 that a major party presidential candidate has rejected public financing for the general election.

headline: War and Peace of Mind
text: Ali Hameed is an Iraqi employee of The New York Times.

headline: Rolling Stones Reunion, Year 2050
text: They just kicked out Hymie the robot and Hal the computer, and now the group has no ego trips or arguments whatsoever. Oh sure, they’ll still blow the occasional fuse every now and then …

headline: Veronis Suhler Taps Ex-AOL Executive as Adviser
text: Veronis Suhler Stevenson, a media-focused private equity firm, will announce Thursday that it has hired the former president of AOL Media Networks as a senior adviser on a non-exclusive basis.

headline: Gannett Invests in Family-Services Site
text: Gannett, the news media giant, said Thursday that it has invested in Cozi Technologies, a Web company that provides free scheduling and communication services for families. The size of the investment was not disclosed.

headline: Gifted Programs in the City Are Less Diverse
text: An analysis by The New York Times shows that following a new policy last fall establishing a uniform threshold for admission to public school gifted programs, children from the city’s poorest districts were offered a smaller percentage than last year of the entry-grade gifted slots in elementary schools. Children in the city’s wealthiest districts captured a greater share of the slots. The disparity is so stark that some gifted programs opened by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in an effort to increase opportunities in poor and predominantly minority districts will not fill new classes next year. In three districts, there were too few qualifiers to fill a single class.

headline: Seas Rising and Warming Faster Than Realized
text: [UPDATE 6/20: On slowing of sea rise since 2006.] On a very busy climate-oil-politics day I was able to just squeak in a short print piece last night on a new study in the journal Nature clarifying what’s happening with the oceans in a heating world (the heat held in by a building greenhouse blanket has largely accumulated in the oceans and physics demands that it will eventually add to atmospheric warming).

headline: Toxic Waste
text: Hexion Specialty Chemicals, represented by the folks at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, has formulated an outstanding deal renegotiation/termination litigation strategy.

headline: Icahn Fails to Win Seats at Biogen Idec
text: Carl C. Icahn has conceded defeat in his proxy fight at Biogen Idec, the biopharmaceutical giant.

headline: Trying to Revive a Board’s Loan Approval
text: Three years ago, I started the process of applying for a home equity loan on a co-op I own. The board reviewed and approved the loan application, and I had to pay the co-op $300 to review the application. I did not follow through on getting the loan back then, but I would like to do so now. Is there a time limit on how long the board’s approval stays in effect?

headline: Avoiding Foreclosure, but Fearing a Rating Cut
text: In a previous question and answer, a lawyer explained that with a deed in lieu of foreclosure, a property owner transfers ownership of a mortgaged property to the lender and the lender agrees to accept the property — and forgive the unpaid balance on the loan — instead of proceeding with a foreclosure action against the borrower. Does this affect the borrower’s credit rating?

headline: Beauty Call | Feeling the Full Axe Effect
text: The Axe Detailer Shower Tool is a souped-up loofah.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Apria for $1.6 Billion
text: The Blackstone Group said Thursday that it has agreed to buy Apria Healthcare Group, a home healthcare services provider, for $1.6 billion, in the private equity giant’s first major leveraged buyout this year.

headline: ‘How Cruel Is That?’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: The Mets fired their manager, Willie Randolph, at 3 a.m. in the morning. 3 a.m. How cruel is that? You know who made the 3 a.m. call? Hillary Clinton.

headline: ‘Wait a Minute. There’s More.’
text: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: A couple of days ago, NASA’s Mars Lander has found traces of ice and salt on Mars. Wait a minute. There’s more. Right now, it’s searching for tequila, which will come in handy because the Lander also found an old blender.

headline: ‘We’ll Need That Extra Power…’
text: Aired Wednesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Congratulations to the NBA champion Boston Celtics. Last night, they beat the Los Angeles Lakers by 39 points. Or as Hillary Clinton would say, “Too close to call.”

headline: ‘He Might Not Be the Last President Bush”
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC:  In a recent interview, President Bush said that he might not be the last President Bush if his brother Jeb decides to run. Yeah, when he heard this, Jeb said, “Please stop reminding everyone we’re related.”

headline: Citi Reshuffles Communications Office
text: Citigroup on Thursday announced a reshuffling of its marketing and communications office under Lisa Caputo, its chief marketing officer. The bank also said that it has appointed a new head of corporate communications, replacing Leah Johnson, who resigned last month.

headline: Thomas Fuller at 400
text: Click here for a slideshow — written by William S. Niederkorn, an editor at The Times — that celebrates the life and work of Thomas Fuller (1608-1661), a forceful and witty English churchman and historian whose work is no longer as well known as it should be.

headline: Australian Senate’s Gordon Ramsay Inquiry
text: For many years, it could be said that world leaders were turning a blind eye to a growing threat. No longer: Gordon Ramsay, the extraordinarily gifted creator of both restaurants and rants, faced the Australian Senate today for filling the television with an astounding volume of foul language.

headline: Bright Spot For Network TV: Sports

headline: The Brits Get ‘Dharma and Greg’ and We Get….

headline: Con Ed Faces New Benchmark for Blackouts
text: People in western Queens who lost power for nine days two summers ago might be surprised to learn that Consolidated Edison did not consider the event a major power failure — at least in the strictest, legal sense.

headline: Bonus Babies
text: Population | The world’s biological clock is ticking loudly for developed nations. So low-birthrate countries — from Russia and Poland to Australia and Singapore — are paying bonuses for babies, as societies once again project “their deepest anxieties onto empty wombs.” But will encouraging families expand the welfare state? — Reason

headline: An Interview With President Ma Ying-jeou
text: On June 18, 2008, President Ma Ying-jeou was interviewed by Keith Bradsher and Edward Wong of The New York Times, and Leonard M. Apcar of The International Herald Tribune. The following is an edited transcript of the interview provided by the Taiwanese Government Information Office.

headline: Behind the Scenes of Bear’s Fund Meltdown
text: What were the managers of Bear Stearns‘ hedge funds thinking as the mortgage markets began to go haywire and investors started asking for their money back? Thursday’s indictments against those former managers, Ralph R. Cioffi and Matthew Tannin, offer some fascinating clues.

headline: Pizza Guy Politics
text: The Mother Jones website has an amusing if not necessarily scientific chart showing how people from various self-identified occupational groups have been directing their political donations over the past few months.

headline: The Morning Skate: A Quick Tour of the NHL Rumor River
text: Welcome aboard The Morning Skate’s Tour of the NHL late June scene. We sail down the river of dreams, sometimes bumping blindly into reality along the shoreline. Coming up on your right is the 2008 NHL Entry Draft and just ahead of that is the start of Free Agency. This means one thing: It’s rumor time!

headline: Recipe of the Day: Lemon Grass Patties
text: Certain flavors appear almost everywhere in Vietnam, so maybe I shouldn’t have been surprised when I was served what amounted to lemon grass hamburgers at a restaurant on the two-lane national highway that runs down the country’s spine. Of all the powerful ingredients in these burgers — lemon grass, shallots, garlic, chili and nam pla — none survived the cooking as well as the lemon grass, whose distinctive scent and flavor reduced the others to bit players.

headline: Scent Notes | Allure Homme Sport by Chanel
text: Scents are constructed with very different philosophies and aesthetics and, as a result, differ fundamentally from one another. The works of every artistic medium, from painting to literature, lie along this continuum. Music, for example, can be pure art (Bach), intellectual art (Schoenberg), political philosophy (Dylan) and commercial product (Ashlee Simpson).

headline: Slow-Acting Pill
text: How much would switching to electronic records cut health care costs? A Rand report embraced by Barack Obama says $81 billion. But factcheck.org notes the savings wouldn’t come until 2019, long after the next administration. And the Congressional Budget Office called the Rand study “overly optimistic.” — Rand, factcheck.org, C.B.O.

headline: Blame the Speculators
text: In Washington, some high prices are deemed better than others. Stocks should go up, and so should home prices. Commodities should go down.

headline: Slowing Traffic With Trompe l’Oeil
text: Speed bumps have long been criticized for damaging cars and slowing down emergency vehicles (and even lowering fuel economy). The city of Philadelphia thinks it may have a kinder and gentler solution to aggressive driving: virtual speed bumps.

headline: New Obama Ad to Air in 18 States
text: In his first television advertisement of the general election, Senator Barack Obama faces the camera and talks about his biography, his family values and his American roots.

headline: A Home Improvement Web Site Begets a TV Series
text: HGTV says “Rate My Space,” a Web site where people submit photos of home renovations for anonymous strangers to evaluate, says it is a place to “test your inner designer.” Now HGTV is testing “Rate My Space” as a television show.

headline: An Assemblyman Vexes Two Cities
text: Assemblyman David F. Gantt, a Rochester Democrat, has been flexing his political muscle — but his unusual behavior has attracted attention recently from reporters around the state.This morning, The Times reported on Mr. Gantt’s move to stop a proposal by the Bloomberg administration aimed at keeping cars out of special lanes that will be reserved for a new class of high-speed buses.

headline: F1 images to remember
text: Having arrived in Magny-Cours today to find that the track is in one of the few parts of France not under perfect sunshine – according to the radio reports I heard – but not wet just yet either, I was reminded that if we do have to go through another wet weekend (which I doubt), there are positive things to capitalize on. One would be a great race on a track where it’s almost impossible to overtake, especially since they wiped out the last chicane a few years ago in favor of a larger, more open corner. Another thing in the wet, of course, is the photo opportunity.

headline: A Bronx Tree Honors a Slain Journalist
text: The untimely death of the journalist Tim Russert has been the subject of much commentary and reflections, especially on television in the past week. The unsolved murder of another journalist, Bradley Will, nearly two years ago never received such saturation coverage.

headline: Advice for Wang: ‘Find a Hobby’
text: On April 22, in Chicago, Brian Bruney tripped and hurt his foot while trying to cover first base. That was the first some of us had heard of the dreaded Lisfranc injury, which claimed Chien-Ming Wang on Sunday.

headline: So You Think You Can Beat Fox in the Ratings?
text: A two-hour installment of Fox’s reality series “So You Think You Can Dance” led the network to victory in the ratings on Wednesday as 8.8 million viewers tuned in to the show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

Bringing the bad news was the Simon Stewart of the Baker IDI Heart and Diabetes Institute, who conceded that it was “a title we don’t really want.”

headline: Ich bin What?
text: Did John F. Kennedy really claim to be a jelly doughnut? On June 15, the Book Review published a review of “Counselor,” a memoir by Ted Sorensen, Kennedy’s close adviser and speechwriter, that referred to Sorensen’s chagrined account of his boss’s famous “Ich bin ein Berliner” speech on a windy day in divided Berlin, June 16, 1963. Here’s Sorensen.

headline: The Fairy Dust at Barnes & Noble
text: Barnes & Noble’s Web site has some extras that no one seems to discuss. Still, they are well capitalized and an interesting indulgence if you feel like tuning in. You and I could even bring the page views up to four. I like their new video series — Barnes & Noble Studio — just because it feels like serious productions values are lavished on us alone, their meager viewership.

headline: Federal Report: Warming = More Harmful Climate Extremes
text: The first thorough federal review of research on how global warming may affect extreme climate events in North America forecasts more drenching rains, parching droughts (especially in the Southwest), intense heat waves and stronger hurricanes if long-lived greenhouse gases continue building in the atmosphere.
