headline: Another Myth Refuted
Treasury Secretary Requests Greater Powers for the Federal Reserve
text: The Bush administration said Thursday that the Federal Reserve should be given sweeping new powers to protect the integrity of the financial system, contending that this year’s market turmoil had exposed a badly outdated regulatory system.

headline: Bain Signs Deal for Japan’s D&M
text: Bain Capital agreed to buy D&M Holdings, the Japanese audio-equipment maker, for about 47.6 billion yen ($441 million) from rival buyout firm Ripplewood Holdings and the other shareholders.

headline: Jana Drops CNet Fight and Pockets Cash
text: Hedge fund Jana Partners on Thursday formally dropped its effort to win control of CNet Network‘s board, more than a month after the Internet media company agreed to be sold to CBS.

headline: Sumitomo Mitsui s Barclays Investment, Report Says
text: Japan’s Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group may invest about $926 million in British bank Barclays, as subprime-hit Western lenders increasingly turn to Asia for funding, Reuters reported.

headline: CVR Cancels I.P.O. Plans
text: CVR Partners, which was formed by CVR Energy to operate a fertilizer facility, has canceled its planned initial public offering, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday.

headline: BofA’s Countrywide Deal Poised to Close, Report Says
text: Bank of America expects to complete its acquisition of mortgage lender Countrywide Financial by July 1, according to Reuters.

headline: China’s Shagang Mulls Bid for Brazilian Iron Ore Unit
text: Jiangsu Shagang Group, China’s biggest privately owned steelmaker, is seeking to buy a stake in Brazil’s Cia. Siderurgica Nacional ‘s iron ore unit as prices for the raw material soar to a record.

headline: Chairman of Live Nation Is Said to Be Preparing to Resign
text: The chairman of Live Nation, the concert promoter, is negotiating to resign after an internal battle over the company’s strategy of signing expensive deals with artists like Madonna and Jay-Z, according to The New York Times.

headline: Bank of England Gains New Oversight Powers
text: The Bank of England announced a revamp of its leadership on Thursday as it was granted enhanced powers to manage financial crises in the biggest overhaul of Britain’s financial regulatory system in a decade.

headline: Ferretti to Set Sail Upon Public Seas
text: Ferretti, the Italian yachtmaker, is preparing to once again launch itself upon the public markets.

headline: 3 Ex-Nortel Executives Are Accused of Fraud
text: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police brought criminal charges on Thursday against three former executives of Nortel Networks, the telecommunications company, more than four years after accounting irregularities were discovered at the firm.

headline: Does DreamWorks Buzz Stem From a Strategic Leak?
text: Is the recently leaked DreamWorks deal to unfetter itself from Viacom, in essence, just a spin job by co-founder David Geffen?

headline: Pimco’s Gross Is Squirreling Away Bank Debt
text: Bill Gross, manager of top bond fund Pacific Investment Management Company, on Thursday said he still holds corporate debt of some of the largest banks slammed by the global credit crisis, including Citigroup, because of their long-term value.

headline: Microsoft Won’t Go on Internet Shopping Spree, Chief Says
text: Microsoft will not seek to make a spate of other Internet acquisitions in the wake of its failed bid for Yahoo, the company’s chief executive told The Financial Times.

headline: Retail M&A Poised for a Rebound?
text: Retail mergers and acquisitions look to have dried up for at least another nine months, according to speakers at the Reuters Retail and Consumer Summit, but once the credit crunch eases and consumer trends are more predictable, buyers are poised for deal-making.

headline: Bazaarvoice Speaks to V.C.’s
text: Bazaarvoice, which provides technology for brands to utilize consumer-generated content, has raised $7.1 million in a fundraising round.

headline: More Big Write-Downs Loom for Citigroup, Executive Says
text: The chief financial officer of Citigroup, Gary L. Crittenden, warned on Thursday that the bank, the nation’s largest by assets, would suffer more substantial write-downs on debt investments in the second quarter.

headline: Funds Sue WCI Steel Over Russian Deal
text: WCI Steel‘s proposed $140 million sale to Russian metals company OAO Severstal is stirring up a legal fight. Funds holdings stakes in WCI, a Warren, Ohio-based steelmaker, filed a lawsuit June 13 in Delaware Court of Chancery to try to stop the transaction.

headline: From the Gulf, Money for Towers in London
text: Some of the construction cranes rising over the City of London, the financial hub of Europe, bear the seal of sovereign riches. Not British riches – Middle Eastern ones.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Pleads Guilty in Tax Evasion
text: One after another, the secrets spilled out. The millions stashed in Swiss bank accounts. The precious jewels and artwork whisked into hiding. The diamonds smuggled in a tube of toothpaste.

headline: Holding Car Companies Like Toyota to Account for Green Advertising
text: As car companies increasingly pander to buyers looking to go green, environmentalists are fighting back with some demands of their own.

headline: Facebook Executive to Join Benchmark
text: Benchmark Capital, the prominent Silicon Valley venture firm, said the Matt Cohler, vice president for product management at the social networking site Facebook, is joining as a general partner in the fall.

headline: More Pain for Blackstone Shareholders?
text: In the case of the Blackstone Group‘s initial public offering, one investor’s loss is a founder’s gain, it seems.

headline: HDTV Makers Must Add More Features to Increase Sales
text: While many Americans have yet to buy their first high-definition television, a new report from DisplaySearch, a consumer electronics research firm, warns the industry that if it wants to keep improving HDTV sales, it will need to quickly install some features that are now extra-cost add-ons available only in high-end models.

headline: United and Continental Form Alliance
text: Continental Airlines and United Airlines, which decided in April not to merge, said Thursday that they had reached an agreement to link their networks and operations worldwide.

headline: Yahoo’s Post-Microsoft Exodus

headline: Yahoo Investor Asks Microsoft to Take Offer to Shareholders
text: An investor with a minority stake in Yahoo urged Microsoft on Thursday to take its most recent offer for a partial investment directly to Yahoo shareholders and prove its merits.

headline: Girlfriend of Fugitive Fund Manager Is Charged
text: Federal authorities have arrested a suspect in the disappearance of Samuel Israel III, the fugitive former manager of the Bayou hedge fund who they say faked his suicide on the day he was to report to prison last week and is now believed to be on the run.

headline: For Wall Street Banks, a Question of Value
text: The case against two former hedge fund managers at Bear Stearns spotlights one of the most vexing problems confronting Wall Street as the credit crisis plays out: How to value tricky investments linked to subprime mortgages and other risky debt.

headline: Wanderlust: Uncommon Objects in Austin, Tex.
text: Imagine if Miss Havisham opened a store with all her favorite knickknacks, dresses and jewelry. Now throw in a little Texas twang, and, voilá, you have the boutique Uncommon Objects.

headline: Renovations at Magny-Cours
text: The French Grand Prix was never supposed to return to Magny-Cours. Somehow it did. Now, plans for the race to return to other parts of France – Paris, Versailles, Rouen, Disneyland – abound. So does a plan that Magny-Cours is offering to update its facilities to tempt Formula One back. While several venues, like Silverstone and Donington Park, are talking about renovations that could cost tens of millions of dollars, Magny-Cours’ latest plans also looks fairly costly, with an updating of the pit building, grandstands being fitting with awnings, etc.

headline: ‘More News From Hollywood’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: What a beautiful day here in New York City –- isn’t it lovely, folks? Oh, here’s how glorious it is today in New York City. It was so nice today that the Mets were firing managers in broad daylight.

headline: Madagascar – A Bronx Tale and a Carbon Sale
text: Lemurs roared and screamed. A young fossa, resembling a stretched-out mash-up of a cat and a mongoose, stalked along a branch. A hundred thousand hissing cockroaches prepared to invade a hollow tree. All of these creatures are from Madagascar, the giant island east of Africa that has spawned a variegated assemblage of unique life forms since it was biologically isolated from the other continents some 70 million years ago.

headline: The Early Word: Sorting Out the Opt-Out
text: The decision on Thursday by Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic nominee, to decline public financing for his general election campaign was not unexpected, but it still sent shock waves through the political community and sparked a debate over the future of the entire system of public campaign financing.

headline: Obama and Clinton to Campaign Together
text: Senator Barack Obama will be joined by his one-time rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, on the campaign trail on Friday June 27, his campaign announced today.

headline: Amid Jeers, Board Approves Steep Rent Increases
text: The board that regulates rents for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments approved its highest rent increases in years at a raucous meeting on Thursday, angering tenants who said high rents were forcing the poor and working class out of the city, Manny Fernandez reports.

headline: Bloomberg Criticizes ‘Whisper Campaign’ Around Obama
text: Updated, 11:21 a.m. | BOCA RATON, Fla. — Injecting himself directly into the presidential campaign and speaking before one of its most crucial constituencies, Jewish voters, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday morning forcefully rejected what he called a “whisper campaign” in the Jewish community linking Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, to Islam.

headline: Branyan May Be This Year’s Cust
text: When the Brewers decided to move Ryan Braun to the outfield to ease his burden on defense, Bill Hall was tapped to take over for him at third base. Russell Branyan, a journeyman infielder who had played for four teams in the last two seasons since leaving the Brewers was not in the picture. But with 10 homers in 62 at-bats since being called up by Milwaukee, Branyan has played his way into the majors and has sent Hall to the bench.

headline: Obama Going for the Gold?
text: “Those tuning in to NBC Sports’ Olympics coverage this year will see spots from General Motors, McDonald’s, Budweiser, Nike and — just maybe — Sen. Barack Obama,” reports Ira Teinowitz of Advertising Age.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Watermelon and Tomato Salad
text: Watermelon and tomato are two fruits that complement each another in an unusual way. When you cut up and combine them, their distinctions become a little blurry and each masquerades as the other. The tomato’s acidity becomes tamed, as does the melon’s sweetness; their juices mingle, and even their flesh seems to meld.

headline: McCain’s Latest Trouble in New Jersey: Oil Drilling
text: This is the time of year, every four years, when the Republican Party looks at the polls in New Jersey and decides it might have a chance to capture the Garden State’s 15 electoral votes.

headline: Lots of Buzz About Anheuser-Busch
text: As the board of Anheuser-Busch met in St. Louis on Friday to consider Inbev‘s unsolicited takeover bid, there were quite a few notable developments in this cross-border beer saga.

headline: Yo, Brooklyn Brand, What’s Up?
text: If you think Brooklyn — or rather, the marketed image of Brooklyn — has been a bit overexposed lately, it may not be your imagination. There was the much-ballyhooed opening, on Wednesday, of Ikea Brooklyn, the latest branch of the Swedish furniture chain.

headline: ‘Imagine if You Tried That With Your Boss’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: President Bush went to Iowa today. He wanted to show Iowans that disaster is difficult, but it can be overcome. Of course, people in Iowa were a little confused. They weren’t sure which disaster President Bush was talking about, the floods or his presidency. Which one?

headline: Hexion’s Damages Claim
text: I’ve been mulling over the argument that Hexion Specialty Chemicals made in this week’s complaint that its damages are limited under the merger agreement to only $325 million. Upon reflection, I think this argument, though not compelling, is stronger than I initially suspected.

headline: ‘He Will Not Accept $85 Million’
text: Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Barack Obama announced today he will not accept $85 million in public financing for his presidential campaign. I guess he’s raising more money on his own, but $85 million is a lot of money. In fact, that much money can get you a whole summer’s worth of gas for your SUV.

headline: Facebook Tries to Blaze a Path in Russia
text: MOSCOW – Google has floundered. So has MySpace. Now Facebook is trying to gain a toehold in Russia.

headline: Who’s Snooping on You at Work?
text: Jeff Quon deserves a hearty thanks from anyone who has suffered a privacy pang or two at work. When his employer, the police department in Ontario, Calif., decided to delve into the text messages sent from his department-supplied pager — some of which were personal and X-rated — he filed a violation-of-privacy lawsuit against the department, the city and Arch Wireless, the vendor the department uses for wireless communications.

headline: ‘The Fist-Bump Is the New High-Five’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC:  Yesterday on “The View,” Barack Obama’s wife, Michelle, did the fist-bump with all the co-hosts. And then she said that the fist-bump is the new high-five. After hearing this, John McCain asked, “What the hell is a high-five?”

headline: ’60 Minutes,’ ProPublica Partner For Investigation Into Al Hurra
text: ProPublica, the non-profit investigative journalism initiative headed by the former Wall Street Journal managing editor Paul Steiger, has announced its joint investigation. It is a partnership with the most esteemed newsmagazine on television: “60 Minutes.”

headline: Rumblings of a Bronx Comeback From Espada
text: He has been out of the political spotlight for a few years. But Pedro Espada Jr. is clearly thinking serious of re-emerging into the raucous Bronx electoral life.

headline: The Morning Skate: The NHL Entry Draft — What Might Happen
text: There’s been lots of conjecture on how the NHL Entry Draft’s first round will shake out tonight, but aside from Steven Stamkos going first overall to the Lightning, nothing seems certain. If you’re watching on Versus, after the way they botched the TV Awards by missing the first six minutes, you can’t even be certain you’ll get to see the draft. So be sure you follow our live blog from the Bunker of Mark Pargas starting around 6:30.

headline: Cooking on the Road
text: An unusual way to look at a salad bar, from David Latt. –MB

headline: A New Twist on Ankle Pain
text: Having recently twisted my ankle during an afternoon sprint to the train station, I was disheartened to learn that my recovery strategy, which is to do nothing, is the wrong approach.

headline: Blame It on McCain
text: Barack Obama is taking plenty of heat over his decision to opt out of public financing for the general election, but Josh Marshall at Talking Points Memo makes the case that John McCain is the real manipulator here.

headline: Where Sunday’s Not a School Night
text: Education | Four-day school weeks are not a new idea. But will fuel prices bring Mondays off into vogue? Already a sprawling rural parish in Louisiana is introducing them in the fall, in part because the savings in bus fuel alone would likely be $92,000. But there are day-care concerns and other downsides. — New Star (Monroe, La.). Background: Christian Science Monitor

headline: In China, Pressure to Succeed
text: China's best athletes are often plucked from poor rural villages, but even winning gold does not ensure a prosperous future.

headline: Does G.P.S. Help Save the Planet?
text: Isn’t it odd that, in all the billions of words that have been written about car G.P.S. systems and about the environment, nobody ever talks about how the former can help the latter?

headline: Renewal Leases and Landlords’ Obligations
text: How many days before a lease expires does a landlord have to send a tenant a renewal lease?

headline: A Case of Liability and a Leaky Ice Maker
text: When I was out of town, the water line to my ice maker leaked and caused damage to the ceiling of the apartment below. The co-op managing agent charged my account for the repairs, and I submitted the bill to my insurance company. But the company will not cover me for the damage because it claims that I am not legally liable, since I had no notice of the problem and had committed no negligent act.

headline: A Plan to Phase Out West Side Helicopter Tours
text: The uproar over the noisy comings and goings of sightseeing helicopters along the West Side of Manhattan has finally led to a plan to eliminate them. Air Pegasus, the operator of the heliport at the west end of 30th Street, has agreed to start phasing out tourist flights next year. The number of those flights would be capped at 25,000 for the year by May 31, 2009, then cut to 12,500 over the following 10 months, then halted completely, according to a draft of the agreement made in State Supreme Court.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Family-Size
text: The average American mother has 2.1 children. The United States is no Hong Kong, where the average mother has 1, but it’s not prolific Somalia, either, where 6.6 is average. Here we just keep procreation moving along.

headline: Man, Nature and the Flood of 2008
text: As the damage toll rises with the floods in the Midwest, the question is: what happened to the assurances after the Great Flood of 1993 that action would be taken to prevent the next flood from being so devastating. Why were new subdivisions built on floodplains? Why did the levees fail? Why is it so hard to blame plain old bad weather?

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘An Intergalactic Super-Virus!’
text: Monday, June 16

headline: MoveOn Terminates Its 527
text: MoveOn.org announced today that it is dismantling its 527 group in response to Senator Barack Obama’s candidacy.

headline: On the Tour du Mount Blanc
text: 16 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: I’ll be riding what I’m told is the easy day of the four-day training camp in the Alps I’m attending.

headline: MBIA Isn’t Double-A, Either
text: Moody’s yesterday became the last of the rating agencies to downgrade MBIA, but it went the other agencies one better: MBIA falls to A, not AA like Ambac. The rating of its insurance subsidiary plunged to a low investment grade.

headline: Ring Masters
text: Sport | Homer and Virgil were fight fans. The boxer Gene Tunney hung out with George Bernard Shaw, Sherwood Anderson and Thornton Wilder. T.S. Eliot took boxing lessons and Ezra Pound sparred. In a new history, a British academic examines why the intelligentsia has been drawn to pugilism over the ages. — Economist, London Telegraph

headline: Kerkorian’s Ford Stake: A Deeper Shade of Red
text: Kirk Kerkorian is a savvy — and wealthy — investor, but lately he has shown an uncanny habit of buying Ford Motor shares just before they take a dive. The stock fell sharply in the weeks after his investment vehicle, Tracinda, made a tender offer for the shares in May. And on Friday, one day after he revealed increasing his stake even more, the stock took another tumble.

headline: The Team Behind the Bear Stearns Charges
text: As Thursday brought the first criminal indictments tied to the subprime mortgage crisis, attention inevitably has swung to the prosecutors who are leading the charge.

headline: More Community Service for Model
text: In the tale of woe that was Heathrow Airport’s disastrous terminal opening earlier this year, Naomi Campbell provided a cautionary subplot.

headline: The Dutch Dilemma: Sport or Ultimate Victory?
text: Was this soccer’s first case of suicide by simple decency?

headline: The Post-Materialist | Design’s Past, Future
text: A report from our Berlin correspondent on design in culture.

headline: EBay Tries to Buy a Little More Love From Sellers
text: With thousands of eBay’s most active sellers converging on its eBay Live convention in Chicago, the embattled online flea market is trying to give both sellers and buyers a little more to win back their loyalty.

headline: Bronx Acclaim: Sexy? Sure. But Deserving?
text: This weekend, the Bronx will honor its accomplished sons and daughters by including them on the borough’s Walk of Fame. For the ages, their names will be etched onto yellow signs affixed to lampposts lining the southern stretch of the Grand Concourse.

headline: Reader Question: The Best Root Brew
text: “I’m not much of a soda drinker,” Eric Asimov wrote in The Times in 2000, “but I love the flavor of root beer. Too often, though, root beers, like all sodas, taste like industrial products, combining harsh carbonation, chemically induced flavors and an overpowering sweetness.”

headline: Britain, Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg
text: BRIEFS Martha Stewart may have moved on to greener pastures since prison, but they weren’t in Britain. A spokeswoman revealed today that her visa application had been rejected, and promptly commenced a public campaign. “Martha loves England,” she told The Telegraph, “and hopes this can be resolved and that she will be able to visit soon.” The border agency refused to comment on the case while tellingly reiterating its opposition to anyone “found guilty of serious criminal offenses abroad.” That standard has been applied to many celebrities, The Times of London added, including Snoop Dogg, whose fight to return to Britain continues. In the absence of an official explanation, one theory seemed inevitable: payback for Amy Winehouse?

headline: Social Networking on Wall Street
text: LinkedIn, a Web site that professionals use to make contacts and trade tips, created quite a stir this week. It announced that it raised $53 million in funding, primarily from Bain Capital Ventures, implicitly valuing the four-year-old company at an impressive $1 billion. It was only the latest evidence that social networks for the more-serious set — think Facebook, as opposed to a more youth-oriented MySpace — have come into vogue with investors.

headline: The Great Seal of Obamaland?
text: At a discussion with a dozen Democratic governors in Chicago on Friday morning, each of the governors was identified with a small name plate but Senator Barack Obama sat behind a low rostrum to which was attached an official-looking seal no one had seen before.

headline: Another Reason to Lock the Door
text: BRIEFS It’s 3 a.m. and your children are safe and asleep — but the front door is unlocked, and the police are trying to stem burglaries in Lakeville, Minnesota … [The Pioneer Press]

headline: At One Year, Turmoil Persists at Arabic-Themed School
text: The first year, it is safe to say, has not passed without its share of problems at the Khalil Gibran International Academy in Brooklyn. The school has gone through multiple principals and lawsuits and even an equal employment opportunity complaint, not to mention a change in location, since opening its doors as the city’s only Arabic-themed school last September. Even the lone science teacher was recently ousted.The biggest problem surrounding the school has no doubt been the removal of its founding principal, Debbie Almontaser, who resigned in August under enormous pressure, much of it from a chorus of critics who said she had a militant Islamic agenda.

headline: Wen and the Art of Calligraphy
text: Can four words scrawled on a blackboard count as an important historical relic? Apparently yes.

headline: Snip
text: Anthropology | A Cornell researcher suggests that male circumcision and other forms of genital mutilation may originally have been meant to prevent younger men from fathering children with older men’s wives. Mutilation reduces fertility, so it’s a price you pay to play with the wives of men you cuckold. Ouch. — Economist

headline: The A.P. Asserts Tough (and Still Secret) View of Copyright on Blogs
text: The Associated Press has punted on its commitment to clarify how much text it thinks bloggers and social news sites can reprint from its articles without violating The AP’s copyright. Indeed, the giant news organization appears to be insisting that bloggers cannot quote the headline of an A.P. story or its first paragraph. While the law is not settled, many lawyers suggest that such short excerpts are permitted under the “fair use” exception to the copyright laws.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Prom for All Nations
text: Students at Brooklyn's International High School have discovered the all-American rite of the high school prom.

headline: It’s Not Paranoia If Everyone’s Out to Get You
text: In opting out of the public financing system, Barack Obama explained that he needed to counter the “smears and attacks” from John McCain’s “allies running so-called 527 groups who will spend millions and millions of dollars in unlimited donations.”

headline: Mrs. Obama Makes a Pitch for Women Voters
text: WASHINGTON — Putting the finishing touches on a week that was meant to be a re-introduction of sorts for her, Michelle Obama on Friday told a women’s advocacy group that helping to improve the lives of working families is a cause that she carries deep in her heart.

headline: FISA
text: My biggest concern about an Obama administration is that, in the end, he won’t make universal health care a priority. My second biggest concern is that “Unity” means never having to say you’re sorry: that in the name of putting past partisanship behind us, the next administration will sweep the abuses of the past 8 years under the rug, the same way Bill Clinton did in 1993; the result of that decision was that the very same people responsible for Iran-Contra showed up subverting our democracy all over again.

headline: Bring It On
text: Campaigns generate headlines with the tough decisions they make. On Thursday, Barack Obama’s campaign made waves with an easy one. Mr. Obama’s decision to leave the public financing system elicited the predictable outrage among reformers (and the McCain camp), but it was probably the most obvious and inevitable decision he’ll make all year — justified both politically and ethically.

headline: U.S. Roster for Barbados Game
text: It will take a collapse of epic proportions for Barbados to overcome the United States in the second leg of their home-and-home World Cup qualifying series on Sunday in Bridgetown.

headline: Now Screening | ‘Mystery’
Court Lets Funds Vote CSX Shares
text: Two hedge funds engaged in a proxy fight with CSX cannot be prevented from voting their shares in the railroad operator, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday. (Download the document here.)

headline: Sous Vide | No Longer Astronauts-Only
text: The cover of “Under Pressure” with rhubarb stalks in vacuum-packed plastic (Deborah Jones).

headline: Rasta Chic | Caribbean Fashion Week
text: Heather Jones collection (David X Prutting/Patrick McMullan).

headline: More 9/11 Responders Get Benefits
text: Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders said they reached a deal to provide “presumptive accidental disability retirement” benefits to a greater number of 9/11 first responders.The agreement follows recommendations of the September 11th Worker Protection Task Force. Interestingly, those receiving benefits under the agreement will include even 911 dispatchers, because of psychological trauma.

headline: Answers About City Room, Part 4
text: This week, Sewell Chan, bureau chief of City Room, is answering selected questions from readers about the blog, which began publication a year ago this week. Mr. Chan joined The Times in 2004 and previously covered transportation and City Hall for the Metro staff. Readers are invited to ask about any topic that City Room has covered — or ought to cover — as well as the blog’s practices, philosophy, design and policies. This is the fourth and final set of answers.

headline: Vehicle Hits 8 Pedestrians in Midtown
text: At least eight pedestrians were struck and injured by a vehicle that drove onto the sidewalk at West 35th Street and Seventh Avenue, in the garment district of Midtown Manhattan, at around 5 p.m. Friday, officials said.The police were questioning the driver of the vehicle, a dark blue Ford Explorer, but it was not clear whether any charges would be filed.

headline: The N.H.L. Entry Draft: Round 1 Is Over
text: The first round of the 2008 National Hockey League entry draft in Ottawa at Scotiabank Place, as viewed on a small television screen and a slightly larger laptop screen in the Bunker, was presented here live on Friday night. My name is Mark Pargas and I hope you were my guest in the Bunker for the first round.

headline: Free Rides Add Up for M.T.A. Official
text: How much has a free E-ZPass been worth to David S. Mack, the vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority? The answer would seem to be about $2,340 a year. Data provided by the authority shows that between November 2006 and November 2007, Mr. Mack recorded 585 transactions on his free E-ZPass tags (Mr. Mack was issued six of them).

headline: Hunting Wild Hogs
text: Wild hogs are running rampant in 37 states, and catching them can prove to be very difficult.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 20
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York. Subjects include the community centers’ financial woes, needing a key to get into city parks, and the Ikea grand opening in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Anna and Alan
text: Anna Roberts and Alan Ostroff met when they were members of a traveling theater troupe.

headline: Anna and Alan
text: Anna Roberts and Alan Ostroff met when they were members of a traveling theater troupe.

headline: A Tale of Three Cities
text: Violence in all of Iraq is the lowest since March 2004, but the country still lacks the formal rules to unite the ethnic, religious and tribal groups under one stable idea of Iraq.

headline: A Tale of Three Cities
text: Moises Saman, a photographer with The New York Times, visited Basra, Mosul and the Sadr City district of Baghdad in May, visually recording the security and social situation in each of Iraq’s three largest cities. (See the slide show.)

headline: Bloggingheads: Energy Politics
text:
Michael Tomasky, left, of Guardian America and Rich Lowry of National Review debate the politics of high energy prices and global warming.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: 'Mad Men' Plays Well on Madison
text: "Mad Men" has become must-see television among people who work in the advertising business.

headline: Cat on a Leash
text: A self-described dog person takes his cat out for walks on a leash.

headline: Obama, McCain Reluctantly Endorse Surveillance Deal
text: Although both were absent from Washington and did not participate in the negotiations, Senators Barack Obama and John McCain on Friday offered qualified approval of the compromise worked out this week on electronic surveillance of terror suspects.

headline: A Strange, Strange Day in Yankeeland, Circa 1999
text: Jolbert Cabrera started at shortstop and socked four hits for the Cincinnati Reds on Friday at Yankee Stadium. But that is not why his name resonated with me. Cabrera played a role in one of the weirdest days in Yankees history, a day I witnessed and covered.

headline: Obama Campaign Takes In $21.9 Million
text: A day after he declined public financing for the general election, Senator Barack Obama reported that he had raised $21.9 million during the month of May. The majority of the funds can be spent before he becomes the Democratic Party’s official nominee for president at the convention in August.

headline: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner
text: Barack Obama is one of the most controlled and disciplined politicians around, but he occasionally shows a glimpse of what he’s really thinking.

headline: Miller Is Sorry for Comments About Mediate
text: Johnny Miller apologized Friday for comments that appeared to reflect negatively on the Italian heritage of Rocco Mediate, the popular runner-up to Tiger Woods in the United States Open.

headline: From Brownfields to Greenbacks
text: The idea was terrific. New York State would help pay for cleaning up toxic sites known as brownfields so developers could come in and build something useful. But like a lot of good ideas, it went astray in Albany.

headline: Barclays Said to Be Seeking Capital From Japanese Rival
text: LONDON  Barclays, the British bank that is seeking funds to replenish its capital, is talking with the Japanese bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, about a cash infusion of 100 billion yen, or $927 million, a person with knowledge of the talks said Friday.

headline: Officials Raid Baltimore Mayor’s Home
text: BALTIMORE  A two-year state investigation into Baltimore’s spending practices took a major turn this week when officials raided the home of Mayor Sheila Dixon and left with several boxes of papers.

headline: Bush May End Term With Iran Issue Unsettled
text: WASHINGTON  For more than five years now, President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney have made clear that they did not want to leave office with Iran any closer to possessing nuclear weapons than when they took office.

headline: Hunger Strike by Hundreds of Islamists in Morocco Jails
text: MARRAKESH, Morocco  A hunger strike among Islamists has been spreading across Morocco’s prisons since March, according to government officials and the head of a prisoner advocacy group.

headline: After Failed Drug Test, Suspicions of Foul Play
text: Two of the most outspoken critics on the use of drugs in horse racing recently had a colt of their own fail a drug test, a result that they are saying was sabotage. Larry Jones, who trained the late filly Eight Belles, and Jim Squires, the breeder of the 2001 Kentucky Derby winner Monarchos, were notified Tuesday that Stones River had tested positive for illegal levels of clenbuterol, a bronchodilator that helps burn fat and promote muscle growth, after a race June 8 at Delaware Park.

headline: Three Siblings Headed to Beijing in Tae Kwon Do
text: STAFFORD, Tex.  Of all the potential explanations for why the Lopez family of suburban Houston has become the dominant force in American tae kwon do, credit Chuck Norris, a one-and-a-half-car garage and Nicaragua. But it all began, really, with a misunderstanding that happened like this.

headline: Britain Sends Information on Suspect to the U.S.
text: LONDON  The government of Britain has turned over classified material to American military prosecutors at Guantánamo Bay about a British prisoner’s allegations that he was interrogated and tortured in Morocco after secretly being taken there by the C.I.A., according to the British Foreign Office.

headline: McCain Pushes Nafta in Visit to Canada as Obama, Again, Defends His View
text: OTTAWA  Senator John McCain’s campaign sent out an e-mail message on Friday highlighting what it called Senator Barack Obama’s “completely mystifying shift” on the North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Solving the Crimes and Battling the Snobs
text: In an effort to rejuvenate the “Masterpiece” franchise, PBS has brought in a new host for its “Mystery!” series, the impish actor Alan Cumming, who arrives with a bright red pocket square, contorting his eyebrows to look like a sine curve, suggesting that we are in for some kinky business. You wouldn’t have wanted him ringing in the grittier hours of “Prime Suspect,” but his playful sense of subversion and his Scottish cadences absent of Sloane Street implication are perfectly synchronized to the spirit of “Inspector Lewis,” which stamps the new season of “Mystery!” as an exploration of elitist deviance and class resentments.

headline: Lightning Selects Forward With Top Pick in N.H.L. Draft
text: Correction Appended

headline: Strange Habits of Successful Tennis Players
text: LONDON  Men’s tennis is in a golden age for talent. Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal and their fast-emerging rival Novak Djokovic have each won Grand Slam singles titles in the last year and are preparing for a grass-court summit at Wimbledon.

headline: Stocks Decline as Price of Oil Rises Sharply
text: A market that had been looking for direction in recent weeks seems to have found one: down.

headline: Former Bush Aide Testifies About C.I.A. Leak
text: WASHINGTON  Scott McClellan, President Bush’s former press secretary, told the House Judiciary Committee on Friday that he had been unfairly vilified by Bush supporters for his recent book criticizing former White House colleagues over the Iraq war and their involvement in leaking the identity of an intelligence officer.

headline: Calls for More Zimbabwe Sanctions
text: BRUSSELS  Amid conflicting reports over the likely course of Zimbabwe’s violence-ridden presidential run-off, the European Union said on Friday that it would consider expanding its sanctions against the regime of President Robert Mugabe.

headline: Double-Barreled Pitcher Provides Shot of Confusion
text: It was a lefty-righty matchup for the ages.

headline: Louisiana’s Latest Assault on Darwin
text: It comes as no surprise that the Louisiana State Legislature has overwhelmingly approved a bill that seeks to undercut the teaching of evolution in the public schools. The state, after all, has a sorry history as a hotbed of creationists’ efforts to inject religious views into science courses. All that stands in the way of this retrograde step is Gov. Bobby Jindal.

headline: Broadway’s Not Stale, So Why Are the Tonys?
text: I stood gaping in front of the Samsung as I watched the first few minutes of this year’s Tony Awards telecast. I had the eerie sensation of having slipped into a time warp.

headline: Swiss Particle Accelerator Deemed Safe
text: That black hole that was going to eat the Earth? Forget about it, and keep making the mortgage payments  those of you who still have them.

headline: Corrections
text: A music column on Monday about the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, in Manchester, Tenn., misstated the summer touring plans of the Dave Matthews Band in citing the absence of some bands from the festival. While not at Bonnaroo, it is touring this summer; it is not “off the road for now.” The column also referred imprecisely to the touring history of Pearl Jam, which played at the festival. While Pearl Jam did stop playing outdoor general-admission festivals after 2000, it resumed playing festivals that met its security requirements in 2005. (Go to Article)

headline: Lottery Numbers
Not Ebbets Field, but Close Enough
text: On Thursday night, the Callahans from Queens, still draped in Mets attire, were rooting for the Brooklyn Cyclones. It was the couple’s first visit to KeySpan Park, where the minor-league Cyclones play, and Bill and Lisa Callahan had come to bask in the atmosphere of the waterfront stadium, to watch baseball with the borough’s famed fanatics  and to forget, for a moment, their real team’s troubled fortunes.

headline: Surgery for Schilling; Career May Be Over
text: Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling always enjoyed it when the attention was focused on him and when the games had the most magnitude. But Schilling would have surely preferred to avoid the spotlight that he was under on Friday after declaring that his career might be over.

headline: A Friendly Break of Clubs in a Semifinal Match
text: The winners of the senior trial for the first World Mind Sports Games in Beijing in October were Reese Milner of Los Angeles; Grant Baze of San Diego; Billy Eisenberg of Perris, Calif.; Sam Lev of New York; Russ Ekeblad of Providence, R.I.; and Matthew Granovetter of Cincinnati. (Granovetter replaced Ron Rubin of Miami at the last minute when Rubin’s wife had a medical emergency.)

headline: Pinpointing Bargains, Big or Small
text: STOCKS have given up much of the gains made in the recovery from the March low, even as the economic outlook has brightened. That may provide a second chance for investors to pick up some bargains. Two successful portfolio managers, one oriented toward growth and the other toward value, offer mostly diverging ideas, naturally, about where they can be found.

headline: Twilight Saga Tour
text: Stephenie Meyer, below, the author of the best-selling young-adult “Twilight Saga,” will appear in a four-city tour to promote the fourth and final novel in that vampire love series, “Breaking Dawn.” Little, Brown, hoping to capitalize on the author’s fans  there are 7.7 million “Twilight Saga” books in print in the United States  said she would headline “an evening of story and song.” The Breaking Dawn Concert Series begins on Aug. 1, the eve of the book’s release, at the Nokia Theater in Times Square and makes stops in Chicago on Aug. 5, Los Angeles on Aug. 7 and Seattle on Aug. 12. Tickets cost $20 and will go on sale this Saturday at 10 a.m.; details are available on stepheniemeyer.com and thetwilightsaga.com.

headline: Bloomberg, in Florida, Blasts Rumor About Obama
text: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, injecting himself directly into the presidential campaign, forcefully denounced on Friday what he called a “whisper campaign” linking Senator Barack Obama, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, to Islam.

headline: Opera Company Shifts
text: Timothy O’Leary will succeed Charles MacKay as the Opera Theater of Saint Louis’s general director on Oct. 1, when Mr. MacKay becomes the general director of the Santa Fe Opera. Mr. O’Leary, the theater’s executive director since January, most recently directed operations and planning at New York City Opera. He has also served as managing director of the Gotham Chamber Opera in New York and has been a stage director and assistant director for companies including Glimmerglass, New York City Opera and Florida Grand Opera.

headline: Corrections
text: A music column on June 10 about the rap star Lil Wayne erroneously included a producer among those credited on his new album, “Tha Carter III.” Just Blaze did not produce any of the tracks. The column also misstated sales figures for the Hot Boys, the New Orleans group with whom Lil Wayne started his recording career. They made a platinum album (a million copies), not gold albums (500,000). (Go to Article)

headline: Land a Job, Then What? Graduates Adjust to Life With No Going Back
text: It is a bittersweet time for freshly sprung college graduates, at least those lucky enough to have landed jobs.

headline: Upstream Levee Breaks Ease Danger in St. Louis
text: The failure of Mississippi River levees to the north in Missouri and Illinois on Thursday eased pressure Friday on St. Louis, where estimates of the river’s crest were lowered below the feared record level.

headline: Gene Persson, Film and Theater Producer, Dies at 74
text: Gene Persson, a movie and theater producer best known for a controversial racial drama, “Dutchman,” and a charming children’s musical, “You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown,” died on June 6 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 74.

headline: A Dubious Milestone
text: Some years ago, I wrote about a teenager named Kendra Newkirk, who was raised by her mom and had only seen her dad once in her life. Because of an emergency, Kendra and her mom had to meet the father at a particularly busy public location in Brooklyn.

headline: Fuel Costs Pinch Cities; Mayors Push Mass Transit
text: MIAMI  Higher fuel prices are forcing cities across the country to cut public services, limit driving by employees and expand public transportation in what has become a sprawling movement to conserve energy.

headline: Putting a Price on Free Passes for M.T.A. Board Members
text: How much has a free E-ZPass account been worth to David S. Mack, the vice chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority who stirred controversy this week over free travel privileges for authority board members?

headline: Banks Trimming Limits for Many on Credit Cards
text: The easy money that led Americans to depend on credit cards to pay their bills is starting to dry up.

headline: In China’s Medal Factory, Winners Cannot Quit
text: FENGCHENG, China  As a reward for winning an Olympic gold medal in flatwater canoeing four years ago, Yang Wenjun  the son of peasant rice farmers  was handed the deed to a three-bedroom apartment here in a neighborhood called Sunny City.

headline: The Heart of the Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: 8 Reasons You Should Not Expect an Inheritance
text: You’ve probably heard about the bumper sticker, even if you haven’t seen it. It’s the one on Cadillacs in Florida and Lexuses in Arizona that says “I’m spending my children’s inheritance.”

headline: Limelight to Shine on Saudis at Energy Forum as Oil Prices Continue to Soar
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The rulers of this conservative desert kingdom have always avoided the limelight.

headline: House Passes Bill on Federal Wiretapping Powers
text: WASHINGTON  The House on Friday overwhelmingly approved a bill overhauling the rules on the government’s wiretapping powers and conferring what amounts to legal immunity to the telephone companies that took part in President Bush’s program of eavesdropping without warrants after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: For Chinese, the Reality of Higher Gas Prices
text: GANSU  Returning the fueling nozzle to the pump, Zhang Li jumped into the driver’s seat of his gas-guzzling Land Rover. “Such a long line,” said the 45-year-old tour guide, shaking his head. “What’s the world coming to? My stocks are worth air, and now I have to wait an hour for overpriced gas, too.”

headline: Get Thee to a 9unnery: Ophelia in Three Pieces
text: Ophelia, the tragic, enigmatic innocent of “Hamlet,” has proved fertile but dangerous ground for centuries of artists and theorists. Both multifaceted and a blank page, she eludes any pat interpretations and many nuanced ones. What to do with such a beguiling sylph?

headline: Opposition Strategist Denied Bail in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  With Zimbabwe’s presidential runoff just a week away, a magistrate in Harare refused Friday to grant bail to Tendai Biti, the opposition’s secretary general and chief strategist, who has been charged with treason.

headline: An Opera’s Homecoming, in a Newly Restored House
text: MUNICH  Dramatic rescues are central to both Mozart’s “Idomeneo” and the Cuvilliés Theater here. Like the main characters of the opera, which had its premiere at the theater in 1781, this beautiful matchbox space (with only 523 seats) was once saved from destruction at the last minute.

headline: Texas: Deal Over Worker’s Death
text: Five years after an immigrant worker was pulled into a food processor and killed, the Texas food company where he worked agreed to a settlement to improve safety conditions for workers across the state. The company, Michael Angelo’s Gourmet Foods Inc., a frozen food manufacturer near Austin, will create a council of concerned businesses to address workers’ safety. It will also donate $375,000 to four nonprofit organizations that educate immigrants on their rights. The family-owned company had faced possible criminal charges in the death of the worker, Daniel Romero-Cruz, 34, of Mexico. “This is a modern-day reminder of the most basic ancient constitutional principle that fairness and dignity does not depend on your citizenship,” said District Attorney Ronnie Earle of Travis County, who worked out the agreement.

headline: China: Olympic Torch Is in Lhasa
text: With a heavy police presence providing tight security, the Olympic torch relay passed through Lhasa in a trip that comes three months after violent protests erupted in the Tibetan capital and has drawn angry condemnation from many Tibetan advocacy groups. Reporters in Lhasa described a carefully orchestrated procession, expected to last three hours, that was heavily guarded as the torch was carried roughly two miles by more than 150 torchbearers. Olympic organizers initially planned for the torch to spend three days in Tibet but later decided to shorten the relay out of security concerns and, possibly, to tamp down international criticism.

headline: Company Hired to Test Concrete Faces Scrutiny
text: Manhattan prosecutors are investigating whether the leading concrete testing company in the New York area, which has been hired to measure and analyze the strength of the concrete poured at some of the biggest construction projects in the city, failed to do some tests and falsified others, officials involved in the inquiry said on Friday.

headline: Beijing Announces Traffic Plan for Olympics
text: BEIJING  With 49 days remaining before the opening ceremonies of the Olympic Games, and the air soupy with smog, Beijing officials on Friday announced temporary measures to unsnarl the city’s traffic and reduce its chronic and sometimes choking air pollution.

headline: Manuel’s Managing Style Has a Playful Phrase Book
text: DENVER  Jerry Manuel wants to set the record straight.

headline: Smithsonian Unit Is Revamped
text: The Smithsonian Institution is restructuring its merchandising unit, its acting chief executive told staff members on Friday in an internal memo. The acting secretary, Cristián Samper, said that effective on July 1, Smithsonian Business Ventures would be renamed Smithsonian Enterprises and would report directly to the Smithsonian’s secretary and Board of Regents, not to the Business Ventures board, which is being disbanded. The move is partly a response to an audit released five months ago that found that the Smithsonian’s revenue-generating arm, established in 1999, was poorly managed and lacked oversight. “What they are trying to do here is make sure the business operations are more closely aligned with the Smithsonian’s mission,” a Smithsonian spokeswoman said. The business unit has been the focus of criticism since 2006, when it signed a contract giving Showtime Networks exclusive access to the Smithsonian archives for documentary purposes.

headline: Sandbagged
text: Iowa City

headline: Live Nation Chairman Will Step Down
text: Michael Cohl, chairman of Live Nation, the world’s largest concert promoter, stepped down Friday after a report of a strategy dispute with the chief executive, Michael Rapino. Mr. Cohl, who had held the post since February, will become a consultant to the company, based in Beverly Hills, Calif. Mr. Cohl, 60, joined the company’s board in 2006 after Live Nation bought a controlling stake in Concert Productions International, which he founded.

headline: Vice Is Nice
text: Let’s discuss the vice presidency. Come on.

headline: Restaurants Prepare for Big Switch: No Trans Fat
text: Say you are given a choice of two cookies. One is made with butter, the other with partially hydrogenated vegetable oil. Both have the same amount of calories from fat. Which do you choose?

headline: A Global AIDS Campaign Stalled
text: A handful of Republican senators is blocking action on a bill that would greatly increase American funding to combat AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria around the world. If their delaying tactics succeed, the United States will lose considerable leverage in trying to persuade other advanced nations to contribute substantially more money to fight against global disease at the upcoming meeting of the Group of 8 industrial nations.

headline: Mussina Sharp; Reds a Bit Sharper
text: Edinson Vólquez of the Cincinnati Reds is one of the best pitchers in baseball on one of the sport’s worst teams. But the primacy of his position was manifest Friday night when he led his team to a 4-2 victory over the Yankees at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Earth Will Survive After All, Physicists Say
text: That black hole that was going to eat the Earth? Forget about it, and keep making the mortgage payments  those of you who still have them.

headline: Footnotes
text: “August: Osage County” is headed to London this fall. The National Theater announced on Friday that this play by Tracy Letts, which has won a Pulitzer Prize and five Tony Awards, would start an eight-week run at its Lyttelton auditorium in November. ... At its annual convention in Philadelphia on Friday, Americans for the Arts presented the 2008 Arts Education Award to the New Victory Theater in New York. ... The American conductor James Conlon will be awarded the Galileo 2000 Prize from the Fondazione Premio Galileo 2000 in a ceremony on Wednesday in Florence, Italy. Mr. Conlon will be the 12th recipient of the prize, which is awarded each year to an artist who has made a significant contribution to music, art and peace. Past winners include Zubin Mehta, Riccardo Muti and Daniel Barenboim.

headline: Boeing’s Dreamliner Passes a Crucial Test
text: Boeing said that tests on the 787 Dreamliner’s power systems were successful, putting the plane on schedule for its initial flight in the fourth quarter and delivery to customers next year. The Dreamliner’s reliance on electricity, along with lighter-weight composite materials and new technology, will reduce fuel consumption by 20 percent from comparable planes in service now. The electrical system on the 787, which has power levels five times higher than on Boeing’s 767, is largely independent of the jet engines, reducing fuel usage because power isn’t being bled away to run lights and other systems.

headline: U.S. May Free Up More Land for Corn Crops
text: CHICAGO  Signs are growing that the government may allow farmers to plant crops on millions of acres of conservation land, while a chorus of voices is also pleading with Washington to cut requirements for ethanol production.

headline: Longest Day of the Year; Few Notice
text: At precisely 7:59 p.m. on Friday in New York, a momentous celestial event, one that has been celebrated around the planet for thousands of years, officially arrived.

headline: Manuel’s Merit System Pays Off for the Mets
text: DENVER  Luis Castillo was told that he would start Saturday, again on Sunday, and the bulk of the Mets’ remaining games at second base. But he sat Friday night against Colorado, replaced by Damion Easley, as part of Jerry Manuel’s pointed message to his players: Produce, and you will play. Struggle, and you may not.

headline: Canadian Court Allows Phone Buyout to Proceed
text: OTTAWA  The largest leveraged buyout in history skirted a potentially crushing blow on Friday.

headline: Avoiding the Gas Pumps
text: THE constant news coverage of gas prices at more than $4 a gallon has motorists  and magazine editors  looking for alternatives to automobiles.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
text: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from June 13 through June 20:

headline: Assets Rise at Charity Arm of Major Fund
text: Judging by its charitable giving, The Children’s Investment Fund, or TCI, did not suffer from America’s economic downturn or the tight credit market last year.

headline: Most of All, This Farmer Needs a Hand
text: Now it is clear why the farmer wants a wife: to help fill sandbags. Matt Neustadt, above, the Missouri farmer who is nearing the end of his televised search for a potential mate on the CW reality show “Farmer Wants a Wife,” found himself with bigger priorities this week when a levee near his family’s farm gave way, opening up some 700 of its 2,000 acres to flooding. Mr. Neustadt, of Portage Des Sioux, about 25 miles north of St. Louis, is just one of thousands along the Mississippi and other rivers who are suffering from flooding. The Neustadt family land, near Alton, has flooded at least a half-dozen times in the last 35 years, Mr. Neustadt said in a telephone interview. Even before the levee broke on Thursday, the land had been soaked by seeping groundwater. “We were able to plant about 500 acres of corn,” Mr. Neustadt said. “We might have 300 left.” The flooding, which had Mr. Neustadt shoveling sand into bags for much of Wednesday and Thursday, has left him little time to think about television. The series, which was taped last summer, is scheduled to conclude on Wednesday, when Mr. Neustadt, 30, chooses between Christa, 22, and Brooke, 23. The women have feuded since the opening episode, when Brooke interrupted Christa’s date with Matt by wrapping his truck in toilet paper. The series has respectable ratings, with an average of 2.2 million viewers tuning in each Wednesday at 9 p.m. Eastern time.

headline: Oft-Injured Gymnast Tries to Prove He Belongs on the Team
text: PHILADELPHIA  For the 15 men in the mix to make the United States Olympic gymnastics team, it has come down to one final afternoon of competition, one final day of pressure.

headline: Big Dig Contractor Faces Charges in Tunnel Collapse
text: BOSTON  The largest construction contractor involved in the Big Dig was charged in federal court on Friday with actions that federal prosecutors say contributed to problems that caused a fatal tunnel ceiling collapse in 2006.

headline: Ready to Attack Obama, if Some Money Arrives
text: UNIVERSITY PLACE, Wash.  A Bible verse taped to a whiteboard in Floyd Brown’s office that he uses to track his efforts to attack Senator Barack Obama reads, “That is why for Christ’s sake I delight in weakness, in insults, in hardships, in persecutions, in difficulties.”

headline: The Gaza Blockade
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taking His Cue From the Fish
text: LOWELL, Mass.  At some point in almost every angler’s life there comes a time when the object of the game goes from catching a lot of fish to catching big fish.

headline: No Money to Heat Homes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bacon a Hard Way: Hog-Tying 400 Pounds of Fury
text: MONTGOMERY, Tex.  That could not have been a wild sow that Nub was barking at down in the scrub brush. Those hogs out behind the golf course were fast, smart and wary of hunters, and Nub was just an unproven pup. At first, the grown hounds ignored his staccato yap.

headline: Faith From the South, and a One-Man Band Too
text: If I had to choose a single word to describe the mystique of the singer Lizz Wright, it would be steadfast.

headline: A Featured Spot for Rove Raises at Least One Eyebrow
text: Is it morally fastidious to find something disconcerting in the fact that the featured speaker at the National Right to Life Committee’s annual convention in two weeks will be Karl Rove?

headline: Price Increases Put Pressure on the Fed
text: INFLATION is suddenly turning into a worry for the Federal Reserve, which knows that its credibility as a central bank would be damaged if investors concluded it was not determined to combat the recent rise in prices.

headline: Mexican Peso Strengthens on Rate Increase
text: Mexico’s peso closed at its strongest level against the dollar in five years Friday after the Bank of Mexico raised its benchmark interest rate, citing higher inflation. The currency was quoted in Mexico City closing at 10.275 pesos to the dollar, compared with 10.3185 at the open and Thursday’s close of 10.3120. The Bank of Mexico raised the overnight rate to 7.75 percent, from 7.5 percent, in its first monetary policy move since last October.

headline: Obama Cites Attack Ads as a Failing of the System
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Senator Barack Obama on Friday justified his decision to drop out of the public financing system for the general election by contending that the system fails to account for vast spending by independent groups.

headline: Rise in Renters Erasing Gains for Ownership
text: WASHINGTON  Driven largely by the surge in foreclosures and an unsettled housing market, Americans are renting apartments and houses at the highest level since President Bush started a campaign to expand homeownership in 2002.

headline: Brooklyn Gains TKTS
text: A new TKTS discount tickets booth is opening on July 10 in Brooklyn. The booth, operated by the Theater Development Fund, will be in the MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn at the corner of Jay Street and Myrtle Avenue. For the most part, it will operate like the two other TKTS booths in Times Square and at the South Street Seaport, except that it will also sell tickets to Brooklyn arts events, like productions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The renovated TKTS booth in Times Square is scheduled to open later this summer.

headline: Comics Convention Beckons Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES  For those planning to attend Comic-Con International, the giant comic-book and fantasy convention scheduled to begin on July 24 in San Diego, the event’s organizers have published some helpful hints. No. 21: “Please don’t smell bad.”

headline: Time Is Running Out for a Celebrated Building
text: Of the many Modernist buildings Paul Rudolph designed in Sarasota, Fla., his stomping ground in the 1940s and ’50s, Riverview High School is among the most influential.

headline: Travelers Shift to Rail as Cost of Fuel Rises
text: WASHINGTON  Record prices for gasoline and jet fuel should be good news for Amtrak, as travelers look for alternatives to cut the cost of driving and flying.

text: The Arts

headline: Italian Plan to Deal With Migrants Could Affect Residents Who Rely on Them
text: ROME  It is an everyday symbol, touching almost, of Italy’s troubled demographics: an older Italian out for some air, at times arm in arm with an immigrant aide. The aides often are not here legally but have been tolerated because they do work few Italians do: care for the nation’s rapidly aging population.

headline: For Yemen’s Leader, a Balancing Act Gets Harder
text: SANA, Yemen

headline: Big Gains for Iraq Security, but Questions Linger
text: BAGHDAD  What’s going right? And can it last?

headline: Knicks Name 3 Assistant Coaches
text: The Knicks’ new coaching staff will be small, familiar and  for the first time in years  will not require a game of musical chairs.

headline: Exhibition in Chinatown
text: The worlds of basketball and soccer will meet on artificial turf in downtown Manhattan on Wednesday when Steve Nash of the Phoenix Suns and Claudio Reyna of the Red Bulls host the Showdown in Chinatown. The soccer match, for the benefit of the two players’ charitable foundations, will be played at Sara D. Roosevelt Park from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. The roster of players also includes the English soccer players Steve McManaman and Robbie Fowler, and the N.B.A. players Jason Kidd, Baron Davis, Raja Bell, Leandro Barbosa and David Lee.

headline: A Mix of Sand, Gravel and Glue That Drives the City Ever Higher
text: It is the sinew of the city’s muscular skyline, without which there would be far fewer skyscrapers, streets and museums.

headline: With Flurry of Deals, and Eye on Calendar, Congress Clears Decks
text: WASHINGTON  After months of sniping and stalemate, a hyper-partisan Congress is experiencing a sudden burst of harmony and productivity, as illustrated by the easy House approval on Friday of a divisive and long-stalled terror surveillance measure.

headline: How to Complicate Habeas Corpus
text: Chicago

headline: Beef Furor Provokes a Turnover in Seoul
text: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-bak replaced 9 of 10 senior presidential aides on Friday, hoping the changes would help restore trust in his four-month-old government, which has been shaken by a deeply unpopular deal on importing American beef.

headline: A.M.D. and Its War With Intel
text: A few weeks ago, Stephen Labaton of The New York Times broke the news that the Federal Trade Commission had decided to open a formal antitrust investigation into Intel, the world’s dominant maker of microprocessors. Subpoenas had gone out not just to Intel, but to many of the computer manufacturers who rely on Intel chips. The investigation, as Mr. Labaton wrote, was going to revolve around “accusations that Intel’s pricing is intended to maintain a near monopoly on the microprocessor market.”

headline: Michael Shernoff, 57, Gay-Health Therapist, Is Dead
text: Michael Shernoff, a psychotherapist who beginning in the early years of the AIDS epidemic wrote widely on its emotional toll on gay men and who organized an early safe-sex workshop, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57.

headline: Fox Takes Thursday
text: On a low-rated Thursday of almost-summer television, Fox came away as the most-watched network, thanks to its game show “Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?” (7.8 million viewers, winning the 8 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsen’s estimates) followed by a results edition of “So You Think You Can Dance” (8.8 million, winning the 9 p.m. slot). CBS finished second for the night, broadcasting comedy repeats during the 8 o’clock hour, a “CSI” rerun at 9 and “Swingtown” at 10, which managed to win its time slot despite an audience of just 6.1 million viewers. Also at 10, NBC’s “Fear Itself” drew only 4.7 million viewers, as did NBC’s 90-minute episode of “Last Comic Standing,” from 8:30 to 10. NBC finished in third place over all. ABC was fourth with a rerun of “Ugly Betty” at 8 (3.1 million) followed by a two-hour “Grey’s Anatomy” repeat from 9 to 11 (3.2 million).

headline: Oil’s Perspective on What’s Behind the Energy Crisis
text: AT a time of record gasoline costs and surging oil prices, oil companies are in an increasingly uncomfortable position. They are blamed by both the public and Congress for the current energy crisis, but complain about being hamstrung in their own search for energy sources.

headline: Hewitt D. Crane, 81, Early Computer Engineer, Is Dead
text: Hewitt D. Crane, who was instrumental in the design and construction of the first commercial computer to automate checking accounts, died on Tuesday at his home in Portola Valley, Calif., not far from Ridge Vineyards, which he helped found. He was 81.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture credit on Friday with a theater entry in the Listings pages about the Clubbed Thumb Summerworks festival misspelled the photographer’s surname. The picture, of a scene in “Vendetta Chrome,” is by Carl Skutsch, not Skutch. (Go to Article)

headline: Owner and Trainer Cry Foul Over Horse’s Positive Test
text: Two of the most outspoken critics on the use of drugs in horse racing recently had a colt of their own fail a drug test, a result that they are saying was sabotage. Larry Jones, who trained the late filly Eight Belles, and Jim Squires, the breeder of 2001 Kentucky Derby winner Monarchos, were notified on Tuesday that Stones River had tested positive for illegal levels of clenbuterol, a bronchodilator that helps burn fat and promote muscle growth, after a race on June 8 at Delaware Park.

headline: Dealer Accused of Selling Banned Munitions to Army
text: WASHINGTON  The 22-year-old president of a Miami Beach arms-dealing company and three other people were charged Friday with selling prohibited Chinese ammunition to the Pentagon to supply Afghan security forces, federal officials said.

headline: Griffey Says His Focus Is on the Reds, Not the Rays
text: If Reds outfielder Ken Griffey Jr. is seriously yearning to join the American League East pennant race and play for the Tampa Bay Rays, he sure did a good job of deflecting the question Friday evening.

headline: Tourist Helicopter Rides Are Set to Be Phased Out
text: The uproar over the noisy comings and goings of sightseeing helicopters along the West Side of Manhattan has finally led to a plan to eliminate them.

headline: The Court and Workers
text: The Supreme Court under Chief Justice John Roberts quickly carved out a reputation for being reflexively pro-business. On Thursday, however, it issued a good ruling in favor of workers suing for age discrimination, the latest of several pro-worker decisions. The ruling is an encouraging sign that the court may be evolving in its approach to cases brought by workers who have been treated unfairly.

headline: Fake Gems, Genuine Appeal
text: MANUFACTURED diamonds have become “as pure and nearly as big as the finest specimens hauled out of the ground,” Ulrich Boser reports in Smithsonian magazine (smithsonianmag.com). This has profound implications for a number of industries, but producers of “natural diamonds,” the magazine reports, “are less enthusiastic.”

headline: The Irish Voted. The Treaty Lost. That’s Democracy.
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Zany Spirit of Shaw, Adapted Into Operas
text: George Bernard Shaw wrote his short, fanciful play “The Dark Lady of the Sonnets” for a performance in 1910 in support of establishing a national theater to honor Shakespeare. Here Shaw puts a royal twist into the mystery surrounding these love poems: To whom were they directed? In another short work, “Passion, Poison and Petrifaction, or the Fatal Gazogene,” Shaw gleefully skewers the murderous mayhem and convoluted plot turns of Shakespearean drama.

headline: Dealing With More Than Just Olympic Trials
text: PHILADELPHIA  There were so many times, too many to count, that Darling Hill wanted to quit gymnastics. Times when she would stand beneath the uneven bars and cry with fear. Times when she would hide beneath her bedcovers, wishing that she could skip practice.

headline: Choosing the Right Gift for a Graduate (Just Don’t Send a Check)
text: MY younger son is already lobbying for his present when he graduates from elementary school  in 2009.

headline: R.E.M.: The Histories and Commentaries
text: Michael Stipe, lead singer of R.E.M., spent a great deal of time explicating on Thursday night, good-naturedly turning Madison Square Garden into a lecture hall. “This,” he said of “Disturbance at the Heron House,” from 1987, “is my rewriting of the novel ‘Animal Farm.’ ” “Ignoreland,” from 1992, was his “barely adult reaction to the Iran-Contra scandal.” And “Man-Sized Wreath,” from this year’s album “Accelerate”(Warner Brothers), was inspired, he said, by the day in 2004 when, met by several hundred protesters, President Bush visited  or, in Mr. Stipe’s description, “desecrated”  the grave of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Still Opposing Plan to Develop Willets Point, One Business Decides to Sell
text: The offer from the city was sweet enough to jeopardize the rewards of decades of tedious surgery  gutted transmissions, mix-and-match motor parts, skeletons of abandoned cars. So sweet, in fact, that it persuaded Daniel Sambucci to aid a plan he still opposes.

headline: After Duty, New Chance for Old Job
text: WESTFIELD, Mass.  Michael Serricchio says being a stockbroker has always been his ideal occupation. And for a time, he had his dream, working for Prudential Securities in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Ford Delays New Pickup and Reduces Production
text: DEARBORN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company said on Friday that it would delay introducing its new pickup, a vehicle critical to its plan to become profitable, and that it would probably lose money for a fourth consecutive year in 2009 because of a precipitous drop in demand for large vehicles.

headline: Chief of Mexican Brewery Quits Busch Board
text: Carlos Fernandez Gonzalez, the chief executive of Grupo Modelo, resigned Friday from the board of Anheuser-Busch as it began an all-day meeting to weigh a $46.4 billion takeover bid from rival InBev.

headline: Hope and Caution as Some See Signs of Mississippi River’s Retreat
text: In besieged cities and towns along the Mississippi River, a tense calm descended Friday as residents greeted federal officials’ predictions of lower flood levels with hope and caution.

headline: Why Is Oil So High? Pick a View
text: People who have spent their careers tracking the ups and downs of the global oil markets say their compasses are spinning. Oil prices rise for reasons they cannot quite fathom, and where prices will be a year from now has become, literally, anybody’s guess.

Roosevelt Park from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. The roster of players also includes the English soccer players Steve McManaman and Robbie Fowler, and the N.B.A. players Jason Kidd, Baron Davis, Raja Bell, Leandro Barbosa and David Lee.

headline: A Harvest That Falls Short
text: India is struggling to grow enough food to meet increasing demand, fueled by expanding population and affluence.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Vice Is Nice
text: As voters, all we need out of a vice-presidential nominee is that he or she be qualified to run the store in the event of crisis, on more or less the same lines as the top of the ticket. Picking a running mate is–no disrespect intended–like picking a pet.

headline: ‘Flocking to Tijuana’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC:  John McCain’s daughter is writing a children’s book based her father’s life. The children’s book is called, “James and the Giant Prostate.”

headline: Wall Street Braces for More Layoffs
text: The blood-letting on Wall Street continues. And even bankers untouched by previous rounds, including those in mergers and acquisitions, are now targets for layoffs.

headline: Calvo on commodities
text: Guillermo Calvo is one of my favorite economists. But — you know there had to be a but — I just don’t buy his latest missive. Still, it’s important that we have this debate: something awesome is happening to oil and other commodities, and figuring out what it means is crucial.

headline: The Early Word: $21 Million May
text: When Senator Barack Obama declined public financing for the general election, he committed himself to a lot of extra fund-raising. And he’ll have to do even more of it if he wants to do better than he did in the month of May, when he brought in about $22 million, as his campaign reported last night – a somewhat unimpressive figure relative to what he has achieved in previous months, and only slightly more than Senator John McCain’s haul. Experts say Mr. Obama likely experienced a surge in donations after he took the nomination earlier this month.

headline: Tomorrow’s Grand Prix today
text: Why do I feel like I should save myself some time tomorrow by writing my race report of the French Grand Prix today? Because two Ferraris scored the fastest times of qualifying, because Lewis Hamilton was third fastest but will be thrown 10 spots back on the grid and cannot hope to win the race, and because Fernando Alonso will therefore be bumped up to third, but cannot hope to win either.

headline: Still Fighting the ‘Swift Boat’ Battle
text: For most people, “Swift Boat” has become a political verb, a synonym for the kind of attack that helped destroy Senator John Kerry’s presidential campaign in 2004.

headline: The Starting Line: U.S. Teams Are Taking Shape
text: A series of marquee Olympic qualifying events in the United States kicked off this week, with the gymnastics and diving trials, followed by the track and field trials and swimming trials next weekend.

headline: ‘You Think You Got Trouble’
text: Aired Friday night on CBS: Hot here in New York City — are you folks hot? I’ll give you an idea how hot it is today: coming to work, coming to work today, it was so hot that the navigation lady kept directing me to Dairy Queen.

headline: U.S. Women Keep On Rolling
text: Angela Hucles scored the game’s only goal in second-half injury time as the United States women’s national team defeated Canada, 1-0, to win the Peace Queen Cup on Saturday in Suwon, South Korea.

headline: The Babe’s Daughter Salutes A-Rod
text: Julia Ruth Stevens, the daughter of Babe Ruth, stood in the summer sunshine behind home plate and blew kisses to the fans at Yankee Stadium on Saturday, and the fans responded with warm cheers. The public-address system played the song “Sultans of Swing”‘ by Dire Straits.

headline: It’s Hong Kong beach season!
text: “What?” careful Globespotters readers might ask. “Didn’t you just write that it’s typhoon season?”  Well, it’s both. If it were rainy, windy and dark from April to September, we’d all emigrate to Canada. (Oh yeah, we already did that during the post-Tiananman crackdown / pre-handover scare, but we’ve mostly returned now).

headline: Mussina and Girardi: Difference of Opinion
text: During Friday night’s 4-2 loss to Cincinnati at Yankee Stadium, the Yankees’ Mike Mussina was not happy about being ordered to walk the left-handed-hitting Jay Bruce with two outs and a man on third in the fifth inning with the score tied, 1-1.

headline: Seeds of Efficient Killing
text: History | It’s a case of plowshares into swords: The idea for Richard Gatling’s war-changing machine gun was borrowed from an earlier Gatling machine, a seed hopper designed to speed planting. Bullets, seeds — both go into a chamber for distribution. — Chicago Tribune , Economist

headline: Nicholas D. Kristof: Inside the West Bank
text: The security system that Israel is steadily establishing is nowhere more stifling than in Hebron, the largest city in the southern part of the West Bank.

headline: Your Comments on my West Bank Column
text: My Sunday column is about the West Bank occupation, told largely through Hebron. More broadly, I argue that when American politicians compete to be “pro-Israeli,” they too often line up behind the one that oppresses Palestinians on the West Bank and not enough behind the one of Israeli human rights groups, historians and journalists that fights relentlessly for fairness for those same Palestinians. I would love to see American politicians showing up not only at Aipac but also at B’Tselem.

headline: Benee Frenzel, Michael Meade
text: Benee Lisa Frenzel, the daughter of Adria L. Frenzel and Bruce A. Frenzel of St. Albans, Mo., was married on Saturday to Michael Meade, a son of Barbara M. Meade and George J. Meade of Oakland, N.J. The Rev. John J. Cryan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Congress Hall, a hotel in Cape May, N.J. Rabbi Charles Davidson participated in the ceremony.

headline: The Executive Power Awaiting the Next President
text: President Bush’s drive for the greatest expansion in executive power since the Nixon era is slowly grinding to a halt after years of challenges by the courts, Congress, and now, the political calendar. Yet that hardly means that he has been pushed all the way back to Sept. 10, 2001.

headline: F.C.C. Bars Verizon Tactic
text: The Federal Communications Commission has voted to stop Verizon Communications from trying to talk its customers out of switching to another telephone provider while they wait for their phone numbers to be transferred.

headline: To the Trenches: The Tort War Is Raging On
text: IN a Washington ballroom bedecked with flags honoring explorers who overcame oceans and mountains to pursue international trade, Thomas J. Donohue congratulated the assembled modern merchants  a group of executives, lobbyists and lawyers  for challenging a more mundane adversary.
