headline: Death Can Be a Canny Career Move
text: FOR years, when the artist Steven Parrino wasn’t jamming power chords on his electric guitar or tinkering with his motorcycle in his garagelike studio in Brooklyn, he was recycling his unsold paintings: twisting them into eccentric new shapes, smashing their stretcher bars or stabbing them repeatedly with scissors.

headline: Inside the List
text: KNOW YOUR BEST SELLERS: Novelists who regularly place books on this list write prose that their ardent admirers can recognize from a block away. Can you tell these writers apart? Here’s a pop quiz. Each sentence below comes from the first page of one of the top 10 novels on your right. See if you can match the sentence with the book  answers are at bottom.

headline: When Height Becomes a Tall Tale
text: How many times have you heard or read that a basketball player is listed at, say, 6 feet 8 inches but that he is really closer to 6-6? Do you ever wonder how something as objective as height can be in doubt, especially for elite players?

headline: Becoming the Boss
text: FOR 10 years Lisa Krizner-George had worked as a draper, making costumes for Broadway shows like “Wicked,” “Hairspray” and “Oklahoma!” She took sketches from designers and turned fantasies into fabric. But becoming a designer herself would have required an extra degree and starting over in the kind of company where she worked.

headline: Henry Chadwick, Scholar of Early Christianity, Dies at 87
text: The Very Rev. Henry Chadwick, an Anglican priest, professor, editor, translator and author whose historical voyages into early Christianity won praise for depth, insight and evenhandedness and helped shed light on modern religious problems, died Tuesday in Oxford, England. He was 87.

headline: Are You Ready for Some Gaelic Football?
text: APPRECIATING the foods immigrants have brought to New York City is pretty easy for the visitor: pop a dumpling into your mouth or chomp on a taco and you get it: this thing tastes good. But checking out the imported and home-grown sports played around the city doesn’t always provide instant satisfaction: someone needs to be there to explain what you’re seeing.

headline: Melissa Schweiger, Mitchell Kleinman
text: Melissa Amy Schweiger and Mitchell Seth Kleinman are to be married on Sunday in New York. Rabbi Daniel Pernick is to officiate at Pier 60, Chelsea Piers.

headline: Susan Burke, Michael O’Neal
text: Susan Helen Burke and Michael Joseph O’Neal were married on Saturday in Westerly, R.I. The Rev. Thomas F. X. Hoar, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

headline: When Reining In an Imperial President Was the Conservatives’ Cause
text: Odd though it may seem, ideological conservatives used to be fierce critics of “executive supremacy.” For instance, in 1940, when Franklin D. Roosevelt sought a precedent-breaking third term, the archconservative Herbert Hoover warned that Roosevelt was a virtual dictator whose growing “personal power over the last seven years” came at the expense of a “disastrous weakening of the legislative and judicial branches ” with Congress “reduced to a rubber stamp for the executive.”

headline: Bed-Stuy’s Long-Playing Music Man
text: JOE LONG, the owner of Birdell’s, a venerable independent record store on Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, has supplied three generations of music lovers with 45s, 78s, 33s, cassette tapes, CDs, DVDs and the occasional dollop of fatherly advice.

headline: Sure, Land Is Cheaper. So Is It Time to Buy?
text: THE real estate market may have cooled, but investor demand may soon be heating up for at least one type of property: land.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Music and Dance

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The cover article this weekend about a horn player who helped teach students at Ditmas Junior High School in Brooklyn how to play instruments misstates the percentage by which New York City’s financing cuts reduced the school’s budget. The school lost 1.4 percent of its financing, not 13 percent.

headline: Sunny Cable Ratings Under Blue Skies
text: BONNIE HAMMER, whose success since she took the helm of both USA cable network and the Sci Fi Channel recently earned her control of the cable programming portion of the newly divided Universal television studio, has a simple formula for her success: upbeat programming.

headline: From Pickles to Paintings in New York’s Lower East Side
text: THE Lower East Side of Manhattan is being SoHo-fied. (Or is it Chelsea-fied?) Concrete floors are being poured next to Chinatown fish stalls. White walls are going up beside kitchen supply shops. And on-the-edge contemporary art is being sold in a neighborhood better known for peddling pickles and counterfeit Goyard bags.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Metro

headline: Casey Bahrenburg, Gregory Forbes
text: Ashford Cameron Bahrenburg and Gregory Wells Forbes were married on Saturday in San Francisco. The Rev. Mark E. Stanger, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Cathedral, and the Rev. Alice M. Trowbridge, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bride, also participated.

headline: Constance Pendleton, Jason Gross
text: Constance Morrow Pendleton and Jason John Gross are to be married on Sunday. The Rev. Chloe A. Breyer, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at Meridian House in Washington.

headline: Wall Street’s Fading Crush on G.E.
text: USUALLY, it’s easy to find bullish analysts on Wall Street. In fact, the criticism leveled most often at stock pickers at major brokerage firms is that they’re too easy on the companies they cover, explaining away every earnings miss and always finding another reason to slap on a buy rating.

headline: Ballet Departures: Life After New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Quest of Perfection, a Menu to Please
text: A FRIEND laughs about the last time she asked for a restaurant recommendation on a recent trip. Not only did I tell her where to go, but I also told her exactly what to order. She still delights in the memory of that meal.

headline: Installations Worthy of the Name
text: Installation art is all about the manipulation of scale and sensibility. The size of the installation is crucial, either occupying most of a gallery to impress at first sight, or radically scaled down so as to invite inspection and enable viewers to focus on the artists’ command of detail. Sensibility is a lot more complicated. The theme or subject of the installation must be sufficiently familiar to allow quick recognition, but also witty or intriguing enough to excite curiosity. The choice of materials helps, preferably something unusual that does not commonly belong in a gallery.

headline: Night Moves
text: Is it dangerous to lark in Central Park at night? Not really, Marie Winn says in “Central Park in the Dark.” The “precinct enjoys the city’s lowest crime rate,” she writes. This may be true on a per acre basis (not per capita), but still, it wasn’t until the author came to know the park extremely well that her fear of the night receded, “though it never disappeared completely. Familiarity breeds content.”

headline: ‘The Pixar Touch’
text: Still another film was in Pixar's pipeline during the making of A Bug's Life. Talk of a sequel to Toy Story began around a month after Toy Story opened, when Catmull, Lasseter, and Guggenheim visited Joe Roth, Katzenberg's successor as chairman of Walt Disney Studios. Roth was pleased and embraced the idea.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: BOTTLEMANIA: How Water Went on Sale and Why We Bought It, by Elizabeth Royte. (Bloomsbury, $24.99.) Royte streams cultural, economic, political and hydrological trends into an engaging investigation of an unexpectedly murky substance.

headline: At Odds With Air Force, Army Adds Its Own Aviation Unit
text: WASHINGTON  Ever since the Army lost its warplanes to a newly independent Air Force after World War II, soldiers have depended on the sister service for help from the sky, from bombing and strafing to transport and surveillance.

headline: The Devil Wears Nada
text: On the first page of “The Garden of Last Days,” a young stripper named April drives her car to work with a scalding hot cup of coffee between her legs. Even if she weren’t about to bare her thighs, along with everything else, this wouldn’t seem to be a great idea. But it’s all too indicative of how her night is going to go  and of April’s judgment, or lack thereof. She’s also a single mother who has strapped her 3-year-old daughter into the car to take her to work. Within a couple of pages, April pulls a U-turn, with predictable results for her thighs.

headline: A Victory for Women
text: Three women from Guinea won a court victory in Manhattan this month in their struggle to win asylum as victims of the barbaric form of persecution known as female genital cutting. In doing so, they have shined a light on the urgent need for consistent humane policies that treat women’s rights as fundamental human rights.

headline: Karen Hui and George Parker
text: Karen Yung-Yee Hui and George Finley Parker were married yesterday afternoon at the Church of Our Lady of Pompeii in New York. The Rev. John C. Massari, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Honoring the ‘Uphill Battle’ of a Champion of New Choral Music
text: THE conductor Harold Rosenbaum, recent recipient of the Laurel Leaf Award from the American Composers Alliance, sees choral composers today as a neglected species. Avocational or school choruses, which account for most choruses in the United States, are reluctant to tackle music they fear will be overly complex, he says. Music publishers fear contemporary works will be too atonal to sell.

headline: Man Fatally Shot After Car Crash
text: A 25-year-old man was shot to death in the Bronx early on Saturday in a dispute that apparently was touched off by a minor car accident, the police said.

headline: Reading File
text: DOING EVERYTHING ALL AT ONCE

headline: She Is What She Eats
text: “I HAVE the biggest sweet tooth in the world,” Abigail Breslin said, her feet swinging above the ground. She was sitting in the back room of Veniero’s, an East Village bakery, one recent afternoon, waiting for her favorite dessert, raspberry mousse cake. “Oh, my God, the anticipation!” she said, her knee jiggling.

headline: Assassins in Zimbabwe Aim at the Grass Roots
text: JOHANNESBURG  Tonderai Ndira was a shrewd choice for assassination: young, courageous and admired. Kill him and fear would pulse through a thousand spines. He was an up-and-comer in Zimbabwe’s opposition party, a charismatic figure with a strong following in the Harare slums where he lived.

headline: Lauren Gendal, River Elliott
text: Lauren Jill Gendal, the daughter of Susan Teicher Gendal of New York and Dr. Jay T. Gendal of Coram, N.Y., is to be married on Sunday to Dr. River McKenzie Elliott, the son of Anne L. Clement of Mount Pleasant, S.C., and Ronald J. Elliott Jr. of Edisto Island, S.C. Cantor Shirah Sklar is to officiate at Monteverde, an inn and restaurant in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y.

headline: Drew Shows Presence in Ortiz’s Absence
text: J. D. Drew could not have picked a better time to find his stroke.

headline: Alexi Curlee, Henry Cashen III
text: Alexi Elysia Curlee, a daughter of Pamela A. Curlee of Denver and Dr. Paul G. Curlee of Durango, Colo., was married yesterday evening to Henry Christopher Cashen III, a son of Leslie Cashen Clevenger and Henry C. Cashen II of Washington. The Rev. Declan Jarry, a priest of the Old Catholic Church of America, officiated at the Beaumont Hotel in Ouray, Colo.

headline: The Great American Float
text: WASHINGTON — Few things are certain in presidential politics, but here are three: it will be expensive; it will get negative; and, at some point, former Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia will be mentioned as a possible Democratic running mate.

headline: These Days, Nitpickers Make House Calls
text: WHEN people call Linda Strand a nitpicker, they’re not kidding.

headline: Trying to Save a Link to a Legend and an Era
text: JOHN BENZ FENTNER, a lawyer from Unionville, Conn., is a serious Marx Brothers fan, if the word “serious” can properly be applied to devotees of that madcap comedy family. Mr. Fentner can name all six brothers  a true litmus test of Marx fandom, he said  and collects even underwhelming Marx Brothers movies like the 1968 Otto Preminger flop “Skidoo,” which featured Groucho as a crime boss named God.

headline: In Search of Perfect Harmony, Through Software

headline: When Brothers Collide

Don Lee’s satiric novel, “Wrack and Ruin,” is narrated by two prime representatives of these rival camps. Lyndon Song is a reclusive slacker and an aimless has-been. He earns a living growing organic Brussels sprouts. Woody Song, an aspiring Hollywood deal-maker, is a pill-popping, germ-phobic overachiever. The two men are brothers. Polar opposites, they despise each other with manic intensity.

headline: On a Forgiving Course, Cink Relaxes and Thrives

headline: Correction: Review of ‘American Nerd’
text: A review on June 1 about “American Nerd,” by Benjamin Nugent, misstated the source to which the book traces the word “nerd.” It was a 1950 work of Dr. Seuss, “If I Ran the Zoo,” not mid-1960s issues of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute’s student humor magazine. (The magazine may have been the first to use the word fully in its current sense, the book suggests; in Seuss, it is a nonsense name for a fanciful animal.)

Memorial Highway.”

headline: Don’t Tell When Hiring
text: I am a supervisor at a large corporation in the Bible Belt. I am gay and out and, while the company has no formal nondiscrimination policy, my colleagues and supervisors generally have no issues with my sexuality. I am about to interview a potential employee in his early 20s, who hunts, drives a truck and did not attend college. I want those who join my team to be of a tolerant disposition. Would it be appropriate to tell this applicant that I am gay?  NAME WITHHELD

headline: Fresh Cuts for the Barbie

As for the livestock, many breeds of pigs, goats and cattle are being raised directly behind the building.

headline: A Green Coal Baron?
text: When I met with Jim Rogers one day this spring, he tossed back two double espressos in a single hour. A charming and natty 60-year-old, Rogers is the chief executive of the electric company Duke Energy. But he has none of the macho, cowboy stolidity you might expect in an energy C.E.O. Instead, he lives to brainstorm. He spends more than half his time on the road, a perennial fixture at wonky gatherings like the Davos World Economic Forum and the Clinton Global Initiative, corralling “clean energy” thinkers and listening eagerly to their ideas. The day we met, he was brimming with enthusiasm for a new approach to solar power. Solar is currently too expensive to make economic sense, according to Rogers, because the cost to put panels on a roof is greater than what a household would save on electricity. But what if Duke bought panels en masse, driving the price down, and installed them itself  free?

headline: Correction

headline: Berlin, the Big Canvas

headline: How My Husband Won Back My Vote
text: LAST year I boycotted our 18th wedding anniversary. My husband, Andy, had gone out of town for our anniversary day but had left me a gift. I refused to open it. He called at least 10 times. I didn’t answer. And, for the first time, I didn’t give him an anniversary gift. I desperately wanted to make a statement, to shake us out of our ingrained and selfish habits.

headline: International Touch Lines
text: A few years ago I spent a semester teaching American history and English in Erbil, the capital of the Kurdistan region of Iraq. The campus of the university where I taught has both a basketball court and a soccer field. The court was always empty, but the dirt field, with lines barely visible and netless goals, was frequently filled with players in mismatched jerseys and winter jackets who lacked for nothing in confidence or joy. Soccer is a sport I’ve enjoyed all my life, and the many invitations I received to play on that field made me feel welcome, not only at the university but in that part of the world. So last summer, when I returned to the region, I suspected it wouldn’t be long before the games began again.

headline: 12 Innocent Men
text: My grandfather lived in West Helena, Ark., in 1919, in Phillips County, the place of the race massacre chronicled in “On the Laps of Gods.” A box of his papers that I recently uncovered shows evidence of that Jim Crow era in action  a receipt for his poll taxes from 1917, identifying him as white and stamped with the name of the sheriff, Frank Kitchens. Robert Whitaker’s book quotes a letter in which Kitchens is described as wanting a “free hand to hunt Mr. Nigger in his lair.”

headline: A Case of Liability and a Leaky Ice Maker
text: Q When I was out of town, the water line to my ice maker leaked and caused damage to the ceiling of the apartment below. The co-op managing agent charged my account for the repairs, and I submitted the bill to my insurance company. But the company will not cover me for the damage because it claims that I am not legally liable, since I had no notice of the problem and had committed no negligent act.

headline: Dinner ‘Plates’ That Are Priced for the Economy
text: FOR decades the place to eat after browsing in the charming shops of Cold Spring Harbor was Wyland’s Country Kitchen, where every meal ended with a piece of one of the famous pies. In 2003, the landmark gave way to a bustling fish house, Bedlam Street Fish and Clam Company, which was succeeded in April by Charlotte’s Bistro.

headline: Hertz Changes Way it Charges for Gas
text: On July 1, Hertz (www.hertz.com) will introduce a new refueling program. Instead of its current practice of charging about $7.50 a gallon to refuel a returned car with less than a full tank of gas, it will charge a one-time fee of $6.99, plus the average price per gallon locally, as determined by the Oil Price Information Service. To calculate the rate, Hertz will take the average price charged by the three gas stations closest to the facility where the car is being returned. Hertz has also revamped its fuel-purchase option. Those who opt to pay for Hertz-provided gas upfront will also pay the local market rates minus a small amount (about 15 cents a gallon).

headline: New Coach for Pelfrey but the Same Old Goals
text: DENVER  For Mike Pelfrey, the message has not changed even if the messenger has. A new pitching coach, Dan Warthen, will oversee Pelfrey’s start against the Colorado Rockies on Sunday, and it is the first time Pelfrey has worked with anyone at the major league level other than Rick Peterson, who was fired Tuesday.

headline: The Greed Beat
text: As I finished Joe Nocera’s “Good Guys and Bad Guys”  a collection of his best business writing over the last quarter-century  I found myself wishing he’d waited a year to publish it. Or maybe just six months. Because by then Nocera would certainly have trained his no-nonsense eye and deceptively simple writing style on the kind of scandal it seems he was born to chronicle: the subprime mortgage disaster. Peopled as it is with so many scoundrels and fools  and even a few good guys  the subprime story is precisely the sort of economic morality tale that Nocera has excelled at telling for so long, with himself cast as the stern schoolmaster.

It found that the frequency of sexual intercourse among married couples 18 to 29 years old was about 109 times a year  not 84 times, which refers to the frequency among all 18- to 29-year-olds.

headline: Now That We’ve ‘Won,’ Let’s Come Home

When a bomb killed at least 51 Iraqis at a Baghdad market on Tuesday, ending an extended run of relative calm, only one of the three network newscasts (NBC’s) even bothered to mention it.

headline: ‘Central Park in the Dark’
text: The first time I walked through the Ramble at night I was terrified. I had been there in the daytime often enough; that thirty-seven-acre wilderness in the heart of Central Park is where I first became a birdwatcher. But the very features that enchanted me by day — the winding paths, the thicket of trees blocking out the city in all directions, the rock formations cropping up out of nowhere, the secret coves, the rustic bridges and sylvan streams — all looked grotesque and menacing in the darkness. A shadow looming up ahead brought back a scary illustration from my childhood fairy-tale book, the silhouette of a horrible, grinning witch about to seize innocent children just like me! And those rustlings to the right of the path and the small, throaty growls from the bushes near the Lake — was I imagining them?

headline: Juliana Terian, Bruce Gilbert
text: Juliana Curran Terian and Bruce Gilbert were married on Saturday in Del Mar, Calif., at the home of the bridegroom’s father, Ross S. Gilbert, and his stepmother, Mary K. Gilbert. Judge Charles G. Rogers of California Superior Court in San Diego officiated.

headline: Retirement Eludes a Multitasker
text: BOSTON

headline: Anatomy of a Workout
text: A sample of what Derrick Rose, above left, faced in his predraft workout with Rob McClanaghan:

headline: A 17-Year-Old From Norway Is Poised to Grab No. 1 Ranking
text: A player can define an era. The 1960s and early ’70s belonged to Bobby Fischer. In the ’80s and ’90s, Garry Kasparov held sway.

headline: Does 8th-Grade Pomp Fit the Circumstance?
text: IT is good to be 14 and graduating from eighth grade.

headline: Anna Roberts, Alan Ostroff
text: Anna Leigh Roberts, a daughter of Patricia and Bert C. Roberts Jr. of Annapolis, Md., was married on Saturday to Alan Nathaniel Ostroff, the son of Susan and Charles Ostroff of Pennsville, N.J. The Rev. John Pfannenstiel, a Capuchin Franciscan friar, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew by the Bay Catholic Church in Annapolis.

text: THE BASICS

headline: Family-Size
text: The average American mother has 2.1 children. The United States is no Hong Kong, where the average mother has 1, but it’s not prolific Somalia, either, where 6.6 is average. Here we just keep procreation moving along.

headline: The Sound and the Furious
text: NAOMI FIRSTMAN, a nurse, lives in an apartment building on the corner of 184th Street and Bennett Avenue, in Washington Heights. Or at least that’s where she gets her mail.

headline: ‘Notes on a Life’
text: May 12, 1986 Washington, D.C.

headline: He’s Pregnant. You’re Speechless.
text: WHEN Thomas Beatie gives birth in the next few weeks to a baby girl, the blessed event will mark both a personal milestone and a strange and wondrous crossroads in the evolution of American pop culture.

headline: Israel in the Season of Dread
text: JERUSALEM — After a year of painful violence  Hamas rockets flying into Israeli communities, soldiers killed and wounded on forays into Gaza  one might have expected the start of a six-month cease-fire with Hamas to be hailed here as good news. Yet what was the front page headline in Maariv newspaper that day? “Fury and Fear.”

headline: Learning to Dance, Even to His Own Beat
text: MIRO MAGLOIRE was only 17 when he took a graduate level composition class at the Cologne musical conservatory in his native Germany. Although he had started piano at 6 and had recently won a prestigious young composer’s award in his home state, North Rhine-Westphalia, his new teacher, the Argentine composer Mauricio Kagel, expressed reservations.

headline: Here’s to the 4th
text: Sparkling Pointe, a new North Fork producer dedicated to sparkling wines, has released its first bottles in time for Fourth of July toasts. The wines are a 2004 brut ($29) and a 2004 rosé named Topaz Impérial ($33).

headline: ‘Not My Fault’
text: Although secrecy and loyalty have been bywords of the Bush White House, its officials have been improbably loose-lipped upon leaving office, particularly in the memoirs they have written. So far, there have been exposés from Paul O’Neill (Bush’s former Treasury secretary), Richard Clarke (his onetime counterterrorism czar), David Kuo (deputy director of the White House’s faith-based initiative), L. Paul Bremer III (the former top civilian in Iraq) and the foreign-policy hands John Bolton and Douglas J. Feith. Each of these books has been a record, to some extent, of disillusionment, and all have excited a good deal of attention. But perhaps none have had the force of “What Happened,” the new memoir by Bush’s former press secretary, Scott McClellan, which has zoomed to the top of the best-seller lists (including the Book Review’s) and brought fresh scrutiny to an administration that had been all but invisible during this election season.

headline: Erika Munro, Keith Kennerly
text: Erika Denise Munro and Keith Wilmont Kennerly were married on Saturday evening in the Bahamas. The Rev. Dianne Coverley, a Pentecostal minister, officiated at the One and Only Ocean Club on Paradise Island. The Rev. A. R. Bernard Sr., an evangelical minister, participated.

headline: Letters | Tough Enough
text: To the Editor:

headline: Predicting Where You’ll Go and What You’ll Like
text: THAT hoariest of real estate truisms  location, location, location  may soon be a clarion call for all sorts of businesses.

headline: National Push by Obama on Ads and Turnout
text: Senator Barack Obama is drawing up plans for extensive advertising and voter-turnout drives across the nation, hoping to capitalize on his expected fund-raising advantage over Senator John McCain to force Republicans to compete in states they have not had to defend in decades.

headline: Waistlines Expand Into a Workplace Issue
text: TAKE a look around your office tomorrow and see if you can identify a condition that’s quietly costing employers billions of dollars a year.

headline: New Cruise Ship to Feature ‘Aquatheater’
text: When Royal Caribbean International’s Oasis of the Seas makes its debut in late 2009, it will be the world’s largest cruise ship at 220,000 tons. The 5,400-passenger Oasis will also introduce some first-time-at-sea amenities. Its Boardwalk neighborhood, a family-friendly area with casual restaurants, a candy shop and fortune telling and temporary tattoo parlors, will feature a carousel and an “Aquatheater.” The theater, home of the largest pool at sea, will offer fountain shows with music, lights and high-diving aerial performances, and will seat 600. Two rock-climbing walls, as well as private deck seating, will overlook the performance space. Another neighborhood called Central Park will feature a football-field-sized open-air space with tropical vegetation (www.oasisoftheseas.com).

headline: Alexis Scott, Michael Faber
text: Alexis Joanna Scott, a daughter of Joanna Colleto Scott and Hal S. Scott of Cambridge, Mass., was married on Saturday on the Massachusetts island of Martha’s Vineyard to Michael Bach Faber, a son of Susan Bach Faber and Richard A. Faber of Memphis. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown.

headline: Correction: Malthus Redux
text: An article last Sunday about the population theory of Thomas Malthus, a British economist and demographer at the turn of the 19th century, misstated the population of Africa. The estimated population last year was about 944 million people, not 770 million.

headline: A World of Censorship, With Sounds to Jog By
text: Nas

headline: New-Age Mutant Ninja Wagons
text: MUTATIONS drive evolution. Say you’re born with six toes on each foot around the time that an epidemic of the Five Toed Virus sweeps the planet and wreaks havoc on the normal-footed populace. From then on, you and the other six-toed people will have the upper hand, and your offspring will wonder how anyone got by with only five little piggies on each foot.

headline: A Cornucopia of Produce
text: In 1969, Joe Smith’s parents decided to buy an old roadside farm stand on Allaire Road in Wall. Since then, the surrounding landscape has changed and farmland has been developed into tracts of homes, schools and soccer fields. Smith’s Farm Market still remains, as timeless as the classic apple pies it sells.

headline: For a Good Retirement, Find Work. Good Luck.
text: Bill Neugent, an engineer in McLean, Va., is doing his bit to ease the looming generational financial squeeze as the nation’s 75 million baby boomers begin to retire. He’s working longer.

headline: Finding Solutions, Together
text: SCARSDALE

headline: Food Stamps Buy Less; Families Are Hit Hard
text: Making ends meet on food stamps has never been easy for Cassandra Johnson, but since food prices began their steep climb earlier this year, she has had to develop new survival strategies.

headline: When Walking the Course Is a Courageous Act
text: There has been a lot of talk in the last week about courage in golf, much said about guts and resolve, about physical and mental toughness and fortitude.

headline: Hoboken Weathers the Market
text: HOBOKEN was often held up as the prime example of the booming real estate market, and now it appears that the city is showing that it can hold its own in a down market, too.

headline: Two Republican Contenders Whose Similarities Are Mostly Skin Deep
text: WASHINGTON  They are war heroes with the injuries to show for it. They are known for hurricane tempers and caustic wit. They are among the oldest men to seek the presidency.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: The Central Intelligence Agency asked The New York Times not to publish the name of Deuce Martinez, an interrogator who questioned Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and other high-level Al Qaeda prisoners, saying that to identify Mr. Martinez would invade his privacy and put him at risk of retaliation from terrorists or harassment from critics of the agency.

headline: And the Band Honked On
text: THE classroom filled with the sounds of a band struggling to be born, a cacophony of squealing and buzzing. Middle school students in a working-class Brooklyn neighborhood were trying to produce the note F.

headline: Family Meal
text: For my sister, Mary, who has lived in a Maryland institution for the mentally retarded since she was 8, there’s no hiding the fact that food is central. When she is eating, food appears to be the focus of her attention. She doesn’t like to be distracted from it by conversations, let alone by dramatic events. In anticipating the birthday lunches my parents planned for her on her yearly two-hour visits to their summer rental in Bronxville, N.Y., to which she was accompanied by an attendant, she would always reel off the menu she was expecting. This meal never varied throughout her teens and remained unchanged as she passed through her 20s, 30s, 40s and 50s: chicken salad, tomatoes, rolls with butter, iced tea, ice cream and cake. Each summer, she would mention the food within moments of arriving. Mary has a way of speaking that can almost be like singing or intoning, with each syllable given enormous weight. This menu always sounded particularly emphatic. During the chicken-salad course, she would mention a few times that ice cream and cake were coming.

headline: Sea of Trash
text: Off Gore Point, where tide rips collide, the rolling swells rear up and steepen into whitecaps. Quiet with concentration, Chris Pallister decelerates from 15 knots to 8, strains to peer through a windshield blurry with spray, tightens his grip on the wheel and, like a skier negotiating moguls, coaxes his home-built boat, the Opus  aptly named for a comic-strip penguin  through the chaos of waves. Our progress becomes a series of concussions punctuated by troughs of anxious calm. In this it resembles the rest of Pallister’s life.

headline: Juliet Eilperin, Andrew Light Jr.
text: Juliet Eilperin and Andrew Ronald Light Jr. were married on Saturday in Washington. Stephen F. Eilperin, the bride’s father, a senior judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated at the Swedish Embassy.

headline: An ME Hotel to Open in Barcelona
text: ME by Meliá (www.mebymelia.com), a hotel line that integrates modern design and fusion cuisine, will add a fourth property to its roster on July 22: the ME Barcelona. This will be the second ME property in Spain, following the opening of the ME Madrid in October 2006. The ME Barcelona is in the Innovation District, a waterfront business park that houses about 200 international companies  many of them technology-related  and is near the convention center. Highlights of the 259-room hotel include the 24th-floor restaurant, Dos Cielos, which has 360-degree views of the mountains and the Mediterranean (a rooftop garden will provide the restaurant with fresh herbs and other ingredients). There is also a pool on the sixth-floor terrace, along with two night life spots: the Chocolate Bar and the Penthouse Pool Lounge. Nightly rates start at 200 euros, or about $322 at $1.61 to the euro.

headline: An Increasing Appeal of Starting a Business
text: FOR many female entrepreneurs, necessity is the mother of their venture. Take Carla Schneider, 40, of Orange, whose product, the WubbaNub, a silicon pacifier with a small stuffed animal attached, has been used in neonatal intensive care units and by mothers of fussy babies around the country.

headline: The Lying Dutchman
text: In the late 1930s and early ’40s, a middling Dutch painter of old-fashioned taste, Han van Meegeren, made several pictures in the style of Vermeer (1632-75), with the object of passing them off as originals. It was a smart choice  only a tiny number of Vermeers (three dozen) were thought to exist, and the passion among collectors to own one was intense. But still, why should any artist want to hide his own name and talent behind that of another? Why, that is, become a forger? These are questions Edward Dolnick tries to answer in “The Forger’s Spell.”

headline: Web Access on the Dash
text: THE Dash G.P.S. unit that went on sale in March was notable for one eye-popping feature: it transmits the position and speed of the car to a network that shares real-time reports of traffic tie-ups with other Dash owners.

headline: The Demography of Death
text: IN a bustling neighborhood defined by crowded apartments and shops stacked on top of one another like intricate mah-jongg tiles, a traditional funeral home bearing the name Gerard J. Neufeld sits on a patch of freshly cut lawn. But despite the neat appearance of the two-story brick house, with its sloping roof and its chimney, it is one of the few survivors in a diminishing world.

headline: Strawberry Fields, Wherever
text: If you had a craving for strawberries in season and a willingness to travel about 80 miles from New York City, you could have gone north last Sunday to the Beacon Strawberry Festival on the banks of the Hudson River, or east to Mattituck’s, not far from the Long Island Sound. Which one to choose?

headline: Pantsuits and the Presidency
text: SOME supporters of Hillary Clinton believe that sexism colored news coverage of her presidential campaign. The Times reported in a front-page article on June 13 that many are proposing boycotts of cable news networks and that a “Media Hall of Shame” has been created by the National Organization for Women.

headline: When the Comedy Is Lost in Translation
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Datebook
text: SONOMA WINE COUNTRY

headline: Shallow Graves
text: Still writing against the grain, Ruth Rendell opens her 21st Inspector Wexford mystery, NOT IN THE FLESH (Crown, $25.95), with a rustic English scene featuring a truffle hound named Honey who leads her master to a fragrant growth of fungi buried in Old Grimble’s Field. Since this author has neither taste nor time for sentimentality, the mood is abruptly shattered when Honey digs up a skeleton and the picturesque countryman whips out his cellphone to call the police.

headline: Party Titans, Updating Disco’s Sound
text: SOMETIMES you instantly know you have a hit on your hands. And sometimes it takes you a few years to realize it, because you mistakenly assume that your lone collaborator hates the song. In 2004 Andy Butler persuaded his friend Antony, the otherworldly singer of Antony and the Johnsons, to record a dance track he had written called “Blind.”

headline: Bakeries Where Cake Is a Many-Layered Thing
text: IN the red, white and blue time between Flag Day and the Fourth of July, is there any dessert more all-American than a big frosted layer cake?

headline: Katharine Shaughnessy, Eric Southard
text: Katharine Meghan Shaughnessy, the daughter of Judith and Bernard Shaughnessy of Garden City, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Eric Donnelly Southard, the son of Christina and Melville Southard Jr. of Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. James W. Adelmann, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Garden City Community Church.

headline: Inching Along on a Master Plan for Jamesport
text: RIVERHEAD

headline: Hold the Private Contractors in Iraq Accountable
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Cost’
text: Her memory was gone.

headline: Lauren Mara, Steven Chaput
text: Lauren Ann Mara, a daughter of Denise and John Mara of Harrison, N.Y., was married on Friday evening to Steven Robert Chaput, a son of Nancy and Dr. Christopher Chaput of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. Daniel O’Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

headline: Mr. Bush, Lead or Leave
text: Two years ago, President Bush declared that America was “addicted to oil,” and, by gosh, he was going to do something about it. Well, now he has. Now we have the new Bush energy plan: “Get more addicted to oil.”

headline: Are Small-Cap Stocks Signaling a Recovery?
text: IN times of economic uncertainty, investors don’t usually flock to volatile assets like small-company stocks. Instead, they tend to favor havens like bonds or shares of stable, industry-leading blue-chip companies.

headline: Letters
text: Too, Too Casual

headline: The List, Where Intent Meets Action
text: IN our house, the tenuous relationship between word and deed begins at the top of the cellar stairs. That’s because there’s a list there, tacked to the wall years ago when we took up residence. Replace basement windows. Pour concrete floor. Repair rotten step. Install shelving. Though nothing but a few words on a scrap of paper, that inventory is a place where an idea became an intention and the intention, a word. And when the word was written down, I was sure it would be the first step toward materiality.

headline: Trading Compost for Condos
text: SOUTHAMPTON

headline: A Fine Day for Music, No Matter Your Taste
text: For unsuspecting visitors to Governors Island on Saturday, there perhaps to see the Federal-style brick buildings or other relics of the island’s military past, something was out of whack. Sharing the normally staid grounds were roving brigades of teenagers and young adults, some in torn black T-shirts and plaid pants, others festooned with piercings and tattoos. They were there to listen to bands like Hipster Holocaust, Beatdown Brigade and Reagan Youth.

headline: Some Severance Deals at Utility Required Silence
text: ALBANY  At least 19 employees who have resigned in recent years from the New York Power Authority, the sprawling and politically powerful state-owned utility, were required to keep secret the circumstances of their departures in order to obtain severance pay or benefits, according to a review by The New York Times.

headline: Battlegrounds
text: For the last six months, several writers from around the country have filed occasional dispatches on the presidential primaries for the Op-Ed page. Well, the primaries are now over. Here, then, are final reports from our correspondents.

headline: Correction: The Love Song of R. Buckminster Fuller
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about R. Buckminster Fuller misspelled the given name of the former assistant curator of Mr. Fuller’s archive at Stanford. It is Hsiao-Yun Chu, not Hisiao-yun.

headline: Abigail Freireich, Mark Weinsier
text: Abigail Suzanne Freireich, a daughter of Nancy Freireich and Paul Freireich of New York, is to be married Sunday to Mark Everett Weinsier, the son of Laurie Sherer Weinsier of Marietta, Ga., and Steven Weinsier of Plantation, Fla. Rabbi Jessica Zimmerman will officiate at the Harmonie Club in New York.

headline: Building’s Auction Ends Feud
text: A RUN-DOWN five-story brick tenement building at 79 Horatio Street, between Washington and Greenwich Streets, will probably generate plenty of buzz when it hits the auction block this summer.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: COMEDY

headline: I’m the Designer. My Client’s the Autocrat.
text: FOUR months ago the architect Daniel Libeskind declared publicly that architects should think long and hard before working in China, adding, “I won’t work for totalitarian regimes.” His remarks raised hackles in his profession, with some architects accusing him of hypocrisy because his own firm had recently broken ground on a project in Hong Kong.

headline: In Fertile India, Growth Outstrips Agriculture
text: JALANDHAR, India  With the right technology and policies, India could help feed the world. Instead, it can barely feed itself.

headline: I’m Richard the Ad Exec, I’ll Be Your Waiter Today
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Breaking Down Barriers to Get Parents Involved
text: NORWALK

headline: Beth Davidson, Clifford Lopate
text: Rabbi Beth Dina Davidson and Clifford Lopate are to be married on Sunday in Manchester, N.H. Rabbi SueAnn Wasserman is to officiate at Temple Adath Yeshurun, where the bride is the rabbi.

headline: At the End of a Leash, a Surprise
text: IN a standoff with a white Chihuahua, Radar, a sleek, 3-year-old feline resident of the Upper West Side, stood serenely at attention. Beneath a canopy of trees on Columbus Avenue, near the American Museum of Natural History, he waited in his yellow harness (size: extra small) as the Chihuahua sniffed him out. Upon realizing that this creature was not one of its own, the dog leapt backward in yelping horror, and Radar, aloof, continued on his walk.

headline: Keep the Rejection Letters
text: I WAS born in Iran and attended a boarding school in Switzerland when I was 13. At 16, I enrolled in M.I.T. and graduated with bachelor’s and master’s degrees in engineering. Afterward, I went to Stanford business school. I graduated in 1980.

headline: Rite of Summer Turns a Little Serious
text: The Mermaid Parade in Coney Island on Saturday had its usual array of sequined mermaid tails, long trains of fish netting, tiny clamshell bikinis and strategically placed plastic swordfish. But this year’s celebration also included a large number of performers with a cause.

headline: Shannon Martin, Landon Nordeman
text: Mary Shannon Martin and Landon Nordeman were married on Saturday at St. Andrew’s Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Charles H. Clark, an Episcopal priest and the former rector of St. Paul’s School, from which the bridegroom graduated, performed the ceremony.

headline: The Shootout Over Hidden Meanings in a Video Game
text: If there’s a subject that’s as contentious as war itself, it might be a video game about war.

headline: Do as I Say, Not as They Do
text: A friend insists that her children address all adults by last name and courtesy title (Mr. Smith, Mrs. Jones). But quite a few of her female friends, including myself, didn’t change our names when we got married, which means her children call us by our children’s surnames instead of our own. She says she is raising her children with proper manners. I think they should ask what we’d like to be called. Who is correct? Julie Atkinson, Redwood City, Calif.

headline: The New Trophy Home, Small and Ecological
text: For the high-profile crowd that turned out to celebrate a new home in Venice, Calif., the attraction wasn’t just the company and the architectural detail. The house boasted the builders’ equivalent of a three-star Michelin rating: a LEED platinum certificate.

headline: Love, Honor, Leave No Carbon Footprint
text: STAYING in a treehouse in Africa, an igloo in Switzerland or a hut in the Amazon may not sound like the perfect honeymoon to everyone, yet these days many newlywed couples are choosing a bed draped with mosquito netting over one dotted with rose petals, shunning the more traditional romantic resorts for retreats that are environmentally friendly.

headline: Staying in the Comfort Zone
text: NEARLY two years ago, Lana Walsh helped her future husband, Marco Tartaglia, choose his bachelor pad at the Zephyr Lofts condominium in Jersey City, just over the Hoboken line. She joined him soon afterward. They knew they wouldn’t be living there long.

headline: Courtland Wood, Trey Colantonio
text: Courtland Wallace Wood, the daughter of Cynthia McNair Wood and Stephen W. Wood of West Simsbury, Conn., was married on Saturday to Second Lt. Donald Francis Colantonio III, a son of Paige S. Colantonio and Mr. Colantonio Jr. of Simsbury. The Rev. Joseph L. Pace, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John’s Church in West Hartford, Conn.

headline: Call for Change Ignored, Levees Remain Patchy
text: CANTON, Mo.  The levees along the Mississippi River offer a patchwork of unpredictable protections. Some are tall and earthen, others aging and sandy, and many along its tributaries uncataloged by federal officials.

headline: Depleted in Dairyland
text: Shorewood, Wis.

headline: See the Economy Through the Eyes of Its C.E.O.’s
text: Did you recently let out a sigh of relief because you escaped the ax? Not so fast. According to a new survey of chief executives, a little over 30 percent expect their United States employment to decline in the next six months.

headline: Remembering a Father, Adored but Distant
text: The Ties That Bind a Father and Son

headline: Healed, Seal Returns to Hamptons Waters
text: HAMPTON BAYS

headline: Paperback Row
text: NEW ENGLAND WHITE, by Stephen L. Carter. (Vintage, $14.95.) Carter, who teaches at Yale Law School and is the author of “The Emperor of Ocean Park” as well as several works of nonfiction, combines mystery, academic satire and reporting on the lifestyles of the black upper class in this stylishly written novel. The wife of the black president of a university much like Yale, herself a divinity school dean, investigates the death of her former lover, an economist who was collecting evidence about a 30-year-old murder that threatened powerful politicians — including her husband’s college roommate, now the president of the United States.

headline: Condos at Pedigree Prices
text: TENANTS at the Apthorp, the elegant full-block complex built by the Astor family for the New York elite, were amused at the high prices listed by the owners when they filed preliminary plans last year to convert its 163 apartments to condominiums.

headline: Grand Central Sunspots
text: Grand Central Sunspots

headline: Nothing Sells Like Celebrity
text: EARLY last year, marketing executives at Totes Isotoner, a Cincinnati company that had spent the previous 30 years churning out a reliable lineup of humble umbrellas, crowded around a computer and listened to a teenage singer from Barbados named Rihanna breeze through a tune titled, appropriately, “Umbrella.”

headline: Paul Hamm Among Two to Win Olympic Berths
text: PHILADELPHIA  When Paul Hamm was named to the United States Olympic gymnastics team Saturday, he stood at the center of the Wachovia Center, the site of the trials, and waved to the cheering crowd.

headline: Navigating the Road to Budget Harmony
text: THE deal hammered out in the past week that all but ensured passage of Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s $32.9 billion budget was born of negotiations that began in earnest two months ago and the bitter budget debate that raged in New Jersey two years ago.

headline: Irena Budimova, Peter Shiba
text: Irena Budimova and Peter Kazumi Shiba were married yesterday evening at the Paauilo Kongoji Mission in Paauilo, Hawaii. Koga Miyazaki, a Buddhist priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Brooklyn for Sale
text: THERE was a time, decades ago, when Steve Hindy’s friends couldn’t believe what he and his partner wanted to call their new business. Brooklyn Brewery? Why, people wondered, would you name a beer after that place?

headline: Orthodox Jews’ Request Divides a Resort Village
text: WESTHAMPTON BEACH

headline: Firing Back at Gay Bashers, Bawdily
text: ENJOYING cocktails after a fatiguing rehearsal for “Bash’d,” a “gay rap opera,” Chris Craddock and Nathan Cuckow, the show’s Canadian writers and actors, recalled an evening nearly a year ago. Having just performed at the New York International Fringe Festival, they were strolling down a Greenwich Village street when, Mr. Cuckow said, a young man passed them and hissed an anti-gay slur.

headline: 36 Hours in Mumbai
text: IT’S the Jazz Age again in Mumbai. The populous metropolis is bursting with stock-market money, a shimmering art scene has a growing global presence, and young people are exploiting their newfound freedoms in dim bars until the wee hours. Indeed, in the city’s more rarefied circles, Champagne is sipped every night and everyone knows everyone, darling. But large swaths of Mumbai, the former Bombay, remain immune to the homogeneity of global glamour. Behind the bustling boulevards are nameless alleys where coconuts are sold, haircuts are given and the city’s frenetic traffic occasionally comes to a honking halt because of a scampering goat.

headline: Katherine Pushkar, Eric Barrow
text: Katherine Pushkar, an editor at The New York Post, and Eric Barrow, an editor at The New York Daily News, were married on Saturday at Christ Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Agency Sees Theft Risk for ID Card in Medicare
text: WASHINGTON  Social Security officials, concerned about the risk of identity theft, are calling for immediate action to remove Social Security numbers from the Medicare cards used by millions of Americans.

headline: One Mall, Two Realities. The Builder’s Is Winning.
text: Oyster Bay

headline: Eleanor and Francis
text: In the early 1970s, newly flush with earnings from “The Godfather,” the director Francis Ford Coppola and his wife, Eleanor  an artist, shy on the surface but not to be underestimated  went house-hunting in Napa Valley. They wanted a place outside of chilly San Francisco where their three kids could play. Also, Francis hoped to grow grapes, maybe make a little wine. On a lark, the real estate agent took them to see a grand old estate that was up for sale. The huge Victorian house had an octagonal lookout tower; there was a perfect oak tree, and the surrounding vineyards dated back nearly a century. “It looked like a movie set! We were enthralled.” Thus writes Eleanor in these winning and quietly provocative if, by definition, highly selective notebook musings on her life and marriage.

headline: Jakarta: Jalan Surabaya
text: If you want to buy a bit of Indonesia’s future, go to one of Jakarta’s many malls. If you want to hold on to a piece of its past, come to Jalan Surabaya.

headline: Quote, Unquote
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reminders of Paris in London’s Truly English Food
text: WHAT are great restaurants for? At worst, they’re a seated passeggiata, where the in-crowd asserts its in-ness, the would-bes try to, and the innocent come to gawp and glut. At best, they nourish the soul. Ideally, they start doing it once you walk through the door and continue long after you’ve left.

headline: Veterans Rebut ‘Swift Boat’ Charges Against Kerry in Answer to Challenge
text: For most people, “Swift boat” has become a political verb, a synonym for the kind of attack that helped destroy the presidential campaign of Senator John Kerry in 2004.

headline: A Circle of Women, Discovered on a Stoop
text: WITH its faded painterly cover, “Kingfishers Catch Fire” caught my eye.

headline: One Mistake Unravels Solid Start for Giese
text: A Yankees starter pitched well again Saturday, but for the second game in a row, a younger Cincinnati Reds starter proved too much for the Yankees to handle.

text: Jersey City

text: MALVERNE

headline: Michelle Mead and John Armor
text: WHEN Michelle Mead met John Armor in 1972, she was in a Baltimore courtroom accusing her husband of assault and battery, and Mr. Armor, her husband’s defense lawyer, was cross-examining her.

headline: Robbed of His Sight, a Car Owner Maintains His Vision
text: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J.  A crew chief named Jay Blake folds his white cane into four pieces and shoves it in his back pocket when he works on his dragster. He is blind, but he knows his way around an engine. His hands are callused, his fingernails greasy.

headline: Letter: The Canals of Venice
text: To the Editor: As a marine geochemist studying the Venice lagoon, I was entertained and slightly horrified by David Kocieniewski’s recent article “On the Grand Canal  in a Kayak” (June 1). After a couple of trips to the local hospital to be treated for bacterial infections, and with knowledge of the contaminants found in those waters, I can make some recommendations to those who are daft or intrepid enough to try it.

headline: The New Pariahs?
text: No country is wholly free of anti-immigrant prejudice, whether it is the United States, where illegal immigration was a hot-button issue in the Republican primaries, or post-apartheid South Africa, where economic migrants were recently burned to death. But in many Western European countries today, something new and insidious seems to be happening. The familiar old arguments against immigrants  that they are criminals, that their culture makes them a bad fit, that they take jobs from natives  are mutating into an anti-Islamic bias that is becoming institutionalized in the continent’s otherwise ordinary politics.

headline: Getting to the Grass Roots
text: Chillicothe, Ohio

headline: Neuro-Liberalism
text: George Lakoff wants to save his country. In a series of books, Lakoff, a linguist and cognitive scientist at the University of California, Berkeley, has explained how the right wins and keeps power: by framing issues and controlling minds. His latest book, “The Political Mind,” grounds his critique and his agenda in neuroscience. Lakoff proposes to beat conservatives at their own game. “Democracy is too important to leave the shaping of the brains of Americans to authoritarians,” he argues. But shaping brains is a treacherous business. It’s hard to manipulate voters and still be a democrat.

headline: To Help Those on the Lowest Rungs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sale of Farm to Developer Is Under Way
text: BALDWIN PLACE

headline: Caitlin Boyle, Curtis Ellis
text: Caitlin Antisdale Boyle and Curtis Cleland Ellis were married on Saturday at Dudley Farm, a house museum in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Michael Maslowsky, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

headline: Network Nation
text: The chatter these days is that the Republicans are a party that has run out of ideas. The Soviet Union is long gone; welfare has been reformed; market logics have permeated almost every aspect of our lives (eBay, anyone?). The truth is that the triumph of conservative ideas may present a political problem for the ailing Republicans, but the party that’s truly lacking in new ideas is my own, the resurgent Democrats.

headline: Letters: The Architecture Issue
text: The architecture-themed issue, “The Next City” (June 8), was a wonderful exploration of how today’s cutting-edge architectural firms, like OMA and MVRDV, are exploding the boundaries of conventional architecture. However, I would have liked to have seen perspectives from landscape architects, or what some refer to as “landscape urbanism.” Even architects like Rem Koolhaas, Bernard Tschumi and Stan Allen are turning toward landscape architecture to infuse and renew their own architectural-design strategies. Planning cities by single buildings was, and continues to be, a shortsighted strategy. To truly design our urban centers, we must now think of the city as a landscape of infrastructure (transportation, utilities) and systems (ecological, social, institutional).

headline: Renewal Leases and Landlords’ Obligations
text: Q How many days before a lease expires does a landlord have to send a tenant a renewal lease?

headline: In Confronting the Foreclosure Crisis, a Bill Strikes a Balance
text: The bill that Gov. David A. Paterson and leaders of the State Legislature announced last week to address the subprime lending and foreclosure crisis was, for Albany, that rarest of things  an effective compromise.

headline: Soft-Core Auteur Turns Attention to Radicals
text: AT its peak in the 1960s the brand of kinky soft-core erotica known as pinku eiga, or pink film, accounted for half of all movie production in Japan. Most pink-film directors were anonymous journeymen, but the industry nurtured its share of eccentric talents. Among the most talented and eccentric was Koji Wakamatsu, a gonzo auteur with a knack for eyebrow-raising titles (“Go, Go Second Time Virgin,” “Violated Women in White”) whose most interesting films owe as much to Karl Marx as to the Marquis de Sade.

headline: Letter: Food and Baseball
text: To the Editor: Peter Meehan’s article “Buy Me Some Sushi and Baby Back Ribs” (June 8) was interesting to read, but as a fan who has attended games for over 50 years in about a dozen ballparks (sadly some of them long gone), I have never once considered the food quality as key to having an enjoyable time.

headline: U.S. Women Triumph in South Korea
text: Angela Hucles scored the game’s only goal in second-half injury time as the United States women’s national team defeated Canada, 1-0, to win the Peace Queen Cup on Saturday in Suwon, South Korea.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: COMEDY

headline: Pathways to the Spirit World
text: Try to keep in mind, as you wander among the sculptures in “Embodying the Sacred in Yoruba Art,” the Newark Museum’s lovely, revelatory show of African art, that many of these objects were never intended to be on public view. The idea, instead, was that they be placed on an altar in a private space and worshipped.

headline: How Big a Payday for the Pay Consultants?
text: THE credit crisis, rising oil prices and the economy may dominate headlines, but excessive executive pay still makes shareholders boil. With the proxy season pretty much over  and with John McCain and Barack Obama both making compensation a campaign issue  let’s see where investors stand in the battle to rein in outsized pay.

headline: Maria Glover, Derek Ho
text: Julie Maria Glover, the daughter of Julie M. Glover and Eugene B. Glover of Maryville, Tenn., was married on Saturday in Washington to Derek Tam Ho, the son of Josephine Tam Ho and Robert P. Ho of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Samuel L. Wood officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension and St. Agnes, where he is curate.

headline: With N.H.L. Draft Over, the Heavy Lifting Begins
text: Summertime for 29 N.H.L. general managers is about making repairs, stocking talent and telling themselves and their fans that they were not that far from competing for the Stanley Cup.

headline: Low-Cost Film With Friends in High Places
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Correction: On the Trail of a Sustainable Feast in Sonoma
text: The Explorer column on June 1, about a tour of sustainable-agriculture farms in Sonoma County, Calif., overstated one grower’s contribution to the region’s production of olive oil. The McEvoy Ranch was among the first to plant olive varietals from Tuscany in Northern California; it did not introduce Tuscan methods of olive oil production to the region.

headline: Meredith Klein, Ryan Buckley
text: Meredith Nancy Klein and Ryan William Buckley were married on Saturday in Chatham, Mass. Rabbi H. Hirsch Cohen officiated at the Chatham Bars Inn.

headline: That Summer in Maine
text: There’s a pitch-perfect passage late in Roxana Robinson’s new novel in which the director of a rehab program meets with the relatives of a heroin addict to prepare them for an intervention. Their task, he explains, is not to judge the young man, whose habit has become life-threatening. “ ‘What we’re here to do is offer support.’ He paused. ‘And love.’ The word: it sizzled in the silence like a live wire, electric, dangerous. Love was not a word their family used. It was not a word they would tolerate from a stranger.”

headline: Real W.M.D.’s
text: Any new entry in the crowded field of books on the 1962 Cuban missile crisis must pass an immediate test: Is it just another recapitulation, or does it increase our net understanding of this seminal cold war event? By focusing on the activities of the American, Soviet and Cuban militaries during those tense October days, Michael Dobbs’s “One Minute to Midnight” passes this test with flying colors. The result is a book with sobering new information about the world’s only superpower nuclear confrontation  as well as contemporary relevance.

headline: Correction
text: A brief report in the Suits column last Sunday about Robert I. Toll, chief executive of Toll Brothers, described the company’s new C.E.O. bonus plan incorrectly. The plan results in a bonus only if certain company and individual performance criteria are met; it does not ensure that Mr. Toll receives a bonus.

headline: An Aching Reporter Feels the Pain of a Predraft Workout
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The sweat cascaded off my nose, fatigue ambushed my body, and my hamstrings pounded. After just 15 minutes, my jump shot became less reliable than the town drunk and I received the ultimate backdoor insult from a former N.B.A. All-Star, B. J. Armstrong, who happened to be my workout partner.

headline: Correction: Buy Me Some Sushi and Baby Back Ribs
text: An article on June 8 about the new food choices at major league ballparks misstated the location of the tavern McNally’s, an outpost of which is on Ashburn Alley at Citizens Bank Park, home of the Philadelphia Phillies. It is in Chestnut Hill; it is not in Germantown.

headline: Sick Days
text: In her second year of college, the poet Sarah Manguso developed a neurological disease so uncommon it doesn’t even have a real name. The autoimmune condition, a rarer form of the already rare Guillain-Barré syndrome, is known as chronic idiopathic demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy, and it took more than four years to run its course. For several of them, Manguso had to undergo periodic treatments in which her plasma was completely removed and replaced. The treatments worked, but sometimes only for a few days. Later, she moved to steroid treatments, which restored a degree of physical well-being but created complicated side effects.

headline: Goya Framed by His City, Madrid
text: MANY painters seem indelibly linked to the cities in which they lived and worked, like Canaletto and Venice or Vermeer of Delft. But paintings are portable and, a few centuries on, can often be dispersed far and wide, which is why one quarter of Vermeer’s output can be seen today in a 10-block stretch of Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: Success Story 2
text: Great paradigm-shifting narratives  entrepreneurs seeing clarity where others saw only fog  often have a feeling of manifest destiny about them. What’s striking about David A. Price’s history of Pixar, the computer animation studio behind “Toy Story,” “The Incredibles” and other movies, is how provisional it all seemed in the moment, how key players at important junctures didn’t really understand what they were doing even as they were doing it. But they kept working because of a sixth sense that something would eventually happen.

headline: With Friends Like Angelo . . .
text: Time and again, the Senate is bedeviled by its own clubbiness, its lost sensitivity to how ordinary people live their lives. So it is with Christopher Dodd and Kent Conrad, who turned up on the “Friends of Angelo” V.I.P. list at Countrywide Financial Corporation.

headline: The Avant Gardener
text: For a first-time visitor, Brussels can be a dreary city. Follow the old town’s meanderings past Gothic squares and gargoyle-laden monuments, and you will invariably come to rows of unyielding, unapologetically functional buildings that house much of Europe’s bureaucracy. Add to that gray skies and frequent drizzle, and the picture can become less than cheery. No wonder that passers-by often stop in their tracks when they come across Daniel Ost’s Art Nouveau storefront on the Rue Royale: his floral emporium feels like a breath of fresh  and beautifully perfumed  air.

headline: Dominating Nadal Stirs Rare Wimbledon Debate
text: WIMBLEDON, England  The outside courts were bustling here Saturday with rank-and-file players pairing off to practice, their shuffling feet making little noise on the still-pristine grass below. But courtside, as the coaches and the agents looked on in the June gloom, the chatter turned to the favorite for the men’s title.

headline: R. J. Vecoli, Historian Who Studied Immigrants, Is Dead at 81
text: Rudolph J. Vecoli, an Italian-American historian whose searching chronicles of the American immigrant experience gave a new view of what immigrants kept and left behind, died Sunday in St. Louis Park, Minn. He was 81 and lived in St. Paul.

headline: Corrections: 	Alexandra Melby, Andrew Farnum
text: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Alexandra Melby and Andrew Farnum described incorrectly the job of Eric D. K. Melby, the bride’s father, from 1987 to 1993. He was a member of the staff of the National Security Council who handled international economic issues and later a special assistant to the president for national security affairs; he was not a member of the National Security Council itself.

headline: Air Travel and Carbon on Increase in Europe
text: MURCIA, Spain  The boom in low-cost air travel has turned this corner of southern Spain into a thriving tourist destination, and retired plumbers and schoolteachers into Europe’s new jet set.

text: Sometimes I feel like Henry Higgins. In the middle of a show that hasn’t quite met my expectations, suddenly there’s a moment of magic and I want to shout, “By Jove, I think they’ve got it!”

text: WHEN I heard the news last week that the Belgian company InBev wanted to buy Anheuser-Busch, I immediately called my bartender. From France.

headline: Cashing In the Chips, Even When the Casino Is Long Gone
text: LAS VEGAS  Wendy Schultz knew that her parents collected casino memorabilia, but not until they died within a few months of one another in 2005 did she understand the magnitude of their efforts.

headline: The State of Iraq: An Update
text: IRAQ remains a violent country plagued by high unemployment, raw wounds from sectarian conflict, extremist militias aided by Iran, more than four million people still displaced by violence, and very limited government capacity to meet the country’s core needs. There has, however, been major progress this spring on two fronts. Together they give reason for hope that the major improvement in security resulting from the surge of American forces may endure even as the surge itself ends this July.

headline: Remembering Fuller: Passing on Inspiration
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is He the Ticket?
text: As the popular governor of Florida and a Republican known for supporting relatively progressive causes, you are often mentioned as a possible running mate for Senator McCain. It’s been said that you could deliver Florida for him in the November election and lend him some overall centrist appeal. It’s very flattering that people would even consider that a notion.

headline: Olympic Torch’s Tibet Visit Is Short and Political
text: BEIJING  The visit of the Olympic torch to the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, came and went in about two hours on Saturday. Leaders of the ruling Communist Party probably exhaled once the flame was trundled onto an airplane without incident and flown out of a city that only three months ago had erupted in violent anti-Chinese protests.

headline: Can the Fed Answer All the Alarms?
text: I GOT a queasy feeling a few weeks ago when I read about a talk that Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave at Harvard, his alma mater. The speech included many sensible and modest elements. But in one part, Mr. Bernanke implied that we would not have a rerun of the so-called stagflation of the 1970s because the labor cost situation was quite different this time around, and because the monetary powers had learned their lessons.

headline: The Carla Effect

headline: An Alsatian With Finesse
text: Since F. E. Trimbach’s founding in Alsace in 1626, the winery has learned a thing or two about making gewürztraminer.

headline: What Happens if We’re Wrong?
text: IN 1995, home prices in the United States rose by 1.7 percent. They kept climbing over the next 10 years at an accelerating rate. The climax was in 2005, when the increase was 15.7 percent, putting home prices at more than double their 1995 level. Except for the early years after World War II and during the great inflation of the 1970s, home prices in the United States had never doubled in the short space of 10 years.

headline: Mary Dailey Pattee, Paul Desmarais

headline: Some Commutes Are Just Too Short
text: I’M no Einstein, and my last attempt at studying physics back in high school was an out-and-out C-minus disaster. But recently, and unexpectedly, I had a flash of understanding not only about time and space, but also about past and future, about boys and men and ties and trains. And it has changed the frame of my life.

headline: Did Your Team Draft Well? You’ll Know in Half a Decade

It’s a reminder of just how long it takes to figure out whether a draft has been fruitful or not — specifically, about five years.

headline: A Summer Blockbuster Alternative
text: The distribution of foreign-language and genuinely independent movies  art films, specialty films, whatever you want to call them  has never been an easy or lucrative undertaking. Competition is severe, costs high, and the audience, never huge, seems to be shrinking every year. Studios, recently so eager to expand their specialty divisions, seem to have entered a period of retrenchment, and a few small, stand-alone companies are reportedly teetering on the brink of ruin.

headline: It’s Mine!
text: Society | In the 100 Thing Challenge, Americans vow to scale back to a mere 100 possessions. Not easy: consider our primordial hard-wiring. The “endowment effect,” in which you value a thing you possess above what the market will bear, may hark back to tribal times when you might be the only seller of that thing. — Time, Economist, Neuron, William and Mary Law Review
