text: Coverage of the war in Iraq has been massively scaled back on television this year. CBS News no longer stations a single full-time correspondent in Iraq, where some 150,000 United States troops are deployed.

headline: Here Comes the K.H.L. With Loads of Money
text: We’ve been saying this was going to happen for about a year, and now here it is: the Russian KHL is up and running and flashing big wads of money at players in Europe and the NHL. Over the weekend Evgeni Malkin’s agent said that the KHL had put up a $12.5 million-per-year offer to Evgeni Malkin, whose contract with Pittsburgh comes up for renegotiation soon. That’s $12.5 million per year, tax-free.

headline: 4 Gymnasts Added to U.S. Men’s Team for Beijing
text: PHILADELPHIA  In a tiny conference room of a hotel here Sunday, as the gymnasts and their coaches collectively held their breath, the names of the men on the United States Olympic gymnastics team were announced, one by one.

headline: Grass Puts Past Champions on Firmer Ground
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Long a cure for what ails the Williams sisters, Wimbledon begins Monday with both in need of a boost.

headline: Republican Running for House Dies at 67
text: Francis H. Powers, a retired Wall Street executive who was recently selected by Republican leaders on Staten Island as their candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, died on Saturday at his home on Staten Island.

headline: A High School Finds Itself Left Behind and Drowning
text: “Hard Times at Douglass High: A No Child Left Behind Report Card” is, despite that subtitle, a draw-your-own-conclusions sort of documentary.

headline: Better-Qualified Teachers
text: The United States has a long and dishonorable history of dumping the least-qualified teachers into schools that serve poor and minority students. This shameful practice has persisted nationally, despite the No Child Left Behind Act of 2001, which required the states to place “highly qualified” teachers in every classroom.

headline: Home Not-So-Sweet Home
text: “Owning a home lies at the heart of the American dream.” So declared President Bush in 2002, introducing his “Homeownership Challenge”  a set of policy initiatives that were supposed to sharply increase homeownership, especially for minority groups.

headline: Study Finds Imbalance on 3 Newspapers’ Op-Ed Pages
text: In the great marketplace of ideas, the opinion pages of major newspapers offer nonjournalists  mainly academics  a rare chance to reach a big audience and influence public policy. So which college professors win the competition for that limited, coveted space?

headline: Iraq Decisions for the Next President
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Sand Bubbles Up Along an Illinois Levee, So Do New Questions
text: CAHOKIA, Ill.  Even as many found cheer that floodwaters along the Mississippi River here would fall well short of what had been predicted, residents and the authorities in this town discovered a stark reminder of what might lie ahead: a sand boil on the aged levee that protects the town, a telltale sign that the swollen river had begun eroding the structure from beneath.

headline: Final Spot on Triathlon Team Decided on Final Leg
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  There were 34 male competitors in the Hy-Vee Triathlon, a World Cup event that served as the final Olympic qualifying race for the United States.

headline: Tom Brokaw Will Host ‘Meet the Press’
text: NBC moved quickly to stanch speculation about who would succeed Tim Russert as moderator of “Meet the Press,” announcing Sunday that Tom Brokaw, former anchor of “NBC Nightly News,” would fill the role for the rest of this election year.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on Friday about pitcher Kei Igawa’s toiling in the Yankees’ minor league system misstated his career statistics with the Yankees. His record is 2-4, not 3-3, and his earned run average is 6.75, not 4.46.

headline: ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Hits Women Much More
text: WASHINGTON  The Army and Air Force discharged a disproportionate number of women in 2007 under the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that prohibits openly gay people from serving in the military, according to Pentagon statistics gathered by an advocacy group.

headline: A Band Rocking and Rolling Past a Few Barriers
text: It would be easy for “Heavy Load”  a documentary about the tribulations of a middle-aged British garage-punk cover band of the same name  to lapse into wet sentiment, and it often threatens to. But the film, Monday on IFC, succeeds, thanks to the resilient dignity of its subjects.

headline: Old Battles Are Burnished by Time
text: Flaubert once wrote that novels are the private histories of nations. Sebastian Barry’s subject is the history of his native land, Ireland, in the early part of the 20th century, with its shifting allegiances, its barbarous tribalisms and its long-remembered slights.

headline: Obama Urges More Regulation of Oil Speculators
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama called Sunday for tighter regulation of oil speculators in an effort to ease record high energy prices, even as backers of Senator John McCain, his likely Republican rival for the presidency, continued to emphasize the importance of increasing domestic oil production.

headline: Accounts, People, Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Agreements Elusive at Oil Talks in Saudi Arabia
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A hastily convened global energy summit meeting led by Saudi Arabia ended largely in disagreement on Sunday, with only a modest pledge of increased production by the Saudis and no resolution on what other practical steps should be taken to ease the crisis over soaring oil prices. The global oil market appeared to shrug off the news, and prices rose afterward.

headline: Golf’s Next Wave
text: Tiger Woods may be hurting right now, but we are beginning to see the results of the boom he spawned in junior golf. Earlier this month, 10-year-old Allisen Corpuz, right, became the youngest player to qualify for a United States Golf Association championship. After rounds of 81 and 88, Corpuz, a fifth grader from Hawaii, did not make the cut at the United States Women’s Amateur Public Links event. She did not appear overly disappointed, though. Perhaps that’s because she nearly beat her college-age playing partners.

headline: As Manuel Molds Them, Mets Show a Winning Form
text: DENVER  The door to the manager’s office at Shea Stadium will have a new nameplate before Jerry Manuel crosses the threshold Monday to begin his next phase of rejuvenating the Mets. In slight but unmistakable ways, Manuel has guided them through turmoil in California and harmony in Colorado, punctuated by a 3-1 victory against the Rockies on Sunday that was their third win in five games since he replaced Willie Randolph.

headline: Two Bits of Guesswork, and Two Different Results
text: In the final of the senior trial, which ended Thursday in Sturbridge, Mass., Reese Milner, Grant Baze, Billy Eisenberg, Sam Lev, Russ Ekeblad and Matthew Granovetter defeated John Onstott, Drew Casen, Dan Morse and Bobby Wolff by 143 international match points to 73.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,096 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: The Fight for Turkey
text: ISTANBUL

headline: Weather Slows Rescue After Typhoon Sinks Philippine Ferry
text: MANILA — Hundreds of ferry passengers, including as many as 45 children, were feared dead on Sunday after their boat capsized and sank in a raging typhoon that devastated part of the Philippines. Rescuers hampered by wind and rains found only a few survivors.

headline: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: The Disappearing Parkland in the South Bronx
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Men Lose in Final
text: The United States men’s team lost to Serbia, 7-3, in the FINA World League Super Final in Genoa, Italy. But the silver-medal performance bolsters the team’s budding chances of contending for a medal in the Beijing Olympics in August. Once considered something of a long shot, the team upset Croatia, ranked No. 1 in the world, this month.

headline: Madison Avenue Likes What It Sees in the Mirror
text: A TELEVISION series about an advertising agency in the 1960s may be generating almost as much buzz on Madison Avenue as the three-martini lunch once did.

headline: Bill to Protect Companies in Inquiries Adds Support
text: Nearly three dozen former federal prosecutors have thrown their weight behind a Congressional bill intended to safeguard confidential communications between lawyers and their clients, a legal bedrock that has come under attack amid corporate fraud scandals.

headline: Going Back, Back, Back to 1939
text: COEUR D’ALENE, Idaho  The first man to drive in a run in an All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium is searching through his memory bank to remember it. He turns 98 in two months, so it is a spacious reservoir of people and places. He listens to some clues, he closes his eyes and he tries to retrieve it, but he cannot.

headline: Limiting Access to the Net
text: To the Editor:

headline: Delaying News in the Era of the Internet
text: WHEN the NBC News host Tim Russert died on June 13, NBC tried to hold back the news from going public for more than an hour to notify his family vacationing in Italy and presumably to prepare for what became six hours of coverage on its cable news outlet, MSNBC.

headline: Vintage Salsa From a Suave Crooner and Percussive Rhymer
text: Cheo Feliciano, a singer who helped define salsa’s golden age, celebrated what he cheerfully called “the first 50 years” of his career at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, joined by collaborators and admirers.

headline: To Make a Stir at City Hall, Make an Appointment
text: The group scrambled under the portico at the top of the steps outside City Hall, seeking shelter from the rain. Paul Nagle, communications director for Councilman Alan J. Gerson, checked his cellphone for the time  10:18 a.m.  and turned to the reporters gathered to cover the first of two back-to-back news conferences on the steps.

headline: In Rift Among Dentist Groups, a Tale of Political Clout
text: This is a parable about power and money and fear and influence and secrecy  in other words, about how a bill becomes law in Albany.

headline: 2 Named to Women’s Team, Meaning More Trials Remain
text: PHILADELPHIA  It came as no surprise Sunday when Shawn Johnson and Nastia Liukin were named to the United States Olympic women’s gymnastics team. For about the past year, it had been a foregone conclusion that Johnson and Liukin, two of the world’s best gymnasts, would be going to Beijing.

headline: Agreements Are Elusive at Oil Talks in Saudi Arabia
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A hastily convened global energy summit meeting led by Saudi Arabia ended largely in disagreement on Sunday, with only a modest pledge of increased production by the Saudis and no resolution on what other practical steps should be taken to ease the crisis over soaring oil prices.

headline: Big Brown’s Owners Say Stable Will Go Steroid Free
text: The owners of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner Big Brown, saying they want to lead the way to the elimination of performance-enhancing drugs in horse racing, announced Sunday that they would immediately begin withdrawing all steroids and any unnecessary medications from their horses.

headline: This Time, Cink Beats the Field, Not Himself
text: CROMWELL, Conn.  As the sky faded to a menacing gray, Stewart Cink was the lone splash of color at the 13th hole. His stunningly yellow shirt, better suited to the glorious sunshine that bathed the Travelers Championship until Sunday morning, stood out in the darkened afternoon when his game did not.

headline: Major Economic Reports for the Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS The economic spotlight will be on the Federal Open Market Committee, which will meet Wednesday to make a decision on interest rates.

headline: Tweeners Tune In
text: “Camp Rock,” Disney’s latest made-for-television musical, kept millions of tween viewers on the couch over the weekend, drawing an average of 8.9 million to the Disney Channel on Friday night and 3.6 million to ABC on Saturday night. The Disney Channel premiere was the most popular show on television on Friday and ranked as cable’s top-rated entertainment telecast of the year. But it did not reach the heights of the reigning tween musical, “High School Musical 2.” Disney had high hopes for “Camp Rock,” which stars the Jonas Brothers and the teenage singer Demi Lovato. In addition to the broadcast premiere on Saturday, it was shown on the ABC Family channel Sunday night and will be streamed on Disney.com beginning Monday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An art review on June 13 about “Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video From Japan,” at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, misidentified the source of comments by the photographer Makato Aida in the exhibition’s catalog. They are from a condensed interview with Masayuki Yoshinaga, another photographer in the exhibition; Mr. Aida did not forgo the catalog interview.

headline: Someone Else’s Alex
text: The people at MoveOn.org have a new Iraq ad that is, if they do say so themselves, their most effective ever. Then again, for the group that brought us the “General Petraeus or General Betray Us?” ad last September, that might not be saying much.

headline: Philadelphia Set to Honor Darwin and Evolution
text: PHILADELPHIA  In the long-running culture war between evolution and creationism, Philadelphia is firing the latest shot.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Arthur Galston, Agent Orange Researcher, Is Dead at 88
text: Arthur W. Galston, a Yale plant biologist who did early research that helped lead to the herbicide Agent Orange, then helped raise awareness of the military’s use of it in Vietnam in the 1960s and its devastating effects on river ecosystems, died on June 15 in Hamden, Conn. He was 88.

headline: For Tom Petty Fans, the True Sound of Vinyl, Also Captured on a CD
text: The vinyl version of the new album from Mudcrutch, the recently reunited band from the early ’70s that features Tom Petty, comes with a CD that buyers can play in their cars or rip to make MP3 files. Those who do will notice that it is abnormally quiet  and that the CD holder instructs listeners to play it on a good stereo and turn it up.

headline: Doubts in South Korea Halt Deal to Restart U.S. Beef Imports
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Beef imports from the United States will not resume soon, officials said Sunday, after a new import deal failed to quell South Koreans’ concerns about mad cow disease and their policy grievances with President Lee Myung-bak.

headline: Increase in Charitable Giving Dampened by Signs of Belt-Tightening
text: Despite a host of troubling economic signals, charitable giving rose slightly last year, according to estimates from the Giving USA Foundation. But there are signs that those trends could give way to a decline this year.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, auctions of four-week bills and two-year notes on Tuesday and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.

headline: Bollywood Goes to Hollywood, Seeking Bargains
text: NEW DELHI  Hollywood loves to show outside investors just how the movie business really works. But some of the people behind Bollywood in India believe they have something to teach Hollywood about making movies.

headline: Obama Camp Closely Linked With Ethanol
text: When VeraSun Energy inaugurated a new ethanol processing plant last summer in Charles City, Iowa, some of that industry’s most prominent boosters showed up. Leaders of the National Corn Growers Association and the Renewable Fuels Association, for instance, came to help cut the ribbon  and so did Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Madagascar in the Lion House
text: New York City is rich in dioramas, the most famous being the beloved trompe l’oeil landscapes at the American Museum of Natural History. Now the city is considerably richer.

headline: Loosen Up, You’ve Got a Friend on the First Tee
text: There was the guy who split the seat of his pants on the first tee. Bill Hancock quietly mended the breach, and stifled the embarrassment, with the safety pins he always keeps handy.

headline: In a Box Office Battle, a Spy Beats a Guru
text: LOS ANGELES  In a comedy slugfest at the weekend movie box office, Steve Carell and “Get Smart” knocked out Mike Myers and “The Love Guru,” though intense competition among a continuing series of comic films could leave everyone looking a little bruised before the summer is over.

headline: In Iowa, Life’s Possessions Become Debris Piles on the Curb
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Alice and Jon Galvin had waited patiently for the day that the water would recede and this flood-ravaged city would drop its barricades and let them go home again, only to find that there is no going home again.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the first round of the N.H.L. draft misidentified the teams that drafted Alex Pietrangelo and Luke Schenn. Pietrangelo was selected fourth by the St. Louis Blues, not the Toronto Maple Leafs. Schenn was selected next by Toronto, not by the Columbus Blue Jackets. The article also misstated the outcome of a trade between the Maple Leafs and the Islanders. The Maple Leafs gained the fifth pick of the first round from the Islanders, not the fourth pick.

headline: The N.H.R.A. Races on After a Driver’s Death
text: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J.  Tim Wilkerson had a trophy under his arm, but he had no desire to celebrate having the fastest funny car on the drag strip. His friend Scott Kalitta was dead, and Wilkerson wore a weary, forced smile during a round of photographs.

headline: Ad Leaders See Web’s Threat and Promise
text: CANNES, France  The growing advertising ambitions of technology powerhouses like Google and Microsoft are creating alarm in the executive suites of ad agencies.

headline: Treaty on Ice
text: Washington

headline: Won’t You Be My Neighbor?
text: Brighton, N.Y.

headline: Town in India Rocks (No Use to Wonder Why, Babe)
text: SHILLONG, India  Lou Majaw wore his signature skin-tight, cutoff short-shorts. His long gray hair hung like dirty threads around his face. Eyes closed in prayer, a guitar cupped in arms, he strummed the chords to “Blowin’ in the Wind.”

headline: Flip-Flops Are Looking Like a Hot Summer Trend
text: This presidential election year may prove better than most at allowing a candidate to survive charges of flip-flopping. And Senators Barack Obama and John McCain seem to have set out to test their luck.

headline: Philanthropist Giving Millions to Two Schools of Journalism
text: Leonard Tow is betting $8 million that universities can figure out the future of newspapers.

headline: Ensuring It Still Feels Like the Old Ball Game
text: OMAHA  People always ask Lambert Bartak about the time an umpire tossed him from a baseball game, a dubious distinction for an organist.

headline: No Planes, Ms. Earhart, but There Is a Trapeze
text: Amelia Earhart, the first woman to fly across the Atlantic, disappeared in 1937 during an attempt to pilot her plane around the world. She remains an object of fascination for many, including Julie Ludwick, a choreographer whose company Fly-by-Night Dance Theater specializes in aerial work. In “The Amelia Project, Phase II,” told in eight sections, Ms. Ludwick aims to pay homage to Earhart’s achievements.

headline: For Rent-Stabilized Tenants, Increases Raise Fear
text: The rent is getting so hard to pay that Maricela Soto can barely afford her favorite green bell peppers at the supermarket. “Soon,” she said in Spanish, “I’m just going to have start eating chicken and forget about the rest.”

headline: Council Victory in Queens Energizes Republican Party
text: When the numbers were finally and officially tallied a little over a week ago, Anthony Como had won a special election for a City Council seat by a mere 41 votes. Mr. Como’s razor-thin victory in a four-candidate race is not only a triumph for him, but also a victory that brings bragging rights for the Queens County Republican Party’s leadership.

headline: Women in Drug Treatment
text: To the Editor:

headline: To Ease Gas Prices, Obama Eyes Speculators
text: Senator Barack Obama on Sunday proposed tightening the regulation of oil speculators in an effort to ease record high gasoline prices and address one of Americans’ top concerns.

headline: 2 Killed in Lebanon Clashes
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least two people were killed and 24 wounded as supporters and opponents of the pro-Western government clashed Sunday in northern Lebanon, security officials said.

headline: New Outreach to Blacks as Border Patrol Grows
text: MEMPHIS  Nearly 1,500 miles from his post at the Mexican border, Cyril V. Atherton, a Border Patrol agent, embarked on one of his trickiest missions.

headline: That’s Some Cheeky Shaman in the Aisles
text: Jim James, the lead singer of My Morning Jacket, couldn’t decide whether Radio City Music Hall was a cathedral or a playground on Friday night. A handful of songs into the band’s triumphant sold-out concert, he pronounced the building “one of the most spiritual places on earth,” sounding awe-struck. A few songs after that he was bolting up a stairway along the hall’s perimeter, stopping short of the balcony to strike a heroic pose.

headline: JVC Jazz Festival in Review
text: TRIBE

headline: Papers Facing Worst Year for Ad Revenue
text: For newspapers, the news has swiftly gone from bad to worse. This year is taking shape as their worst on record, with a double-digit drop in advertising revenue, raising serious questions about the survival of some papers and the solvency of their parent companies.

headline: Theater Notes
text: Bill T. Jones, below, the Tony-winning choreographer of “Spring Awakening,” is back at work in the theater as the choreographer and director of “Fela!,” a musical based on the life of the Nigerian Afrobeat musician and political activist Fela Anikulapo-Kuti (or Fela Kuti, as he is widely known). The show features a book by Mr. Jones and Jim Lewis (“Chronicle of a Death Foretold” on Broadway) and music by Mr. Kuti, who died of AIDS in 1997. It will run Off Broadway at 37 Arts from July 29 to Sept. 21. ... “Arias With a Twist,” the collaboration between the puppeteer Basil Twist and the drag performer Joey Arias, has been extended at the Here Arts Center through Aug. 31. The run had been scheduled to end July 13. ... The Goodman Theater in Chicago has announced that Jeff Daniels (“Blackbird”) and Rachel York (“Dirty Rotten Scoundrels”) will star in the world premiere of “Turn of the Century,” a new musical directed by Tommy Tune with a book by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice, the writing team behind “Jersey Boys.” Previews begin Sept. 19. ... The New York Neo-Futurists will present a special Gay Pride edition of their weekly show “Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind,” June 27-29. The new version, “Too Much Pride Makes the Baby Go Gay,” will include the usual 30 plays in 60 minutes. Details are at nynf.org. ... Eddie Mekka, who played Carmine Ragusa on the sitcom “Laverne & Shirley” from 1976 to 1983, will take over in the solo show “My Mother’s Italian, My Father’s Jewish and I’m in Therapy” beginning July 15 (ItalianJewishTherapy.com).

headline: Bad Medical News for Amy Winehouse
text: The troubled singer Amy Winehouse, right, has early stage emphysema as a result of smoking crack cocaine and cigarettes and may need an oxygen mask to breathe if she cannot stop, her father told a British newspaper, The Sunday Mirror, in an interview. Ms. Winehouse, 24, was taken to the hospital last Monday after a collapse and underwent tests last week. “The doctors have told her if she goes back to smoking drugs it won’t just ruin her voice, it will kill her,” her father, Mitch Winehouse, said. Mr. Winehouse, who said his daughter also had an irregular heartbeat, added that focusing on her work has sometimes helped her to stay away from drugs, and that had she not performed recently in Moscow and Portugal, “she could have been dead by now.” Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to sing on Friday at a London concert celebrating the 90th birthday of Nelson Mandela and also plans to take part in the Glastonbury music festival on Saturday.

headline: ABC Moves to Expand Its Reach on Video Web Sites
text: SAN FRANCISCO  ABC, the stingiest of the major television networks when it comes to syndicating its programs across the Web, is loosening up a little.

headline: Uniting Neighbors, in Fun and Sorrow
text: There are buildings in New York where residents typically exchange little more than token pursed smiles every time they find themselves on the elevator at the same time, lest anyone suffer the imposition of an unwelcome friendly overture. Then there are the buildings where the lobby is a great sinkhole of sociability, a liminal space where 20 or 40 minutes of time vanish in pleasantries and catching up and invitations to dinner parties that require no more of a commute than an elevator ride or a walk down the hall.

headline: Labor Needs to Improve Conditions for Nonunion Workers, Official Warns
text: Ed Ott, the executive director of the New York City Central Labor Council, an umbrella group for the city’s labor unions, has an unexpected and unnerving warning for New York’s more than one million union members.

headline: Dutiful Grandsons Down Yonder in the Paw-Paw Patch
text: Perhaps you’re one of those people who have long lamented, “If only ‘Weekend at Bernie’s’ had been funnier and had starred actors with some chemistry.” Your wait is over.

headline: More Money Trouble for Ed McMahon
text: Financial troubles continue to mount for Ed McMahon, below, the erstwhile sidekick to Johnny Carson and the former host of “Star Search.” Citibank has filed a lawsuit against him in Los Angeles County Superior Court seeking to recoup almost $200,000 in outstanding debt, The Associated Press reported. Earlier this month The Wall Street Journal reported that Mr. McMahon, 85, was $644,000 behind in payments on $4.8 million in mortgage loans on his six-bedroom home in Beverly Hills and faced foreclosure on the property. Mr. McMahon and his wife, Pamela, appeared on “Larry King Live” and discussed their financial problems, attributing them to a poor economy as well as Mr. McMahon’s inability to work since he broke his neck 18 months ago.

headline: Reporters Say Networks Put Wars on Back Burner
text: Getting a story on the evening news isn’t easy for any correspondent. And for reporters in Iraq and Afghanistan, it is especially hard, according to Lara Logan, the chief foreign correspondent for CBS News. So she has devised a solution when she is talking to the network.

headline: Live Music Thrives as CDs Fade
text: A little over a week ago, Patterson Hood, a guitarist and singer in the Drive-By Truckers, stood in front of a sleepy but amped noon crowd at Bonnaroo, the music festival in Manchester, Tenn., explaining profanely that it was time to, um, wake up. As he kicked into “The Righteous Path,” a song from the group’s new-ish record “Brighter Than Creation’s Dark,” it was if the space in front of him was filled with sunburned bobble-heads, each bouncing in unison to every word: “Trying to hold steady on the righteous path, 80 miles an hour with a worn-out map.”

headline: A Bunny, Too, Can Strut and Fret Upon This Stage
text: What’s up with the guy in the rabbit suit?

headline: New CDs
text: ALEJANDRO ESCOVEDO

headline: Years Later, Climatologist Renews His Call for Action
text: Twenty years ago Monday, James E. Hansen, a climate scientist at NASA, shook Washington and the world by telling a sweating crowd at a Senate hearing during a stifling heat wave that he was “99 percent” certain that humans were already warming the climate.

headline: Mad Dash of Bikers Leaves Island in Its Dust
text: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man  Halfway down the suburban road that descends Bray Hill, past the traffic lights, between the elementary school and rows of homes with families relaxing in their front yards, there is a barely perceptible bump.

headline: The New Fight for Financial News
text: TORONTO  For years, the Thomson Corporation was the information giant that rarely talked about its own business.

headline: The Cure Mopes Through Town With Songs of Love, Endings and War
text: There’s no question that Robert Smith has one of rock’s most irritating voices. It’s quavery and strangled, yelpy when he raises it and morose when he doesn’t, the voice of a hypersensitive high-school poet who cherishes his own wounded feelings. But if that voice were any less irritating, his songs for the Cure wouldn’t be anywhere near as durable.

headline: Looted Antiquities Returned to Iraq
text: Almost 2,500 ancient artifacts that had been looted from archaeological sites and from Baghdad’s national museum during the American-led invasion in 2003 and were recently seized by Jordanian border officials were returned on Sunday, Reuters reported. Maha al-Khatib, Jordan’s tourism minister, presented the pieces  including coins, necklaces, ancient scrolls and ceramic pots  to Mohammed al-Uraibi, Iraq’s antiquities minister, at a ceremony in Amman, Jordan. One of the most valuable of the pieces is an ivory relief from the first millennium B.C. that came from the ancient Assyrian city of Nimrud. Mr. Uraibi said 15,000 items were stolen during the looting in 2003, and about 8,500 have been returned.

headline: Doubting Case, a Prosecutor Helped the Defense
text: The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, had a problem. The murder convictions of two men in one of his office’s big cases  the 1990 shooting of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub  had been called into question by a stream of new evidence.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A report in some editions of the Sports Briefing column on Friday about the United States Olympic men’s basketball team misspelled the surname of a player who withdrew from consideration for the team and misspelled the surname of the managing director of USA Basketball. The player is Amare Stoudemire, not Stoudamire, and the managing director is Jerry Colangelo, not Colangleo.

headline: Making Progress on Pensions as the Session Draws to a Close
text: ALBANY  Heading into the last day of the legislative session on Monday, Gov. David A. Paterson and lawmakers are close to agreement on a series of changes aimed at preventing abuses of the state pension system, people involved in the negotiations said.

headline: Going Back to Bruckner for a Formidable Finale
text: Lorin Maazel will end his next season with the New York Philharmonic, his seventh and last as music director, with a series of blockbuster programs: much the way he ended this season, in fact. In recent weeks there were Mahler’s Ninth Symphony; Mr. Maazel’s own orchestral distillation of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle; a concert presentation of Puccini’s “Tosca”; and finally, on Friday and Saturday, Bruckner’s Eighth Symphony.

headline: The Met’s Math: 2 Stars, 6 Encores, 50,000 in Park
text: The speculation that 100,000 people, maybe even 150,000, might turn up for the Metropolitan Opera’s concert in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Friday night may have been strategic hype from the company’s media-savvy general manager, Peter Gelb. Still, Mr. Gelb promised a big show, and this concert, featuring opera’s starriest married couple, the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna, was certainly that.

headline: The Demographics of Smoking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Metro

headline: Heroes Who Drink Milk and Know Their Xbox
text: One of the enduring attractions of comic books and graphic novels is the ease with which they explain the universe. Evil is identifiable, external and fairly simple to vanquish with the application of the appropriate superpowers. And sometimes, as in the case of ABC Family’s new comic-based series “The Middleman,” evil is downright funny.

headline: Couple’s Downfall Is Culminating in Sentencing in Long Island Slavery Case
text: MUTTONTOWN, N.Y.  With their courtship complete and their arranged marriage only a few weeks old, Mahender and Varsha Sabhnani set out for New York from India in 1981, leaving behind their wealthy families and households with live-in servants.

headline: Fashion on the Fairway, With Function in Mind
text: A few weeks ago, we offered some tips on men’s golf fashion. In advance of this week’s United States Women’s Open, the L.P.G.A. Tour players Morgan Pressel and Christina Kim discussed what they wear on the golf course.

headline: An Unlikely Promoter Drives Nokia’s Push in Hollywood
text: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  Tero Ojanpera is an unlikely media entrepreneur. Mr. Ojanpera, a veteran Nokia executive, is not a fan of “American Idol,” although he says he enjoys it from time to time. And when he tried to watch a recent episode of “Hannah Montana,” one of his sons switched the channel.

headline: Rudolph J. Vecoli, Scholar of Immigration, Is Dead at 81
text: Rudolph J. Vecoli, an Italian-American historian whose searching chronicles of the American immigrant experience gave a new view of what immigrants kept and left behind, died on June 17 in St. Louis Park, Minn. He was 81 and lived in St. Paul.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: AbelsonTaylor, Chicago, promoted three employees and hired two. Julie Anne Lewis, copywriter, becomes senior copywriter. And Pearl Ochoa and Julia Thiel, art directors, become senior art directors. The new employees are Tony Pope, senior copywriter, who had been senior copywriter at Goble & Associates, Chicago, and Kevin Tran, art director, who worked most recently as a freelance.

headline: Flying High
text: To the Editor:

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about business deals announced on the eve of trade talks between the United States and China misstated the name of the school where the top Chinese delegate to the talks, Vice Premier Wang Qishan, was educated. It is Northwest University, in his native Shanxi Province  not Northwestern University.

headline: ABC and Writers Skirmish Over After-Hours E-Mail
text: BlackBerrys blur the lines between work and play. A recent dispute at ABC News asked: at what point does checking e-mail after hours constitute working overtime?

headline: What Time Is It? Time to Go Outdoors.
text: A campaign from Timex is trying to be as big as all outdoors.

headline: The Case for Mining Law Reform
text: On June 17, the generally conservative commissioners of Lincoln County, New Mexico, terrified by the prospect of a big gold mining operation in the nearby Capitan Mountains, asked the Senate to amend the 1872 mining law to give local officials some say in the matter. Two days later, Representative Raúl Grijalva of Arizona urged the secretary of the interior to take emergency measures to protect lands adjacent to the Grand Canyon from uranium mining. And the day after that, three Western governors added their voices to the reform chorus.

headline: From Afghanistan, NATO Shells Militants in Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO forces in Afghanistan shelled guerrillas in Pakistan in two separate episodes on Sunday, as escalating insurgent violence appeared to be eroding the alliance’s restraint along the border.

headline: Mugabe Rival Quits Zimbabwe Runoff, Citing Attacks
text: JOHANNESBURG  The leader of Zimbabwe’s opposition party withdrew Sunday from a presidential runoff, just five days before it was to be held, saying he could neither participate “in this violent, illegitimate sham of an election process,” nor ask his voters to risk their lives in the face of threats from forces backing President Robert Mugabe.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the songwriter-singer Tony Joe White, who will perform at Joe’s Pub on Wednesday, misidentified an artist who recorded his “Rainy Night in Georgia.” It was Brook Benton, not Gladys Knight. (She recorded “Midnight Train to Georgia,” by Jim Weatherly.)

headline: For One Night, a Feeling of Caramoor on the Seine
text: KATONAH, N.Y.  Almost as soon as American music was weaned of its early dependency on German models it developed an adolescent crush on France. George Gershwin, of course, celebrated the allure of Paris. The relationship was consummated by the influential pedagogue Nadia Boulanger and her distinguished line of American students, chief among them Aaron Copland.

headline: ‘The Misfits’ on Block
text: A film of Marilyn Monroe on the set of “The Misfits,” her last completed movie, brought $60,000 at an auction of cinema memorabilia held by Julien’s Auctions at Planet Hollywood Resort and Casino in Las Vegas on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. The 47-minute film, “On the Set With ‘The Misfits,’ ” was shot by Stanley Floyd Kilarr, an extra in the movie, and includes candid bits with Monroe, above in a still from the movie, Clark Gable, Montgomery Clift and the director John Huston. The auction also included a disco ball from “Saturday Night Fever,” an original script of “The Godfather” signed by Marlon Brando, and Alfred Hitchcock’s driver’s license. (It went for $8,000.)

headline: Census Damage Control
text: Preparations for the 2010 census are a shambles.

headline: A Musical Daisy Chain Leads Up to Balanchine
text: The new program that entered City Ballet’s repertory on Friday and Saturday evenings features four ballets whose greatest common factor is that they were all choreographed by Balanchine. Since they are so unalike, that itself is a real fascination.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Big Paycheck or Service? Students Are Put to Test
text: A prominent education professor at Harvard has begun leading “reflection” seminars at three highly selective colleges, which he hopes will push undergraduates to think more deeply about the connection between their educations and aspirations.

headline: Bright Spots on a Rainy Day
text: In the wacky category of Yankees highlights Sunday, Jason Giambi stole a base and Andy Pettitte was knocked off the pitching mound by a gust of wind during a rain-delayed 4-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Yankee Stadium.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article Saturday about Steven, Mark and Diana Lopez, siblings who qualified for the Olympics in tae kwon do, misstated the origins of karate. It is a Japanese martial art, not a Korean martial art like tae kwon do.

headline: Bruno, N.Y. Senate Majority Leader, Won’t Seek Re-Election
text: Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, the New York State’s highest-ranking Republican, said Monday evening that he would step down at the end of his term in December.

headline: Judging Children as Adults: The New York Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amid Despair in a Venezuelan Prison, Strains of Hope From a Music Program
text: LOS TEQUES, Venezuela  When Nurul Asyiqin Ahmad was taken seven months ago to her cell at the National Institute of Feminine Orientation, a prison perched on a hill in this city of slums on the outskirts of Caracas, learning how to play Beethoven was one of the last things on her mind.

headline: More Time Spent With Online Videos
text: Compared with previous years, the number of Internet users who watched videos on YouTube and other Web sites has risen only slightly. The overall number crept to about 135 million in April from 132 million in May 2007, according to comScore, an online measurement firm.

headline: Why an Abortion Provider, Under Siege, Presses On
text: To the Editor:

headline: Old World Lesson for the New N.B.A.
text: Brandon Jennings smiled Sunday afternoon when someone suggested that he might be considered a trendsetter.

headline: In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds
text: ALGIERS  First, Abdel Malek Outas’s teachers taught him to write math equations in Arabic, and embrace Islam and the Arab world. Then they told him to write in Latin letters that are no longer branded unpatriotic, and open his mind to the West.

headline: Once an Internet Giant, InfoSpace Dismantles Itself
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A couple of weeks ago, the handful of people who were still trying to use InfoSpace.com to look up phone numbers and addresses started finding themselves on the homepage of SuperPages, the business-listings site owned by a Verizon spinoff.

headline: Another Female Suicide Bomber Strikes Iraqi Province, Killing 15 Near Courthouse
text: BAGHDAD  The latest in a wave of female suicide bombers killed 15 people and wounded more than 40 others on Sunday near a heavily fortified courthouse and government outpost in central Baquba, Iraqi security officials said. Seven of the dead and 10 of the wounded were Iraqi police officers.

headline: Soggy Cleanup in Cedar Rapids
text: As the floodwaters slowly recede, residents find that going home is only one step toward recovery.

headline: NASA’s Hansen: Humans Still Loading Climate Dice
text: [UPDATED 6/23, 9:30 a.m.] Twenty years ago today, James E. Hansen testified before the Senate Energy Committee — in a room kept intentionally warm by committee staff — that the atmospheric buildup of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases from burning fossil fuels and forests was already perceptibly influencing Earth’s climate.

headline: Meet the Starter
text: Bill Pennington meets the club's starter and learns the etiquette of beginning a round.

headline: Bob Feller: Lots of Words, Plus a Ride to the Airport
text: If you spend two hours interviewing the Hall of Fame pitcher Bob Feller, you are bound to get some terrific stories and some saucy opinions. When I spoke with Feller last week for a story about the 1939 All-Star Game in today’s paper, he delivered. He gave me priceless anecdotes and blunt comments.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Richard W. Stevenson, Political Editor
text: Richard W. Stevenson, political editor and deputy Washington bureau chief, answered questions from readers June 23-27, 2008. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

headline: ‘The Shack’
text: 4 The Great Sadness

headline: Flip-Flops Are Looking Like a Hot Summer Trend
text: This presidential election year may prove better than most at allowing a candidate to survive charges of flip-flopping. And Senators Barack Obama and John McCain seem to have set out to test their luck.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 67 Western Michigan
text: Location: Kalamazoo, Mich.

headline: George Carlin, 1937-2008
text: George Carlin died of heart failure on Sunday at 71. The envelope-pushing comic was featured here just last week on the occasion of being named recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. Since earlier Carlin was cleaner Carlin, here’s some audio from the 1960s of his fake newscast, including the Hippy Dippy Weatherman:

headline: ‘Optimist of the Year’
text: More of your user-generated jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Friendly Little Guy
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Lloyds Said to Eye Big German Deal
text: British bank Lloyds TSB would consider a significant acquisition and is looking at a possible deal in Germany, according to Reuters.

headline: Macau Casino Giant Said to Seek I.P.O.
text: SJM Holdings, Macau’s largest casino operator, may raise as much as 5.1 billion Hong Kong dollars ($653 million) from a share sale repeatedly delayed by a dispute between billionaire Stanley Ho and his sister Winnie, according to press reports.

headline: Nokia to Buy Germany’s Plazes in Social-Network Push
text: Nokia said Monday that it has inked a deal to buy Plazes, a German social network, as part of the mobile phone giant’s push to transform itself into a next-generation entertainment company.

headline: Conrad Says He Asked for No Favors From Countrywide
text: Senator Kent Conrad never asked for or expected discounted mortgages or a “sweetheart deal” from Countrywide Financial, he wrote in a letter appearing in Monday’s edition of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Dexia Extends $5 Billion in Credit to FSA After Ackman Attack
text: William Ackman’s grim view of bond insurer Financial Security Assurance is costing its European parent a pretty penny.

headline: Morgan Stanley Makes Japan Hire to Bolster Private Equity Unit
text: Morgan Stanley said it had appointed Yoshihiko Shigenari head of its private equity unit in Japan as the investment bank strengthens its business in the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Wall Street’s Fading Crush on G.E.
text: These days, it’s hard to find much love on the Street for General Electric, once the bluest of blue chips. Shares of the company, which makes everything from light bulbs to jet engines to movies, sank to a five-year low last week after one of the few remaining bulls on the stock finally threw in the towel.

headline: Bunge to Acquire Corn Products for $4.4 Billion
text: Bunge said Monday that it would buy Corn Products International for $4.4 billion in stock, as the fertilizer and oilseed processor seeks to better compete against other American agricultural giants.

headline: Future Broker to Bid Adieu to Nymex
text: In another sign that trading on the floor of the nation’s stock exchanges isn’t what it used to be, futures-brokerage giant R.J. O’Brien & Associates is exiting the floor-trading business on New York’s commodities exchanges, The New York Post reported.

headline: Fortress Said to Mull Additional $1 Billion for Distressed Assets
text: Fortress Investment Group is considering adding another $1 billion to the war chest it has amassed to take advantage of the pain being felt on Wall Street, The New York Post reported.

headline: Kaltura Raises Second Round
text: Kaltura, a video company that is considered a blend of YouTube and Wikipedia, has closed a second round of funding.

headline: Neocleus Raises $11.4 Million from V.C.’s
text: Neocleus, a company that provides “endpoint virtualization,” has raised $11.4 million in a second round of funding.

headline: Investors Approve Sale of Getty Images
text: Shareholders say Getty Images can go ahead with its plan to sell itself to the private equity group Hellman & Friedman of San Francisco.

headline: Hellman Joins Group Mulling an Informa Bid
text: Hellman & Friedman is part of a private equity group that is considering a joint bid for British media company Informa, fellow members Providence Equity Partners and The Carlyle Group said.

headline: Comcast’s Fandango Buys Disney’s Movies.com
text: While Comcast didn’t succeed in buying Walt Disney a few years ago, it has now succeeded in buying a part of it, PaidContent.org reports.

headline: Ex-Bear Stearns Fund Manager Uses Homes to Post Bail
text: Former Bear Stearns hedge-fund manager Ralph Cioffi, who was indicted Thursday, has used his homes in New Jersey and Naples, Fla. to secure a $4 million bond, but did not use his toniest address in Southampton to gain his freedom pending trial, The New York Post reported.

headline: MAN Said to Hire Goldman to Explore Sale of Unit
text: German conglomerate MAN asked Goldman Sachs  to sound out interest in its plant engineering and industrial services unit MAN Ferrostaal, Financial Times Deutschland reported.

headline: ABC Moves to Expand Its Reach on Video Web Sites
text: ABC, the stingiest of the major television networks when it comes to syndicating its programs across the Web, is loosening up a little.

headline: Once an Internet Giant, InfoSpace Dismantles Itself
text: A couple of weeks ago, the handful of people who were still trying to use InfoSpace.com to look up phone numbers and addresses started finding themselves on the homepage of SuperPages, the business-listings site owned by a Verizon spinoff.

headline: Bollywood Goes to Hollywood, With Some Tinsel of Its Own
text: Hollywood loves to show outside investors just how the movie business really works. But some of the people behind Bollywood in India believe they have something to teach Hollywood about making movies.

headline: Bill to Protect Companies in Inquiries Adds Support
text: Nearly three dozen former federal prosecutors have thrown their weight behind a Congressional bill intended to safeguard confidential communications between lawyers and their clients, a legal bedrock that has come under attack amid corporate fraud scandals.

headline: Republic to Buy Allied Waste for $6.07 Billion
text: Republic Services said Monday that it acquire Allied Waste Industries for $6.07 billion in stock, uniting two of the largest companies in the waste disposal industry.

headline: Congress Wrapping Up Surveillance, War Bills
text: There will be a torrent of major votes in the Senate this week as lawmakers dash toward the July Fourth recess eager to dispense with a number of hot-button issues.

headline: Diamonds or Oil, Is a Cartel Forever?
text: As Lab readers were debating Malthusianism and oil reserves, I noticed a couple of interesting items about diamonds, one of the most expensive and restricted resources on Earth.

headline: Fed, S.E.C. Said to Redraw Wall Street Regulations
text: The Federal Reserve and Securities Exchange Commission are finalizing an agreement to start the process of redrawing how Wall Street is regulated, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The Softer Side of TCI
text: The founder of founder of The Children’s Investment Fund, Chris Hohn, gave 324 million pounds ($648 million) to his charitable foundation last year, making the activist hedge fund manager among the most generous of the current wave of super-rich British philanthropists, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A Tougher Time for Banks to Hunt for Money
text: Remember that time not-so-long ago when banks were rushing to raise capital to shore up their balance sheets?

headline: Goldman Said to Prepare Scores of Layoffs
text: Even Goldman Sachs is acknowledging the new reality: job cuts in investment banking are necessary.

headline: Now they tell us
text: So, the people who didn’t see the housing bust coming, and in fact argued strenuously that there was no bubble, now tell us that it’s the worst housing slump in 60 years. Thanks a lot, guys.

headline: The Early Word: McCain’s ‘Clean Car Challenge’
text: After coming under criticism in some quarters last week for elements of his energy plan, Senator John McCain today is expected to once again call for weaning America off its dependence on foreign oil by encouraging automakers to sell alternative fuel vehicles, according to an excerpt of a speech he will give in Fresno, Calif.:

headline: Multitasking’s Out
text: Workplace | Multitasking used to be the wave of the future. Now it’s in disrepute. It’s not only unsafe in some cases (cell phones and cars) but “infomania” is being called a serious threat to worker productivity. Besides, flitting from one activity to another may be an outmoded throwback to nomads who led a peripatetic life. It’s ill-suited to the demands of modern society. — The New Atlantis, Economist

headline: Analyst Sees Tougher Times for Merrill, UBS
text: Banc of America Securities expects Merrill Lynch and UBS to write down $3.5 billion and $7 billion respectively in the second quarter and forecast a quarterly loss for the investment banks, Reuters reported.

headline: More Answers From Iraqi Teens
text: Video

headline: Milan Fashion Week
text: Photos from the Prada, Gucci, Versace, Alexander McQueen, Armani and Bottega Veneta spring/summer 2009 collections in Milan.

headline: Want to Protest at City Hall? Make an Appointment
text: The steps of City Hall — once the scene of loud, colorful protests and even a few violent riots — are now available only by appointment and must be booked much like a Saturday morning golf tee time, Fernanda Santos reports. With the public barred from City Hall Plaza, the only potential audience is the overstretched press corps, and only a few time slots — clustered around noon — really matter. Competition for them is intense.

headline: Time Running Out For Actors’ Contract Talks
text: The Hollywood Reporter: “The Screen Actors Guild celebrated its 75th anniversary this weekend in the face of a grim reality: There are only eight days left to negotiate a deal with the major producers and studios before its TV/theatrical contract expires.”

headline: ABC and Writers Skirmish Over After-Hours E-Mail
text: BlackBerrys blur the lines between work and play. A recent dispute at ABC News asked: at what point does checking e-mail after hours constitute working overtime?

headline: Is There Any Comfort in a $30 TV Dinner?
text: This is a city where there seems to be no end of the humble foods that can be transformed into a luxury. Joining the $60-plus hamburger and the $95 beer is the $30 TV dinner, courtesy of Loews Regency Hotel and the childhood nostalgia of its executive chef, Andrew Rubin.

headline: George Carlin, A Comic Mainstay Of HBO and Late-Night, Dies
text: “George Carlin, the Grammy-Award winning standup comedian and actor who was hailed for his irreverent social commentary, poignant observations of the absurdities of everyday life and language, and groundbreaking routines like ‘Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television,’ died in Santa Monica, Calif., on Sunday,” Mel Watkins reports.

headline: Reactions: Opposition’s Withdrawal in Zimbabwe
text: Opposing President Robert G. Mugabe has never been a safe endeavor for Zimbabweans, so Morgan Tsvangirai‘s stated reason for ending his election campaign to replace Mr. Mugabe — violence — was an easy one for people to question.

headline: Bowing to times, Spain developer advertises 25 percent discount
text: In a rare public acknowledgment of the situation in Spain, developer Taylor Woodrow de España is advertising a 25 percent discount on selected projects.

headline: 1 Dead in Chinatown After Dump Truck Hits Bus
text: Updated, 1:15 p.m. | A commercial dump truck rammed into a bus in Chinatown on Monday morning, sending it onto the sidewalk and crashing into the front of a bank, killing a 57-year-old woman and injuring four others, including two police officers, officials said.

headline: Huntsman Gets Personal in Apollo Lawsuit
text: The gloves are off in the Huntsman–Hexion Specialty Chemicals dispute.

headline: A Novelist’s Extreme Anti-Extremism
text: “The novelist Ian McEwan has launched an astonishingly strong attack on Islamism, saying that he ‘despises’ it and accusing it of ‘wanting to create a society that I detest,’ ” reports The Independent of London. “His words, in an interview with an Italian newspaper, could, in today’s febrile legalistic climate, lay him open to being investigated for a ‘hate crime.’ ” McEwan was speaking out in defense of his friend and fellow novelist Martin Amis, who has come under attack for expressing anti-Islamist views.

headline: Dubai and The Donald
text: BRIEFS New city of superlatives, meet the man who has always gloried in building the biggest and the best, or at least most expensive: “Trump penthouse breaks Dubai records.” If you are on the fence about paying $3,000 per square foot, take this note of reassurance from Donald Trump: “I have created some of the world’s most spectacular buildings and hotels,” he told told The National of the United Arab Emirates, “but my project with [Dubai developer] Nakheel will be one of the most impressive undertakings.”

headline: Recipe of the Day: Fried Hominy
text: This is a popular pre-meal dish made at Cookshop, the Manhattan restaurant at 10th Avenue and 20th Street. It was an easy order for me the first time around, because I’m a huge fan of all forms of dried corn.

headline: Deutsche Bank Adds Two to Midwest Banking Team
text: Deutsche Bank announced Monday that it has hired two investment bankers to help bolster its Midwestern region operations.

headline: Some Like It Hot
text: Angelo Vignara, a 63-year-old Vietnam veteran, sunbathes on a blanket in the middle of the sidewalk at Broadway and 109th Street.

headline: U.S. Men’s Basketball Roster Announced
text: [Updated at 5:15 p.m.]

headline: Two-Time N.H.R.A. Champ Dies in Crash
text: N.H.R.A.: The Funny Car driver Scott Kalitta died Saturday as a result of a crash during a qualifying attempt at the Lucas Oil SuperNationals at Old Bridge Township Raceway Park in New Jersey.

headline: Degrees of Church Estrangement
text: ITALY Evidently, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has sat out one too many communions. Under church law, the Italian leader is forbidden from the rite along with most other Catholics who have divorced and remarried. But his patience ended — if only for a moment — in Sardinia on Saturday, when he surprised a bishop performing Mass. “When are you going to change this rule that stops me taking communion?” he blurted out, according to The Guardian. The bishop wisely sidestepped the issue, advising him to appeal to a higher authority.

headline: Britain’s Mouse Trap for Car Thieves
text: There’s a whole lot of backseat thieving going on today in Britain. Is James Milsom the country’s “dumbest criminal” or are the courts far too soft?

headline: Loaded Rotation Has Angels Flying High
text: The Philadelphia Phillies learned what American League teams have known for months now: the Los Angeles Angels have one of the most successful rotations in baseball this season.

headline: ABC and ESPN Adds Videos To Veoh
text: “ABC, the stingiest of the major television networks when it comes to syndicating its programs across the Web, is loosening up a little,” Brad Stone reports.

headline: Another Texas Buyout Showdown
text: Huntsman made the logical counter-attack in its fight with Apollo Management. It sued Leon Black, Joshua J. Harris and over a dozen other Apollo affiliated funds and entities in Texas for more than $3 billion.

headline: High Court Won’t Hear Appeal on Atlantic Yards
text: Updated, 2:33 p.m. | The United States Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal by about a dozen New York City property owners and tenants whose homes and businesses are scheduled to be taken over by the government and demolished to make way for the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn.

headline: 1988-2008: Climate Then and Now
text: Global warming has felt like breaking news a few times in recent years. But the first big pulse of coverage and public attention came in 1988, when the Amazon rain forest and Yellowstone were ablaze, a searing drought had farmers kicking dusty fields in frustration, and global temperatures had seen enough of a rise that a NASA climate expert, James Hansen, asserted before a Senate panel that statistics showed “the greenhouse effect has been detected and is changing our climate now.”

headline: London Theater Journal: The Cost of Everything
text: Of course the journey had to begin with Brecht. On Friday, my first day of a month of concentrated theatergoing in London, I had the occasion to hear God (well, one of three gods) advise a kindly prostitute to “be good” and hear the prostitute answer, “How can I, when everything’s so expensive?”

headline: Lettering in Double Dutch
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Go for Broke | Chanel Jacket, $4,710
text: An updated classic (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times).

headline: A Dinner of Side Dishes
text: Ed returns from the farmers’ market with the first of the great spring vegetables. –MB

headline: Take a Shuttle to the Bronx Floating Pool
text: Just in time for this Friday’s opening of the Floating Pool Lady in the Bronx, the city will provide shuttle bus service to the western edge of the Hunts Point peninsula. The bus will run from June 27 through September 1 and will stop at several subway stations along the 2, 5 and 6 IRT lines in Longwood and Hunts Point. Regular bus fare applies, as do transfer policies.

headline: “Parents Who Don’t Parent”
text: The United States’ 50 largest cities graduate only 50% of their high school students. Chicago public school teacher Will Okun discusses some of the consequences, as well as some promising solutions.

headline: Ask the Experts About Algeria
text: Three experts on youth development in the Middle East have read Michael Slackman’s latest piece in the “General Faithful” series, “In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds, “ and will answer some reader questions about points the article raised. Two of them have also given their initial reaction to the article in this latest posting of The Majlis, a blog that runs in tandem with “Generation Faithful.”

headline: Job Offer Titillates Watchers of State Senate Majority
text: ALBANY — Is Gov. David A. Paterson, a Democrat, working to keep the State Senate in Republican hands?

headline: George Carlin and the Inaugural ‘SNL’
text: “Talk about a live show! It’s nice to see you, welcome, and thanks for joining us — live.”

headline: George Carlin’s Televised Stage
text: George Carlin will be remembered for producing 23 comedy albums, writing 3 books and coining the “Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television.” And here’s another: he hosted 14 comedy specials on HBO, apparently more than any other comedian in the premium cable channel’s history.

headline: Shopping via Cellphone Slowed by Security Fears
text: While much is discussed these days about what kind of entertainment consumers want to enjoy on their mobile phones, perhaps an equally interesting development to watch is whether they will use them to shop.

headline: Ad Agency Ad on Ad Show
text: An ad agency advertises on "Mad Men," a show about advertising.

headline: Many Normal-Weight Teens Feel Fat
text: At a time when much of the Western world is focusing on obesity problems, even teens who are at a healthy weight may develop a distorted body image.

headline: Beijing Starts Effort to Rid Olympic Areas of Mosquitoes and Other Pests
text: It may be the year of the rat, but that’s not granting Chinese vermin any immunity.

headline: Candidate’s Death Adds Turmoil to Race for Fossella Seat
text: Updated, 4:50 p.m. | The death on Sunday of Francis H. Powers, the man selected by Republican leaders on Staten Island as their candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, has once again plunged party leaders on Staten Island into uncertainty.

headline: Reminder: Tell Matt Where to Go
text: Just one week left to tell me where to go during Week 10 of my 12-week Grand Tour of Europe.

headline: The Morning Skate: A Drafty Weekend
text: The week between the NHL Entry Draft and the July 1 onslaught of free agency is a time of furtive activity. There’s tons of contract negotiating (you can’t say any longer that GMs and agents “burn up the phone lines;” can anyone out there suggest some decent hyperbolic nomenclature for heavy cellphone use?) and some teams — Buffalo and St. Louis are two we know — are conducting lightly publicized development camps.

headline: Unlearned Lessons from 1993
text: As states assess the damage of the recent floods in the Midwest, they are faced with the same questions that were raised after the flood of 1993: Why were new subdivisions built on floodplains? Why did the levees fail? Why are “great floods” occurring not every 150 years but every 15?

headline: Service That Downloads Video of Olympic Events to Become Available
text: A technology company announced Monday morning that it will provide NBC Olympics content on-the-go.

headline: In Lithuania, Better Hide That Hammer and Sickle
text: MOSCOW — Even this many decades later, the legacy of World War II still arouses tensions in Eastern Europe. Consider the latest row between Russia and its Baltic neighbors.

headline: It’s Your Turn to Ask Questions
text: Here’s your chance to ask questions about our political coverage — Dick Stevenson, The Times’s political editor, is the featured “Ask the Editor” this week.

headline: The Polish Play
text: In today’s Arts section, Charles Isherwood reviews a new Polish production of “Macbeth 2008,” presented by the St. Ann’s Warehouse in a stunning outdoor stage on the waterfront in Dumbo. Having seen the production last week, I wholeheartedly second Isherwood’s take.

headline: Looking Beyond Synergies in Making Mergers Work
text: Don’t forget your customers. That’s the moral of a new report conducted by Accenture, the consulting firm, examining the problems sales organizations encounter after corporate mergers and acquisitions.

headline: U.N.I.T.Y., That’s a Unity
text: If any Democrats are worried whether there will be natural unity between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday when they make their first on-the-road appearance since the primary battle ended, they can rest easy.

headline: Principal’s Claims on Pregnancy Pact Disputed
text: Update, 6:15 p.m. Scroll for Time magazine’s response.

headline: Build a Better Car Battery and a Cash Prize Could Be Yours
text: FRESNO, Calif. – In the 18th century the British parliament offered a £20,000 prize to anyone who figured how to solve the problem of calculating longitude. More recently, Netflix offered a million-dollar prize for improving its movie recommendation software. And now Senator John McCain is suggesting a new, national prize: $300 million for anyone who can develop a better, more efficient car battery.

headline: Lefties Rule
text: “While this year’s presidential campaign has been marked by historic firsts, the nominations of senators McCain and Obama will renew one surprising trend: For the fifth time in the last 35 years, America will have a lefty in the White House,” notes The New York Sun’s Russell Berman. “Both major party candidates are southpaws, contributing to a largely unexplained phenomenon that has vexed researchers and historians — and drawn notice from a federal judge destined for the Supreme Court. Though left-handers comprise just 10 percent of the population, they are dominating presidential politics.”

headline: Albany Leaders Reach Deal on Gun Checks and Other Items

Bruno, and the State Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver — in Albany on Monday afternoon to announce an agreement on nine legislative items.Agreement on several other major issues, including Mr. Paterson’s call for a cap on local property taxes, remained elusive, but the three leaders, who collectively have near-total control over state government, emphasized consensus in a joint news conference.(The announcement came on the same day that Mr. Bruno indicated that he would step down as Republican leader of the Senate and would not seek re-election.)

headline: An Author Enters a Fray
text: The prizewinning British author Ian McEwan has caused a minor uproar by saying that he despised “Islamism” because of its intolerance of homosexuality and its limits on women’s freedom, The Telegraph of London reported. Mr. McEwan, right, known for his many novels including “Enduring Love” and “Atonement,” made the comments to the Italian newspaper Corriere Della Sera while defending his friend the writer Martin Amis from charges of racism. Mr. Amis has written that people who look as though they are from the Middle East should be strip-searched and possibly deported. Mr. McEwan said, “As soon as a writer expresses an opinion against Islamism, immediately someone on the left leaps to his feet and claims that because the majority of Muslims are dark skinned, he who criticizes it is racist.” He added: “This is logically absurd and morally unacceptable. Martin is not a racist. And I myself despise Islamism, because it wants to create a society that I detest, based on religious belief, on a text, on lack of freedom for women, intolerance towards homosexuality and so on  we know it well.” He called fundamentalist Christians with similar views “equally absurd,” though at least they are not trying to kill people. Mr. McEwan’s words drew criticism from the Muslim Council of Britain.

headline: Court Voids Finding on Guantánamo Detainee
text: In the first civilian judicial review of the government’s evidence for holding any of the Guantánamo Bay detainees, a federal appeals court has ordered that one of them be released or given a new military hearing.

headline: Dody Goodman, 93, Television Actress, Dies
text: Dody Goodman, an actress who combined a dancer’s grace, a strawberry blond mane and exquisitely timed scatter-brained humor to create television legends, first as a fey foil to Jack Paar and later on the soap-opera parody “Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman,” died Sunday in Englewood, N. J. She was 93, older than she often said.

headline: Prognosis: Diabetes and Depression Track Each Other
text: Depressed people may have an increased risk of Type 2 diabetes, and those with diabetes may be at increased risk for depression. A study published on June 18 in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggests a new level of complexity in the relationship between the disorders.

headline: More Closing Doors
text: Regional theaters aren’t the only cultural places falling on hard times. Cody’s Bookstore in Berkeley, Calif., a literary lighthouse for more than 50 years, closed for good on Friday. Yohan Inc., a Japanese distributor and retailer, bought the store in 2005, and Hirosho Kagawa, Yohan’s president, said in a statement posted on the bookstore’s Web site, codysbooks.com: “Unfortunately, my current business is not strong enough or rich enough to support Cody’s. Of course, the store has been suffering from low sales and the deficit exceeds our ability to service it.” During the 1960s the bookstore was an outpost of the Free Speech Movement. Mr. Kagawa was one of the many writers and readers who fell in love with the store. This is a “heartbreaking moment,” he said, adding, “It means so much to me and I apologize to the people who have supported Cody’s for not being able to keep this landmark independent bookstore open.”

headline: Democrats in Senate Seek to Block Deals for Iraqi Oil
text: A group of Democratic senators led by Charles E. Schumer of New York is appealing to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to block a set of contentious no-bid oil contracts that Iraq has decided to award to the Western oil giants Exxon Mobil, Shell, Total and BP.

headline: A Seductive Urban Sound Hushes Carnegie Hall
text: Bossa nova, the quietly revolutionary Brazilian music that João Gilberto introduced 50 years ago, quickly became associated with the sunswept beaches and sweeping mountain vistas of Rio de Janeiro in songs like “Garota de Ipanema” (“The Girl From Ipanema”) and “Corcovado.” Yet in the hands of Mr. Gilberto, who returned to Carnegie Hall for a JVC Jazz Festival concert on Sunday night, it is also very clearly an urban music, working its subtleties within confined spaces and rigid limitations, like an apartment dweller intent on not disturbing neighbors.

headline: Calls From Crocodile Eggs Serve as Alerts
text: Babies make a lot of noise when they leave the womb, crying and otherwise carrying on.

headline: Top Senator in New York Won’t Seek Re-election
text: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader and New York State’s highest-ranking Republican, said Monday evening that he would not seek re-election in November, after a 32-year career in the Senate.

headline: Technology Leaders Favor Online ID Card Over Passwords
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft, Google and PayPal, a unit of eBay, are among the founders of an industry organization that hopes to solve the problem of password overload among computer users.

headline: On Coach’s Turf, Lagat Aims for Olympic Gold
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  Sunset last Monday seemed to bring a perfect ending to a perfect day in what so far had been a perfect year. Bernard Lagat had just finished a nine-mile trail run as his coach, James Li, followed along on a bike. They had escaped the desert heat of Arizona for cool shade to train for the Olympic track and field trials. Then the evening calm was shattered, along with two windows of the rental car in which they had ridden.

text: Leonard Downie Jr. will step down after 17 years as the top editor of The Washington Post, he told his newsroom staff on Monday, making way for a generational transition under a new publisher, Katharine Weymouth, at a time of financial and technological strain for newspapers.

text: An obituary on Friday about Bert Shepard, who pitched in the major leagues after losing a leg in World War II, misstated his relationship to Betty Shepard. She was not his wife at the time of his death; they were divorced.

headline: Mediate Gets a Greeting That’s Fit for a Champion
text: BARRINGTON, R.I.  The phone rang Monday morning, and Rocco Mediate fumbled for the receiver. On the other end was an unfamiliar voice, informing him that his driver was downstairs waiting. “What time is it?” Mediate said. “And where are we?”

headline: A ‘Bonfire’ Returns as Heartburn
text: Almost exactly a year ago, Tom Wolfe, the author of “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” was wandering the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Dressed in his trademark white suit, he darted around traders and whisked past trading booths, shaking hands and waving, just before the market was about to open.

headline: Last Train to Cross Connecticut Drawbridge
text: In Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor, the railroad’s weakest link  a 90-year-old drawbridge across the Thames River in eastern Connecticut  was scheduled to carry its last train on Monday evening, as a four-day, round-the-clock marathon to replace the span was to begin.

headline: Government Study Criticizes Bush Administration’s Measures of Progress in Iraq
text: Beyond the declines in overall violence in Iraq, several crucial measures the Bush administration uses to demonstrate economic, political and security progress are either incorrect or far more mixed than the administration has acknowledged, according to a report released Monday by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: American Envoy Is Linked to Arms Deal Cover-Up
text: WASHINGTON  An American ambassador helped cover up the illegal Chinese origins of ammunition that a Pentagon contractor bought to supply Afghan security forces, according to testimony gathered by Congressional investigators.

headline: Officials Reject Report of Pregnancy Pact
text: GLOUCESTER, Mass.  The mayor of this seaside city said Monday that there was no independent evidence that a group of high school girls here had made a pact to become pregnant and raise their babies together, as a magazine reported last week.

headline: Tropical Diseases Add to Burden Among the Poor in the U.S.
text: Ailments of poverty, including some tropical diseases much more common in poor countries, are a burden in several regions of the United States, a new analysis finds.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Coach Names Her Olympians
text: When Pia Sundhage was hired as coach of the United States women’s national team seven months ago, her to-do list included taking the team back to the top of the soccer world, preparing it to defend its Olympic gold medal, and altering the chemistry and composition of the roster.

text: The Columbia University professor who gained widespread attention last fall after a noose was found hanging on her office door was fired on Monday after months of wrangling over charges that she plagiarized the work of two former students and a former colleague.

headline: New York Sees Big Potential in a New Wave of Chinese Tourists
text: “New York looks a lot like Shanghai,” said Fu Jiang Li, 47, as he studied the bronze peace sculpture with its knotted gun barrel on United Nations Plaza. He should know, because that’s where he’s from. “But China has only one Shanghai  and America has so many big, modern cities.”

headline: Registry for Lobbyists Is Greeted Coolly
text: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Monday opened its voluntary registry for the thousands of lobbyists and special interest organizations operating in Brussels, aiming to shed more light on a group that seeks to influence regulations on everything from computer software to greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Germany: Calls to Remove U.S. Arms
text: Social Democrats, who share in Germany’s governing coalition, and opposition parties called on the United States to remove all nuclear weapons stored in military bases in the country after a report found that security and safety standards at most sites for nuclear weapons in Europe fall well short of Pentagon requirements. The report was commissioned by the United States Air Force. The Pentagon said it planned to close some sites, but declined to identify them.

headline: From a Prominent Death, Some Painful Truths
text: Apart from its sadness, Tim Russert’s death this month at 58 was deeply unsettling to many people who, like him, had been earnestly following their doctors’ advice on drugs, diet and exercise in hopes of avoiding a heart attack.

headline: Rights Groups Assail U.S. for Withholding Aid to Haiti, Citing Political Motives
text: An array of human rights groups has strongly criticized the United States government, saying it withheld money meant to provide clean drinking water to Haiti as leverage for political change in the country.

headline: Leadership Void Seen in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan is in a leaderless drift four months after elections, according to Western diplomats and military officials, Pakistani politicians and Afghan officials who are increasingly worried that no one is really in charge.

headline: Agreements Elusive at Oil Meeting; Price Moderates
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  A hastily convened global energy summit meeting led by Saudi Arabia ended largely in disagreement on Sunday, with only a modest pledge of increased production by the Saudis and no resolution on what other practical steps should be taken to ease the crisis over soaring oil prices.

headline: China’s Visa Policy Threatens Olympics Tourism
text: BEIJING  The plush lobby of Beijing’s Kerry Center Hotel is usually crowded with foreign guests, many of them listening to jazz and sipping martinis in Centro, the hotel’s fashionable bar, or lining up for taxis after dinner at the Horizon restaurant.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD

It was seven, not six. The column also misspelled the title of one encore piece, which was repeated. It is “Granada,” not “Grenada.”
