headline: Court Overturns Guantánamo Hearing
text: After the first court review of the basis for holding a Guantánamo detainee, the federal appeals court in Washington has overturned the Pentagon’s decision and ordered that the man be released or given a new military hearing.

headline: Some Doubts Upon Entering a New Carboniferous Era
text: Has any phrase in the English language ever spread more quickly than “carbon footprint”? There are contenders  “hanging chad,” for instance  but they don’t reflect the potential revolution in consciousness that carbon footprint suggests. After all, carbon footprint captures something we’ve never really had a simple phrase for before: the measurable totality of your environmental impact, or, to put it more simply, what your way of life actually costs the planet. “Carbon footprint” is to your physical being what “soul” is to your spiritual being.

headline: Achieving Wellness, Whatever That Is
text: There are so few good belly laughs in health care these days. What a pity I am likely to be the only person on the planet to enjoy the guffaw-laden, if slightly unnerving, experience of reading Dr. Nancy Snyderman and Dr. Nortin Hadler’s new books in tandem, taking careful notes.

headline: Firefighters Start to Gain in Northern California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Firefighters began to gain an upper hand on some of the hundreds of fires that erupted across Northern California over the weekend.

headline: A Theater Goes Dark
text: In 2005 Minneapolis’s inventive Théâtre de la Jeune Lune won the special Tony award for the nation’s best regional playhouse. Now it is closing its theater and selling off its building to pay off a $1 million debt. “After much soul searching and extensive fund-raising and debt management efforts, we have determined it to be the only prudent and fiscally responsible choice,” Dominique Serrand, the artistic director, wrote in a letter posted its Web site, jeunelune.org. Mr. Serrand helped found the theater in 1978, and it traveled between the United States and France before it bought the Allied Van Lines building in Minneapolis’s warehouse district in 1992. The board voted over the weekend to close on July 31.

headline: A Master of Words, Including Some You Can’t Use in a Headline
text: Stand-up comedy in America is not, for the most part, a long-lived profession. Comics burn out, go stale, lose their edge. Some, like Lenny Bruce and Richard Pryor, almost literally consume themselves. Others, like Steve Martin, prudently retire from the stage at the top of their form and then find other things to do. And a few old-timers, like Don Rickles, have turned themselves into living museums, doing a kind of humor that commemorates its own borscht belt roots.

headline: Footnotes
text: Apparently not everything that happens in Las Vegas stays in Las Vegas. The 25th annual MTV Video Music Awards will be held in Los Angeles on Sept. 7. ... The original cast recording of “The Hired Man,” part of the current “Brits Off Broadway” festival at 59E59 Theaters, will be on sale at the theater starting Tuesday. The show continues through June 29 (britsoffbroadway.com). ... The comedian Don Reed will present his autobiographical solo show “East 14th: True Tales of a Reluctant Player,” about growing up in Oakland, Calif., in the 1970s. Previews start at New World Stages Thursday (East14th.com). ... After a successful run at the Piccolo Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., last month, “Silence of Lucky,” the comedian David Lee Nelson’s solo show of monologues and video, will run at the 78th Street Theater Lab on Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m. between July 13 and 28 (smarttix.com). ... The architects Zaha Hadid and Ben van Berkel will each design a pavilion for the 100th anniversary of Daniel Burnham’s influential “Plan of Chicago” in the city’s Millennium Park next year.

headline: Cameras Emerge as a Tool in a Conflict Over Land
text: KHIRBET SUSIYA, West Bank  The conflict between Arabs and Jews over grazing land and water wells in the ancient, arid hills south of Hebron in the West Bank has a distinctly biblical feel, like the flimsy tent encampments and dank caves in which some local Palestinian farming families dwell.

headline: To Avoid Student Turnover, Parents Get Rent Help
text: FLINT, Mich.  Because he has moved so often, 9-year-old Richard Kennedy has already attended four different schools in Flint. In his mother’s latest rental house the other day, he described how it felt to enter an unfamiliar classroom.

headline: Safety: Deaths Soar After Repeal of Helmet Law
text: In 2003, Pennsylvania legislators repealed a law requiring motorcycle riders to wear helmets. Researchers who studied deaths and injuries over the next two years say that decision had lethal, and expensive, consequences.

headline: What’s Obscene? Google Could Have an Answer
text: Judges and jurors who must decide whether sexually explicit material is obscene are asked to use a local yardstick: does the material violate community standards?

headline: Dia Art Foundation Names a Curator as Its Next Director
text: After two years of flux, the Dia Art Foundation said on Monday that it had hired a prominent contemporary-art curator, Philippe Vergne, deputy director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, as its director.

headline: M.T.A. Cuts Delay Some Big Projects Until 2010
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released a cascade of grim financial assessments on Monday that mean delays in subway station renovations and other major improvements, as well as possible cutbacks in service and increases in fares and tolls.

headline: Kidnappers Release Greek Industrialist After Ransom Is Paid
text: ATHENS  A Greek industrialist who was kidnapped at gunpoint two weeks ago has been freed unharmed after his family paid an unspecified sum in ransom.

headline: Truths, Convenient or Not (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Two U.S. Soldiers Killed by Gunman, but Details Are Disputed
text: BAGHDAD  A security guard for an Iraqi politician grabbed his Kalashnikov automatic rifle and opened fire on at least a half-dozen American soldiers, killing two of them, during a meeting with Iraqi officials in a village southeast of Baghdad on Monday, an Iraqi Interior Ministry official said.

headline: Built to Order: Myanmar’s New Capital Isolates and Insulates Junta
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  The bamboo forests and sugar cane fields that once covered the gently sloping hills here have been replaced by hulking government buildings, roads so long and straight they resemble runways and a vast construction site marked by a sign: “Parliament zone. Do not enter.”

headline: Conflict With Farmers Takes Toll on Argentina
text: ROSARIO, Argentina  Country roads and highways swelled with trucks bearing grains and gasoline over the weekend, as Argentina’s farmers cleared the highways after lifting their fourth strike in three months.

headline: After Rose and Beasley, Plenty of Questions to Choose From
text: The N.B.A. holds its draft in a Manhattan theater, a setting that evokes drama, colorful characters and wily plot twists. It is, in the best of years, a night of exultation and exclamation marks. This is not one of those years.

headline: A One-Time Tax Break Saved 843 U.S. Corporations $265 Billion
text: More than 840 of the largest American corporations reaped a $265 billion windfall thanks to a one-time tax break aimed at bringing home profits stashed overseas, according to recent government data.

headline: A Familiar Tale of a Man Losing Himself in the Wild
text: In April 1992 a young man named Christopher Johnson McCandless left civilization for the Alaskan wilderness, determined to live off the land and “kill the false being within.” Several months later hunters found his corpse and a note, saying: “SOS. I need your help. I am injured, near death and too weak to hike out of here.” He was dead at 24.

headline: Small Towns in Illinois and Missouri Await River’s Crest
text: GRAFTON, Ill.  Residents in cities and towns north of St. Louis continued battling floodwaters Monday as forecasters warned that the Mississippi River would remain near its current peak levels through much of the week.

headline: Lawyer Says N.B.A. Is Trying to Intimidate Donaghy
text: The N.B.A.’s attempt to recoup nearly $1.4 million in restitution from the disgraced referee Tim Donaghy is “a transparent attempt at witness intimidation,” his lawyer said Monday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
M.P.G. Can Mislead When Searching for Fuel Efficiency
text: In an era of climate change and expensive gasoline, a vehicle’s fuel efficiency, measured in miles per gallon, is an increasingly important factor to consider when shopping for a car.

headline: Justices Take Case on Navy Use of Sonar
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday stepped into a long-running environmental dispute over the impact on whales and other marine mammals of Navy training exercises off Southern California.

headline: Memo Pad
text: UNITED ADDS MINIMUM STAY RULES  United Airlines says it will put minimum stay restrictions on almost all its coach fares, for travel starting Oct. 6. The move comes two months after United said it would add Saturday night stay requirements on 65 percent of its routes, and as other airlines are generally reintroducing minimum stay and Saturday night stay rules that were largely discarded in 2001 because of competition from low-cost airlines. In general, said a United spokeswoman, Robin Urbanski, the lower the fare, the higher the minimum stay requirement. For some of the lowest fares in some markets, a combined Saturday and Sunday night stay will be required. Minimum stay requirements have generally been used by airlines to discourage business travelers from buying the cheapest fares.

headline: School Is Out, and Nutrition Takes a Hike
text: As my 9-year-old daughter began summer day camp last week, we talked about swimming rules, sunscreen and ... cheese fries.

headline: Federer Wins Like Clockwork, but Others Face Sterner Test
text: WIMBLEDON, England  The clock on the new Centre Court scoreboard is digital, but the schedule is the same. On Monday at 1 p.m. sharp, the crowd begins to applaud. Moments later, Roger Federer walks onto the meticulously kept rectangle of English lawn that he has made his own over the last five years, and another Wimbledon is under way.

headline: Death Row Inmate’s Case Gets 3rd Hearing
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to have a third look at the case of a death row inmate in Tennessee, this time to consider whether he has forfeited the opportunity to argue that prosecutors withheld evidence important to his defense.

headline: Waste Firms Set Merger for $6 Billion
text: Republic Services said on Monday that it would acquire Allied Waste Industries for $6.07 billion in stock, uniting two of the largest companies in the waste disposal industry.

headline: G.M. Offers Deals to Cut Overstock
text: DETROIT  General Motors, which has struggled to stop depending on big discounts to draw in customers, is pulling the sale banners out again.

headline: Doctors Say Medication Is Overused in Dementia
text: Ramona Lamascola thought she was losing her 88-year-old mother to dementia. Instead, she was losing her to overmedication.

headline: McCain Proposes a $300 Million Prize for a Next-Generation Car Battery
text: FRESNO, Calif.  In the 18th century the British offered a £20,000 prize to anyone who figured out how to calculate longitude. More recently, Netflix offered a million dollars for improving movie recommendations on its Web site. Now Senator John McCain is suggesting a new national prize: He said here Monday that if elected president he would offer $300 million to anyone who could build a better car battery.

headline: George Carlin Didn’t Shun School That Ejected Him
text: George Carlin, who died on Sunday at age 71, is not the most famous graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx. That honor would probably go to either Martin Scorsese or Regis Philbin.

headline: Alaska: Energy Rebate Is Proposed
text: Gov. Sarah Palin wants to dip into the state’s budget, overflowing with oil-tax revenue, and give every Alaskan a $1,200 rebate to offset rising household energy costs. Ms. Palin, a Republican, said the rebate would cost $729 million in the fiscal year that begins July 1. Every man, woman and child who has lived legally in the state for more than 180 days would qualify for the payment. The state’s Department of Revenue estimates that record crude oil prices could pump $14 billion into state’s coffers in the coming fiscal year, $7 billion more than needed to meet current spending requirements. Ms. Palin’s deputy press secretary, Sharon Leighow, said the bill was likely to face opposition in the Legislature, which must approve the spending. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: Hopes for Survivors Fading at Sunken Philippine Ferry
text: MANILA  Rescuers failed on Monday to find signs of life in a capsized ferry that held more than 800 passengers and crew members when a typhoon struck on Saturday.

headline: Dying Is Hard. Comedy Is Harder.
text: THE honest truth is, for a comedian, even death is just a premise to make jokes about. I know this because I was on the phone with George Carlin nine days ago and we were making some death jokes. We were talking about Tim Russert and Bo Diddley and George said: “I feel safe for a while. There will probably be a break before they come after the next one. I always like to fly on an airline right after they’ve had a crash. It improves your odds.”

headline: The Bush Paradox
text: Let’s go back and consider how the world looked in the winter of 2006-2007. Iraq was in free fall, with horrific massacres and ethnic cleansing that sent a steady stream of bad news across the world media. The American public delivered a stunning electoral judgment against the Iraq war, the Republican Party and President Bush.

headline: The Times and I.H.T. Study Web Merger
text: PARIS  The New York Times Company is developing plans to merge the Web site of the International Herald Tribune with that of The New York Times, in a bid to expand their global reach and deepen their appeal to advertisers.

headline: Survey Shows U.S. Religious Tolerance
text: Although a majority of Americans say religion is very important to them, nearly three-quarters of them say they believe that many faiths besides their own can lead to salvation, according to a survey by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

headline: Fred Wilpon Discusses the Dismissal of Randolph
text: As speculation about Willie Randolph’s job status as manager of the Mets simmered for weeks, Fred Wilpon, the team’s owner, declined to comment. But one week after Randolph’s dismissal, Wilpon finally spoke about the decision.

headline: Canada: Suspect in Terror Plot Tried to Ship Detonators, Prosecutors Say
text: A man charged with participating in planning terrorist attacks in Britain hoped to use an internal courier service of Canada’s Department of Foreign Affairs to send remote bomb detonators to England, prosecutors said at the opening of his trial in Ottawa. The man, Momin Khawaja, a former software developer at the department, also used the department’s computers to exchange messages about the detonators and a bomb plot with fellow conspirators in Britain, prosecutors said. Mr. Khawaja, a Canadian, is charged with plotting to bomb various sites in Britain.

headline: Microbes Eating Away at Pieces of History
text: At Angkor Wat, the dancers’ feet are crumbling.

headline: Woman Is Killed When Truck Hits Bus in Chinatown
text: The green street sign says, “Welcome to Manhattan,” but drivers coming off the Manhattan Bridge usually have no trouble knowing precisely where they are.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, the Shortcuts column on Saturday, about gifts for graduates, misstated the sales of a popular gift, the Dr. Seuss book “Oh, the Places You’ll Go!” It sells several hundred thousand copies a year, not several hundred thousand dollars’ worth of copies. The column also misstated the rate of sales growth for the book. Sales, which have been increasing steadily, rose by 10 percent this year, not by 10 percent each year since it was published in 1990.

headline: Football Talk Soon Turns to Race on Imus’s Show
text: The radio host Don Imus, fired by CBS last year for referring to the Rutgers women’s basketball team as “nappy-headed hos,” waded into racially treacherous waters again on his new radio program Monday morning, in a brief exchange about a suspended professional football player, Adam Jones.

headline: Car Rental Agencies Using Add-Ons to Lift Returns
text: While a lot of attention has been paid in recent weeks to the fees that struggling airlines are adding to ticket prices, car rental companies have been quietly doing the same thing.

headline: Fit, Not Frail: Exercise as a Tonic for Aging
text: Fact: Every hour of every day, 330 Americans turn 60.

headline: Onward, Copy Editors!
text: To the Editor:

headline: With New Sorter, the Worms Go in, the Worms Go Out
text: Sorting worms is not necessarily anyone’s idea of a good time. But it’s something that happens a lot in laboratories devoted to the study of C. elegans, the tiny nematode that serves as a model organism in so many fields of research.

headline: Macedonian Murder Suspect Dead in Cell
text: PRAGUE  A Macedonian journalist who wrote vivid accounts of the grisly murders of three cleaning women was found dead in his cell on Monday after the police arrested him on suspicion that he was the killer.

headline: Death Creates More Turmoil in S.I. Congressional Race
text: The death on Sunday of Francis H. Powers, the man selected by Republican leaders on Staten Island as their candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, has once again plunged party leaders on Staten Island into uncertainty.

headline: The Trials of Physicians (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Olympics Compete
text: NBC’s coverage of the United States Olympic Trials gave the network a boost in the ratings on Sunday, making it No. 1 for the night among adults 18 to 49. But that was not enough to pull NBC ahead among total viewers. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the women’s gymnastics contenders put NBC in the lead in the 18-to-49 demographic during the 7 and 8 p.m. hours despite averaging only a modest total audience of 6.2 million. That tally fell short of CBS’s programming in those time slots: “60 Minutes” (8.9 million) followed by “Million Dollar Password” (8.3 million), helped CBS edge past NBC for the night in total viewers. NBC’s “Dateline” ranked first during the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with 8.2 million viewers, outpacing CBS’s repeats of “Criminal Minds” (7.3 million) and “The Unit” (6.9 million). ABC finished third for the night with a lineup of all repeats. Fox was fourth, although it fared particularly well with the 18-to-49 set. Fox’s “Family Guy” rerun at 9 earned the night’s highest ratings in that age group but just 5.5 million total viewers.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Sunday about a rating system for ecologically minded homes misidentified the architect of an environmentally friendly home in the Venice section of Los Angeles. As the article correctly noted, the architect is Melinda Gray  not Kelly Meyer and Tom Schey, who were the builders.

headline: In 1960, a Series to Remember (or Forget)
text: PITTSBURGH  Typically, Herb Soltman and his legion of Pittsburgh Pirates fans have only one day a year to pay homage to the most dramatic ending in the 104 years of World Series play, when Bill Mazeroski blasted a game-ending Game 7 home run off Yankees reliever Ralph Terry at Forbes Field.

headline: New York Gifted Programs: The Education Dept. View
text: To the Editor:

headline: For 2 Geologists, Collaboration Blossomed Into More
text: When they began their collaborative study of the waterways of central Pennsylvania, Dorothy J. Merritts knew a lot about them and Robert C. Walter knew just a little. Or so it seemed.

headline: Legislators Raise Pay, and a Governor Pays the Price
text: NEW ORLEANS  The reformist image of Gov. Bobby Jindal, considered by Republicans a top potential vice-presidential choice, has recently taken a beating after Mr. Jindal refused to veto a sizable pay increase that Louisiana legislators voted for themselves this month.

headline: Homecoming of Odysseus May Have Been in Eclipse
text: That Odysseus took his time, 10 years, getting home to Ithaca from the Trojan War is the story Homer engraved in the “Odyssey.” But exactly when did he rejoin his Penelope, who had been patient beyond belief?

headline: Follow the Silt
text: LITITZ, Pa.  Dorothy J. Merritts, a geology professor at Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa., was not looking to turn hydrology on its ear when she started scouting possible research sites for her students a few years ago.

headline: The Claim: Listerine Can Ward Off a Swarm of Mosquitoes
text: THE FACTS

headline: Kermit Love, Costume Creator, Dies at 91
text: Kermit Love, the costume designer for some of ballet’s most renowned choreographers whose greatest fame came as a creator, with Jim Henson, of the beloved “Sesame Street” characters Big Bird and Mr. Snuffleupagus, died on Saturday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 91 and lived in Stanfordville, N.Y.

headline: Security Council Urges Zimbabwe to Halt Violence
text: UNITED NATIONS  With Zimbabwe’s opposition under siege and its leader taking refuge at the Dutch Embassy, the Security Council on Monday issued its first sweeping condemnation of the violence gripping the nation, saying it would be “impossible for a free and fair election to take place.”

headline: Mothballing a Critic
text: In the wave of buyouts and layoffs hitting newspapers this season, The Kansas City Star has decided it can no longer afford a classical music critic. Paul Horsley, who took the critic’s job eight years ago, was quoted on the Web site MusicalAmerica.com as saying, “I think it was a very ‘corporate’ decision.” He added, “I think they eliminated the beat they thought they could most easily farm out.” Kansas City’s orchestra, opera and ballet companies are said to be organizing a formal protest. The newspaper’s owner, the McClatchy Company, cut 1,400 people from its workforce last week because of declining revenues. Howard C. Weaver, vice president for news, sent a memo to the staff saying that across the company, 310 to 320 newsroom positions would be cut.

headline: In a Salute to Robbins, Variations Mr. B Might Not Have Considered
text: As hoped, the current Jerome Robbins Celebration at New York City Ballet is certainly demonstrating Robbins’s diversity. At many points, however, it only adds to the puzzle of just who Robbins the artist was.

headline: Borat, in Good Company
text: Who said you can’t get anywhere being rude and obnoxious? Sacha Baron Cohen, below, the irreverent creator of “Borat,” was one of 105 people asked to join the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Monday, Agence France-Presse reported. Also on the list was Marion Cotillard, who won an Oscar this year for her portrayal of Édith Piaf in “La Vie en Rose”; Josh Brolin, who starred in “No Country for Old Men” and is playing President Bush in Oliver Stone’s forthcoming film “W”; the martial arts master Jet Li;  the director Jason Reitman; and Diablo Cody, the screenwriter of the Oscar-winning comedy “Juno.”

headline: The Hague: Serb Police Chief on Trial
text: Stojan Zupljanin, a former Bosnian Serb police chief who is accused of atrocities against Bosnian Muslims and Croats, made his first appearance in The Hague before the United Nations tribunal that will try him. Arrested by the police in Serbia on June 11, Mr. Zupljanin declined to enter a plea. He was indicted on seven counts of war crimes and six of crimes against humanity, accused of murder, torture, unlawful detention, forcible deportation, the destruction of villages and political, racial and religious persecution. Mr. Zupljanin, 56, sat mostly stoically as the charges were read out, apart from an occasional sigh and shake of his head.

headline: Greece: Kidnapped Businessman Freed
text: A Greek industrialist who was kidnapped two weeks ago was freed unharmed after his family paid an unspecified sum in ransom. George Milonas, 49, is chairman of Alumil, an aluminum company with operations in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. He was released in a deserted area west of the city of Thessaloniki, where his business empire has its headquarters, the police said, hours after his captors collected the ransom in a parking lot.

headline: Before Judge, Spirited Clash on Subpoenas for Bush Aides
text: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for the Bush administration and Congress clashed on Monday before a federal judge over whether White House officials could refuse to comply with subpoenas from the House Judiciary Committee.

headline: At Shea, a New Manager Fosters a New Attitude
text: The Mets’ clubhouse feels like the morning after a thunderstorm. The birds are chirping and the sun is glistening off the wet grass.

headline: Justices Refuse Checks on Border Fence
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court sided with the White House on Monday in two cases involving national security and worries about the environment, strengthening the Bush administration’s drive, at least for now, for sweeping executive powers in the post-9/11 world.

headline: ‘Alex’ and the Ad Against the War
text: To the Editor:

headline: Zimbabwe’s Stolen Election
text: Zimbabwe’s presidential runoff election is still scheduled for Friday. But President Robert Mugabe has already stolen the vote.

headline: Muslim Voters Detect a Snub From Obama
text: As Senator Barack Obama courted voters in Iowa last December, Representative Keith Ellison, the country’s first Muslim congressman, stepped forward eagerly to help.

headline: U.S. Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Atlantic Yards Case
text: The United States Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal by about a dozen New York City property owners and tenants whose homes and businesses are scheduled to be taken over by the government and demolished to make way for the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn.

headline: Drug-Resistant High Blood Pressure on the Rise
text: High blood pressure, the most commonly diagnosed condition in the United States, is becoming increasingly resistant to drugs that lower it, according to a panel of experts assembled by the American Heart Association.

headline: Home Depot Offers Recycling for Compact Fluorescent Bulbs
text: Some big retailers are promoting compact fluorescent light bulbs as a way to save energy. But improper disposal of the bulbs creates a hazard, because they contain small amounts of mercury.

headline: Christian Novel Is Surprise Best Seller
text: Eckhart Tolle may have Oprah Winfrey, but “The Shack” has people like Caleb Nowak.

headline: Dedicated to Gold, U.S. Basketball Team Is Named
text: By the United States basketball team’s lofty standards  standards re-established by the Dream Team of 1992  anything short of Olympic gold is seen as a failure. So when Team USA returned from Athens in 2004 with the bronze medal, having won three straight gold medals before that, the program was revamped.

headline: Car-Free Streets, a Colombian Export, Inspire Debate
text: When the crowds stream down Park Avenue and bicyclists have taken over Lafayette Street, the question may strike even the most ardent ambler: Whose idea was this, anyway?

headline: Living With Cancer (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hopes Fade in Search for Ferry Survivors in Philippines
text: MANILA  Hopes faded on Monday that more survivors would be found in what could be one of the Philippines’s worst sea tragedies as rescuers failed to find signs of life inside a capsized ferry that had held more than 800 passengers and crew members when a typhoon struck on Saturday.

headline: Our Pen-and-Paper Doctors
text: With electronic health records seen widely as a way to make medical care better and possibly cheaper, it is disturbing how slowly they are being adopted by American physicians. If this country does not accelerate the conversion from paper to modern technologies, many of the gauzy promises of health care reform made by politicians and health planners will become irrelevant.

headline: The Police and Tasers
text: New York Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly is eager to make the use of firearms a last resort for his officers. Now, based on a recommendation from the RAND Corporation, he and his top lieutenants are considering arming more New York police officers with a less lethal but still controversial weapon, the Taser. Mr. Kelly has concerns about the device, which delivers a jolt of electricity meant to temporarily incapacitate the target. He is right to move with caution.

headline: Nutrition: Chinese Ingredient Said to Help the Heart
text: Chinese food may be good for the heart. Researchers tested a common ingredient, Chinese red yeast rice, or rice fermented using a certain yeast species, and found that it reduced the risk of repeat heart attacks in people who have already had one.

headline: Soccer 1, Mugabe 0
text: IN these last few weeks, the full nature of Robert Mugabe’s repressive regime in Zimbabwe has been cruelly exposed. With his increasingly brazen resort to torture and hit squads to terrorize his own people, Mr. Mugabe has crossed a moral line. Some United Nations lawyers now say there is enough evidence to charge him with crimes against humanity.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A listing of books, a Web site, movies and restaurants on Friday with the Weekend Explorer column, about sites in New York associated with the photographer Weegee, referred incorrectly to Lombardi’s Pizza, at 32 Spring Street on the Lower East Side, an area where Weegee lived and worked. It sells pizza only as pies, not by the slice.

headline: George Carlin, Comic Who Chafed at Society and Its Constraints, Dies at 71
text: George Carlin, whose astringent stand-up comedy made him an heir of Lenny Bruce, who gave voice to an indignant counterculture and assaulted the barricades of censorship on behalf of a generation of comics that followed him, died on Sunday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 71 and lived in Venice, Calif.

headline: Chemical Maker Files Suit Over Approach to Merger
text: In his more than three decades on Wall Street, Leon D. Black has played many roles, including wunderkind investment banker and private equity mogul. On Monday, however, he assumed an altogether different one: defendant in a civil lawsuit.

headline: Japanese-Style Game Shows: Cash for Winners, Humiliation for Losers
text: Human Tetris. Slip ’n’ Slide bowling. Diaper-wearing contestants spinning around in cribs and tackling an obstacle course. These stunts are trademarks of Japanese game shows  and they’re about to be introduced to American television viewers.

headline: Where the Whole Agenda Is Innovation
text: WASHINGTON  John Kao’s “non-career career” began with the study of philosophy and social science at Yale and a summer as a keyboardist with Frank Zappa and the Mothers of Invention. Then there was Yale Medical School and a psychiatry residency at Harvard, interrupted by a fellowship at Harvard Business School that turned into 14 years of teaching about the integration of science, technology and entrepreneurship.

headline: At Ballet Hispanico
text: Tina Ramirez, the founder of Ballet Hispanico, announced Monday that she was hanging up her shoes after 38 years as artistic director. “I am planning to continue as a roving ambassador and spokesperson for the company and school and to carry forward my work as an advocate for dance education,” she said in a news release. Ms. Ramirez, above right, was awarded the National Medal of Arts for in 2005 for her work over the years. She has said that her father, a bullfighter, first taught her to dance. The unifying element, to her, has always been the music. “I wanted to show who Hispanics are,” she once told The New York Times. “Our culture. Why we move the way we do. Our music. There is so much that unites us, like language and love of home and family. Yet there’s so much variety within the given.”

headline: Gone on Business, but Back by Storytime
text: IT’S no secret that publicists travel a lot. In nearly two decades, I’ve probably circled the globe at least twice, going on tour, on photo and video shoots and doing what publicists do, which is helping clients at a moment’s notice. I always loved the whole experience of arriving in a new place.

headline: California: Shootout on Freeway
text: A gun battle on the Riverside Freeway in Orange County left a suspect dead and a woman caught in the crossfire wounded, an Anaheim Police Department official said. The shootout followed a chase along the freeway, also known as California Route 91, around midnight after police officers spotted the car of a 40-year-old man wanted after he fled the scene of a shooting of a police officer at an Anaheim hotel on Sunday morning. Sgt. Rick Martinez said two officers had responded to a call about a man exposing himself to guests from the window of his room at a Best Western hotel about a mile from Disneyland. When the officers arrived, the man, who was not identified, was getting into a car. Shots were fired, and one officer was shot in the thigh. The suspect was next seen driving on the freeway about midnight Sunday. While chased by the police, he crashed and ran from his car, Sergeant Martinez said, then exchanged shots with officers and was killed. A woman who was in a nearby car was wounded in the elbow and lower abdomen, the officer said; she was expected to be released from a hospital. EDWARD WYATT

headline: Does Test Prep Have a Place in the Classroom?
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Alien Life-Seekers, New Reason to Hope
text: Twinkle, twinkle, all you stars

headline: Cable Channels Gain on Broadcast Networks
text: AS the cable channels that populate the television dial conclude their advance advertising sales, they have something to celebrate: they made much greater gains than the broadcast networks.

headline: Learn From History in Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pakistan Court Bars Sharif From Election
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A high court on Monday barred the leader of the junior partner in the government, Nawaz Sharif, from running for Parliament in a by-election later this week, a decision that is bound to intensify the hostilities within the fractious ruling coalition.

headline: The Cycle of Life, Damaged by the Horror of War
text: Three scalding monologues make up Judith Thompson’s “Palace of the End” at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, and three pitch-perfect performers deliver them. Which, a couple of years ago, would have made for courageous, electrifying theater, since Ms. Thompson’s subject is the travesties associated with the war in Iraq.

headline: New York Students Improve in Reading and Math
text: Reading and math scores for New York students in grades three through eight improved significantly across the state this year, with particularly sizeable gains in the large urban areas, including New York City.

headline: Pitcher’s Singular Slam Buries Mets
text: Johan Santana’s strategy was to throw Félix Hernández a high fastball, a pitch that was purposely out of the strike zone and one that an inexperienced hitter would chase. Hernández had not batted this season, and had one career hit. With the bases loaded, what chance did he have?

headline: Reading and Math Scores Rise Sharply Across N.Y.
text: Reading and math scores for New York students in grades three through eight showed extraordinary gains across the state since last year, with particularly striking leaps in the large urban areas, including New York City.

headline: Bunge to Acquire Corn Products for $4.4 Billion
text: The fertilizer and oilseed processor Bunge said on Monday that it would buy Corn Products International for $4.4 billion in stock, seeking to better compete against other American agricultural giants.

headline: Two Businessmen Are Charged in Sale of Military Parts to Iran
text: WASHINGTON  Two American businessmen were charged Monday with selling military parts to Iran to help prop up its aging air fleet, the latest in a string of cases that American prosecutors say violate longstanding bans on exports to Tehran.

headline: Worldwide Wonders (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making a Case for Partnership Pay
text: It only seems fair on the face of it. If your income  let’s face it, your financial survival  is not guaranteed as an owner of a small business, shouldn’t your employees take some of the risk in return for sharing in your success?

headline: Caught in the Middle
text: The article “In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds” is the latest installment in the “Generation Faithful” series, and The Majlis is a site within The Lede blog where reporters, experts and readers can discuss the points raised about the Middle East and its youth.

headline: The High-Tech Job Capital Is…The Big Apple?
text: UPDATED 9:18 a.m.| Added link to AeA report

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 66 New Mexico
text: Location: Albuquerque.

headline: Is This It for Imus?
text: Don Imus has managed to do the impossible — make Pacman Jones a sympathetic figure.

headline: Crossroads in Jordan
text: A look at apartments in the Abdoun district of West Amman, Jordan.

headline: Gothic Views in Ireland
text: Photos of a four-bedroom restored Victorian Gothic country house in County Cork.

headline: Excerpt From ‘Worried Sick’
text: Do you know when you want to die?

headline: $1 Million Homes
text: Properties on the market in Florida, Minnesota and Washington.

headline: S. Korea Court Clears Lone Star of Stock Manipulation
text: A South Korean high court on Tuesday cleared U.S. private equity house Lone Star of manipulating the stock price of a former credit card unit of Korea Exchange Bank, rejecting an earlier ruling.

headline: NYSE Eurnonext Takes 25% Stake in Doha Exchange
text: Trans-Atlantic stock market operator NYSE Euronext said it would buy a 25 percent stake in the Doha Securities Market for $250 million, boosting its access to the fast-growing Middle East economy.

headline: Seinfeld on Carlin
text: In a tribute to George Carlin on today’s Op-Ed Page, Jerry Seinfeld recalls the bane of his generation of comedians — “Carlin already did it”:

headline: Ex-Broadcom Executive Pleads Guilty to Lying to Investigators
text: Technology billionaire and philanthropist Henry Samueli pleaded guilty Monday to a felony charge of lying to regulators about his role in an alleged plot to secretly reward his Broadcom employees by manipulating stock options.

headline: Judge Dismisses Some A.I.G. Claims In Starr Battle
text: A judge has dismissed several claims made by American International Group in its three-year battle to regain control of a block of its shares held by an investment fund once used mainly to compensate A.I.G. executives.

headline: A One-Time Tax Break Saved 843 U.S. Corporations $265 Billion
text: American corporations reaped a $265 billion windfall thanks to a one-time tax break aimed at bringing home profits stashed overseas, according to recent government data.

headline: In Europe, Registry for Lobbyists Is Greeted Coolly
text: The European Commission on Monday opened its voluntary registry for the thousands of lobbyists and special interest organizations operating in Brussels, aiming to shed more light on a group that seeks to influence regulations on everything from computer software to greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Del Monte Sells StarKist Unit to S. Korean Company
text: The food company Dongwon said on Tuesday that it would buy the canned tuna company StarKist from the Del Monte Foods Company for about $300 million in the latest push by South Korean food makers for global expansion.

headline: Nokia Dials Up Deal for Britain’s Symbian
text: Nokia, the world’s biggest maker of mobile phones, offered to buy the 52 percent of Symbian that it doesn’t own for about 264 million euros ($410 million) to gain control in the maker of operating systems for handsets.

headline: AGA Medical Seeks $200 Million in I.P.O.
text: AGA Medical has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of stock to raise up to $200 million.

headline: Hilfiger Puts I.P.O. Plans Back in the Closet
text: Tommy Hilfiger has taken its plans for a possible initial public offering off the table, and instead plans to focus on expansion after turning around its U.S. business.

headline: IAC Moves Ahead With Ticketmaster Spin-Off
text: Ticketmaster is expected to be spun off from IAC/InterActiveCorp by late July or early August and will borrow $750 million to pay a dividend to its former parent, IAC Chief Financial Officer Tom McInerney said Monday.

headline: McCain Proposes a $300 Million Prize for a Next-Generation Car Battery
text: In the 18th century the British offered a 20,000 pound prize to anyone who figured out how to calculate longitude. More recently, Netflix offered a million dollars for improving movie recommendations on its Web site. Now Senator John McCain is suggesting a new national prize: He said Monday that if elected president he would offer $300 million to anyone who could build a better car battery.

headline: Carlyle Touts Results But Takes Cautious View of the Future
text: Based on the annual report it released on Monday, The Carlyle Group is preparing for a rougher year ahead.

headline: In Apollo Suit, Huntsman Takes a Page Out of Clear Channel’s Book
text: In his more than three decades on Wall Street, Leon D. Black has played many roles, including wunderkind investment banker and private equity mogul. On Monday, however, he assumed an altogether different one: defendant in a civil lawsuit.

headline: BG Goes Hostile With $13.1 Billion Bid for Australia’s Orgin
text: British gas producer BG Group launched a hostile $13.1 billion bid for Australia’s Origin Energy, as it seeks to boost its position in Asia-Pacific’s fast-growing gas market.

headline: Fisher Communications Rejects Unsolicited Bid
text: Fisher Communications shares rose 10.4 percent, to $35.17, on Monday after the company rejected an unsolicited offer to buy the television and radio station owner for about $384 million.

headline: The Bonfire of the Vanities, the Sequel
text: When the Blackstone Group went public about a year ago, Tom Wolfe, the author of “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” on hand on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange, delivered this prophecy: “We may be witnessing the end of capitalism as we know it.”

headline: Cookie Monster on ‘Colbert’
text: The Cookie Monster’s pushing fruit now. Is nothing sacred? From last Thursday’s show:

headline: New Rules Show Big Short Bets on Banks
text: Harbinger Capital Partners revealed that it has made a significant bet on HBOS‘s price falling, while British rival GLG admitted it is targeting the rival mortgage bank Bradford & Bingley, as investors were forced on Monday to disclose their short positions to the market for the first time.

headline: Analysts Voice Concern on Circuit City Bid
text: Shares of Circuit City Stores fell more than 18 percent on Monday after analysts voiced concerns about the electronic retailer’s ability to turn its business around and a potential takeover offer.

headline: Goldman Admits It Goofed on Upgrades
text: Goldman Sachs strategists urged stock investors on Monday to “underweight” U.S. financial and consumer shares, admitting it was wrong when it upgraded both sectors just seven weeks ago.

headline: Youth Exposure to Alcohol Marketing Still Too High, Study Says
text: What is planned to be the final report from a watchdog group that monitors alcohol advertising concludes that progress still lags in curbing the access of young viewers to television commercials selling liquor, beer and wine.

headline: Hedge Funds Results Take a Beating in 2007
text: Hedge funds around the world became more cautious, reducing the amount of debt they took on to buy assets by the end of last year as returns took a beating from turmoil in global credit markets, according to a study released on Monday by Greenwich Associates.

headline: JPMorgan Poised to Receive Tax Break for Boston Move, Report Says
text: The Massachusetts Economic Assistance Coordinating Council, which oversees government incentives for development, is expected to give its approval to a $3.5 million tax break for banking behemoth JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday, The Boston Herald reported.

headline: Austin Ventures’ $50 Million Online Bet
text: Austin Ventures, a venture capital firm managing around $3 billion across nine funds, has invested $50 million to try and create a new media franchise called Atcor Holdings.

headline: Will More Bankers Take the Private Equity Plunge?
text: The many investment bankers from Citigroup and Goldman Sachs getting pink slips this week will be thrust into a job market already saturated with thousands of unemployed bankers. Where will they go, The Deal wonders?

headline: ‘Only Seven?’
text: More user-generated comedy (send via the comment link below):

headline: Yoono Adds $4 Million to V.C. Haul
text: Yoono, the social network browser plugin that relaunched in May, said that it has raised a $4 million extension to their Series A funding round led by AGF Private Equity. The company also announced that it has entered public beta.

headline: Auction to Break Bread With Buffett Kicks Off
text: Early bids are in for a charity lunch with billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Extra Hands and Missing Fingers
text: We all know that Photoshop is amazing, and that it’s used in just about every shred of commercial photography (ads, for example).

headline: SunTrust ‘Now Worth More Dead Than Alive,’ Analyst Says
text: The weather in Atlanta has reached the mid-90s in recent days, but that doesn’t compare to the heat that SunTrust Banks is feeling. The Atlanta-based bank’s stock has fallen nearly every day for weeks, and now Richard X. Bove, the ubiquitous bank analyst at Ladenburg Thalmann, has declared the firm “now worth more dead than alive.”

headline: Seal of Ridicule
text: Jon Stewart pokes fun at Barack Obama for four minutes Monday night, reminding the audience: “You’re allowed to laugh at him.”

headline: London Theater Journal: Time for a Ganja Break at ‘The Harder They Come’
text: “Fifteen minutes for a ganja break.” Thus was intermission signaled by a deep-voiced, dredlocked man with a head mike at the end of the first act of “The Harder They Come,” a stage adaptation of the film that launched a thousand spliffs in cult movie houses in the 1970s.

headline: Banks Said to Still Push for Bell Canada Changes
text: The Bell Canada buyout may have received a stay of execution from the Supreme Court of Canada, but the private equity deal remains far from done.

headline: A History of Wall Street Layoffs
text: Wall Street has seen its fair share of bloodletting over the years, but this latest round brought about by the credit crunch is shaping up to be one of the worst in recent memory.

headline: The Early Word: Terrorism and the Campaign
text: Expect the Obama campaign to continue hammering Charlie Black, the McCain senior adviser, today for comments he made in a Fortune Magazine article that another terrorist attack would be “a big advantage” for Senator John McCain in the election.

headline: What Bruno’s Retirement Means for New York
text: The decision by Joseph L. Bruno to retire after 32 years in the State Senate came as a surprise to the New York political establishment; Mr. Bruno, whose district is north of Albany, had been the leader of a Republican majority in the chamber since 1995, after he ousted the previous leader, Ralph J. Marino, in a coup.

headline: Full Speed Ahead for Nanotechnology?
text: Nanotechnology holds vast potential for producing energy efficient products and processes — from purifying water to making better solar cells. In my Business of Green column this week, I write about how the market for such products could be worth trillions of dollars in coming years.

headline: Imus Ambles Into Racial Territory, Again
text: Has Don Imus broken the promise that carried him back to the airwaves? Last December, this was his solemn vow:

headline: Stand-Up Guy
text: A stand-up comedian, not a movie star or a television dad: George Carlin “was unique among stand-ups of his era in remaining a top-drawing comedian for more than 40 years, with virtually no help from movies or TV sitcoms,” writes Richard Zoglin, the author of “Comedy on the Edge: How Stand-Up in the 1970s Changed America,” in Time magazine. Zoglin adds, “And he helped bring stand-up comedy to the very center of American culture. It has never left.”

headline: Hell freezes over
text: I agree with a lot of what this WSJ editorial says. The difference, I think, is that they seem to believe that speculation is always good; I don’t, but I fail to see any evidence that speculation is the villain in this particular crisis.

headline: On HBO, a Second Round of Head Therapy
text: “In Treatment,” the HBO series about a psychotherapist and his sessions with patients, will return for a second season in 2009.

headline: In the Subway, the 3 New Yorks of E. B. White
text: There may be two Americas, but there are three New Yorks (roughly). Or so claims E. B. White, excerpts of whose 1948 essay, “Here is New York,” were introduced last month as part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s new Train of Thought literary campaign (which displaced the Poetry in Motion campaign, much to the dismay of poets).The selection, which is supposed to represent a slice of history, seems particularly meaningful on the subway, for Mr. White posits:

headline: ABC Game Show Contestants Will Wallow in Goo
text: If you’ve turned on ABC any time in the past month, you’ve no doubt seen the commercials for “Wipeout.”

headline: Iron resolution
text: Chinese steelmakers have agreed to a 96 percent increase in the price they pay for Australian iron ore.

headline: Olympic Lottery: All You Need Is a Yuan and a Dream
text: To help celebrate — not to mention cash in on — the start of the Olympic Games, China recently released a series of Olympic-themed lottery scratch cards, The Beijinger reports.

headline: Reaction to Bruno’s Retirement
text: Within minutes of Joseph L. Bruno‘s surprise announcement on Monday evening that he would retire after 32 years in the State Senate, and nearly 13 years as the leader of the Republican majority in the chamber, reactions from politicians and other public figures began pouring in — much of it laudatory but some of it critical. Below is a sampling of the many statements that have been issued about Mr. Bruno’s decision, which could affect the balance of power in Albany for years to come.

headline: ‘Golden Boy’ Hurdle Returns to K.C.
text: Once upon a time, Colorado Rockies Manager Clint Hurdle was a Kansas City Royals prospect who seemed destined for stardom. Selected ninth overall in the 1975 draft the first baseman was dubbed “This Year’s Phenom” on the March 20, 1978 cover of Sports Illustrated.

headline: Trailer: Guitar Hero Aerosmith
text: A trailer for Guitar Hero Aerosmith.

text: CNBC interviews Andrew Liveris, chief executive of Dow Chemical, on the company's plans to increase prices and institute freight charges.

headline: Bruno: ‘It’s Bittersweet, It’s Sad and It’s Happy’
text: Updated, 11:40 a.m. | Joseph L. Bruno, New York State’s top Republican official, choked back tears at an emotional news conference Tuesday morning about his decision to retire from the State Senate and from his position as the majority leader.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Grilled Pork Escabeche
text: This technique, usually called escabeche, was once used to preserve food. It is really a form of pickling. It’s a great way to add flavor to meat, and one that can easily be tinkered with.

headline: Teammates for the Étape?
text: 12 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: a day off after four days of climbing Alps. I’m contemplating a round of golf, but given that almost every step you take in this part of the world is either up or down, just sitting around on some level ground might be the best way to begin my recovery.

headline: Alltel’s Deals That Might Have Been
text: Alltel may be the subject of two successive takeovers over the past year, including its recent sale to Verizon Wireless for $28 billion. But before those, the nation’s fifth-largest cellphone service provider sought to strike a few other deals — with itself as the buyer.

headline: Iraq Briefing
text: A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog’s Google Reader Shared Items.

headline: Using Technology to Bring Politics Out of the Darkness
text: The political world is a picture with a lot of chiaroscuro. Some elements are illuminated with very bright lights. Others are shrouded in shadows.

text: At the top of this morning’s MSN, one of the most popular Web sites in the world, seven words you can never say two days after George Carlin’s death was widely reported:

headline: Obama Camp Hits McCain Aide Over Terrorism Remark
text: On a conference call organized by the Obama campaign this morning, Richard Ben-Veniste, a member of the Sept. 11 Commission, stopped short of calling for the resignation of Charlie Black, a McCain campaign senior adviser, but accused him of politicizing terrorism.

headline: Six Questions to Find Ovarian Cancer Early
text: A few simple questions may help women identify the early, often quiet, symptoms of ovarian cancer.

headline: For the Moment | Kim Jones
text: Kim Jones

headline: Manuel and the Mets’ Disappearing Offense
text: Mets Manager Jerry Manuel is not shy about expressing his disappointment with the team’s offense. Manuel discussed it before and after a 5-2 loss to the lowly Seattle Mariners on Monday night in which the Mets managed just four hits.

headline: In Tomorrow’s Dining Section
text: At last it’s summer, the season when a young blogger’s fancy lightly turns to thoughts of piña coladas, root beer and lemon verbena tea served by waitresses in English maid outfits. Yes, it’s time for the Dining section’s annual summer drinks issue.

headline: New McCain Ad Uses Obama’s Words
text: The McCain campaign obviously didn’t miss the scathing criticisms written by editorial writers and campaign reform advocates about Senator Barack Obama’s decision last week to eschew the $84 million in public financing for the general cycle.

headline: The Morning Skate: Melrose, Analog Coach in a Digital World?, and Sweet Dreams for Sundin
text: Melrose meets the press in Tampa Bay earlier today.
