headline: Housing Prices Rally?
text: I am a contrarian by nature. These days that requires me to look for good economic news. And there is some of that in the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller house price indexes released today.

headline: And Now a Brief Word From Bill Clinton…
text: In a terse one-sentence statement today, former President Clinton tried to erase any doubt that he supports Senator Barack Obama as the Democratic nominee.

headline: ‘Know What They’re Bickering About Now?’
text: Aired Monday night on CBS: You know what the big problem now is in Central Park? Snapping turtles. Apparently, we’ve got an epidemic of snapping turtles, and they’re brazen, ladies and gentlemen. Be very careful — I saw one today trying to mate with a bike helmet.

headline: A Stroll With a Papal Pedigree: Happy Birthday Via Giulia
text: When Romans want to fare una passeggiata (take a stroll), they inexplicably tend to head to the Via del Corso, Rome’s soulless main shopping street. But you can see Zara and Rolex stores (not to mention McDonald’s) in any city.

headline: XM, Sirius Closer to Merging. What Now?
text: When does a merger mean more choice for consumers? When it’s a satellite radio merger — at least according to XM and Sirius, which have been trying to finalize their merger plans for more than a year. Now, indications are that the deal may be consummated this summer.

headline: Lingua What-a?
text: Language | English-language restroom sign in China: “If you are stolen, call the police at once. Please omnivorously put the waste in garbage can.” Bad English? Or evidence that, thanks to globalization, English is “happily leading an alternative lifestyle without us”? — Wired

headline: Pelosi: Clinton Did Face Sexism
text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said today that she believed sexism against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was a factor in the 2008 Democratic primary fight, but added that the Democratic presidential candidate also benefited from being a woman.

headline:
Waiting for the Olympics:
What’s Ready, What’s Not
text: Took a tour of the Olympic Green the other day. It’s about eight times the size of London’s Hyde Park and contains half the venues for the Beijing Games.

headline: ‘Cowboy’
text: Lexicon | A Texas rancher’s son says it’s time to rehabilitate “cowboy,” a word “thrown around as a pejorative, hijacked by pundits and politicians to refer to arrogant, reckless types who go it alone.” Now, just who could they be talking about? — Texas Monthly

headline: Words You Can’t Say on This Blog
text: Bloomsbury has just published “Dirty Words: A Literary Encyclopedia of Sex,” edited by Ellen Sussman. We can’t mention quite a few of the subjects discussed (or even show you the cover), but there are plenty we can. The book features more than 90 writers, including Stephen McCauley on “anal sex,” Bliss Broyard on “one-night stand,” Phillip Lopate on “duration” and Danielle Trussoni on “striptease.”

headline: Various notes on speculation
text: First, Friedrich von Schiller was right.

headline: The Starting Line: China’s Projected Medal Count — a Suspiciously Lucky 88
text: [Also today: Brazil’s female footballers lose their captain; an armed robbery haunts Russia’s tennis team; Denmark’s top triathlete is wary of the Beijing smog; and a special sturgeon dies in Hong Kong.]

headline: Jokes vs. Communism
text: Humor | “Q: What is the difference between communism and capitalism?” “A: Capitalism is the exploitation of man by man; communism is the exact opposite.” In the old Soviet Union, little jokes like that had meaning in a system regarded as one big, cruel joke, according to a new book, “Hammer & Tickle.” — Telegraph of London

headline: Monday Night Was a Dead Heat for Viewers
text: In a low-rated Monday night of network television filled with mostly summer repeats and reality fare, CBS, ABC, and Fox finished in a virtual dead heat for first place in the ratings during prime time.

headline: Guillen and Pinella, Budding Hip-Hop Stars
text: We’ve already written about terrible/hilarious local baseball advertisements, so we felt the need to bring this Chicago gem to your attention.

headline: What to Expect From the Fed
text: CNBC interviews Robert Parry and Lyle Gramley, both former Fed officials, on expectations for Wednesday's FOMC meeting.

headline: Rethinking Life in the Distant Suburbs
text: For many, life in the outer suburbs has become an ordeal, not only from the long commuting times, but also from the huge run-up in the price of gas.

headline: Thailand Tourism and the Myanmar Cyclone
text: My wife and I are looking to travel to Thailand (Bangkok, Chiang Mai, and Ko Chang) at the end of August. While we are aware that it will be hot and possibly rainy, what about ill effects of the recent nearby cyclone? Should this be cause for concern?

headline: Welcome Back, Clinton
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton emerged today to claim her well-paid, perk-laden consolation prize — a return to the United States Senate, a place she has barely seen for the last 16 months.

headline: Audit Says Buildings Dept. Failed to Fix Hazards
text: The city’s Department of Buildings, which has already been the object of intense scrutiny over fatal construction accidents and accusations of corruption, is facing more criticism. On Tuesday, City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. released an audit finding that the department has repeatedly failed to make sure that hazardous conditions were fixed.

headline: False Alarm: Microsoft Is NOT in Talks with Yahoo Again
text: Yahoo ‘s shares surged Tuesday afternoon after TechCrunch reported that Microsoft is back in talks to buy the company. Yahoo’s stock was up more than 2 percent on the news.

headline: Pumped Up | The Rise of Shoetube.tv
text: Shoetube.tv walks the line between gonzo television and footwear fetishism.

headline: Global property industry can find good news in wealth report
text: For suffering members of the global second- and vacation-home industry desperately looking for a kernel of good news, this is it: The number of millionaires and billionaires around the world continues to grow at a brisk rate.

headline: McCain and the Internets
text: John McCain is having a town hall meeting tonight. Nothing necessarily remarkable about that; he has them all the time.

headline: The Thinking Jester
text: Just over a week before his death, George Carlin granted a long interview to the magazine Psychology Today in which he discussed, among other things, his views on writing and his formative influences — including this bit:

headline: Downsized Turkey to Face Juggernaut Germany
text: Turkey has just 14 fit players — two of them goalkeepers — available for its semifinal match against Germany in the European Championship on Wednesday, leading the team’s coach to suggest that the third-string goalkeeper may start at center-forward.

headline: For Mike Myers, Et tu, Canada?
text: BRIEFS It’s been a tough few days for Mike Myers. His movie, “The Love Guru,” was skewered by this paper’s movie critic and many others late last week. Over the weekend, it bombed at the box office as well. And then the criticism grew even sharper, somehow, and closer to home. On Monday, a newspaper columnist in Canada, his birthplace, decided to disown Mr. Myers on behalf of the country. The article, “Mention Mike Myers and few of us smile anymore,” leads the most popular list on the National Post’s Web site.

headline: Cable Channels Enjoy Upfront Gains
text: As the cable channels that populate the television dial conclude their advance advertising sales, they have something to celebrate: they made much greater gains than the broadcast networks.

headline: On Practicing What You Preach
text: In the middle of thinking about, researching, and writing last week’s Minimalist column — how to eat less meat — I volunteered to cook for a dinner party of 10. My initial inclination was to make two huge salads — one with fennel and celery (a current favorite), the other . . . I don’t know, but it got vetoed by the Central Committee.

headline: Conservation Efforts Are Slipping
text: A few weeks ago, I pointed to data from MasterCard SpendingPulse that showed a sharp fall-off in gasoline purchases. Then after the Memorial Day weekend, I saw more evidence of price-induced conservation.

headline: ‘Why Don’t You Convert to Islam?’
text: The article “In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds,” written by Michael Slackman, is the latest installment in the “Generation Faithful” series. The Majlis is a site within The Lede blog where reporters, including Mr. Slackman, experts and readers can discuss the points raised about the Middle East and its youth.

headline: As the Wrench Turns
text: An excerpt from "Click and Clack's As the Wrench Turns," based on NPR's "Car Talk."

headline: Californians Object to McCain’s Drilling Plan
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -– The McCain campaign sometimes makes a virtue of Senator John McCain’s propensity for telling people not only what they want to hear, but also what they don’t. It certainly seemed like many of the people he met in California this week did not want to hear about his newfound support for off-shore drilling.

headline: Got a Fin?
text: When the new models arrive in showrooms this fall, 50 years will have passed since the apogee of the tailfin. Most automotive historians agree that the 1959 model year marked the extreme reach of the tailfin craze, which was born on the 1948 Cadillac as the fishtail.In a brief time, the tailfin became a symbol of the space age and an icon of prosperity — and excess. To mark the anniversary, the Antique Automobile Club of America Museum in Hershey, Pa., is offering the show “Fins: The Rise and Fall of the Tail Fin in American Automotive Design” through Oct. 12.

headline: The Joy of Sacks | Art Show at Kiosk
text: The plastic-bag artwork of the artist Jason Rosenberg.

headline: Unsafe Sex Remains Common Among New Yorkers
text: More than one-third — 36 percent — of New York City men who have sex with other men and have had five or more sex partners within the past year do not consistently use condoms. City officials said that statistic was one of the most troubling findings from a new report — titled “Are New Yorkers Having Safe Sex?” — that was released on Tuesday by the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

headline: You Probably Think This Note Is About You
text: The unknown subject of “You’re So Vain” responds to Carly Simon, from Pop Song Correspondences:

headline: Gas Tourism
text: Americans who live near Mexico are taking advantage of cheaper gasoline prices south of the border.

headline: Prosecuting War Crimes
text: It didn’t take much to set off the left-wing blogosphere. Just a sentence in the preface to a report last week by the Physicians for Human Rights on the long-term effects on former Guantanamo inmates of the torture they say they endured there, plus some new disclosures about the C.I.A.’s role in training interrogators at Guantanamo.

headline: A Look Back: Great Floods of ’93
text: As Iowans enter their post-flood phase — they are currently deciding what to do with millions of wet, bacteria-laden sandbags — Missourians faced another failed levee today and possibly a month-long wait for the Mississippi River to drop below flood stage.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, June 24:

headline: Wimbledon — Day Two
text: The tennis went to form on the second day of Wimbledon in spite of an upset that really was not surprising.

headline: Networking Strategy: Walking and Talking
text: I am always looking for good ways to develop and nurture my network. My friend Sarah Milstein, the business manager for the blog Boing Boing, has started something she calls the “urban hike.” I like the idea so much that I will likely start something similar on my own. I asked her to do a guest post about it, and her post will be the first in a series on innovative networking strategies. And now, I give you Sarah. – Marci

headline: New Safety Policy for Construction Cranes
text: During Congressional testimony in Washington, the acting commissioner of the city’s Department of Buildings, Robert D. LiMandri, announced an overhaul of crane safety policies in response to two fatal crane accidents in New York City. The May 30 accident raised questions about the buildings department’s ability to properly track damaged and repaired parts.

headline: Tourist Trophy: The Most Dangerous Show on Two Wheels
text: In Monday’s World section was this wonderful article by John Burns on the Tourist Trophy races on the Isle of Man. These motorcycle races occur on public roads. Last year, an English rider set the lap speed record, averaging over 130 miles an hour over the 37 3/4-mile circuit:

headline: Making of Guitar Hero: Aerosmith
text: Members of Aerosmith discuss their participation in the making of the latest version of Guitar Hero.

headline: D.N.C. Sues McCain Over Campaign Loan
text: Updated The Democratic National Committee filed suit today in U.S. District Court in Washington challenging Senator John McCain’s decision to opt out of the federal public financing system in his primary race.

headline: Remembering the Travel Scandal at the Port Authority
text: So the E-ZPass is even easier than anyone thought — good for a lifetime and free, as long as you are, or ever were, a board member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. But if you’re shocked — shocked! — at that perk (which an embarrassed authority is expected to revoke on Wednesday for former members and restrict to official business along with free transit and commuter rail passes), consider for a moment the freebie-travel scandal that shamed the agency’s more imperious cousin, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, some 30 years ago.

headline: As Time Expires, Memories of the Austin Ice Bats
text: As Michael Brick reports in The Times, the Austin Ice Bats of the Central Hockey League, formerly of the Western Professional Hockey League, are almost certainly dead and buried. If they do indeed pass into the icy great beyond, they will be yet another minor league team among the hundreds to have come and gone over the years. (Here is the list of defunct hockey leagues, never mind teams.)

headline: ‘Human Tetris’ Becomes ‘Hole In The Wall’
text: The most popular of the Japanese game shows on YouTube is a stunt called “Human Tetris.” It comes from Fuji TV’s “Tunnels No Minnasan No Okage Deshita,” or “Tunnels Thanks to Everybody.”

headline: ‘I Survived…’ A Life-Size Arcade Game and A Milk Jug Race?
text: “I Survived a Japanese Game Show” premieres tonight on ABC. What’s so hard about a Japanese game show, you ask?

headline: The Four-Part Monologue You Can Repeat on Television
text: As TV Decoder noted yesterday, George Carlin hosted the inaugural edition of “Saturday Night Live” in 1975. This weekend the late-night landmark will pay tribute to the comedian, who died Sunday, by broadcasting that premiere episode.

headline: Charter Suspends Plan to Sell Customer Data to Advertisers
text: Charter Communications, the big cable company, said Tuesday that it is suspending its plan to sell data about its customers’ Web surfing to an advertising company.

headline: A Safer, and Brighter, School Design
text: [There’s a lot of interest in climate right now, but other predicted risks still loom, as well, so back we go to earthquakes.] Some of you may recall the image above, which I included with a recent post on efforts to make schools less likely to fall down in earthquakes like the one that shattered so many communities in China’s Sichuan province. It is the product of research by Santiago Pujol, a structural engineer at Purdue who is focused on cutting losses from predicted earthquakes, particularly in schools. After a question from a Dot Earth reader, Dr. Pujol drew a more brightly lit variant, which you can see below.

headline: McCain Camp Calls Obama ‘Dr. No’ of Energy Security
text: As Senators Barack Obama and John McCain pushed their competing energy plans at campaign events today, advisers to Mr. McCain opened up a few new lines of attack on the presumptive Democratic nominee – one of them cinematic.

headline: Nothing Says Capitalist Pig …
text: … quite like the bacon briefcase:

headline: ‘A New Type of Battery’
text: Aired Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: John McCain says that if elected president, he will give a $300 million prize to anyone who can design a new car battery. McCain can get a new type of battery invented because he’s the guy that came up with the idea of not cranking the car up at the start.

headline: More Answers From Iraqi Teens
text: Video

headline:
Second Thoughts on Pinot,
All Good
text: In my recent post  on the Eyrie Vineyards  I complained that too many American pinot noirs are no longer versatile enough to serve as bridge wines, as they are too big and often too sweet to go with more delicate foods. Naturally, I hedged by saying exceptions abound, and of course they do. So I thought I would talk about some of the other American pinot noirs that I enjoy and that I think still strive for the classic pinot noir characteristics of finesse and elegance.

headline: George Carlin on ‘Larry King Live’
text: In a 2001 interview (with video clips) to promote his book “Napalm & Silly Putty,” the comedian looks back on his career:

headline: Lehman Keeps Reshuffling Its Deck
text: The investment bank announced four new executive postings Tuesday, as it continues to try to convince the markets that things are looking up.

headline: McCain’s Misguided Strategy?
text: As the 2008 general election heats up, one of John McCain’s strongest political advantages is his opponent Barack Obama’s lack of political experience. No surprise there: when Mr. McCain began his political career, Mr. Obama was still a college student.

headline: A Picasso Muse Wants to Protect Pei Towers
text: The Landmark Preservation Commission had a hearing Tuesday to determine whether Silver Towers/University Village, a concrete complex designed by I. M. Pei in 1966 as part of a Robert Moses urban renewal program, should be designated a historic landmark.

headline: MSNBC's Campaign Edition
text: Reporters from The New York Times discuss the latest campaign news on MSNBC.

headline: Introducing TimesPeople Beta
text: The newly launched TimesPeople Beta is where The New York Times meets the social Web — think of it as all the news that’s fit to share. But it’s not a Timesian Facebook or MySpace: there’s no fretting over “friends” to accept or reject, no navigation of the foggy realm of online etiquette. Instead, you can choose the TimesPeople members whose activity you’d like to follow: the content they recommend, the comments and reviews they post, and the ratings they give to movies, restaurants and hotels. And those interested in your recommendations can see your activity too. It’s New York Times content brought to your fingertips (or rather, browser toolbar) by the readers you know.

headline: Speculation and Signatures
text: I’m trying to get my own thoughts on the oil stuff clear; so for the econowonks, a tiny theoretical paper for your enjoyment and/or detestation.

headline: Obama’s Detail Work
text: “If Obama becomes president, he will have spent more time serving as a state legislator (eight years) than anyone who has occupied the White House since Abraham Lincoln,” writes Alan Ehrenhalt, the executive editor of Governing magazine, in Newsweek. He later adds, “[F]or a smart, curious and hard-working young legislator — for a Barack Obama in the Illinois Senate — can we be so sure that the skill set picked up over eight years in a state Capitol is inferior as presidential preparation to two decades in the pompous, cordoned-off environment of the U.S. Senate? I seriously doubt it.” Ehrenhalt explains:

headline: Cute Teens + Catchy Songs = Another Hit Disney TV Movie
text: “Camp Rock,” Disney’s latest made-for-television musical, drew as many viewers as last year’s “High School Musical 2,” but only if you add up the audience numbers from three broadcasts and an evening of Internet viewing.

headline: Charlie Black, James Dobson, Scarlett Johansson
text: Barack Obama more or less shrugged off the comments of McCain chief strategist Charlie Black, who opined that a terrorist attack in the months before the election would be a “big advantage” to the McCain campaign.

headline: Oregon Republican Touts Work With Obama in New Ad
text: In special House elections in Mississippi and Louisiana earlier this year, Republicans tried to tie the Democrats to Senator Barack Obama, who at the time appeared increasingly likely to win the presidential nomination.

headline: On to Where There Are No Votes
text: Since he became the all-but-certain Republican nominee this year, Senator John McCain has traveled to Iraq, Jordan, Israel, Britain and France (on the taxpayer’s dime) and to Canada (on his campaign’s). Next week, Mr. McCain will travel to two more places without Electoral College votes: Colombia and Mexico.

headline: The Inner Obama
text: Here is something you might not know about Senator Barack Obama: His musical tastes are pretty mainstream. His reading list is, well, a little dark.

headline: A Brew Everyone Can Love
text: Hey, it’s summer. Do you know what time it is? Well, counterintuitively for The Pour, which covers wine, beer and spirits, it’s root beer time!

headline: Obama Asks Funders to Relieve Clinton’s Debt
text: Senator Barack Obama asked his leading fund-raisers in a conference call today to lend a hand to retire the campaign debt of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Catch and Release
text: I found a new song swimming around in my head yesterday afternoon. I’ve landed it and will prepare it before you. I’ve fished these parts for years, and I know that once I identify what’s on the end of my line, we can proceed.

headline: Bar Nibbles, Promoted to Dinner
text: THERE may not be any dish I’ve enjoyed more in recent months than the pork blade steak at Terroir.

headline: Domino Sugar Is Gone, but Sign Will Live On After Ruling
text: The Domino Sugar sign that announced the mill on the East River in Brooklyn for generations will be displayed atop new apartments being built at the site under a plan approved on Tuesday by the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission.

headline: Top Engineers Shun Military; Concern Grows
text: When Paul G. Kaminski completed his graduate work in 1971 with degrees from M.I.T. and Stanford, he started building advanced airplanes for the Air Force. By the time he stopped several decades later, he had played a pivotal role in producing a flock of new weapons, including radar-evading stealth aircraft.

headline: Strahan’s Sundays Will Never Be the Same on Fox
text: Michael Strahan was in the midst of being introduced as the newest pundit on Fox’s “NFL Sunday” on Tuesday when a television show broke out.

headline: Coldplay Changes, and Stays the Same
text: Here’s an adjective not commonly associated with the British whine-rock specialists Coldplay: bruising. Here’s another: swaggering. And finally a third: surprising.

headline: 4 Worthy Survivors in Euro 2008 Battle
text: In a world that frequently disappoints, there is something refreshing about a sports tournament with four deserving semifinalists of seething ambition. I am referring to the soccer championship, Euro 2008, very much a fixture in the United States, via good old ESPN (and its marvelous addition, the Scottish ex-player with the burr and the enthusiasm, Andy Gray).

headline: Uncertainty Adds to Burden Along the River
text: WINFIELD, Mo.  The only door still inside Karl and Carol Broseman’s home is the most essential: the one to the bathroom. The rest, all nine, have been removed and stowed in a friend’s barn for safekeeping, along with the stove, the kitchen cabinets, the carpeting and a king-size water bed.

headline: Correction
text: A brief report in the Off the Menu column on May 7 about the opening of South Brooklyn Pizza misspelled the surname of its owner. He is Jim McGown, not McGowan.

headline: High Medicare Costs, Courtesy of Congress
text: On Wal-Mart’s Web site, you can buy a walker for $59.92. It is called the Carex Explorer, and it’s a typical walker: a few feet high, with four metal poles extending to the ground. The Explorer is one of the walkers covered by Medicare.

headline: Difficulty of Work Blamed for Delays Replacing Park Space Lost to Yankee Stadium
text: A parks department official, called before the City Council to explain why an effort to replace recreation space lost to construction of the new Yankee Stadium has been plagued by delays and cost overruns, said on Tuesday that the department’s inexperience with such complex projects was partly to blame.

headline: In Baltimore, Mayor Tells of Her Link to Developer
text: BALTIMORE  Mayor Sheila Dixon, whose home was raided last week in a state investigation into city spending practices, acknowledged on Monday that she had been in a “personal relationship” with a prominent developer who prosecutors say gave her gifts, went on trips with her and benefited from tax breaks and zoning changes she supported as City Council president.

headline: Florida to Buy Sugar Maker in Bid to Restore Everglades
text: LOXAHATCHEE, Fla.  The dream of a restored Everglades, with water flowing from Lake Okeechobee to Florida Bay, moved a giant step closer to reality on Tuesday when the nation’s largest sugarcane producer agreed to sell all of its assets to the state and go out of business.

headline: Brazil’s Loss Could Be a Boost for the U.S.
text: The United States women’s Olympic soccer team received what may be a boost to its medal hopes on Monday, the day its roster was announced: the captain of its archrival, Brazil, announced she would not play in the Beijing Games because of an injury.

headline: Uncomfortable in His Skin, Thriving in His Mind
text: Albert Camus was one of the two pillars of postwar French literature. The other was Jean-Paul Sartre, his comrade in letters if not quite in arms (during the Resistance, Camus dangerously put out a clandestine newspaper, while Sartre stayed safely studying and writing). Then in the early 1950s, they bitterly split.

headline: Praise for a Restoration
text: Expanding its drive to preserve Modernist landmarks, the World Monuments Fund has awarded a prize to two German architects who restored a Bauhaus-era school, above, for the German trade union confederation. Winfried Brenne and Franz Jaschke, both of Berlin, are the first recipients of the Knoll Modernism Prize, established to recognize architects and designers who rejuvenate Modern structures. The pair re-exposed elements of the 1928-30 ADGB Trade Union School in Bernau, Germany, that were hidden or removed during the East German era, like glass brick, stainless steel and the original bright red color of the steel framing. The jury was led by Barry Bergdoll, chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, and included the architectural historians Kenneth Frampton, Jean-Louis Cohen and Dietrich Neumann. The prize consists of a $10,000 honorarium and a limited-edition chair made by Knoll.

headline: Croque-Monsieur, a Perfect Companion for Drinks
text: MY only criterion for a summer drink is that it go well with summer food. Years ago  O.K., decades  my friend Philip and I were in the drinking-till-dawn business, otherwise known as suburban summer theater.

headline: Germany, Turkey and Jumbled Loyalties
text: BERLIN  A game is not just a game when it pits the national soccer teams of the deeply intertwined countries of Germany and Turkey against each other.

headline: Hidden Sex Scenes Draw Ho-Hum, Except From Lawyers
text: Lawyers who sued the makers of the video game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas profess to be shocked, simply shocked, that few people who bought the game were offended by sex scenes buried in its software.

headline: After Philippine Ferry Wreck, Many Bodies and Few Survivors
text: MANILA  What Rodel Laborte could not forget was the screaming of fellow passengers. As the strong waves and wind tossed around the 24,000-ton ferry  “like a paper boat,” he said  pandemonium broke out. The shrieks got so loud, he said, he could not determine if the captain had given an order to abandon the ship.

headline: 28-Year-Old Completes His Quest to Reach the Majors
text: PITTSBURGH  People always told Justin Christian that if he produced for his college baseball teams, he would be drafted into the pros. He wandered through programs in California and Alabama before earning all-America honors at Southeast Missouri State in 2003.

headline: Rockets Hit Israel, Breaking Hamas Truce
text: JERUSALEM  Three Qassam rockets fired from Gaza on Tuesday struck the Israeli border town of Sderot and its environs, causing no serious injuries but constituting the first serious breach of a five-day-old truce between Israel and Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza.

headline: New Jersey Dealing With Solar Policy’s Success
text: With oil prices skyrocketing, demand for solar power is booming. And New Jersey, which has used a rebate program to help install more solar panels than any other state but California, is getting burned by its own success.

headline: When Small Businesses Lose to Big Companies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Missionary’s Downfall
text: Adapted from Forbidden Island, Alameda, Calif.

headline: More Sopranos
text: For fans of “The Sopranos” who can’t get enough, HBO Video is releasing “The Sopranos: The Complete Series” on Nov. 11. The limited-edition DVD set  weighing in at 10 pounds  will cost $399.99. The 30-disc collection includes an interview between Alec Baldwin and the show’s creator, David Chase; a roundtable with cast members titled “Supper With the Sopranos”; and 16 scenes that did not appear on television. Also included are three soundtracks.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,097 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: The Mets Knuckle Under Early in a Rout at Home
text: It was frustrating for the Mets when Luis Castillo’s weary legs and faulty throwing arm allowed two runs to score in the second inning. And it irked them even more when Oliver Pérez’s maddening inconsistency cost them another two runs in the third. So by the time the Mets’ fourth inning rolled around, and they trailed by five runs against the Seattle Mariners, the team with the worst record in baseball, it did not take much to set tempers ablaze.

headline: Deal to Build Waste Station in Manhattan
text: ALBANY  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the State Legislature reached an agreement late Tuesday to build a waste-transfer station in Manhattan, allowing a major piece of the mayor’s environmental agenda to move forward.

headline: Obama Assails Remarks by McCain on Offshore Oil Drilling
text: LAS VEGAS  Senator Barack Obama took a poke at his Republican opponent on Tuesday, saying that for Senator John McCain to talk of a “psychological benefit” from expanded offshore drilling is to define that policy as a gimmick.

headline: A Fresh Take on a 19th-Century Gingerbread Village
text: TOMSK, Russia  The building at 32 Kartashov Street had had enough. It once served as home to a 19th-century merchant, a little log masterpiece with ornate doors and shutters carved like doilies and a structural swagger that said, “Look at me!”

headline: Life and Death, No Fiction Needed
text: Dr. Alfredo Quiñones-Hinojosa, a brain surgeon at Johns Hopkins Hospital, walks the halls as if he owns the place, but no one can accuse him of forgetting his roots.

headline: Report Sees Illegal Hiring Practices at Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON -- Justice Department officials over the last six years illegally used “political or ideological” factors to hire new lawyers into an elite recruitment program, tapping law school graduates with conservative credentials over those with liberal-sounding resumes, a new report found Tuesday.

headline: New Festival Will Urge Orchestras to Be Bold
text: It, or something similar, was probably inevitable. With the huge success of City Center’s Fall for Dance festival over the last four years, it was only a matter of time before someone would decide to spring for something.

headline: Director at Spoleto Is to Retire Next Year
text: Charles Wadsworth, the director of Spoleto Festival USA’s chamber music series for more than 30 years, has announced that he will retire in 2009, ArtsJournal reported. Mr. Wadsworth, who turns 80 this year, has organized music for the festival for 50 consecutive seasons, beginning with Gian Carlo Menotti’s Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy. “We will miss Charles and look forward to celebrating his birthday and his tremendous artistic contributions,” said Paula Edwards, a spokeswoman for the American festival.

headline: New Allegations Revive an Italian Mystery of the 1980s
text: ROME  On June 22, 1983, Emanuela Orlandi, 15, was walking home in central Rome from a music lesson when she vanished.

headline: Bipartisan Group to Speak Out on Detainees
text: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of 200 former government officials, retired generals and religious leaders plans to issue a statement on Wednesday calling for a presidential order to outlaw some interrogation and detention practices used by the Bush administration over the last six years.

headline: In Cairo or Queens, It’s Fate
text: To the Editor:

headline: There’s Lots of Rough at Women’s Open, but the Greens Get Most of the Attention
text: EDINA, Minn.  The 16th green at Interlachen Country Club is typical of this Donald Ross-designed course  pitched toward the fairway and as slick as linoleum.

headline: Congo: Former Warlord’s Trial Halted
text: Lawyers at the International Criminal Court in The Hague fought over the possible release of Thomas Lubanga, a former warlord in Congo, whose trial on war crimes charges has been halted. Judges at the court warned last week that they might have to free Mr. Lubanga, who is charged with recruiting child soldiers during militia violence in 2002-3, because of errors by the prosecution involving the withholding of evidence. At the heart of the dispute is whether judges and defense lawyers will be allowed to evaluate about 200 confidential United Nations documents obtained by the prosecution. In an attempt to have the trial resumed, the United Nations legal office, which had refused to release the documents, sent a letter saying the three judges could privately read them under United Nations supervision but could not take notes. The judges said they would rule in the case next week.

headline: NYSE Buys 25% of Qatar Securities Market
text: LONDON  NYSE Euronext agreed on Tuesday to buy a 25 percent stake in the Qatar securities market, gaining a lead in the race against its British and German rivals to become a truly global stock exchange at a time when growth has slowed in their home markets.

headline: Boy George Denied U.S. Visa for Tour
text: Boy George, below, has canceled his American summer tour after being denied a visa by the United States because he is facing trial in London in the fall, his management said in a statement. He had been scheduled to show up in New York in August for the Department of Sanitation’s annual family day. (Boy George cleaned the streets for five days in 2006 as court-ordered community service after falsely reporting a break-in to his New York home. He wanted to give a concert for department workers.) The statement said that Boy George was “devastated” and that “George is astounded at the decision and is having lawyers here in the States look at it in the hope that someone will change their mind.” Boy George, whose real name is George O’Dowd, is facing trial in November on a charge of falsely imprisoning a man. The statement said, “George has not been convicted of anything in London, and there is a presumption in the Western world of innocence until proven guilty.”

headline: At 32, Davenport Still Has Enough to Survive on the Graveyard Court
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Lindsay Davenport’s welcome-back present at Wimbledon was a first-round match on the Graveyard, otherwise known as Court 2.

headline: Coldplay’s Strong Sales Buck Industry Trend
text: Near the beginning of Coldplay’s free concert at Madison Square Garden on Monday night to promote its new album, “Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends,” Chris Martin, the lead singer, joked with the crowd: “I understand there have been some complaints about the ticket price.” The roar of 11,500 fans suggested they were quite happy.

headline: America’s Next Chapter
text: Kittredge, Colo.

headline: Consumer Confidence Declines to a 16-Year Low
text: Consumer confidence dropped to its lowest point in 16 years in June while home values fell in 20 metropolitan areas across the country, according to two economic reports released Tuesday.

headline: Casting a Wider Net
text: Several leading lights of the Internet world believe that access to broadband is a civil right, like water, roads and sewage treatment, and have renewed their call for making such access a national priority. To further their goal, they have introduced a Web site, internetforeveryone.org.

headline: A Kingpin of State Politics Bids Adieu to a Stage He Relished
text: ALBANY  Like any good showman, Joseph L. Bruno knows how to leave his audience wanting more.

headline: Two Romeos in a Modern Tragedy
text: Those familiar with Manhattan gay culture may not find a lot of new ground in “Bash’d!,” billed as a “gay rap opera,” other than the novelty of a story recited entirely in verse and set to electronic rhythms and samples. Certainly not in the sexual explicitness of its lyrics, its nightclub argot or its star-crossed “Romeo and Romeo” narrative. But such an audience should be impressed by the passion of its convictions.

headline: Let It Be
text: We read the news today  actually a couple of days ago  that representatives of the Beatles are in talks to develop a Beatles-themed video game. The commercial logic is impeccable. Guitar Hero, a video game that allows you to play along with a rock band, has been a huge, unexpected hit, and a video game based on the Beatles would be a way to introduce their music to an audience whose parents had not yet been born when the band first came to America.

headline: Near Tie in Prime Time
text: In a low-rated Monday night of network television, filled mostly with summer repeats and reality fare, CBS, ABC and Fox finished in a virtual dead heat for first place in the prime-time ratings. CBS eked out a victory as the most-watched network, according to Nielsen’s estimates, earning the night’s top ratings at 9 with a rerun of “Two and a Half Men,” which attracted nine million viewers. CBS also led during the 10 o’clock hour with a repeat of “CSI: Miami” (8.2 million), which easily outpaced ABC’s struggling reality show “The Mole” (4.1 million). During the 8 and 9 o’clock hours, ABC’s two-hour installment of “The Bachelorette” averaged a competitive 7.5 million viewers, leading during both time slots among adults 18 to 49. ABC and CBS tied for first place for the night in that demographic, just slightly ahead of Fox, which broadcast repeats of “Bones” (6.4 million) at 8 and “House” (7.4 million) at 9. NBC was a distant fourth for the night, drawing 4.9 million viewers for “American Gladiators” at 8, followed by “Nashville Star” (6.1 million) from 9 to 11.

headline: Hot and Complicated: Thai in the Village
text: PORK on Fire. This contender for spiciest dish in the city should draw heat-seeking chowhounds to Rhong-Tiam, a restaurant that opened in Greenwich Village in March. But the timid shouldn’t be turned off: Rhong-Tiam also explores the complexities of Thai dishes that have nothing to do with heat.

headline: U.S. High Tech Said to Slip
text: The United States may be synonymous with the high-tech revolution, but it is in danger of losing its high-tech edge, according to Cybercities 2008, a report released Tuesday by AeA, a technology industry trade association.

headline: The More Things Change in Albany
text: Joseph Bruno, the powerful leader of the New York State Senate, surprised nearly everyone this week, announcing suddenly that he will not seek re-election. It is hard to know what that means for Mr. Bruno, who at age 79 is facing a federal investigation of his outside businesses, or for the Republican’s slim Senate majority. We hope that politicians in Albany  from both parties  will capitalize on this shift to finally clean up one of the most dysfunctional and expensive state governments in the country.

headline: Croque-Monsieur
text: Adapted from Bar Boulud

headline: House Votes to Block Cut in Doctors’ Medicare Fees
text: WASHINGTON  The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill to prevent a 10 percent cut in Medicare payments to doctors that was scheduled to take effect July 1.

headline: More Phony Myths
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Cartagena Limeade
text: Adapted from the Charleston Santa Teresa, Cartagena, Colombia

headline: Approval Is Near for Bill to Help U.S. Homeowners
text: WASHINGTON  With sinking home values continuing to drag down the economy, Congress is poised to approve a huge package of housing legislation, including a refinancing program aimed at rescuing hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure and the most sweeping government overhaul of mortgage financing since the New Deal.

headline: Churros at Home, Without the Deep-Fryer
text: Fresh, warm churros dusted with sugar are an irresistible treat on village plazas in Spain, near the zócalos of Mexican towns, and, increasingly, in restaurants like Pamplona and Bar Jamón in New York, and even in some subway stations here.

headline: Clinton Returns to the Warm Embrace of Her Day Job
text: WASHINGTON  If Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was seeking solace from the heartache of a bruising, losing campaign, she came to the right place on Tuesday.

headline: An Italian Red, for Hot-Weather Sipping
text: Think of summer wine and white and rosé come to mind. But in Milan this year, an unusual red wine, Anthos, has become popular. It is made from the brachetto grape of Piedmont, which is usually turned into a fairly sweet sparkling wine.

headline: A Musician Who Mixes and Matches
text: Herbie Hancock was in good form as a host at Carnegie Hall on Monday night: gregarious, generous, unassuming, charming. And as a pianist he produced moments of typically ingenious effervescence. His problems arose in other areas, like concept and organization. But those things are crucial, and so the concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, felt glib and undernourished. It should have been a lot better than it was.

headline: Showdown on South Street
text: A VISIT to the former Fulton Fish Market in Lower Manhattan on Sunday will be a little like watching a boxing match with a culinary twist.

headline: Add a Splash of Ad-Lib
text: HERE’S how I learned to make cocktails. Some years ago, I discovered mojitos, which I liked a lot, at least when they were made well. But they varied wildly when I ordered them in bars and restaurants. So I began tinkering at home and found my way: dark rum, a little simple syrup (half water, half sugar, heated until the sugar melts), loads of lime, not much mint. No club soda (a weakening aberration, even if it’s “correct”). No muddling (too much work, too showy, and I don’t even like the sound of the word). No white rum (unconventional, but I like rum with flavor).

headline: Rosenberg Case Materials Are Closer to Publication
text: The trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, that touchstone of atomic espionage, is a case that launched a thousand doctorates and enough historical texts to make a library groan. Now, however, the 50-year-old record may grow even more complex: on Monday, the federal government, in an unusual move, consented to release most of the secret grand jury testimony taken in the case.

headline: Keeping Things Artful While Picking Up the Tempo
text: For a few expectant moments on June 17, the four members of Sigur Ros stood in a corridor of the Museum of Modern Art, near the entrance of an Olafur Eliasson exhibition called “Take Your Time.” They were about to play a concert in the museum’s lobby, where hundreds of fans crowded before a makeshift stage. The show had sold out almost instantly, prompting much complaining (and some price gouging) online.

headline: Bid for Australian Energy Company Turns Hostile
text: PARIS  The BG Group, the British gas utility, took its $13 billion bid for Origin Energy, the Australian energy company, directly to shareholders on Tuesday, saying Origin was overplaying its hand by demanding a larger takeover offer.

headline: A Monet Sets a Record: $80.4 Million
text: LONDON  The summer auction season here began at Christie’s on Tuesday night when a standing-room-only crowd of dealers, collectors and art lovers came from all over the world to watch and bid on one of the largest London sales the auction house has held. Early in the evening a record price for a Monet, $80.4 million, was set for one of the rarest of his waterlilies.

headline: Walsh Ready for Backlash From Draft
text: Donnie Walsh will make his first Knicks draft pick on Thursday night, then brace himself for the inevitable backlash. Booing draft picks is, after all, a time-honored Madison Square Garden tradition.

headline: Evangelical Leader Attacks Obama on Religious Views
text: Just days after Senator Barack Obama met quietly with religious leaders, including the son of the Rev. Billy Graham, another of the evangelical movement’s most prominent names, James C. Dobson, has sharply attacked Mr. Obama, accusing him of having “a fruitcake interpretation of the Constitution” and twisting the meaning of both the Old and New Testaments.

headline: Service With a Wink to a Japanese Fad
text: Culver City, Calif.

headline: Truck Was Unsafe, Crash Inquiry Finds
text: The dump truck that crashed into a bus in Chinatown on Monday, killing one person and injuring four others, was not safe to drive, according to the authorities.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the hiring of a new director for the Dia Art Foundation, Philippe Vergne, the deputy director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, misstated the current title of a former Walker director whom Mr. Vergne was said to have been a candidate to replace when she resigned last year. The former director, Kathy Halbreich, is associate director of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, not an associate curator.

headline: He’ll Hold His Breath Until You Call Him a Man
text: Spending 80 minutes with Alby Cutrera (Matt McGrath), the insufferable protagonist of “Full Grown Men,” a serious road comedy about arrested development, is excruciating enough. But it is hard to imagine why any sane woman would actually marry and have a child with this unemployed 35-year-old cartoonist, who has the emotional maturity of a 10-year-old.

headline: In Overhaul, Disney.com Seeks a Path to More Fun
text: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company, concerned that its main Web site is not entertaining enough, is moving once again to overhaul Disney.com.

headline: Japanese Warship Visits Chinese Port
text: SHANGHAI  A Japanese destroyer docked at a heavily guarded naval base in Guangdong Province on Tuesday for a five-day port call, the first by a warship from Japan in China since World War II.

headline: Footnotes
text: The comedian George Carlin, who died on Sunday, will posthumously receive the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Reuters reported. Mr. Carlin was named the winner last week. ... The Golden Globe winner and Emmy Award nominee Dylan McDermott (“The Practice”) has joined the cast of Playwrights Horizons’ first production of 2008-9, “Three Changes.” The new play, by Nicky Silver, begins previews on Aug. 22. ... The Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center on Long Island celebrates its 10th-anniversary season with performances by Gilberto Gil, Kathleen Battle, Herbie Hancock, K. D. Lang, Pilobolus Dance Theater and New York City Opera (whbpac.org). ... Brian Wilson  is joining Jimmy Buffett, Trey Anastasio, the Black Crowes, and Stephen Marley and Damian Marley at the Newport Folk Festival in August. ... Smithsonian magazine has picked Sept. 27 for its Museum Day, when participating museums and cultural institutions around the country drop admission fees for the magazine’s readers and Smithsonian.com visitors who present a special admission card. ... Eleven fans of the 1990s sci-fi television series “Babylon 5” chipped in to buy a prosthetic mask worn by the actor Andreas Katsulas in his role as the exiled alien ambassador G’Kar. They bought it on eBay and then donated it to the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens. ... The Tony-nominated performance artist Justin Bond will perform his show “Lustre” at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side for four nights starting on Thursday (henrystreet.org/arts).

headline: South Korea Warns Against Further Beef Protests
text: SEOUL  President Lee Myung-bak, attempting to reassert his authority after weeks of demonstrations against his decision to resume imports of American beef, said Tuesday that his government would not tolerate further violent protests.

headline: Holding Back Young Students: Is Program a Gift or a Stigma?
text: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.  With the increasing emphasis on standardized testing over the past decade, large urban school systems have famously declared an end to so-called social promotion among youngsters lacking basic skills. Last year, New York flunked 6 percent of its first graders, and Chicago 7.7 percent.

headline: Housing Aid Bill Passes Senate Test
text: WASHINGTON  A bill aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure cleared an important test vote in the Senate on Tuesday, raising the prospects for final passage of an aid bill by mid-summer.

headline: Efforts to Slow Defense Industry’s Brain Drain
text: When Paul G. Kaminski completed his graduate work in 1971 with degrees from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford, he started building advanced airplanes for the Air Force. By the time he stopped several decades later, he had played a pivotal role in producing a flock of new weapons, including radar-evading stealth aircraft.

headline: Baghdad Blast Kills Four Americans
text: BAGHDAD  American soldiers and civilians had a surprise for the Sadr City District Council on Tuesday, and gathered in the office of its acting chairman to make the presentation just before the weekly meeting.

headline: The Station That Dared to Defend Carlin’s ‘7 Words’ Looks Back
text: As the encomiums for George Carlin have rolled in from stand-up legends, celebrities and scholars, his death at 71 has also been noted at a diminutive, iconic and iconoclastic radio station in Manhattan, WBAI-FM.

headline: Italy Gives Cultural Diversity a Lukewarm Embrace
text: ROME  An exhibition of art from India was being installed here the other morning, at the Luigi Pigorini Museum of Prehistory and Ethnography. Beyond the mah-jongg, Chinese music and Andean ritual dancing displays, Putli Ganju; Juliette Fatima Imam; and Juliette’s mother, Philomina Tirkey Imam, were hanging their paintings of animals and fish.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A chart on Sunday with the continuation of a front-page article about the C.I.A.’s secret interrogation program misidentified the Pakistan cities where two major Al Qaeda figures, Abu Zubaydah and Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, were captured. As the article correctly noted, Mr. Zubaydah was captured in Faisalabad, not Rawalpindi, and Mr. Mohammed was captured in Rawalpindi, not Karachi. The chart also misstated the year of Mr. Mohammed’s capture. As the article also correctly noted, he was captured in March 2003, not 2002.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening this Week

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about stream restoration misspelled the surname of a researcher. She is Dorothy Merritts, not Merrits. And the picture credit misstated the surname of the photographer. He is Robert Walter, not Walker.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Slow-Food Fest

headline: A Curmudgeon Leaves Millions to Poor Children of Panama, and the Battles Begin
text: PANAMA — In life, Wilson C. Lucom was not exactly child friendly. The gruff octogenarian never had children himself and was not especially close to the offspring of his third wife, Hilda, either. When he opened his ample checkbook, friends say, it was more likely to finance a conservative political cause than to help underprivileged youths.

headline: Cherry Crush
text: Time: 5 minutes

headline: As Bats Shatter, Baseball Considers New Rules
text: Bat makers, beware. The future of maple bats was discussed by baseball’s safety and health advisory committee on Tuesday, and the dialogue could lead to more stringent qualifications for companies seeking approval to make major league bats.

headline: MoveOn’s ‘Alex’ Ad: More From the Torrent
text: To the Editor:

headline: Man in Kentucky Kills 5 Co-Workers
text: HENDERSON, Ky.  A man who worked at a Henderson plastics company called his girlfriend from the plant about two hours before he fatally shot five people and then killed himself and told her that he was going to kill his supervisor, police officials said at a news conference on Wednesday.

headline: Portrait of a Haunted Artist Who Befriended Giant Spiders
text: From an art historical perspective, the work of Louise Bourgeois effects a startling synthesis of traditions. In the 1930s Ms. Bourgeois fell in with the Paris Surrealists, and their touch (totemic, irrational, biomorphic, uncanny) can be felt on her sculptures, installations and drawings to this day. Other Modernist influences  the elemental rigor of Brancusi, the archaic vigor of Picasso  fused, in the postwar era, with her experiments in unorthodox materials and techniques (fabrics, knitting) and disquieting new forms (distorted anatomies, giant spiders) in sync with emerging ideas of the body, gender and sexuality.

headline: Taking Ownership of Iraq?
text: Having recently returned from Egypt, I have the Suez Canal on my mind. And looking at Iraq from Cairo, the thought occurred to me that maybe the Iraqis have just crossed the Suez Canal. If so, that’s good news.

headline: City Proposes More Regulations to Improve Construction Safety
text: WASHINGTON  New York City officials announced a new seven-point plan on Tuesday that they said would increase safety at tower crane construction sites by strengthening inspections and requiring safety reviews each time a crane passes from one owner or operator to the next.

headline: Albanian Custom Fades: Woman as Family Man
text: KRUJE, Albania  Pashe Keqi recalled the day nearly 60 years ago when she decided to become a man. She chopped off her long black curls, traded in her dress for her father’s baggy trousers, armed herself with a hunting rifle and vowed to forsake marriage, children and sex.

headline: Ally Warns Outsiders Not to Push Zimbabwe
text: Despite an increasingly thunderous chorus of complaints that Zimbabwe’s presidential runoff election will be neither free nor fair, the African National Congress, South Africa’s governing party, rejected outside diplomatic intervention on Tuesday, arguing that “any attempts by outside players to impose regime change will merely deepen the crisis.”

headline: Beer Lovers Make Room for Brews Worth a Wait
text: WHEN Matthew VandenBerghe brings home his favorite beers, he doesn’t make room for them in the fridge. He takes them to his beer cellar.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the closing of the Théâtre de la Jeune Lune in Minneapolis referred incorrectly to the artistic director, who commented on the closing in a letter posted on the theater’s Web site. The artistic director, Dominique Serrand, is a man.

headline: Investor, a Socialite, Is Charged With Fraud
text: An Italian businessman who was accused last year by the entrepreneur Ron Burkle of misusing more than $1 million he had put up for investments was arrested on Tuesday and charged with fraud and money laundering.

headline: Dutrow Faces Steroid Ban
text: A horse trained by Rick Dutrow that finished second in a $100,000 stakes race at Churchill Downs the day before Big Brown won the Kentucky Derby has tested positive for twice the allowable level of clenbuterol that helps burn fat and promote muscle growth, according to Kentucky racing officials.

headline: Religion and Its Role Are in Dispute at the Service Academies
text: Three years after a scandal at the Air Force Academy over the evangelizing of cadets by Christian staff and faculty members, students and staff at West Point and the Naval Academy are complaining that their schools, too, have pushed religion on cadets and midshipmen.

headline: Fuel Prices Shift Math for Life in Far Suburbs
text: ELIZABETH, Colo.  Suddenly, the economics of American suburban life are under assault as skyrocketing energy prices inflate the costs of reaching, heating and cooling homes on the distant edges of metropolitan areas.

headline: New Charges for 2 Accused of Embezzling Council Funds
text: A scheme by two City Council aides to embezzle money from a charity financed by their boss’s discretionary awards of city money was more widespread than an earlier indictment had alleged, federal prosecutors charged on Tuesday.

headline: Suspects in Kennedy Plot Extradited From Trinidad
text: Three men who face terrorism-related charges in connection with a plot to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport were extradited from Trinidad on Tuesday night.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: A picture on Friday with an article about Europe’s carbon-trading market may have left an incorrect impression that the smog shown obscuring the Eiffel Tower was caused by emissions of carbon dioxide. While smog and carbon dioxide emissions share a common source in automotive and industrial use of fossil fuels, smog results from a combination of ground-level ozone and hydrocarbon particulates, not from carbon dioxide.

headline: Britain: Ad Company’s Sales Growth Slows
text: The WPP Group, an advertising company, said sales growth slowed in the first five months of the year as business in Western Europe continued to lag behind other regions. Sales excluding acquisitions and currency swings climbed 4.5 percent, WPP said. On that basis a year earlier, sales grew 5.2 percent, the company said at the time. Advertising spending in Western Europe has been hurt as soaring energy prices sapped households’ buying power and companies lowered marketing expenses. WPP said sales in Continental Europe had grown less than in Asia, Latin America, Africa and Eastern Europe. Stock in WPP, which is based in London, fell 3.7 percent.

headline: U.S. to Take North Korea Off Terror List
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government announced on Thursday that North Korea will hand over a declaration of its nuclear program and that, if the information is verified to be accurate, the United States would then remove North Korea from a list of state sponsors of terrorism and end some economic sanctions against it.

headline: No. 1 Faux Pas in Washington? Candor, Perhaps
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  It was the journalist Michael Kinsley who changed Washington’s understanding of gaffes with his observation that they occur not when people lie, but when they say what they really think.

headline: Audit Says Follow-Up on Buildings Is Lacking
text: The city’s Department of Buildings, which has already been the object of intense scrutiny over fatal construction accidents and accusations of corruption, is facing more criticism.

headline: An Honor That Bush Is Unlikely to Embrace
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Reagan has his highways. Lincoln has his memorial. Washington has the capital (and a state, too). But President Bush may soon be the sole president to have a memorial named after him that you can contribute to from the bathroom.

headline: As the Levees Fail, Time for Tough Questions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Army Awarded Contract, Unaware of Dealer’s Past
text: WASHINGTON  When the Army last year awarded a contract worth up to nearly $300 million to a tiny Miami Beach munitions dealer to supply ammunition to Afghanistan’s security forces, it overlooked a very checkered past.

headline: The Pulse of Summer: Blender Drinks Are Back
text: YOU may regard the electric blender as a helpful household appliance. For your bartender, it is a tool straight from the devil.

headline: Richard J. Koke, Visionary Curator of New York’s History, Dies at 91
text: Richard J. Koke, who as curator of the New-York Historical Society for nearly 40 years organized much of the institution’s transformation from a repository of documents and artworks into a space where visitors come face to face with relics of New York City and its place in American history, died on May 28 in Plattsburgh, N.Y. He was 91 and lived in Peru, N.Y.

headline: Revival of ’70s Play
text: Ntozake Shange’s play “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf” ran on Broadway in 1976 and toured the country. Now Whoopi Goldberg is bringing a new version, with added material written by Ms. Shange, to Circle in the Square Theater. Choreographed by Hinton Battle and directed by Shirley Jo Finney, “For Colored Girls” is scheduled to open in September with the Grammy-winning singer-songwriter India.Arie.

headline: A Love Without End in a World Beyond Time
text: American Ballet Theater’s production of “La Bayadère,” choreographed by Natalia Makarova, can leave you feeling as if you’ve stumbled, perhaps after a few drinks, onto a dusty old movie set. “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom” comes to mind, though no one in the ballet, alas, has his still-beating heart pulled from his chest.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Tuesday about the use of antipsychotic drugs in dementia patients misspelled the names of two drugs in a different class, sometimes used to treat the symptoms of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. They are Exelon and Namenda, not Exalon and Menamda.

headline: Service From Google Gives Crucial Data to Ad Buyers
text: In announcing a new service for media buyers on Tuesday, Google said that its Ad Planner was meant to make life easier for the people whose job it is to identify Web sites where their clients’ messages will have the most impact.

text: Sonny Okosuns, a Nigerian singer and musician who achieved international stature by aiming his music  a catchy, rock-inflected cocktail of funk, reggae, Afrobeat and more  at human-rights abuses, died on May 24 in Washington. He was 61.

text: It has been 15 years since real estate auctions held by property developers have been commonplace, but in the current torpid real estate market, they’re starting to re-emerge in cities throughout the country.

headline: Illinois to Sue Countrywide
text: The Illinois attorney general is suing Countrywide Financial, the troubled mortgage lender, and Angelo R. Mozilo, its chief executive, contending that the company and its executives defrauded borrowers in the state by selling them costly and defective loans that quickly went into foreclosure.

headline: More German Troops to Afghanistan
text: BERLIN  Under pressure from NATO, Germany announced Tuesday that it would increase the number of soldiers available for duty in Afghanistan by almost one-third to 4,500, but that it would maintain its policy of keeping the bulk of them away from the relatively violent southern provinces.

headline: Smoke at Post Office
text: Firefighters responded on Tuesday night to reports of smoke coming out of the James A. Farley Post Office building, on Eighth Avenue across from Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Hockey Team Built on Showmanship Is Sidelined Indefinitely
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Looking back on the whole marvelous caper, the high point was not so much the playoff runs or the bewildered crowds or even all those underdressed Texas sweethearts shivering around the hockey rink glass. No, the high point was probably Guaranteed Fight Night.

headline: Medicare Savings vs. the Lobbyists
text: To cut costs and reduce fraud in one corner of the sprawling Medicare program, Congress called for competitive bidding on medical equipment that is provided to elderly and disabled Americans and set a sensible schedule for phasing in the program. Demonstration projects were held, the results looked promising, and last year Medicare received competitive bids from companies to supply equipment in 10 metropolitan areas.

headline: Congress Looks for a Culprit for Rising Oil Prices
text: With Americans growing angrier by the day about high gasoline prices, nobody can accuse Congress of turning a deaf ear.

headline: White House Refused to Open Pollutants E-Mail
text: The White House in December refused to accept the Environmental Protection Agency’s conclusion that greenhouse gases are pollutants that must be controlled, telling agency officials that an e-mail message containing the document would not be opened, senior E.P.A. officials said last week.

headline: Citigroup Considers Repealing a Pledge, and the Slogan With It
text: LAST year Citigroup made a promise to millions of people who flex its credit cards: “A deal is a deal.” The slogan was used to trumpet an announcement that the financial giant would no longer reserve the right to raise interest rates on cards at any time, for any reason.

headline: Pirates Pound Yankees With 19 Hits
text: PITTSBURGH  Joe Girardi tries hard to stay optimistic and project confidence in all of his players. But there are games that try him, and Tuesday’s was one of them.

headline: Wright Accepts the Order to Take a Night Off
text: David Wright’s first game on the bench this season proved to be the perfect night for some time off.

headline: Woods Has Successful Surgery
text: Reconstructive surgery to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament in Tiger Woods’s left knee was successful and the long-term prognosis is for a full recovery, one of Woods’s doctors who performed the operation said Tuesday after the procedure in Park City, Utah.

headline: Longtime Art in America Editor Steps Down
text: After more than three decades as the editor of Art in America magazine, Elizabeth C. Baker, a powerful voice in the contemporary-art world, is stepping down, the magazine said on Tuesday. The change comes shortly after a shake-up in the magazine’s ownership. Peter M. Brant, a newsprint magnate and art collector, took over Brant Publications, the magazine’s publisher, in January after buying out the 50 percent stake owned by his former wife, Sandra Brant. Mr. Brant appointed Fabien Baron and Glenn O’Brien as joint editorial directors of Art in America and the company’s two other publications, Interview and The Magazine Antiques. Ms. Baker, known as Betsy, took over the magazine in 1974. Under her leadership Art in America grew from a bimonthly publication with a circulation of around 45,000 to a monthly with a circulation of more than 75,000, featuring the writing of many influential critics. Marcia E. Vetrocq, who joined Art in America in 1998 as a senior editor, will take over as editor. Ms. Baker will become editor at large in charge of special projects, which will include book publishing and Web site development.

headline: City Questions 9/11 Workers’ Claims of Illness
text: The first detailed review of the medical records of nearly 10,000 ground zero workers who are suing New York City and its contractors suggests that many are not as sick as their lawyers have claimed, attorneys for the city say.

headline: Parings: Root Beer Semifreddo
text: The list of ways to put root beer to use is fairly brief. A root beer float or granita are obvious options, as is making a Cuba libre (cola, rum and ice) with root beer instead. Root beer can also be used as the basis for a barbecue marinade, best made by first reducing and concentrating the root beer.

headline: Low Mexican Gas Prices Draw Americans
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico  When George Terrazas was mugged at gunpoint in this Mexican border city several months ago, he vowed never to return.

headline: Report Assails Political Hiring in Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON  Justice Department officials illegally used “political or ideological” factors in elite recruiting programs in recent years, tapping law school graduates with Federalist Society membership or other conservative credentials over more qualified candidates with liberal-sounding résumés, an internal report found Tuesday.

headline: W.H.O. Issues a Checklist to Make Operations Safer
text: The World Health Organization issued its first guidelines on Tuesday aimed at reducing complications and deaths from the rising numbers of operations now being performed.

headline: Bronx Groups Demand a Voice in a Landmark’s Revival
text: Residents of the northwest Bronx have long taken a proprietary interest in the Kingsbridge Armory, a huge city-owned Romanesque-style fortress that looms over the elevated subway tracks on Jerome Avenue.

headline: As Ordered, Track Body Offers Plan to Get Trim
text: After years of prodding and a recent ultimatum from the United States Olympic Committee, USA Track & Field submitted a reorganization plan near the eve of its Olympic trials.

headline: A Cool Glass of Cashews
text: Milky cashew juice, served chilled, is a refreshing change of pace. O.N.E., a company that sells coconut water, has just added this tropical beverage to its line. The company also makes coffee berry juice, which is less distinctive, since the flavor of the coffee fruit and bean is masked by the addition of strawberry and acerola fruit purée.Whole Foods sells the juices in 11-ounce cartons, $2.99 for the coffee berry and $1.99 for the cashew. The juices are also available online in packages of 12. The cashew juice is $23.20, and the coffee berry juice is $28.67 at onenaturalexperience.com.

text: Adapted from the Rusty Knot

headline: Guilty Verdict in 19-Hour Rape and Torture of Student
text: A jury convicted Robert A. Williams of attempted murder, rape and arson on Tuesday for the attack on a former Columbia University journalism student who was tortured and raped repeatedly for 19 hours last year.

headline: In Balancing Act on National Security, a Stumble
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  It was the journalist Michael Kinsley who changed Washington’s understanding of gaffes with his observation that a gaffe occurs not when someone lies, but when they say what they really think.

headline: G.O.P. Picking Bruno’s Replacement
text: ALBANY  The Republican-led state Senate moved on Tuesday to install Dean G. Skelos, a Long Island senator for more than two decades, as its new majority leader.

headline: Brazil Seizes Livestock to Protect Rain Forest
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  In an unprecedented move against rogue cattle ranchers in the Amazon, the Brazilian government has seized livestock grazing there illegally, the new environment minister announced Tuesday.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about the comedian George Carlin misstated the location of the Playboy Club where he angered an audience by joking about the Vietnam War. It was Lake Geneva, Wis. (There is no town named Lake Geneva in New York.)

headline: South Korea: Tougher Line on Protests
text: President Lee Myung-bak, trying to reassert his authority after weeks of demonstrations against his decision in April to resume imports of American beef, said his government would not tolerate further violent protests. “The government must deal sternly with illegal and violent protests, as well as rallies that challenge the state’s system,” Mr. Lee said at a cabinet meeting. His comments contrasted with the low-key, apologetic stance he had taken in recent weeks. The demonstrations led Mr. Lee, who took office in late February, to ask Washington to revise the original agreement on beef. In a new accord unveiled on Saturday, the United States agreed to export beef only from cattle younger than 30 months, to allay South Koreans’ fears of mad cow disease. Protest organizers vowed to keep rallying until Mr. Lee agreed to a complete renegotiation of the pact.

headline: Nokia to Open Access to Mobile Software
text: BERLIN — Nokia, the world’s largest maker of cellphones, said Tuesday that it would make the software that runs its phones available to outside developers, as the company tries to head off competition and stimulate the use of mobile music, video, e-mail and other services.

headline: A Summerful of Parties to Pour by the Pitcher
text: When I make sangria, it’s usually a hit-or-miss affair. I keep adding wine, brandy, fruit and soda to a pitcher until it tastes right. So it’s nice to have a recipe.

headline: Test-Driving Parenthood Is Teenage Wake-Up Call
text: To judge from the current state of romantic comedy, the modern American couple reproduces first and reconciles to love later  morning sickness before mornings after. This reversal of order supplied a plot line during the final seasons of “Sex and the City” and the basis for the films “Knocked Up” and “Juno.” More recently, the movie “Smart People” reiterated the message, giving us a grumpy and imperious literature professor, played by Dennis Quaid, resolving to become less grumpy and imperious once his girlfriend’s E.P.T. result comes up positive. In the new scheme procreating doesn’t merely make us more responsible; it makes us more appealing and datable.

headline: Another Rebuke on Guantánamo
text: One of Guantánamo’s many horrors is just how long people have been held there in a cruel legal limbo. Huzaifa Parhat has been detained for six long years, despite his insistence that he was an innocent swept up in the chaos in Afghanistan. It is welcome news that a federal appeals court has now ruled  in the first decision of its kind  that Mr. Parhat was improperly labeled an “enemy combatant.”

headline: Dow Chemical Raises Prices for Second Time in a Month
text: The Dow Chemical Company said Tuesday that it was raising prices for the second time in a month to offset a “relentless rise” in energy costs, a sign that companies may increasingly have to pass on price increases to their customers.

headline: Diabetes Cases Increase 15 Percent in 2 Years
text: The number of Americans with diabetes increased by 15 percent in two years to 24 million, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. About 8 percent of the population now has the disease, mainly Type 2 diabetes, which is linked to obesity and sedentary living, the agency said in a report using data from 2007. A quarter of people ages 60 and older had diabetes, the agency said. The number of people worldwide with diabetes will double to 366 million by 2030, according to the World Health Organization, which calls the disease an epidemic. Most people with diabetes have resistance to insulin, which the body uses to convert blood sugar to energy. The C.D.C. report was its first update of the prevalence of diabetes since 2005, when it reported that about 21 million Americans had the disease.

headline: Florida Buying Big Sugar Tract for Everglades
text: LOXAHATCHEE, Fla.  The dream of a restored Everglades, with water flowing from Lake Okeechobee to Florida Bay, moved a giant step closer to reality on Tuesday when the nation’s largest sugarcane producer agreed to sell all of its assets to the state and go out of business.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: An article on Monday about weekend box office results misstated the number of weekends “Kung Fu Panda,” which was second in receipts behind “Get Smart,” has been in theaters. This was its third weekend, not its second.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
text: The Advertising column on Tuesday, about cable channels’ gains in advance advertising sales, referred incorrectly to the increases. Top-tier cable channels received increases of 9 to 10 percent in the cost per thousand viewers for commercial time, not per minute. An accompanying picture caption also carried the error.

headline: Chrysler Taps a $2 Billion Credit Line
text: DETROIT (Dow Jones)  Chrysler made use of a $2 billion credit line that was a condition of its sale last year from Daimler to Cerberus Capital Management, Daimler reported Tuesday.

headline: China Orders Up Menus for Tourists
text: IN preparation for the Olympic Games later this summer in Beijing, the Chinese government has released an official list of suggested English translations for Chinese dishes, a road map through idiosyncratic nomenclature that officials fear will spook or confuse thousands of tourists.

headline: New Day in Albany Opens as the Senate Selects Bruno’s Successor
text: ALBANY  Senate Republicans on Tuesday selected Dean G. Skelos, an aggressive legislator known for his firm stands on anti-crime issues, to succeed Joseph L. Bruno as majority leader. The vote came amid signs that a federal investigation into Mr. Bruno’s activities may be intensifying.

headline: Searching for Aaron Small
text: Ever since a magical late-summer run in 2005, any journeyman pitcher who’s had a little success for the Yankees is compared to Aaron Small. He is the gold standard for the out-of-nowhere success story, going 10-0 in the second half of the season.

headline: Baroque Bad Boy Shows in Rome
text: It’s been the destiny of the Baroque artist Agostino Tassi to be better remembered for his personal vicissitudes than his art. If non-art historians recognize the name at all it’s most likely because they’ve heard the notorious story of Tassi’s 1612 conviction on charges of raping the painter Artemisia Gentileschi, the daughter of Orazio Gentileschi, also a painter and Tassi’s partner in several Roman commissions. She was in her teens, he in his 30s.

text: At the Urban Assembly New York Harbor School, the mission is to raise academic achievement by connecting students with the harbor.

headline: BrisConnections Said to Seek $1.18 Billion in I.P.O.
text: BrisConnections, a group including Australia’s largest construction company Leighton Holdings plans to raise 1.23 billion Australian dollars ($1.18 billion) in an initial public offer, The Australian newspaper reported.

headline: Kodak to Repurchase $1 Billion in Shares
text: Eastman Kodak said Tuesday that it was buying back up to $1 billion, or about a quarter, of its outstanding stock, sending its shares up sharply.

headline: Illinois to Sue Countrywide

headline: BlackRock Is Preparing for Bigger Economic Slowdown
