text: Shareholders at CSX will vote for board members at the railroad operator’s annual meeting Wednesday – capping months of squabbles between the company and activist hedge fund shareholders.

headline: A Tentative Pact for Pilots of Merging Airlines
text: Negotiators for pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines said Tuesday that they had a tentative agreement with Delta management on a joint contract to cover both pilot groups when the companies combine later this year.

headline: Resolution Revises Bradford & Bingley Offer, Report Says
text: Clive Cowdery was last night refining his proposal to rescue Bradford & Bingley, the British mortgage lender, as shareholders stepped up pressure on the board, which has told him and the four institutional investors backing his plan that their offer was unacceptable, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Burned on Bradford & Bingley
text: London hedge fund giant GLG Partners and Tiger Global Management were among the hedge funds licking their wounds from their short positions in Bradford & Bingley, after details of a bid from financial services group Resolution sent shares in the U.K. mortgage lender up more than 10 percent, Financial News reported.

headline: Investor, a Socialite, Is Charged With Fraud
text: An Italian businessman who was accused last year by the entrepreneur Ron Burkle of misusing more than $1 million he had put up for investments, was arrested on Tuesday and charged with fraud and money laundering.

headline: Countrywide Shareholders to Vote on Bank of America Deal
text: Countrywide Financial shareholders vote on Wednesday to approve the largest U.S. mortgage lender’s purchase by Bank of America, marking the demise of the company perhaps most closely associated with the nation’s housing bubble and subsequent collapse.

headline: Goldman Funds Said to Make Comeback
text: Two large hedge funds run by Goldman Sachs have rebounded so far this year after big losses in 2007, according to MarketWatch.

headline: We’ve Had Better Days
text: This turned up on the social news Web site Reddit.com this week. Curious, we checked it against our archives. It is indeed an actual Times article:

headline: Washington Mutual May Not Have Tap More Cash, Analyst Says
text: Washington Mutual may be able to withstand estimated losses of $36 billion and remain in business, and avoid an additional capital raise, said Ladenburg Thalmann analyst Richard X. Bove, who narrowed his 2008 loss forecast for the thrift.

headline: Circuit City Said to Have Several Interested Bidders
text: Blockbuster, it seems, may have some competition for its bid to acquire Circuit City.

headline: Delta and Northwest Chiefs Say Deal Will Offset Oil Costs
text: The network formed by a merged Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines would help them avoid cutting the number of cities they serve if oil prices force more capacity reductions, their chief executives wrote in The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday.

headline: One Equity Dons Precision Gear
text: One Equity Partners has acquired Precision Gear Holdings from New York buyout shop First Atlantic Capital in a deal valued at roughly $80 million.

headline: Wachovia Hires Goldman to Advise on Loan Portfolio
text: Wachovia, it appears, really values Goldman Sachs. The bank has hired the Wall Street investment firm for advice on its loan portfolio.

headline: Bezos Backs Twitter in New Round
text: Twitter, the popular microblogging service, announced that it has picked up some new investors: Spark Capital and Jeff Bezos, via his Bezos Expeditions fund.

headline: Chrysler Taps a $2 Billion Credit Line
text: Chrysler made use of a $2 billion credit line that was a condition of its sale last year from Daimler to Cerberus Capital Management, Daimler said on Tuesday.

headline: WhiteHat Scores $7 Million
text: WhiteHat Security, a provider of Web site security services, has raised a fourth round of funding.

headline: Monitor101 Seeks Fresh Funding, Mulls Sale
text: Monitor110 seeking outside capital and exploring a sale, the data information provider’s chief, Jeff Stewart, told The Deal.com.

headline: What’s Alan Schwartz’s Next Move?
text: The fate of Bear Stearns’ former chief executive, Alan Schwartz, has been an open question for several months. And now it may be remain that way for several months more.

headline: T-Mobile Offers New Home Phone Service
text: How is this for a twist: Wireless carrier T-Mobile wants to sell consumers phone service in their homes.

headline: Apria and the Failure of Private Equity
text: What was Apria Healthcare Group thinking?

headline: BlogTalkRadio Chats About New Financing and New Plans
text: The pirates of radio are losing their eye patches and going legit.

headline: Smithfield Foods to Merge European Unit
text: Smithfield Foods plans to merge its European unit with Campofrio of Spain in a deal worth about 1 billion euros, according to The Financial Times. The deal would create to mamoth food company with sales of more than 2 million euros, the paper said.

headline: Ruling in CSX Battle Has Changed Activist Tactics
text: As CSX shareholders meet to vote on director nominees proposed by two activist hedge funds, the landscape for these battles has changed drastically.

headline: A Security Concern Over ID Card Deal
text: L-1 Identity Solutions, which is battling for control of Digimarc, is raising questions about whether rival bidder Safran would be prevented from buying Digimarc by United States authorities because the French government owns a 30 percent interest in the company.

headline: Bringing Jobs Back Home?
text: Economy | Rising energy, wage and transport costs are dulling China’s edge in manufacturing. Does that mean American manufacturing is an idea whose time has come, again? Look at the Europeans: The euro’s rise against the dollar means European cars and aircraft are shifting production to the United States. — Business Week

headline: UBS Said to Hire Lazard; Is a Sale in Its Future?
text: Investors seem to think UBS has something up its sleeve — and it may be a sale of some kind.

headline: London Theater Journal: Take That, a New Twist on Jukebox Musicals
text: I was glad to discover Tuesday night that the jukebox musical, that brave new art form, has not been standing still in London. The latest great step – sideways – in its evolution was on display at the Savoy Theater, home to “Never Forget,” a show based on the songs of the British boy band Take That. (Since it never crossed the Atlantic with much success, let me explain that Take That, which was formed in the early 1990s, was a wildly popular British answer to the American teenybopper’s pre-fab delight, the New Kids on the Block; its breakout star was its youngest member, wee Robbie Williams, who left the group in 1995 for a meteoric solo career.)

headline: The Early Word: Countdown to Unity
text: As Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton get ready to appear together at a fund-raiser in Washington Thursday night and at a campaign stop in New Hampshire on Friday, the two once-bitter rivals seem to be repairing old wounds.

headline: Dangerous populists?
text: Martin Wolf calls for

headline: Return to Sender: E.P.A. E-Mail on CO2 Refused by Administration. Old Pattern Back?
text: My colleague Felicity Barringer has a story filling in a detail on the White House’s refusal to accept the need for restricting carbon dioxide as a pollutant, even as President Bush and the administration have accepted, with ever more firmness, that rising concentrations of the gas are a serious problem and must be reversed (somehow, someday). The action fits a longstanding pattern.

headline: For the Moment | Lions and Tigers and Kim Jones
text: Kim Jones

headline: InBev Obtains Committed Financing for Bud Bid
text: InBev announced this morning that it has obtained committed financing for its bid for Anheuser-Busch. InBev said in a letter to August A. Busch IV, Anheuser-Busch’s chief executive, that it has paid $50 million in fees to a lending group comprised of Banco Santander, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Barclays Capital, BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank, Fortis, ING Bank, JP Morgan, Mizuho Corporate Bank and Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Review Questions Extent of 9/11 Illnesses
text: The first detailed review of the medical records of nearly 10,000 ground zero workers who are suing New York City and its contractors suggests that many are not as sick as their lawyers have claimed, lawyers for the city say.

headline: FIA World Council decisions
text: Here are the decisions concerning Formula One from today’s World Council meeting at the International Automobile Federation in Paris. Stay tuned for further comment later:

headline: A Husband Scorned?
text: Does Barack Obama need to build a bridge to the 20th century? “Bill Clinton has a beef” with the Democratic nominee, says Marc Ambinder at his blog for The Atlantic. “A Democrat who has spoken directly to Clinton about his feelings said that the former president remains ‘miffed’ for two reasons.” Ambinder continues:

headline: Kanye Wins Two Prizes At BET Awards
text: Reuters reports on the eighth annual BET Awards, presented live on the BET cable channel:

headline: Neighbors | Fifth Avenues
text: In a new Lens series, the photographer Damon Winter of The Times uses double exposures to capture the endless juxtapositions in New York City. Read about how he creates these photographs.

headline: Unwelcome to Italy
text: Buoyed by some of the strictest anti-immigration laws in Europe, some Italians are increasingly making things tough for foreigners.

headline: Viewers Reject Repeats, Watch Reality
text: How low are the ratings for network reruns this summer? Here’s how low: “Last week’s ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ airing reached 3.2 million people, a smaller audience than 14 programs that aired on Univision,” the Associated Press reports. “ABC’s ‘Desperate Housewives’ had virtually the same size audience as Univision’s ‘Amas Casa Desperados.'”

headline: Energy Crisis or Bust
text: Interest in renewable energy has brought to the fore the question of harnessing the power of female breasts. There’s already a “bra-pod,” which Adrienne So, writing on Slate, wants to take to the next level:

headline: Shaquille O’Neal vs. ‘America’s Toughest Sheriff’
text: It was only a matter of time before Joe Arpaio, the Arizona lawman who cultivates an image as “America’s Toughest Sheriff,” made national headlines with one of the oldest tropes in television and film: “Hand in your badge.”

headline: Victor Emerges in Battle of the Dentists
text: That bill empowering the New York State Dental Association to oust any chapter that violates certain undefined standards passed the State Legislature on Tuesday. And none too soon. So confident was the state association of its clout in Albany that, before the bill even got to the floor, the executive committee of the board of governors scheduled a special meeting last Friday to do just that — remove the Manhattan group originally chartered in the 19th century and replace it with a new association incorporated this year.

headline: An Unexpected Savior?
text: The nation's largest sugarcane producer agreed to sell its assets and 187,000 acres of land to Florida for Everglades restoration.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Spiced Pepper Purée
text: Even at its most basic, a pepper purée is a condiment with more potential than even ketchup or salsa. One of the true minimalist preparations, it’s the foundation for any number of impressive dishes, but can be made in minutes and with almost no effort.

headline: Lara Logan’s New Assignment: D.C.
text: Lara Logan, the CBS News chief foreign correspondent who loudly decried the lack of media coverage of Iraq and Afghanistan last week, will no longer be based overseas, the network said Wednesday.

headline: ‘You Know, I Don’t Need Any of This’
text: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Thank you for being here, but, you know, I don’t need any of this. I own a gas station in Mexico.

headline: ‘It Was a Very Awkward Moment’
text: Aired Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Arnold Schwarzenegger met John McCain today. And it was a very awkward moment when they shook hands because McCain’s hand broke off.

headline: ‘And It’s Not Helping’
text: Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Hey, there was an interesting study released today which says that people who live here in the state of California are less convinced that there is a God than the people of any other state in the country. On an unrelated note, more than 800 wildfires here in California are currently burning out of control.

headline: Generation Faithful: Answers on Algeria
text: Three experts on youth development in the Middle East have read Michael Slackman’s latest piece in the “General Faithful” series, “In Algeria, a Tug of War for Young Minds,” and as part of “The Majlis” have answered some reader questions about points the article raised. They are Navtej Dhillon, Djavad Salehi Isfahani and Tarik Yousef, who are part of the Middle Eastern Youth Initiative (M.E.Y.I.), a joint program of the Wolfensohn Center for Development at the Brookings Institution and the Dubai School of Government.

headline: Serious Fun With a Swizzle Stick
text: I haven’t mapped this out precisely, but it seems to me that we’ve entered Phase Three of our current restaurant cocktail renaissance. It’s the most promising phase of all, befitting how much attention many of us are paying to what we drink, a passion that drives today’s Summer Drinks Issue of the Dining section.

headline: M.T.A. Revokes Travel Perks for Board Members
text: Updated, 2:49 p.m. | Bowing to pressure from Gov. David A. Paterson and State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted unanimously on Wednesday morning to revoke free travel privileges it had extended to former and current members of its board, allowing them unlimited use of E-ZPass tags as well as travel on the authority’s commuter railroads, subways and buses.

headline: What Your Doctor Really Thinks
text: Reader’s Digest recently asked two dozen doctors to talk about what’s on their minds. The result: a litany of complaints, insights and observations about patients and medicine.

headline: Is There Only One Way to Make a Cocktail?
text: Today’s Minimalist column, about cocktails, has already inspired the now expected crowd of people telling me that I’m doing everything — or at least some things — wrong. My point was this: There is no “wrong.” There are cocktails you make up yourself and there are classics. But even the classics are made in different ways by different people.

headline: The Friendly Skies, Now With WiFi
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Befuddled by Microsoft Products?
text: BRIEFS Befuddled by Microsoft products? So is Bill Gates, the software pioneer who founded Microsoft, at least for a moment. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer has dredged up a 2003 e-mail in which he cites chapter and verse on the difficulties of finding Moviemaker, a home video program, on a Microsoft Web site. Here’s one snippet from his wrestling match that shows that even Bill Gates gets mystifying technical advice sometimes: “So they told me that using the download page to download something was not something they anticipated.” Trust us, Mr. Gates: We’ve been there. [Seattle Post-Intelligencer]

headline: Just Asking | Wimbledon Couture
text: Maria Sharapova, world number two, gives us Escada, circa 1997. Yes, that’s a trench on Serena Williams. And no, it has not been raining. (Getty)

headline: Reports: Energy Thirst Still Topping Climate Risks
text: Two studies out Wednesday — one on energy trends, one on climate as a security issue — bode poorly for those seeking to prevent global warming from passing dangerous thresholds. Coal and oil use climb relentlessly, at a rate similar to that for growth in wind, solar, and nuclear power, but in vastly larger quantities.

headline: Mozilo’s Free Ride
text: Given that the Illinois attorney general’s office is planning to file a civil lawsuit against Countrywide Financial and its chief executive, Angelo Mozilo – alleging unfair and deceptive practices in mortgage loans – Mr. Mozilo must be crossing his fingers (twice!) that the Bank of America deal occurs.

headline: MasterCard Pays $1.8 Billion to American Express
text: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Oversize Art | The Energy Wall of China
text: Beijing’s building-sized video installation. Very “Blade Runner.” (Simone Giostra & Partners)

headline: Day 2 on the Hill for Clinton
text: On her second day back to work at the Capitol, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton met with the House Democratic caucus, as Speaker Nancy Pelosi hailed her as “the most respected political figure in America” drawing a huge round of applause.

headline: The Morning Skate: Who Own Da Chief? The N.H.L. Crime Wave Continues
text: This is the kind of thing that makes some fans’ eyes glaze over and slide shut, but the list of NHL owners who have been convicted of a crime, gone broke or had their team go broke — as more than a couple have over the last dozen years — just seems to grow and grow.

headline: Talk May Be Cheap, But It May Be More Effective Offline
text: For the second time in a week, a study has been released that concludes that the word-of-mouth conversations generated offline may be deemed more credible and positive by consumers than those conversations held online.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Allison Glock
text: Allison Glock is the author of “Beauty Before Comfort,” a memoir.

headline: A Glimpse at the Future High Line
text: A selection of renderings just released by the High Line that show the future of the space.

headline: Confusions about speculation
text: OK, Tyler Cowen weighs in — but I think that he partly misunderstands my point.

headline: High Line Designs Are Unveiled
text: City officials and the Friends of the High Line presented the final design on Wednesday for the first phase of the High Line, the $170 million park that is under construction on the West Side of Manhattan and has been called one of New York City’s most distinctive public projects in generations.

headline: The Starting Line: When It Comes to Sappy TV Montages, China Does Not Lag
text: Also today: Shanghai police warn activists to stay out of Beijing; China’s fired kayak coach speaks out; the Paralympic torch relay gets trimmed; a rowing berth for Zimbabwe (that’ll improve life there); and Oz’s intimidating walker.

headline: Russert’s Highway
text: Tim Russert, the NBC journalist and host of “Meet the Press” who died June 13, may soon have his memory enshrined as Congress moved a step closer on Tuesday toward renaming a stretch of highway near Buffalo, N.Y. in his honor.

headline: Live From the CSX Meeting
text: So far the CSX shareholder meeting, here in the Gentilly railyard outside New Orleans, hasn’t had any major fireworks.

headline: Mopeds, Horsemeat and Pynchon on Malta
text: Last Friday night, Sunny Bar & Restaurant filled up quickly. Families, couples and friends gathered at the simple wooden tables to share bowls of snails and platters of spaghetti with rabbit sauce, while men of all ages stood at the bar, drinking Cisk lager and watching the tense Croatia-Turkey football match on TV. Occasionally, one would wander outside to greet a friend in front of the huge, moonlit church that dominates the main square of the village of Mgarr, on the west side of the island of Malta.

headline: When Does a New Home Become Old?
text: There are a lot of new homes getting old out there.

headline: Mugabe, a Knight No Longer
text: Because most people might know him as the face of brutal oppression in Zimbabwe, it might come as a surprise that Robert Mugabe has enjoyed a distinct honor in Britain since 1994: honorary Knight Grand Cross in the Civil Division of The Most Honorable Order of Bath

headline: NBC Settles With Family of Suicide Victim Over ‘Predator’ Episode
text: A lawsuit filed by the family of a man who killed himself during a sex predator sting on “To Catch a Predator” has been settled, with NBC paying an undisclosed amount to the family of Louis Conradt.

headline: They Don’t Make Atheists Like They Used To
text: If only George Carlin were around to ponder this oxymoron: Steven Waldman, the editor-in-chief of Beliefnet, digs into the U.S. Religious Landscape Survey, conducted by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life (and reported on by The Times yesterday), and finds an interesting nugget: “21 percent of atheists believe in god.”

headline: The Basics of Fatherhood
text: When it comes to issues of childhood health and raising kids, mothers tend to dominate the discussion. But as the Web site PsychCentral points out today, fathers play an essential but often undervalued role in the health and development of children.

headline: The Sworn Virgins of Albania
text: The tradition of the sworn virgin in Albania, a ritual of self-empowerment for rural women, is now a disappearing phenomenon.

headline: Company Topic Pages
text: We believe those content aggregation tools are onto something, providing the information and news you want in one place—kind of like our newly launched 6,000+ company topic pages. To see how your Yahoo! or Exxon stocks are affecting your portfolio, take a look at the price chart. And while you’re at it, glance at the Peer Performance module for a competitive analysis. Continuously updated stock snapshots, quarterly earnings, analyst ratings… it’s all there, right next to NYTimes.com’s most important product, our journalism.

headline: Personal Tech Product Reviews & Guides
text: Canon’s XH A1 camcorder or Sony’s HDR-FX1? And while we’re on the subject of tech gadgets, trying to figure out which handheld (or camera, or laptop, or MP3 player…) is right for your lifestyle?

headline: Another Sign of Civilization’s Demise?
text: “Wipeout,” a new reality series in which people compete for cash prizes by traversing a mud-filled obstacle course, became the highest rated new show of the summer, lifting ABC to first place on Tuesday night among adults 18 to 49. Viewers who tuned were treated to sights like an overweight woman covered in mud trying unsuccessfully to walk across a set of slippery inflated balls that were set across a swimming pool (hint: she fell in).

headline: What Does Exxon Owe Alaskans? 1994: $5 Billion; 2006: $2.5 Billion; Today: $0.5 Billion…
text: Time heals all wounds, and reduces most lawsuit payouts.

headline: Did an Umpire Cross the Line at Shea?
text: That the Mets were ineffective in nearly every department during last night’s 11-0 hiding by the Seattle Mariners is not a matter of debate. Eight hits and no runs off R.A. Dickey, a knuckleballer who had lost 11 of his 12 previous decisions and carried a 5.77 earned run average into the game, left little to discuss. But the game did throw up at least one major talking point in the fourth inning when umpire Brian Runge ejected manager Jerry Manuel and Carlos Beltran amid a flurry of bumping and finger-wagging.

headline: Noise
text: On an entirely different note (and as a way to procrastinate just a few minutes more before finishing the Chapter 28 revision): this Salon piece on noise struck home.

headline: To Be Young (Like 9, on Average?) and Homeless
text: Is the average age of a homeless person 9 years old?

headline: The Three Worst Places to Live
text: The most failed of all the failed states is…Somalia! Foreign Policy has just published its annual “failed states ranking,” and Somalia heads the list. Sudan comes in second, and Zimbabwe ranks third, followed by Chad, Iraq, Congo and Afghanistan.

headline: Nader Defends Remarks About Obama
text: Update | 5:15 p.m. Asked about Ralph Nader’s critical comments at a news conference in Chicago on Wednesday, Senator Barack Obama said Mr. Nader had not been paying attention to his campaign, where “I’ve devoted multiple speeches, town hall meetings to” the issues Mr. Nader raised.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, June 25:

headline: By Mr. Kristo
text: A reader in Ann Arbor, Michigan, Henrietta S., sent in a clip from the Ann Arbor News and asks: “Are you the author of a recent column, reprinted in last night’s Ann Arbor News under your byline” taking Obama to task for not mentioning military service as a public service career?

headline: War? Recession?  Not Here
text: Over at Barrons.com, they provide instant analysis of various economic indicators here. If you click on yesterday’s consumer confidence report, you will find a quite accurate summary of the report.

headline: Arts, Sports, Whatever
text: The Guardian recently asked its arts critics to cover sports for a day — and vice versa. The results are quite winning! I mean, where else can you read something like this?

headline: The Atmosphere in Basel
text: The Swiss half of Euro 2008 draws to a close on a warm summer evening after a blazing, humid, summer day on which temperatures in Basel reached 30 degrees Centigrade, or 86 Fahrenheit.

headline: Mixed Feelings for Turkey at the Half
text: Should the Turks be satisfied or worried. Written off beforehand, they took the lead, dominated much of the play and created far more chances — the official statistics say 15 shots to 3, with the only German shot on target, Schweinsteiger’s goal. Yet at half time their reward is that they are level with Germany.

headline: Is Anne Frank Rolling in Her Grave?
text: A website called Political Mavens blasts me for, in effect, dishonoring Anne Frank. The Anne Frank Center, a non-profit organization devoted to promoting tolerance and her memory, gave me its annual award at a banquet the evening before I left for the Middle East, largely for my work on Darfur. Political Mavens notes that I then criticized Israeli policies in Gaza and the West Bank in my columns from the Middle East trip:

headline: The Digital Ramble | Culture Jamming
text: The Digital Ramble explores aesthetic topics through materials found online.

headline: McCain’s Lexington Project
text: LAS VEGAS – Some might have called it bold, and others foolhardy, when Senator John McCain followed his call to allow offshore drilling with a visit to California, where the idea is controversial to say the least. The same thing could be said of his trip here on Wednesday, where his call for 45 new nuclear plants by 2030 cannot but remind voters of the plan to store nuclear waste at nearby Yucca Mountain.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion | Mondrian Mania
text: It’s all about Mondrian. From left to right, the classic tricolor colorblocking at Jil Sander and a more muted palette at Marni. (AP/Getty)

headline: Gansevoort Deal Ends Impasse Over Waste
text: In October 2004, the Bloomberg administration announced its intention to reopen a long-closed waste transfer station in Greenwich Village, on the Hudson River near 12th Street, to handle recyclable materials from Manhattan. The idea was part of a much larger Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan — pronounced “swamp” — that would transform how the city handles residential waste.

headline: Publicis Introduces Digital Media Initiative and Shakes Up Leadership
text: Publicis Groupe, the large advertising holding company that owns Digitas, Leo Burnett and Saatchi & Saatchi, announced Wednesday morning that it was reorganizing to better focus on digital media.

headline: Wimbledon — Day Three
text: An upset and near-upset marked the third day of Wimbledon.

headline: Innocents in Guantanamo
text: McClatchy is publishing a major report on innocent people whom we kept in Guantanamo. It’s depressing reading:

headline: A New Report Card on Iraq
text: The improved security situation in Iraq is good news for all Iraqis and Americans. Violence is way down. More Iraqi security forces have been trained to help protect the country. The central government is beginning to assert its authority. Parliament has adopted some vital new laws.

headline: Answers About Child Health Care in New York
text: Following is the first set of answers from Judy Wessler, the director of the Commission on the Public’s Health System. This week, Ms. Wessler answered questions about health care services for children and young people and about access to care for the uninsured. We are no longer taking questions for this feature.

headline: Et Tu, Intel? Chip Giant Won’t Embrace Microsoft’s Windows Vista
text: Intel, the giant chip maker and longtime partner of Microsoft, has decided against upgrading the computers of its own 80,000 employees to Microsoft’s Vista operating system, a person with direct knowledge of the company’s plans said.

headline: Office Security Guards Reach Union Accord
text: The Service Employees International Union has been very successful in unionizing tens of thousands of janitors and doormen in New York City, and now it has set its sights on unionizing — and winning improved wages and benefits for — tens of thousands of security guards in the city. On Wednesday, one of the union’s giant New York locals, Local 32BJ, announced an important step toward that goal, saying that it had reached a tentative four-year contract covering 1,500 security guards in scores of office buildings in Manhattan, including Rockefeller Center.

headline: MTV Wants Its Political Ads
text: MTV has never accepted political candidate advertising. But that’s about to change.

headline: Turks and Germans Trading Screams
text: It is difficult to script a better “everyone wins” game for the mixed Turkish-German population with divided loyalties.

headline: Final Score: Germany 3-2 Turkey
text: Duncan Irving was online providing commentary and fostering discussion of the Euro 2008 semifinal between Germany and Turkey, two teams with a sporting rivalry rooted in the two countries’ intertwined cultural experiences. As many of you also watching on ESPN noticed, the feed from Basel provided some difficulties during the match. Read the recap below.

headline: Big Coal Fires Back Over James Hansen’s Criminal Complaint
text: PHOTO REMOVED (see updates below).

headline: The Wait at CSX
text: CSX‘s announcement that it will take a full month to announce the outcome of its election is a bit cheeky to say the least. CSX is incorporated in Virginia, and Section 681 of the Virginia Stock Corporation Act allows an aggrieved shareholder to bring a suit for summary disposition with regard to any claim that the election of directors was mishandled.

headline: August A. Busch IV’s Diary Entry
text: What’s August A. Busch IV, the sixth-generation Busch to run St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch, to do, now that foreigners have come to take his company over? Wall Street Journal columnist Holman Jenkins Jr. delved into the mind of this former bad boy turned chief executive in his Business World column.

headline: MTV Wants Its Political Ads
text: MTV has never accepted political candidate advertising. But that’s about to change.

headline: Men’s Fashion | Aristocrat Fetishism
text: The Italian aristocrat Lapo Elkan at the Pitti Uomo men’s fashion shows in Florence.

headline: ‘Self-Select’ Security Lines Come to La Guardia
text: The Transportation Security Administration introduced a new screening system at La Guardia Airport on Wednesday that tries to speed things up — and reduce anxiety and frustration — by asking travelers to choose a line based on their familiarity with checkpoint procedures.

headline: Income Tax Break for Peace Corps Worker
text: I recently heard about a change in the law that helps a member of the Peace Corps serving outside the United States to qualify for the capital gains tax exclusion on the sale of a principal residence. Can you explain this?

headline: Insider Prices in a Conversion
text: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Brooklyn, and rumor has it that the building is going to be converted to a co-op or condo. Is it the landlord’s choice whether to offer me an insider price? There is no way I would be able to afford market-rate prices.

headline: Get Ready for the Persuasion Army …
text: Or at least grow accustomed to the use of the term. Senator Barack Obama’s campaign manager used that term or similar phraseology several times today as he outlined for journalists a bit of the campaign’s general election strategy.

headline: The Reverend McCain
text: In an essay on The Times Op-Ed page in March, the writer Neal Gabler suggested that the reason John McCain has enjoyed excellent relations with the press is that they are birds of a feather. According to Mr. Gabler, Mr. McCain is “an ironist wooing a group of individuals who regard ironic detachment more highly than sincerity or seriousness.”

text:
Ben Smith of The Politico, left, and Matt Cooper of Portfolio discuss Barack Obama's rejection of public financing.

headline: Yahoo to Shareholders: Google Is Better for Us Than Microsoft
text: In a new letter to its shareholders on Wednesday, Yahoo once again explained why a search advertising deal between Yahoo and Google is far superior to an alternate proposal that Microsoft had made to buy Yahoo’s search business.

headline: We Get Mail
text: Here at the Book Review, we get a ton of mail.
