headline: The Petro-Manipulators
text: Anyone who lived on the West Coast during the phony energy crisis of 2000 and 2001 cannot help thinking of Texas and two of its worst products — Enron and a politician not named George Bush — as gas creeps up toward $5 a gallon this summer.

headline: The Petro-Manipulators
text: Anyone who lived on the West Coast during the phony energy crisis of 2000 and 2001 cannot help thinking of Texas and two of its worst products — Enron and a politician not named George Bush — as gas creeps up toward $5 a gallon this summer.   What happened during the great energy heist at the start of the new century was like an extended bad dream, part "Twilight Zone" and part "Chinatown," the extraordinary 1974 film about water manipulation and long-buried secrets.   The price of energy spiked — tenfold, a hundredfold — despite low demand. Californians became the most efficient users of power in the nation, and still suffered through dozens of rolling blackouts. None of it added up.   And into the worst energy crisis since the Arab oil embargo of 1973 came Vice President Dick Cheney, blasting conservation as a sissy virtue and saying the nation needed to build a new power plant every week for the next 20 years.   The administration's neglect was breathtaking, a harbinger of what was to come when a natural disaster, Hurricane Katrina, would do to Louisiana what a man-made disaster had done to California. We now know, of course, that the problem eight years ago was caused by manipulation by Enron and other speculators who gamed a faulty system, sticking it to Grandma Millie while laughing at how easy it was to rob 40 million people.   Now consider the present dilemma: oil doubling over the last year, gas at $4.50 a gallon in places and the oversized influence of speculators in a market where few used to tread. Big investors are free to run up oil futures contracts thanks in part to former Senator Phil Gramm. He is the Texas Republican who co-sponsored the so-called Enron loophole in 2000 at the behest of what was later found to be one of the nation's biggest criminal enterprises.   Enron may be gone, but its legacy lingers in the work done by politicians who did its bidding. And Gramm, who once told corporate contributors, "I have the most reliable friend you can have in American politics, and that's ready money," is now the chief economic adviser to Senator John McCain.   Gramm's role in helping to unleash energy speculators has been well-documented in recent months, and Senator Barack Obama has made an issue of it. Both Obama and McCain have called for closing the loophole. But just how big a role that kind of global gambling plays in the overheated commodities market is only now coming to light.   Testifying before the Senate on Wednesday, the ever-knowledgeable Daniel Yergin blamed speculation for part of the run-up. Yergin, an author and the chairman of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, pointed to numerous other causes, as have other experts.  But he also noted that 2007 may have been the peak year for oil demand in the United States. In other words, the world's largest energy consumer has reached the height of its gluttony, and will be using less oil from here on out.   Keep that in mind when thinking of the parallel to California. Less demand from the biggest consumer, yet record high prices. Why? Yes, tight supply during the end stages of the 200-year reign of fossil fuels, higher use by China and India, and global troubles all contribute to the bloat of oil prices.   But market manipulation seems obvious.  Over the last five years, investment in index funds tied to commodities like energy and food has gone from $13 billion to $260 billion. At the same time, the prices of those commodities have risen 200 percent.   Take away the excess speculators who are in the market purely for the ride, and oil prices could drop by half. That's the view of Michael W. Masters, a hedge fund manager who's been advising Congress this year.   "There are no lines at the gas pumps and there is plenty of food on the shelves," said Masters, whose testimony has been widely discussed in financial circles but rarely in the political realm. What has changed, he said, is the presence of big speculators making futures bets.  "If Wall Street concocted a scheme whereby investors bought large amounts of pharmaceutical drugs and medical devices in order to profit from the resulting increase in price, making these essential items unaffordable to sick and dying people, society would be justly outraged," he said.   This testimony came before a committee chaired by Senator Joseph Lieberman, the former Democratic vice presidential candidate who is now one of John McCain's biggest boosters. If you want to see the effects of McCain's top financial adviser, look no further than the hearing run by McCain's top ally in the Senate.   With five months to go, it looks like energy will dominate the presidential campaign. Nutty ideas will abound, from the gas tax holiday to $300 million prizes for wonder batteries.   And just as in California eight years ago, the oil industry's most devoted politicians will use this troubled time to advance a tired agenda – more drilling for the last of the nation's oil, in distant, fragile corners of the earth.   If nothing else, we should remember the lesson from that debacle: When something smells this bad, look for rotten fish as well.

headline: Citi Names a New Compliance Chief
text: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: A New Enemy: Overconfidence
text: 11 Days to L’Étape. Today’s training: another day off to recover from the rigors of the four-day slog through the Alps.

headline: Anheuser to Reject InBev Bid
text: Anheuser-Busch‘s board is planning to reject InBev unsolicited $46.4 billion takeover bid this week, people close to the company said. The move, which has been widely expected, will formally start what is likely to become a bitter fight that may even spill over to a political debate about the maker of Budweiser.

headline: Critics' Picks: Hunter S. Thompson
text: A. O. Scott discusses the documentary "Gonzo" and looks at the life and legacy of the writer Hunter S. Thompson.

headline: Critics' Picks: Hunter S. Thompson
text: A. O. Scott discusses the documentary "Gonzo" and looks at the life and legacy of the writer Hunter S. Thompson.

headline: Tax Refunds
text: Come in now or you'll wish you did later.

headline: Jackson Hewett
text: "Get more in return."

headline: From Campaign 2.0 to Governing 2.0
text: In her latest Web column, Katharine Q. Seelye writes that Web analysts are already looking beyond November at how to take the energy that goes into manipulating voters to win elections and convert it into listening to voters and being transparent, accountable and accessible. Go to column

headline: Jets’ Jenkins Is Charity Spokesman
text: In March, after the Jets traded for defensive tackle Kris Jenkins and signed him to a contract extension, we visited him near his off-season home in Washington.

headline: Obama Disagrees With Supreme Court Decision on Death Penalty
text: Senator Barack Obama told a press conference today that he disagreed with a Supreme Court decision outlawing the execution of child rapists.

headline: Your Comments on my Iraq Refugees Column
text: My Thursday column, the last from my Middle East swing, is about Iraqi refugees and their destabilizing influence in Jordan in particular. While there aren’t any ideal solutions for Iraq itself (although I continue to favor a phased withdrawal), it’s clear what we need to do for the refugees: Make sure that they get educated and don’t form a long-term volatile diaspora that causes upheavals for decades to come.

headline: Memo to Mets’ Reporters: Be on Time For Manuel
text: Manager Jerry Manuel prefers to be on the field with the Mets during batting practice, so he wants to do his pregame interview with the news media at 3:40 p.m. That is three and a half hours before 7:10 games, which is the precise time reporters are allowed into the clubhouse. Joe Girardi of the Yankees also likes to observe batting practice and usually talks to the media about three hours before the first pitch.

headline: A Genetic Quest for Better Chocolate
text: (UPDATED 6/26/08 10:33 a.m.| Corrected reference to cocoa trees’ lack of presence in the United States. They do grow in Hawaii.)

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: United We Campaign
text: Unity has spread through the Clinton offices where formerly fierce political operatives have taken on the aura of a particularly mellow religious cult. Hillary has been saying that her supporters are moving through the five stages of grief. But she herself seems to have invented some brand-new sixth stage of chipper serenity.

headline: Chacon, a Former Yankee, Attacks Astros General Manager
text: I can’t remember a day with more ex-Yankees in the transactions column. Some of the items make you smile, like the news that the all-time good guy Andy Phillips is staying in the big leagues with the Mets. Some make you cringe, like the news that Scott Proctor, Joe Torre’s favorite ironman reliever, is finally going on the disabled list with an elbow injury.

headline: Outside the Big Loop
text: Central Park’s 843 acres provide runners with nearly limitless options. “So why in the name of Frederick Law Olmsted do so many choose to run in circles on the 6.1-mile asphalt road looping the park?” Liz Robbins writes in The Times today. “Because runners are creatures of habit. The workout is the thing, peace often found in the rhythm of repetition and the exploration of personal limits, rather than the surrounding natural space. Efficiency is of utmost concern.”

headline: Homeless Pets Crowd Shelters as Families Hit Hard Times
text: ATLANTA  “Desperate Pets!” read the headline of an online classified ad posted from Lee County, Fla., which is ranked first in the nation in home foreclosures.

headline: Justices Bar Death Penalty for the Rape of a Child
text: WASHINGTON  The death penalty is unconstitutional as a punishment for the rape of a child, a sharply divided Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Some Postproduction Pizazz for the Digital Video Artist
text: Giving your digital movie the feel of opening credits in a 1970s action movie is now a drag-and-drop affair with Pinnacle Studio 12, the latest version of the video-editing software.

headline: And the Judgment Is...
text: How long will you give your team’s new draft pick before deciding that he’s a boon or a bust?

headline: For Iraqi Christians, Money Bought Survival
text: MOSUL, Iraq  As priests do everywhere, Archbishop Paulos Faraj Rahho, the leader of the Chaldean Catholics in this ancient city, gathered alms at Sunday Mass. But for years the money, a crumpled pile of multicolored Iraqi dinars, went into an envelope and then into the hand of a man who had threatened to kill him and his entire congregation.

headline: A Spate of Ads Gives Vent to That Howard Beale Feeling
text: IN the age of $5-a-gallon gas, $15 baggage fees on airlines and toxic tomatoes, plenty of people probably feel ready to stick their head out the window and yell, “I’m mad as hell and I’m not going to take it anymore.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about research into whether a passage in the “Odyssey” was a reference to a real solar eclipse misstated the time it took in the epic for Odysseus to return home from the Trojan War. It was 10 years, not 19.

headline: Corrections
text: Front Page

headline: Thai Leader Under Fire Before Confidence Vote
text: BANGKOK  With his coalition still intact, the Thai prime minister, Samak Sundaravej, appeared set to prevail over Thailand’s emboldened political opposition in a confidence vote this week. But accusations that his five-month-old government bowed to Cambodia in a territorial dispute have weakened the government and stoked nationalist sentiment.

headline: Hermitage Says to Turn It Down
text: Ears aren’t the only items that may suffer from blaring rock music. The preliminary results of a Russian study by scientists at the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg found that rock concerts by the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney and others in the adjacent Winter Square have affected their collections over the past three years, The Independent of London reported. The research, now being examined by the Grabar Art Restoration Institute in Moscow, showed that every 10 concerts above 82 decibels added an extra year to the age of a work because of vibrations. After a 2004 McCartney concert shook the windows of the Hermitage, the museum asked the Stones last year to keep the sound level below 85 decibels to protect works by the likes of Cézanne and Matisse in the palace’s nearby wings.

headline: A Hedge Fund Struggle for CSX Is Left in Limbo
text: NEW ORLEANS  A battle over the future of one of the nation’s largest railroads was joined here Wednesday in a rail yard on the outskirts of town.

headline: Man Who Killed Five People in Kentucky Had Called Girlfriend Before Shooting
text: HENDERSON, Ky.  A man who killed five people and himself at a plastics plant here early Wednesday morning called his girlfriend about two hours earlier and told her he was going to kill his supervisor, police officials said Wednesday.

headline: Anger and Restraint
text: For the law to be just, it must temper society’s anger over even the most horrible acts with decency and restraint. The Supreme Court exemplified that principle on Wednesday, striking down the death penalty for the rape of a child. While acknowledging the horror of the crime, Justice Anthony Kennedy’s majority opinion drew on widely shared standards of decency, constitutional law and real-world impact to explain why the Constitution forbids punishing it with death.

headline: The Pros Tackle Madden
text: Marshall Faulk hasn’t let retirement stop him from playing with his hometown New Orleans Saints. And free agent quarterback Daunte Culpepper says he’s throwing long with the Dallas Cowboys. Something tells me that’s not exactly what Wade Philips and Tony Romo have in mind for next season.

headline: Kanye Blogs Back
text: When Kanye West, right, decided to move his 8:15 p.m. appearance to 4:30 the following morning at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., last week because he wanted it dark enough for his light show, audience members were understandably upset, and they let him know it by booing, waving makeshift signs (“Kanye hates hippies!”) and scrawling anti-West graffiti. The criticism continued on the Internet. Now Mr. West has hit back on his own blog. “This Bonnaroo thing is the worst insult I’ve ever had in my life,” he wrote on his Web site, kanyeuniversecity.com. “This is the most offended I’ve ever been ... this is the maddest I ever will be.” He continued, “Call me any name you want ... arrogant, conceited, narcissistic, racist,” adding, “BUT NEVER SAY I DIDN’T GIVE MY ALL!”

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the first visit to China by a Japanese warship since World War II misidentified the warship’s port of call. It was Zhanjiang, a naval base in southern Guangdong province, not Shanghai.

headline: In Battle for Vienna: Soccer 1, Culture 0
text: VIENNA  In Europe now nothing  not rising oil prices; certainly not the recent visit of the departing President Bush; not even, for the moment, Carla Sarkozy  occupies more attention than Euro 2008. The continent’s quadrennial soccer championship, hosted this year by Switzerland and Austria, ends on Sunday here. For the city’s cultural institutions, after a month of matches leading up to it, the final won’t come a minute too soon.

headline: Another W.T.O. Push for a New Trade Deal
text: BRUSSELS  Pascal Lamy, the director general of the World Trade Organization, has called a week-long meeting of ministers next month aimed at reaching a breakthrough deal on liberalizing global trade, officials and diplomats said Wednesday.

headline: Hospital’s True Traumas, for Patients and Doctors
text: Johns Hopkins is the place to go for a liver transplant, a gunshot wound or separating twins conjoined at the head.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Tuesday about the time that the comedian George Carlin, who died on Sunday, spent at Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx included an erroneous year from school officials for the graduating class he entered with (he did not graduate from Hayes, however). It was 1955, not 1954.

headline: Olmert in Deal to Avoid Early Vote
text: JERUSALEM  The embattled prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, agreed Wednesday to hold a leadership vote in his centrist Kadima Party by late September, averting an imminent political crisis for his governing coalition but also paving the way for his possible ouster before the end of the year.

headline: A Fine Piece of Editing in Cooperstown
text: When Jackie Robinson was on the Hall of Fame ballot in 1962, he requested that the voters among the Baseball Writers Association of America judge him only as a player. He didn’t want his social significance as the modern major leagues’ first black player to be considered. Vote for him  or don’t vote for him  on his merits as a player, as all the other Hall of Famers from Babe Ruth and Cy Young had been measured.

headline: I’ll Take the Shiny One With Bang!
text: IT was panting-hot the day I shopped for guns, so I ran into Nello, a sidewalk cafe on Madison, for a bottle of sparkling water. The thick cylinder of glass gave me an inkling I was about to get soaked, but even preclenched, I was unprepared for the bill to be $18.

headline: 160 Arrested in Immigration Raid at a Houston Plant
text: HOUSTON  Federal immigration agents arrested 160 employees on Wednesday in a raid on a used clothing and rag exporting plant.

headline: An East Village Shop Opens a Provincetown Outpost
text: John Derian, the designer who made découpage stylish, didn’t plan to open a store in Provincetown, Mass. “I hadn’t been here in years, came to visit a friend, happened upon the house and fell in love,” he explained. The object of Mr. Derian’s affection was a 1789 sea captain’s house. He bought it last year and put a smaller version of his East Village shop in the gray-shingled carriage house just behind it.

headline: New Job for CBS Reporter Critical of War Coverage
text: Lara Logan, the CBS News chief foreign correspondent who deplored the lack of media coverage of Iraq and Afghanistan last week, will no longer be based overseas, the network said on Wednesday.

headline: Now at La Guardia: Self-Sorting Security
text: The Transportation Security Administration introduced a new screening system at La Guardia Airport on Wednesday that tries to speed things up  and reduce anxiety and frustration  by asking travelers to choose a line based on their familiarity with checkpoint procedures.

headline: The President, Right or Wrong?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some ‘Camp Rock,’ Some ‘Enchanted,’ Lots of Avril
text: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  During the 3 days, 22 hours and 33 minutes between the conclusion of the premiere of “Camp Rock,” the latest Disney TV-movie juggernaut, and the beginning of Demi Lovato’s set at the Crazy Donkey here on Tuesday night, something overwhelming happened: This disarming 15-year-old singer-actress became a name brand.

headline: NBC Settles With Family That Blamed a TV Investigation for a Man’s Suicide
text: NBC has settled a lawsuit filed by the family of a man who killed himself when confronted with cameras for the documentary series “To Catch a Predator.”

headline: The Betsy Ross Label
text: BETWEEN the Olympic Games and the election, not to mention the Fourth of July, you could argue that a heightened sense of patriotism has made fashion designers go flag happy.

headline: Strong Sales of Software Lift Oracle’s Net Income
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Oracle sounded a warning bell that growth was likely to slow in the first quarter as the company absorbed its latest major acquisition, BEA Systems.

headline: Apartment Fire Leaves 1 Dead in Midtown
text: An apartment fire in Midtown Manhattan left an 83-year-old man dead on Wednesday evening, officials said.

headline: A Spanish-Modern Mashup in Los Angeles
text: WHEN it comes to architecture, Los Angeles can sometimes seem like a battlefield of styles. Mixed into the mishmash of nondescript buildings that dominate the city are a large number of houses with distinct characters and little apparent interest in getting along  in particular the bright white Spanish-style villas that overtook the town early last century, and the earnest early Modernist boxes that followed a decade or so later. These two domestic forms have been dueling it out for nearly a century.

headline: Activists Warned on Olympic Protests
text: SHANGHAI  In the latest sign of efforts to prevent dissent during the Beijing Olympics, political activists in Shanghai say they have been warned against expressing their opinions, speaking with foreigners or visiting Beijing until after the Games.

headline: Brooklyn Blog Helps Lead to Drug Raid
text: Most neighborhoods in Brooklyn have at least one blog  and in some places, there seems to be one in every house, every bedroom  but not many read like BayRidgeTalk.com, where the subjects over the last year or two veered away from apartment sales and plumbing tips and block parties and sounded more like rat-a-tat police reports.

headline: Another Anchor Fired
text: Six months ago KYW-TV, the CBS affiliate in Philadelphia, fired its newscaster Alycia Lane, above with her former co-anchor, Larry Mendte, after she was arrested for reportedly hitting a New York City police officer. Now the station has dismissed Mr. Mendte, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The F.B.I. has been investigating Mr. Mendte, seizing his computer to determine if he illegally broke into Ms. Lane’s e-mail account and forwarded its contents to news organizations. A statement from KYW said that Mr. Mendte’s termination “was based on an independent investigation conducted by CBS.”

headline: Why Obama Should Visit a Mosque
text: ISTANBUL

headline: Mississippi’s Misplaced Priorities
text: Congress is finally asking hard questions about Mississippi’s handling of $5 billion in emergency federal aid that was supposed to help victims of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: A Hedge Fund and Its Nonprofit Twin
text: Christopher Cooper-Hohn and his wife, Jamie, follow a simple economic formula: he makes money, and she gives it away.

headline: State Bill Expands Pool of Possible 9/11 Benefit Recipients
text: Even as New York City battles thousands of ground zero workers over their health claims in federal court, New York State is making more workers eligible for health care benefits.

headline: Zimbabweans Make Plea for Help as Runoff Nears
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe  As Zimbabwe’s neighbors urged it to postpone this week’s presidential runoff, hundreds of beaten, newly homeless Zimbabweans gathered Wednesday outside the South African Embassy here in a desperate bid for help during the electoral crisis.

headline: Snuggling Up to the Bundlers
text: In his self-serving retreat from the spending restraints of public financing, Senator Barack Obama hailed his formidable Internet army of small donors as “a new kind of politics.” Maybe so. But just in case, the senator is not about to neglect the old politics of special-interest money bundlers in his presidential campaign.

headline: New York Grit, With Flat-Screen TVs
text: The red brick building at 113 Jane Street in the West Village, with its lighthouselike corner tower and storied history (it sheltered the surviving crew of the Titanic), is about to get a new life  in stages.

headline: A Warehouse Sale for Italian Luxury Linens
text: Nancy Koltes at Home, a company that sells Italian cotton bed and bath linens, will have its first warehouse sale starting July 10. Selected items, reduced 25 to 80 percent, include Dot Embroidery shams (about $50, marked down from $68), left, and duvets ($130 in full/queen size, reduced from $175); Hotel sheet sets ($150 in queen size, marked down from $300); and Ikebana bath sheets with floral embroidery ($69, reduced from $138). Through Aug. 10 at Nancy Koltes at Home, 31 Spring Street (Mott Street), (212) 219-2271 or nancykoltesathome.com.

headline: Correction
text: A brief report in the Currents column last Thursday about a new line of furniture from Hida Sangyo, a Japanese company, misstated the name and price of the chair pictured. It is called Piave, not Po, and it sells for $870, not $770.

headline: Running Into the Past
text: PORTLAND - Twenty-eight years ago, when the United States Olympic track and field trials were last held at Hayward Field on the University of Oregon campus in Eugene, earning one of the three slots on the American team was the equivalent of a mayoral candidate in Baltimore winning the Democratic primary. Just as the victorious politician was a shoo-in in the general election, the winning athlete had already proved herself among the best in the world. Now that the trials have returned to Eugene, by contrast, America has long since ceded domination of distance running to the Africans. And in events where American athletes still flourish -- the sprints and jumps -- doping has all but destroyed public confidence. In 2008, most elite American track-and-field performers are thrilled to get to the point where they’re suspected of juicing.

headline: Sorenstam Welcomes All Aboard at the Open
text: EDINA, Minn.  Finding Annika Sorenstam on the back nine at Interlachen Country Club is a snap. Just look for the largest crowd.

headline: Impasse in India on Nuclear Pact With the U.S.
text: NEW DELHI  India’s governing party and its communist allies failed again to agree on the terms of a nuclear agreement with the United States on Wednesday, dimming prospects for the deal.

headline: Sacred Songs Sell, Drawing Attention to Their Source
text: HEILIGENKREUZ, Austria  As noon draws near, the monks glide into the church, their white cowls billowing behind them. They line up in silence, facing each other in long choir stalls. Wood carvings of saints peer down on them from the austere Romanesque nave.

headline: Down With Helvetica: Design Your Own Font
text: WHEN Spike Gjerde started to build a new restaurant in an old mill in Baltimore, he did not want a slick menu with crisp, perfect letters. “We’re all totally about salvage and reuse,” he said. The menu had to reflect the restaurant’s goal: presenting local ingredients in a rough-hewn complex that once cast the 36-inch-wide columns that support the dome of the United States Capitol.

headline: For One Night in Central Park, Two Orchestras for the Price of None
text: The Metropolitan Opera may have dropped its commitment to presenting a concert tour of parks throughout the boroughs of New York this summer. But not the New York Philharmonic, which began its 43rd season of these popular free programs with a concert on Tuesday night on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

headline: Huge Meteor Strike Explains Mars’s Shape, Reports Say
text: The lopsided shape of Mars may well be a result of a cataclysmic impact of a Pluto-size meteor billions of years ago, three teams of scientists are reporting. That would suggest that the lowlands of Mars’s northern hemisphere are a single gigantic impact crater, the largest crater in the solar system.

headline: Fed Shifts Its Concern to Inflation
text: The Federal Reserve’s policy makers ratcheted up their worries about inflation on Wednesday without abandoning their view that the American economy is weak.

headline: Taking Lessons, and Confidence, From the Water
text: She had rowed a boat, in the East River. She had learned to swim. She had eaten an oyster; it was gross, yes, but it was a challenge, and she had met that challenge. And now, in a final rite of passage, she was at the helm of the Lettie G. Howard, the historic 125-foot schooner that is her school’s classroom-on-the-Hudson.

headline: Suggested Read: The Rookie Life
text: It’ll be years before we can declare with full-throated authority the winners and losers of tonight’s draft, yet one thing is already certain: the lives of the lottery picks will change fully and immediately. Basketball executives can only hope that their draft pick manages the transition as well as Amare Stoudemire, whose background didn’t exactly portend smooth sailing. Stoudemire entered the 2002 draft straight out of high school (he attended a handful of them) and with a mom who had been in and out of jail.

headline: In Milan, All Masculinity, No Pretense
text: MILAN

headline: The Ball Bounces Ivanovic’s Way
text: WIMBLEDON, England  It has been a heady month for Ana Ivanovic, who rose to No. 1 and won her first Grand Slam singles title at the French Open. But an unseeded Frenchwoman, Nathalie Dechy, came within an inch or two of ruining Ivanovic’s Wimbledon on Wednesday before the Serbian star prevailed, 6-7 (2), 7-6 (3), 10-8.

headline: Gene Testing Questioned by Regulators
text: Regulators are cracking down on companies that sell genetic tests directly to consumers, threatening to crimp the growth of one of the hottest sectors of the biotechnology industry.

headline: Push in Bronx for H.I.V. Test for All
text: The New York City health department plans to announce on Thursday an ambitious three-year effort to give an H.I.V. test to every adult living in the Bronx, which has a far higher death rate from AIDS than any other borough. The campaign will begin with a push to make the voluntary testing routine in emergency rooms and storefront clinics, where city officials say that cumbersome consent procedures required by state law have deterred doctors from offering the tests.

headline: Corrections
text: A bibliographical note on Wednesday with the Books of The Times review, about a translation of Albert Camus’s notebooks, misstated part of the title and the years the notebooks cover. The title is “Notebooks 1951-1959,” not 1951-58.

headline: Afghans See Pakistan Role in Karzai Plot
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government for the first time publicly accused the Pakistani intelligence service on Wednesday of organizing the failed plot to assassinate President Hamid Karzai at a parade in Kabul in April.

headline: Coming Soon to YouTube: My Face-Lift
text: LAST September, Michelle Wilder left Dr. Emil W. Chynn of Park Avenue Laser armed with the usual postoperative fare: eyedrops, sunglasses and a pair of prescription-free contact lenses. And oh, yes: a DVD of her Lasek surgery, so she could experience from the confines of her own home the joy of watching the doctor scrape her eyeballs.

headline: Safin Ousts Third-Seeded Djokovic
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Did Marat Safin really once hate grass-court tennis with all his Russian soul?

headline: A Forecast of Violence in a Neighbor of Chechnya
text: MOSCOW  Though violence in Chechnya has decreased markedly in recent years, fighting between Muslim insurgents and Russian troops threatens to engulf a neighboring region, a human rights group said in a report released Wednesday.

headline: Colorful and Well Connected, a Laptop That Stands Out
text: It’s summer, so why shouldn’t one’s laptop match one’s hot-pink bikini? Dell’s Studio line comes in seven colors and offers some impressive computing power inside.

headline: Provence in a Plant: Just Inhale
text: AN herb that smells as good as lavender simply has to be grown, even though it’s not a native plant. I feel a little guilty saying this, because lately I have been so vigilant about planting natives, to feed the insects and birds that evolved with them. But lavender, which hails from the Mediterranean  as do oregano, bay, thyme, rosemary and so many other herbs  is one of those fragrant plants that settle in your soul.

headline: United We Campaign
text: Hillary Clinton is so united!

headline: City Unveils Final Plan on First Slice of the High Line
text: City officials and the Friends of the High Line presented the final design on Wednesday for the first phase of the High Line, the $170 million park that is under construction on the West Side of Manhattan and has been called one of New York City’s more distinctive public projects.

headline: Hundreds Seized in Sweep Against Child Prostitution
text: Twenty-one sexually exploited children have been saved from the streets, and 389 people arrested on charges of trafficking children for prostitution, in what the Federal Bureau of Investigation calls the largest such multistate sweep ever, officials said Wednesday.

headline: The Right Mulch for Any Occasion
text: Q. I want to add mulch to my flower beds, but I’m confused by all the choices. What kind is best?

headline: Exploring What Lies Beyond Manifest Destiny
text: Confined at its birth to the area east of the Mississippi River, by 1867 the United States reached all the way to the Bering Strait. Never has a nation grown so large so quickly.

headline: Home and Garden Advice, and a Little Music Besides
text: While Amazon’s Kindle seems to have grabbed the most attention lately, there are plenty of electronic book readers out there that are worth a quick look  or read.

headline: Much Left Undone, Again, as Session Ends in Albany
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson took one more chance this week to distance himself from the strategy of his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, the man he ran alongside nearly two years ago.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about “The Shack,” a Christian-themed novel by William P. Young that has become a surprise best seller, misidentified a Web site of the publisher, Windblown Media, where the book can be purchased. It is theshackbook.com.

headline: Hollywood Braces for an Actors’ Strike
text: LOS ANGELES  Labor unrest continues to dominate the landscape in Hollywood, and the possibility of a strike by actors has large movie studios planning to shut down production after Monday and has television studios rushing to complete episodes of series scheduled to return in the fall or January.

headline: Donaghy Is Not Responsible for Costs of N.B.A.’s Inquiry
text: A federal judge said Wednesday that the disgraced referee Tim Donaghy will most likely not have to reimburse the N.B.A. for the cost of its internal investigation into betting by referees.

headline: Hoboken, an Economic Success That Can’t Pass a Budget
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Europe Plans New Push to Cut Mobile Charges
text: BERLIN  The European Commission, having capped roaming fees on international mobile phone calls, plans a new move to lower cellphone charges that could result in even greater savings for European consumers.

headline: Girl Gone Wild, Idaho Style
text: MaryJane Butters (born Mary Jane) was once a single mother of two and a forest ranger, among other tough jobs. She is now an organic farmer, a grandmother and an activist, living on a farm in Northern Idaho.

headline: Mind the Gap: A Button Too Far
text: GOLDILOCKS had nothing on Tommy Fazio.

headline: Low Maintenance, and It’s a Bargain
text: When Jeremy Cole, a London designer, was last interviewed in this section, he had just introduced a gold version of his Aloe lamps, which ranged in price from $4,430 to $37,500.

headline: Rhythm in His Hips, Technology on His Mind
text: Gilberto Gil’s show at the Nokia Theater on Tuesday night started with his band’s arrangement of the famous Nokia cellphone ring tone. If corporate mediation of cultural events puts you on edge, hearing that particular melody in that particular place might make you especially nervous.

headline: Obama and Clinton in Talks to Unify Party
text: WASHINGTON  With the help of one of Washington’s best-connected lawyers, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are negotiating a thicket of complicated issues, like how to repay Mrs. Clinton’s campaign debt and her role at the Democratic convention. The talks come as they try to leave behind their intense rivalry and work out a plan to cooperate this fall.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Doctors Document the Horror
text: To the Editor:

headline: Not Just Another Jelly Bean
text: Easter may be long gone, but the Jelly Belly Candy Company is still producing jelly beans, 300,000 pounds a day.

headline: Manager Moves on After Ejection
text: A day after being ejected from Tuesday’s game by the home plate umpire, Brian Runge, during a dispute about balls and strikes, Jerry Manuel said he was not carrying any grudges.

headline: Suit Claims a Warhol Is Not, Well, a Warhol
text: The title, “315 Johns,” sounds less like the name of an artwork than a headline describing a prostitution bust. But in the second volume of the catalogue raisonné enumerating the works of Andy Warhol, it is listed as a 1967 Warhol creation: a series of silk-screens made from a photograph of the artist John Chamberlain and arranged in a heroic grid.

headline: Close by: Another World
text: The Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park has seen better days. Erected in 1923 by the philanthropist Elkan Naumburg, who had presented free symphonic concerts in the park since 1905, the handsome limestone structure has fallen into neglect. After repairing the half-dome roof in 2005, the Parks Department has gone no further to restore this once vital landmark to its former elegance.

headline: Anheuser to Reject InBev Offer
text: The board of Anheuser-Busch is planning to reject this week an unsolicited $46.4 billion takeover bid from InBev, a rival brewery based in Belgium, people close to the American company said on Wednesday.

headline: Correction: An Olympic Cyclist’s Levelheaded Advice
text: An article last Thursday about training advice from Christian Vande Velde, an Olympic cyclist, referred incorrectly to the technique he uses during five-minute sequences in which he tries to push his pedals as hard as possible while the wheels turn slowly. He drops into what is known as a big gear, not a low gear.

headline: Lincoln Trove to Move
text: One of the largest museums dedicated to Abraham Lincoln is closing its doors on Monday and giving away its $20 million collection, The Civil War News reported. The Lincoln Museum collection in Fort Wayne, Ind., includes more than 18,000 books and pamphlets; 7,000 prints; 5,000 photographs; 350 documents signed by Lincoln, including one of 13 copies of the 13th Amendment he signed; and thousands of newspaper clippings and Lincoln-related items. The Lincoln Financial Foundation, which runs the museums, intends to donate the collection “to one or more of the nation’s major nonprofit institutions specializing in Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War,” and to digitize documents to make them more accessible for next year’s Lincoln Bicentennial, a spokesman said. The Library of Congress, the National Museum of American History, Ford’s Theater and President Lincoln’s Cottage have formed a partnership to try to buy the collection, The Washington Post reported.

headline: Ex-Big Board Chairman Wins Round in Pay Fight
text: On Wall Street, there are stars that fade and stars that fight. Richard A. Grasso is one of the latter.

headline: Weighing New Candidates for Fossella’s House Seat
text: Following the death of their candidate for Congress, Republican leaders on Staten Island and in Brooklyn are turning their attention in earnest  once again  to finding potential candidates to run for the seat. And they say they will probably reach a decision by the weekend.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Say They Killed 28 Men From Peace Group
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The bodies of 28 members of a government-sponsored peace committee were found dumped on a road near the tribal area of South Waziristan on Wednesday, Pakistan officials said. The Pakistani Taliban said the men were killed because they supported the government, according to a Taliban statement made to a local journalist.

headline: Judge Rejects Bid to Let Police Check Immigration Status
text: LOS ANGELES  A Superior Court judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit seeking to end a longstanding police policy that prohibits officers from initiating contact with people for the sole purpose of learning their immigration status.

headline: Lehrer Back on Camera
text: Jim Lehrer plans to return to the anchor desk at “The NewsHour” on PBS on Thursday, after being absent since late April while recuperating from aortic valve replacement surgery. “The NewsHour” said Mr. Lehrer, 74, planned to anchor the nightly newscast two or three evenings a week before eventually returning to a full-time schedule. He is also planning to anchor PBS’s live coverage of the Democratic and Republican conventions later in the summer. Mr. Lehrer has been an anchor on “NewsHour” and its predecessor, “The MacNeil/Lehrer Report,” since 1975.

headline: N.B.A. Draft Puts Mayo in Customary Spotlight
text: O. J. Mayo has been a magnet for publicity and controversy since age 14, so it seems only natural that he is now a central figure in what may be the N.B.A.’s wildest draft night in years.

headline: The Spanish Connection: Dealing in Charm or Fire
text: The allusions flew fast and furious at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, as Ballet Biarritz performed two works by its director, Thierry Malandain. The company is the final feature of the French Collection festival, but — mon Dieu! — Mr. Malandain’s gaze is on Spain in both pieces.

headline: 8 Civilians Killed in 2 Disputed Attacks, Iraq Says
text: BAGHDAD  American soldiers fatally shot three Iraqi bank employees Wednesday as their car passed a convoy near Baghdad International Airport, according to an Interior Ministry official and Yarmouk Hospital, where the bodies were brought.

headline: More Delays for Cameras in Subways
text: Aging fiber-optic cable in Brooklyn and Queens has become the latest obstacle to a planned high-tech system of surveillance cameras meant to safeguard the subway and commuter railroads, according to Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials.

headline: Extra Work Pays Off for Manuel and Mets
text: Jerry Manuel, a week into his stint as the Mets’ interim manager, continued searching Wednesday for some trick, some ploy to snap his sluggish team out of its funk. Three hours before the Mets tried to keep the Seattle Mariners, the worst team in baseball, from sweeping them at home, he ordered his players to take stretching exercises as a team.

headline: New G.O.P. Leader Says Mayor Has Pledged Support
text: ALBANY  The State Legislature’s newly installed Republican leader said on Wednesday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would back the Republican Party’s efforts to defend its thin majority in the State Senate.

headline: Sentences Reduced for Adelphia Founder and Son
text: The prison sentences of John J. Rigas, the founder of Adelphia Communications, and his son Timothy were reduced by three years each on Tuesday after an appeals court overturned a count of bank fraud.

headline: In Pittsburgh, Posada Takes in All Things Clemente
text: PITTSBURGH  Jorge Posada is a five-time All-Star, but this week he is an awestruck fan. The Yankees are playing in Pittsburgh, where Roberto Clemente starred for the Pirates, and Clemente is a hero to Posada.

headline: Books, Not Bombs
text: AMMAN, Jordan

headline: Leonid Hurwicz, Nobel Economist, Dies at 90
text: Leonid Hurwicz, who shared the Nobel Prize in economics last year for his work on mechanism design theory, which helps explain the interaction among individuals, markets and institutions, died Tuesday. He was 90 and lived in Minneapolis.

headline: From Campaign 2.0 to Governing 2.0
text: Much has been made this year of how the presidential candidates have expanded their use of the Internet, particularly for raising money, organizing supporters and sharing videos.

headline: Profit Expands for BlackBerry Maker
text: OTTAWA  Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, said on Wednesday that its first quarter profit was more than double that of last year. But the result fell short of analysts’ estimates, causing the company’s shares to fall in after-hours trading.

headline: Soccer and N.B.A. Stars Play for Kicks and a Good Cause
text: Of course Baron Davis had played soccer before  he was in seventh grade at the time. And of course he had a game plan for Wednesday night’s pickup soccer match.

headline: Justices Cut Damages Award in Exxon Valdez Spill
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday reduced what had once been a $5 billion punitive damages award against ExxonMobil to about $500 million. The ruling essentially concluded a legal saga that started when the Exxon Valdez, a supertanker, struck a reef and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound in Alaska in 1989.

headline: At a Last Party, Real Estate Claims the Night
text: LAST week, a memorial of sorts was held in the former New York home of Pat and William F. Buckley Jr.

headline: When Your Camera Knows Where You Are
text: “Any sufficiently advanced memory card,” Arthur C. Clarke once didn’t write, “is indistinguishable from magic.”

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Death Penalty for Child Rape
text: WASHINGTON  The death penalty is unconstitutional as a punishment for the rape of a child, a sharply divided Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

headline: Lee Is Focus of Trade Talk by the Knicks
text: After early speculation that the Knicks might move up in Thursday’s draft, the latest indications are that the team is in discussions to move down.

headline: House Votes to Expand Civil Rights for Disabled
text: WASHINGTON  The House passed a major civil rights bill on Wednesday that would expand protections for people with disabilities and overturn several Supreme Court decisions issued in the last decade.

headline: In Alaska, Rage and Sorrow Over Decision
text: When the Exxon Valdez ran aground in 1989, Andrew Wills was a successful herring fisherman in Alaska and the owner of three canneries.

headline: Turkey Scores Late Again, but Not Late Enough
text: BASEL, Switzerland  This time, when it counted most, Turkey made its late comeback a little too early.

headline: Castillo’s Contract Looms Over Mets
text: The $25 million second baseman, Luis Castillo, has the tools of his trade sitting on a chair in front of his Mets’ locker. There is a jar of heating ointment, an Ace bandage, a roll of black tape, a roll of white tape and a pair of surgical gloves. Castillo uses those materials to treat and wrap his injured left leg.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on May 20 about the arrest of a foster mother in Harlem accused of accidentally killing a 6-year-old girl by placing a fentanyl pain patch on her neck referred incompletely to the basis for determining dosage and referred incorrectly to fentanyl’s effect on respiratory function. Along with the patient’s weight, the dosage is generally based on his or her tolerance to opiates and body fat content. Slowed breathing is a side effect of the drug, not the mechanism by which it relieves pain. This correction was delayed for research.

headline: Dancer on the Block
text: When the Impressionist and modern art auctions continued in London on Wednesday night at Sotheby’s, it was a far more modest affair than Christie’s blockbuster auction the previous evening, which saw a record price of $80.4 million for one of Monet’s late waterlilies. Of the 55 works offered Wednesday, the standout was probably “Dancer,” right, a 1915 painting by Gino Severini. Four telephone bidders vied for the painting, and it ended up selling to one for $29.6 million, far above the high estimate of $19.8 million and a record at auction for the artist. The previous record for a Severini, $3.6 million, was set in 1990 at Sotheby’s in New York for “Sea=Dancer.” The painting sold Wednesday dates from the end of Mr. Severini’s Futurist period and was later acquired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, where it hung from 1944 until 1988, when it was deaccessioned. An unidentified collector who had owned the painting ever since was the seller.

headline: Laptop Searches in Airports Draw Fire at Senate Hearing
text: WASHINGTON  Advocacy groups and some legal experts told Congress on Wednesday that it was unreasonable for federal officials to search the laptops of United States citizens when they re-enter the country from traveling abroad.

headline: Complaints Against New York Judges Reach a High, but Fewer Merit Investigations
text: A record number of complaints were filed against New York State judges in 2007, according to a report by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct. But the number of complaints that warranted a full investigation during that time was lower than it had been in a decade, the report said.

headline: Working Alone in a Group
text: MY book proposal was not writing itself. It was half-done, and the stack of research in the corner was growing tall enough to topple. Because it was the only project, among several, without a deadline, it always seemed to fall off the to-do list entirely.

headline: Sales of New Homes Decline a Fifth Time in Six Months
text: Sales of new homes fell again in May, the fifth decline in six months, as buyers stayed on the sidelines despite lower prices.

headline: Strong Economy and Labor Shortages Are Luring Polish Immigrants Back Home
text: WARSAW  For a long time, Germany has been good to Katarzyna, a 28-year-old Polish woman who works in a pharmacy in Frankfurt during the day and cleans houses in the evenings.

headline: MasterCard Will Pay $1.8 Billion to American Express
text: MasterCard Worldwide agreed on Wednesday to pay $1.8 billion to its credit card rival American Express to settle claims related to a 2004 antitrust lawsuit.

headline: Rain Heightens Worries Along the Mississippi
text: CLARKSVILLE, Mo.  A storm that federal forecasters had expected would quietly pass through here instead brought about six inches of rain in places along the Mississippi River overnight Tuesday, dashing expectations that the worst of the flooding was over.

headline: Acquittal in Case of Winehouse’s Husband
text: Blake Fielder-Civil, the husband of the singer Amy Winehouse, got into a barroom fight in 2006 and beat up a pub manager, James King. Though he has admitted he offered Mr. King $400,000 to keep quiet about the incident, a British court acquitted Mr. King on Wednesday of obstructing justice by taking a bribe, The Associated Press reported. Mr. King, who ended up with a broken cheekbone, said he had been intimidated into dropping assault charges. Mr. Fielder-Civil and three others face jail terms when they are sentenced.

headline: Nissan and Others Add Factories in Emerging Markets
text: ORAGADAM, India  On a dusty sun-baked field, in a ceremony presided over by a chanting Brahmin priest tossing water and rice, the Japanese carmaker Nissan Motor made a bold step into the Indian auto market.

headline: New iPod, New AV Cable
text: Q. I can’t select the TV Out menu option on my new iPod when I have it connected to my television with an iPod video cable. Is there some other setting I need to adjust so I can play videos from my iPod on the TV screen?

headline: Maryland: Mayor Speaks on Case
text: Mayor Sheila Dixon of Baltimore criticized state prosecutors and the news media in her first comments since acknowledging she had been in a relationship with a major developer whose projects she supported as City Council president. The news media have acted as “judge and jury,” even though she has not been charged, and the Office of the State Prosecutor has leaked information, Ms. Dixon said, but she is forbidden to respond publicly because of the two-year investigation into city spending practices. Ms. Dixon, a Democrat, issued a statement Monday confirming that she had been in a “personal relationship” in late 2003 and early 2004 with Ronald H. Lipscomb, a developer who owns Doracon Contracting. Prosecutors said they were investigating possible bribery, perjury and misconduct in office. The authorities raided Ms. Dixon’s home last week and seized numerous boxes, and a grand jury began hearing testimony this week.

headline: South Korea Lifts Ban on U.S. Beef
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea lifted an import ban on American beef on Thursday, despite an overnight protest in which thousands of people rallied in central Seoul to protest the government move and the police fired water cannons and detained at least 120 protesters.

headline: Study Shows Problems With Olympic-Style Tests
text: Athletes who want to cheat by injecting themselves with a performance-enhancing drug that boosts their blood cell count can do so with little risk of getting caught, a new study indicates, possibly exposing another flaw in what is regarded as the world’s toughest anti-doping program.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about Michael Shernoff, a gay psychotherapist who wrote widely on the emotional toll of AIDS on gay men, misstated the diagnosis he received in 1982. Although he wrote that he learned that year that he had tested positive for the human immunodeficiency virus, a virus was not established as the cause of AIDS until 1983, and the term H.I.V. did not come into use for a few more years. His precise diagnosis in 1982 remains unclear.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Tuesday about the comic actress Dody Goodman misspelled the surname of the host of “The Tonight Show” who had her as a regular guest. He was Jack Paar, not Parr.

headline: Applicant Checks May Dig Deep
text: BUYING a condo or co-op, or even renting an apartment, can be arduous, and most applicants understand that part of the process may involve being investigated by a board or a management company.

headline: On-Screen Forecast: Hazy
text: If it’s summer on network television, somebody is probably being humiliated.

headline: A Chance for the Everglades
text: The languishing effort to revive and restore the Everglades  one of the most ambitious environmental initiatives on the planet  received an unexpected and potentially spectacular boost on Tuesday when Gov. Charlie Crist announced that Florida had agreed in principle to buy 187,000 acres of farmland from the United States Sugar Corporation, the state’s (and the nation’s) largest sugar-cane producer.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about Jordan’s return of looted antiquities to Iraq misspelled the name of the ancient Assyrian city from which one of the most valuable pieces came. It was Nimrud, not Nimrod.

headline: Tip of the Week: Previewing Search Results
text: Sometimes in your Google search results it’s hard to tell from just the text link and description if the Web pages have the information you actually want. The Google Preview browser extension adds a small thumbnail image of each hit on your results page to help you see what you’re getting before you click the link. Versions are available for Firefox and Internet Explorer at www.googlepreview.com, and despite the name Google Preview also works with Yahoo search results.

headline: Filmmaker Says Distributor Failed Him
text: Alex Gibney, the director of this year’s Oscar-winning documentary “Taxi to the Dark Side,” has filed for arbitration, asserting that its box office prospects were undermined by the financial troubles of the film’s distributor, ThinkFilm.

headline: At Reisinger, a Tip on Defending in No-Trump
text: There are two premier events at the Edgar Kaplan Eastern States Regional in New York, and traditionally each takes up a share of the Memorial Day weekend. On Saturday and Sunday the Goldman Pairs is contested. On Monday the Reisinger Knockout Teams usually begins, running for the rest of the week. This year, though, because of the United States open team trial, the Reisinger was moved forward by a week.

headline: Ira Tucker, Gospel Singer Who Gave Dixie Hummingbirds Emotive Edge, Dies at 83
text: Ira Tucker, a little man with a giant vocal range and acrobatic stage antics who as lead singer of the Dixie Hummingbirds helped propel gospel music toward a harder-edged, more emotive style, died on Tuesday in Philadelphia. He was 83.

headline: Fight Terror With YouTube
text: Baku, Azerbaijan

headline: The Tyranny of the Heirloom
text: MELODIE BRYANT, a New York City composer, never wanted the portrait of her Uncle Ivins.

headline: Cellphone Filled With Features, Hidden Away
text: A Bluetooth phone headset frees up your hands  if you remember to bring it along. The LG Decoy may appeal to people who like to travel light, because the phone’s designers have built a detachable Bluetooth headset into the back of the phone so the earpiece is there when you need to make a hands-free call.

headline: Shopping for the Urban Gardener With Robin Simmen
text: ROBIN SIMMEN calls herself a guerrilla gardener. Even though she has lived in New York City, where backyards are the exception, for 29 years, she has always found a ledge or a stoop to use as an urban plot. “There’s nothing like being able to look out of your window at a garden,” she said, “even if you have no land.”

headline: Greece: Fire Ravages Athens Forest
text: A wildfire swept through the outskirts of Athens, burning one of the city’s last forests. Firefighters and soldiers, aided by tanker planes and helicopters, battled the wind-driven fire on Mount Hymettus, bringing it under control in about eight hours.

headline: Echoes of Bush’s ’04 Campaign in Sales Pitch for McCain
text: LIVONIA, Mich.  President Bush, offering a glimpse of the White House strategy for selling Senator John McCain to voters this fall, told a Republican crowd here on Wednesday that Mr. McCain, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, is the only candidate “who knows what it takes to defeat our enemies.”

headline: Barclays Bank Seeks $8.9 Billion Through a Share Issue
text: LONDON  Barclays joined rivals in tapping the wealth of Asian and Middle Eastern investors to strengthen its capital base on Wednesday, indicating that losses from the subprime mortgage turmoil in the United States still wear on European banks.

headline: Footnotes
text: Despite an outcry from some critics and Muslims, the novelist Salman Rushdie picked up his knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday. ... Jon Krakauer has withdrawn “The Hero,” his book about Pat Tillman, the former National Football League player killed in Afghanistan, because he is unhappy with the manuscript, Publishers Weekly reported. ... Derek Keeling and Ashley Spencer, finalists on the NBC audition series “You’re the One That I Want,” are joining the cast of “Grease” on Broadway in the lead roles of Danny and Sandy. Max Crumm and Laura Osnes, who won the competition, will play their final performances on July 20.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mother, It’s Too Elegant! And Other Lies to Protect Your Home From Unwanted Heirlooms
text: TWO things in modern life are inevitable: death and downsizing. Lest you be caught off-guard when a family member insists you take a piece of furniture you do not want, a few tips.

headline: New York Gifted Programs: The Education Dept. View
text: To the Editor:

headline: By Legislative Act, State Dental Group Prevails in Dispute
text: That bill empowering the New York State Dental Association to oust any chapter that violates certain undefined standards passed the State Legislature on Tuesday. And none too soon.

headline: Parties Split on How to Expand Offshore Drilling
text: HOUSTON  The two political parties have settled on markedly different strategies for improving domestic oil supplies to help lower gasoline prices.

headline: Text of the Federal Reserve’s Statement
text: Following is the full text of the statement released Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

headline: Wilber Hardee Dies at 89; Founded Restaurants
text: Wilber Hardee, a farm boy turned grill cook who went on to open the first Hardee’s hamburger stand in 1960, starting a chain that now has nearly 2,000 restaurants in the United States and overseas, died Friday at his home in Greenville, N.C. He was 89.

headline: Career Programs Stress College, Too, and Give Students a Leg Up, Study Says
text: Forget the old-fashioned “vocational ed” classes that sent students on a decidedly noncollege track. Over the last quarter-century, a new kind of high school program known as a career academy has proliferated, especially in low-income districts, that combines job placement, college preparation and classes beyond the vocational trades, from accounting to health care.

headline: California Will Offer Plan to Cut Harmful Emissions
text: California will introduce a detailed plan on Thursday to cut greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels in 12 years by requiring more energy-efficient appliances and buildings, lowering vehicle emissions and generating 33 percent of its energy from renewable sources.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on June 10 about fishers, weasel-like predators whose range has expanded into suburban settings, misspelled the location of one sighting of a fisher. It is South Kingstown, R.I., not South Kingston.

headline: MSNBC Documentaries
text: MSNBC is creating MSNBC Films, which will finance feature-length documentaries, The Hollywood Reporter said. The move is part of an effort to turn the cable news channel into more of a player in the feature world. While each deal will be structured differently, MSNBC intends to contribute to several elements of a film’s development, from production to marketing for theatrical release.

headline: Bride-to-Be Takes a Chance on eBay for a Bidding Bridesmaid
text: Being a bridesmaid can be expensive, as any woman who has been fitted for a dress she did not pick out, or spent hundreds of dollars for a plane ticket, can attest. But, then again, most bridesmaids know the bride.

headline: Out of the Loop and on the Run in Central Park
text: CENTRAL PARK was designed for refuge, discovery and communing with society. Not for running.

headline: Chamberlain Moves From Future Tense to Present
text: PITTSBURGH  It could be that Joba Chamberlain is more than the future ace of the Yankees. With each start he makes, Chamberlain seems closer and closer to being the ace of the moment.

headline: Damages Cut Against Exxon in Valdez Case
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday reduced what had once been a $5 billion punitive damages award against Exxon Mobil to about $500 million. The ruling essentially concluded a legal saga that started when the Exxon Valdez, a supertanker, struck a reef and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the Prince William Sound in Alaska in 1989.

headline: Facing a Critic, an Embattled Sprinter Plots a Clean Path to the Olympics
text: When the sprinter John Capel first broached the idea of restarting his track career last year, with his two-year suspension from the sport for marijuana use nearing its end, his toughest critic voiced her doubts loudly and clearly.

headline: Turkey: When Secularism and Democracy Collide
text: To the Editor:

headline: Help for Ailing Memory Cards
text: Q. I’m having trouble getting certain photos off my digital camera. Is it possible that the camera’s memory card has gone bad?

headline: M.T.A. Cuts Free Use of Passes by Its Board
text: Bowing to intense pressure and saying it wanted to move beyond what had become a lengthy distraction, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted 12-0 on Wednesday to give up lifelong free E-ZPass tags and other travel passes for former members and limit their use by current members.

headline: Euro 2008: Germany vs. Turkey
text: Germany's Philipp Lahm broke a tie with Turkey in the 90th minute to win the European Championship semifinal, 3-2.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 64 Houston
text: Location: Houston.

headline: Aspen Aerogels Nabs $37 Million
text: Aspen Aerogels, a start-up that uses nanotech processes to make insulation materials, has taken $37 million in a fourth round of funding.

headline: SodaHead Bulks Up With $8.4 Million
text: SodaHead, a Web site that describes itself as an “opinion community focused on discussing today’s hottest topics,” has raised an $8.4 million second round led by Mission Ventures. Also participating the round was previous investor Mohr Davidow Ventures.

headline: V.C.’s Pour $15 Million Into SpringSource
text: SpringSource, a provider of Java infrastructure software, has raised $15 million in a second round of funding. Accel Partners led the round, which included participation from existing investor Benchmark Capital.

headline: UniCredit to Shed 9,000 Jobs
text: UniCredit , Europe’s fourth-largest bank, plans to cut 9,000 jobs — around 4.97 percent of its workforce — under its strategic plan for 2008 to 2010, it said in a statement on Thursday.

headline: Deutsche Bank in Underwriting Venture With Shanxi, Report Says
text: Deutsche Bank has reportedly moved to grab a slice of China’s lucrative domestic underwriting fees.

headline: Fortis to Raise $2.4 Billion
text: Fortis, the Belgian-Dutch bank that partnered up to buy ABN Amro last year, said it plans to raise 1.5 billion euros ($2.4 billion) of equity and cancel its interim dividend to boost capital.

headline: China’s Zoomlion Teams With Goldman in Italian Cement Deal
text: China’s Changsha Zoomlion Heavy Industry Science & Technology Development and Goldman Sachs have teamed up to buy Italian cement truck maker Compagnia Italiana Forme Acciaio, or Cifa, for 271 million euros ($423 million).

headline: Initiate Systems Snuffs Out I.P.O. Plans
text: Initiate Systems on Wednesday pulled the plug on its planned initial public offering.

headline: Tyson Sells Canadian Beef Business
text: Tyson Foods said on Wednesday that it has inked a deal to sell its Canadian beef operation to XL Foods for 107 million Canadian dollars ($106 million).

headline: L.S.E. and Lehman Team Up for European Trading Platform
text: The London Stock Exchange plans to set up a pan-European trading platform with Lehman Brothers to stave off start-up rivals eroding its market share, the groups said.

headline: California Sues Countrywide Over Lending
text: California joined Illinois on Wednesday in suing Countrywide Financial, claiming the company had practiced deceptive mortgage lending. The embattled company’s shareholders, meanwhile, approved its takeover by Bank of America.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Reduce Reliance on Credit Ratings
text: Securities regulators proposed weaning investors and Wall Street institutions from over-reliance on credit ratings, part of changes to the rating industry prompted by the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Verizon Files for $10 Billion Offering
text: Verizon Communications on Wednesday filed to periodically sell as a much as $10 billion in common and preferred stock and debt securities.

headline: Gene Testing Questioned by Regulators
text: Regulators are cracking down on companies that sell genetic tests directly to consumers, threatening to crimp the growth of one of the hottest sectors of the biotechnology industry.

headline: Ex-Big Board Chairman Wins Round in Pay Fight
text: On Wall Street, there are stars that fade and stars that fight. Richard A. Grasso is one of the latter.

headline: Sentences Reduced for Adelphia Founder and Son
text: The prison sentences of John J. Rigas, the founder of Adelphia Communications, and his son Timothy were reduced by three years each on Tuesday after an appeals court overturned a count of bank fraud.

headline: ‘Suspicion of Nude Jogging’
text: More of your user-generated comedy (send via the comment link below):

headline: Suitors Said to Drop Out of Auction for G.E. Credit Card Unit
text: General Electric‘s auction of its $30 billion credit-card business is attracting only tepid interest, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Deal Chatter Pushes Continental Higher

headline: Will Routine H.I.V. Testing Reduce AIDS Deaths?
text: The New York City health department plans to announce today an ambitious three-year effort to give an H.I.V. test to every adult living in the Bronx, which has a far higher death rate from AIDS than any other borough. As Anemona Hartocollis reports in a front-page article, the campaign will begin with a push to make the voluntary testing routine in emergency rooms and storefront clinics, where city officials say that cumbersome consent procedures required by state law have deterred doctors from offering the tests.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Shrimp in Moroccan-Style Tomato Sauce
text: If you saw this dish, you would immediately take it for Italian, or more specifically, southern Italian or even Italian-American. It is nothing more than shrimp in tomato sauce, a combination that is served over pasta all the time. But by varying the spices, using seasonings are from the other side of the Mediterranean, you can transform the common into the exotic.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Power of Wind in Two Master Classes on Class
text: I spent Wednesday on the sun-dappled South Bank, where I was buffeted by winds both outdoors and in. The outdoor winds swept up from the Thames and had that brisk, stirring coolness that can energize even a weary theater-binger. The indoor winds at the National Theater, where I took in back-to-back shows, were made up of words, words and more words, coming at you with cyclonic force. They could not be dismissed as hot air.

headline: Some Questions About Those Commitment Letters
text: The report today is that Anheuser Busch is going to reject the InBev offer. InBev will now have to decide whether it will launch a consent solicitation to remove all of the Anheuser directors. This can be done at any time. Alternatively, at the request of 25% of Anheuser’s shareholders a special meeting of Anheuser shareholders can be held. So, InBev can also go this route and remove the Anheuser directors at the special meeting if they can get enough shareholder support for it to be called. I suspect that if InBev does attempt to remove and replace the Anheuser directors, InBev will arrange a consent solicitation rather than attempting to call a special meeting: it is quicker.

headline: Joy and Cooking: What I Had for Dinner

And though I experience this almost daily, it occurs to me that I don’t write about it enough here: it’s too obvious to me (maybe it’s too obvious to you), but I hope it’s evident. headline: Poverty Among Women Growing in New York State
text: In comparison with all American women, women in New York State are worse off financially than two decades ago, with more of them below the poverty line, according to a new report [pdf]. More than one of every seven women in the state was poor in 2005, compared with about one in eight nationwide, the report said. Among the states, New York ranked 40th in the share of women living above the poverty line, a decline from its 30th place spot in 1989, according to the study released on Thursday by the Institute for Women’s Policy Research.

headline: Scent Notes | Carolina Herrera
text: I once exited a creative meeting in Paris with Hermès’ in-house perfumer, Jean-Claude Ellena, and heard him make a simple comment. Ellena had presented an iteration of the perfume he was working on to the creative team. The perfume was “not there yet,” but, they all agreed, “Ça sent bon.” It smells good. In the hallway, Ellena repeated it with evident relief. As long as he could get them to “Ça sent bon,” he said, he knew he was going in the right direction.
