headline: Q&A: Scalia's Gauntlet
text: The Supreme Court's decision today declaring the District of Columbia's ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.   Steve Wermiel is adjunct professor and associate director of the Marshall-Brennan Constitutional Literacy Project at the American University Washington College of Law.     Q. In Slate, Dahlia Lithwick refers to what she called your "rather brilliant observation" asking why none of the dissenters in today's decision cautioned the majority that it "will almost certainly cause more Americans to be killed." Can you explain more?    A. Use of that phrase is partly serious and partly flip. Justice Scalia used those words (hence the quotation marks) in a very strident dissent on June 12 when the Supreme Court ruled that Guantanamo Bay detainees have a right to go to federal court to challenge their detentions. My initial point is that it seems appropriate for the justices Scalia was criticizing in the detainees' case to throw that line back at him when he has written a decision that will facilitate the possession of handguns by individuals.  Answering on a more serious (perhaps less flip) level, whether it is individuals shooting others in self-defense or those committing crimes having easier access to weapons, it does seem likely that more people may be killed using handguns as a result of the newly declared Second Amendment right. At the very least, it seems more likely that people will die from the constitutional right to own firearms than from the constitutional right of an enemy terrorist to challenge his detention in federal court.

headline: Q&A: Scalia’s Gauntlet
text: The Supreme Court’s decision today declaring the District of Columbia’s ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.

headline: Q&A: The Ratifiers and the Second Amendment
text: The Supreme Court's decision today declaring the District of Columbia's ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.   Brian Frye, a lawyer in New York, is the author of "The Peculiar Story of United States vs. Miller," an article published in the New York University Journal of Law & Liberty, Vol. 2, 2007.  Q. What was your reaction to today's Court decision, based on what you know about the history of the Second Amendment?   A. I am not an authority on the ratification and early history of the Second Amendment, so I will refrain from commenting on the Court's opinion and dissents in that respect. That said, it does seem that the Court's opinion overemphasizes the role that personal self-defense played in ratification. It is probably true that a common-law right to own weapons for self-defense existed at ratification.   But the prefatory clause suggests that the need for collective self-defense through the militia, rather than individual self-defense, prompted ratification of the Second Amendment. Of course, it appears that the ratifiers assumed that the Constitution guarantees common-law rights as well as specifically enumerated rights. So while they may not have understood the Second Amendment right to directly guarantee the right to own weapons for self-defense, they would have understood it as consistent with that right.   Q. How do you see today's decision in the context of the last big Second Amendment case before the court, in the 1939 Miller decision, which more or less allowed states and localities to adopt gun control measures?  A. The Court affirms the D.C. Circuit's holding that the Second Amendment, under Miller, guarantees a right to own weapons "in common use at the time," which now includes handguns. I would suggest that the Miller holding is more closely tied to militia service. I suspect that a slightly more accurate characterization would be that Miller held the Second Amendment guarantees a right to own a weapon suitable for militia service, in order to ensure that members of the unorganized militia are familiar with the use of such weapons and possess then in the event militia service becomes necessary. I'm not really qualified to say what sort of  weapons are suitable for militia service, but it is certainly conceivable that long guns are suitable and handguns are not.  Q. Why do you think it has taken the Court so long -- the last decision was almost 70 years ago -- to rule on a Second Amendment case?  A. I suspect that the Court has taken a long time to hear a Second Amendment case because the constitutional validity of gun control laws was a controversial question lacking a burning need for resolution. Miller provided a workable resolution, effectively  permitting state and local gun control based on state and local preferences. Gun owners are politically powerful. Accordingly, they are rarely the target of unreasonable regulations. Perhaps the District of Columbia regulation was sufficiently unreasonable that the Court felt obliged to step in.

headline: Q&A: The Ratifiers and the Second Amendment
text: The Supreme Court’s decision today declaring the District of Columbia’s ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.

headline: Q&A: Jack Rakove on Heller and History
text: The Supreme Court’s decision today declaring the District of Columbia’s ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.

headline: Q&A: Jack Rakove on Heller and History
text: The Supreme Court's decision today declaring the District of Columbia's ban on handguns unconstitutional is producing a wave of reaction. The New York Times has asked several lawyers and legal historians to comment on specific aspects of the case.   Jack N. Rakove, a professor of history, American studies and political science at Stanford University, won a Pulitzer prize for "Original Meanings: Politics and Ideas in the Making of the Constitution." He was the lead author of a historians' amicus brief written in support of the District of Columbia's position.   Q. In reading the Heller decision today, what leaps out at you?   A. The two main opinions differ enormously in how they think about which elements of history help most in understanding the original meaning of the Second Amendment. Justice Scalia's opinion has remarkably little to say about the drafting of the Amendment or the constitutional debates of 1787-1789. By contrast, Justice Stevens' dissent focuses tightly on the immediate context within which the value of "a well-regulated militia" and "the right of the people to keep and bear arms" were actually discussed.   Scalia replies that "It is dubious to rely on such history to interpret a text that was widely understood to codify a pre-existing right, rather than to fashion a new one." Scalia similarly claims that "most [Americans] thought" the right was "even more important for self-defense and hunting" than it was as an antidote to the danger of a standing army. Scalia's history depends on a deep background understanding of the right that presumes its content and purpose were only slightly affected by the events of the Revolution or the distinct way in which the Militia Clauses of Article I, Section 8, of the Constitution became controversial during the ratification debates of 1787-1788.   Stevens's history, by contrast, says that the true (and really the only) subject under active debate when the Amendment was framed was the militia. The legal rights of individual Americans to own and use firearms remained a matter of state and local regulation, it suggests, and no one at the time understood that the adoption of the Amendment would modify their authority in any way.    Scalia's historical basis for asserting that his interpretation was the one that was "widely understood" at the time remains unclear. The best-known statement of an avowedly individual right to own and use firearms came in a document issued by the minority Anti-Federalist delegates to the Pennsylvania ratification convention. Their "Dissent" was issued early in the ratification campaign, and could have become a rallying point for the Constitution's critics. Instead the "Dissent" quickly became an object of Federalist ridicule precisely because its idea of protecting a right to "hunt and fowl" seemed too trivial to merit constitutional recognition. Thereafter the discussion of the right to keep and bear arms was concerned almost exclusively with the militia, which is why I continue to find Scalia's argument historically deficient  Q. How sweeping is the ruling?   A. As an endorsement of the "individual right" view of the Amendment, the decision is about as sweeping as it could be. Never one for understatement when it comes to castigating his fellow Justices, Scalia minces no words in endorsing an unequivocal interpretation of the essentially private activities the Amendment was meant to protect.   But because today's ruling is so open-ended, even vague when it comes to laying down the appropriate standards for regulation, it will be years before the impact of the decision will be known. By then, the composition of the Court will have changed, and a Court that could toss aside the 1939 precedent of the Miller case so casually might follow suit with Heller as well.  Q. Why has it taken so long for the Court to take up a Second Amendment case?  A. Controversy over the meaning of the Second Amendment is a relatively modern phenomenon. It took the transformation of the National Rifle Association from an organization primarily concerned with promoting the safe and skillful use of guns into an active advocacy group bent on opposing all forms of firearm regulation to give the Second Amendment any salience in constitutional debate.   At that point, it became something of a touchstone issue for conservative legal activists and some federal judges with impeccable right-wing credentials, like Laurence Silberman of the D.C. Circuit. A handful of cases and opinions endorsing the individual right interpretation and challenging the conventional view of the Miller case created enough dissonance within the federal judiciary to make it possible for the Supreme Court to take on the issue.   But of course, the fact that today's opinion took the predictable 5-4 form of so many other issues of recent years could not possibly mean that the political preferences of the Justices had anything to do with the outcome. Heaven forfend!

headline: Noth Out, Goldblum In For ‘Criminal Intent’
text: The Associated Press: Jeff Goldblum will be joining “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” while Chris Noth is leaving after three seasons, a series spokeswoman said Thursday. “Criminal Intent” was recently picked up for a 16-episode eighth season by USA Network.

headline: Ben Affleck’s ‘Nightline’ Assignment
text: “Oscar winner and actor Ben Affleck has taken on a new job, if only for one assignment, traveling to the war-torn eastern Congo to do a report for Thursday’s edition of ABC television news program ‘Nightline,'” Reuters reports.

headline: Joking With Jeter, and a Walk for a Cause
text: PITTSBURGH — Remember that bet Hideki Matsui won with Derek Jeter and Bobby Abreu in spring training, when he sneaked off to New York to get married? Turns out the still-single Jeter still has not paid up.

headline: And The Top Ten Emmy Finalists Are…
text: The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences has released lists of the top ten Emmy vote-getters for outstanding drama series and outstanding comedy series.

headline: Did Arnold Diss Charlie?
text: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California is opposed to ending the federal ban on offshore oil drilling, putting him at odds with his party’s presumed nominee, Senator John McCain. On Thursday he also criticized politicians who suggest expanded oil exploration off America’s coasts would lower gas prices, to the delight of the Obama campaign, which saw the remark as an intra-party slap.

headline: Of Mice and Women
text: I spent last week at M.I.T.

headline: Of Mice and Women
text: I spent last week at M.I.T.  You don't know me well enough to know how funny that statement is.  I am someone, you see, who dropped science after 9th grade. Who dropped math after 10th. Who studied an accumulated 18 years of foreign languages, but has never set foot in a lab.  So it was an education. To put it mildly. But, predictably enough, I probably didn't get out of my week-long science course precisely what I was supposed to be taking in.  I was attending a journalism workshop called "Frontiers of Brain Science." The other participants were all real science writers, people who don't have to rack their brains to remember the meaning of the word "ion."  I was there because I thought that, given the fact that I am writing a book on children's mental health issues (yes, I know I promised never to bring that up again), I ought to know a little more about the brain.  What I hadn't realized is that "brain science" is far from synonymous with psychiatry. Locating, identifying, computationally modeling "qualia" — what we might call subjective experience — remains to this day the elusive final frontier of neuroscience.  (Though it can be done: one of the most fascinating things I learned, last week, is that you can actually see, via a visual representation of the electrical activity of a rat's brain, what it is "thinking." You can recognize a recurrent pattern of mental activity — what it looks like in the rat's brain when the rat is running through a maze and what it looks like when the creature is thinking over the sequence afterward, as rats apparently do. "These animals are three- to six-months-old and their experiences are only what we've given them," Matt Wilson, a professor in M.I.T.'s department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, told us. In other words, scientists can read rats' minds because they know what they put in them.)   At M.I.T., I learned a great deal about neurons, dendrites, action potentials, the localization of function, visual perception and transcranial magnetic stimulation.   I learned that you can make a mouse "depressed" by dunking it repeatedly in cold water, by giving it electrical shocks over and over again, by subjecting it to "chronic forced swimming," or making it experience "social defeat," by putting a mean mouse in its cage. The latter method is the best way to test antidepressants, because after such a negative social experience it takes a mouse three weeks of drug therapy to recover, an interval that neatly parallels the amount of time antidepressants take to reach their optimal effectiveness in humans.   But let's move on.  I also learned a great many things about my own brain at M.I.T.   I learned that I can take copious notes without understanding a word.   I learned that I can take copious notes while falling asleep.  I learned that I can jerk myself out of sleep by attempting to translate my notes into French. (If you don't know a word, just add an "e" at the end.)  I learned that I can take copious notes on paper while writing utterly unrelated notes on the inside of my hand.  And I learned that, no matter where I go, no matter what I learn or try to do, my mind always runs along the same old grooves, much like a rat that has been trained, all its pitiable life, to run one eternal maze. And that all the thoughts in my own one-track rat-trap of a mind lead back to … Hillary Clinton.  Here's how:  At M.I.T., we were mostly spoken to by men, various kinds of men, of different ages and with different speaking styles, and we interacted with them with typical reportorial formality. Some were more popular with us than others; some were more engaged with us than others. Some spoke right over our heads; some reached even me with perfect clarity.  Something very different happened, however, on the two occasions when we were spoken to by women. The atmosphere in the room changed. We all became more familiar. We asked more questions. We interrupted more. We made sounds of assent or dissent; we questioned methods, concepts, base assumptions. It was as though, with the women, the boundaries dissolved. We were all immediately drawn into relationships.  How much of this had to do with the fact that the women tended to speak more relationally ("I think," "I feel"), I don't know. I don't know if it was created by the fact that the women — to varying degrees — turned the story of their work into personal narratives.  I know that there was no conscious desire on anyone's part to talk back to them or treat them with less respect. But one woman in particular, Rebecca Saxe, a young, dynamic professor of neurobiology at M.I.T. who gave a riveting presentation on social cognition — "how we reason about the desires and intentions that motivate others' actions" — was interrupted so much by her super-engaged audience that she didn't have time to get through essential portions of her talk.   I did not ask questions of this amazing young woman. I was struck, once again, with one of my crippling bouts of shyness, and besides that, I was too busy writing down her every word and wondering why on earth I had never taken science and whether my daughters might attend M.I.T.   Maybe I could send them to do summer study, I thought. (Once they'd both learned their multiplication tables, of course.) Maybe I should sport little wire glasses and wear my hair in a long braid. Or buy Birkenstocks.  "What did you think?" I breathed to a fellow female fellow, as we filed out of the classroom for lunch.   "I have a crush on her," she said. The women around us made approving noises.  "It was her passion and energy and approach that was infectious," she later explained in an e-mail. "I really had an emotional reaction to her, and found myself day dreaming about being her friend."  What is this thing we so often do, when confronted with an impressive woman? Why do they, in particular, set off such a Pavlovian rush of emotion? Why, for women in particular, do they set off this me/not me engagement, this game of my friend/not my friend, this eternal, sometimes infernal play of positive or negative mirroring?  Men do a version of this with women, too — though I think it plays out more in terms of validates me/doesn't validate me, which may amount, in slightly altered form, to much the same thing. I don't see them doing it with other men. I don't hear of men getting "crushes" on other men because they're impressed with them. They don't seem to get so flooded with the desire to be them, to try on their skins; they don't appear to be constantly testing their identities against another man's example, calling into question, at the drop of a hat, their clothing style or hair or general sense of being in the world.  My husband, Max, has no interest in spectator sports. But he can survive office conversations about the Washington Redskins without feeling that his very selfhood as a man has been called into question. The fact that Barack Obama is barely seeing his children this year is not setting off a cultural conversation on modern working fatherhood. I don't think that any man, in the Clinton years, felt personally implicated, defined or not-defined as husbands and fathers, by Bill's intimate affairs.   Which brings me back to Hillary.  I have long been convinced that the heart of the endless cultural brouhaha about Hillary turns around this me/not me business, the fact that her face, her life, her choices, her style have had, for some reason, to serve as a funhouse mirror for millions of American women (and men).  One of the biggest criticisms of her in the race for the Democratic nomination was that she entered it as a wife-of; and, like Geraldine Ferraro before her, that "of-ness" proved toxic. Yet the main relationship that defined her, I believe, was not the one she had with Bill, but with individual members of the public. She set off a firestorm of neuronal activity in the social cognition center of the national brain. Conscious or not.

headline: Geo-Tagging Your Photos
text: David Pogue takes a look at the Eye-Fi memory card, which stamps photos with the location where they were taken.

text: Photos of the Louise Bourgeois retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Obama-Clinton Meeting Fest
text: WASHINGTON – Senator Barack Obama said Thursday that he had written a personal check of $2,300 to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a goodwill gesture intended to nudge his top donors to help ease Mrs. Clinton’s debt and help the two Democrats move beyond their rivalry to focus on the fall campaign.

headline: Rain Delay Theater at Its Finest
text: PITTSBURGH — There’s a rain delay here at PNC Park, and the Pirates have already shown highlights of the 1960 World Series on the scoreboard. So what did they show next?

headline: Speculate speculate
text: Some links for those who want more wonkishness related to the 6/27 column.

headline: Bush and the U.N. Population Fund
text: President Bush said today that he would withhold all U.S. funds for the U.N. Population Fund for the seventh straight year (Colin Powell sneaked it by the White House in the administration’s first year). That is American policy-making at its most inane.

headline: Senate Fails to Block Cut in Doctors’ Medicare Fees
text: Senate Democrats came within one vote on Thursday night of pushing forward with a bill to prevent a 10 percent cut in Medicare payments to doctors, which will take effect next month without legislative action. And the only senators missing were John McCain of Arizona, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who is ill.

headline: Eugene, a Track and Field Kind of Town
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The United States Olympic track and field trials will begin Friday in the city that grandly calls itself Track Town, USA. In truth, it is entitled to that title because no other site in the nation treats the sport with so much reverence and enthusiasm.

headline: Next For The Osbournes: A Variety Show?
text: “Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne — who pioneered the comedy-reality format with their landmark MTV series — are headed back to television, this time with a weekly variety show,” TV Week reports.

headline: FCC Votes to Consider New ‘Embedded’ Ad Rules
text: Reuters reports:

headline: U.S. Trials: Four Years’ Effort Made or Broken in a Day
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The U.S. Olympic track and field trials (and the U.S. Olympic swimming trials, too) are the most cutthroat in the world. No track and field athlete gets a free pass to the United States Olympic team. Every runner, jumper and thrower must finish in the top three here or sit at home and watch on television what might have been.

headline: Police Official and Guard Are Killed in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  A gunman killed a high-ranking commander in the federal police and a bodyguard as they ate lunch at a busy restaurant here on Thursday, in what appeared to be the latest attack on law enforcement officials who are waging a campaign against drug traffickers, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections
text: The TV Watch column on June 19, about Michelle Obama’s appearance as a co-host on “The View,” referred incorrectly to her mention of her gratitude to Laura Bush after Mrs. Obama was criticized for saying she was really proud of her country for the first time and Mrs. Bush sympathized with her. Mrs. Obama said that she had sent a note to Mrs. Bush, not that Mrs. Bush had sent a note to her.

headline: Yankees Are Frustrated by a Rainout
text: PITTSBURGH  The Yankees started Thursday’s game with four extra-base hits in a row, and they were leading the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-1, when a storm blew through PNC Park. The teams waited two and a half hours before the game was postponed until July 10, with all statistics erased.

headline: As One Controversy Is Settled, an M.T.A. Official Faces Another
text: David S. Mack has turned in his free E-ZPasses. Now the State Police want him to turn in his badge.

headline: Feats of Death-Defying Spandex
text: “Cirque Dreams,” a stunts-and-spandex spectacular that opened Thursday night at the Broadway Theater, is ideally suited for children ages 6 to 12 with an advanced interest in either jungle fauna, gymnastics or sequins. If your child has a passion for all three, by all means waste no shekels on tickets for “The Lion King.” This is the show for you.

headline: Bloomberg and Council Reach Deal on Budget
text: With a legal deadline four days away, city officials brokered a deal on Thursday night on a $59.1 billion budget that would preserve a popular tax cut for homeowners and a $400 rebate and add $129 million in education spending to what had originally been proposed.

headline: InBev’s Bid for Anheuser Turns Hostile
text: Directors of the American brewing company, Anheuser-Busch, rejected an offer from the rival brewery, InBev of Belgium, on Thursday, as InBev decided take its takeover bid directly to shareholders.

headline: Cannibal Witches on the Prowl
text: It’s not the water that menaces in “Wicked Lake,” an inept, nasty and absolutely irredeemable entry in the stale torture-porn subgenre of horror that more often than not features bloodthirsty clans residing in the backwoods. The lake serves only as a skinny-dipping site for four vacationing lesbians, who eventually reveal themselves as more villainous than the assorted deranged males who follow them to a secluded cabin, where at midnight they transform into some sort of cannibal witches. (That this is someone’s idea of female empowerment is by far the most frightening thing about the film, besides, perhaps, the universally atrocious acting.)

headline: Theater Listings
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: In May, Housing Market Rallied With Small Gain
text: The ailing housing market got a bit of a bump last month, as steadily falling home prices led to a small increase in sales, a realty group said Thursday.

headline: Justices Rule for Individual Gun Rights
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday embraced the long-disputed view that the Second Amendment protects an individual right to own a gun for personal use, ruling 5 to 4 that there is a constitutional right to keep a loaded handgun at home for self-defense.

headline: Mr. Ravitch to the Rescue?
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the state agency that runs the city’s subways, buses and commuter trains, has warned that it is so far in the red that it may have to raise fares, trim service, defer repairs and cut major projects.

headline: Baby on Board for NBC
text: The premiere of “The Baby Borrowers,” a new reality series in which teenage couples learn firsthand about parenting in an intense three-week child-sharing experiment, gave NBC a boost on Wednesday, when the network was runner-up in the night’s 18-to-49 ratings demographic. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Baby Borrowers” delivered the night’s second-highest ratings in that category, with 7.8 million viewers at 9. It was also NBC’s best-rated hour of programming on Wednesday, better than “Deal or No Deal” at 8 (6.6 million) and “Celebrity Circus” at 10 (5.7 million). Fox led the night over all with the top-rated show, “So You Think You Can Dance,” which averaged 8.1 million viewers from 8 to 10. ABC and CBS ranked third and fourth, respectively, in the 18-to-49 set.

headline: Appeals Court Rejects Request for a Fast Decision on Gases
text: A federal appeals court in Washington unanimously rejected the petition by a group of states and environmental organizations to force a speedy decision on whether and how to regulate heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide. In the wake of a 2007 Supreme Court decision in the case brought by these states and environmental groups, the Environmental Protection Agency concluded that such gases were pollutants requiring regulation. When the agency forwarded its finding to the White House, it was told that the e-mail would not be opened. That finding remains in limbo, as does a draft E.P.A. regulation setting emission standards for motor vehicles. A less direct draft rule, which outlines the issues involved in regulation, is due “soon,” an agency spokesman said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about the Federal Reserve’s decision to keep interest rates unchanged included an outdated statement from the Fed on the status of the economy. The article quoted from an earlier Fed statement, issued April 30, rather than the June 25 statement, the text of which accompanied the article. The text can also be found at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Union Says It and Con Edison Are Far Apart on Contract
text: Consolidated Edison and the union that represents nearly 9,000 of its workers appear to be making little headway in negotiations to renew their four-year contract before its expiration at 12:01 a.m. on Sunday.

headline: The Sam’s Club Agenda
text: Among the many dark tidings for American conservatism, there is one genuine bright spot. Over the past five years, a group of young and unpredictable rightward-leaning writers has emerged on the scene.

headline: What to Ask About Vasectomy
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Friends Recall a Young Peacemaker and Aspiring Lawyer
text: Aaliyah Clark and Chole Toppin tied a handful of balloons to the rusted old gate. Some were purple and heart-shaped. Some said, “I Love You” or “Friends Forever.” A figurine of Betty Boop hung beneath another, attached to its string.

headline: At Open, Some Stars Struggle on Deceptively Soft Greens
text: EDINA, Minn.  Lorena Ochoa, annoyed at being three over par and still awaiting her first birdie after 13 holes, spied a leader board teeming with red numbers. The names mixed the familiar (Laura Davies, Helen Alfredsson) and the unknown (Ji Young Oh of South Korea). Even the amateur María José Uribe, the bubbly Colombian playing in the same group with Ochoa, was three under.

headline: Earmarks Persist in Spending Bills for 2009
text: WASHINGTON  Despite a pledge by Congressional leaders to reduce pork-barrel projects, new information shows that both the number and amount of earmarks have increased in several spending bills now making their way through Congress.

headline: Two Testify on Memo Spelling Out Interrogation
text: WASHINGTON  Two Bush administration lawyers who provided important legal justification for harsh interrogation methods that critics denounce as torture made a rare public appearance on Thursday to defend their actions.

headline: Gay Has His Sights on Olympic Trials and a Formidable Opponent
text: EUGENE, Ore.  An absent person’s shadow will loom large over the men’s 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials  Usain Bolt of Jamaica, who set a startling world record of 9.72 seconds at the Reebok Grand Prix meet in New York on May 31.

headline: Record Wool Price Set in Australia
text: An Indian fabric maker paid nearly $250,000, a record price, for a 200-pound bale of exceptionally high grade wool at an auction Thursday in Australia.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the arrest of the Italian businessman Raffaello Follieri on charges of fraud and money laundering misstated his investment relationship with the Yucaipa Companies, the private equity firm controlled by Ron Burkle. Yucaipa put up more than $55 million in a joint venture with Mr. Follieri’s company, the Follieri Group  not in the company itself.

text: Peter Huntsman, the chief executive of Huntsman Chemical, thought he had a solid deal. When some on Wall Street showed their doubts, he bet millions they were wrong.
