headline: Umpire Suspended for Manuel Bump
text: Brian Runge, the umpire who bumped Mets Manager Jerry Manuel during an on-field argument Tuesday night, has been suspended one game, the commissioner’s office announced.

headline: Senate Passes Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Fourth of July fireworks came early on Capitol Hill.

headline: New York Asian Film Festival 2008
text: Back for its seventh year, the New York Asian Film Festival is known for its disdain of “art house” movies and its feverish support of Asian popular cinema, particularly in its more disreputable and blood-splattered variations.

headline: The Day Robert Mugabe Was Greeted at City Hall
text: Foreign leaders aren’t routinely honored with receptions at New York’s City Hall. In the last two decades, as best as we can tell, only two Africans have received this red-carpet treatment.

headline: Government Seeks Dismissal of End-of-World Suit Against Collider
text: Calling its claims “overly speculative and not credible,” and saying that it is too late anyway, lawyers for the federal government argued this week that a so-called “doomsday suit” intended to prevent the startup of a the world’s most powerful particle accelerator should be thrown out of court.

headline: In a World Left Silent, One Heart Beeps
text: The first 40 minutes or so of “Wall-E”  in which barely any dialogue is spoken, and almost no human figures appear on screen  is a cinematic poem of such wit and beauty that its darker implications may take a while to sink in. The scene is an intricately rendered city, bristling with skyscrapers but bereft of any inhabitants apart from a battered, industrious robot and his loyal cockroach sidekick. Hazy, dust-filtered sunlight illuminates a landscape of eerie, post-apocalyptic silence. This is a world without people, you might say without animation, though it teems with evidence of past life.

headline: A Second Woof
text: John Grogan, the author of the 2005 man-and-his-dog best seller “Marley & Me,” is writing a prequel called “The Longest Trip Home,” HarperCollins announced. On sale in October, this memoir will recount the childhood days of Mr. Grogan, above with his dog Gracie. It is part of a Grogan-fest this year that includes a children’s book, “A Very Marley Christmas,” and a film adaptation of “Marley & Me,” starring Owen Wilson, Jennifer Aniston and oh, yes, a dog.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about marketplaces opening near the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan misstated the starting time of a one-day food market called the New Amsterdam Public that will be held on Sunday. It will open at 11 a.m., not 10, and close at 4 p.m.

headline: A Whirling, Digitized Ride on a Small Celluloid Raft
text: The filmmaker Ken Jacobs calls his new feature-length movie “Razzle Dazzle,” and boy, he isn’t kidding. Subjecting a minute-long film made by Thomas Edison in 1903 to a kaleidoscopic array of digital distortions, effects, filters and montage techniques, Mr. Jacobs, one of America’s most esteemed avant-garde filmmakers, has orchestrated a scintillating tour de force.

headline: The Sex and the Fury, French Aristocracy Style
text: The first time you see the courtesan called La Vellini, she’s stretched out on a divan and wearing a smile, or perhaps a scowl. It’s hard to tell with this woman, whose lips restlessly tremble and twist with rage and pleasure. She’s dressed like the supine subject of Goya’s painting “The Clothed Maja,” which, like its sister image, “The Nude Maja,” was condemned as indecent by the Spanish Inquisition. To look at the figure on screen writhing like a pampered cat is to understand why those paintings made some observers uneasy.

headline: A Company Computer and Questions About E-Mail Privacy
text: When he was fired, Scott Sidell was angry enough. Then he found out that his former employer was reading his personal Yahoo e-mail messages, after he had left the company.

headline: Branching Out in Bilbao
text: Government officials in Bilbao, Spain, have proposed that a new branch of the Guggenheim Museum there be built in the countryside, beyond the city’s outskirts, Reuters reported. José Luis Bilbao, who leads the Vizcaya provincial government, said that local officials could finance the project, to be built in a nature reserve. Juan Ignacío Vidarte, director general of the Bilbao Guggenheim, known for its twisting, titanium-clad building designed by Frank Gehry, said the new branch would link art with the notion of environmental sustainability. He did not say who would design the building or when it would open. In New York, Betsy Ennis, a spokeswoman for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, said it had reviewed an initial proposal from the Guggenheim Bilbao for the new satellite museum and would analyze its programming, architecture, operations and budget issues over the next few months.

headline: Truce Is Strained as Militants Launch Rockets and Israel Keeps Goods Out of Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  A barely week-old truce between Israel and the Hamas rulers of Gaza frayed further on Thursday when Palestinian militants launched two rockets against Israel, and Israel prevented goods from entering Gaza for a second day.

headline: Moving to Stravinsky, Debussy and Winehouse
text: As a dancer, Nicholas Leichter is one of the best New York has to offer. His impulse to move springs from a deep place untainted by superfluous details. But in his ensemble dances Mr. Leichter is just part of the group, and this is where the trouble begins: his astounding natural ability never manages to translate to the rest of his cast.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Guide to Viewing the Waterfalls
text: “The New York City Waterfalls,” Olafur Eliasson’s work of public art, will be even more public than “The Gates” were. After all, you had to go to Central Park to see “The Gates.”

headline: Waits Plague Transfers of Children to Relatives’ Care
text: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  When child welfare officials in Washington removed five young children from their parents’ home in May, relatives in this Washington suburb quickly stepped in, offering to share guardianship.

headline: The Sad, Proud Elegies Start in Bruno’s District
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  On Tuesday evening, as the State Senate rose in the Capitol in Albany to applaud Joseph L. Bruno, a few middle-aged men gathered at the Park Lane Tobacconist here in downtown Saratoga Springs, smoking cigars the size of bratwursts as the sun sank in the sky.

headline: With Trade, the Nets’ Rebuilding Is Official
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It might have been the 2008 edition of the N.B.A. draft, but 2010 seemed to be the year on everyone’s mind in the Nets’ camp Thursday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a political crisis in Argentina caused by a tax dispute between the government and farmers misidentified the capital of Santa Fe province, a major agricultural region. It is Santa Fe, not Rosario.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Google Tries Tighter Aim for Web Ads
text: Google, with its deep reservoir of data about online behavior gathered by tracking hundreds of millions of computers, is for the first time testing ways to use some of that data to aim ads at Web users.

headline: The Myths and Realities of a Vasectomy
text: Dr. Marc Goldstein is director of the Center for Male Reproductive Medicine and Microsurgery at Cornell University Weill Medical College. Dr. Goldstein was one of the first surgeons to introduce no-scalpel vasectomies in the United States and remains a leader in research in the field of male contraception and fertility.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a report by the inspector general of the Justice Department on the department’s use of political or ideological factors in hiring mistakenly conflated the cases of two rejected job applicants mentioned in the report (but not named in the article). One was described in the report as having worked for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton; the other was described as having a MySpace page with an unflattering cartoon about President Bush. They were not the same person.

headline: Allegations in Russia Could Hurt BP Venture
text: BP’s grasp on its extensive oil assets in Russia became more tenuous Thursday after its Russian partners said that a general shareholders’ meeting for a joint venture had been held in violation of Russian law.

headline: Job-Seeking Baby Boomers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cascades, Sing the City Energetic
text: When Walt Whitman crossed the East River on the Brooklyn Ferry, the sheer ecstasy of the trip made him see the future. It was us, the coming generations of urban dwellers who would draw the same energy he did from his wonderful town and its waterways.

headline: For Obama, a Pragmatist’s Shift Toward the Center
text: Barack Obama has taken a stroll this week away from traditional liberal political positions, his path toward the political center marked by artful leaps and turns.

headline: Dashing Spain Transcends Its Anguish
text: This is something that has not happened in 24 years, most of them frustrating. Spain’s national team  La Selección  has disappointed so often, so graphically, so diversely. But on Thursday came the biggest win in a generation.

headline: Ed Arno, Cartoonist of New Yorker Whimsy, Is Dead at 92
text: Ed Arno, whose sketchy, casually rendered cartoons on topics domestic and cosmic appeared regularly in The New Yorker for more than 30 years, died on May 27. He was 92.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Tigers No Longer Looking Back
text: DETROIT  Todd Jones, the Tigers’ closer, put on a shaggy wig and a Magglio Ordóñez jersey and took a bat to the tarp-covered infield during a rain-delayed game at Comerica Park.

headline: Council Seeks Harsher Penalty in Urban Climbs
text: The death-defying climbers who scale New York City’s skyscrapers shut down entire blocks, tie up dozens of police officers and risk the safety of bystanders below. And for that, the city slaps some of them with the equivalent of a parking ticket.

headline: Reflections Through a Surrealistic Eye: Dalí and the Camera
text: Nearly 80 years on, the famous image from “Un Chien Andalou,” which Salvador Dalí and his art-school friend Luis Buñuel cobbled together in Paris in April 1929, remains one of the most shocking in all cinema. A woman’s face fills the screen. A man’s left hand widens the lids of her left eye; his right begins to draw a straight razor across it. Then there is, as it were, a jump cut. The razor slices through the eye of a dead cow and gelatinous ooze tumbles forth. Yick, and whew.

headline: For Love of the Game
text: On Sept. 1, 2006, two dozen of America’s top-ranked high school basketball players converged on Rucker Park in Harlem for an unprecedented event. Regardless of age, experience or sneaker-company affiliation, these athletes would play for no other reason than love of the game.

headline: Lock and Load
text: Thirty-thousand Americans are killed by guns every year  on the job, walking to school, at the shopping mall. The Supreme Court on Thursday all but ensured that even more Americans will die senselessly with its wrongheaded and dangerous ruling striking down key parts of the District of Columbia’s gun-control law.

headline: Complex Ties Lead Ally Not to Condemn Mugabe
text: JOHANNESBURG  President Robert Mugabe’s enforcers had already begun to rampage across Zimbabwe, beating his political opponents, when television cameras captured a startling image of Mr. Mugabe holding hands with the smiling South African president, Thabo Mbeki, a professed champion of African democracy.

headline: Footnotes
text: Eli Broad, below, the philanthropist whose donations to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art helped it to build one of the largest contemporary-art institutions in the country, is stepping down from a formal role on the museum’s board, the museum announced on Wednesday. Mr. Broad will serve as a life trustee, a nonvoting member of the museum’s board. Christopher V. Walker, a former vice chairman and chairman of the museum’s finance committee, also stepped down from its board. ... Adriane Lenox, who won a Tony for her work in John Patrick Shanley’s “Doubt: A Parable” in 2005, will lead the cast of Lynn Nottage’s “Ruined,” about a businesswoman dealing with strife in Congo, at the Manhattan Theater Club next season. The play will have its premiere this fall at the Goodman Theater in Chicago.

headline: Philippines: Typhoon Toll May Exceed 1,300
text: The death toll from Typhoon Fengshen could reach more than 1,300, including the passengers and the crew of a ferry that capsized Saturday in the storm, officials said. As many as 809 people on the ferry are thought to have died. Divers continued to search the boat, where hundreds of bodies are believed to be trapped, as villagers, left, prayed for the victims during a Mass on Sibuyan Island. Apart from the ferry disaster, officials raised the death toll to 498.

headline: Post-Spitzer, a New Breed of Reformer
text: No one is dusting off those valiant titles once bestowed on Eliot Spitzer, honorifics like “The Enforcer” and “Sheriff of Wall Street.” But slowly, even a bit gently, Mr. Spitzer’s successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry.

headline: CBS to Appeal Military Court Ruling on Haditha Interview
text: A First Amendment case has escalated between CBS News and a military court over a “60 Minutes” report about an attack at Haditha, Iraq.

headline: H.I.V. and Aids Diagnoses Rise in Men Who Have Sex With Men
text: Diagnoses of H.I.V. and AIDS in men who have sex with men rose significantly from 2001 to 2006, while declining in other demographic groups, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. The increase in infection rates was especially high among males ages 13 to 24, with an annual increase of 12.4 percent, compared with 1.5 percent for men over all. The annual increase was higher still among young African-American men who have sex with men, nearly 15 percent. “It’s a grim report,” said Dr. Ronald Stall, an epidemiologist and professor of public health at the University of Pittsburgh. “It means roughly speaking that about half of the American AIDS epidemic is occurring among a few percent of the adult population. And the terrible trends we’re seeing among white gay men are even amplified further among minority men.”

headline: Citing Need for Assessments, U.S. Freezes Solar Energy Projects
text: DENVER  Faced with a surge in the number of proposed solar power plants, the federal government has placed a moratorium on new solar projects on public land until it studies their environmental impact, which is expected to take about two years.

headline: Bruise-Inducing Games: Young Sadists at Play
text: With an actress as extremely gorgeous as Meital Dohan and a script that requires her to thrash around in ways most often seen in straight-to-video steamers, you would think that “Stitching” would be heating up the Wild Project theater to the boiling point.

headline: Dipping Into Many Modes
text: An old Indian legend tells of how, after several years of intense meditation, the Buddhist monk Bodhidharma began to grow sleepy. His goal being spiritual awakening, this just wouldn’t do, so he removed his eyelids and flung them to the ground. From the spot where they landed grew the first tea leaves.

headline: Alkaline Soil Sample From Mars Reveals Presence of Nutrients for Plants to Grow
text: Stick an asparagus plant in a pot full of Martian soil, and the asparagus might grow happily, scientists announced Thursday.

headline: Mexico: 14 Men to Be Compensated for Vasectomies
text: Officials of Guerrero State have agreed to pay $3,400 each to 14 indigenous men who were coerced into having vasectomies a decade ago. The men will also get water storage tanks and cement to build new homes, Luis Barrera Rios, the state health secretary, told The Associated Press. During a visit to the village of El Camalote in 1998, health workers demanded that men with more than four children be sterilized, the National Human Rights Commission said last year in a report. The men said state workers had promised them new homes and scholarships for their children if they underwent the procedure.

headline: Obama Gives $2,300 for Clinton Debt
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama said on Thursday that he had written a personal check of $2,300 to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a good-will gesture intended to nudge his top donors to help ease Mrs. Clinton’s campaign debt and help the two Democrats move beyond their rivalry to focus on the fall contest.

headline: An Inexhaustible Energy Source: Heated Words. But Can It Be Tapped?
text: WASHINGTON  Fourth of July fireworks came early on Capitol Hill.

headline: Take Out the Trash Precisely, Now. It’s the Law.
text: WHITEHAVEN, England  The citizens of Whitehaven try, really they do. They separate out their cans, their paper, their cardboard and their glass, and they recycle them all. They compost. They jump up and down on their trash to cram it into their government-issued garbage cans, and they put the trash out for collection at exactly 7 a.m., twice a month.

headline: A Grim Image of Politics in Zimbabwe Emerges
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe As President Robert Mugabe defied intensifying international condemnation to insist that Friday’s presidential runoff would proceed, a picture was emerging on Thursday of the circumstances under which Zimbabweans would be forced to go to the polls, and what they might face if they resisted.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,098 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

headline: Fuels on the Hill
text: Congress has always had a soft spot for “experts” who tell members what they want to hear, whether it’s supply-side economists declaring that tax cuts increase revenue or climate-change skeptics insisting that global warming is a myth.

headline: Legal Loophole Allows Taxpayer to Profit From False Filing
text: In 2004, city investigators discovered that the owner of a parking garage in Lower Manhattan had cheated the city out of roughly $210,000 in property taxes over seven years.

headline: Muslim Supporters Shouldn’t Be a Political Liability
text: To the Editor:

headline: Finding a Comfort Zone With Bach and Beethoven
text: John Kamitsuka takes a modest approach to the piano that, depending on what you want from a public piano recital, can be either endearing or frustrating. He is not a pianist who likes to show off his instrument’s power or, for that matter, the more fiery aspects of piano technique. And when he plays pieces that require such things, his readings can seem distant and cautious. But in music that thrives on a focused, intimate sound and clean articulation, he is often interesting and original.

headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down ‘Millionaire’s Amendment’
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday struck down a law meant to level the financial playing field when rich candidates pay for their own political campaigns.

headline: On eBay, Bride Finds Sponsor for a Wedding
text: The eBay auction to be a bridesmaid in Kelly Gray’s wedding is officially over, but the surprises keep coming.

headline: Philippines Toll Could Reach 1,300
text: MANILA  The death toll from Typhoon Fengshen, the storm that battered the Philippines last week, could reach 1,300 if the missing passengers and crew of a capsized ferry are included, officials said Thursday.

headline: Housecleaning on a Grand Scale
text: Collectors are always on the lookout for works that have not recently been for sale in galleries or at the auction houses.

headline: Settling Inquiry, Anheuser Drops Caffeinated Brews
text: Anheuser-Busch has agreed to stop selling caffeinated alcoholic drinks to settle complaints that it was misrepresenting the beverages and marketing them to minors.

headline: Fast Field in 100 Stands in Way of Felix’s Pursuit of 4 Gold Medals
text: EUGENE, Ore.  When Allyson Felix folds her long legs into the starting blocks in the first round of the 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials Friday, she will feel a little more at home than usual.

headline: Ex-Leader of Bus Drivers’ Union Is Sentenced in Bribery Case
text: The former president of a union representing 15,000 New York City school bus drivers was sentenced on Thursday to four years and nine months in federal prison after pleading guilty to extortion and receiving bribes in a Mafia-controlled racketeering conspiracy.

headline: The Knicks Look Abroad and Hope for the Best
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Phase III of Donnie Walsh’s rebuilding project went into effect Thursday night. Charged with the task of orchestrating the ramshackle Knicks’ first draft on his watch, Walsh reached overseas for the newest piece of the franchise.

headline: Jury Convicts Motorist of Causing Train Crash
text: LOS ANGELES  The man who caused a catastrophic train crash that killed 11 people and injured scores of others was convicted on Thursday of 11 counts of first-degree murder and may face the death penalty.

headline: Corrections
text: Business Day

headline: A Trip Through the Revolving Doors of Perception
text: Paul McCarthy fans are in for a shock. They will find almost nothing of what this Los Angeles master of transgressive provocation is famous for in “Central Symmetrical Rotation Movement: Three Installations, Two Films” at the Whitney Museum of American Art. No psychotic clowning, no scatological food play, no pornographic vaudeville, no raunchy political satire, no gross self-abnegation.

headline: Not Your Mother’s Original-Cast Albums
text: A surge of oxygen pours through the original cast albums of “In the Heights” and “Passing Strange,” two musicals that have shown Broadway how to revitalize a somnolent form this season.

headline: Black Hills Rail Line, on Spoked Wheels Instead of Steel
text: THE Lakota called the incongruous patch of low mountains erupting from the prairies of southwestern South Dakota Paha Sapa  Black Hills  for the dark drapes of ponderosa pine that decorated the gray granite slopes. To the Indians they were sacred. Then prospectors discovered gold, the United States Army took over, and miners, railroad men and settlers dug, drilled and dynamited. Despite these scars  and this judgment might not pass muster with the Lakota who knew them first  the Black Hills remain downright stunning.

headline: The North Korea Deal
text: For six years, President Bush rejected any serious diplomacy with North Korea. That obstinacy made the world a more dangerous place. While he was refusing to talk, Pyongyang made more fuel for more weapons and tested a nuclear device. Now that American diplomats finally have been freed to negotiate, there is a chance that North Korea can be persuaded to give up its weapons. That would make the world a safer place.

headline: Throwing a Line
text: WHO Mickey Youmans, 58, an executive of “Farmers’ Almanac TV,” and his wife, Annette, 45, an executive assistant in fuel marketing, from Savannah, Ga. WHAT 3-bedroom cottage WHERE Topton, N.C.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some editions on Tuesday with an article about the 1960 World Series between the Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates misstated the name of the building at the University of Pittsburgh where home plate from Forbes Field is embedded in the floor. It is Posvar Hall, not Posner Hall.

headline: One Gloomy Family
text: Leave it to the Irish to turn misery and recrimination into an art form. In “Red Roses and Petrol,” a soused, post-funeral postmortem on a dysfunctional Dublin family, the misery seeps from the screen in cold, damp waves; by the end you’ll be grabbing for the bottle yourself.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Movie Listings Highlight: Brigadoon
text: To find Brigadoon, it seems, you must move backward. That’s what the director Vincente Minnelli and the cinematographer Joseph Ruttenberg did for MGM’s “Brigadoon.” First they shot the discovery scene as a clear view of a village nestled in a valley and then pumped in fog to cover it over. Finally they projected the sequence in reverse, and Brigadoon emerged magically from the Highland mists for its one day every 100 years.

headline: The Kid Keeps Himself in the Picture
text: LONG BEACH, Calif.  There is a slight paunch and a tilt in his gait, the result of all the knee surgeries that serve as penance for all the years he spent as a major league catcher. But Gary Carter, even at 54, has the same camera-ready smile, the same golly-gee enthusiasm that he carried into rookie ball after graduating from  where else?  Sunny Hills High School.

headline: A Gambler Goes to Sin City in Search of Atonement
text: If the title “Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas” didn’t already belong to Hunter S. Thompson, it would perfectly fit Peter Tolan’s viciously funny satire, “Finding Amanda.” Set mostly in Sin City, it offers a through-the-looking-glass vision of confused Americans losing their already shaky bearings in the world’s gaudiest honky-tonk.

headline: How Well Will Budweiser Travel?
text: FRANKFURT

headline: Things to Know if You’re Considering a Vasectomy
text: Dr. Edmund Sabanegh Jr., is director of the Center for Male Fertility at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, where he has counseled hundreds of men about vasectomies. He offers a checklist of five things every man should know before deciding to have a vasectomy.

headline: Gifted Programs: The Teachers’ Union Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Your Brain Lies to You
text: FALSE beliefs are everywhere. Eighteen percent of Americans think the sun revolves around the earth, one poll has found. Thus it seems slightly less egregious that, according to another poll, 10 percent of us think that Senator Barack Obama, a Christian, is instead a Muslim. The Obama campaign has created a Web site to dispel misinformation. But this effort may be more difficult than it seems, thanks to the quirky way in which our brains store memories  and mislead us along the way.

headline: Another Yahoo Overhaul as It Tries to Right Itself
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  Under pressure from many shareholders for its poor performance and for its failure to complete a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo is doing something it has done several times before: reorganizing itself.

headline: Win One, Lose One for Dallas Museum
text: LONDON Now that Christie’s has celebrated one astronomical sale this week  a 1919 Monet waterlily painting that went for a record-breaking $80.4 million  it is gearing up for another.

headline: Call It Disney’s Food Kingdom
text: WHEN our children were 4 and 6, the idea of taking them to Disney World for part of spring vacation was under consideration. For about five minutes. Instead, we booked a trip to Rome, Naples and Sicily.

headline: Microsoft Seeks Path Beyond Gates’s Legacy
text: Bill Gates is retiring, sort of. He is still only 52, and he is going off to spend more time guiding the world’s richest philanthropy, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. He will still be Microsoft’s chairman and largest shareholder, but Friday is his last day as a full-time worker at the software giant, marking the unofficial end of his career as a business leader.

headline: Doctors Face Payment Cuts for Patients on Medicare
text: WASHINGTON  Doctors face a 10 percent cut in Medicare payments next week, following the Senate’s failure on Thursday to take up legislation that would have averted the cuts.

headline: Guitar Music, Chatty Players, No Dress Code
text: The summer procession of institutes and festivals at Mannes College the New School for Music reached its guitar installment, formally called the New York Guitar Seminar, on Wednesday evening.

headline: Man, 39, Charged in Fatal Stabbing of Girl, 15
text: A 39-year-old man who has been charged with the fatal stabbing of a 15-year-old girl on Wednesday night told police officers that he was acting in self-defense, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Thursday.

headline: Vasectomy: Safe, Simple and Little Used
text: A tiny puncture and a little snip, done under local anesthetic — that’s essentially all there is to a vasectomy.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Into Funding by Council Is to End Soon
text: A federal investigation into the City Council’s appropriation of funds to fictitious groups should conclude within 90 days, a prosecutor said on Thursday.

headline: When an Eloquent Voice Was Stilled in Hollywood
text: Peter Askin’s stirring documentary “Trumbo” gives you reasons to cheer but also to weep. It makes you lament the decline of the kind of language brandished with Shakespearean eloquence by Dalton Trumbo, the blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter, in his witty, impassioned letters excerpted in the movie.

headline: Phillips, New to Mets, Knows Opponent Well
text: PITTSBURGH  When he learned Wednesday that he was the newest member of the Mets, Andy Phillips had no hint he would head right back to Yankee Stadium. He had just been there last weekend, with the Cincinnati Reds, and used to play home games there for the Yankees.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: The Adventures of Georgia, Queen of the Desert Painting
text: It has been a big year for art onstage, with the revival of Stephen Sondheim’s “Sunday in the Park With George” and Mercedes Ruehl as Louise Nevelson in “Edward Albee’s Occupant.” Now comes the eager, animated actress-playwright Natalie Mosco tackling Georgia O’Keeffe, perhaps America’s first female superstar painter.

headline: 3 U.S. Marines and More than 30 Iraqis Die in 2 Bomb Attacks
Better Rail Service
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Rucker Park Documentary to Top of the N.B.A. Draft
text: On a muggy September day in 2006, Kevin Love became “Kevlar,” Jerryd Bayless got a name (“Pay Up”) to rhyme with his game (shifty layups) and Michael Beasley nearly tore the rims down at Manhattan’s most legendary outdoor court.

headline: Our Corner of the American Dream
text: To the Editor:

headline: Queens Bus-Stop Dispute Ends With Girl Dead
text: It began shortly before 10 on Wednesday night with an accusation that a woman had cut in line while waiting for a bus in Queens. It ended less than an hour and a few miles later with a 15-year-old girl lying mortally wounded on the sidewalk.

headline: Hunting With Hounds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gun-Control Supporters Show Outrage
text: Gun-control advocates across the country reacted with shock and outrage at the Supreme Court’s decision to strike down the District of Columbia’s ban on handguns today, saying the ruling would threaten gun-control measures in other states.

headline: Early Exits for Roddick and Sharapova
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Another historically bad day for American tennis ended with Andy Roddick demonstrating much better touch in the Wimbledon interview room than he had on Centre Court, where he was eliminated in the second round by Janko Tipsarevic of Serbia.

headline: On the Summer Menu: Light Musical Fare, Served With a Few Wry Asides
text: No sooner had the British conductor Bramwell Tovey kicked off the New York Philharmonic’s annual tour of the city’s parks with a festive program in Central Park on Tuesday night than he led the players back to Avery Fisher Hall for the first of this year’s Summertime Classics concerts on Wednesday.

headline: Dancing to Aspen
text: Damian Woetzel, who retired last week from the New York City Ballet after 23 years, has been named the 2008 Harman-Eisner Artist in Residence at the Aspen Institute. Mr. Woetzel will begin his tenure there this summer, taking part in leadership forums, an “idea festival” and a symposium on Tibet. (He has a master’s in public administration from the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and is a charter member of the Young Leaders Forum of the National Committee on United States-China Relations.) Mr. Woetzel, 41, is also the artistic director of the Vail International Dance Festival, which runs from July 27 to Aug. 10 this year.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Tuesday about Kermit Love, a costume designer and a creator, with Jim Henson, of “Sesame Street” characters including Big Bird, misstated Mr. Henson’s role in starting “Sesame Street.” The show was created by a team put together by the Children’s Television Workshop, now called Sesame Workshop; Mr. Henson was not the creator.

headline: A Pep Talk at Chrysler, Hailing Its Hero of the ’80s
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.  For one afternoon at least, it was like the good old days again at Chrysler.

headline: 'Idol' Tryouts in Puerto Rico
text: “American Idol” will conduct auditions for its eighth season in San Juan, P.R., and seven other cities; this is only the second time that the singing competition has gone outside the continental United States in its search for contestants. (Auditions were conducted in Hawaii in Season 3.) The auditions will begin on July 17 at the Cow Palace in San Francisco and continue in Louisville, Ky., on July 21; Phoenix on July 25; Salt Lake City on July 29; San Juan on Aug. 2; Kansas City, Mo., on Aug. 8; Jacksonville, Fla., on Aug. 13; and East Rutherford, N.J., on Aug. 19. The auditions are open to men and women ages 16 to 28 as of July 15 who are eligible to work in the United States; full regulations and details are available at AmericanIdol.com.

headline: Survey of Teachers Shows Dissatisfaction With Klein
text: A school year that began with a choreographed show of harmony between New York City’s schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, and the president of its teachers’ union, Randi Weingarten, ended on Thursday in discord, with the release of a survey in which thousands of the city’s teachers voiced strong disapproval of Mr. Klein’s leadership.

headline: Raw Materials of a Life, Revealed by Sculpture
text: Spirals abound in Louise Bourgeois’s art. She says they make her think of control and freedom, and of strangling someone. So it’s perfect that her retrospective, seen in London and Paris, is now in the looping rotunda of the Guggenheim Museum. It looks great there, clean but organic  fecund, tumid, enwrapping  and unclassically classical.

headline: Iran Fights Scourge of Addiction in Plain View, Stressing Treatment
text: TEHRAN  Ali blew out a candle on a small round cake. More than 200 people cheered, celebrating the first anniversary of his becoming drug-free.

headline: Kauai Lagoons and Derbyshire
text: Kauai Lagoons

headline: Trying to Find the Right Balance for the Seaport
text: For a relatively long moment in the late 1970s and early ’80s, Boston was pretty hot. Between the Preppy Handbook (which came out in 1980), the hit television series “Cheers “ (which premiered in 1982) and Steve’s Ice Cream (which originated in Boston and helped begin the national craze for fancy ice cream), all things Brahmin and baked-beany felt of-the-moment, if not exactly chic. Possibly the country was enjoying some kind of a post-bicentennial afterglow, leaving behind the messiness of the ’70s (and all that cinematic urban decay) for the kind of wholesome Americana vibe that Boston always captured so well.

headline: In the Metal Recycling Business, It’s Loud, Dirty and Suddenly Lucrative
text: Bob Rommeney steered his flatbed truck into a scrap-metal recycling plant in Brooklyn and unloaded two battered cars that had been wrecked days earlier at Riverhead Raceway on Long Island.

headline: All About Families, Generation After Generation
text: IT was clear from the day he got his driver’s license where Louis Cerone was going to hang out at the Jersey Shore.

headline: Clooney Offers Actors a Pre-emptive Strike
text: George Clooney, below, is offering some proposals aimed at breaking the negotiating standoff between the Screen Actors Guild and movie and television production companies: among them, annual pay reviews to be personally overseen by stars like Tom Hanks and Jack Nicholson and a substantial increase in the dues that high-earning actors pay the union. Mr. Clooney floated the ideas in a public statement on Thursday. The actors’ current contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers expires on Monday night, and talks have been stalled for weeks. “I’m not the brightest bulb out there,” Mr. Clooney’s statement said, inviting fresh thinking from anyone who has a better idea. His proposals involve creating a panel of high earners  “10 people that studio heads don’t often say ‘no’ to”  to seek an annual adjustment in actors’ pay based on information compiled by SAG and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, another actors’ union. He also suggested that actors, whose dues are now calculated on only their first $1 million in earnings, agree to eliminate the cap and pay $6,000 on each $1 million they earn, without limit. “That could go a long way in helping pensions and health care,” Mr. Clooney said.

headline: Correction: On Martha’s Vineyard on a Budget. Seriously.
text: An article on June 13 about Martha’s Vineyard on a budget misstated the price for one adult round trip on the Vineyard Fast Ferry over Memorial Day weekend. The round-trip fare was $86.50, which included fuel surcharges and port and security fees; not $94.50. (See www.vineyardfastferry.com for current fares.)

headline: Coming Next, Court Fights on Guns in Cities
text: WASHINGTON  The individual right to bear arms identified by the Supreme Court on Thursday will have little practical impact in most of the country, legal experts said, though Washington’s comprehensive ban on handguns used for self-defense in the home will have to be revised, and similar laws in several cities are also vulnerable.

headline: A Diplomatic Success That Defies the Critics
text: WASHINGTON  North Korea’s declaration of its nuclear activities is a triumph of the sort of diplomacy  complicated, plodding, often frustrating  that President Bush and his aides once eschewed as American weakness.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about a series of exhibitions in Philadelphia about evolution gave an erroneous identification from The Associated Press for a woman shown looking at an exhibit at the University of Pennsylvania. She is Bonnie Grant  not Bonnie Squires, a friend of Ms. Grant’s.

headline: ‘An Ex-mas Feast’
text: Now that my eldest sister, Maisha, was twelve, none of us knew how to relate to her anymore. She had never forgiven our parents for not being rich enough to send her to school. She had been behaving like a cat that was going feral: she came home less and less frequently, staying only to change her clothes and give me some money to pass on to our parents. When home, she avoided them as best she could, as if their presence reminded her of too many things in our lives that needed money. Though she would snap at Baba occasionally, she never said anything to Mama. Sometimes Mama went out of her way to provoke her. "Malaya! Whore! You don't even have breasts yet!" she'd say. Maisha would ignore her.

headline: A Close-Knit Trio Turns Itself Into a Quartet for a Night
text: Since officially declaring bandhood around the turn of the millennium, the Bad Plus has convincingly modeled a closed society. Its members  the pianist Ethan Iverson, the bassist Reid Anderson and the drummer David King  all hail from the upper Midwest, where they first played together as teenagers. Their chemistry is reactive but stable, and their methods don’t avail much room for outside contributions.

headline: Rikers Guards Accused of Passing Contraband to Inmate
text: Two Rikers Island correction officers were fired on Wednesday after they were accused of smuggling marijuana, alcohol and tobacco to an inmate who is awaiting trial in the death of a police officer last July, officials said.

headline: China Says It Opposes Politicizing Olympics
text: SHANGHAI  After months of warning other countries not to politicize the summer Olympic Games in Beijing, China has come under criticism from the International Olympic Committee for doing just that.

headline: You Talkin’ to Me, Boys? (Bang-Bang, My Pretties)
text: The money shot in “Wanted,” its pièce-de-special-effects-résistance and reason for green-lighted being, appears in the opening minutes of this noisy, ultraviolent shoot-’em-up with Angelina Jolie, her many tattoos and some guys. A man has soared onto the roof of a high-rise where he has laid a handful of others to waste. Suddenly the camera cuts to his face as a bullet exits his forehead in slow motion, his skin stretching forward as the projectile tears through it, going straight for the camera and our already numbed skulls.

headline: Giants to Charge Seat License Fees for New Stadium
text: Less than five months after winning the Super Bowl, the Giants said Thursday that they would charge their fans one-time fees, called personal seat licenses, for every seat in the stadium that they were building with the Jets.

headline: Suit Claims UBS Misled Investors
text: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS on the grounds of fraud, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities and that it pushed the increasingly risky instruments on individual investors to reduce its own potential losses.

headline: Selected Studies: Vasectomy
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Mayo Shows That He Was Made for New York
text: Fifteen minutes into the conversation, you begin to wish that O. J. Mayo were being drafted by your N.B.A. team. Especially if your team is the hapless Knicks, a franchise lost in darkness that has not had a great point guard in more than three decades. They incurred the wrath of fans Thursday by making Danilo Gallinari of Italy their No. 1 pick, passing up D. J. Augustin of Texas and Eric Gordon of Indiana.

headline: New Flavors for Addresses on the Web Are on the Way
text: PARIS  Move over .com and .org. Get ready for a nearly infinite variety of new Web addresses ending in words like .perfume, .sports and .paris.

headline: Gloom Descends Over Wall Street Again
text: Once more, gloom is descending over Wall Street.

headline: Corrections: The Harbor View Hotel & Resort and Azulera Resort Village
text: A report in the Breaking Ground column last Friday about the Harbor View Hotel & Resort in Edgartown, Mass., using information from a representative of the developer, referred incorrectly to several phases of construction at the site.

headline: Mother of 2 Killed at Y.M.C.A. Pool
text: A 31-year-old woman was shot and killed at a Y.M.C.A. pool in Montclair, N.J., on Thursday night by the father of her two children, officials said, as her son and daughter and dozens of other children and parents watched from a few feet away.

headline: Retirees Find the Time May Be Right to Buy
text: THE euphoria is past. The era of rampant house flipping is gone. What was once a seemingly unstoppable climb in home prices has given way to a plunge in value in many areas.

headline: N.B.A. Draft and 2 Trades Change Outlook in East
text: An N.B.A. draft that promised wild twists, trades and misdirection instead unfolded with an almost predictable rhythm Thursday evening.

headline: Bush Rebuffs Hard-Liners to Ease North Korean Curbs
text: WASHINGTON  Two days ago, during an off-the-record session with a group of foreign policy experts, Vice President Dick Cheney got a question he did not want to answer. “Mr. Vice President,” asked one of them, “I understand that on Wednesday or Thursday, we are going to de-list North Korea from the terrorism blacklist. Could you please set the context for this decision?”

headline: Wicked Witch Bounces in Like a Bohemian Big Sister
text: When you are as closely identified with a role as Idina Menzel is with Elphaba, the Wicked Witch of the West in the Broadway musical “Wicked,” how do you step out of it into a concert without alienating your fans (in her case mostly girls and young women) who expect her to be a version of Elphaba? That was the question Ms. Menzel wrestled with in her eccentric concert on Wednesday evening at Town Hall, where she appeared with a drum-heavy rock quartet and two backup singers.

headline: With 3 You Get Egg Roll and a Side of Adventure
text: “Three Delivery” is a great-looking new prime-time cartoon on the Nicktoons network. Set in Chinatown in San Francisco, it features three young orphans who save the world nightly while delivering food for their adoptive Nana’s restaurant, Wu’s Garden. The action takes place after dark, and the animation is a riot of reds, greens and yellows: neon signs, rampaging dragons, rivers of hot-and-sour soup.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Scientist, Claiming Bias, Sues U.S. Over Revoked Clearance
text: PITTSBURGH  An Egyptian-born nuclear physicist who worked in a government-financed laboratory here for 18 years filed a lawsuit on Thursday saying the Energy Department had revoked his security clearance because of his ethnicity, his Muslim faith and comments he made criticizing the war in Iraq.

headline: Justices, Ruling 5-4, Endorse Personal Right to Own Gun
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday embraced the long-disputed view that the Second Amendment protects an individual right to own a gun for personal use, ruling 5 to 4 that there is a constitutional right to keep a loaded handgun at home for self-defense.

headline: Vic Hershkowitz, Dominant Handball Star, Dies at 89
text: Vic Hershkowitz, a New York City fireman who learned handball on the playgrounds of Brooklyn and was considered by many to be the sport’s most brilliant player, died Monday in Plantation, Fla. He was 89 and lived in Davie, Fla.

headline: Marching Noisily Toward Late Middle Age
text: As increasing numbers of baby boomers march noisily into late middle age and early dinners, the wrinkly romance (a genre generally ignored by youth-obsessed Hollywood unless the wrinkles belong to Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson) could become a multiplex staple. Look out for softer popcorn and larger subtitles.

headline: London Exchange Plans New Trading System
text: London Stock Exchange Group, seeking to regain a leading role, said on Thursday that it would create a pan-European trading system in partnership with Lehman Brothers.

headline: Foreign Investment in City Is Growing, Report Finds
text: More than one-tenth of all the goods and services produced in New York City and 1 of every 20 jobs are supplied by companies controlled by foreign investors, according to a report scheduled to be released on Friday by the Partnership for New York City.

headline: U.S. Beef to Reach South Korean Markets Next Week
text: SEOUL -- Thousands of tons of American beef, held for months in South Korean warehouses because of concerns about mad cow disease, will be released to the markets next week, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Corrections
H.I.V. Diagnosis Rates Continue to Rise Among Young Men, African-Americans
text: Diagnoses of H.I.V. and AIDS in men who have sex with men rose significantly between 2001 and 2006 while declining in other demographic groups, the federal Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday.

headline: DDT on Ice
text: It has been getting ever harder to pretend that Antarctica is a pristine place. We like to think of it as being scoured clean by hostile winds and extreme cold. But more and more, Antarctica, like the Arctic, shows the lasting scars of human negligence.

headline: Oooooh, Canada
text: LATE last Saturday evening, La Ronde, an amusement park that’s just a stone’s throw from downtown Montreal on an island in the St. Lawrence River, seemed an unlikely venue for a world-class competition. Teenagers with the giggles and other signs of roller-coaster overexposure contemplated yet another ride on the Super Manège or Le Monstre. Younger children, slowed by too much barbe à papa (cotton candy) and poutine (that Québécois concoction of French fries, cheese curds and gravy), were willed along by weary parents. The occasional large Fred Flintstone or Scooby-Doo plush doll appeared among the midway crowd, bounty from booths like Frappez la Taupe (Whack the Mole) and Roulé-Boulé (a form of skeeball).

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Corrections
text: The Big City column on June 16, about the Abrahamson family, African-American Hasidic Jews who moved from Omaha to Brooklyn, included an erroneous distinction from the family matriarch about her family. The Abrahamsons were not in fact the only Hasids in Omaha when they lived there.

headline: Water, Soap and Open Air
text: SUMMER means the beach, the sand, the sun, the pool  factors that prompt many second-home owners to think about installing an outdoor shower. Whether the goal is to wash off the ocean brine after a swim, to prep for the pool before you jump in, or to serenely bathe au naturel outdoors, an exterior shower can be a beautiful thing. But building and maintaining one takes planning.

headline: Europe Tells Airlines to Pay for Emissions
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union reached a landmark agreement Thursday to cap emissions from aircraft, raising the stakes in an increasingly ferocious battle with the United States over how to regulate global greenhouse gases.

headline: As Africa’s Horrors Rage, Suffer the Little Children
text: It’s Christmastime in Kenya in “An Ex-Mas Feast,” the first short story in Uwem Akpan’s startling debut collection, “Say You’re One of Them.” The narrator is Jigana, an 8-year-old boy. His 12-year-old sister is a prostitute, which makes her Jigana’s most fortunate family member by a long shot. His 10-year-old sister wants to follow the older girl’s example. There are also 2-year-old twins and a baby who’s used as a prop for begging. The family’s most precious Christmas gift is a container of sniffable glue.

headline: Twenty Five Years Later, Dave Righetti’s No-Hitter
text: It was a warm holiday afternoon nearly 25 years ago, a perfect day for July 4th baseball. For the Yankees’ Dave Righetti, it was also a perfect day to pitch a no-hitter against the Boston Red Sox. On that afternoon, Righetti whiffed Wade Boggs, flung his arms in the air and celebrated his doodle of a day at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Friday’s Link: The Illustrated Work-Life
text: I have been spending some time over at Ribbon Farm, the blog of Venkatesh Rao, who brings fresh insights to the discussion on work-life balance through whimsical and thoughtful drawings like the one above. The drawing comes fairly close to what my blurry work-life looks like most weeks, though I still aim for at least a day or two a week that look like the Sunday on Mr. Rao’s “then” drawing (though not necessarily on a weekend).

headline: Now That Europe has Capped Airline Emissions, Will America Follow?
text: With the EU capping emissions on intercontinental flights, American airlines might be forced out of Europe if they fail to comply. (Daniel Munoz/Reuters)

headline: Donadoni Out for Italy; Lippi Back In
text: Four days. Four days is all it took Italian soccer officials to banish Roberto Donadoni and replace him as national team coach with … Marcello Lippi.

headline: Personal Seat Licenses: Jets to Giants, You First
text: The Giants and the Jets are sharing in all aspects of their new stadium.

headline: Euro 2008: Spain vs. Russia
text: Spain beat Russia, advancing to the finals of the 2008 European Soccer Championships.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 63 Washington
text: Location: Seattle.

‘What an Insult’
text: More of your user-generated comedy (send via the comment link below):

headline: A weekly roundup of the latest from the T Web site
text: With her penchant for armor and feathers, the fashion muse Daphne Guinness has been to known to turn heads. But in her short film “The Phenomenology of Body,” the beer heiress cum director puts the politics of fashion on display. Taking the viewer through a revolving journey of how clothes have defined, constricted and liberated women throughout history, Guinness presents a stark catalog of vintage, new and costume pieces. The result, a spare and thoughtful voyage set to “Great Release” by LCD Soundsystem, reveals both the warrior and swan in Guinness. T: Online unveils  the exclusive short here.

headline: Jesus Held Hostage
text: For some reason this story from earlier this year eluded Laugh Lines, until now. From a local TV news station in Michigan:

headline: Part-Time Pickups
text: Pontiac has announced it will begin selling the Holden Ute, a car-based pickup much like the sporty haulers that Americans had known years earlier as the Chevrolet El Camino and Ford Ranchero.

headline: AniBoom.com Draws $10 Million
text: AniBoom.com has raised $10 million in funding led by venture capital firm Draper Fisher, Reuters reported. The Internet site allows animators to create and share their work.

headline: Middle Eastern and Asian Investors Flock Into U.S. and European Property
text: A wave of capital from the Middle East and Asia could be on its way into the ailing U.S. and European property markets, as a weak dollar and falling asset prices lure sovereign wealth funds and institutional investors.

headline: Duke Energy Acquires Catamount in $320 Million Deal
text: In a privately negotiated deal, Diamond Castle Holdings has sold Catamount Energy to Duke Energy for $320 million including debt.

headline: KSG Raises $194 Million in I.P.O.
text: KSK Energy has completed an initial public offering to raise $194 million just four months after fixing the price at the bottom of the indicated range, Finance Asia reported.

headline: News Corp. Could Bid for European Pay TV Players
text: The News Corporation may bid for two major pay-TV players, Germany’s Premiere and Spain’s Digital+, in a move that could give more responsibility to James Murdoch, son of News Corp. chief Rupert Murdoch, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday.

headline: Asia Deal-Making Rises in 1st Half of 2008
text: Mergers and acquisitions across Asia are headed to mark an 8.7 percent rise to $362 billion in volume for the first half of 2008, after accelerating in the second quarter, according to preliminary data from Thomson Reuters.

headline: Virgin Green Fund Raises $199 Million
text: Virgin Group‘s first green investment fund has attracted the interest of such maiden investors Wolverhampton City Council and Calpers, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Microsoft Said to Find Deal for Powerset
text: Microsoft has agreed to buy Silicon Valley semantic search engine Powerset, Venture Beat reported. The acquisition price is rumored to be slightly more than $100 million with an announcement expected in July.

headline: Are Spacs Back in Fashion?
text: Navios Maritime Acquisition‘s $220 million initial public offering this week could be an indication that special purpose acquisition companies are back in favor, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Everbright in Shanghai I.P.O.
text: Everbright Securities is gearing up for an initial public offering to sell as many as 520 million shares in Shanghai.

headline: National Australia Bank Eyeing HBOS Unit
text: National Australia Bank may bid for HBOS‘s Australian unit, Bloomberg reported citing people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: China South Locomotive May Roll With I.P.O.
text: China South Locomotive & Rolling Stock may sell a 30 percent stake in a Shanghai initial public offering to help fund nearly 9 billion yuan ($1.3 billion) of projects, Bloomberg reported citing a company filing.

headline: Judge Rejects Hedge Funds’ Attempts to Block Candover-Expro Deal
text: Britain’s High Court has rejected a last-gasp effort mounted by a group of hedge funds to block Candover‘s 1.8 billion pound bid for oil services group Expro, The Telegraph reported.

headline: GMR Takes Half of InterGen for $1.1 Billion
text: GMR Infrastructure has bought 50 percent of InterGen from AIG Highstar for an equity value of $1.1 billion. The deal marks the largest ever acquisition of a global energy utility by an Indian company, Finance Asia reported.

headline: Stray Questions for: Mary Jo Salter
text: Mary Jo Salter is the author of “A Phone Call to the Future: New and Selected Poems.” She is a professor in the writing seminars at Johns Hopkins University.

headline: Bank of America to Cut 7,500 Jobs After Countrywide Deal
text: Bank of America on Thursday said it expects to eliminate about 7,500 jobs over the next two years after it completes its acquisition of Countrywide Financial, the largest U.S. mortgage lender.

headline: Apollo Has Cut 1,500 Jobs at U.K.’s Countrywide
text: Apollo Management has slashed more than 1,500 jobs at Countrywide since buying the British company at last year’s market peak, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bradford & Bingley Shareholders Up in Arms but Cowdery Remains Resolute
text: Bradford & Bingley investors are clamoring for an urgent clarification of the agreement between the lender and Texas Pacific Group because of growing fears that the private equity firm’s deal would make it almost impossible for the company to negotiate with other bidders.

headline: America – An Iraqi’s First Impression
text: Suadad al-Salhy is an Iraqi reporter who recently joined The New York Times in Iraq. In May she was one of five Iraqi journalists who visited the United States on a reporting tour organized by the State Department to learn about ‘How America’s Middle East Policy is Formulated.’

headline: Cadence May Have to Raise Bid for Mentor, Analysts Say
text: Earlier this month, Mentor Graphics rejected an unsolicited $1.6 billion takeover bid from Cadence Design Systems Inc. Analysts now say Cadence will have to up the ante in order to succeed in buying the rival chip design software maker, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: For Smaller U.S. Banks, Risk Management Might Become Easier
text: The majority of U.S. banks would have the option to adopt alternative risk-based capital adequacy rules based on the Basel II accords, under a proposal agreed to by a top U.S. banking regulator, Reuters reported.

headline: Spoleto Italy: The Menottis Are History
text: SPOLETO, Italy — Menotti? Menotti who?

headline: As Markets Plunge, Deal-Making Plummets
text: Gloom has descended over Wall Street once again. While the price of oil is rising, the health of the financial sector is flagging, taking yet another heavy toll on the markets.

headline: I’m In Like With You Pulls in $1.5 Million Round
text: Social-network-turned-gaming-site I’m In Like With You has raised $1.5 million of venture funding led by Spark Capital, CNet News reported.

headline: He Says That to All the Possible Running Mates
text: CINCINNATI – You are a (comparatively) young Republican making a name for yourself, and your name keeps cropping up on media lists of potential running mates for Senator John McCain. But with the McCain campaign playing its cards so close to the vest, it can be maddeningly hard to figure out where you stand.

headline: Another Yahoo Overhaul as It Tries to Right Itself
text: Under pressure from many shareholders for its poor performance and for its failure to complete a deal with Microsoft, Yahoo is doing something it has done several times before: reorganizing itself.

headline: London Theater Journal: Ibsen, in “Rosmersholm,” Still Keeps Them Guessing
text: By the second intermission, speculation had become feverish at the Almeida Theater on Thursday night. Anthony Page’s hot-ticket production of Ibsen’s “Rosmersholm,” starring Paul Hilton and Helen McCrory as the fatally entwined central characters, might have occasioned all sorts of cerebral commentary: about its contemporary relevance in its portrayal of unbridgeable class divisions, vicious political warfare and the tyranny of a lie-mongering press in shaping opinion.

headline: Settlement Reached in Facebook Case
text: From our colleagues at Bits:

headline: JPMorgan’s Jimmy Lee Honored
text: JPMorgan Chase vice chairman James B. Lee Jr. was honored last night at The New York Public Library. Stephen Schwarzman, the chairman of Blackstone Group introduced him by saying, “Jimmy Lee has lent more money than anyone in the history of the world. It’s truly astounding and he’s gotten virtually all of it back.”

headline: Hedge Funds to Back Barclays Bid for $8.9 Billion
text: The $8.9 billion that Barclays plans to raise will be backed by several of London’s largest hedge funds, The Financial Times reported citing a prospectus issued by the bank on Thursday. But an analyst said that fundraising round may not be enough.

headline: Suit Claims UBS Misled Investors
text: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS on the grounds of fraud, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities and that it pushed the increasingly risky instruments on individual investors to reduce its own potential losses.

headline: Chrysler Denies Bankruptcy Speculation
text: A spokesman for Chrysler said on Thursday that market rumors of a bankruptcy filing by the privately held automaker were “without merit,” saying the company had ample liquidity.

headline: When a Done Deal Unravels
text: At the time he agreed to sell the Huntsman Corporation for $10.6 billion last year, the chemical maker’s chief executive thought he had a solid deal. But now Peter Huntsman is steaming mad.

headline: New Ad Hits Obama on Abortion
text: The lobbying arm of the Family Research Council, the conservative Christian organization, is going on the air in several cities on Friday with a television ad featuring a personal note from the group’s president, Tony Perkins, to Senator Barack Obama. The message: Mr. Obama’s abortion rights stance is hypocritical.

headline: Post-Spitzer, a New Breed of Reformer
text: No one is dusting off those valiant titles once bestowed on Eliot Spitzer, honorifics like “The Enforcer” and “Sheriff of Wall Street.” But slowly, even a bit gently, Mr. Spitzer’s successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry, according to The New York Times.

headline: Video: N. Korea’s Nuclear Demolition
text: To follow up on Thursday’s post, the cooling tower at Yongbyon nuclear facility is no more:

headline: How High Must InBev Go to Reach a Friendly Anheuser Deal?
text: Now that Anheuser-Busch has rejected a $65 a share offer by InBev — and with the Belgian beer maker making it clear it is prepared to go hostile — just how high will InBev go to ensure a friendly deal?

text: From Talk Left:

text: Kim Jones

headline: NBC.com Sees ‘Tens of Millions’ in Profit in 2009

headline: The Early Word: Meet Me in New Hampshire
text: Among the Democrats, it seems that party unity has been in the air all week. And today, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, each the head of their own warring faction during the long primary march, will join at an event and in a place dripping with the symbolism of togetherness.

headline: Matters of convenience (very wonkish)
text: The reading list for today’s column is below.

headline: Fueling 1,000 Stories
text: While $4-a-gallon gas has introduced the nation to issues like a gas-tax holiday, ethanol, hydrogen fuel cells and offshore drilling, its effect on individuals reminds me of what one of my college professors said about the ’60s television show “Gilligan’s Island.” He explained that the entire show could be distilled to one basic formula: Each episode, a new element is introduced onto the island (giant spider, butterfly collector, jungle boy, robot, magic mind-reading seeds, meteorite), and the plot/comedy is derived from how the castaways react to it.

headline: Mayor and Council Reach Deal on $59.1 Billion Budget
text: With a legal deadline four days away, city officials brokered a deal on Thursday night on a $59.1 billion budget that would preserve a popular tax cut for homeowners and a $400 rebate and add $129 million in education spending to what had originally been proposed, David W. Chen and Michael Barbaro report.

headline: Deal Volume Falls, but Corporate Buyers Keep Rising
text: Already, one report has noted doom and gloom in the deal-making world. Now Dealogic is adding its own take on the slump that has overtaken the world of mergers and acquisitions.

headline: All Aboard the Trip to Unity
text: Updated WASHINGTON – Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton boarded a plane together here today, destination: Unity.

headline: Gun Crazy
text: The Supreme Court’s gun-rights decision, District of Columbia v. Heller, continues to occupy the chattersphere:

headline: Anheuser’s Staggering Defense
text: InBev on Thursday filed suit in Delaware Chancery Court against its resisting target, Anheuser-Busch. The Brazilian-Belgian brewer is seeking a judicial declaration that the five Anheuser directors elected when Anheuser’s board was staggered are eligible for removal without cause.

headline: AIG Expects Up to $5 Billion in Losses on Subprime Write-Downs
text: After the ouster of its chief executive and a massive loss, one might think that the American International Group has suffered plenty. But one of its executives told Bloomberg News that the insurance giant plans to absorb losses for a dozen units after their securities-lending accounts suffered $13 billion of subprime-related write-downs.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Sautéed Cherries With Ice Cream
text: This is a rethinking of the summer pie: a sweet, chunky sauce that’s great with ice cream, without the crust or the superfluous spice.

headline: ‘Ich Bin ein Berliner’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Big ruling coming out of the Supreme Court now: they have ruled individuals have the right to carry guns. Oh my God, yeah, but now listen, seriously, don’t think you can just go into a gun store and buy a gun. No, no, no, no, no, there is still a strict 15-minute waiting period.

headline: Being JT
text: There’s a funny scene in “Short Cuts,” the Robert Altman movie based loosely on Raymond Carver’s stories, where a frazzled Lois (Jennifer Jason Leigh) is changing her baby’s diaper while talking dirty to a customer on a phone-sex line.

headline: Pregnancy Pact Principal Stands Firm
text: As his statements to Time magazine stirred national attention and a local furor over his credibility, the principal of Gloucester High School in Massachusetts has been silent on this year’s spike in pregnancies among his students and the word he used to describe their intentional nature: “pact.”

headline: Chelsea Plants a Flag Stateside
text: When you tug on Superman’s cape, you tend to get a swift reaction.

headline: George Carlin’s 1989 Appearance on Kiner’s Korner
text: One of the late George Carlin’s best bits was his comparison between baseball and football where he dissects the differences between America’s two favorite sports.

headline: An Election With One Candidate
text: Zimbabweans voted Friday in a runoff presidential election with only one candidate â€” President Robert Mugabe.

headline: Now Screening | Daphne Guinness
text: The new look of T’s Web site featuring Daphne Guinness.

headline: Spoleto Italy: Reveling in the Seclusion of a Hill Town
text: SPOLETO, Italy — The festival has made Spoleto a well-known place, but in so many ways it is just another north-central Italian hill town. Impressively narrow streets dip and rise steeply, voices echo among the buildings, ancient architectural features sit embedded in plastered walls, the local government is leftist-led, and large death notices mourning lost citizens cover billboards.

headline: Graffiti Artists, Kings of Walls, Now Dress Windows
text: Biz Markie’s “Just A Friend” from 1989 echoed through Tats Cru’s South Bronx studio, where a hazy cloud of spray paint hung in the air. As the grafffiti artists worked on a mural, they’d stop, lean back to gauge their progress, and then lean in close to do fills and lines.

headline: McCain Ad Touts Energy Policy
text: The McCain campaign appears to be trying to ensure that Senator John McCain’s energy plan, which includes a grab bag of proposals such as lifting the federal moratorium on offshore oil exploration and developing alternative fuels, will have broad resonance.

headline: The Starting Line: Today’s Cavalcade of Doping
text: Still more doping suspensions dominate today’s worldwide Olympic news, including a lifetime ban for one of China’s top swimmers — but let’s start with the withdrawal of Bulgaria’s entire weightlifting team after 11 of its members tested positive for the banned anabolic steroid methandienon earlier this month. The Bulgarians’ withdrawal bears an eerie resemblance to last month’s revelation that 11 members of the Greek weightlifting team had tested positive for banned substances.

headline: Built for Speed

headline: On the Road to Yankee Stadium
text: Good morning from the media bus zooming over the Triborough Bridge. I’ve got George Vecsey sitting in front of me, Mike Vaccaro of the Post behind me. We were supposed to leave at 11:30 a.m. – promptly, from what I was told by the Mets’ PR staff – and, wow, at 11:31 and we pulled out. That’s punctuality, right there.

headline: The Insider | Tim Barber
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the photographer, curator and publisher Tim Barber shares a few of his stylish essentials. Barber, who runs the online art gallery Tiny Vices and the newly launched print-on-demand publishing house TV Books, is hosting a special two-day exhibition/catalog viewing this weekend (see the invitation after the jump). But Barber doesn’t keep his curatorial sixth sense strictly digital. He has brought his hyperlinking vision to a range of international exhibitions and gallery spaces, most recently as a co-curator of the 2008 New York Photo Festival.

headline: Letters: Anonymous Sources and the Apostate Column
text: Re “Culling the Anonymous Sources” (June 8 ) : I believe the problem with accountability of anonymous statements can be solved with a simple baseball-like statistic. Reporters and their editors should carry a “believability average” — some ratio of “proved true,” “still unknown truth,” “proved false” — whereby anonymous statements are reviewed multiple times after those statements were published.If individual writers and editors had individual ratings attached to them, the public would be better informed about anonymous sources while those reporters and editors would have to think harder about what to publish because their entire decision-making history would be on the line.Scott KaczmarekSeattle, June 8, 2008

Your column is a case in point. Is it worth asking whether The Times has been biased in its reporting, or whether it has been prejudiced? Certainly! headline: The Yankees’ Morning After the Night Before
text: The Yankees began ambling into the clubhouse Friday around noon for the 2:05 p.m. game. “Business as usual,” Manager Joe Girardi called it. Eleven hours earlier, they were just getting off their flight from Pittsburgh, putting an end to a frustrating night that saw them sit at PNC Park in a two-and-a-half-hour rain delay until the game was called off. Not the ideal way to prepare for a day-night, two-stadium doubleheader against the Mets.

headline: Levantine Kaffeeklatsch
text: In a back page essay for this Sunday’s Book Review, I write about a boutique Jerusalem-based publisher, Ibis Editions, which is devoted to publishing books from the Levant. It was founded in 1998 by the biographer and critic Adina Hoffman and the poet and translator Peter Cole, whose book of Medieval Hebrew poetry we reviewed here. Ibis recently issued the first English translation of a controversial Hebrew novella, “Khirbet Khizeh,” by the Israeli author S. Yizhar, which tells of the violent evacuation of a Palestinian village by a Jewish unit in the 1948 war of independence. (In recent years, Toby Press has released English translations of two other books by Yizhar, “Midnight Convoy and Other Stories” and “Preliminaries.”)

headline: Emmy Finalists: The Likely Nominees and Long Shots

headline: The Morning Skate: Jagr, Avery, Sundin, Orpik and Dinah Washington
text: July 1, as every hockey fan knows, is a special day. It’s Canada Day! (Quick translation here for Americans: It’s sorta Canada’s Fourth of July, but it’s three days earlier and it also doesn’t celebrate Canada’s complete independence from Great Britain the way July 4 does — because that didn’t happen on July 1, 1867, but rather in 1982 when the final constitutional link was broken, but it was the start of the process.)

headline: Your Sister’s Dress
text: The Paris men’s shows have started. Last evening, a beautiful Paris sort of evening, Mr. Alloux and I were on our way to Dries Van Noten’s show in the 15th, at the site of a former slaughter house for horses. Our destination prompted a culinary discussion (in my limited French) about the differences between horse and beef. Mr. Alloux said that horse meat was once a commonplace in France and that, in terms of taste, you could barely distinguish it from beef. He asked me if horse was ever popular in the States, and I replied that it may have been at one time in some places but that we Americans tended to keep Nelly in the barn.

headline: Carving the Presidents in Dumbo
text: Even with Independence Day and then Election Day fast approaching, the most presidential place in New York City at the moment just might be an unexpected one: the work space of the design and fabrication company StudioEIS on the fourth floor of an anonymous-looking building in Dumbo, Brooklyn.There, in one corner, is a nearly completed new sculpture of Abraham Lincoln standing with a horse. In another, a Thomas Jefferson statue bound for Monticello. And down a hallway, an early version of a sitting James Madison that will one day join a statue of his wife, Dolley Madison, and take up residence outside their historic home at Montpelier.

headline: Dr. Gary Wadler of the World Anti-Doping Agency Gives His Answers to Your Questions (Part II)
text: Last week we solicited your questions to one of the world’s top experts in detecting prohibited performance-enchancing drugs — Dr. Gary Wadler, chairman of the World Anti-Doping Agency’s Prohibited List and Methods Committee. Many of your questions pertained to issues recently raised in connection with drug-detection tests administered to Olympic athletes.

headline: An Ex-Banker’s Unusual Job Pitch
text: It’s hard to find a job these days on Wall Street. Most financial firms are liquidating staff from top to bottom amid a global economic slowdown that has hit the financial sector particularly hard. Those that find themselves out of a job are busy sending resumes to recruiters and human resources personnel, but they seem to get lost in an electronic abyss.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: The Oracle Collective
text: You’re not supposed to use the Internet like a Magic 8 Ball. Google can’t tell you whether you’ll pass the bar exam or find happiness in Spokane. But almost from the start, the Web has been barraged with personal questions — often highly subjective ones. Internet users want to do more than “conduct searches” as if they were military police. They want to canvass opinions, plead for sympathy, share an experience or otherwise be humored.

headline: Man Sentenced for Plundering Body Parts
text: A New Jersey dentist, Michael Mastromarino, 44, was sentenced to 18 to 54 years in prison on Friday after pleading guilty to being the mastermind behind a multimillion-dollar enterprise that harvested tissue and body parts from funeral homes and sold them for use in transplants and medical research. Among the bodies plundered was that of Alistair Cooke, the British journalist and former host of “Masterpiece Theater.” Mr. Mastromarino, 44, had pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on March 18 to numerous charges of enterprise corruption, reckless endangerment and body stealing. He admitted leading a harvesting operation that sold hundreds, perhaps thousands, of bone fragments and bits of flesh from people who had never given their consent to being donors. The body parts were sold to tissue processors around the country, and eventually to medical companies for use in surgical transplants like bone and skin grafts.

headline: Church Has ‘Outside Chance’ of Playing This Weekend
text: Ryan Church could rejoin the Mets as soon as Saturday if he felt well after playing the outfield Friday night in Class A Brooklyn’s game against Aberdeen. He went 0 for 3 and played seven innings in right field. But Manager Jerry Manuel said Church, on the disabled list since June 6 because of post-concussion symptoms, would have only “an outside chance” of playing this weekend. “If he’s not quite ready, Sunday could be a good day for him, could be,” Manuel said. “That would be kind of pushing it anyway.” Manuel said Church would definitely not start Saturday, when Andy Pettitte, a left-hander, is scheduled to pitch. Church went 3 for 3 and played right field Thursday for Brooklyn but the Mets recommended he play another game before evaluating him.

headline: Paris: Showing Off
text: The French are feeling as economically pinched as Americans, but I get the sense they are busting to look fashionable. I’ve noticed it all day as I go around to shows and look at people on the streets. Heading to Montmartre, I saw a young woman—20s, thin, medium height—in a pair of slim gray shorts that ended mid-thigh, a loose navy popover top, and a classic pair of black stilettos. Super chic. I’ve seen slim-fitting shorts with a sailor front, worn with chunky black sandals and a cream silk blouse. The look is tailored and sexy. And there are lots of women in mini skirts; this afternoon I saw a woman in a flaring navy cotton skirt with a red and white striped polo shirt. The best-looking dress at the moment seems to be a dark tunic. I’ve noticed a lot of the guys in the front row also wearing shorts, especially as a kind of nerd school-boy uniform with knee socks and maybe a pastel vest and a tie. And it’s a little surprising how many shows have hats—the porkpie, the scarecrow, the snap-brim. Shades of next summer…
