headline: In a Virtual Galaxy, Assembly Is Required
text: Most video games can be likened to a theme park. The fun, like a roller coaster’s, has been entirely created by a team of professionals, and the players then progress through each loop, each dip, each turn in a way that has been meticulously designed to produce a specific effect. Books and films tell stories in a similar way.

headline: Number of Salmonella Illnesses Grows
text: The number of reported illnesses from the salmonella outbreak associated with raw tomatoes has risen to 810 cases in 36 states and the District of Columbia, federal officials said. Investigators are also “looking into other ingredients” that could be the source of the outbreak, although it remains most closely linked with tomatoes, said Dr. Patricia Griffin of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Ransom Frees Lawmaker’s Kin in Mexico
text: A Mexican citizen who is a distant relative of a prominent congressman from Texas was kidnapped last week in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, and then released within three days after the victim’s immediate family paid ransom of $32,000.

headline: Class-Action Lawyer Gets 5 Years in Bribery Case
text: Richard F. Scruggs, whose successful battle against the tobacco industry in the 1990s made him one of the country’s best-known plaintiff’s lawyers, was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison for conspiring to bribe a judge.

headline: A Goya Downgraded
text: The Prado Museum in Madrid said on Thursday that “El Coloso,” right, the oil painting of a looming giant long attributed to Francisco de Goya, was probably painted by an assistant. The authenticity of the painting, which was created during Napoleon’s occupation of Spain, had been disputed by a Goya specialist at the museum, Manuela Mena, The Independent of London reported. “Stylistically, it is completely alien to Goya,” said Ms. Mena. “The person who painted the bulls in ‘El Coloso’ knew nothing about the anatomy of a bull, which Goya knew everything about.” José Luis Díez, a curator at the Prado, also claims that initials at the bottom corner of the work belong to Asensio Juliá, Goya’s assistant, The Telegraph reported. The painting has been omitted from “Goya in Times of War,” a special exhibition commemorating the bicentennial of the start of the Spanish War of Independence, which runs through July 13.

headline: For Now, Ponson Fits Into Yankees’ Puzzle
text: The new savior was sitting beside the entrance to the Yankees’ clubhouse. The pitcher who was charged with making sure that Friday was not a total waste for the Yankees was waiting for his teammates to shower and dress. Sidney Ponson, the accidental Yankee, was actually smiling.

headline: Scientist Is Paid Millions by U.S. in Anthrax Suit
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department announced Friday that it would pay $4.6 million to settle a lawsuit filed by Steven J. Hatfill, a former Army biodefense researcher intensively investigated as a “person of interest” in the deadly anthrax letters of 2001.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Working Together, Obama and Clinton Try to Show Unity
text: UNITY, N.H.  Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton set off on their maiden political voyage on Friday, trading their rivalry from the presidential primary battle for a newfound display of harmony intended to set a fresh tone for any Democrats still harboring bitterness from their grueling duel.

headline: Face to Face: A Council of Online Gamers
text: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  This city near the top of the world has a distinguished history of hosting summit meetings. Presidents, prime ministers and premiers have come here to discuss their differences and chart earth’s future.

headline: Senate Democrats Attack Republicans on Medicare
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats moved swiftly on Friday to assail Republican senators for voting against a major Medicare bill and said the Republicans should be held responsible for a 10 percent cut in payments to doctors that takes effect next week.

headline: Royalty Bill Moves Forward
text: Musicians, singers and record companies seeking more radio royalties won an initial victory in Congress on Thursday. The House Subcommittee on Courts, the Internet and Intellectual Property passed the Performance Rights Act, which would reverse terrestrial radio’s exemption from paying royalties to the performers of sound recordings, which satellite and Internet radio stations are required to pay. The measure still faces opposition in the House and in the Senate, which is considering its own version.

headline: Fox Tops Slow Night
text: Fox ranked No. 1 in the ratings on a slow summer Thursday of network television, as “So You Think You Can Dance” led the night over all with 8.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 9 p.m. dance competition followed Fox’s 8 p.m. game show, “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” (6.9 million), which edged past CBS’s rerun of “Million Dollar Password” (6.8 million) to win its time slot. CBS finished second for the night, attracting 7.2 million viewers at 9 for a “CSI” repeat and 5.7 million for “Swingtown” at 10. NBC was third, with “Last Comic Standing” from 8 to 10 (5.3 million) followed by “Fear Itself” (4.5 million). ABC earned a fourth-place finish with reruns of “Ugly Betty” at 8 (3.5 million) and “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 (3.4 million). At 10, the first part of “Hopkins,” ABC’s six-part documentary filmed inside the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, led its time slot by a slim margin with 5.8 million viewers.

headline: North Korea’s Intent in Razing Tower Is Unclear
text: TOKYO  International television crews were invited to reclusive North Korea on Friday to witness the destruction of the cooling tower at the country’s main nuclear weapons plant. Viewers around the world later watched the most visible symbol of the North’s nuclear ambitions collapse in a cloud of shattered concrete.

headline: Albany’s Latest Haul
text: The New York State Legislature passed more than 800 bills in the session that ended this week. Some were merely elaborate press releases  especially those that passed only one house but can still be waved proudly at this year’s voters as proof of statesmanship. Others were favors  somebody wanted the deposit on beer kegs reduced from $75 to $50, and it was done. And a few were actually worthwhile.

headline: Saxophone Leaps Over Wall of Funk
text: Joshua Redman is a saxophonist of such intelligence and energy that you could probably place him in any musical setting, and he would find a way to make himself at home. Sitting in with the trio Soulive on Thursday night for a JVC Jazz Festival performance at Le Poisson Rouge, he did just that.

headline: Oil Hits New High as Dow Flirts With Bear Territory
text: The bear peeked out of its cave on Friday.

headline: Gazprom Investors Elect an Ex-Prime Minister
text: The revolving door between politics and business in Russia spun on Friday as Gazprom shareholders elected former prime minister Viktor A. Zubkov as chairman of the board, replacing Dmitri A. Medvedev, who stepped down after he succeeded Vladimir V. Putin as president. The company’s chief executive, Aleksei B. Miller, retained his position. Also at the meeting, Gazprom floated a proposal to expand its retail business in Western Europe with a chain of natural gas fueling stations for passenger cars.

headline: For Gay, a Defeat Is Followed by a Tuneup
text: EUGENE, Ore.  An absent person’s shadow will loom large over the men’s 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials  Usain Bolt of Jamaica, who set a startling world record of 9.72 seconds at the Reebok Grand Prix meet in New York on May 31.

headline: Russian Shift: A European Charm Campaign
text: KHANTY-MANSIYSK, Russia  The food was nouvelle cuisine, the wine was French and the coffee was served on a terrace with a spectacular view of the Siberian countryside. At his first summit meeting with the European Union, the new Russian president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, dispensed with the aggressive rhetoric of his predecessor, Vladimir V. Putin, and tried a new tactic on the Europeans: being nice to them.

headline: Mexico Accepts Anti-Narcotics Aid From U.S.
text: MEXICO CITY  With a deadly drug war spreading around the country, beleaguered Mexican officials on Friday welcomed $400 million in anti-narcotics assistance in a bill that was given final Congressional approval in Washington on Thursday night.

headline: Unity Is Crowded
text: Unity, N.H.

headline: Laughter From the Assembly Line
text: “Factory,” a new series beginning on Sunday, is the first original comedy from Spike TV, which makes no effort in expanding its brand. Happen on it serendipitously and you would think, “I must be watching Spike, the television network for men with 40-inch waists and wives they’d like to stick in a witness protection program.”

headline: Citing Weather Forecast, U.S. Postpones Transfer of Authority for Anbar Security to Iraqis
text: BAGHDAD  As funerals were held on Friday near the site of a suicide bombing in Anbar Province the day before, the American military delayed plans to transfer authority over security in the province to Iraqi forces. The final death toll in the suicide bombing was placed at 20.

headline: Charles Parkhurst, Who Tracked Down Looted Art, Dies at 95
text: Charles Parkhurst, a museum director in Baltimore and Washington and one of the “monuments men,” an Allied Forces team that chased down leads, pried open crates and snooped around museums, salt mines and castles in search of art stolen by the Nazis during World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 95.

headline: Travelers Face Deep Flight Cuts by Summer’s End
text: With summer barely under way, it may seem too early for travelers to start thinking about Labor Day. But that is when significant cuts in the airlines’ fleets and schedules will begin taking effect, making for a particularly jarring end to summer.

headline: Goldman Sachs Sees More Pain for Home Builders
text: Higher refinancing costs may leave American home builders, including D. R. Horton and Lennar, the two largest, with negative cash flow in 2009, according to a report by Goldman Sachs. Goldman changed its neutral rating on homebuilders to cautious. Goldman holds at least $15 million of D. R. Horton’s debt, according to the report.

headline: Challenges to Bans on Handguns Begin
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Using the new judicial muscle provided by the Supreme Court’s affirmation of the right to bear arms, the National Rifle Association and another pro-gun group sued San Francisco and its housing authority on Friday to invalidate a ban on handguns in public housing.

headline: Hoping the Upswing Is Nigh
text: DON’T worry! All the bad news about the economy is actually good news, Kiplinger’s Personal Finance says as part of a package of articles highlighted on its cover with the headline: “Market Update: For Stocks, the Worst Is Over.”

headline: The Leadership to Battle Religious Prejudice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chief of 9/11 Health Programs Gains Support
text: Labor leaders, business executives and members of New York’s Congressional delegation say they fear that the federal government’s health programs for ground zero workers will be endangered if Dr. John Howard, who has coordinated those programs since 2006, ends his term as scheduled on July 5.

headline: Bollywood Flavors Opening of Spoleto
text: SPOLETO, Italy  A cast member of “Padmavati,” the opening-night production at the Festival of Two Worlds here on Friday, ambled slowly up a narrow and steep street on her way to the theater. She was plenty early and plenty wrinkled, even without makeup.

headline: To Build a Young-Adult Crowd, ABC Family Gets More Physical
text: LOS ANGELES  “The Secret Life of the American Teenager,” a coming cable drama, opens with a 15-year-old getting pregnant at band camp. Subsequent scenes depict two teenagers, each asking adults for free condoms.

headline: Prosecutors Play Down Donaghy’s Help
text: Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, has overstated the extent of his cooperation with the government, federal prosecutors said in a court filing Friday. But the prosecutors did not specifically refute any of the recent charges Donaghy made about N.B.A. officiating.

headline: Experts to Discuss One Puzzling Autism Case, as a Second Case Has Arisen
text: Federal health officials on Sunday will call together some of the world’s leading experts on an obscure disease to discuss the controversial case of a 9-year-old girl from Athens, Ga., who became autistic after receiving numerous vaccinations.

headline: Off the Fire Escape Is in Play
text: The police will close off three side streets next weekend in Manhattan to serve as the asphalt playing fields for what East Harlem graybeards are hailing as the world series of stickball. That’s right, no more “cheese-it-the-cops” moments. In the old days, stickball was a deliciously intrusive blight on urban order, powered by three-sewer home-run blasts soaring above dangerous traffic intersections. Now the series players  more than a few in their 60s  apply for permits.

headline: Calculating the Worth of East River ‘Waterfalls’
text: Amid all the hoopla over Olafur Eliasson’s “New York City Waterfalls,” which opened on Thursday along the East River, one might think the city was in for a windfall.

headline: North Korea Destroys Tower at Nuclear Site
text: SEOUL, South Korea  In a gesture demonstrating its commitment to halt its nuclear weapons program, North Korea blew up the most prominent symbol of its plutonium production Friday.

headline: The Court’s Landmark Ruling on Guns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Want to Play Handball? Better Not Forget Your Ego
text: Around the Coney Island handball courts, the handball mecca of New York City, there was the usual thwock of rubber balls against concrete walls, sneakers sliding on sun-baked courts and raspy trash being talked among the players, many of whom had deep tans, taut bodies and egos big enough to play great playground handball.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A entry in the “What’s on Today” television highlights on Friday for “20/20” on ABC, using information from the network, gave outdated information on segments about FitFlops sandals and a deadly love triangle. After the section went to press, they were pulled from the program. (Go to Article)

headline: Dutrow Says Drug Violation Is Overblown
text: Concerned that he has been unfairly labeled a cheat, Rick Dutrow, the trainer of Big Brown, said Friday that his latest drug offense had been overblown and insisted that he did not purposely break any rules.

headline: Spate of Changes in Airline Industry Heightens the Need to Plan Ahead
text: Planning to fly this fall? Better have a backup plan.

headline: A Small Slam Appears Beatable, but ...
text: The diagramed deal is from the final of the Reisinger Knockout Teams, played on May 23 at the Edgar Kaplan Eastern States Regional in New York. The winners were Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn.; William Ehlers of Jersey City; and John Fout, Michael Kopera, John Ramos and John Rengstorff of New York.

headline: Floodwaters Threaten 100 Homes as a Levee Falters in Eastern Missouri
text: WINFIELD, Mo.  The Pin Oak levee, the last remaining barrier between about 100 homes here and the lakelike Mississippi River, finally gave way before dawn Friday. But the fight to save those homes continued into the evening as the authorities coordinated an effort to wall them off with a new sand-filled barricade.

headline: Footnotes
text: Nelson Mandela, below, celebrated his 90th birthday on Friday in London with a concert in Hyde Park to support his global campaign to fight AIDS. Proceeds from the show will go to 46664, the charity named after Mr. Mandela’s prison number and dedicated to raising awareness of the H.I.V./AIDS epidemic. Mr. Mandela turns 90 on July 18. Video of the concert, which was scheduled to include performances by Amy Winehouse, Josh Groban and the Soweto Gospel Choir among others, is available at 46664.com. ... New York Theater Workshop has announced its 2008-9 season, which will include new works by Peter Brook, Michael Weller and Naomi Wallace. The company also announced the inaugural season of Off Again, a series of concert versions of revivals of Off Broadway musicals. Proposed shows include “Iphigenia in Concert,” by Peter Link; “Promenade,” written by Maria Irene Fornes, with music by Al Carmines; and “The Waves,” written by Lisa Peterson, with music by David Bucknam.

headline: Revisiting a Debut Album and Its Semi-Confessions
text: Back in the early 1990s, Liz Phair was hanging out with indie-rockers in Chicago and quietly writing songs on her own. The ones she released on her 1993 debut album, “Exile in Guyville” (ATO), spoke so frankly that the album sold half a million copies and has just been re-released. Ms. Phair, 41, and her band have done four sold-out concerts, playing it from start to finish, including two New York shows at the Hiro Ballroom. “Fifteen years seems like a minute,” she said.

headline: Nice Spot to Eat After Golf, but Women Are Barred
text: PHOENIX  When the men of the Phoenix Country Club saw their feeding ways in peril, they did not tarry. Some sent nasty e-mail messages, hectored players on the fairway and, for good measure, urinated on a fellow club member’s pecan tree.

headline: Fitch Weighs Lower Rating for Wachovia
text: Fitch Ratings may lower the credit ratings of Wachovia, the bank that ousted its chief executive after greater-than-expected mortgage losses. In a report Friday, Fitch said that Wachovia, based in Charlotte, N.C., increased its loan loss reserve by $2 billion as of March 31, which represented “only about 1.2 percent” of the bank’s $170 billion mortgage portfolio. About 70 percent of Wachovia’s mortgages are option adjustable-rate mortgages that let borrowers skip part of their payment and add the sum to their principal. The company declined to comment.

headline: Venture Investors Wrap Up an Unusually Bleak Quarter
text: SAN FRANCISCO  So far this has been a challenging year for companies hoping to go public. But it has been even rougher on venture capitalists who were hoping to get a big payday from such an offering.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,105 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

headline: The Europeans Step Up
text: It has been nearly two years since the United Nations ordered Iran to stop enriching uranium. Tehran continues to defy that order, and its scientists are getting closer to mastering a process that is the hardest part of building a nuclear weapon. So we welcome the European Union’s decision  after much foot-dragging  to impose new sanctions on Iran that go beyond what the United Nations Security Council has mandated.

headline: Economy Can Wait; Stimulate Your Savings
text: IT’S one of those classic ant-versus-grasshopper financial decisions, and millions of Americans are facing it.

headline: I’m So Old, (Insert Punch Line)
text: John McCain, when I was born, you were nearly six years older than my mother. Now, seven years into her retirement, you want a new job: the hardest job in the world. Wow!

headline: Yankees and Mets’ Two Games Are Miles Apart
text: The Mets arrived at Yankee Stadium in full uniform Friday morning, like the varsity busing to meet a rival across town. If schoolyard rules had really applied, the game would have been over in the top of the eighth inning, by virtue of the 10-run rule. There was, after all, another game to play.

headline: China Is Just One Market for Travel Expansion
text: Ctrip.com, a nine-year-old online travel agency based in Shanghai, and traded on the Nasdaq, introduced an English-language Web site this year that offers the company’s leisure and business travel services within China. Last month, it began selling packages for the Beijing Summer Olympics with air transportation from the United States.

headline: In a Collection of Memorabilia, Politics at Its Most Boisterous
text: One of the great unanswerable questions of the exuberant exhibition “Campaigning for President: New York and the American Election,” which opened this week at the Museum of the City of New York, concerns a handsome 1888 ceramic chamber pot that sports an elegant monogram intertwining the initials of Grover Cleveland and Allen G. Thurman. If this vessel was ever used, was it out of support for these Democratic Party candidates, or the opposite?

headline: It’s Nice to Be Rich
text: Millionaires are already wildly overrepresented in Congress. The Supreme Court gave a big boost to rich candidates this week by striking down the “millionaire’s amendment,” which was designed to help level the playing field for candidates running against wealthy opponents.

headline: With Elbow Grease and an Artist’s Eye, a Sculpture in Harlem Regains Its Luster
text: When the artist Richard Hunt conceived Harlem Hybrid, a welded bronze sculpture on a traffic island at West 125th Street, he intended for it to blend in with its surroundings: the triangular plaza it sat on, the church across the street, the street itself.

headline: An Angel Rides in to Preserve a Family (and India)
text: What happens when a rich, single-minded businessman is ordered to take care of four children he is responsible for orphaning? God himself (Rishi Kapoor, in a white suit with a Nehru collar) sends help: a mischievous angel, who bikes to earth on a rainbow to save the day, Mary Poppins-style. (And, yes, Virginia, there are dolphins in heaven.)

headline: Frost/Nixon Film to Open Festival
text: The movie version of “Frost/Nixon,” the acclaimed play by Peter Morgan, will open the London Film Festival in October, BBC News reported. The movie, directed by Ron Howard, reconstructs interviews between former President Richard Nixon, played by Frank Langella, and the British journalist David Frost, played by Michael Sheen, that were shown on television in 1977. Both actors are reprising their stage roles for the film. The annual film festival, now in its 52nd year, runs from Oct. 15 through Oct. 30. The movie also stars Kevin Bacon, Oliver Platt and Sam Rockwell. The play, which opened in London in 2006, later came to Broadway and earned three Tony nominations in 2007.

headline: With Wireless Network, City Agencies Have More Eyes in More Places
text: Rigor mortis had set in by the time Joseph Mauro, a supervisor with the Department of Sanitation, drove by a dead opossum on Park Drive East in the Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens.

headline: McCain Pitches a ‘Bipartisan’ Plan for Achieving Energy Security
text: This advertisement for Senator John McCain, the presumed Republican nominee, will be going on the air in key closely contested states and on national cable television. Titled “Purpose,” it runs for 30 seconds.

headline: World Stocks Sag as Oil Price Surges
text: LONDON  Oil reached $142 a barrel, a record high, and world stock indexes declined as Wall Street braced for markets to open a day after a painful 300-point plunge in the Dow.

headline: A Candidate Runs to a G.O.P. Chorus of ‘Don’t’
text: ATLANTA  He has been called a spoiler. A would-be Ralph Nader. A thorn in the side of Senator John McCain and the Republican establishment.

headline: Serbs Choose New Premier for Coalition
text: PRAGUE  Serbia’s finance minister, Mirko Cvetkovic, was nominated on Friday to become prime minister of a new pro-European coalition government.

headline: Fox News Finds Its Rivals Closing In
text: When prime-time cable news ratings for the second quarter of 2008 are officially released next week, they will show that Fox News reclaimed the top spot among viewers in their mid-20s through mid-50s, those of greatest interest to news advertisers, according to estimates from Nielsen Media Research.

headline: Battered by Oil, Dow Touches Bear Territory
text: After eight brutal months on Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average finally made it official: Blue-chip stocks have stumbled into bear territory.

headline: The Odds Are as Big as Their Dreams
text: Michael Rodgers came from California to New York City last month to defy the odds of making a living as an actor, not to defy death by pedaling a secondhand bicycle through Midtown traffic.

headline: By Adding Yi, Nets Hope to Expand Their Market
text: Yi Jianlian was about 7,000 miles away when he made the move from Milwaukee to New Jersey. As he trained with the Chinese Olympic basketball team, the Nets made a three-player trade with the Milwaukee Bucks on Thursday afternoon, before the N.B.A. draft, acquiring the 7-foot Yi and putting him in the spotlight on the East Coast.

headline: Baltimore Woman, Subject of ’05 Article, Is Found Dead
text: BALTIMORE  The troubled stepdaughter of a former city police commissioner was found strangled here on Friday morning.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about Ira Tucker, the innovative lead singer of the Dixie Hummingbirds gospel quartet, misstated his relationship to two survivors. Sundray Tucker and Lynda Laurence are his daughters, not his sisters. The obituary also paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Anthony Heilbut, an expert on gospel music, about Mr. Tucker’s standing in the genre. Mr. Heilbut said Mr. Tucker was “the presiding intelligence” of gospel quartet music, a subgenre  not of gospel music over all.

headline: Some Crinoline and an Accordion Too
text: RedShift Dance unites two choreographers, Kelly Hayes and Katy Orthwein, who met as teenagers while dancing at Joseph Holmes Chicago Dance Theater. For the company’s new evening of dances, first presented at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night, the artists have split their program, “Tell Her/To Stay,” in half.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about the CSX Corporation’s annual shareholder meeting in New Orleans referred incorrectly to the location of the meeting. It has been held in various sites in CSX’s 23-state territory, including the Greenbrier, a resort in West Virginia, but it has not “usually been held” there.

headline: Rested Martínez Labors Through a Weary Start
text: Pedro Martínez is prone to embellishing every now and again, but there was no denying his displeasure Friday night after his dismal start against the Yankees. Between innings, he sat silently and slumped in the dugout. After the Yankees thrashed him for six runs in their 9-0 victory against the Mets, Martínez spoke to reporters with his arms folded across his chest and a blank expression on his face.

headline: Not in Lead, Sorenstam Is Still Star of Open
text: EDINA, Minn.  Before thunderstorms rolled across Interlachen Country Club and delayed second-round play at the United States Women’s Open, Annika Sorenstam strode up the 18th fairway in sunshine to a standing ovation from fans packed into the grandstands. She waved in thanks for the gesture, as much an acknowledgment of lifetime achievement as for the chance at an eagle that she just had given herself.

headline: Dark Knight Pays Tribute
text: The closing credits of “The Dark Knight,” the highly anticipated sequel to “Batman Begins,” include a tribute to Heath Ledger, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who plays the Joker in the film, directed by Christopher Nolan, died of an accidental overdose of prescription drugs in January. The tribute, which also acknowledges the death of Conway Wickliffe, a special-effects technician who was killed in September in an accident, reads, “In memory of our friends Heath Ledger & Conway Wickliffe.” The film opens July 18.

headline: Unlikely Allies on a Former Wedge Issue
text: During his years as the attorney general of Virginia, Mark Earley periodically visited his state’s prisons. In a very real way, he was looking at the human consequences of his career as a public servant, the men and women jailed for fixed, lengthy sentences without parole under laws Mr. Earley had endorsed. Not surprisingly, many inmates pulled back a few steps when introduced to their visitor.

headline: A Witness to Poland’s History, Now Its Diplomatic Voice
text: GDANSK, Poland

headline: Why Some Succeed Wildly
text: MALCOLM GLADWELL’S forthcoming examination of how mega-success is achieved will not be out until November, but judging by the buzz already surrounding it, “Outliers: Why Some People Succeed and Some Don’t” promises to be this winter’s “it” book.

headline: 11 Bulgarian Weight Lifters Are Dropped From Games
text: Doping scandals emerged in two Olympic sports Friday, with grave consequences for athletes caught cheating six weeks before the Beijing Games.

headline: Montreal’s Poet Son Heralds Its Festival
text: MONTREAL  On Wednesday night, in the last of his three concerts presented as preludes to the Montreal International Jazz Festival, Leonard Cohen, the 73-year-old hometown poet-hero on tour for the first time in 15 years, said that on his last time through town he was “60 years old, just a kid with a crazy dream.” Between waves of applause and hollers in French and English, he added, “I am so grateful to be here and to be from here.”

headline: Even With a Strong Wind, 100-Meter Time Impresses
text: EUGENE, Ore.  Even though the runners and fans at Hayward Field on Friday night knew that Marshevet Hooker ran her quarterfinal heat in the 100 meters with a stiff tailwind, her time of 10.76 seconds still sparked a ripple of surprise at the United States Olympic track and field trials.

headline: Ailey II to Berlin
text: Members of Ailey II, below, the junior troupe of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will perform in Berlin on July 5 to mark the reopening of the United States Embassy in the onetime capital of East Germany. The official opening of the embassy will be celebrated with a public open-air festival and stage program titled Amerikafest on the historic Pariser Platz, near the Brandenburg Gate. The official opening of the embassy will be on Friday, with President Bush and Chancellor Angela Merkel scheduled to appear. In addition to Ailey II, the soul singer Jocelyn B. Smith is scheduled to perform.

headline: Coughlin Overcomes Fear in Individual Medley
text: OMAHA  The 200-meter individual medley and Natalie Coughlin were made for each other like quarterbacking and the Mannings. Few swimmers in the sport’s history appear better suited for the event than Coughlin, a native Californian who is among the fastest in three of the four strokes: butterfly, backstroke and freestyle.

headline: Gallinari’s Scouting Report in a Word: Potential
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks had a chance Thursday to obtain a player with a scouting report to make fans swoon: Tall (6 feet 9 inches) and still growing. Skilled enough to bring the ball up the court and shoot 3-pointers. Tough enough to score in traffic and get to the free-throw line. Averaged 17.5 points and 5.7 rebounds at age 19. Works hard. Wants the ball in crunch time.

headline: A View From the Senate: Ratify the Law of the Sea
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The 36 Hours column on Page 11 this weekend, about Bangkok, misidentifies the film that memorialized Patpong, the city’s red-light district. It was “The Deer Hunter” that included scenes shot in Patpong, not “Apocalypse Now.”

headline: Easy Target, but Not the Right One
text: So now we know: it’s all the fault of those damnable speculators. They’re the ones to blame as the price of oil tops $140 a barrel.

headline: Leonard Pennario, 83, Classical Pianist, Dies
text: Leonard Pennario, a popular classical pianist known for his enthusiastic public performances and recordings of the more melodic modern composers, died on Friday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 83.

headline: President of Colombia Seeks Replay of ’06 Vote
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Faced with an intensifying corruption scandal involving his re-election to a second term in 2006, President Álvaro Uribe of Colombia threw the country’s political establishment into turmoil on Thursday night by calling for the vote to be held again.

headline: 3 Nominees Approved by Senate to Fill Openings on S.E.C.
text: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)  The Senate has cleared three nominees to the Securities and Exchange Commission, agreeing by unanimous consent to confirm Luis A. Aguilar, Elisse B. Walter and Troy A. Paredes.

headline: In Park Slope, Frustration With a Parking Holiday
text: Many of the cars on Richard Herbert’s block, in the Park Slope neighborhood in Brooklyn, seem to be on vacation, and a very lazy one at that.

headline: Sitting on the Porch, Leaving the Car in the Garage
text: IF Americans do as they say, this may be a summer of conspicuous nonconsumption.

headline: Garden Is a Seedbed for Green Cosmetics
text: ECKWÄLDEN, Germany  You know you are not in an ordinary garden when a man in dirt-covered trousers, tending witch-hazel plants, describes his work in words that could come from Nietzsche.

headline: Mayo and Love Switch Teams After Draft
text: O. J. Mayo, who was one of the N.B.A. draft’s most intriguing figures Thursday night, became the pivotal player in a blockbuster trade hours after the draft concluded.

headline: Food-Shopping Tips Direct From the Store Manager
text: At the bottom of some of its receipts, Heinen’s Fine Foods prints its phone number and asks customers to call in with comments. And each week, Tom Heinen, who runs the 17-store chain in the Cleveland area with his twin brother, Jeff, listens to a recording of those calls as he drives to work in his Chevy Blazer.

headline: Swiss Firm to Design New TriBeCa Tower
text: The Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron has been enlisted to design a new residential tower in TriBeCa that will incorporate a monumental public sculpture at ground level by the artist Anish Kapoor, the project’s developer said. The real estate company Alexico Group, which also developed the Mark Hotel, said a design would be released in the fall. The tower is to rise at the intersection of Leonard and Church Streets, and the sculpture will be fully integrated into the architecture. Mr. Kapoor, who was born in India and lives in London, is known for vast public sculptures like “Sky Mirror,” a convex stainless steel reflecting sculpture that was installed at Rockefeller Center two years ago. Herzog & de Meuron’s many projects include the new national stadium for the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing, the Tate Modern museum complex in a former power station at Bankside in London, and an expansion of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

headline: Drag, Water, Repeat: Caring for Major League Dirt
text: YOU’VE got to learn how to wait your turn when you’re a rookie groundskeeper in the major leagues, especially if it’s your first day on the job for the New York Mets. I reminded myself of that as I walked backward along the infield dirt at Shea Stadium pulling a five-foot-wide steel mesh drag, sweat pouring from my every pore.

headline: An Interview With President Ali Abdullah Saleh
text: Yemen, in the southern corner of the Arabian peninsula, is facing security threats on several fronts. An uprising by northern rebels belonging to the Zaydi branch of Islam reached the outskirts of the capital last month. Al Qaeda's Yemeni branch claimed several attacks on foreign embassies and other targets in recent weeks. The past year has also seen riots and demonstrations across the south, which was a separate country until 1990. The current discontent, some say, has its roots in unresolved conflicts dating back to 1962, when a revolution toppled north Yemen's ancient system of religious rule and the country's modern history began. Robert F. Worth, the Times's Beirut bureau chief, interviewed Yemeni president Ali Abdullah Saleh earlier this month in the capital, Sana. The president spoke in Arabic; this transcript is a translation.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Ugly and the Beautiful, on Stage and Newsstands
text: A London newsstand is much like a New York newsstand. Step back a few feet from one and you behold a field of anonymous pulchritude: of actresses and models air-brushed into interchangeable, bionic perfection on magazine covers. Glance through the people pages of a daily tabloid, and you’ll find it practically impossible to distinguish your Charlizes from your Siennas without reading the captions. (Thank heavens for the abiding presence of the unmistakable Amy Winehouse.)

headline: Spoleto Italy: Plying a Specialty in Beethoven
text: SPOLETO, Italy — The Orchestra of the 18th Century was rehearsing Saturday morning before its evening concert at the Spoleto festival’s outdoor Roman amphitheater. Rehearsing is a relative term. Two Beethoven symphonies, the Fifth and Sixth, were on the program, and this orchestra of period-instrument players has performed them numerous times (like most orchestras). Its recordings of the Beethoven symphonies in the mid-1990s are what brought the orchestra extra attention. It was a breakout from the confines of the Mozart-Haydn axis, where it had concentrated its activity early on.

headline: Spoleto Italy: Music in the Streets
text: Local police bands held their own minifestival of sorts in Spoleto on Saturday, a nice proletarian moment amid all the high culture of the Festival of Two Worlds. The bands played in piazzas around the city at the same time. Now, Spoleto is not big enough for much band privacy, so a walk through the streets meant that oompahs and snare drums and woodwind reels overlapped. One band sound receded as another came to the fore. It was as if Charles Ives had come to Umbria.

headline: Coming Soon, Ryan Church…and Moises Alou?
text: No one’s holding his breath on this, but Jerry Manuel said that Moises Alou, who has played only six more innings than you or I have for the Mets since May 22, may begin a minor-league rehab assignment Monday. If all goes well — notice the bold and italicized font — then it’s possible Alou could rejoin the team in time for next weekend’s huge four-game series in Philadelphia. My instinct, not to mention history and precedent, tells me we won’t see him there, but the thought of Alou being ready makes Manuel almost giddy.

headline: Shea, Goodbye
text: It’s appropriate, I think, that my favorite memory of Shea Stadium is of leaving it. I had just finished covering a Mets-Red Sox game in 2001 when my wife called and said I should meet her at the hospital; we were having a baby. Needless to say, I was more eager than usual to leave the old yard that night.

headline: ‘Dance’ Leads Slow Thursday
text: Fox ranked No. 1 in the ratings on a slow summer Thursday of network television as “So You Think You Can Dance” led the night overall with 8.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 9 p.m. dance competition followed Fox’s game show “Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?” (6.9 million), which edged past CBS’s rerun of “Million Dollar Password” (6.8 million) to win its 8 p.m. time slot.

headline: Your Comments on my Zimbabwe Column

I argue that African countries need to take the lead and offer Mugabe a choice: comfortable exile in South Africa with $5 million to play with, or International Criminal Court indictments and a cut-off of electricity and military equipment and spare parts. I think that would get him out.

headline: Stress Test

Rather than having a sign describing the merchandise, the windows were papered over with foot-high aphorisms in punchy red and white type. “Friends are more important than money.” “Jealousy works the opposite way you want it to.” True enough, I suppose. But the one that caught my attention was this: “Stress is related to 99 percent of all illness.”

headline: Reading Lolita in Moscow
text: A work of art has no importance whatever to society,” Vladimir Nabokov insisted. “It is only important to the individual, and only the individual reader is important to me.” Nabokov was in fact notoriously averse to groups or “movements” of any sort, whether political, artistic or social. So it’s hard not to be amused at Nina L. Khrushcheva’s contortionate attempts to recruit him as a sociopolitical figurehead for the land of his birth in her earnest and urgent “Imagining Nabokov: Russia Between Art and Politics.”

headline: In Defense of Impatiens
text: I’D like to say a few words about impatiens. Nice words, not the usual condescending ones you often hear, like “colorful, but common,” or “perfect for beginners.” They are both, but that doesn’t necessarily make them banal. It is possible to have a garden of cutting-edge plants arranged with such expertise, taste and charm that your neighbor asks if he can bring his cousin, the botany professor who is looking for illustrations for his seventh book, to see your garden, and still grow impatiens  or, rather, stick them in your soil where they will grow themselves. Impatiens would be much more desirable to serious gardeners if they were a bit tricky to grow.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on June 8 about problems with New York City’s new policy of moving troubled teenagers out of group homes and into foster care misstated the reason that two teenage boys left the home of one foster mother, Mary Chancie, after six months and misstated the age of the older one during that time. The boys both left to live with relatives, as planned; neither “lasted only six months” because of behavioral problems. The older boy was 17 at the time, not 19. (He stayed with Ms. Chancie again for four months when he was 19; that departure was prompted by behavioral problems, Ms. Chancie said. Since the article was published, he has returned to her home.)

headline: So Ready to Send the Kids Off to College
text: “IT’S only a two-minute ride to school,” said Adam. “Calm down, Dad.” He had his final final exam of high school, in economics, at 10:15 on June 17, and it was now 10:03, and how was he preparing? Reviewing his notes? No. (That’s what his older brother, Ben, would do.) Sharpening those No. 2 pencils? No. (That’s what his younger sister, Annie, had done that morning, before the eighth-grade state math test.)

headline: Voices of Genuine Originals, Chosen by One Who Should Know
text: AFTER releasing scores of albums, winning 12 Grammys and gaining a place in the Country Music Hall of Fame, Emmylou Harris still has one goal that she hasn’t accomplished: playing the accordion. “I thought I’d be able to learn it, but I’ve given up,” Ms. Harris, 61, said. No matter. On “All I Intended to Be” (Nonesuch) she sings the type of dazzling harmonies and arrangements that won her all those awards, accompanied by a new quintet that includes someone who plays the instrument that has so far eluded her grasp. Apparently the sound has taken root. Released on June 10, “Intended” is her highest ranking album, reaching No. 4 on Billboard’s country charts and No. 22 on the main chart. As she took in the hackberry, maple, magnolia and oak trees near her Nashville home during a break from her tour, Ms. Harris spoke with Winter Miller about what she’s listening to now.

headline: Israel’s Identity Crisis
text: What would Theodor Herzl, the father of modern political Zionism, make of today’s Israel? He would find not one Jewish state but a multiplicity, Bernard Avishai suggests. First, Israel the international actor, a member of the United Nations, signatory to peace treaties with Egypt and Jordan. Then the Zionist state-within-a-state. It predates Israel’s independence in 1948, but lives on in the Jewish Agency, which deals with Jewish immigration, and in the Jewish National Fund, which owns substantial amounts of land in the name of the Jewish people.

headline: Architects and Ethics: One Dilemma Too Many
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Brutality, Mugabe Offers an Olive Branch
text: JOHANNESBURG  President Robert Mugabe once boasted he had a degree in violence, and he has surely added a doctorate in the savage presidential runoff season that is likely to stagger to a close this weekend with his proclaiming himself the Zimbabwean people’s choice despite an election denounced across the globe as a sham.

headline: A Hewlett Guy Living His Dream Writing
text: NICK SANTORA is the romantic guy who recalls the day of his first date with his wife (July 2, 1995). He is the sentimental guy who saves a seven-year-old message on his answering machine from his late grandmother, which she left the day he moved to Los Angeles to become a television writer. (“Nicky, I hope you find whatever you want out there.”)

text: Kathleen Tracey Larkin, the daughter of Susan G. Larkin and James T. Larkin of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Albert Johannes Laverge, the son of Regine Laverge-Schade of Washington, Conn., and Hendrik J. Laverge of New York. Msgr. Frank C. Wissel, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Church in Greenwich, where he is the pastor.

headline: In Hamptons, a Recipe for Prize-Winning Beaches
text: Southampton

headline: Cultural Crossoads of the Levant
text: From the war in Iraq to the rumblings in Iran to the heightening tensions between Israelis and Palestinians, there are few bright spots in the Middle East these days. But one boutique Jerusalem press has cleared a space for conversation in a contentious region. Started in 1998 by a husband-and-wife team, Ibis Editions has published English translations of works in Hebrew, Arabic, Greek, French, German and Judeo-Spanish  all relating to the Levant.

headline: If Only Mugabe Were White
text: Patson Chipiro, a democracy activist, wasn’t home when Robert Mugabe’s thugs showed up looking for him.

headline: WFUV-FM Co-Sponsoring ‘Neu Nights’
text: THE opening of “Multiplicity” on June 20 not only celebrated the start of the furniture exhibition, but also represented the debut of a new kind of event at the Neuberger Museum of Art. Neu Nights Out, jointly sponsored by the museum and WFUV public radio, is a series of Friday night socials that is one part art, one part music and one part happy hour.

headline: Ghosts of the Cul de Sac
text: JUST when did it become sane to have a three-hour commute, anyway? High gas prices may help restore some degree of collective common sense while also forcing much-needed innovation in the way we design and plan our communities.

headline: Theatrical Families Aren’t All Onstage
text: THAT the theater community functions as one big extended family is a cliché that might have been overheard four centuries ago at the Mermaid Tavern in London. Neither is it news that there are countless biological families within that larger family; audiences have watched generations of Barrymores, O’Neills, Rodgerses and Hammersteins pass through Shubert Alley. But the theater’s family businesses stretch well beyond those who put on the shows. Name a trade tangentially related to the stage, and you can find its version of the Booth clan. Here are a few.

text: For the profiteroles:

headline: Deanna Ho and Jonathan Montgomery
text: Deanna Eve Ho, the daughter of Cynthia Ho and Shu-Kuang Ho of Carlisle, Mass., was married on Saturday evening to Jonathan White Montgomery, a son of George Granville Montgomery Jr. of San Francisco and the late Elinor White Montgomery. The Rev. David J. Robb, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York.

headline: ‘Personal Days,’ by Ed Park
text: Who died?

headline: Massage, Not Work, on the Kibbutz in Israel
text: “WHY don’t you try Kibbutz Haon?” a friend asked as we sat in her apartment in Herzliah, poring over a map of northern Israel.

headline: A Stroll in Rome With a Papal Pedigree
text: WHEN Romans want to fare una passeggiata (take a stroll), they inexplicably tend to head to the Via del Corso, Rome’s soulless main shopping street. But you can see Zara and Rolex stores (not to mention McDonald’s) in any city. If it’s beauty, history and stress-free strolling you’re looking for, head to Via Giulia, a roughly half-mile-long cobbled street that is lined nearly end to end with churches and elegant palazzi. This summer is a perfect time to explore the street, which is celebrating its 500th birthday and is being feted with various tours, concerts and renovations.

headline: Unrest in India’s Hill Country
text: A long-brewing separatist movement in the Darjeeling hills had, until recently, receded into the past so thoroughly that it became fodder for fiction, setting the backdrop for Kiran Desai’s 2006 Booker Prize-winning novel, “The Inheritance of Loss.” Earlier this month, it burst out into the open again, chasing away tourists, signaling the prospect of ugly ethnic clashes and prompting the Indian government to send in paramilitary forces.

headline: Correction: Hardcover Nonfiction
text: Entries on the nonfiction best-seller lists of June 15 and June 22, for “Stolen Innocence,” omitted Elissa Wall’s co-author. The book was written with Lisa Pulitzer.

headline: Lauren Papp, Renaud Pelletier
text: Lauren Ann Papp and Renaud Stéphane Pelletier were married on Saturday. The Rev. Tomislav Mlakic performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great in Harrison, N.Y., where he is a parochial vicar.

headline: For Albany, a Year of Can-You-Believe-It?
text: ALBANY  Most years, New York’s capital has been known by a few familiar clichés. A stagnant, provincial backwater. A political laughingstock, home to frisky lawmakers and late budgets. The stomping ground, occasionally, of presidential aspirants.

headline: Correction: Retirement Eludes a Multitasker
text: An article last Sunday about Nicholas Martin, the new artistic director of the Williamstown Theater Festival, misstated the month that the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles is reopening with a production of “House of Blue Leaves,” directed by Mr. Martin. It is Sept. 14, not in November.

headline: An Endless Summer Searching for the Perfect Spike
text: BELMAR, N.J.  Ray D’Errico sat courtside last Sunday, his toes in the sand, with shards of sunlight and a volleyball logo adorning his shaved head.

headline: Let Your Fingertips Be Your Guidebook
text: IS it worth taking a laptop along when you visit New York City?

headline: Kaitlin Hancock, Douglas Rose
text: Kaitlin Emily Hancock, a daughter of Cheryl L. Hancock and Woodrow S. Hancock of Kiawah Island, S.C., was married on Friday to Douglas William Rose, the son of Victoria G. Rose and William S. Rose of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Brian Morgan performed the ceremony at St. Andrew’s Episcopal Church in Mount Pleasant, S.C.

headline: Payouts and Payoffs
text: My friend, a young artist at the start of his career, offered to sell me a 1 percent share in him for $9,000. I would receive a portion of his lifetime earnings but would have no say in the sort of work he did. This seems like a good deal for us both, but it does feel a bit like slavery. Is this agreement ethical?  PATRICK HEBRON, BROOKLYN

headline: Hidden Gardens of Paris
text: NEXT to the Palais de la Découverte, just off the Champs-Élysées, is a flight-of-fancy sculpture of the 19th-century poet Alfred de Musset daydreaming about his former lovers. As art goes, the expanse of white marble is pretty mediocre, and its sculptor, Alphonse de Moncel, little-remembered. For me, however, it is a crucial marker. To its right is a path with broken stone steps that lead down into one of my favorite places in Paris, a tiny stage-set called Jardin de la Vallée Suisse.

headline: Pow! Take That, My Fellow Banker
text: Bankers and traders at Trader Monthly’s Wall Street Boxing Summer Showdown last week could hardly exchange a greeting without joking about the most dramatic matchup at a similar event last fall. That was before the collapse of Bear Stearns, and the night’s most powerful fighter, from the trading desk at Bear, pummeled a Goldman Sachs trader to the ground in seconds. Spectators cried out to the Goldman boxer, “Don’t worry, you’ll end up with the bigger bonus.”

headline: Casey Fisher, Zachary Georgeson
text: Casey M. Fisher and Zachary A. Georgeson were married on Saturday in St. Helena, Calif. The Rev. Alvin Villaruel performed the ceremony at St. Helena Catholic Church.

text: NEW ROCHELLE

text: HARTFORD

headline: The Greeks Hoist the Dramatic Flag of Scotland
text: THE gold lamé kilt  fabulous. The Afro-Scottish backup singers  sorry, Greek chorus  perfection. The drunken orgies, the violent dismemberment, a bonny Alan Cumming as a really angry Dionysus? Scary.

headline: Burnishing Credentials, Obama Will Visit the Middle East and Europe
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama will make his first international trip as a presidential candidate this summer, his campaign announced Saturday, traveling to the Middle East and Europe in an effort to bolster his foreign policy experience in his fall campaign against Senator John McCain.

text: Jersey City

headline: Sarah Campbell, Jeffrey Pribyl
text: Sarah Percy Campbell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Campbell of Short Hills, N.J., was married on Saturday to Jeffrey Richard Pribyl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Pribyl of Millstone, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Johann J. Bosman performed the ceremony at the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, where he is pastor.

headline: Pettitte Catches Reyes on the Run
text: No one in baseball has been picked off this season more than José Reyes. Only one other pitcher has picked off as many runners as the Yankees’ Andy Pettitte. That was not a favorable combination for the Mets, who watched Reyes and Pettitte play leading roles in one of the pivotal moments of a 3-2 loss Saturday.

headline: Market Data, Far From the Market
text: WHETHER it’s for an Armani-suited Wall Street trader or a farmer in rural India, the right information at the right time is a baseline for success.

headline: Breaking In a New Coach and New Shoes
text: EUGENE, Ore.  In an attempt to win another Olympic gold medal and set the world record at 400 meters, Jeremy Wariner made two dramatic moves this year  changing his coach and his shoes.

headline: Big Hair, and a Tussle in the Skies
text: THE commercial airlines say business aircraft contribute significantly to congestion in the skies and don’t pay their share of the costs of running the air traffic control system.

headline: Teaching by Doing in the N.B.A.
text: Based on Joe Dumars’s deft touch as an N.B.A. executive, you might assume he had an M.B.A. His management of the Detroit Pistons has turned them into a powerhouse team that advanced to the last six Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Macho Mesh Is Back
text: I WAS looking closely at Cate Blanchett’s neck the other day and there I saw it: chain mesh, like the front of cars these days, from Bentleys to Suburbans and Silverados.

headline: E. Coli and You
text: From Victorian England to contemporary America, creationists have often denied that we are related to other primates. But the hard truth of our genealogy does even greater damage to human pride. We are cousins of every living thing, including the billions of E. coli bacteria in our intestines. This kinship may not be flattering, but it is useful. By studying these tiny creatures, we learn about other organisms, including ourselves. As the French biologist Jacques Monod once said, “What is true for E. coli is true for the elephant.”

headline: Mr. Surrealist Goes to Tinseltown
text: “I’M in Hollywood,” Salvador Dalí wrote in a postcard to André Breton in 1937, “where I’ve made contact with the three American surrealists, Harpo Marx, Disney and Cecil B. DeMille.”

headline: Roses Among the Wallflowers
Budget Bus Fares as Low as $1
text: Now you can travel comfortably between New York City and Toronto without spending your entire budget en route. Neon, a new low-fare bus service from Greyhound Canada and Adirondack Trailways, offers two daily departures from both cities for as little as $1 (there is at least one $1 seat on every bus)  although a $25-to-$75 price range is more likely  one way. Buses have video screens, Wi-Fi service and power outlets. Customers board in New York outside Penn Station and in Toronto at the Royal York Hotel. Walk-up tickets cost $85 (one way), and the better deals (the earlier the reservation, the lower the price) are available at www.greyhound.com.

headline: For Iraq’s Oil Contracts, a Question of Motive
text: From the first days that American-led forces took control of Iraq, the conquering army took pains to broadcast that it was there to liberate the country, not occupy it, and certainly not to cart off its riches. Nowhere were such words more carefully dispensed than on the subject of Iraq’s oil.

headline: Beating the Odds in Life, and at the U.S. Open
text: EDINA, Minn.  Stacy Lewis, a professional golfer for just 19 days, is neither surprised nor particularly nervous about leading the United States Women’s Open after three rounds at Interlachen Country Club.

headline: Letters: Questions for Gore Vidal
text: At 82, Gore Vidal can still teach us all something: the validity of the adage, “There’s no fool like an old fool” (“Literary Lion,” June 15). Vidal says it is only a rumor that John McCain was a P.O.W. and claims to have doubts because Vidal “is West Point” and he knows “a lot of the Annapolis breed.” Gore certainly did not attend that academy, and yet he feels comfortable defaming McCain by implying that he did not suffer in the P.O.W. camp. We have all seen the pictures of McCain in the Hanoi Hilton, but Vidal wants us to believe him, and not our lying eyes.

headline: Welcome to Toontown, Radio Guys
text: TOM AND RAY MAGLIOZZI, the brothers who’ve turned a call-in show about car trouble into a weekly highlight for National Public Radio listeners, have long seemed ripe for a television show.

headline: Choux City
text: I fell for choux paste, a k a cream-puff dough, early in my cooking career. At one of my first restaurant jobs, creating pretty slices for our cheese-plate service left the kitchen with countless dismal little ends of cheese. (We cooks called them cheese butts.) Choux (pronounced SHOO) paste proved the perfect home for the orphaned bits of Boucheron, Roquefort and cheddar. The cheeses would be stirred into the paste, which then was shaped into neat quenelles and fried into beignets; crisp on the exterior, oozy and fragrant on the interior. From near garbage came near perfection, all thanks to a strange, decidedly old-fashioned dough.

headline: Gaffe
text: To a fisherman, a gaff is an iron hook attached to a pole to drag aboard a large catch; to a sailor, it’s a spar attached to the mast; to a Hollywood director, a gaffer is the chief lighting electrician hanging from the set’s rafters; to a “gotcha!” journalist, a gaffe  with an e ending, from the Old French for “hook”  provides the hot news lede on a dull campaign day. To a politician  even one who can “stand the gaff” or abuse  it’s the dread mistake that pierces the psyche like the angler’s sharp hook.

headline: Freshness City Dwellers Hunger For
text: On a recent day when rain was in the forecast, Ron Binaghi Jr. was picking basil at Stokes Farm in Old Tappan, which has been in his family since 1873. When gray clouds rolled in, Mr. Binaghi, who cultivates herbs and vegetables as well as flowers on his 18-acre farm with 16 greenhouses, picked up the pace. But rain or no rain, he is used to working fast.

headline: Sitting in Judgment
text: PURCHASE

headline: Playing Markets That Trade Miles
text: ANY traveler who has tried to redeem frequent flier miles for an award seat, only to be thwarted by blackout dates or limited availability, knows that attractive alternatives are hard to come by. You could spend miles for magazine subscriptions, donate them to charity or, in a few cases, purchase merchandise in an exchange that often doesn’t quite add up (17,000 miles for a coffee maker?).

headline: When the Office Gives You Chills
text: Q. Now that the air-conditioning is running in your office, you and some co-workers think it’s too cold. But others say they feel just fine. What’s going on?

headline: 15,000 Protesters Defy Government in Seoul
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Thousands of people opposing American beef imports clashed with the police in a protest that continued into early Sunday morning, hours after Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urged South Koreans to accept their government’s decision to lift an import ban on beef from the United States.

headline: Blending Tastes, Inside a Cool Spot
text: I KNOW an entree is good when I return to a restaurant and want to order it again. Although my job requires that I try as many offerings as possible, on my second visit to Meritage in Scarsdale, I found myself justifying a reorder.

headline: Why Oil and Wages Don’t Mix
text: Oh what a circus, oh what a show,

headline: Brothers for Life
text: JOSH PECK had been missing his crew. On television, the actor, 21, usually rolls with Drake Bell, his co-star on the popular Nickelodeon series “Drake & Josh.” (Mr. Peck’s MySpace page asserts that they are friends in real life.) In his new movie, “The Wackness,” Mr. Peck plays a loner who deals pot to his therapist, Ben Kingsley.

headline: In the Hamptons, Plain and Fancy
text: IN THE HAMPTONS

headline: Urban Poet
text: Death is often a good career move in poetry. No sooner are the obsequies over and the baked meats eaten than the publisher warms up the presses for a definitive edition of the collected poems, solemnly proofread down to the last querulous comma. Yet not all poets are well served by such an exhaustive volume, which may seal up a reputation forever  indeed, such a book has sometimes been called a tombstone. A collected poems may be cruelest to a poet whose genius shone as intermittently as a firefly.

headline: Subway Riders Criticize M.T.A.’s Postponement of Station Repairs
text: In the distance is one of the city’s most stunning views: the Statue of Liberty, Manhattan skyscrapers and a pristine New York Harbor. But the trip to the top of Brooklyn’s Smith-Ninth Street subway station, the highest in the city, is not so appealing.

headline: Delphine Sherman, Philip Tendler
text: Delphine Ghislaine Sherman, a daughter of Liliane Sherman and Dr. Jeffrey Sherman of Hartsdale, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Philip Jonathan Tendler, a son of Debbie Tendler and Joel M. Tendler of Austin, Tex. Rabbi Yonatan Cohen is to officiate at the Marin Art and Garden Center in Ross, Calif.

Maxwell of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Joseph B. Pomeroy, a Roman Catholic priest, will perform the ceremony at St. Joseph Memorial Chapel at the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass.

headline: David Caminer, a Pioneer in Computers, Dies at 92
text: David Caminer, who as an employee of a legendary chain of British tea shops found the earliest ways to use a computer for business purposes, including standardizing flavorful, cost-effective cups of tea, died June 19 in London. He was 92.

headline: Skyward-Looking Sculpture Joins Park
text: Yorktown Heights

headline: The Chief Justice, Dylan and the Disappearing Double Negative
text: The last chief justice liked light opera. The new one cites Bob Dylan.

headline: Letter: On Genocide
text: To the Editor: Joshua Hammer ends his article on Namibia (“Living Reminders of Africa’s Colonial Past,” June 15), past and present, by noting that the “Waterberg tragedy remains a source of bitter controversy. The debate pits historians who see the carnage as foreshadowing the Holocaust against those who regard it as no different from Britain’s tribal wars in South Africa and Rhodesia.”

headline: E-Mail That Investors Might Like to Read
text: EVERY few years, the conflicts of interest so deeply embedded in the Wall Street business model emerge from the shadows for all to see. Coming to light last week, courtesy of Massachusetts regulators, was UBS’s dual roles in the auction-rate securities market, which have had devastating effects on the people and institutions that invested in them.

headline: Journey to a Prom of Dreams
text: The Distance Traveled to Get to the Dance

headline: Swingers
text: It takes a certain kind of person to have fun playing golf. Carl Hiaasen is not that kind of person. The author of antic novels (“Strip Tease,” “Skinny Dip,” “Nature Girl”), Hiaasen writes books that are fun to read, and “The Downhill Lie” is no exception. But while the escapades of his fictional characters  a ragtag cast of slackers, drifters, drug runners, litterbugs, lobbyists, poachers and other indigenous forms of Florida lowlife  strike most readers as impossibly exotic, Hiaasen’s hilarious misadventures on the golf course are all too familiar to anyone who has ever flailed at the ball in futile attempts to conquer a sport that mercilessly strips us of our dignity.

headline: Pakistan Shells Islamic Militants Near Peshawar
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  With Islamic militants tightening their grip around Peshawar, kidnapping residents and threatening the city itself, the new coalition government of Pakistan delivered its first military response to the Islamists on Saturday.

headline: The Spy Who Wouldn’t Love Me
text: Before Jason Bourne, before Jack Ryan, there was Bond, James Bond, the original two-dimensional, world-saving secret agent.

headline: No Mortgage? Try Theirs
text: AT the Fitzgerald, a new condominium development carved out of a prewar warehouse on West 117th Street in Harlem, sales have been steady but slow, with some would-be buyers worried about getting the jumbo mortgages they need.

headline: Obama Supporters Take His Name as Their Own
text: Emily Nordling has never met a Muslim, at least not to her knowledge. But this spring, Ms. Nordling, a 19-year-old student from Fort Thomas, Ky., gave herself a new middle name on Facebook.com, mimicking her boyfriend and shocking her father.

headline: ‘It’s Over, Lady!’
text: UNITY, N.H.

headline: Inside the List
text: GENUINE ARISTOCRATS: Forty-five years ago this week, on June 30, 1963, the best-seller list still had a somewhat placid, ’50s-era vibe. The book at No. 3 on the nonfiction list, however  James Baldwin’s “Fire Next Time”  offered a glimpse of where the decade was heading.

headline: Nancy Oster, Andrew Rosner
text: Nancy Meredith Oster, a daughter of Karen A. Oster and Dr. Martin W. Oster of Armonk, N.Y., was married on Saturday in New York to Andrew Douglas Rosner, the son of Eileen S. Rosner and Dr. William F. Rosner of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. Rabbi Lance J. Sussman officiated at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Battery Park.

headline: What Do Graduates Owe the World?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Life After Tenements
text: THE arrival of a renewal lease kicked Maggie Weber and Joey Arak into gear. After three years, the monthly rent on their East Village tenement one-bedroom was set to surpass $2,000. “If we are going to start putting down some serious money,” Mr. Arak said, “let’s at least go somewhere we can enjoy coming home every day. ”

headline: Turning Away Wrath
text: Turning Away Wrath

headline: Where King John Gets His on the 10-Yard Line
text: Don’t you hate it when you’re sitting in the front row and Hamlet looks up from his “Frailty, thy name is woman” speech, stares right into your eyes and adds, “Yeah, you”? (O.K., that’s if you’re female. Maybe into the eyes of your wife, girlfriend, sister, mother, colleague or classmate if you’re male.)

headline: Correction: 36 Hours in Vienna
text: The 36 Hours column on June 15, about Vienna, misspelled the German for “Vienna” in a reference to a concert hall. And an accompanying map repeated the error and also misspelled the German for “Vienna” in reference to a club. The concert hall is Wiener Konzerthaus and the club is Badeschiff Wien  not Weiner and Wein.

headline: Glasgow: ABode Glasgow
text: THE BASICS

headline: The Watch List
text: While the Rangers’ biggest need may be pitching, the team’s biggest assets are its still-developing hitters. With the promotion of Chris Davis, below, from the Oklahoma Redhawks, Texas may have another masher to add to its lineup. A 22-year-old first baseman, Davis hit 23 homers this season between Class AA and Class AAA, with 10 coming in only 111 at-bats at the higher level. His 73 strikeouts in 297 at-bats were high, but his on-base plus slugging percentage was over 1.000 against both lefties and righties. He homered Friday, in the Rangers’ hitter-friendly park, in his first major league start.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Letters: When Mom and Dad Share It All
text: I find it disheartening that in 2008 couples who share parenting duties equally have such an unusual arrangement that it merits a cover article in your magazine (June 15) and that much of Lisa Belkin’s focus was on organizations that assist parents who may strive to achieve such equality. My husband and I equally divide parenting tasks in much the same manner as the schedule set forth on your cover, but not because we discuss divisions of labor ad nauseam or take classes to learn how to split the work  it simply never occurred to either of us that we’re not equally responsible.

headline: It’s ‘Row-SHANN’
text: My in-laws are lovely people, without a passive-aggressive bone in their bodies. But they have mispronounced my first name for several years now. It’s an unusual name, but most people figure it out after a few gentle corrections.

headline: Skelos’s New Role Could Benefit the Island
text: THE sudden elevation of Dean G. Skelos, a Republican from Nassau County, to be the majority leader of the State Senate  one of the most powerful positions in Albany  bodes well for Long Islanders and the issues they care about, political and civic officials say.

headline: Brooke Coughlin, Nicolás Barquín
text: Brooke Ellen Coughlin, a daughter of Linda C. Coughlin of New York and Ronald V. Coughlin of New Canaan, Conn., was married on Saturday evening to Nicolás Philip Barquín, a son of Jean C. Barquín and Ramón C. Barquín of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Martha Metzler performed the ceremony at St. James’ Episcopal Church in New York.

headline: A Look Back at Canarsie, Clouded by Copyright Woes
text: THE photograph, in the archives of the Brooklyn Historical Society, showed a group of people having drinks at Whittaker’s Hotel, a long-disappeared way station in Canarsie that once served travelers bound for the Rockaways. It was just what Brian Merlis, who publishes books of historical Brooklyn photographs, wanted.

headline: Good Enough to Lose
text: Johan Santana entered Saturday’s games ranked fourth in the National League in earned run average, tied for fifth in strikeouts and was, unofficially, first in starts that have evoked the phrase, “he pitched good enough to win.” The next sentence uttered by one of his Mets teammates usually includes a “but” and some sort of explanation or apology for offensive inconsistency.

headline: The Frenzied Battle to Be Valedictorian
text: AT last week’s graduation ceremony at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, two valedictorians shared the stage, each giving her own speech under a threatening, dark gray sky.

headline: More Waste, Fraud and Abuse
text: Representative Henry Waxman recently asked a question for which we would also like an answer: “How did a company run by a 21-year-old president and a 25-year-old former masseur get a sensitive $300 million contract to supply ammunition to Afghan forces?” Mr. Waxman raised the issue after executives of a Miami Beach arms dealer, AEY, were indicted on fraud charges this month, accused of pawning off tens of millions of banned and decrepit Chinese cartridges on the United States Army to supply Afghan security forces.

headline: Mentor Recalled as an Award Is Given
text: NEWARK

headline: Oil and Inflation
text: This month, Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, broke from the usually banal official pronouncements about the dollar to talk bluntly about the risks of inflation. He told an international conference that a weakening dollar had caused an “unwelcome rise” in inflation and pledged to guard against such dangers.

headline: City Directory Is New for ’08 and Greener Than Ever
text: One legend has it that Vincent Impellitteri, an obscure legal secretary for a judge, was chosen for the Democratic ticket in 1945 by party leaders who plucked his name from the index of the Green Book.

headline: The Light Stuff
text: AMERICA needs to put its cars and trucks on a diet.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An article last Sunday about the TV series "Mad Men" referred incorrectly to the history of original series on its network, AMC. “Mad Men” is AMC’s first scripted drama series; the show is not AMC’s maiden voyage in original programming. (That occurred with "Remember WENN," a comedy about a radio station that ran on the network from 1996 to 1998 when it was known as American Movie Classics.)

headline: Eureka! Where Do I Cash the Check?
text: When a documentary called “Who Killed the Electric Car?” came out in 2006, laying blame on the usual suspects  oil companies, automakers and the Bush administration  it was hailed by some viewers as a brave exposé and dismissed by others as a conspiracy theory. But the film’s broader thesis was hard to dispute. You don’t have to be paranoid to believe that the inertia of the status quo acts as a drag on innovation.

headline: Tangled Up in Red
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Blunder, Gay Sets U.S. Record in 100 Meters
text: EUGENE, Ore.  The United States Olympic track and field trials greeted its sprinters with blazingly hot temperatures Saturday, and they responded with sizzling performances.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on June 8 about problems with New York City’s new policy of moving troubled teenagers out of group homes and into foster care misstated the reason that two teenage boys left the home of one foster mother, Mary Chancie, after six months and misstated the age of the older one during that time. The boys both left to live with relatives, as planned; neither “lasted only six months” because of behavioral problems. The older boy was 17 at the time, not 19. (He stayed with Ms. Chancie again for four months when he was 19; that departure was prompted by behavioral problems, Ms. Chancie said. Since the article was published, he has returned to her home.)

headline: Athletes Disabled by Wars Lead Iraqi Team in World Games
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqis love sports. Anyone who doubts it should consider the rat-a-tat of automatic weapons fired after every Iraqi soccer victory. Yet after five years of war, Iraq’s chances of fielding a competitive Olympic team are vanishingly small.

headline: O Romeo, Romeo, Wilst Thou Smile at This Finale?
text: TWO years ago, when the choreographer Mark Morris was receiving an honorary doctorate from Bard College, Leon Botstein, the Bard president and a conductor, asked him a question: “Are you interested in this original manuscript of ‘Romeo and Juliet’ that we found?”

headline: As Housing Bill Evolves, Crisis Grows Deeper
text: When Congress started fashioning a sweeping rescue package for struggling homeowners earlier this year, 2.6 million loans were in trouble. But the problem has grown considerably in just six months and is continuing to worsen.

headline: Weighing the Costs of a CT Scan’s Look Inside the Heart

headline: A Swimmer of a Certain Age
text: NEAR THE WARM-UP POOL AT THE Missouri Grand Prix swim meet, in Columbia, a crop of Olympic hopefuls lolled around in practice suits and towels on a Saturday morning in February. Fully clothed among them stood some relics of Olympics past: Scott Goldblatt, who won a gold medal in the 2004 Games, wore an aqua sport coat and a striped tie and was doing on-air commentary for Swimnetwork.com; Mel Stewart, who won two golds and a bronze in 1992, wore the same goofy get-up, working as Goldblatt’s sidekick. Meanwhile, Dara Torres, who won the first of her nine Olympic medals in 1984, a year before Michael Phelps was born, stripped off her baggy T-shirt and sweat pants, revealing a breathtaking body in a magenta Speedo. She pulled on a cap marked with her initials and prepared to swim. Torres is now 41 and the mother of a 2-year-old daughter, Tessa Grace. She broke her first of three world records in 1982, at 14, and she has retired from swimming and come back three times, her latest effort built on an obsessive attention to her aging body.

headline: The Road to Ikea
text: EVER since I was a kid, I’ve been very adventurous and curious. I went to college in Denmark, and when I was writing my dissertation I decided to go to the United States and stay with a family on Long Island. The subject of my dissertation was a comparison of the American health care system and socialized medicine.

headline: Tiny Voices Defy Child Marriage in Yemen
text: JIBLA, Yemen  One morning last month, Arwa Abdu Muhammad Ali walked out of her husband’s house here and ran to a local hospital, where she complained that he had been beating and sexually abusing her for eight months.

headline: Part-Time Pickups Back From the Outback
text: WHEN the reincarnated Pontiac GTO was introduced as a 2004 model, it seemed destined for success. By grafting a Pontiac grille onto the front of the muscular Monaro coupe from Holden, its Australian subsidiary, General Motors would revive a legendary nameplate and pump excitement into a division whose performance image had been tarnished by ill-conceived utility wagons and sport vans.

She’s about to sing the treacly romantic ballad “Hopelessly Devoted to You.” But, appalled by the way the show has slid downhill since its original production and the John Travolta movie, she sings “Hopelessly Demoted” instead. Her male co-star soon joins her in a duet, “There Are Worse Shows We Could Do.”

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Minders of Make-Believe’
text: A review on June 15 about “Minders of Make-Believe: Idealists, Entrepreneurs, and the Shaping of American Children’s Literature,” by Leonard S. Marcus, referred incorrectly to Laura Ingalls Wilder’s autobiographical novels. Though none ever won a Newbery Medal, several were named Newbery Honor books; they were not “repeatedly shut out” of Newbery competitions.

headline: Finding the Beat of Chicago’s Latino Quarter
text: IN a fifth-floor art gallery in Pilsen, Chicago’s fashionable Latino neighborhood, vibrant guitar chords were pouring out an open window on a recent Friday night. Four Latina artists were showing their paintings, and the shoebox of a gallery was jammed with a mixed, talkative crowd. Some swayed in time to the music, swigging beer and sipping wine. The din seemed to be drawing art patrons and good-time Chicagoans from all over the huge building at 1932 South Halsted Street, the central site of an every-second-Friday art walk.
