headline: Riders Will Pay Before Boarding, and Save Time, on Revamped Bus Route
text: Beginning on Sunday, passengers on a revamped bus route in the Bronx and Upper Manhattan will pay their fares before they get on the bus, as part of a series of innovations intended to allow faster travel.

headline: Where the Walls Have Big Ears
text: IN a city as big and complicated as New York, many buildings have their shares of urban legends, tales of ghosts walking, lurking in the service elevators or haunting the storage areas. Imagine what life must be like in the Dakota on West 72nd Street near Central Park, where fiction (“Rosemary’s Baby” was filmed there) merged with stranger-than-fiction tenants like Boris Karloff and Judy Garland.

At a moment of economic insecurity in the United States, these challengers from afar have been depicted as sweeping over the American economic landscape to devastating effect.

headline: Luxury Ranch in Montana Has New Name and Green Image

The Lodge at Sun Ranch, which opened earlier this month on the grounds of a 26,000-acre sustainable ranch in Cameron, in the state’s southwestern corner, is inviting visitors to do all of that and more, with a little pampering thrown in.

headline: The World Beats a Path

headline: Arts Patrons, the Next Generation
text: THE dinner last month at the French Consulate on Fifth Avenue honoring Lin Arison, the Miami arts patron, and her book “Travels With van Gogh and the Impressionists: Discovering the Connections,” seemed like just another night on New York’s high-end art circuit. Luminaries like Agnes Gund, the former president of the Museum of Modern Art, and the patrons Steven and Kimberly Rockefeller studded the guest list. The meal  of dishes van Gogh ate at the Auberge Ravoux outside Paris, prepared by Daniel Boulud, Yosuke Suga and Jacques Torres  was displayed on blue glass plates set beneath sky-high shoots of yellow sunflowers in homage to the artist.

headline: The Worm Turns
text: In the early 1990s, Joel Weinstock, a gastroenterologist, encountered a puzzle. The prevalence of inflammatory bowel disease (I.B.D.) across North America increased markedly during the 20th century. Many thought that “bad” genes would eventually explain the spike, but Weinstock didn’t buy it. In areas where fewer than two generations ago the I.B.D. incidence might have been as low as 1 in 10,000, it was now 1 in 250. A defective gene couldn’t spread that quickly, he reasoned. It had to be something in the environment. But what? Stumped, Weinstock tried turning the question around. Instead of asking what triggered I.B.D., he asked what, before the 20th century, protected against it?

headline: Can Weeds Help Solve the Climate Crisis?
text: Lewis Ziska, a lanky, sandy-haired weed ecologist with the Agriculture Research Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, matches a dry sense of humor with tired eyes. The humor is essential to Ziska’s exploration of what global climate change could do to mankind’s relationship with weeds; there are many days, he confesses, when his goal becomes nothing more than not ending up in a fetal position beneath his battleship gray, government-issue desk. Yet he speaks of weeds with admiration as well as apprehension, and even with hope.

headline: 101 Secrets (and 9 Lives) of a Magazine Star

But in all of those places, there is someone who is more ubiquitous, more oddly present, than all those women combined.

headline:
Bet You Didn’t Know:
Falls Are Everywhere

headline: On Court That Defied Labeling, Kennedy Made the Boldest Mark
text: WASHINGTON  It was not last year’s spectacularly divided Supreme Court. The term that ended Thursday lacked last term’s gory display of 5-to-4 decisions, with only 11 cases out of 67 decided this time by one-vote margins.

headline: Abe, We Hardly Knew Ye This Way
text: THREE stories above the Peas and Pickles market in Dumbo, Brooklyn, behind a blank door in a nondescript converted industrial building, two sculptors stood back and watched last week as a former vice presidential chief of staff climbed up onto a wooden box and peered across their studio. From a few feet away, a clay and plaster Abraham Lincoln gazed back, his hand on his horse and a new twinkle in his eye.

headline: Ladders of Memory
text: HOWARD STREET runs a short distance east to west from Centre Street to Mercer, one block north of Canal. At one end is a fish market where men in shabby overalls haul boxes of seafood off trucks by the dollyload; at the other, tourists and model types slink around bazaars and fine boutiques.

headline: With Stewart Cink
text: Stewart Cink ended a four-year dry spell last Sunday by winning the Travelers Championship in Cromwell, Conn. It was at the same course where he won his first PGA Tour event as a rookie in 1997. Cink, 35, is playing some of the best golf of his career and is third in the FedEx Cup regular-season rankings with only Phil Mickelson and the sidelined Tiger Woods in front of him. JOSHUA ROBINSON

headline: Helen Shen, Kent Tarrach

headline: Brother, Who Art Thou?
text: If Marie Brenner and her brother, Carl, can learn to love each other, there might be hope for our divided America after all. She’s a hot-shot writer at large for Vanity Fair, an investigative journalist known for taking down corporations; her exposé of the tobacco industry became the 1999 movie “The Insider.” He is an apple farmer in Washington State with the N.R.A. sticker on his truck who complains about his sister’s “A.C.L.U. friends in New York.” Illness turns out to be this family’s cure. Carl is discovered to have cancer, and Marie flies to apple country to try to save him.

headline: An Abundance of Choices, Defying Expectations
text: YOU arrive for dinner, shoulder your way into the tiny foyer through a flock of waiting customers, give your name to the cheerful but feverishly multitasking hostess, and hope for the best. (No reservations are accepted.) At length, she calls your name and escorts you to a cramped table.

headline: In a Season of Discontent, Many Protests Sweep India
text: NEW DELHI  Discontent is sweeping through India in the form of widespread protests over land use, food, fuel and jobs.

headline: What the Green Bubble Will Leave Behind
text: All the talk about the bad oil bubble obscures the potentially good bubble still inflating in the realm of alternative energy. Wind turbine installations more than doubled last year. Ethanol production capacity will nearly double once all the plants under construction are completed. Investors have given SunPower, a solar panel spinoff from Cypress Semiconductor, a market value much larger than that of its former parent.

headline: Fuel for Inequality
text: AS if the widening wage gap weren’t bad enough, the bottom half of the American work force  everyone who will earn less than about $42,000 this year  is getting hit by the equivalent of a whopping regressive tax in the form of soaring gas prices. And fuel isn’t a discretionary item like cable TV that can be cut from the family budget.

headline: Windows Could Use a Rush of Fresh Air
text: MICROSOFT Windows has put on a lot of weight over the years.

headline: The Oracle Collective
text: You’re not supposed to use the Internet like a Magic 8 Ball. Google can’t tell you whether you’ll pass the bar exam or find happiness in Spokane. But almost from the start, the Web has been barraged with personal questions  often highly subjective ones. Internet users want to do more than “conduct searches” as if they were military police. They want to canvass opinions, plead for sympathy, share an experience or otherwise be humored.

headline: Pakistan Forces Shell Bases of Militant Leader

headline: New York Getaway Packages

headline: Anxious in America
text: Just a few months ago, the consensus view was that Barack Obama would need to choose a hard-core national-security type as his vice presidential running mate to compensate for his lack of foreign policy experience and that John McCain would need a running mate who was young and sprightly to compensate for his age. Come August, though, I predict both men will be looking for a financial wizard as their running mates to help them steer America out of what could become a serious economic tailspin.

headline: Midday Havens, Lost to a Faster-Paced City

Schrafft’s, the lunchroom and candy and ice cream maker, was like that  a vibrant recollection in the minds of people over 50-something, but a mute hieroglyph to those born after Nixon was president.

headline: V.A.-Backed Loans on the Rise

headline: The Country Comes Bearing Products to Go
text: IF you think you hear the “waaaaa” of baby goats at your favorite farmers’ market, chances are Lisa Agee is there with her small stand of Goatboy Soaps. As an added incentive for shoppers to linger, she usually takes along two or three black-and-white Nubian kids, tucked behind an improvised wire fence, for petting.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘A Writer’s People’
text: A review on June 8 about “A Writer’s People. Ways of Looking and Feeling: An Essay in Five Parts,” by V. S. Naipaul, misstated the nationality of Derek Walcott, whose work Naipaul considers. While Walcott has lived and worked in Trinidad over the years, he is St. Lucian, not Trinidadian.

headline: Traffic Sputters on Auto Row
text: GIVEN the standing of the automobile in New York’s hierarchy of transportation modes, some city residents may be surprised to learn that there’s a place in Manhattan known as Automobile Row. The strip, which extends from West 41st Street to 57th Street on 11th Avenue, is lined with dealerships, their tinted-glass facades and vast, serene interiors conjuring visions of suburbia.

headline: Something Not to Worry About
text: The evidence is getting stronger that our neighbor, Mars, was struck by a massive asteroid or other space object some four billion years ago, at the dawn of the solar system. Three papers published in the journal Nature make a persuasive case that a cataclysmic impact stripped away much of the Martian surface in the planet’s northern hemisphere, leaving behind a huge, smooth basin to puzzle modern researchers.

headline: Psychoanalysis by the Gallon
text: AMERICANS may think of Europeans as accustomed to high gas prices  with our relatively high sales and excise taxes, the cost of gas in Europe has long been double or triple what Americans pay. But the price has increased so much lately that even we are feeling it.

headline: 36 Hours in Bangkok
text: THE heat. The traffic. The crowds. That’s all anyone ever talks about when you say you’re going to Bangkok. All of it’s true, of course — particularly the part about the traffic, as you will discover if you bypass this city’s efficient mass transit system and instead find yourself trapped in a one-hour cab ride covering a distance that, on a map, looked like no more than a 10-minute journey. But there are surprising pockets of tranquillity in this city of nearly 9 million people — leafy temple complexes, graceful neighborhoods, inviting restaurants — that offer a chance of momentary rest or rejuvenation before you head back out into the mesmerizing chaos that is Bangkok.

headline: 1968: A Different Era, a Lower E.R.A.
text: A few minutes before Robert F. Kennedy was shot by an assassin 40 years ago, he was talking baseball, expressing his “high regard to Don Drysdale, who pitched his sixth straight shutout tonight.” He added, “And I hope that we have as good fortune in our campaign.”

headline: Listening Early for the Call of Christ
text: THE 44 seniors who graduated this spring from Cathedral Preparatory Seminary in Elmhurst, Queens, looked like your average high school grads. Wearing blue caps and gowns, they gathered excitedly in the hallway, then walked down the aisle in the school gym past rows of proud parents.

headline: A Good Fit for Everyone Involved

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE FIRST WORD: The Search for the Origins of Language, by Christine Kenneally. (Penguin, $16.) How and when did humans learn to speak? Is language a uniquely human attribute? Noam Chomsky’s answers to those questions (the principles of grammar are hard-wired in human brains; language is uniquely human) long prevailed, but as his dominance of linguistics wanes, researchers have begun to consider the notion that language, like other complex abilities, evolved, and that many other species share abilities that are necessary for language. Kenneally, who holds a Ph.D. in linguistics, explains difficult ideas and reports on fascinating experiments.

headline: Restraint in Shot Put
text: EUGENE, Ore.  The world champion Reese Hoffa won the shot put at the Olympic track and field trials on Saturday, but refrained from his usual celebration of nibbling on a turkey leg in triumph.

headline: Rescued by an Israeli Soldier
text: I’M not sure what I expected to discover in Israel. Though three generations of women in my family were avid Zionists, the country never held much significance in my life. I didn’t expect to find answers to my personal quandaries about religion, politics or human rights. Nope, I mostly hoped to find a beach.

headline: Is Your Tank Half Empty or Half Full?
text: High gas prices have had some obvious immediate effects on Americans: Hummer sales are down, commuting by public transit is up, airlines are charging for nonessentials, like baggage. But if $4 gas (or higher) is here to stay, we can expect our lives to change in other ways, too. The Op-Ed page asked 10 writers to reflect on the consequences  unexpected, unnoticed, unrealized, good, bad or indifferent  of really expensive fuel.

headline: Letter: Airline Pet Fees
text: To the Editor: The exorbitant fees charged by airlines for “extra” baggage (“Checking Baggage. Not at These Prices, ” June 15), pale in comparison with JetBlue’s recent doubling of fees to carry a pet in the flight cabin. My seat on a September trip to Tampa costs $94; to take my 12-pound miniature schnauzer in a carry-on bag, crammed under the seat in front of me, I must forgo the legroom, forgo carrying another carry-on bag, and pay $100. I could, of course, pay an extra $20 to recoup part of the lost legroom by purchasing a seat in the “extra legroom” bulkhead seats or I could find another airline for future trips. I am choosing the latter.

headline: The Wife’s at Work, So ...

headline: Violent Love
text: In his first two novels, Darin Strauss made the strange familiar. Taking the perspective of a 19th-century Siamese twin in “Chang and Eng,” he brilliantly humanized a figure known to history as a traveling curiosity. And “The Real McCoy” turned the story of the famous boxer Kid McCoy into the tall yet intimate tale of a flimflammer who slugged and conned his way to notoriety at the turn of the 20th century. Although Strauss’s new novel, “More Than It Hurts You,” is set in present-day Long Island, where he grew up, this is no retreat into a safer territory and time. What he’s after is, in fact, very ambitious: to show what strangers we can be, even to those we think we know best.

headline: The Marimba, Rich and Warm, Makes Itself Heard
text: “THE marimba is coming of age right now, and you can’t throw a dead cat without hitting a marimba concert,” the composer and guitarist Steven Mackey said the other day. Until recently only a handful of classical performers specialized in this exotic underdog instrument, but now there are virtuosos, festivals and international competitions dedicated to bringing it out from the shadows of its more established orchestral colleagues.

headline: Letters: Father Knows Pets
text: O.K., here we have a cover article wondering, “Will Dad ever do his share?” How shocking then  and telling  is the sentence in Ben Greenman’s article (Lives, June 15): “I didn’t have to clean Greenland [cat urine] off the couch, or take my hat to the dry cleaner. . . . My wife did.” Can you believe it?

headline: If Terrorists Rock the Vote in 2008
text: DON’T fault Charles Black, the John McCain adviser, for publicly stating his honest belief that a domestic terrorist attack would be “a big advantage” for their campaign and that Benazir Bhutto’s assassination had “helped” Mr. McCain win the New Hampshire primary. His real sin is that he didn’t come completely clean on his strategic thinking.

headline: One Reason Gas Is Emptying Your Wallet: Nigeria
text: When armed rebels from the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta attacked an enormous oil facility 75 miles off the swampy West African coast on June 19, traveling hours by speedboat under cover of darkness and kidnapping an oil worker, their brazen assault underlined the perhaps underappreciated dependence of the United States  and the world  on oil from Nigeria.

headline: Cubicle Rats
text: When the Spanish philosopher Miguel de Unamuno said that “work is the only practical consolation for having been born,” he could not have foreseen the lot of the 21st-century cubicle drones who populate Ed Park’s witty and appealing first novel, “Personal Days.” Today, it seems, notions of work have been transformed from “every man a king” to mass e-mailings of cat pictures.

headline: Oakland, Calif.: Camino
text: During his 13 years as chef and produce buyer at Chez Panisse, Russell Moore had one of the finer kitchens at his disposal. His home kitchen, however, was tiny, and he took to cooking his dinners on an open fire in his backyard.

headline: Matsui May Require a Knee Operation
text: Hideki Matsui was the ironman of Japanese baseball, playing 1,250 consecutive games despite a chronic arthritic condition in his left knee. Now that he is 34, the knee is worse, and the Yankees acknowledged Saturday that it might need surgery.

headline: Corrections: For The Record
text: An obituary last Sunday about the Very Rev. Henry Chadwick, a British historian of early Christianity, omitted a survivor. He is his brother, Owen Chadwick, also a historian of Christianity.

headline: Seeing the Light
text: As a professor of Buddhist studies at Columbia University and the first American to be ordained as a Tibetan monk, you don’t need to be reminded that the people of Tibet want to reclaim their country from China. Why won’t the Chinese give it back? The Chinese have been brainwashing their people into thinking that Tibet is an inalienable part of their territory. No Chinese people lived in Tibet before 1950. Zero. It’s absurd they claim that they were there.

headline: Arts and Entertainment | In the Spirit of Giverny, Americans in France
text: Almost three-quarters of the artists who flocked to Giverny in the late 19th century were Americans. Strangely, this fact was not mentioned at my university when we were schooled in Impressionism, a movement that came to be largely associated with this small French village where Claude Monet lived from 1883 until his death in 1926 and where he built a garden and pond filled with those famous water lilies.

headline: Would You Hire Your Husband?
text: NINE years ago, Laura Udall noticed that her young daughter Rachel suffered back pain from lugging her books back and forth to school. Ms. Udall, a former saleswoman at AT&T, decided to develop and market a backpack light enough for children to wear safely.

headline: Amnesia
text: I lived in Los Angeles for almost 10 years, but it all runs together. I can never remember what happened when. In memory, I’m always driving down a sunny stretch of road, listening to National Public Radio, trying not to spill my latte. Sometimes I have a splitting headache, which must mean I am on the east side or in the valley, and sometimes the ocean is glittering nearby. Occasionally I can remember the jacarandas being in bloom, which means, what? May? But that still doesn’t tell me the year. It’s just an odd lot of incidents, a memory salad. Here, look:

text: The topic makes Kyle Farnsworth cringe. Some people may be surprised that the Yankees’ bullpen functions without Joba Chamberlain, but Farnsworth is not. He was signed as the Yankees’ setup man when Chamberlain was still in college.

headline: Aerosmith in a Can? No, in Guitar Hero

But when he picked up the electric-guitar controller and started strumming, so to speak, he bombed. “Not being able to play it past the first level was a very humbling realization,” Mr. Perry said in a telephone interview.

headline: Radioactive Grass
text: In “History and Utopia,” the Romanian philosopher Emil Cioran speculated about whether it’s “easier to confect a utopia than an apocalypse.” Utopia and its discontents, so central to Eastern European writers, are central to Gyorgy Dragoman’s darkly beautiful novel. A scathing portrait of life in a totalitarian society, “The White King” is both brutal and disarmingly tender. Dragoman’s answer to Cioran’s question is plain: Utopia creates its own hell.

headline: In an Age of Fossil Fuel, Returning to the Water for Electricity
text: FOR most of its 271 years, an old lumber mill along the Rahway River in Cranford got its power from water spilling over the falls near its banks. The building is now used for office space, its old-fashioned waterwheel long ago displaced by electricity generated from a modern fossil fuel-burning plant.

headline: No Babies?
text: IT WAS A SPECTACULAR LATE-MAY AFTERNOON IN SOUTHERN ITALY,but the streets of Laviano  a gloriously situated hamlet ranged across a few folds in the mountains of the Campania region  were deserted. There were no day-trippers from Naples, no tourists to take in the views up the steep slopes, the olive trees on terraces, the ruins of the 11th-century fortress with wild poppies spotting its grassy flanks like flecks of blood. And there were no locals in sight either. The town has housing enough to support a population of 3,000, but fewer than 1,600 live here, and every year the number drops. Rocco Falivena, Laviano’s 56-year-old mayor, strolled down the middle of the street, outlining for me the town’s demographics and explaining why, although the place is more than a thousand years old, its buildings all look so new. In 1980 an earthquake struck, taking out nearly every structure and killing 300 people, including Falivena’s own parents. Then from tragedy arose the scent of possibility, of a future. Money came from the national government in Rome, and from former residents who had emigrated to the U.S. and elsewhere. The locals found jobs rebuilding their town. But when the construction ended, so did the work, and the exodus of residents continued as before.

headline: Wie Tries to Rebuild Her Game and Her Fame

headline: Giambi Goes From .150 Hitter to Possible All-Star
text: When Jason Giambi was hitting .150 in early May, the lowest average in the major leagues, he said Yankees Manager Joe Girardi and Kevin Long, the batting coach, kept him from plummeting into a mental funk.“Those were the two guys that really kept my head on straight and didn’t let the human emotion get in the way where you look up at the board and you go, ‘I’m hitting .150,’” Giambi recalled.Since then, Giambi is hitting .322 and seems look a good bet to be picked for the All-Star team and perhaps compete in the Home Run Derby. I asked Giambi about those possibilities for Sunday’s Times and he used words like “cool” and “awesome” to describe how he would feel if he was selected.As Giambi’s average deteriorated, he said that Long had told him to stop worrying about statistics. Instead, Long told Giambi to analyze each individual at-bat.“At the end of the game, we’d go in there and we’d line them up,” Giambi said. “He would be like, ‘Awesome, three out of four at-bats, a line drive or a hard-hit ball.’ That’s how we were breaking it down. He was like: ‘Look at it, you’re doing great. I know the numbers don’t show it, but you are.’ He told me to just keep doing the same things and I’d start to get out of this.”Long was right. Giambi, who seemed lost in May, is a productive hitter again.

headline: Spoleto Italy: At the Zeppelin Cafe, Another German Trauma
text: SPOLETO, Italy — Spoleto was the scene of a strange juxtaposition on Sunday night. In the Roman amphitheater, the well-known Spanish actress Victoria Abril was giving a flamenco-inflected concert of French chansons. Directly above her, in the Piazza Della Libertà, a large screen was set up in an outdoor cafe to broadcast the truest music of the continent: the sound of a soccer match.

headline: U.S. Track Trials: Lagat Aims for 1,500, 5,000 Double

headline: The Gay Pride Parade
text: Scenes from Sunday's gay pride parade on Fifth Avenue in New York.

headline: Big Decision Awaits a Big Recruit
text: Thayer Evans recently caught up with Jamarkus McFarland, a 6-foot-3, 285-pound defensive tackle who is rated by many as the top defensive recruit in the country.

headline: U.S. Track Trials: At Age 40, Vaulter Is Returning to Olympics after 12 Years
text: EUGENE, Ore. — In the previous two United States Olympic trials, Jeff Hartwig was on the painful end of the quirks of the pole vault. He failed to clear a single height in 2000, when he was the dominant force in the sport, and he failed again in 2004.

headline: Better Know an N.H.L. Rival: The K.H.L.
text: With the July 1 free agent deadline almost upon us, it’d be a good idea to bone up on the Continental Hockey League teams you’re going to be hearing a lot about once the offers start flying. Below, we present a capsule summary of each of the KHL’s 24 clubs, so you can memorize where they are, who they’ve got, and which “nefts” — the suffix for oil companies, very important on the local level — are doing the bankrolling.

headline: Fox Ramps Up Marketing For ‘Fringe’
text: TV Week: The out-of-the-box marketing campaign for the Fox drama “Fringe” continues this week, “as Fox begins unleashing paid media in 10 major markets, as well as a nationwide online campaign. The focus of the ads: A series of images — such as a six-fingered hand — designed to reflect the show’s extreme-science theme.” Read more…

headline: Tom and Ray Become ‘Click & Clack’
text: The popular radio show “Car Talk” is finally being adapted for television. An animated spinoff, “Click & Clack’s As the Wrench Turns,” will debut June 9 on PBS, Elizabeth Jensen reports.

headline: U.S. Swimming Trials: Rival Pushes Phelps to World Record in 400 I.M.
text: OMAHA — For as long as he can remember, Ryan Lochte has played Lil Wayne to Michael Phelps’s Jay-Z in the 400-meter individual medley. For all his immense talent, Lochte has been unable to unseat the king, Phelps, who has owned the world record in the event since 2002.

headline: Final Hours of Florent
text: Florent, a restaurant that helped transform Manhattan’s meatpacking district, closed after more than two decades in business.

headline: U.S. Track Trials: Gay Runs Wind-Aided 9.68 to Win 100 Meters
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Because of a stiff tailwind, Tyson Gay did not shatter the limits of human possibility with his astounding time of 9.68 in the 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials on Sunday.

headline: Sam H.F.J. Manekshaw Dies at 94; Key to India’s Victory in 1971 War
text: Field Marshal Sam Hormusji Framji Jamshedji Manekshaw, India’s best-known soldier and the architect of the country’s victory in the 1971 war with Pakistan that gave birth to Bangladesh, died in Wellington, India, on Friday. He was 94.

headline: Better Days at Justice
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Winehouse Punch
text: Amy Winehouse  performed for a crowd of about 80,000 on Saturday at the Glastonbury Music Festival in England, and there was just one small problem: She appeared to punch a fan during the show, the BBC reported. Video of the incident, which is widely available on the Web, does not indicate a clear cause of the altercation, though witnesses said a fan tried to grab her. By Sunday the police had received no complaints of assault and said there would be no further investigation. It was a busy weekend for Ms. Winehouse, a woman who was in the hospital a week ago. On Friday she appeared at a concert in Hyde Park in London to celebrate the 90th birthday of Nelson Mandela.

headline: Pérez Shows His Good Side, Which Is Bad for the Yanks
text: Hardly anyone dominates left-handed hitters quite like Oliver Pérez, but then again, hardly anyone does most things like him. These truths confronted Joe Girardi on Sunday morning as he filled out the Yankees’ lineup card. He chose to sit Bobby Abreu, Robinson Canó and Jason Giambi, all lefties, while preparing for  maybe expecting  Pérez’s quirkiness to reveal itself, as it often does, through command problems and a lack of focus.

headline: 6 Killed and 3 Are Injured as Copters Collide
text: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.  Two medical helicopters collided on Sunday as one was taking off and the other landing, killing at least six people and critically injuring three others, officials said.

headline: In a Dry Spell This Season, Kurt Busch Benefits From the Rain and Wins a Race
text: LOUDON, N.H.  Kurt Busch won a Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday even though he was not sitting in his stock car at the time. A tarpaulin covered his blue Dodge, which was parked on pit road and had a part ominously dangling from the bottom.

headline: A Master of Nonchalance in Control of His Illusions
text: When the artist formerly known as Frédéric Gafner changed his name to Foofwa d’Imobilité in the mid-1990s, it seemed both the gesture of a surrealist and irritatingly pretentious. But when he returned last week to New York after several years, things had changed.

headline: Malaysia Opposition Leader Accused of Sodomizing Aide
text: Anwar Ibrahim, the leader of Malaysia’s resurgent political opposition, took refuge on Sunday in the Turkish Embassy in the capital, Kuala Lumpur, saying he feared for his security after an aide accused him of participating in homosexual acts.

headline: Group Suggests an Exchange to Trade Internet Capacity
text: PARIS  There are exchanges where you can buy and sell stocks, futures, pork bellies, wine and even pollution allowances.

headline: Ferrying From Manhattan to Bare It All on the Beach
text: SANDY HOOK, N.J.  In honor of Nude Recreation Week, traditionally celebrated after July 4, join us on the Wall Street ferry SeaStreak as it makes its twice-daily run to Gunnison Beach, the busiest clothing-optional recreation area in the nation, devotees say.

headline: Thinking the Unthinkable: A World Without Nuclear Weapons
text: When Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev talked at the 1986 Reykjavik summit about giving up all of their nuclear weapons within a decade, it was dismissed as a trick or more frightening proof that the American president was out of touch with strategic realities. The deal fell apart over Mr. Reagan’s refusal to limit testing of a missile defense program that was notional then and is still.

headline: A Revisionist View of a Century Dominated by War
text: It is safe to speculate that at some point in his young life, the Scottish historian Niall Ferguson happened upon the documentaries of the art critic Robert Hughes and believed he had found his destiny.

headline: Israel’s Diplomatic Offensive
text: Few countries can afford the luxury of limiting their diplomacy to friendly countries and peace-loving parties. National security often requires negotiating with dangerous enemies. Fortunately, Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, is now displaying a clearer grasp of such realities than President Bush has mustered.

headline: Energy-Efficient Homes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bee by Bee
text: Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Online Tunes, in Service to Africa
text: The music business is known for supporting causes with events like the Live Aid and Live Earth concerts, which generate lots of money and publicity for a relatively short time. But on Monday (RED), a nonprofit organization that arranges for companies to contribute a share of profits on certain products to fight AIDS in Africa, is starting a digital music service for that purpose, and it plans to operate for the long haul. The new venture has already arranged to release new songs from U2, Bob Dylan, Elvis Costello, Elton John, Emmylou Harris and Death Cab for Cutie.

headline: A Terrible Bust Is Born
text: DUBLIN

headline: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A chart on June 6 with an article about the rising rate of foreclosures and overdue mortgage payments had incorrect rates for some states in some editions. Seven states  Arizona, California, Georgia, Illinois, Louisiana, Mississippi and Rhode Island  had delinquency rates of 4 to 5 percent, not 5 to 6 percent. Two states, Indiana and Ohio, had delinquency rates of 5 to 6 percent, not over 6 percent. A corrected version can be found at nytimes.com/business.

headline: A Hurdler Lives Up to Her Name
text: EUGENE, Ore.  Queen Quedith Earth Harrison did not expect to jump an 11th barrier in the women’s 400-meter hurdles at the Olympic track and field trials, especially one that was human.

headline: Expanding Democracy in Florida
text: Among the world’s democracies, the United States is uniquely unforgiving in denying ex-offenders the right to vote. Nowhere is the problem worse than in Florida, where criminal justice experts estimate that as many as 950,000 felons are barred from the voting booth.

headline: In Italy, ‘Eroica’ Energizes a Frail Fixture of Period Music
text: SPOLETO, Italy  The stooped figure, his head topped with a shock of white hair, made his way slowly out onto the stage of a toy-size theater on Sunday as muses gazed down from the frescoed ceiling.

headline: 15-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot in Harlem
text: A 15-year-old boy was killed early Sunday by what appeared to be a stray bullet while walking with a friend in Harlem, the police said.

headline: For a Good Cause: Bits and Pieces and Company Depth
text: As a benefit for its Dancers’ Emergency Fund, New York City Ballet on Friday presented a one-time-only galalike event, “Dancers’ Choice.” It fell to a principal, Jonathan Stafford, to be the dancer who chose. Apart from selecting material from a repertory that contains (he told us) 238 ballets, he came up with a number of novelties. These included new and unfamiliar casts in known works, excerpts of dances unseen in several seasons, and the world premiere of a ballet choreographed and composed by a pair of 27-year-old company members.

headline: Anglican Conservatives, Rebelling on Gays, Will Form New Power Bloc
text: JERUSALEM  Anglican conservatives, frustrated by the continuing stalemate over homosexuality in the Anglican Communion, declared Sunday that they would defy historic lines of authority and create a new power bloc within the communion led by a council predominantly of African archbishops.

headline: Beloved Pets, Displaced by Floodwaters, Find Temporary Shelter in Iowa
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  As floodwaters began to rise this spring, forcing thousands from their homes, Sgt. Kent Choate oversaw one of the larger evacuation efforts, providing shelter to hundreds of animals whose owners had been displaced.

headline: A Long Way to Catch the Yanks (and the Phils)
text: There are millions of New Yorkers who refer to the Mets as the second baseball team in a two-team city, from teachers to actuaries to pharmacists. They are probably Yankees fans or truthful fans. The Yankees have a history that dwarfs the Mets’ history, and they have routinely been the better club across the past 16 seasons.

headline: Commanding a Role for Women in the Military
text: WASHINGTON  For more than a decade, Lt. Gen. Ann E. Dunwoody has delighted in leaping through the doors of military planes and plunging into the night with a parachute on her back.

headline: Online Encyclopedia Gets New Push From Discovery
text: On the Internet, there’s an answer to every question  even “how are marshmallows made?” and “how do toilets work?” The Web site HowStuffWorks wants to remind television viewers and Web visitors that it knows how.

headline: Relax, and Don’t Forget Your Umbrella
text: Alice Dye, the wife of the famed golf architect Pete Dye and the author of the 2004 book “From Birdies to Bunkers,” has been a tireless and prominent advocate of the game for decades. A winner of 50 amateur titles, Dye offered some of her advice for golfers, delivered with twinkling eyes while playing another 18 holes last week:

headline: McCain Gets Praise, Not Backing, From Grahams
text: Senator John McCain, who has had trouble courting faith-based voters, went to the mountaintop on Sunday  Billy Graham’s Blue Ridge mountaintop retreat in western North Carolina, that is  and met with the evangelist and his son the Rev. Franklin Graham for a private, 45-minute conversation.

headline: U.S. Advised Iraqi Ministry on Oil Deals
text: A group of American advisers led by a small State Department team played an integral part in drawing up contracts between the Iraqi government and five major Western oil companies to develop some of the largest fields in Iraq, American officials say.

headline: Sweet-Talking a Crowd With Flirting and Flowers
text: “Only thing I can do is be myself,” Al Green told the Carnegie Hall audience at his JVC Jazz Festival concert on Friday night. Fans know that. An Al Green concert is a free-form excursion, a hodgepodge of virtuosity, teasing, flirting, preaching, making faces, dancing, flinging red roses and coaching audience participation. Sometimes he tosses the show away, doing more smiling than singing. And sometimes he displays the voice and presence that make him one of soul’s greatest singers.

headline: Mugabe Is Sworn In to Sixth Term After Victory in One-Candidate Runoff
text: JOHANNESBURG  Robert Mugabe, the runaway winner in a one-horse race, was quickly inaugurated Sunday as president of Zimbabwe after a runoff election on Friday. His opponent had already dropped out because state-sponsored enforcers were beating and killing his followers.

headline: Artist’s Daughter-in-Law Accused of Theft
text: The daughter-in-law of the Op Art pioneer Victor Vasarely has surrendered her French passport after being accused of stealing artwork from a storage site in Chicago that was being rented by a dealer, Agence France-Presse reported. The artist’s daughter-in-law, Michèle Taburno-Vasarely, said the paintings that she was trying to take belonged to her and that she feared that the gallery owner, Thomas Monahan, was planning to steal them from her. Mr. Monahan said he had indeed been storing thousands of pieces for Ms. Taburno-Vasarely but became concerned about how she had obtained them when he heard of an inquiry now under way in France. He said his lawyer had advised him to hold on to the works until rightful ownership could be established. Prosecutors asked a county judge to postpone Ms. Taburno-Vasarely’s case until July 16 and said they intended to seek a grand jury indictment on felony theft charges. She was arrested on June 22 when the authorities discovered her trying to move the bubble-wrapped paintings from Mr. Monahan’s unit into an adjacent one. She was released on a $125,000 bond two days later. Mr. Vasarely died in 1997.

headline: In China, Jeers and Cheers for ‘Kung Fu Panda’
text: Sometimes it is important to take a political stand. And sometimes it is just fun to watch a cartoon panda trying to do kung fu.

headline: An Emotional and Unpredictable Opening Week
text: WIMBLEDON, England  Crack! went one racket as Radek Stepanek slammed it against a chair Saturday evening. Crack! went a second racket a few moments later.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: The Advertising column on June 12, about two television shows in which the sponsors are integral to the show’s content, misspelled the given name of a host of one program and misstated her background. She is Shanon Cook, not Shannon. And she is a host and contributing reporter on CNN; she is not an actress.

headline: With Skirts of Crinoline and an Accordion Too
text: RedShift Dance unites two choreographers, Kelly Hayes and Katy Orthwein, who met as teenagers while dancing at Joseph Holmes Chicago Dance Theater. For the company’s new evening of dances, first presented at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night, the artists have split their program, “Tell Her/To Stay,” in half.

headline: Presidential Campaign Turns Personal
text: WASHINGTON  The presidential campaign turned personal on Monday as John McCain’s camp offered an unusually sharp and vigorous defense against attacks on the relevance of his military experience to national leadership, and as Senator Barack Obama attacked head-on the persistent rumors that his loyalties to the country are doubtful.

headline: So, How Would You Like Your Culture Clash? Joke-Filled or Sugar-Glazed?
text: CHICAGO  Tracy Letts’s Pulitzer-and-everything-else-winning “August: Osage County” is a full theatrical meal, a nine-course tasting menu of family angst. His new play, “Superior Donuts,” which opened Saturday at the Steppenwolf Theater here, is a much less ambitious repast. It has a lot in common with the deep-fried breakfast food of the title. It’s insubstantial and sweet, with virtually no nutritional value.

headline: Chinese Riot Over Handling of Girl’s Killing
text: BEIJING  Thousands of people have rioted in a county in southwest China, setting fire to government buildings and overturning cars in angry protests over the official handling of the death of a local teenage girl, according to a human rights group, state news media and videotapes of the events.

headline: Falling Prices Grip Major Stock Markets Around the World
text: FRANKFURT  As the United States markets edge toward bear territory, losing nearly 20 percent of their value from last fall’s peak, investors might wonder where they can turn for relief.

headline: Jagr Wants to Stay a Ranger, but He Has a World of Options
text: With the free-agency signing period to begin Tuesday, the drama surrounding the future of Rangers right wing Jaromir Jagr has only deepened.

headline: Siemens Is Said to Be Preparing to Cut More Than 17,000 Jobs
text: PARIS  Siemens, the German engineering and electronics company, plans to cut 17,200 mostly white-collar jobs as it reorganizes to reduce its cost base, a person who has been briefed on the plans said on Sunday.

headline: Amid U.S. Policy Disputes, Qaeda Grows in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON  Late last year, top Bush administration officials decided to take a step they had long resisted. They drafted a secret plan to make it easier for the Pentagon’s Special Operations forces to launch missions into the snow-capped mountains of Pakistan to capture or kill top leaders of Al Qaeda.

headline: Friends Reunited at a Wedding on Maine’s Rocky Coast, Dashed Hopes All Around
text: One of the rich, adrift Yale chums in Galt Niederhoffer’s second novel never quite managed to apply to film school after graduation. But he did buy expensive screenwriting software, read part of its manual and write an unfinished script “about a clique of college friends who reunite at a funeral.” This little self-referential nugget is nicely buried in “The Romantics,” Ms. Niederhoffer’s book about a clique of college friends reuniting at a wedding.

headline: A Team, and a Country, Finally Unite as One
text: With his strawberry-blond locks and fair cheeks, Fernando Torres of Spain does not look like the grim, physical forward who could bedevil mighty Germany.

headline: Cabaret’s Non-Sinatra
text: “Un-Frank-like,” meaning not in the Sinatra manner, said Tom Wopat, describing his approach to “That’s Life” on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. Swinging lightly and joking his way through the 1966 hit that Frank Sinatra turned into a vocal punching bag, Mr. Wopat treated it as an offhanded sparring match between the urge to triumph and the impulse to throw in the towel. “That’s alliteration,” he joked, after singing the lines, “I’ve been a puppet, a pirate, a pauper, a poet, a pawn and a king.”

headline: Nine-Game Test Awaits the Yankees
text: The schedule says the Texas Rangers will make their only appearance at Yankee Stadium this week, but that is not exactly accurate. A chunk of the Rangers’ lineup will probably come back next month for the All-Star Game.

headline: Little Movies, Big Problems
text: Hollywood is having a good-to-great summer. Box office is marginally up  mostly on the strength of increased ticket prices, but still, there’s over $4.52 billion already in the bank this year, according to Media by Numbers. The big studios  the sworn enemy of moviegoing snobs  have used great casting, like Robert Downey Jr. in “Iron Man,” Steve Carell in “Get Smart,” filmmaking innovation in Pixar’s “Wall-E” and “Wanted” and smart retreading in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” and “Sex and the City” to leave both audiences and the people in the studio corner office happy.

headline: Celebrating Female Composers (Without Polemics)
text: During a panel presented recently at the National Performing Arts Convention in Denver, the American Music Center and the American Composers Forum reported preliminary findings from “Taking Note,” a survey of American composers. The study was undertaken to help those organizations better serve their constituencies. According to its findings, the average American composer is a highly educated 45-year-old white male.

headline: Jozef Szajna, 86, Writer of Quiet Protest in Poland, Dies
text: Jozef Szajna, a Polish playwright, set designer and theater director who through often nearly wordless productions evoked the beastliness of humanity, the suffocation of individuality and the oppressiveness of dictatorship  gaining acclaim even during the Communist era  died on Tuesday in Warsaw. He was 86.

headline: A Game Changer Left Unchanged by the Game
text: LUFKIN, Tex.  After sitting through a lesson in a college algebra class, Jamarkus McFarland trotted out to a tan sports utility vehicle driven by his mother.

headline: Intel’s Dominance Is Challenged by a Low-Power Upstart
text: SAN DIEGO  From mainframes to minicomputers and then PCs, each new computing generation has displaced its predecessor by reaching a broader audience and costing far less. And each time, the dominant company in one generation loses control in the next.

headline: Israel Agrees to Exchange Prisoners for Dead Soldiers
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s government voted Sunday to trade one of the most notorious convicts in its prisons, a Lebanese murderer, for the bodies of two Israeli soldiers whose cross-border capture led to and partly motivated its monthlong war with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah in summer 2006.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: The Business Marketing Association presented the Best in Show Award at the 26th annual New York Ace Awards ceremony to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, for the “blade center” integrated marketing campaign, created for I.B.M. BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, won in the corporate brand category, for the “ecomagination” campaign for General Electric. Merkley & Partners, also part of Omnicom, won in the rich media online ad category, for AXA Equitable. And Summit Marketing won in the promotional materials and/or product service catalog category, for Coca-Cola.

headline: Google and Creator of ‘Family Guy’ Strike a Deal
text: LOS ANGELES  Google is experimenting with a new method of distributing original material on the Web, and some Hollywood film financiers are betting millions that the company will succeed.

headline: Veterans Long to Reclaim the Name ‘Swift Boat’
text: Years ago, when William Miller talked about being in the Vietnam War  if he talked about being in the Vietnam War  he would tell people he served on a Swift boat.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC INDICATORS Economic reports will include the Chicago purchasing managers’ index for June (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index for June and construction spending for May (Tuesday); factory orders for May (Wednesday); and unemployment for May and the I.S.M. service index for June (Thursday).

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Thursday about a speech by President Bush at a fund-raising event for the Michigan Republican Party misspelled the surname of the cleric who delivered the invocation at the event. He is Rabbi E. B. Freedman, not Friedman.

headline: South Korea Cracks Down on Suspected Protest Organizers
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The police on Monday raided the offices of two civic groups accused of leading weeks of protests against American beef imports. The raids followed government warnings that it would get tough on the demonstrations.

headline: New Board Member Reflects Global Influence on Goldman
text: LONDON  The steel magnate Lakshmi N. Mittal joined the board of Goldman Sachs as an independent director, a move that underscores the growing importance of the developing world for Wall Street’s behemoths.

headline: China to Resume Talks With Dalai Lama
text: SHANGHAI  China said Sunday that it would soon resume talks with representatives of the Dalai Lama, weeks before the start of the Olympic Games.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Solution, or Mess? A Milk Jug for a Green Earth
text: NORTH CANTON, Ohio  A simple change to the design of the gallon milk jug, adopted by Wal-Mart and Costco, seems made for the times. The jugs are cheaper to ship and better for the environment, the milk is fresher when it arrives in stores, and it costs less.

headline: The Tombstones Have It
text: Performances presented by Danspace Project take place in St. Mark’s Church: the tombstones in the entryway to St. Mark’s Church, with their poignantly terse testaments to brief lives, are reminder enough. But once inside, both audiences and artists tend to regard the church as a neutral, if atmospheric, theatrical space.

headline: ‘Love Guru,’ Panned in U.S., Heads to India
text: What’s worse: that the new Mike Myers movie, “The Love Guru,” satirizes Indians and mocks Hinduism, or that it is just not funny?

headline: Rookie Wins on European Tour
text: The Spanish rookie Pablo Larrazabal won the French Open for his first European Tour victory, closing with a four-under 67 to beat Colin Montgomerie by four strokes at Versailles. Larrazabal, who had to play two qualifying rounds, finished at 15-under 269.

headline: Pakistani Forces Appear to Push Back Militants
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani paramilitary forces pushed fighters belonging to an Islamic militant group farther from Peshawar on Sunday and destroyed unoccupied bases and houses belonging to members of the group. But the militants’ leader appeared to remain unscathed.

headline: Beef Protest Turns Violent in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The government of President Lee Myung-bak sealed off major rallying points in central Seoul on Sunday after hundreds of citizens and police officers were injured during a protest against United States beef imports.

headline: Through Decades of Change, a Core Crew Remains
text: Danbury, Conn.

headline: The Digital Doctor Will See You Now
text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Put Civil Liberties in the White House
text: Chicago

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: A picture in some editions on Wednesday with the continuation of an article about a review by New York City suggesting that many ground zero workers who are suing over their injuries are not as sick as their lawyers have claimed carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The photograph of workers searching the rubble of the twin towers was by Ruth Fremson of The New York Times, not by Tyler Hicks of The Times.

headline: Trying to Keep His Home, Guardsman Loses His Life
text: Gloria Hedges walked out into the hot, muggy morning air last Thursday and made her way, as if against her will, around the corner to Liberty Avenue, the main strip in South Ozone Park, Queens. She trudged into a corner bodega looking for candles, then headed to the supermarket, where she finally found some among the mops and liquid cleaners. When she paid, she asked for a few pieces of tape from the cashier, then headed to the cab stand where the man she loved used to work. She asked the dispatcher what he thought: better inside or out?

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of four-week and one-year bills on Tuesday.

headline: Bloomberg’s Next Battle: Revamping Senior Centers
text: After clashes with entrenched interest groups over education, firehouse closings and other knotty issues, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is seeking to bring his business-minded, results-based approach to an especially challenging constituency: the elderly.

headline: A Movie on Your TV at Home, Before You Can Rent It
text: The very future of how we consume media rests on the movie star shoulders of Will Smith. That is Hollywood hyperbole  but it contains a speck of truth.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An article on Thursday about career academies, which combine job placement, college preparation and classes beyond the vocational trades, misidentified a high school in southern California that has such a program, called the Global Academy of Finance. It is Valley High School, not Santa Ana High School.

headline: CORRECTIONS
text: An Associated Press picture in some editions on Wednesday with an article about the federal government’s consent to release most of the grand jury testimony in the 1950s atomic espionage case against Julius and Ethel Rosenberg was published in mirror image. Julius should have been on the right and Ethel on the left.

headline: Con Edison Contract Talks Suspended
text: With a strike deadline looming on a hot, stormy weekend, Gov. David A. Paterson late Saturday night persuaded Consolidated Edison and the union that represents nearly 9,000 of its workers to take almost three days off from their negotiations.

headline: The Manhattan District Attorney Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Overindulgence in Small Packages
text: It is a truism of public health that people consume more junk food from large packages than from small ones. In response, food companies have decreased portion sizes and introduced single-serve packages, particularly for foods like ice cream and snack chips that people have usually bought in bulk, deciding on their own what constitutes a proper portion.

headline: Identities on Display: Bonding at the Museum
text: SEATTLE  In Ballard, a quiet neighborhood not far from the waterfront where many of its residents once worked, I found a replica of an Icelandic badstofa.

headline: Attention Goes a Long Way at a School, Small by Design
text: They sighed with relief when the college applications were completed, and celebrated when the acceptance letters poured in. But even after graduation on Thursday, one more job remained for the high school’s college counselor and principal: hound their students to make sure they have completed every last task to enroll in their college classes in the fall.

headline: New CDs
text: VANESSA HUDGENS “Identified” (Hollywood)

headline: Iraq Criticizes Attacks by American Troops
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi government officials on Sunday criticized the American military for two recent attacks in which soldiers killed people who the government said were civilians.

headline: Celebrating Gay Pride and Its Albany Friend
text: If there was ever any doubt that gay people form one of Gov. David A. Paterson’s most loyal and enthusiastic constituencies, that doubt was erased on Sunday by the howl of a drag queen on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Hoarding Nations Drive Food Costs Ever Higher
text: BANGKOK  At least 29 countries have sharply curbed food exports in recent months, to ensure that their own people have enough to eat, at affordable prices.

headline: From Trash to Auction, Faster Than a Speeding ...Well, You Know
text: Comic-book collectors like their numbers. They know that the first issue of X-Men, which introduced Marvel’s mutant superheroes, was published in 1963 and had a cover price of 12 cents. They also know that today a copy of that issue, in near mint condition, is worth $16,500. (Parents, take note.)

headline: New Course Is a Marriage of Ingenuity and Nature
text: I had a favorite golf moment during my 18 holes last week with Pete and Alice Dye, he the 82-year-old famed mad scientist of golf architecture and she the pioneering golf administrator, author, architect and winner of two national amateur titles:

headline: The Choice They Made
text: Half a century ago the philosopher Leo Strauss remarked that the passage in which the Declaration of Independence proclaims its self-evident truths “has frequently been quoted, but, by its weight and its elevation, it is made immune to the degrading effects of the excessive familiarity which breeds contempt and of misuse which breeds disgust.”

headline: Closing Time at a Diner That Never Closed
text: They gathered for one last time, bathed in peach fluorescent lighting under garlands of twinkle lights, to say farewell to a place that for untold thousands encapsulated everything that New York was meant to be and now has lost.

headline: Chicago Shows, Going and Coming
text: “Adding Machine,” the musical adaptation of Elmer Rice’s bleak 1923 play, presented in New York by the Next Theater Company, is to close on July 20 after 16 previews and 149 regular performances at the Minetta Lane Theater. The production, with a score by Joshua Schmidt and a libretto by Jason Loewith and Mr. Schmidt, was well received by New York critics after a successful run in Chicago, where it won a Joseph Jefferson Award for best new musical. Another new show from that city is on its way to New York. Beginning July 9, Theater Oobleck’s production of “The Strangerer,” by Mickle Maher, will be presented off Broadway at the Barrow Street Theater with the four-member Chicago cast intact. A political satire, Mr. Maher’s play mashes together an unlikely combination: the works of Albert Camus (of “The Stranger” fame) and a George W. Bush-John Kerry presidential debate of 2004. The political rivals grapple with many questions, including the moral implications of murdering the debate’s moderator, Jim Lehrer.

headline: A Digital Music Store That Sells More Than Just MP3s
text: So far, most online music retailers have come from the world of technology. But one of the next companies to take on Apple’s iTunes store has roots in the mall.

headline: Traveling Overseas to Win Votes at Home
text: Colombia hardly constitutes a general election battleground. Neither does France nor Jordan. But Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are heading to those countries and others because votes can be won there.

headline: Obama Camp Thinks Democrats Can Rise in South
text: WASHINGTON  As they look to the fall election, Democrats face a strategic decision that has bedeviled their party for 40 years: How hard should they fight in the South?

headline: Wim Wenders to Lead Venice Film Jury
text: Organizers of the 65th Venice International Film Festival have announced that the German director Wim Wenders will head this year’s jury, the BBC reported. The festival’s lineup of films has yet to be announced, though “Burn After Reading,” a black comedy written and directed by Joel and Ethan Coen (“No Country for Old Men”), will start things off after the opening ceremony on Aug. 27. The film, scheduled for a September release, stars George Clooney and Brad Pitt, who won best actor in Venice last year for his role in “The Assassination of Jesse James.” Mr. Wenders, 62, began his career as a film critic but went on to direct such films as “Paris, Texas” (1984) and “Wings of Desire” (1987). Another of his films, “The State of Things,” won the Golden Lion at Venice in 1982.

headline: Rival’s Fast Finish Propels Phelps to Another Record
text: OMAHA  For as long as he can remember, Ryan Lochte has played Lil Wayne to Michael Phelps’s Jay-Z in the 400-meter individual medley. For all his immense talent, Lochte has been unable to unseat the king, Phelps, who has owned the world record in the event since 2002.

headline: On Road to Las Vegas, Finding a Trump Lead
text: Look at the West hand and the auction. What would you lead against six hearts?

headline: In 100-Meter Win, Gay Pushes the Limits
text: EUGENE, Ore.  Because of a stiff tailwind, Tyson Gay did not shatter the limits of human possibility with his astounding time of 9.68 seconds in the 100 meters at the United States Olympic track and field trials on Sunday.

headline: A Veteran Takes a Bow as a Youngster Takes the Title
text: EDINA, Minn.  There was a sense of symmetry to the conclusion of the United States Women’s Open at Interlachen Country Club on Sunday. On a day when the finest female golfer in modern times played in her last Open  the event she had made her first professional win back in 1995  a 19-year-old went ahead and made this Open her first professional victory.

headline: A French Village Revives the Franc, and Hopes It Will Return the Favor
text: COLLOBRIÈRES, France  Christine Amrane says it is mostly about profit, not just protest and nostalgia. This village deep in Provence has decided to accept the French franc in everyday commerce, along with the euro, and the colorful old bills adorned with French heroes and writers have people thinking.

headline: Maybe I’ll Get Better on My Own
text: While politicians have been debating endlessly over the best ways to reform the American health care system, the plight of American patients has rapidly worsened. A new national survey found that an alarming 20 percent of the population, some 59 million people in all, either delayed or did without needed medical care last year, a huge increase from the 36 million people who delayed or did not seek care in 2003.

headline: The Robot Rules
text: Disney-Pixar had a good day on Friday, when the animated feature “Wall-E” earned an estimated $23.1 million at the box office, breaking a record for the most lucrative opening day for a G-rated film. (“Finding Nemo,” which made $20.2 million on its first day in 2003, was the previous record holder, Variety reported. Andrew Stanton is the screenwriter-director behind both films.) It is hardly surprising, then, that “Wall-E,” the story of a lonely robot charged with clearing the earth of trash discarded by humans while also seeking love, was the top draw for the weekend, taking in $62.5 million, according to the box office tracking company Media by Numbers. Universal’s new action film “Wanted,” based on the comic strip by Mark Millar and starring Angelina Jolie, James McAvoy and Morgan Freeman, came in second, earning $51.1 million for its first weekend. Third was last week’s No. 1, the Steve Carell spy comedy “Get Smart” (Warner Brothers), which made $20 million in its second week, for a cumulative $77.3 million. The Paramount-DreamWorks animation movie “Kung Fu Panda” earned $11.7 million, enough for fourth place. That movie, about a panda named Po, voiced by Jack Black, who dreams of becoming a kung fu master, has made $179.3 million in four weeks. Rounding out the Top 5 was “The Incredible Hulk,” from Marvel and Universal Pictures, which earned $9.2 million, for a total of $115.5 million in three weeks.

headline: Pole-Vaulter on Team at 40
text: EUGENE, Ore.  In the previous two United States Olympic trials, Jeff Hartwig was on the painful end of the quirks of the pole vault. He failed to clear a single height in 2000, when he was the dominant force in the sport, and he failed again in 2004.

headline: Fortis Said to Get $630 Million From Russian Billionaire

headline: OpenTable.com Talks New Features and Growth
text: OpenTable.com, the Internet’s dominant restaurant reservations site, does a good job of telling people where they can  dine. It does a poor job of telling people where they should dine –- the best restaurants in a certain region, within a certain cuisine category or for a certain occasion. For that, newer foodie community sites like Yelp and ChowHound do a much better job.

Coming to light last week, courtesy of Massachusetts regulators, was UBS‘s dual roles in the auction-rate securities market, which have had devastating effects on the people and institutions that invested in them, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson wrote in her latest Sunday column.

headline: A Small School Where Attention Yielded Results
text: At the Urban Assembly School for Law and Justice in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, 93 percent of the senior class — nearly all college-bound — collected their diplomas on Thursday, far higher than the city’s graduation rate of roughly 50 percent. Many in the first graduating class of 79 seniors were from the city’s poorest neighborhoods, and have struggled academically for years, but they received the kind of personal attention more commonly associated with the priciest prep schools.

headline: Bloomberg Sees Positive Side to Gun Ruling
text: Mayors Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston — the co-founders of the Mayors Against Illegal Guns coalition — wrote an opinion essay in The Wall Street Journal today arguing that last week’s Supreme Court decision is not bad news for gun-control advocates. (The court found that the Second Amendment guarantees an individual right to own a gun for self-defense.)The essay, “Some Gun Rules We Can All Agree On,” elaborates on opinions Mr. Bloomberg advanced on Thursday, following the court’s landmark decision. The two mayors argued that the ruling does not affect most existing state and local restrictions on gun ownership and argued, “For years, shouting matches over the Second Amendment drowned out reasoned discussion of any middle ground.”

headline: Less-meat-ism, continued
text: Two other experiences with the less-is-more style of cooking. The first involved large beans (you could call them gigantes, but maybe they were limas; once the beans are out of the bag and into the jar, I forget what I bought), a sausage, a meatball, a strip of bacon. It’s cassoulet, or fabada, or franks ‘n’ beans, or whatever you want to call it. In any case, a quarter pound of meat (really: two ounces of sausage, one of ground lamb/beef, maybe one of bacon) fed four. With salad.

headline: Interest Rates and Student Loans
text: Even in the dog days of summer, student loans are generating some news. Thanks to Congressional action, the interest rates charged on some federal student loans are set to drop as of July 1. Here is a complete update on the new rates, from the Web site of the federal Education Department. Rates charged on new subsidized Stafford loans, on which the government pays interest while students are enrolled, will fall to 6 percent from 6.8 percent; rates on unsubsidized Stafford loans will remain 6.8 percent.

headline: Heart of Corruption
text: Business | Jacob “Kobi” Alexander, an Israeli-born tycoon now on the lam in Namibia, seems to have bought himself status there as a modern-day “Lord Jim.” He flew in 200 friends for a swanky bar mitzvah for his son, and has endowed a $20,000 scholarship. But unlike the Joseph Conrad character, Alexander exhibits little of the “acute consciousness of lost honor.” Rather, he’s into “effective bribery and ostentatious display.” — Wall Street Journal

headline: Higher Costs and Delays Expected at Ground Zero

headline: Wiki-Astronomy

text: “The contract covering 120,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild expires on Monday night at midnight, and that date was widely seen as likely to pass without a settlement or work stoppage, plunging the world’s entertainment capital into labor limbo,” Reuters reports.

headline: How Much Power Does the Nissan GT-R Really Have?
text: It seems as though the only time you hear about car companies fudging horsepower numbers, it’s when they’re busted advertising more beans than are actually present in the under-hood burrito. Mazda got in trouble for exaggerating the 2001 Miata’s power output. Ford had to recall the 1999 SVT Mustang Cobra when owners realized its motor fell about 20 horsepower short of its official numbers. In the early 2000’s, Hyundai offered its customers extended roadside assistance and warranties after several models suffered double-digit horsepower deficits.

headline: Yahoo’s New Pitch to Shareholders

headline: Wimbledon: The Fourth Round
text: Wimbledon lost its second- and fourth-seeded women on a day in which every men’s and women’s singles match was scheduled.

headline: A Hard-Liner Bemoans Korea Deal
text: “This is a sad, sad day,” John R. Bolton said last week as the Bush administration prepared to take North Korea off the U.S. terror list. Today, the longtime Bush loyalist and former top State Department official on arms control had a few more words on the decision — 955 of them in fact. “The Tragic End of Bush’s North Korea Policy,” an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, was his elegy for one of the first major foreign policy shifts of George W. Bush’s presidency:

headline: No G.O.P. Consensus on Fossella Replacement
text: These are tense days for Republican officials on Staten Island.

headline: U.S. Swimming Trials: Two World Records in Less Than Two Minutes
text: OMAHA – For about two minutes, Hayley McGregory was on the top of the world. Swimming in the second-to-last heat of the preliminaries for the 100-meter backstroke at the United States Olympic Trials, McGregory, a 22-year-old from Texas, clocked a 59.15 to break the world record by .06 seconds.

headline: An Underdog Challenges Speedo
text: OMAHA — In 1992, Roque Santos made the Olympic team as a decided underdog, handing the world-record holder Mike Barrowman his first defeat in the 200-meter breaststroke in three and a half years at the United States Swimming trials. Sixteen years later, he is at these trials, reprising his role as the earnest long shot.

headline: CBS Completes CNet Acquisition
text: Television and radio station operator CBS Corporation said Monday that it completed its acquisition of CNet Networks, the Associated Press reports.

headline: U.S. Track Trials: 800 Meters — the Beautiful Race
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The 800 meters is one of the beautiful races in track and field. In the shorter races (100, 200 and 400), one mistake usually means defeat. In the next-longest Olympic race, the 1,500, there is enough time and distance to overcome some mistakes.

headline: NBC Escapes a Ratings Inferno
text: “Ten Scariest Escapes from Death” lifted NBC’s “Dateline” to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday among adults 18 to 49, though the network finished second in total viewers. [A promo for the show promised, “People trapped in burning planes, sinking ships, a roaring avalanche, skydiving accidents ­ and each one is caught on tape. You can’t help but ask, “How could anyone survive that?!”]

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, June 30:

headline: Guess Again
text: Psychology | Haven’t much of a clue? Guess again. Researchers have found that the average of first and second guesses is more accurate than either guess on its own. But it’s best to solicit other views, a la “The Wisdom of Crowds”: more heads are far better than one. — Economist

headline: An Opaque Argument for Market Transparency
text: Since Friday, one of the most-discussed items on Wall Street has been an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, penned by Citigroup‘s chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit.

headline: The Quad Countdown: No. 60 Northwestern
text: Location: Evanston, Ill.

headline: Paris Men’s Shows | Video Round-up
text: As the Paris men’s shows wind down to a close, it’s time for a men’s wear video retrospective courtesy of Suzy Menkes, a T columnist and one of our favorite colleagues over at the International Herald Tribune. The clips feature candid interviews with style guydols like Tom Ford (he confirms he is dressing Daniel Craig in the next James Bond installment!), Paul Smith (he plays peek-a-boo behind a pair of bright green shoes!), Stefano Gabbana and Domenico Dolce (they describe Naomi Campbell as being like a little sister!), Bottega Veneta’s Tomas Maier (he says the key look in a men’s wardrobe is the jacket!), and, er, Fergie? Check out that clip, if for nothing else, to see Fergie call Menkes a “goddess” and confess to always loving the fetching IHT fashion editor. Suzylicious!

headline: A Not-So-Gay Street in the Village
text: Randy Credico is a standup comedian and opponent of severe drug laws. Video by Corey Kilgannon.

headline: New Obama Advertisement Is Aimed at Workers
text: The Obama campaign is hitting the airwaves with its second general election advertisement. This one is meant to highlight Senator Barack Obama’s commitment to the American worker, the campaign says.

headline: T.G.I. 4:20
text: There’s a new memoir by Mike Edison called “I Have Fun Everywhere I Go: Savage Tales of Pot, Porn, Punk Rock, Pro Wrestling, Talking Apes, Evil Bosses, Dirty Blues, American Heroes, and the Most Notorious Magazines in the World.” A Columbia dropout, Edison has been a writer for Penthouse Letters and Al Goldstein’s Screw, an editor at Wrestling’s Main Event magazine, and the publisher of High Times.

headline: Wabbit Fan

headline: Pride Month Letdown: Lesbian Bar Will Close
text: Amid all the teeth-gnashing and garment-rending over the closing of Florent, the diner whose demise after nearly 23 years seemed to embody the changing fortunes of New York, news about the demise of a smaller, less-established business was overshadowed.

headline: With China and Dalai Lama Talking, Sarkozy Says He May Attend Games
text: French president Nicolas Sarkozy said Monday he might attend the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics if talks announced Sunday between the Chinese government and representatives of the Dalai Lama make progress.

text: Laura Holson talks to two New Yorkers about their favorite rooftop parties.

headline: Steak, with a Side of Questions
text: The New York restaurant world is a volatile one: not a week goes by without jolting announcements about something that’s suddenly gone away (Bette), something that’s newly on the boards (a Boqueria in SoHo) or something that’s going through a Kafka-caliber metamorphosis, by which I mean an attention-getting one.

headline: If Tattoos Actually Told the Truth
