headline: Paraguayan Idol: U.S. Envoy?
text: A headline in Sunday’s paper, “When Ambassadors Had Rhythm,” was not exactly referring to some grand era of fox-trotting diplomats, but America’s current ambassador to Paraguay almost fits the bill. Earlier this year, James C. Cason decided to record an album in Guarani, the dominant language there. To the surprise of everyone, it’s a hit.

headline: What If There Were a Web in 1920?
text: Last night I saw a great moment at a droll mothering site we’ll call MotherBoard. I provide no link, in observance of the first rule of message boards, which I keep having to relearn.

headline: The Plague
text: History | The Black Death brought to life: Simon Winchester reviews (glowingly) a book not of conventional history but a “literary docudrama” told through a single English village, Walsham. The story of devastation is told month by month, year by year. “Seven centuries later, it is once again a pretty little village.” — New York Sun

headline: Another Brick in the ‘WALL-E’
text: Two denizens of National Review ­ Greg Pollowitz and Shannen Coffin ­ think Pixar’s latest is a bit of “leftist propaganda about the evils of mankind,” as Coffin puts it.

headline: 81 Down, 81 to Go
text: We are a little more than 2 hours from beginning the second half of the Mets’ season, and I won’t even bother predicting what we’ll see over the next 81. Instead, here’s one man’s thoughts on the best and worst moments from the first half.

headline: Photo Album: Managing My Hives
text: A beekeeper never really knows what’s going on inside a hive until she takes a look. You can see bees coming and going, and you can observe a funnel of activity at the entrance and assume the worst (bees have a natural swarming instinct, often expressed as a small tornado of swirling bees at the front of the hive, which can presage a mass exodus). Are they ready to swarm because of cramped quarters from bulging frames of honey? No way to know until you take a look.

headline: Pixar's 4th Dimension
text: A. O. Scott discusses the universal appeal of Pixar's films.

headline: Pixar's 4th Dimension
text: A. O. Scott discusses the universal appeal of Pixar's films.

headline: About Those Guns Our Shooting Team Is Taking to Beijing…
text: The United States shooting team is headed to the Beijing Olympics as one of the favorites, but there’s just this one thing: U.S. government controls against exporting firearms and weapons technology to China.

headline: Obama Talks With Bill Clinton
text: Updated KANSAS CITY, Mo. – Senator Barack Obama and former President Bill Clinton spoke by telephone on Monday, their first conversation since the combative Democratic presidential primary season ended this month.

headline: Poets in the Cave
text: Poetry doesn’t matter to most people, and one guy you can blame is Plato. Reality, for Plato, was “a perfect world of ideas,” writes Jay Parini. “Artistic representations of nature were thus at several removes from the ideal, hence suspicious.” Poets have been back on their heels ever since. — Chronicle Review

headline: G.E. Foundation Gives $17.9 Million to Schools
text: The G.E. Foundation, the philanthropic arm of General Electric, will give a $17.9 million grant to benefit New York’s public schools, officials announced Monday. The grant is largest single corporate donation made to the Fund for Public Schools, a private group that raises money for the Education Department.The money will be distributed to roughly 10 middle schools in northern Manhattan, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said during a press conference at St. Nicholas Park Plaza to announce the grant.

headline: A Bon Jovi Concert (With a Slip-Up Over Troubled Waters)
text: Updated, 6:49 p.m. | The rock band Bon Jovi will give a free concert on July 12 to as many as 60,000 people on the Great Lawn of Central Park in honor of Major League Baseball’s 79th All-Star Game, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced at a news conference on Monday afternoon. The humorous highlight of the news conference occurred when the band’s lead singer, Jon Bon Jovi, teased the mayor for mispronouncing Art Garfunkel’s name. (Mr. Bloomberg, citing previous performances on the lawn, had referred to “Simon and Garfinkel.”)

headline: A New Cable Option for People Who Run Late (Among Others)
text: Let’s say you get home at 9:30 on Tuesday and “Hell’s Kitchen” is halfway over. Time Warner Cable customers in New York City will soon be able to start the episode from the beginning.

headline: Campaign Watch: Will This Be Another Swift-Boated Election?
text: Many Democrats have long expected that their presidential nominee would face a well-funded campaign of attack ads from shadowy independent organizations. That is, a 2008 version of the “Swift Boat Veterans for Truth” attacks on 2004 nominee John Kerry.

headline: Cast Your Vote for Week 10
text: Where will I go during Week 10 of my Grand Tour? Readers sent in more than 170 recommendations, and whittling those down to three was far from easy, especially when everywhere sounded so enticing. Vienna, wrote Janice, is “the epicenter for modern Western culture.” Ibiza is “like the Cabo of Europe times 100,” cheered Eric. And Kosovo is “super-cheap, but still sophisticated and fun,” said a reader named Texas.

headline: Go Forth and Get It On
text: Faith | Churches oriented toward young adults are promoting better sex and more of it. Scheduling time for sex appears to be in vogue (“Tues: Quickie in any room besides the bedroom,” says one church’s daily planner). Hey, is this the patriarchy up to its old tricks again? — Time

headline: Would You Buy an Electric Car Now?
text: In February, I wrote about researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory who proposed sucking carbon dioxide out of the air and turning it into gasoline as one way to battle global warming and find a new energy source. That prompted vehement e-mail messages from some readers who felt that I was being irresponsible in suggesting that gasoline could have a long-term future, and that to raise that possibility drew attention from electric cars, which they said was the real solution.

headline: Guns and Democrats
text: Dan Schnur was the national communications director for John McCain’s presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)

headline: An Uncommon Thread, Part One
text: It’s been more than 25 years since I ventured out on my creative walkabout as a songwriter. While traveling these songlines, I have had — and hope to continue to have — the good fortune to work with a number of truly gifted and inspiring men and women. One thing I have found in all of these artists, no matter how green or how legendary they appeared to be, is an uncommon thread, common to all of us, a strange strand of tribal D.N.A. living in our veins that connects us to each other. We experience the rush of taking something that has been hidden from the world and then we bring it back into the light to be seen and heard.

headline: Queens Sikhs March Against Bias Crimes
text: Protesting two recent attacks against Sikh public school students, hundreds of Sikhs, in an action organized by the Sikh Coalition and the victims’ parents, marched through Richmond Hill, the heart of the Sikh community in New York.

text: As layoffs around the country continue to make headlines, some among the newly unemployed are venting their frustrations by posting their stories and grievances online, on blogs and Web sites. Others are using the occasion as an impetus to start their own businesses.
